column2: Now celebrating its fifty-fifth anniversary, the Jewish Theological Seminary has earned an enviable place in the educational and religious life of our community and nation. Under the able guidance of its president, Dr. Louis Finkelstein, the Seminary has held fast to those spiritual values that are more important today than ever before.

S. Howard Cohen and David B. Costuma probably will be redesignated by the Democratic and Republican County Committee, respectively, for re-election by the City Council as members of the Board of Elections, it was said yesterday. The terms of all four members of the board expire Dec. 31.

Spurred by the expectation of a rise in the parity price, cotton traders covered short positions yesterday near the close on the New York Cotton Exchange, sending the list to net gains of 5 to 17 points, the session's best prices.

A jury of five women and eight men, the youngest among them in the middle Thirties, was chosen yesterday in General Sessions for the trial of three theatrical men on an indictment accusing them of giving an indecent performance of the show "Wine, Women and Song" on the night of Oct. 31.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- William H. (Bill) Terry today severed all his connections with the Giants and thus for the second successive year enabled the New York club to provide the outstanding news item as baseball men of the major and minor leagues gathered for their momentous wartime conferences which begin tomorrow.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (Reuter) -- The call to civil disobedience in Italy has been sounded by the Italian Socialist party in a manifesto, the text of which, drawn up and circulated secretly in Italy, has just reached Britain, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Rumors in wartime fall into five separate classes, the Office of War Information said today after the dissection of 4,500 specific rumors coming to the attention of various government agencies during the last eleven months.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Paul Governali, Columbia's star forward passer, was named the "football player of the year" by the Maxwell Memorial Football Club today.

The original uncut version of Walt Disney's "Fantasia" will open an extended revival engagement today at the Little Carnegie Playhouse. A special sound apparatus has been installed for the run at which there will be five continuous performances daily at popular prices.
The theory that a nation can be conquered by air power alone was tested over Britain during the year following the collapse of France, and particularly from September, 1940, through July, 1941.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Senator McCarran said today that silver State Senators decided at an executive meeting to take "appropriate action" against authors and publishers of recent magazine articles critical of the so-called Senate silver bloc.

The most horrible fact about the Cocoanut Grove disaster is that it needn't have happened. The fire itself was an ever present risk. When a place of entertainment is as full of tinder as this Boston night club was some one is likely to touch a match to it sooner or later.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- Declaring that the American people in 1943 would be left with $40,000,000,000 which they could not possibly spend, Randolph E. Paul, general counsel of the Treasury Department, warned tonight that unless the greater part of that amount were drawn off or immobilized "the mark of spending power to the market will break through price ceilings on a broad front."

DECATUR, Ill., Nov. 30 (AP) -Representatives of 1,000 smaller newspapers rallied today to the defense of The Associated Press against a government monopoly suit with an assertion that they believed most of their colleagues "have no interest in the controversy between two powerful Chicago morning newspapers."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- All of the larger aircraft manufacturing companies have joined with the Navy Department in a program to provide useful work for men partially disabled as a result of war injuries, the Navy announced today.

Werner Fred Luck, 27 years old, and Edward John Penn, 22, were cleared of kidnapping conspiracy charges yesterday on which they had been convicted a year ago by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals. The same young men were convicted in Westchester, in 1938, of trying to extort $30,000 from the parents of the kidnapped and murdered Peter Levine, 12-year-old New Rochelle boy, a case not affected by the new ruling.

The report of the Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses, taxes and other charges of $4,919,800, compared with a net of $3,610,150 in the preceding twelve months.

There is more than enough killing and suffering going on in the world without adding unnecessarily to it. We can, and should, dispense with traffic accidents for the duration. Above all let's make sure that we stop every last one of them at Christmas time.

Speaking at the Winter meeting of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, James A. Fulton, president of the Home Life Insurance Company, asserted that freedom could be destroyed as much by "unrestrained bureaucracy" as by military invasion and domination.

In the absence of official figures, estimates in financial circles yesterday were that in the first day of the nation-wide campaign to sell upward of $9,000,000,000 of new government securities, the New York Victory Fund Committee booked orders for approximately $1,000,000,000.

The Greater New York Hospital Association announced yesterday that it had placed in all voluntary hospitals in the city posters explaining that the war had caused curtailment of hospital services and luxuries. Thep osters, under the caption: "Please Bear With Us," read:

In 1941 Chief Justice Stone, by authority of the yearly Judicial Conference of Circuit Judges, appointed a committee of Federal judges to study the qualifications of a uniform system of Federal jury duty. The committee has brought in its report just at the moment when the scarcity of men has so notably increased the demand for the services of women.

NATHANIEL PEFFER may not know it, but he is becoming a legend with his Columbia University students in international affairs. His mixture of idealism and acidity, knowledge and humbleness, strikes just the right note with young men and women who are tired to death of a battle which has been carried on for twenty years between inflated optimists and curmudgeonly cynics.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 30 -- Prime Minister Churchill's terrible threats to Italy caused no surprise in Italy since that country has been preparing for just such a contingency for a long time, according to the Palazzo Chigi's spokesman at his press conference today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 30 -- Reports from Berlin today state that Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, former Reichsbank head and Minister Without Portfolio in Reichsfuehrer Hitler's Cabinet, has been assigned to the job of drafting plans for a national post-war economic program.
Charles Stern, New England district manager for United Artists Corporation, was a victim of the Cocoanut Grove fire. A native New Yorker, Mr. Stern was 56 years old.

MADRID, Nov. 30 (AP) -- It was announced today the Bank of Spain held yesterday its first general meeting in six years and heard the secretary's report on operations since 1936, a period which included the civil war years.

A special performance of the Ice Follies of 1943, oldest skating revue presented in the United States, was given last night at Madison Square Garden for a gathering of service men and their guests. The public was not admitted and all seats were reserved for men in uniform and their escorts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Oliver Lyttelton, British Minister of Production, declared today that military events of the last week or two had changed the entire complexion of the war and had made possible a more complete agreement between the United States and Great Britain on war production and lend-lease shipments designed to produce the greatest possible impact on the enemy in 1943.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Possible bargaining advantages that might be sufficient to bring Argentina into the war soon on the United Nations' side are seen by foreign traders here. They have urged that Argentina get a share in the sale and shipment of wheat and corn to populations in areas recovered from the Axis by United Nations forces.

The Rev. Robert E. Savage, 26-year-old curate of Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., was, sworn in yesterday as a V-7 recruit, and after four months of training will be eligible for a commission as ensign in the fighting branch of the Navy.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

The impact of the war on industrial production was illustrated yesterday at the opening of the Fifteenth National Exposition of Power and Mechanical Engineering at Madison Square Garden, when exhibitors, instead of emphasizing sales of new industrial equipment concentrated on promoting repair and maintenance of existing apparatus and materials. Many exhibitors, of course, could sell only to companies with high priority ratings.

Although both Bob Steuber of Missouri and Gene Fekete of Ohio State increased their scoring totals in last week's games neither threatened the leadership of Eddie McGovern of Rose Poly, whose team completed its schedule two weeks ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission directed today that testimony be taken on the damage claim of about $40,000,000 filed by the Illinois Iowa Power Company against its parent, North American Light and Power Company, before the commission rules on a motion to dismiss the action.
The George A. Zabriskie prize for the most popular painting in the just closed exhibition by the Allied Artists of America at the New York Historical Society was awarded to Marion Gray Traver.

BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Aral Jean de la Borde, commander of the French Home Fleet, who gave the orders for the mass scuttling at Toulon last Friday, is in the hands of the Germans, French naval sources said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- With nationwide mileage rationing scheduled to start at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow, some 27,000,000 passenger cars and 5,000,000 trucks and buses come under restrictions invoked by the Office of Price Administration to conserve rubber tires.

A new war standard for color specifications, expected to eliminate much existing confusion in matching colors, was announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting under the auspices of the American Standards Association at the Hotel Roosevelt. Several hundred executives of industries in which color is an important factor attended the meeting.

The twelve-story hostelry known as the Dauphin, at the southwest corner of Broadway and Sixty-seventh Street, has been purchased by Benjamin Winter, operator, from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -Moving toward the establishment of specific "cents-per-pound" ceiling prices for beef sold by packers and wholesalers, the Office of Price Administration issued standards today for the cutting of beef.
On the long road to victory that lies ahead it is unlikely that we can depend upon air bombardment alone.

Application through the State Department of Social Welfare for an appropriation from Federal funds to provide a Day Care Coordinator in Brooklyn was urged yesterday in a report on child-care facilities in that borough made public by Miss Julia Hatch, chairman of the Brooklyn Council of Social Agencies' Committee on Day Care for Children.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Two French submarines that escaped from Toulon when the Germans entered that French Mediterranean port arrived safely at Algiers today and were welcomed by Allied officers.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting has broken out on the left side of the Buna front stretching along a narrow strip of the northeastern New Guinea coast and Allied airmen, supporting their American and Australian comrades on the ground, have shot down seven more Japanese Zero fighter planes in dogfights over the front, the Allied command announced today.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The French Navy is now in the process of demobilizing and releasing 2,000 to 3,000 mer daily, it was reported here today. The demobilization of the army, consisting of some 90,000 men, is being completed tonight.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- The rate of increase in the number of mental patients in the State's civil hospitals has not only been halted but the number is decreasing for the first time in fifty years, the Temporary Commission on State Hospital Problems said in a report to Governor Lehman today following a two-year survey of nineteen such institutions.

When Anglo-American forces landed in French North Africa, Germany demanded that France declare war on the Allies and unite with the Axis, but the French Cabinet, by the close vote of 8 to 6, refused, it was learned today.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- Rival factions of Local 17 of the International Hod Carriers Building and Common Laborers Union of America, A.F. of L., laid claim today to the organization's leadership following the local's second election of officers within two weeks.

The bittersweet of Puccini's music never found a better subject than in "La Boheme," which remains his most consistently successful opera. Given only a passable performance, its sentiment is guaranteed to hold its audience. If it is done well, as it was in most particulars at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, it is an affecting work.

AT AN ADVANCED OUTPOST, in Tunisia, Nov. 29 (Delayed) -- I stood atop a hill less than twelve miles from our objective today and saw the suburbs of Tunis. I watched United States medium tanks, supported by a famous British infantry unit, advance into a village [probably Djedeida] east of Tebourba while German shells threw up pillars of dust and smoke around them and enemy planes constantly strafed them and us.

A new issue of $5,000,000 of temporary loan notes was announced yesterday by Boston, Mass., for award at noon tomorrow. The issue be dated Dec. 4, 1942, and will be payable Oct. 1, 1943. Bidders are required to name the rate of interest, on the usual "interesto-to-follow" basis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Friends of the principle of collective bargaining and other proper protections which organized labor has acquired from Congress in the last decade are disturbed over the possible consequences of the recent NLRB complaint against the Henry J. Kaiser shipyards on the West Coast.

It is to the heroes of the merchant marine that Norman Armstrong has dedicated "Lifeline." They have been mainly unsung and unrewarded; they have taken their old, slow and rusty ships across incredible seas to keep open the front for freedom.

Fresh lend-lease emergency buying of substantial proportions for the immediate relief of impoverished North African civilians was reported here yesterday by suppliers of rainwear, footwear, hosiery and sweaters.

Athletic directors of eleven leading Eastern colleges, addressing the final meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's restaurant yesterday, declared unanimously that they were in favor of carrying on all sports and football in particular as long as possible."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- The U.S.S. New Jersey, heaviest battleship ever constructed, will be launched from the Philadelphia Navy Yard next Monday, Dec. 7, a year to the day since Japanese infamy took form in the attack on Pearl Harbor.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in November fell slightly below the previous month's volume. Although sales reached the second largest monthly total of the year, business was the smallest for a corresponding month in twenty-nine years, or since November, 1913, the year prior to the first World War.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Nonagricultural employment in the month ended Oct. 15 increased by 207,000, bringing the total to 38,555,000, the highest on record, and 2,500,000 above the 1941 period, Secretary Perkins reported today.

Nathaniel L. Goldstein, Attorney-General elect, was the guest of honor last night at the opening of the Brooklyn lawyers' division's campaign on behalf of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities at the Unity Club, Bedford Avenue and Dean Street, Brooklyn.

If the secret of Hitler's amazing success in conquering a dozen countries can be reduced to a single phrase, that phrase is: "Divide and conquer." His conquests would have been utterly impossible if the peoples over which he now rules had presented a single front against him from the beginning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, lifted the ceiling on agricultural wages today, at least temporarily.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander of the Pacific Fleet, today decorated fifteen Marine fliers who took part in the Battle of Midway and are now leaving this base "for new adventures with the enemy."
Ainsley Richard Lohr, 27 years old, who gave his address as 906 Hillside Avenue, Antioch, Ill., was arrested by detectives yesterday. He was charged with grand larceny in the theft of an automobile.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 30 -- Smoke still rises from the wreckage in Toulon harbor, where the French fleet was scuttled last Friday. German sentries prevent access to the quays. Spars and other debris float on oily waters, cranes stand as gaunt skeletons, gasoline tanks as black masses.

BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- The total of dead in Saturday night's fire in the Cocoanut Grove Night Club here mounted tonight to 487, with 426 identified. There were 176 victims in hospitals, with scant hope held for many of them.

President Carlos Arroyo del Rio of Ecuador predicted yesterday that the United States would dictate the laws governing humanity throughout the post-war world and that its flag would become the banner of the globe.

AFTER listening to a distinguished group of graduate managers and directors of athletics at Eastern colleges discuss the problems of inter-collegiate sport when a war is on, this innocent bystander had to smile a little bit.

Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday that he would confer tomorrow afternoon at his offices, 20 Exchange Place, with Republican legislative leaders. The conference will be devoted to consideration of budgetary problems and other matters of State policy.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 15 per cent last week under the comparative veek a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The week, because of the Thanksgiving holiday, included five days against six last year.

A net profit of $2,040,532, equal to $4.51 a common share, was reported yesterday by the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company and its domestic subsidiary sales concern for the first nine months of this year.

While many corporations were prevented by mortgage or indenture provisions from calling securities for redemption in the short time which remained from Oct. 21, when the Revenue Act of 1942 was signed, to Dec. 31, in order to take advantage of the 10 per cent excess profits tax refund, the amount of debt that will be retired for this purpose is bulking larger than is generally known.
CAIRO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A British General Headquarters and Royal Air Force communique:

Helmut Leiner, Nazi party member who ran errands for Edward John Kerling in the brief time before Kerling was arrested as a saboteur sent here by submarine from Germany, was cleared of treason charges in Federal court yesterday by Judge John W. Clancy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Dave K. Headley, varsity tackle from St. Paul, received Princeton's highest football award when he was presented with the John Prentiss Poe Cup at the annual football dinner tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The French National Committee announced today that the island of Reunion, 350 miles east of Madagascar, in the Indian Ocean, had capitulated without the loss of life to a Fighting French expedition. It was the last island in the French Empire that was under Vichy control.

Jose Iturbi. Spanish pianist, will play Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue" with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos, on Dec. 24, 25 and 27. It will be the first time for the work to be performed by the orchestra at one of its regular subscription concerts.

Marisa Regules, Argentine planist, who made her debut here a year ago, last night gave her second recital at Town Hall. She showed again that she is a performer of exceptional technical gifts at well as a serious interpreter.

With financial circles throwing full strength behind the $9,000,000,000 Victory loan drive, there was little attention left over yesterday for trading in the stock market. The closing session of November on the Stock Exchange saw business at its lowest ebb of the month and prices moderately easier, while bond dealings sank to the smallest since last mid-August.

CHARLESTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 30 -- P.H. Faulconer's Roman Boy, as much a part of this racetrack as the eighth pole, showed that the years have dulled none of his speed when he led throughout the fifth race to win by a length and a half today. R.C. Naple's Rolls Rough was second and L.T. Davis's Cavu third in the field of eight going over the four-and-a-half-furlong course.

Curtailment of bus service in Manhattan in compliance with the order of the Office of Defense Transportation will result in virtual elimination of "owl" service on various lines in downtown Manhattan, according to schedules filed yesterday with the State Transit Commission, 270 Madison Avenue.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Alabama, a team with a glamorous Bowl tradition, and Boston College, only last week the top eleven in The Associated Press ranking poll, will meet in the Orange Bowl here New Year's Day.

SOMEWHERE IN AFRICA, Nov. 27 (Delayed) -- At an air transfer base the other day, who should turn up but Sergeant Bear Gilbert, the old campaigner who travels with a dictionary and an alarm clock and is prepared to take on a Japanese or a German with his bare hands.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30 -Bill Robinson, 64-year-old Negro tap dancer, will return to the screen after a four-year absence to play the leading hole in Twentieth Century-Fox's "Thanks, Pal," a cavalcade of Negro music and entertainment since 1918, the studio announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Secretary Ickes was reported today to be extremely reluctant to leave the Department of the Interior and to assume the combined functions of Secretary of Labor and head of the National Manpower Organization, but he will probably comply with Mr. Roosevelt's wishes if the President insists on drafting him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Army Flying Fortresses operating in the Solomon Islands area on Saturday (Solomons time) attacked a small Japanese convoy that possibly was bound for Guadalcanal with supplies for the Japanese forces there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that an explosive turn of events would not be surprising in Italy, which is under an aerial bombardment of broadcasts and bombs designed to take her out of the war.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:
The police policy on Mayor La Guardia's ruling against bingo in churches remained unclarified yesterday. Questions on the issue submitted to Commissioner Valentine went unanswered.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 30 (AP) -- William and Mary, which won its first Southern Conference football championship this season, placed four players on the circuit's 1942 Associated Press all-star eleven.

New financing here last month was the smallest for any month since November, 1933, with only tax-exempt bonds being offered to the public. There were no stock offerings for the first time in three months, making it the first November since 1931 without such emissions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Colonel John H. Davies, commander of a squadron of American attack-bombers and dive-bombers in the Southwest Pacific, said today that the quality of Japanese pilots had shown a marked deterioration recently.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- British and American bombers carried out the biggest twelve-hour air attack of the war on Tripolitania Saturday night and yesterday, it was disclosed today.

The entire distilling facilities of the Schenley Distillers Corporation are in use for the production of war materials, Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman, and Lester E. Jacobi president, announced in the annual report for the fiscal year ended Aug. 31 and made public yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Anglo-American motorized forces were battling hard tonight to drive a wedge between the Axis forces holding Bizerte and Tunis while French forces were driving toward Sfax and Gabes to prevent enemy reinforcements from coming into Tunisia from Tripolitania.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Despite extremely bad weather a small force of Royal Air Force bombers crossed the Alps and penetrated Italian defenses to drop more bombs last night upon fires that were still burning after the raid on Saturday night when four-ton bombs were unloaded over Turin.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in November-were fewer than in the preceding month and the smallest for any November since 1933. They totaled $56,004,000, against $73,764,000 the month before, $167,091,000 in November 1941, and $13,170,000 in the same month of 1933.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Mrs. Roosevelt assured seven Brazilian newspaper men today that despite coffee rationing Americans would retain their fondness for the beverage.

In close competition an underwriting syndicate headed jointly by Coffin Burr, Inc., and the First Boston Corporation won yesterday the award of $12,500,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Central Maine Power Company on a bid of 106.31 for 3 1/2s due in 1972.

DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Irving Crane of Livonia, N.Y., dropped his second match in defense of the world pocket billiard crown tonight by the narrowest possible margin, bowing to Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, 125 to 124 in seven innings.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Governer Charles Edison, commenting on a report that Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City had offered to make the Governor the next President of the United States if Mr. Edison would "play ball" with him, said today that Mr. Hague had not "exactly offered" the post to him.

There has been talk of establishing, after the war, a permanent and potent international political agency, be it called a federation, league or United States of the World. But the central problem that will confront the postwar world does not embrace simply the establishment of some form of international government and its police counterpart.
Mrs. Ralph Gelder of Stanley, N.Y., supports her family by her delicious baked goods. Orders from New York for cookies and tea cakes fill her mailbox every morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A truce to interunion raiding was the first subject discussed today when labor peace conferences were reopened after an interval of three years by committees representing the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The first three medals to be awarded in memory of Major Gen. William Crawford Gorgas, Surgeon General of the United States Army before his retirement in 1918, will be presented by the Association of Military Surgeons of the United States at a luncheon to be held in the Cosmos Club in Washington on Dec. 15, according to an announcement made here yesterday.

As a part of a topsy-turvy season in which it was not unusual to see the underdog run wild against a more highly regarded foe, the nation's college football teams went on a scoring spree unequaled since 1930.

Replete with treats and rich in glamour, the Ice Follies of 1943 officially launched a ten-day run in Madison Square Garden last night, with the lavish applause of a gathering of 14,000 figure-skating enthusiasts proclaiming the show a topnotch hit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. l -- President Roosevelt will not prophesy the probable length of the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Roosevelt approved several minor bills and held his press conference; his visitors included I.C.C. Commissioners Clyde B. Aitchison and Claude R. Porter, Governor Harold E. Stassen, Dr. Carlos Salazar, Guatemalan Foreign Minister, and Charles Michelson.

ALLLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander in Chief in North Africa, personally decorated Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark with the Distinguished Service Medal today for his "outstanding characteristics of leadership, sound judgment and soldierly qualities" in carrying out a hazardous secret mission to Africa before the Allied invasion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The draft and the demand for war workers have caused a decline of 13.7 per cent in enrollment in teachers' and normal schools, colleges and universities since October last year, the United States Office of Education reported today.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- The Italian military situation, steadily deteriorating under Allied blows and internal dissension, has sent Premier Mussolini to bed, seriously ill of heart disease, it was reported today.

" Who Done It?" a Universal comedy-mystery starring Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, will open today at Loew's Criterion. Among the film's featured players are Patric Knowles, William Gargan, Louise Allbritton, William Bendix, Jerome Cowan, Mary Wickes and Don Porter.

Directors of the Cooper-Bessemer Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock for payment on Dec. 28. This increases the year's disbursements on this issue to $1.50 a share, as compared with 50 cents received by common stockholders in 1941.

With gasoline rationing nationwide, the industry is interested in just how this will affect overall consumption. Based on the experience in the East since coupon rationing went into effect last July, it will mean an overall decline in domestic consumption, including that consumed by the armed forces, of roughly one-third from the comparable period of 1941.

Despite the stupendous gains made by wartime industrial production in the United States, a further increase of 15 to 20 per cent in total industrial output should be possible before the peak is reached, the National City Bank says in the December issue of its economic and financial review.

Wood has taken the place of scarce metals in quite a few industrial products, a survey at the Fifteenth National Exposition of Power and Mechanical Engineering revealed yesterday at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Victory for Donald M. Nelson was indicated tonight in the fight for control over the scheduling of munitions production.

A large subscription has already been reported for the performance of "The Pirate," the new comedy with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne in the leading roles, on the night of Dec. 15, at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Washington Cathedral.

New kinds of fighting men keep popping up in this war, in the Army and Navy we know best. Lieut. Comdr. Thomas Burton Klakring, who has just got back from a profitable Cook's Tour in Japanese waters, "talks like a divinity student, and a diffident one at that." So says our reporter, Robert Trumbull, who interviewed him at Pearl Harbor.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 -- Air warfare over the forward areas around El Agheila, which broke out two days ago, continued yesterday as a spell of clear weather moved eastward along the coast.
Gerald S. Morris, superintendent of telegraph for the New York City Police Department, filed application yesterday for retirement.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- Holding that the Soldiers and Sailors Civil Relief Act was not designed for the benefit of former employers of persons in military service, the Securities and Exchange Commission refused today to grant a motion for a stay in the proceedings against Guaranty Underwriters, Inc. of Jacksonville, Fla., to determine whether its registration as a broker-dealer should be revoked.
The Jews of this city will observe today in mourning and prayer for the millions of Jews threatened with complete extermination in the countries dominated by Nazi Germany.
The battle for Tunis was approaching a climax yesterday, as Allied forces pressed in against the narrowing defensive arc the Nazis hold around the naval base of Bizerte and the city of Tunis.

The fifth "authors' night" at the thirty-seventh annual exhibition of new books of the year at the National Arts Club will be held tonight at 8:15. The speakers will be Antoine de Saint-Exupery, author of "Flight to Arras"; Mrs. Oliver Harriman, whose "Book of Etiquette" was released recently, and Charles J. Rolo, author of "Radio Goes to War."

Bidders paid $39,025 last night for fifty-two paintings from the collection of Mrs. William Fox, wife of the former motion picture producer, at an auction sale in the former Jay Gould residence, 579 Fifth Avenue, a branch of the Kende Galleries of Gimbel Brothers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Transporta tion today "froze" the rental car industry. The order affects approximately 300,000 livery cars, 28,000 funeral cars and 5,000 drive-yourself cars. The order provides that no person or company not licensed in the rental car business as of today may engage in the business, and that no person or company may increase the number of vehicles now engaged in rental service.

IT was said in recent years that the stronghold of football was the Southwest. They had great teams down that way. But this is a turbulent universe in which nothing remains static. Astronomers and physicists have been talking of a red shift in the solar spectrum. They think it's important. There seems to have been a shift in the geographical distribution of football power.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today purchased Maxwell Anderson's play of the 1941-42 season, "Candle in the Wind," and named Otto Preminger to produce and direct it early next year. It is expected that Jean Gabin will play Raoul St. Cloud in the film, taking the role done on Broadway by Louis Parell, while the leading feminine screen star will be sought to fill Helen Hayes's stage part, that of Madeline Guest.

With thirty-four tracks throughout the country represented either in person or by proxy, the first annual meeting of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations of the United States was held here yesterday with the discussion devoted chiefly to the problems confronting wartime racing.

Rudolf Serkin, who gave a piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall, demonstrated his remarkable musicianship and mastery of his instrument throughout the evening, and not least in his playing of sonatas by Beethoven and Schubert -- long sonatas, which in other hands would have been ineffective, but which, under the circumstances, reaped much applause.

Lieut. Comdr. Thomas Burton Klakring, the audacious submarine skipper who sank eight Japanese ships within sight of Japan's ports, was described yesterday as a man who was gentle, calm and meek on the surface but who became hard, thorough and vicious when engaged in any contest.

Summonses have been issued for a manufacturer and a distributor of soldiers' Christmas gift boxes found to be shortweight and mislabeled, it was announced yesterday by city Markets Commissioner Daniel F. Woolley. The Commissioner said his investigators are now active in the wholesale and retail fields of this business, adding that violators of the law would be prosecuted promptly.

Any advertising which infers that inspection of tires at a particular station will make it possible to get new tires without the usual considerations of eligibility, is not in the public interest and should not be published, E.S. Ferguson, regional rationing executive, declared yesterday.

A slightly better tone prevailed yesterday in the stock market. Trading in sizable blocks of a few issues helped lift sales on the Stock Exchange to 561,220 shares, heaviest since last Wednesday, against 472,100 on Monday.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 1 -- After completing the first quarter of his eight-week course as a civil pilot training cadet, Ted Williams, the major league's temperamental and often-turbulent batting champion, today said he found flying so thrilling that he was willing to give up baseball for a naval aviator's career.

The New York Victory Fund Committee, which at the start of the nation-wide $9,000,000,000 government financing program on Monday achieved sales in excess of $1,000,000,000, was well along on the second $1,000,000,000 yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Navy announced tonight that survivors have been landed at a United States east coast port from a medium-sized Norwegian merchant vessel which was torpedoed and sunk by an enemy submarine in the Caribbean area early in November.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. -- Navy, owned by Mrs. E.D. Sowers of Washington, found a heavy track to his liking and romped off with the feature race today. The big son of Annapolis and Chatter Anne won by three lengths from Shrimpie, with Red Wrack a distant third. Only two others, Darby Du and High Name, a stable-mate of the winner, competed on the test of a mile and a sixteenth.

Simone Michelle gave a solo dance recital last night at the New York Times Hall, making use of music by Bach, Schumann, Grieg, Debussy, Scriabine, Rachmaninoff and one or two others. As this would indicate, the program was of a conventional rather than an adventurous sort, and suggested not a little the old days of the interpretative dance.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, acting with the assertion that Marshal Petain is a prisoner of the Germans in Vichy, has taken over authority as Chief of State in French Africa, it was announced tonight from Morocco.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 2 -- Russian armies rode roughshod over stubborn German resistance in the Stalingrad area and on their new Rzhev-Toropets front yesterday, capturing several localities and killing more than 7,000 Axis troops, the Soviet High Command announced today. Fifty big transport planes with which the Germans were trying to supply encircled units on the Stalingrad front were destroyed, twenty in air battles and thirty in Soviet raids on airdromes, the midnight communique said.

The office of Henry J. Kaiser at 281 Fourth Avenue, acting for the Pacific Coast shipbuilder as an employment center for the Kaiser yards at Portland, Ore., and Vancouver, will close on Jan. 1, when it will cease to recruit workers for the Kaiser organization, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Orders for resumption of work in the naval arsenal at Toulon for the first time since the French Fleet was destroyed there last Friday, when the Germans occupied the Toulon district, provoked riots yesterday, according to reports reaching London today.

Joseph Arnold, 33 years old, one of three jewelry "fences" who gave four gunmen $20,000 for the $125,000 in gems obtained in a hold-up in Philadelphia in 1939, voiced dissatisfaction yesterday with the indefinite three-year penitentiary term Judge Owen W. Bohan had imposed on him in General Sessions.

Chief Justice Bayes of Special Sessions announced today that he and Justices Boyle and Weiboldt, sitting as an appellate court, had denied the appeal of Joseph E. McWilliams, leader of the one-time American Destiny party, for a reversal of his conviction and sixty-day workhouse sentence on Sept 9, 1941, on a disorderly conduct charge growing out of his attack on the Jews.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The "full story" of what happened at Pearl Harbor will be revealed by the Office of War Information next Monday, first anniversary of that historic and tragic event, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox stated today.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC AIR BASE, Nov. 20 (Delayed) -- By the grace of God, his own quick thinking and the sturdiness of his Flying Fortress, Colonel La Verne Saunders, commander of an Army bombing group that has been giving the Japanese what-for in the South Pacific since last July, came back to the land of the living today.

Members of fifty business and professional women's clubs in the metropolitan area will hold their fourth annual shopping day at the Franklin Simon Co. store, 414 Fifth Avenue, today from 9:30 A.M. to 9 P.M., with 5 per cent of the net proceeds contributed to the clubs' treasuries.

Hopes of refrigerator producers that additional quantities of vital copper and brass might be made available to them for 1943, due to contemplated adoption of new lightweight steel shell casings, were dispelled yesterday by George W. Meek, conservation division, War Production Board.

The Army is seeking to relieve chaplains of recreation duties and other extra work so that they may appear "primarily as ministers of religion," the Right Rev. Oliver J. Hart, Bishop Coadjutor of Pennsylvania, reported yesterday-at the annual meeting of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Episcopal Diocese of New York at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Five centers of war activity, Washington, San Diego, Norfolk-Portsmouth-Newport News. Mobile-Montgomery and Corpus Christi, have gained more than 25 per cent in population since the 1940 census, the Census Bureau estimated today.

One could almost imagine the far-off tinkle of Santa Claus's sleigh bells as the Saks Fifth Avenus showing got under way yesterday noon at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. At the base of a Christmas tree parcels glistened red in their Yuletide glory.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 -- American industry this year will produce war materials worth $55,000,000,000, Ernest Kanzler, director general of the War Production Board, told 2,500 manufacturers today at the first of a series of "clinics" on the new WPB's controlled materials plan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The total number of Japanese ships sunk or damaged by American submarines rose to 148 when the Navy today announced that our undersea craft operating in Pacific combat waters had sent five more enemy vessels to the bottom and damaged two others, one of which may have been sunk.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET in the South Pacific, Nov. 16 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Navy men who lived through the great battle of the Solomon Islands paid tribute today to "Uncle Dan" Callaghan and others of their mates who did not live.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Leaders of the British Labor party in the House of Commons today traced a broad outline of post-war reconstruction as envisaged by them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Roosevelt said at his press conference today that he would receive General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, if the General should come to this country. But the President remarked that reports that he had invited General de Gaulle to come here were inaccurate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Maritime Commission has awarded the M pennant for meritorious production to nine manufacturing plants and one shipyard and has given gold stars to six shipyards which have already received their pennants for continuing excellence in production.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- American and Australian troops slowly are "contracting" their grip on the enemy along a narrow strip of the Northeastern New Guinea coast between Gona and Buna, and four more Japanese destroyers are lurking off shore, apparently attempting to land reinforcements for the beleaguered garrison, the Allied command announced today.

The City Council's defense committee recommended yesterday elimination from the air raid law of a requirement that certain buildings be equipped with stirrup pumps, sand and shovels. This was a sequel to charges by Mayor La Guardia and William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, that an attempt had been made to "shake down" a distributor of stirrup pumps.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Senator Brewster of Maine said today he was at a loss to understand how the War Manpower Commission could classify newspapers as essential to the war effort and at the same time issue directives to the United States Employment Service that the production of newsprint was non-essential.
New York City's 2,500 tire inspectors appointed by OPA for mileage gasoline rationing reported little activity yesterday on their first day of business.

WEST POINT, Dec. 1 -- President Carlos A. Arroyo del Rio of Ecuador and his entourage paid a visit to the Military Academy this afternoon but inclement weather caused cancellation of the scheduled review by the corps of cadets.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Federal Court was asked today to approve payment of back interest on $7,000,000 of Central of Georgia Railway Company bonds and to instruct the trustee to finance collateral trust bonds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Testimony that government red tape, particularly the flooding of industries with questionnaires, was strangling business, increasing consumer and taxpayer costs and hampering war production prompted the Joint Committee on Reduction of Non-essential Federal Expenditures to report out unanimously today a resolution calling for a Congressional investigation and legislative remedies.

The cotton futures market rebounded yesterday from slight losses at midday under the impetus of more active price-fixing and covering operations. Scale-up hedging checked the advance, however, and left active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange unchanged to 5 points higher than on Monday.

The future of the world is dependent upon the relations between the United States and Great Britain, Captain Leonard D. Gammans, a member of the British House of Commons, declared yesterday in an interview at the Advertising Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- In a special amendment to maximum price regulation No. 33, the Office of Price Administration today supplied discount and premium provisions applicable to certain types of carded cotton yarns. Eight changes set forth in the amendment provide:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Mrs. Josephine Stephenson of the Wykagyl Gardens Apartments said today that her husband, Captain Henry Stephenson of the Grace Steamship Line, still doesn't know the fate of the Brooklyn Dodgers at the hands of the St. Louis Cardinals in the last National League pennant race -- although he had appealed for information in letters to her from a German prison camp.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a series of proposed transactions by the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company and eight of its subsidiaries, as part of which Consolidated will redeem $7,445,100 of Central Gas and Electric Company first lien collateral trust sinking fund bonds.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- The first experimental tests on the possible effect of large amounts of raw egg white on human cancer were described today before the annual meeting of the Radiological Society of North America by Dr. Ira I. Kaplan, chief of the Radiation Therapy Department, Bellevue Hospital, New York City, and his associate, Dr. Milton Zurrow.

The Western Conference champion, as usual, is on top of the nation's football heap. When Ohio State whipped the Iowa Navy Pre-Flight team, 41 -- 12, last Saturday, while Holy Cross was wiping out Boston College, 55 -- 12, the sports experts participating in The Associated Press ranking poll were sufficiently impressed to vote the Buckeyes into first place and drop B.C. to eighth.

The Blaw-Knox Company of Pittsburgh has been selected to prepare the fundamental engineering designs for the co-polymerization plants for the entire synthetic rubber program, it was announced yesterday. The selection was made by the Defense Plant Corporation on the recommendation of four leading rubber companies.

More than 1,500 volunteer money raisers had breakfast yesterday morning at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street, and then went out and began personal solicitation for funds for the support of the 116 medical and social welfare agencies affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Dec. 1 -- Paying special tribute to the submarine and air arms of the Navy, which, he said, have been the "spearheads" of United States advances in the Pacific, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet, today presented awards to twenty-one officers and men at the submarine base here.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 1 -- A New York-Philadelphia foursome led the first session of play for the women's team-of-four title as the national contract bridge championships got under way this afternoon.

It is almost two months since Mr. Justice Byrnes resigned. The short-handedness of the Supreme Court was manifested only the other day when the Chief Justice and three Associate Justices disqualified themselves for one case. Mr. Roosevelt's various, intense and ever-increasing round of duties impose a heavy burden on him.

The Le Roy Trio, consisting of its founder, Rene Le Roy, French flutist: Janos Scholz, 'cellist, and Albert Hirsh, pianist, made its first New York appearance last night before a large audience at Town Hall.

The cooperation of taxpayers and their advisers with the Treasury Department and the Bureau of Internal Revenue was urged yesterday by Randolph E. Paul, general counsel of the Treasury Department, at the second session of the New York University Institute on Federal Taxation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The War Department made public today the names of forty-seven American soldiers, sailors, merchant marine seasmen and civilian ambulance drivers who are held as prisoners of war by the Germans, Italians and Japanese.

KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 1 -- Two 10,000-ton cargo ships, the Santa Catalina and the Santa Barbara, built for the United States Maritime Commission, were launched here this afternoon at the plant of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation.

The General Realty and Utilities Corporation has granted a leave of absence for the duration of the war to Sylvan L. Hanauer, vice president, secretary and director of the firm, who has been commissioned a lieutenant in the Navy, where he will serve in an engineering capacity.

Michael Schaap, president of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., reported yesterday to stockholders that the net profit for the six months ended on July 31 increased to $179,064 from the revised net profit of $57,046 the year before, despite substantially larger tax charges.

J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, in his report yesterday to stockholders at the one hundred and forty-third annual meeting, estimated the net operating income of the bank for 1942 at $3,550,000, exclusive of profits or losses on the sale of securities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Roosevelt told his press conference today that the dispute between the WPB and the Armed Forces over the control of war production scheduling had been settled without impairing output.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 1 -- coffee conservation methods started more than a year ago by the Army Quartermaster Corps have reduced the requirements for each 100 men in the Army from seven pounds to four pounds per meal and have materially increased the percentage of coffee available for the general public, according to announcement made today at the Jersey City quartermaster depot.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The vanguard of the United States Women's Army Auxiliary Corps -- five comely, smart-looking Waacs from five different States -- posed at Army headquarters this afternoon for their photographs.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 138 East Thirty-sixth Street, on a plot 62.5 by 98.9 feet adjoining the corner of Lexington Avenue, has been sold by Mildred S. Otto to an investing client of Harry Posner through Harold M. Silverman, broker.

In every country where Hitler's edicts run, every day is a day of mourning for Jews. Today has been set aside, by action of the chief Rabbinate of Palestine, supported by the leading Jewish organizations of the United States, as a day of mourning, prayer and fasting among the Jews throughout the free countries of the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A modified bill giving President Roosevelt discretionary power to suspend laws governing the movement of property and information into and out of the country was voted upon favorably today by a subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 1 -- Under the regime established since the Germans denounced the Armistice Convention and occupied the whole of their territory, the French will soon have to choose between being "collaborationist" or "terrorist."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 -- Tony Martin, screen and radio singer, has been discharged by the Navy and was on his way tonight to Beverly Hills to report to his draft board. Until yesterday a chief specialist in the Navy, he was expected to be an Army private by Friday.
Eleven prize-winning photographs out of 250 entered in the third annual photography contest of the Camp Fire Girls will be "hung" today in the lobby of the Waldorf-Astoria for a two-week exhibit.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Juvenile delinquency in thirteen upstate war industry counties has increased 22 per cent, child neglect 39 per cent and first admission of children to foster care 33 per cent, according to a preliminary report of wartime influences on children's problems by the State Board of Social Welfare.

A compromise was reached yesterday settling the dispute between the City of Yonkers and Westchester County over which was entitled to money from the sale of thirty-three acres of land formerly owned by the city but now part of the county park system.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Willie Mosconi of Jackson, Mich., gained his third successive victory today and alone remained unbeaten in the world pocket billiards championship. He defeated the defending champion, Irving Crane of Livonia, N.Y., 125 to 45, in seventeen innings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Leon Henderson was subjected to another broadside of criticism today by ten State agricultural officials who charged at a meeting of the Senate farm group that the price chief's policies "will result inevitably in starving America."
Nine new nursery schools will be opened shortly in the city, it was learned yesterday. They will be operated by WPA with the sponsorship of Mayor La Guardia and under the Board of Education.

The Office of War Information has dissected 4,500 specific rumors coming to the attention of various Government agencies since our entry into the war. OWI divides these rumors into five classes -- those caused by hate, by anxiety, by wishful thinking, by belief in the action of supernatural agencies in the war, and by mere attempts to satisfy curiosity.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Nov. 30 (delayed) -- Two formations of P-40 pursuit planes flown by American pilots tangled with Japanese Zeros over the Buna battlefield today and, fighting at a medium altitude, shot down seven of an estimated twelve of the Jap anese. The Americans lost two ships, but the pilots were seen to parachute safely to earth.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- A jury was expected to be completed tomorrow for the trial of Samuel Nuzzo, deposed business agent of Local 17, International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America. Mr. Nuzzo is under indictment on charges of grand larceny and forgery in connection with the embezzlement of more than $35,000 from the union's treasury.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Accompanied by a private of the first class on the piano, a corporal with a fine Irish tenor was in the last bars of "I'll Take You Home Again, Kathleen" as a line of khaki-clad men filed into the grand ballroom of old Stevens Hotel.

The German High Command reported yesterday that bitter fighting was raging in the Kalinin and Toropets sectors, northwest of Moscow, with the Russians throwing tanks and newly arrived reinforcements into the struggle, according to broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.
The mounting toll of merchant seamen who have gone down while delivering the goods is realized full well by the seaman's wife who hears her husband say: "I've just made a ship."

They were to have burned books before the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue yesterday. The occasion was to mark the opening of an exhibition within the library of a collection of some of the books that have been heaped on the bonfires in Germany or else denied to readers in Nazi-dominated countries.

ON the last day of November, the Moon of Falling Leaves, the writing woman's book about "our strange man" was published. Curly was he called while young, because of his fair skin and light hair, and Crazy Horse when his great deeds and many coups won him his father's name, who thereafter was called Worm. Great hunter, great fighter, great war chief was he.

The 3 per cent transportation tax, effective yesterday, will further increase the squeeze under the GMPR on many merchants and will "discriminate" against those retailers who organized community delivery pools at the Government's request to save rubber and gasoline, or who belong to a consolidated delivery service, according to comment in retail circles here yesterday.

There must be no lowering of standards for workers in the child care field in spite of the present emergency, Dr. Alice V. Keliher, chairman of the newly created department of child care, development and protection of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, warned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- Challenging the veracity and accuracy of twenty-seven items, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had reasonable cause to believe that a $3,000,000 registration statement filed by the Curtiss Candy Company on Nov. 17 included "untrue statements of material facts."

ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Labor will have to make sacrifices in the effort to win the war, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of manpower, informed delegates to the annual legislative conference of the State Federation of Labor today.

A new fingerprinting depot of the American Women's Voluntary Services was opened yesterday morning by Mayor La Guardia at a branch of Strauss Stores, Inc., at Fifty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue. He took the prints of the first applicant, Fred V. Fell, publisher, of 45 Astor Place.

The A.O. Smith Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries had a net income in the fiscal year ended on July 31 of $3,703,114, according to the preliminary statement, subject to renegotiation of war contracts, announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Ray (Sugar) Robinson, New York's unbeaten welterweight, scored a technical knockout over Izzy Jannazzo of Brooklyn in the eighth round of a scheduled ten-round bout at the Cleveland News seventeenth annual Christmas Fund boxing show tonight.
Features of the hunting season will be discussed tonight at the annual meeting of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, to be held at the County Center, White Plains.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Farmers will have to plant within 10 per cent of their 1943 AAA crop allotments in order to obtain maximum benefit payments authorized by farm legislation, it was stated today by the Agriculture Department in a move designed to obtain a high degree of compliance with next year's record farm production program.

Many dinner parties were given in advance of the Premiere performance of the Ice Follies of 1943 last night at the Madison Square Garden, which had been taken over by the Musicians Emergerncy Fund. Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw was a dinner hostess at her home, 60 East Sixty-sixth Street.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 1 (AP) -- More than ten Japanese divisions are stationed in territories about Yunnan Province for a possible campaign to close this "backdoor" of China, an Army spokesman disclosed today.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Into the hands of members of Parliament today went the plan that Sir William Beveridge, its author, holds will insure freedom from want to every one in the United Kingdom.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Liberty ship construction virtually ceased tonight at the South Portland Shipbuilding Cor poration plant as night shift employes joined day workers in a walkout stemming from a wage dispute. More than 6,000 men are involved.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

Connecticut is putting on a special drive for highway safety that well might be copied elsewhere at this season and under the pressure of emergency conditions. Emphasis will be put on pedestrian protection, on a rigid enforcement of the maximum thirty-five-mile-an-hour speed law and on observance of the regulations for zones of still lower speed in congested areas.

Five more State witnesses, including a lawyer, a clergyman and a retired school principal, had testified yesterday before Judge Owen W. Bohan and the mixed General Sessions jury in the trial of three theatrical men on the charge of giving an indecent performance of the show "Wine, Woman and Song," when the prosecutor, Assistant District Attorney Sol Gelb, announced the close of the State's, case.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 1 -- Appeals to the United Nations, especially the United States, Britain and Russia, to bend every effort to terminate the slaughter of Jewish communities in Nazi-held Europe and to rescue those threatened with extinction, especially the children, were made at yesterday's special session of the Jewish National Assembly -- the supreme representative body of Palestine Jewry -- attended here by delegates from all parts of the country.

Like a troop of insistent camp followers, scores of new and troublesome questions gather in the wake of our advance in North Africa. This is inevitable for two reasons. One is that the war balance visibly changes with the appearance of the first American expeditionary force on the Western battlefront.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- The Soviet High, Command's midnight communique:
ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's valedictory address:

The full-page ad of Eastern Air Lines wants to know if we ever heard of logistics? We sure have. Logistics, as the ad goes on to explain, is the science and art transportation in war. But as a matter of fact, it is not only the generals a the admirals who have to worry about logistics.

Archibald Douglas, member of the law firm of Douglas, Armitage Holloway, has leased a furnished apartment of thirteen rooms and four baths in 817 Fifth Avenue through the International Real Estate Company. Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company denied today allegations that its long distance telephone rates were burdensome to the public and asked the Federal Communications Commission to dismiss an investigatory proceeding or at least postpone the hearing until next April 1.

It will be the Giants against the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds on Sunday. On a corresponding date last year the interborough rivals also rang down the curtain on the National Football League race. It will be recalled that on that afternoon Ace Parker, the One-Man Gang from Brooklyn, gave one of the greatest performance of his great gridiron career, as he paced the Dodgers to a 21-7 victory over the Giants.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Following are excerpts from Sir William Beveridge's report on economic reforms for post-war Britain:

Unless drivers of New York City vehicles are more careful they will be without jobs, Mayor La Guardia yesterday warned 200 executives of municipal departments on a visit to the training school maintained by the Municipal Civil Service Commission in the Port Authority Building at 111 Eighth Avenue.

James W. Parker, outgoing president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, now holding its annual convention at the Hotel Astor, charged at a luncheon held yesterday under the auspices of the Society's Management's Division that the country is handicapped in meeting the emergency by "government mismanagement."

As opposed to the 1942 Victory book campaign of Winter and Spring when requests were made for large quantities of books (about 50 per cent of which had to be discarded as unfit), the campaign beginning Jan. 5 will avoid the "attic-cleaning psychology" and ask the donation of good books for the armed services.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Still apparently groping a bit in the dark, the club owners of the National and American Leagues met today in the first of their two separate sessions to evolve a war program for 1943, dispose of such matters as night baseball, player limits and the quality of the ball itself, and then left it to their respective steering committees to iron out whatever differences existed between the two circuits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, was instructed by the board today to communicate with Montgomery Ward Co. to clear up a dispute over a maintenance-of-membership provision in the contract which that company is now writing with the Congress of Industrial Organizations' United Mail Order, Warehouse and Retail Employes, Local 20.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Rioting has broken out at Toulon among French naval arsenal workers protesting a purported plan to deport them to Germany in connection with last Friday's sinking of ships, indirect French reports said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee, in a tumultous session during which Senator McCarran of Nevada said his life had been threatened, received assurances today from the largest silver buyer in the country that removal of government restrictions would provide ample foreign supplies of the metal for manufacture of jewelry and tableware.

Like many parents who have children in school, I am much concerned by recent reports about the state of discipline in our public schools, incipient riots, intervention in school buildings by the police, flouting of the authority of teachers, physical assault upon teachers, the murder of one teacher within a school building -- it is a sorry and disturbing record.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 573 as against 777 in the preceding week and 562 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 389, which compared with 249 last Tuesday.
Ten months ago Mrs. Isabel Daniel was a housewife in Los Angeles. Today she is in New York City on a week's factory "furlough."

The jury of award for the Artists for Victory Exhibition of Contemporary American Painting, Sculpture and Graphic Art, which is to open at the Metropolitan Museum next week, was announced yesterday by William Church Osborn, president of the museum.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 1 (AP) -- American heavy bombers flew hundreds of miles across the Bay of Bengal yesterday to assault the Japanese-occupied Andaman Islands for the first time since enemy warships there were dealt a punishing blow by Flying Fortresses on April 3.

WITH AN AMERICAN TANK COLUMN IN TUNISIA, Nov. 24 Delayed) -- Huge American tanks with their heavy armament have made amazing headway over twisting roads and part of the Atlas Mountain chain, traveling more than 100 miles daily to arrive in time to aid the spearhead of the British First Army, of which, with other American units, they form a part.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Grain markets developed unusual strength today on the Board of Trade with rye advancing more than 2 cents a bushel and wheat and corn more than 1 cent. Rye sold at a new high in more than a month and corn went into new high ground for about two months.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The New York League of Nations Association, in cooperation with the Board of Education of the City of New York, opened an exhibition yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, comprising entries on its student art contest on "Winning the Peace."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Voicing the opinion that next year's farm labor problem would be critical, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, revealed today that plans were being made by his organization, in collaboration with the Department of Agriculture, to provide labor for record agricultural production.

President Carlos Arroyo del Rio of Ecuador was the guest of honor last night at a dinner given by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman in the archiepiscopal residence, 452 Madison Avenue, immediately after a Solemn Te Deum and Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
A five-minute make-up that will last for five hours is now all in the day's work at the Mona Manet Salon, 48 East 52d Street, where time-budget beauty treatments were demonstrated yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- As the Boston Committee on Public Safety revised its figures on the number of dead in the Cocoanut Grove fire down to 474 today after discovering duplications in its previous list, which had shown a total of 492, Attorney General Robert T. Bushnell stepped in this afternoon to take personal charge of an all-inclusive investigation into the tragedy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Further operating hours were granted today to WNYC, New York City's radio station.

Those of our countrymen who love France, who are grateful to her for what she has taught us and taught the world, should refrain at this critical moment in her history from hasty generalizations and bitter denunciation of persons. Some of us admire General de Gaulle, who, oblivious of disaster, fought on.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Business remained quiet on the stock market today. The 3 1/2 per cent war loan, on which the half-yearly interest of 33,000,000 was paid today, rose 1/8 to 104 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Two days hence, when pending agreements made by the State Department with the Republic of Panama come up for discussion in the Senate, one of the most vigorous debates of recent years is promised on the Administration's foreign policy and its Good Neighbor policy in particular.

The New York metropolitan area is confronted with another meat shortage more severe than that of last Summer. Throughout the city there are many butchers who have no roast beef, steak and chops and no immediate prospects of obtaining supplies of the red meats, which are needed for the armed forces and for lend-lease.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 1 -- The results of Sunday's election, though still incomplete, today permit a fairly accurate forecast to be made of the strength of the various parties in the National Senate and Chamber of Deputies. In both branches of the Legislature representatives of the Liberal-Democratic Colorado party will greatly outnumber those of the conservative Blanco or National party.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 30 (Delayed) -- Going "over the hump" from India into China is now an off-told tale, but if its cold, dogged heroism -- a heroism that gets no reward has no glamour -- should be neglected or even forgotten for a day, the folks back home would be doing an injustice to a great outfit doing a great job.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Although President Roosevelt at his press conference today said he had reached no definite conclusion regarding the number of French naval vessels sunk or damaged at Toulon, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox expressed the opinion that the four submarines reported to have escaped from Toulon were the only units of the fleet not destroyed or damaged.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan for the sale of the physical properties and for the subsequent dissolution of Missouri Electric and Power Company, a subsidiary of Central States Power and Light Corporation.

Speaking at the hanging of a service flag honoring the 153 employes of the Controller's office now in military service, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott said yesterday that he had received "magnificent cooperation" from city officials in his work as Director of Selective Service in New York City.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Governor Lehman delivered over a State-wide radio network tonight his valedictory address to the people of the State. He leaves Albany tomorrow after fourteen years of public service here, four as Lieutenant Governor and ten as Governor.

Your family is temporarily tired of cheese dishes and they had fish yesterday, so you are faced again with the question of what to serve for dinner that will not infringe on the meat quota. Beans are the answer -- dried beans that may be prepared in a hundred different ways, baked or fried or transformed into soups.

Rochester, N.Y., made yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,600,000 of refunding bonds to a syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co., and including Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., First Boston Corporation, Blyth Co., Inc., Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo, L.F. Rothschild Co., W.E. Hutton Co., Coffin Burr, Inc., and Edward Lowber Stokes Co.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 -- A Senussi Arab chief, Sheik Ali, who was imprisoned during the Italian occupation of the Siwa Oasis for his refusal to tell where British gasoline was hidden, revealed the cache recently to a Royal Air Force sergeant.

Because Lily Pons is suffering from a cold, the title role of Delibes's "Lakme" will be sung tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House by Marie Wilkins, American soprano, who was engaged for the role yesterday when Edward Johnson was informed by Miss Pons's physician that she would be unable to sing.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Bruins upset the Red Wings, 5 -- 2, tonight before 10,000 at Boston Garden to climb into a second-place tie in the National Hockey League. A four-goal surge in the opening period did the damage and the Wings were never able to get back into the game after that outburst.
Mayor La Guardia's Sunday radio pronouncement that bingo is unlawful wherever it is played, was challenged again last night and is due for a court test today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- William J. Bingham, athletic director at Harvard University for twenty-two years, tonight was granted a leave of absence so he can join the United States Army as a major.
The eight-family house at 690 Sackett Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Laffel Realty, Inc., to Berjouhe Kaloustian through Paul A. Bogossian, broker.
Herbie Katz, 175 1/4, Brownsville, knocked out Tommy Campanella, 173, Bay Ridge, in the fourth round of the scheduled ten-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

" This Little Hand," a melodrama with an all-woman cast, by Wilfrid H. Pettitt, goes into rehearsal today under Reginald Denham's direction. A.H. Woods is the sponsor; Columbia Pictures the backer. In the cast: Adele Longmire, Mary Orr, Joan Yendis, Elaine Ellis, Mary McCormick, K.O. Copeland, Irene Daily, Marilyn Erskine and Ruth Krakaskai.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- The Women's Supreme Council of B'nai B'rith designated today that January be set aside as a period during which members will study and prepare to enter industry in an endeavor to relieve the labor shortage.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A communique:

The famous "integrated" train that was run experimentally over the BMT lines several years ago after Diesel-engine streamliners had become the vogue on steam railroads is destined for the strategic metal scrap pile as the result of an order of requisition served yesterday on William Jerome Daly, secretary of the Board of Transportation, by the Federal Government.

ON THE RUSSIAN CENTRAL FRONT, Dec. 1 -- I have had the opportunity to see in this small Russian market town, about thirty miles from the front line of the central front, how the reoccupied zone is backing up the Red Amy's operations and how vigorously the work of reconstruction is undertaken by the Soviet authorities to create a solid rear for the offensive forces.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Other than omission of the section covering entrance of aliens, the redrafted war powers bill differed little from the form in which it was presented previously to the Ways and Means Committee. Just what its reception in the committee would be remained uncertain.

Since the start of October the priorities division of the War Production Board of this region has issued emergency preference ratings for production material in sixty-two cases, thus preventing stoppage of vital work in many instances, it was learned here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Sales of independent retailers gained 13 per cent in October, as compared with October last year, J.O. Capt, Director of the Census, announced today. A gain of 8 per cent for October as compared with September was reported.

JERSEY CITY, N.J. Dec. 1 (AP) -- Vice Chancellor Henry T. Kays reserved decision today on an application by Milton M. Unger, Newark, for a fee of $300,000 from the preferred stockholders of the American Car and Foundry Company of Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Roosevelt put in the lap of Congress today the question whether income from sources other than salaries should be limited to an annual net of $25,000 after taxes and other payments just as salaries are now limited by Executive order.

Two physicians and the 22-year-old receptionist of one of the doctors were indicted yesterday by the Bronx County grand jury for manslaughter in the first degree in the death after an illegal operation on Nov. 18 of Miss Madeline McGeehan, 26, an OPA employe at Washington.

Three speakers yesterday, in their efforts to impress upon the American mind the necessity for continued help to Great Britain, painted Americans as a people unconscious of England's great part in the war, intimated that we feel a superiority, and warned against local hostility toward the "British Empire."

Lieutenant (junior grade) Henry P. Jenks, United States Naval Reserve, a son of Maurice L. Jenks, vice president of the American Surety Company here, has been killed in action, his family announced yesterday. Lieutenant Jenks was 28 years old.

Tom Mercer Girdler, chairman of the board and former president of the Republic Steel Corporation, will marry today Miss Helen R. Brennan, a secretary, of 865 First Avenue, according to information obtained at the Marriage License Bureau, Municipal Building.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Thrusts by land that were reported tonight to have pierced the enemy's defenses, coupled with a twenty-four-hour air bombardment more intense than any yet unfolded in this campaign, may mean that the decisive battle for Tunisia has begun.

Frederick (Big Freddie) Bertolotti, 35 years old, the ex-convict who is on Mayor La Guardia's list of racketeers to be driven by the police from this city, was convicted yesterday in Special Sessions on a usury charge. He is to be sentenced on Friday, and faces a penitentiary term up to three years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Canada and the United States have agreed through an exchange of notes, made public tonight, that post-war settlements must be of a sort which will promote mutually advantageous economic relations and the betterment of world-wide economic relations.
