Hundreds of thousands of Italo-American and Italian workers in the United States will be mobilized by the Italian-American Labor Council to help encourage and finance revolt against the Mussolini regime in Italy with the aim of getting Italy out of the war as soon as possible and thus help promote the victory of the United Nations, it was announced yesterday by Luigi Antonini, president of the council.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The methodical destruction of Italy's industrial cities by Royal Air Force raids has created "an immense desire for peace" in the Italian masses, the Tribune de Lausanne said today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 1 -- A trek overland of 78,000 men, who must travel on foot more than 600 miles across mountain, river, jungle and swamp to the Amazon region, is the ambitious plan that the Coordinator of Economic Mobilization, Joao Alberto Lins de Barros, has for immediate execution.

Designed to coordinate the retail industry in a unified patriotic effort, the first issue of a bulletin of retailers' war campaigns will1 be issued next week and will appear monthly thereafter, it was reported yesterday at the meeting of the Central Committee of National Retail Associations at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

HARTFORD, Dec. 2 -- A student group of women fire insurance underwriters made their first actual inspection of a typical fire insurance risk yesterday. The plant visited was a large laundry and dry-cleaning establishment.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The report made to the House of Commons by Sir William Beveridge on social security caused a reaction in the stock markets today as life insurance shares fell and the industrial insurance groups registered heavy declines.

Marie Wilkins came to New York from her home in Lawrence, Kan., three weeks ago to make another try at the Opera Auditions of the Air, and last night she found herself making her debut on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House in the title role of "Lakme."

BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- An assertion that a revolving door cost two or three hundred lives in the Cocoanut Grove fire and testimony that decorations once fireproofed required annual reproofing were expressed before a board of inquiry today as the toll of lives in the Saturday night disaster reached toward 500.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 -- Unless at least 40,000 farm workers are rehabilitated next year and the drain of labor from farm to industry is stopped, California, instead of producing record food crops in 1943, will fall short of equaling its 1942 production, the first all-California war conference was told today by Senator Downey.

The recently reported agreement with Brazil by which import control will be "decentralized" was generally approved as being designed to facilitate foreign trading under present conditions, but drew some criticism at a meeting yesterday of the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Willie Mosconi of Jackson, Mich., grabbed a commanding lead at the halfway mark of the world pocket billiard championship tonight by downing Erwin Rudolph of Chardon, Ohio, 125 to 48, in eight innings.

GUADALCANAL, Nov. 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- Japanese patrol parties that have lost face because they have been defeated by United States Marines apparently have made little or no effort to rejoin the main Japanese forces, marines returning from jungle fighting reported today.

In Topics of The Times on Nov. 27 it is stated that J.M. Keynes's book "The Economic Consequences of the Peace" does not state correctly the history of the Fourteen Points in connection with the German surrender and the Treaty of Versailles.

Present knowledge of the behavior of food materials being dehydrated is entirely inadequate, Lieutenant Matthew E. Highlands of the Subsistence Research Laboratory, Chicago Quartermaster Depot, said yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Society of Refrigerating Engineers in the Hotel Commodore.

Another of the season's musical cycles was launched last night at Town Hall when Joseph Schuster, 'cellist, and Nadia Reisenberg, pianist, played the first of their two recitals devoted to the five sonatas and three sets of variations composed by Beethoven for 'cello and piano.

A general but limited improvement continued yesterday in the stock market as a modest demand cropped out for some of the industrial issues. The buying was of a better type, although a cautionary note ran through the trading as the lack of any sizable tax-selling volume this week has only served to threaten an avalanche of such sales when they reappear.

Of course, you're doing your part in this war effort by saving on sugar and coffee, by walking instead of riding, by conserving what you own -- but do you long for a real job, one which will give you the satisfaction of knowing you are contributing in a major way to final victory?
The Great Lakes Naval Training Station, still known for the mighty football team it turned out during World War I, again is the nation's leading service football power.

Unofficial estimates in financial circles yesterday indicated that since the Treasury's nation-wide drive to sell $9,000,000,000 of government securities this month was begun on Monday, the sales effort of the New York Victory Fund Committee had accounted for approximately $2,500,000,000.

President Herbert Davis of Smith College gave a dinner last night in the Regence Room of the Weylin for members of a special committee of women's colleges. The guests included Presidents Ada Louise Comstock of Radcliffe College, Katharine E. McBride of Bryn Mawr College and Roswell G. Ham of Mount Holyoke College, Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College and Dean Mildred Thompson of Vassar College.

There were no simulations from the witness stand in General Sessions yesterday of the alleged suggestive songs, gyrations "strip tease" and "fan dance" of two girl principals in the cast of "Wine, Women and Song."

President Carlos Arroyo del Rio of Ecuador received last night the Gold Medal of the Pan American Society for his work in promoting solidarity and friendship in the Western Hemisphere. The presentation was made at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel sponsored jointly by the Pan American Society and the Ecuadorean-American Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee gave formal approval today to a bill which would permit the sale or lease of unpledged government silver for consumptive uses in industry "in furtherance of the war effort."
It's a case of the blind leading the blind, literally, into war work. At the Solar Manufacturing Company in West New York, N.J., there are now ten blind young men and women gauging mica spacers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- As a step toward a joining of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations and as a war production measure peace committees of the organizations agreed today to submit all jurisdictional disputes to arbitration.

Butler Brothers' warehouse serving the New York division of the company and located in Jersey City will be taken over by the War Department, T.B. Freeman, president of the wholesale house, announced yesterday. The company will operate from the warehouse until Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- An uprising developed in a group of House Democrats today against "bureaucratic government," and demands were heard that Congress take back for itself some powers delegated to the executive branch.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The Cripps mission was disappointing from the Indian princes' point of view, said the Maharajah of Nawanagar, Chancellor of the Chamber of Princes, in addressing the East India Association in London today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Roosevelt delivered today to a new Petroleum Administration for War, headed by Secretary Ickes, his wartime powers to control the petroleum industry and centralize government policies affecting it. Secretary Ickes preferred to retain his present Cabinet post and his war responsibilities affecting oil and solid fuels rather than accept a Presidential commission as Secretary of Labor and Manpower Director.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 3 (AP) -- communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Unanimous approval was given today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee to a bill which would increase by $5,000,000,000 the authority of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to borrow and lend to war industries.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall the new attraction will be "You Were Never Lovelier," a Columbia musical comedy starring Fred Astaire and Rita Hayworth. The film, which has a Latin-American background, features songs by Jerome Kern and Johnny Mercer and a supporting cast including Adolphe Menjou, Xavier Cugat and his orchestra, Leslie Brooks, Adele Mara, Isobel Elsom and Gus Schilling.

Ralph Kirkpatrick was heard in the first of a series of four harpsichord recitals last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. During the course of the series it is Mr. Kirkpatrick's intention to perform all of the harpsichord works to be found in Bach's "Clavieruebung."

Bankers headed by the First Boston Corporation and Coffin Burr, Inc., today are offering a new issue of $12,500,000 Central Maine Power Company first and general mortgage series M 3 1/2 per cent bonds due on Sept. 1, 1972. They are priced at 107 3/8 and interest, to yield 3.12 per cent.

Conferences between work shirt producers and interested government agencies seeking concentration of suitable utility fabrics into one basic "Victory" model, which would be made available to consumers in both mill-finish and preshrunk qualities, may result in an early directive ordering industry-wide compliance, it was reported yesterday in the market.

Legislation for relief of State income-tax payers was virtually promised yesterday by Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey after a conference with Republican legislative leaders at his law office at 20 Exchange Place.

Dedication of an airplane radio instrument landing system that will permit safe arrivals when weather ceilings are below the safety level prescribed by the Civil Aeronautics Administration shared honors with a 150-pound birthday cake yesterday as La Guardia Field marked the third anniversary of its opening.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Dec. 2 -- A new speed record for airplanes in a power dive, 725 miles an hour, was set by two young Army fliers when they plunged their P-47 fighter planes earthward from an altitude of 35,000 feet over an East Coast air base on Nov. 15, it was announced today by the Republic Aviation Corporation, makers of the P-47, also known as the Thunderbolt.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Declaring he considered food production just as essential as the manufacture of tanks and airplanes, Donald M. Nelson assured farmers today that the War Production Board would grant agriculture all the assistance possible in meeting record 1943 production goals.

It is four days since Winston Churchill's speech of last Sunday, but people still find occasion to come back to it, usually remarking, "By no means the least interesting point in Mr. Churchill's speech," or something of the kind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The United States ended the fifth month of the current fiscal year with the public debt exceeding $100,000,000,000 for the first time in history. It increased from $99,932,589,166.25 last Saturday to $100,379,324,851.62 Monday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 2 -- Negotiations were resumed today at the Foreign Ministry on the plan suggested by the United States by which Argentina, in return for drilling equipment and parts for refineries which the United States would supply, would help relieve the gasoline shortage in neighboring republics.

In a message broadcast by short wave to France and North Africa Mayor La Guardia last night called upon the French to resist the Nazis by destroying factory machinery, slowing down industrial production and by "burning the food intended for your enemies, the murderers of your people."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- American shipbuilders moved nearer President Roosevelt's 1942 objective of 8,000,000 tons of new cargo vessels, the Maritime Commission said today, by delivering eighty-four vessels totaling 891,700 deadweight tons in November.

Brick and tile manufacturers in the New York area face the prospect of a virtual shutdown, perhaps by government order, and are seeking ways of meeting their economic plight and at least keeping in a position to meet the possible revival in civilian construction after the war, members of the industry reported at a conference held yesterday in the Biltmore Hotel under the auspices of the Structural Clay Products Institute.

Mussolini was right yesterday when he said he thought the Italian people wanted to hear from him. After his long silence in the face of unrelenting disaster, the victims of his policy must have wanted to know what he could say in defense of the ruinous course that has left Italy in worse position than defeated France.
Perhaps this is no time to talk about going fishing, but the subject always interests Arthur Benson, president of the National Association of Fishing Tackle Manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A second system of rationing, the "point" method, is to be introduced to consumers about Jan. 1, when beef, pork, lamb and veal are put under formal distribution curtailment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- Frank E. Gannett, Rochester publisher, tonight entered the race for chairmanship of the Republican National Committee, which will be vacated Dec. 7 when Joseph W. Martin steps out.

As our North African campaign rolls onward we are all taking an increasing interest in the unfolding of Allied strategy and war aims in the Mediterranean. I am particularly interested in trying to gauge their effect on Italy. As a long-time resident in that country I feel I can say with assurance that our policy of alternating appeasement and threat will end in confusion and disaster.

A drive to obtain war orders for the dress industry is being launched by the union, it was reported yesterday by Julius Hochman, general manager of the Dress Joint Board. A special bureau is being set up at the headquarters of the union, 218 West Fortieth Street, which will be devoted to war work requirements and to aid manufacturers in conversion or in any reorganization of their physical equipment that may be needed.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Dec. 1 (delayed) -- Relentless and persistent attacks by Australian and American troops brought further gains against strong Japanese positions in the Buna-Gona area of New Guinea today. The Allied ground forces were aided by a heavy air activity that took the form of almost continuous bombing and strafing attacks on the Japanese positions by many types of Allied planes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Transportation appeal today that tickets be sold only to those persons living in the area where the games will be played brought immediate responses of cooperation from the five major bowls and also from the officers of the East-West game in San Francisco, which is played annually for the benefit of the Shrine Hospital in the California city.

After more than a quarter of century of work, the New York Zoning Committee met yesterday at its offices at 233 Broadway and voted to disband formally at the end of the year because it had "successfully accomplished" the major purposes for which it was organized in 1916.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- C.M. Van Kirk, vice president of E.R. Squibb Sons, has been quoted as charging before a Senate committee that the Office of Price Administration delayed action six weeks in giving his company a price at which it could sell a new product for the treatment of whooping cough, Leon Henderson, Price Adiministrator, said in a formal statement today.

Gerard S. Nollen, president of the Bankers Life Company of Iowa; Holgar J. Johnson and Arthur C. Daniels were re-elected, respectively, chairman, president and secretary at the annual business meeting of the Institute of Life Insurance, held yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- Six Army officers and 96 enlisted men received at Walter Reed Hospital yesterday Purple Heart decorations for wounds in action.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Ways and Means Committee, still deadlocked over the new war powers sought by the Administration over tariffs, immigration and information, asked its chairman, Representative Doughton today to introduce a bill in the House, but only for the purpose of providing a basis for the public hearings which have been demanded.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Brown football followers saw the movies of the Thanksgiving Day Brown-Colgate game today and moaned. The films, shown for the first time at the weekly gridiron luncheon of the Providence Brown Club, show distinctly that a fourth-quarter end zone pass from Doc Savage to Charlie Tiedemann was caught by Tiedemann well within bounds in the Colgate end zone.

For the first time since prohibition was repealed, there will be no all-night drinking permits issued for New Year's Eve by the State Liquor Authority, it was announced yesterday by Henry E. Bruckman, chairman.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 2 -- At the annual meeting of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association, held today at the Montclair Golf Club, Mrs. William W. Povey of the Essex County Country Club was unanimously elected president, succeeding Mrs. Harold Ford of Ridgewood.

BOSTON, Dec. 2 -- In voting a posthumous pardon today to Arthur St. Germain, 27, of Haverhill, the Executive Council revealed today that the young man, who served a long term at the Norfolk State prison colony, gave his life in secret Navy tests, the results of which might save thousands of lives.

In an otherwise excellent editorial in THE TIMES of Nov. 27, "Thanksgiving in the Abbey," I cannot refrain from calling attention to two unfortunate errors, both contained in the same sentence, as follows: "For the first time this cathedral, older than the Church of England."

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS in Australia, Thursday, Dec. 3 -- Allied airmen have downed twenty-three Japanese Zero planes and driven off a naval convoy that attempted to reinforce the entrapped Japanese at Buna, on the Northeast New Guinea coast, the High Command announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Pierre Laval, French Chief of Government, has arrived in Berlin for discussions on the formation of a new Vichy government, a Swiss dispatch from Milan, Italy, said tonight.

The annual Christmas bazaar in aid of St. George's Episcopal Church will be held today and tomorrow at Memorial House, 207 East Sixteenth Street. The setting for the event will be a simulated New England village green around which will be grouped many miniature shops devoted to the sale of a wide variety of useful and decorative articles.
THE big league ball players were for a revision of the major league schedules, anyhow. Those four-trip schedules had the men dizzy packing and unpacking their suitcases and dashing to catch trains.

Tom Mercer Girdler of Cleveland, chairman of the board and former president of the Republic Steel Corporation, and Miss Helen R. Brennan, a secretary, of 865 First Avenue, were married at 4 o'clock yesterday at the home of Victor Emanuel, 895 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Congressional Medal of Honor was awarded posthumously to Captain Harl Pease Jr., of Plymouth, N.H., for "gallantry and intrepidity above and beyond the call of duty" in combat with Japanese airplanes in the New Guinea area last August.

With the publication on Saturday of two titles a new publishing firm -- new to this country, that is -- will be introduced. The firm is Roy Publishers, 381 Fourth Avenue, headed by Marion Kister, who founded in Warsaw in 1925 the publishing firm of Tow: Wydawnicze.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- American aircraft builders turned out more planes in the first year of the present war than they built in all the twenty-three peacetime years following the first World War, the Aeronautic Chamber of Commerce stated today.

Charming and unusual flower arrangements were displayed yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in a preview of floral suggestions for 1943, sponsored by the Florists Telegraph Association, composed of florists all over the United States.

Men's wear retailers will make formal application within the next week to relieve them from the present Maximum Price Regulation 177, which they consider confusing and complicated, and will ask the Office of Price Administration to place their price regulations on a mark-up basis rather than the base period now in effect, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Two procedures which manufacturers of upholstered furniture may follow in marketing furniture in which they have used wood or other substitute materials for the metal springs which have been banned since Nov. 1, were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

Women, because of their greater intuition, can do more than men in battling fascism, George Hamilton Combs Jr., radio commentator, declared yesterday. They see "the danger signals flying before men do," Mr. Combs told 1,000 women leaders of Brooklyn philanthropic, cultural and social organizations at the President's Day conference of the Brooklyn Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

While Americans now must ration their consumption of coffee, their government owns more than 1,000,000,000 pounds of coffee beans stored in Brazilian warehouses that it is unable to transport to the United States, it was reported here yesterday by Dr. Moacyr E. Alvaro, secretary-general of the National Committee for the Prevention of Blindness in in Brazil and Professor of Ophthalmology at the Sao Paulo School of Medicine.

In an effort to halt the excessive profits being earned by many concerns holding government contracts, the Price Adjustment Board of the War Department has been asked to renegotiate agreements with 7,300 companies, it was disclosed yesterday by Charles O. Pengra, chief counsel of the board.

Waving a calabash pipe picked up on shore leave in Capetown, South Africa, and brandishing a recalcitrant "mike" in the other, Second Officer Frank A. Santina, recipient of the Merchant Marine Distinguished Medal" for heroism above and beyond the call of duty," recounted yesterday his experiences under fire, at the evening program of the Business and Professional Women's Clubs fair at Franklin Simon's.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A Senate committee to investigate the havoc which war has wrought upon Puerto Rican economy organized today and selected as counsel Rafael Bosch, a native Puerto Rican and now a New York lawyer, who said he had never been connected with Puerto Rican politics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Director Joseph B. Eastman of the Office of Defense Transportation today asked managers of the annual bowl football games and schools participating to restrict the sale of tickets to these New Year's contests to the immediate areas in which the games will be played.

LONDON, DEC. 2 -- The mutual dependence of the United Nations after the war must be recognized as the cornerstone of peace and prosperity for the whole world after the conflict ends, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today, winding up the two-day debate on the Labor amendment calling for a postwar program.

The city of Boston, Mass., made yesterday the award of a new issue of $5,000,000 of temporary loan notes, dated Dec. 4, 1942, and payable on Oct. 1, 1943, to the First Boston Corporation and the Chemical Bank and Trust Company. The bankers jointly bid on a 0.67 per cent basis, plus a premium of $78. Reoffering of the notes is being made to yield 0.60 per cent.

The audience last night in the Broadway Theatre sat fascinated by the New Opera Company's performance of Verdi's "Macbeth" -- by the lusty and often superbly imaginative music of the opera, and the manner of its performance. It is a notable achievement.

Eleven days ago the Russians announced the start of their Stalingrad offensive and last Sunday they reported the opening of offensive operations on the important Rzhev front. Yesterday, the Soviet communiques continued to claim successes, though with less specific detail than hitherto.

New fighters, bombers and transport planes still on the secret list that are "enough to make the angels gasp" and tanks described by a British general who used them as "the answer to a tank-man's prayer" were among the items revealed yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Hotel Astor by American Army officers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- A new Air Force X-ray machine which has won the praise of Lieut. Gen. Dwight Eisenhower for its front line service in the North African campaign, drew the interest today of delegates to the annual convention of the Radiological Society of North America.

Imperial Japanese headquarters announced yesterday "the virtual termination of mopping-up operations in the Philippines" against American and Filipino remnants holding out in mountainous or other inaccessible parts of the islands, according to Tokyo broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 2 -- Because they gave the world the story of the scuttling of the French fleet at Toulon last Friday several members of the editorial staff of Havas, the official news agency in Vichy, France, are under arrest, threatened with trial for "disseminating false information."

UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES HEADQUARTERS, in North Africa, Dec. 1 -- (Delayed) -- (U.P.) -- One of the most daring feats of the North African campaign was credited today to an American pilot who landed his plane last night near Gabes and rescued the crew of a United States bomber that had been forced down after having raided that Axis-held Tunisian port.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- General Wladislaw Sikorski, Premier of Poland, who is here on an official visit upon the invitation of President Roosevelt, declared at a press conference today that the initiative had been taken by the United Nations in the European war, but he stressed that Adolf Hitler was preparing to wage a defensive war within "the fortress of Europe."

Paintings from the collection of Mrs. William Fox, wife of the former motion-picture producer, were sold at auction last night for $38,935, making the total for the two sessions of the sale $77,960. The auction was held at the former Jay Gould residence, 579 Fifth Avenue, now a branch of the Kende Galleries of Gimbel Brothers.

A series of mural paintings which, it is believed here, will be the first in any public building in Washington, D.C., to depict the contribution of the Negro to America, will decorate the lobby and library of the Recorder of Deeds Building there.

Women's careers must be sacrificed as "ruthlessly" to the war program as men are sacrificing their lives, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College declared yesterday in a talk on "College Women in the War" before the Women's Graduate Club of Columbia University, meeting in Philosophy Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Treasury announced today that sales of war bonds in November amounted to $734,500,000 against a quota of $800,000,000, but that voluntary payroll deductions for the purchase of Series E war bonds had risen to a record total of $340,000,000.

The amended Walker Law under which boxing is conducted in this State will be revised to lower the age limit for professional boxers to 16 years if plans of the State Athletic Commission materialize. Chairman John J. Phelan revealed yesterday he will recommend in his annual report to the Legislature that the 18-year-old limit be reduced to meet a growing emergency caused by the war.
A High, Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
Racing's leaders from many States and representing most shades of opinion gathered here yesterday to agree unanimously on a continuance of the sport and of the sport's war effort in 1943.

Mrs. Wendell Willkie and Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, chairman of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, were present yesterday as 1,200 pounds of used silk and nylon stockings, or approximately 30,000 pairs, were deposited at a midtown center.
James Monroe's soccer players beat Lafayette High, 1-0, to win the City P.S.A.L. championship yesterday at Ulmer Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Roosevelt was reported today as still holding to the idea of concentrating all manpower functions in a revivified Labor Department despite the fact that he abandoned his intention of having Secretary Ickes take the new post.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Reaction to Sir William Beveridge's social security report, issued yesterday, has been sharp and widespread, as expected, with the public buying up the voluminous text avidly and politicians generally coming out with guarded statements of approval.

Operations of Wm. Filene's Sons Company and its subsidiaries in the six months ended on July 31 resulted in a net profit of $336,309, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 47 cents a share on 500,000 common shares, according to the report of Edward J. Frost, president.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 2 -- Fifteen sailors out of a party of seventeen in a twenty-eight-foot boat lost their lives early today when the craft was capsized in a storm. Five bodies had been recovered tonight, and virtually no hope was held for the ten missing men, for whom the search continued.

The 1943 Salvation Army campaign in this city will commence in mid-January, will have a goal of $525,000 and will be headed by Clifford E. Paige, president and chairman of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, it was announced yesterday by Walbridge S. Taft, chairman of the Salvation Army's Greater New York Advisory Board, at a luncheon of the board in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.
Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine continued yesterday their adroit avoidance of any direct comment or action on the issue of bingo in the city's churches.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- Governor Lehman formally relinquished his post this afternoon, turning over the reins of office for the next twenty-nine days to his personal friend and adviser, Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- President Roosevelt will honor ten "production soldiers" at the White House Dec. 10 for outstanding contributions to the war.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Indian army jungle patrols, combing the marshy Burmese coast near the Indian frontier, were reported victors today in two small clashes with the Japanese.
Colonel and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Biddle of Philadelphia are at the Savoy-Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Lieut. Col. Boyd David (Buzz) Wagner who wrote aviation history in the Philippines and Southwestern Pacific, has been missing since Monday on a routine Florida-Alabama flight, the War Department disclosed today. He took off from Eglin Field for Maxwell Field.

CHARLES TOWN, W.V., Dec. 2 -- Two lucky racegoers stepped up to the pay-off window today and received $1,330 each because an hour earlier they had invested $2 on the chances of a pair of daily double long shots.

" Vicious and stupid rumors" which are utterly unfounded have been circulated to the effect that blind persons could obtain Seeing Eye dogs by collecting quantities of tinfoil, empty match folders, cigarette packages or similar articles, Edward L. Greene, general manager of the National Better Business Bureau, said yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Excerpts from Premier Mussolini's speech as recorded from Axis broadcasts fol-follow:

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 2 -- A broad school program, calling for the training for war production of 1,500,000 men and women, now in non-essential industries, at a cost of close to $100,000,000 was announced here today at the opening of the annual American Vocational Association Convention with 1,000 educators from every part of the country in attendance.

In remarking to his press conference that there were lots of kicks around the country because the net $25,000 salary limitation did not apply to income inherited or invested and in suggesting that it was up to Congress to do something about it, President Roosevelt pointed to a situation that must have been foreseen when the salary-limiting order was promulgated.

As the Brooklyn Dodgers prepare to wind up the National Football League season against the Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sunday they are confronted with the probability of having to face their interborough rivals with only one spare end.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 2 -- Foreign Minister Joaquin Fernandez made a long exposition of Chile's international position at a secret Senate session tonight. No details have been given out, but it is presumed that he confirmed recent statements made by President Juan Antonio Rios admitting that "Chile is ready to break off with the Axis when her own and the continent's interests make it advisable."

German military circles hinted yesterday at imminent counter-operations against the Russians on the Eastern Front, and declared the initiative still remained in German hands in the Stalingrad area, according to broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

Sponsors and patrons of the benefit performance of the Ice Follies tonight at Madison Square Garden will give many dinner parties before the event, which will commemorate the twenty-first anniversary of the beneficiary -- the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

Students of organization -- military, business and governmental -- should welcome the statements of your editorial of Nov. 26, "War Organization." Most writers on the subject agree that "* * * an organization that breeds constant internal disagreements is on its face an inadequate organization.

Sam W. Murphy, president of the Electric Bond and Share Company, yesterday called for a moratorium on the "death sentence" for utility holding companies during the war period. In his quarterly report to stockholders of the huge holding company, Mr. Murphy asked for a fair valuation of utility assets and declared that such assets should not be sacrificed under present war-torn market conditions.

Our correspondent at Berne writes that under the regime established since the Germans denounced the Armistice Convention and occupied the whole of their territory the French will soon have to choose between being "collaborationist" or "terrorist." This is the only choice, it might be added, that Hitler gives to any one.

Pledging their full continued support to the war production program and acceptance of any sacrifices that may be necessary to achieve victory, leaders of American industry in addresses before the War Congress sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers demanded yesterday that the system of free enterprise be preserved after the war and warned against utilizing the war emergency as a springboard for revolutionary experimentation.

The thousands of New Yorkers who have not obtained War Ration Book 1, either because they use neither sugar nor coffee or because they do all their eating in restaurants, were advised yesterday to get the ration book anyway, and to do so by Dec. 15.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Taken by surprise, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and his advisers made a close examination today of the proclamation broadcast over the Morocco radio last night announcing that Admiral Darlan had assumed "the rights and responsibilities of a government" and established under his authority a High Commissariat and a French Imperial Council which together would "represent France in the world."

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association divided the prized North Jersey Group 4 football championship among four undefeated elevens tonight in an unprecedented move which left the recipients a bit bewildered but apparently satisfied.

Warning of the possibility of a reduction in the value of fuel oil ration coupons, Ralph C. Baker, district rationing officer of the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday that the situation in the Eastern States was far more serious than most householders realized.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

Mayor La Guardia addressed the opening session of the National Institute of Municipal Law Officers at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, telling the legal advisers of the cities of this nation that their localities have made "great contributions to the Federal effort" but warning them against "Federal ambition of jurisdiction."
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A British Headquarters Royal Air Force communique:
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A Soviet information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Regulations under the James F. Byrnes stabilization program designed to stabilize salaries as near as possible to the level prevailing on Sept. 15 and prevent the payment to any one of a net salary after Federal taxes of more than $25,000 were issued by the Bureau of Internal Revenue today.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Princess Margaret Rose has given her favorite doll -- a rosy-cheeked "character" doll with brown hair -- to be sold at the Red Cross sale opened in Grosvenor House today by Mrs. Winston Churchill in connection with War Prisoners Week.

MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- Both northwest and southwest of Stalingrad the Germans have been unable to make a stand on the hill lines where their commanders had elected to halt the Russian advance and they are gradually being pushed back, in one case toward the city and in the other way from it, according to today's reports.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Universal announced today that Charles Boyer and the Charles K. Feldman Group Productions, an organization established by the Feldman Agency, will produce an episodic film for Universal under the title "Our United Nations," dealing with the United States' Allies in the present war.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- There is nothing in the milk production figures to indicate a shortage, Holton V. Noyes, Commissioner Of Agriculture and Markets, declared today. He said there had been "alarmist reports," and to inform the citizens of the real situation he stated that in the past ten months New York dairymen have produced about 5 per cent more milk than in the same period of 1941.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- An enemy counter-attack in the Tebourba area of Tunisia has been repulsed by Anglo-American forces, tonight's official communique from Allied headquarters in North Africa said, while the Axis claimed success.

Assistant United States Attorney T. Vincent Queens announced in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday that the indictment charging Julius Eichel, 46 years old, a chemist, of 742 Montgomery Street, Brooklyn, with violation of the Selective Service Act, had been nolle prossed.

Besides contributing his services for the concert with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the American Red Cross last Monday, Arturo Toscanini has also presented a signed blank check to make sure that the Red Cross receives $20,000 as a result of the concert, it was learned yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 2 -- Mrs. Olive Avery Peterson and Mrs. Benjamin Golder of Philadelphia and Miss Ruth Sherman and Mrs. Olga Hilliard of New York won the national women's contract bridge team-of-four championship here today as the national bridge tournament entered its second day.

Cold weather accompanied by high winds moved into the New York area yesterday, with every indication of being here to stay awhile. Dropping from a high of 54 degrees at 1 A.M., the temperature was expected by the local Weather Bureau to go down to 12 degrees this morning, with the wind continuing strong.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Coach D.X. Bible may not have planned it that way, but Texas, last year a football powerhouse with a scoring record of 338 points, emerged today as 1942's best defensive aggregation.
The text of a speech made by W.L. Mackenzie King, Prime Minister of Canada, last night follows:

Industrial plants in this city salvaged 61,774,670 pounds of scrap between Oct. 20 and Nov. 20, it was announced yesterday by the Industrial Salvage Committee, of which Rolland J. Hamilton is chairman. This included 41,244,301 pounds of iron and steel, 7,873,365 pounds of non-ferrous metals, 153,046 pounds of rubber and 12,503,958 pounds of other essential materials, bringing the total since the industrial salvage drive started last May to 134,000 tons.

Although no pianos have been produced for the last six months, the industry has decided to continue its full promotional activities for 1943, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the executive committee of the National Piano Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 2 -- When the Constitutional Convention was resumed today, Prime Minister John Curtin announced that the drafting committee appointed Monday had unanimously recommended the adoption of a draft bill for the transfer by the States to the Commonwealth of fourteen specific powers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- A request by the American Telephone Telegraph Company for dismissal or postponement from Dec. 16 to April 1 of the pending inquiry on rate reduction proposals, was denied today by the Federal Communications Commission.

LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Herbert Morrison, Home Secretary and Minister of Home Security, accused Premier Mussolini tonight of "squealing" about the Royal Air Force raids on northern Italy, and an R.A.F. commentator declared that they had caused panic and chaos in northern Italy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The grain markets continued today to show outstanding strength on the Board of Trade. Wheat and corn sold at new high levels in two months or more and old crop number 2 yellow corn sold at 89 1/2 cents a bushel in the cash market, said to be the highest price paid for that grade since 1937.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 2 -- The Navy's newest aircraft carrier, the Belleau Wood, will be launched Sunday, the first of three warships to slide down the ways in the Philadelphia district in observance of the first anniversary of the United States entry into the war.

Asking that all teachers and pupils in the city's school system mark the anniversary of Pearl Harbor, Superintendent John E. Wade yesterday sent a circular to superintendents and principals directing them to halt classroom work for a moment on Monday in honor of the men serving in the armed forces. In his message Dr. Wade said:

In exactly twenty-two days Christmas will be upon you with all its glitter and tinsel, fresh scent of evergreen and heartwarming meetings of old friends. Perhaps this year you find yourself too busy for holiday baking, and so are planning to buy the cakes and cookies and confections you will need.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The War Labor Board set aside for the first time today provisions of a collective bargaining agreement providing an escalator clause relating wage changes to the cost of living.

The era of freedom for which the United Nations are now fighting will be achieved only "as human welfare and social security become the main concern of men and nations," W.L. Mackenzie King, Prime Minister of Canada, said last night.

Theodor Broch, Mayor of Narvik, Norway, who escaped from the Nazi invaders and came to the United States in 1940, was received at City Hall yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, who greeted him as "my courageous and energetic colleague from Norway."

Gasoline stocks throughout the country at the close of last week were 78,854,000 barrels, an increase of 271,000 over the 78,583,000 at the end of the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these supplies amounted to 86,889,000 barrels.

Anthony Cramer, 42-year-old Yorkville mechanic, was sentenced yesterday to serve forty-five years in prison and fined $10,000 as punishment for treason. He escaped sentence of death only because of his hazy notion of the destructive mission of the submarine-borne saboteurs to whom he had given aid.

The concept of a "melting-pot" here has been scrapped through gradual realization of its fallacies, Earl G. Harrison, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, declared last night at a dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt marking the tenth anniversary of the Neue Volkszeitung, German-language weekly described as the oldest anti-Nazi publication in that language in this country.

Washington announces that the "full story" of what happened at Pearl Harbor will be told by the Office of War Information next Sunday. A fuller account than has yet been given to the American people has long been overdue. But the question can be raised, and should be raised, as to the wisdom of saving the story for publication a year later.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 2 -- Air forces of the Middle East Command continued today to support the Allies in Tunisia by bombing airdromes in Tunisia and Sicily. At Bizerte on Monday night bombs fell near the railway junction, on iron stores and on barracks.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 2 -- The little man in Germany has now lost all faith in Adolf Hitler, according to Berlin reports from qualified observers, received here through private channels.

When Green Bay and Pittsburgh clash at Milwaukee on Sunday Cecil Isbell of the Packers will have a fine opportunity to overtake Washington's Slingin' Sammy Baugh in their duel for individual passing honors in the National League.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The American Butter Institute was told today by R.E. Pearsall, its president and vice president of Armour Co., that it is up to the industry to work out some sort of a control plan to meet the shortage of butter developing under a combination of rising war needs and domestic demand.

Oil executives here generally are pleased with the delegation of additional power to Secretary of Interior Harold L. Ickes. For several months many persons in the industry have contended that control over petroleum should be centered in one man for the duration of the war rather than in three or four groups.

An Internation Commercial Arbitration Commission, which will set up rules of procedure and provide the facilities for an international system to assist in the peaceful settlement of economic controversies in the post-war period, was established here yesterday at a conference of representatives of eleven organizations interested in foreign trade.

Many times since women began smoking in department stores I have watched them trying on fluffy dresses or leaning over lingerie or dry goods counters with lighted cigarettes in their hands. I am wondering if the experience at the Cocoanut Grove in Boston doesn't bring before us squarely the issue of what fire hazards we must face and which ones could be eliminated.

For the third consecutive session, the cotton futures market, supported by a moderate amount of mill buying, worked into higher ground yesterday and ended the day with gains of 9 to 15 points, only slightly under the peak prices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Roosevelt made Secretary Ickes Petroleum Administrator for War, replacing the Office of the Petroleum Coordinator for War. He lunched with the Polish Prime Minister and Under-Secretary Welles; his visitors included Lyndon Johnson, William Green, Leon Henderson; he presented posthumous award of the Congressional Medal for Captain Harl Pease Jr. to Captain Pease's parents.

Martin Van Buren, last surviving grandson of the eighth President of the United States, was found dead yesterday in a chair in the lobby of the Murray Hill Hotel, where he had lived alone when in New York for the last twenty-five years.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Admiral Jean Francois Darlan has received the secret approval of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain for his pro-Allied administration of French North Africa, and he hopes to make his post there permanent, United States authorities in Africa told me.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The trial of three corporations and an individual on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in dealings on the Indianapolis Livestock Market ended abruptly last night as a Federal court jury returned a verdict of acquittal after deliberating less than ten minutes.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz imposed prison and penitentiary terms yesterday on four former officials of Local 138 of the Teamsters Union, A.F. of L., in connection with a series of extortions under threat of strike, said by the prosecution to have cost Brooklyn wholesalers and retailers in groceries, furniture, flour and canned goods "many hundreds of thousands of dollars a year."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Pilots of American medium bombers that, with an escort of P-38 fighters, blasted the Tunis airdrome again today, reported at least twelve Axis bombers and transports destroyed on the ground.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Red Army punched more holes in the German lines between Velikiye Luki and Rzhev on the central front yesterday and captured a strategic height southwest of Stalingrad in a continuing joint offensive that left more than 3,800 dead Nazis in its wake, the Russians announced today.
Frieda Hempel's wild dog of the Central Park bush turned out yesterday after its capture by A.S. P.C.A. agents to be pretty much of a pal, after all, although a trifle nervous.

The Amateur Comedy Club will open its fifty-ninth season with the presentation of S.N. Behrman's "Biography" tonight, Friday and Saturday nights at the Heckscher Theatre. By invitation of the United States Military Academy the play will be repeated at West Point Sunday afternoon for the officers, cadets and enlisted personnel.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements for the purchase of the assets of the Santa Rita Oil and Gas Company, operating principally in Montana, for 83,333 shares of its capital stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, is reported alarmed by what he considers the unwarranted wave of optimism about an early end to the war which has risen in recent weeks.

Advertising lineage in eight New York newspapers last month was practically unchanged from that in November of 1941, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. A decline of less than 0.1 per cent was registered.

Vice Admiral Eikichi Katagiri, commander in chief of Japanese Naval Aviation Headquarters, has been dismissed from his post and appointed to the Imperial War Counvil, the Tokyo radio reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Admiral Jean Francois Darlan's proclamation of himself as "Chief of State in French Africa" with an "imperial council" does not in the least affect what President Roosevelt described as the "temporary arrangement" made with him on behalf of the United States by Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander in Chief in French North Africa, it was said in authoritative quarters here tonight.

" Women Can Take It" is the title of show portraying women throughout the ages to be produced by Nat Harrison at the Rivoli Theatre on Jan. 5, to obtain funds for the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy. This will be the first all-woman show to be produced to aid the war and several hundred women prominent in society, the theatrical and literary professions will be in its cast.

A "subscription to beauty" is one of the pleasantest presents that any woman can find in her stocking on Christmas morning. You not only endow her with a vision of loveliness, but also with a clear conscience about indulging in a luxury.

Special services in temples and synagogues and a ten-minute work stoppage at 10 A.M. by 200,000 clothing and fur workers marked yesterday the observance here of a solemn period of mourning and prayer for the millions of Jews slain or threatened with slaughter by Hitler.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Officials of both the Air Ministry and the Ministry of Economic Warfare reported today that recent Royal Air Force raids on Italy, during which more than 1,500 tons of bombs were dropped on the industrial cities of Genoa, Turin and Milan in the brief period since Oct. 22, had caused "immense damage" to Premier Mussolini's war-production machine.

The largest group of naval reservists to be sworn in at one time in the history of the Navy -- a class of 1,085 -- received commissions as ensigns from the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School, quartered at Columbia University, in ceremonies yesterday morning in Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
CAIRO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A United States Army Headquarters communique:

Political differences of nearly 1,000 Frenchmen were forgotten in the interest of unity, at a solemn requiem mass celebrated in the Church of St. Vincent de Paul, West Twenty-third Street, as a memorial to the officers and sailors who died a week ago today at Toulon when the Germans occupied that city.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced today in the House of Commons that the Treasury on Dec. 1 had authorized an increase in Britain's fiduciary note issue for the Bank of England by 70,000,000 ($280,000,000), making a total of 950,000,000.

A century of Christmas cards was commemorated yesterday at a luncheon held by the Greeting Card Industry, a trade group of a hundred manufacturers, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The first Christmas card was etched by the English artist, William Maw Egley, and is now preserved in the British Museum in London.

Canadian Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King yesterday shook hands with five survivors of a torpedoed ship, one of them a Canadian and the others British, and heard them tell their story of the sinking of their ship and release from a French internment camp by Americans.
The Russian campaign of last Winter, which has become clearer with the perspective of time, is probably the best background against which to study the situation in Russia today.

The Nov. 25 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES reported the disconcerting news that the German Gestapo chief, Heinrich Himmler, has ordered the slaying of half of the Jewish population in Poland as a prelude to the eventual slaughter of all the Jews in that country.

The promotion of American composers, conductors and orchestras, and the part they will play in the post-war period formed the general topic discussed at the luncheon given by the New York Federation of Music Clubs in honor of its new president, Mrs. William B. Thomas, yesterday at the Great Northern Hotel.

Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey announced his first appointment yesterday, naming John E. Burton of Garden City to be director of the budget at $12,000 a year. Mr. Burton will succeed J. Buckley Bryan on Jan. 1.

If management and labor continue to hamstring one another legally, they will both wind up in the power of the Legislature, Cyrus S. Ching, employer representative on the War Labor Board, warned yesterday at the opening of the annual meeting of the Society for the Advancement of Management in the Hotel New Yorker.

The problems of wartime food rationing, now echoing through the American cupboard, has helped develop a novel system for the exchange of recipes, dietary suggestions and food economy hints between women employes, wives and mothers on an American war plant and the women of an English establishment devoted to the war.

"Mashenka," the Soviet importation at the Stanley Theatre, will start a third week today. . . . "Ravaged Earth," the feature length factual film about Japanese atrocities in China, has entered its second week at the Gaiety. . . . Revivals of "Lives of a Bengal Lancer" and the French film "Orage," with Charles Boyer and Michele Morgan, will be shown today through Monday at the Park Theatre.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The stock markets were dull again today. Gilt-edge securities eased fractionally and insurance shares were steadier.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Four United States Army sergeants now serving with an engineer unit in North Africa have received a unique honor by being elected honorary members of the oldest petty officers' mess in the British Navy, the staff instructors' mess for gunners' mates in the British Naval Gunnery School, it was learned today.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 -- A year of war production by the automobile industry, which began with little more than blueprints, will end on the anniversary of Pearl Harbor with production records which surprise no one more than the men who have made these changes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- In a letter to Representative Emanuel Celler of New York Secretary Stimson has reaffirmed the War Department's view that there is no authority of law for the commissioning of women students in the medical corps of the Army.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 3 -- Abe Greene, president of the National Boxing Association, tonight flatly disapproved of the action of the New York State Athletic Commission in abandoning plans to authorize a tournament with all the lightweight contenders, including Tippy Larkin, and Beau Jack, participating.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- During the week ended Dec. 2 member bank reserve balances increased $94,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from increases of $377,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $4,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by increases of $200,000,000 in money in circulation, $26,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $4,000,000 in Treasury cash and $59,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

The soldier must be prepared after the war to assume the responsibility of directing the government to think in terms of the future rather than the past, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday in advocating that Army officers lead their men in "discussion groups on what the war is all about."

Roman Catholic churches in the Archdiocese of New York have been ordered by the chancery office to discontinue bingo games not yet advertised, the Rev. John J. Hughes of St. Jerome's Church, 138th Street and Alexander Avenue, the Bronx, disclosed last night at the close of a game at St. Jerome's Parochial School.

A little portrait of a smiling clergyman by Frans Hals, whose paintings of jolly Dutchmen are among the art treasures his country has given the world, bought $30,000 last night at an auction of pictures at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Members of the Board of Estimate have been asked by the Citizens Union, in a letter made public yesterday, to defer action on any pension application filed by former First Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines until after a thorough investigation of the circumstances under which he recently resigned from office.

Dr. Arthur Freeborn Chace, a specialist in internal ailments, was elected president of the New York Academy of Medicine last night, for a term of two years. A consulting physician at several hospitals in the metropolitan area, Dr. Chace also is president of the board of directors of Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital.

Some of those concerned with our way of life outdoors will spend part of the next few months attending conferences and indoor gatherings. What was smilingly called in other years the open season on dinner-meetings is about to start.

The Department of Health disclosed yesterday that it had received 3,727 complaints about insufficient heat in dwellings here last month, twice as many as during November, 1941. At the same time the Office of Price Administration said it was getting forty to fifty complaints a day that rents are being increased in the New York defense area in disregard of Leon Henderson's request that rents here be voluntarily maintained at the levels of last March.

Questionnaires are being sent to manufacturers in the toilet goods industry to determine their reaction to a "self-imposed" rationing plan, it was made known yesterday by H.L. Brooks, president of the Toilet Goods Association.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Harold D. Smith, Director of the Budget, today took the mystery out of OPA's Form 1-1701-Plof-5-Nobu-Cos-Wp, which has puzzled the Senate Economy Committee as it has delved into the whys and wherefores of the multitude of government questionnaires about which some elements of American business are complaining.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- In a surprise move the House revived and passed unanimously today a farm parity price bill which Administration forces successfully opposed last September on the ground that it would add billions of dollars to the cost of living.

In an effort to assist companies which are too busy now with war production to be able to plan for the period following peace, Cecil Presbrey, Inc., have established a post-war planning department, it was announced yesterday. David C. Moss of the investment firm of Moss, Pratt Co., has been appointed to direct this department.

Estimates of life insurance in this country indicate that it will reach $130,000,000,000 by the end of 1942 and cover 67,000,000 persons, half the population, according to a statement by Vincent P. Whitsitt, manager and general counsel of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents, which held its annual business meeting here yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 3 -- The mailing of 2,000,000 allowance and allotment payments to dependants of men in the armed services, representing a total of $150,000,000, is now under way at the Office of Dependancy Benefits here, Colonel Harold N. Gilbert, director of the ODB, announced today.

HARRISBURG, Dec. 3 -- Captain E.H. Van Patten, supply officer in command of the new $40,000,000 naval supply depot at Mechanicsburg, announced tonight that an investigation was being made by proper Federal agencies into "what appears to be financial transactions of a questionable nature" in the construction work.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The important South Rhineland industrial center of Frankfort on the Main was heavily attacked last night by the Bomber Command of the Royal Air Force, along with several other targets in Western Germany.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES ON GUADALCANAL, Nov. 22 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- They bounced thirty bullets off his tin hat and kept him ducking lead punches all night in a shell-hole, but the fighting heart that never quit in the ring stood up to the Japanese on Guadalcanal, and Marine Private Barney Ross emerged winner and still champion.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Navy communique 209:

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Grain futures sagged on the Board of Trade today as recent buyers took profits on purchases made at lower levels. The demand for cash corn, however, continued unabated and this finally caused a sharp upturn in the December delivery, which closed 1/8 cent a bushel higher, while the deferred months were off 3/8 to 7/8 cent.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- An investigation by the State police into complaints from workers employed by construction companies in the erection of a military installation near here that they were being victimized by a "kickback" racket resulted today in the arrest of a foreman and an assistant foreman employed by the Caldwell-Wingate Company.

Production of airplanes that can transport 400 passengers at 500 miles an hour and make non-stop round trips to Europe as bombers was promised by Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation, in an address at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 60 Liberty Street.

Benjamin Levine, 47 years old, who was described in General Sessions by Assistant District Attorney Alexander Dreiband as a "prominent executive" in the garment industry in this country, was sentenced yesterday by Judge John A. Mullen to a one-year penitentiary term.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Characterizing Admiral Jean Francois Darlan's proclamation Tuesday night assuming new powers as "the unilateral inspiration of himself," Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that the British Government did not deem itself bound in any way thereby.

Resolutions condemning the War Labor Board "and other government agencies" for breeding strife by "confusing and extra-legal decisions" were adopted yesterday by the War Congress of American Industry, meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the National Association of Manufacturers.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 3 -Edward G. O'Neill, Assistant Attorney General, today blamed James Bove, vice president of the International Hodcarriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America, in charge of the New York City office, for many of the conditions that existed in its Local 17 of Newburgh, formerly headed by Samuel Nuzzo, now on trial on charges of embezzling union funds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A bipartisan group of the Ways and Means Committee continued hammering today at the third war powers bill, apparently not mollified by its having been pared to what four Administration officials told the committee where the essentials to speed prosecution of the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The War Labor Board rejected today the reasoning of an arbitrator in making a wage increase because of what he termed substandard conditions, but it permitted the increase to go into effect to correct some inequalities.

Prime Minister King's speech at the Pilgrim dinner was worthy of his office and his country. It was clear, dignified, all the more forcible for its restraint. His first theme was Canada's part in the war. We all knew in a way what Canada has done, but it was good to hear in some detail and from the first authority.
The address of Herbert Hoover before the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday follows:

WITH THE ALLIED ARMY IN TUNISIA, Nov. 28 (Delayed) -- Infiltration by parachutists, interruption of communications and bombing and strafing -- stratagems that served the German army well in the campaign of 1940 in France and Flanders -- are failing in Tunisia against an alert American and British soldiery and an aroused populace.
The caliber of football played by college teams in 1942 may not have been as high as usual, but the spectators generally got a run -or a spectacular pass -- for their money.

One thing about the Giant and Dodgers as they prepare for their meeting in Sunday's professional football finale at the Polo Grounds is that both teams have to drill under the same weather conditions. They had to hustle earnestly on frozen fields to keep warm yesterday.

Breaking away from its aimless course at midday following the announcement that the House would pass a resolution, which it subsequently did unanimously, to include labor costs in the method of computing parity for agricultural commodities, the cotton futures market advanced yesterday to score moderate gains in more active trading.
WITH UNITED STATES FORCES IN LIBERIA (Delayed) (AP) -- Napoleon Edward Taylor, 31-year-old Negro private first class, led ashore th6 first American expeditionary force ever to set foot in Africa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Fifty-eight prime contracts with a total value of $21,000,000 have been awarded at the instance of the smaller War Plants Division of the War Production Board since the division began operations, it was announced today.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase of $297,109,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, which were at a record high. Note circulation for the system as a whole was at the highest of the year to date, while ratio of reserve for the system and also for the New York bank were at a low for the year.

The sweeping victory of the liberal pro-United Nations forces in Uruguay's national elections is significant in many respects. The ballots that returned President Baldomir's own Colorado party overwhelmingly crushed at the same time the reactionary Blanco or National party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The methods of desert warfare which are being taught to troops in Southern California will be brought more and more to resemble the conditions prevailing in North Africa, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said today as he discussed the plans of Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, who commands the Army ground forces.
At the annual meeting of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association held yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of Baltusrol was re-elected President for the coming year.

The charge of supressing "freedom of speech" was hurled at the Board of Transportation yesterday by Douglas L. MacMahon, president of the New York local of the Transport Workers Union. C.I.O. It was made after Chairman John H. Delaney refused to permit the display, in subway cars of the city transit system, of a paid advertisement reciting the union's side of its controversy with the board over wages, hours and working conditions.

English and French art treasures of the eighteenth century are to be placed on view on Dec. 19 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services. Included among the objects shown will be furniture that once belonged to Marie Antoinette, to be lent by the Metropolitan Museum, which acquired the pieces last year from the Blumenthal Collection.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 -- Describing domestic transportation as "dangerously close" to the margin of safety, Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, gave a new warning today to industries which had not cooperated in the program to eliminate "unnecessary cross-hauling or other excessive movement" of goods.

The opening clashes have begun in the battle for the triangle between the port of Tunis and the naval base of Bizerte, which Mr. Churchill calls "the tip of Tunisia." Unlike the usual African battleground, this triangle is not desert. The coasts of the granary of ancient Rome, sown now with gardens, olive groves and vineyards, are a verdant reminder that this is the margin of Europe rather than the edge of Africa.

Although a number of civilian volunteer defense workers have been killed throughout the nation and others seriously injured in blackouts, dimouts and rehearsals for air raids, the legal responsibility for the cost of such injuries, or compensation to families reduced by such deaths, still remains unattached to local, State or Federal governments.

TRENTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Charles R. Erdman Jr., director of the State Municipal Aid Administration, said today that many New Jersey industries have preferred to hire inexperienced women to employable men who are on the State's relief rolls.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiary companies had a net profit of $8,554,512 from operations in the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, after provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes of $8,250,000, according to the report of Harry M. Warner, president, issued for release today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
ALBANY, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The State Conservation Department comes to the aid of Santa Claus this season by making available 20,000 Christmas trees, three times last year's total.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Jungle-toughened Australian and American troops had divided the Japanese on the north shore of New Guinea into two contracting pockets around Buna and Gona today and fought so close to the enemy lines they could hear the curses of the dying Japanese.

The New York State Athletic Commission decided yesterday to revise its plans for seeking a successor to Sammy Angott, Washington, Pa., boxer, who recently surrendered the lightweight championship of the world because of bad hands.

In view of the fact that THE TIMES survey showed the great majority of our colleges have ceased to offer entrance examinations in American history and that in an even larger proportion students need not take any American history in college, it seems pertinent to note the following observation by Edgar Eisenhower on the youthful predilections of his distinguished brother.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Aiming to lighten the demands on "diminishing" civilian doctors and eliminate "dangerous or useless first-aid practices," at the scene of an air raid, James M. Landis, Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, urged today a reorganization of the Emergency Medical Service, patterned on lessons learned under fire in England.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 3 -An official statement issued today from Vichy shows how active the police were in November and at the same time reveals how active was the opposition.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The problem of assuring a steady flow of vital food supplies to more than 100,000 inmates in New York State hospitals, mental institutions and prisons is becoming increasingly difficult.
AT ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 3 (AP) -A communique:

The Greyhound Corporation reports a consolidated net income of $6,811,585 for the first nine months of 1942 after all charges and taxes, equal after preferred dividends to $2.39 a share on 2,792,075 common shares, compared with $5,418,640, or $1.89 a share, earned in nine months of the previous year.

It is the avowed purpose of the present nation-wide $9,000,000,000 Victory Loan Drive to raise as much money as possible outside the commercial banks and thus reduce the hazards of inflation. Figures released yesterday covering sales of the new securities in the New York Federal Reserve District indicate that better than 60 per cent of the subscriptions has been made by others than commercial banks.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission referred today to the Justice Department, "for prosecution," information on the asserted failure of M.S. Vencedor, Inc., of New York City, to file rate schedules for freight transportation between eastern seaboard ports and Puerto Rico.

JUST recently there was some comment in this corner on the rivalry among the branches of our armed forces. This rivalry always has existed and is a healthy Stimulant to added effort in the field. But in the war now going on, the feats of the "Commando" units, British, Canadian, Australian or whatever they might have been, added fuel to the hot flames of debate that run through military circles.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Only 1,000,000 to 1,250,000 Jews are still alive in Poland of the 3,500,000 before the German occupation, according to a report received in London from secret Jewish labor groups.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Japanese warships tried again Monday night and early Tuesday morning (Solomons time) to fight their way to Guadalcanal Island with troop transports and again the United States Navy smashed the attempt, sinking nine enemy vessels and sending to their deaths an estimated 4,000 to 5,000 Japanese troops.

While material shortages continue to be an important problem, the stove industry concentration program, chaotic for the first few months of its existence, is beginning to work more satisfactorily, manufacturers reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- President Roosevelt in messages to Congress requested enactment of legislation to permit continued United States participation in inter-American organizations and conferred with the A.F.L.C.I.O. labor war board.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 3 -- Harry J. Fishbein and Miss Ruth Sherman of New York won the national contract bridge mixed pair championship today in the third day of the tournament here.

A one-day exhibit of attractive and lasting Christmas toys made out of waste material, such as ice cream containers, discarded powder boxes, butter tubs and corrugated cardboard, was held yesterday at the Child Education Foundation, 535 East Eighty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The European war in its various aspects was discussed at a luncheon given at the White House today by President Roosevelt in honor of General Wladislaw Sikorski, Premier of Poland, who is here on an official visit.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's planes, which on Wednesday scored a big aerial triumph by downing twenty-three Japanese Zeros over Northeast New Guinea, have destroyed or damaged twenty,one more Japanese planes in a raid on Kupang at the southwest tip of Portuguese Timor, the High Command announced today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's noon communique:

Since quite clearly the world now is engaged upon a final war between the men and the robots, it has occurred to the Messrs. Silberman and Blank to revive the late Karel Capek's "R.U.R." This is the social satire in melodramatic form which gave to the English language the word robot.

Eighty-six athletic insignia have been awarded to members of two Columbia varsity and three freshman teams, Dr. Edward S. Elliott, director of athletics, announced yesterday. Thirty men, twenty-one in football and nine in cross-country, received major letters.

MONTREAL, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Canadiens scored twice in the final period to turn back Toronto, 4 -- 2, in a National League hockey game tonight after the Maple Leafs had rallied to tie the count late in the second session.

MIAMI, Dec. 3 -- Cautious Ben Loving of Springfield, Mass., snipped four strokes from par with a 66 today to take a one-stroke lead in the first round of the Miami open golf tournament. The field was only half its normal size.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- The Germans lost last night more high ground without which they will be forced to fight on the flat steppe in the Stalingrad sector. Faced with this danger, they are digging in and clinging desperately to every position favorable to defense.

Two Navy firemen, who were on board the United States transport Joseph Hewes as members of the crew, told yesterday how that ship and four others, the sinking of which in the North African campaign was announced yesterday, had gone down.

Although bank clearings at the twenty-three leading cities of the country covered last week only five days because of the Thanksgiving Day holiday, the volume was 5.7 per cent larger than the preceding full week and 6.7 per cent above the corresponding six-day week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Suppliers of textiles and other essentials of the character currently being bought for immediate shipment to French North Africa by lend-lease procurement official should communicate in writing with the International Division, Office of the Quartermaster General, War Department, Washington.

GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 3 -Mrs. Irene Shafer, 55, will halt her housework and war work tomorrow for a trip to the Great Lakes Naval Station, where she will prepare a report for other Navy mothers on the country's largest school for sailors.

A physical fitness and war sports program designed to build up the health of employes in New York war production plants has been arranged by the Greater New York C.I.O. under a plan worked out among the State War Council, the Board of Education and the C.I.O., it was announced yesterday.

The resurrected recovery drive in the stock market pushed forward yesterday with more vigor, although the appearance of some resistance in the afternoon restricted the advance of prices. Traders placed greater emphasis on the out-and-out war issues, and brokers interpreted this as indicating a revision of the idea of an early victory.
