The $25,000 a year limit on salaries is communistic in its inception and the government suit against The Associated Press is not a suit to stop monopoly, but aims at stifling the freedom of speech, Colonel Roane Waring, national commander of the American Legion, declared yesterday in an address before New York newspapers and press service executives at a luncheon in the Hotel Lexington sponsored by the Legion.

Ralph Parker writes to THE TIMES about one of the many regained villages on the Russian front. This one has a common grave in the park, in which are buried soldier and civilian victims of the Nazi terror. It has a temporary monument on which are listed the names of the dead and the items of damage done to property -- a total of 75,000,000 rubles.

Former President Herbert Hoover, who headed the American Relief Administration of World War I, yesterday urged former Governor Herbert Lehman, who has received a similar assignment in this war, to undertake immediately the task of providing food to civilian populations of the occupied democracies of Europe, particularly Belgium, Holland, Norway and Poland, and to amplify the relief program now in effect for Greece.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Liberia disclosed officially today that a task force of American soldiers had been built up on her soil with her full agreement and that the African republic had decided on "a policy of full collaboration with the United Nations during the existing hostilities."

Berkshire Industrial Farm, a year-round home and school for problem boys, will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Without Love," Philip Barry's new comedy, with Katharine Hepburn and Elliott Nugent in the leading roles, tonight at the St. James, Theatre.

Meat is becoming increasingly scarce, according to a spokesman for the Consumers' Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets. The most successful way to buy it is to decide what you want only after inspecting your butcher's supplies.
LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Mrs. Tuckerman Draper gave a dinner last night in the Cottage of Hampshire House before the meeting of the Thursday Evening Club, which was held at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William Church Osborn, 40 East Thirty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Axis submarines sank five United States Navy transports during the occupation of North Africa by American forces early last month and damaged five other of this courtry's craft, the Navy Department revealed today.

Effects of the $9,000,000,000 Victory Loan Drive which began on Monday found full reflection in the weekly Federal Reserve figures, as of Wednesday, released for publication this morning. It is disclosed that, to help the open market for Federal bonds, the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System purchased $297,109,000 of United States Government securities, largest purchases in any week since that ended on Oct. 21, when member banks were losing excess reserves rapidly.

Following hard on the heels of Arturo Toscanini and Serge Koussevitzky, Artur Rodzinski tried his hand at the controversial Seventh symphony of Shostakovich at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The United States has entered into a defense agreement with Liberia that is calculated to give this country military control in the African republic for the duration of the war and so safeguard a region that could be used by the Axis for operations in the Atlantic or against Dakar and other strategic points on the West African coast.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 3 -- Racing was conducted here today on a frozen track with a cut cushion and the sport proved uneventful. The horses made excellent time over the hard surface. Some 1,500 fans crowded the fires in the clubhouse and under the grandstand.

TOLEDO, Dec. 3 -- Declaring that a serious teacher shortage now faces this country, educators attending the American Vocational Association Convention reported that 20,000 vocational teachers had left their classes and had not been replaced, depriving 1,000,000 boys and girls of essential vocational training.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The power of the Industrial Commissioner under the Minimum Wage Law to fix minimum wage standards in industries employing women and minors was upheld in a 4 to 3 decision by the Court of Appeals today.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Nov. 24 (Delayed) -- Brig. Gen. Hanford MacNider, former Assistant Secretary of War, received eight wounds in the explosion of a Japanese rifle grenade last night during the American attack on Buna, enemy strongpoint on the northeastern New Guinea coast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Prices for certain farm commodities and their products, particularly grains, cereal products and fruits and vegetables, continued to rise last week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. However, markets for other commodities have become fairly well stabilized under government regulation, and the bureau's index of nearly 900 price series has remained unchanged for three consecutive weeks at 100.1 per cent of the 1926 average.

The National Association of Insurance Commissioners has approved the report on "filling the gaps" between losses insured by the Federal War Damage Corporation and those insured by the insurance industry, it was learned yesterday.

Following is the war program of American industry adopted at yesterday's session of the War Congress of American Industry, under the auspices of the National Association of Manufacturers, in the Waldorf-Astoria:

Despite the 55-to-12 upset by Holy Cross in its final game, Boston College has been voted the football championship of the East and a leg on the Lambert Trophy, it was announced yesterday. The Eagles received forty-six votes of the fifty-eight cast by leading sports writers and radio commentators.

As one who has devoted the last four decades to the propagation of the idea of a Danubian federation I feel it as a duty to express my deep concern about the plan of a Habsburg restoration, even if such a measure should be restricted to Austria or Hungary, or both.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson's advancing British First Army in Tunisia made up of veterans of Dunkerque, and Americans eager for battle, has beaten back another heavy enemy counter-attack in the neighborhood of Tebourba that was intended to halt it in its tracks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Republican leaders, heartened by large gains in Congress in the November elections, are expected to avoid an intraparty row over selection of a new national chairman when the national committee meets in St. Louis Monday to accept the resignation of Representative Martin of Massachusetts.

Eddie Dowling reports that Lucille Prumbs's new comedy, "I Take the High Road," will be his next Broadway offering and not William Saroyan's "Get Away, Old Man," as the producer had previously announced. The switch was brought about by the topical nature of Miss Prumbs's script, Mr. Dowling explained.

Bruno Walter conducted Mozart's "Don Giovanni" for the first time in the Metropolitan Opera House last night and the results were immediate. They were proclaimed with the first crashing chords of the one of his operatic overtures in which Mozart directly forecasts what is to come in the drama that follows.

Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, bluntly told a group of 400 railroad executives at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Hotel Astor yesterday that the railroads must stop their current practice of discrimination against women and Negroes in their hiring of workers because "their men will continue to be withdrawn for the armed services."

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- The story was told here today of how Russian engineers built an invisible bridge secretly within 150 yards of German sentries, enabling tanks to cross a river on the Central Front and open an offensive where the enemy least expected it.

Representatives and executives of Y.W.C.A. branches of seventeen large cities yesterday unanimously went on record urging local Y.W.C.A. branches as well as the organization's national board "to make every effort to have employment opportunities opened to Negro women as they now are open to white women."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales last week were 2 per cent lower than during the corresponding week a year ago. In the preceding week such sales were 30 per cent greater than in a similar period in 1941.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The Court of Appeals decided today that money allowances for subsistence and quarters furnished to persons in the armed services does not constitute part of the compensation paid for military duty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Because of the seriousness of the fuel oil shortage in the Eastern States, the War Production Board today cleared the way for stove manufacturers to use iron and steel without restriction for the manufacture of heating stoves to replace fuel oil heating equipment.

The conversion of many plants that formerly manufactured housing supplies and the exhaustion of existing dealers' stocks is causing difficulties in the Federal Public Housing Authority program, Herbert Emmerich, commissioner, said yesterday.

Rehabilitation and prevention, rather than punishment, are the answer to the rising number of cases of juvenile delinquency in so-called problem areas of New York's school system, Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, Queens member of the Board of Education, said yesterday.

The producer and two of his aides in the presentation of the show "Wine, Women and Song" were found guilty yesterday afternoon by a General Sessions jury of five women and seven men of permitting an indecent performance in the Ambassador Theatre, on West Forty-ninth Street, on the night of Oct. 31.

Several hundred men in the uniforms of all the branches of our armed forces and leaders in war production and civilian life, joined here last night in paying tribute to two "old fashioned college professors" who are scheduled to retire in the Spring from Union College, Schenectady, N.Y., when they both reach the age of 70.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Four Axis cargo vessels, carrying vital supplies to Tunisia, and three enemy destroyers forming part of their escort were destroyed Tuesday night in "a spirited engagement" with British surface craft, according to an announcement today by the British Admiralty.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- "The British colonial empire is not coming to an end; the work we have to do is only beginning." Viscount Cranborne told the House of Lords today in response to a request for a statement on colonial policy in the light of the Atlantic Charter.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Andy Ponzi of Philadelphia, in second place, pulled closer to the tournament leader, Willie Mosconi, tonight by defeating the veteran Ralph Greenleaf of New York, 125 to 74, in eleven innings in the world pocket billiard championship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The clash between the military services and the WPB over the production of airplanes and ordnance has "been settled amicably," Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said at a press conference today, adding: "But I won't discuss it."

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, announced yesterday in his capacity as chairman of the New York Victory Fund Committee that total sales in the New York Federal Reserve District in the nation-wide $9,000,000,000 Victory Loan Drive that started on Monday amounted to $2,507,900,000 as of noon yesterday.

Benjamin Heffner, assistant attorney general in charge of the anti-trust division of the State Law Department, resigned that position yesterday, effective Dec. 15, to enter private law practice at 270 Broadway. Mr. Heffner had been an assistant to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for nine years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Caging two shots in a twelve-second interval in the first period, the Black Hawks tonight defeated the Rangers, 3 to 1, before a crowd of 6,730 and for the third time this season hopped into a tie with Detroit for the National Hockey League lead.

Sentences of fifty years to life in Sing Sing Prison were imposed yesterday by Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato on Neil Simonelli, 16 years old, and Joseph Annunziata, 19, the "zoot suit" youths convicted of second-degree murder in the slaying of Irwin Goodman, 36-year-old mathematics teacher, in William J. Gaynor High School in Brooklyn on Oct. 2.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- First Lord of the Admiralty A.V. Alexander thrilled the House of Commons today with the most complete report yet made on the part the Royal Navy played in the North Africa landing, "the greatest combined operation ever undertaken." His balance of Allied losses, not including merchantmen, and of successes scored against the enemy at last brings into a true light the extravagant claims made by Berlin.

The progress of this war has proved what had been suspected before, that Americans are a mercurial people. It is our nature to be optimistic most of the time. Like most optimists, we sometimes wake up in the morning with a feeling that nothing is worth while and all is lost.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 3 -- The government published today a decree, dated yesterday, setting up under the Director General of Posts and Telegraph strict control over all cable, wireless and telephone communications between Argentina and foreign countries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 3 -RKO today announced the purchase of "Higher and Higher," Richard Rodgers-Lorenz Hart musical comedy of the 1939-40 Broadway season, and assigned Tim Whelan to produce and direct the screen version.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Legislation to authorize the transfer of lands in Panama to the Panamanian Government and carry out other provisions of an agreement negotiated by the State Department was attacked in the Senate today, largely by members formerly identified with the isolationist and noninterventionist groups, who charged that the Administration was "by-passing" the Senate's function of ratifying treaties.

The American people must be prepared for more controls and restrictions, "more czars, more red tape and rationing" in 1943, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, told 4,000 industrialists at the War Congress of American Industry, held under the auspices of the National Association of Manufacturers, in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, yesterday.

A warning that the Japanese must be hit with full force before they have had an opportunity to consolidate the gains in materials and manpower since Pearl Harbor was voiced last night by Dr. Wei Tao-ming, the new Chinese Ambassador to the United States.

It is rarely that every dress shown in a collection gets applause. That is exactly what happened yesterday noon in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel when the Zoe de Salle collection of Christmas holiday and advanced Spring costumes was presented.

A promissory note for $60,000, payable "on demand" to Irwin Steingut, leader of the Democratic minority in the State Assembly, and given on June 29, 1939, by the late Max Kalik, bookmaker, was revealed yesterday in papers on file before Surrogate James A. Foley in an accounting proceeding in the Kalik estate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- By Nov. 1, last, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and its subsidiaries had financed or contracted to finance the construction, equipment or expansion of 1,337 plants for the production or fabrication of ships, bombing, fighting, transport and cargo planes; tanks, heavy guns, ordnance, magnesium, aluminum, steel, tin, copper and other metals; synthetic rubber, high octane aviation gasoline, machine tools, flying schools, pipelines and other products.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Unanimous approval was given by the Senate for a formal investigation into the necessity for the multitude of questionnaires and other report forms with which government departments and agencies are deluging business and individuals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he was considering shifting the Selective Service Administration to the War Manpower Commission and continuing Paul V. McNutt as chairman of the commission.

There is general agreement among informed persons that this country will face shortages in many items of food. Some of these shortages are already known by housewives, better known by their grocers, and still better known by the food processors and distributors, who can see further ahead.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- Governor Poletti had a heavy schedule on his first full day of office today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 3 -Fordham's basketball team ushered in its schedule tonight by vanquishing St. Peter's College, 54 to 29. The Rams assumed an early lead and were in front at half-time, 26 to 17.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Major league baseball's club owners today concluded their "momentous wartime conclave" with a joint session that seemed to have only two distinguishing features. One was its brevity; it lasted barely an hour and forty minutes.

ALLIED FORCE HEADQUARTERS in North Africa, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Allied tank forces prepared for another smash at strong German positions twelve miles west of Tunis today after a forty-eight-hour battle that resulted in "about equal losses on both sides."

All's quiet on the flower front. A post-Thanksgiving and pre-Christmas lull pervades the market. The let-down that normally follows a holiday rush is reported by the New York State Department of Markets.

OTTAWA, Dec. 3 -- Two Americans, Captain R.L. Rizon of Montrovia, Calif., and Regimental Sergeant Major Rosario Levesque of New Bedford, Mass., were among sixty-eight service men decorated this afternoon by the Governor General, the Earl of Athlone. Some of the crosses and medals were given to the relatives of men who had been killed or died on active service.

Changes that have taken place in the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company since its last report to the New York Stock Exchange, including acquisition through subsidiaries of a possible oil field in the State of Washington and the election of Serge Rubinstein as chairman of the board, are covered in an amendment to its listing statement, made public yesterday.

MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 4 -- Russian shock troops broke through a strong German line and captured a railroad station behind it on the central front west of Rzhev yesterday, and a powerful base covering the Axis flank in South Stalingrad fell to the advancing Red Army.

John E. Doyle, chief engineer of the tug Brittania of the Dalzell Towing Company was drowned yesterday after a Norwegian motor ship had rammed his vessel in the bay off Rosebank, S.I., The tug was beached at the foot of Clifton Avenue after the collision and last night only her pilot house remained above water.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 3 -- The supply situation for Nazi General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Africa Corps had deteriorated further as reports today indicated that Allied Middle East air attacks had heavily damaged the remaining Axis Libyan port of Tripoli.

This habit of Prime Ministers and heads of state quoting poetry is spreading. Night before last Prime Minister Mackenzie King did it at the Pilgrims dinner here in town. His quatrain about freedom this department will not attempt to place.

Within the last three weeks $53,653,000 in government orders and subcontracts have been awarded to small New York concerns manufacturing durable and essential consumer goods, George A. Sloan. chairman of the Mayor's Business Advisory Committee, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Dwellers in "target area" cities were told today by the Office of Civilian Defense how to use and care for their stirrup pumps, but James M. Landis, director, emphasized that the new instructions did no explain "especial techniques" for fighting the new-type delayed-action incendiary bombs, about which Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh of New York City recently sounded a warning.

Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel reserved decision yesterday on a motion by Park Commissioner Robert Moses to dismiss the suit brought by Pierce Trowbridge Wetter, treasurer of the Greenwich Village Historical Society, to restrain Mr. Moses from demolishing the old Aquarium building in Battery Park, which was originally Fort Clinton.

When an X-ray picture had to be made in the home twenty years ago a motor truck would rumble to the door and mechanics would unload ponderous apparatus and set it up at the bedside. Since the house current could not be used, the X-ray machinery had to be connected by cables with special generators and transformers on the truck.

MONROVIA, Liberia (Delayed) (AP) -- In the first interview granted to any newspaper man in nine years, Edwin Barclay, President of this Negro republic, has outlined Liberia's wartime status as a benevolent neutral.

Oxford University Press has added to its lists "The Book: The Story of Printing and Bookmaking," by Douglas McMurtrie. A new edition, the seventh, will be issued in January. It was in 1927 that Covici-Friede published MR. McMurtrie's "The Golden Book," which went through four editions.

Governor Harold Stassen of Minnesota said last night that the payment of overtime for work beyond forty hours a week should be modified in order to increase production during the war by "definite, positive arrangements for longer hours of work" rather than by the "blunt, thoughtless repeal of the forty-hour law."

Parental inconsistencies in dealing with the adolescent's problems were assigned equal responsibility with the shifting attitudes of the child himself by the members of the forum held last night on the adolescent child at the New York Times Hall, 244 West Forty-fourth Street.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Women "MP's" made their appearance here today as the new Waac training center put its own military police into the field.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- A feature of today's stock markets was a rise in the South American rails which was influenced by the payment of 1 1/2 per cent arrears on the Central Argentine 4 per cent debentures. Ordinaries were 1/2 to 3/4 better and prior charges rose to 2 1/4 points.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Large formations of Spitfires carried out a series of day-long keeps over the English Channel and Northern France today, the activity continuing until dusk.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- A serious rift in British-American relations may develop from the censorship policy such as is now operating in the Darlan dispute, it was said this morning by The Manchester Guardian in an article warning the peoples on both sides of the Atlantic that newspaper correspondents did not have a chance to tell the whole truth.

Declaring that while American industry and labor have achieved an enormous task in war production during the last year, President Roosevelt pointed out in a message read at the dinner of the Congress of American Industry at the Waldorf-Astoria last night that the full objectives of production had not been attained, and urged that there be "no relaxation on the part of the manufacturers of the country as long as any hostile force confronts us."

While the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York yesterday announced its readiness to cooperate with Mayor La Guardia in his crusade against bingo, spokesmen for the Diocese of Brooklyn were not reached for an expression of their attitude.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada arrived at the White House today and will remain through the week-end for conversations with President Roosevelt on the war and the post-war world. The conversations were begun immediately.
I think that the Heisman Memorial committee erred in selecting Frank Sinkwich as the recipient of its coveted award which goes annually to the foremost football player in the nation.

HARRISBURG, Dec. 4 -- Commissioner Friedman said tonight that he had refused to amplify his charges of corruption in the construction of the Mechanicsburg naval supply depot for a personal emissary of Secretary Knox because of threats leveled at him by Attorney General Biddle.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Warships so new they still are on the "secret list" were reported today to have joined Britain's Mediterranean Fleet as the toll of Axis shipping sunk by Allied sea and air battles rose to six Tunisia-bound supply vessels, three destroyers and a torpedo boat, all apparently sunk within a 24-hour span.

Ralph A. Sturges was re-elected president of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York at its annual meeting yesterday in Fraunces Tavern, Broad and Pearl Streets, the headquarters of the society.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The meeting of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues became heated today when some of the minor circuit clubs that do not expect to be able to operate next year tried to effect a split of the organization's reserve fund of more than $250,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Work Projects Administration was ordered abolished today in the face of rising war employment.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The Council of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers adopted a resolution yesterday at the closing sessions of the society's annual meeting in the Hotel Astor calling for the deferment of students in accredited engineering schools to assure an adequate supply of engineers for the armed forces and the war industries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that gross revenues of 796 rural electric systems financed by the Rural Electrification Administration have reached a record high rate of more than $50,000,000 a year.

Competition must be regulated further in order to facilitate the elimination of the so-called "frills" in retailing, but care should be taken that no rules are issued which do more harm than good, Oswald W. Knauth, president of Associated Dry Goods Corporation, declared yesterday at the annual conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management in the Hotel New Yorker.

Disbarment proceedings against State Senator Joseph A. Esquirol of Brooklyn, who on Dec. 31 will relinquish his office to his Democratic successor, were started yesterday in the Brooklyn Municipal Building before Leander B. Faber, official referee.
The laundries are cleaning up. More people with more money are sending out their wash.

As the basis of a book called "Happy Landings," out Monday under the Houghton Mifflin imprint, is the premise that there is something about flying "that makes men write better than they know how." Three editors, convinced of this, have put together an anthology of stories and articles on flying, under such headings as "How It Feels to Fly," "Airmen at War," "High Adventure" and "Learning to Be a Pilot."

Alvin Allen, 12 years old, who was tried yesterday in Children's Court as a juvenile delinquent, was placed on probation for throwing a rock at a teacher. Arrangements also were begun to have the boy transferred to another school.

The Rev. Harold C. DeWindt, for the last five years pastor of the Webb Horton Memorial Presbyterian Church, Middletown, N.Y., will begin his duties on New Year's Day as pastor of the West Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 4 -- It is now established that near the Agheila line in Libya there is still little army activity. Lately, fairly large numbers of enemy bombers and fighters have been attacking the forward forces of the British Eighth Army, but they have met strong ground fire and often have been intercepted by Allied fighters.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 4 -- Pope Pius will not leave Rome if the British carry out their threat to include it in their "systematic bombardment of Italian towns," but will move to the Basilica of St. John Lateran in the center of the city, according to a report received here tonight.

Contributions to the United Hospital Campaign for $1,383,729 in behalf of seventy-six voluntary, non-profit hospitals in this city yesterday totaled $1,105,722. Among the large gifts announced at the headquarters of the fund, 370 Lexington Avenue, were $50,000 from the George F. Baker Charity Trust, $5,000 from Mrs. John M. Schiff, $2,000 from Mrs. L. Victor Weil, an additional $1,000 from Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse and anonymous contributions of $5,325 and $1,000.

With an attendance exceeding that of the previous show in 1940, the fifteenth National Exposition of Power and Mechanical Engineering closed last night after a five- day run at Madison Square Garden. Exhibitors expressed themselves as fully satisfied with results.

Late night service on all lines of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company will be eliminated under revised schedules becoming effective on Monday, John E. McCarthy, president of the company, announced yesterday. The new schedules will reduce bus mileage 15 per cent, in accordance with the orders of the Office of Defense Transportation.

Dividend declarations announced yesterday by two companies will increase their payments for 1942 over the amounts received by stockholders last year. South West Pennsylvania Pipe Lines authorized a dividend of $3 for payment on Dec. 26.
COACH LOU LITTLE of Columbia and Coach Herb Kopf of Manhattan, football cronies from away back, were sitting around talking about the game and making lateral passes at each other in sportive vein.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMORED FORCE IN DJEDEIDA SECTOR, Tunisia, Dec. (Delayed) -- The first gun slammed five minutes after we left our headquarters en route to the rear sector. There was a familiar whine of shells overhead, then off to the left the dull thud of their burst.

Four triple-threat backs and seven fast, hard-charging linemen were selected by sports editors and writers from all over the country for the 1942 United Press All-America football team, announced yesterday.

The United States is producing combat armaments in as great a volume as all the Axis powers combined, while the output in weapons of war by the United Nations already is twice that of their enemies. Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chief, disclosed last night in a report covering the last year's achievements on the production front.

DETROIT, Dec. 4 -- The automobile industry is producing today war material at a rate far greater, as measured in employment and dollar volume, than its peak rate in the top years of motor car production.

J. Augustus Keogh, 58 years old, of 280 West Twelfth Street, director of the Irish Repertory Players of New York, was killed Monday in an automobile accident at Walnut Ridge, Ark., according to word received here yesterday, Mr. Keogh was a member of a USO mit that had been presenting "The Male Animal" at an Army camp in the vicinity of the accident.
The Police Anchor Club yesterday dedicated its regular First Friday (of the month) mass and communion service to the men of the armed forces who have died in this war.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 4 -- Survivors of an Allied merchantman brought here from an island farther south, where they had landed after the torpedoing of their vessel, disclosed that the captain and the chief engineer of the ship had been taken aboard an Axis submarine as prisoners, but the captain's wife, who pleaded that she be taken with her husband, was left in a lifeboat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Declaring that the Nazi anti-Jewish policy sought "to exterminate a whole people," sixty-three Senators and 181 Representatives sent to President Roosevelt today a joint declaration expressing their support of this country's "declared and traditional policy" favoring restoration of a Jewish national homeland in Palestine.

In his speech of Dec. 2, before the Chamber of Fasces and Corporations, Mussolini, in his effort to contradict Prime Minister Churchill's statements concerning British-Italian friendship, deceived his countrymen when he declared that the "English-speaking peoples have never had tender sentiments toward Italy."
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters and R.A.F. communique:

The Board of Estimate adopted yesterday a capital outlay budget for 1943 totaling $34,748,532. Of this sum $222,325 has already been appropriated by the board since it received from the City Planning Commission the original proposed budget of $37,769,570 and from which it cut about $3,000,000.

WITH ALLIED FORCES ON DJEDEIDA FRONT, Tunisia, Nov. 30 (Delayed) -- Yesterday was a day of fighting -- fighting as bloody as any this war-scarred country has yet seen. Its heroes were the officers and men of a battalion of a Midland regiment, who battled their way onto a ridge commanding Djedeida, and despite severe casualties, held it until driven off by six dive-bombing attacks and concentrated enemy mortar and machine-gun fire.
Why wouldn't this be a good time to replace our badly muddled State Athletic Commission's boxing rules with the comprehensive, sportsmanlike "Teddy Roosevelt Boxing Rules by James J. Corbett"?
GUADALCANAL, Nov. 10 (Delayed) -- From the press tent near Henderson Airfield the sound of firing on the western front was only a distant rumble.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Mary E. Whitney's Ilefetchit, under a strong ride by Jockey Danny Scocca, won the best offering on the Charles Town program today. The son of Stepinfetchit and Avila came under the wire a half length in front of the Presgrave Brothers' Royal Fleet and another length in advance of N.E. Brice's Linden Girl.

Two Japanese organizations for school girls employing certain Girl Scout practices, but toward entirely different ends, were described here yesterday by Miss Clara Eastlake, American writer who was born in Japan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Here is the roll-call by which the Senate passed a joint resolution authorizing the transfer to Panama of certain United States property:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Facing a fuel oil supply situation so critical that the deputy oil administrator, Ralph K. Davies, predicted today that some New Englanders might freeze to death this Winter if the problem was not solved, the Office of Price Administration is at work on plans for compelling wholesale conversions of furnaces from fuel oil to coal.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, Inc., appropriated $7,250,000 for relief, emigration aid, educational and reconstructive assistance to 795,000 people abroad during 1942, James H. Becker, chairman of the organization's national council, declared at the twenty-eighth annual meeting yesterday in its offices, 100 East Forty-second Street.

Your assertion that the British resisted the Blitz because they knew that the alternative was servitude is, of course, correct, but you have not attempted to explain whence a whole population drew the sheer physical, and above all the nervous, strength necessary to withstand such an ordeal.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 4 -- Middle East war planes have accounted for nearly half of the Axis merchantmen reported sunk during convoy battles in the central Mediterranean this week. The latest victims of air attack, two Axis vessels caught on Wednesday off Eastern Tunisia, brought the Allied air forces' score to three ships sunk and one probably sunk.

One year ago today, though we little realized it at the time, we were on the eve of the greatest naval disaster in our history -- and of the beginning of American participation in a war which will decide the life or death of democratic government. There was a brief calm before the storm.

Frederick (Big Freddie) Bertolotti, 37 years old, the ex-convict who was said in court to have amassed $100,000 in recent years as a combination handbook operator, usurer and "fence" for robbers at his stamping ground in front of the Manhattan entrance to the Queensboro Bridge, was sentenced as a loan shark yesterday in Special Sessions to a one-year term in penitentiary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Overriding charges by a minority that the executive branch of the government was attempting to usurp treaty-making powers, the Senate passed today by 40 to 29 the joint resolution authorizing transfer of United States-owned lands and facilities in Panama to the Panamanian Government under agreements negotiated by the State Department.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 5 -- The Red Army seized ten more villages in the Stalingrad area yesterday, presumably in the zone between the Volga and the Don Rivers west of that city; surrounded a German stronghold near Velikiye Luki on the frozen central front and killed more than 2,500 Nazis in twin offensives that still are gaining ground, the Soviets announced early today.

John Woolcott Forbes and Alfred Ernest Dawson, who are wanted in Australia and Canada, respectively, on criminal charges, were faced in Federal court here yesterday with charges that if proved are likely to keep them detained in this country for a long time.

At last the Boston College balloon has been deflated, and by a team that won only five of nine games played. The Eagles would have been better off if they had ended their season the Saturday before the game with Holy Cross.

The Canadian Wartime Prices and Trade Board has sent a questionnaire to all newspapers and magazines in the Dominion requesting information on their use of paper preparatory to control of consumption through establishment of quotas for each publication, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 4 -- With the aid of several French farmers, their sons and daughters and a German vocabulary consisting of a nursery rhyme and "Ja jawohl," two Royal Air Force officers who were shot down in Tunisia spent eight days in German-occupied territory and escaped.

A suit to restrain the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation from carrying out its plan for sale of its interest in the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, and for distribution of its other assets, was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday in connection with a motion to dismiss the suit on the ground that the court has no jurisdiction and that the plan has been approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SYRACUSE, Saturday, Dec. 5 -- The contract bridge team-of-four championship was won early today by the Philadelphia team comprising Charles H. Goren, John Crawford and Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia and G. Jay Becker of New York.
MOSCOW, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's noon communique:

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $353,137,066 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on Nov. 30 was $25.41, compared with $25.65 at the end of October, a decline of 24 cents.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Assemblyman David Young 3d of Morris County answered today before Supreme Court Commissioner Nicholas W. Bindseil here questions which he had refused to answer previously in hearings concerning his part in a suit against the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation.

Fred Baker of Seattle, National Committeeman from Washington, has been put forward as a compromise candidate for election as chairman of the Republican National Committee at the meeting in St. Louis on Monday, it was learned yesterday.

TRENTON, Dec. 4 -- The New Jersey Civil Service Commission declared categorically today that public employes had no right to strike in upholding Newark's dismissal of fifteen employes of its Garbage Department and the suspension of fifty others who participated in a six-day work stoppage early this Fall.

The approximate status of the municipal bond marked is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Judge Mortimer W. Byers, sitting in Brooklyn Federal court, yesterday dismissed a writ of habeas corpus obtained by Winfred W. Lynn of Jamaica, Queens, a gardener, who raised for the first time the question of discrimination against a Negro in the operation of the Selective Service Act.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The long struggle between the War Production Board and the armed services to determine whether war production was to be under civilian or military control brought about today the grant to Charles E. Wilson, WPB vice chairman, of general supervisory authority over the scheduling of all arms output and particular direction of the output of aircraft, radio and detection equipment and escort vessels.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- "Chaos, chiseling and black markets" will result if governmental plans for control of meat prices and distribution of meat products are put into effect, the National Association of Retail Meat Dealers warned in a letter sent to President Roosevelt today.

A new pastoral letter issued by the Catholic Bishops of Germany criticizes Nazi morality as being on the "same level as an animal or not much higher," according to an account in the conservative Swiss Catholic newspaper, the Ostschweiz, which was reported yesterday to the Office of War Information.

"Pearl Harbor Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in the churches of the New York area. The first anniversary of our entrance into World War II also will be commemorated today in the synagogues, with their observance of the "Frost of Lights" or Chanukah.

The performance of "Tristan and Isolde" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House had a pronounced shortcoming and many excellences. Its novel and very interesting feature was Helen Traubel's Isolde.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 -- Robert Paige and Grace McDonald have been named by Universal to play the romantic leads in "Solid Senders," with the Andrews Sisters. Earle Kenton will direct the film. Governor Cole Stevenson of Texas and. Dr. T.O. Walton, president of Texas Agricultural and Mining College, will appear as themselves in Universal's "We've Never Been Licked," the studio has announced.

Rockefeller Center will observe the Christmas holiday season this year by using no essential war materials and by preserving the "spirit and the general effect which have become traditional in the center's observance of the holiday season," the center announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- December wheat and corn acted tight on the Board of Trade today, reflecting strength in cash grain, which showed independent strength. No. 2 hard Winter wheat sold at $1.32 1/2 a bushel, or 5 1/2 cents over the December and at 1/2 cent premium over the government loan basis, while old crop No. 1 yellow corn brought 90 3/4 cents, a new high since September, 1937.

Sweeping readjustment of the umbrella business is inevitable in 1943 as a result of the drastic limitation Order L-36 issued recently by the War Production Board, it was reported here yesterday. Consolidations or possible closings of some of the frame producers upon whom manufacturers rely for the ribs and shoulders of umbrellas were predicted.

Albert Lebrun, last President of the French Republic before the German conquest, and Francisco Largo Caballero, former Premier of Republican Spain, have been taken into custody in France by the German occupying forces and imprisoned, according to private advices from Europe received last night in New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Roosevelt met with the Cabinet, ordered prompt liquidation of WPA, held his press conference, attended the ceremony at which Herbert Lehman was sworn in as Foreign Relief Director and signed several minor bills; his visitors included Prime Minister Mackenzie King, Harold S. Smith, William McReynolds and Edwin W. Pauley.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- An Executive Order by President Roosevelt tomorrow, delegating sweeping authority over the Selective Service System and the United States Employment Service to Paul V. McNutt, director of the War Manpower Commission, was believed probable tonight.

The Golden Rule Foundation yesterday held a luncheon meeting attended by representatives of various religious, philanthropic and war relief agencies to discuss plans for a cooperative educational stewardship program to obtain increased contributions. The meeting was held at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Expressing satisfaction at the speedy and general acceptance given the retailers' Economy for Victory Plan, the Office of Price Administration today made public reports of merchants' cooperation in the program received from several cities.

A class of 204 Coast Guardsmen will be graduated as pharmacists' mates from the College of Pharmacy of Columbia University today at 2:30 P.M. in the Little Theatre of the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West Sixty-third Street. They are the second class to be trained at Columbia, the only private institution in the country giving such a course.

Jan Smeterlin, the Polish pianist, has been playing in our concert halls regularly since his debut in 1930. To one who has heard him in his recital at the Town Hall last night and who has listened to him off and on during these years, his style has altered little in its essentials.

A sprinkling of tax selling easily discouraged yesterday any follow-up to the three-day recovery movement in stocks and the market retreated fractionally. Accent was on the low-priced issues, and without any leadership from the pivotal stocks most traders were content to carry over on previous holdings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- The Navy Department released today U.S. Merchant Marine casualty list No. 3, covering the period Oct. 22 to Nov. 21, inclusive and listing 305 persons from thirty-two States as dead or missing. [There were also twelve men on the casualty list with next of kin in foreign countries, The Associated Press reported].

Despite the recent war developments favorable to the United Nations -- the American victories in the South Pacific and the triumphs in North Africa -- the end of the war is not in sight, but it will come more quickly "if we concentrate all of our thoughts upon the goal of increased production," James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, declared yesterday.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Dec. 4 -- A twentieth-century Paul Revere, with an idea instead of a horse and a message, will receive an individual production award of merit from the War Production Board at a luncheon here next Monday, it was announced today by the lamp division of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, his employer.

With the volume of Christmas trade here rising sharply, retail trade showed increases for the week. Department store volume was estimated at about 8 per cent ahead of the 1941 week. Largeer gains were anticipated for specialty shops.

The price of a rebuilt bicycle, whatever the make, should not be more than $32.50, the ceiling set for new war model bicycles, Walter Endel, chief of the consumer durable goods division of the regional Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday in announcing that an authorization to sell bicycles of this type has been granted L. Bamberger Co. and Gimbel's under Section 3C of GMPR.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Russians may have begun another offensive in the Lake Ilmen area with the idea of delivering Leningrad from a sixteen-months-old semicircular German siege line and eventually knocking Finland out of the war, well-posted observers here said today.

Charles E. Hall of New York will head the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association next year, succeeding Daniel S. Johnson, acting president, it was announced by the association's nominating committee yesterday.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- Plans to provide more fish for a meat rationed State were considered today at a meeting of State fish culture experts called by S.M. Cowden, Superintendent of the State Conservation Department's Bureau of Fish.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Former Governor Lehman of New York took the oath of office today in the office of President Roosevelt as Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations.

DETROIT, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Youthful Willie Mosconi of Jackson, Mich., all but grabbed a stranglehold on at least a tie for the world pocket billiards championship tonight by defeating veteran Ralph Greenleaf of New York, 125 to 97, in nineteen innings. Mosconi's victory was his seventh against a single loss.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Developments on the war fronts and more recently the Beveridge report have stimulated various governments in exile and emigre groups here to stronger activity in planning their countries' post-war future.

Acting on orders from Mayor La Guardia, issued on Thursday, License Commissioner Paul Moss yesterday revoked the license of the Ambassador Theatre on West Forty-ninth Street. The theatre, a Shubert house, formerly housed the revue "Wine, Women and Song," whose producers were convicted Thursday by a General Sessions jury of staging an indecent performance.

While reading your fine sports pages on Tuesday I was surprised to note that apparently there is a great difference of opinion existing between Army and Navy leaders on the one hand and Washington appointees on the other concerning the value of interscholastic and incollegiate athletic contests.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Rialto the attraction will be "Cat People," an RKO mystery written by DeWitt Bodeen and produced by Val Lewton. Heading the melodrama's cast are Simone Simon, Kent Smith, Jane Randolph, Tom Conway and Jack Holt. . . .

Helmut Leiner, who was absolved of treason when Federal Judge John W. Clancy directed his acquittal on Monday, was indicted again yesterday for misprision or concealment of treason and for violation of the Trading with the Enemy Act.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 4 -- With legal fee awards totaling $41,000 wiping out all but $3,000 of remaining assets of the bankrupt estate of William Fox, former millionaire movie magnate, creditors with $123,000 in recognized claims will recover but slightly over two cents on the dollar in final disbursements in the six-year-old case.

Trailing by 15 -- 14 at the half, Thomas Jefferson High's basketball team rallied to beat Boys High, 34 to 29, on the latter's court yesterday. It was the second straight Section 1, Brooklyn P.S.A.L. triumph for the Orange and Blue tossers.
BOSTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the wool market tomorrow:

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 4 -- Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., 1933 winner here, sank a forty-foot chip shot on the eighteenth hole today to complete a brilliant 65, five under par, and take the half-way lead with 135 in the $5,000 Miami open golf tournament.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The gigantic war program which sent the Federal debt skyrocketing above the $100,000,000,000 mark has helped hundreds of cities to reduce their indebtedness. The Census Bureau reported today that total debt of 410 cities with 25,000 or more inhabitants dropped 2 per cent in the last fiscal year.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- The Japanese, attempting to relieve their beleaguered garrison in the Buna-Gona area of Northeastern New Guinea, dropped about 100 bundles of supplies by parachute yesterday as American and Australian forces continued to drive the enemy into a narrowing pocket, it was announced today.

The likelihood of extensive cross-hauling bans on many products next year is delaying the preparation of 1943 campaigns in some industries, reports yesterday indicated. Advertisers and agencies are sketching programs in a general way but are holding off complete selection of media until they get some indication of whether zoning will become effective in their industries or not.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- Fighting French sources today grudgingly acknowledged that American acceptance of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan as head of French North Africa might have been justified as a military expedient, but warned that it would weaken resistance to the Axis within France.

Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel granted a temporary injunction yesterday restraining Police Commissioner Valentine from keeping a uniformed patrolman on the premises of the Unity Contract Bridge Club, 2121 Broadway. The patrolman has been stationed there since a raid on the club on Aug. 6.

Price-fixing in the near months and hedging in the distant positions by spot firms featured trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. The market ended the session irregular, 4 points higher to 6 points lower than Thursday's final prices.

China and Russia must participate as equals with the United States and Great Britain in all peace plans and "agreements concerning the future world" if the Allied desires for the establishment of a peaceful world after the Axis has been crushed are to be realized, Walter Nash, Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand and member of the Pacific War Council, declared here last night.

The parts of the Beveridge report cabled to this country indicate that it is not quite the "revolutionary" document so widely expected. Its basic proposal is an extension of the social security program that has been in existence in Great Britain in some form for more than a generation.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- David C. Adie, Commissioner of the State Department of Social Welfare, predicted today that the order of President Roosevelt ending the WPA would mean "added home relief costs for the State and the localities."

Unofficial estimates that the nation-wide Victory Loan Drive to raise a minimum of $9,000,000,000 this month had passed the halfway mark were confirmed yesterday by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau. The Secretary, however, gave no figures.

Appointment of a single manpower administrator, independent of any other agency, to handle the critical problem of manpower as it affects the armed services, industry and agriculture was urged in a resolution adopted yesterday by the War Congress of American Industry, sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers, at its closing session in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- Reports from both the central front northwest of Moscow and the Stalingrad front today were confident in tone.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 4 -- Urging an accelerated program to enable boys and girls to complete their high school course before they reach the age of 18, the American Vocational Association adopted a resolution today recommending that vocational schools operate on a twelve-month basis.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 4 -- Although details of the three-hour speech made at a secret Senate session Wednesday by Foreign Minister Joaquin Fernandez were not disclosed, political circles favoring a break with the Axis expressed greater confidence yesterday that Chile was approaching a rupture.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Two American Methodist missionaries, Professor D.L. Sheretz of Soochow University, and a 79-year-old Rev. Mr. Burke, who has been in China for fifty-five years, have been arrested by Japanese authorities in Shanghai while awaiting repatriation, reliable information reaching here today said.

Thousands of dollars' worth of negotiable and non-negotiable bonds and securities were missing for several hours yesterday afternoon because Leonard Fass, 17 years old, a messenger employed by Halle Stieglitz, stock brokers, of 25 Broad Street, had an untied shoelace.
LONDON, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- Italy's internal troubles were reported today to have caused a number of Senators to demand of King Victor Emmanuel that the war cease.

Judge John J. Freschi told a young Negro Harlem mugger in General Sessions yesterday that he would have sent him to State prison for a term of thirty years had not one of the jurors, a member of the Columbia University faculty, written the court urging clemency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Attorney General Biddle said today that he was demanding that United States Commissioner Sidney E. Friedman of Harrisburg "put up or shut up" in connection with his charges of interference with an investigation of irregularities in construction of the new $40,000,000 naval supply depot at Mechanicsburg.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Entrance into war industries of mothers who must leave their children in care of others should be discouraged "unless their presence becomes essential to winning the war," the State Association of Children's Court Judges believes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Confronted by problems far more perplexing than anything they encountered even in the lean years of the depression a decade ago, the minor leaguers held their annual convention today, determined to carry on in 1943 if it is at all possible.

Mrs. Roosevelt was quite right in reminding the boys at City College the other day that governments "are apt to have elder statesmen." Whether the First Lady was equally sound in arguing that elder statesmen need watching by the boys in college is a debatable matter.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- A fierce tank battle raged today in the vital railroad and highway triangle between Bizerte and Tunis, the immediate objectives of the Allied drive in Tunisia, according to reports reaching London tonight from both Allied and enemy sources.

LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Dispatches from Lourenco Marques, Portuguese East Africa, said today Axis submarines had sunk three United Nations vessels in the Indian Ocean this week, including the 10,799-ton British liner Llandaf Castle.

Six condensed soups -- the result of the war in one way or another -- appear in groceries from coast to coast. Each comes in an eleven-ounce can, wrapped in the scarlet label of a famous company, and each serves from two to three persons, depending on whether it is used as a first or main course.

The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company reported yesterday for the ten months ended on Oct. 31 an estimated net profit of $4,761,647 after $2,489,136 provision for domestic and foreign Federal taxes on income.

A check-up of the city's department stores has shown that decisions are pending on the establishment of modified self-service in departments adaptable to the method. Christmas buying is currently taking precedence over any immediate changes, but store executives know that labor shortages will soon force them to "help the customer to help herself."

The receipt of $56 from a man who considers jury service a "great privilege," for which no pay should be accepted, was announced yesterday by Judge John O. Knox, senior jurist of the Federal court of the Southern New York District here.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- The finest American beef may soon grace the tables of General Douglas MacArthur and Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in their respective war theatres.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, has reported to Congress that premiums collected to Nov. 1 by the War Damage Corporation, which was formed in December, 1941, and started operations last April, totaled $119,000,000.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A series of terrific Axis counter-attacks through the mountains between Djedeida and Mateur, which caught the British First Army with its American armored forces on the flank at Tebourba, were reported tonight to have left the situation at Tebourba in doubt.

On balance the losses we have suffered in the first year of war far outweigh the gains. Japanese naval strength is being steadily sapped by our attacks, and Japan has added little to her conquests since the first tornado-like swoop down the Pacific.

ALGIERS, Dec. 3 (delayed) (U.P.) -- The captain of the French submarine Casabianca, which escaped from Toulon last Friday through German-sown magnetic mines and a hail of bombs, said today that only a lack of fuel prevented all the French warships there from making a dash for freedom.

An American soprano, Helen Traubel, and a leading American orchestra, the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, performed the magnificent music, which an American audience, comprising more than one nationality, thunderously applauded.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- President Roosevelt has asked Sumner T. Pike, Republican member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to arrange for a six-month furlough to go to Washington to handle petroleum problems and attempt to straighten out the crude oil tangle which threatens to reduce further the supply of fuel oil in the East.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Navy in its encounter Monday night with Japanese forces that were attempting to land supplies and reinforcements for their troops on Guadalcanal Island has won round three of the Solomons struggle, Secertary Knox said at a press conference today.

The National Institute of Municipal Law Officers, composed of the official legal advisers of cities throughout the country, closed a three-day war conference at the Hotel Commodore yesterday with a unanimous vote of confidence in the "wisdom and wartime leadership" of President Roosevelt, "pledging our fullest cooperation."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Apparently satisfied that they have blocked the possibility of action by the present Congress on the Administration's third war powers bill, opponents on the Ways and Means Committee agreed today to a "tentative" end of public hearings on the bill by Thursday at the latest.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 4 -- In France "white terror" is meeting "red terror," the Nazis' name for opposition to Vichy as interpreter of German desires.

The Boston chapter quickly mobilized 500 trained first-aid volunteers under direction of its professional staff.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director, warned today that threatened delays in the construction of facilities for making synthetic rubber because of lack of materials would force the country's stockpile of this commodity to fall below the 120,000-ton "disaster deadline" set by the Baruch committee.

International Hod Carriers Building and Common Laborers Union, who is on trial here on charges of embezzling about $10,000 from the union's treasury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Moving to conserve butter fat for butter, the War Production Board at the behest of its Food Requirements Committee, gave orders today to commercial manufacturers of ice cream, frozen custard, milk sherbet and other frozen desserts and of ice cream mix, to reduce their output in December and January about 20 per cent.

Flotation of the largest issue of public utility securities since the middle of September increased the total of bonds offered here this week for public subscription to the largest in seven weeks. Five separate issues aggregating $20,636,865, one of which was a public utility loan of $12,500,000 and the others for municipalities, comprised the week's flotations.

Necessity for adequate sales promotion by all levels of distribution, to enlist consumer acceptance of "victory" washable daytime dresses planned for Spring to aid the WPB's conservation of available cotton fabrics and manpower, was emphasizes here yesterday at the "Fabric Saving Clinic" sponsored by the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

GRACE ZARING STONE used to write shapely novels bearing exotic titles like "The Bitter Tea of General Yen." Somehow they always seemed Gallic to me, as if they were books by Anatole France translated into English. Then "Ethel Vance" wrote a shapely thriller called "Escape," about Europe under the Nazi heel. Although Ethel Vance was known to be a pseudonym, no one guessed "Escape" to be the work of Grace Zaring Stone.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 4 -- Formal charges of complicity in espionage activities detrimental to continental security and defense were preferred today against more than one member of the German Embassy staff by the Federal Public Prosecutor, Belisario Gache Piran, who, shortly before had conferred at great length with Foreign Minister Ruiz Enrique Guinazu.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Four and a half billion dollars of the $9,000,000,000 of government securities whose sale was launched by the Treasury four days ago have been sold already, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today.

Kent Cooper, general manager of The Associated Press, disclosed yesterday for the first time the full story of a two-decade crusade for international freedom of the press won by the breaking down of a powerful European monopoly.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- In the face of fierce onslaughts by Axis infantry, tanks and dive bombers as the enemy attempted to break the Allied horseshoe menacing Tunis and the naval base of Bizerte, Allied advance troops in Northeastern Tunisia have withdrawn and occupied strongly entrenched positions on the heights overlooking Tebourba, according to a communique issued in London tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A stay of execution for Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Emanuel Weiss and Louis Capone, sentenced to die at Sing Sing Dec. 10, was granted today by Supreme Court Justice Roberts. The stay was granted until Jan. 4 to permit them to appeal to the Supreme Court from a decision by the New York Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Major Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, announced today that, in accordance with President Roosevelt's order of yesterday for the end of the Works Projects Administration, all WPA operations in sixteen States and the District of Columbia would be closed by Feb. 1 and projects in other States "as soon thereafter as feasible."

Nearly 100 persons in the fields of music, the theatre, the press and radio attended a testimonial dinner last night at the Twenty-one Club, to Dr. Frank Black on the occasion of his tenth anniversary as director of music for the National Broadcasting Company.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Members of the Flavoring Extract Manufacturers Association of the United States were informed today by John S. Hall, executive secretary, that a rebate on alcohol taxes, where use is for non-beverage purposes, can be claimed only after the finished product has been manufactured, sold and the title actually transferred to the purchaser.

In fact, there is less likelihood of the grass sprouting than ever, since the streets are being scuffed by a million more feet than in the past -- the feet of dismounted citizens trying to gain a toe-hold on the overcrowded, obsolete transportation system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission and Federal Security Administrator, received today through an Executive order by President Roosevelt sweeping power over the country's manpower, including control over the operations of the Selective Service System and the moving of workers in non-war industries into war industries.

Rutter, regional enforcement attorney.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today the rates of benefit payments it will make to farmers cooperating with crop adjustment phases of the 1943 war food program. They are slightly lower in most cases than those offered under this year's production program.

Appointment of John F. McKernan, regional deputy director for war production, as chairman of WPB's Regional Labor Requirements Committee was announced yesterday by John P. Maguire, regional director. The most extensive, difficult and complicated salvage and repair job ever undertaken has been virtually completed at Pearl Harbor, and most of the ships sunk or damaged in the treacherous Japanese attack last Dec. 7 already have been repaired and are back in service.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The nation's flour trade was at a virtual standstill today while millers and government officials endeavored to find a way out of the predicament brought on by the ceiling on prices and a rising wheat market. The crisis was precipitated by Thursday's ruling by the Office of Price Administration extending without change the flour price ceilings that have been in effect since Oct. 3.

Commodore George E. Roosevelt has been nominated again to head the list of flag officers of the New York Yacht Club. The makeup of the ticket is tantamount to election, which will be held at the annual meeting of the organization in the clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street, on Dec. 17.

The scholarship fund of the New York Mount Holyoke College Club will be augmented by the annual concert, to be given here by the Mount Holyoke Glee Club on the night of Dec. 18 at the Town Hall. Miss Katherine R. Williams of Pelham, N.Y., heads the concert committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Additional gasoline rations were given today to traveling salesmen for "essenital" commodities by the Office of Price Administration acting on the request of William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director.

The people of this country have some $80,000,000,000 invested in homes. Protecting this investment -- maintaining those homes in good order -- is a large-scale undertaking at all times. But now home owners are faced with shortages of materials, shortages that are likely to last for some time.
TORONTO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs routed the Canadiens tonight, 9 to 1, and vaulted over the idle Bruins into third place in the National Hockey League.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET in the Southwest Pacific, Dec. 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- The complete score in the decisive twenty-minute naval action off Savo Island near midnight Monday this week may show United States Continued on Page Seven forces achieved a greater, victory than already has been made known definitely.

A person can never tell in what direction his thoughts will be sent scampering by something he hears or reads. Here, for example, is a magazine article reporting on British conditions and prospects. It contains one sentence which sets a person to thinking about birds of a feather which flock together, and evil communications which corrupt good manners, and a man being known by the company he keeps, and similar maxims.

COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Scoring touchdowns in the last two periods, Bloomfield High defeated Collingswood High, 12 -- 0, in Robert's Memorial Stadium today before 6,000 spectators for the mythical interscholastic championship of New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The war is now to strike home to the nursery.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, who was runner-up for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1940, announced today that he was not a candidate for the 1944 nomination and would support Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio, who was just elected to a third term.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 5 (AP) -- California's Bears, flashing the form expected of them but seldom produced this season, closed their 1942 football schedule today with a smashing 12-to-6 victory over the powerful and favored St. Mary's Navy Pre-Flight team.

WILLIAM MILLER, president of the Luna Park Operators Corporation and proprietor of the booking agency named after him, reports that he and Dr. Think-a-Drink Hoffman, the sleight-of-hand expert who can turn water into practically every well-known drink, have formed a partnership with the object of opening a new Broadway night club on the premises once occupied by Mother Kelly and, lastly, by the Mardi Gras atop the Winter Garden Theatre, Broadway and Fiftieth Street.

THE tough, hard-hitting Red Army moves forward again. It has fought many bloody battles in the last few months, but once more it has blunted the power of the Nazis and turned to the offensive. This army which refuses to be beaten is more than a military machine. It is a symbol of the Russian people, of the character of the Russian man.
Lieutenant Cummins Catherwood, U.S.A., and Mrs. Catherwood have arrived at the Pierre from Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia.

There may be nothing new in the life of man, but as industry levels the barriers against women, the distaff side is being introduced to many a novel undertaking. Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of a citizens' committee of three to investigate the facts in connection with the pension application of former First Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines, who recently resigned under charges of improper acceptance of gratuities.

If you are inclined to go in for prophecy, try this one on your futurama. . . . In 1789 began the French Revolution, leading to the first French Republic. In 1918, after 129 years, came the German Revolution and the start of the Weimar Republic.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Three hundred day shift workers at the Budd Manufacturing Company plant left their jobs today in the second walkout in three days, after the management informed them they would not receive time-and-one-half overtime pay for their work today.

Gounod's "Faust" received its first performance of the season last night when it was presented as the second of the Metropolitan Opera's popular priced Saturday evening productions. Wilfred Pelletier conducted.

AN exhibition of hand-woven and printed textiles of the early nineteenth century, just opened at the New York Historical Society, centers around quilts, spreads and homespun materials, along with printed cottons and silks of the time, especially commemorative kerchiefs from the Mrs. J. Insley Blair collection.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A dispatch from Rome tonight said it was "possible" that the Ministry of Defense and other departments that could be considered military objectives have been evacuated from Rome, although there was no official confirmation.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- With Prenuer Mussolini reduced to the status of a mere puppet of Reichsfuehrer Hitler, and Italy firmly held in the grip of Germany, economically if not yet militarily, the only prospect that can presently be seen of knocking Italy out of the war is by Allied conquest.

The crucial importance of North Africa in the Allied blueprint for attack on the Nazi "fortress of Europe" was thus outlined last week by Winston Churchill. As Britain's Prime Minister spoke -- it was the eve of his sixty-eighth birthday and he was still in the "ebullient mood" engendered by Allied victories -- the tempo of the battle in Tunisia, Libya and the Central Mediterranean mounted steadily.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 5 (AP) -- W.H. Klepper, business manager of the Portland club of the Pacific Coast League, today reported the signing of Mervyn Shea, former Detroit coach, as catcher-manager, and the purchase of seven other players for 1943.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 5 -- First thing on Monday morning the case against the alleged Nazi spies, including one or more members of the German Embassy, will be placed in the hands of the Supreme Court which alone is empowered to proceed against persons shielded by diplomatic immunity.

German sources said yesterday that their forces destroyed 192 Russian tanks Friday "in the course of continued successes achieved in defensive struggles," according to Berlin broadcasts re corded by The United Press in New York.

By adopting an "eight-day week," wherein two shifts of employes work eleven hours a day for six consecutive days and then have two off, Mergenthaler Linotype Company has been able to increase war contract operations from 67.5 per cent of maximum hours to 92 per cent, without the addition of a third shift, according to George W. Allison, assistant vice president.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- An agreement has been reached by the United States, British and Iranian Governments under which the United States and Britain will supply Iran with wheat and other cereals to bring up her stocks to minimum requirements, it was announced in London today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Telephone and telegraph communications between France and Spain and Switzerland were disrupted tonight, and a Paris dispatch to The Geneva Tribune said it was done while the Germans took new steps to consolidate control in the former free zone of France and to conclude negotiations for a new out-and-out Nazi regime in Vichy.

Decimation of the ranks of Roman Catholic clergy in the Axis-occupied countries of Europe will require the church to enlist American missionaries for the reconstruction of Catholicism in Europe after the war, declared Mgr. Edward A. Freking of Cincinnati in a sermon in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

Stocks did little yesterday. Fluctuations on the New York Stock Exchange were narrow, the close was dull and mixed and volume was only 246,016 shares. Of the 606 issues traded, 204 rose, 180 declined and 22 did neither.

Commenting last Sunday on an appeal by Saint-Exupery "To Frenchmen Everywhere," THE TIMES wrote that "Mr. Hull would be astonished if any but the merest negligible fraction of the French in America took their stand for disunity."

Flames of Christmas cheer will burn in lonely outposts of the armed forces this year as a result of a special project undertaken by the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy. The Yale Glee Club, conducted by Marshall Bartholomew, and the Sarah Lawrence College Chorus, under William Schuman, gave a joint concert last night in Town Hall for the benefit of their respective scholarship funds. A highly diversified program, devoted largely to brief numbers of a happy, carefree nature, was presented, and all of it was delivered with verve and charm.

While resignations are being compensated for, in some cases by new arrivals in the community, a number of metropolitan groups are recording a net loss as families move to industrial centers or to military posts.

City College opened its regular basketball season last night at the City gymnasium by defeating Panzer College, 51 -- 39, before a crowd of 900. The Lavender lads outplayed their New Jersey opponents from the start, leading by 27 -- 12 at the intermission.

HAVANA, Dec. 5 -- President Carlos Arroyo del Rio of Ecuador spoke here today of the profound impression he had received of the United States war machine and said he foresaw much closer economic relations between the nations of the Americas following the war.

Retail trade was excellent last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, with all Christmas gift departments busy, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 -- During 1941, the last full year before almost complete conversion of their plants to war production, twenty-two of the nation's leading producers of passenger automobiles, commercial cars and trucks showed combined net profits of $280,000, 000, an increase of $35,000,000 over 1940, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Sir William Beveridge's social security report, which received a great welcome from the British press this week and some measure of approval from most ranks of Parliament except the extreme right and left wings may win an important triumph in the near future by gaining the support of the powerful Trades Union Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Reviewing the financial position of the country on the first anniversary of Pearl Harbor Secretary Morgenthau stated today that while income payments to individuals would have increased by $49,000,000,000 from 1940 to 1943, Federal, State and local personal taxes would have increased by only $12,000,000,000.
