WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Almost on the eve of the first anniversary of the "date which will live in infamy," the Navy Department tonight finally disclosed the facts about Pearl Harbor. The sinking or serious crippling of ten warships -- including five battleships -- and damage to three other battleships and five smaller warcraft were revealed as part of the melancholy toll, making Dec. 7, 1941, the blackest day in United States naval history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- One of the first battles in the new Congress doubtless will be fought over the moral correctness, economic effect, social significance and legality of the new Presidential order limiting gross salaries to $67,200 a year, plus certain qualified allowances for life insurance payments, fixed obligations and customary charitable contributions.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 5 -- Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be the principal speaker Dec. 12 at a dinner marking the graduation of 400 Dartmouth College senior. SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Seton Hall opened its season by defeating a previously undefeated Coast Guard team from Brooklyn, 39 -- 28, before 3,200 spectators in Setonia Gym tonight. WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- With the publication by the Treasury this week of its regulations governing salaries and the establishment by the War Labor Board of its nation-wide organization to control wages, both wage and salary workers in the United States now know where they stand under the Byrnes stabilization program.

SYRACUSE, N.Y. Dec. 5 -- Seventy-two pairs entered the second of four sessions of play for the national contract bridge pairs championship here tonight. The field will be cut to thirty-two pairs for the final round which will decide the contest tomorrow night and bring to a close the American Contract Bridge League's sixteenth annual tournament, which has been in progress here since Tuesday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 5 -- Bob Steuber dashed 58 yards for a touchdown on the second play from scrimmage today to give Missouri a 7-to-0 victory over the Iowa naval pre-flight football team in a game played on a heavy field before a crowd of 7,600.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5 -- Top-weighted Shot Put, Mrs. Marie Evans's sturdy campaigner, won the Pelican Handicap at the Fair Grounds today, stepping the mile and a furlong in 1:53 4-5.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 -- Dapper Willie Mosconi returned today to the world pocket billiard championship after a year's absence, and Monday morning, bright and early, he'll return to his war job at Jackson, Mich.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Price relief for flour millers will be forthcoming by Jan. 1, an Office of Price Administration spokesman predicted today as reports reached Washington that many flour mills faced shut-downs because of a price squeeze.

The letters just exchanged between Secretary Hull and Leighton McCarthy, Canadian Minister at Washington, were pleasant reading. They told us that representatives of Canada and the United States are going to sit down together from time to time and try to agree upon a plan, open to all the other United Nations, for the extension of production and commerce and the reduction of tariffs and other barriers to trade.

It happens during a blackout on election night in a city somewhere on the West Coast. A woman falls or is thrown from a window on the thirteenth floor of City Hall, where the election returns are being tabulated. Bill Randall, police reporter for The News, is there in the line of duty and is the first person to identify the body.
lated two battalions of enemy infantry and one cavalry squadron.

Continuing their demands for the immediate appointment of a food administrator with over-all control of the nation's food production, industry spokesmen yesterday again warned that a serious shortage of supplies threatens unless such action is taken.

The Bronx Board of Trade announces that studies are being made by the Board of Transportation with a view to providing transit facilities for the East and West Bronx sections through construction of a Second Avenue-Bronx subway in the post-war period.
SODA SPRINGS, Idaho, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Pocatello Air Base listed today the ten men who were aboard a four-motored A_,Tny bomber which crashed in a Southeastern Idaho mountain canyon.

Travel Lines: The Toronto Ski Club is out on a membership drive with a goal of 5,000; men in the armed forces who were members of the club the year before their enlistment are entitled to use the club button, which carries certain perquisites with it, according to the Ontario Travel Bureau at Toronto. . . .

LYNDONVILLE, Vt. -- Up here in the land of snow and sugar maples, life goes on as usual despite transportation snarls and tire rationing. While Northern Vermont seems remote from big cities, it is reached by comfortable trains that halt at small villages to take on and discharge passengers stopping over to do business or make a family visit.

BOSTON, Dec. 5 -- True to its tradition of service to humanity, the American Red Cross swung into action at Boston's Cocoanut Grove catastrophe with a speed and efficiency that amazed even those familiar with its long record of disaster relief.

With four teams remaining unbeaten, the P.S.A.L. senior high school swimming series reached its sixth week yesterday. In the Brooklyn-Richmond division, Brooklyn Tech and James Madison each annexed their fifth straight triumph of the season, while De Witt Clinton and James Monroe remained deadlocked in the Manhattan-Bronx section, each with six victories in a row.
Considering the reward to be reaped, it really is not so long to wait after Fall planting until a magnificent color symphony greets the gardener who has planted Spring Flowering Sweet Peas.

MOSCOW, Dec. 5 -- Moscow was bright with flags today in honor of the sixth anniversary of the 1936 -- or Stalin -- Constitution. The holiday this year brought no interruption of work. In interpretative articles the press pointed out that elements of the population that Czarist Russia dared not mobilize for military service now are serving loyally far from their homes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The task of fighting spies and saboteurs, watching alien enemies and foreign agents, and exposing war profiteers, has been the outstanding duty of the Department of Justice in the first full year since Pearl Harbor, Attorney General Biddle indicated today.

Professional baseball, from soup to dessert, as one might say, meaning from Spring training to world series, now seems reasonably assured of going through next year with its second successive wartime campaign.

Individuals, organizations and industries, as well as States and nations, must look forward to the post-war period. This applies particularly to the business of breeding thoroughbred dogs and the sport of showing them in competition.

APPROACH the fish dealer with an open mind these days, prepared to take what you can get for a meatless meal. You'll find stocks smaller, less diversified than they used to be. On occasion you'll be confronted with varieties -- such as hake or burbot or whiting -- for which you, in common with most cooks, show little appreciation.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: a heavy mulch of well-rotted manure (or of compost if manure is not available) will help greatly in giving asparagus and rhubarb plants an early, strong start in the Spring. . . . Banking the coldframe or hotbed high with earth now will help greatly in keeping out frost. This treatment is desirable even if the frame is to remain empty during the Winter.

Fuel oil shortages this Winter may reduce many human beings to a shivering condition, but for house plants they will usher in the boom days. Too long have geraniums, cyclamens and primroses dropped unopened buds or lost exhausted foliage because of being forced to live in an atmosphere as uncomfortable and unhealthy for them as would be the tropics for an Eskimo.

LIEUTENANT BILL GRADY'S cousin Prue, on a visit to Akron, Ohio, meets two young men who are great admirers of the lieutenant and would like to make his acquaintance, but Prue tells them that the only way to induce him to come to Akron would be to provide a body.

A SOUTH PACIFIC AIR BASE, Nov. 4 (Delayed) -- There were eight of us and several thousand pounds of freight jammed into the fuselage of the big transport plane of a type similar to that used by American commercial airlines. The freight took up most of the room, so the passengers sat on the catwalk between the spare gas tanks.

A.N. Groves of Syracuse will be installed as president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards at an all-day meeting of the organization in Albany on Friday. Mr. Groves succeeds George L. Long of Brooklyn.

Forces and factors in American life which lead to the development of attitudes among younger persons and promote national unity and international understanding will be examined next Saturday at the Greater New York Conference on Racial and Cultural Relations in the United States at Benjamin Franklin High School, 114th Street and East River Drive.

WHEN word got around recently through the publishing underground that Antoine de Saint-Exupery was writing and illustrating a children's book, most people who heard about it figured that "the Joseph Conrad of the air" (in the jacket-copy cliche) was doing a child's book on flying.
A STOCK figure in cartoon and comedy is the baffled gentleman at the perfume counter, trying to describe the elusive qualities and characteristic preferences of the lady of his choice.

Another major sport will embark on a new season Saturday, when intercollegiate basketball makes its big-time bow in Madison Square Garden with the first of the double-headers there. City College will clash with the Oklahoma Aggies in one end of the twin bill, while Long Island University faces Brigham Young in the other.

THE usual method of fiction is to follow the thread of one story or else of a set of stories so closely related that they act and react importantly on one another. In his new novel, "It Happened Like This," Mr. Hutchinson has used a fairly novel variation of the latter method.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Heavy bombers of the United States Army Air Forces in India attacked Japanese troop and truck concentrations near Mandalay yesterday, dropping nearly 100 bombs "with telling effect," an official Air Force communique said today.

"THE SHINING TREE" is subtitled "A Christmas Story, which is just about as accurate a description as is likely to emerge from a far wordier attempt to characterize it. It is a novel, certainly, but one which pretty well defies all efforts to fit it into any recognized subdivision of that species.

THIS book will serve as a guide to thrilling adventures in the world of growing plants, especially to those who have had no opportunity for botanical training. The author indicates that when he graduated from Yale "not so many years ago" the only native tree he knew was the elm.

Motorists with A cards are finding that there are problems and worries in addition to the limited driving range imposed by a ration of three gallons of gasoline a week. And not the least of these is the automobile battery.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Josephine Baker, the Negro dancer who played as a child around her mother's washtubs in St. Louis and later went on to fame on the Paris stage, now is living in the native quarter at Marrakesch, an inland city southeast of here.

AS with every other aspect of American life, a year of war has wrought many changes in radio. If nothing else, radio has finally come of age in that it has won deserved recognition from governmental and private leaders as a vital factor in successful prosecution of the Allied cause.
A recent analysis of some of the characteristics of the wild turkey started a bit of reminiscing on the part of the visitor.

One of the most progressive units in the National Ski Association of America, the Central Ski Association of the Midwest, has outlined a Winter program for physical fitness, the aim being to organize as many people as can be enlisted to ski regularly for healthful exercise and mental invigoration.

A free world will come not from the decision of one or two men but from free peoples planning as a whole for humanity, Louis Dolivet, secretary-general of the Free World Association, declared yesterday.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Britain's hard-fighting warships in the Mediterranean, keeping pace with the Eighth Army's advance across the Western Desert, have sunk or damaged forty-eight Axis ships since the westward offensive began two months ago.

Renegotiations and price ceilings have revealed the almost universal dissimilarity in cost accounting methods employed by business concerns, according to T.C. McCobb, president of the Controllers Institute of America and controller of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, who urged yesterday that a standard procedure be adopted which would be generally acceptable to the public and the government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- With the suspension of induction into the Army of all men 38 years of age or older, the War Department issued this statement:

NEW YORK'S two-year battle to obtain more daily operating hours for Station WNYC currently appears to have reached a wartime solution. Last week the Federal Communications Commission granted a special permit for the municipal broadcaster to continue operating Until 10 P.M., on the assumption that such operation will be all-important in the city's civilian defense program.

A final committee meeting will be held Thursday morning at the Navy League Center, 640 Madison Avenue, to complete plans for the first benefit performance of Chekhov's "The Three Sisters," which the New York City Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States will take over on the evening of Dec. 22 at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A tremendous production record was rolled up in "the first year on the home front," the Office of War Information stated today in a review of 1942's accomplishments, but it added that President Roosevelt's production goals were not reached completely, and the American people must work in 1943 with "bare muscle" as against "peacetime fat."

THE second Earl of Shelburne was one of the loyal opposition which tried to save the British Tories from themselves in their dealings with the American colonies. He helped bring about the repeal of the Stamp Act, and as Secretary of State for the Southern Department adopted a policy of enlightened conciliation.

DR. RAYMOND BANNISTER is not the hero of this thoughtful story of a family living on the edge of the campus in a Western university town. He is the middle-aged doctor, almost a failure in his profession, but so wise, humorous and penetrating that, in a crisis, he is the only one who can save the family of his successful brother.

THIRTEEN-YEAR-OLD Sonia Childs of Seattle, Wash., took first prize in the Camp Fire Girls third annual photography contest, on the subject "Young America," with a snapshot of a smiling country boy chewing on a carrot. Her reward is a $25 war bond, donated by the National Photographic Dealers Association, plus a $100 photography scholarship offered by the School of Modern Photography.

Metal from the city's scrap piles, which passed into the Federal government's possession last Sunday, is now "moving satisfactorily" toward the steel mills, George Sutherland, regional manager of the War Production Board's conservation division, said yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Displaying his characteristic caution about predicting the course of the war while at the same time taking good cheer from the events of November, Prime Minister Churchill warned Britain today that the "struggle is approaching its most tense part."

FROM Damascus word came last week that Syria and Lebanon would officially merge next April 1 and that plans are being made to commemorate the event with a series of nine stamps with total face value of 125 piastre, or about $5.

THE question, I take it, is not whether this time of war is good for writing books. Every critic worth quoting can tell you that no time is good for writing books except the past -- and the more remote the better. The question is whether the writing of books is good for this time.

A new instrument called the "audio" scale, enabling the blind to weigh small articles accurately by sound, was demonstrated last week at the American Foundation for the Blind, which sponsored its development after a blind woman in Buffalo had suggested its production by the Toledo Scale Company.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Charles H. Saunders, a salty merchant seaman whose discharge from the Navy shows that he put in nearly four years of submarine duty, including the years of the first World War, has been selected by the United Seamen's Service as manager of the new service club for officers and men of the merchant marine at 321 South Fourth Street, Philadelphia, Pa.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 5 -- Weakened by hunger and privations before their capture or suffering "grievous wounds," 12,000 of Finland's 56,000 Russian prisoners of war died in Finnish prison camps up to July 1, according to a statement issued by the Finnish Legation here today.
The battle for North Africa was becoming a vicious, hard-fought struggle last week, with the climax yet to come.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Mileage rationing, that device by which government officials hope to preserve existing tires on civilians' cars in usable condition through the long months until synthetic rubber can be spared for other than military use, was introduced on a national scale at 12:01 A.M. Tuesday.
MONTREAL lies a thousand miles inland. Winter freezes its waterways. Yet it is one of the greatest seaports of the world. And -- as the statements above indicate -- as a port it is unique.

IT'S difficult to begin a story like this, which will try to explain why the appointment of Vice Admiral (now Admiral) William Frederick Halsey Jr. as commander of naval forces in the South Pacific has put a new spirit in the Pacific Fleet -- a spirit of confidence that says, "Now we're going places!"

The Giants and the Dodgers pulled off their practice uniforms for the last time of the season yesterday. For almost half of them it will be the last time until the bigger game is over. Hence it was a sadder and more somber final drill than either team ever had before.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Notre Dams needed only two offensive chances to score two touchdowns in 3 minutes and 45 seconds today -- on runs of 82 and 68 yards by Corwin Clatt and Creighton Miller -- and tied the favored Great Lakes Naval Training Station football team, 13 to 13, in the season's finale here before 35,000 excited fans at Soldier Field.

AMONG the things that greatly impressed Wendell L. Willkie on his recent mission to Moscow was the Russian eagerness for education. What he probably doesn't know, however, is that even movie actresses go to school in Russia.

An entertainment beginning with a cocktail party at 5 P.M. and continuing until midnight will be given next Saturday in the Tapestry Room of the Park Lane as the first in a series of events designed to raise funds for the Father Duffy Canteen at 219 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The close connection between domestic economic programs and the war effort is indicated by the attention devoted by Nazi spokesmen in the last few days to the report to the British Parliament by Sir William Beveridge, proposing what its author called a revolutionary extension of Britain's system of social security.

Fuel oil ration coupons totaling 50,000 gallons have been voluntarily turned back to the Office of Price Administration by householders in this city who have changed to coal heat since registering for their fuel oil rations a month ago, Lee S. Buckingham, OPA State director, announced yesterday.

The Near East College Association, Inc., "an investment in international good-will," has taken over the first public performance this season of "Boris Godunoff" at the Metropolitan Opera House on the afternoon of Dec. 30, for its fifteenth annual opera benefit.

Uneven playing, some of it wonderful, was done by George Copeland when he gave his piano recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. There was, for instance, the perfect style and aristocratic feeling of the major Haydn Sonata, which has a slow movement of a few measures, totally unrelated to the rest of the piece, which most players spoil.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Dreamers may dream and theorists may theorize but the census man counts noses and knows what he is talking about. The picture, therefore, that the Census Bureau gives of the vast changes that have taken place in the economic system of the country since Pearl Harbor and how they have affected the lives of all Americans is painted with the brush of statistical accuracy.

Although a few sizeable Regulation V loans are still in course of preparation, including those being negotiated by the Bendix Corporation and the Borg-Warner Corporation, the country's banks have found that borrowing under loans of this sort have been far smaller than had been expected.

IF we want competition we must expect duplication. Each major record company is bound to issue its up-to-date version of the staples of the repertory. Thus Columbia heads its December list with a new recording of Richard Strauss's Don Quixote (M-506, five 12-inch records), played by the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra under Fritz Reiner with Gregor Piatigorsky as solo 'cellist.

In a recent issue of THE TIMES, one of your contributors dwelt on the failure of the schools to exert efficient disciplinary measures in dealing with today's boys and girls. Practically on the heels of this communication, appear accounts of rather terrifying youthful conduct in certain schools.

A bank guard with a generous heart and $11,000 of his employer's funds to give it full play was in the Philadelphia lock-up yesterday slightly crestfallen that police had caught up with him while he still had $3,300 left.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Italian lire are available in Switzerland at the rate of twenty-four to one for the Swiss franc although the legal rate is 4.5. A few weeks ago the lira sold at sixteen to one for the Swiss franc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Senator David I. Walsh, Democrat, of Massachusetts, chairman of the Senate Naval Committee, said tonight the Navy's record in repairing vessels and aircraft damaged at Pearl Harbor was "most gratifying."

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- King Peter of Yugoslavia was poorer by five siblings today and 0pal Anderson, American woman transport pilot now attached to the British air transport auxiliary, was ahead by the same amount.

The Japanese radio, almost a year after the attack on Pearl Harbor, broadcast yesterday a claim that the United States fired the first shot there and thus incurred the "responsibility" for the war in the Pacific.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 6 -- The Red Army drove forward on three fronts today, the anniversary of the start of its crippling offensive against the Axis last year, crushing German opposition to its new attack southwest of Stalingrad as well as within the Volga city and on the central front.

ONE way to get a story about the dangers of running war cargoes past German Uboats, surface raiders, mines and Stukas is to ask Marjorie Dent Candee at Seamen's Church Institute to round up some seamen for you.

We are making wonderful plans for post-war rehabilitation abroad, Dr. Alice V. Keliher said in an interview the other day, expressing her delight in the appointment of Governor Lehman as director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation. Then she added: "Must we not have a lend-lease agreement with our next generation?

Dwellings in Flushing attracted considerable attention last week among buyers of Long Island properties. Commander William F. Murphy sold his residence at 45-52 167th Street, Flushing, to Miss Helen L. Stahl, through the L.O. Trilisch Agency.

Ten German aliens, all members of the German-American Bund and its affiliated organizations, were seized in week-end raids in Nassau land Suffolk Counties, it was revealed yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, agent in charge of the local offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

ON top of all their other wartime woes, theatre operators around the country now are confronted with a wave of gate-crashing and vandalism by 'teen-age hooligans. Even the big Broadway first-run theatres are having their share of trouble, though stern counter-measures adopted in recent weeks by the theatres and the Police Department reportedly are showing good results.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Captain Harold N. Chaffin of Fort Smith, Ark., who outwitted the Japanese in Hawaii on Dec. 7 last and saved his heavy bomber from disaster, has been awarded an Oak-Leaf Cluster for his Distinguished Flying Cross, the War Department announced today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 5 -- For the first time in military history the United States struck directly at Italy, when a heavy force of B-24 Liberator bombers raided the harbor of Naples just at dusk yesterday. Their blows sank an Italian cruiser and crippled a battleship and a second cruiser, among other damage.
Two burglars broke into the home of Mr. and Mrs. David Radom at 1,795 East Eighth Street, Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, early yesterday, pummeled the couple with their fists and escaped with $5,000 loot.

THE Russian theatre, which has long done much in the rear of the battle lines to educate and entertain the workers of the Soviet Union, is also fulfilling an important role at the front. How amusement and propaganda are combined is best illustrated by a show called "Happy Landing," recently put on in Moscow by a company of troupers on its return from a three-and-a-half-month tour of the Southern Front.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 5 -- German military commentators are cited in today's dispatches from Berlin as taking a more optimistic view of the fighting in Tunisia and of the ability of the Axis forces to retain their present advantage there.

The New York City Housing Authority's program for new low-rent housing must favor Negroes because they are most in need of better living conditions, Edmond B. Butler, chairman of the authority, declared yesterday.

The Women's Division of the Travelers Aid Society maintenance fund campaign will hold a tea and report meeting Thursday afternoon in the Palm Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Bruce Barton, chairman of the division, will preside.

BUD ABBOTT and Lou Costello are not exactly what you might call a flash in the pan. In less than two years these frantic comics have been starred in seven quick films -- eight, indeed, counting their latest, "Who Done It?" which drained the sidewalks into Loew's Criterion last week.

ON THE anniversary eve of that morning when treachery struck out of the skies over Pearl Harbor, the efforts of our military and civilian leadership are bent toward counsel against overconfidence. The war will not be over on an early tomorrow, these informed leaders insist, and the road to victory must still be considered a long and hard one.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- By placing the Selective Service system under Chairman Paul V. McNutt of the War Manpower Commission, President Roosevelt, one year after. Pearl Harbor, has taken a step which Congressional circles hope means (1) the strengthening of civilian control over manpower policies, and (2) a preliminary move toward further integration of procurement, production and manpower requirements.

Greater development of child care services was urged yesterday at a meeting held by the West Side Defense Council, a branch of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, at Public School 165, 109th Street, between Amsterdam and Broadway.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Howitzers now hammering the Japanese in the Buna-Gona area of New Guinea were brought up by order of General Douglas MacArthur. The American 105-millimeter (4-inch) howitzers flown from Australia to batter the outposts at Buna, Gona, Sanananda and Cape Endaiadere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Selective Service System has forwarded to local draft boards a new deferment guide designed to keep thousands of agricultural workers on farms to help produce 1943 war food needs.

THE best account yet available of how the United States Navy, shaken to the very depths of its being by one of the most complete and humiliating defeats ever inflicted on a first-class naval power, gradually regained its self-confidence and initiative in the months following the attack on Pearl Harbor, until it won the tremendous victory of Midway against great odds, is offered in this book.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Treasury warned today that the use of paper 1-cent and 5-cent pieces issued by merchants' associations was illegal and punishable by six months' imprisonment and $500 fine.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY AT CASABLANCA, Morocco, Dec. 1 (Delayed) (AP) -- For braving naval gunfire while guarding documents seized from the German Armistice Commission, Sergeant Richard N. Ryan, 31-year-old grandson of the late New York financier, Thomas Fortune Ryan, today received the Army Silver Star medal for gallantry in action.

H. REY'S "Uncle Gus's Farm" and "Uncle Gus's Circus," two picture books in which the animals, clowns and farm implements will push out of the page with slight pressure, ready to stand up when folded according to simple directions, have been popular with both children and their parents.
OTTAWA, Dec. 5 -- This week began with the election of three new Members of Parliament and next week will begin with the convention of the Conservative party in Winnipeg.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- By placing the Selective Service system under Chairman Paul V. McNutt of the War Manpower Commission, President Roosevelt, one year after. Pearl Harbor, has taken a step which Congressional circles hope means (1) the strengthening of civilian control over manpower policies, and (2) a preliminary move toward further integration of procurement, production and manpower requirements.

Fire caused damage estimated at $60,000 to the Jewish Synagogue of the Congregation Bes Medras Hagade, at 157 Throop Avenue, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, early yesterday morning. The blaze was attributed to an overheated furnace.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Informed observers in London tonight are willing to nominate for the prize as the wildest report of the month the one coming from Paris to the effect that Admiral Jean Francois Darlan would "send or lead" a military mission here to discuss with Prime Minister Churchill the development of the operations in North Africa and Admiral Darlan's own plans in the future.

NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 5 -- William and Mary showed for three quarters today the stuff that made it king of the Southern Conference, but Oklahoma threatened regicide in the last period before the Virginians finally won, 14 -- 7.

WHEN musicians take to brush and easel, they apparently are not interested in music. Or at least that seems to be the lesson of the first annual exhibition of art by musicians, which will conclude its fortnight stay tomorrow at the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The Polish National Council made public today its declaration of war aims, calling for the security of Poland's frontiers and promotion of the country's economic and cultural development.

Extending its program to aid inter-American relations, which it has developed through the exchange of students and special projects, New Jersey College for Women this year introduced a course in Portuguese in which twenty-two women and one Rutgers University student are enrolled.
Palm oil and olive oil, both formerly imported, are no longer available in large amounts. The research laboratories of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey have therefore developed substitutes.

Having been successfully tested in a dozen plants, the Manning Table Plan for manpower inventory in essential war factories is being adopted rapidly throughout the country and by the end of the year hundreds of plants will be using it, reports yesterday from business and trade association executives indicated.

IN the event of America's being afflicted by a major paper shortage, it may be as well to take warning from what has been happening here. Some time ago every British household was exhorted to surrender for pulping every scrap of clean paper that was no longer wanted.

Vacuum cleaners, frozen for months, have just been unfrozen by the War Production Board, which means that they can be bought again, as long as they last. Nobody knows exactly how many vacuum cleaners are thus made available in the stores, but one well-informed source declares the number to be "substantial" and the styles varied.

IT all began with the Hotel Ansonia. I was walking up Broadway on a fine morning in October last year when I saw its rococo shape rising before me like something out of my childhood. I did not know what it was, but I had an odd sense that it was somehow important to me, and I decided to go on and find out.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 5 -- Throughout the stirring days when the British Eighth Army was breaking German resistance at El Alamein and pushing on to Libya, the United States Army Services of Supply carried on with the somewhat prosaic but highly important work of supporting the Allied efforts in the Middle East.

When the sandwich hampers are piled high in the truck and the ten-gallon jugs of coffee are secure, the midnight patrol of the Women's Home Leagues of Newark starts out on its nightly round of anti-aircraft posts. Before their work is over every man stationed beside gun emplacements has had a hearty snack to bridge over the hours between Army meals.

The first formal assemblage of debutantes of this season took place last night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton, where the Debutante Charity Ball was given as the annual dance in aid of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House. Many debutantes were guests of honor at dinners given earlier in the Oval Room.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- Set in a patriotic tricolor decor, an entertainment entitled "Furlough Frolics" will be given at the Hotel Gramatan next Saturday night by the Bronxville League for Service as its annual benefit fete. The proceeds, as in the past, will aid many local charitable organizations as well as individual cases of need.

The National Gallery of Art at Washington has received three important sculptures as a gift from Mrs. Ralph Harman Booth of Detroit in memory of her husband, who was a distinguished art collector, philanthropist and at one time United States Minister to Denmark.

POCONOMOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Winter fun is on the way in the Poconos; the first good snowfall will set the toboggans and sleighs in motion and bring out skiers and skaters to glide down the mountain slopes and over the lakes and ponds.

A proposal that President Roosevelt, with Congressional approval, "call a conference of representatives of the United Nations for the purpose of formulating specific plans for an international economic union and for its subsequent organization at the peace table" was released here yesterday by its sixty-four sponsors.

WHEN the dawn came up like thunder last Dec. 7 and Hawaii was awakened by the roar and flame of Japanese bombs, the thunder swept across this continent from the Pacific to the Atlantic and shattered at one stroke the last obstinate illusion of American security.

Life insurance policy loans outstanding in the nation have decreased $217,000,000 during the year, the greatest single year's decrease in history, bringing the ratio of policy loans to total life insurance reserves available for loans to a new all-time low of 9 per cent, nearly one-half that in force at the begining of World War I.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Johnny Crimmins of Detroit, who has averaged 203.26 pins per game in A.B.C. tournaments during the last ten years, was named tonight the "outstanding bowler of the nation for 1942" by the National Bowling Writers Association.

MANY and varied though the books on the Third Reich are that have been published in this country the past several years, there have remained certain blank spaces in the picture they have combined, even when taken all together, to paint of life in the New Germany.

THE first of the many musical programs scheduled for this season throughout the country in honor of the twentieth anniversary of the League of Composers will be given Wednesday night, in Town Hall, as a feature of the Town Hall Endowment Series.

MANCHESTER, England, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Dr. Eduard Benes, President of the Czechoslovak Government in Exile, said today that it would be a profound mistake to allow Germany to retain even an inch of conquered territory after the war.

Impending WPB restrictions on chemicals vital to production of both rayon and motion picture film may force a choice on the agency as to whether to assure sufficient cellulose for rayon apparel or enough celluloid to continue double-feature programs in motion picture houses.

A series of eight patriotic supper dances, to be given fortnightly in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria through the Winter and early Spring, has been arranged by the Theatre Wing Supper Club to benefit the American Theatre Wing War Service, Inc.

The Ice Follies of 1943 will present a matinee session today to which children will be admitted at half price. The afternoon performance will be the only one of the show, which will close on Thursday night. The Follies includes numbers of particular appeal to children, based on nursery rhymes and fairy tales.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The entry of the United States into the war a year ago changed the scope and character of the conflict and sealed the doom of the Axis. But how many more years must pass before the resistance of the enemy is finally broken?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The House bill to force the inclusion of all farm labor costs in the parity formula by which "fair exchange" agricultural prices are established was unanimously approved by the Senate Agriculture Committee today and reported to the Senate.

Certificates signifying completion of twelve weeks of training as pharmacists' mates at Columbia University's College of Pharmacy, were presented to 198 Coast Guardsmen yesterday afternoon in the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West Sixty-third Street.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 5 -- With the slogan, "Remember Pearl Harbor," the Brazilian National Students' Union will sponsor a high mass at Candelaria Cathedral on Monday in honor of the Pearl Harbor dead.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Controlled Materials Plan or CMP, which in Detroit has been familiarly referred to as the "Curses -- More Paper" plan, will not mean that, according to a statement today by Harold Boeschenstein, director of the WPB division which will administer it.

CHUNGKING, China, Sunday, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Sending a message of greetings to President Roosevelt on the eve of the anniversary of Pearl Harbor, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek said today that American victories in the war had been "heartening to all freedom-loving peoples."

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Dec. 5 -- The order for liquidation of the WPA confronts Puerto Ricans with the prospect of increasing the already overwhelming unemployment. Roy Schroder, regional administrator, was in touch with Washington authorities, but no information was obtainable as to the conversation.

Many retail buyers were in the market last week making final holiday purchases, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Most garment manufacturers have delayed new Spring production, it was said, awaiting the new OPA price ruling covering such output.

Joseph W. Frazer, president of Willys-Overland and a director of the Automotive Council for War Production, yesterday assailed as "half-baked" and "impractical and stupid" the suggestion by Henry J. Kaiser, Pacific Coast shipbuilder, that the automobile industry design and announce its 1945 models for delivery after the war and accept war bonds as down payments.

"WE could learn to watch for airplanes if they would trust us," said one 11-year-old when asked how he thought he could help in the war. Said another youngster between 12 and 14: "I would like to be a messenger, but they say I'm not old enough."

LONDON, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Martial law was proclaimed in Sofia, Bulgaria, today during a round-up of 500 "Communists," including one said to have dropped into the city by parachute, a D.N.B. (German official news agency) broadcast reported.

The raft on which Captain Eddie Rickenbacker and his comrades drifted for twenty-four days before they were finally rescued received its buoyancy from a small steel bottle of carbon dioxide -- the same gas that makes ginger ale fizz. The turn of a valve on the carbon-dioxide bottle transforms the raft into a seaworthy boat, capable of carrying five men -- all in a matter of seconds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- If every American worker will increase his output by 15 per cent it will go "a long way toward solving the manpower problem," Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, suggested tonight in a Pearl Harbor anniversary statement.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Confronted with their most difficult decisions in twenty-five years, athletic directors and faculty representatives of the Big Ten will ponder the fate of sports in the conference for the duration of the war at their annual Winter meetings Tuesday and Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, by his selection of Secretary Wickard as Supreme Commander of the nation's food front, placed that assignment in the hands of a real dirt farmer.
Four new films will make their Broadway bows during the week. The schedule follows:

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES in Papua, Dec. 4 (delayed) -- In a jungle in the forward area a group of American doctors and their assistants are operating a field hospital after making a thirty-eight-day trek over the Owen Stanley Mountains carrying much of their equipment for the hospital on their own backs.

Meat in Great Britain is rationed on a value basis, not by the point system. The ration has been 23 cents a week for adults (half as much for children under 5 years of age since July, 1942, and under 6 years of age before that date) since July 7, 1941; prior to that time the ration was somewhat higher.

Ships are a key to victory in this war; to keep them moving over the great expanses of the seven seas is the one major task that cannot be subordinated to any other. Yet there is not an adequate appreciation of the menace that the German submarine campaign means.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- America's twin-engined P-38 Lightning fighter plane, capable of blasting a tank on the ground a mile away, has met the test of action over Tunisia, in the Southwest Pacific and among the Aleutians and "has lived up to its name," Lieut. Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, Deputy Chief of Staff of the United States Army, made known in a "labor for-victory" radio program broadcast from the national capital today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The dominant note in America's war effort is unity, "unity of our people and the unity of the United Nations," President Roosevelt said in a letter made public today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears hammered the Chicago Cardinals, 21 to 7, today and pointed for their championship play-off with the Washington Redskins next Sunday with their first unbeaten, untied record for the regular National Football League season in eight years.

With the abrupt withdrawal on Saturday night of "R.U.R." from the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, the number of Broadway departures last week was increased to three. The revival of Karel Capek's play, "R.U.R." (the initials stand for Rossum's Universal Robots).

Preaching against bingo in churches, the Rev. Dr. L. Wendell Fifield, minister of Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday morning cited Christ's driving of the money changers out of the temple as an example of "what would happen" were Jesus "to chance upon a bingo game in a modern church."

The upswinging Giants ended what had started to be a very dismal season on a high note before 27,449 spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday as they vanquished the Dodgers for the first time in their last five tries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A "Kaiser case" which has just been disclosed in the railroad industry may cause as great a repercussion among rival railway brotherhoods as its counterpart is causing to affiliates of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations over certain legal rights in three West Coast shipyards.

All men, whether citizens or aliens, who have reached or will reach their eighteenth birthdays between June 30 and Dec. 31, 1942, must register for Selective Service. Those whose birthdays occurred in July and August must register between next Friday and Dec. 17; those whose birthdays were in September and October must register between Dec. 18 and 24, and those whose birthdays fall in November and December must register between Dec. 26 and 31.

Twenty-five service flags, each studded with stars representing members of congregations affiliated with the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues, were massed yesterday at a special service at the Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Farm and food leaders tonight greeted the appointment of Secretary Wickard as food administrator with enthusiasm and pledged their support.

A crowd of 4,000 turned out yesterday to celebrate the opening of the new soccer field at Starlight Park. The two Bronx clubs, the New York Americans and the Brookhattans, who will jointly occupy these grounds, battled to a 0 -- 0 tie in their American League encounter.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 6 -- The close of the first year of war finds the United States Pacific Fleet looking toward operations in Japan's home waters, and the early achievement of this aim depends upon the speed of the production program, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, indicated at a press conference on the eve of the anniversary of the Pearl Harbor attack of Dec. 7, 1941.

Speaking at the annual commemoration of the anniversary of the birth of Joyce Kilmer, soldierpoet who wrote "Trees" and was killed in action in the Aisne-Marne offensive in the first World War, James E. McCabe, chairman of the Americanism committee of the State Department of the American Legion, yesterday urged a tripled war effort for victory of the United Nations.

October shipments of all types of hosiery, amounting to 13,011,889 dozen pairs as compared with 14,977,350 dozens in the 1941 month, showed a decrease of 13.1 per cent, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. Of this total, women's hosiery, both full-fashioned and seamless, accounted for 768,400 dozens.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York observed two anniversaries, a day in advance, yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The first was the 100th anniversary of the society's first concert. The other was the first anniversary of Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 6 -- The battle in the Stalingrad area has developed into four main Russian offensives as follows:

A year of American participation in global war ended yesterday, with almost 1,000,000 men of the armed forces of the United States scattered across the world from the jungles of the Solomons to the glaciers of Greenland.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Announcement that the government would support the market for hogs at a minimum price of $13.25 a hundredweight here until September, 1944, is regarded by brokers as indicating that hopes of a revival of trading in lard futures will have to be abandoned unless there is a drastic revision in ceiling prices.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 6 -- Field Marshal Hermann Goering, Commander in Chief of the German Air Force, arrived in Rome this afternoon after a long inspection trip through southern Italian and Sicilian aerial bases. Accompanied by a numerous suite, the marshal is traveling with his own personal armored train, which is equipped with three batteries of heavy-caliber anti-aircraft guns.

War materiel is now pouring out of American armament factories at more than four times the rate of a year ago, the National Association of Manufacturers said yesterday as it released a sixty-four-page illustrated booklet entitled "One Year After Pearl Harbor -- America's War Production Record."

On leave from his duties as chaplain in the United States Navy, the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, returned to his pulpit yesterday morning and urged his congregation to maintain the same trust in God as those in the armed forces have shown.

HEADQUARTERS UNITED STATES ARMY, Hawaii, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- The Japanese will attack Pearl Harbor again, but next time they will be repulsed with disastrous losses, Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, commander of the Army's Hawaiian Department, forecast tonight.

One of Harcourt, Brace's first 1943 releases will be a new book by Albert Rhys Williams. This is called "The Russians: The Land, the People and Why They Fight." Mr. Williams has done a number of books on Russia, among them "The Soviets," a biography of Lenin and an account of the revolution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Enough wheat to feed Europe for a year, 1,000,000,000 bushels, is at Herbert H. Lehman's disposal in United States and Canadian warehouses as the former New York Governor digs into his new job as Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, a post in which he may take a part in reshaping the economy of the whole world.

On last week's stock market prices recovered slowly; at one time regaining the greater part of the loss incurred after Nov. 9. In this it resembled the week before Pearl Harbor; but on the Sunday news of that disaster, the stock average fell 5 1/4 points, and went lower still before the year-end.

Stranded for several hours during a business trip beside a much-traveled New England highway, yet one with rather limited bus service, I passed part of the time making a traffic count, noting especially the automobiles with unoccupied seat spaces. These proved by tally to be passing at the rate of about three a minute.

One silver lining to the cloud of wartime ecoonmies is the disappearance of the fancy package. Time was when the first hint of Christmas in the air precipitated a flurry of satin trappings, tinsel and tulle.

TANGIER, Spanish Morocco, Dec. 5 (Delayed) -- Interned in Spanish Morocco with some companions after their plane had made a forced landing in neutral territory, A.W. Osmond of Falls Church, Va., a United States Army parachutist and private first class, reflected today on the bad luck that overtook him just when he was looking forward to some action in Africa.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The City Affairs Committee, which usually has endorsed Mayor La Guardia's policies, took issue yesterday with his contention that Federal power would encroach upon local autonomy if the War Labor Board took jurisdiction over the controversy between the Transport Workers Union and the Board of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Nov. 28 to Dec. 4 are given in the appended tabulation:

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 -- After rioting in which Japanese-Americans were beaten up and a hospital, police station and camp police were attacked, the Manzanar Reception Center for Japanese in Inyo County has been put under military law.

The future of America as a great nation lies in the sanctification of its homes, Mgr. Philip J. Furlong, principal of Cardinal Hayes High School, declared yesterday in the second in a series of Advent sermons at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6 -- Efforts of Republican party chieftains to prevent a bruising, intraparty struggle for chairman of the National Committee appeared near failure late tonight.

No word in common use has about it such an aura of mystical significance, of true sacredness, as has the word freedom, the Rev. Samuel M Shoemaker, the rector, declared in a sermon yesterday in Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

Bruno Walter will conduct Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro" for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday night, Dec. 16, it was announced yesterday with the release of the repertoire for the fourth week of the season.

Germany's situation today is parallel to her status early in 1918 and it is quite likely that the war in Europe may end during 1943, Sava Kosanovich, Minister of the Yugoslav Government in Exile, told 1,000 persons gathered yesterday in Manhattan Center to commemorate the twenty-fourth anniversary of Yugoslavia's Unity Day.

Wars and other disasters bring together in a common job people who wouldn't otherwise know much about each other or who might not otherwise get on well together. Pearl Harbor, which was at once a disaster and the beginning of a war, did this for the United States.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6 -- Orson Welles accepted his first straight screen acting engagement yesterday when Twentieth Century-Fox signed him to play Rochester in Aldous Huxley's film adaptation of Charlotte Bronte's "Jane Eyre."
NEW DELHI, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A British communique:

In our school days we were taught to estimate the distance of the lightning bolt by the time between its flash and the sound of the accompanying roll of thunder. The modern combat airplane is now so highly developed that it could cover such a distance in approximately the same time as it took the reverberation of the lightning discharge to reach our ears.

Samuel Reshevsky, playing the black pieces in the sixth game of his United States chess championship match with Isaac I. Kashdan at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, broke the continuous series of successes for white by drawing a hard-fought encounter after 39 moves.

ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- The Emergency Council of Food and Drug Officials of the Northeastern States will open here tomorrow a special three-day "war training institute" for food and drug officials of eight Northeastern States. The institute's principal purpose is to train the chief personnel in "the art of handling food and drug supplies during and subsequent to any war emergencies such as bombing, gas attack, sabotage and fire."

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 6 -- Allied war planes of the Middle East Command have not slackened in their attacks on Tunisia and Tripolitania. During the past two days they raided Tripoli Harbor and the dock area near Tunis.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Governmental agencies in Washington are providing an intellectual safety net for the American woman who is forced to swing on the wartime mental trapeze of running a home.

Instructions have already been sent out to all local Selective Service boards to stop the induction of men who have passed their thirty-eighth birthday, in accordance with the President's executive order, it was revealed yesterday by an official of the local Selective Service System.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Outside interest in corn has increased considerably as the result of independent strength shown in the cash market sales being made last week on the Board of Trade at the highest price in five years for the yellow variety, while the white kind was only slightly below its high record, established several months ago.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- _An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Two young men from Orange, N.J., who were friends in civil life and who joined the Army the same day, trained and fought in the same unit, were wounded in the same engagement and are now lying side by side at Walter Reed General Hospital here, both proud possessors of the Purple Heart, it was disclosed today by the War Department.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 6 -- Steel ingot output last week again remained unchanged at 99.5 per cent of rated capacity, and the more or less comfortable position with respect to scrap supplies would indicate substantially the same activity this week.

George S. Van Schaick, regional director of the Office of Civilian Defense, said yesterday in a letter to Mayor La Guardia that repeal of the city's ordinance requiring stirrup pumps as essential defense equipment for dwellings and other buildings "would be an unfortunate step backward in this country's efforts to prepare for the possibility of attack."

Westchester has just emerged with dignity from the trials of its first deer hunting season since 1928, during which the metropolitan press did its best by sly innuendo and otherwise to have some fun with the county's archers.

WITH THE ALLIED ARMY, Near Djedeida, Tunisia, Dec. 2 (Delayed) -- With a rumble and roar a strong force of United States tanks, motorized artillery and infantry, protected by a full squadron of Spitfires, smashed into a German sector this morning in a counterstroke designed to end three days of confused but furious fighting in this hotly disputed area.

Demands of war, especially government financing and government taxes, have dominated the stock markets of the country since the attack on Pearl Harbor a year ago. Business on the New York Stock Exchange, save for unusual activity in the revivified rails, has been slack.

The United States Steel Corporation is expanding its plants at a cost of more than $700,000,000, about two-thirds of which is for the account of the United States Government, Irving S. Olds, chairman, said yesterday in reviewing the accomplishments of his company in the first year of the war.

Taking exception to reports that there is a serious rise in juvenile delinquency as a result of the war, Justice Anna Kross of the Magistrate's Court contended yesterday at a meeting of the New York Metropolitan Section of the National Jewish Welfare Board at the Hotel New Yorker, that "at present we are not inundated in crime."
BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- The Bruins took full advantage of a penalty and scored twice within forty-one seconds to defeat the New York Rangers, 5 -- 4, tonight before a crowd of 12,000 at the Boston Garden.

In the mailbag containing outdoor notes of various kinds is the report from Frank C. Bellrose Jr., Illinois Natural History Survey game technician, who announces that the ducks are moving south for new feeding grounds.

The annual memorial service for members of the Episcopal Actors' Guild who died during the last year was held yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner), 1 East Twenty-ninth Street. Channing Pollock made a brief address and read the names of those who have died.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Chicago's Black Hawks took over undisputed first place in the National Hockey League tonight before a stadium crowd of 12,560 by defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 5 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Secretary Wickard, under the new powers vested in him today, takes over from the WPB final authority over food rationing. As chairman of the WPB Food Requirements Com mittee, now abolished, he had a large voice in establishment of present food rationings and no change of policy is expected in connection with rationing of sugar and coffee nor in the plans to ration meat.

Until advised otherwise by the War Department, the city will continue with its present system of air raid warnings, despite orders from Major Gen. William N. Haskell, State Director of Civilian Protection, establishing a different procedure, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio "Talk to the People" from his desk at City Hall.

STOCKKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 6 -- Soviet airplanes disturbed the Helsinki celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Finnish independence. An alarm sounded at noon, wherefore a jubilee service at the cathedral had to be canceled and a minor ceremony substituted in underground premises.
Contributions to the United Service Organizations War Fund have reached a total of $30,166,538, it was announced yesterday by Prescott S. Bush, national campaign chairman.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Spreading operations between December and May grain contracts and liquidation by holders of December futures on the Board of Trade last week resulted in the largest aggregate business in more than seven months.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 111.8 on Nov. 24. This compares with 111.9 a fortnight before, 111.7 a month before, 107.4 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Hedging sales of oats, presumably against purchase of Canadian grain, tended last week to hold the price of that grain in check on the Board of Trade and the close yesterday was 1 1/4 cents a bushel higher to 3/4 cent lower for the week, the former on December, in which there is now a relatively small open interest.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Stock markets remain in the subdued and cautious mood that developed almost immediately after the activity and buoyancy that preceded and momentarily accompanied the Allied occupation of North Africa. Daily business markings show that the turnover has dwindled to the lowest level since the events of Toulon, while Prime Minister Winston Churchill's further broadcast review of the war situation evoked little or no response.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The speech that Queen Wilhelmina delivered today to her subjects in the Netherlands and overseas, promising that upon liberation of her territories she would convoke a kind of imperial council to adapt "the structure of the kingdom" to the "changed circumstances" of the times, was described in Netherland circles here as a contribution to the definition of United Nations war aims so often urged lately in this country and in Britain.
Food is on hand for holiday feasting -- to make Christmas jolly in your own household and those of your friends.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has denied a petition of the National Power and Light Company for an extension until Feb. 15 of its plan for exchanging each share of its $6 preferred stock for two common shares of the Houston Lighting and Power Company.

The American Actors Company opened up its fifth season on Saturday night by producing another drama by its favorite playwright, Horton Foote, the minnesinger of Texan morals, attitudes and family life. Mr. Foote can always be counted upon to have some ideas in his plays, and that also is true of his "Only the Heart," which is the fourth to be offered by the group.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Japan's maritime strength has been cut to within a few thousand tons short of desperately impairing her extended lines of communication and supply, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox has written in an article to be published in the forthcoming issue of The Army and Navy Journal, it was disclosed tonight.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 6 -- Albert H. Morehead of New York was elected president of the American Contract Bridge League and chairman of its executive committee at the annual meeting of the members today. Mr. Morehead is bridge writer of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Because of the wartime shortage butter has been eliminated from the menus of all city institutions except hospitals, and in those its use has been cut drastically, with little assurance that sufficient supplies will be available in the future, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio "Talk to the People" from City Hall.

For some time it has been apparent that the two great problems of manpower and food could not much longer be left to the overlapping and conflicting jurisdictions of different agencies and branches of the Government. Strong, centralized control of each is needed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The text of President Roosevelt's Executive Order "delegating authority with respect to the nation's food program" follows:
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 6 -- Bachelors, widowers and childless couples of Bulgaria are to be taxed for the support of large families under a new State program to halt the decline of the birth rate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- President Roosevelt tonight named Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard Food Administrator, with orders to "assume full responsibility for and control over the nation's food program."

Japan marked the eve of the surprise attack on Pearl Harbor by a steady flow of broadcasts, recorded in this country yesterday, designed to show the Japanese people that they were the innocent victims of a war plot hatched by the United States and Britain.

The drive by the city administration against suggestive stage shows received support yesterday from the churches of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn when pastors of all the churches within the diocese read a letter to their parishioners from Bishop Thomas E. Molloy condemning the "glorification of licentiousness and of crime."

LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A cordial exchange of messages between United States Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander in Chief in French North Africa, and French Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, with mutual good wishes for victory and the resurrection of France, was reported tonight by the Morocco radio.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 7 -- Virtually all of the London newspapers this morning hail the recovery the United States Navy has made since the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor a year ago, and are high in their praises of the manner in which the United States has geared itself to war, both in fighting power and on the home production front, within the last twelve months.

Approximately 70 per cent of the nation's advertising clubs just surveyed by the Advertising Federation of America report they are organized -- several with 100 per cent enrollment of memberships -- in war advertising committees. The various groups indicated they were contributing the talents of members in the promotion of not simply one, but two, three, five or seven important war projects.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 -- Passage by the House of a bill to in clude costs of farm labor in the calculation of parity prices for agricultural commodities was chief in a series of bullish developments last week which contributed to advances of $1.60 to $2 a bale in cotton futures here.
MOSOCOW, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Interest of buyers continued last week to center upon getting delivery of holiday goods in time, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The St. Mary's College Gaels defeated the University of Detroit Titans, 2 -- 0, today in a football game witnessed by only 500 fans.

Germain Glidden of the Englewood Field Club, who held the national championship for three years in a row, beat the present champion, Charles Brinton of Philadelphia, three games out of four, in the final of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's invitation "combination" tournament at the Yale Club yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 6 -- The first anniversary of the Japanese attack that brought war to this continent will be fittingly remembered in Buenos Aires tomorrow by means of a great public meeting wherein the people of this capital will express their admiration of and devotion to President Roosevelt.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Born of necessity during a war that has seen airpower as a major factor in battle for the first time, the aircraft carrier Belleau Wood was launched here today on a day strangely reminiscent of that fateful Sunday almost a year ago that will "live in infamy."

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- A new organization to deal exclusively with the U-boat menace has been formed under the personal supervision of Prime Minister Churchill, with Sir Stafford Cripps as his deputy, it was disclosed by Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts of South Africa in a recorded broadcast to the empire given in a British Broadcasting Company program tonight.

A request that war price and rationing boards meet evenings in this city was sent to Leon Henderson, chief of the Office of Price Administration, by the Greater New York Industrial Council, C.I.O., yesterday. Saul Mills, council secretary, wrote to Mr. Henderson that the practice of the local boards of meeting only during daytime business hours made it impossible for workers to take up their problems with the boards without losing time from their jobs.

As production figures climb steadily in the huge aircraft plants of the Pacific Coast and the mid-continent and in the automotive plants now fabricating parts and engines, the close cooperation of the airplane and the automobile industries becomes increasingly apparent.

Our religious faith must preserve us from an easy optimism as well as from a paralyzing pessimism, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, declared in a sermon yesterday.

A UNITED STATES HEAVY BOMBER BASE, in North Africa, Dec. 4 (Delayed) -- American four-engined Consolidated bombers hurled 100,000 pounds of explosives into Naples harbor at dusk tonight and, from a vantage point in one of the planes, I saw our bombs directly hit or only narrowly miss a half dozen Italian battleships, cruisers and destroyers.

Unconditional surrender by the Axis countries and their complete disarmament in order to make them militarily impotent forever was advocated last night by Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska as the first step that the United Nations must insist upon if a permanent peace is to be established by the democracies after the war.

Miss Marilyn Sahner of the Women's Swimming Association, holder of the national 100-yard free-style championship, captured the 100 yesterday in the London Terrace pool in the annual event for the Charlotte Epstein Memorial Trophy. Miss Sahner scored easily in 1:06.6.

The city's funded debt, which has been steadily rising in recent years, was reduced by $33,088,148 in the fiscal year ended June 30, according to Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick's annual consolidated report, made public yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 (AP) -- It looks like anybody's game, that Southern California-U.C.L.A. affair Saturday for the Rose Bowl nomination.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Fliers of eight Allied nations struck the enemy hard in Nazi-occupied France and the Netherlands today with the greatest daylight bombing offensive of the war.

The thirty-first annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York started yesterday with a total of $15,819.73 in contributions from 122 donors. While the greater part of this total came from trust funds set up for the Neediest through the years, there were some gifts from members of the armed forces who had not forgotten and many from old friends who see the work of the fund enhanced by war conditions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Unfavorable weather conditions resulted in little progress in corn husking and soy bean combining last week. The more northern sections of the main producing areas were under a blanket of snow.

The Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at 108.5 for the fourth consecutive week. Although there were fractional advances in the miscellaneous and in the fuel and lighting groups, the declines in the farm products and foodstuffs groups were large enough to hold the index at the same level as in the preceding week.

Rather than face possible court action and the subsequent closing of another theatre, Lee Shubert on Saturday ordered the closing next Saturday of "Native Son," Paul Green and Richard Wright's drama of Negro life now playing at the Majestic Theatre, it became known yesterday.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES IN PAPUA, Dec. 4 -- (delayed) -- The Japanese have made virtual fortresses out of a number of strong points in the Buna-Gona area and this, in a large measure, explains their ability to hold out against the concerted attack that the American and Australian troops have been making for the last two weeks.

MOSCOW, Monday, Dec. 7 -- Smashing as many as twenty desperate German counter-attacks in one day, Russian soldiers captured four Nazi strong points west of Rzhev yesterday while their companions pushed ahead in the Velikiye Luki area and southwest of Stalingrad over the bodies of hundreds of Germans, the Russians announced today.

Lawson Purdy, who is distressed over incorrect usage of the word "like," has my undying sympathy. But I, for one, have long ago given up the fight to preserve either the sense or the pronunciation of many words. It cannot be done in the spoken language.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Japanese bombers and fighters raided the Chittagong area on the Bay of Bengal yesterday, causing slight damage and light casualties, while the Royal Air Force struck at two enemy points in Burma, a British communique announced today.
HAVANA, Dec. 6 -- President Fulgencio Batista will fly to Miami tomorrow and continue to Washington, where he will be the guest of President Roosevelt.

Repeated attacks by tank-supported Russian troops on an im portant river position in the big bend of the Don were warded off, the German High Command reported yesterday, according to a broadcast recorded by The United Press.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines tonight called upon his countrymen to have faith that the United States is not neglecting them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A band of the Marine Corps' grimmest killers -- tough, jungle-hardened raider troops -- wiped out five Japanese bases and 400 men on Guadalcanal Island and lost only seventeen of their own number in doing the job, the Navy announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Presidential order naming Paul V. McNutt as manpower dictator of the United States is expected to have the effect of a new broom, sweeping Capitol Hill clean, temporarily at least, of the various legislative proposals and theories for manpower control which had arisen in recent months when public concern over delay in handling the problem was mounting.

DETROIT, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings came from behind in the second period to battle the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 2-to-2 tie in a National Hockey League game tonight before an overflow crowd of 13,772. Alex Motter's 45-foot shot squared the count and there was no scoring in the last period.

In honoring the heroism of war we must not forget the valor of peace, for the one comes out of the other. In reading the records of the Hundred Neediest Cases, for which THE TIMES is now making its thirty-first annual appeal, one comes again and again on instances of courage which deserve a medal of honor.

The spiritual lessons of the year since Pearl Harbor were expounded yesterday from Catholic, Protestant and Jewish pulpits throughout the city. Chaplains with the armed forces also held Pearl Harbor services.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that through a voluntary agreement the six big manufacturers of glycerine would reduce their price 1 cent a pound on all sales to the government. This will result in considerable saving on glycerine, a vital ingredient of ammunition and other military supplies.

Increased price-fixing orders, stimulated chiefly by the probability that costs of farm labor soon will be written into the parity formula for agricultural commodities, improved values in the cotton futures market last week. At the end of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange on Saturday active contracts showed net gains of 26 to 46 points, or $1.30 to $2.30 a bale, for the period.
Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, hailed the "Fighting Jews" last night as counterparts of the fighting units of all other groups allied in the United Nations.

ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- New York State needs 1,867 more nurses, according to Miss Emily J. Hicks, executive secretary of the New York State Nursing Council for War Services, in an appeal for young women to take nursing courses to aid in the war effort.

America's goal in the war was discussed yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman at the dedication of a new service men's canteen operated by the National Catholic Community Service at 17 East Fifty-first Street.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The present boom for a better Britain after the war was marked by two developments today. Sir William Beveridge packed the Oxford Town Hall with the largest crowd that it had seen in many years and Clement R. Attlee, Deputy Prime Minister, in an address at Wakefield, asserted that the Labor party would not shrink from assuming its share of the responsibility for changes.

The program of the New Friends of Music concert given late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall was presented by the Musical Art Quartet and Bronislaw Hubermann, violinist. The major part of the concert was given over to Mr. Hubermann's performances of two Bach works for unaccompanied violin, the Sonata, No. 1, in G minor, and the Partita, No. 2, in D minor.

LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Creation of a post-war Netherlands "Commonwealth" whose four parts would be independent in internal affairs but combined by "readiness to render mutual assistance" was visualized by Queen Wilhelmina today in a broadcast address on the eve of the first anniversary of the outbreak of war in the Pacific.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Retail sales in Britain in October showed a rise of 9.2 per cent from those in October, 1941.
The New York Telephone Company will begin today distributing some 616,000 copies of its new December, 1942, Manhattan telephone directory to subscribers in Manhattan.
MOSCOW, Monday, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Violent fighting in the Djedeida-Tebourba-Mateur triangle between Bizerte and Tunis -- the immediate objectives of Allied operations in Northeastern Tunisia -- was in progress today, according to an unofficial report broadcast tonight by the Morocco radio and heard in London.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Chinese Embassy announced today that Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, who is undergoing hospital treatment in this country, is making satisfactory progress.

BEHIND THE RUSSIAN LINES, ON THE CENTRAL FRONT, Dec. 6 -- The main burden of responsibility for the re-establishment of order in territory regained from the Germans falls on local Communist party organizations. They take over from the military and with Red Army help build up a strong hinterland behind the front.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- Allied troops have broken through to the beach east of Buna village on the northeastern New Guinea coast, isolating a Japanese pocket of resistance, the Allied command announced today.

That Lotte Lehmann's hold on the public is as strong as ever after a decade of appearances here was evidenced by the size and enthusiasm of her audience at her recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The passing years have not robbed her in the slightest of her warmth of temperament, or diminished the spontaneity of her singing, and today as heretofore, she occupies a niche of her own in the vocal field.
