LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The mystery surrounding the whereabouts of Admiral Jean de da Borde, who disappeared after the French fleet had been scuttled at Toulon, seemed to have been cleared up today when the Vichy radio broadcast an announcement that the Commander in Chief of French naval forces had been released, at the request of the Vichy Government, from the jail where he had been held by the German authorities.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The mystery surrounding the whereabouts of Admiral Jean de da Borde, who disappeared after the French fleet had been scuttled at Toulon, seemed to have been cleared up today when the Vichy radio broadcast an announcement that the Commander in Chief of French naval forces had been released, at the request of the Vichy Government, from the jail where he had been held by the German authorities.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- One American marine who took part in the recent fighting at Guadalcanal was a 13-year-old Eau Claire (Wis.) boy who had concealed his age in enlisting, a Chicago mother has revealed.

American eyes turn to the Pacific today. They turn to the past. As they reconstruct the story of Pearl Harbor in the light of the facts at last made public, it is even more shocking in retrospect than it seemed a year ago -- not because the damage was so great, not because we were caught completely off guard, but because the full story shows more clearly than ever that it was an unnecessary disaster.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 6 -- Harold McSpaden of Philadelphia put on the pressure under fire today to card a triumphant last-round 66 and snatch the biggest golf prize of the Winter -- the $1,000 first money in the Miami open tournament.

After fifty-seven years in the Wendel estate, the vacant plot, 50 by 80 feet, at 405-7 Grand Street and 165 Clinton Street has been sold by the Wendel Foundation to the 405 Grand Street Corporation. The Cross Brown Company was the broker.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 6 -- Charles Seymour, president of Yale University, in his annual report to the alumni, issued a warning today that although it is our primary and immediate duty to win the war, it is also a national obligation to keep intact the educational institutions which are the guardians of the culture and traditions upon which the nation is founded.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 7 -- Alvin Roth of Washington and Tobias Stone of New York City won the national contract bridge pair championship here tonight, bringing to a close the tournament which has been in progress since Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Even greater support for the Red Cross blood plasma project during the coming year was asked today by the Army and Navy.

A post-war "association" of the United Nations, as "vitally necessary for the safety of our own nation" and as insurance against another war was envisioned yesterday by Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 6 -- Don Hutson, Green Bay's great end, kicked a 28-yard field goal from a difficult angle today to provide the winning points as the Packers defeated Pittsburgh, 24 to 21, in the season's final National Football League game here.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 6 -- The Danish army has now had to deliver to the Germans on the Eastern front all woolen blankets that "it does not need itself," after a curt demand from General Hermann von Hanneken, commanding the troops of occupation, according to advices received here through private channels.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 7 -- Anson Kurtz's Thrift Shop, claimed during the Rockingham meeting for $1,000, won for the second time in two attempts for his new owner when he led every step of the journey to score by a length over H.G. Bedwell's Ginoca in the mile and one-sixteenth sixth race, feature event at this track today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Optimism and confidence over the condition and future of American agriculture prevailed at the opening today of the annual American Farm Bureau Federation convention.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell, State Director of Civilian Protection, bluntly told the Army today that it had no business advising Mayor La Guardia not to change the air raid warning signal system in New York City, as prescribed by a recent order of the State War Council.

With butter supplies dwindling alarmingly in groceries all over the country, more and more housekeepers are turning to margarine in the hope that it will prove a satisfactory substitute. Many of them hope blindly, for although they have heard of this shortening, they do not know what it actually is.

More than 80 per cent of the total output of the folding paper box industry is now going to the Army, Navy, lend-lease and the food industry, N.A. Rothstein, Eastern representative of the Folding Paper Box Association of America, reported yesterday at a luncheon on packaging problems of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- German authorities have executed thirty-six Czech and Yugoslav patriots on charges of treason and sabotage, including a former leader of the Czech liberation movement, Jan Sykora, reports from the Continent said today.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The Marquess of Linlithgow has agreed to continue as Viceroy of India for an additional six months, according to an announcement from 10 Downing Street tonight.

Federal officials are studying the conflict between city defense officials and Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell, State Director of Civilian Protection, over air raid warning signals, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A communique:

Observances of the anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor continued throughout the city yesterday with a rally of war workers at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, a pause of a minute's silence in the city's public schools and gatherings for the sale of war bonds.

Distribution of coat and suit labels in the metropolitan area continued high last week, the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board stated yesterday. The total was 295,000, or a gain of 67.2 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago. Label sales in November far exceeded that for other years.

"Jacare," a feature-length adventure picture filmed by Clyde E. Elliott in the jungles of the Amazon River last Winter and Spring, will have its local premiere at the Globe Theatre on Saturday, Dec. 26, it was announced yesterday by United Artists, the distributors.

Steel operations for the current week have been set at 98.6 per cent of capacity, slightly ahead of the 98.3 per cent operations in each of the two preceding weeks, and steel output in November was 7,184,560 net tons, the largest for any thirty-day month on record, according to announcements by the American Iron and Steel Institute yesterday.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- A witness for the State testified today that Samuel Nuzzo, former business agent of Local 17 of the International Hodcarriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, "cleaned out" the files of his office last February when he learned that an investigation was impending.

BUFFALO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Buffalo probation officer cited today "fabulous wages for young people who are getting more money than is good for them," among new causes of increasing juvenile delinquency.

UNITED STATES HEADQUARTERS, Guadalcanal, Nov. 27 delayed) (U.P.) -- Father Albert De Theye told today how two Roman Catholic priests and two nuns were slain by Japanese on Gaudalcanal because the priests refused to carry a propaganda message to the American marine commander, Major Gen. A.A. Vandergrift.

George L. Berry, president of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants' Union, announced yesterday that by referendum vote the union membership has again approved renewal of the arbitration agreement between the union and the American Newspaper Publishers Association, which has been in operation for thirty-six years throughout the United States and Canada.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Britain sent out a "strong force" -- indicated as many more than 100 -- of heavy bombers last night and pounded objectives in Southwestern and Western Germany on the Nazis' supply route to Italy and North Africa.

Wage increases amounting to almost $2,000,000 a year for 15,000 employes of the Department of Hospitals have been agreed upon informally by representatives of the city and Federal officials under James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, it was learned last night.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 7 -- Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador, tonight made a strong plea for unity and understanding between the people of this country and his, warning that the Axis was using propaganda as a weapon to drive them apart.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Representative Hartley, New Jersey Republican, told the House today that the War Labor Board was "the most biased judge and packed jury ever to be inflicted upon the American people."
The statement by Secretary of the Navy Knox that Japan's merchant shipping has been seriously hurt by the ravages of war again emphasizes the importance of ship construction and ship destruction.

Christmas will still be Christmas, of course, but this year Americans accustomed to the profusion of holly, evergreen, tinsel and candy canes accompanying it may have a chance to reappraise the holiday. Some of the trimmings will be missing and those not on the absentee list will be spread about thinner than in other years.

While - thousand persons took time out from their lunches and shivered in the cold, speakers outlined the strides taken by the Red Cross since Pearl Harbor at a rally yesterday on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The nation's farm women were called upon today to play a major part in meeting the wartime goals of nearly 4,800,000,000 dozen eggs and 4,000,000,000 pounds of chicken meat next year.

Working with a small squad is not a novel experience for Nat Holman. Apparently, the tall fellows who have basketball ability just don't go to C.C.N.Y. Holman, however, is used to that. For the past twenty-three years he's been doing the best he could with the material on hand.

The Pierpont Morgan Library at Madison Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street has liberalized its rules to allow the admission of the general public without special permission, and in return the city has withdrawn its opposition to the exemption of the library from taxation, it was revealed yesterday in a consent judgment signed by Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch.
LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill declared today that the "storm which now lowers over Germany and Italy is spreading to Japan; there will be no softness or respite for her."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 7 -- Counsel for Mayor James J. Donovan and two other Bayonne officials indicted on charges of "misconduct in office" announced today that New York's Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine would be called to testify on Dec. 18.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Senator Reed of Kansas told the Senate today that the country faced "a bread shortage within thirty days" unless flour price ceilings were lifted.

Food trade spokesmen, who have been urging the appointment of an over-all food administrator, yesterday expressed general approval of the week-end developments by which Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard was named to the post, and indicated special satisfaction that the step was coupled with the appointment of a manpower director, Paul V. McNutt.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- New York City is scheduled to receive a "windfall" of several million dollars from the State, it became known today, as a result of the already noted rise in State revenues, which are helping produce the $75,000,000 State surplus scheduled to exist at the end of the current fiscal year.

ON THE GERMAN FRONTIER, Dec. 7 (Reuter) -- Intense German pressure is being applied to King Boris to suppress the growing agitation in Bulgaria against the country's attachment to a doubtful cause. This is the secret of mass arrests of Bulgarians which began over the weekend, say reports from Sofia.

A look at our cause in the Latin-American mirror yesterday was reassuring. Avowed friends of the United Nations in the Southern lands reaffirmed their faith in official messages, public meetings and church services. In the two countries which have not yet broken with the Axis there were encouraging gestures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- An estimated one million American soldiers serving overseas have, in the first year of this war, "played a far more important role in this conflict" than did the half-million soldiers sent to France in the first year of World War I, the Office of War Information said tonight in a summary of operations.
MOSCOW, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
Maine is the first State to announce some of the results of the recent deer season and if the Pine Tree Commonwealth is any barometer it appears that records tumbled wherever deer hunting was legal.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 7 -- Formal charges of espionage against six alleged Nazi agents and at least one member of the German Embassy staff were submitted today to the Supreme Court, which immediately took the case under its jurisdiction and began to examine evidence supplied by the Federal public prosecutor, Belisario Gache Piran, and Federal Judge Miguel Jantus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A net income of $1,000,000,000 for the railroads this year was forecast today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. Estimating the income at $707,000,000 for the first ten months, the commission said the total for twelve months would exceed $1,000,000,000 if the November and December increase over 1941 approximated that of October, which was 152 per cent. Net income is the sum left after interest, rentals and all taxes.

Railroad issues were sharply depressed yesterday on the move afoot in Washington to cancel rate and fare increases, and this setback produced an irregularly lower trend in the stock market. Both bonds and stocks of the carriers sold off from the start on the week-end request of the OPA that the I.C.C. eliminate the rise in rates granted earlier this year.
PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 7 (AP) -- The historic battleship Oregon, covered with rust and glory, was tossed on the scrap heap today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Words are a weapon of inestimable power in this war, Robert E. Sherwood, the playwright, who is Director of Overseas Operation of the Office of War Information, said in an article today in The Army and Navy Journal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Paul V. McNutt said today that his newly strengthened War Manpower Commission was prepared to "ration scarce labor where available manpower is insufficient to meet all competing demands."

Frank Le Voci, 27-year-old toolmaker, standing in front of 1,000 fellow employes of the Aero Spark Plug Corporation, 635 Greenwich Street, to receive a "certificate of individual production merit" for a spark plug gas setter he invented, said yesterday the praise should go to "all the fellows in the tool room."

Christmas trade here is now beginning to hit its stride. Gift shopping crowds last week-end were the heaviest of this holiday season and merchants yesterday expressed the belief that Yule trade is about to enter its peak period.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- Wendell Willkie, in an article written for The London Evening Standard, attacked "international censorship" today and charged that American censorship had prevented him from discussing Admiral Jean Francois Darlan's position in North Africa.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 7 -- The service of the churches in wartime ministry was stressed here today by Dr. Luther A. Weigle, president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court by 5 to 3 dismissed today an anti-trust suit brought by the Justice Department charging a group of companies with conspiracy to fix the prices and monopolize the sale of gasoline computer pumps which register the quantity and price of the product sold.

A Brooklyn detective, with four citations for bravery, was close to death last night because he questioned two suspicious-looking men who later became the quarry in one of the city's most dramatic running pistol fights since the prohibition era.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 7 -- British long-range fighters harried the North African coast yesterday from Tunisia to the Gulf of Sidra, attacking all types of targets.

The adherence of French West Africa, with its strategically important port of Dakar, to the pro-United Nations regime of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan was announced officially at Algiers last night by Lieut. Gen. Dwight Eisenhower, Allied Commander in Chief in French North Africa, according to broadcasts by the Algiers radio correspondents of the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company.
Weekly "consumption reports" to simplify the fuel oil problem for householders and to help them "budget" their rations were begun yesterday by OPA.

As a map published in this newspaper yesterday shows, the sun never sets on the new A.E.F. Our land, sea and air forces, in units ranging from armies to detachments, carrying on operations varying from guard duty on the Caribbean island of Aruba to guerrilla activities in the Philippines and major battles in Tunisia, are in sixty-five areas outside the continental United States.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Frederick H. Prince, Newport financier, and two Chicago stockyards companies of which he is the principal stockholder, today asked for dismissal of suits brought against them in Federal District Court here by the trustees of former stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Representative Philip A. Bennett of Missouri died of a heart ailment at Naval Hospital early today after suffering an attack on Saturday night. His age was 61. A first-term Republican, Mr. Bennett represented the Sixth Missouri District and lived at Springfield.

Commercial banks in this State have lost a third of their staffs during the year since Pearl Harbor, it was announced yesterday by the New York State Bankers Association, which just has completed a State-wide survey. Based on 557 replies from the 718 commercial member banks of the association, the losses are shown to be 10,180 employes out of the original staffs aggregating 34,000.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Morocco radio said today that fighting was in progress at Mateur as well as Tebourba. Reuter said that commandos of Lieut. Gen. K.A.N. Anderson's British First Army had landed behind German lines and cut a coastal road after a seven-mile advance inland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Chewing gum is moving off retail counters faster than manufacturers can produce and distribute it, John M. Whittaker, chief of the confectionery section of the War Production Board, said today. He was discussing the shortage of chewing gum which is prevailing despite the fact that 1942 production almost equals the 1941 record output.
BOSTON, Dec. 7 -- Led by the launching of the new aircraft carrier Bunker Hill at Fore River, the shipyards of New England today emphatically marked the first anniversary of Pearl Harbor.

Fraud in the $250,000 bankruptcy of Strezou Brothers, fur manufacturers, formerly of 315 Seventh Avenue, was charged yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. George and Peter Strezou, brothers and partners in the firm since 1922, were arrested with five others, all on charges of violating the national bankruptcy act.
Elizabeth, Lady Cheylesmore, has come to the Savoy-Plaza from Tuxedo Park.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 7 -- America has been playing an increasingly important part in Mid dle East Arab affairs lately -- an interest reflected by President Roosevelt's sympathetic reference to the Arabs in his recent message addressed to General Nuri es-Said, Iraq's Premier, and the appointment of George Wadsworth as the first American diplomatic agent to Syria and Lebanon.
LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- An inquiry for foreign rails was the only thing of note in a generally quiet stock market today. Based on hopeful predictions by the chairman of the Buenos Aires Pacific and the payment of arrears on the Central Argentine 4 per cent debentures many ordinaries gained 1/4 point, while a number of prior charges were 1/2 to 1 point better.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The government won a marked, even if a temporary, victory today when the Court of Claims unanimously decided that the domestic air mail contracts were legally canceled nearly nine years ago and rejected claims of the United Air Lines Transport Corporation and two subsidiaries for almost $3,000,000.

Joseph Fuchs, New York violinist, made his first solo appearance in this city in more than fifteen years last night when he played the Brahms Violin Concerto at Carnegie Hall with the National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin as conductor, at its second Monday evening concert of the season.
AN EAST COAST PORT, Dec. 7 (AP) -- One hundred and thirty-five men are dead or missing after the daylight torpedoing of a United Nations ship early last month off South America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, as announced today by the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 2: A decrease of $1,372,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and increases of $1,782,000,000 in United States Government deposits, $256,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities, and $201,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Representatives of the "Big Five" railway brotherhoods, meeting in Chicago today, contended that the government's request Saturday for cancellation of rate increases granted early this year was a roundabout way of sidetracking their demands for higher wages.

Three small children who had been playing on the thin ice covering the artificial pool in Central Park, near West 101st Street, fell into the water when the ice cracked about 3 P.M. yesterday and were rescued from drowning by Patrolman Vincent Wood of the Arsenal Precinct, who was driving through the park on "summons duty" when he heard the children's screams.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The first year of war cost the United States armed forces 58,307 casualties, the Office of War Information reported today.

The Hanover Fire Insurance Company of New York filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission a petition yesterday asking for a modification of the plan for the reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company, approved by the commission on Oct. 6, in respect to the property of the Boston Providence Railroad Corporation.

An announcement by Japan, apparently for the first time, that she had added new "powerful" battleships to her fleet and a statement of Japanese naval losses -- the largest she has acknowledged to date -- were broadcast by the Tokyo radio yesterday and recorded here by The Associated Press.

Censorship of the stage, official or otherwise, suffered a setback on Broadway yesterday when Lee Shubert, controller and operator of the Majestic Theatre, rescinded his order closing the Negro drama "Native Son."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- October's rate of war production was up only 3 per cent compared with September, representing the smallest monthly increase this year, Donald M. Nelson disclosed today in a report in which he emphasized his disappointment at the showing for the month, and called for a sharp step up.

Glaring dental and other physical defects among the nation's manpower have been brought to light by Selective Service and there must be a post-war fitness program to correct such defects as far as possible, Dr. C. Raymond Wells, president-elect of the American Dental Association and chief dental officer of the Selective Service system, last night told the eighteenth annual Greater New York dental meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The morale of youth, "at least in Chicago and the Middle West, needs improvement," asserts Dr. Mandel Sherman of the University of Chicago, following an investigation of the attitudes of 7,000 youths in Chicago.

The charitable trust fund set up in the will of the late George F. Baker, banker and philanthropist, has distributed $1,667,000 to thirty-three organizations since the fund was declared valid last August by Surrogate James A. Foley, it was disclosed in an accounting filed yesterday by the trustees in Surrogate's Court.

The French Chamber of Commerce of the United States, headed by Pierre Cartier, will open today at its office, 4 East Fifty-second Street, a registry of Frenchmen in New York who are willing to accept such a regime as may be "officially recognized in North Africa in full accord with the American Government and also in accord with the French and native population of North Africa."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 7 -- The British Eighth Army offensive against the Agheila line is expected in Berlin to start at any moment, the Nazi-controlled S.T.B. News Agency reports.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull congratulated the American Foreign Service on its work the past year in Christmas messages published today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Selection of fifty-eight more workers, two of them women, to receive recognition for suggestions which help war production were announced tonight by the board for individual awards of the War Production Board.

Charging that Mayor La Guardia had instigated and conducted a "personal campaign" against them and that they could not receive a fair trial in Special Sessions, to which judges are appointed by the Mayor, Thomas J. Ryan and Alfred J. Goodman, arrested on gambling charges in a police raid on Oct. 1, asked the Supreme Court yesterday for a jury trial in General Sessions.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7 -- The Republican National Committee ended its most spirited party leadership contest in twenty-five years today by unanimously electing Harrison E. Spangler of Iowa as national chairman and dedicated itself on the anniversary of Pearl Harbor "to victory over our foreign enemies, to a just peace when war shall end and to the preservation of the Republic under our Constitution."

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Grains developed a reactionary tendency on the Board of Trade today after an early upturn had carried December wheat, oats and rye and December and May corn to new high prices since mid-August for the latter grain and since early in October for the others.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Sharp reductions in the volume of wooden pencils, fountain pens and mechanical pencils to be produced next year, was ordered by the War Production Board today. At the same time the war agency banned for the duration use of crude and reclaimed rubber for erasers on both wood case and mechanical type pencils.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, who last week assumed the title of "Chief of State in French Africa," retains sufficient influence in North Africa to hold up the long-projected broadcasts to Europe by the United States Office of War Information from the radio stations in those French colonies, it was learned authoritatively here tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- Anglo-American officials are working rapidly to relieve shortages of food and other essentials in North Africa and, as soon as military requirements permit, cargoes will begin to arrive at Moroccan and Algerian ports.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration authorized today a 1 cent per quart increase in the retail price of Grade A pasteurized milk in seven Western New York counties.
IT appears to this baffled bystander that the big league baseball magnates were forced to leave many of their problems on bases when they broke up their conference in Chicago.

ON Sept. 8, 1914. Melville Stone, general manager of The Associated Press, received a cablegram from La Nacion of Buenos Aires, asking for help in getting certain news from Europe. It seemed that the Havas news agency, which had a monopoly of the cable news to South America, had refused to forward from Paris the text of the German communiques on the war.

I am greatly concerned over the ungenerous criticism of our Ally, Great Britain, in its handling of the problem of India. It may weaken unity in the prosecution of this war and seriously endanger post-war collaboration. Malicious influences are at work to stir up distrust and dissension among the United Nations.

James Melton's name and voice have been known to the American public for a good many years as a result of his work in radio, concerts, records and the movies. If that public needs any further endorsement of his attainments, Mr. Melton provided it last night by becoming a member of the Metropolitan Opera Association in good standing.

Record breaking is an American habit, war or no war. A total of 141 marks was shattered this year, Dan Ferris announced yesterday, and these new figures will be submitted for acceptance or rejection to the delegates to the fifty-fourth annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union at Chicago on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt asked Americans today to commemorate this first anniversary of Pearl Harbor by resolving that "such a thing shall never happen again."

The anniversary of Pearl Harbor and our entrance into the war was primarily and inevitably an occasion for retrospect. Now we are entering our second year of the war, and without forgetting the lessons learned, or forgiving the crimes of our enemies, we can look forward with hope and confidence.

AT AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Nov. 21 (Delayed) -- Ten days ago from a hill 1,000 yards behind the front line on Guadalcanal I saw a skirmish line of marines advance across a ridge ahead of us and enter a heavily wooded ravine.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique:

Facing his thirteenth heavyweight battle of the year, Tami Mauriello, Bronx ring favorite, yesterday approached the end of training confident of his ability to conquer Lou Nova of California in their ten-round bout Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A deputy United States marshal and a guard tonight hustled off Howard Victor Broenstrup, 56, to Washington to face trial on a charge of seditious conspiracy in operations of the Silver Shirts, German-American Bund and other organizations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- High praise for Admiral Daniel J. Calaghan, former naval aide to President Roosevelt, who lost his life on the bridge of his flagship in action against the Japanese off Savo Island on Nov. 13, was spoken today by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York at a requiem mass in St. Matthew's Cathedral.

Samuel Goldstein, former assistant district attorney of Brooklyn, was exonerated yesterday by unanimous decision of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn of all charges of unprofessional conduct made against him by one of the extraordinary grand juries assisting Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's inquiry into alleged official corruption in Kings County.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Judge Michael L. Igoe in the Federal district court directed today a jury verdict of not guilty in behalf of four union officials, two contractors, two unions and one contracting firm charged with conspiracy in violation of the anti-trust laws.

S. Howard Cohen was nominated last night for another term as a commissioner of the Board of Elections at a meeting of the New York County Democratic Committee in Tammany Hall. The nomination now goes to the City Council which has the power of election.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today the Treasury had sold $5,586,000,000 in securities in the first five days of this month -- the largest amount ever disposed of in such a short period in Treasury history.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 7 -- Possibility of a big increase in the size of the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps was envisioned here today by Colonel Thomas Jones, chief apparel procurement officer, Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot, when he asked coat and suit manufacturers to bid for contracts even if they involve only small initial quantities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and affiliated subsidiaries failed today to obtain a Supreme Court review of a decision sustaining a $409,819 Federal income tax deficiency for 1930 as an outgrowth of the famous Teapot Dome oil leases.

Registrants who have reached the age of 38 on or before the date set for their induction will not be taken into military service, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City draft director, said yesterday, but men over 38 who have been inducted and are on their seven-day furloughs will have to report at Army reception centers when the furloughs expire.

Milt Gross of The New York Post was elected president of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association yesterday at the Hotel Lincoln. Gross, vice president last year, succeeds Ensign Joseph M. Sheehan, now on leave from THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 7 -- New Zealanders are offering many entertainments for the United States forces. Last night two dances were given for them. New Zealand's bays and beaches welcome swimmers who seek rest after intensive training.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- The Philadelphia Navy Yard remembered Pearl Harbor today by launching the U.S.S. New Jersey, the largest battleship ever built, into the Delaware River a year almost to the hour after the Japanese attack that plunged this nation into war.

While material shortages this year failed to have any appreciable effect on advertising media, such as newspapers, magazines and direct mail, 1943 will see the picture considerably changed, it was pointed out yesterday. The surplus of newsprint and printing papers this year will be converted into a shortage, because of restrictions on pulp output and the use of zinc will be curtailed 50 per cent starting in February.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Destruction of twenty-one Japanese airplanes in fierce fighting in New Guinea was reported today by the Allied High Command.

Judge James G. Wallace yesterday in General Sessions suspended a sentence of seven and one-half to fifteen years he had just imposed on David Price, 36 years old, a robber, on a guilty plea, because Price had aided in the first-degree murder conviction recently of Irving Nitzberg, a member of the notorious murder ring in Brooklyn.

American painters, sculptors and printmakers received awards totaling $52,000 yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art at the opening of the Artists for Victory Exhibition. This was said to be the largest amount ever distributed in prizes at a single display of contemporary American art.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- One explanation of Admiral Darlan's ascent to power in French North Africa is provided by the arrival of several French business men from North Africa.

The moving picture firm of Twentieth Century-Fox has put its money in another stage production. It has bought a one-half interest for a reported $17,500 of the forthcoming Theatre Guild production of "The Russian People." This melodrama is due at the Guild Theatre Dec. 29, after a two weeks' engagement in Washington, starting Dec. 14.

Pending completion of research on substitutes in the sanitary chemicals field, future supplies of such basic products as pyrethrum and rotenone for household and industrial uses will depend to a large extent on Allied success in controlling shipping lanes from the Far East and North Africa.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 7 -- Repressive measures continue to be taken in France by the Vichy Government and they appear aimed principally at preventing any development of the Fighting France movement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Starting in May and June, the country's high school and college youths will take over relatively unskilled farm jobs, according to a joint plan of the Department of Agriculture, the Office of Education and the War Manpower Commission creating a national volunteer farm labor organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- A pleasant-spoken, well-dressed woman, who has been a patient suffering from amnesia at Hannemann Hospital since the day after Thanksgiving, remembered today that she was Mrs. Emma Biederbeck of 69-04 Fifty-Eighth Road, Maspeth, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The government and counsel for privately owned utilities are studying with deep interest the recent decision of the First United States Circuit Court of Appeals in the case of the Puerto Rico Railway, Light and Power Company. And the outcome of the issue will be of as great interest to the investing public and to those who oppose or advocate the extension of government ownership and operation of the utilities.

In one of the largest mass inductions into the armed forces of the United States, 2,300 young men were sworn in last night as Naval Aviation cadets simultaneously in 128 cities. Over a coast-to-coast hook-up of the National Broadcasting Company the youths responded to the oath administered by a naval officer in this city.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Admiral Jean Francois Darlan is a menace to the Allied armies fighting in North Africa, having long ago outlived whatever usefulness he may have possessed, General Georges Catroux declared here today in urging most strongly that Washington lose no time in severing all connections with the man who is "best compared to the legendary Trojan horse."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The United States will have a sufficient supply of raw materials next year to meet all military and essential civilian needs, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, Chief of the Army Service of Supply, told the Senate Small Business Committee today.

If every American worker will increase his output by 15 per cent, according to Eric A. Johnston, President of the United States Chamber of Commerce, it will go "a long way toward solving the manpower problem."

Joseph Miller, an official of a concern supplying millions of dollars worth of Navy uniforms on contract, and a former associate of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, the condemned industrial racketeer, was held in bail of $25,000 yesterday on a Federal complaint charging the bribery of a civilian employe of the Navy.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 7 (AP) -- An exchange of letters between Mustafa Nahas Pasha, Premier of Egypt, and President Roosevelt, emphasizing the common desire of Egypt and the United States to see democracy triumph in this war, was disclosed today.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- General Fulgencio Batista, President of Cuba, arrived by plane from Havana today on the way to Washington for conferences with President Roosevelt.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 7 -- Yugoslav regular forces and guerrillas under the command of General Draja Mikhailovitch have unleashed their most serious attacks since last September, striking in Serbia, Bachka, Bosnia, Hercegovina and Montenegro, inflicting heavy losses on German, Italian, Hungarian and Bulgarian garrison troops and carrying out extensive sabotage, according to reports from Balkan intelligence sources to Istanbul.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 7 (AP) -- President Juan Antonio Rios sent a message to President Roosevelt on the anniversary of Pearl Harbor today, saying that Chile "has been and will be at every moment at the side of the democracies."

The Beech Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday in its statement covering the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 net income of $2,417,819 after provision of $891,930 for Federal normal income and surtax, reserve of $5,537,466 for Federal excess profits taxes after deducting $47,053 for post-war excess profits tax refund and provision of $7,200,000 for refund on United States Government contracts.

Summing up the present year's harvest results, the Department of Agriculture estimates the European wheat crop, exclusive of Russia, at about 1,380,000,000 bushels. This would be approximately 40,000,000 less than in 1941. Europe produced 1,746,000,000 in 1933 and nearly as much in 1939.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Still handicapped by enemy air superiority, the Allied forces in Tunisia held fast today as German tanks, aided by preliminary dive-bomber raids, renewed their onslaughts in the triangular sector formed by Tebourba, Djedeida and Mateur, where the outcome of the bitter fighting may determine which side will control the vital railroad linking the naval base of Bizerte with the capital and key city of Tunis.

The fourth annual Maria Moors Cabot prizes for "distinguished service in the field of inter-American relations" have been awarded to two South American newspapers and their editors and to The Christian Science Monitor, published in Boston, Columbia University announced yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 7 -- Following is the text of the speech delivered here tonight by Lord Halifax:

Expressing concern about the sudden drying up of suitable Spring and Summer cotton fabrics for children's wear and other essential home-front activities, fabric suppliers and cutters yesterday urged immediate action by the WPB to clarify its recent order assigning A-2 ratings to a wide range of utility cloths used by women's workwear producers.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission was enjoined today from enforcing its $5,000,000 annual gas rate reduction order against the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, pending a review of its findings by the Eighth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared today that the first anniversary of America's entry into the war was so intimately interwoven with all there is in treachery and cruelty and fiendishness among the Axis powers that it spoke for itself, with special reference to Japan.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Seven trim new Navy ships which Rear Admiral James L. Kauffman, commander of the Gulf Sea Frontier, said "we need badly," slid down the ways here today in the South's largest mass ship launching.

The Macmillan Company, having obtained from the British Bureau of Information the only complete copy in this country of Sir William Beveridge's report, "Social Insurance and the Allied Services," is crowding through for Dec. 18 publication a 50,000-copy edition.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Britain's food supplies are assured for months ahead, Lord Woolton, Minister of Food, said in London today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- Because of extensive highway and building construction in recent years, with accompanying deforestation and swamp drainage, Westchester County has become subject to flash floods resulting in severe property damage, harbor pollution and a threat to public health, Commissioner of Public Works James C. Harding told the Westchester Board of Supervisors today.
The 1942 football season generated enough thrills to last spectators until the next campaign, even if they have to wait for it until after the war.

One hundred and forty-seven contributions totaling $13,685.20 were received yesterday for the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York, which were published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sunday. The gifts, coming in quick response to the thirty-first annual appeal for the men, women and children in greatest distress in the city, brought the Fund to $29,504.93.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Senator McCarran of Nevada offered a measure today which he said would provide Treasury-owned silver for war industries and relieve other industries needing silver for consumptive purposes.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 7 -- John L. Taylor, assistant to the president of the Pittsburgh Civic-Business Council and prominent as a Boy Scout executive, died today in the Allegheny General Hospital. He was stricken with a cerebral hemorrhage on Thursday while serving as a volunteer at the Mount Lebanon rationing board.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7 -- Merle Oberon and Joan Crawford were named today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to head the all-feminine cast of "Cry Havoc," Allan Kenward's play about volunteer nurses on the Bataan Peninsula, which the studio purchased last October.

Eight major opponents have been booked for Columbia's 1943 football team. The schedule, announced yesterday, is one of the most difficult ever arranged for the Lions. The card includes five games at Baker Field.

The recently established philanthropic fund of the Overseas Press Club of America will be the beneficiary of the American premiere showing of Noel Coward's new motion picture, "In Which We Serve," to be presented the night of Dec. 23 at the Capitol Theatre under the patronage of Viscount Halifax British Ambassador to the United States, and Lady Halifax.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Paul V. McNutt, Director of the War Manpower Commission, indicated today that the total population would now be considered a national pool from which the needs of the armed forces, industry, agriculture and essential civilian activities would be supplied.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Rose Bowl and other bowl classics of the football world must draw their patronage from areas adjacent to the field, Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, made it clear today in ruling that "home town delegations" and "team followers" are not to be permitted to travel to such post-season games, scheduled for Jan. 1.

Officers to serve with Frederick Coolidge Crawford, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, were reported yesterday to the executive committee of the association by its nominating committee. The new officers will take their posts on Jan. 1.

Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday that in the interests of economy and the war program his inauguration in Albany Jan. 1 would be extremely simple, with many of the former traditional and elaborate ceremonies held in connection with the installation of a new Governor eliminated.

The annual medal of the St. Nicholas Society of the City of New York, an organization of residents whose families have lived here since New York was New Amsterdam, was presented last night to Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service, at the 108th dinner of the society in the Hotel Plaza.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 7 -- -- Clarification of Pope Pius XII's declaration that he would not leave Rome should the British bomb the capital came from the Holy See today when an official spokesman referred to an incident that occurred last Thursday.

Governor Lehman in his farewell address urged us in his own quiet fashion to hold fast to our social gains. The Administration in Washington, in its own vigorous fashion, tells us it will never consent to let war necessity be made an excuse for abandoning social gains.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 7 -- Three young men are being held by Newark police on a murder charge resulting from the death of a "mugging" victim. Detective Captain Frank O'Neill said today that the trio also had confessed to thirty-seven recent robberies in downtown Newark.

A study of the Revenue Act of 1942 has convinced trustees of the George Putnam Fund of Boston that it should qualify as a corporation, for tax purposes, rather than as a regulated investment company, holders of shares in the fund are being notified.

Convictions were obtained in 99.4 per cent of all criminal cases prosecuted in the year since Pearl Harbor, despite a 40 per cent turn-over in the personnel of his office, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa announced yesterday. The personnel changes were due to the entry of many of his assistants into the armed forces.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Dr. John Brown Watson, president of the Arkansas Agricultural, Mechanical and Normal College for Negroes here since 1928 and one of the South's outstanding Negro educators, died at his home here last night after a long illness.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 7 -- Three young men are being held by Newark police on a murder charge resulting from the death of a "mugging" victim. Detective Captain Frank O'Neill said today that the trio also had confessed to thirty-seven recent robberies in downtown Newark.

A study of the Revenue Act of 1942 has convinced trustees of the George Putnam Fund of Boston that it should qualify as a corporation, for tax purposes, rather than as a regulated investment company, holders of shares in the fund are being notified.

Convictions were obtained in 99.4 per cent of all criminal cases prosecuted in the year since Pearl Harbor, despite a 40 per cent turn-over in the personnel of his office, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa announced yesterday. The personnel changes were due to the entry of many of his assistants into the armed forces.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Dr. John Brown Watson, president of the Arkansas Agricultural, Mechanical and Normal College for Negroes here since 1928 and one of the South's outstanding Negro educators, died at his home here last night after a long illness.

The election of Ralph A. Uihlein of Milwaukee as president of the Family Welfare Association of America was announced yesterday by Linton B. Swift, general director of the organization. Mr. Uihlein has been for several years on the board and vice president of the association and has been president of the Family Welfare Association of Milwaukee.

Five hundred persons prominent in the theatrical profession and other walks of life attended a month's mind requiem mass offered yesterday morning for George M. Cohan at St. Malachy's Church, 239 West Forty-ninth Street. The Catholic Actors Guild of America was sponsor for the mass.

A civilian army of 100,000 volunteers is to be mobilized here to assist in carrying through myriad civilian war mobilization and education campaigns projected by the Federal Government, Marcel H. Stieglitz announced yesterday after his appointment by James G. Blaine, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, as director of the Block Service Organization of Greater New York.

Looking through this year's list of Neediest Cases we find repeated the familiar misfortunes and calamities. Here are the deserted wives and children, the gray hairs brought down with sorrow and want, the tubercular, the blind, the homeless and the helpless of many sorts, the victims of the caprice of fate or the cruelty of man.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 7 -- The number of concentration camps in Northern Norway for German soldiers who have deserted from Northern Finland or have refused to go to the Eastern Front has recently increased, according to reliable reports reaching Stockholm.

Four youths, one of them a sailor who was A.W.O.L. from his ship, were tentatively charged with murder in Homicide Court yesterday after all had confessed, according to the police, the slaying on Sunday afternoon of Wong Gee, 37 years old, a laundryman, of 3468 Broadway.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A communique of British headquarters and the Royal Air Force:

Lloyd's, the world-wide British insurance organization, intends to set up a communications office in this city in the next few weeks to safeguard further information on marine and other insurance risks transmitted between the United States and foreign points, according to a copyrighted article in the current issue of The United States Investor of Boston.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- Recognizing the importance of physical fitness during wartime, the Bear Mountain and Harriman areas of the Palisades Interstate Park will-offer a program of Winter sports this season more comprehensive than in 1941-42.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 7 -- Secretary Wickard, who was appointed yesterday by President Roosevelt as national Food Administrator, declared here today that food had assumed "equal priority" with military materiel and appealed to farmers of the nation to step up their production as much as possible in order to produce the essential food for the nation and its Allies.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Russian troops attacking German "hedgehog" positions west of Rzhev on the central front drove the Nazis from two fortified positions yesterday, but Moscow made it clear today that enemy resistance was growing in that area and in the Stalingrad sector.

Directors of the American Crystal Sugar Company authorized yesterday a year-end dividend of 50 cents a common share, payable on Dec. 28. The current dividend raises disbursements this year to $2.50, against $1.25 distributed on common stock in 1941.

Fordham's basketball team withstood a second-half rally to triumph over the Fort Monmouth quintet, 41 to 36, on the Ram's court last night. It was the second straight victory of the season for the Rams but the visitors came close to scoring an upset.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The new war ration book, No. 2, to be distributed probably in January, will give the government a versatile weapon for dealing with shortages.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Registration of women for war work is needed only in specific communities, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, said today, adding:

Claiming that wartime conditions are making heavy demands on the schools, the Public Education Association yesterday sent a letter to Governor-Elect Dewey urging that in making his 1943-44 budget requests he recommend State financial aid for education at the same level as for the year 1941-42.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses won yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel the dismissal of the injunction suit brought to restrain him from demolishing the Aquarium Building in Battery Park -- designated by Mr. Moses as the "Aquarium, nee Fort Clinton."

A New York drawing room of more than a century ago has been reproduced at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets, and will be opened to the public tomorrow. The display is called "The Mrs. Henry Wilmerding Payne Memorial Exhibition of Furnishings from a New York House of the Federal Period."

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra of New York, Artur Rodzinski guest conductor, gave a concert last night under the auspices of the USO-Camp Shows, Inc., observing at the time its one hundredth anniversary and also what could be called another anniversary, not a hundred years old, and not as gratefully remembered by the nation.

In your issue of Nov. 10 you published a letter from me in which I took issue with a statement emanating from the United States Office of Education announcing that "State and regional accrediting associations must adjust their requirements," and further that "a campaign * * * to break down the existing prejudices in favor of the strictly academic college preparatory courses is also required."
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- For the first time, all officials for the Orange Bowl game Jan. 1 will be Southerners.

After moving narrowly in a very quiet session, cotton prices closed irregular, 1 point higher to 5 points lower than on Saturday, with the near months on the New York Cotton Exchange registering gains under price-fixing orders and the distant positions exhibiting weakness under a moderate amount of hedging.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Owen Lattimore, American political adviser to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, declared today after calling on President Roosevelt that "final, decisive victory against Japan can only be won on land in China."

Greek War Relief will benefit from an auction of art objects to be held Friday and Saturday afternoons at the Plymouth Galleries, 106 East Twenty-third Street. All the articles for sale were donated by the New York Society for relief of the occupied country.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Dec. 7 -- Harrison E. Spangler, new chairman of the Republican National Committee, is one of those party wheelhorses who came up in politics the hard way and never ran for office.

Like America, Japan also observed the anniversary of Pearl Harbor with numerous speeches and pronouncements. Japanese leaders pointed with pride to unprecedented victories which surprised not only the world but Japan herself; and they forecast bigger and better things to come.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Dec. 7 -- To help relieve the shortage in oil for both cooking and chemical purposes, the Archer Daniels Midland Linseed Oil Company plant here today switched over completely to the production of oil from soy beans.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- A total of 562 new stock companies were formed in the State in November, bringing the eleven months' total to 8,023, against 12,782 for the same period last year, Secretary of State Walsh reported today. The capital of 206 companies which gave the amount of their capital stock was $7,496,655, while 356 new organizations declared issue of stock without par value.

Director McNutt declares that his newly strengthened War Manpower Commission is now prepared to "ration scarce labor." It is important to keep in mind, however, that some of the present scarcity of labor is artificial. Artificial restrictions on the labor supply ought to be removed before we come to labor rationing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Uniform aircraft warning signals will be the subject of two conferences for civilian defense officials of Northeastern States, announced tonight by OCD Director James M. Landis.
The text of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's speech yesterday to the new Falangist party council, as given by a Spanish broadcast recorded by The United Press:

Medical services are "woefully inadequate" in many localities today with actual surveys of some 400 war production and military areas frequently revealing far fewer physicians and dentists than the essential minimum of one for every 1,500 of civilian population, Dr. W.F. Draper, assistant surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service, warned yesterday.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 8 -- The Vichy government seems preparing to take further action against listeners to foreign broadcasts, which have been a thorn in its side for many months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Roosevelt assured a delegation of representatives of Jewish organizations today that the American Government would give full consideration to a proposal made by the delegation for the United States to name a commission which, in conjunction with the United Nations, would promptly collect and examine all evidence bearing upon "criminal acts" by the Nazis in occupied countries.

Preparations for the Yuletide season already have begun in the Swedish bakery. Signs of them greet you as you enter the shop. There are the red and green ornaments, for example, that are ranged in a glass cupboard -- soon to be hung on the evergreen tree that will tower near the bay window.

Price restraint, emphasis on utility types of fur merchandise and coordination of production with actual demand were urged at the annual meeting last night of the American Fur Merchants Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

By a vote of 17 to 7, with two members not voting, the City Council yesterday afternoon rejected a local law that would have dropped stirrup pumps from the list of fire fighting articles that must be kept in certain buildings. The vote followed a declaration made by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh that he considered retention of the pumps necessary.

ISLIP TERRACE, L.I., Dec. 8 -- The body of Mrs. Emma Gesine Nies, 33 years old, who had been stabbed thirty-eight times, was found by a neighbor in the bathroom of the Nies bungalow, Charles Street and Andrew Avenue, here, this afternoon at about the same time her husband, Rudolph, 36, was being arrested in Washington for causing a disturbance in the barber shop of the House of Representatives.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Minister of Information Brendan Bracken assured the House of Commons today that there would be no censorship of anything its members said on the floor of the House as long as it was correctly reported. He made this statement in replying to a question by Emanuel Shinwell, Laborite, who intimated that he had received information to the contrary.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- The amazingly swift and deadly Ventura bombers, the latest type of American-made planes, which probably haul up to three tons of bombs, have been added to Royal Air Force striking power, the Air Ministry revealed today.

The savings and home war conference of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations will be held tomorrow and Friday at the Waldorf-sAtoria Hotel, with 500 delegates from 225 associations in all parts of the State expected to attend, it was announced yesterday by Zebulon V. Woodard, executive vice president.

The general death rate in New York City declined slightly last week to 10.6 per 1,000 population, it was reported yesterday by Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins. Lower mortality was registered for syphilis, cancer, diabetes, heart disease and pneumonia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- Columbia announced today that Merle Oberon and Brian Aherne will be co-starred in "Commandos," a film adaptation of an unpublished novel by Elliott Arnold. The studio has engaged Dorothy Arzner to direct the picture, which will go before the cameras next Tuesday.

Rolling up an all-time record score for a N.Y.U. basketball team, the Violet varsity overwhelmed Upsala College of East Orange, N.J., 89 -- 40, on the University Heights floor last night. The previous high of 86 was established in 1919, the year Jake Cann's team won the National A.A.U. championship at Atlanta.
Angered police trudged from hospital, to autopsy room, to courtroom yesterday determined to build up an air-tight case against two men arrested for the murder of Detective Joseph A. Miccio.

The New York Rangers' regularly scheduled National Hockey League game with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden on Thursday, Jan. 14, will be for the benefit of the Red Cross, Manager Lester Patrick announced yesterday.

Expenses of all Salvation Army operations in the five boroughs of New York during the year ended Sept. 30, 1942, totaled $1,983,833, Colonel Norman S. Marshall, chief secretary of the Army's Eastern Territory, reported yesterday.

Premier Hideki Tojo broadcast to the Japanese Empire yesterday that Japan had "entered a critical point in the war," in which the Allies were "trying all kinds of tricks to get back at us," and declared that Japan was "fighting to match her strength with the enemy countries."

Old and loyal friends of the Neediest hastened yesterday to send their contributions with expressions of hope that the appeal on behalf of the sick, the discouraged and the homeless of the city will not suffer because of the harsh demands of war.
The board of directors of the Eastern Steamship Lines, Inc., yesterday authorized a year-end distribution of 25 cents a share for payment Dec. 28 on the common stock.
MOSCOW, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The new "Song of the Waves," composed by two members of the Women's Naval Reserves, will be heard over the National Broadcasting network at 6 P.M. tomorrow. Fifty Waves stationed in Washington will sing the words.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The back-stage contest at the Capitol over continued independence of the Board of Economic Warfare or its return to Reconstruction Finance Corporation control, a controversy which has involved Vice President Wallace as chairman of the agency created to acquire stock-piles of war materials, and Secretary Jones as R.F.C. head, appeared today to swing toward the BEW.

Declaring that American business could not survive a repetition of the widespread charge of profiteering that took place after the last war, Maurice Hirsch, in charge of settlement and review of the War Department Price Adjustment Board, declared yesterday that the aim of renegotiation of war contracts is protection of the good name of industry.

At Columbia University today the fourth annual Maria Moors Cabot Prizes for "distinguished service in the field of inter-American relations" will be presented. For the first time an American journal, The Christian Science Monitor, receives this honor. It will be represented by its managing editor, Erwin Canham, who used to report for it the sessions of the Assembly of the League of Nations and other important foreign conferences.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 8 -- The Japanese military attache in Berlin, General Bansai, has unexpectedly left for Tokyo via Turkey and Russia to report on the present situation, according to private advices received here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Following an acrimonious conference today of Montgomery Ward Co. with the War Labor Board, in the course of which the Ward representatives rejected the board's compromise formula on maintenance of membership and compulsory arbitration to be embodied in a union agreement, the board issued a new order directing the United Mail Order, Warehouse and Retail Employes, C.I.O., and the company to accept its compromise proposal "forthwith."

The report of the Brillo Manufacturing Company for the first nine months of 1942 shows a net income of $263,295 after income tax deductions of $316,129. The result is equivalent, after dividend requirements on the Class A stock, to $1.62 each on 145,310 shares of common stock.

Talcott M. Banks Jr., general counsel of the Board of Transportation Investigation and Research, declared yesterday at the closing session of the regional war conference of the American Bar Association that the government had acted wisely in the present war by leaving domestic transportation in private hands rather than assuming direct control as in the last World War.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Although the great bulk of the French fleet at Toulon was put out of commission or severely damaged by the action of the crews of the ships, some fifteen warships and five tankers remained apparently intact, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox told a press conference here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The contest for air mastery over Tunisia and the Mediterranean is currently "touch and go," Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commander of the Army Air Forces, said today. It may lead, he added, to a decision in the struggle for air control over all Europe.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- William J. Rich of Salem, president of the New York State Grange, said here today that farmers of this country must receive the full cost of production "if America's food supply is to be maintained."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 8 -- "Today, on this tragic anniversary, we find that our confidence has been fully justified. Events are marching rapidly and the day is approaching when peace-loving peoples everywhere will once more find restored their sovereign rights as nations and their inalienable rights as individuals."

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 8 -- Twenty thousand additional women from the metropolitan area will be hired for mechanical work in the six plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation in Passaic and Bergen Counties, it was announced today by Myron B. Gordon, vice president and general manager of the company.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- A series of sweeping decrees, providing penalties as severe as death for workers deserting their posts and closing all schools for two months, were reported issued in Rome today, apparently in anticipation of all-out aerial assaults on all corners of Italy.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Britain took another stride today toward tapping the last reserves of her youth for military service when the House of Commons adopted on second reading a bill providing for the call-up at 18 years of age, lowering the previous limit from 18 1/2 years.

Presentation of the first annual Downey award for "the finest American children's book of 1941 written in the Catholic tradition" was made yesterday to Covelle Newcomb for her biography of Cardinal Newman, called "The Red Hat," published by Longmans, Green.

WITH ADVANCE UNITED STATES FORCES, in New Guinea, Dec. 5 (Delayed) -- The commanding officer in the first of two peeps waved and boomed in broad American, "Good morning, boys," as we passed between long lines of native carriers toting supplies to this front. The natives, some dressed only in breechclouts and others in shorts or laplaps, smiled and waved back, some shouting:

MADRID, Dec. 8 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, in a state speech, told the nation today that the world had only the choice between communism and fascism, and made it plain that in this choice he favored fascism. Generalissimo Franco carefully re frained, however, from leaning one way or the other in his attitude toward the war.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 -- With more than 900 restaurants in this area closed or on the verge of closing because of a shortage of help, Southern California clubwomen, headed by Mrs. Paxton Lytle, told the Restaurant Owners Association today that they would do everything in their power to meet the situation by urging their own members to step in and fill the hundreds of vacancies.

The differences which have existed between the New York State Athletic Commission and the National Boxing Association at various intervals have been revived in connection with the Beau Jack-Tippy Larkin lightweight battle to be held Dec. 18 in Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- More in sorrow than in anger, Michael F. Walsh, Secretary of State and the officer tradition dictates should arrange for Thomas E. Dewey's inauguration as Governor, admitted today that he could not save the $25,000 on the inauguration ceremony which Mr. Dewey announced yesterday in New York would be saved by simplification of the rite.
Mrs. Carlos Martins, wife of the Brazilian Ambassador, has come to the St. Regis.

The Board of Economic Warfare reassured foreign traders yesterday that "as long as possible and in so far as possible" the regular channels of distribution abroad will be maintained under the "screening" system which the agency now contemplates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The American Museum of Safety presented medals for achievement in safe transportation tonight to Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission; W. Averell Harriman and E. Roland Harriman, railroad owners, and Juan T. Trippe, president of the Pan American Airways.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- In its first action against a large department store for alleged violation of the General Maximum Price Regulation, the Office of Price Administration here today obtained a temporary restraining order against the Hecht Company, Washington department store.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA -- Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- Important ships of the surviving French fleet, including the modern battleship Richelieu and three cruisers, apparently came under the United Nations banner, along with Dakar and French West Africa, by an agreement "for prosecution of the war against the Axis."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The one-man filibuster in the Senate by Senator McCarran was recessed today until Friday under circumstances which indicated that, while the present Congress was still in session, it was to all intents and purposes virtually through legislating.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 754, which compared with 573 in the preceding week and 499 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations numbered 312, as against 389 last Tuesday.

Each month, in its statistical summary, the Securities and Exchange Commission publishes index numbers on the stocks of industries which account for at least 1 per cent of the annual volume on the New York Stock Exchange. The base is 100 for January, 1939. Against this yardstick stock prices in the middle of November made a poor showing.

The accession of Dakar and French West Africa to the Allied cause and the Navy's announcement yesterday that some of the French warships at Toulon were still afloat indicate a net gain for the United Nations.

Instead of using the negative approach to metal closure restrictions, WPB will list the actual essential products which are to be allowed use of such metal in the rewritten version of its Order M-104 to be issued shortly, E.F. Bertrand, Owens-Illinois Glass Company, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Association of Insecticide and Disinfectant Manufacturers, Inc., in the Roosevelt Hotel.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 8 -- Two months to the day after a conflict over the treatment accorded prisoners of war on both sides led to the shackling of British prisoners in Germany and German prisoners in Great Britain and Canada, the Political Department (the Foreign Office) of Switzerland, the protecting power for both belligerents, issued the following communique outlining its efforts to break the deadlock:

BALTIMORE, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Baltimore Sun said today that the average temperature in Federal office buildings in Washington was in excess of 76 degrees, or eight degrees higher than the basic temperature ordered for such structures two months ago.

An optimistic picture of the future of lawn tennis was painted yesterday by Holcombe Ward, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, auguring for a continuation of activity in this sport in 1943.

To make a program of two-piano music and give it the distinction bestowed by Vitya Vronsky and Victor Babin when they performed last night in Carnegie Hall is to show the most eclectic taste and the most exceptional musicianship. One can take technical apparatus more or less for granted in these days of technology, which is manifest in music as in other arenas of competitive effort.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Although business remained restricted, a much firmer tone was seen in today's stock markets. Gilt-edge issues were better, both the 3 and 3 1/2 per cent war loans gaining 1/16 point.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 8 -- The Army will take over about half of Yale's dormitories and a third of the university's classroom space next month for a group of 2,000 young men in pre-flight training for the Air Corps and their 600 instructors.

Children's conceptions of Santa Claus have changed to fit developments since Pearl Harbor. That became apparent yesterday when Postmaster Albert Goldman allowed reporters to examine a thousand letters at the General Post-office, all addressed to Santa.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 8 -- The avoidance of "apparent shortages" which would needlessly dislocate civilian distribution is one of the major objectives of governmental control, Joseph White, chief of the textile, clothing and leather section of the War Production Board, told members of the executive committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board at today's session of the three-day annual meeting here.

They don't ask much. Two hundred and fifty dollars will take care of Mrs. Stella F. and her four-months-old baby until she can go back to the $16-a-week factory job she left before the baby was born; she isn't eligible for public relief, because her husband has deserted her and it hasn't yet been established legally that he cannot help with her support.
An All-America men's swimming team that must take rank with the strongest ever chosen has been named by the special Amateur Athletic Union committee, of which Larry Johnson of Boston is the chairman.
For the second successive year the big bad Bears from Chicago dominate the All-National League professional football team chosen by Associated Press and newspaper sports writers.
ALBANY, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The State Tax Commission declined today to take a position for or against application of the Ruml "pay as you go" plan to collection of New York's personal income taxes.

Ward Morehouse of the staff of The New York Sun has signed a contract with Lippincott to write a life of George M. Cohan. There is a working title of "George M. Cohan: Fifty Years of the American Theatre," and publication is planned for Fall of next year.

Fines designed to wipe out profits made by their violations of price ceilings on waste paper were imposed in Federal Court yesterday on seven persons and six concerns of which they are officials. The penalties were set by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe on recommendation of Samuel H. Reis, assistant United States attorney.
CAIRO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A joint communique of the British Middle East headquarters and the Royal Air Force:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones announced today that the Defense Plant Corporation has authorized contracts totaling approximately $2,750,000 with three companies to provide additional war production facilities.

Ten thousand men from 18 to 35 years of age drilled, rowed, floated in life saving suits and worked at various merchant marine tasks yesterday at the press preview of the United States Maritime Service Training Station, Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn.

Drawing its playing talent from all sections of the country, the Little All-America football team, named for the ninth time by The Associated Press yesterday, features a crack all-around backfield operating behind a sturdy line that averages 196 pounds from end to end.

LIFE in the twentieth century makes other periods of war and tragedy seem almost attractive. It is not the distance that lends enchantment to the view, but the contrast. The Civil War was destructive, sanguine and horrible enough, yet it was also a war in which gallantry, individual exploits and the power of personality could play a noticeable, if subsidiary, role.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- Clifford M. Shoemaker, 45-year-old New York bank guard, said today he was "willing to go back and face the music" after he had played a merry tune for three days and nights here last week with $9,000 of the bank's money.

Sentencing five Negro youths yesterday for raping a young white woman in Harlem last August, General Sessions Judge John J. Sullivan defended "the respectable Negro people" of the district, and declared that they were "only too willing to aid the police in driving criminals from their streets."

It is interesting to know, in the light of the difference of opinions between Winston Churchill and the Indian Autonomists that the British Prime Minister in his birthday eve broadcast returned to mystical depth of Hindu wisdom when he cited Kipling's poem "If":
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Major Gen. Fulgencio Batista, President of Cuba, arrived today for an official visit as the guest of President Roosevelt, being received with high and colorful honors.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Criticizing the Washington administration as showing favoritism toward labor groups, Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, told convention delegates today: "When the people get tired of being pushed around they say so with votes, as was amply demonstrated, particularly by farmers, at the recent election."

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Daily Mail tartly criticized press facilities in the North African campaign today and demanded that "those with the power and authority overhaul the present arrangements."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A simplication program in the builders' hardware lines was invoked by the War Production Board and cut the number of items from a present total of 27,000 to approximately 3,500. The program, WPB officials said, is "one of the most extensive yet announced in the realm of manufacture."

Some support was noticed yesterday in the market for railroad issues, and this coupled with strength in the pivotal groups permitted a moderate improvement in prices on the Stock Exchange.
