Followers of the carriers were not so pessimistic over the move in Washington to cancel rate and fare increases granted earlier this year, for there were indications that the request of the Office of Price Administrator might meet strong opposition.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8 -- Perhaps the most admirable and courageous attempt to avoid capture during this Libyan campaign has ended happily for a young Australian fighter pilot, who, wounded badly in both legs, crawled crablike on his hands across the desert for four days before he found a haven, from which he was finally rescued.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Roosevelt said today that more than 50,000 patents owned by nationals of enemy or enemy-occupied countries would soon be made available for use in the war effort and for general use by American industry.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Authoritative circles said tonight that the government would give close consideration to the Swiss proposal that the shackling of prisoners of war cease on a date to be determined.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The following questions and answers intended to clarify points in the fuel-oil rationing program, which is in effect in thirty Eastern and Middle Western States, were issued today by the Office of Price Administration:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Roosevelt met the plane bringing President Batista of Cuba, who was a White House guest at a dinner in his honor, and held his press conference; his visitors included Senator Josh Lee, Joseph P. Kennedy, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise and a Jewish delegation, Wayne Coy, and Harold Smith and Lord Halifax.

Representative Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany Hall, announced yesterday that he had invited all Democratic legislators from New York County to meet with him tomorrow evening to formulate "a constructive legislative policy to be pursued during the coming year."

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8 -- R.A.F. medium bombers again pounded the Bizerte-Tunis area today. At Bizerte, despite cloudy weather, bombs were placed among fuel installations in the harbor. In the Tunis area enemy fighters came up but failed to bring down any Allied bombers.

So far as war conditions permit, a full program of intercollegiate competition was envisaged for the year ahead from the action taken yesterday by member associations of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics, in session at the Hotel Biltmore.

UNITED STATES AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, China, Dec. 7 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American airmen blasting Japanese bases in China, despite very great enemy superiority in numbers, won twenty-six Silver Star awards today for gallantry in action.

While production of the highly important sulfa drugs is running many times that of 1941, shortages exist of sulfadiazine and to a lesser extent of sulfathiazole, Fred J. Stock, chief of the drug and cosmetic section of the chemicals branch of the War Production Board, said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- Sumner T. Pike, SEC Commissioner, who is to be an aide to Leon Henderson, head of the OPA, will examine the crude oil output of the country with a view to emphasizing production of the types most urgently needed for the war effort, it was learned today on his return from Washington.

Stronger bonds between the United States and the South American republics are made imperative by war, Admiral Edward Clifford Kalbfus of the Navy General Board declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria given by Columbia University in honor of the 1942 winners of the Maria Moors Cabot prizes in journalism.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Wheat traders are again marking time pending further developments at Washington, especially in regard to the release of mash grains to mills which are being squeezed by the low ceiling on flour, and Senate action on the House bill which would include farm labor costs in computing parity prices on agricultural products.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (AP) -- William Goldman Theatres, Inc., lessee of the Erlanger Theatre, filed a $1,350,000 damage suit in Federal Court today against twelve major motion picture producers and distributors, charging violation of the anti-trust laws.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Despite Donald M. Nelson's concern over an apparent leveling-off trend in war production, Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen forecast a production peak far greater than Germany's or Japan's as new plants came into operation and thousands of war workers gained skill.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- An automatic price regulation to cover new and changed products in cosmetics and toiletries was described today by Edward P. Morrish of the Office of Price Administration in an address at a conference of Midwest manufacturers, members of the National Beauty and Barber Industries Association.

The letter concerning liquor taxes by Professor Yandell Henderson of Yale University, published in THE TIMES of Nov. 29, contains errors which, in fairness to an industry which is the nation's largest single industrial taxpayer and an important contributor to its war effort, should not be allowed to stand unchallenged.

A total of $5,035,000,000 of war production loans and commitments were outstanding on the books of 421 of the nation's largest banks as of Sept. 30, it was reported yesterday by the American Bankers Association. This represented an increase of $856,000,000 during the third quarter.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- With Ralph A. Bard, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, predicting unquestionable victory for the United Nations, the Cramp Ship Building Company, risen from the rust of years of disuse, launched its first major warship in eighteen years today.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 8 -- Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt probably is the target of more adverse criticism and the object of more praise than any other woman in American history.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- At the request of counsel for "Father" William E. Riker, self-styled "wise man of the Far West," a Federal court subpoena was issued today against "Father" Divine, the Negro "God," summoning him as a witness at the sedition trial of the California cult leader.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8 -- Joe W. Brown's Brownie and Mrs. H.P. Bonner's Heartman won the Fair Grounds features today, two trial races for Saturday's $15,000 added Louisiana Handicap.

In your recent editorial on the serious problems facing our colleges you expressed the opinion that no news would give Hitler greater satisfaction than to hear that the war had resulted in the debacle of our institutions of higher learning. Certainly, the collapse of higher education in America would constitute a loss of immeasurable proportions.
Some enlightening figures are found in the survey L.G. McNamara, New Jersey Superintendent of Game Management, is making of the public hunting areas in his State.

A new regulation designed to clarify the status of war contracts under the New York City sales tax law was issued yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick as the outgrowth of a long series of conferences attended by Mayor La Guardia, Mr. McGoldrick and representatives of the War and Navy Departments.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Governor Charles Poletti declined today to accede to the requests of high Army officials that New York State call off its new, and apparently successful, air-raid warning system. In polite language of unmistakable meaning the Governor declared that if the Army offers a "better system" the suggestion will be considered.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Robert S. Hudson, Minister of Agriculture, called on British farmers today to till 1,000,000 more acres "for the absolutely vital harvest of 1943" and praised the 1942 harvest as one of the greatest that the country had ever seen.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Athletic chiefs of the Western Conference not only signified their intention of carrying on their own sports program today but also urged that intercollegiate athletics throughout the nation be continued, "as requested by Army and Navy officials, regardless of spectator attendance."

A bill that, if it becomes law, would permit soldiers, sailors and marines in uniform to ride free on all city-owned and operated transit facilities was passed yesterday in the City Council by a vote of twenty to two, with three members of the Council not voting.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Cliveden, Viscount Astor's famous Buckinghamshire estate, will be handed over by Lord and Lady Astor to a national trust for the enjoyment of the public and to promote understanding and friendship among English-speaking peoples."

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- One reaction of the French underground movement to the Allied attack in North Africa and the occupation of all France by the Germans is contained in the Nov. 20 issue of the Franc-Tireur, the first of the underground French newspapers to reach London since the invasion of Africa.
Sharp criticism of Mayor La Guardia came from Judge Thomas Downs in Queens County Court yesterday, in connection with the current drive against bingo games.

German armored forces, counter-attacking in the Kalinin-Lake Ilmen sector northwest of Moscow, broke through Russian positions to a depth of nine miles and now are astride Russian supply lines, the German High Command reported yesterday, according to broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 -- Violent and persistent enemy resistance is being encountered in all active sectors of the front, but the newspaper Pravda today gave editorial support to reports in dispatches from the front that the improvement in the Russian situation is continuing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Roosevelt, at his press conference today, warned the people of the country not to believe stories that there are hundreds of thousands, or millions, of civilian employes of the Federal Government holding down soft desk jobs.

WHEN Al Schacht's mail was opened -- that's all right; he opened it himself -- it contained practically no surprise at all. He had asked for mail votes on an all-time all-star baseball team from what he called a circle of his friends. He received a total of 105 votes, thus proving to his satisfaction that he is not alone and friendless in the world.

Two more physicians and a registered nurse were arrested yesterday as abortionists. When they were arraigned in the Felony Court, District Attorney Whitman Knapp told Magistrate Morris Rothenberg that one of them, Dr. Frederick B. Henschel, 49 years old, of 151 East Eighty-third Street, is suspected of being the head of a chain of abortion mills in this city and New Jersey.

The great value and importance of hearty cooperation between the military authorities and local police agencies in the fight against enemy operations within the United States was discussed yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the Eastern Defense Command, in an address before 300 police officials from various communities at a conference arranged by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A rebalancing of the entire war production program involving heavy cancellations of contracts and even temporary shutdowns and unemployment is under way in some parts of the country, it was learned tonight from a War Production Board spokesman.

The new national chairman of the Republican party is a veteran Iowa politician, Harrison E. Spangler, who has been helping elect Iowa candidates and organizing "grass roots" conventions for more than twenty years. At the St. Louis meeting of the National Committee on Monday he was elected chairman on the third ballot, after a successful effort had been made to block the candidacy of Werner W. Schroeder of Illinois.

GUADALCANAL, Nov. 11 (Delayed) -- Relentlessly and as speedily as the terrain -- the roughest over which American troops ever fought -- will permit, the Marines and Army forces are extending their lines on the north shore of Guadalcanal, both to the east and the west from Henderson Airfield.

Through agencies working with colleges and universities the Federal Government has embarked upon a huge educational program to cost more than $500,000,000 annually, R.B. Stewart, controller of Purdue University, declared yesterday.

Failure of the cotton futures market to respond yesterday to a bullish estimate of the crop given by the Department of Agriculture resulted in the appearance of a small amount of liquidation that depressed the list moderately. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts rallied slightly in the closing minutes, but showed losses of 5 to 12 points at the end.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- Women, who have taken jobs by the thousands in West Coast aircraft factories and have appeared in lesser numbers in shipyards and war plants as the manpower shortage became more serious, invaded the waterfront yesterday and started work as carloaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Damage from unfavorable weather and insects and inability of some growers to obtain adequate harvesting help caused 1942 cotton crop prospects to decline 347,000 bales in November, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Two unusual features in connection with the proposed offering of bonds in the municipal financing field were contained yesterday in a notice of sale posted by the State of Arizona. The first was that the State was undertaking to sell a new issue of securities in behalf of one of its counties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Secretary Ickes, in his first report to the country as Petroleum Administrator for War, declared in a radio broadcast tonight that heating oil would probably remain scarce for the duration of the war. He asked men and women everywhere to accept sacrifices in their comforts at home with the slogan, "Sixty-five degrees will make it plenty hot for the Japs."

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS in Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 9 -- Another frantic attempt of the Japanese to rush warships to the aid of their faltering forces pocketed at Buna and Gona on the coast of Northeast New Guinea has been repulsed by planes of General Douglas MacArthur's air force, the High Command announced today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A communique:

At the direct request of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., issued yesterday an order restraining litigants in New York from their attempts to block the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation from complying with the dissolution provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Voicing the great national need for more manpower, President Roosevelt appealed today to employers in civilian industries to assure employes who take up war work that their seniority rights will be protected as the seniority rights of those who go into the armed services are protected by the Selective Service Act.

Pointing out that in the early days of Selective Service 20.9 per cent of registrants were rejected because of dental defects, Dr. Leon L. Abbey, president-elect of the Dental Society of the State of New York, called yesterday for a "vast rehabilitation" program.

Sir Thomas Beecham, who has won world-wide fame as a conductor, provided a fresh chapter for collectors of Beecham anecdotes last night when he made his first appearance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and conducted the first concert of the Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra's second season.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 8 -- Harrison E. Spangler of Iowa, compromise choice as chairman of the Republican National Committee, said tonight that efforts to solidify the party will be made at conferences in New York next week with Wendell L. Willkie, Herbert C. Hoover and other Republican leaders.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 8 -- All the serious health and social welfare needs of the country at war, including those of the armed forces, have been met by the government, Charles P. Taft, assistant director of the Office of Defense Health and Welfare Services, reported tonight to the biennial meeting of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, meeting here with six ether interdenominational bodies.

While in London the Fighting French Commander of the Levant, General Catroux, was issuing a statement to the press denouncing Admiral Darlan as a "Trojan horse" and urging Washington to sever all connections with him without delay, in North Africa General Eisenhower was negotiating an agreement with Governor General Boisson of French West Africa by which the port and airfields of Dakar are turned over to the United Nations.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 -- Testimony by a Charlestown sign maker, Henry Weene, that Barnett Welansky, operator of record of the Cocoanut Grove, boasted that "Mayor Tobin and I fit," led Boston's Mayor to deny tonight he ever permitted any violation of the law prior to the deaths of 496 persons in the night club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Unless tankship delivery can be increased substantially, a prospect that is distinctly improbable, further shortages in petroleum products for the East Coast region were forecast tonight by the petroleum industry war council's committee on petroleum economies.

" The Sun Field," a dramatization by Milton Lazarus of Heywood Broun's novel of the same name, will open at the Biltmore tonight. The play is about the life and loves of a home-run king, the sun field being, of course, the outfield.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (Canadian Press) -- In connection with the lowering of the draft age to 18, Labor Minister Bevin disclosed that to meet the growing manpower problem Britain would send men between the ages of 37 and 41 directly into war factories.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Soviet troops plunging across the snow-swept central front wiped out several German garrisons in the Velikiye Luki area ninety miles from the Latvian border yesterday and cut down 700 Nazis, using only bayonets, the Russians announced early today.

A tentative draft of an ordinance setting up standards of safety against fire in night clubs, cabarets, restaurants, dance halls and similar places has been completed by engineers of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, W.E. Mallalieu, its general manager, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, in expressing satisfaction in the House of Commons today with United Nations cooperation in the war, characterized as utterly untrue reports of "unfortunate incidents" in North Africa.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 8 -- A.A. Gray's Rough Amos, who quit in his previous outing here, held on long enough today, as a 17-1 shot, to win the sixth race. The 3-year-old son of Sir James and Off and On had only a scattered backing in the field of eight sprinters and paid a $36.40 mutuel. N.E. Bryce's Spectator was second, a half length off the winner, with H.M. Cornwell's Clarie Whizz third.

Cycles seem to be in fashion this season, and Samuel Dushkin, violinist, began a series of three concerts at the Town Hall last night. He has given the series no less a title than "Profiles of Three Centuries of Music for the Violin," and the first program was subtitled "Romanticism and Impressionism."

Both the people of Great Britain and those of the United States are "far ahead" of their respective governments in social reform, Mrs. Eugene Meyer, until recently the chairman of the Westchester County Recreation Committee, declared yesterday in analyzing trends in "Great Britain's Social Revolution."
Imminence of the point system of rationing finds the consumer information set-up under the CDVO planning to expand and accelerate its operation.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 9 (UP) -- Long-range Royal Air Force bombers struck heavily at Italy again last night, British officials said early today, resuming the aerial offensive that has devastated the principal shipping and industrial areas of Northern Italy in eight great attacks last month.

A statement contending that the War Labor Board has no jurisdiction over wage disputes between municipalities and their employes was issued last night by Mayor La Guardia as president of the United States Conference of Mayors.

Frank Sinkwich, star halfback of the University of Georgia, became the eighth recipient of the Heisman Memorial Trophy in ceremonies at the Downtown Athletic Club last night. Chosen by a nation-wide vote of sports writers and broadcasters as the season's outstanding football player.

CAIRO, Dec. 8 -- Allied fighters and fighter-bombers continued to attack points along the Tripolitanian coast Behind El Agheila yesterday, damaging General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's communications and pinning down his air force.

" Life Begins at 8:30," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy drama, will have its local premiere this morning at the Roxy. Monty Woolley and Ida Lupino are co-starred in the film, which was directed by Irving Pichel. Nunnally Johnson produced and wrote the picture's screen play from a play by Emlyn Williams.

American industry is meeting with unequaled skill and enterprise the challenge of production for war. But even now it faces a challenge in another field. This is the challenge that Henry J. Kaiser laid before the annual meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers -- the challenge of production for peace.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- Harold S. Smith of Newburgh, former recording secretary for Local 17, International Hodcarriers, Building and Common Laborers of America, was an important witness for the people today at the trial of Samuel Nuzzo, former business agent, accused of embezzlement of funds.

TRENTON, Dec. 8 -- Plans for the use of the former Hopewell, N.J., home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh as a hospital and rehabilitation center for women infected with venereal diseases were approved today by the State Department of Health.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:
LONDON, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- British political circles said today that Generalissimo Franco's speech was mere "lip service" to the Axis and predicted that Spain would continue neutral.
It is now quite proper to say that as Indiana goes so goes the nation; or else! Four sons of the Hoosier State among them have taken over pretty nearly the whole of our civilian lives.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opened with a preview late yesterday afternoon its large exhibition of twentieth-century portraiture. It opens to the public today and will remain current through Jan. 24, after which the assembled work in various media is to tour under the direction of the museum's department of circulating exhibitions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Five flying officers, none over the age of 35, returned to Washington today from almost a year of constant operations in Flying Fortresses over the Southwestern Pacific. They are the top officers of the Army's Nineteenth Bombardment Group, which fought from Luzon in the Philippines to Australia and New Guinea.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Hitting back hard in Northeastern Tunisia, Allied tanks have pushed back Axis forces that had pierced the British First Army's lines west of Tebourba, according to an Allied Headquarters announcement tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Wage increases for more than 22,000 employes of 105 hotels in New York City were approved today by the War Labor Board.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The "little fellow" will receive the utmost consideration in the current shift in types of war material produced for America and her allies, Major Gen. Campbell, chief of ordnance, pledged today.

In a move which may introduce a new phase of advertising agency service, James T. Chirurg, president of the Boston agency of that name, is going to England to study methods used by war plants there to stimulate workers to produce more goods.

Boston College's football team, despite its setback at the hands of Holy Cross which constituted one of the major upsets of the recent season, came into its own as the leading eleven of the East yesterday when its coach and officials designated by the college accepted the Lambert Memorial Trophy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Representatives of the Big Five railroad operating unions, representing about 350,000 members, voted today to ask the railroads for a 30 per cent increase in wages, with a minimum increase of $3 a day. Heads of the unions will now ask the local lodges on the individual roads to approve the request, an action which is expected.

Evidence that more restraint will be used in obtaining emergency military and lend-lease textile needs, thus avoiding serious dislocation of civilian trade such as characterized the Army Quartermaster's recent unannounced and still unexplained seizure of civilian bed sheet stocks in the hands of mills, was noted here yesterday by Worth Street suppliers.

WILLIAM STEIG is best known for his cartoons in The New Yorker featuring Small Fry. But he has a secret artistic life which periodically strives to escape the private category of doodling on the blotter or the telephone pad. Ordinarily a sober lad as cartoonists go, the Steig at eve occasionally drinks his fill of gall and wormwood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau's statement this week that hoarding of currency seemed to be on the increase was borne out by the rise in per capita circulation of money shown by the Treasury statement issued today. It was $110.07 on Nov. 30 for every man, woman or child in the United States, an increase of $4.35 since Oct. 31 and of $30.37 in a year.

A special regional service for handling all problems in connection with War Production Board orders for Federal, State, county or municipal government agencies and for private and public non-military institutions has been set up here in offices at 122 East Forty-second Street, Sydney Hogerton, chief deputy director of WPB Region II, announced yesterday.

America's first coffee rationing trials were held yesterday in the Empire State Building, resulting in the conviction by an Office of Price Administration trial examiner of the operators of six restaurants charged with having understated their coffee inventories by nearly 2,000 pounds.

The gauze dimout curtains and lowered lights required by city regulations this season have not blacked out the public holiday spirit. The stores, on and off the Avenue, report an increased enthusiasm among the crowds who press their faces against the window panes to peer at the decorations.

WHEN Jack Doyle, the Sage of Broadway, began spinning tales of sport he could go all the way back to the ancient era when Yale and Harvard played football on the Hampden Park grounds at Springfield, Mass. That was Jack's home town. It was there that he first edged into big-time sport. As a half-grown kid he had a job "running copy" for the gentlemen of the press who were covering the Yale-Harvard scrimmages.

Charles H. Gregor, 30 years old, a former law student, waived examination for the action of the grand jury yesterday in the Felony Court and was committed to the Tombs in default of $5,000 in his alleged theft of about $37,000 in the last three years from Lloyds of London through fake accident claims.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Forty-five more persons have been executed and 400 rounded up in the campaign of Axis terror striking again in Europe, exclusive of France, London and continental reports said tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- The Civic League of Westchester, in a letter to Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey today, declared it would be the "proper and fair thing" for New York State to take over Westchester County's parkway system and assume the county's parkway debt of $49,000,000.

The Treasury's Victory Drive to raise $9,000,000,000 or more this month is off to a fine start. Secretary Morgenthau has just announced that $5,586,000,000 has been realized in the first five days of this month, of which $3,381,000,000, or about 60 per cent, has come from non-banking sources.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Congressional Medals of Honor were presented by President Roosevelt today to the families of Rear Admirals Daniel J. Callaghan and Norman Scott, who were killed in the naval battle off the Solomon Islands last month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- One year of war has cost the United States more than $46,000,000,000, more than the entire cost of participation in the world conflict of twenty-five years ago. Staggering as this sum appears, it is dwarfed by latest budget estimates of war expenditures for the 1943 fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The formation of a United Nations organization for relief and rehabilitation was discussed by the Pacific War Council when it met with President Roosevelt today and it was decided to consult each of the United Nations regarding the setup of the organization.

CAIRO. Egypt. Dec. 9 (AP) -- Long-range British fighters tore into a flight of fifty German transport planes, presumably flying home toward Europe after having delivered troops and supplies to Tunisia, and shot down three transports and one escorting fighter, the British reported today.

On the question of the Fire Department's intimation that there may be a holocaust in the Greater City due to women smoking in department stores and to Esmeralda DeMar's letter asking why can't we be intelligent enough to prevent such a disaster instead of waiting for it to happen and then enforcing the law -- may I say that perhaps one reason is that there is no such law?
First National Stores, Inc., reported yesterday a net profit of $591,176 for the quarter ended on Sept. 26, after depreciation, taxes and all charges.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- Andrew J. Higgins, New Orleans shipbuilder, has reveived the award of a War Department contract for 1,200 Army cargo planes to be built at the unfinished Maritime ommission shipyard at New Orleans which has been leased to Higgins by the Defense Plant Corporation for $1 a year rental.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- Lieutenant (j.g.) George Bradford Patterson, grandson of the late Rear Admiral Philip H. Cooper, is missing in action, according to a Navy Department notice sent to his parents, the Rev. and Mrs. William C. Patterson of suburban Gwynedd.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Fordham weathered a strong Princeton rally to score its third straight basketball victory tonight. The Rams came from behind in an overtime period to conquer the Tigers by 46 -- 45. It was Princeton's first defeat in two starts.

Plans for three low-rent housing projects to be included in the city's post-war construction program were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. They will provide 3,634 apartments for 14,000 tenants. The commission approved also an adddition to the master plan, establishing a low-rent area in the old Astoria section of Queens, facing Hallett's Cove.

Since among the recognized great American pastimes are baseball and the writing of plays, Milton Lazarus, like a number of others before him, has decided reasonably enough to combine the two. From "The Sun Field," a novel written by the late Heywood Broun, he has taken the story of the player who married the cultured pearl and thereafter went into a slump such as only the Dodgers could emulate in real life.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- Second Lieutenant Clarence W. Lipsky of Great Neck, L.I., who received the Distinguished Flying Cross for bringing back a Flying Fortress that was damaged seriously in a raid on France, was taken prisoner on a subsequent mission over Europe and is now held in Germany.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- A Reuter dispatch today from Rabat, French Morocco, quoted Pierre Boisson, Governor General of French West Africa, as saying that "Dakar and the rest of French Africa intend to intervene against Germany with their full strength as soon as we have received materials and equipment from America."

OTTAWA, Dec. 9 -- All accounts from Winnipeg today of the opening session of the national Conservative party convention agree that John Bracken, Premier of Manitoba, will be elected the party leader in place of Arthur Meighen, who announced that he would resign at the close of the convention.

A mixed pattern was presented yesterday on the stock market where only the chemical shares and an assortment of specialty issues managed to show strength. Heaviness ran through the other major groups, although the rails resisted the influence of the demand of the brotherhoods of railway employes for increases in wages, this factor having been discounted on Monday with other current problems.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Major Gen. Fulgencio Batista, President of Cuba, declared at a press conference today that the German submarine menace in Cuban waters had been practically eliminated. It has subsided particularly since the opening of the offensive in North Africa.

LONDON Dec. 9 -- Viscount Cranborne, Lord Privy Seal, told the House of Lords today during a discussion of post-war relief plans that the Allied committee, appointed some time ago to investigate the future needs of various countries, had already received from all Allied governments estimates of their food needs during the first eighteen months after the war was over.
AN ENGLISH EAST COAST PORT, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- Twenty-six American seamen who spent three days in a lifeboat battered by gales and a blizzard were landed here today by a British trawler.

Lord and Lady Astor are to grant their estate of Cliveden to the national trust "for the enjoyment of the public and to promote understanding and friendship among English-speaking people." They will remain as tenants at their will. They have been at this Buckinghamshire place for nearly fifty years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Treasury's program of war financing represents an effort to provide necessary funds while sidestepping those factors that would lead to inflation, Secretary Morgenthau wrote today in a piece published in Army and Navy Journal.

A post-war planning program, with emphasis on coordinated research and marketing changes, has been launched by the Producers Council, representing leading building material manufacturers, it was announced yesterday by Arthur H. Hood, director of dealer relations for Johns-Manville Corporation, at a luncheon of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- How the United States Coast Guard cutters Walney and Hartland crashed through the boom into Oran Harbor before the Walney was sunk and the Hartland was blown up was told by two officer survivors in London today.

Returning from the convention of the State Conservation Council at Binghamton, Harold Kimball, president of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, brought back in his brief-case a few notations on proposals the conservation leaders endorsed there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Mandays of idleness caused by strikes have dropped in the twelve months since Pearl Harbor to the lowest level of the last five years, the Office of War Information reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The fuel oil situation in New England was the subject of prolonged discussion today in conferences between Federal and State officials, all of which led to the conclusion that the speed with which every consumer having the means to do so accomplishes the conversion from oil to coal will make all the difference between inconvenience and real suffering for the people in that area.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A good demand for fat lambs, an outstanding characteristic of the livestock market for the last week, was again apparent today. Two loads sold at $15.75 a hundredweight and many additional head brought $15.50 and $15.60. Since Dec. 3, when the Office of Price Administration's temporary price-freeze order ended, there has been no ceiling on mutton.

Steve Vasilakos, "the White House peanut vender," whose activities include the sale of war savings bonds and stamps, will be proclaimed "The Common People's Man of the Year" at a Greek-American war bond rally and dance Sunday night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced yesterday by the New York War Savings Staff.

Lovely girls and lovely clothes gave a cachet to a fashion show in the Sert Room of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday at noon. Lange, who can mold a gown to a figure with as much skill as any one in town, called forth styles suited to Winter in town as well as resorts of the South and Southwest.

Despite high winds, rain and snowstorm, New York's volunteer airplane spotters, members of the Aircraft Warning Service, kept on the job twenty-four hours yesterday, reporting all planes to the Army Filter Center for identification.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- "Father" William E. Riker, leader of the Holy City, a Negro religious organization, testified in his sedition trial today he had been "a real warrior," doing all in his power to "demonstrate my Americanism."

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 -- A plan for the establishment or a North American Council of Churches of Christ was presented tonight to the biennial meeting of the Federal Council of Churches, in session here with six other interdenominational groups.

Despite difficulties with materials, the corset industry is going strong and will survive this war as it did the first World War, William Weinstein of the Rite Form Corset Company, Inc., new president of the Associated Corset and Brassiere Manufacturers, Inc., said last night at the annual meeting of the organization at the Hotel McAlpin.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Wheat futures, after showing a relatively easy undertone on the Board of Trade in the early trading today, turned very strong late in the session on small buying headed by a mill broker which disclosed little for sale and, with stop-loss orders uncovered, the December rose 1 1/4 cents a bushel and closed at the top, setting a 2-month high.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A group of hard-hitting dive-bomber and torpedo planes from Henderson Field, on Guadalcanal Island, escorted by fighters, hit a Japanese naval force last Thursday with such force as to sink one warship and damage three others so severely that all were observed in flames on the following day.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec, 9 -- President Alfonso Lopez Pumarejo has called a special session of Congress for Dec. 16 to act on the government's request for the approval of a new concordat with the Holy See and to study fiscal problems.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- For the first time in ten years the San Francisco Opera Company has just closed a season with a profit. It made $2,872 this Fall, compared with last year's $50,000 deficit, which was made up by assessing the guarantors $100 each.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Senator Byrd expressed the view today that President Roosevelt's denial yesterday that the Federal establishment was overstaffed with civilian employes was "confusing" and stated that the joint committee on governmental economies, which he heads, was engaged in getting "direct" information on the subject.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 -- John P. Busarello, candidate of John L. Lewis in the contest for the District 5 presidency of the United Mine Workers of America, was apparently the winner over Patrick T. Fagan, adherent of Philip Murray and incumbent for twenty-two years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The American Red Cross has distributed about $62,000,000 in supplies to about 30,000,000 persons abroad in the last year, Chairman Norman H. Davis reported today. About half of these supplies went to Britain, he said in his report to the annual meeting of the board of incorporators.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Creation of a volunteer women's land army to augment the nation's agricultural manpower was suggested tonight by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in an address prepared for nation-wide broadcast over the Blue Network.

Reaching a new high, steeplechasing and hunt racing distributed $360,675 during the season just closed, a gain over 1941's figure of $329,908, according to the annual report made yesterday by Fred Parks, secretary of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.

WASHINGTON Dec. 9 -- The speech made yesterday by Generalissimo Francisco Franco, head of the Spanish Government, was interpreted by some observers here today not as indicating any deviation from the recently reiterated official neutrality of Spain, but rather as an expression of a deeply rooted habit of thought on the part of the Spanish leader, which has shaped all his utterances since the beginning of the Spanish civil war in 1936.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Army has no hope of obtaining from Japan a complete and accurate list of some 18,600 American prisoners taken at Bataan and Java, Major Gen. Jay L. Benedict, War Department dependency board president, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today.

MOZHAISK, Dec. 9 -- On the way to this Central Russian market-town, where a German Army corps wintered and Colonel Gen. Adolf van Strauss had headquarters for nearly 100 days, we crossed the historic Borodino battlefield.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- So great is public disquiet here over the anomalies of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan's position in French North Africa that both Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden may undertake to allay suspicions in the House of Commons when the whole matter is taken up at a secret session.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The Italian industrial city of Turin, home of the Fiat works and other war production factories, quivered and crackled again last night as large formations of big R.A.F. bombers delivered another destructive attack, dropping many four-ton and two-ton bombs and tens of thousands of incendiaries.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Navy communique No. 215:

Final official statistics, released yesterday, reveal that Cecil Isbell of the Packers once again is the forward-passing champion of the National Football League. Isbell, having tossed three touchdown passes against the Steelers last Sunday, is the first passer to repeat in the history of the league.

Users of fuel oil who believe that the rations allowed to them by their local boards are less than they are entitled to may make four successive appeals which will finally place their cases before Office of Price Administration officials in Washington if they do not get satisfaction along the way, Edward Coffey, chief rationing attorney of the New York district OPA office, said yesterday.

It is Clair Bee's belief that his Long Island University basketball team is headed for its worst record in years. This despite the coach's surmise that the current edition of Blackbirds, potentially, is as good as any L.I.U. squad in the nine years that he's been coaching there.

Supporters of the New Deal must organize in this State for "militant counter-action against reactionaries who plan for a restoration of the 'normalcy' of the era of President Harding," Dean Alfange, candidate of the American Labor party for Governor at the last election, declared last night.

A new system of air raid signals, substantially the same as that already put into effect in New York State by order of Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell, State Director of Civilian Protection, will probably be issued within the next few days by the Federal Office of Civilian Defense with the approval of the War Department, it became known yesterday.

Thirty-one persons were indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy to violate the Federal Housing Act by obtaining fraudulent loans of $500,000 for alleged real estate renovations.

National League hockey, picked by many to be the first major sports casualty of the war, is zooming along at an attendance pace only 9 per cent behind last season's record figures, an Associated Press survey reveals.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma promised delegates to the Farm Bureau Federation convention today that the new Congress, in view of the results of the election, would be sympathetic to any farm program they might submit to it.

Nearly twice as many New Yorkers were rejected by the Army in the first nine months of 1942 after X-ray examinations of the chest than were rejected for the same cause in 1941, it was reported last night at a symposium on chronic pulmonary diseases at the Cornell University Medical College.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The War Department announced today awards of 106 Purple Heart decorations to members of the United States Army, the Philippine Army and the Philippine Scouts, for wounds received in meritorious service in actions in the Southwest Pacific area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Filipo de Hostos, president of the Puerto Rican Chamber of Commerce, accused the National Administration today of aggravating the island's food shortage by "ignoring and rejecting" the cooperation of Puerto Rican merchants.

The Town Hall gave a birthday party for the League of Composers last night in the only appropriate way a concert hall could felicitate a league of composers. As the third event of its endowment series, the hall presented "A Salute to the League of Composers" in celebration of its 'twentieth anniversary.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 9 (AP) -- State Athletic Commissioner John J. Hall said today New Jersey would recognize the winner of the Tippy Larkin-Beau Jack fight as the world's lightweight boxing champion, despite the attitude of Abe J. Greene of Paterson, president of the National Boxing Association and Hall's predecessor as Commissioner.

The sound of the auction hammer and the hoarse voice of the auctioneer at the seizure room of the United States Customs marked yesterday the dispersal into private hands of thousands of pieces of furnishings and equipment from the unlucky French liner Normandie.

While actual tonnage figures cannot be revealed for reasons of national security, production of heavy armor plate at the Lukens Steel Company's works near Coatesville, Pa., increased more than 400 per cent during the fiscal year which ended on Oct. 10, it was announced yesterday by Robert W. Wolcott, president.

Most violations of OPA regulations by responsible retailers will be found to be due to misunderstanding, and Price Administrator Henderson and the OPA should not be "too eager to bring formal charges of violations against stores which may unwittingly be in violation."

A contributor to the fund for the Hundred Neediest writes that "even though war needs engross us we must care for our unfortunates at home." A gift comes from a mother with a son in the service for this "more than ever necessary cause." We think her son would approve.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Representatives of 3,000 C.I.O. strikers at several Bethlehem Steel Company mills here voted today to end their twenty-four-hour-old walkout which arose from a dispute over double pay for Sunday work.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Big Ten's faculty representatives voted today to delay action on making freshmen eligible for varsity teams, but reserved the right to meet again on twenty-four hours notice any time a critical shortage of athletic manpower develops.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Charges of a monopoly in the fluorescent lighting industry were made by the government in a civil complaint filed today at Trenton against the General Electric Company, the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and eight other defendants.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 -- German reserves were reported today to have reached the northwest sector of the Stalingrad front. They encountered Russian Guardsmen and failed to make headway. On the central front also the flow of reinforcements is continual, and tanks and units of the German Air Force are participating in greater numbers in counter-attacks of un-slackening violence and persistence.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 9 (AP) -- The sensational performance of Jockey Danny Scocca at the Charles Town race track was interrupted today when he was struck in the eye by a clod of dirt during the fourth race.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Time for once is restoring the balance of power to the Allies in the Tunisia fighting. Their strength in the air is growing constantly and every day reinforcements are catching up with the advance units that reached their objectives before it was planned that they should and before they were ready for a full-scale clash with the enemy.

Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday the appointment of Paul E. Lockwood, long intimately associated with him, as secretary to the Governor. As secretary Mr. Lockwood will recive $12,000 a year, the same salary that he now gtes as chief assistant district attorney of New York County.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 9 -- An organization to make sound and color movies in combat conditions has been set up by an American force now at a South Pacific base. The outfit includes 35-mm. and 16-mm. motion-picture cameras and a battery of still cameras and is commanded by a captain and former Hollywood assistant director.

A request that the Board of Education appoint 1,000 regular teachers to the New York City school system immediately, instead of attempting to license new substitutes, was made yesterday at the board's bi-monthly meeting by Dr. Bella V. Dodd, legislative representative of the Teachers Union.

A letter on this page day before yesterday, describing the unpatriotic automobile speeders on the Boston Post Road, had an additional merit. It began by saying "A friend tells me," etc. It did not say "A friend of mine tells me."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A majority of a War Labor Board panel today recommended a 5 1/2-cent an hour wage increase, retroactive to June 1, for about 64,250 employes of the "Big Four" packing companies to "restore the traditional relationship" with steel wage rates.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- The war was credited by the State Health Department today for an October birth rate of 20.3 per 1,000 population, highest of any month in seventeen years and the highest in an unbroken thirty-one month trend.

Constant reduction of less essential output in order to speed ultimate victory was predicted here last night by Robert R. Nathan, chairman of the WPB planning committee. He warned that, although he was confident of final termination of the conflict in favor of the United States, the most difficult days still lie ahead for both soldiers and producers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 9 -- Reports from Norway of the demoralization of German troops there gained substance tonight when it was reliably learned here that by order of the Gestapo all radio sets belonging to soldiers and officers under the rank of major are being confiscated.

Wars of coalition are hard to wage. Not only militarily but also politically, diplomatically and -- propagandistically. Every nation tends to put its own views and interests first, and the best that can be expected is that every ally will fit his own views and purposes into the common cause.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Higher social security contributions, higher taxes, including compulsory savings, and possibly a pay-as-you-go plan will be pressed on Congress by the Administration next year, according to reports current today.

The announcement from Washington yesterday that a "rebalancing of the entire war production program" was under way emphasized what had been evident for some time -- that the "Arsenal of Democracy" had overshot its mark in some munitions of war at the expense of what had proved to be more important items.
Jan. 6 will mark the second anniversary of President Roosevelt's message to Congress in which he first enunciated the Four Freedoms: of speech, of worship, from fear, from want.

An increase of 452 cases of juvenile delinquency during the first eleven months of 1942 as compared to the same period of 1941 was shown yesterday in figures made public by John F. Keenan, administrative assistant to Presiding Justice W. Bruce Cobb of the Children's Court.

Purchase of $4,000,000 of new securities by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in the nation-wide Victory Loan drive to raise $9,000,000,000 this month was revealed yesterday. This purchase consisted of tax savings notes, one of the several types of securities included in the drive.

Owing to government curtailment of ice cream Schrafft stores are discontinuing the sale of ice cream by the pound and are limiting patrons to one ball of it in their sodas or sundaes, it was announced yesterday by Gerald G. Shattuck, president of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, which operates Schrafft's stores.

The New York Adult Education Council will hold a conference on "The Place of Adult Education in Civilian War Activity" in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, at 3:15 P.M. tomorrow. Tickets of admission, for which there is no charge, may be obtained from the council at 254 Fourth Avenue.
CAIRO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A British Headquarters and Royal Air Force communique:

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Despite the projected ending of WPA projects, the State's outlays for home relief are likely to drop below budget estimates for the current fiscal year and will be millions less in the fiscal year 1943-44, according to figures of the Department of Social Welfare.

Books in the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, aided the War Department in planning the North Africa campaign, Frank L. Polk, president of the library, disclosed yesterday. After a meeting of the trustees in the late afternoon, Mr. Polk and other members of the board went down to the library's main exhibition room where the ninetieth star was placed on the institution's service flag.

Traffic on the westbound tracks of the Hempstead branch of the Long Island Railroad was delayed for two hours early yesterday when the contact shoes were stripped from the cars of two passenger trains near Floral Park, L.I., shortly after 7 A.M.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 -- The National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board will make a thorough investigation of the encroachment upon the women's apparel trade by the men's clothing industry, according to a resolution adopted at the final session of the three-day meeting of the executive committee of the organization at Hotel Statler.

In a review of its activities in the first year of war, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey pointed out yesterday the revolutionary changes brought about in its business. It emphasized its heavily increased production of butadiene rubber, toluol for explosives and high octane gasoline.

Events today: "Goetterdaemmerung," Metropolitan Opera House, 7:30 P. M.: Philharmonic- Symphony Orchestra, "Artur Rodzinski conducting, Jarmila Novotna, Frederick Jagel, Ezio Pinza and Abrasha Robofsky, soloists, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Francis Pelton-Jones, harpsichordist, and Claire Alcee, soprano, joint recital, Hotel Plaza, 3:30; Eve Heath, Soprano, program of songs by Helen Dallam, Academy of Allied Arts, 349 West Eighty-sixth Street, 8:30; Brooklyn Philharmonic Choir, conducted by Paul J. Thayer, seventh annual Christmas concert; Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 9 -- The 165 men and women who yesterday afternoon declared a work stoppage in the East Paterson plant of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation returned to their jobs this afternoon and early this evening after a conference participated in by their leaders, the management and State and Federal mediators.

Stocks of all major oil products dropped sharply last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period supplies of gasoline throughout the country were 75,934,000 barrels, a drop of 2,920,000 from the 78,854,000 reported a week earlier.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Germans have imposed their first stern measure of hostage reprisal in the remainder of France, which they occupied Nov. 11, by rounding up 100 men and women at Lyon and holding them for execution for an attack on a German soldier, the Fighting French declared today.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The stock markets today were brighter. Further satisfactory declarations of dividends and statements of profits strengthened the industrials and several of the leaders advanced. Courtaulds rose 6d to 45 1/4s and British Celanese, 3d to 29 1/4s.

LIVINGSTON, N.J., Dec. 9 -- In this quiet village of the Watchung Mountains, eight miles northwest of Newark, snow fell quietly in the dark streets tonight, but in many drift-hidden homes there was loud controversy over the odd thing.

MANZANAR, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) -- How fourteen Japanese-American Boy Scouts defied a mob of pro-Axis sympathizers attempting to seize the American flag during a fatal riot at the Manzanar relocation center Sunday was described today by Ralph P. Merritt director of the center.

Modern industrialism has lost one of its pioneers in the death of Albert Kahn. The indelible mark of this great architect whose work endures in cities from Detroit to Novosibirsk is to be found in mass production as we have come to know it and to be thankful for it under the pressure of war.

William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare, reiterating his charge of Oct. 29 that discrimination against Negroes exists in several of the city's child care institutions, declared yesterday afternoon that such prejudice stands in the way of the kind of a world we want after the war is over.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The aggregate net indebtedness of government, individuals and business concerns in the United States was $185,000,000,000 at the beginning of 1942, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Labor, management, civic organizations and high officialdom united last night under the honorary chairmanship of former Governor Herbert H. Lehman to pay homage to Father John P. Boland, retiring chairman of the New York State Labor Relations Board.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Forty French officers and 1,500 men led by Lieut. Col. Rainal, one of the senior officers of the Vichy garrison at Jibuti, French Somaliland, East Africa, have arrived at Diredawa, Ethiopia, and offered their services to General Paul Le Gentilhomme, recently named Fighting French High Commissioner for Madagascar, who has been serving as Fighting French Commissioner for East Africa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Chairman Donald M. Nelson of the War Production Board said today that war plants would be expected to stay on the job New Year's Day and get out "a regular work-day's production of war goods."

Fritz Kreisler, noted violinist, was the guest of honor at a dinner given last night by Miss Elsa Maxwell in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. The guests included many well-known persons in the worlds of society, music and art.

Ninety-five per cent of the offering of 20,000 ranch mink changed hands yesterday at the sale conducted by the New York Auction Company. The top was $33. No comparison was available. Auction officials reported all types were in demand and competition was keen.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Nov. 24 (Delayed) -- There was the blistering heat of the days in the little rubber boat, the bitter cold of the tropic nights when they huddled together for warmth, the first sweet drink of coconut milk brought to them by natives as they lay exhausted on the beach of San Cristobal Island.

Tami Mauriello, Bronx boxing favorite, yesterday finished training for his ten-round clash against Lou Nova, Californian, in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. The battle may well prove the most important in the Bronx lad's campaign among the heavyweights.
I am in the Navy. Never in my life have I seen men so closely bonded in friendship as these fellows. When they take the oath and don the uniform they seem to assume an air of poise, honor and pride.

The demands of the five operating railroad Brotherhoods for an increase of 30 per cent in pay was stiffer than the managements of the carriers had been expecting. Since the wage rise was broached about two weeks ago, it had been thought the Brotherhoods-would ask for not more than 15 per cent.

Alleging that "confusion, disorganization and lack of uniformity" have characterized renegotiation of textile war contracts, the executive committee of the Cotton-Textile Institute yesterday, in the first industry-wide protest against separate settlements with each government procurement agency, asked the Controller General to study the existing situation and to make suitable recommendations to the incoming Congress.

Richard Strauss's "Salome" was given a very eloquent performance as the second part of a double bill last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. George Szell made his debut in this theatre as the conductor. Lily Djanel appeared for the first time on this side of the water in the title part.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 9 -- Among Berlin reports received here through private channels is an item that the orders of Army Group B for the Voronezh part of its front are no longer signed by Col. Gen. Hermanr Hoth, but by General Field Marshal Fritz Erich von Marnstein.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Russian airmen in two days have destroyed sixty-eight transport planes trying to ferry supplies to German troops in the Stalingrad sector, and the Red Army fighting near Velikiye Luki has killed more than 6,000 troops of the 246th Nazi Infantry Division in an exhausting struggle on the frozen central front, it was announced early today.

'Many of the streets of my neighborhood have hanging across them enormous flags dedicated to the men who are serving in the armed forces. Today some of the flags are new; others, dedicated in the early Summer, have been worried to dismal tatters by the winds and the rains.

"Somewhere in Australia" and "somewhere in England," their minds focused on grave crises far from New York, were men who yet found time to think of the humble and distressed folk of the Hundred Neediest Cases, For yesterday the Fund received gifts that three of our soldiers asked to have sent for them.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 10 -- Allied forces along the northeastern shore of New Guinea have occupied the mission village of Gona, it was officially, revealed today, freeing them for new manoeuvres designed to clean up the last pockets of Japanese resistance to the south. Prime Minister John Curtin announced the occupation while delivering a war review at Canberra.

The immediate question raised by General Franco's address to the Falange National Council is whether a leader who associates himself so whole-mindedly with the Nazi and Fascist revolutions would remain neutral if he could in the event that the Germans demand passage through Spanish territory.

A double bill consisting of Joseph Wood's "The Mother" and Randall Thompson's "Solomon and Balkis" was presented by the Opera Department of the Juilliard School of Music last night in the Juilliard Concert Hall in connection with the current twentieth anniversary celebration of the League of Composers.

A new Summer camp for children will be financed and established next year by the Cooperative Council of welfare societies working with Jewish families in New York to meet the growing demands for children's recreation in wartime, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Albert Fink, president of the organization, with headquarters at 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

A special Federal statutory court of three judges refused, in a decision filed yesterday, to interfere with a merger of fourteen trucking lines which had received the sanction of the Interstate Commerce Commission. The court dismissed the petition of McLean Trucking Company, Inc., for an injunction against the merger and against the financing of the new organization, Associated Transport, Inc.

Appealing directly to President Roosevelt to stop discrimination against medical women in the armed services, America's women doctors chose the first anniversary of Pearl Harbor for their latest step in a year-long attempt to "adjust" their differences with the Army and Navy.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Governor Poletti consented today to the return of Julian Johnson, a fugitive from justice who escaped from the Caledonia Prison Farm in North Carolina on July 13, 1938, and who has since been living in this State.

With good skiing at many points an unusually early start for this Winter sport this is an appropriate time to prepare for an activity which provides healthful recreation and keeps participants in the open air at a time of the year when too little exercise is apt to be the rule for the majority.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The order suspending voluntary enlistment in the armed forces will not interrupt the Army's volunteer officer candidate program, but no man who has passed his thirty-eighth birthday will be accepted, the War Department said today.

A warning was sounded yesterday by R. Merrill Decker, Regional Chief of the Conservation Division of the War Production Board, that the WPB will have to requisition arbitrarily the needed materials unless industry redoubles its efforts in its voluntary scrap campaign and achieves its goal through voluntary cooperation.

Marian Anderson's concert in the Daughters of the American Revolution's Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C., will take place on Jan. 7, it was announced yesterday by Sol Hurok, her manager. The event will be for the benefit of United China Relief, as it has become known that no further civilian participation is desired in the fund-raising campaign for Army Emergency Relief.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee questioned Byron Price for three hours today, and afterward Chairman Van Nuys declared that in his opinion the censoring of mail betwen the United States and its outlying territories was "wholly illegal."

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Receipt of about 2,000 ballots from New York voters in foreign military service was reported tonight, a number insufficient to affect any results of the Nov. 3 election for State-wide offices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Federal Communications Commission today ordered telegraph companies to cease giving priorities to messages of certain types known as "X" and "RX." These messages receive special handling at no extra charge, the commission said, and this constitutes the granting of unreasonable preferences and advantages to certain types of customers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A realignment of the present fourteen sections of the textile, clothing and leather division of the War Production Board into ten main branches was announced today by Frank L. Walton, who becomes director of the division Dec. 15.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

IN THE BRITISH FRONT LINE, near Medjez-el-Bab, Tunisia, Nov. 25 (Delayed) -- When infantry of the British First Army, supported by United States "tank busters," won a foothold on two sides of Medjez-el-Bab, the ancient city, the name of which means "gateway to the sea" and over which Hannibal fought the Romans, was furiously shelled by both sides and dive-bombed by the Germans.

On the belief that the government soon will place a huge order for cotton goods for lend-lease purposes a moderate amount of buying entered the cotton futures market near the close yesterday, rallying the list of active months from losses of as much as 10 points to gains up to 11 points.

Save for a novel by Philip Wylie that will be published the last day of the year, Farrar Rinehart is devoting the rest of this month to books on the war. Released to day is "German Strategy of World Conquest," an analysis of geopolitical writings.

The desperate plight of the peoples of five Axis-ravaged countries as a consequence of scarcity of food, fuel and other necessities was described yesterday by representatives of these countries in a Golden Rule Foundation-National Broadcasting Company program, presented as part of International Golden Rule Week.

The names of fifty-one men, chairmen in forty-five States, the District of Columbia and four United States possessions, of the annual fund-raising campaign against infantile paralysis, were announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Internal conditions in Italy steadily grow worse, but as yet there is no indication of a revolution by the Italians against Nazi control, Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, said at a press conference today.

"The Willow and I," a play by John Patrick, will open tonight at the Windsor under the auspices of Donald Blackwell and Raymond Curtis, in association with David Merricks Martha Scott and Barbara O'Neil head the cast, which includes Edward Pawley, Cora Witherspoon, Gregory Peck, Francis Compton, Robert Harrison, Amanda Randolph, Pauline Myers, and Alec Englander.

A syndicate headed by Harris, Hall Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,950,000 of equipment trust certificates of the Southern Pacific Company, due serially from 1944 to 1953. The winning bid was 99.091 for the first five maturities as 2 per cents and the last five as 2 1/2s.
The declarations of year-end dividends continued yesterday, with special or increased payments making up a large part of the announcements. Important actions fOllOWS:

When you serve an eggnog or punch or other holiday beverage, take care to couple it with something appropriate. This was the good counsel implied yesterday afternoon at the Christmas tasting of the Wine and Food Society, an annual event that took place this year at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Questions of censorship underwent extensive investigation by the Senate Judiciary Committee today, with Byron Price, the director, defending some operations but condemning others.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. "The Palm Beach Story," a Preston Sturges comedy starring Claudette Colbert and Joel McCrea, will open tonight at the Rivoli Theatre. Featured in the Paramount production are Rudy Vallee, Mary Astor, William Demarest, Sig Arno, Franklin Pangborn and Robert Warwick. . . .
DETROIT, Dec. 9 -- Detroit faced a virtually meatless Christimas today, with seven packing houses closed and at least six others ready to shut down until after the holidays.

Stage, screen, opera and radio entertainers will take part in the show "Stars Shine for Young America" Tuesday night in Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Police Athletic League Juvenile Aid Bureau. Funds for the league previously were raised through the annual police show, but members of the force cannot be spared this year for this purpose because of war conditions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 9 -- The Swedish authorities today released the news that the French Legation in Stockholm had broken with Vichy. That the French Minister, Count de Vaux Saint-Cyr, had severed relations with Vichy had been known to everybody here for a week, but it had been impossible to report it.
The fate of the fleet under Rear Admiral Rene Emile Godfroy off Alexandria, Egypt, has still to be decided before the whole issue of the French Navy can be dismissed as belonging to the past.

All the coffee stamps in War Ration Book 1 of children under 15 years of age will be counted by the official registrar before Ration Book 2 is issued, Lee S. Buckingham, State director of the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday.

Almost relegated to the realm of lost arts is the practice of making one's own Christmas presents. Yet, in the field of beauty accoutrements, there are many enchanting gifts that may be made -- in whole or in part -- by the giver. A great deal depends on ingenuity and nimble fingers.
MOSCOW, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Although American duplication of the Britain's Women's Land Army to recruit United States farm labor is rejected by the Department of Agriculture and only politely received by the War Manpower Commission it is possible that such a unit might be organized here, according to a farm labor expert in the Agriculture Department.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

If you are accustomed to buying frozen fish for the family dinner, you will find several varieties from which to choose, according to a spokesman for the Fishery Council. There is a good supply of mackerel and porgies, butterfish and weakfish, and more of all types are expected soon.

The use of Latin-American diplomacy to win over and protect Spain and the Moors and Arabs of North Africa from the Axis powers was advocated yesterday afternoon by Erwin D. Canham, managing editor of The Christian Science Monitor, who represented the Boston paper for the fourth annual Maria Moors Cabot awards in journalism given by Columbia University at a convocation in Low Memorial Library.

Charged with deliberate sabotage, opponents of intercollegiate athletics in general and football in particular were verbally burned in effigy yesterday by the members of the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association at their meeting at the Hotel Biltmore where "carry on in 1943" was the keynote.
LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President Roosevelt met with members of the Pacific War Council, presented the Congressional Medal of Honor for the late Admirals Callaghan and Scott to members of their families and held a brief reunion with his boyhood friend, R.E. Cropley of Summit, N.J.; his visitors included Governor Hurley of Connecticut and Ambassador Francis P. Corrigan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Spokesmen for several farm and labor organizations and an industrial group called upon Congress today to protect their interest from foreign competition and deny President Roosevelt broad wartime authority to suspend tariff laws and regulations.

DETROIT, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The No. 1 plant of the Bohn Aluminum and Brass Company here, engaged in producing war material, closed today after about 1,900 men walked out. A company official said the move apparently was to protest failure of the War Labor Board to approve a wage increase.
PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Leo Patrick Scullion, third class fireman in the Navy, thinks things have taken a turn for the better.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- An unnamed United States merchant vessel wrote a new chapter of war history late in September in the South Atlantic when it probably sank one of two attacking surface raiding vessels and damaged the other before succumbing to a shell that exploded in its magazine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Mayor La Guardia and New York City transit authorities were rebuked today for failing to send representatives to a hearing before the War Labor Board to consider a request by the Transport Workers Union of America that the board take jurisdiction over the dispute between the New York City Board of Transportation and the union.

At a time when national advertisers of scarce products are generally turning to institutional advertising, Riverside and Dan River Mills will start their first national advertising campaign for Dan River sheets, adding another to the comparatively limited number of national brands in that field.

Charged with deliberate sabotage, opponents of intercollegiate athletics in general and football in particular were verbally burned in effigy yesterday by the members of the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association at their meeting at the Hotel Biltmore where "carry on in 1943" was the keynote.
LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President Roosevelt met with members of the Pacific War Council, presented the Congressional Medal of Honor for the late Admirals Callaghan and Scott to members of their families and held a brief reunion with his boyhood friend, R.E. Cropley of Summit, N.J.; his visitors included Governor Hurley of Connecticut and Ambassador Francis P. Corrigan.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works announced yesterday an initial dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable Dec. 29. This will be the first dividend received by common stockholders in more than ten years. The last one was 87 1/2 cents paid on the old common stock in the latter part of 1931.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Buying of December wheat by mills combined with a lack of general pressure sent the price of that delivery today on the Board of Trade up over 1 cent a bushel at the extreme to the highest price since last May, and the deferred deliveries to within a fraction of a cent of the seasonal high point.

"Yankee Point," featuring Edna Best, John Cromwell and Elizabeth Patterson, will close after tomorrow night's performance, its twenty-fourth, at the Longacre. The departure of the Gladys Hurlbut drama will be the second of the week, "Beat the Band" also leaving as of tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Batista paid tribute today at the shrines of the country's heroes. After a luncheon, as guest of Nelson A. Rockefeller, coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, the President visited Mount Vernon, home of George Washington; the Tomb of the Unkriown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery, the monument to officers and men of the lVIaine and the Lincoln IV[emorial.

Three men were injured, none seriously and fourteen others, including twelve girls, escaped when a vat of chemicals being mixed at the Polychrome Corporation, manufacturers of stencils, on the eighth floor of 521-23 West Twenty-sixth Street, exploded yesterday.

In a setting of evergreen foliage the Yorkville Dinner Dance was given last night in the ballroom of the Plaza to aid the Yorkville Community Association in maintaining a Summer camp in Harriman State Park for underprivileged children of this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Ten workers, whose ideas for increasing the efficiency of production efforts in plants engaged in war work, were feted here in a day which included presentation to President Roosevelt at the White House and a luncheon with high officials of the military, naval and, war production forces, cabinet officers and members of Congress.
New York City's union bartenders decided yesterday that they will grimly oppose admission of women into their union, even though other large cities -- notably Boston -- have weakened.

With the recent change in the Selective Service Act making young men of 18 and 19 liable to military service and pruning down the age limit of older men to 38, it seems to me that this is a timely moment for the Federal Government to take advantage of the machinery already set up by various State Guards and fully utilize the manpower not likely to be called to arms.

To study the patients in that hostel of pain, the Hundred Neediest Cases, is to give an ironical twist, for a moment at least, to some hallowed phrases and principles. Life, liberty and happiness! Some of these lives are under the shadow and in the sure grip of death. Without exterior help, what liberty have these save that to suffer?

Wholesale liquor dealers completed their filing of January price schedules with the State Liquor Authority yesterday. While no actual analysis of the listings is possible until the schedules are made available for inspection by the authority, it was learned in the trade that prices were generally unchanged from current levels.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- German prisoners "shackled" two months ago in reprisal for like action taken by the enemy will be "unshackled" Saturday, the Foreign Office announced today. This is three days earlier than the date mentioned in the Swiss Government communication proposing the relief of captives.

In today's war finance figures $62,000,000 seems very little. You can do great things with it, however. The American Red Cross, as Chairman Norman H. Davis reported this week, spent that much during the past year for supplies sent to 30,000,000 persons abroad.

Entering the Eastern manufacturing field for the first time to round out their ship construction activities, the Six Companies, West Coast construction federation of which Henry J.
