Kaiser has been the most prominent figure, have purchased the assets and business of the Crocker-Wheeler Electric Manufacturing Company for $3,200,000 in cash.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase of $405,932,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, which were at a record high. Note circulation for the system as a whole was at the highest of the year to date, while ratio of reserve for the system and also for the New York bank were at a low for the year.

An American soldier, one of the first to be wounded in the American landing at Oran, asked one of his commanding generals to do him a favor before he died -- write a letter to his parents. The letter, with news of the death of Lieutenant George S. Koushnareff, a former cadet officer in the City College Reserve Officers Training Corps, was disclosed here yesterday by his father.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 (AP) -- All the projects of the $289,000,000 plant expansion program of the United States Steel Corporation in the Pittsburgh district probably will be in operation in the first half of 1943, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the corporation, said today.

Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew became indignant yesterday when counsel for twenty-seven independent theatre owners asked him for an injunction to restrain Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine from interfering with the operation of screeno, bingo and similar games in their theatres.
Plans were announced yesterday by Random House for the publication in April of "A History of Bigotry in the United States," the last work by Gustavus Myers, who died Monday night at the age of 70.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Fuigencio Batista, President of Cuba, told the House in an address today that the Atlantic Charter offered "a further perspective" for the United Nations and stands as a beacon to guide the writing of a victorious peace.

"Tomorrow's America will be as strong as today's children," Basil Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, Inc., told guests yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel New Yorker of the Federal employes division, Committee on the President's Birthday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 10 -- While arrests multiply in France "to render powerless saboteurs of collaboration," Marshal Henri Philippe Petain had a talk in Vichy with Field Marshal Karl von Rundstedt, commander in the western occupied areas, who has been placed by Adolf Hitler "at the permanent disposition" of the French Chief of State.
The Friedsam Medal was awarded last night at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, to Royal Bailey Farnum, chief executive of the Rhode Island School of Design, Providence, R.I.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Permission to take the anti-trust suit against James C. Petrillo and his American Federation of Musicians to the United States Supreme Court was granted today by Judge John P. Barnes in Federal District Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Every one seems terrified of what the Chicago Bears are going to do to the Washington Redskins in the National Football League championship play-off Sunday. That is, every one but the capital Braves. They are going about their work with complete unconcern and with an amazing degree of confidence.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 -- "The Mojave Kid," a magazine short story by Borden Chase about an American desert fighting crew which is sent to Africa to combat Field Marshal Rommel's forces, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and will be adapted to the screen for production early next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Children's Bureau of the Labor Department is attacking wartime children's problems on the four fronts of health, day-care, labor standards and juvenile delinquency, Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, bureau chief, said today.
MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

Everything is in readiness for the registration, beginning at 9 o'clock this morning, of young men who have become 18 years old since June 30, it was announced yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City draft director.

Judge Vincent L. Leibell of the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York ruled yesterday that the judgment entered in the suit of minority stockholders of the General Motors Corporation against officers and directors for maladministration of the company's bonus plans should provide for the payment of allowances amounting to $795,000, of which $100,000 was for the accountants and $695,000 for the attorneys in the action.

The question of the extent of the United States' responsibility in the vast post-war reconstruction in Europe and Asia was raised yesterday by Victor Schoepperle, vice president of the National City Bank.

Three Harlem muggers, all natives of Puerto Rico, were found guilty last night in General Sessions of fiirst-degree murder in the fatal stabbing of Private Edwin Berkowitz, 22 years old, of 2 Prospect Avenue, Hackensack, N.J., whom they robbed of $6 in the early morning of last Oct. 3 in the basement area of a church rectory at St. Nicholas Avenue and ll4th Street.

From 1901 to 1940 the Nobel prizes were annually awarded in Stockholm and Oslo to scientists, literary artists and promoters of peace. Alfred Nobel expressly declared that not the slightest attention was to be paid to nationality. Did he foresee the rising tide of the narrow nationalism that has given us the Germany, Italy and Japan of today?

During the last year, Pearl Buck told a distinguished gathering of Nobel Prize winners and other world leaders at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, the war "has ceased to be a fight for freedom," and is now "not even a war to save civilization, but only a war to save European civilization."

There will be no let-up in demands for the reduction of the consumption of fuel oil in the East as long as "two-thirds of the tonnage originally scheduled for this area must be allocated to our new Second Front in North Africa," Sumner T. Pike, newly appointed aide to Harold Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, declared last night.

Bank transactions of the twenty-three major cities of the country amounted to $7,314,301,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, a gain of 11.4 per cent from the $6,568,671,000 for the corresponding week a year ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia resorted to ridicule yesterday as his answer to criticism directed against him in Washington on Wednesday by two members of the War Labor Board for his failure to have the city represented at a public hearing on the question of the board's jurisdiction over the pending dispute between the Board of Transportation and the Transport Workers Union.

The Oklahoma Aggie and Brigham Young University basketball teams are in fine shape for their contests at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. The Aggies are listed to oppose the City College quintet and the Cougars will meet Long Island University.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Thousands of German troops, supported by scores of tanks, charged from their ice-covered fortifications yesterday in sustained counter-attacks on the central and Stalingrad fronts, but the Russians maid they destroyed at least 3,500 Nazis and fifty tanks and held firmly lo the wedges they have driven into German positions.

The 1943 pennant hopes of the Dodgers received a jolt yesterday when it was learned that Pete Reiser, top-ranking outfielder in the National League the last two years, had been reclassified 1-A and probably would be inducted into military service next month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A recommendation that newspapers confine their quarterly tonnage use of newsprint in 1943 to the quantity used in corresponding quarters of 1941 was made to the War Production Board today by a special subcommittee of the newspaper advisory committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The general level of wholesale prices remained unchanged in the week ended on Dec. 5, and the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of nearly 900 prices stood at 100.1 per cent of the 1926 average. As in earlier weeks principal market changes were for farm products, with declines in hogs and in fruits and vegetables, largely offsetting higher grain prices.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a revision of Rule N 23 C-1 under the Investment Company Act of 1940 broadening the scope of the regulation to permit repurchases by closed-end investment companies of their own securities in situations not previously allowed.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 10 -- The Essex County Board of Freeholders approved here today annual bonuses for county employes earning up to $3,000 a year and also voted to ask the Legislature to remove restrictions against bonuses for workers making more than $3,000 and up to $10,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Protests from private concerns that the Office of War Information had gone extensively into the business of making recordings to the detriment of private industry are denied by the government agency.

The Boys Club of New York held its principal event of the year yesterday afternoon at its Tompkins Square Building, 287 East Tenth Street -- the ninth annual Little Sister Show. The coveted prize was "Miss Boys Club for 1943."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Department store sales for the week ended Dec. 5 were 9 per cent up from the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This followed a loss of 1 per cent (revised) in the preceding week. For the latest four-week period sales were 12 per cent higher.

Five Army and Navy officers were among the eleven new tenants in London Terrace reported yesterday by William A. White Sons, brokers. The leases were issued to the following: Lieut. Col. John R. Reitenmeyer, Captain Edward L. Jenkins, Captain William H. Burril, Lieutenant Jerome K. Adams, Ensign David L. Merrill, Dr. Frank E.B. Bissell, William B. Jones, Harry N. Kepler, George M. White, Arthur A. Denico and Hilda Warner.

Next week's offering of ninety-one-day Treasury bills will be stepped up to the unprecedented amount of $600,000,000. During the last eight weeks the weekly offerings have been $500,000,000. Presumably there now will be a series of $600,000,000 offerings, and against these will be current weekly bill maturities of $400,000,000.

Continued production of toys which do not take material from the war effort is necessary for home-front morale and is essential to the industry, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A. at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Although flavor selection may be smaller, family and social groups will still be able to get ice cream in pint and quart packages for parties, ice cream manufacturers were agreed yesterday. Under a new War Production Board order designed to conserve cream and butterfat, ice cream production for December and January is limited to 60 per cent of the October output.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The question of opening Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's press conference to men as well as women has been settled in the negative with the rejection of an application for admission of Gordon Cole, of PM's Washington Bureau, the first newspaper man to apply formally for the privilege.

Representative Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany, announced last night that the Manhattan Democratic members of the Assembly, State Senate, City Council and Congress had agreed to support every measure needed in the conduct of the war proposed by President Roosevelt, Governor-elect Dewey and Mayor La Guardia.

Wine and liquor sales figures for October, during which period "beat the tax" buying pushed sales of distilled spirits in this State to 227 per cent above the volume in the same period in 1941 and wine sales were advanced 95 per cent, "clearly indicate the necessity of rationing stocks" on the part of wholesalers and distillers, the Greater New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association declared yesterday.
Many anglers are pleasantly reminded of experiences of the past season when they find their names appear these days on lists as contest winners.

A UNITED STATES ARMY AIR BASE in Central China, Dec. 9 (Delayed) -- Although China lies at the dim end of our long lines of communication, Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, commander of our China Air Task Force, retains his enthusiasm and confidence.
MOZHAISK, Russia, Dec. 10 -- Tonight I got as near to the German terror as I have been since I saw the Schupos [State police] smashing the hands of Czech miners at Kladno three and a half years ago.

"Next of Kin," the British anti-loose talk film, wil not be withheld from exhibition in American motion picture theatres, it became known yesterday. Last October reports were current that British officials in this country were reluctant to have the picture released here because they believed that it cast an unwarranted reflection upon certain British officers, and also showed too many English soldiers being killed.

Much mystery shrouded the arraignment late yesterday afternoon in General Sessions of Dr. Frederick Bruno Henschel, 49 years old, a naturalized German physician who, three years ago, despite the Sino-Japanese war, went to China from this city as a medical member of a religious mission.

Pursuant to the policy of the Federal Reserve Board to keep member banks of the Reserve System well supplied with reserves so that they may do their share in buying new government securities the open market committee of the Federal Reserve System bought $405,932,000 of government securities from the banks and others in the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 10 -- The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, was elected unanimously as president of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America today at its biennial meeting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Abolition of the National Youth Administration and the Farm Security Administration, with their functions transferred to other government agencies, was urged today by Senator Byrd after the Joint Economy Committee, which he heads, went over the affairs of these organizations with representatives of the Budget Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Additional worsted fabrics will be available for civilian consumption in 1943 as a result of an order increasing worsted manufacturers' production quotas for the coming eight months, the War Production Board announced tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- The utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, condemning bitterly the "unremitting exploitation" of the Florida Power and Light Company by its parent, American Power and Light Company, has recommended recapitalization of the subsidiary on a basis giving publicly held securities first call on the benefits.

Mr. Kaiser's project for the planning of a post-war economy -- a summary of which was published by THE TIMES of Dec. 6 -- deserves more understanding and cooperation than the non-constructive criticism which followed his proposals. His suggestions have two important aspects:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- M.J. Gormley, executive assistant of the Association of American Railroads, declared today that "every unit of the nation's serviceable railroad equipment must do a 5 per cent bigger job in 1943 if transportation demands are to be met."

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 10 -- Upon the Allied air forces, perhaps more than at any time since the African war began, depends the success of Anglo-American arms in Tripolitania and Tunisia at present. It is safe to say that as the air battle goes so goes the ground campaign.

Teachers, alarmed by the breakdown of discipline among city school children, have appealed to the police over the heads of the Board of Education for protection, it became known yesterday. The step was unprecedented.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- The War Manpower, Commission soon will freeze about 110,000 seamen in their present status to insure adequate manpower for cargo ships carrying supplies and equipment to the war fronts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- When the measure granting President Roosevelt broad wartime power to suspend tariff laws was shelved in Congress today it was the Administration's first major setback there since the November elections, as well as the first outright denial of extraordinary powers requested by the President since Pearl Harbor.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- For the second time, Montgomery Ward Co. referred its labor dispute to President Roosevelt today, this time agreeing to sign a C.I.O. union contract, without a duress clause, if it is ordered to do so by the President "as Commander in Chief in time of war."

Sales of the various issues of new government securities that are part of the $9,000,000,000 nationwide Victory Loan Drive that began on Nov. 30 have amounted to $3,014,231,500 in the New York Federal Reserve District, it was announced yesterday by Perry E. Hall, executive manager of the New York Victory Fund Committee.

The Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn., will have its first women students beginning late this month, it was revealed yesterday. Officer candidates for the Spars, newly created Coast Guard auxiliary, will receive part of their training there, according to Lieut. Comdr. Dorothy C. Stratton, auxiliary director.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Ways and Means Committee voted unanimously today to postpone action on the third war powers bill until after the new Congress convenes Jan. 4.

MOSCOW, Dec. 10 -- Little change was reported today on the main fronts, where after a week characterized by violent attack and counter-attack the hard-contested issue appears to be gradually going in the Russians' favor.

Bolstered by the influx of a substantial amount of price-fixing which, in turn, attracted covering operations by New Orleans interests and local traders, the cotton futures market became strong yesterday after three successive sessions of nervous and irregular movement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A Congressional uprising against questionnaires brought virtually to final enactment today a bill to curb the volume of questions government agencies may ask, particularly in relation to OPA's price controls.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- In an attempt to remedy growing shortages of beef in many areas, the Office of Price Administration tonight revamped wholesale price ceilings to permit "moderate" increases in some cases.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Try Flying, owned and trained by Mrs. Arthur Bevans, scored his second triumph of the Charles Town meeting today by defeating six other speedsters in the feature event, a sprint of about four and a half furlongs.

Skiing usually, is not possible much before the first week in January but several of the major resorts offer some activity at the present time, according to reports received yesterday. A few of the centers have a fair base and a thoroughly frozen sod, which would make for excellent undercover for another good snowfall and thus provide good skiing on a larger scale.

Sammy Baugh, ace of the Redskins, just managed to hold on to his punting championship, according to the final statistics of the National Football League, which were released yesterday. Baugh, who had lost a close tussle with Cecil Isbell for the passing crown, managed to shade Dean McAdams of the Dodgers in the punting title.

"To be used as is needed most" -- "I hope you will apply this check to help wherever you think it most needed" -- "I enclose my annual check for $50 to be used for any case that may not be singled out for special contributions."

While the long battle line in Africa is in that state of taut suspense which precedes action, probably at both ends together, the capture of the Gona area in New Guinea is a reminder that our fighters in the Pacific are not pausing to watch the action in the Mediterranean.

During the last twelve months Great Britain and the United States have sent 3,000 aircraft, 4,000 tanks and 30,000 vehicles to Russia, Air Vice Marshal F. Mac-Neece Foster, deputy head of the Royal Air Force delegation in Washington, revealed last night at an "Industries Dinner" of the Russian War Relief in the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Action on all fronts for relief from the Eastern States petroleum shortage, was taken today in a unified effort to avert suffering in New England in midwinter.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won the award yesterday of a new issue of $425,000 Hudson County, N.J., nurses' home and hospital bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1942, and due serially from Dec. 1, 1943 to 1967. The bankers bid 100.389, naming the interest rate as 2 3/4 per cent.

With five brothers already in the armed forces, William Cavanaugh, son of the "iron man" of football, the late Major Frank Cavanaugh, yesterday cleaned out his desk in preparation for his induction into the Army today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -Hiland G. Batcheller, head of the War Production Board's steel division, said today that drastic WPB moves to hair non-essential construction would lower the requirements for structural steel shapes henceforth to around 325,000 tons a month, compared with 480,000 tons monthly in midsummer and 373,000 tons last month.

A redoubling by thrift organizations of their efforts to aid the government in the war effort by promoting the sale of war bonds and stamps was urged yesterday by speakers at the opening of the two-day savings and home war conference of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations.

Paramount Pictures common moved into the spotlight yesterday by topping the list of stocks that have short interests on the New York Stock Exchange. It has reached this position gradually. At the end of June short interest in the issue was 5,010 shares. By the end of July this had increased to 18,748 shares.

WITH ADVANCE U.S. FORCES in New Guinea, Dec. 8 (Delayed) -- The most important peg in the American line on the Buna front was held today by a little group of men under Sergeant Herman Bottcher. They occupy a little frontage of Pacific Ocean beach between a maze of Japanese tunnel and pillbox positions at Buna mission and at Buna village about 600 yards farther west.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A Chinese military spokesman charged today that Japan was building a native army of 150,000 men in French Indo-China with the cooperation of the Vichy French Governor General, Rear Admiral Jean Decoux.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- With all types of bulls bringing the highest prices on record in the livestock market here, packers today paid as much as $13.15 a hundredweight for heavy sausage offerings. Other grades sold at $11.25 to $12.75 in a strong to 15 cents higher trade. Fed stears and yearlings were steady in a slow market.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The Polish Government has asked the Allied governments if there is any possibility of restraining the German from continuing their mass extermination of the Jewish population of Poland and their plans to obliterate the Poles as a nation.

A notable revival, that of Berlioz's "Damnation of Faust," was given by Artur Rodzinski, with assisting soloists, the Westminster Choir, and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall -- notable for the high excellence of the singing, the virtuosity and dramatic spirit of the chorus, and Mr. Rodzinski's zeal and command.

Standing outside a large room yesterday, a City College student, with a broad grin on his face, looked in on twenty of his professors who were mixing pots of moist plaster, painting miniature trees, hiding toy soldiers behind small patches of foliage, and remarked, "It's good to see them work for a change."

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Nov. 22 (Delayed) -- Another piece in the jigsaw puzzle that is the story of the night naval battle off Savo Island in the Solomons on Nov. 13 was supplied today by the skipper of an American destroyer that was sunk in the action.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Albanian people were encouraged to overthrow Italian rule by Secretary of State Cordell Hull tonight in a statement that forecast American military assistance to the guerrilla bands that are operating against the Italian forces in that country.
Winter, with its roaring gales and bitter seas, has come to the Atlantic, and with it have come new problems of supply for the United Nations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- A sixteen-hour day, seven-day week for leaders of American business was advocated today by Henry J. Kaiser on his return from New York and Washington.

The problems of banks in replacing employes lost to the armed service and to war industries were discussed yesterday at a "bank personnel clinic," in the auditorium of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York under the auspices of the American Bankers Association.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin, warned Australia today that it must be prepared to repulse strong air and sea-borne attacks from Japanese concentrated on Timor Island. He added that Allied guerrilla forces were still active on Timor, doing "bold and courageous work."

The three-story building on a plot 20 by 100 feet at 90 Avenue O, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Sumpter Equities Corporation for cash. The building contains two six-room apartments and one store. The assessed valuation is $17,000.

The Office of War Information appealed to the women of America yesterday to consider housing, sanitation and transportation facilities in congested areas before moving in on war jobs, or letting their husbands uproot the family for the same purpose.

Rensselaer E. Dayton, recently with Butler Baldwin and a specialist in Long Island property, has joined Douglas L. Elliman Co. Jennie Prati has obtained from the Bronx Savings Bank a first mortgage loan of $95,000 at 4 1/2 per cent on the parcel at 2024 Hughes Avenue, the Bronx, through Ramapo Estates, Inc.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- While signs of rising public indignation over Admiral Jean Francois Darlan's status in North Africa increased today, the House of Commons heard Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement on the matter at a secret session and then debated its pros and cons behind closed doors.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- General Kurt Zeitzler, a 47-year-old "political general," who until this year was only a colonel and a personal friend of Gestapo Chief Heinrich Himmler, has become Adolf Hitler's principal military aide, displacing General Franz Halder as Chief of the German General Staff.

Meat is even more scarce this week than it was last. Choice is limited, with most customers willing to buy whatever is available. Here is a list of some of the cuts you may find in New York butcher shops, together with the average prices reported by the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets.

A rise of more than 20 per cent in venereal disease among boys and girls of high school age in New York City so far this year has prompted the Health Department to press anew for adequate social hygiene education in the public high schools, it was disclosed yesterday.

The monstrous inhumanity displayed by the leaders of Germany and Japan has awakened the bitter hostility of millions of men. These men have divided opinions, political and other. Can the United Nations afford to refuse the help of any group among them which is prepared to fight the common enemy, irrespective of factional differences?

The Greenwich Village Humane League was opened yesterday at 55 Eighth Avenue at 2 P.M. by Miss Margaret Speaks, radio singer and patroness of the league which has been dedicated to the late hero dog, Paddy Reilly, and his late companion, Orphan Annie, the cat which for many years solicited funds on the streets of New York for a local Humane Society.

A pleasant custom is growing up in New York. The bus driver has just closed the doors and is about to press the starting lever, or whatever it is that sets the vehicle in motion. A belated and somewhat breathless citizen taps on the door from the sidewalk.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS in Australia, Friday, Dec. 11 -- The collapse of a counter-attack by Japanese ground troops trapped at Buna and confirmation of reports that the Allies had occupied all of Gona, on Northeast New Guinea's shore, were announced today in General Douglas MacArthur's noon communique.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Last night for the second night in succession home-based Royal Air Force bombers battered Turin, home of the Royal Italian Arsenal and the large Fiat factory, once again causing widespread havoc. Where fires started during Tuesday night's raid still smoldered the British fliers last night started fresh ones in a concentrated attack lasting fifty-five minutes.

The youngest of the college rowing bodies, the Dad Vail Rowing Association, completed plans yesterday to carry on through the 1943 season. Meeting at the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics in the Biltmore the board of stewards voted to hold the fifth annual regatta on the Charles River Basin in Boston on Saturday, May 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Senator George W. Norris, nearing the close of nearly forty years in Congress, was described by Vice President Wallace tonight as "one of the far-visioned social planners of his time."

Considerable increases in Army and Navy contracts placed in New York City were disclosed yesterday in a report submitted to Mayor La Guardia by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission.

Thus far the country has been fortunate in its enjoyment of an almost complete freedom from effective sabotage in our war plants and in relative immunity from serious fires or other casualties adversely affecting the production of munitions, it was declared yesterday by Harold V. Smith, president of the Home Insurance Company and chairman of the insurance committee for the protection of American industrial plants.
TORONTO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Toronto turned back Chicago, 7 -- 2, tonight and moved into a tie for first place in the National Hockey League, along with the Black Hawks and Boston.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 -- War production workers in the Detroit area were stabilized in their jobs today in a sweeping order to industry and employers issued by Montague A. Clark, district director for the War Manpower Commission for Michigan and Northern Ohio.
MOSCOW, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's noon communique:

Some 700 to 800 representatives of small business associations, polled by the Conference of American Small Business Associations, favor a national sales tax, the forty-eight-hour-week for labor without overtime, a ban on strikes, and a voluntary system of rationing.

A potential increase of 45 per cent in the heating power of fuel oil, with a corresponding saving of available supplies, was indicated yesterday in a demonstration of a new "colloidal fuel" at the plant of the Metropolitan Petroleum Corporation, East 136th Street and Locust Avenue, the Bronx.

Though Pearl Harbor will always stand in the memory of the American people as the signal for our entrance into the war, today, and not Dec. 7, is actually the anniversary of the beginning of full-scale hostilities with the Axis. It was on Dec. 11 of last year that Hitler and Mussolini led their people into war with us.

American business and industry, in so far as it can be done without detracting from war production, must start now to draft plans for the post-war reconstruction period, Frederick C. Crawford, newly elected president of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared here yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Leon Henderson, who has been holding the two offices of Price Administrator and Chief of the WPB's Office of Civilian Supply, resigned the latter post today to devote his energies entirely to administration of the price office.

NEWBURGH, Dec. 10 -- Harold Foster and Anthony Damiano, arrested late last night charged with bribing a State's witness in the trial of Samuel Nuzzo, former business agent of Local 17 of the International Hodcarriers. Building and Common Laborers Union, were held in $15,000 bail today, after a hearing before Justice Riley H. Heath.

To help conserve fuel oil for the government the New York Telephone Company, it was learned yesterday, will convert from oil to coal heating in all their buildings throughout the State where the change is possible. Although no figures were available, it was said that enough oil would be saved to heat 3,000 homes throughout the year.

LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England today reported an increase of almost 12,000,000 in note circulation to the record total of 889,524,000 for the twelfth consecutive weekly advance.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 10 -- The Supreme Court action against members of the German Embassy accused of espionage advanced another step today when the court received information about the suspected persons it had requested the Foreign Ministry to supply Monday.

Lou Nova, the California heavyweight who has been asking for one more chance after every losing battle in the past three years, will have one more chance to re-establish himself among the leading contenders for the title when he faces Tami Mauriello of the Bronx tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Maximum prices for two manufacturers of stirrup pumps were established and the ceiling prices previously fixed for two others were revised in an action announced today by the Office of Price Administration.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 10 -- Count Edmondo de Robilant and five other Italian spies were sentenced to long terms today by the National Security Tribunal. One prisoner was freed.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Since new license plates for automobiles will not be issued for carowners in New York in 1943, some 70,000 holders of low or special numbers, issued by Democratic State administrations over a period of years, will be able to keep their present plates for an indefinite period.

The two-story business building at 151-3 West 125th Street, adjoining the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue, has been purchased by Loomis J. Grossman, the operator, for cash over a ten-year mortgage held by the Irving Trust Company, It is assessed at $160,000 and was sold through Albert H. Graham and the Slater Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Claude R. Wickard told his first press conference today in his new role of Food Administrator that the United States would continue in 1943 to be the best-fed country in the world.

Appeals for further support of Russia were made in the heart of the garment center yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, Dr. Stephen S. Wise and other leaders of the United Jewish War Effort at a rally announcing the gift of the first of 1,000 medical field units to be sent to the Russian fronts.

WITH Sergeant Joseph Louis Barrow occupied with his cavalry duties, it's only fair that the heavyweight boxing crown be "frozen" for the duration. What these other fellows are fighting for might be called a "regency." It may not be important, but it serves to while away the time in heavyweight circles.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 10 -- Without waiting to know whether the Germans had agreed to the Swiss proposal for the unshackling of prisoners of war, Prime Minister Mackenzie King this morning announced his government's decision to unshackle as from tomorrow evening those Germans who have been subjected to this treatment in prison camps here.

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., made $1,531,665 after taxes, or $1.61 a share in the first nine months of this year, in contrast to the net loss of $49,204 reported for the corresponding period of 1941, the company's statement disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- After a quiet opening the markets were firm. Trading was light. Giltedged issues were steady and the home rails hardened. Great Western was 1/4 higher at 57s, London Midland Scottish 1/8 up at 26 1/4s and Transport "C" 1/2 up at 55s.

The Berlin radio announces that Hitler has shaken up his army, air and navy staffs. He has ousted Col. Gen. Franz Halder as chief of the Great General Staff of the German Army and has appointed to this all-important post a comparatively unknown man, a General Kurt Zeitzler, who is reputed to be an old Nazi party member and a friend and confederate of Heinrich Himmler, chief of the Gestapo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- How two storms met headlong in the Atlantic and destroyed each other, calming the sea miraculously for the landings of the Anglo-American forces in North Africa; how the concept and magnitude of the expedition took the Germans by surprise; how work began on that concept as early as last January -- these and facts about the expedition can now be told.

A program intended to further trade and industrial development between the United States and Latin-American countries through cooperation on industrial and engineering standards was announced yesterday by the American Standards Association.

Wage increases to help employes meet the 5 per cent Victory tax may not be granted unless the increases are justified under other provisions of the Wage Stabilization Act, Theodore W. Kheel, acting director of the New York regional office of the War Labor Board, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Seventy-seventh Congress is ready to quit. Adjournment sine die was discussed by leaders today. Soon, possibly tomorrow or Saturday, a tentative date may be set.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first ten months of this year, made pubic yesterday by A.N. Williams, president, shows a net income after all expenses, taxes and other charges, of $7,457,500, as compared with a net of $5,835,837 in the ten months to Oct. 31, 1941.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The arrival of American tanks and artillery at the front and the steadily growing Allied strength in the air were reported today to have improved the position of Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson's British First Army in Tunisia.

Food retailers may adopt the selling prices suggested by manufacturers or wholesalers only if they do not exceed the retailer's own ceiling prices, and wholesale grocers who continue to print price posters for their customers must be careful to see to it that the individual retailer's ceilings are observed, the Office of Price Administration has warned the trade.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today against the State in its long legal attempts to regulate and control private power developments at Niagara Falls, but in the nature of its ruling put the right to make such regulations in the hands of the Legislature, which right the power companies contended did not exist.

The German communique said yesterday that Russian forces had broken into German lines between the Volga and Don Rivers, but had been surrounded and wiped out, ac cording to broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Confidence that Russia would join this country and Great Britain in the effort to turn war unity into an equally strong union in peacetime was expressed today by Admiral William H. Standley, Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

An impressive array of resumed or extra dividends supplied yesterday an effective base for gains of a point or more among scattered issues of securities, but the remainder of the market held dull. Sizable blocks of low-priced shares changed hands on the Stock Exchange, but the turnover of 573,710 shares was the smallest since Monday and compared with 616,377 shares on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Representatives of the "big four" packing companies at a War Labor Board hearing today challenged the contention of a board panel that there was a traditional relation between wages in the steel and packing industries and declared that any wage increase would threaten the cost of living structure.
The decentralization of administering price controls was praised yesterday by Charles W. Cole, newly appointed regional price executive of the Office of Price Administration.

Thirteen million pounds of critical materials, including the bent plates and twisted fittings of torpedo-struck merchantmen, have been salvaged from American ships that have put into Atlantic ports during a four-month period, the War Production Board disclosed yesterday.

Hard on the heels of controversy over the forthcoming Noel Coward film, "In Which We Serve," from which the "Hays office" has ordered the elimination of certain words, it was revealed yesterday that the same censorial office had ordered the deletion of the words "damn" and "hell" from the new March of Time feature film, "We Are the Marines."

Japanese broadcasts recorded in New York by The Associated Press said Premier General Hideki Tojo declared yesterday that Japan had established a strategic position that would enable her to win the Pacific war, however protracted, and contribute supplies to Germany and Italy to aid in the joint fight to establish an Axis world order.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- All members of Army bomber crews, including armorers, radiomen and mechanics, hereafter will be expert aerial gunners in addition to their other qualifications, the War Department said tonight.

When the Nazis crossed the French demarcation line on Nov. 11 they announced that their purpose was to prevent a United Nations invasion of France by way of Corsica. "The German Army does not come as an enemy of the French people, nor of their soldiers," the announcement continued, "nor does it intend to govern these territories."

With a decline this month of between 3 and 4 per cent in advertising linage, monthly magazines have wound up the year with a total loss of only about 7 per cent, according to estimates yesterday. Weekly magazines, with December linage not yet figured, will show a smaller loss for the year, probably less than 2 per cent.

AN EAST COAST PORT, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Sixteen persons, including five passengers, were killed when a medium-sized Greek merchant vessel was trapped in the cross-fire of deck guns on two Axis submarines in the South Atlantic, survivors reported when brought here.

Full effect of the WPB's action this week, placing key chemicals used in acetate rayon under strict allocation control, will not be felt by women's dress manufacturers until advance styling for the next Fall season begins in May or June, textile suppliers said here yesterday.

The British and Canadian Governments have wisely accepted the Swiss proposal that they stop chaining German prisoners of war. The episode was a result of a German charge that prisoners caught in the Dieppe raid were tied up by the British. Berlin thereupon announced that a suitable number of British prisoners had been manacled.

Leonard Horwich, 40 years old, of the Park Central Hotel, pleaded innocent to a charge of bookmaking in Night Court last night and was held by Magistrate Edmund L. Palmieri in $100 bail for a hearing Thursday in Jefferson Market Court.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- In many towns and villages in France, Frenchmen tonight were reading a true story written especially for them by President Roosevelt. The story relates to an incident in the last war in which Mr. Roosevelt, then Assistant Secretary of the Navy, and a Breton village priest played the chief roles.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- Scandinavian reports said today that specially trained Nazi propagandists were touring Norway to stiffen the morale of German soldiers disgruntled by lack of victories, the hostile population and the rigors of Arctic weather.

The extent to which small plants will get subcontracts for war work will depend largely upon their ability to present a rounded-out picture of what they are able to do, Howard P. Ingels, deputy director of the Small War Plants Corporation in New York and New Jersey, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Navy Department has acquired property owned by the Standard Oil Company of California in the Elk Hills Oil Field, Kern County, Calif., and made an agreement by which the company will operate these holdings on a royalty basis, it was announced today.

Christmas shopping expanded sharply here this week. Department store volume was estimated as increasing about 10 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Larger increases were foreseen for specialty shops. A year ago trade suffered from the reaction caused by the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor and the marked loss in volume occurring on Tuesday of the week when there was a false air raid alarm which practically suspended shopping for several hours.

Deferment for students now attending recognized engineering schools was urged this week by the consultative committee on engineering for the professional and technical division of the War Manpower Commission as being necessary "pending a more thorough study of the requirements of engineering manpower both by war industries and the armed forces," it was learned yesterday.
Churches in many communities have become "bright spots" for service men seeking worship, diversion and relaxation beyond camp confines.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- A complaint charging grand larceny was issued tonight by Foster Wheatley, justice of the peace, against Ralph Coghlan, editor of the editorial page of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, in connection with an unauthorized attempt by two men to take three old war cannon from the State Capitol grounds to a junk pile.

Civilians must be aroused by a nationwide program of adult education in the fundamental principles for which this nation is fighting if they are to take part more fully in the all-out war program and become an effective force in the drafting of a permanent peace once the war is won, Chester S. Williams, director of civic and adult education of the United States Office of Education, declared here yesterday.

One of the contributions to the war on the part of investors in corporate enterprises is wartime taxes, according to a dividend message addressed yesterday to 414,000 stockholders of the General Motors Corporation by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman.
Anne O'Hare McCormick stated lately: "A common strategy for peace is already as imperative as a common strategy for war."

BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt recommended today a detailed study of the recruiting women in England as a possible solution to the farm labor and manpower problem in this country, declaring that the English had learned that "there is nothing a woman cannot do equally as well as a man, except a job requiring brute strength."

Contributions of $143,713 have been received in a campaign for $200,000 now being conducted by the Young Women's Christian Association of New York City, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon in "Y" headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Roosevelt told Congress today that by the end of this month American forces overseas will total more than 1,000,000 men and that the "Axis powers have, temporarily at least, lost the initiative."
NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 11 -The Duke of Windsor has gone to the United States, partly for a rest and partly on business connected with the new economic policy which he has introduced in the Bahamas.

Application here for articles of incorporation of the American Council for Judaism, an organization that will seek to identify and define the Jew as a member of a religious community and nothing else, was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Penalties of a $500 fine or a year's imprisonment, or both, for violations of the thirty-five-mile speed limit set by the New York War Council were disclosed today in an opinion by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

Contests involving two strong Western teams and a pair of New York City's leading unbeaten quintets tonight will raise the curtain on the ninth Madison Square Garden collegiate basketball campaign. The twin bill, first of nineteen college double-headers scheduled at the Garden this season, will send Long Island University against Brigham Young in the opening game and City College against the Oklahoma Aggies.

I am glad to accept your suggestion that I answer the letter of "Gotham Boxing Fan" which appeared in your paper this morning. At the outset let me say that since the adoption of the Walker Act of 1924 the members of the Boxing Commission have been outstanding men of unimpeachable character whose sole desire has been to keep the sport in this State upon as high a level as possible.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 -- The Pittsburgh district reported three defense strikes today, two of which were settled, while negotiations designed to adjust the third controversy were stalemated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Only about one-third of the couples who recently applied for marriage licenses in this city plan to furnish an apartment or house before they reach their first anniversary. Fewer than a fourth of them plan to buy furniture in their first year of married life.

The tremendous enthusiasm for medical and scientific research that he encountered everywhere was what impressed Dr. Bela Schick most when he visited Soviet Russia before the war, the pediatrician told 600 physicians at a Russian War Relief dinner in his honor last night at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The big, bad Bears from Chicago are due to arrive here tomorrow morning for Sunday's world championship football play-off with the Redskins, and the more timid of the capital citizens have headed for the storm cellars.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -Representative Martin said today that the Republicans would conduct a vigorous drive in Congress convening next month to cut expendi tures by government agencies not performing war functions and to curb "the use of unreasonable power by bureaucrats."

Last July, William Phillips, former United States Ambassador to Rome, was sent to London as chief of the Office of Strategic Services in the British capital with the rank of Minister. In this post, his work was of a military nature and somewhat different from anything in his distinguished career in the State Department, in which he had twice been Under-secretary of State.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- A special grand jury investigating the financial affairs of Local 17 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America filed an indictment today against J. Harold Foster and Anthony Damiano, described as aides of Samuel Nuzzo, former business agent of Local 17, now on trial on grand larceny and forgery charges involving the funds of his union.

The trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric system yesterday presented to Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell proposals for the settlement of claims against certain accounting and legal firms, the most important of which involves the payment of $250,000 to the A.G. estate by the accounting firm of Haskins Sells.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 11 -- The arrest of two filling station attendants and the driver of a tank truck on a charge of selling gasoline ration coupons was announced today by Assistant District Attorney Harold F. Strohson of Nassau County, who said one of the men had boasted that he and his companions had disposed of coupons with a total trading value of 100,000 gallons.

In THE TIMES last Saturday, Mr. William H. Evans of Philadelphia reviewed the records of Boston College's opponents during the 1942 football season, but made the pointed mistake of omitting North Carolina Pre-Flight, the toughest foe on the Eagles' schedule.

Insignificant and irregular price changes ruled generally yesterday in the stock market, although volume swelled somewhat, due to the heavy turnover in low valued issues, and in this group tax selling was a factor. Transfers on the Stock Exchange were 641,330 shares, compared with 573,710 on Thursday.

Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein heard arguments yesterday on a motion to prevent Cravath, de Gersdorff, Swaine Wood from entering a general appearance for Chosen Corporation in a suit brought in this State on behalf of its shareholders against Serge Rubinstein and others.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Reports that the inventory control order to be issued by the War Production Board will be delayed beyond next Monday, when it was originally expected to be issued, circulated here today. According to information available, the order is now undergoing some last-minute changes and its issuance may be held up until late next week.

Representative Jerry Voorhis of California has signed with Devin-Adair to do a book on the financial problems of the war and postwar period. In announcing the contract, Mr. Voorhis's publishers speak of the Representative as the successor to Maury Maverick "as the chief literary light of Congress." The book is due in the Spring.

That was a rattling dispatch of Foster Harley's in this newspaper yesterday. In a hospital on an advanced South Pacific base the nameless skipper of a nameless destroyer told its adventures in a night naval battle off Savo Island in the Solomons on Nov. 13. The time of the story is forty as crowded minutes as man or ship can have known.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Don Ameche's next assignment at Twentieth Century-Fox will be "Stars and Stripes Forever," a screen biography by John Philip Sousa, the studio announced today. Kenneth Macgowan will produce the picture in association with Harry Goetz, New York stage producer, who negotiated the deal whereby Fox acquired rights to Sousa's autobiography and to his music.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -The Newspaper Industry Advisory Committee has been told that a rise in the price of newsprint is "imminent," W. G. Chandler, chief of the printing and publishing branch of the War Production Board, said tonight.
Many with schoolbooks under their arms, the vanguard of 21,000 New York City boys who have reached their eighteenth birthdays since June 30 began registering for military service yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Delegates to the fifty-fourth annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union were puzzled today over sites and dates for the 1943 championship meets in sixteen sports, but also devoted considerable attention to President Lawrence di Benedetto's plan for a nation-wide physical fitness program.

Sovereign immunity against suit in the courts of the State is not taken from a foreign government because that government is at war with this country, the Appellate Division held yesterday in a suit by Laszlo Telkes an American citizen, against the Hungarian National Museum for $11,706 allegedly due for employment as director of the Hungarian Reference Library here.

Of the huge overseas empire that was once the pride of the French Republic, only the Red Sea port of Jibuti, along with a stretch of adjacent territory, still pays obedience to the Vichy government, but it will not continue to do so for very long.

Preliminary surveys of consumer goods industries in which concentration of production is desirable for the war effort are being concluded, and detailed programs will be developed by the WPB leading to the selection of firms for continued production, Joseph L. Weiner, director of the Office of Civilian Supply of the WPB, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Standards Association at the Hotel Astor.

It is a fine thing that men at the lathe, drill, press or stamping machine, or those putting things together on assembly and sub-assembly lines, who have ideas for improving the processes at which they work should receive conspicuous recognition for putting them to use.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Two officers and three members of the crew who helped to save the destroyer Blakeley after it was torpedoed in the Caribbean were named to receive the Legion of Merit today by order of President Roosevelt.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- A new policy for a unified formula of censorship by Britain and the United States is believed to have been worked out tonight by John G. Winant, United States Ambassador, and Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, after a series of conferences following publication on both sides of the Atlantic of reports by correspondents of the extent to which the free interchange of opinion had been fettered by wartime restrictions.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11 -- Gasproof garments of olive drab, will be worn by every soldier who leaves the United States, Major Robert L. Dillon of the Army Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot said here in a talk this morning at the opening session of a Government Garment Industry Conference attended by approximately 250 representatives of southern concerns.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters and R.A.F. communique:

"We Are The Marines," a feature-length factual film, will have its local premiere this morning at the Globe Theatre. The drama, which was made by the March of Time in cooperation with the United States Marine Corps, treats of the training of that armed force from recruits to campaigners.

The city school authorities rejected yesterday the recommendation of Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins that instruction in social hygiene be given to high school children because of the 20 per cent rise in venereal infection among boys and girls 15 to 19 years old.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The stock markets were quiet again today.

Assistant District Attorney Herman T. Stichman of New York County was appointed council yesterday to William F. Bleakley, Moreland Act Commissioner investigating abuses in workmen's compensation insurance administration. District Attorney Frank Hogan granted Mr. Stichman a six-month leave of absence.

The Appellate Division reversed yesterday a Supreme Court ruling which held that owners of a controlling interest in a corporation owed a duty as fiduciaries to the corporation and to its minority stockholders and could be held liable for losses to the corporation resulting from its mismanagement or looting by persons to whom they sold the controlling interest.

News that Hitler has changed his army, navy and air chiefs, displacing officers of the older military tradition with younger men from the Nazi ranks, is a kind of climax to the struggle that has been going on within the army since long before the war. It has been intensified as the Fuehrer has more and more flouted the advice and decisions of his general staff.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES ON GUADALCANAL, Dec. 7 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Japanese troop losses in killed have exceeded ours by more than ten to one and more than 450 enemy planes have been destroyed in the four months' campaign on Guadalcanal, and our positions now are stronger than ever before, Major Gen. Alexander A. Vadegrift, Marine commander, said today.

Magistrate Ambrose Haddock in a sixteen-page opinion handed down yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court held that written notations of bets on horse races need no longer be considered as essential evidence for bookmaking conviction if surveillance over a period of time establishes other indications of bookmaking activities.

Paul A. Gammons and Theodore Revillon have formed a proxy committee and are circularizing shareholders of Burco, Inc., in an effort to oust the present board. Their purpose is declared to be liquidation of the corporation and distribution of its assets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The United States Treasury and its local Victory Fund Committees have sold $6,600,000,000 of the projected $9,000,000,000 Victory Fund to help finance the war, accomplishing in eleven days the sale of almost as large an amount of government obligations as was sold in the fourth Liberty or Victory Loan of the first World War in three weeks, the Treasury announced today.
A three-day celebration commemorating the 100th anniversary of the founding of Congregation Rodeph Sholom began last night with special services at its temple, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

A ten-room penthouse apartment in 1175 Park Avenue has been leased to Thomas F. McLaughlin, assistant to the president of the Crucible Steel Company, for George S. Pollitz Jr. through William A. White Sons.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 11 -"All is well," report the American diplomats and newspaper men at Lourdes, in the Pyrenees, who today start their second month of weary waiting for exchange. They left Vichy on Nov. 11 after the French Government had "registered a rupture of relations with the United State" and provided a special train for them.

Although war-time shortages in varsity manpower gave lower classmen unprecedented opportunities to shine this season, the eighteenth annual All-America football team chosen yesterday by The Associated Press is the nearest approach to an all-senior group in years.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA Dec. 11 (AP) -- Field artillery hurled tons of shells into the shrinking Japanese hold around Buna today after American troops repulsed a second counter-attack on their beachhead between the village and mission.

The High School of Music and Art presented last night its first opera, "The Second Hurricane," the work of Aaron Copland, with libretto by Edwin Denby, in the school auditorium at 135th Street and Convent Avenue. If the prolonged applause was any indication, both the opera and its performance were successes.
OTTAWA, Dec. 11 -- John Bracken, Progressive Premier of Manitoba for over twenty years, was elected today in Winnipeg leader of the National Conservative party.

All that a person needs to be a good air raid warden is "a helmet, an armband and the spirit of determination," according to John H. Morris, commandant of the air warden service, who appeared before the defense committee of the City Council yesterday in opposition to a proposed local law requiring the city to provide free uniforms for his subordinates.

What amounts to a concerted drive on adherence to closing dates has been started by magazine publishers, as a result of the numerous production, manpower and shipping problems created by the war. Individually and cooperatively, publishers are urging agencies to get their advertising copy in on time.

OTTAWA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Canadian corvette Morden has rescued an entire ship's company of 195 men, women and children from a Canadian merchantman torpedoed in the Atlantic, the Navy announced tonight, and has landed them in a "western Atlantic port."

The State Racing Commission yesterday established Thursday, April 8, as the 1943 opening date for racing in New York, the earliest beginning for the thoroughbreds since the renaissance of the sport in 1913. Dates for only two tracks, Jamaica and Aqueduct, were assigned, whereas in previous years the entire schedule for the five New York tracks was announced at the same time.

Eight hundred pieces of Victorian jewelry, all made by Austin, a New York jeweler of the era, were shown in a press preview yesterday at Franklin Simon's Round-Up Lounge. The exhibit will be open to the public Monday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Major League baseball clubs, accustomed to making long Spring training trips each year, may make sweeping revisions after Clark Griffith, owner of the Senators, calls on Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, within a week.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 11 (AP) -Randolph E. Paul, general counsel of the Treasury, said today that increased incomes resulting from wartime activities constituted "the explosive factor" in the country's economy.

Two opinions about Western civilization and the rest of the world were heard at the Nobel Prize Winners dinner. Pearl Buck said that the war is no longer a war for world freedom but only for European civilization, presumably including American civilization.

The four-story apartment house at 683 Broadway, Newark, N.J., has been sold for cash by the Haddon Hall Apartments, Inc., to the Newark Realty Company through Abeles-Stevens, Inc., brokers. The seller was represented by Roderick L. Perkins and the buyer by Popper Brothers, who were co-brokers in the deal.

A strong denunciation of bureaucracy and the extension of Federal powers under the present administration was voiced last night by Governor Frank M. Dixon of Alabama at the annual dinner of the Southern Society in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Big Five operating unions are asking the railroads for a 30 per cent increase in wages, with a minimum increase of $3 a day. In connection with their claims, it is to be hoped that attention will be called to certain remarkable wage-payment and make-work practices that have grown up on the railroads.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 12 -- Repeated Japanese counter-attacks to break Allied siege lines in the Sanananda sector of New Guinea, five miles up the coast from Buna, were thrown back yesterday, while in the newly won Gona area 440 enemy dead and sixteen prisoners already have been counted, the Allied Command announced today.

Year after year we recall, at this season when the appeal for the Hundred Neediest is made, the degrees of charity as defined by Maimonides. This wise philosopher found eight steps in the golden ladder of giving:

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Four Nazi Foeke-Wulf 190 fighters were trapped today when they came prowling at low altitude over the countryside of Southeast England. Anti-aircraft batteries forced the foe inland, where R.A.F. fighter pilots met them. One Nazi was sent spinning to earth and the others ran for home.
Mrs. Reginald B. Rives is at the Ritz-Carlton.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Adolf Hitler carried the policy of Nazi party domination over Germany a stride forward today following the shakeup of the High Command that made Gestapo-trained General Kurt Zeitzler the chief of the General Staff.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- Eight San Francisco Bay area landlords and two apartment house managers were accused in criminal actions today of charging too high rents, illegal evictions and false registration.

Directors of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company voted to pay a week's salary to officers and employes on Dec. 1, E.H. Little, president, announced yesterday. Payments will be made to those who are not on a regular commission or bonus plan and to those who have worked the equivalent of twelve months during the eighteen months immediately preceding Dec. 1.
MOSCOW, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's noon communique:
A vacant lot, lofts and a one-story commercial building were among downtown properties reported traded in yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Mills and cash interests bid up the wheat market today as a result of inability to purchase the actual grain. Professional traders are acting with extreme caution on the selling side, due to the continued agitation to lift the flour ceiling and prevent the sale of wheat below parity prices.
BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the wool market tomorrow:

Senator McCarran's one-man filibuster, which has helped to make it almost impossible for the present Congress to complete any further important legislation, once more calls attention to the serious need for amending the Senate's rules of debate. The closure rule, adopted in 1917, has again been shown to be ineffective.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- Along both railroads to Stalingrad, across the great Don bend and south of the Don from the Kuban, German forces are being brought to attack the broad belt that the Red Army has drawn around General von Hoht's trapped army west of Stalingrad.

In a round of carefully staged celebrations, speeches by the heads of States and note exchanges, the Rome-Berlin-Tokyo Axis celebrated yesterday the first anniversary of the German and Italian declarations of war on the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Criticizing the Office of Price Administration's fuel-off rationing system as "unnecessarily complex," inequitable and unworkable in determining consumer heating requirement, the Senate Truman Committee investigating the national defense program called today for a straight-line percentage reduction instead.

Tami Mauriello, the Bronx's candidate for the heavyweight title, got up from the floor of the ring at Madison Square Garden last night to end the fistic career of Lou Nova, husky Californian, before a gathering of 15,369 excited fight followers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 11 -- Many arrests of Danish leaders opposing the new pro-Nazi regime of Premier Erik Scavenius were reported from Denmark tonight. Among those arrested were the secretary of the Communist party of Denmark, Axel Larsen, and Professor Ole Chewitz. who was accused of underground activity in contact both with Communists and with the Conservative leader, former Commerce Minister Christmas Moeller, who is now in London.

In a plea to the private secondary schools of the nation to accept responsibility for "continuing long term tasks of general education and at the same time to prepare older youths for the training the will soon be called upon to take Dr. J.W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education declared last night that conservatism must not be confused with complacency in facing problems of a warring world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -President Roosevelt disclosed today that he had asked his old friend, Senator Norris of Nebraska, to continue to work for the principles he has long fought for, even though he is 81 and suffered political defeat last month after nearly forty years in Congress.

An entire floor in the building at 82-92 Beaver Street has been leased by Garcia Diaz, represented by Thomas Morch, through the Charles F. Noyes Company, which also rented space in the same building to the Commodity Research Bureau, Inc., and to the David C. Reid Company.

The country's third largest steel producer, the Republic Steel Corporation, announced yesterday that it reached, at 7 A.M. yesterday, the volume of steel produced in the whole of 1941, giving it twenty full days in which to ring up a new high record of output in 1942.

Harry is 4 months old and lives in a single furnished room with his parents and sister Jenny, who is 4, and brother Peter, 2. There are no toys for the children, no recreation for any of them. But they are a nice family doing the best they can, with their chins up, on Mr. T.'s $16.50 a week earned as a dishwasher.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The German Government was reported today to be sympathetic to the proposals for unshackling prisoners of war, most of them Canadians, who were placed in confinement early in October. The request that reprisal shackling be abandoned by both sides has been made by Switzerland as the protecting power and already Britain and Canada have agreed to free their German prisoners of their bonds tomorrow.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 -- In a statement on Latin America, the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America declared today that "we deplore the pretension of the Roman Catholic Hierarchy to circumscribe the religious freedom of Protestant Christians in the proclamation of their faith, while by implication reserving for themselves the right to the universal proclamation of their own."

Twenty-one months ago the Axis Powers may have looked upon American lend-lease aid to their enemies as a cloud no bigger than a man's hand. Now, added to our own war thunder-bolts, it masses formidably in the Western sky. This is the story told in the seventh quarterly report on lend-lease operations which the President sent to Congress yesterday.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES IN NEW GUINEA, Dec. 8 (Delayed) -- American and Australian forces in making the slow but steady progress in their attack against the Japanese shoreline foothold in Papua have been achieving local successes -- a thirty-yard advance here, capture of a gun position there -- and progressive constriction of the Japanese occupied area.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks today allowed trustees of the New Haven Railroad System to make bond interest payments amounting to about $11,200,000 and to purchase twenty-five new motor coaches for its subsidiary, the New England Transportation Company, at a cost of $375,000.

Bitter criticism was leveled last night by Assistant Superintendent of Schools William Harem on those teachers who obscure the "soundness and success" of the war courses program of the secondary schools by "selfish preoccupation" with their own futures or with the immediate effect of the program on their chosen subjects.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 -- Following is the text of a statement, "Our Heritage of Religious Freedom," by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Reorganization of the Workers Service Program of the Work Projects Administration into a permanent Federal education extension service for organized labor is being considered.

Covering operations for Southern mills in the December and January positions on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday prompted general buying from other sources and accounted for gains up to 26 points. On the advance, however, profit-taking developed and the list receded to an irregular close.

The report of the Outboard Marine and Manufacturing Company and its subsidiaries issued yesterday for the fiscal year ended with September shows a net profit of $1,122,315 after income and excess profits taxes and $300,000 provision for future losses on inventories and other contingencies.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Federal Judge John Biggs Jr. today directed Daniel O. Hastings, special master in bankruptcy proceedings of the Midland United Company and the Midland Utilities Company, to file as soon as possible a report on the claims of each company against the other.

The special committee named by Mayor La Guardia to investigate the pension status of former First Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines had under consideration yesterday a letter from the Citizens Budget Commission objecting to any pension award on the ground that it would be both illegal and inequitable.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- The heavy cruiser San Francisco, "night boat to Tulagi," which took the measure of a Japanese 14-inch gun battleship, a cruiser and a destroyer in the Solomons on Nov. 13, steamed, battered but proud, into the bay here today to receive from her home city the homage due the first United States combatant ship to win a decoration for heroism in this war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Loss of a freighter of 6,198 tons in the South Pacific "as the result of enemy action" was announced in a communique issued here today by the Navy Department, which also reported that a Flying Fortress attacked by fifteen Zeros in the Solomons had shot down five of them and returned home safely.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The curbs which he has managed to hold upon advances in the cost of living are a source of greater satisfaction than any other wartime accomplishments of his office, Leon Henderson, head of the OPA, told a press conference today.

Five of the twenty-two household scrap metal piles that the Federal Government acquired from the city two weeks ago have been cleared away and material from all but one of the others is moving to the steel mills at "a satisfactory rate," George Sutherland, regional salvage manager of the War Production Board's conservation division, disclosed yesterday.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin's controversial proposal to make the Australian militia available for service outside Australia was laid aside for at least six weeks today when the House of Representatives adjourned after defeating by a voice vote a resolution opposing such conscription.
I noticed a letter from Joshua Greenfield in THE TIMES last Saturday to the effect that the Heisman Trophy Committee had erred in picking Frank Sinkwich as the football player of the year.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- Governor Charles Poletti, long an advocate of public control and development of water power resources, demanded today that Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey and the incoming Republican Legislature act to secure the State's rights in the Niagara Falls power development, following yesterday's decision of the Court of Appeals that such action was within the Legislature's powers.

The Appellate Division set aside yesterday the condemnation award made by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin a year ago in the Sixth Avenue Elevated Railroad case and ordered a new trial in the condemnation proceedings. Justice McLaughlin had made an award of $12,519,063, plus interest of $1,639,997, making a total of $14,159,060.
Class A stockholders of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad Company will receive a dividend on Jan. 15 for the first time in its twenty-year history.

On Dec. 8 the City Council passed a local law permitting service men to ride free on city-owned subways and buses. All well and good if the city can foot the bill. I do not think it can. As a New Yorker in service, I do not approve of this local law.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Russians have destroyed sixty more big Axis transport planes in the Stalingrad area, making a total of 133 in four days, and the Red Army has "occupied heights of considerable tactical importance" in the area of Velikiye Luki on the frozen central front, it was announced here early today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 11 -Russian-Turkish relations have reached their firmest understanding since the outbreak of the war and a rapprochement between the Soviet Union and the government of Prime Minister Shukru Saracoglu, with the possibility of fresh unilateral or even bilateral declarations of friendship and non-aggression, may be expected in the coming weeks, this correspondent learned from high foreign diplomatic sources in the Turkish capital today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Income payments to individuals during October reached a high record of $10,279,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11 (AP) -Ten other horses are entered, but it's Whirlaway, the little horse with the big bank roll, who officials expect to fill the Fair Grounds with the largest crowd in its history tomorrow when the $15,000-added Louisiana Handicap is run.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -President Roosevelt nominated seventy-five high ranking Army officers for promotion today, among them several who have distinguished themselves in combat. The nominations were confirmed immediately by the Senate.

Paul Dullzell, executive secretary of Actors Equity Association, expressed the hope yesterday that the theatre would be able "to avoid any form of official censorship from the city or police or from the reform organizations." He spoke at the association's quarterly meeting in the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- The synthetic rubber program is to undergo another Senatorial investigation, on the heels of a study just concluded by the Truman committee which took in not only rubber but the gasoline and fuel-oil situation as well. Senator Gillette, Democrat, of Iowa, chairman of a Senate agriculture subcommittee which recently explored the synthetic-rubber problem, announced that his group will open a new investigation next Wednesday.
Of all the catch-penny, vote-getting schemes, the Free Ride Bill just passed by the City Council takes the prize.

Advent sermons will be preached in the city's churches tomorrow. Christmas music will be used by many choirs, including Bach's "Christmas Oratorio" and also that of Saint-Saens. In keeping with a national celebration of the day as Universal Bible Sunday among Protestants, many sermons will deal with Bible reading.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight W.
