Eisenhower, commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force in North Africa, has expressed himself as well satisfied with the cooperation he has received and still receives there from French Army officers, who are thoroughly acquainted with the country, and from native troops under them, it was learned in military circles here today.

State headquarters of the Office of Price Administration, which so far received only one appeal from the fuel-oil rations allowed by local boards, prepared yesterday for an increase of complaints by setting up a volunteer panel of five physicians and five heating engineers who will advise State Director Lee S. Buckingham on the disposition of appeals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- William Phillips, veteran career diplomat and recently Ambassador to Italy, was appointed by President Roosevelt today his personal representative in India with the rank of Ambassador. He is at present in London, where he is connected with the Office of Strategic Services of the Army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Under a rent-enforcement drive on a national scale by the Office of Price Administration, charges of criminal violations of its rent regulations were filed today against sixty to eighty landlords in various parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A special committee to deal with the problem of draft deferment for thousands of eligible Federal employes was named today by President Roosevelt. Paul Bellamy, editor of The Cleveland Plain Dealer, heads the committee, and Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, New York City, and Eric Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, are the other members.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Veteran Japanese troops, with fresh reserves from Burma, are stabbing repeatedly at the far-flung Chinese lines defending the mountainous heart of Yunnan Province from invasion, the High Command reported tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 11 -Both Paris and Vichy today were at pains to explain that Marshal Henri Philippe Petain is in perfect health, both mental and physical, and that Pierre Laval is "patiently obstinate in the pursuit of a single aim" -- "collaboration."

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Walther Nehring's Axis forces in Tunisia, now said to number 28,000, of which 25,000 are believed to be German, are attempting to extend their bridgehead before arrival of reinforcements gives Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson the strength to crush them.

THERE must be something in all that chatter about the climate of California. They are still playing college football out yonder. In this area we have had a fall of snow and the colleges have turned their attention to basketball, a game that is played under a roof. Not only that, but professional ice hockey has been on tap around here for some weeks.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 11 -- The Essex County Tax Board ordered this city today to add a total of $2,104,616 as omitted tax assessments for 1940 and 1941 against intangible personal property owned by the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Ogden D. Miller, director of athletics at Yale, announced today that regular rowing activities had been suspended for the duration and the appointments of rowing coaches, including Ed Leader, terminated.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- Governor Poletti opened the seventh annual session of the Hi-Y Assembly in the Capitol today, and in welcoming the 400 delegates from all parts of the State said that America had not ignored the interests of youth. He pointed out that vocational, health, recreational, citizenship and character forming needs had long had attention.
"We felt there was no reason we should be punished just because we had jobs."

Featured by sharp gains in apparel volume, sales of twenty-eight leading mail order and chain store companies showed an increase of 9.4 per cent in November, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Only a day after it was disclosed that the teachers of this city had asked for police protection against intruders and unruly pupils, another case of violence occurred yesterday when an angry mother entered a Brooklyn school and assaulted a teacher who was conducting a class.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Roosevelt met with the Cabinet, issued the quarterly report on lend-lease activities and held his press conference; his visitors included Representative Joseph E. Casey, B.B. Hickenlooper, Governor-elect of Iowa; Luis Munoz Marin, James W. Gerard and Robert E. Sherwood with Spencer Tracy.

More than 125,000 workers employed in the men's and boys' clothing industry throughout the country will be covered by a life insurance and health program as a result of a collective bargaining agreement between the Amalgamated Clothing Workers and the Clothing Manufacturers Association, it was announced yesterday.

The run of "Winter Soldiers" has been extended again, this time until Dec. 20, it was announced yesterday by the Studio Theatre of the New School for Social Research, which is presenting the play at 66 West Twelfth Street. Dealing with saboteurs in Nazi-conquered countries, the Dan James play had been scheduled to end its engagement after tomorrow night's performance.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

Because convertible sinking fund debentures of American Type Founders, Inc., due in 1950 have been called for redemption on Jan. 15 at 105 and interest, the New York Stock Exchange has ruled that commissions may be agreed upon mutually and that dealings may be in variations of 1/32.

Although the so-called variety cuts, about which you have been hearing so much recently, are on the list of non-rationed meats, they are very hard to come by in some instances. Hearts, for example, are far from plentiful. One butcher told this column that he received only eight or nine a day; a packer declared that all his company handled went into sausage.

England's failure to achieve the American conception of mass production proved a blessing in disguise when the blitz came, because the wide dispersal of plants prevented a slowdown of more than 15 per cent during the heaviest bombings, Malcolm Muir, chairman of the war committee of the National Association of Manufacturers and president and publisher of Newsweek, said yesterday in his first public statement since he returned from an eight-week tour of British plants.

HISTORY may not repeat itself according to any precisely predictable design, but principles, if they are true ones, always work themselves out in the same way. With this knowledge to give point to his story, Arthur Bryant, the biographer of Pepys, has written an extremely contemporary document in his study of England during the first half of the Napoleonic era, "The Years of Endurance."*

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- British troops made a demonstration in Teheran yesterday following an outbreak of riots in the Iranian capital Wednesday, reports from there today said. There has been no occupation of the city by Allied forces, however, and the troops who went through Teheran to protect oil installations and other British property.

The first offering of equipment trust certificates in three months featured a small volume of new security flotations here this week. Three separate issues, aggregating $4,522,000, were offered to the public in the form of bonds and certificates, against four diversified issues totaling $20,636,865 the week before and one municipal loan of $925,000 in the corresponding week in 1941, when the market was virtually at a standstill because of the declaration of war.

Warning that the Republican party must not permit those who believe that the United States should turn its back on the rest of the world as it did after the first World War to nominate its next candidate for President, was issued last night by Newbold Morris, president of the City Council. Mr. Morris spoke at a meeting of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club, 122 East Eighty-third Street.

SEATTLE, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The War Department and the Office of Censorship, commenting on a Seattle newspaper's agreement with a regional Army authority on limited use of a story it uncovered, said today that the military neither intends nor is empowered to advise papers how they should handle their news.
Mayor La Guardia celebrated his sixtieth birthday yesterday by giving blood to the Red Cross at 2 East Thirty-seventh Street.

A renewed emphasis upon Bible reading is to be made by thousands of Protestant ministers in sermons throughout the country tomorrow, when Universal Bible Sunday will be celebrated under the auspices of the American Bible Society. Special meetings will be held in many communities, virtually all Protestant denominations taking part.

The report of the American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months to Oct. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $11,356,578 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.15 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $14,704,063, or $2.90 a common share, in the twelve months to Oct. 31, 1941.
Attention has been called to the editorial on Pulaski in your issue of Oct. 10 in which you inquired for the famous banner made in 1778 by the Moravian Sisters of Bethlehem.

Change from heavy to light cream effective since Thanksgiving Day has occasioned little drop in sales volume in the New York metropolitan area, spokesmen for the large milk distributors reported yesterday.

All of the components of violin playing at its best were to be found in the performances put forth by Nathan Milstein at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Technically, tonally, or viewed from the standpoint of interpretation, each of his varied offerings proved a masterly achievement.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- Representatives of practically every real estate board in the State attended the induction today of A.N. Groves of Syracuse as president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards.

In a very courteous and factual letter in THE TIMES of Dec. 9 Thomas F. McCarthy, president of the Allied Liquor Industries, tries to refute the views expressed in my letter in THE TIMES of Nov. 29 in which I pointed out the "exorbitant profiteering of the distributive set-up of the liquor industry."

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Harvesting of wheat in the Southern Hemisphere is well advanced, according to Broomhall, British grain authority, and yields in both Argentina and Australia are reported to be well up on average, while quality is said to be very satisfactory. Broomhall's report continued:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -Stocker and feeder cattle were moved into the Midwestern Corn Belt in record volume during November to bring the total for July to December well above the corresponding months of 1941, the Agriculture Department reported today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 11 -- A recent increase in British patrolling in the area of El Agheila, Libya, has obtained indications, according to today's British communique, that the Axis forward troops "are in a state of some nervousness."
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 11 -- Criminal actions were filed in the Federal court here today against nine landlords in the Northeastern New Jersey Defense Rental Area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Roosevelt called upon Congress today to correct inequalities in straight and overtime pay and hours of work among the government's 2,500,000 civilian employes, or give him the power to do it.
Although the deer shooting season has closed another appeal has been issued to hunters by the New York Conservation Department to turn in deer hides they may have.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, issued a statement today for the guidance of employes who wish to pay Christmas or year-end bonuses in 1942 to employes whose salaries are within his jurisdiction.

IT might be in order to supplement briefly your account of Nov. 29 regarding Dr. M.N. Chappell's speech on daytime serials. His information covers the number of listeners to any given program at a specific time or over a period of time.

BACK in the Pennsylvania mountain villages of the Eighteen Seventies, when the children marveled and guffawed at Professor Blair's traveling puppet show it was always Herodia whom they remembered longest.

BY way of Cuba comes information that Italy planned to issue -- and perhaps has already released -- stamps to commemorate the tercentenary of the death of Galileo Galilei, the astronomer and experimental philosopher, and the 150th anniversary of the birth of Gioachino Antonio Rossini, operatic composer.

The interval of prosperity that the railroads now are enjoying is being challenged from two directions. The railroad employes are seeking an increase of 30 per cent in pay, while the Office of Price Administration has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to rescind the increases in passenger and freight rates granted earlier this year.
Because chemicals have unfamiliar names and are complex and ramified, the public does not always realize how much they are used in our ordinary daily life.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Paul V. McNutt, the silver-haired, genial former Governor of Indiana, utilized his first week as "czar" of American manpower by burning the midnight oil in an effort to streamline his organization commensurate with the wide and unprecedented powers granted him by President Roosevelt.

A CHANCE stop on a camping trip at a California ranch resort brings Tim Danvers and his friend Hank right in at the beginning of a mystery concerning the disappearance of a boy movie star. To Tim, son of a newspaper family, this looks like the story of the year and also the chance to help his brother Rob, cub reporter, who has lost faith in himself and his father's confidence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Because increased demand in New York Harbor for coal to meet bunker fuel requirements has necessitated importation of coal from Southern fields, the Office of Price Administration today set maximum prices which would assure a sufficient supply for ocean-going vessels carrying war materials which fuel at New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Indications this week of the early accession of French West Africa, with its valuable base, Dakar, to the ranks of the United Nations seemed to supply further justification of the recognition, first by Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, then by this government, of the de facto authority in French North Africa of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan.
The Braves and the Phils wound up the 1942 National League season in seventh and eighth place, but each club can boast a player who set a fielding record that is likely to stand for a long time.

TAMPA, Fla. -- One year of war has brought about a drastic change in this resort area, but as long as sunshine escapes the ration list the West Coast is going ahead with preparations to entertain Northern visitors this season.

A SIMPLE topic, projected into the midst of the world political and economic history of the last fifteen years and developed into a book at once scholarly and sound in content, yet breath-taking for the reader -- here is the undeniable merit of Dr. Egon Glesinger's book.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- The Sunday Dispatch, in a report from New York, charged today that Wendell L. Willkie had launched a series of "unrestrained attacks upon so-called British imperialism and British leaders."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, has signed four directives which bolster the powers of his vice chairman, Charles E. Wilson, by giving him full authority to direct the scheduling and production of aircraft and all other munitions.

TORONTO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Veteran Syd Howe scored three goals and assisted in a fourth tonight, but he labored in vain as Toronto shaded Detroit, 5 -- 4, before 10,915 fans to move into a tie for the National Hockey League leadership with the Boston Bruins.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Office of Defense Transportation authorized the railroads today to operate special trains, or extra sections, from Dec. 12 until Jan. 15, when necessary, to move service men on furlough.

THE town's roster of night spots continues to grow noticeably. On Dec. 23, Max Cassvan, for the past twenty years one of Europe's more active dispensers of after-dark entertainment, officially opens the Casbah at 112 Central Park South.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A Senate Military subcommittee investigating shortages of technological skills in the United States war program was warned today by Pierre Cot, French Minister for Air from 1936 to 1938, that France made a fatal error in draining her airplane factories and other plants of men to build up the huge army that met disaster so rapidly in June of 1940.

NO matter how ingeniously you may scheme to prevent it, the last few days before Christmas bring, as they will this year, the familiar flurry of last-minute shopping, tree trimming and package wrapping.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (U.P.) -The Manpower Commission estimated tonight that 63,000,000 men and women of the United States would be fighting the war on battlefronts and in factories and farms of the home front a year hence.

OF all the many books about Hawaii which have appeared within the past few years, none can compare with Professor Bradley's historical treatise for patient, exhaustive scholarship and keen insight into the causes of the growth of American influence in the islands.

"SUDS IN YOUR EYE" is a crazy, funny story of Southern California -- and very unlike most of the tall tales that have come out of that region. In Mrs. Laswell's book there is no Hollywood, no swimming pools, no glamour girls. The setting is a dilapidated, flower-grown junk yard.

CAROLINE LE ROY WEBSTER was the second wife of Daniel Webster and rumor, in the form of some biographers, seems to suggest that she was not too good for him. In other words, she was not the restraining force in the life of Black Dan'l that his first wife, the somewhat puritanical Grace Fletcher, appears to have been.

BOSTON, Dec. 12 -- A three-goal scoring burst in the second period, two of which were registered by Flash Hollett within thirty-three seconds, enabled the Boston Bruins to protect their undefeated National Hockey League home-game record by topping Montreal's Canadiens, 3 -- 2, today at the Boston Garden.

AT THE FRONT, IN TUNISIA, Dec. 8 (delayed) -- In the tradition of Rogers' Rangers, British and American fighters have made a raid behind the German line, arriving at a point near Bizerte. They held up an estimated German division, cut communications and threw the stereotyped German mind into confusion.

Despite the battering he suffered at the hands of Tami Mauriello on Friday night in their Madison Square Garden bout, Lou Nova of California announced in St. Clare's Hospital yesterday that he does not intend to retire from the ring.

As was expected, wartime conditions have somewhat curtailed the supply of decorative greens and accessories for this Christmastide. But a preliminary survey among wholesalers reveals that there still will be a rich selection to choose from.

VIRTUALLY all the major recordings released in 1942 have been heard and commented upon. The only exception is the new version of Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto by Artur Schnabel, Frederick Stock and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, which has just reached this department.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Spain finds herself today in the muddled position of being pro-Axis in her sympathies, yet fearful of a complete Axis victory. She can confidently expect that her unhappy neutrality will continue for some time, but cannot view war developments with anything but misgivings, no matter whether the Allies or the Axis powers emerge victorious.

Serious tie-ups in essential war production are in the making as a result of employers' inability under the wage stabilization order to attract office personnel or even keep the clerks they have, Dr. Coleman L. Maze, president of the National Office Management Association, warned yesterday.

An announcement that should be of unusual interest to every breeder of sporting dogs in the United States is that of the English Setter Club of America, which proclaims the inaugural breeders' sale of American sporting dogs to be held Friday evening, April 9, as a feature of that organization's annual Spring field trial meeting.

Recommendations advocating more aggressive promotion of lacrosse in colleges and schools and its inclusion in the athletic program for the nation's armed forces were adopted yesterday at the Hotel Lincoln as leaders of the sport convened for their annual meetings.

CHARLES TOWN V. Va., Dec. 12 -- Danny Scocca, leading jockey of the meeting, brought home three winners, including Mrs. C.M. Greet Jr.'s Hard Telling in the six-and-a-half-furlong Willard Purse today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Although in six years there were only seventeen days when the sun did not shine on Puerto Rico, she needs more than that free vitamin exposure to correct her ills.

IT is clear from the number of informative books about Canada that have been written during the last three years that both Canadians and their neighbors are taking keen interest in the present development and future probabilities of this only remaining major New World country with an Old World attachment.

CARIO, Egypt, Dec. 12 (U.P.) -- Colonel Mary Booth of the Salvation Army, recently released after two and a half years in German prison camps, said today that she was convinced that she had had "the narrowest escape" from death before a firing squad.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Add a generous coating of Army khaki and Navy blue to the normal peacetime picture of the New Jersey shore during the Winter vacation season; allow for dimmed-out lighting in areas fronting on the ocean and you get an idea of current conditions in the score of resort communities along the coastal stretch from Long Branch to Atlantic City.

General Hideki Tojo, Japan's blustering Premier, told an assembly of military leaders at the Tokyo War Ministry a few days ago that "making use of our great material resources, we are ready to annihilate the British and Americans at any moment at any point on the globe."

A report released yesterday by Fred D. Hesley, president of Todd Erie Basin Dry Docks, Inc., revealed that 53,088,804 pounds of scrap had been collected from July 2 to Nov. 20 by the shipbuilding and ship repair yards in the Greater New York area.

LONG years ago, when the radio was scarcely more than a spark in Guglielmo Marconi's wireless. Stephen Leacock penned an amusing, slightly nostalgic essay entitled "The Decline of the Drama," wherein he recalled to adherents of the then new drawing-room play the glories of old-time melodrama.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 12 -- Farmers of the Southwest are asserting that everything possible will be done to attain the 1943 crop-production goals, but they have serious doubts over being able to deliver in the face of the labor shortage and other handicaps.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Board of War Communications today postponed indefinitely an order which would ban all telegraphic greeting messages beginning on Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The President's Third War Powers Bill was blown aside by the first gust of a legislative storm that is forecast in full fury for Washington soon after Jan. 3. While it is raging many documents -- and individuals -- are likely to be blown aside and away.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (Science Service) -- Many applications have already been received by the Office of the Alien Property Custodian here for licenses to manufacture devices and materials covered by enemy-owned patents, under the policy just announced by the President.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -Survivors of the crew of the President Coolidge today related dramatically stories of the escape from the former palatial liner as she plunged into the Pacific after hitting a mine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Junior Naval Officers' Committee of Washington will give its Christmas Ball on Friday night at the Mayflower Hotel. The United States Marine Corps Band will provide the music for dancing, and it he proceeds from the party will be donated to naval war charities.

Mrs. Ernest R. Adee will give a reception for the Right Rev. James E. Freeman, Episcopal Bishop of Washington, the Right Rev. Noble C. Powell, coadjutor of the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland, and members of the New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association on Tuesday afternoon in the small ballroom of the Colony Club. During the afternoon the film "Building of a Cathedral" will be shown.

A fund of more than $10,000 is expected to be raised through the eighteenth annual concert under the auspices of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, which will take place tomorrow afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

MONTREAL -- With the exception of the Marquis and Domain d'Esterel at Ste. Marguerite's, all the resorts in the popular Laurentian Winter sports area, extending from Shawbridge to Mont Tremblant, will keep their doors open this season.

HERE is a book which presents what might justly be called a refresher course in the history of the war from the Treaty of Versailles to the present. It is a book to be studied, not merely read; to be kept close at hand and consulted in connection with the news from day to day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A total of 1,613 new casualties of the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard were reported to next of kin from Nov. 16 to 30.

LONDON, Dec. 12 (U.P.) -- The Air Ministry today revealed details of the rescue of seventy-three survivors of a torpedoed British boat after reconnaissance planes had flown 55,000 miles and naval units had combed hundreds of square miles of the ocean in a thirteen-day search.

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange progressed at a slow pace in yesterday's abbreviated session. Small hedge selling was sufficient to retain values below the previous close for most of the session. At the cessation of trading losses of 2 to 5 points were posted on options from March forward, while nominal quotations on the December and the January placed them at losses of 18 and 15 points respectively.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- President Roosevelt will broadcast Christmas greetings to the nation on Christmas Eve from the National Community Christmas Tree on the South Grounds of the White House, when Mrs. Roosevelt and he will preside over the annual ceremony around it.

Taking exception to Pearl Buck's recent statement that the Asiatic people no longer felt they would gain freedom through our participation in the war, Dr. Oliver Caldwell, secretary of the Associated Board for Christian Colleges in China, maintained yesterday at a meeting of the Association of Teachers of the Social Studies, that America's allies in the Far East realized that they would benefit greatly from a United Nations victory.

LANCASTER, N.Y., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Bart may be only a pedigreed Belgian shepherd dog, but he wears an Army-Navy "E" production pin and has a photo-identification badge to get him past the armed guards at the gates of the Scott Aviation Corporation plant.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (Netherlands News Agency) -- The third annual soccer match to be played on foreign soil between teams representing the Netherlands and Belgium ended in a 0-0 tie today.

ATLANTA, Dec. 12 -- Although it was inaugurated six months ago and has a fund of $150,000,000 appropriated specifically to help small factories get war orders, the Smaller War Plants Corporation, headed by Lou Holland, deputy WPB administrator, has given Georgia industries no aid and has done little or nothing for any other Southern State.

A revolutionary type of furniture is appearing this week in some of the metropolitan stores. Geared to both wartime and peacetime home needs, it is easy to ship from place to place, because it is light in weight and can be packed flat; yet it is good-looking and extremely adaptable.

MORIZ ROSENTHAL celebrates his eightieth birthday this coming Friday. He will be thinking of many things. We are informed that he is completing his memoirs. If they are couched in terms anything like the wit and shrewdness of his customary conversation, we shall have a record worth reading.

The Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., announce that the thirteenth annual judges' and exhibitors' course will be held on Jan. 12, 13, 14 and 15 in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

THE Russian War Relief, which has not always had an easy time of getting the cooperation of radio in the furtherance of its important work, has prepared a major item for presentation next Sunday from 3:30 to 4 P.M. over WOR and Mutual.

Many recent predictions of the supremacy of transocean air service over steamship travel after the war have failed to take into account the "all important factor" of patronage, Peter van den Toorn, managing director of the Holland-America Line, declared yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 12 -- Royal Air Force medium bombers started a fire at the entrance of the Tunis Canal Thursday night, it was announced today.

Maintaining that it would be "not only unpatriotic, but disastrous," to continue the "traditional" college curriculum in wartime, the Hunter College Chapter of the New York College Teachers Union issued a plan yesterday for a two-year program designed solely to train women for specified war occupations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The War Labor Board today approved a 15 per cent wage increase to 475 employes of eleven Connecticut cigar-making plants to correct what it termed maladjustments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Price reductions and cash refunds totaling $829,332,800 resulted from the re-negotiation of the War Department's contracts during the seven-month period from April 22 to Dec. 1, this year and by Jan. 1, are expected to reach an aggregate of $1,000,000,000, the department announced today.

"THERE is nothing new in this recital of events leading to the greatest struggle of all times; nor is it an 'inside' story with exclusive thrills," Lilian Mowrer writes in the introduction to her new book. "It is a primer for those who have little time for study, but who begin to realize how much there is at stake."

CANDOR about money matters has never been the rule in Hollywood, and a proposal made this week by Lester Cowan, former executive secretary of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and now a Columbia producer, that the cost of all pictures competing for Academy Awards be listed, has created a stir among production companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission has ordered fifteen manufacturers of nonpatented wire rope, and the association through which they are alleged to have combined, to cease and desist from what it termed a conspiracy to fix prices.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 12 -- Whirlaway, running his usual race, turned on the power in one of his famous stretch drives today and won drawing clear from a field of seven other horses in the $15,000-added Louisiana Handicap. A record crowd of 20,000 was on hand to see him romp at the Fair Grounds.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- Fordham scored its fourth straight basketball victory of the season tonight, defeating Cornell by 41 -- 34. Bob Mullens and Tony Karpowicz paced the attack, the former leading a rally that broke a 23-all deadlock in the second half.

The New York Rangers, still in last place in the National Hockey League race, will skate against the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden tonight. Despite the fact that neither team possesses a formidable record, the game promises to attract a fair-sized gathering.

Declaring that the final report on Pearl Harbor proved the wisdom of withholding full information at the time of the disaster, Rabbi Hyman J. Schachtel in West End Synagogue, 160 West Eighty-second Street, said yesterday that our faith in our government and war leaders consequently should be strengthened.

Not much that happens in the little town of Alder Valley escapes the attention of Martha Berry. She has been postmistress there for many years, and before that she taught school. Consequently, she knows everybody and is ideally situated to help Captain Courtney Brade solve the mystery of the stranger who is found dead of a bullet wound not far from Martha's own house.

Major Carey Peters ("Pete" to his friends), who is Provost Marshal at Fort Bragg, scents coming trouble at this Army post, and so does Janet Bingham Masters, a young widow who is visiting at the post. They are both right.

In its editorials of Nov. 29, "Full Employment," and of Dec. 5, "The Beveridge Report," THE NEW YORK TIMES raises questions about post-war economic policy of what seem major importance. Everybody agrees that for some time after the war government interference in the economic field will have to continue on a big scale.
SILVER SPRINGS, Fla. -- Marineland at St. Augustine and Eagle's Nest Oriental Gardens at Clearwater are the only two of Florida's major attractions that will not be open for the duration.

An audience of 2,500 invested $5,011 in war stamps yesterday in order to hear the concert given in the late afternoon at Carnegie Hall by the New York City WPA Symphony Orchestra as the second in the series of four being sponsored by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia on behalf of the United States Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A Japanese tanker was damaged, another was straddled by two bombs, and six enemy Zero planes were shot down by United States Army Flying Fortresses and Lightning Fighters, the Lockheed P-38's, in a raid on Faisi Harbor, 275 miles northwest of Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons, the Navy announced today.

Gifts in memory of loved ones who are gone are made by many contributors to the Neediest Cases Fund. Such gifts, like all the others, bring new hope and courage as well as material aid to the families and individuals among the Neediest.

NEARLY every day's headlines contribute new evidence of the importance of merchant shipping in the global war that is being fought. Whether it be Hitler's lines of supply across the Mediterranean or the Allies' in the two major oceans and the Arctic, these arteries of war are likely to hold the outcome of the fighting on any and all fronts.

The Navy League of America offers a new Yuletide suggestion which has already been followed by Mrs. Fritz Kreisler and others. They have donated funds which would have been used for personal remembrances, to be spent by the League in buying Christmas kits for sailors.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's fourth "Students" concert of the season last night at Carnegie Hall was devoted to Johannes Brahms. It consisted of the Violin Concerto, with Mishel Piastro, the orchestra's concertmaster, as the soloist, and the Symphony No. 1 in C minor.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- Full responsibility for the State budget now in the process of preparation was assumed today by the incoming Dewey administration. With the approval of all parties concerned, Governor Poletti announced that all decisions on policy in connection with the budget would be made by Mr. Dewey and his incoming budget director, John E. Burton, thus giving the new administration an extra twenty days to prepare the document.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WE ran here two weeks ago the figures compiled by Publishers' Weekly that showed a decline of about 10 per cent in the number of books published in ten months of this year compared to the similar period last year.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- Allied heavy and medium bombers attacked Japanese airdromes at Salamaua and Lae, today's communique reported, while heavy tropical rains kept ground operations to a minimum and gave respite to the enemy's strong Buna coastal positions where a heavy Allied offensive is imminent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson said at a press conference today that there had been initial successes for the Allied arms in North Africa but warned that all was not over, that "the main work, the big work, is still to be done."

THE supply of flash bulbs for amateur use is definitely restricted to the stocks available on dealers' shelves before the recent WPB order went into effect ruling out the amateurs. That means there will be no more bulbs for amateurs after this supply is exhausted, a period variously estimated at two to six months.

AMERICAN Ambassador to Japan during the decade of mounting strain and recurring crisis that culminated in the bombing of Pearl Harbor, Joseph Clark Grew, on the basis of his own dispatches and observations, could have written a book of unique authority and value on the background of our present war in the Far East.

The primary purpose of the loan privilege in insurance policies is to provide the policyholder with a source of funds for emergency purposes. The extent to which policyholders take advantage of this is indicated by the fact that in the four critical years 1929-1932 the life insurance companies of the country extended nearly $3,000,000,000 in new policy loans.

Acceleration of the aircraft and shipbuilding programs will go far to offset any production slack created by the cutback in output of numerous items on the general ordnance list, arid procurement officers will make every effort to replace canceled contracts with new orders, ordnance officer incated here last week.

THE titanic effort which alone can bring our nation victory over the Axis war machines cannot be the responsibility of any single group in America. Our major home-front factors labor, management and agriculture, and government representing all three -- each has its specific responsibilities, but none can function fully and effectively except as part of a team.

As a result of the draft and the high salaries offered in war industries thousands of teachers throughout the country have left their classrooms, creating a serious shortage that threatens to curtail educational facilities in elementary and secondary schools.

THOMAS HARDY fans will do well to keep in touch with the Colby College Library, which seems to be making a specialty of retrieving lost articles belonging to their idol. Coming upon the heels of the "Maumbury Ring" sketch, it has just brought out of obscurity, after sixty-five years, a forgotten short story of his salad days.

THE universality of Bach's music seems to give justification to varied interpretations. The fact that expression marks and dynamics are only rarely found in the actual manuscripts of Bach seems to challenge the interpreter to fill the vacuum.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 12 (U.P.) -- A Chinese communique said today that Japanese columns, striking northward from Tengyueh in Western Yunnan had been stopped by the Chinese in a severe engagement still in progress, and other military reports told of apparent Japanese preparations for invasion of the interior of Yunnan.

Christmas shopping expanded steadily here last week and merchants look for further sharp increases until the peak is reached possibly next week. Department store volume was estimated as about 10 per cent greater than for the corresponding week of 1941.

Various States may have different opinions on how their conservation departments should continue to function during wartime. A departure from regular procedure, occasioned by the emergency, has been adopted in Missouri, where a new post of supervisor of the department's defense activities has been created.

Rollin M. Huyler has taken over the commandership of the South Shore Power Squadron, succeeding Michael F. Travers, who becomes treasurer for the coming year. Dr. Anthony A. Scimeca has become lieutenant commander and C.R. Wulf the first lieutenant.

The hockey team of St. Paul's School, Concord, N.H., will play its annual benefit Christmas season game at Madison Square Garden on Thursday afternoon, when it will meet the Princeton University junior varsity team in a match that will draw many relatives and friends of the young men on the two squads, as well as alumni of the two institutions and others interested in the traditional appeal of this game.

THE exploits of Tony Beaver, Paul Bunyan's southern counterpart; of Pecos Bill, inventive cowboy; of Stormalong and Ichabod Paddock, New England whale hunters extraordinary, never fail to rouse hilarious admiration when recounted to boys and girls.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- In almost ceaseless air operations from Mid-Eastern and British bases, United States Army and Royal Air Force fliers subjected the Italian cities of Naples and Turin to more batterings late yesterday and last night and pounded the French city of Rouen during daylight today, along with offensive sweeps over the Netherlands and France.

The gremlin, a fabulous imp who plays tricks on war fliers, has a cousin in human form who puts kinks into America's rationing program by writing false figures on application forms, according to a tale told yesterday at one of the two coffee ration trials in the Empire State Building.

There is a question that one would sometimes like to put to the Nationalist leaders in India or their partisans in this country. It would be a genuine question wholly designed to procure information, and not intended as criticism or challenge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The country found its food supply put under the control of a single Food Administrator this week for the second time in a quarter of a century and itself faced with a revolution in its dietary habits such as had not been enforced by the first World War under the food regime of Mr. Herbert Hoover.

Many debutantes of the season, who in less serious times would have made their debuts at private parties, will be introduced to society en masse at the Victory Debutante Cotillion and Ball to be held the night of Dec. 21 at the Ritz-Carlton.

AMERICA'S women must supplement men in the manpower of the nation. Theirs is the double task of winning victory and raising children. Yet, while they have increasing responsibility for the war effort, it must not be overlooked that their primary duty is to their homes.

The chief complaint of employers in war industries against women workers "boils down" to their high absenteeism rate, mostly among very young women and those who have children, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins said here yesterday.

The Greek nation is still fighting and "is resolved to continue the struggle until complete victory is won," Cimon Diamantopoulos, Greek Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera Victory Rally which was one of the intermission features of the regular Saturday afternoon Metropolitan Opera broadcast.

LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The American communique from Cairo today announced that the heavy bombers of the Ninth United States Air Force set large fires at Naples in daylight yesterday, with hits observed on the Victor Emmanuel and Viga moles, and scored also on a medium-sized merchantman moored at the Massaniello mole and other ships in the target area.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- A very Brundage, president of the United States Sports Federation, urged the Amateur Athletic Union tonight to adopt a more widespread program of physical education to bring this nation up to a mass sports level with the totalitarian countries.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Here are some questions about the draft with answers by the Office of War Information:

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, yesterday congratulated Eugene P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council, upon his selection as chairman of the New York maritime industries section of the United Seamen's Service.

In your editorial of Dec. 1, "An Offer to Italy," you very rightly refer to assurances that must be given to the Italian people as to the war aims of the United Nations in so far as they touch upon the future of the territories of the Kingdom of Italy, and its colonies.

Under the auspices of the New York Mount Holyoke Club the glee club of the college will give its annual concert of Christmas carols on Friday night at the Town Hall. Dr. Roswell G. Ham, president of Mount Holyoke College, and Mrs. Ham will be the guests of honor at a dinner to be given at the headquarters of the alumnae club at the New Weston.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 12 -- Governor Charles Edison, warning that isolationism and repetition of the "mistakes" made after World War I might pave the way for World War III, told the fifth annual convention of the New Jersey State C.I.O. Council here today that labor should settle its differences and present a vigorous front against "the forces of reaction" in our post-war policies.

Snow belongs to the countryman. In the city there is little beauty or wonder in any snow that falls, except as it is seen sifting down in a dappled curtain that whitens the rooftops and window ledges. In the city's canyons it becomes slush and ice, a darkening nuisance to be plowed aside and carted away.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- The controversial rule for full disclosure of facts in sales of securities over the counter, proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission to protect uninformed buyers of securities from unscrupulous dealers, popped up unexpectedly again last week when the commission indirectly made a case for itself in favor of the measure.

Calling her a "menace" and a disgrace to her race, Magistrate Abner Surpless held Mrs. Alice Thompson, a Negro who stalked into a school on Friday and attacked a teacher, in $5,000 bail yesterday on charges of felonious assault. Presiding in Brooklyn Felony Court, the Magistrate sharply criticized Mayor La Guardia, holding that he must share some of the blame for what is taking place in the schools.

President Roosevelt paid high tribute to the men of the American merchant marine, "who are so gallantly working and fighting side by side with our Army and Navy," in a message read yesterday at dedication exercises for the new United States Maritime Service Training Station at Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn.

Forecasting that while it might not be possible to build a "perfect" world in the post-war period, a "better" one was within reach, Wendell L. Willkie appealed last night to the Jewish people to keep burning "the lights of the temples" they had built in every corner of the world.

NEW ORLEANS -- Few cities can be more aware of the war than this one, which remembers many wars. With its busy port of embarkation, its naval air training station, its Coast Guard station, its lakefront given over to service activities, its industries turning out cargo planes, ships, tugs and tank-landing boats, it daily feeds life into the struggle.
BOSTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Senator Byrd of Virginia declared today that "there are those in the government who are using the emergency of the war to accomplish so-called reforms."

Whatever one may think about the desirability of engaging at present in post-war planning, there is no doubt in my mind that there is a necessity for such planning in certain parts of the economic field, if we do not wish chaotic conditions to continue one day longer than necessary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Operators and miners in the Appalachian coal fields, working for an agreement for a six-day work week in order to produce more coal for the war program, failed to get together largely because of a dispute as to whether existing penalties for contract violations should apply to the extra day's work, according to statements issued here today by the conflicting parties.

SOME high school girls think Fredric March is practically the most gorgeous man in the movies. They are sure he exists at the center of the most glamorous circles in Hollywood, that his life is a round of extravagant parties mixed with exciting work, land that he moves generally in a world lit with champagne bubbles.

The registration of New York City's youths for military service continued yesterday and Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Selective Director, announced that 600 youths had enrolled with 280 local boards in the five boroughs. On Friday officials said some 1,200 had registered.

THE keynote of these twenty-four character sketches, the underlying quality, is understanding, sympathetic response to the artist's nature, intent and achievement. To use Zigrosser's own words: "Knowledge based upon lifelong friendship."

Budget Director Kenneth Dayton has resigned to become one of a group of key assistants to former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, it was disclosed yesterday. Mr. Dayton, who has been associated with La Guardia administrations since 1934, will start on his new job tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 12 -- A general spirit of confidence that the Republican party will be returned to national power in 1944 pervaded the Republican National Committee meeting here this week, although the feeling of exultation subsided noticeably whenever any one suggested that the 1944 Democratic Presidential nominee might be Franklin D. Roosevelt, whose vote-getting abilities are highly respected by the opposition.

Invitations are being sent out this week for the Christmas tea dance which members of the junior committee of the Spence Alumnae Society will give Dec. 28 at the Stork Club for the benefit of the Spence Adoption Nursery. Mrs. William Malcolm Mather is president of the society, which is celebrating this year the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding and the placing of the one-thousandth child in a foster home.

Kurt Appelbaum was heard in the last of a series of three recitals devoted to piano sonatas by Beethoven, late yesterday afternoon, in Town Hall. At this final event the program comprised the sonatas in A major, Op. 101; E flat major, Op. 27, No. 1, and A flat major, Op. 110.

The news that Sweden, the last remaining neutral European maritime power, has already lost more than 40 per cent of her pre-war tonnage in the present conflict was contained in a report released here yesterday by Ernst Raberg, secretary of the American branch of the Swedish Seamen's Union, an affiliate of the International Transport Workers Federation.
KINGSTON -- Winter sports officials in Ulster and Greene Counties, the Catskill Mountain region usually blessed with powder snow, championship events and keen sport, are anticipating a record season.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Berkshire County, comprising 959 square miles in the Western Massachusetts uplands, is expecting an invasion of Winter sports devotees. For those hardy perennials known as the skiing crowd there are now twenty-one tows, for all of which gasoline will be available.

A SAFETY "DON'T": A household safety rule is, never fool around with firearms. To illustrate the importance of caution, the National Safety Council last week told this story. A cat scratched Mrs. Julien Hebert of New Orleans. The irate lady chased the animal with a revolver.

Columbia's wrestling team opened its 1942-43 season by defeating Rutgers, 19 -- 13, at University Hall yesterday. In a preliminary meet, the Rutgers junior varsity matmen won from the Lion jayvees, 20 -- 16. "

In the twelve months bounded by Pearl Harbor and its first anniversary last week the American industrial production front has achieved prodigies. It has taken huge strides toward converting the greatest peacetime industrial machine into the mightiest wartime arsenal.

MR. ARNOLD is the most baffling of the New Dealers. He is not a Socialist. He does not believe that the solution of all our economic ills lies in government "planning." He does not play politics. He attacks manufacturers and unions with equal relish.

Officials of the Kosciuszko Foundation will be hosts this evening at an informal supper dance for the "Ten Times Ten" committee now being organized in the interests of the benefit Polka Military Ball to be given Jan. 22 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The quiet lull that overhangs major Japanese military operations gives the immediate impression that Japan may have slipped back into a defensive role, but close observers here have begun to calculate whether this is not the prelude to another sharp and powerful attack in our direction.
The Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue, will have its monthly flower show at 2:30 P.M. on Wednesday. B.Y. Morrison is to speak on the subject of "Peru."

From the pelicans of California Henry J. Kaiser drew a moral lesson for Americans in his recent speech before the N.A.M. Beside Monterey Bay was a sardine factory. Daily the refuse of the cannery went overboard into the bay, and daily a huge flock of pelicans came to feed upon it.

LONDON, Dec. 12 (U.P.) -- Great Britain and Canada struck the chains from German prisoners today in reply to a proposal of the Swiss Government, but Germany said that her decision on the matter of unshackling Allied prisoners was still in "the stage of diplomatic negotiations."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Diplomatic conversations have been undertaken by the United States with the United Nations, looking possi bly, to a joint declaration by them regarding the "criminal acts" of murder and persecution of Jews and other people in the Nazi-occupied countries of Europe.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- The Hi-Y Assembly went on record today for reduction of the voting age to 18 years. The "bill" introduced by the Olean delegation, stirred much debate.

WHEN American troops stormed into French North Africa, motion picture film went along to play its part in winning over to our side the populace of Algiers and Casablanca by providing relaxation and entertainment in theatres that had previously been used by the Axis and their Vichy collaborationists as propaganda outlets.

Although Americans should "do anything to win the war," they also must keenly analyze every step taken by the government to make certain that all liberties will be restored after the war, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, declared yesterday at the Central Branch Y.W.C.A., Lexington Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- This season finds the Cloister, the center of resort life on this semi-tropical island, a haven for military men and their families, as well as for civilians on furlough from war work.

ACCORDING to a "publisher's introduction" to this small but significant volume, Mr. Gandhi -- whose activities are at the moment in abeyance -- is liable to suffer "injustice." There is allusion to "opponents who easily find ways to falsify his position."

The President Coolidge was a modern turbo-electric liner built at the Newport News Shipbuilding plant in 1931 for the transpacific trade along with her sister vessel the President Hoover, which was lost by grounding in the Pacific several years before the war.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 12 -- Yale opened its hockey season tonight with a salvo of goals to defeat Boston University by 19 -- 1.

THE glorious annals of American heroism have been considerably enriched since last Dee. 7, and it is gratifying that acknowledgment of the main deeds of valor during the first months of the war has been made in book form.

Reporting on operations for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, Paul L. Davies, president of the Food Machinery Corporation, said yesterday that "profits before Federal taxes amounted to $5,565,135, or $2,558,406 in excess of our best previous fiscal year."

SEVEN artists who were prize winners in the Artists for Victory exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum are among those contributing examples of their work for the auction for Russian War Relief this afternoon, from 3 to 7 o'clock, at Hotel One Fifth Avenue.

In wartime the curve of adult crime usually goes down, while juvenile crime rises sharply. The process is at work in the United States, where this year commitments to reform schools have risen as much as 66 per cent over 1941. The situation is typical in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- One year after Pearl Harbor President Roosevelt has completed an organization for the management of the civilian war effort which appears to answer, for the present at least, the questions which have aroused public turmoil since we became a belligerent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -- On the quarterdeck of the battered heavy cruiser San Francisco, hero ship of one of America's greatest naval successes, Admiral Ernest J. King today presented the Congressional Medal of Honor to Commander Bruce McCandless, the young officer whom fate designated to take over the vessel's direction in the thick of battle.

NEW group exhibitions, one-man shows and special displays designed to attract the Christmas shopper were about equally divided among the events of last week, most of the attractions continuing to or through the holidays.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 12 -- Loot of conquered areas is now littered all around the Pacific by the Japanese, and some of it has passed back into American hands and is being used against Premier Hideki Tojo's men.

SANFORD, Fla. -- This season there is a new type of guest in Florida -- the family-to-visit-service-man. Also, there are as usual the elderly people who flee from the cold of the fuel-rationed North and Winter residents who own their homes.

OMAHA, Dec. 12 -- With the corn crop virtually all in the crib, the average Middle Western farmer is temporarily over the worst of his labor worries. With the vexations of gasoline rationing to complain about as a substitute, he isn't talking quite so much about labor now as he was a few weeks ago.

IN this week holiday trade will reach its peak and, in spite of country-wide gasoline rationing and the huge victory loan, retailers expect to see 1941 sales exceeded by a good margin. The comparison, of course, will be with the period immediately following Pearl Harbor, when trade acceleration almost halted.

CHRISTMAS PIE in the old English manner: Select small tart apples, peel, core, but do not slice. Arrange in a greased, fairly deep baking dish. Sprinkle generously with sugar, add grated lemon rind and lemon juice, top with rich pastry and bake.
Mrs. Jeanne Stanley Oakes, wife of Thomas Fletcher Oakes of Hartford, Conn., and daughter of Philip Bartholomew Stanley, was found dead in her apartment, 743 Madison Avenue, at 11 A.M. yesterday.

Two years ago an employment manager who wanted to hire the cream of the nation's college students would have written coaxing letters to half a dozen top-ranking seniors, after traveling all over the country visiting the campuses of colleges for men.
MOSCOW, Dec. 12 -- The pattern of the battles in the Stalingrad and central salients has not changed appreciably in the last twenty-four hours.
A LOG of short-wave broadcasts from the far-flung corners of the world reflects growing confusion in the Axis camps but slowly mounting strength for the United Nations.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12 -- St. John's staved off a desperate rally in the closing minutes of play to defeat Princeton's basketball to by 56 -- 51 tonight. It was the Indians' third straight victory, and the second setback in three starts for the Tigers.

For the first time in fifteen years foreign-born players are honored in the rankings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, as released last night for the war season of 1942, with Frederick Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles in the top positions.

TWO years ago the Washington Redskins met the Great Big Bears for the national professional football championship and G. Preston (the Magnificent) Marshall, the luxurious laundryman who owns the Redskins, still shudders when he recalls the ghastly fate of his hirelings. They were harried, chivvied, knocked down, rolled flat and trodden upon ignominiously.

Long before the war the Germans experimented with air trains, which consisted of an engine-driven plane or "locomotive" to which gliders were coupled. The gliders were released one by one and soared down to their local destinations, while the rest of the train traveled on.

Applications for the Spars, the new Women's Coast Guard Reserve, are coming in "very slowly," it was said yesterday by Lieutenant James Giddings, recruiting officer for the Waves and Spars, at the Office of Naval Officer Procurement, 33 Pine Street.

IT is the little things that make Christmas merry and it's not too early to think about them. You can evoke the spirit of bygone holidays in small ways, duplicating the traditional celebrations in mood if not in detail.

The purchase of $31,000,000 of the 2 1/2 per cent Victory Bonds due in 1968 was announced yesterday by the Aetna Life Affiliated Companies of Hartford, Conn. In addition, it was stated, the companies of the Aetna Life group had purchased more than $1,000,000 of tax savings notes.

THIS is "not a private adventure at all," for the Glen Hazard boys, as Dale Gillow realizes when that indefatigable gang finds itself on the Mississippi in as hot pursuit as an old shanty boat will permit of a band of Nazi spies.

Russia will fight on and in the event of a military victory for the United Nations should be an important factor in formulating a lasting peace, according to participants in a discussion of "Russia -- A Long View" at a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Senate and House leaders agreed today that, barring unforeseen emergencies or complications, the Seventy-seventh Congress would adjourn sine die Wednesday after a second session running through 346 days and setting a full-Congress record of 711 days since Jan. 3, 1941.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 12 -- For the fifth time during the war, Switzerland was on the receiving end of explosive and incendiary bombs dropped last night by "unidentified" planes apparently en route to Northern Italy, according to an official Swiss statement, which said the bombs caused considerable material damage at at least two points.

ONE of the ironies of the present situation has been pointed out in a letter sent to The Times by two of our leading publishers -- G. Wren Howard of Jonathan Cape's and Stanley Unwin of Allen Unwin's.

IN this engaging volume, Prince Hubertus zu Loewenstein, who scarcely needs an introduction to the American reader, presents an odyssey of his years as a passionate anti-Nazi crusader. The story begins in April, 1933.

A transfer of 1,000,000 workers from posts in the Federal Government to private industry, as a means of improving the manpower situation, was advocated last night by Major Gen. Edward Martin, Republican Governor-elect of Pennsylvania.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 12 -- During the 1941-42 academic year, 3,243 doctoral dissertations were accepted by American and Canadian universities, Dr. Edward A. Henry, director of libraries at the University of Cincinnati, announced today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- With the trains and buses that in former Winters were bright with the gaudy raiment of skiers and thick with the smell of ski-wax now engaged in more important work, Bear Mountain is the best available Winter sports spot for the metropolitan snow-sports addict.

Although the American Bible Society distributed 8,096,977 volumes of Scriptures in 1941, the largest total of any year since 1931 and 35 per cent over 1940, the organization declared that distribution of Scriptures in 1942 undoubtedly would exceed last year, according to a report yesterday by Religious News Service, 381 Fourth Avenue.

Representatives of the Treasury and the Federal Reserve System are conferring with the Office of Economic Stabilization to devise new defenses against the danger of inflation. The problem is, according to Secretary Morgenthau, to induce consumers "to refrain from spending" some $40,000,000,000 in 1943.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 (AP) -- John L. Halpin, deputy commissioner of the New York Conservation Department, has been re-elected president of the National Conference on Conservation Education and Publicity for 1943 on the basis of a mail vote among members.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Strength in the cash wheat market was again today the dominating factor in the futures market. All deliveries of wheat except May, rose to the highest levels of the season, with millers on the buying side of December and the close on the Board of Trade was near the top with gains of 1/8 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel. the current delivery showing the most strength.

The snow-capped peaks of the Alps glowed red last week, reflecting a mass of flame from the proud city of Turin below. For the twenty-fourth time since Benito Mussolini hit a France already reeling under German blows, the city -- in Italy's economy it is Detroit, although in actual size it ranks with Baltimore -- was under air attack by R.A.F. bombers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- (U.P.) -- American and British forces battling the Axis for control of North Africa may shortly be reinforced by 50,000 Senegalese troops, the Office of War Information said tonight.

ALL news editors and most intelligent readers have long known that our enemies have used news as a weapon in their total war on us. Few, however, have realized how effective a weapon it has been. Mr. Gordon, who was news editor of the Columbia Broadcasting System and is now a member of the staff of the Office of War Information, has done a thorough exposure of German.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12 -- It came as no particular surprise to the Argentine people to be told, as they were told last week by Federal Public Prosecutor Belisario Gache Piran, that the German Embassy here was actively engaged in espionage on a large scale.

Arriving by plane from Washington, after a four-day state visit as the guest of President Roosevelt, Major Gen. Fulgencio Batista, President of Cuba, put in a busy day here yesterday attending a round of formal and private receptions until his departure for Buffalo shortly before midnight.

Men's clothing sales should improve from 5 to 8 per cent during the balance of the year and the Spring season as a result of the 38-year age limit ordered for Selective Service, clothiers stated yesterday. This, however, will offset only part of the marked decline in sales since the Summer.

RICHARD ROSSON, who has run into plenty of uninvited trouble in his various worldwide treks filming authentic scenes for the movies, has just returned after making five transatlantic round trips aboard Canadian Navy corvettes, which were looking for nothing but trouble, in order to get actual scenes of the Battle of the Atlantic for Universal's picture, "Corvettes in Action."

MIAMI, Fla. -- It takes more than a war apparently to keep visitors away from this resort of sun, sand and sports. Reports of big waterfront hotels in Miami Beach being taken over by the military have resulted in more vacationists in this town, which is connected with the former by good bus service.

The hugest scholarship fund in history is this year being offered -- even urged upon -- the male youth of America. According to an estimate made by R.B. Stewart, controller of Purdue University, it will amount to more than half a billion dollars. This sum is to be spent at about 300 colleges and universities to train young men for war, or for services connected with the war.

The performance of "Der Rosenkavalier" on the night of Jan. 8 at the Metropolitan Opera House, has been taken over by Smith College Club of New York for its annual opera benefit, in aid of its scholarship fund. Lotte Lehmann and Rise Stevens head the cast.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Dec. 12 (U.P.) -- Ralph Coghlan, chief of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch editorial staff, was arraigned today on a complaint charging him and two others with grand larceny in an attempt to move an old cannon from the Capitol lawn to a scrap metal heap.

WITH the inevitability of death and taxes, someone periodically raises the question. Is the Novel Done For? Wallace Stegner, himself an accomplished novelist, writes under that heading in the current Harper's, tells us why he is seriously concerned, and what he believes is necessary to save the situation.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 12 -- For the first time since the beginning of the "militaristic" phase of the fascist era with the onslaught against Ethiopia, the average Italian is learning what war means on his own doorstep. From this vantage point it seems clear that this realization has not brought with it the final sense of the inevitable -- in terms of military defeat.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12 -- One hundred faculty members and administrative officers have resigned their positions at Princeton University to enter war service, a survey completed here this week reveals. The figure represents about 25 per cent of the university's normal staff.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 12 -- Sixty former and present members of the Victory Class Association gathered tonight in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club for a reunion and there was much talk over pleasant sailing days in the small sloops, which for twenty-two years have been spreading canvas on Long Island Sound.

Pointing out that racial tensions are most prevalent in economically depressed and congested areas, 300 educators and social workers at a conference on racial and cultural relations held yesterday at Benjamin Franklin High School, ll4th Street and East River Drive, urged an increase in the teaching staffs of schools in these sections.

The Salvage Shop Depot at 34 West Fifty-eighth Street, maintained by the salvage committee of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association to collect scrap metal for war industries, will be the setting Tuesday afternoon for an open house party at which Mrs. A. Pierson Riker will act as hostess.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (Canadian Press) -- High scoring marked play today in the British football leagues as leaders in all sections gained easy victories.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 13 -- The Russians have captured 74,500 officers and men and killed 169,000 -- a total of 243,000 German losses -- since the beginning of their twin Winter offensives on the Stalingrad and central fronts, the Soviet Information Bureau announced today as the Germans were reported making a desperate fight to break out of an encirclement northwest of the Volga city.

The food industry, which since Pearl Harbor has been urging creation of a Food Administration to direct its complex war time activities, now fears that it may have won a nollow victory with the appointment of Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard, according to comment in some trade quarters.
MR. ROBERTS, who has written often of the sea and the men who follow it, has in "The U.S. Navy Fights" brought together the men and ships and deeds that compose American Navy tradition.

A BOOK that remains to be written, and it should be written soon, or most of the people who are the only surviving sources of information will be dead, is the history of barnstorming in aviation. It has been called the "Minsky era" of flying by some of those who took part in it, and for the years just following the last war it was about the only way in which aviation was kept alive.

The smashing of a Long Island black market in gasoline ration coupons, whose business since July is declared to have been in 'excess of 150,000 gallons, was seen by enforcement attorneys of the Office of Price Administration last night, after the arraignments of six men, including the head of an oil corporation, before two United States Commissioners.

TO a Hoosier boy who has never been deaf to the call of destiny nor averse to doing a little discreet calling himself if destiny were too long silent has been given more power over the lives and happiness of Americans than any man ever has exercised before.

BACK in the days when gang-killings and crusading district attorneys were "hot" news, Darryl Zanuck, and Mervyn Leroy after him, established the Hollywood practice of blasting front-page headlines onto the screen.

Since the Christmas season is traditionally a time rich in happy memories, the reader who scans the columns devoted to the Hundred Neediest feels doubly depressed by their cheerless stories. How can Christmas possibly be made merry for them? Yet behind these bleak histories of poverty, illness and misfortune one happy thought lights up the darkness.

Featured by steady expansion of Christmas shopping, retail trade was active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

A broad form of social insurance that would eliminate the necessity for all forms of relief and end qualification tests was advocated yesterday by Commissioner of Public Welfare William Hodson, nearing the end of his ninth year as head of the city's Welfare Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Navy announced today the names of three officers and thirty-four enlisted men to whom letters have been sent commending them for courageous performance of duty while under attack.

During the next few weeks young women of society will take an active part in holiday entertaining for men in the armed forces who are stationed here or near by and are in the city on furlough. Three dances at which the young service men will be special guests are in prospect for this period.

IN writing of war and peace. Mr. Hambro has weighty claims upon our attention. He is one of Norway's principal journalists (long editor of the Morgenbladet) and perhaps her foremost political leader. He has been President of the League of Nations Assembly and a member of the League Council.

Making his first important player transaction since becoming major domo of Brooklyn's baseball affairs, Branch Rickey yesterday announced that the Dodgers had obtained Reuben Franklin (Rube) Melton, powerfully framed right-handed pitcher, from the Phils for Johnny Allen, veteran hurler, and cash.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 12 -- Lieut. Comdr. Tom Hamilton of the United States Navy is football's "man of the year" for 1942.
As the battle for North Africa entered its second month last week with no signs of an immediate decision, the Allies were preparing for another German counter to their Mediterranean coup.

The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that its production of forgings is now at a rate twenty-five times that of 1938, the year before the war started in Europe. George J. Stanley, vice president and general sales manager, said the expansion of aluminum forging, a comparatively new industry when the war began, had been second to none in the aluminum field.

IF it were not for such sponsoring agencies as the Y.M.H.A., the Students Dance Recitals series and the Dance Observer, the American dance would be in a sad state indeed these days; but thanks to these agencies quite the reverse is the case, and it is possible for the second Sunday in succession to write enthusiastically in these columns of rising young American artists.
"THREE GREAT DOCUMENTS ON HUMAN LIBERTIES," with an introduction by Vincent Starrett, has been published by Normandie House, Chicago.

Owners of notable private residences in this city have contributed whole-heartedly from their collections of rare furniture and objets d'art to the unique benefit exhibition of French and English art treasures of the eighteenth century, which will be opened at the Park-Bernet Galleries Saturday night with an invitation preview.

A potential Nazi plan by which Admiral Jean Francois Darlan was to head a "European fleet" built around the French warships, now sunk in the harbor of Toulon while Admiral Darlan is with the Allies in Africa, was reported yesterday by the French newspaper Pour la Victoire, published here.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Contrary to early prophecy, all indications here are for a long and active season in which many branches of war work and benefits will be added to the regular sports and social program. Since many visitors remained throughout the Summer, and many more arrived unusually early, practically every house is occupied.

Another college basketball season, the ninth since Director Ned Irish reintroduced the sport at Madison Square Garden, was launched there last night. With a record crowd of 18,386 on hand for the intersectional double-header, C.C.N.Y. lost to the Oklahoma Aggies, 38 -- 32, after L.I.U. had turned back Brigham Young University, 43 -- 40.

"ONCE upon a time in the city of Belgrade there lived a poor widow with her three sons. . . ." That, says the author of this story of the Serbian irregulars under General Draja Mikhailovitch of the Chetniks, is the way he would like to begin his tale.

After an absence of a season Massenet's "Manon" was restored to the repertoire at the Metropolitan last night. A special feature of the revival was the inclusion of the Cours la Reine scene, which had not been presented for many years at the Broadway house.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The Admiralty announced today that an enemy cargo ship and an escort vessel were sunk and four other ships damaged off Dieppe last night when a German convoy was overtaken by light British naval forces.

Future debutantes and young men of "prep" school and early college years will be feted during the Christmas holiday season at several series of subscription dances that have been continued over a period of many years.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 12 -- While Chief of Government Pierre Laval, either in Vichy or in Paris, is pursuing his "patient efforts" to devise a Franco-German agreement that will satisfy at once Reichsfuehrer Hitler and French opinion, his police continue systematically to remove opposition by arresting "terrorists," all described as "dangerous" and some as having confessed.

Holding its rivals scoreless from the field in the first half, the St. Ann's Academy basketball team, defending Manhattan-Richmond C.H.S.A.A. champion, routed St. Simon Stock, 44 to 21, in one of the battles on the scholastic quintuple-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

If George A. Cromie really wants to get a ride from a passing car, he should learn to fly the distress signal. This consists of hoisting the International Flag -- namely, a one-dollar bill -- each time a car approaches.

WHEN Chief Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes of the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts became Associate Justice Holmes of the United States Supreme Court and went to Washington, he adopted the practice of his deceased predecessor, Justice Gray, of taking on each year as secretary a member of the class which was being currently graduated by Harvard Law School.

The head of the Mint clan and holder of the purse strings is old Obadiah Mint, now very feeble and almost blind. Most of the others are descendants of Obadiah's brother Ezra, long since deceased. The former Sherry Locke, now Mrs. Kit Storm, is more distantly related, and she has not been one of the inner circle like the others, who all live within hailing distance of Obadiah's house.

THE history of all great wars shows that whatever their causes or results, they leave deposits that change the contour of the existing society. It was so in the Napoleonic wars, in the Civil War and in the first World War. Doubtlessly it will be so in the present war.

ONE of Hollywood's toilers does nothing but drill extras in army formations. He is Ted Deputy, a tall Scotch-Irish ex-Army man, and his value to the studios is that he knows the formation manoeuvres and route steps of the armies of various countries.
