CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Livestock prices were mainly steady today as only small numbers of hogs, cattle and sheep were offered for sale. The report of the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The mighty Chicago Bears, unbeaten in their last twenty-four games and winners of thirty-nine of their last forty, will collide with the Washington Redskins in the world chamship football play-off before a capacity crowd of 36,000 in Griffith Stadium tomorrow afternoon.

WE now are entering the second year of what is, quite clearly, the war of the people of the United States against the Axis. For every one is in it. Into the Army, Navy and the other armed forces have gone millions of young men, eager to get the matter settled so that things can be normal again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Office of War Information issued today the following list of Selective Service classifications, revised to include the new category created by the recent order suspending induction of men over 38:
OTTAWA, Dec. 12 -- Unless we have peace by next year this looks like Canada's las old-fashioned Christmas for some time. But this year's Christmas trees and fancy wrappings have been saved.

The Radcliffe Appointment Bureau has just released a booklet to students on "War and Placement" as a oide to jobs correlated to their fields of concentration. It describes calls which have come fn from government agencies, industry, business concerns and educational institutions, and helps girls to visualize what college training they need to be fitted for tile types of work offered.

FOR the first time in history a vast pool of the engineering knowledge of the country has been formed to modernize, standardize and streamline the radio apparatus used in Uncle Sam's tanks, ships, airplanes and land stations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- President Roosevelt today again directed Montgomery Ward Co. to sign a maintenance of membership contract with a C.I.O. union without inclusion of a disputed "under duress" clause. He acted as "Commander in Chief in time of war" after the company had asked him to intervene.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 12 -- Emphasizing the principle that no nation attacker or attacked, should gain territory as a result of war, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, proposed today that the world should return to the boundaries which existed before Japan's attack on Manchuria and then redraft those boundaries in accordance with the decisions of a revitalized League of Nations.

THE Civilian Defense Volunteer Office will present a free United Nations Christmas festival Dec. 21 at the Hunter College auditorium. The Manhattan CDVO Music Unit, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Landram MacFarland, is in charge of the program, which Rill feature choruses and dance groups from Belgium, Greece, Norway, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Latin America.

When children respond to an entertainment with silence it may mean one of several things, according to a Handbook for Children's Theatre just published by the Association of the Junior Leagues of America. The children may be bored, or absorbed in the story, or "filled with wonder at the first sight of a play."

Scoring its third straight triumph the N.Y.U. basketball team last night routed the Fort Monmouth quintet, 67 -- 39, on the University Heights floor. The Violet, ahead throughout, held a 23-17 edge at the intermission.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Snow has come earlier than usual to the Green Mountains this Winter and already skiers are flying over the slopes of Mansfield and the other mountains throughout Vermont. The mile-and-a-quarter chair lift will go into operation on Saturday, it has been announced, and will run daily except Wednesdays for the remainder of the Winter, conveying skiers from the lower slopes of Mansfield, on the eastern side, to the top of the mountain.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 12 -- Farmers face the immense task of producing in 1943 more than they did in 1942, one of the best crop years in history, with less help and less machinery and only a hope that weather conditions will be as ideal.

THE Civilian Defense Volunteer Office will present a free United Nations Christmas festival Dec. 21 at the Hunter College auditorium. The Manhattan CDVO Music Unit, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Landram MacFarland, is in charge of the program, which Rill feature choruses and dance groups from Belgium, Greece, Norway, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Latin America.

OPPORTUNITY is offered to antique collectors anal decorators to see an unusually authentic early American setting for fine Duncan Phyfe furniture. At the Museum of the City of New York, a drawing room, newly arranged and just opened to the public, is an appropriate background for antiques from an old Manhattan mansion.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 11 -- United States forces in New Zealand now find the "girl" situation complicated as applications are being made by men of the outfits here for permission to marry.

THE Museum of Modern Art could have made its portraiture show bigger and more comprehensive by increasing the span so as to represent portraiture through the ages. But the show is certainly big enough, just on a twentieth-century basis, luring the visitor on and on through every room in the second-floor maze.

In his letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 29 Count Richard Coudenhove-Kalergi wishes to convey the idea that unless we create a United States of Europe immediately after this war we shall inevitably have a World War III. Unfortunately, there are erroneous assumptions in the letter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The movement of iron ore on the Great Lakes this year exceeded the War Production Board's goal of 91,500,000 tons, the Office of Defense Transportation announced today as the last cargo of the season neared its dock, on a lower lake, en route to the steel mills.

When children respond to an entertainment with silence it may mean one of several things, according to a Handbook for Children's Theatre just published by the Association of the Junior Leagues of America. The children may be bored, or absorbed in the story, or "filled with wonder at the first sight of a play."

Scoring its third straight triumph the N.Y.U. basketball team last night routed the Fort Monmouth quintet, 67 -- 39, on the University Heights floor. The Violet, ahead throughout, held a 23-17 edge at the intermission.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Snow has come earlier than usual to the Green Mountains this Winter and already skiers are flying over the slopes of Mansfield and the other mountains throughout Vermont. The mile-and-a-quarter chair lift will go into operation on Saturday, it has been announced, and will run daily except Wednesdays for the remainder of the Winter, conveying skiers from the lower slopes of Mansfield, on the eastern side, to the top of the mountain.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 12 -- Farmers face the immense task of producing in 1943 more than they did in 1942, one of the best crop years in history, with less help and less machinery and only a hope that weather conditions will be as ideal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The 21,936-ton liner President Coolidge has been sunk in the South Pacific as a result of striking a mine when in use as a transport, but only four men were lost out of approximately 4,000 Army troops on board, the Navy announced today.

The first round of the crucial Battle of Africa drew to a close last week. It had been opened early in November by a smashing British victory in Egypt and by the brilliant American landing in Morocco and Algeria. A grand Allied pincers, designed to squeeze the Axis from the Mediterranean's lower shore and expose Southern Europe to second-front assault, had won some 1,800 miles of African coast.

The seventh round of P.S.A.L. dual swimming meets was completed in two divisions yesterday, and ties for first place were finally broken in both. DeWitt Clinton took the first place slot in the Manhattan-Bronx league by defeating Commerce, 45 to 20, while James Monroe bowed to Stuyvesant, 35 to 32. It was the seventh straight triumph of the season for the unbeaten Governors and the first setback for Monroe.

Coaches from most of the rowing colleges of the country held their annual meeting at the Hotel Lexington yesterday and found themselves confronted with war conditions that made continuance of competition on a regular basis doubtful.

The big bombers roar out on their missions against the Axis in a tempo that is increasing as the war goes on. The range far to reach industrial cities, even fly over the towering Alps, carrying the huge bombs that carry demoralizing terror in their whistling downward flight, that smash machinery and disrupt production.

The task of rebuilding the schools and the cultural life of Europe after this war will be staggering. Not only will it be necessary to help such countries as Poland or Czechoslovakia to build again their schools and other cultural institutions on the ruins left behind by the Nazis, but an even more difficult task will have to be faced in the Fascist countries.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 -- It's Georgia and the University of California at Los Angeles in the Pasadena Rose Bowl New Year's Day.

According to Washington dispatches, the Joint Committee on Reduction of Non-Essential Federal Expenditures has offered a resolution calling for a Congressional investigation and legislative remedies for what is alleged to be a tangle of government red tape, the flooding of industries with questionnaires and resultant increased consumer and taxpayer costs, hampering war production.

An authentic eighteenth-century production of "The Clandestine Marriage" by David Garrick and George Colman will be staged by the Barnard College dramatic organization, Wigs and Cues, on Wednesday night in Barnard's Brinckerhoff Theatre.

THE purpose of this book, by the director of radio productions for the University of Chicago, is to provoke discussion about radio's part in the war effort. As a start for that discussion, each chapter is followed by a commentary by a person qualified to speak on the subject with which that chapter deals.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The conviction that the Allies have made a sorry mess of things in North Africa, as far as Admiral Jean Francois Darlan is concerned, was expressed today by the London Trades Union Council. Distrust of him personally and dislike of the whole policy that put him into power are so widespread in Great Britain now that any strong opinion like the council's is well received by the man in the street.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 12 -- A plot by the Japanese military clique to assassinate Charlie Chaplin in Tokyo in 1932 in the hope that this act would precipitate a war between Japan and the United States was revealed by the film comedian in an interview here today.

BIOGRAPHERS know that letters constitute a very important source of information. Since most letters are written without thought of future examination or publication in mind, they reveal, therefore, comparatively honest expressions of belief and extempore observations of events.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson's British First Army in Tunisia has beaten off all enemy attempts to drive wedges into its positions controlling the strategic strong points on the roads leading to Tunis, Allied Headquarters reported today.

THE men of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra have got such a kick out of the two concerts they have given for service men that they are eager to play more of them. They are sure to be given the chance. One likelihood is that they will give a concert dedicating the new auditorium at the Naval Training Station at Lakehurst, N.J.

THE last of the seven auctions of from one-fifth to one-fourth of the philatelic holdings of the late Colonel E.H.R. Green was concluded last week and the reaction of New York observers is that the American stamp market was never stronger than today.

LAKE PLACID -- With its motto, "Vacation for Victory," this pioneer Adirondack Winter resort is preparing to offer ice and snow enthusiasts the same program of activity as it has in the past. Facilities in the area will be in full operation except only that the bobsled run on Mount Van Hoevenberg will be curtailed.

Three latex-bearing plants with annual crop possibilities are being specially grown and studied -- goldenrod, with rubber mainly in its leaves; kok-sagyz, or Russian dandelion, with rubber mainly in its roots, and cryptostegia, with rubber in both stems and leaves. The last, a perennial, may be capable of providing many harvests each year.

SABOTAGE on a grand scale is the subject of this thriller. Many airplanes have been stolen from the factory where they were made, and neither Military Intelligence nor the F.B.I. has been able to discover who took them or where they were taken.

IN these troubled days when, more than ever, man must help man, surely we shall remember the Neediest. Surely we shall not pass by these saddened neighbors of ours who, except for the turn of fortune, might be any of us.

Proflavin powder has succeeded in conquering infection of wounds where sulfanilamide failed. It is not yet clear whether proflavin is effective by itself or whether there must be a preliminary dusting of wounds with sulfanilamide. At any rate proflavin combats both streptococcus and staphylococcus infections.

As an octogenarian keenly in sympathy with change, may I express approval of the stand taken by Ted Pittenger in his recent letter to THE TIMES on "Language and Usage"? I never said "Name and address, please," but I must approve when Webster yields to countless thousands of shop girls who do.

Activity in low-priced shares set the tone for trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and resulted in the heaviest Saturday volume in a month, 340,730 shares. The market was also the broadest since Nov. 7 and of the 661 issues traded 245 rose, 168 fell and 248 were unchanged.

Life has brightened a lot for women war workers, who are now drawing higher pay than they learned before the war. Many have $10 to $20 more weekly to spend or to save. Just where this extra money goes gets as many answers as there were unfulfilled feminine wishes in the leaner years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Office of Defense Transportation tightened its controls today over tank car movements of petroleum products to the East Coast in the hope of raising daily receipts from 750,000 to 900,000 barrels. The action was taken by Joseph B. Eastman, chairman of the ODT. At the request of Donald ]@[. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

THE take-out or informatory double has long been used in rubber bridge as a strengths-showing bid, usually stronger than a simple overcall. In duplicate bridge, experts give the double a different meaning. They have learned that in duplicate it is often safer to double than to overcall, since the double gives partner a choice of suits.

AL JOLSON, who hasn't produced a show since he and George Hale were responsible for the musical "Hold On to Your Hats," back in '40, is seriously considering opening a producer's office. He has several scripts under his scrutiny.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

APPARENTLY Preston Sturges completely convinced himself with his "Sullivan's Travels" last Winter that comedy is the fare for these times -- and not just conventional "idea comedy" but comedy of the most frivolous sort.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Anxiety lest an Allied invasion force strike the Norwegian coast somewhere between Namsos and Bodoe is growing among German troops garrisoning that bastion of Hitler's "fortress of Europe." Word received by Norwegian Government circles in London tells of the enemy becoming more and more convinced that a "second front" will be opened before long against them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Newspapers which have "substantially" increased circulation next year over 1941 levels will have to apply to the War Production Board for increased newsprint supplies if a supply reduction formula submitted to the WPB Thursday by the Newspaper Industry Advisory Committee is adopted.

Sometimes failure to comply with tax laws operates by indirection so as to bring about the equivalent of severe penalties. Such a case was recently decided under the New York Stock Transfer Tax Law by the highest court of the State.

Guest ranches and desert resorts in the Tucson (Ariz.) area report advance reservations 35 per cent higher than last year for early December. San Marcos Inn at Chandler and the Arizona Biltmore at Phoenix open on Tuesday for the season, and Christmas Day will see the opening of the Ingleside.

I WOULD like to say a word concerning a statement in your review of my book, "Robert Cain." Your reviewer wrote that because of the subject-matter of my novel I would do well to avoid my home town in the future.

PARENTS asking what books to get for children at Christmas say, "Mary insists upon reading adult books; do you think I should let her?" And "Jim reads only the comics," and "John simply refuses to read." Or maybe the trouble is that Peter doesn't care for the lovely books his brother read when he was 12.

OTTAWA, Dec. 12 -- The election of John Bracken to the leadership of the Conservative party and the addition to its title of the name Progressive by the national convention in Winnipeg are viewed here as events of very great importance in Canadian political development.

When looking for the right way to care for a newcomer to our list of house plants, we have to keep an eye on its natural habitat. The home of Laceplant or Panamiga (Pilea involucrata) is in Central and South America. The name Panamiga is a combination of Pan-america and amiga (Spanish for friend) and the introducer gave it this name as a reminder of inter-American friendship.

Lee S. Buckingham, State Director of the Office of Price Administration since last May, will leave that post at the end of this month to resume his duties as president of the Clinton Trust Company, it was announced yesterday by Sylvan Joseph, OPA regional administrator.

THE series of which this volume is the latest branch or tributary must have puzzled some readers. Measured by quantity of water. the upper and lower Mississippi, the Hudson or the Delaware can have little in common with the Chicago -- a thick five miles of muck which cannot even operate nowadays without the aid of a pump.

IN this volume Mr. Coffin, a Pulitzer Prize winner, with seven volumes of verse behind him, discusses his poems: their origin, evolution and the physical and emotional events which provoked them. By narrowing the discussion mainly to his own works, Mr. Coffin's volume gains in intimacy and authority what it has lost in richness and scope.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 13 -- The British Eighth Army in Libya has launched its awaited offensive against the Axis lines at El Agheila and Axis positions "far to the south" have been penetrated, the Berlin radio announced early today.

Concentration of production and simplification of consumer goods will be steadily carried forward in the period directly ahead and will be well advanced six months from now, Joseph L. Weiner, who has just become director of the Office of Civilian Supply of the WPB said in an interview last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Wholesalers and retailers of seventeen grocery products, manufacturers of which have been allowed to increase their quotations to take care of higher material and labor costs, will be permitted to increase their prices by the exact amount of the increase allowed to the manufacturers, the Office of Price Administration said today.

The church of today has failed miserably, the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver, pastor of the John Street Methodist Church, 44 John Street, declared yesterday in the first of a series of sermons preparatory to a study course opening Jan. 14 at the church on "Christian Bases for a Just and Enduring Peace."

Just about now every last citizen of New York apparently realizes for the first time that there are very few shopping days left till Christmas -- ten, to be precise -- and yet nothing has been done about Aunt Hattie, Grandmother or little Susie Belle.
The Newspaper Guild of New York denied last night that Wendell L. Willkie had made "an anti-British speech" in an off-the-record talk at a guild meeting on Nov. 19.

Random House, with thirty books lined up for the period through May, will bring out these next month: "Strip for Action," the book form of the Lindsay-Crouse show; "Siberia," by Emil Lengyel; "Guadalcanal Diary," by Richard Tegaskis; "The Dream Department," by S.J. Perelman; "Twenty-four Hour Leave," by Renee Shann, and "South of the Congo," by Selwyn James.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- By way of supplying a final madhouse touch to a football season that was noted for its lunacies and upsets, the Redskins soundly trounced the supposedly invincible Bears before an incredulous and deliriously happy gathering of 36,006 spectators in Griffith Stadium today to win the world professional championship.

The annual report of the Carnegie Corporation of New York for the year ending Sept. 30 reviews three decades of giving since the endowment of the fund by Andrew Carnegie in 1911, and concludes that gifts totaling almost $185,000,000 have placed many agencies "for the advancement and diffusion of knowledge" in position to render useful service to the government in the war.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Prices of corn on the Board of Trade here held last week within a range of about 2 cents a bushel but they went to the highest levels since mid-August. However, a sharp break early in the week had a tendency to unsettle sentiment.

The first shock that came with the decision that men of 38 were too old for this war will by now have lost some of its sharpness. But it was a stunning blow. Many a man who at breakfast and on his way to train or subway that morning had reflected on how well he was standing up found that by nightfall he had passed from youth to age.

Carmen Amaya gave her first and only Manhattan performance of the season at Carnegie Hall last night and so did her sisters and her cousins and her uncles, not to mention her featured partner, Antonio Triana, and his partner, Lola Montes, and the pianist, Raymond Sachse.
The Union for Democratic Action and The Nation will give a dinner for Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska at the Hotel Commodore Tuesday evening, Dec. 29.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 13 -- After more than three hours of debate, the New Jersey State Industrial Union Council, in the final session of its fifth annual convention in the Essex House here, defeated today a resolution that called upon the organization and its national leaders to reconsider labor's "no strike" pledge unless labor leaders received government posts of authority and unless equality of sacrifice was enforced at once.

MOSCOW, Monday, Dec. 14 -- Powerful and repeated counter-attacks by a "considerable force" of Axis soldiers southwest of Stalingrad were hurled back yesterday, the Russians announced early today, as the Red Army drove forward its twin Winter offensives, which in twenty-five days have cost the Axis nearly 250,000 men killed or captured.
In your issue of Dec. 9 you printed a letter from William L. Standard, who discussed the undemocratic method of selecting jurors in the Federal courts in the Eastern District.

The city had its fourth snowfall of the season yesterday morning, followed within two hours by subfreezing temperatures that left streets covered with a thick film of ice, creating a dangerous hazard to pedestrians and motorists. Five thousand Department of Sanitation workers attempted to clear the streets and bridges but were hampered by the cold.

A United Nations service dedicated to United China Relief was conducted in St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, yesterday afternoon, with representatives of seventeen of our Allies attending.

Although preholiday jewelry business has flourished, with many retailers reporting the largest volume in their history, behind the scenes lie war-created uncertain-ties, handicaps, hazards and restraints for the future, according to a survey just conducted by Jewelers' Security Alliance of the United States.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 13 -- Adoption of a resolution favoring establishment of an Office of War Mobilization, as proposed in the Kilgore-Pepper bill, was the highlight today of a conference here of women in New England Industry. About 500 delegates attended, all of them prominent in their field in Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut.

GROTON, Conn., Dec. 13 -- The widow of a crew member reported lost with the submarine Grunion in Pacific action sent the new Navy submersible Muskallunge down the ways of the Electric Boat Company here today into the Thames River in the presence of scores of the concern's employes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Council of State Governments, urging a program of debt retirement and war-work priorities, called on State and local authorities today to make preparations now to assure a cushioning of economic shocks of the post-war period.

Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner John H. Morris, commander of the Air Warden Service, has been ordered to active duty with the Army, it was revealed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in his weekly broadcast.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 -- Backlogs of orders for steel changed little last week, and the total decrease in the last month is said to have been no more than 10 to 15 per cent. It is believed that rearrangements in war and other priority orders have not affected unfilled orders as much as had been supposed.

New York City these days may seem as dark at night as an old-fashioned country village. It is not so dark that a submarine commander, 75 miles offshore, cannot see the glow of its lights against the sky. The present dimout regulations have been criticized as too severe.

FREEPORT, L.I., Dec. 13 -- Ernest Machenbach, 57 years old, an interior decorator, of this village, and his wife, Bessie, 48, were burneed fatally here early today when an automobile in which they were riding overturned after a collision with another car and caught fire.

The Neediest Cases Fund for the most distressed families and fragments of families known to eight leading private charities in the city began the second week of its thirty-first annual appeal with gifts of only $4,532.50 yesterday. This amount was the smallest received to date and the number of contributors, which was 163, was the smallest since the first Monday.

Buying of cotton futures last week was tempered by indications that the House-approved Pace bill, which provides higher parity prices for agricultural commodities by inclusion of the cost of farm labor in the parity formula, probably would not be brought before the Senate until the new Congress convened.
AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Dec. 12 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- An Australian correspondent, F.C. Folkard, who entered Gona with the victorious Australian forces, wrote of the carnage and destruction there.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Amateur Athletic Union adopted a revised version of its physical fitness program today and passed a resolution urging a nationwide plan of "swim to live" before closing its three-day convention.

Mothers and fathers need have no fear for the spiritual welfare of their sons in the armed forces, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday morning in his sermon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

If evaporated milk is needed for infant feeding or heavy cream for a required special diet and is not obtainable at the neighborhood grocery, a doctor's prescription will do the trick, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday in his weekly radio talk from City Hall.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Major Gen. Fulgencio Batista, President of Cuba, said today that he was "greatly reassured to see the earnestness and the success in turning out the weapons of war with which the men and women of America are working."

MOBILE, Ala. Dec. 13 -- The S.S. Colin P. Kelly Jr., first of three 10,000-ton Mobile-built ships named by school children of Florida, the aviator's home State, was launched today at a ceremony attended by several thousand persons, including Mr. and Mrs. Colin Kelly, parents of the late hero.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Dec. 11 (Delayed) (AP) -- After twenty-three days of attacking through New Guinea jungles and swamps against a foe determined to resist to the last man, Americans and Australians still have a formidable task.

In so far as markets were influenced by war news, they did not indicate any change. Both in Africa and in the Pacific Islands Allied forces held their own. In the prevalent financial view it is now felt that Germany and Italy will before long crack open; Hitler's manoeuvres certainly suggest something like desperation.

The Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., sent yesterday to William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, a telegram asking immediate action on the union's plea that the board intervene in a dispute with the Board of Transportation over wages and hours of the 32,000 employes of the city's unified transit lines.
Mr. and Mrs. William Rogers Coe of Glen Cove, L.I., are at Hampshire House for the Winter.

By a sad coincidence the annual report of the Superintendent of Schools, made public today, follows close upon revelations by two teachers' groups that disciplinary conditions in some schools are bad enough to require the attention of the police. The Superintendent's report, issued under the title chosen by the late Superintendent Harold G. Campbell.

A concert of delightful music making, which memorably conveyed chamber compositions by J.S. Bach, was conducted by Otto Klemperer for the New Friends of Music, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. It was an occasion of masterly performance and interpretation by a small group of chamber music players, under a great leader, and it was an occasion on which theories fortunately gave way to facts of living music.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

CAIRO, Monday, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- As in the break-through at El Alamein, Egypt, that paved the way for the present successful British campaign, the Agheila break was said today to have been achieved after shattering artillery and air attacks on the Africa Corps.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- The priceless heritage of American liberties gained 151 years ago by the adoption of the first ten amendments to the Constitution, known as the Bill of Rights, was celebrated today at historic St. Paul's Church, East Chester.

There will be a city-wide blackout drill some time this week, with two audible alarms preceding the all clear signal, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall. The procedure to be followed will be that prescribed recently by Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell, State Director of Civil Protection.

How the New York City school system with its 1,000,000 children and 35,000 teachers has geared its activities to the war program is disclosed in the forty-third report of the Superintendent of Schools, made public yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

While advertising devoted to a hundred odd war themes has formed a substantial portion of advertising linage this year, the proportion in 1943 will be considerably greater, according to agency executives. Two of the most ambitious projects are the car conservation program being prepared by the Advertising Council and the projected institutional campaign of the food industry, which is just beginning to get under way.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 13 -- The exchange of friendly letters between Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha and President Roosevelt about the Christmas gift by King Farouk to the United States troops in the Middle East has set the seal of official approval on the rather anomalous status of the American Army in Egypt, it was evident today.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- Governor General Pierre Boisson returned to Dakar yesterday after agreeing to let the Allies use the port and its air facilities, it was revealed today, and the Morocco radio quoted him as saying that West Africa "will share in the common war effort."

LONDON, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- A large majority of Indian leaders attending the standing committee meeting of the Non-Party Conference at Allahabad, India, today favored Pakistan (the proposed separate Moslem State), the Exchange Telegraph Agency reported.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Canadian oats and barley continue to be bought in volume by American interests, and sufficient hedging against this grain has developed to give the market a relatively easy undertone. However, the full effect of the business in the imported grain is offset by the smallest receipts of domestic grain in many months.

The USO War Fund is richer by $612,550.99 as a result of contributions from the field of sport made since May 11, 1942, according to an announcement made yesterday by Robert F. Kelley, chairman of the Special Events Committee. USO benefits for a month for about 900,000 service men will be provided by the sum, Kelley said.

The New York Rovers attained three objectives yesterday afternoon in beating the Philadelphia Falcons, 6 -- 1, in the feature game of an Eastern Hockey League double-header at Madison Square Garden. In their most important accomplishment the locals broke a tie with the Falcons and the Coast Guard Cutters to gain undisputed possession of first place.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Senate Committee on Small Business has summoned representatives of more than fifty trade associations in the wholesale and retail field to assist it in formulating its legislative program for the coming session of Congress, it was announced today.

RANDOLPH FIELD, Texas, Dec. 13 -- Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, Army Air Force chief, declared today that American air experts have a "secret weapon or two up their aerial sleeves" and will soon "put on a special demonstration for Hitler and Hirohito -- and we don't think they are going to like it, either."
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Deploring what he called the "indifference" of part of the British press and some government circles to "the most appalling massacre in history," the Nazi mass murders of Jews in Poland, Britain's Chief Rabbi, Dr. J.H. Hertz, asked the United Nations today to save at least the children.

The Rev. Dr. John W. Bradbury, editor of the Baptist national weekly, Watchman-Examiner, was the guest speaker at a special service yesterday morning that marked the beginning of a week's program in celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Central Baptist Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
United Nations forces were still on the march on many of the global battlefronts last week, although our progress in Russia, North Africa and New Guinea had been slowed.

St. John's Prep, the defending titleholder, and St. Francis Prep continued in a deadlock for first place in the annual Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. team swimming championships yesterday at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus pool.

GENEVA, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- In the first December commencement in the history of Hobart and William Smith Colleges, forty-five seniors were graduated here today with exercises marked by the conferring of an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws on Dr. George D. Stoddard, Commissioner of Education of the State of New York.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Wintry weather with temperatures below zero in many parts of the Winter Wheat Belt sent the plant last week into the dormant stage to remain there until next Spring. Weather conditions in the Southwest, however, were generally favorable and some growth was reported from that area.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- A check-up on yesterday's heavy daylight raid on Rouen, in which United States bombers escorted by 300 Allied fighters, fought one of the fiercest air battles they have thus far participated in over enemy-occupied France, showed today that twenty- three Nazi fighters, rather than eighteen, as previously announced, were destroyed.
Gayest dancer at a party yesterday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Weiss of 146 Central Park West was the guest of honor, Mrs. Regina Margareten, celebrating her eightieth birthday.

The main objectives of the National Ski Association of America, controlling body of the sport in this country, will be aid to the War Department, local defense units and the physical fitness program. These points are stressed by Roger Langley, president of the N.S.A., in his annual report to the board of directors.
Only four new films are scheduled to open at Broadway theatres this week. The program follows:

Harry Walters, who recently bought the building in which he has his department store from the Manee Estate, has added to his property by purchasing the three-story store and apartment building adjoining at 635-7 Cookman Avenue, in Asbury Park, N.J.

IN good Queen Bess's glorious days, when the Spaniards were conquering the savage Indians of America for gold, empire and propagation of the faith, the English were battling the wild Irish in the howling wilderness of their native island in much the same spirit. The Irish spoke an outlandish tongue, clung to customs that were strange and foreign and preferred their own religion.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- American Flying Fortresses and Mitchell B-25 medium bombers, in the greatest aerial assault of the North African campaign, sank one ship and set roaring fires amid the docks and warehouses of the three main Tunisian harbors of Bizerte, Tunis and Sousse today, a dispatch from North Africa said tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 -- Twelve fighting memorials roared off the Lockheed Air Terminal runway today as the Lockheed and Vega companies dedicated P-38 fighters, Flying Fortresses and Ventura bombers to former employes who have given their lives for their country.

CAIRO, Egypt, Monday, Dec. 14 -- Striking again with all the strength at his command, General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery has sent his Eighth Army against General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's strong positions at El Agheila with such force that the enemy has started retreating toward Tripoli, according to reports reaching here early today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Strict limitations on mark-ups and selling prices on Spring and Summer lines of makers of women's apparel were put into effect today by the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- It requires "preliminary argument" to convince many employers that they ought to hire professionally trained women instead of men, despite the fact that only by full utilization of the labor reserve, which largely comprises women, can the war labor problem be solved, Dr. Leonard Carmichael, president of Tufts College and director of the national roster of scientific and specialized personnel of the War Manpower Commission, said today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler has turned over to certain Rumanians German-occupied Moldavia, Crimea and Odessa, and these Rumanian hangmen are preying upon the defenseless population.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Argentine Government's preliminary grain-crop estimate, made available to the local grain trade, showed the following forecasts for 1943, compared with 1942 and 1941, all in thousands of bushels:

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 13 -- A sleek and beautiful lady of the sea, the schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, queen of the Atlantic fishing fleet, went to war today as flagship of the Coast Guard's corsair fleet patrolling the coast.

The Christmas sale now being held under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the Maple Leaf Fund, Inc., at its branch headquarters and shop at 682 Madison Avenue, will continue until Christmas. Mrs. Henderson Robb is chairman of the chapter, and Mrs. Frederick Nichol heads the Christmas sale committee.

Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday that today's world crisis presented a challenge to every one to be "faithful, loyal and fearless in standing for the things that really matter." He preached and he confirmed a class of candidates at All Angels Protestant Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street.

The Trapp Family Singers, composed of the Baroness Maria von Trapp, her eight daughters and two sons, made their first appearance of the season at Town Hall yesterday afternoon in a program of Christmas music. With Dr. Franz Wasner conducting, the gifted group followed its usual procedure of devoting part of the list to works for recorders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Some of the boys "on the inside," trying to find reasons for Washington's surprise victory over the Bears today, saw a parallel between a meeting of the Redskins just before the 1940 play-off and one the Bears held last night.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A communique:
Charles Thomas, Lancaster, Ohio, third baseman, was the nation's best semi-pro hitter during the 1942 season.

Paraphrasing Prime Minister Churchill's famous words, uttered when days looked darkest for Great Britain, War Secretary Stimson has also issued a warning to America that "while everything that has happened is better than we expected," the main work must still be done, and this will mean "toil and sweat and blood."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- With the anticipated alignment beside the United Nations of French West Africa, in addition to North Africa and Equatorial Africa, it is expected here that the efforts of the United States and Britain will be concentrated upon strengthening the military resources of those territories rather than upon political differences among Frenchmen.
AS a transportation problem in time of war, a Florida or California Spring training camp for a ball club isn't as bad as it sounds.

Progressive measures, reflecting their firm belief that the sport can help greatly in preparing men for war, were given the stamp of approval yesterday by members of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association in their sixtieth annual meeting at the Hotel Lincoln.
"Strip for Action," the comedy about burlesque and strip-tease by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, will close on Jan. 3, according to a notice posted backstage last night.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Dec. 13 -- Fire and panic claimed the lives of 100 or more persons here last night as roaring flames fed by inflammable Christmas decorations swept through the Knights of Columbus Hostel, where a barn dance and a service men's radio program were under way.

Among the contributors to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund are people from many parts of the country who send in their contributions regularly, year after year. They know that their gifts are carefully administered; money is not haphazardly handed out. Families and individuals who merit aid are helped steadily during the year until they have a new hold on life.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, announced yesterday that an economy consolidation of its library facilities would force the dismantling in the near future of the Museum of Living Art, which for the last fifteen years has occupied exhibition space on the first floor of the university's main building at Washington Square.

DETROIT, Dec. 13 -- The United Mine Workers Union, led by John L. Lewis, has begun a raid on the railroad brotherhoods, it was revealed here today through the distribution of handbills urging Detroit railroad workers to break off their present affiliations and form "one big union" under District 50, the U.M.W. all-inclusive division.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Calling for decentralization of the Office of Price Administration, Senator Tydings declared today that rationing and price control had demonstrated that many persons believed "the whole country should be run from Washington."

The Metropolitan Opera Association will present Puccini's "La Boheme" on Christmas eve and Verdi's "Aida" on Christmas night, it was announced yesterday with the release of the repertoire for the fifth week of the season.

There was a time when the two weeks before Christmas found many an angler and hunter beating the trail to sports stores, rod-makers and gunsmiths. One of the booklets usually expected at this season of a peaceful year would be an illustrated affair with a list of gift suggestions substantial enough to cover much acreage under numerous Christmas trees.

Pierre Cot. the French Minister for Air from 1936 to 1938, has warned a Senate Military subcommittee that France made a fatal error in draining her airplane factories and other plants of men to build up the huge army that met disaster so rapidly in June of 1940. It would be folly for us to ignore an authoritative warning of this nature that springs from bitter experience.

P.B. Sawyer, president of the National Power and Light Company, said yesterday, according to The Associated Press, that the company had asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for a rehearing on its order ending an offer of an exchange of shares by which the company had retired $10,000,000 in preferred stock.

Leopold Stokowski joined the list of eminent conductors who have played the Shostakovich Seventh symphony in this city when he conducted the work yesterday afternoon with the NBC Symphony Orchestra in Studio 8-H, Radio City.

BOSTON, Dec. 13 -- The owners and occupants of all stores, halls and places of public assembly in Boston will be directed to remove immediately all inflammable decorations, by an order to be released tomorrow by Fire Commissioner Reilly.

Because of the pressure of events, the launching on Dec. 7 of the daily raising and lowering of the flag in twelve small Manhattan parks received only a brief word in the press. No mention was made of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, under whose auspices the ceremonies will be conducted for the duration with the cooperation of the Boy Scouts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Black Hawks knocked Toronto from a first-place tie and left Boston setting the pace in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Maple Leafs, 5 to 2, before a Stadium crowd of 13,017.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Allied troops, mostly British, are still holding Medjez-el-Bab tonight. That is the most important news from the front because it is the only gap left in the line that has been built up from the Mediterranean to Pont du Fahs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- Governor Dwight H. Green said tonight that he would meet with Illinois health authorities, probably Tuesday, to discuss "bureaucratic bungling" of fuel oil rationing by Federal officials.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 12 (delayed) (UP) -- The United States will associate itself with a new Turkish-Russian diplomatic accord that is expected to be announced next week, it was reported reliably today.

The first in a series of rallies to raise $50,000,000 through the sale of war bonds was held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the American Hellenic Educational Progressive Association, with Steve Vasilakos, "the White House peanut vender," singled out for special honor as the Greek-Americans' choice for "The Common People's Man of the Year."

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 13 -- Chief of State Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, as anticipated, has replied to Reichsfuehrer Hitler's two long letters, one to justify the total occupation of France, the other to announce warlike action against Toulon.

A tribute to Father Ledochowski as a great leader, respected by Catholics and non-Catholics alike, was paid on behalf of his fellow-members of the Jesuit Order here last night by the Rev. John LaFarge, executive editor of America, national Catholic weekly, who said:
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Tercentenary observances of the birth of Sir Isaac Newton were begun today at Grantham, near the peaceful hamlet of Woolsthorpe-by-Colsterworth, where the scientist was born.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- J. Edward Sproul, program secretary of the National Council of the Y.M.C.A., speaking today before the Hi-Y assembly, took exception to a statement made by an executive at a recent industrial conference in New York in which he was quoted as remarking that the United States was not fighting to provide the hottentot with a quart of milk.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 7 -- Many explorers are credited with discovering uncharted rivers and then putting them on the map. But this week Captain Felix Cardona claimed the distinction of being the first explorer who ever took a river off the map.
MOSCOW, Monday, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Assailing "amazing conflicts" among governmental agencies as a factor in the fuel oil shortage and declaring that President Roosevelt had been slow in appointing an "oil czar" to remedy the situation, New England members of Congress appealed tonight for prompt action to alleviate the "dire and dangerous" situation confronting their States.

Superb manoeuvring enabled Samuel Reshevsky to gain a superior position and defeat Isaac I. Kashdan last night in the seventh game of their match series for the United States chess championship. Reshevsky now leads by a score of 4 1/2 to 2 1/2.

Plans for rehabilitation of 30,000 Jewish refugees being cared for temporarily in neutral Europe and North Africa were discussed yesterday before 2,500 persons at the thirteenth annual convention of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society of America's Council of Organizations. Delegates from 800 organizations in the council were at the meeting at 111 Second Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- Thanks in part to an understanding by the working press of the United States of its obligations to democracy, President Roosevelt expressed today his "profound confidence" in the ability of the nation to meet the "bitter necessities of total war without losing any of its essential devotion to liberty."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 13 -- In one of the war's boldest exploits, a submarine commanded by a shy 28- year-old Englishman made a series of night raids along the Italian coast, stopping a railway by shelling a train about to enter a tunnel, damaging another train and leaving an olive oil factory in blazing ruins.

A German broadcast, recorded by The United Press in New York yesterday, said Axis troops had thrown back a series of Soviet attacks on scattered fronts from Lake Ilmen, below Leningrad, to the Caucasus in which 167 Russian tanks had been destroyed or disabled.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 13 -- Brazilians now breathe easier as a result of being assured that inflation days are over. According to statistics released by the Minister of Finance, monetary circulation, which between July, 1941, and October, 1942, increased nearly 40 per cent, decreased in November nearly 5 per cent, and even though purchasing power has increased, prices have remained about on the same level for the past three months.

Yielding a three-goal lead at one time, the Canadiens of Montreal braced toward the end and riddled the Rangers' cage often enough to register a one-sided triumph over the Blueshirts in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

SENECA, Ill., Dec. 13 -- A large-type, tank-landing ship of welded steel was launched at the shipyards of the Chicago Bridge and Iron Company on the Illinois River today before more than 7,000 persons, including naval officers.

Ed Wynn has been signed by Peter Arno to star in the latter's show, hitherto known as "Peter Arno's Cartoon Revue" but at present without a title. Rehearsals will start probably on Jan. 4. Present plans are to rehearse four and a half weeks and then open in New York without an out-of-town tryout.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 13 -- Big bombers of the New Zealand Air Force are now policing Pacific waters from island bases where American construction units have cut airfields from the jungle and coconut groves.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department reported today that the production of oranges during the 1942-43 season was indicated at 84,144,000 boxes.Production last season totaled 84,534,000 boxes. The indicated production by States this season and last, respectively, included:
FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., Dec. 13 (AP) -- For the first time in her career as one of the leading actresses of the American stage, Katharine Cornell gave a curtain speech today.

The Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, admitted in his sermon yesterday morning that amid all the world's turmoil "it is not easy to preach that Christ is a success."

To inspect, every two months, the tires on 20,000,000 cars and trucks at ten minutes each -- and it's likely to take fifteen minutes -- would consume 20,000,000 mechanics' hours a year. This is equivalent to the work of 9,615 men working steadily forty hours a week for one year.
MOSCOW, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
NOME, Alaska, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Alaska is winding up its liquor business and getting prepared for a dry Winter.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 13 -- An 8,000-ton German vessel which was intercepted by Allied naval forces recently in the Indian Ocean and scuttled by its crew was en route to Germany with a valuable cargo from Japan, it was revealed today.

AT THE FRONT, in Tunisia, Dec. 5 (Delayed) -- Lads from New York, the South and the West, participating in the struggle between American and German tanks, with artillery accompaniment, outside Tunis, described during a brief rest their experiences in action.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- RKO has concluded an agreement with Warner Brothers to borrow John Garfield for the leading role in "The Fallen Sparrow," with Maureen O'Hara, Anna Lee and Walter Slezack. The picture, which is being adapted from a novel by Dorothy B. Hughes about espionage here and in Europe, will go before the cameras in January, with Richard Wallace directing and Robert Fellows producing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Wheat prices continued on the upgrade last week, with futures in new ground since last May in sympathy with pronounced strength shown in the cash market. Number 2 Red Winter, the supply of which is abnormally small this season, went to $1.50 a bushel, or 18 cents over the basic government loan level for this market, without attracting offers from the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department said Friday its subsidy program designed to encourage a greater production of American cheddar cheese to meet war needs went into effect Wednesday.

DETROIT, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The astonishing Boston Bruins, who have dropped only one National Hockey League game in a dozen starts in a month, played the Detroit Red Wings to a 1-to-1 tie tonight before 10,653 spectators. Art Jackson's second-period goal offset one by Joe Carveth of Detroit in the first period.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Anton Mussert, 48, who for eleven years has led the ineffective Netherland Nazi party, has been recognized by Adolf Hitler as the "leader of the Netherland people," the Germans announced today.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices advanced from 108.5 to 108.8. Price changes occurred almost entirely in agricultural products. Advances in practically all commodities in the farm products index caused it to rise 1.3 per cent.

A detailed account of a visit by Emperor Hirohito to the Ise Shrine at Kyoto, broadcast from Tokyo to the Japanese Empire last night, was interpreted by Federal Communications Commission translators on the Pacific Coast, in a report to the Office of War Information, as connected with Japan's current propaganda campaign exhorting the Japanese people to fanatical war efforts.

A large duplex apartment in the building at 875 Park Avenue has been leased by Captain Sidney Van den Bergh of the Dutch Army through Douglas L. Elliman Co. The latter also rented suites in 30 East Sixty-eighth Street to Arthur B. Grover, in 81 Irving Place to Charles Snyder and in 136 East Thirty-sixth Street to L.A. Dubics.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- The besieged Japanese defense positions in the Buna area of New Guinea are being kept under continuous artillery and mortar fire, while Allied planes continue to blast them with bombs and bullets, the Allied command announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- The American Federation of Labor union representing 4,500 elevated lines employee remained steadfast today in its determination to call a strike at 4 A.M. next Sunday to enforce demands for wage increases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- American sea and air forces struck Friday and Saturday (Solomons time) at eleven Japanese destroyers heading for Guadalcanal and sank one destroyer, set afire and probably sank a second and damaged a number of others, the Navy announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- A Fighting French spokesman said today that Reichsfuehrer Hitler had ordered Chief of Government Pierre Laval to conscript 400,000 French workers to go to Germany in return for an unspecified number of French war prisoners.

The Public Education Association feels that it is unfortunate that the confidence of New York City citizens in their free schools is being undermined by lurid headlines dealing with sporadic instances of unruly behavior on the part of pupils in the schools.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces defending strategic Yunnan Province have repulsed new Japanese attempts to cross the Salween River, and Allied fliers have blasted enemy supply lines to the front, it was announced tonight.
OLD FORGE, N.Y., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Buglers blew reveille this morning in a thousand Army camps, but a newly wed soldier on a free honeymoon in this snow-mantled Adirondack resort heard not a note.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- More is likely to be heard soon about the increase in the Bank of England's circulation. Heretofore the public had regarded the expansion with complacency, accepting the explanations of Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, without comment or suspicion.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13 -- With the final crop estimate just ahead and the bill to boost the farm parity price pending in the Senate, cotton futures held within a relatively narrow range most of last week except for a belated "squeeze" in the expiring December option.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- With yearend factors operating to their full extent, the stock markets have experienced another subdued and inactive week. Despite the usual desire for liquidity at this period of the year, there has been little selling of securities to provide the resources required now and early in the new year for taxes and other obligations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The War Labor Board moved today to stabilize employment and prevent widespread labor pirating in a highly critical industry when it issued a blanket order establishing maximum wage rates for the more than 50,000 tool and die workers in all jobbing and manufacturing plants in a six-county Detroit area.

Mayor La Guardia was accused yesterday of "buck-passing, sidestepping and name-calling" and neglect of his duties as chief executive of the city for failure to take immediate action against assaults upon teachers and the reported breakdown of discipline in the city's public schools.

Root vegetables -- the kinds that may be gathered in the Fall and successfullly stored for use during the following seasons -- are plentiful They are cheap. And, like death and taxes, they are always with us.
A strike called yesterday afternoon without notice by the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, an independent organization, prevented the normal delivery of this morning's newspapers.

Wholesale trading was brisk last week as retailers sought to replenish holiday stocks and also covered their early Spring requirements, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Although increased receipts of hogs has eased the lard situation to some extent, the demand for lend-lease purposes and for civilian consumption continues unabated. Brokers who predicted there would be a surplus this Winter have changed their minds to some extent, although it is expected that supplies in cold storage will increase from now on.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- The extent to which the State is prepared for post-war housing, both to meet the shortage of homes and to create a reservoir of "ready to go" public works, was revealed today in the annual report to the Governor and the Legislature of Edward Weinfeld, State Commissioner of Housing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Navy communique 218:

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net profit of $1,786,310 for the three months ended Oct. 31, after a provision of $2,700,000 for estimated Federal excess profits taxes, normal taxes and surtaxes on income, or 82 cents a share on the outstanding common stock, according to a report issued for publication today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 13 (Reuter) -- Soldiers in the field and in the Union will welcome Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts's recent announcement that South African troops would soon be called upon for service outside of Africa.

MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I., Dec. 13 -- Everett Pfeiffer Jr., 8 years old, is the most recent member of the Pfeiffer family to qualify for the Army Aircraft Warning Service at the post established on Rainbow Ranch, Middle Country Road, this village.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The National League of Women Voters, asserting that isolationism did not die with Pearl Harbor, put forward today a formula for deciding whether a member of Congress is "giving lip service to the idea of America's responsibility after the war while at the same time condemning every step toward international good feeling."

The United States, through its participation in the war, has proved that democracy can work on a world-wide basis and stand up successfully against dictatorship, Senator Claude Pepper of Florida declared last night at the fourteenth annual dinner of Yeshiva College in the Hotel Astor.

An orchestral concert sponsored by the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University was given last night in Carnegie Hall with Igor Buketoff as conductor, Mr. Buketoff was entitled to this appearance at the head of a chamber orchestra of thirty-five players as the result of a competition held recently in this city, at which he won the fund's first annual conducting award, intended to encourage native American talent.

James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, praised the Greeks yesterday for their fight against the Axis powers and urged the people in this country to contribute generously so that medical supplies can be sent immediately to Greece. He spoke at a vesper service in- Christ Church, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street.

The Hotel Wentworth at 59 West Forty-sixth Street through to 56-60 West Forty-seventh Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, has been sold by the Empire City Savings Bank to a client of G.V. Stoeber and Louis F. Hines, brokers.

The outlook for the American baby, 1943 style, is favorable, despite the topsy-turvy world into which he will be born, it appeared yesterday on the basis of a roundup by the Office of War Information.

The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (The Little Church Around the Corner), Twenty-ninth Street east of Fifth Avenue, suggested in his sermon yesterday morning that individual responsibility must be substituted for today's "casualness."

Mrs. Robert E. Moore has been named chairman of a committee in charge of a "Stars on Ice" performance on Jan. 14 at the Center Theatre for the benefit of the Camp Fire Girls Council of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday.

Leo T. Crowley, the Alien Property Custodian, reports to the President that by the end of the year he will have seized some 50,000 patents granted to enemy nationals. We seized enemy-owned patents in the last war too, but dealt with them in a manner that was not wholly satisfactory.

On the subject of European rule in Asia it would do our more excitable prophets a world of good if they managed to read and take to heart Nathaniel Peffer's fine article in our magazine section last Sunday. It is a swift survey of white domination in Asia, past and present, and its chief virtue is that it reminds us that there is a past.

After trailing by a 20-to-16 margin at the intermission, Long Island University's quintet overcame the Brooklyn Battalion Coast Guard team, 54 -- 38, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night. The triumph extended the Blackbirds' unbeaten streak this season to five games.

Major Gen. Fulgencio Batista, President of Cuba, returned here yesterday from a tour of war plants up-State, enthusiastic regarding the "amazing change" in the American war spirit and confident that "victory and liberty for the civilized world is not far off."

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The opposing armies in Tunisia have entered their third day of relative inactivity. Although attention has shifted from Britain's First Army to the exploits of the Eighth Army, moving west through Tripolitania, there are signs that Lieut. Gen. Walther Nehring, the Axis commander in Tunisia, is awaiting reinforcements in the form of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Africa Corps.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Reporting the North African campaign has become something of a fiasco after a brave start. The chief trouble has been the lack of adequate facilities for the transmission of war correspondents' stories from the field. British as well as American newspapers have suffered in consequence and there has been criticism of the arrangements from both sides of the Atlantic.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler has ordered the occupied countries of Europe to contribute another 1,000,000 workers to his slave labor legion to bolster the Axis war machine and erect coastal fortifications against an Allied invasion, private advices said today.

AT A UNITED STATES BASE, in Central China, Dec. 12 (Delayed) -- Several bombers of Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's crack China Air Task Force dropped two and a half tons of incendiary and fragmentation bombs this afternoon at Tengchung [Tengyueh], thirty miles west of the Salween River, where the front line Japanese headquarters is situated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Women's Army Auxiliary Corps will train parachute riggers, glider instructors, bombsight repair workers and other technicians for specialized work in the Army Air Forces, releasing enlisted men therein for combat duty, the War Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- War Damage Insurance protection may be obtained after Dec. 21 against loss through damage to or destruction of money and securities, it was announced today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce.
LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The text of a British-Fighting French communique issued today follows:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 14 -- The state of siege, which for 363 days has forbidden public discussion of the international situation and of Argentina's policy of "strict neutrality" was prolonged for an indefinite period by a decree issued tonight.

Ralph Kirkpatrick, American harpsichordist, who is a fine scholar as well as a sensitive artist, last night gave the third of his four recitals devoted to Bach at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. His program included the Four Duets, the fifth and sixth Partitas, the A minor Fantasy and Fugue and three of the Preludes and Fugues from the first book for The Well-Tempered Clavier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Senator Reed of Kansas said today that James F. Byrnes, the Economic Stabilization Director, had offered to increase the price of flour fifty-eight cents a barrel if Congress would change the law so as to permit the Commodity Credit Corporation to sell up to 150,000,000 bushels of wheat at less than parity.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- Describing the Hawaiian Islands as "peculiarly exposed to fifth column activities," the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in a majority opinion upheld today a lower court decision denying a writ of habeas corpus to an American citizen arrested there by a military board.

A preview of the exhibition called "Art Schools Go to War" was held last evening at the Museum of Science and Industry. This exhibition, describing the contributing art schools to the war effort, includes three-dimensional displays of camouflage, made by Pratt Institute, the Phoenix Art Institute and the Westchester Workshop and supplemented by explanatory back-grounds.

The cotton futures market, reflecting the quiet business prevalent in the Southern spot markets, returned yesterday to its modest upward movement and closed with net gains of 8 to 13 points. Volume was reported to be the smallest for a full day in several weeks.

IT appears that G. Preston (the Magnificent) Marshall wasn't afraid of the Big Bad Bears. Even while the Bears were advancing on Washington, D.C., where they were subdued and caged upon arrival through the courtesy of Red Flaherty and his Redskins, the luxurious laundryman who owns the new champions of the professional field was working on a document of wider importance than one football game.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Chief Justice Stone disagreed with all of his present seven Supreme Court colleagues today when they ruled that there is a "twilight zone" in which harbor workers and longshoremen can claim State compensation even though protected by the Federal Longshoremen's and Harbor Workers' Act.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 14 (Reuter) -- Mobile columns of the Eighth Army -- light tanks, armored cars and motorized infantry -- are pursuing General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's forces in their rapid retreat from El Agheila.

A Negro accused of robbing and raping ten white and Negro women in Harlem was held in $10,000 bail yesterday ill the Felony Court, pending a hearing Friday. Detective Thomas Catterson captured the suspect at 4 A.M. after he was alleged to have threatened a man and a woman in an automobile in front of 464 West 142d Street.

The British Eighth Army has struck again and Marshal Rommel's North Africa Corps is once more in full retreat along the coast of Libya. The battle that began at the gates of Egypt has been resumed after an interval of barely three weeks. This is a remarkable achievement considering the length of the British line of communications and the tough country which it crosses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Marine Corps said today that using a preference system, it would attempt to supply most of its ground officers and its aviation flight training candidates as well as enlisted men through Selective Service channels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration today authorized increases of about one cent a quart for milk sold at wholesale and retail in the Buffalo and Rochester milk marketing areas in New York State. The OPA acted because minimum producers' prices had increased from $3.40 to $3.80 a hundred pounds, equivalent to about one cent a quart, since March, 1942.

The seriousness of our farm labor problem can scarcely be exaggerated. If present trends continue, agriculture, according to the estimates of the Department of Agriculture, will lose a million workers in the twelve months ending next July 1. By October, the end of the harvest season, the prospective loss will amount to 1,300,000 workers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The support which has come to Byron Price, Director of the Office of Censorship, for instituting a watch on correspondence between persons in the United States and those in our outlying possessions is probably not confined to the government officials who counseled him to institute it.
Indications are that New Jersey hunters will be out in full force for the brief deer season which the State allows.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Plans for the immediate training of at least 250,000 young inductees of college age at leading educational institutions which will be geared to the demands of the armed servives will be made known this week, it was disclosed today following a press conference by Paul V. McNutt, Director of the War Manpower Commission.

Marjorie Lawrence, Australian soprano, will sing again at the Metropolitan Opera House on Dec. 27 at a concert arranged by her colleagues there as a "tribute to her courageous spirit." She will appear with Lauritz Melchior in the Venusberg scene from Wagner's "Tannhaeuser."

There are service men who like to eat, who even say -- when you ask them what they want -- that a dozen brownies or a layer cake is the kind of present they like to receive. Accordingly, the Bureau of Home Economics has issued directions on what sort of food travels well and how best to pack it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Bombers from Henderson Field on Guadalcanal Island again attacked the new Japanese airfield at Munda in the Solomons on Sunday (Solomons time) as part of the continued campaign to render ineffective the Japanese forces that still threaten Guadalcanal, the Navy Department reported in a communique today.

With New York taking up the slack caused by the shut-down of the sport in California last Winter, thoroughbred horse racing poured vast sums into the State's coffers in 1942 as wagering soared to a new high in the United States.

The Zenith Radio Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended on Oct. 31 an estimated consolidated operating profit of $2,010,109 after depreciation, excise taxes and reserves, but before provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes estimated at $954,403.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Selection of forty-four industrial plants to receive the joint Army-Navy production award for outstanding performance on war work was announced today by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.

If Britain follows an appeasement policy toward the Moslem world at the peace conference, there will be "great difficulty in Palestine," Dr. Stephen S. Wise, chairman of the American Emergency Committee for Zionist Affairs, warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Congressional leaders made plans today to adjourn the present session on Wednesday or Thursday, and advised President Roosevelt that the new Congress would organize on Jan. 6, and be ready to receive his message on the state of the Union on the following day.

Led by Johnny Simmons and Sam Mele, who tallied 18 points apiece, the N.Y.U. basketball team swept to a 73-42 victory over the Montclair Teachers at the University Heights gymnasium last night. The triumph was the fourth straight this season for the Violets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Planning now for post-war building was urged by Major Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Administrator of the Federal Works Agency, in an address at the forum meeting tonight of the Washington Building Congress.

DETROIT, Dec. 14 -- Proposing a new cooperative international order, Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota today suggested a postwar linking of the United Nations as the nucleus and major factor for preservation of world peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The basis for assertions by the United States Civil Service Commission that a shortage of civilian government employes requires the hiring of part-time clerical workers will be investigated by the joint Congressional-Departmental Committee on reduction of Federal expenditures, Senator Byrd, its chairman, said today.

Anton Mussert is a self-made man. The son of a village schoolmaster in the Netherlands, he graduated as an engineer and secured a position in the public service. Whether he was discharged for incompetency or, as he prefers to put it, for "political activity," he lost this position.

The value of skiing and mountaineer troops was officially recognized last Fall by the formation of the First Battalion, Eighty-seventh Infantry Mountain Regiment at Fort Lewis, Wash. It was an experimental unit for this country, although it proved its value as an effective mode of travel and transport during the first World War and the Russo-Finnish conflict.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Doctors going "into the market place in an attempt to bolster their income" are engaged in trade and cannot expect immunity from antitrust prosecution, Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, argued before the Supreme Court today in the case of the American Medical Association and the Medical Society of the District of Columbia.
MOSCOW, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

The Navy announced yesterday the sinking last month of a medium-sized United States merchant ship off the north coast of South America with the loss of thirty-nine lives and also released eyewitness accounts of the sinking of a large British ship off Africa in September with the loss of 1,800 to 2,000 lives, mostly of Italian prisoners of war.

There will be no Professional Golfers Association championship tournament next year. Instead, the P.G.A. is flipping back the pages of the calendar to 1917 and 1918 and copying a program of charity exhibitions which in those two war years raised more than $1,000,000 for the Red Cross.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 14 -- The sending of Christmas greetings to folks at home is a major activity now of the United States forces in this area. The troops are getting organized for a Christmas that for many of the men will be their first outside America as well as their first midsummer Christmas.

Thumbing through ponderous official railroad guides as they route imaginary passengers from Chicago to the Pacific Northwest or from St. Louis to Texas, women students in the New York Central Railroad's school for ticket sellers are preparing to replace men who have been called into service.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- All deliveries of wheat futures went into new seasonal ground today and for the first time prices on the Board of Trade sold above the government loan rate of $1.32, December going 1/2 cent a bushel above that figure, while the September sold at $1.35, the highest price quoted for any future since last February.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- A plot to set up a black market in gasoline in Chicago and make possible sales in violation of rationing has been broken up by the arrest of three promoters, the Secret Service revealed today.

Representatives of C.I.O. unions, headed by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, voted yesterday to ask organized workers in this city for $2,000,000 for Allied war relief, community welfare organizations and underground opposition movements in Axis areas. The group met at a luncheon in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- With the object of increasing steel output and obtaining its most efficient possible use in the 1943 war production program, the United States, Great Britain and Canada created a Combined Steel Committee today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Big Boy, a six-foot, 400-pound Russian brown bear, pleaded his own case in court so well today that the judge dismissed charges of drunkenness and disorderly conduct against him.

While the word is out that St. John's and N.Y.U. are what is sometimes referred to as "loaded" and have the metropolitan basketball laurels wrapped up between them, Fordham is not without its share of support.
