CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 14 (AP) -- One hundred American fighter planes laden with bombs hammered General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's retreating Axis forces yesterday in the Agheila sector in the greatest fighter-bomber offensive yet staged in Africa, and presumably they were continuing those punishing blows tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Reorganization of the Office of Price Administration and of Congress itself, and abolition of the National Youth Administration and the Farm Security Administration were listed by House Republican leaders today as among their first objectives in the Seventy-eighth Congress.

Following is the text of the statement issued last night by the Publishers Association of New York setting forth its side of the controversy involved in the strike of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union:

More than $2,500,000 in cash was brought out for investment yesterday in response to two special offerings and a secondary distribution on the New York Stock Exchange. Both of the special offerings were heavily oversubscribed and allotments were arranged later in the day.

There is a disheartening similarity in the disaster at the Knights of Columbus Hostel in St. Johns to that at the Cocoanut Grove night club in Boston only two weeks ago. In each case the loss of life was not only extremely high in itself, but incredibly high in proportion to the number of persons in the building when the fire broke out.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 14 -- Father Alessio Magni was named in the will of Father Vladimir Ledochowski, Jesuit Superior General, to head the Society of Jesus pending the election of a new superior at the end of the war.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 15 -- American troops, scoring their first major offensive victory over the Japanese for General Douglas MacArthur, captured Buna village, New Guinea, yesterday as Allied airmen "largely parried" the strongest of eight Japanese attempts to land reinforcements, the Allied Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The right of the Federal Communications Commission to enforce antimonopoly regulations against the National Broadcasting Company and Columbia Broadcasting System will be debated before the Supreme Court under an order issued by the high tribunal today.

The current clamor caused by a let down in discipline again calls attention to the need for developing a sense of responsibility in boys and girls in our schools by throwing responsibility upon them as fast as their shoulders can bear it.

Members of the Western Conference have decided to carry on football next year even if they have to play near-by small college teams to cut down traveling, said Paul Brown, gridiron coach of Ohio State University for the last two seasons, at a dinner last night given by the Ohio Society of New York in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Rising steadily toward its peak, Christmas trade here last week showed a rise of 9 per cent over the corresponding period last year. The increase, announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, compared with a gain of 2 per cent in the preceding week.
A German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York yesterday said the German High Command had reported that "fighting, in part very fierce, continues against a strong enemy" in...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Following Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's suggestion that the United States should study Great Britain's experience in recruiting woman power for war work, the Office of War Information reported today on facts gathered by the British Information Services, showing that although women are subject to drafting in England, most working women there are employed voluntarily.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- Dr. Gilbert S. Osincup, president of the Florida State Medical Association, told a Senate subcommittee today that the armed forces are heavily overstaffed with doctors, to the detriment of civilian needs. He put forward the proposal that physicians taken into the Army and Navy go through a brief indoctrination course and then be allowed to return to their civilian practices until actually needed.

Councilman Louis Cohen, Bronx Democrat, announced yesterday that he would ask the City Council today to give its support to a measure increasing the membership of the Board of Elections from four, the present total, to ten so that each county within the city may choose two members, one representing each of the major parties.
WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Libya, Dec. 13 (Delayed) -- This morning it became a certainty that the enemy had pulled out of his El Agheila positions and was withdrawing westward.

The Nazi-controlled Lyon radio reported in a French domestic broadcast yesterday that Pierre Laval had said in his Sunday-night press interview that "I want Germany to win." The broadcast was recorded by the Federal Communications Commission, the Office of War Information reported.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- The Westchester Office of Civilian Protection asked police of all Westchester municipalities today for a strict enforcement, beginning next Friday, of dimout rules for automobile headlights. The order, issued by Captain Rossiter Holbrook, deputy director of civilian protecton, seeks to coordinate the action of local Police Departments, some of which are already levying fines while others are simply warning violators.

Did George Herbert originate or pick up the proverbial statement now grown somewhat moldy that half the world knows not how the other half lives? In the Hundred Neediest Cases there is a qualification if not a refutation of the proverb. They show us their little world where they are trying to live rather than living.

Admitting "outside" members to its directorate for the first time, directors of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., at a special meeting yesterday elected to the board Alfred P. Sloan Jr., E. Tappan Stannard, James L. Thomson and John S. Zinsser.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Dec. 14 (U.P.) William Duggan of St. John's, whose son perished as the father escaped, described the scene.
A kidnap scare in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn ended yesterday when a witness, with inside information, sold his secret to the police for 5 cents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Treasury officials said today that less than 2 per cent of the purchases of war bonds have been redeemed for cash.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Connie Schwoegler wrapped $1,500 around his bankroll today and lugged home a huge trophy after winning the national match game bowling championship with a remarkable pin-spilling display.

So many lines of need appeal to us, but this seems the most beautiful, the most Christ-like, the most tender of them all," wrote a Jersey City friend of the Neediest Cases Fund, who sent $6 in gifts under the initials W.F.S. and M.F.
Your issue of Dec. 12 carries two letters from persons opposed to free rides for service men. This opposition is based on lack of information.

The past year probably has been "the most significant in our nation's history," Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade declared yesterday at the organization's seventieth annual meeting. He said the year had welded the American people "into an invincible nation whose sole aim is victory."

ATLANTA, Dec. 14 -- A group of leading Southern Negroes offered today "a basis for interracial cooperation and development in the South" at a time when "war has sharpened the issue of Negro-white relations in the United States, particularly in the South."

Necessity for studying regional variations in mark-ups required by dry goods wholesalers in order to service different sections of the country has contributed to the delay by the OPA in announcing the long-promised ceiling price schedules for women's rayon hosiery, it was reported yesterday.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States declined $2,514,000 in November to a total of $118,067,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of the market. Compared with a year ago the volume outstanding on Nov. 30 was off $77,523,000.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 14 -- The precipitate withdrawal of the Axis forces from El Agheila most probably indicates the state of Axis arms in Tunisia -- by that token, a rather desperate state -- it was said here today.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- The possibility that the State income tax may be made payable in quarterly installments, starting with the April 15 payment, appeared strong today as legislative leaders of the Republican party discussed this and other aspects of the State fiscal program with John E. Burton, the incoming Budget Director.
The new pricing order MPR 287, effective today on women's, misses' and children's outer apparel for next Spring and Summer, received preliminary analysis in trade quarters yesterday.

Adequately staffed public and private social agencies are needed immediately to combat the continuing increase of delinquency among adolescents, according to child-care leaders and others who appeared before the committee on juvenile deliquency of the State Board of Social Welfare at a public hearing yesterday in the State Building, 80 Centre Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 9: Increases of $362,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $159,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $297,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 14 -- All is harmony between the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the American Federation of Musicians, A.F.L., according to Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the orchestra, which gave a concert here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Four basic principles which the Office of Price Administration is using as a guide in passing on protests against maximum rent regulations were laid down today in rejecting applications for rent increases from landlords in Bridegport, Conn., Philadelphia and Cleveland.

Parcels containing supplementary food rations and medical supplies for Yugoslav prisoners of war in German and Italian camps will be bought with the proceeds of the United Yugoslav Relief Fund's Christmas bazaar, to be open until Christmas at 11 West Fifty-seventh Street.

In an effort to strengthen the authority of industry "czars," such as Jeffers of rubber and Wickard of foods, the government is planning to give them the status of "claimant agencies" in the Controlled Materials Plan set-up, it was learned here yesterday.

A cautionary tone continued yesterday on the stock market, although volume jumped to the largest in a month because of the activity in low-priced issues. Price movements were narrow throughout the session with mixed tendencies at the close.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14 -- Southwest of Stalingrad a powerful German force is disputing Russian possession of an important stretch of the Stalingrad-Kuban railroad, reach ing almost as far as Kotelnikov. The first shock of the new German assault, the heaviest made so far in an attempt to relieve the trapped forces before Stalingrad, was taken yesterday by Russian artillery.

A large gathering of members of society, and a group of United Nations service men who were guests of Mrs. Michael Gavin, attended the annual concert in behalf of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, of which George L. Bagby is president, held yesterday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The stock market opened cheerfully on the latest news from the Libyan battle front but interest failed to broaden and the market quieted down. Home railway issues were the only feature, junior stocks being in demand on increased dividend prospects.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that Britain and Australia had asked the United States to lease-lend silver until after the war for coinage purposes and revealed that Canada had sold the United States her supply of gold dollars to pay North African natives for their services.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 14 -- The 1942 Legislature met today for the last time this year. It will reconvene on Jan. 12, an hour or so before the 1943 Legislature organizes.

At present, more than sixty national manufacturers are participating in the drug, cosmetic and allied industry campaign cooperating with the Treasury Department in promoting the sale of war plans and are thus enabled to added as rapidly as individual companies decide on their 1943 plans, and are thus enabled to make allocations from budgets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The British have "broken" the German position at El Agheila with what London described yesterday as "suspicious ease."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Complete control over the production and delivery of carbon steel made in electric furnaces was established by the Director General for Operations with the issuance today of an amended conservation order, M-21-A.
AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Dec. 14 (AP) -- There is a sleek little number on this battlefront that has been driving the Japanese in Buna Mission and on Cape Endaiadere to distraction. Her name is Helen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- All soldiers serving either overseas or in this country will get turkey twice on Christmas Day, hot for dinner and cold for supper. This became known today with the release here of details of the official menu for that day.

In October, 1941, the Procurement and Assignment Service established by Presidential action to meet the wartime medical needs of civilian and the armed forces began its administrative existence. The record of a year's failure is worth examining as it was disclosed before Senator Pepper's committee by the directors of the service and by public health authorities.

"Little Isles of Freedom," a two-reel film enactment of the occupation of the islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon by the Free French warships, will have its first public showing at Carnegie Hall on Monday night as a benefit for the people of the islands.

The failure of the Supreme Court yesterday to hand down a decision in the railroad reorganization cases pending before it caused disappointment to many persons in the financial community. On each Monday, for several weeks, it has been anticipated that a decision in these cases would be handed down.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Berlin's hopes of drawing Vichy France into unqualified support of the Axis rested once more tonight on Pierre Laval and his expected interview soon with Adolf Hitler.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- Finance Minister Dr. H.H. Kung today appealed to the United States to send more bombers to China for "mass raids" against Japan's industrial centers and bring about Japan's collapse.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 14 (AP) -- The State neared the end of its grand larceny-forgery case against Samuel Nuzzo, 46, with a review of the defendant's testimony before the extraordinary grand jury which indicted the former union official.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Dec. 14 -- The toll in the Knights of Columbus fire stood tonight at 100, of whom seventy-eight have been identified, as an investigation went forward and workers dug at the ice-covered wreckage in search of more bodies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- To cover the rise in the cost of butter and butter fat from March to October, the Office of Price Administration today authorized an increase of about one cent per half pint in the retail price of light cream, and a proportionate increase at wholesale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Credit in breaking up a ring which was aiding Axis agents to refuel Nazi submarines off the Atlantic Coast, and in the sharp reduction in sinkings of American and Allied ships, was given today to the censoring of communications passing between the United States and one of its territories by Captain Ellis Mr. Zacharias, acting director of Naval Intelligence.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- Mrs. Lytle Hull of Staatsburg and New York, widely known for her musical interests, made tonight her debut in the high school auditorium here as a concert pianist at a concert opening the Winter season of the Dutchess County Philharmonic Orchestra.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- How nearly thirty Polish soldiers -- part of the escort of some 2,000 Italian prisoners -- died when the liner transporting them was torpedoed was told in London today.
Sir George and Lady Bettesworth-Piggott, who have been at the Plaza, leave today for Palm Beach.

BOSTON, Dec. 14 -- A special commission recommended to the State Legislature today that pari-mutuel booking offices be established in cities and towns by the Massachusetts State Racing Commission and that the State increase its "take" from horse and dog racing tracks.

To practical-minded men the Atlantic Charter with its four freedoms is misleading to the extent that it encourages those who subscribe to it to believe that mere agreement offers an opportunity to achieve freedom from want and freedom from fear, whereas neither of them is within the power of any government to bring about without radical changes in the habits of the people and in the character of the government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Roosevelt today vetoed a measure which would have authorized the United States Court of Claims to pass judgment on a claim by John L. Alcock of Baltimore for approximately $195,000, which represented the profit which Mr. Alcock asserted he would have realized on 301 carloads of lumber if the government had not requisitioned or stopped shipment of it during the first World War.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 14 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, New Jersey Power and Light Company and the Jersey Central Power and Light Company joined today in an attack in the Supreme Court here on the constitutionality of a 1941 law excluding service connections from entering the formula for computing the State's 5 per cent franchise tax on portions of the gross receipts of public utilities.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 14 (ONA) -- Sweden's Catholics will observe the fourth Sunday of Advent [Dec. 20] as a day of prayer for Jews at the call of Bishop Johannes Mueller, who has joined the Swedish State Church [Protestant] in protesting Reichsfuehrer Hitler's massacres.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- The State Board of Canvassers, meeting here today, certified the election of Thomas E. Dewey as Governor by a plurality of 647,628 votes.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 14 -- Staff Sergeant Alexander T. Kaczmarczyk, 22 years old, died on a life raft in the Pacific as the result of drinking sea water, Johnny Bartek, 23, one of the seven rescued with Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, revealed today as the soldier arrived home for a thirty-day sick leave.

Mrs. M. Harris Hamersley gave a housewarming and buffet supper last night in her new home at 865 First Avenue. Christmas greens were used in the decorations. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Francis Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. Chester L. Dane, Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Moulton, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Oakey, Mr. and Mrs. Vilhelm Kiorboe, Mr. and Mrs. Francis K. Green, Mrs. Dorsey Cullen and Mrs. G. Chipman Drury.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday certain changes in rules pertaining to questionnaires that must be filled out by member firms. This is expected to aid firms that are understaffed.

Rowdyism in the Times Square area, including reports of women and children being molested by young hoodlums under the nightly dimout conditions, was being investigated by Chief Inspector Louis F. Costuma last night by order of Police Commissioner Valentine, who admitted receiving a complaint from a business man whose wife and child had been molested last Friday night on West Forty-second Street after attending a performance at the Metropolitan Opera House.

DANVILLE, Va., Dec.14 (AP) -- F.C. Beverley, 65, Pittsylvania County tobacco planter and brother-in-law of the late Secretary Claude Swanson of the Navy Department, was shot and killed today in the dining room of his home. A posse fanned out tonight in the Whitmell sector of the county in search of a suspected slayer.

Santa Claus will not forget New York City's children this year. In fact, there is a rumor that, taking example from workers in essential industry, Santa is putting in a good deal of overtime to make sure that even war will not interfere with each child's share of the usual round of gifts and parties.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The U.C.L.A. Bruins, new football champions of the Far West, participated today in a preview of the Georgia style of play.

Wholesale demand for lamp shades increased sharply yesterday following the announcement by the War Production Board on Saturday that output of types containing critical materials must stop by Jan. 1. Manufacturers, whose unit output is now limited to 60 per cent of that in the base period, accepted most of the business offered, but without giving definite assurance of delivery in all cases.
Great Britain, in its widespread attention to the youth of the nation, has avoided any kind of stereotype youth organization, Miss Margaret Bondfield, former British M.P., said yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 14 -- Suffolk County farmers are confronted with serious problems in 1943 because of the labor shortage and the rationing of farm machinery, according to speakers at the twenty-sixth annual meeting of the Suffolk County Farm Bureau and Home Bureau and 4-H Club Association, here this afternoon. Selective Service should defer all young men who are actively engaged in agriculture, it was urged.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 14 -- Thrust out of its Aghelia position, the German Africa Corps was rushing today in the direction of Tripoli to escape furious fighter-bomber attacks by the Allied air forces.

AN AMERICAN AIRFIELD, on the Burma Front, Dec. 10 (Delayed) -- The dramatic rescue of three American airmen who had been given up as lost in the wilds of Burma was learned about here today when two men were flown in and the third was located and saved by a British patrol.

TULAGI, Solomon Islands, Nov. 8 (Delayed) -- Forty marines have just returned from the island of Malaita, where they executed one of the most successful patrol actions carried out in the Southeast Solomons.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Meat processors, apparently disappointed at the failure of hog runs to expand as much as was anticipated this month, bid actively for all hogs and sows today and prices spurted 25 to 35 cents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Dr. Alexander Loudon, Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, today described the Dutch Nazi leader, Anton Mussert, appointed "leader of the Dutch people" by Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler, as an "unimportant pipsqueak who cannot even be dignified by the name of Quisling.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Many and varied are the requests which reach the Private Hospitality Bureau of the American Red Cross Washington Club under the able directorship of Mrs. William R. Brazier of New York. Soldiers from every part of America, on London leave, bring personal problems to her to be solved.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The State Department has been informed that all disputes between the British and the former Vichy French officials at Dakar have been ironed out and that British internees in French West Africa have been released, it was learned today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -- Bill Elliott, former Columbia cowboy start, has been signed by Republic to make eight pictures a year for five years, the studio announced today. Elliott will be teamed prominently with George Gabby Hayes and Anne Jeffreys in his first film.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 14 -- The emigration to the Amazon Valley of rubber gatherers seeking work is still unorganized but has already put 13,088 persons to work, according to official figures furnished by the Amazon State.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 14 -- The normal labor supply is almost exhausted in Connecticut, according to William G. Ennis, director of the United States Employment Service of the War Manpower Commission in this State. Field offices report that it is no longer necessary to persuade Connecticut employers to use women, and there is even a shortage of women in some areas.

TRENTON, Dec. 14 -- As counsel for the Republican Citizens Committee of Jersey City, former State Senator Alexander Simpson filed today with Governor Charles Edison a petition for an investigation of the conduct by William E. Sewell of the office of Superintendent of Elections and Commissioner of Registration of Hudson County.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 14 -- The "white terror" is to be intensified in France with arrests, internment and control of every citizen, it was evident today. Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, in one sentence of a Vichy press declaration, asserted he would "crush ruthlessly everything in my path that may prevent me from saving France," in his collaboration with Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Ray (Sugar) Robinson, hard-hitting Harlem welterweight, battered Al Nettlow at will tonight to score a three-round technical knockout over the game chief boatswain's mate from the Navy's Jacksonville, Fla., base.

June Walker, who at one time subsituted for Dorothy Stickney in "Life With Father" here, will replace Margalo Gillmore in the touring company of that comedy on Jan. 11 in Pittsburgh, the Oscar Serlin office said yesterday.

OTTAWA, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Two members of the Knights of Columbus staff lost their lives in the St. John's fire, P.N.L. Phelan, national director of the Canadian Army huts, said today. He said the men, both natives of Newfoundland, were a Mr. St. John and a Mr. Corbett.

The four West Indies Negro leaders of the Ethiopian Pacific Movement, who went on trial in Federal court yesterday on sedition charges, were energetic in their pro-German exhortations before Pearl Harbor, and shifted to pro-Japanese arguments after that event, according to testimony introduced by John F. Sonnett, Federal prosecutor.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- Squadrons of R.A.F. fighter planes and bombers continuing an almost daily offensive against German communication lines, attacked railway targets in Northern France and Belgium today.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 14 -- State labor laws that prevent women from working seven days a week, "no matter how excellent in peacetime, impose a foolish restriction on production during wartime," according to the Aircraft Workers of America, which calls upon Governor Charles Edison and the Legislature to change these particular labor regulations.
Among the apartment rentals reported yesterday was one for nine rooms and three baths at 901 Lexington Avenue signed by Forbes Morgan through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

Martin A. Hirsch, tax consultant, of 44 Court Street, Brooklyn, was placed on trial before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe and a jury yesterday on a charge of perjuring himself to frustrate an inquiry into funds of the Internatinal Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Owners of the National Football League today voted to postpone the annual draft of this year's crop of college seniors until the meeting next April.

SOUK-EL-KHEMIS, Tunisia, Dec. 11 (Delayed)(U.P.) -- An 8-year-old automobile that chugged along as if each turn of the wheels would be the last brought a group of correspondents here after another hectic retreat that turned out to be a false alarm.

Joseph Schuster, who is first 'cellist of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, and Nadia Reisenberg, pianist, gave the second of their two concerts devoted to all the Beethoven compositions for 'cello and piano at the Town Hall last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- The proposed 1943 Westchester County budget of Herbert G. Gerlach, county executive which contemplates a county-wide tax levy of $8,073,519, an increase of $314,583 over the appropriation of $7,758,935 this year, was attacked tonight by individuals and taxpayer groups at a public hearing in the County Court House here called by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors.
AT UNITED NATIONS' HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Striking employes of the Baltimore Transit Company voted tonight to return to work immediately after a day-long tie-up of nearly 25 per cent of Baltimore's street car and bus transportation system.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 15 -- German troops, smashing forward southwest of Stalingrad, forced back Soviet defenders of the besieged city and renewed counter-assaults on the central front, which were beaten back, the Russian midnight communique reported early today.
A nation-wide celebration on April 13 will mark the 200th anniversary of the birth of Thomas Jefferson, the Bill of Rights Sesquicentennial Committee announced yesterday.

A storekeeper and his clerk who pleaded guilty to selling underweight packages of nuts for members of the armed services were denounced yesterday by Magistrate Charles E. Hirsimaki for "practicing thievery of the meanest type" when he imposed stiff fines in Municipal Term Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Through the single word "denied," the Supreme Court today refused to interfere with a Securities and Exchange Commission ruling that the Public Service Company of New Jersey was a subsidiary of both the United Gas Improvement Company of Pennsylvania and the United Corporation of Delaware.

MAX EASTMAN has always annoyed a certain type of ascetic radical because he insisted on being gay and healthy even when he was a revolutionary. Somehow his more mournful companions back in the early Twenties couldn't reconcile a passionate interest in the theorizing of Lenin with an equally passionate delight in swimming at a Black Sea beach resort.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Dec. 14 -- Tribute was paid tonight to the gallantry of Canadian and American service men who died in the fire while helping their girl companions to safety.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 14 -- Charges that Louis Vierbucken, Hudson Manhattan tube train motorman, was "under the influence of liquor" and "began to go faster and faster, disregarding warning signals and curves," preceding the wreck of his train at Exchange Place here April 26 were outlined in court today.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The British Ministry of Information issued a statement today similar to General McClure's. The Ministry mentioned articles in The New York Daily News on Dec. 11 and The Chicago Tribune on Dec. 12.
SALEM, N.J., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Three Salem County muskrat hunters who told a whale of a fish story here last week were vindicated today. They have the whale to prove it.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 14 -- Mrs. J.B. Hatfield's Knitetta, bounding back after a twenty-seven-length defeat last out, proved a worthy investment for long-shot players today when she won the seven-furlong sixth race by three lengths. Knitetta returned $19.40 for $2. J.L. Friedman's Sir Kid was second and Mrs. C.P. Miles's Petes Bet third.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 14 (AP) -- An official Chinese review of conditions in Manchuria said today that about 1,000,000 Japanese troops were now concentrated in that region and Japanese military preparations there had been increased considerably in the last year.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 14 -- An eventual choice between "democratic controls and appointed masters" was predicted today by the Rev. Louis J. Weitzman, S.J., at the Catholic Conference on Industrial Problems.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has brought Alaskan air transport under the Civil Aeronautics law by granting operating certificates to twenty-one Alaskan air carriers.

With a better type of buying in evidence, the stock market moved yesterday over an irregularly higher course and some of the investment type issues added a point and more. Although the heaviest business continued to center in low-priced shares there was a decided stepped-up interest for the higher-priced type.
The mine that hit the liner President Coolidge made hardly any sound at all and was just felt as a jar by the men on board, a deep, shaking jar.
Shadow Brook Farm of fifty acres in Shrewsbury, one of New Jersey's outstanding farm estates, has been acquired by Ray Stillman of Eatontown for investment.
Several thousand persons from the financial district gathered in front of the Sub-Treasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets at noon yesterday to witness the induction of 500 naval aviation cadets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Senate and House quickly and unanimously adopted resolutions today to make adjournment sine die tomorrow automatic after finishing routine matters and to bring the new session of Congress into session on Jan. 6.

FAIRFIELD, Utah, Dec. 15 -A Cedar Valley rancher and an executive officer of the Utah Civil Air Patrol said tonight that the two passengers who survived a Western Air Lines plane crash did so because their safety belts were fastened.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Persistent buying of December wheat attributed to mills advanced all deliveries to new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade today and the close was about the top with gains of 2 to 2 1/2 cents.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The War Labor Board began an investigation today into a Chicago printing trades controversy. According to N.M. Di Pietro, international representative of the Typographical Union, $50,000,000 worth of publishing work is involved.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -War production leaders embarked today on a program of relief for small business squeezed by the nation's war effort, ordering all war contractors to start intensified subcontracting to put to use thousands of nearly idle machine tools.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Roosevelt made it clear today that he was not in sympathy with suggestions that the projected size of the United States Army by the end of 1943 should be reduced below 7,500,000. At his press conference the Chief Executive was asked whether recent strategic or other developments had led to a reconsideration of the Army's planned strength, with a view to reducing it because of supply, transport and equipment problems.

President Fulgencio Batista declared here last night that he is returning to Cuba after a week's official visit to the United States, during which he conferred with President Roosevelt, convinced that the sole immediate objective is to win the war -- that the details of the post-war world can be arranged later.

The Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., granted yesterday an injunction sought by the Securities and Exchange Commission and thereby restrained minority stockholders from blocking consummation of a plan of dissolution of the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation.

With three of the seven classifications registering increases, the loss in newspaper advertising linage in fifty-two cities measured by Media Records last month was held to 1.3 per cent. For the first eleven months of this year, the decline was 5.6 per cent.

The interests of Harlem -- and therefore of New York City -- can sometimes be harmed as much by injudicious and uninformed efforts to help as by deliberate attempts to hinder. There has been much discussion about the rise of juvenile delinquency in New York, and invariably the accent has been on Harlem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan took the Senate floor today to attack the critics of American collaboration with Admiral Jean Darlan in North Africa. Obviously some of his shafts were directed at Wendell L. Willkie, the titular leader of his party, although he did not mention Mr. Willkie by name.

Sales of government securities in the New York Federal Reserve District in the $9,000,000,000 December nation-wide Victory Loan drive amounted to $3,109,285,020, as of noon yesterday, according to an announcement by Perry E. Hall, executive manager of the New York Victory Fund Committee.

Despite the increasing manpower scarcity and the necessity of confining lumber output to war needs, there will be sufficient paper-making materials to take care of allowable paper output for the first half of next year, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by wood pulp manufacturers.

N.Y.U. has played four basketball games to date. The Violets took the measure of Upsala, Fort Monmouth, Queens and Montclair Teachers and in so doing scored a total of 288 points, while limiting the opposition to a mere 152. Offensively, then, they have averaged seventy-two points per game.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Women workers who stay away from their newly acquired jobs in war plants to shop, attend weddings or parties, or to get heir hair done, are retarding the war drive, says William H. Spencer, regional director of the War Manpower Commission.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, Dec. 16 -- Remnants of a Japanese force that made a landing, despite bloody losses, at Cape Ward Hunt, about half way between Lae and Buna, are being harassed by Allied planes, General Douglas MacArthur's noon communique reported today.

Private industry, including industries working for the war, is making increasing use of blind workers and becoming convinced of their special capabilities, M.C. Migel, president of the American Foundation for the Blind, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization in the Helen Keller room of its headquarters, 15 West Sixteenth Street.

Additional evidence, if it were needed, that Morton C. Cooper well deserved the most valuable player award voted him by the baseball writers' committee, is contained in the National League pitchers' averages, released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A rationing program covering coal and oil-heating stoves for private dwellings will be put into effect Friday in the thirty-State fuel oil rationing area, the Office of Price Administration said today. The program virtually suspends sales of oil heaters in the thirty States, but makes coal heaters freely available to householders who wish to convert from oil to coal.
Among the many interesting articles in your Sunday issue two appealed to me particularly. One was "Plants Reassured on Output Switch," and the other was "Manpower Hoard Is Charged to U.S."

LONDON, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- Admiral Emile Muselier of the Fighting French, taking issue with United States Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox, said today that close examination of photographs of Toulon showed that virtually the entire French fleet there was scuttled.

The season for choosing 1942's film "bests" was opened yesterday by the Young Reviewers of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, who announced their selection of the ten best motion pictures released between Dec. 1, 1941, and Dec. 1, 1942.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres predicted today that 1943 "will probably be our toughest war year, both for individual business men and for corporations."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed in November amounted to 913,038 bales of lint and 113,728 of linters, compared with 972,490 of lint and 116,259 of linters in the preceding month and 849,143 of lint and 116,976 of linters in November, 1941.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Dr. Samuel S. Stratton, 44, an economist specializing in the iron and steel industry, has been elected president of Middlebury College. He will take office Jan. 1.

Writing paragraphs for a newspaper column while the paper deliverers are on strike suggests Mr. Longfellow's experience. It will be recalled that the poet breathed a song into the air and it fell to earth he knew not where.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Senator Wheeler said tonight that the Office of Defense Transportation was planning to "deploy" its men in temporary field stations in an effort to eliminate confusion over gasoline rationing to truck drivers.

The major leagues yesterday reiterated their hope that they could go through with training plans in Florida and California even though some of the clubs said they already were considering alternative arrangements in line with a government hint that they be prepared to move their Spring bases.

Wage negotiating committees representing the managements of virtually all Class I railroads in the country and the fifteen nonoperating railway unions opened here yesterday a three-day conference to consider demands of the latter for an increase of 20 cents an hour and a minimum hourly rate of 70 cents for 900,000 employes.

IN the sporting field Philadelphia has had to face two vexing problems, the Phils and the Athletics. Now another problem has been tossed into the laps of the residents of the City of Brotherly Love. It's the big football game to be played there Dec. 27 between the champion Redskins and a National League all-star outfit for the benefit of the United Seamen's Service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Roosevelt had a slight cold and did not leave the White House until afternoon to hold his press conference; he nominated several high naval officers for promotion; his visitors included John J. Dempsey, Paul Bellamy, Ordway Tead and Eric A. Johnston and Senator Prentiss Brown and James F. Byrnes.

Edgar S. Bloom, president of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines has informed stockholders that several of the company's ships have been lost since the United States entered the war. The War Shipping Administration has requisitioned two additional combination passenger and freight vessels, he said, and the balance of the fleet continues to be under charter to the United States Government.

Immediate pay increases, ranging from 5 to 15 per cent of their present salaries, for 125,000 city employes receiving $5,000 or less a year were proposed yesterday in a resolution and local law introduced in the City Council by Councilman Frederick Schick, Staten Island Democrat.

GREENLAWN, L.I., Dec. 15 -- An estimated 8,000 North Shore commuters between Port Jefferson and points west were delayed up to 2 hours and 38 minutes in reaching their places of employment this morning because a main driving rod of a Jamaica-bound Port Jefferson local steam train on the Wading River branch broke at the Lake Avenue crossing between here and Huntington.
An appeal for women volunteers to become troop leaders was issued yesterday by the board of directors of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York.

In 1792 appeared the first number of what was to be an annual classic, The Farmer's Almanac, calculated for the year 1793. Under its later and more familiar name, The Old Farmer's Almanac, the 152d issue is just out. It was founded by Robert B. Thomas, son of a Massachusetts farmer and schoolmaster.

Major league baseball yesterday received its first official intimation on how the government's salary freezing regulations will apply to bail players' contracts for next season when Leo J. Bondy, vice president and treasurer of the Giants, received word that his ball club would be permitted to sign its players, with increases or decreases, just as it has done in the past.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 15 -- As the German withdrawal along the shores of the Gulf of Sidra continued yesterday, there were indications that the next Axis stand would be made this side of Misurata, which is some 300 miles air line beyond El Agheila.
LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

It is rumored again in Scandinavia that the Finns are ready to discuss peace terms with Russia. Since they have fought little in recent months and have long been ready to stop if they could get some guarantee of protection and permanence on the frontiers agreed upon, there is little news in these reports.

A new method for investigating the dynamics of stellar systems, which provides a new lead for evaluating the age of the universe, won one of two $200 prizes of the New York Academy of Sciences at the 125th annual meeting of the academy at the Roosevelt Memorial Building, American Museum of Natural History, last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations, expressed the belief today that adequate relief work in reoccupied countries will go a long way toward shortening the war and establishing a stable peace and the kind of world we are interested in.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 16 -- The Russians announced the capture of two more populated places west of Rzhev on the frozen central front yesterday, but the midnight communique made it apparent that steady Nazi counter-attacks still were slowing the Red Army both there and on the two wings of the Stalingrad sector.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
Frankie Sinkwich, for the last two years a member of the Associated Press All-America football team, has been voted the No. 1 male athlete of 1942.
RENO, Nev. Dec. 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Lolita Armour Mitchell, once known as the world's richest girl, obtained a divorce from John J. Mitchell today.
Patrolman Sol Pollack, on post at Neptune Avenue and Brighton Eighth Street, Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, was startled yesterday afternoon by the sound of strange rappings under his feet.

Lady Ribblesdale will give a dinner on Dec. 23 at her home, 420 Park Avenue, before the American premiere showing of the motion picture "In Which We Serve," at the Capitol Theatre, in aid of the philanthropic fund of the Overseas Press Club.

Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein refused yesterday to reduce bail of $25,000 set by General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. for Dr. Frederick Bruno Henschel, 49 years old, of 151 East Eighty-third Street, who has been indicted on abortion charges.
Eighteen new tenants have signed leases for apartments in Tudor City, according to the Fred F. French Management Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The President at his press conference today referred disapprovingly to contentions that the planned United States Army may be too large to be maintained by the domestic population that must service it all over the world.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- Without comment but prominently displayed, news of the military and political situation in North Africa is attracting considerable attention in Moscow.

"Stars Shine for Young America," a gala performance featuring stars of the stage, screen, radio and operatic world, was presented at Madison Square Garden last night for the benefit of the Police Athletic League Juvenile Aid Bureau, known throughout the city as P.A.L.

Pierre Laval's public declaration that he "wants Germany to win" and will "crush ruthlessly" everything in the path of collaboration reveals nothing new in his character or attitudes. The butcher's son from the Auvergne, the former Socialist politician who grew rich in a succession of offices, the man of iron who saved his hide in the First World War by pleading varicose veins as a reason for exemption from military service, is a one-man party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Three men who have contributed to the advance of preventive medicine in the armed forces received today Gorgas Medals from the Association of Military Surgeons of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Reviewing war activities of the RFC, Chairman Jones upheld his handling of the rubber situation today and disclosed the RFC's war-purpose commitments had reached more than $18,000,000,000, a gain of $6,000,000,000 since March.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -The all-service draft cannot be put into effect until about Feb. 1, and men of 17 through 37 years may volunteer through their local draft boards meanwhile.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The War Department announced tonight the names of 197 Army men, including ten from New York, five from New Jersey and two from Connecticut, who are held as prisoners of war by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Dec. 15 -- Two boys who had been released from the Hudson County Parental Home at Bayonne last October were arrested by the Hoboken police this afternoon in connection with nine recent robberies in this area, two of which resulted in fires that caused damage estimated at $60,000.

Mrs. Busch Greenough gave a luncheon yesterday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre before the final musicale in the series of Tuesday Afternoon Musicales, organized by Rafaelo Diaz. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. Robert Morris Phillips, Mrs. Arthur Ryle, Mrs. Robert Rives, Mrs. A. Von Gontard, Count Roger de Palleul, Ralph McBain, Lucius Humphreys and Charles Stevens.

Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight champion, who is now a lieutenant in the Coast Guard, was on the witness stand for nearly an hour yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null at the trial of his suit for $50,000 damages and an injunction to restrain distribution of a book entitled "How to Fight Tough," by Lieutenant Jack Dempsey, U.S. Coast Guard, and Frank G. Menke.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 15 (AP) -- ODT Director Joseph B. Eastman, commenting on a proposal to divide major league baseball into Eastern and Western divisions, said tonight "we are very much interested in anything that will save travel, but I haven't the remotest idea whether the plan is practicable."
CAIRO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique:

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- A slump in beef production to less than 1941 levels for the first time in seven months was reported today as the packing industry prepared to go under wholesale beef price "ceilings" tomorrow with a protest that the levels will be too low to permit profitable operations as long as prices for cattle remain as high as they are.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -- Republic today signed Simone Simon for the leading feminine role opposite Dennis O'Keefe in "Tahiti Honey," which will go before the cameras Jan. 4 with John Auer directing. The title "Tahiti Honey" had previously been used by Republic on a film which was released as "Moonlight Masquerade."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and John B. Blandford Jr., administrator of the National Housing Agency, announced today a joint policy on war housing designed to provide the maximum amount of accommodation to war workers despite shortages of construction materials.
The Florsheim Shoe Company reported yesterday for its fiscal year ended with October net profit totaling $1,031,770 after Federal income and excess profits taxes.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 15 -- Bombers of the Middle East Command on Sunday night gave the Tunis dock area known as La Goulette a four-hour pounding that destroyed three ships, oil installations and parts of the docks themselves.

Liquidation in the near months on the New York Cotton Exchange, while small, was able yesterday to offset commission-house buying in the distant positions, causing final net losses of 4 to 9 points on active contracts.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- Considerable attention has been given by the press to an article in Time magazine entitled "Mikhailovitch's Eclipse," dealing with the relations between General Draja Mikhailovitch's Yugoslav Chetniks and the

Some forty recent acquisitions were placed on view yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art. With a few exceptions most of these items are trivia of the modern art movement -- drawings, small sketches and the like. They are, however, not without interest and some of the drawings are highly characteristic.

The bantamweight championship recognition accorded to Lou Salica was withdrawn by the New York State Athletic Commission at its meeting yesterday because the Brooklyn boxer had failed to defend his title in a sanctioned bout in the required six months.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- With next Summer tin cans will fast be disappearing from pantry shelves.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Recent statements that the spread of venereal disease in Britain since the outbreak of war had increased some 70 per cent were confirmed in the House of Commons today by Ernest Brown, Minister of Health, in a debate on control of the disease.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Army and Navy bombers based at Henderson Field on Guadalcanal Island have bombed for the fifth time in six days a Japanese air field at Munda, on New Georgia Island, the Navy reported today. This last bombing occurred on Monday (Solomons date).

Terminating its engagement at the Morosco Theatre on Saturday night is "The Great Big Doorstep." Directed and produced by Herman Shumlin, the comedy will have been performed twenty-eight times with a cast headed by Dorothy Gish and Louis Calhern.

A vast market research program to acquaint the other nations of the world with our needs must be undertaken soon if our export-import trade after the war is to be mutually profitable and if further repudiation of loans is to be avoided, J. George Frederick, president of the Business Bourse, research and publishing organization, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Hundred For One Club at the Uptown Club.

Continued efforts by the State Board of Mediation, headed by Arthur S. Meyer, to settle the strike of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, an independent organization, which has tied up distribution of eight New York City newspapers since Sunday, were still deadlocked early this morning after all-day and all-night conferences on proposals of the union and counter-proposals by the Publishers Association.

A new issue of $800,000 of water revenue bonds, due serially from Dec. 15, 1944 to 1970, was awarded yesterday by Longview, Wash., to a banking group comprising Blyth Co., Inc., and A.C. Allyn Co., Inc. and associates. The bankers bid par for $83,000 of the bonds as 3 1/2 per cents and $717,000 as 2 3/4 s.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A capacity Washington audience, including the Soviet Ambassador and Mrs. Maxim Litvinoff, saw last night the premiere of "The Russian People," a stirring drama of Russia at war, written by Konstantin Simonov and adapted by Clifford Odets.

BREGA, Libya, Dec. 14 (Delayed) -- The enemy, who has relinquished fortified positions along the so-called Agheila line, of which this hamlet was the strongest position and, in fact, the key of the whole system of defenses, has withdrawn farther westward. It is believed that only a skeleton force now holds El Agheila itself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Truman Defense Committee of the Senate asserted in a report today that the country was facing an "acute" lumber shortage for essential military and civilian needs next year and declared that an official of the War Production Board should be "censured" for delays which it held contributed to the threatened shortage.

In view of the deadly seriousness of the rubber situation it is essential that every motorist should conserve his tires. Inflation must be checked, small cuts and injuries must be repaired, and, above all, the speed and manner of driving must be held strictly to the pattern which will save every possible ounce of rubber.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- With Flash Hollett setting the stage, the Bruins strengthened their hold on the National Hockey League's lead by topping the Red Wings, 3 to 2, tonight as they extended their unbeaten home season string to nine games.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 14 -- Arrests of Danish patriots introduced with the Cabinet of Erik Scavenius assume ever-growing proportions, according to news received here through private channels. Danish uneasiness about the future has been further increased by the voyage to Norway of Dr. Werner Best and Major Gen. Hermann von Hanneken, Hitler rulers in Denmark, to "compare notes" on the fine points of occupation rule with Josef Terboven.

WASHINGTON, Dec 15 -- Disturbed because President Roosevelt spelled Generalissimo with too many "l's," the Office of War Information tonight sent out a hurry call for ink eradicator and meanwhile held up distribution of facsimiles of a letter which he wrote to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

There was only one place in which beef was "sold" in the city yesterday -- a banquet room in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The selling was that of an idea and was done by representatives of the Office of Price Administration for the benefit of 500 local butchers and wholesale meat dealers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Hog receipts failed to expand appreciably today, despite Monday's upturn in prices, and the market held steady to strong with the top again at $14.10. Cattle prices also held steady, but lambs were weak.

THE Rivers of America series just keeps rolling along. Uneven in quality, often blandly indifferent to any valid connection to a particular river, personal and capricious in their selection of material, the river books now number some nineteen volumes. Judged solely as popular Americana, as regional history of an informal, sprightly variety, their average quality is surprisingly high.

A UNITED STATES SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Dec. 14 (delayed) (U.P.) -- American Flying Fortresses have carried out smashing raids the past few days against the new Japanese airfield on New Georgia island, about 200 miles northwest of Guadalcanal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The War Labor Board unanimously decided today that it had no authority to decide labor disputes between municipalities and employes' organizations. The ruling was on a case from Newark, but the decision on jurisdiction applied as well to disputes involving 32,000 transportation employes of the City of New York, and to 600 workers in the gas and water system of Omaha, Neb.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Approximately 14,000 corporations in New York were dissolved today by Secretary of State Michael F. Walsh for failure to file annual franchise tax reports in the last three years.

Premier Hideki Tojo of Japan called upon the people of that country yesterday, according to a Tokyo broadcast recorded by The Associated Press, to discard peacetime ways of thinking and concentrate all their efforts upon the prosecution of the war.

Some of the details of negotiations relating to the acquisition of land in Canada for the restoration of "duck factories" are being related by Tom Main in a series of articles that might go under the heading of "inside stories."

Maximum Price Regulation No. 287, effective yesterday on women's, misses' and children's outer apparel for next Spring and Summer, will result in a series of major "squeezes" on the garment industry, the most important of which includes a rollback of the "first cutting" costs to the lower levels of January or earlier instead of March, as under the GMPR, and the 10 per cent cut in maximum allowable margin in the face of higher overhead.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Senator Byrd, chairman of the Joint Congressional-Departmental Committee on Reduction of Federal Expenditures, asked the War Department today whether the recent purchase of the Stevens Hotel in Chicago meant that the government, or the department, was going into the hotel business after the war.

Those who have read carefully the records of the Hundred Neediest Cases must have noticed how much hope was linked up with dire misfortune. Private givers are not asked to carry the whole burden of support in these human predicaments. A little added to what the recipients have, or expect to have, will often tip the scales.
In mid-1942 our work-week was 42.5 hours. In regard to suggested changes three questions are involved: Should we lengthen the week? If so, by how much? And by what means?
LONDON, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- British planes today again attacked German communication lines in France and Belgium, continuing an almost daily campaign begun against such targets in late November.

Martin A. Hirsch, a 47-year-old tax consultant, was convicted yesterday of perjury as the result of false statements made by him to a Federal grand jury investigating the participation of Chicago gangsters in extortions by three former leaders of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.

LONDON, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- An Allied communique issued here said today that widespread damage had resulted yesterday from the third straight day of heavy daylight raids on Axis dispositions in Tunisia while the United States Twelfth Air Force announced at its African headquarters that American fliers had destroyed seventy enemy planes and damaged forty-three thus far in the North African campaign.

The determination that those in greatest need at home must not be forgotten because of worthy and more dramatic appeals to relieve suffering abroad prompts many of the gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund.

A preview of what will be seen in the South and Southwest as soon as the tide of women and girls going to visit the male members of their families in camps sweeps in those directions was given yesterday at the luncheon hour in the Ritz-Carlton.

The death rate in New York City rose last week to 11.1 per 1,000 population, a high for the season and the seventh successive week in which the rate exceeded the "expected" mark, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday.

At a meeting held yesterday in Cleveland, the directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company elected Carl E. Newton as president. For the two subsidiary roads, the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company and the Pere Marquette Railway Company, John W. Davin and Robert J. Bowman respectively were elected presidents.

Rolling up fifty-five points in the second half, the Fordham basketball team overwhelmed an invading Iona squad, 84 to 38, on the Rams' court last night. This was the fifth straight for the undefeated Rose Hill team.

With money in circulation expanding rapidly, the Federal Reserve Board, to lighten the demands on the Bureau of Engraving, has authorized the twelve Federal Reserve Banks to place in circulation approximately $660,000, 000 of Federal Reserve Bank notes, as distinguished from the usual Federal Reserve notes now in common use.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 15 (U.P.) --President Enrique Penaranda de Castillo declared martial law in five important tin-mining areas today, following yesterday's nationwide state-of-siege decree, to prevent "extremists," believed to include Nazi-controlled elements acting under orders from Berlin, from hampering tin production.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 693 as against 754 in the preceding week and 354 in the similar period of 1941, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 272, which compared with 312 last Tuesday.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 15 (AP) -Five Kansas City women have been running street-cars ever since the World War, the survivors of 130 conductorettes.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Samuel Nuzzo's defense opened today with two witnesses testifying they recalled the granting of an expense account to the former union business agent. Nuzzo is on trial for grand larceny and forgery.

Most people in America are not yet alive to the gravity of the world situation today, James E. Freeman, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Washington, D.C., told a group of philanthropic leaders yesterday at a luncheon given by the Golden Rule Foundation, at the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.
Samuel Reshevsky and Isaac I. Kashdan played a draw last night at the Henry Hudson Hotel in the eighth game of their match for the championship of the United States.

Post-war relief and rehabilitation in war-torn countries must be in spiritual as well as material terms, Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, rabbi of the Temple of Cleveland, last night told the annual Hanukkah dinner of the Jewish Education Committee at the Hotel Astor.

Leonard Robert Jordan, leader of a highly unsuccessful movement to bring the Negroes of Harlem into the Axis camp, planned to have "President Roosevelt picking cotton, and Secretaries Knox and Stimson riding me around in rickshaws," when the United States had lost the war.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Dec. 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- Two seamen who risked their lives and a destroyer commander who risked his ship to save survivors from a carrier sunk in the Battle of Santa Cruz Island on Oct. 26, were cited for heroism today.

Employes of many American corporations, including those in the armed services, will receive extra Christmas spending money in the form of bonuses now being announced and distributed. In awarding the bonus checks many companies have suggested that a portion of the money be used to purchase war bonds and stamps.

AT A UNITED STATES TANK BASE, Somewhere in England, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Santa Claus came rumbling across the fields in a General Grant tank today, bringing more candy for each of the children of this village than they ordinarily get in months.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- The German forces that were reported last night to have made some progress southwest of Stalingrad continued their attacks during the last twelve hours. Russian reports said there had been four assaults in quick succession, but that they were meeting the massive resistance of Russian artillery and had failed to make further headway or dislodge the defenders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Roosevelt denied today reports that Leon Henderson had resigned or had intimated his willingness to resign as Federal Price Administrator.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The Tunisian fighting front east of Medjezel-Bab, a crucial point in the Bizerte-Tunis salient, remained more or less static today, but the seemingly tireless Allied air forces, on which the drive for the complete conquest of Tunisia is so dependent, kept up their activities, according to advices reaching London tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The stock market remained cheerful in today's session, although business still is on a small scale. Home railroad issues continued to find support, Southern Deferred rising a quarter, London, Midland Scottish an eighth, and London North Eastern preference a quarter.

The editorial judges of the Book-of-the-Month Club decided yesterday on its March books, making a dual selection of a novel by Berry Fleming, "Colonel Effingham's Raid," and "The Human Comedy," by William Saroyan. The former book is from the Duell, Sloan Pearce list.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Japanese forces in Southwest Yunnan Province, stalled in their attempted push northward from Tengyueh, may soon launch a drive directly eastward across the Salween River toward Yungchang, Chinese base 200 miles west of Kunming, capital of Yunnan, a Chinese military spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Rear Admiral Francis W. Rockwell, who won Army and Navy honors for the manner in which he evacuated Cavite Navy Yard, near Manila, was nominated today by President Roosevelt for permanent promotion to his present rank.

The Hollywood Victory Committee, organized three days after the Pearl Harbor attack to coordinate the efforts of film, stage and radio personalities in the entertainment of the armed forces and in otherwise assisting the national war effort, released yesterday its first annual report through the Industry Service Bureau of Motion Pictures in Hollywood.

Racing, at the start of the 1942 season, set a goal of $2,000,000 as its contribution to war relief. Yesterday, at the offices of Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the Turf Committee of America as well as the New York State Racing Commission, it appeared that the sport had passed that total by a million dollars and that its final contribution to war relief agencies for this year would be $3,000,000.

Statistics attempting to prove that juvenile delinquency is not rising were termed "misleading" yesterday by Mrs. Claire Argow, acting vice director of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, who told the Hunter College Social Service Society that delinquency among adolescent girls had risen 24 per cent.

Some time ago I was favorably struck by an editorial appearing in your columns suggesting that drivers on the highway going at sixty miles an hour, wasting rubber and gasoline, might be deterred by tooting the victory signal on the horns of those going the regulation thirty-five.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Asserting that they now earned less revenue for hauling a ton of freight a mile than in any year since 1918, the railroads asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to deny petitions filed by the Office of Price Administration and other government agencies for the elimination of increases in rates and fares authorized last Spring.

The statement of Food Administrator Wickard that he knows of no definite plan for widespread food rationing and his explanation that such rationing is being blocked because "Congress just won't grant the funds" is cause for genuine concern.

Inability to obtain sack deliveries of substantial quantities of specific utility clothing needed for refugee aid by lend-lease buyers may cause the WPB to issue priority ratings to the Treasury Department's procurement division that would divert "over-runs" and "seconds" of military contracts to such channels, it was reported yesterday in the textile markets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A Navy board today pursued an examination as to the actual cause of the sinking of the Army transport President Coolidge by mines, but President Roosevelt and Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox declined today to discuss reports that American mines might have sunk the ship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A mission to Soviet Russia which will collect information about the chemical and engineering experience of the U.S.S.R. In connection with the manufacture of synthetic rubber was named today by William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director.
AT UNITED HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- The Yugoslav Government in exile agreed today that its "supreme duty" was to defend General Draja Mikhailovitch, War Minister and leader of the guerrilla army in Yugoslavia, against attempts to discredit him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The testimony yesterday of Dr. Gilbert S. Osincup, president of the Florida State Medical Association, before a Senate subcommittee that there were "too many doctors" in the Army, and that they were "going crazy" for want of something to do calls attention to one of the major problems of this global war.
Outstanding among the dividend actions taken yesterday by corporation directors were the announcements of four companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Establishment of "area pricing," a new policy so far as the Office of Price Administration is concerned, was revealed here today by an OPA announcement that it has issued specific dollars and cents ceiling prices for hand laundries in Eastern Massachusetts.

LONDON, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- Britain would have had fewer than 100 tanks to throw against the Germans if they had tried an invasion after Dunkerque, and even that feeble array of armor had been proved no match for Nazi anti-tank guns, Prime Minister Churchill revealed today.

Edward Lazansky, presiding justice of the Appellate Division, Second Department, received last night an oil painting of himself at a reception and dinner marking his seventieth birthday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The presentation was made by Irving Lehman, chief judge of the New York State Court of Appeals.

Thousands of NEW YORK TIMES readers braved snow and sleet last night to stand in line to buy newspapers as they came from the presses. Before the first edition was ready the line reached from the Times Building at 229 West Forty-third Street eastward to the Paramount Theatre marquee.

The two-story taxpayer at the southeast corner of Second Avenue and Forty-second Street was sold by the New York Savings Bank to a client of Cravath, deGersdorff, Swaine Wood, attorneys. This property is assessed for $335,000 and is occupied principally by chain stores.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 16 (UP) -- One of Great Britain's most successful submarines, H.M.S. Truant, returned to her home base today after having sunk or damaged twenty Axis ships during an 80,000-mile voyage through the Atlantic, the Mediterranean, the Indian Ocean and the Pacific.

LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Dominions Secretary Clement R. Attlee declared today that the formation of a Supreme Imperial War Cabinet or Supreme Allied War Council "sounds nice and logical but, unfortunately, it is completely impractical."

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Dec. 15 (AP) -- American sharpshooters strapped in the trees in Japanese fashion poured a deadly fire into the Buna Mission area today, after taking Buna Village in a fierce hand-to-hand fight, while to their rear they and Australian Allies kept a wary eye for an enemy force of undetermined size that landed and opened a new sector.

The things a manufacturer does today under wartime conditions will influence the public in its attitude toward a company for years to come, K.B. Elliott, vice president in charge of sales of the Studebaker Corporation, declared yesterday in outlining his com pany's efforts to maintain its dealers in business.

Every New Yorker should be pleased with the news that the controversy over the air raid alarm system is dying down. The alarm system is either not necessary at all or it is sternly serious. Until the war is over we have to assume that it is necessary because air raids may occur.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
FAIRFIELD, Utah, Dec. 15 -- A Western Airlines transport plane crashed in a desert area near here today, killing seventeen of the nineteen persons aboard, four of whom were women.
Following is the text of Herbert Hoover's address in Chicago last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Chairman Gillette of a Senate agriculture subcommittee declared today that somebody was to blame for the halting progress of the rubber program "and we're going to find out who." In the presence of the rubber director, William M. Jeffers, and Bradley Dewey, his assistant, the Senator said the subcommittee was at present in a lull, but "the other half of the cyclone is yet to come."

Wendell L. Willkie declared in a public speech here last night what he has said several times previously in off-the-record talks since he returned from his round-the-world trip -- that he is not satisfied with the "British Empire" attitude toward colonial and subject peoples.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Federal authorities announced today that twenty-one Negroes had been arrested here in connection with an alleged conspiracy to encourage evasion of service in the armed forces.

Five great shortages exist in the midst of educational plenty in the United States, Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared in his annual report to the Board of Trustees for the academic year ended last June, made public yesterday.
As a Frenchman I wish to express my indignation at the article by Pertinax which appeared in your columns Dec. 12. I quote:

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- Dr. Rufus B. von Kleinsmid, president of the University of Southern California, proposes that citizens of the United States be known as "Usonans" instead of "Americans" or "Gringos" in Inter-American relations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Wheat markets turned reactionary today after having been on the upgrade for seven days, but not until May and July had sold on the Board of Trade at the highest prices of the season. Aggressive buying for mills, credited to the removal of hedges against sales of flour, was responsible for the early strength, but when support gave out professional traders turned to the selling side and profit-taking also was evident.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- N.M. Di Pietro, international representative of the typographical union, declared today that unions refusing to handle any work done in part by two large printing plants here would not change their attitude pending a hearing before the War Labor Board tomorrow to which all "interested parties" were invited.

Rising costs have caused more than half the daily newspapers in the United States to increase at least some part of their circulation rate structure since the start of the war in 1939, Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, told The Associated Press yesterday.

Political considerations should give way to military strategy, General Wladyslaw Sikorski, Premier of Poland and commander in chief of her armed forces, declared here yesterday. He defended the Allie acceptance of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan in French Africa and also hailed General Charles de Gaulle.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 16 (AP) -- A State-wide test mobilization of the New Jersey State Guard was held tonight. Members were summoned from their homes by telephone and from theatres and other public places by ushers and public address systems.

For the second time in his dozen years as a major league catcher, Ernie Lombardi of the Boston Braves has been crowned batting champion of the National League. Big Cyrano had an average of .330 in the 1942 campaign, according to the official averages released for publication today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Louis A. Vierbucken, on trial for manslaughter as the motorman of the Hudson and Manhattan tube train that crashed at the Exchange Place station here last April 26, resulting in five deaths and injury to more than 100 passengers, took the witness stand today in his defense and denied he was drunk when operating the train.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Captain Lawrence T. Haugen won commendation from Secretary Knox today for his work in maintaining and repairing escort vessels, which in a thirteen-month period took more than 2,000 ships across the Atlantic convoy lines with a loss of only eight.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Walter White, the Rev. A. Clayton Powell and many others whom Leonard Robert Jordan considered "dumb American Negroes" were marked for decapitation by that British West Indies Negro, according to the testimony of Herbert S. Boulin, Negro agent of the Federal Court yesterday.

Commemorating the thirty-ninth anniversary of the first flight of a powered heavier-than-air craft, made by the Wright Brothers near Kitty Hawk, N.C., on Dec. 17, 1903, a four-day exhibit of aeronautical photographs, models and other aviation equipment will be opened today at 4 P.M. in the Kitty Hawk cocktail lounge in the La Guardia Field Administration Building.

Failure of two government agencies, the War Production Board and the Federal Trade Commission, to issue basic information needed for trade guidance prior to the recent relaxing by the WPB of civilian woolen restrictions on blankets has led to confusion and costly delays in planning of essential civilian requirements for 1943, manufacturers and buyers reported yesterday.

AKRON, Dec. 15 -- Purchase of the Yankee Network of twenty-one stations, the fifth largest radio chain in the country, was announced today by the General Tire and Rubber Company here, through Wiliam O'Neil, president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The War Labor Board, attempting a unique solution of the union security issue, granted maintenance of membership to a union on a probationary basis, revokable if the union failed to end work stoppages and discipline those who caused them.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 16 -- The first class of Spar officers was commissioned today in the Coast Guard Reserve. The twelve women were graduated with about 500 Waves officers at the Naval Training School at Smith College.

Disclosing the loss of two more United States merchant ships, the Navy revealed yesterday that hope had been abandoned for all those on board one of the vessels, overdue for several weeks in the South Atlantic. Among those lost was Lieutenant (j.g.) Carl Frederick Zeidler, former Mayor of Milkaukee.
