WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Spokesmen for the railroads urged the War Labor Board today to retain jurisdiction over pending wage demands by a group of unions on behalf of 1,500,000 railway workers, and protested against permitting a Presidentially-created railway labor panel to administer the President's stabilization order of Oct. 3, for the railroads.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Only men in Class 1-A may enter the Navy, Marines or Coast Guard under the plan permitting draft registrants of 18 through 37 years to volunteer for induction into those services through their local draft boards.

A letter to Paul V. McNutt from representatives of thirteen major women's organizations, urging the War Manpower Commissioner once more to appoint qualified women to policy-making boards in Washington, was released yesterday by Miss Olive O. Van Horn, chairman of a recent meeting of the groups.

Manufacturers of unpainted furniture, who are sold up indefinitely on most items, have notified some accounts that full shipment on outstanding orders may be impossible due to the shortage of lumber, most of which comes from the Pacific Coast.

While new orders have shown a sharp decline in recent months, manufacturers of heavy electrical equipment have sufficient business on their books to keep them running all through 1943, reports here indicated yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16 -- Whirlaway, Calumet cannon-ball and the turf's leading money winner of all time, was selected today as the horse of the year for the second time in a row in the annual poll of the Turf and Sport Digest.

NESQUEHONING, Pa., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Lieutenant John Jean De Angelis, navigator of Captain Eddie Rickenbacker's plane on its Pacific flight, came home tonight, and nearly every one in this town of 4,000 persons turned out to greet him.

Official Civilian Defense Volunteer Office sheepskins were given yesterday morning to a group of women graduates of a ten-week training course in volunteer child care. Forty women were on hand at headquarters of the Child Study Association, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street, which conducted the course, to receive their certificates, while an additional thirty will receive theirs by mail.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 16 -- Five of six suspected German spies awaiting trial for "actions likely to alter the friendly relations between Argentina and foreign powers" were released on bail today.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16 -- President Lawrence Di Benedetto of the Amateur Athletic Union today reported that 16,000 A.A.U. athletes had gone to war, but that the union nevertheless is just embarking on its greatest athletic program in history to fit men for armed service.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A story of Morocco "come to life," of a country now adding stores of food and minerals to the United Nations' resources and feeling the prosperity brought to a people who had been bled by Germany through her Armistice Commission was told today by the United States Army Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- American shipyards required an average of only fifty-six days from keel-laying to completion in delivering sixty-eight Liberty ships in November, the Maritime Commission stated today. This was an improvement of ten days as compared with October.

There is a tradition that in addition to the three wise men a fourth set out for Bethlehem. He never arrived at his destination. Like the three Magi he carried many gifts from the East. On the road he met a miserable peasant to whom he gave his gold; then a weeping woman who begged help for her sick husband and to whom he gave all his silver.

Post-war refunds of excess-profits taxes, as provided for in Section 250 of the Revenue Act of 1942, should be shown in financial statements as a non-current asset, the American Institute of Accountants, 13 East Forty-first Street, recommended yesterday in a bulletin to members.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Proposals that the President should form a War Cabinet, composed of the operating heads of those units under him which are actively engaged in the combat program, appear to have met chief resistance in the White House inner circle.
The greeting of "Merry Christmas," usual at this time of the year, was suspended yesterday as far as Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, was concerned.

The need for soil conservation as an immediate project to permit maintenance of wartime production levels, rather than as a mere long-term program as it has previously been understood, was stressed yesterday by speakers at the closing sessions of the Department of Agriculture's regional production goals meeting at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Tightening of import control of strategic materials was ordered by the War Production Board today. To carry out its aim, WPB amended the general imports order M-63 by eliminating the exemption in favor of importations of List 1 and 2 materials under existing contracts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, denied today a report current here that President Roosevelt's broadcast to the French was inadvertently put on the air before American troops had made their landings at Casablanca on Nov. 8.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Boston's third disastrous fire in a month sent more than sixty-five firemen and Coast Guardsmen to hospitals today and wrecked the five-story brick Amory Building in the downtown shopping district with a loss estimated officially at "more than $300,000," and possibly as high as $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Army, the Navy and the War Manpower Commission worked today on a formal announcement of a joint training program which, informed sources said, would finance specialized instruction in colleges for about 250,000 picked service men.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- The right of property owners operating between States to seek protection in the Federal courts against union violence was upheld today in a majority opinion by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in the long-standing dispute between the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.

TRENTON, Dec. 16 -- Salary increases aggregating $185,650 a year for 600 to 700 State employes, to be effective Jan. 1, were ordered today by Governor Charles Edison in a directive to Vincent Keuper, president of the Civil Service Commission.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 16 -- Despite their commitments on the Tripolitanian front, Middle East Command planes continued yesterday to support the Allied effort in Tunisia.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 16 -- Using the double-audible alarm system for the first time, with sirens sounding on the intermediate blue alert signal as well as on the red alarm, Nassau and Suffolk Counties blacked out tonight for thirty minutes and thirty-one minutes, respectively, in an air raid precaution test called by the State Office of Civilian Protection.

According to dispatches from Chungking, the Japanese are now concentrating increasing numbers of troops, planes and artillery in the southwest of Yunnan province for what may prove to be a final effort to complete the conquest of China. Japan has been preparing for such an effort ever since the conquest of Burma, and has made repeated thrusts northward and eastward from Tengyueh since last May.

Every day's news from Russia confirms the belief that for the second time the Nazis have suffered a decisive defeat on that front. This defeat is not measured by favorable changes on the war map. These have been slight in contrast with the vast areas conquered by the Nazi troops since June, 1941. A year ago Leningrad was almost encircled. It still is.

Johann Schenk's "Der Dorfbarbier" ("The Village Barber"), a typical eighteenth century Viennese Singspiel, was presented by the Columbia Theatre Associates of Columbia University last night at Brander Matthews Hall. So far as is known, the work, first produced at the Kaerntnerthor Theatre in Vienna in 1796 and long popular, had not been performed previously on this side of the Atlantic.

The strike of 3,000 members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, an independent organization, which ended early this morning, was called without notice on Sunday afternoon at a membership meeting of the union in Webster Hall, East Eleventh Street and Third Avenue, and went into effect that evening, tying up the delivery of four morning papers, THE NEW YORK TIMES, Herald-Tribune, Daily News and Mirror.

After moving at slight losses during most of yesterday's dull session, the cotton futures market returned at the close almost to the day's opening gains as small amounts of price-fixing in the March and May positions found offerings very limited.
LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Air and Home Security Ministries:

TRENTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- New Jersey farmers face the prospect of being unable to meet their production quotas next year because of shortages of labor, fertilizer, machinery and truck transportation, the New Jersey Farm Bureau said today.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The joint United States-British shipbuilding program for 1943 will insure the construction of 20,000,000 tons dead-weight of new shipping, Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, told the House of Commons today, reporting on his recent visit to Washington, where he conferred with American production officials.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- Formations of Flying Fortresses bombed the harbors of Tunis and Bizerte yesterday while American B-26 bombers attacked the Tunis airdrome, hitting runways, hangars and other installations, the Morocco radio said today.

The serious situation in the New York City schools which has been dramatized by outbreaks of violence in the last few months is not new. The war, and the problems arising out of it, have merely accentuated and highlighted the problem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A year and a month after it was first recommended, a barge and tug-building program which will bring 100,000 barrels of oil a day to the Eastern seaboard has been approved by the Maritime Commission, the WPB, the ODT and other interested government agencies.

WITH ALLIED FORCES HOLDING MEDJEZ-EL-BAB, Tunisia, Dec. 14 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A completely unarmored American "flying column" unwittingly penetrated the German lines to within two miles of Tunis the other night and then, by a stroke of luck, all hands got back to our lines the same night.

Day before yesterday this newspaper's masthead on the editorial page might have appropriately read "THE NEW YORK TIMES, Printed for The New York Times Company at 229 West Forty-third Street, And to be sold on the Premises situated between the Times Square Hotel and the Paramount Theatre."

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- The National Food Dehydrators Association learned from a group of government speakers today that requirements for dehydrated foods of all types during the 1943-44 fiscal year will approximate 1,750,000,000 pounds, of which 400,000,000 pounds will be vegetables.

The Board of Estimate is scheduled to act today on the pension application of Philip A. Hines, former First Deputy City Clerk, who recently resigned under charges of misconduct in office. Presumably the board will have available the report of the special committee named by Mayor La Guardia to investigate the facts and the law concerning Mr. Hines's resignation and his subsequent re-employment by the city as a clerk in the Hospital Department.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Leon Henderson, price administrator, reduced today the charges which the nation's 16,000,000 bowlers pay for their pastime and fixed maximum charges for playing billiards at March, 1942, levels.

American industry is making good use of management-labor committees. Some 1,600 plants now have such committees, and they are helping to increase war production. Instances by the score could be cited. One good example is the "Work to Win" program of the Packard Motor Car Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Roosevelt welcomed today the statement of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan that his only purpose was to save French Africa and free Continental France by helping the United Nations defeat the Axis and then to retire to private life with the hope that the French people would select their own form of government and future leaders.

Three new pictures will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. "Random Harvest," Metro's screen version of the James Hilton novel, starring Greer Garson and Ronald Colman, will have its world premiere at the Radio City Music Hall. Directed by Mervyn Leroy, the romantic drama features Philip Dorn, Susan Peters, Henry Travers, Reginald Owen and Bramwell Fletcher.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique:

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Taking advantage of a low cloud-cover, enemy planes crossed the Channel singly and bombed and machine-gunned several south and southeast coastal towns today. Fighters went out after them and, under conditions favoring the attackers, managed to bring down two German aircraft off the southeast coast.

Performance of the great classics, five hours practice a day and cultivation of the mind and spirit by literature. This is the advice offered to young American pianists who seek success in their art by Moriz Rosenthal, Polish pianist, who will celebrate his eightieth birthday tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 16 (AP) -- An Army bomber carried seven men to their deaths as it crashed and burned last night a few minutes after taking off from the Lambert-St. Louis Airport. Two others escaped with injuries.
MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Balked in its efforts to get the War Labor Board to take jurisdiction of its controversy with the city over the wages and working conditions of the 32,000 employes of the unified transit lines, the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., began yesterday to plan a campaign to force city authorities to submit the dispute to impartial machinery under State laws.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 16 (AP) -- At least forty men were employed as pickets to protect members of Samuel Nuzzo's union working on a $300,000,000 New York City water project in 1940, a union member testified today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The war is again in one of those periods of relative lull that always precede a storm.

WASHIGTON, Dec. 16 -- Two air raids of fairly long range by American bombers from Henderson Field, on Guadalcanal Island, were made without any opposition to our planes, the Navy Department reported today.

The Biltmore Theatre has been reserved by Alfred de Liagre Jr. for his presentation of the Stanley Young comedy, "Ask My Friend, Sandy." The opening date has not been selected yet because the producer-director is uncertain whether he can book the week of Jan. 18 in Washington.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Tass, the Soviet news agency, in a dispatch from Istanbul, reported today that the German High Command had set up a "Balkan punitive council" at the request of Gestapo Chief Heinrich Himmler.

A syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company won yesterday the award of $3,140,000 of Richmond, Va., public improvement bonds dated Jan. 1, 1943, and due serially from Jan. 1, 1944 to 1963. The price paid was 99.539 for the bonds as 1 1/2 per cents. Five other syndicates submitted tenders for the issue.

JOURNALISTICAL LY speaking, the fact that Americans are busy fighting in Guadalcanal and Papua makes Caroline Mytinger's "Head- hunting in the Solomon Islands Around the Coral Sea"* a timely January choice for the Book of the Month Club. But the book itself has absolutely nothing to do with the war, or with Henderson Field, or with General MacArthur, or with anything else that is currently making history in Miss Mytinger's old stamping grounds.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 16 -- Members of the A.F.L. Machinists Union employed at the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation plant voted at mass meeting to day to ask President Roosevelt to release them from their no-strike pledge for the duration and authorized their officials to set a date for taking a strike vote if such release were granted.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- American bombers attacking Japanese communications in Burma have blasted railroads, river transports and land convoys in daily raids this week, a United States Army Air Forces communique said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Army, represented by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and the heads of both the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, testifying today before two Senate committees, took opposing views on the issue of whether war production should come under civilian or military control.
OTTAWA, Dec. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King tonight announced a sharp reduction in the amount of beverage alcohol that may be released from bond.

Contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund on behalf of the most distressed families and fragments of families, old people and struggling individuals and abandoned children known to eight leading private charities in the city have held up reasonably well, despite the fact that THE NEW YORK TIMES with its daily reminder of the plight of the Neediest has not reached its readers since Sunday.

Florists "said it with flowers" yesterday morning when 15,000 cut flowers and 2,000 potted plants were donated by members of the wholesale market, Twenty-eighth Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, to hospitalized service men in eight military and naval hospitals here.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 16 -- Discussing the situation on all fronts in the current issue of the magazine Reich, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, asserts that the Axis powers up to the present have succeeded in retaining the offensive wherever possible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Dr. F.D. Mott, chief medical officer of the Farm Security Administration, proposed today that a war health council be set up to draft physicians for civilian service in critical areas.

In an attempt to clarify his position Admiral Darlan issued a formal statement yesterday declaring that the Germans had him "by the throat" as long as he remained in France and disclaiming personal ambition as the motive of his turn to the Allies in French and West Africa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The National Labor Relations Board gave permission today to the Oregon Shipbuilding Corporation and Kaiser Company, Inc., to file affidavits with the board by Dec. 26 in support of the charge that Chairman Harry A. Millis and Gerard Reilly, two of the three board members, had shown prejudice against the companies, which have been ordered to answer a complaint by the C.I.O. that they have discriminatorily discharged several hundred workers.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 17 -- Russian troops captured an inhabited point more than eighty miles to the rear of the German Stalingrad siege army and destroyed fifty Nazi tanks and a regiment of motorized infantry in a two-day battle southwest of the Volga River city, where enemy counterattacks had been increasingly troublesome, the Soviet command announced early today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Princeton's Tigers pulled out from behind in the second half today to win, 51 -- 48, in a closely contested game with the Rutgers quintet.

A broad investment demand which lifted business yesterday to the largest volume since early November shot the industrial issues on the stock market to the highest levels since Pearl Harbor. While the rise was all-inclusive, the widest gains appeared in the chemicals and rubbers with increases in other groups limited generally to major fractions.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Admiralty asserted tonight that Royal Air Force photographs of the scuttled French fleet at Toulon were testimony to "the thoroughness with which French seamen carried out their bitter task," but it insisted that no exact list of the results could be drawn from the photographs alone.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Fighting French circles in London characterize Admiral Darlan's press statement as "a masterpiece of impudence and hypocrisy." They reiterate that, despite his assertions, the admiral's policy today, "as always, is governed by his own ambitions."

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Nine United States fliers -- two privates who were lost while acting as gunners of bombing missions and seven officers and enlisted men who were lost when their bomber was shot down in New Guinea last August -- have been posthumously awarded with Silver Stars for gallantry in action by Major Gen. George C. Kenney, commander of the Allied air forces in the Southwest Pacific.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 -- Decision to sell the Yankee and Colonial radio networks, serving twenty-one New England stations, was based on a requirement for cash to meet future inheritance taxes, John Shepard 3d, presdient of the chain, said today.
For the first holiday season in thirty-two years the "Tree of Light," the community Christmas tree in Madison Square, will be dark. It is a victim of the dimout regulations.
CAIRO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique:

American soldiers at bases on the British Isles are not at all averse to having their pictures taken if they know the photographs are to be used to reassure the folks back home, Miss Toni Frissell, fashion magazine photographer, declared yesterday on her return to this country after spending several weeks in Britain as an official American Red Cross news photographer.

BAYONNE, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Miss Saidee Harriman, 63 years old, of 518 West 152d Street, New York City, who said she was an employe of a New York detective agency engaged in collecting evidence on gambling and vice in Bayonne, was held today in $1,000 bail when arraigned before Police Judge James L. Sweeney on a disorderly person charge based on the allegation she had placed several bets on the numbers game.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- A three-man panel of Department of Labor conciliators will conduct a hearing between union "L" employes and company representatives, starting tomorrow, on union demands for increased wages.

WITH THE ALLIED ARMY, Near Djedeida, Tunisia, Dec. 2 (Delayed) -- Under the searching fire of German mortars and attacks by screaming dive-bombers, American and British soldiers are learning to like and respect each other. Differences in pay, environment and education are forgotten while they stand shoulder to shoulder.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A former outstanding woman golf and tennis player sits -- occasionally -- in an office of the American Red Cross service club that serves the troops in the area of United Nations Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The United States has the seventh lowest infant death rate in the world, the Census Bureau reported today, and has a higher survival rate than that of the Axis countries despite their efforts to increase population.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Reports of conflict between Jesse Jones, head of various government lending agencies, and Vice President Wallace as head of the Board of Economic Warfare were confirmed today by the release of secret testimony before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee concerning a bill to increase the lending authority of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by $5,000,000,000.

Information that the War Prisoners Aid of the World's Committee of the Y.M.C.A. is being permitted to carry on in Japan the work it has been doing in other countries, both Allied and Axis, was received yesterday by Tracy Strong, general secretary of the group.

At the last moment the expiring Congress, by unanimous consent, and without any debate worth speaking of, passed a measure that will mean pay increases for an estimated 1,500,000 Federal civil employes. The measure, which on an annual basis would cost an added $230,000,000 to $260,000,000, should have received considerably more study than it got.

Out of the minds of babes came yesterday one of the most appealing dramatizations yet offered on the subject of civilian defense. Fourth graders in the Ethical Culture School brought down a house full of schoolmates at the premiere of a puppet show, held in the school auditorium, 33 Central Park West.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Reuter reported a D.N.B. Berlin broadcast today saying that the German Government had handed a note to the Swiss Government at Berne of the manacling of British prisoners in Germany, but that the contents of the note had not been disclosed.

Net sales of Federated Department Stores, Inc., and its subsidiaries rose to $60,052,864 in the six months ended on July 31, from $54,895,039 in the same period last year, according to a report for release today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- The current steel shortage is so serious that any public statement of the actual figures is impossible at this time, a report released today by a subcommittee of the House Merchant Marine Committee said.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Denaturalization proceedings have been started, the United States District Attorney's office said today, against "Count" Anastase A. Vonsiatsky of Thompson and two other Connecticut residents.

The news from the Fishery Council is the best it has been for weeks. There is a good supply of salt-water fish, principally, yellow-tail flounder and Canadian smelts, for heavy catches of both have been arriving in the markets during the last couple of days.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The stock markets were quiet again today. Several gilt-edge securities improved, the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan rising 1 1/4s to 104 3/8 and others advancing fractionally.

The strike of 3,000 members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union ended early this morning when the strikers voted unanimously to bow to an order of the War Labor Board, issued in Washington yesterday afternoon, to call off the walkout and return to work, pending arbitration under the direction of the board of the dispute with the Publishers Association.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- A Horatio Alger hero of the Victorian era, inventor of the feather boa that swept court and society circles, stepped out of millionaire obscurity today to offer 10,000 for the capture of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel.

Dean Hannah M. Egan of Hunter College will emerge from a "metamorphosis machine" as the 'Hunter College glamour girl of 1943" in a "Medicine Show" to be presented at the college today and tomorrow at noon. Proceeds will go toward establishing a Hunter canteen for service men.

By the time you have triumphantly checked off the last name on your Christmas list and carried the last mountain of packages to the parcel post, it will be high time to buy a Christmas present for yourself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Senator Prentiss Brown, Michigan Democrat, who was defeated in the November election, was reported tonight to have agreed reluctantly, at a White House conference, to become Price Administrator when and if Leon Henderson steps out.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The many divisions, offices and services which have been added to the War Manpower Commission in recent months were reorganized today under five new operating divisions by Paul V. McNutt, Manpower Director.

The Relief Fund of the Coast Guard will be the chief beneficiary in a settlement, announced yesterday by Supreme Court Justic Samuel Null, of the suit brought by Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight champion, who is now a Coast Guard lieutenant, for $50,000 damages and an injunction to restrain publication of a book appearing under his name entitled "How to Fight Tough."
Mr. and Mrs. Girard van Barkaloo Hale will come to the Plaza today from Santa Barbara, Calif.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 16 -- Admiral Jean Francois Darlan told American and British newspaper men at an interview tonight in his closely guarded villa in Algiers that in leading French North and West Africa against Germany and Italy he was not motivated by personal ambitions.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 16 -- Lieutenant Gaylord D. Propst of Geneva, Neb., a hero in the battle of Midway, was in command of a twin-engined Navy patrol bomber missing since Dec. 4 off Southern California, the Eleventh Naval District reported tonight in releasing names of the nine-member crew.

A plea for unity and preparedness was made yesterday by Mme. Denise Davey, representative of the Fighting French in Great Britain, at a meeting of the British War Relief Society, Inc., at the St. Regis Hotel to formulate plans to raise $7,000,000 for its work during the coming year.

ATLANTA, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Physical education leaders of eight Southeastern States adopted today a program for physical toughening of high school students and arranged for 200 "institutes" to familiarize secondary schools in every city, country town and county with the undertaking.

The Rangers will tackle the Bruins in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The game, one of the few Thursday encounters scheduled for the local arena this season, promises to attract a large crowd, despite the fact that the local sextet is in last place and Boston tops the circuit.

In a statement issued from his office at City Hall late yesterday afternoon Mayor La Guardia called public attention to the fact that he had announced in his weekly broadcast last Sunday that there would be a blackout drill this week to test the new system of using three siren signals instead of two.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Expressing confidence in Republican prospects for 1944 "if we can keep our mistakes few and minor," Harrison E. Spangler, the party's new national chairman, paid a hurried visit to Republican headquarters today to begin a reorganization of campaign personnel.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 16 -- It is reliably reported from Rome this evening that immediate steps are being considered for the withdrawal of all military installations in and around the capital, simultaneously with its declaration as an open city.

A forum in which officers of the armed forces and educators from local colleges will discuss "The Liberal Arts Studies in the War" will be held this afternoon at 2 o'clock under the auspices of the City College chapter of the American Association of University Professors in the Faculty Room of the college, 139th Street and Convent Avenue.

A plan to liquidate the arrears of dividends of $9.55 a share on the 7 per cent $25 par preferred stock of the Canadian Car Foundry Company, Ltd., is expected to be ready for official announcement within thirty days, according to reports from Montreal yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Roosevelt sent a message of appreciation and seasonal greeting to Congress and commented favorably on the statement of Admiral Darlan that he has no political ambitions following victory.

THE hockey schedule will make both ends meet at Madison Square Garden tonight when the Bruins will play the Rangers. The Bruins are at the top of the league and the Rangers at the bottom. It's nothing to find the Men of Ross at or near the top of the league, but it is strange, indeed, to find the Rangers roosting humbly on the bottom rung.

Describing the butter situation as "very serious," Mayor La Guardia called yesterday for a "let down" in the State laws that make it a penal offense for an official to purchase oleomargarine for public institutions.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 16 -- Although rear-guard fighting and rough terrain kept the British advance in Libya to the most moderate distances yesterday, the Allies began to do serious damage to the enemy with intense air attacks.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- Pierre Laval, whose political status as well as that of occupied France is expected to be established by Adolf Hitler at a meeting in Berlin in a few days, is reported to have conferred today with numerous French officials and political leaders.

LAKE CITY, S.C., Dec. 16 (AP) -- An Army detachment from Shaw Field at Sumter took control today of an automobile graveyard here while War Production Board representatives planned to turn the yard's more than 700 junked cars and used parts into scrap needed to keep the nation's war plants in operation.

Marry Cohen, boxing promoter at the St. Nicholas Palace, the Ridgewood Grove and the Queensboro Arena, yesterday reiterated his decision to withdraw from the field until the expiration of the term of the present State Athletic Commission.

Foreshadowing possibly the policy of the Metropolitan Golf Association for 1943, Isaac B. Grainger, newly elected president, expressed it as his opinion last night that the association should stimulate interest in golf as a contribution to the member club.

Declining to reveal the findings of his six-week trip to the United Kingdom, to survey entertainment needs of the United States armed forces there, Abe Lastfogel, president of the USO-Camp Shows, Inc., who arrived at the marine terminal, La Guardia Field, late yesterday, declared the American soldiers liked British entertainment "well enough" but preferred American shows.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The State Bureau of Motor Vehicles estimated today that several hundred motorists who have lost licenses under New York's safety-responsibility law will be eligible to apply for relief after Jan. 1.

A telegraphic appeal to OPA officials in Washington for a thirty-day extension of provisions of MPR 287 on Spring garments was made yesterday by the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers on the ground that it was impossible to prepare immediately the statistical pricing data required on cuttings of Spring styles now in work.
A large furnished suite in 36 Central Park South has been leased by Conrad Nagel, stage, film and radio actor. Rose Fabricant was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Seventy-seventh Congress, which came into being Jan. 3, 1941, split widely and bitterly over international policies and issues and merged suddenly and vigorously for the prosecution of a total war, adjourned sine die today after 711 days of service, 346 of them in the record second session which it brought to an anticlimactic close.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 -- Today's reports from the Stalingrad front, official and otherwise, indicate that the Russians southwest of the city have the situation well under control and that yesterday the Germans failed everywhere to develop the slight successes they obtained during the week-end when at high cost they dented the Russian lines.

The Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church will have assets in excess of $36,000,000 on Dec. 31, according to a preliminary year-end report to its board of trustees yesterday by its president, Bishop Cameron J. Davis.

WITH ADVANCED AMERICAN FORCES in New Guinea, Dec. 14 (Delayed) -- American troops occupied Buna village on the Papua front today, taking over a position that has been one of the strong points of the Japanese resistance after only a short final battle.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- As a means of preventing a repetition of "the tragedy of Versailles" and assuring "a people's peace," former President Herbert Hoover proposed tonight a new approach to the whole method and process of peacemaking. The details, he said, "must be hammered out on the anvil of debate" before the United Nations had defeated the Axis Powers.

In line with its policy of insisting on "frozen," or even reduced rate structures for public utility companies for the duration of the war, the Office of Price Administration yesterday entered the rate case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that was instituted several weeks ago by the Federal Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Citing a mounting rush of long-distance telephone calls, the American Telephone Telegraph Company endeavored today to show the Federal Communications Commission that lowering of rates might impede the war effort by bogging down the system through stimulation of traffic.

The suspension of all major cup races for the duration of the war was recommended by the Rowing Coaches Association of America in a resolution released yesterday by Harrison Sanford of Cornell, secretary of the group.

Domestic help still can be had -- but at a price. And the women who turn up for the jobs of housekeepers, cooks and nurses in homes throughout the city are now asking for privileges that never would have been granted in pro-war days.

An initial dividend of 10 cents a share has been declared on the 1,473,259 shares of the Loft Candy Corporation, payable to stockholders on Jan. 15, according to an announcement yesterday by Albert M. Greenfield, chairman of the board of directors.

It is possible to speak of grand opera in its literal meaning this morning when discussing last night's Metropolitan Opera performance of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro." The work itself has that stature, and its first presentation of the season last night was worthy of it.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- Governor Poletti warned today that the country's food situation was much more serious than the people seemed to realize. He made this comment on the food situation in general while disclosing that he had issued orders, effective immediately, to increase production of dairy products, vegetables, pork and beef on farms at State institutions, so as to make those institutions, with 120,000 population, more nearly self-sufficient as to food supplies.

TRENTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Employment in New Jersey has reached an unprecedented high, while relief rolls have dropped to an all-time low, Charles R. Erdman Jr., State director of the Municipal Aid Administration, reported today.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- There is so much confusion in the public mind regarding progress of the battle for Africa in sectors both east and west that authoritative quarters in London undertook today to clarify the situation. Facts given by a Royal Air Force commentator disclosed the reason for the confidence that is radiated everywhere concerning the outcome of the two campaigns, in which the British First and Eighth Armies are engaged.

Events tonight -- "Lakme," the Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 o'clock; New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Serge Rachmaninoff, soloist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; University Glee Club, assisted by the choir boys of St. Thomas Church, Channing Lefebvre conducting, Waldorf-Astoria, 8:45; "The Village Barber," Brander Matthews Theatre, Columbia University, 8:40.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- In a speech before the adjournment of Congress today, Representative Thom, Democrat, of Ohio said:

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS IN NEW GUINEA, Dec. 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- "A shooting fool" from a Michigan farm who is as cool while hunting Japanese as when he was husking corn was listed in official records today as one of the outstanding sniper hunters in this jungle battleground.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 17 -- Japanese Emperor Hirohito, according to a prisoner, has ordered the trapped Japanese in New Guinea to fight to the last man, it was learned today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 16 -- Pierre Laval, now in Paris, met with an accident on his way there from Vichy, it was revealed today, but he escaped unscathed. In a thick fog the car went into a ditch and overturned, but the Chief of Government was extricated without injury.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden rejected several strongly worded suggestions in the House of Commons today that Britain protest against General Francisco Franco's speech praising Premier Mussolini and his message to Adolf Hitler expressing hope for an Axis victory over Russia.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -- Captain Albert F. France of New York, commander of the hero ship of the Nov. 13 Solomon Islands naval battle, gave assurance today at a "Cruiser San Francisco Celebration" that the people "haven't heard the last of the cruiser named for this city."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Dr. I.W. Schmidt of 2745 Reservoir Avenue, New York City, a retired dentist whose hobby is photography, received the second national award of $100 in war savings bonds in the November photo contest of the American Red Cross.

WITH AMERICAN AIR FORCES in China, Dec. 14 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American bombers resumed their offensive against Japanese air bases today, devastating the Gialam airdrome across the Red River from Hanoi, in Northern Indo-China.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Senator Norris, who was defeated for re-election in November, was absent today from the closing session of the Senate. It was also his last session in the Seventy-seventh Congress.
New Jersey's abbreviated deer hunting season opens today with prospects highly favorable if recent surveys of the State are any indication.

Among the measures which died yesterday when the Seventy-seventh Congress adjourned was the Third War Powers Bill. Its adoption had been urged by the Administration primarily in order to give the Government authority to suspend tariff laws and regulations which now handicap the war effort. A good case was made for the enactment of some such legislation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The fuel oil rationing program includes provisions for meeting abnormal demands likely to arise from sudden cold snaps in various parts of the thirty-State rationed area, Leon Henderson, head of the Office of Price Administration, said here today.

Dr. Theodore Sedlmayr, vice president in charge of research of Standard Brands, Inc., for many years, was elected yesterday vice president in charge of manufacture, purchasing and traffic and a director of the company, to succeed the late John W. Luce.
AT ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 16 -- The following is the text of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan's statement today to foreign correspondents:

TRENTON, Dec. 16 -- Governor Edison today named Spencer Miller Jr., State Highway Commissioner, as snow removal coordinator for the State, with broad power to act for the maintenance of essential traffic under all weather conditions.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Despite the protest of Mayor Vincent J. Murphy, a majority of his colleagues on the City Commission stripped him today of two divisions in his Department of Revenue and Finance.

FAIRFIELD, Utah, Dec. 16 -- A. F. Gardner, a Marine Corps lieutenant, told from his hospital bed today how he tried to quiet a dying passenger after a Western Air Lines transport crashed yesterday killing seventeen men and women.

SOUTH WEYMOUTH, Mass., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Women guards are proving efficient at the Naval Air Base here, relieving Marines and civilian men guards for other duties, Lieutenant Colonel Chester Knowles said today.
By an overwhelming, if sometimes confused vote, Miss Gloria Callen, the record-smashing backstroke swimmer from Nyack, N.Y., has been chosen as the outstanding figure in women's sports in 1942.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A communique of the United States Army Air Forces for China, Burma and India:

The nation's fuel oil supplies dropped further last week, but there was a sharp increase in gasoline stocks, according to the weekly figures of the American, Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period gasoline stocks amounted to 77,622,000 barrels, an increase of 1,688,000 over the 75,934,000 a week earlier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- W.B. Garner, vice president of the Waterman Steamship Corporation, of Mobile, Ala., asserted today that the controller general was "inexcusably inaccurate" in his report to Congress criticizing transactions between his company and the Maritime Commission.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Leon Henderson has accepted an invitation to a coffeeless, sugarless, butterless, meatless dinner in Baltimore tomorrow night.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Federal Judge W. Calvin Chesnut ruled today that street distributors of newspapers are not employes of the publication and dismissed a suit for back pay and overtime brought by three "rackmen" against The Baltimore Sunpapers.

The formation of an army of stateless and Palestinian Jews to fight against fascism was advocated by several speakers, including Alben Barkley, majority leader in the United States Senate, at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night.
For the second year in succession Budge Patty of Los Angeles heads the junior rankings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, released yesterday in the call for the annual meeting.

Substantial quantities of Russian furs for the account of the Amtorg Trading Corporation will be offered to the American fur industry at auctions to be held by Lampson, Fraser Huth, with the first sale scheduled for Jan. 11, it was announced yesterday by officials of the auction company.

The degree of effectiveness with which milk distributors in this city and its suburban areas have reduced their delivery mileage during one month's experimental period will determine whether deliveries will be permitted to continue on a seven-day week schedule, it was indicated yesterday at the offices of the Metropolitan Milk Distributors Commission.

While the speeding up of research under the impetus of war is developing new products or variations on old ones, they are not being advertised to the public to any extent. The chief exception is the electronic devices field, which, visualizing a host of post-war applications, is starting a widespread campaign to acquaint the public with electronics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Senator McCarran of Nevada told the Senate today that his life had been threatened as the outgrowth of magazine articles in which he and other Silver State Senators were criticized.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Leon Henderson submitted his resignation today as Administrator of the Office of Price Administration because of a recurring back ailment and an impairment of his eyesight which will necessitate a rest of at least four months.

Accepting a silver medal yesterday for his "promotion of better understanding between Christians and Jews in America," Wendell L. Willkie deplored the use of the word "tolerance" in connection with the treatment of one group by another in this country.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, paid tribute here last night to the leadership of the petroleum industry, of which President Roosevelt recently appointed him administrator, and declared it now remained for the public to discipline itself, likewise, so that every "necessary vehicle" may be kept running for civilian activity and the armed forces.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Mill buying of wheat futures, regarded as a reflection of additional sales of flour, especially to the family trade, lifted prices of wheat around 1/2 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, with September selling at the highest level of the season and December equaling its previous record.

Despite all that has been written about Nazi persecution of the Jews, the facts in the joint statement issued yesterday in Washington, London and Moscow in the name of the United Nations will come as a shock to all civilized people who have preserved a modicum of human decency.

A bout, originally arranged for the purpose of producing an acceptable successor to Sammy Angott, retired lightweight champion of the world, but which promises to throw the division into confusion, will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Alfred Frederick Cito, 18-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. May Cito of 206 Miriam Street, the Bronx, was one of nine enlisted men of the naval guard on a merchant ship who received letters of commendation today from the Chief of Naval Personnel for their outstanding conduct during dive-bomber attacks which sank their vessel. Cito is a signalman, third class.

" The maintaining of good labor standards is just as important, if not more important, in wartime than in peacetime," Miss Frieda S. Miller, director of the State Department of Labor, told the Women's City Club at its monthly meeting yesterday at 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

The Citizens Committee for the Arts will open today an exhibition and sale of work by outstanding artists at the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. Eighty-three items, including water-colors, prints and pieces of sculpture, will be sold for $5 each to raise funds for the work of the committee.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 17 -- The Anglo-American air force inflicted heavy blows today on Tunis and Bizerte, while the Germans raided Tebessa. American fliers shot down three and damaged five Axis planes without losses to themselves.

One laurel the Seventy-seventh Congress earned. It sat longer than any of its predecessors. Its two sessions consumed 711 days, almost two straight years. Its closest rival for the chronological prize is the Fortieth Congress, 1867-69. This was Thad Stevens's Congress, of unconstitutional and unsavory memory.

Sales of government securities in the Second Federal Reserve District in the nation-wide $9,000,000,000 Victory Loan Drive that began on Nov. 30 amounted to $3,356, 878,118, as of noon yesterday, according to a tabulation released by Perry E. Hall, executive manager of the New York Victory Fund Committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The need of unity among the United Nations was stressed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in response to questions at his press conference today concerning the attitude of French leaders, particularly with reference to the campaign in North Africa.

The German High Command said yesterday that German and Rumanian troops had thrown the Russians back still farther between the Don and the Volga and had repulsed strong enemy attacks in the Don bend. Thirty Soviet tanks were destroyed, said the communique, quoted in Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A joint declaration by members of the United Nations was issued today condemning Germany's "bestial policy of cold-blooded extermination" of Jews and declaring that "such events can only strengthen the resolve of all freedom-loving peoples to overthrow the barbarous Hitlerite tyranny."

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- Samuel Nuzzo, ousted business manager of Local 17, International Hodcarriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America, who is on trial on a charge of embezzling more than $35,000, testified in his own behalf today.
R. Henry Norweb, United States Ambassador to Peru, and Mrs. Norweb have been joined at the Waldorf-Astoria by their daughter, Miss Jeanne Norweb, a student at Vassar College.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A group of Army Flying Fortresses operating in the Solomon Islands on Wednesday destroyed an entire force of twelve Japanese Zero fighter planes that attacked the Americans in the vicinity of New Georgia Island, the Navy reported in a communique issued here today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet nformation Bureau's noon communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Roosevelt proclaimed Jan. 12 today as Farm Mobilization Day and called upon all farmers to confer that day with officials of the Agriculture Department and other agencies on "ways and means of insuring for the year 1943 the maximum production of vital foods upon every farm in this country."

Federal and city officials and leaders in the oil industry agreed yesterday that the gasoline shortage in the New York City area was critical, although there was some difference of opinion as to the full extent to which stocks have been depleted.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 17 -- Asserting that military songs of the armed services were public property in wartime, Dr. Joseph E. Maddy, University of Michigan music professor and chairman of the State's wartime civic music committee, said today that he would appeal to Washington against private copyright owners.

Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the State Securities Bureau, announced yesterday his resignation to return to the private practice of law after twelve years of service under Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. Mr. McCall will serve until the end of his term on Dec. 31.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- Abrogation of the current Lehman budget three months in advance of its expiration date and starting of the State's new fiscal year April 1 have been decided on by the incoming Dewey administration, according to reports here.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 17 -- Dr. Enrico Celio, Federal Councilor and Director of the Department of Posts and Railways, was elected President of Switzerland for 1943 by both houses of the Swiss Parliament sitting jointly this morning for the purpose.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The civilian meat allowance for the first three months of 1943 was cut 5 ounces a week, from 40 to 35, today by Price Administrator Leon Henderson, but at the same time he moved to relieve local meat shortages over the Christmas season by authorizing slaughterers to begin deliveries of their new first quarter quotas on Dec. 20, twelve days ahead of schedule.

Reformed Mr. Scrooge "knew how to keep Christmas well." He kept it by making people happy. Now, when the world seems more like a witch's sabbath than a Christmas, that manner of observance is wanted more than ever. The necessities of the people of the Hundred Neediest Cases are as well known to us as if we were in the room with them.

With wartime restrictions making travel difficult, the weather man ironically continues to favor Eastern skiers. Usually at this season skiers scan the skies for encouragement, but now they can find good sport at many points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- There is an imminent possibility that "A" gasoline ration cards in the sixteen Eastern States will be suspended for an indefinite period within forty-eight hours, it was learned authoritatively late tonight after a conference between Petroleum Administrator Ickes, Joseph B. Eastman, Director of Defense Transportation, and Leon Henderson, Price Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Roosevelt's promise that this country would become the "arsenal of democracy" was being realized in "cold steel" the War Production Board said today in a report to the nation on its progress during the first year of war.

Gifts from handicapped children, a doorman, soldiers, a mother thankful for the return of a son whose ship was torpedoed and from steadfast friends of the Neediest came yesterday for the Neediest Cases Fund. All were given in the true spirit of Christmas to help those in deep distress.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Former President Hoover, who was food administrator in the first World War, declared today that the present food control machinery was creating local famines and "black markets" throughout the country and endangering the whole scheme for bringing order out of chaos in other countries after the war.

Isidore H. Herk, 59 years old, the ostensible producer of the show "Wine, Women and Song," which, he had told a General Sessions jury, was made up of "scraps of old vaudeville acts," was sentenced to a six-month penitentiary term yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan on his conviction Dec. 3 of giving an indecent performance last Oct. 31.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 17 -- Rent control by the Office of Price Administration forced the country's rent index down almost as rapidly as it had risen in the period from early 1941 until the rent controls were authorized, according to survey figures released today by the Rent Department of OPA.

A Filipino who has been described as having enlisted Leonard Robert Jordan in a Japanese-inspired movement to "unite the darker races" was a witness against the accused West Indies Negro in Federal Court yesterday. Jordan and three fellow leaders of the Ethiopian Pacific Movement are being tried on charges of sedition.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 17 -- Leon Henderson came here to be the guest of honor tonight at a "Smileage Rationing" party given by the fifty-three members of a local rationing board.

The communiques of the German High Command continue to withhold news of Rommel's troubles in North Africa. They speak only of repelling all efforts of the enemy in fierce fighting. But it is increasingly clear that if Rommel has not met with a new disaster he has encountered something pleasantly like it.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- To mark their support of the government declaration made by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons today against the German persecution of European Jews, the members stood in silence for a few moments.

Sixty-three plans for industrial buildings, estimated to cost $1,331,865, in this State outside of New York City were filed last month with the State Labor Department. The number and dollar volume of the plans were below the averages for November for the last eighteen years, which have been eighty-eight plans and $1,491,880.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Minister of Information Brendan Bracken told American corespondents here today that criticism of United States Army authorities in general, and of Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in particular, for the paucity and tardiness of newspaper dispatches from the North African front was unjustified.

New analytical techniques for handling flight test data of airplanes are contributing much to improved aircraft design and even to greater utility and service of planes already in military service, Edmund T. Allen, engineer and test pilot, revealed last night when he delivered the sixth annual Wright Brothers Lecture before the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences.
AT ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A communique:

The executive board of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., at a meeting held last night at 153 West Sixty-fourth Street, called upon Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Transportation to resume promptly negotiations with the union over the wages and working conditions of the 32,000 civil service employes of the city's unified transit lines.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 17 -- The able seamanship of the second officer of a torpedoed ship and the quick help rendered by a United States Army doctor plus the action of Brazilian air pilots, resulted in saving the lives of sixty survivors who have arrived at an undisclosed point in Northeastern Brazil after eight days adrift, fighting heavy seas in a flimsy, damaged lifeboat.
The directors of the Duval Texas Sulphur Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of $1 a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents, both payable on Dec. 31.

Declining sharply for the fourth consecutive month, merchandise inventories of New York City department stores at the end of November were only 16 per cent above those of the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 17 -- Indifferent to artillery fire, the screaming dives of sinister Stukas and occasional local patrol raids of tanks against them, crack British Guard units are holding their lines around Medjez-el-Bab after having played a major part in preventing a German breakthrough.

Taking a cue from strength in the stock market, traders on the New York Cotton Exchange placed price-fixing orders in the near months and covering in the distant positions in late dealings in the cotton futures market yesterday, sending the list to final net gains of 3 to 12 points.
An increase in facilities for handling parcel post to meet an increase of 37 per cent in this classification of Christmas mail was announced yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A British communique:

Too few realize that the Revenue Act of 1942, while protecting the social security of the wage-earner through the so-called Federal Insurance Contribution Act, tends to destroy that social security for all of the rest of the American people, including the small business man, the professional man, the farmer, agricultural labor and those in domestic service. Social security for all these classes depends to a great degree on life insurance.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Business in most sections of the stock markets was small today. Home rails eased 1/8 to 1/4, but oils were steady. Industrials saw Celanese ordinary and preference shares and Courtauld's each 1/8s down.

Further details of the agreement between the Mexican Government and the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, of which Thomas W. Lamont of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., is chairman, were made public yesterday by Mr. Lamont, with the approval of the Mexican authorities.

In the most boisterous session so far this year, the stock market established yesterday new records for 1942 in both volume and price enlargements. In the extension of the year-end rally, which set in earlier than had been expected by brokers, gains of 1 to 4 points were scored in a wide variety of industrial issues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The State Department today made public a message that President Roosevelt wired to the Emperor of Ethiopia, acknowledging that country's declaration of war against the Axis and noting that Ethiopia was eligible for lend-lease aid.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- A hidden fire that has been smoldering over the prospect of post-war competition between United States and British civil aviation companies for control of the world's most important skyways flared up in the House of Commons today when W.R.D. Perkins, M.P., who is a mechanical engineer, complained that the Pan American Airways was already "spreading its tentacles all over the world."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Rutland Railroad Company filed a petition for reorganization with the Interstate Commerce Commission today, explaining that it felt reorganization would be in the best interest of creditors. A similar petition has been filed with the Federal District Court in Vermont.

The St. John's University basketball team scored its fourth straight triumph last night, routing the Clarkson Tech five, 68 to 34, at the DeGray gymnasium in Brooklyn. The Redmen held a 30-7 lead at the half and increased their advantage to 51 -- 20 at the end of the third quarter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Sharp advances in primary markets of prices for grains, cotton, peanuts, seeds and certain fruits and vegetables brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of nearly 900 price series up 0.4 per cent during the week ended on Dec. 12.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Royal Air Force Blenheim bombers, escorted by fighters, subjected Japanese bases in Burma yesterday to their fifth bombardment in five days, attacking enemy-occupied villages in the Maungdon and Buthidaung areas, a British communique announced today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- Allied patrols are exerting pressure on Japanese outposts at Salamaua, major enemy base 140 miles up the New Guinea coast from the Buna sector, on which American and Australian troops are closing in despite strong resistance, the Allied command announced today.

" Flying Fortress," a drama of aerial warfare produced at the Warner Brothers' Teddington Studios in England, will have its local premiere at the Strand this morning. Richard Greene, who received a special leave of absence from active duty in the British Army, is co-starred with Carla Lehmann in the picture.

In the period following the last war, although women have been hard-working, intelligent, willing to learn and "bursting with ideas," they have not been "good enough," Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES told a Fashion Group luncheon meeting yesterday.
ALBANY, Dec. 17 (AP) -- An accelerated high school curriculum designed to hasten graduation of students facing army service at 18 years, was outlined today by the State Education Department.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Army and Navy made known today their plans to mobilize 200 to 300 colleges and universities for training men in the armed forces. Secretary Stimson and Secretary Knox joined in a statement revealing some of the details of the program.

The St. Paul's School hockey team gave the Princeton junior varsity a 6-to-0 drubbing at Madison Square Garden yesterday and retained possession of the treasured Hobey Baker Memorial Trophy, the prize being the stick used by one of the greatest hockey players ever produced in this country.

No public man has thought more deeply and sincerely about the conditions of the coming peace than former President Hoover. And few men are as well equipped to discuss the peace. For Mr. Hoover played a key role in the drama that he so vividly describes which immediately followed the First World War.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 17 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has acquired screen rights to "Flight Surgeon," a magazine article by Major Robert Lateiner and Donald E. Keyhoe, and will combine material from it with "Vicki and Her Eagles," which originally was announced in 1940 under the title "Flight Surgeon."

" Americans are looking too much at the 80,000 French fighting with the United Nations outside France; they are looking not enough at the 30,000,000 French fighting inside France, who form the large army of General De Gaulle, hampering and harassing the Nazis and breaking down Nazi morale in every way possible," said Captain "Livry," a Fighting French Air Force officer, attached to the R.A.F., in an interview here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- The conviction of William Dudley Pelley, former leader of the Silver Shirts, on a charge of criminal sedition and his sentence to fifteen years' imprisonment were unanimously upheld today by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed decrease of $8,654,000 in holdings of United States Government securities. Note circulation for the system as a whole was at the highest, while ratio of reserve was at a low for the year.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Three of the biggest manufacturers of soap and soap products in this country and their presidents were fined a total of $60,000 after they had pleaded no defense before Fedderal Judge Guy L. Fake here today to a criminal information charging violations of the Sherman Anti-trust Act.

The report of the National Cash Register Company and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday for the first nine months of 1942, shows a net profit of $2,276,030 after depreciation, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other charges.
MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The British Eighth Army, throwing a strong force across the line of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's retreat in Libya, has cut the German commander's fleeing columns in two and now threatens to inflict another major disaster upon them.

The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission has held two meetings since its organization last June. Recently at Baltimore some of its problems were clarified and yesterday Edmund L. Dunn of Boston, its chairman, issued a statement summarizing the work to date.

The Times Literary Supplement of London, Nov. 21 issue, reached here yesterday. Except for a short Page 1 article about an earlier American Christmas visitor to England, Washington Irving, and today's American visitors, the supplement looked almost as it has for many months -- lean and sparse.

Freight space applications for Brazilian shipments are now being delayed by the War Shipping Administration, although previously such applications received prompt attention, exporters reported yesterday. While no definite information was available, traders expressed the belief that decisions were being held up pending the inauguration of the Board of Economic Warfare's new "decentralization" plan which has been scheduled for initial operation in Brazilian transactions.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 17 -- During his broadcast tonight over WCAO and CBS, Leon Henderson said:

Bank clearings in twenty-three cities for the week ended on Wednesday increased $632,299,000, or 8.6 per cent over the total of the preceding week, but for the first time in many weeks they fell below the level of the corresponding week of last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a long-awaited action, announced today the adoption of revisions of its proxy rules applicable to all solicitations after Jan. 15, 1943.

The most comprehensive simplification program undertaken thus far in behalf of the war effort has been in the manufacture of carpets and rugs, where eight of the major mills have reduced the number of grades 81 per cent since the last January market.

For the first time in twelve weeks the Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System, acting for the twelve central banks of the system, sold government securities instead of buying heavily. This was revealed yesterday in the weekly Federal Reserve figures, covering the week ended Wednesday.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The text of the joint Army-Navy announcement on military use of colleges is as follows:

A continuously developing shortage of clocks of all types, but particularly of inexpensive electric or hand-wound alarm clocks, had reached the stage yesterday where many stores were completely out and others had small stocks left that were rapidly being exhausted.

WITH THE U.S. ARMY at Casablanca, Morocco, Dec. 17 -- Sergeant Richard N. Ryan, grandson of the late New York financier, Thomas Fortune Ryan, today became one of the first enlisted men in the African campaign to win promotion in the field.

While youths who became 18 years old in September and October will begin to register for selective service today, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City draft director, announced yesterday that twenty-six registrants who were 18 or 19 years old on June 30 had been ordered to report for induction into the Army this morning -- making the first group of men under 20 to be called since the draft age was lowered last month.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 -- Looking thin but remarkably well after his three weeks on a rubber raft in the Pacific, Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker arrived in San Francisco en route to Washington to report to the War Department.

LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Bank of England in its condition statement issued today reported one of the largest weekly increases for notes in circulation. The figures established a new all-time high of 908,323,000, an increase of 18,799,000 over the previous week.

Arguments on the cuts made by the Hays office production code administrators in "We Are the Marines," a factual drama of the Marine Corps produced by The March of Time, were heard yesterday by the board members of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America at their regular quarterly meeting in the association's headquarters, 28 West Forty-fourth Street.

Details of a new system of marine transportation, a convoy of revolutionary-type concrete ships, completely automatic, crewless and operated by remote radio control were announced yesterday by F.B. Woodworth, an executive of the Maris Transportation System, Inc., and Radio Controls Corporation.

IT may be that Government agencies are rationing and regulating in the wrong direction. The Office of Price Administration is protecting the keglers of this country by freezing the prices at the bowling alleys. This baffled bystander hadn't heard the keglers yelling for help, though doubtless the ruling will be duly appreciated by everybody interested in bowling except the owners of the alleys.

Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, 52 years old, brought here recently from a Federal prison in Michigan to face a five-year-old indictment accusing him, his former racketeer chief, Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, and numerous others of an extortion conspiracy in the garment industry was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions.

MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Red Army killed 1,235 Germans and knocked out twelve tanks yesterday in sharp fighting along the railway leading to Kotelnikov, ninety miles southwest of Stalingrad, made small gains on the central front and consolidated its position deep inside the Don River elbow, the Russians announced early today.

LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- British naval observers declared tonight that formidable French naval units at Dakar probably could be put in fighting trim in a comparatively short time, but that the immobilized French warships at Alexandria could not be ready to join the fight against the Axis for several months at the earliest.

Millions of New Yorkers who had been without their favorite newspapers for three days because of the strike of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union swamped the newsstands yesterday after the end of the strike had restored the papers to sale.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Organized baseball poured $1,314,825 into war relief and recreation coffers during 1942 and hopes to do better next season, Earl Hilligan, American League director of publicity, said tonight.
MONTREAL, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs swamped the Canadiens, 8 -- 1, tonight in a National Hockey League game. It was the third Toronto triumph in four meetings of the Canadian teams this season.

Fifty-nine women, graduates of a seven-week course in occupational therapy, were accepted formally as therapy assistants of the United States Citizens Service Corps in a ceremony yesterday afternoon at the New York Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

In the days when Winter was Winter few American homes were what we should now consider well heated. They were not well aired, either, because fresh air was cold air. A good many people thought that the air which had been good enough for their fathers and grandfathers was good enough for them.

Extraordinary expenditures of $197,033,722, all provided out of its own resources, have been made by the Pennsylvania Railroad since Aug. 31, 1939, through Oct. 31, last, according to a report to stockholders accompanying the dividend of $1.50 a share being paid today.

Baseball's player mart, which has been practically at a standstill since the world series, experienced an unexpected pick-up yesterday when the Yankees and Indians completed a transaction involving four players.

Further recognition of the heroic exploits of the officers and crew of the U.S.S. Boise in a running night engagement off Cape Esperance, Guadalcanal, on Oct. 11 and 12, was given yesterday through the presentation of a bronze plaque on behalf of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

R. Hoe Co., Inc., will pay on Dec. 31 6 per cent against accrued additional interest on its 6 1/2 per cent bonds and 10 per cent against similar interest on its 7 per cent notes, both of which will mature on Oct. 1, 1944. This operation will complete payment of all fixed and additional interest on the bonds and notes to Sept. 30, 1942.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Bad weather last night restricted the Royal Air Force's activities to attacking targets in Northwest Germany with a small force of bombers, while mine-laying aircraft of the Bomber Command dropped their deadly charges in certain sea lanes used by Axis shipping.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 17 -- A considerable portion of the German Africa Corps has been cut off and apparently trapped by a British force of mixed arms that swung up from the southeast yesterday, broke through to the sea at Wadi Matratin, some sixty-five miles west of El Agheila, and then took up positions southward.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- The increasing use of prison labor to aid the war effort by manufacturing articles which private industry is not in a position to supply was stressed today by Governor Poletti, as he announced two new contracts by the Department of Correction with the War Production Board.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company obtained yesterday the award of $800,000 of Waterbury (Conn.) tax anticipation notes, payable on June 2, 1953. It bid an 0.49 per cent interest basis for the issue.

The ration ticket system used in Moscow, where the number of coupons issued to a civilian is based upon the amount of work he does, was described by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as "a good idea." The Mayor addressed 150 members of the tin can committee of the salvage division of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in the City Council Chamber at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The greatest tactical advantage of the United Nations in this global war was again emphasized yesterday by a sharp but brief action over the New Georgia Islands in the Solomons.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton, said today that the joint announcement of Secretaries Stimson and Knox in regard to college training would have "a stabilizing influence on American college students who since last September have been standing by, awaiting instructions."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Department store sales for the week ended Dec. 12 were 16 per cent up from the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This followed a gain of 10 per cent in the preceding week.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Elliott Roosevelt, son of the President, and his pilot, Major Harry Eidson of Indianapolis, have made preliminary flights over every major target chosen for bombing by the United States Twelfth Air Force.

The increased production in this country of Atabrine, a synthetic substitute for quinine for treating malaria, has nullified to a great extent the advantage gained by the Japanese in capturing the world's supply of quinine, Rear Admiral Charles E. Stephenson, director of the United States Typhus Commission, declared here last night.

A jury trial in General Sessions was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein in the case of Thomas J. Ryan, alleged head of a racing information syndicate, and thirty-two others accused with him of gambling and bookmaking offenses in connection with the business of dispensing news of horse racing over wires.

New York City's first test of the double alarm air raid signal system took place last night with results that were not entirely satisfactory. It was twenty-nine minutes from the first audible alarm until the all-clear was sounded. In the Times Square area and elsewhere there was a considerable amount of confusion as lights went on, pedestrians started to move and traffic began to roll at the second audible signal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- If Leon Henderson had elected to stay on, simultaneously defying the physical ravages of overwork and the hostility of the incoming Congress, it would have been a great surprise even to those who are acquainted with his bulldog courage.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 17 -- Although the Chinese version of "Hamlet" has been on view here for a fortnight, it was not ready for formal Broadway criticism until last night at the Kuo T'ai Theatre, just around the corner from the New Life Centre and within a few steps of the banking district.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 17 -- Germany, Italy and Japan protested this afternoon measures adopted by the Argentine Government two weeks ago limiting to 100 words daily the messages foreign diplomats may send by wireless in code.

Showing a precise, smoothly functioning attack that baffled theri rivals completely, the Boston Bruins had little trouble subduing the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Hub skaters, holders of first place, walloped their cellar-bound opponents, 7 to 3.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Price Administrator Leon Henderson, who believes reduction of long-distance telephone rates would help his price-control program, was permitted today by the Federal Communications Commission to intervene in its proceedings concerning rates charged by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
