Sales of three loft, store and office buildings, including the sixteen-story structure at 257-67 West Thirty-ninth Street, were reported yesterday. The buyers in each case were investors.

As the temperature in the city fell yesterday at 7:20 A.M. to 9.8 degrees above zero, the lowest of the 1942-43 Winter season, the Weather Bureau revealed that there has been a departure from normal aggregating minus 76 degrees so far this month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Individual savings in 1942 were estimated today by the Department of Commerce at the unprecedented total of $26,000,000,000 -- more than twice as great as in 1941 and more than three times as great as in 1940.

Returning home from the post-office yesterday morning after she had mailed a Christmas package to her son, Mrs. Margaret Cameron, 41 years old, of 463 Dean Street, Brooklyn, received a telegram from the Adjutant General's Office in Washington, D.C., informing her that her son, Private First Class Raymond Cameron, had died as the result of a gunshot wound in the Western European area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The War Labor Board heard a six-hour argument today on the question whether a labor dispute at Chicago, which has delayed delivery of millions of dollars of publications, including Time and Life magazines, was or was not a strike and violation of contracts.

OTTAWA, Dec. 17 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, replying to a telegram sent by Prime Minister Mackenzie King on Dec. 7 on the anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor, said the determination of the Canadian people to accomplish the complete defeat of the common enemy "is being made manifest daily by Canada's magnificent war effort."

Breaking a ninety-year-old tradition, the New York Yacht Club, at its annual meeting in the clubhouse at 37 West Forty-fourth Street, last night voted to take membership in the North American Yacht Racing Union.

Grocers throughout the city were hoping yesterday that the Office of Price Administration would take immediate steps to add butter to the list of rationed commodities because of an acute shortage that has developed here. They are now limiting sales to customers, but say the practice is unsatisfactory in many respects.

Basil Dean, London producer and Director of National Service Entertainment, somewhat the British Government's counterpart of USO-Camp Shows, Inc., has been here seeking more stage performers for the British Isles. He has been concerned mainly with working out arrangements to help British artists who would like to go back home and do some service for the Empire.

Chinese good manners refuse to take note of the fact that President Roosevelt spelled Generalissimo with an extra 1 in his letter to Chiang Kai-shek. That it is peculiarly Chinese tact we are not so sure.

Opposition to the Army-Navy plan for the military use of colleges was voiced yesterday by representative college presidents who felt that not enough attention was paid to liberal arts education and that the small college would suffer.

Once more the Senate silver bloc has succeeded in putting its pet vested interest above the nation's interests. The Seventy-seventh Congress adjourned without taking any action to release the Government's huge silver hoard for use in the war industries where it is needed.

Dr. Stefan de Ropp, director of the Polish Information Center here, opened an exhibition called "Poland's Part in the War" yesterday afternoon at the New York Museum of Science and Industry, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. The display will continue through January.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A total of $7,300,000 in prime contracts was distributed to 176 small business houses in the two weeks from Nov. 28 to Dec. 12, the Smaller War Plants Division of the War Production Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Members of a Senate agriculture subcommittee criticized today the composition of an American rubber mission sent to Russia, complaining to William M. Jeffers, rubber director, that none of the four men selected was an expert in the manufacture of synthetic rubber from agricultural products.

AT ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 17 -- Admiral Jean Francois Darlan flatly declared today that formidable French fleet units at Dakar, Alexandria and North African ports would join the British and United States fleets on the high seas to fight the Axis.
For the eleventh straight time baseball has produced the outstanding athletic team of the year, the honor for 1942 going to the Cardinals.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- A war-created shortage of trained personnel at the Rockland State Hospital here, one of the largest institutions for mental defectives in the State, has developed into a "critical" situation that may cause serious trouble unless a remedy is found, Dr. Russell E. Blaisdell, superintendent of the hospital, declared today.

Faced with a serious depletion in reserve stocks of oil for the manufacture of gas, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York warned several thousand wholesale users yesterday that it might have to curtail service to them unless oil stocks could be replenished soon.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that that institution was taking into account the fact that many corporations would not be able to file their annual financial reports by the customary dates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that a woman of "world viewpoint," one who had contributed to the war effort, should have a seat at the peace table after victory was won. Youth, too, "has every right to be represented," she added.

Possible action by the OPA in Washington on numerous applications for an extension of time on MPR 287 was awaited in the garment trades here yesterday. Reports here indicated that a "flood" of such petitions had been made from apparel trade groups in many sections of the country.

Railroads are up against a tough proposition. OPA asks for the rescinding of increases in passenger and freight rates, and employes are seeking an increase of 30 per cent in pay. Farmers want higher prices so they can compete with wages in armament industries.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- In a sharply worded resolution the National Canners Association said today that it must "both record its dissent and vigorously reject as unnecessary and unworkable" the OPA proposal for collective grade labeling of canned foods in connection with its 1943 price control program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- "Point" rationing will be set up in the United States early next year but will not include for the present the rationing of clothes, according to the OPA.

Labor trouble for the farmer was inevitable, once we got into production and defense plants began to pay as much a week as the farmer could afford to pay in a month. Lack of modern facilities on our farms, more particularly as regards electricity, is one important reason why thousands of farmers have recently thrown up the sponge.
LONDON, Friday, Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- American planes bombed the Axis bases of Bizerte and Tunis yesterday for the sixth straight day.

The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to postpone until its next meeting, on Jan. 14, consideration of the pension application of former First Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines, who resigned five days after he was charged by Investigation Commissioner William B. Herlands with illegally accepting gratuities for performing marriage ceremonies.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Three more supply ships of the Axis forces in Tunisia have been torpedoed and probably sunk in the Mediterranean by British submarines, the Admiralty announced today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- The British flying column that split General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's columns fleeing westward from El Agheila, Libya, was reported taking over the pursuit of

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Hans G. Beutler, a research associate in the Department of Physics at the University of Chicago, who was a noted German spectroscopist before he fled to this country six years ago, was found dead yesterday in his home here.

The cotton futures market progressed yesterday through another featureless session, with price fluctuations in an 11-point range just above the previous close. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts receded slightly from the day's best quotations to end the session with net gains of 2 to 7 points.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The career of David M. Bressler in philanthropy and nation-wide social service was praised yesterday at a funeral service conducted in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street. Several hundred leaders in business and the professions and persons engaged in the welfare field attended.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini's newspaper today devoted a large share of its space to soothing the tempers of ruffled Italians complaining of the arrangements made to protect them from bombs and chided those who seem unable to take it.

Sparked by Tony Karpowich, who tallied seventeen points, the undefeated Fordham basketball team gained its sixth victory of the season last night by vanquishing Brooklyn College, 53 to 45, in the latter's gymnasium.

Unless women are willing to learn how to make their own curls and give themselves manicures, they may soon be forced to return to straight hair and untinted nails, heads of employment agencies in the metropolitan area agreed yesterday.

Ever since the outbreak of the war newspaper sports pages have contained numerous letters, editorial comments and incidental references concerning the position of athletic spectacles in our war effort.

Leon Henderson has resigned from what the President rightly describes as the "difficult and thankless task" of Price Administrator. Despite inevitable mistakes and hardships involved in the imposition of price ceilings and rationing, Mr. Henderson, on the record, has made a great contribution to our wartime battle against inflation.

Mell Ott, the mighty little man who manages the New York Giants, during the recent season continued to add to records he already holds and to compile some new marks, according to the official figures announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Five masked men who, State police say, may have been members of the Roger Touhy gang who escaped from Stateville Prison in October, held up an armored money car outside the Buick plant in Melrose Park today, shot one of the two guards and escaped in the armored car with about $20,000 in currency.

In the summary by Edmund L. Dunn, chairman of the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, of the work of the group during recent sessions, there is an indication that restrictions may be put into effect on the taking of channel bass.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Fulfilling the Allied promise that, although the air commands for Western Europe were preoccupied at present in attacking Italian cities that are centers of enemy war production for the African fronts, Germany would not be forgotten, Royal Air Force bombers in some number blasted points in Northwestern Germany last night, the Air Ministry reported today.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 18 -- An unsuspected hurdle -- curtailment of gasoline sales -- sprang up today in the path of track operators preparing for the opening Monday of Florida's Winter horse racing season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The procedure of the War Labor Board drew a second attack from a C.I.O. source today when the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America called for speedier handling of cases to avert "a decided loss of morale on the production front."

Jorge Bolet, 28-year-old Cuban pianist, who was largely trained here, is a brilliant young artist. He plays with a fine romantic flavor, and in a recital at Carnegie Hall last night he gave performances that had the ardor of a colorful personality but that were founded nevertheless on a rockbed of discipline.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- With one dissenting vote the Securities and Exchange Commission conditionally approved today an $18,648,438 write-down of the utility plant account of the Carolina Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of the National Power and Light Company.

Even in wartime puppies and kittens are popular Christmas gifts. Perhaps they are more needed now than in peacetime, for a playful animal can bring gayety to an anxious home. But to be playful they must be healthy and happy, so it is well to consider that a pet is a responsibility.

It was an unusually dull day at Local Draft Board 1 at 33 East Broadway until forty-seven Chinese youths charged into the place in the early afternoon and demanded vociferously to be enlisted at once "to end this damn war."
MOSCOW, Dec. 18 -- Today's Soviet communique reported further development of the Red Army's successes on both the Stalingrad land central fronts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The preliminary report of the House Small Business Committee to Speaker Rayburn reads as follows:
MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's noon communique:

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Dr. A. Noah Schiller, New York physician, who was long identified with the Jewish Memorial Hospital there, died here yesterday after a brief illness. His age was 58. He arrived three weeks ago.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- The Times Square Credit Union, 229 West Forty-third Street, New York, has applied to the State Banking Department for authority to begin business. The incorporators include Stanley P. Nelson, Joseph M. Perota, William Desimini, James B. Daly, Muriel Hursley, Thomas J. Murphy and Robert E. Hughes.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting has broken out at the southeastern end of the Allied line in the Buna sector of New Guinea with American troops storming a strong Japanese defense line of pillboxes and machinegun posts, the Allied Command announced today.

Metropolitan ski enthusiasts took advantage of the recent snowstorm to test their freshly waxed hickory runners at city and State public parks, golf courses and, for that matter, any available snow-covered slope or hill. Department and sporting goods stores revealed a tremendous upswing in public interest and a consequent increase in their equipment sales.
ST. PAUL, Dee. 18 (AP) -- The Minnesota State Supreme Court ruled today, 4 to 3, that Northwest Airlines, Inc., must pay personal property taxes and penalties totaling $18,266 to Ramsey County.

Beau Jack, Georgia Negro who was a golf caddy less than two years ago became the world lightweight champion last night in Madison Square Garden, as a yelling crowd of about 18,817 fight fans saw him enthroned.

The joy at Christmas time of helping neighbors in great distress, good and brave people overwhelmed by conditions beyond their control, was manifest in letters from many contributors to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. Moved by deep sympathy for the men, women and children who are the Neediest known to exist in the city by eight leading private charities, the contributors gave to help them -- their neighbors in spirit if not in place.
Services that will be held this week-end in the city's temples and synagogues follow:

TRENTON, Dec. 18 -- The curb on the sale of gasoline along the Atlantic Seaboard came today as Governor Charles Edison moved to reduce by at least 40 per cent the mileage traveled by motor vehicles used for State purposes and as a drastic curtailment of heating oil for buildings other than homes was threatened.

Yesterday the scene of The Play was transported from the Rialto to Chungking. Brooks Atkinson, our Ariel-Mercury, invaded China with his winged heels. Eager for business as usual, he went to see the Chinese version of "Hamlet" at the Kuo T'ai Theatre. It was a great night for Shakespeare.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Sales of independent retailers increased 7 per cent in November over the same month last year, according to preliminary data based on reports from 15,618 stores in thirty-four States released today by the Census Bureau. There was a drop of 9 per cent from October volume.

The emergency curtailment of A. B and C gasoline rations by the OPA yesterday left essential services such as taxicab transportation, milk distribution and other kinds of delivery holding T cards still operating on a "hand-to-mouth" basis. Even those higher ratings performing vital services were wondering in some instances whether they would have sufficient gas to operate on Monday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 18 -- Negotiations with Vatican mediation between Italy and the United States and Britain to make Rome an open city are believed to be nearing completion. London and Washington are said to have agreed "in principle" but are reported to have demanded further guarantees.
LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The American submarine score for Japanese ships destroyed in the Pacific area rose to 105 today, with announcement of seven more officially credited sinkings.

Plans for consolidating the offices of the Army Air Forces in larger quarters downtown were disclosed yesterday when it was announced that the Army had leased quarters in the International Telephone Building at 67 Broad Street and was moving from 90 Church Street and the other buildings it occupies.

Taking the risk of outstripping the advance of their protecting air force, the Allies made a desperate bid for Tunisia and came within an ace of rushing Tunis before the Germans established themselves on the Bizerte-Tunis front, covering 400 miles and fighting several engagements in less than a month, according to an account of the campaign in Northwest Africa by an authoritative American military spokesmen in London reported by the British official wireless.

Announcement that the Museum of Living Art at New York University is to be discontinued strikes a note of sadness. The art world will feel this loss. The Museum of Living Art, founded and directed by Albert E. Gallatin, is small but unique -- set up, as it has been since the pioneering venture was launched on Dec. 12, 1927, in one of the study rooms of the university in Washington Square.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 19 -- Russian troops engaged in a death grapple on the snow-covered central front advanced again near Velikiye Luki yesterday, killing more than 300 Germans and destroying twenty-six enemy planes, the Soviet Command announced early today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- The Yuletide spirit has pervaded this city to such an extent that Mayor Stanley W. Church ordered police today not to arrest automobile headlight dimout violators until after Christmas. By his order Mayor Church defied Captain Rossiter Holbrook, deputy county director of Civilian Protection, who on Monday ordered that the State War Emergency Act regulating headlights be strictly enforced beginning tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18 -"The Merry Widow Goes West," a photoplay which Felix Jackson and Leo Townsend are writing, has been scheduled at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Kathryn Grayson. Joseph Pasternak will produce the picture, which deals with a vaudeville comedian and his daughter, who inherits a Western gold mine.

An extensive advertising campaign designed to stimulate public participation in war activities on the homefront will be sponsored cooperatively by national magazines beginning in February, the National Publishers Association announced yesterday.

Although corporation executives, pressed with a shortage of help and other war-production worries, are not expected to cheer at the new proxy rules announced by the Securities and Exchange Commission to become effective in mid-January, they may view them as a partial victory.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The stock markets brightened slightly today. One pleasant surprise in the diamond section was an announcement by De Beers Consolidated Mines, Ltd., of a dividend of 40 per cent, against one of 20 per cent a year ago. The shares jumped 7/8 to 11 1/4.

A City Council investigation of the entire field of juvenile delinquency, including the alleged failure of the school system to cope with the problem, was urged yesterday at a public hearing held at City Hall by the Council's welfare committee.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 18 -- Flying Fortresses made a direct hit on and set fire to an enemy warship believed to be a light cruiser fifteen miles off Bizerte today as the tempo of the air war increased and the Germans tried to halt the Allied air onslaughts, with disastrous results for them.

THE interest in basketball is largely academic, which is to say that it's the college variety that dominates the Winter floors. This observer encountered Mr. Ned Irish, the energetic gent who persuades teams from all over the country to show up at Madison Square Garden for the Winter bombardment of the backboards there, and asked him whether or not transportation difficulties would cut off some of his customary visitors from far-off places.

One flotation of municipal bonds totaling $3,140,000 was the only new issue of securities offered here this week for public subscription. The total was the smallest for such a period since the week ended Nov. 13, and contrasted with $4,522,000 for three offerings in the preceding week and with $36,461,000, representing thirteen emissions, in this week a year ago.

Some refrigerator manufacturers are becoming more confident that the War Production Board will eventually ease the current restrictions on the sale of boxes, so that some of the expensive luxury units may be disposed of, reports here yesterday indicated.

Christmas trade approached its final stages this week in a heavy buying rush, particularly on Thursday. Department store volume was estimated at about 10 per cent ahead of the corresponding week last year. Specialty shop increases were larger.

An audience of 2,000 persons rose in homage and applauded for several minutes when Moriz Rosenthal, the eminent Polish pianist, entered Hunter College Assembly Hall last night at the start of the testimonial concert given in his honor on his eightieth birthday.

Hats off to the basketball schedule makers of Manhattan College and Brooklyn College! Not a single non-Eastern opponent appears on either slate. Sport fans who are 100 per cent patriots can support those teams wholeheartedly without having any qualms of conscience.

Joseph Hilton Smyth, a confessed secret agent of Japan, testified against Leonard Robert Jordan in Federal Court yesterday because, he said, he was interested in racial problems and felt that in seeking to stir up Negroes against the United States, Jordan was "hurting his own [Negro] race."

Edwin F. Chinlund resigned yesterday as president of Postal Telegraph, Inc., to become associated with R.H. Macy Co. as a vice president, a member of the executive committee and a director of the department store company. However, in resigning as president of Postal, Mr. Chinlund will remain temporarily as chairman of the board of the communications concern and will devote his efforts to effecting the proposed merger of the nation's telegraph companies.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- Samuel Nuzzo, ousted business agent of Local 17 of the hodcarriers' union, offered in testimony today an explanation of a $500 item listed in one of the counts of grand larceny and forgery on which he is being tried.

The State's temporary first family, consisting of Governor Poletti, Mrs. Poletti, Carla Poletti, Charles Ellis ("Chuck") Poletti and Joanna Poletti, warms the nonpartisan heart by its decision to move into the Executive Mansion at Albany for the Christmas holidays.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

The Belmont Theatre will be reopened today with the local premiere of "The Playboy," an English-made film starring Harry Richman. Directed by Walter Forde, the picture's supporting cast includes Maureen O'Hara, Florence Desmond and Ambrose and his orchestra.

Four unbeaten teams, two of them generally acclaimed as the leading contenders for the metropolitan basketball laurels, will see action in Madison Square Garden tonight when St. John's of Brooklyn will oppose Oklahoma University and N.Y.U. will face Syracuse.

HAVANA, Cuba, Dec. 18 -- President Fulgencio Batista said on his return from Washington today that the magnitude of the United States war effort was almost impossible to describe. He warned Cubans that greater sacrifices would be required.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Smaller colleges and the less well endowed schools will receive some preference in designation for participation in the joint Army-Navy program to mobilize 200 or 300 universities and colleges for training men in the armed forces, Secretary Knox said today.

Indicating that Japan is beginning to feel the pinch of a shipping shortage as a result of war losses, the Berlin radio broadcast a dispatch from Tokyo yesterday saying that Japanese shipyards were planning construction of a large number of Chinese junks for use in Asiatic waters.

In the status of a seaman in the British Royal Navy I have just spent several weeks in New York. I felt that it might be of interest to your readers to know of the appreciation of at least one of those whom they have entertained so well.
A High Command communque broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

No longer will women found guilty of gambling before Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto have the alternative of paying a fine or serving a jail sentence. From now on, he announced in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, they will have to serve out a jail term.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- John C. Weigel, regional director of the Office of Price Administration, relaxed fuel oil rationing regulations in the Midwest tonight to permit users affected by severe Winter conditions to obtain additional supplies during the coming week.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

In response to the demands of the Army for more satisfactory containers for dehydrated foods, a group of industry executives have set up an informal committee to "pool" data and experience on the subject, it was learned yesterday. One of the principal problems of the dehydrated foods industry has been the development of a substitute for the hermetically sealed container of tin, now in extremely short supply.

Postmaster Albert Goldman was conducting a group of reporters and photographers through his busy mail rooms at the General Postoffice, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, yesterday, when he stopped and pointed to a corner known as the "patch-up table."

The selection of Branch Rickey as president of the Brooklyn Dodgers and the retention of Leo Durocher as manager throw an interesting sidelight on the ability of men leaving one major league to make good in the other. This is especially true as regards the three baseball clubs in this city.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18 -- Because some motion pictures have hindered unwittingly the war effort by their dialogue and subject matter, Lowell Mellett, chief of the Motion Picture Bureau of the Office of War Information, has requested studio heads to submit screen treatments and finished scenarios of all pictures to the OWI before filming begins, his Hollywood representative disclosed today.

A slight improvement in its gas-making facilities was reported yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company, which on Thursday had advised several thousand wholesale users of gas that it might have to curtail service unless its oil stocks could be replenished soon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Office of Price Administration suspended the sale of gasoline at noon today to holders of A, B and C ration hooks in seventeen Eastern States and the District of Columbia, but later in the afternoon gave assurances that the motor-fuel famine would probably abate sufficiently by midnight Sunday to allow resumption of sales.

There is only one favorable comment to make on the meat situation -- pork feet and knuckles are fairly plentiful and comparatively cheap. All other meats are scarcer than ever, and cost the same as they did last week. The following list of prices is based on reports from the Consumers' Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Underground advices to the Yugoslav government in exile and a Belgrade newspaper report disclosed today that Axis occupation authorities have executed seventy-one Yugoslav hostages and that twenty more are awaiting execution within the next week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Navy communique 223:

Industrial training for youth, now being conducted on a countrywide scale by the National Youth Administration, must be continued and expanded after the war to assure American youngsters an opportunity to find their proper places in the post-war world, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday afternoon.

According to an official Chinese review issued at Chungking, the Japanese have increased their forces in Northern Manchuria to 1,000,000 men and are building fortifications along the Manchurian-Siberian border so secret that Chinese workers employed on them are killed afterward to guard against betrayal.

W.L. Hemingway, president of the American Bankers Association, announced yesterday the appointments of twelve members to the executive council and four members to the administrative committee. Mr. Hemingway is president of the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis.

LAST night Santa Claus poked his head down the chimney of your Tuesday-Thursday-Saturday reviewer. Said he: "I've got a good list of Christmas books from your pal Orville Prescott. But I need some more titles. What would you be giving away if you were me?"

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Latest surveys on this year's production of fats and vegetable oils for food and industrial purposes indicate that the United States faces a shortage in 1943 of 800,000,000 to 1,000,000,000 pounds, an Agriculture Department official said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The government reported today well-balanced harvest for this year estimated to be 14 per cent greater than last year and nearly 12 per cent larger than the record production of 1937.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Progress is being made toward stepping up soft-coal production to meet the 1943 war goal of 600,000,000 tons, highest in history, and, "given adequate manpower, equipment and transportation," the soft-coal industry can meet the test, Secretary Ickes reported today in his capacity as Coordinator of Solid Fuels.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 17 (Delayed) (U.S.) -- Admiral Jean Francois Darlan as High Commissioner of French North Africa was described today as having full authority over all civil affairs.

With the blessing of Actors Equity, managements are permitted to lay off attractions, at no expense to them, during the pre-Christmas period. Touring shows taking advantage of Equity's ruling and the cities where the engagements will be resumed are noted below:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The sudden resignation of Leon Henderson as Price Administrator was received by many at the Capitol today as "a victory for Congress."
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 18 -City officials prepared today to regulate the sale of horse meat for human consumption.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 18 -- While Pierre Laval is discussing what may prove to be a peace treaty with Germany, obviously unilateral in the circumstances, the French in the former free zone are realizing each day what total occupation means.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 -- Decimated and battered by fighting resulting from British outflanking movements, the German Africa Corps moved on westward in Libya yesterday.

The necessity for training women in the arts and sciences for the war and of preparing to supply the teachers in a range from nursery school to college was emphasized yesterday in a statement released by the Seven College Conference, of which Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard is chairman.

The large loan exhibition of eighteenth century French and English paintings, sculpture, furnishings, etc., held under the patronage of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, will open with a private view this evening at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- An unprecedented gasoline buying wave amid widespread confusion beset Philadelphia service stations today as thousands of apprehensive motorists sought to fill their tanks before the Federal order suspending gasoline sales to A, B and C ration book holders went into effect.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- A Radio Morocco broadcast heard here by United Press announced today that Governor General Charles Nogues of French Morocco arrived in Casablanca yesterday and conferred with Major Gen. George S. Patton Jr., American western task force commander in North Africa.

Profit-taking slowed down yesterday a continuation of the yearend rally in the stock market as business there passed the million-share mark for the second consecutive session and the fifth time this year. The upturn in prices carried over from Thursday at the opening of trading under the stimulus off large blocks of starters, but once this heavy demand had subsided the list battled periods of mild selling and closed with only fractional gains.
An apartment of seven rooms and three baths has been rented by William J. Lippincott, vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, in 21 East Ninetieth Street through Payson McL. Merrill Company.

Permission to celebrate midnight masses Christmas Eve has been granted by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman to the parishes of the Archdiocese of New York. The permission, according to canon law, can be given for only one year at a time.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- William Werntz, chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission, held today that the post-war 10 per cent refund on the excess profits tax should be shown on corporation balance sheets as "other assets" rather than current assets or investments.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 18 -- Commander Edward Nelson (Butch) Parker, 38, of Lexington, Ky., today described the twenty-minute free-for-all naval battle off Savo Island in the Solomons the night of Nov. 12-13, in which his destroyer torpedoed a Japanese battleship and was itself sunk by the combined fire at least two enemy cruisers and several destroyers.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- American bombers again struck heavy blows at the Axis in Tunisia yesterday, setting ablaze an Italian light cruiser while en route to Bizerte, where further damage was heaped on docks and shipping, to round out a week of daily assaults.

In the Northern Neck of Virginia the chief observer at the Heathsville post of the Aircraft Warning Service is the Rev. Ryland C. Reamy, Baptist minister. A priest, the Rev. John J. Gaffney, is the chief plane spotter at Rock Lake, Pa.

Directors of the Riverside and Dan River Cotton Mills ordered yesterday the payment on Dec. 29 of a preferred dividend totaling $225,000 owing since Jan. 1, 1938. This clears up the arrears of $12 a share on the stock and brings total disbursements on the stock this year to $18 compared with $9 distributed in 1941.

In a game which saw the rivals never more than 3 points apart, Andrew Jackson High, defending city P.S.A.L. champion, topped Franklin K. Lane's basketball team, 27 to 26, on Lane's floor in a South Queens battle yesterday. The victory gave Coach Lew Grummond's team undisputed possession of the South Queens lead.
ALBANY, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Former Governor Lehman will witness the hanging of his portrait among those of his predecessors in the "Gallery of Governors" in the Executive Chamber on Monday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 18 -Louis A Vierbuchen, 48-year-old motorman of the Hudson Manhattan tube train that was wrecked after derailment at the Exchange Place Station here last April 26, was acquitted on all five counts of manslaughter by a jury before Judge Lewis B. Eastmead in the Court of Quarter Sessions tonight.
BOSTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey announced yesterday that the city had successfully weathered its second moderately heavy snowfall. The situation, he said, was "pretty well under control," with only the regular departmental force on duty.

American planes have been actively interested in Marshal Rommel between El Agheila and Tripoli. These recent weeks Americans have been active in the whole Stephen Decatur country. Tripoli, Tunis, Algiers saw a good deal of Decatur between 1804 and 1815.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Nine-year-old Mary Druty was struck by a freight train today, and both legs were severed above the knees, but she still held the quart of ice cream with which she had been hurrying home for her birthday party.

Looking like a miniature edition of a West Point regiment on parade as they executed difficult military manoeuvres with a sharpness and precision tht earned them the plaudits of 2,000 relatives, guests, and reviewing officers, the Knickerbocker Greys, crack junior cadet corps, yesterday held its sixty-second annual Christmas drill and reception at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Five women took their oaths yesterday as the first inductees from the Third Naval District in the Spars, new Coast Guard auxiliary. They were sworn in by Rear Admiral L.C. Farwell, Coast Guard, retired, at the office of Naval Officer Procurement, 33 Pine Street.

The greatest surprise of the war -- as great as when the first British tanks rumbled into action in World War I -- came to the Germans just when they were expecting to break through the Alamein lines and roll on to Alexandria, the Nile and the Suez Canal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Asserting that three critical situations resulting from policies of the Office of Price Administration threatened the destruction of independent small business and with it "a breakdown on the home front," the House Committee on Small Business filed a special report today with Speaker Rayburn and promised another which would reveal "many startling facts."
The Colorado Southern Railway Company has reported to the New York Stock Exchange that its petition for adjustment of indebtedness filed under Chapter 15 of the Bankruptcy Act has been approved.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 18 (U_R.) -- American bombers struck last Monday at Gialam airdrome at Hanoi, the capital of French Indo-China, damaging repair shops, runways and two hangars and setting large fires in what were believed to be oil and ammunition stores, a United States Army communique announced today.

Medals and distinguished service crosses are awarded to soldiers who display conspicuous gallantry in action. This is as it should be. But there aren't any honorary decorations for civilians who show outstanding courage in their battles against poverty, disease and misfortune.
Hammerin' Henry Armstrong, the great little fighter who has won thirteen bouts since coming out of retirement early last Summer, yesterday was acclaimed for the year's outstanding comeback in sports.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 -- Acting simultaneously in four California areas, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested today sixteen leaders of the mysterious organization known as Mankind United, charging conspiracy to violate the Sedition Law.

The New York Little Symphony, founded and conducted by Joseph Barone, gave a program of music at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night. The chamber orchestra, like the American Little Symphony founded in Philadelphia by Mr. Barone, is "dedicated to the purpose of creating more orchestral debut opportunities for outstanding young American soloists, conductors and composers."

Twenty-five hundred members and guests of Local 579, Bakers and Confectionery Workers Union of America, A.F. of L., yesterday attended a huge war bond rally and service flag dedication, the climax of a five-week bond drive by the union.

Lower Greenwich Village lay under dense smoke from 4:30 P.M. through early evening yesterday as fire, following an explosion, raced through the three loft buildings from 188 to 196 West Houston Street between Sixth Avenue and Varick Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Roosevelt sent a German Iron Cross today to John O'Donnell, Washington correspondent of The New York Daily News, and Mr. O'Donnell issued a statement saying he was "amazed and bewildered" by the President's action.

The greatest concentration of troops ever assembled in one armory here will pass in review tomorrow afternoon before former Governor Herbert H. Lehman when he inspects 10,000 officers and men of the New York Guard at the Eighth Regiment Armory, 29 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Shipments of war materials from plants of the automobile industry reached a total value of $577,621,000 in September, an increase of 7.5 per cent over August, the War Production Board said today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A British communique:

The Tokyo radio indicated yesterday that the Japanese continued to be anxious concerning United States air raids on Japan, asserting steps had been taken to forestall such an attack on the anniversary of the Pearl Harbor raid, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek expressed the hope today that the United Nations would realize soon "our common war aims in advancing the cause of freedom and equality in a world of peace, order and happiness."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Legislation of the second and final session of the Seventy-seventh Congress pivoted mainly around the participation of the United States in the war, taxation and appropriations, and included the declarations of war on Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania and further wide extension of the President's emergency and war powers.

Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, the middle-aged former partner of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, the racketeer chief now under sentence to die for a murder, triumphed yesterday over Assistant District Attorney Sol Gelb in the move to keep Gurrah in a Tombs cell until he comes to trial in General Sessions on the five-year-old garment industry extortion-conspiracy indictment.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18 -- While a sharply worded statement issued at Rio de Janeiro yesterday said that "not a single ounce of rubber can leave Brazil without United States consent," Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu asserted today that negotiations were in progress between Argentina and Brazil for an agreement by which Argentine petroleum would be exchanged for Brazilian rubber.
TENAFLY, N.J., Dec. 18 -- Twenty-two persons were injured, none seriously, in bus collisions in Bergen County this morning. Both accidents were attributed to slippery roads.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Miss Katharine Lenroot, chief of the Department of Labor's Children's Bureau since 1934, received the Rosenberger Medal at the convocation of the University of Chicago today. The award was made in recognition of her thirty years of service devoted to the welfare of children in North and South America.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration put wholesale and packer sales of lamb and mutton under specific maximum prices tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Buying of wheat futures attributed to cash interests and mills and estimated at 1,000,000 bushels or more lifted the price of futures on the Board of Trade today to the highest marks of the season, with the September selling at the highest level reached by any delivery since 1937.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- Brig. Gen. Clayton L. Bissell, commander of United States air forces in China, Burma and India, said today that American aerial reconnaissance had disclosed no increase in enemy ground or air activity in Burma despite unofficial reports that the Japanese were preparing to invade India.

The net income of the Borden Company and its domestic and Canadian subsidiaries for the year 1942, after taxes and providing a substantial contingency reserve for inventories, is estimated between $1.80 and $1.90 a share, Theodore G. Montague, president, informed stockholders yesterday in a statement accompanying dividend checks.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters:
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 18 -Edwin Jay Prindle, retired patent lawyer, who was a former president of the New York Patent Law Association, died here yesterday at the age of 74.

The Metropolitan Distributors, Inc., which provides the trucks for the distribution of four of the city's large daily newspapers, including THE NEW YORK TIMES, was hopeful last night that deliveries over the week-end would not be interrupted by the gasoline shortage.

Offering complete cooperation, the heads of many leading American colleges and universities declared yesterday that they stood ready to turn over their campuses, buildings, laboratories and equipment for the use of the Army and Navy.
Sales by builders of apartment properties in the Washington Heights and Inwood sections were among realty deals in Manhattan reported yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 18 -- On the eve of commencement, Yale's class of 1943 planted its ivy tonight in a silver centerpiece on the stage of Woolsey Hall instead of beside the walls of the university library, where it will be transplanted in the Spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Railroad operating revenues in November were 48.6 per cent greater than in the same month last year, the Association of American Railroads reported today on the basis of preliminary reports from eighty-four of the 136 Class 1 carriers.
The quarterly list of books recommended especially for members of the Roman Catholic Church by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee was released yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 -- Enemy preparations to make air attacks from Lampedusa Island, between Tunisia and Malta, were upset yesterday when Allied fighters and fighter-bombers raided the airfield there and scored hits among assembled planes.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A communique from the British command in Cairo today spoke significantly of "the remains of Axis rear guards," but was somewhat reserved as to the situation in the area of the cut-off, saying only that "the extent of the damage inflicted on the enemy in the area between Marble Arch and Wadi Matratin is not yet known."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The War Department reached into the high schools today to begin the training of thousands of specialists needed in modern mechanized warfare and sent to the principals of 50,000 public, private and parochial schools outlines of five courses which could be offered to students and in night classes to older men now facing induction.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The strict rules of etiquette governing social relations in Africa, particularly as regards the conduct of men toward women, were compressed into a forty-two-page booklet issued to our soldiers in Morocco and Algiers, which was summarized today In a description issued by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Despite increased dairy production and prospects of a new all-time high production record in 1943, military and lend-lease needs next year will be so great that the civilian population will have to cut its consumption of milk and dairy products by about 18,000,000,000 pounds, a Department of Agriculture spokesman disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- With the Army's procurement program for sheets completed and the Navy's buying program expected to be finished soon, retailers can expect an easing in the current "freeze" of sheets, it was learned here today.

One aspect of the forty-hour-week question which has escaped public notice is that where the thirty-five or forty-hour week is being observed, as it is being by many miners, building workers and workers producing articles for civilian consumption, these workers are enjoying two full holidays a week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that railroad dispute cases would continue to be handled by the National (Railway) Mediation Board rather than by the WLB.

After twenty-five minutes' consideration a jury of seven men and five women in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday returned a verdict of guilty against the Manhattan Coffee and Sugar Company, Inc., of 25 Division Place, Brooklyn, and Nathan Goldsmith, its president and treasurer, on charges of making false statements to the Office of Price Administration. Judge Mortimer W. Byers set Jan. 4 for sentence.

We of the Third Avenue Committee have presented to the Board of Transportation an application to effect a real saving of labor, power and equipment by shutting down the Third Avenue elevated during the night trick from 9 P.M. to 5 A.M.

The nation's Seventy-seventh Congress last week passed into history without fanfare or drama. The event brought none of the hilarity and horseplay that so often have marked final adjournments on Capitol Hill. The last-day-of-school atmosphere was missing.

Paper currency of an unfamiliar type will appear here this week. To the average citizen it will look just about like the present paper money, but experienced handlers will discern the difference quickly. The bills about to go into circulation are Federal Reserve banknotes which were issued at the time of the banking crisis in 1933 and then withdrawn quickly.

Because the new proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission are so much milder than in their original draft, Wall Street has been slow to react. Study is revealing, however, that, while certain surface objections to them have been eliminated in the rewriting, fundamental objections have not been answered.

Boys and girls around town have been making toys for children in hospitals, paper dolls and other gifts for day nursery youngsters. These further ideas for brightening Christmas in the children's ward come from a volunteer nurses' aide: picture books; any simple plaything to occupy their hands; and for little girls, fresh, bright hair ribbons.

While many breeds of dogs are being recruited and trained for various duties with the armed forces, they are mostly of the larger varieties. In view of the fact that these dogs are used as guards, in sentry work, for communications and with Red Cross rescue parties, it is obvious that strength and stamina are the first requisites.

With special precautions to keep receivership attorneys from taking possession of the remaining assets the Securities and Exchange Commission has moved into Fiscal Fund, Inc., a Delaware investment trust. United States District Court Judge Paul Leahy on Friday signed the order for a temporary receivership and appointed Howard F. McCall, president of the Central National Bank of Wilmington, as receiver.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 19 -- The government announced tonight that a plot by the leftist Revolutionary party to unseat the government and destroy Bolivia's republican political system had been discovered.

JUST recently the eminent Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the Turf Committee of America, pointed with some pardonable pride to the fact that racing had contributed roughly $3,000,000 for war relief work this year. Organized baseball produced $1,314,825 for the same general purpose. Golf, tennis, bowling, boxing, hockey and a dozen other sports came through with handsome donations in the same direction.

The regular United States Chess Federation championship was augmented in 1942 by a national rapid-transit event with a time limit of ten seconds a move. In addition, the first national amateur championship was staged.

The Army-Navy E pennant for outstanding industrial production and 533 silver E pins were presented yesterday to the Radiomarine Corporation of America and its employes at ceremonies in the concern's offices in 75 Varick Street. The award was the third of its kind given to a subsidiary of Radio Corporation of America.
BE of good cheer, photographers; it is still possible to take good pictures after dark in spite of, and sometimes because of, dimout regulations.

GIVE the children a happy Christmas. Don't give up having a tree, if you can find and afford one, or the presents to be piled under it, or hanging the stockings, or putting wreaths in the windows, or singing Christmas carols, or whatever traditional things you've always done.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Fourth Naval District announced today that President Roosevelt has promoted from lieutenant commander to commander two officers of the cruiser Boise, the navy's "one-ship fleet" which recently sank six Japanese warships off the Solomons.

It is difficult to point to any sport except professional football for the greatest upset of 1942. That came in the championship play-off at Griffith Stadium in the capital last Sunday, when the Washington Redskins subdued the Chicago Bears, 14 -- 6.

THE author of this book describes herself as an armchair anthropologist and freely admits that she has leaned heavily on books, thus warning away those who might expect to find in these pages any new evidence of the antiquity of man.
Skeet and trapshooting came in for greater attention this year because of the war and the inculcation of skeet into aviation gunnery training.

Some particularly nasty Nazis supply the crime element in this story of murder and espionage in Dakr and Rio. he action shutties back and forth between thega two At]antic ports, beginning and ending in Dakar. There is a little matter of a secret formula at stake, a secret locked in tile n2ind of a woman of Rio de Janeiro who refuses to give it up,

In conjunction with the benefit premiere of the Noel Coward motion picture, "In Which We Serve," at the Capitol Theatre on Wednesday night, the American Theatre Wing War Service, Inc., will give an after-theatre supper party and entertainment to mark the opening of the new Casbah supper club at 112 Central Park South.

THERE was a distinct drop in the number of contemporary compositions recorded and released in 1942. Where 1941 saw a cheering representation of the music of our own time on disks, generally with several compositions issued each month, 1942 has had only a scattering of recordings of composers of our day.

Two volumes, descriptive of the doll's house made for the Dowager Queen Mary of England as a token of affection, were auctioned off last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, at a preview of the exhibit of French and English Art Treasures of the Eighteenth Century to be held there for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

There were enough competitive thrills to content the most exacting during the racing season, but as the year drew to a close thoroughbred followers paid more attention to how the sport had got along under war conditions. The raising of approximately $3,000,000 for service men, with the biggest single contribution coming from seven extra days at Belmont Park, was merely one phase of dovetailing racing with tile war effort.

For three days last week an average of 40,000 people a day came to The New York Times Building on West Forty-third Street to buy their morning newspaper. Some came quite a distance -- from remote places in the five boroughs and from points beyond in Long Island and New Jersey.

RAFAEL ORIOL, president of the Philatelic Club of Cuba, passed through New York last week, concluding a five-week business trip in the United States, and in an interview outlined Cuba's stamp program for early 1943. There will be four series deferred from 1942, according to Mr. Oriol, together with two stamps as a memorial to Mario G. Menocal, the republic's third President, who died about ten months ago.

Cold, like virtue, is relative. Its severity depends on where you are and in what circumstances. Statistically it depends on who takes the temperature readings and where. That accounts for the fact that while the Weather Bureau would concede a low of only 9.8 above zero last week it was zero and below hereabout in the language and the records of those who had to be out in the raw-edged wind.

WHEN eight-year-old Peter Griggs is sent to stay with friends in Sweden, language and country are strange to him and the voyage on the ocean liner is the first he has ever made. Peter, however, is sensible and brave and it is not hard for him to make friends even in a language he does not know.

IF the dance season has been a little on the slow side this year, for reasons which are too obvious to need discussion, at least there will be plenty of activity during the holidays for those who crave choreography. At present the schedule looks something like this:

Once again the National League furnished the baseball fireworks in 1942 but, unlike a majority of the previous dozen years, the senior circuit, represented by the Cardinals, carried more explosive power into the World Series.

While other students have been glad enough to get away from classes during the Christmas holidays, 100 students at Columbia College will continue their studies of their own volition in an effort "to make their college education as complete as possible" before they are called into the armed forces.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- The Morocco radio broadcast today a Turkish report that units of Marshal Rommel's Africa Corps had begun to arrive at Tripoli and there were indications that Marshal Rommel would attempt to evacuate his remaining troops directly to Tunisia to join forces with Lieut. Gen. Walther Nehring.
This has been America's greatest boating year. Yet there have been few regattas of consequence.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 19 -- British pursuit groups were reported to be harrying the Axis rear guard yesterday near Sultan, 135 miles west of El Agheila on the Tripolitanian coast road. There was still no sign of any important enemy rearguard action and the retreating columns were already nearing open country where any stand would be difficult.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Captain Eddie Rickenbacker told today how he outrode death for twenty-three tortuous days on a life raft in the Pacific; then, at the end of his recital, he described the ordeal that American boys are undergoing in the South Pacific and, with almost savage intensity, challenged civilians and production workers on the home front to try to equal their record.

The annual Christmas song festival of the People's Chorus of New York, to be held Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, is dedicated this year to the armed forces of the nation. Many persons prominent in society and musical circles have taken boxes and seats for the event, the fifteenth in the series.

Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday the appointment of Thomas J. Curran, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, as Secretary of State at $12,000 a year. Mr. Curran on Jan. 1 will succeed Michael F. Walsh of Brooklyn, Supreme Court justice-elect.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (Science Service) -- Dive bombers will be able to pull out of their dizzying plunges with less trouble from the momentarily disabling "blackouts" caused by violent and sudden changes in blood circulation in their brains; such is the promise held out by a Los Angeles inventor, Frederick P. Dillon, on behalf of an automatic pilot's seat on which he has just received United States patent No. 2,304,781.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 19 -- Swedish-German commercial negotiations, which began in Berlin last November, led to no results because the Swedish delegation refused to grant to Germany a commercial credit of 100,000,000 kroner, but they were resumed in Stockholm on Dec. 12 and ended with the signing today of a commercial agreement for 1943.

MUSSORGSKY'S "Boris" will be done on Wednesday afternoon, Dec. 30, at the Metropolitan, as a benefit for the Near East College Association. At this initial performance of the revival the cast will include Ezio Pinza in the title role, Rene Maison as Dmitri, Kerstin Thorborg as Marina and Salvatore Baccaloni as Varlaam.

Breeders of pure-bred dogs, exhibitors, handlers, fanciers and the millions of dog lovers in this country may look backward over the first year of our participation in the war with keen satisfaction in a job well done.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The threatened strike of 4,500 elevated railroad employes, which would have tied up the Chicago Rapid Transit Company's system at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow, was deferred today at the request of the War Labor Board.

WHILE enumerating the different musical versions of the immortal "Faust" story, Mr. Downes has forgotten to deal with one of the last tentatives to solve the operatic problem of the legend: Ferruccio Busoni's opera "Dr. Faust."
TO thousands in the city, Christmas would be bleak if there were no Fund for the Neediest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Political pressures caught up with America's first Price Administrator this week, and Leon Henderson, ascribing poor health as the reason, turned in his resignation to President Roosevelt. Although it has been known for some time that the boss of the Office of Price Administration was carrying on his duties despite eye trouble and a sacroiliac condition, few credited the official version as the true reason for Mr. Henderson's retirement.

Germany is "combing occupied Europe to get supplies for Germany's Christmas table," the British radio said in a broadcast recorded yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System, which gave these details:

FOR many years Wanda Landowska, whose Monday afternoon recitals are a notable feature of WABC's schedule, has been known to the music world as a great harpsichordist, a scholar, a musician whose skill and devotion have made music of the eighteenth century and earlier sound frequently more contemporary than many a work written only yesterday.

THE American composer Henry F. Gilbert wrote to the League of Composers at its inception in 1923. "I have been somewhat of a pioneer in American music, and that fellow usually has a hard time." We little thought then how often we would quote him during these twenty years.
The woman worker living at home must spend about $347 more this year to pay her taxes and maintain an adequate living standard than during the period from Sept. 15, 1940, to the same day of 1941.

AN EAST COAST PORT, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- An Italian and a German submarine sank sank a medium-sized British merchant vessel in the Atlantic off the northern coast of South America in mid-November with the loss of two lives, survivors reported today.

IF you recall, this department's first report on the Artists for Victory show at the Metropolitan Museum (published have two weeks ago) was perforce based on a preliminary inspection, with the material only in part installed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19 -- Heinrich Roedel, described by Federal agents as a former Nazi Storm Trooper, was convicted today of trying to sabotage one of Henry J. Kaiser's shipyards and sentenced to thirty years in a Federal penitentiary.

With a view to making available a fund for the use of corporations in the transition period, when war production facilities must be converted into peacetime facilities, the Congress provided in the 1942 Revenue Act for a post-war credit of 10 per cent of the amount of excess profits taxes paid during the war period.
SANFORD, Fla., Dec. 19 -- "Baseball, the national sport, will emerge from this war more popular than ever before, in my opinion," President Bob Quinn of the Braves declared today.
A THREE-YEAR incubation period was what Susan Peters, the screen newcomer in "Random Harvest," designated for herself when she passed her screen test with flying colors and was signed to a contract.

THOUGH he no longer has a youth orchestra, Leopold Stokowski is still interested in imparting his ideas about music and orchestral playing to young musicians. This season he has hit on a new plan. He has decided to offer his services free to a few selected schools and colleges that have orchestras.

THE irresistible appeal of beautiful antique furnishings will be felt by those who visit the Loan Exhibition of French and English Art Treasures opening this afternoon at 2 o'clock at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. It is for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services and was installed under the direction of Mme. Louis Jacques Balsan, chairman of the exhibition committee.

For nineteen years, since he walked away from an Arkansas prison farm while serving a three-year term for burglary and grand larceny, James T. Owens has lived a normal and respectable life as Philip Sullivan, machinist and handyman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The current lull in the battle of the South Pacific marks the end of one small phase of our war with Japan that military observers here feel should be considered only as a prelude to major action rather than a victory in itself.

Rebecca Finn, 17-year-old Boston coloratura soprano, made her concert debut in this city yesterday morning when she appeared at the second of the season's young people's concerts to be presented at Carnegie Hall by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Germany has abandoned the pretense of seeking French "volunteers" to work in Germany since the invasion of unoccupied France and has begun taking men by violence, Fighting French headquarters here said today.

With only five days remaining in which gifts can be speeded to the Neediest Cases Fund before Christmas, the thirty-first annual appeal on behalf of the most distressed men, women and children in the city known to eight leading private charities rounded out its second week with a total of 4,052 contributors who have given $122,946.88.
The entry of the United States into the war following the 1941 college football season raised a big question mark over the future of the sport.
What is happening to the 5,000,000 Jews of German-held Europe, all of whom face extermination, is described in a statement released yesterday by the United Nations Information Office.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 19 -- With Walt Budko, a freshman, contributing 25 points, the Columbia basketball team opened its season under a new coach, Cliff Battles, and defeated the Brown quintet tonight, 57 to 52.

The three main objections of the apparel industry to Maximum Price Regulation No. 287, issued last week by the OPA to govern the pricing of women's, misses' and children's Spring apparel, center on the record-keeping, selling price and margin "squeeze" provisions, according to Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association and chairman of the legal and legislative committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

THE Sadler's Wells ballet was having a successful tour in Holland when the German hordes invaded that unhappy country. The English dancers escaped after thrilling adventures, though not without some loss. Properties, scenery, costumes and even scores had to be left behind with the result that the company's repertory has been ever since less varied than it was.

Cuttings from some evergreens may be sprouted in moist sand, and longer branches may be sprouted by the layering method, but I doubt if it is usual to have large branches sprout in water, without chemical aid.

MOSCOW Dec. 19 -- The Red Army's attitude toward the enemy and the Russian estimation of the German's fighting capacity varies according to experience. Pilots, for instance, to whom I have talked have a high opinion of the ability of fighter pilots in the Luftwaffe.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Dec. 20 -- Allied shock troops, smashing through a belt of heavy field fortifications, have wrested the Cape Endaiadere area from the Japanese along the northeast coast of New Guinea, while heavy bombers sank a Japanese light cruiser off the coast to the northwest, General MacArthur's headquarters reported today.

Have a substantial reason for journeys, buy tickets early, travel light. This is the Yuletide advice of transportation officials at this holiday season. The Office of Defense Transportation lays emphasis on "the need" for travel. Don't make a journey unless there is real need for it, is the word passed out by the ODT.
MY pop used to say, "It looks like white Christmas, Jim." I can tell you one thing, it won't be a white Christmas here.

Experiments are being made with food which is both dehydrated and compressed. The additional space saved by compression ranges from 30 per cent for dried whole milk to 80 for cream of cabbage soup. The bricks are wrapped in cellophane, which is then heat-sealed against moisture and germs.

The Rev. Harry C. Graham, national director of the Holy Name Society, in reporting yesterday on the society's war work, asserted that "never before in modern history have men marched to war so cognizant of the necessity for spiritual supplication."

To those who are most deeply interested in the Hundred Neediest Cases it sometimes seems that another list of "cases" might be drawn up. It would be a list that would warm anybody's heart, because it would include thousands, not hundreds, whose need to help others was greater than their need, or desire, to spend money on things for themselves.

When New York's first electrical show was opened, toward the close of the last century, Nikola Tesla exhibited a small submarine in a tank which he controlled by what was called "wireless." Since then we have had similar demonstrations of the ease with which unattended machines can be started, stopped and otherwise directed at a distance.

The crisis that developed suddenly last week in the gasoline supply situation on the Atlantic Seaboard resulted mainly from the necessity of forwarding to the fighting front in North Africa additional oil supplies from the nearest source. Another contributing factor, particularly in the New York metropolitan area, was the greater use of the limited transportation facilities for bringing in larger quantities of light and heavy fuel oil supplies for the Winter.

Among the desert plants of tropical America, none are more beautiful, whether in leaf or in flower, than the Echeverias. Even their foliage has texture, form and color to commend it to the eye, and their flowers are brilliant in hue and graceful in arrangement.

MONTREAL -- Throughout the vast Laurentian ski terrain to the north of this city extensive plans have been completed to carry on the sport during this wartime Winter. All major resorts are being kept open and town and ski schools will be in operation.

CHRISTMAS trade pushed ahead against all obstacles last week toward the all-time record which was predicted for it earlier. How the sudden gasoline ban in the Northeast would affect final results was not clear, of course, but the prospect of a total holiday trade gain of 12 per cent over last year was indicated.

Puccini's "Tosca" received its initial performance of the season at the Metropolitan last night with Grace Moore in the title role. Since last Winter, when Miss Moore first was heard here in the part, both her acting and singing of it have radically improved.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN TUNISIA, Dec. 19 -- Despite the fact that shipments to the Tunisian battle front consist almost entirely of essential fighting supplies, 1,000 sacks of mail containing Christmas presents and letters have been sent, with top priority, to the officers and men in this theatre of operations.
SIDNEY, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- More women are now employed in the sprawling Bendix plant on the edge of this village than there were citizens in the town two years ago.

That traditional symbol of Noel -- a lighted taper in the window -- has fallen prey to dimout regulations. City officials have requested that out-of-door Christmas trees and all Christmas candles (electric or otherwise) which shed their light into the street be extinguished half an hour after sundown.

OWNERS of 16mm. home movie projectors have a unique opportunity of making a lasting Christmas present to thousands of soldiers on overseas duty by donating or selling those machines to the War Department, which urgently needs thousands of them to provide film entertainment -- in many instances the only possible means of diversion -- for our fighting forces.

A "last minute" appeal for holiday gifts for men of the Norwegian merchant marine was sent out yesterday by the Norwegian Seamen's Christmas and Relief, Inc., at 80 Broad Street, which has conducted the campaign in cooperation with the Norwegian seamen's churches in this country.

The Rainbow Room and the Rainbow Grill, two of the city's more popular after-dark retreats, located on the sixty-fifth floor of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, will suspend operation Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by Hugh S. Robertson, executive manager of Rockefeller Center.
Tennis had a year of considerable activity despite the burden of carrying on with the nation at war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A suggestion made by Breckinridge Long as Third Assistant Secretary of State to the American Commission at the Paris Peace Conference of 1919, as disclosed in official papers published by the State Department today, bared apprehensions felt at the end of World War I about Japan's strategic ambitions in the Pacific.

FROM the moment a man enters one of the armed services he is under the constant care and supervision of medical officers. First he is examined to determine his fitness for war duty; then, if he is accepted, every possible precaution is taken to see that he remains fit.

NO important biography of Hitler has appeared since Heiden published a book so complete and well informed that it seemed unlikely any new treatise could do more than carry the story forward to the present time. Mr. Wagner, an Austrian journalist, has certainly not discovered a new Hitler.

BROADWAY'S creative writers are feverishly summoning the muse these days and from out of forgotten archives old plays, scripts, blackouts, minstrel show material -- in fact, everything that comes under the general head of spoken entertainment -- is being brought forth and dusted off.

In what is reported to be the first case of its kind involving the Federal Trade Commission. Miles Laboratories, Inc., of Elkhart, Ind., last week instituted a suit for a declaratory judgment against the commission, contending that the FTC overstepped its powers in attempting to force the company to change its labeling and advertising.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Finnish Government, through its legation here, declared today that Jews were not being persecuted in Finland and that there had been no change in their status.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 19 -- W.H. Lipscomb's Overlin, 2-year-old daughter of Dunlin and On Top, scored her second victory of the meeting and her third in a row when she led throughout to score by two and one-half lengths in the Waterford Purse, sixth and feature event on the closing card today.

DORCAS, competent mother of two lively children, engaging wife of a man with party-giving instincts, feminine head of a maidless household, past mistress of the art of cookery, has a plan for the holidays. It's a schedule that carries her over that hectic span which begins the day before Christmas and lasts through New Year's.

SINCE there has been so much talk about the length of the Shostakovich Seventh symphony and whether or not it has seemed longer when played by one conductor or another, a statistical report seems called for.

Although the cotton futures market continued yesterday the listlessness that had been characteristic for seven sessions, trade buying and New Orleans support worked prices into slightly higher ground for the third successive day.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 19 -- A special communique issued in Rome late today announced that Premier Mussolini on the proposal of Aldo Vidussoni, Fascist party secretary, had signed a decree naming a new national directorate of the Fascist party.

Although wholesale business was less active than in previous weeks, there were a great many telegraph orders for last-minute Christmas items, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The collection, which is the gift to the nation of Joseph E. Widener in memory of his father, the late Peter A. B. Widener, is reported to have been assembled at a cost of $50,000,000. In asking Congress to appropriate $195,000 to pay the Pennsylvania 5 per cent State Gift Tax, however, President Roosevelt gave the estimated present value as $3,900,000.

The "Tannhaeuser" performance given yesterday afternoon by the Metropolitan Opera Association was a presentation of uncommon excellence. Mr. Szell conducted his second opera for New York audiences. To this writer's mind, his overture started mundanely enough, but the second act pulsed with dramatic blood, and the same thing holds true of the third.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- With the early resumption of large-scale operations in Tunisia expected momentarily, the opposing commanders took advantage of the present lull and improving weather conditions today to rush up reinforcements to the Medjez-el-Bab sector, where hot clashes have occurred between advance forces.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, the United Council of Church Women and the Foreign Missions Conference of North America have adopted resolutions advocating that immediate steps be taken to extend to Belgium and other Axis-occupied countries of Europe the relief feeding program now in effect in Greece, according to an announcement yesterday by the National Committee on Food for the Small Democracies, 420 Lexington Avenue.

A German woman who said she would kill her husband if he enlisted in the United States armed forces was among the thirty-five enemy aliens seized in the city and vicinity during the week, it was announced yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, assistant Director of the Federal Bureal of Investigation.

A conversion deadline of Jan. 26 has been fixed for the transformation of oil-burning heating plants of 10,000 gallons or more yearly capacity into coal burners, it was announced jointly yesterday by Charles L. Harding, director in charge of the district office of Petroleum Administration of War; Sylvan L. Joseph, regional OPA director, and John P. Maguire, regional WPB director.

The honor roll of Waacs, Waves, Spars, Wafs, etc., in THE NEW YORK TIMES set me thinking of the millions of women who are tied down by home duties growing increasingly difficult, the mothers of young children whose best service to their country, I believe, consists in keeping their homes functioning successfully.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 20 -- The third great Russian Winter offensive within a month has struck deep into German defenses along the Don in the Voronezh area, and 20,000 Germans have been killed and 10,000 captured, the Soviet Information Bureau said in a special communique today.
That a nation at war -- and this a mighty global, all-out war of unprecedented proportions -- should remain a great nation at play must sound a trifle incongruous, to say the least.
