Passenger car traffic fell off sharply throughout the metropolitan area yesterday, the second day of the emergency restrictions on gasoline sales, but all essential services -- including police and sanitation, transportation of war workers, and milk and newspaper deliveries -- were maintained and had enough gasoline to tide them over to the expected replenishment of stocks tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The national income in 1942 is expected to exceed $117,000,000,000, setting an all-time record, and rise even higher in 1943, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, said today.

The nation last week was feeling, in increasing degree, the pinch of total war. As American military action expanded over the globe men and women of the home front pulled in their belts another notch. Priority must go to the armed forces; civilians must get along on what was left.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Ever since Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, denounced "organizers," certain factions of organized labor had brought into the open their long-standing covert effort to displace him. By "organizers," who the admiral said ought to be "shot at sunrise," he was referring to all those who concentrate on the advancement of special interests regardless of the effects on the war program.

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator and chairman of the Board of the United Seamen's Service, yesterday appealed to American yachtsmen for support of the service's campaign to raise $6,000,000.

You see him here and there from time to time, but too often you do not recognize him. He is usually of military age. If things have been going well with him he is vigorous looking, often, but not always, with a face tanned and toughened by weather. He may have a tense look about the eyes.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 19 -- "Absolutely no civic rights" will be left to Jews in France after a "vast legislative program" concerning them has been put into application. In short, the notorious "Nuremberg Laws" will be introduced throughout the country.
A rebuke to "lovers of force, power and conquest" was contained in a Vatican broadcast to Spain reported yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission. The broadcast said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- French West Africa and French North Africa will be treated increasingly as one by the United States, whose lend-lease aid to those regions probably will take the form of a purely military arrangement under the authority and control of Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, commander of the Allied forces in North Africa, it was learned on high authority here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson of the War Production Board has supreme control over scheduling the production programs of the armed services, it was learned today, by orders more sweeping than an earlier announcement had indicated.

JOHN BRENT, whom we first met in "I'll Eat You Last," has a triple-murder case on his hands. The stage has been set to make it appear to have been murder and suicide, but Brent is not easily fooled. To begin with, he has known two of the victims intimately, and neither the suicide nor the suggested motive for it and the two murders appears credible to him.

On the brink of elimination after losing the first three games of a four-out-of-seven final series, the Toronto Maple Leafs surprised hockey followers by striking back to take four straight from the Detroit Red Wings last Winter. This unprecedented performance enabled the Leafs to garner the Stanley Cup, symbolic of the world professional championship.

Heralded as the two best teams in town, the St. John's and New York University quintets continued on their unbeaten way before a gathering of 17,644 in Madison Square Garden last night. The Redmen vanquished Oklahoma, 51 to 43, for their fourth straight, while the Violet turned back Syracuse, 38 to 31, for its sixth in a row.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 19 -- The way was cleared late today for Tropical Park to open Florida's Winter racing season Monday with a top-grade inaugural program which had been threatened with cancellation because of gasoline restrictions.

A Navy pre-flight school will be established at Wesleyan University, Acting President Victor L. Butterfield has announced. The first contingent of cadets will arrive Jan. 7. The school will be maintained by the Navy as a separate unit to operate independently of Wesleyan's regular liberal arts curriculum.

As thousands of women in New York City join in Christmas work undertaken by local war recreation committees, the Yuletide emphasis spotlights men of the merchant marine. Festivities planned in their behalf should leave no doubt that their heroism is at last receiving due recognition.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Quirino Beltram, president of the International Edge Tool Corporation at 43 South Sixth Street, said tonight that as "a citizen of heaven" and "a follower of the New Testament and its teachings" he had steadfastly refused to manufacture anything destined for use in the war.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- So complicated are the drug industry problems created by the war that the National Association of Retail Druggists is considering setting up a special department or division to cope with them, it was learned today.

Funds for medical aid and for the United Nations War Relief to be distributed by the Maple Leaf Fund will be raised by an entertainment on Jan. 25 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to be given by the Canadian Club of New York.
MY thanks to Mr. Downes for his article in last Sunday's TIMES.

NOT the most modest of the arts, the broadcasting business frequently gives its public to understand that every day is Christmas Day; and that they (the broadcasters), far from being the soulless executives described at a Federal Communications Commission hearing, are in point of fact a group of roly-poly Santa Clauses, fairly bursting the year-round with gifts for their little friend, the radio listener.

ANKARA, Dec. 19 -- The latest edition of the News and Picture Magazine Parade reaching Turkey bears on its cover a picture of a waggish, steel-helmeted British Tommy leaning on the sill of a shattered window somewhere in Sidi Barani, in mimicry of a suburbanite at a railway station, purchasing a ticket for Tripoli.

MONTREAL, Dec. 19 -- The Montreal Canadiens and New York Rangers battled to a 1-1 deadlock in a National Hockey League game before 4,000 spectators at the Forum tonight. The result was that the Rangers remained in the cellar, 3 points behind the Canadiens.

THE year about to close has brought fewer newcomers to philately's gallery than any other twelve-month calendar period in recent times. Normally the world's governments pay postal homage, during each year's course, to more than a hundred persons not before associated with the hobby, but 1942 has brought this honor to scarcely more than half the customary number.

Omer B. Becu, American representative of the International Transport Workers Federation, who returned to this country last week after a lengthy absence abroad, said yesterday that British public opinion is tremendously impressed with American feats of production, particularly in the shipyards.

A NORTH AFRICAN PORT, Dec. 19 -- "It is getting dark. You see a phosphorescent wake. So you ram it. That 'sub' is bigger than you are and you wonder whether it is going to be your bow or the 'sub's.' He bangs on underneath you, then goes straight down."

The recent episode in the Supreme Court of the United States in the Aluminum Company case, when the Chief Justice and three justices recused -- that is, declined to sit (probably by reason of the fact that some phase of the case had been before them when officials of the Department of Justice) -- presents an interesting situation.

THE second annual Town Hall Music Forum series will be presented on Wednesday nights, Jan. 13, Feb. 17 and March 31, at Town Hall, under the sponsorship of the Town Hall Music Committee and the Boosey Hawkes Artists Bureau, Inc.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Dec. 19 -- As the Pacific Coast continued to experience a serious shortage in meats and some other commodities, local headquarters of the Butchers Union said tonight that most of San Francisco's markets were out of meat soon after noon.

CLARE LEIGHTON -- artist in both words and wood engravings -- came several years ago from England to push her roots, as she says, "into their new earth on this American continent"; and during those years she has, as she puts it. "wandered over the South."

IHFACT OF WAI: Bethlehem, Conn., home of 544 people, is a town among the hills and far from the beaten track. It usually has few visitors, except at Christmas time, when outsiders drop in to send their Christmas mail with a "Bethlehem" postmark. Last Yuletide the village postoffice star_ of two had to take on ten more employes to handle 2[75,000 pieces of main.

KENT COOPER'S plain tale of a long international transaction in news-control may not attract the attention it deserves in these days when all reading eyes strain for the latest information about the war. It will attract much more notice when historians sit down to write in perspective the story of these times, for it is an important book, dealing with matters whose very meaning only a few understand nowadays.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Liberal buying of wheat futures by brokers who act for houses with Northwestern and Southwestern mill connections ran prices to the highest levels of the season today. December took the lead, going to $1.37 a bushel at one time, or 1/2 cent over May in contrast to a discount of 5 cents a short time ago.

MENTION Custer's last fight, on the Little Big Horn, June 25, 1876, to any group of Americans and, unless some specialist in Western history happens to be present, the only Indian name that is likely to be spoken in connection with the tragic event will be that of Sitting Bull.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- The granting of additional powers to the State War Council, so that it can act without statutory restrictions to meet emergencies which may arise when the Legislature is not in session, is being considered by some of the principal Republican legislative leaders.

Possibility that the Office of Price Administration will soon provide relief for importers of finished goods of all types was being seriously discussed in trade circles last week following issuance by the agency of its Revised Supplementary Regulation No. 12 which permits "industrial users" to add increases in total landed costs to their March ceiling prices.

A study of the records of 555 boys referred by the Children's Court to the Big Brother Movement reveals that only 101, or 19.9 per cent, have "backslid" from time to time or readjusted themselves slowly, if at all.

Four hundred children of dead members of the Police Department, boys and girls from 5 to 14 years old, shouted with glee at the antics of a magician, enjoyed the singing and dancing of children of their own age and cheered Mayor La Guardia yesterday at an annual Christmas party for their benefit.

Having hitched his own little wagon to Hitler's fading star, Laval now parrots Hitler's battlecry against the menace of Communism, which he declares is threatening France, Europe and civilization. That was to be expected. Communism and conquest were the two talking points which brought Hitler to power in Germany.

Employment of school children on farms most successful when regulated by school authorities according to reports arriving at the State offices of the League of Women Voters from twenty leagues in agricultural centers. These groups have been studying the operation of the Young-Milmoe act, which regulates such employment, during the year's Spring planting and Fall harvesting.
Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, accompanied by Mrs. Rickenbacker and their two sons, Billy, 14, and David, 17, arrived at La Guardia Field at 5:03 P.M. yesterday.

The Committee for Binoculars for the Armed Forces turned over twelve pairs of binoculars yesterday to Lieut. Col. E.S. Davis of the Marine Corps at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, bringing to thirty-one the total of usable glasses it has collected in a month.

Milton Solomon, lawyer, former deputy controller and Democratic candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen in 1933, who was accused last month by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, of attempting an $8,000 shakedown in connection with a bill then pending in the City Council affecting the stirrup pump market, was indicted by the New York County Grand Jury late Friday afternoon for attempted larceny in the first degree.
Mrs. Jane Vaughn Sullivan of Philadelphia retained her women's national figure-skating title at Chicago last February.

The original high altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral was consecrated in a new setting yesterday morning by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman at the Fordham University Church on the Bronx campus. The marble structure, which was replaced last May in the Cathedral by a new altar and baldachin, was presented recently to Fordham by the Archbishop, who is a graduate'of the university.

WORD reached New York from Rome last week that Italy some months ago commemorated the 2,000th anniversary of the birth of Titus Livius (59 B.C.-A.D. 17) with four semi-postals: 20-centesimi plus 10c red, 30c plus 15c brown, 50c plus 25c violet, 1.25-lire plus 1L blue.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- Two murder convicts imprisoned years ago, one as a boy of 15 and the other at 68, were among fourteen State prisoners to whom Governor Poletti granted Christmas commutations and freedom today.

With the cooperation of the United States Office of Education, New York University has organized an intensive retraining program for members of its own staff and other faculties in New York City. To meet the growing need for skilled instruction in mathematics, physics and allied sciences, faculty members, from instructors to full professors, are going back to school.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Small warships from the French fleet at Dakar already are being used to escort Allied convoys both in the Atlantic and in the Mediterranean, Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunninghan, Allied naval commander in North Africa, revealed today in an optimistic survey of the shipping situation in this war theatre.

MR. WILLIS burst through the red curtain into the Santa Claus relief booth. He hollered, "What's the matter with all the reindeer in here? My goodness alive." Mr. Goode, the second-string Santa, patted his mustache and wig, pulled his pants deeper into the shiny black leggings and stomped on to the set in Mr. Willis's place.

FURTHER extending a service which has grown fivefold in the past ten years, London is now adding more fine music to its European transmissions with three 15-minute periods devoted daily to one special country. Sunday it is "Music for Sweden"; Monday, "Music for Yugoslavia"; Tuesday, for Holland.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 20 -The Russians announced new successes today. A special communique of the Soviet Information Bureau reported an advance on two fronts on the right bank of the Don River, near the point where it begins to flow eastward. [The Don turns east near Kalitva, about twenty-five miles west of Boguchar.]

THIS Spring will mark the tenth anniversary of a ceremony that symbolized the death of civilization in one of the leading countries of our time. It was on the tenth of May, 1933, in a drizzling rain that the Nazis made a public bonfire of some 25,000 volumes in the square before the University of Berlin.
TORONTO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Boston's Bruins retained their three-point margin at the top of the National Hockey League tonight by battling Toronto to a 3-3 deadlock at Maple Leaf Gardens.

The browning of evergreens in early Fall, especially arborvitae and chamaecyparis, always startles and alarms the gardener unless he knows the cause. In dry seasons this browning often occurs in September in the northeast, while the deciduous trees are in full leaf.

IN a single year, the American public spends more than half a billion dollars on cosmetics. In 1941 -- the biggest year in the history of the industry -- $517,500,000 in cold cash was spent on paints, powders and perfumes. And there is every indication that 1942 will surpass that figure.

After tonight's hockey game between the Rangers and Toronto, Madison Square Garden will be closed until Saturday night while the famous sports plant has its heating and power units converted from oil to coal burning units. Two nights of amateur hockey, scheduled during the week, have been shifted to other dates.

Captain Walter E. Reed of Oaklyn, N.J., master of a tanker of torpedoed off the Atlantic Coast last Spring, received yesterday the Maritime Commission's Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal for bravery.

With 164 faculty members and administrative officers having resigned their positions or been granted leaves of absence to enter some branch of war service, a survey made public yesterday by the City College Bulletin, the school's official publication, disclosed that 20 per cent of the college's normal day and evening session staffs were either in the armed forces or employed by the government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Passage by Congress Tuesday of the Federal Overtime Pay Bill raised the morale of government employes from a dangerously low ebb.

WHAT shall we tell children about the war? It had not occurred to me until recently that American parents and teachers would be deeply disturbed about that question. My first realization of this perplexity came when I visited a Midwest community and was being shown through a new school building.

Four constitutional amendments affecting the courts are proposed in the program of State legislation of the Citizens Union made public yesterday by George H. Hallett Jr., secretary, who will represent the union again at Albany.

Speaking at the fourth Opera Victory Rally, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Walter Nash, New Zealand's Minister to the United States, said yesterday that the people of the British Commonwealth of Nations were fighting for freedom and economic security not only for themselves but for all peoples.

Heavy turnovers in low-priced utility shares for tax-loss purposes increased volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and resulted in the largest Saturday figure since Nov. 7: 372,060 shares. Price movements were irregular and the close was mixed.

BEVERLEY BAXTER, M.P., and probably the highest paid journalist in London, who came from Canada to work for his fellow-countryman, Lord Beaverbrook, and who was his right-hand man for years, is the newest West End dramatist.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Judge Frank J. Merrick dismissed today the suits of two Cleveland Negro women charging three local war plants with employment discrimination against Negro persons.

WHETHER one is speaking literally of individuals or figuratively of a nation one has to say that coming of age and growing up in today's America is more complicated than it was in the Samoa and the New Guinea of which Miss Mead wrote in her well-known earlier books.

Rowing felt the pinch of wartime with the abandonment of the four-mile events at Poughkeepsie and New London. After long discussion and a futile attempt to find a date and place for a shorter race suitable to those interested, the Intercollegiate Rowing Association suspended Poughkeepsie, while Harvard and Yale moved from New London to Yale's two-mile Housatonic River course.

An entertainment, sponsored by the Friends of the Fighting French in America, will be given tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the people of the islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon that were occupied in 1941 by the Free French fleet. A feature of the event will be the world premiere of "Little Isles of Freedom," the film made by Victor Stoloff with the cooperation of the Free French fleet.

Stanford and West Virginia, by virtue of triumphs in the two major post-season tournaments, gained top rank in basketball during the 1941-42 season, which saw the collegiate pastime further establish itself as a Winter attraction of wide appeal.

In the first eleven months of this year the Jewish Labor Committee distributed $328,000 for relief abroad and for "educational activities" here, David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, announced at yesterday's session of the committee's convention in the Hotel Capitol.
WHILE the Council on Books in Wartime's "Pearl Harbor Anniversary'' program was intended primarily as a report to the book industry, it was not without interest to the general public.

An audience of 2,700 jammed Carnegie Hall last night to hear the New York Oratorio Society's 119th performance of one of the greatest art works of all time, Handel's "Messiah." And Albert Stoessel, the conductor, celebrated the 200th anniversary of the first performance of the oratorio by restoring seven sections, making the version far more complete than those presented in previous seasons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- It was expected that President Roosevelt would include in his budget message to Congress next month what he has called "a comparative program for expanding and extending the whole social security system." Yesterday Mr. Roosevelt told reporters at his press conference that he had no plans to ask extensive revisions of the act.

The biggest track and field race of the year was the rush of athletes to the colors. Some departed before the indoor campaign, others at the end of the outdoor season and still others in between. But all things considered, this was an excellent year.

FOR every time a song writer is asked "What's written first, the words or the music?" somebody inquires of a radio director: "How do you make it come out just right?" They are talking about the problem of making a radio program end at exactly the right second, and they seldom wait around to hear the answer.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A Soviet Bureau of Information special communique:

In the poll to determine the outstanding woman athlete of the year the sport of swimming was honored by the selection of Miss Gloria Callen of Nyack, N.Y., a member of the Women's Swimming Association of New York. Miss Callen received almost three times as many first-place votes as any other woman.
CAIRO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

NO great metropolis can be contained between the covers of a single book, least of all that conglomeration of cities called Paris, but suggestions can be made, fingerposts, as it were, pointing in many directions and at many aspects, that will arouse in the sympathetic reader an apprehension of the vastness and limitless boundaries of such a subject.
The importance of an early discussion of peace aims was emphasized by Rabbi Israel Goldstein in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway yesterday.

THE plea made by F.J. Warburg for the adoption of a system of planning by British publishers has started a discussion which has been running for seven weeks, not without some acerbity, in the correspondence columns of The Times Literary Supplement, and in which well-known authors, as well as publishers, have taken part.

Ethelbert Smith said that when people speak of building a planned society or a planned world after the war it only shows how things move in cycles. Because of gasoline shortage the horse-and-buggy is coming back. Because of fuel shortage and an old-fashioned Winter the old woolen underwear is coming back.

As a prism catches the light and separates it into colors delicately gay and clear, so in "Bright Morning" Mrs. Bianco has captured the quality of early childhood, when sensation is keen and every experience intensely personal and absorbing.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Mrs. Frances Stevens Hall, one of the most dramatic figures in the unsolved Hall-Mills murder mystery, died at her home here this morning at the age of 68. She had been in poor health for some time and recently had suffered several heart attacks.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 19 -- In a setting reflecting the solemnness and determination of America at war, 570 members of the graduating class of 1943 received their degrees here today at the 242d annual commencement exercises of Yale University, held six months ahead of normal peacetime schedule in conformance with the wartime speed-up of the academic curricula.

Shortages of essential goods in France were becoming more critical, even before the German occupation of the Vichy zone, Mme. Elise Jusserand, widow of Jules Jusserand, World War Ambassador of France to the United States, wrote in a letter to a friend recently received in New York.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Distinguished Flying Cross has beenI awarded to four A_-neriean fliers, the Oak Leaf Cluster to eleven others and the Air Medal to forty, it was announced today by the Eighth United States Army Air Force.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 19 -- A part of the 1,000,000-man army of General Sir Archibald P. Wavell has passed to the attack after months of preparation and has advanced about forty miles into Burma in the first phase of an offensive to reopen the Burma Road to China.

Winter motoring, always more hazardous than that of other seasons, demands special precautions this year. There is extra congestion in the neighborhood of industrial plants, military posts and construction projects. The share-your-car practice -- not yet nearly as well established as it should be in the interest of rubber conservation -- brings added responsibilities because of heavier average loading of passenger cars.

With another year almost at hand the Conservation Department of New York has anticipated the demand for 1943 hunting, fishing and trapping licenses and sent some 750,000 of these permits to various county clerks and district offices.
Squash tennis and squash racquets felt the pinch last Winter as sports dependent upon rubber.

BECOMING more and more cognizant of the legitimate theatre's potentialities, Twentieth Century-Fox, which has offered backing before, now has gone a step farther and will subsidize Jed Harris for an unstipulated number of plays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, said today that the ban in the seventeen-State Eastern area on the sale of gasoline to private motorists would end at midnight tomorrow, but that the value of B and C ration coupons would be cut from four to three gallons to match a recent cut in the value of A cards.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 -- Southern California closed a long and arduous football season with a 21-to-13 victory over the Navy Pre-Flight School of St. Mary's today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Republic Steel Corporation today described as "without foundation" a declaration by Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., that Republic has been wasting nickel in production of armor plate. The steel concern sent a telegram to this effect to James E. Murray, chairman of the Senate Small Business Committee.
Wartime restrictions and weather conditions curtailed recreational skiing last Winter, but competitive skiers indulged in an extensive schedule.

It is a healthy sign that Mr. Willkie and so many others are beginning to speculate about the nature of the post-war world. No one would question the wisdom of continuing to act on the assumption that we still face a long, hard struggle.

ALTHOUGH occasionally it did seem to be slowing down a trifle, time has continued to pass at about the usual rate of speed, so that now once again it is the Christmas season. This corner, following a custom that dates back to antiquity, again looks over the theatre as played upon Broadway, setting down a little about each of the attractions as a guide to the holiday shopper.

Increasing shortages of skilled: manpower in both the factory and the office are gradually removingI the employment of Negroes from! the realm of social reform into that of necessity and with favorable results ill most oases, according to a survey just completed by tile American iV[anagement Association.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Barnard of Bronxville, N.Y., of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Violet Duke, to Jean Rodger Nesbit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean H. Nesbit, also of Bronxville.

John Stanley of Cleveland, with a three-game total of 756, won the singles at the seventy-two-day American Bowling Congress in Columbus, Ohio. However, the National Bowling Writers Association named Johnny Crimmins of Detroit, who has averaged 203.26 a game in ten A.B.C. tourneys, the nation's outstanding kegler for 1942 and Connie Schwoegler of Madison, Wis., captured the national match game title at Chicago.

THERE never has been a Christmas quite like the one that the year of our Lord 1942 will bring. It will be celebrated by American boys keeping their lonely vigil in the bleak fastnesses of Iceland. It will be solemnly noted by others slashing their way through the jungle to meet the Japanese on the steaming little islands of the Southwest Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -German propaganda aimed at the home front now seems to reflect two not quite compatible desires: to frighten the Germans into greater fortitude for a long struggle and to dispel fears of the massive war production of the United States.
MOSCOW, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
Ensign Rumsey Ewing, U.S.N.R., and Mrs. Ewing have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Newport, R.I. Mrs. Ewing is the former Miss Rosalie McRee, daughter of Mrs. Henry McRee of Clayton, Mo.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A communique:

Between January and May of 1942 the Japanese conquered Burma and thereby won a prize comparable in importance to Singapore and Java. The British Crown Colony -- almost as large as Texas with a population of 15,000,000 -- was the last great overland route to China.
Wartime restrictions and weather conditions curtailed recreational skiing last Winter, but competitive skiers indulged in an extensive schedule.

It is a healthy sign that Mr. Willkie and so many others are beginning to speculate about the nature of the post-war world. No one would question the wisdom of continuing to act on the assumption that we still face a long, hard struggle.

ALTHOUGH occasionally it did seem to be slowing down a trifle, time has continued to pass at about the usual rate of speed, so that now once again it is the Christmas season. This corner, following a custom that dates back to antiquity, again looks over the theatre as played upon Broadway, setting down a little about each of the attractions as a guide to the holiday shopper.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Barnard of Bronxville, N.Y., of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Violet Duke, to Jean Rodger Nesbit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean H. Nesbit, also of Bronxville.

Herbert H. Lehman now bears the resounding title of Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations. One wishes a simpler title could have been found. Our Latin-American friends ought not to mind if we call Mr. Lehman's organization the Good Neighbor Agency, thus applying to a larger field an idea that the Roosevelt Administration has tried to work out in this hemisphere.

Although it has met with vigorous opposition in educational circles, the Army-Navy college program, announced by the government last week, is scheduled to begin when the Spring semester opens in February. Despite outspoken criticism, the college and university heads have pledged full cooperation to the military officials.

READY-MADE WALLS -There's an element of legerdemain in the way architects are adapting various materials to new, wartime demands. If there isn't any metal, they dream up plumbing made of glass or plastic. If there isn't any time to waste, they find a paint that dries in an hour, a plaster that hardens overnight.

OTTAWA, Dec. 19 -- Several Canadian newspapers this week have offered the suggestion that if and when the time comes for holding a peace conference Ottawa would be the most suitable place. This suggestion, it is admitted, is in no way official and no hint of it has yet come from the Canadian Government, but it is known that it is being discussed in diplomatic circles.

Hedges that require constant clipping and care will be out of favor for the duration. But the home owner who has a new hedge to put in or an old one to replace need not feel that, because he does not like the prospect of trimming privet, his ground must go hedgeless.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Vital food problems throughout this country and the United Nations are being complicated by "a nightmare of waste" of milk and a loss of shipping space for all basic edible commodities through tardiness in full-scale addition of dehydrating processes, the Senate Military (Kilgore) Subcommittee on Technological Mobilization was told by nutrition and research experts today.

Despite the fact that harness racing was curtailed to some extent because of the war, the sport thrived sufficiently in 1942 for Will Gahagan, Trotting Horse Club of America executive secretary, to announce that all important stakes would be renewed next year.

THE second wartime Christmas will be observed by radio with programs of every type -- some serious, befitting the somber mood in many quiet homes, others in the vein of laughter and modern music to entertain our troops here and abroad.

The beloved Christmas of song and story can live only in the hearts of sorely tried men this war-debauched year -- except in the privileged Americas. So we of this undespoiled continent are doubly charged with the true keeping of Christ's day until all peoples of good-will and indomitable endurance can again join us in traditional homage.

The Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation announced yesterday the declaration of dividends of $14 on its 7 per cent Class A preferred stock and $12 on the 6 per cent Class B preferred stock, both payable on Jan. 15, 1943, to stockholders of record on Jan. 5.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The tens of thousands of enemy patents which have been seized by the United States Government are to be held as a "permanent pessession of the American people" and "their use in the furtherance of any monopoly or cartel system or any similar exploitation contrary to the public interest" is to be prevented.
The City College basketball team turned back the Fort Totten five, 67 to 42, on the Beavers' court last night. The victory was the third for the Lavender in four games.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Attorneys for the Chicago North Western Railway said today that they had asked the United States Supreme Court to approve use of available cash to pay the road's obligation to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Horse racing tomorrow at Tropical Park marks the inaugural of Greater Miami's wartime Winter season. Officials of the Gables Racing Association declare that conditions attending resumption of the sport here are much better than might have been expected.
The metallic clink of the box-office turnover, which had accompanied the thud of padded fists heretofore, was supplanted by the tread of boxers marching to the service of their country in 1942.

The first and only Junior Assembly for this season will be held on Wednesday night at the Ritz-Carlton, which has been its locale for more than a quarter of a century. Having a dance during Christmas week will be a departure from the usual routine in the long history of this series of the most popular dances for debutantes of the current season, and those of the previous Winter.

AN exhibition of posters and original cartoons that have appeared in the labor press recently opened in Room 322 of the New York Public Library. The theme of this display is to highlight the efforts of "Labor in the War," and was collected with the assistance of the Labor Production Division of the War Production Board.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A British communique:

Cotillion figures modernized to the beat of wartime music will be novel features of the Victory Debutante Cotillion and Ball to be given tomorrow night at the Ritz-Carlton. One hundred debutantes of the season will attend the event and many of them will be introduced to society en masse and participate with their escorts in the special dances.

A seven-point wartime crime-prevention program beginning with expansion rather than contraction of community chest funds normally appropriated for crime prevention and morale-building agencies, is recommended in the report of the committee on crime prevention of the American Prison Association.

The giving of plants for Christmas is no novelty for home gardeners, but this year such gifts will be more significant than ever. Never has home meant more, nor at any time has a more concentrated effort been made to preserve its essential beauties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Roosevelt porsonally took up the cudgels this week for an army of more than 8,000,000 strong when he told his press conference in effect that a nation of this size could well support such an army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The trend in structural steel production clearly indicates that the construction phase of the war program is nearing completion so far as steel is concerned, the War Production Board announced today.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York starts its Christmas observance officially tonight with a carol service in the institute's chapel and the appearance of its quartet at Hoffman Island to sing carols. The festivities will continue through Dee. 29, when a dance will be held.

Visitors to a small village in Eastern Pennsylvania are sure to notice the large number of beautiful spruce trees growing around every house in the village and also along the village street. Some of these spruces are twenty feet tall. The townspeople are ready to tell inquiring visitors that the young people of the village have been planting spruces for over ten years, after they had served their hour as Christmas trees.

Despite the recent fire which destroyed much valuable plant material -- including orchids, begonias and poinsettias -- in some of the greenhouses at the New York Botanical Garden, the annual Christmas display will be as colorful and interesting as ever.

Lieutenant Joseph Bell of the Army Air Forces died when his pursuit plane crashed near Moore Field, Texas, on Friday, his relatives in Wetumpka, Fla., and New York City were advised yesterday. Lieutenant Bell was 23 years old and was graduated from West Point last June.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Roosevelt porsonally took up the cudgels this week for an army of more than 8,000,000 strong when he told his press conference in effect that a nation of this size could well support such an army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The trend in structural steel production clearly indicates that the construction phase of the war program is nearing completion so far as steel is concerned, the War Production Board announced today.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York starts its Christmas observance officially tonight with a carol service in the institute's chapel and the appearance of its quartet at Hoffman Island to sing carols. The festivities will continue through Dee. 29, when a dance will be held.

WHILE the War Manpower Commission is reportedly considering classifying some categories of film workers as essential civilians, the Motion Picture Producers Association this week announced that 4,000 of the industry's 18,000 male workers have been taken into the armed services.

Over a war-torn Summer, yachting, in the form of sailing, surpassed expectations. There were those who, last Winter, could foresee only a murky future on the water. Others were determined to take a plunge.

Blanking its rival in the first quarter and then permitting only two field goals in the second chapter, the smartly drilled La Salle Academy basketball team conquered St. Peter's High of Staten Island, 42 to 23, in one of the contests on the scholastic basketball quintuple-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Office of Price Administration administered a shock to millions of motorists in seventeen Eastern States and the District of Columbia on Friday, this week, when, after some brief preliminary warning hints, it ordered gasoline retailers in this area to refuse "until further notice," to honor any gasoline rationing coupons except T coupons for commercial vehicles and one coupon of any type needed for emergency use in necessary driving.

IT is a matter for deep gratitude that Alfred McIntyre, who contributes a sprightly foreword to this volume, should have remembered his own enthusiasm at 9 years of age for the story of Prince Prigio and decided that it might well be reprinted with drawings by Robert Lawson, an illustrator eminently fitted for the task.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- In the first raid since Dec. 11, American bombers resumed their pounding of Japanese shore installations on the Aleutian Island of Kiska, the Navy reported today.

THAT old bugaboo of the movies, prohibitive censorship, has been making itself a bloody nuisance in certain respectable quarters these past few weeks. First the new Noel Coward picture, "In Which We Serve," got the edge of the blade from the gentlemen of the Hays office for a couple of "offensive" words.

ALGIERS, Dec. 20 -- Colorful French African troops have retaken the town of Pichon on the eastern flank of Tunisia, it was reported today, as official announcements here indicated increased French military and naval participation in the African campaign.

Somewhat staggering and at the same time reassuring is the recent report from the University of Cincinnati noting that in the last fifteen years 40,000 Doctor of Philosophy degrees have been awarded to deserving scholars by the colleges and universities of this country.

Announcement of the Army-Navy program for the higher education of picked youth of college age should end the doubt and indecision that have been apparent on most campuses since the 18-year-olds were brought within the scope of Selective Service. Students and faculties now know about what to expect and can lay their plans accordingly.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Police Lieutenant L.O. Ecklund said that the body of Byron D. Chandler, 62, millionaire spendthrift well known on Broadway early in the century, was found floating today in Lake Worth with a bullet wound in the chest.

The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America yesterday issued a declaration condemning the ruthless persecution of the Jewish people in Nazi-occupied countries and denouncing "the violence and inhumanity which Nazi leaders have publicly avowed toward all Jews."

Five million copies of an illustrated booklet "How You Can Help Keep Wartime Prices Down!" have been released by the regional Office of Price Administration, it was announced yesterday by Leston P. Faneuf, regional administrator of the OPA information division.

A resolution voicing the gratitude of the 500,000 organized Jewish workers in the United States and Canada to President Roosevelt and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, for their "humanitarian aid" to the Jews of Europe, was unanimously adopted at the closing session of the annual convention of the Jewish Labor Committee yesterday at the Hotel Capitol.

CAIRO, Dec. 20 -- Enemy columns still were east of Buerat el Hsun, 135 miles from El Agheila, yesterday, but information received today indicates the Germans are being severely mauled. It is now certain the Allies won an important victory when they split the Nazis at Wadi Matratin and that the fighting around Nofilia went in favor of the British pursuit groups and resulted in further enemy casualties.

Creation of a regional office of war transportation for the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area to coordinate the policies of nearly a dozen existing government agencies was recommended yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Hedging sales of oats futures against purchases of Canadian grain gave the market for oats on the Board of Trade a relatively weak undertone last week, and prices held within comparatively narrow limits, the close being 5/8 to 1 cent a bushel higher, with December at 52 3/8 cents, May at 54 1/8 to 54 1/4 and July at 53 5/8.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 20 -- Robert D. Murphy, tall diplomat whose liaison work with the French greatly lessened hostilities at the time the Allies landed in North Africa, has received the rank of Minister from President Roosevelt, Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Commander in Chief here, announced tonight.
Yale made a clean sweep on all four boards to defeat Harvard, 4-0, and regain the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League championship at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

New regulations designed to increase public safety in night clubs, dance halls and other places of assembly have been prepared through joint efforts of the Police, Fire and Building Departments, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Senator Capper declared today that he thought Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, was "wrong in classiflying The Associated Press as violating the anti-trust laws."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- The United Gas Improvement Company, oldest public utility holding company in the United States, has submitted the details of a plan providing for its eventual dissolution with the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was learned tonight.

The Allies assumed the initiative on two new fronts last week as the Axis High Command apparently was reaching decisions of far-reaching importance in a series of conferences in which Pierre Laval participated.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The stock markets last week experienced their dullest week in nearly three months. On some days the number of bargains recorded shrank to the lowest level since September. This slackness is seasonal, with investors large and small throughout the country being preoccupied with preparations for Christmas and the year-end.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 20 -- The Treasury Department has commenced a nationwide distribution among income tax payers of a notification announcing compulsory subscription for war bonds, commencing Jan. 1, it was disclosed today.

Women in the occupied countries of Europe -- housewives and teachers, factory workers and school-girls -- are risking not only deportation to Germany for forced labor but their lives in an effort to resist Axis aggression and the spread of fascist education in their native lands, according to recent reports from abroad.

This will be a wretched year for Santa Claus, and already the children are worrying about it. In other years it naturally was they who insisted no blaze brighten the fireplace on Christmas Eve, lest the gentleman get a bad burn coming into the house. In other years that seemed fair enough, but this time some one almost certainly will be offended.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 20 -- American forces in New Zealand laid plans today for the publication of their own newspaper and are pushing regional surveys in an effort to determine the likely circulation. Unexpectedly high printing charges here made the promoters feel it desirable to ascertain the support likely from those in this country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Calling for a restoration of constitutional government in Hawaii "consistent with the defense of the islands," Delegate-elect Joseph R. Farrington, Republican, of Hawaii, said tonight that the continuance of military rule was not only contrary to every American tradition "but in fact is a positive detriment to the total war effort."

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20 -- Steel ingot output last week in the country as a whole again was unchanged at 99.5 per cent of rated capacity. Primary steel operations are expected to continue throughout the Christmas holiday and, while some finishing mills may be down for a day this week, practically all companies will be melting steel.

The Gremlins, those insidious little creatures credited with throwing a monkey wrench into so many well-laid plans, are rapidly becoming a popular advertising theme. Popular Science has started a campaign in which Gremlins confuse the thinking of space buyers, and Jasper, Lynch Fishel has prepared an employe-stimulation campaign for its clients in war work which uses the Gremlin theme.
OTTAWA, Dec. 20 -- Coupon rationing of butter will become effective throughout Canada tomorrow. The ration will be one-half pound per person per week.

Although Ted Williams, in winning the American League batting crown last season for the second successive year, suffered a decided drop from his glittering mark of the previous campaign -- he hit .406 in 1941, against .356 for 1942 -- the lanky outfielder of the Red Sox, now in the service, has ample reason for feeling satisfied with his work.

MOSCOW, Monday, Dec. 21 -- The Red Army, sweeping across the frozen Don valley plains at a sixteen-mile daily, clip, was nearing the key railway junction of Millerovo on the Moscow-Rostov line today after a powerful offensive that has cut the railway and inflicted 41,500 casualties on the Nazis and threatens the entire German Army anchored in Southern Russia.

LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 20 (Reuter) -- The Spanish Foreign Minister, General Count Francisco Gomez de Jordana, announced today the creation of an Iberian bloc, which he said would seek to maintain the neutrality of Spain and Portugal.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 20 -- British troops were officially reported advancing at a point less than sixty miles from Akyab tonight in the continuing "piecemeal invasion" of Burma, which must be freed of the enemy to give effective aid to China's fighting millions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 20 -- "There are in Italy more than 40,000,000 people, who, on the whole, do not hate foreign people, who are not bigoted, who have not an aggressive, nationalistic attitude toward other populations," says Dr. Massino Calabresi, assistant clinical professor of medicine at Yale, who was a resident of Italy until September, 1939.

LONDON, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- Lieutenant Hal Basso, a Connecticut Yankee in the Canadian Army, detailed today the plight of himself and some 10,000 other Americans in the British and Canadian forces who are tired of English cigarettes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that Americans on the home front had broken all financial records in history by subscribing for more than $10,000,000,000 of government securities thus far in the December "Victory Fund Drive."

Instead of worshiping the manger where the Child of Bethlehem was born, people today are worshiping the scientist's laboratory, the totalitarian state and some messianic leader, the Very Rev. Lawrence Rose, Dean of the Berkeley Divinity School, New Haven, Conn., declared in his sermon yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Red Wings, getting two goals from the demoted Eddie Wares, defeated the Canadiens for the fourth time this season by taking a 4-to-3 National Hockey League decision tonight. The Canadiens, rallying with two goals twelve seconds apart in the last period, just missed tying the score.

Love, even when incarnated in a helpless little babe, is mightier than tyranny and hate, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

German soldiers standing before the new Russian offensive on the middle Don have "shortened their front," while on the central front the Russians are massing for another offensive south of Rzhev, D.N.B. acknowledged last night, according to a German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press.

Leadership, a savior and truth are the basic needs facing the world today and in all these three the practical issue is "Christ vs. Antichrist," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Baptist Church.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 20 -- Ambassador George S. Messersmith praised Mexico's war effort today and stated that never had the relations between and the United States and Mexico been on a firmer and more friendly basis.
New Yorkers found themselves stretching their dwindling fuel supplies to the limit yesterday as they shivered through the city's coldest Dec. 20 in the history of the local Weather Bureau.

Answering a charge made Saturday by the Finnish Legation in this country that the Swedish trade union daily, Arbetaren, was "Communist" and spreading "false rumors" in accusing Finland of being anti-Semitic, Kurt D. Singer, United States correspondent for Arbetaren charged yesterday that the Finnish Legation was spreading pro-Axis propaganda in attempting to cover Finland's anti-Jewish activities.

LONDON, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- Anton A. Mussert, the leader of the Netherland Nazi party, said in a broadcast over the German-controlled Netherland radio tonight that, if the Germans allowed him to form a puppet government, he would raise a Netherland army not only to fight the Russians but to help oust the United States from Africa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Donald M. Nelson declared today that he was doing all he could as chairman of the War Production Board to strengthen small business because he regarded it as the backbone of "independent enterprise," which must "not only survive but also become a stronger, more effective force in economic life" if America was "to win the peace as well as the war."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 18 (Delayed) -- Francoise Rosay, French stage and motion picture star who escaped from German-occupied Tunis and has reached a city in the rear of Allied lines, told today how the Italians arrived in Tunis like conquerors, "just as if they had taken the whole country."

I was much interested in the statement of Dean Furniss of Yale in THE TIMES of Dec. 6 concerning the courses organized by the university to prepare young men and women for post-war rehabilitation work in the war-torn countries, and the similar statement of Professor Kotschnig in THE TIMES of Dec. 13.

The sixth annual Wright Brothers' lecture delivered before the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences is another reminder of the almost incredible progress of aeronautics since that blustery December day, thirty-nine years ago, when Wilbur and Orville Wright demonstrated the practicability of powered flight at Kill Devil Hill.

One hundred and sixty residents of College Point in Queens risked frostbite if not pneumonia yesterday to give a unit of the North Shore-Long Island Division of the Coast Guard Auxiliary practice in carrying out an over-the-water evacuation of civilians from a "disaster" area.

Ushering in the Christmas holiday season community and other organizations interested in the welfare of children, unfortunates and all groups whose Christmas otherwise might be drab began celebrations throughout the city yesterday coincidentally with the release of President Roosevelt's annual Christmas message to the Boy Scouts of America.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Ted Lyons, for twenty years a pitching fixture with the Chicago White Sox, has changed bosses at last -- now he is pitching for the United States Marines.

Katharine Cornell will present a revival of Anton Chekhov's drama, "The Three Sisters," at the Ethel Barrymore tonight. Miss Cornell heads the cast, in which the other leading roles are played by Judith Anderson, Edmund Gwenn, Ruth Gordon, Dennis King, Gertrude Musgrove, Alexander Knox, McKay Morris, Tom Powers and Eric Dressier.
When the Cardinals walloped the Yankees four straight after dropping the first game of the world series, they furnished the biggest surprise of the year in sports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Leon Henderson's leading aides in the Office of Price Administration have agreed among themselves to offer their resignations to his successor, it was learned authoritatively today, to give him a clear field for any changes.
MOSCOW, Monday, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Soviet regular midnight communique:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Captain Jerauld Wright, who brought General Giraud from France to North Africa, is the modest son of a famous Army officer, Lieut. General W.M. Wright, retired.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 20 -- The Wilhelmstrasse was tonight interpreting both Adolf Hitler's meetings with Pierre Laval and Count Ciano of Italy at the former's headquarters and the negotiations between Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar of Portugal and Count Francisco Gomez de Jordana, Spain's Foreign Minister, as marking progress in the policy of the countries involved, highly favorable to the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations presented today to Paul V. McNutt, Manpower Director, a seven-point program for "fullest mobilization of manpower" calling, among other things, for a labor voice in the drafting of war workers, "adequate protection" of the rights of "frozen" war workers, and some minimum standards of social security for all workers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The future air of the United States new official guest house. Blair House, is entrusted to the taste of two women, Mrs. Warren Delano Robbins, chief of the foreign service furnishings division of the Department of State, and Miss Gladys Miller, decorative consultant to the public buildings administration of the Federal Works Agency, who are racing against time to renovate the century-old mansion before official visitors start arriving about Jan. 15.

Addressing 1,000 guests who had paid $50 each for dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night, Senator Claude Pepper of Florida denounced the "unspeakable outrages that Hitler has perpetrated against the Jews of Nazi-held Europe" and predicted that the democracies would establish "a free Jewish State in Palestine" after the war.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 108.8 to 109.1. In the farm products index gains in the price of hogs, fruits and grains were balanced against declines in cattle prices resulting in a 0.7 per cent gain for the index.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 20 -- The position of Judaism alongside Christianity in an eventual peacetime world will be discussed at a four-day round table opening here tomorrow in the Hebrew Union College.

Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff," in the Rimsky-Korsakoff version, which has not been heard at the Metropolitan for two years, will be revived on the afternoon of Dec. 30, it was announced yesterday with the release of the Opera's repertoire for the sixth week.

The fortunes of the Rangers continued their adverse trend last night. The cellar-locked skaters suffered another one-sided defeat when they bowed to the speedy Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.
Quick resales of realty holdings in the downtown section of Manhattan have been made by Elias A. Cohen, the operator.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Edward Weinfeld, State Commissioner of Housing and the first administrator of the $300,000,000 housing fund voted by the people in 1938, announced today his resignation, effective Dec. 31.
WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE in China, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- It will be a "make-believe" Christmas for America's fighting men in remote Far Eastern outposts this year.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Dee. 20 -- For the hundredth time in as many years the citizens of this town, regardless of religious faith, gathered in the Congregational Church yesterday afternoon to pay homage to the Pilgrim Fathers and all other American pioneers.

An application by the Consolidated Edison System for permission to start bimonthly meter readings and billings was assailed yesterday by Herman E. Cooper, attorney for the Brotherhood of Consolidated Edison Employes, as an attempt to "impose a concealed rate increase on New York consumers."

The "White Mountains" of Carteret, N.J. -- 4,500 tons of snow-covered and unprocessed tin cans piled so high along the railway that they hide the freight trains that run through the artificial gulch -- became yesterday the center of the latest salvage controversy.

The darkness of the world never has and never will be able to black out the light that comes from Jesus, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

The New York Rovers definitely were not "on" yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. The locals suffered their first defeat on home ice in nine games, losing to the Coast Guard Cutters of Curtis Bay, Baltimore, 5 -- 2. A gathering of 8,731 watched the feature game of an Eastern Hockey League double-header.

The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning that there were people who were planning to give vent to their hatred after the war and seeking to justify their "foolish programs" in the name of Christianity.

In an all-cash transaction, the seven-story warehouse at 447-49 West Forty-ninth Street has been purchased by Warner Bros. for the storage of scenery. The property is 50 by 100.5 feet and was bought from the Manhattan Savings Bank through J.P. and L.A. Kissling, brokers.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

It's still a man's world. At least a man won out in a race to a jewelry counter at one of the leading department stores in the Christmas rush. He was small and energetic and he came up triumphantly clutching a large rhinestone pin with green sparkles in the middle.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Corn, although carried upward by the strength in wheat to the highest prices since mid-August on the near-by deliveries on the Board of Trade, failed last week to attract a broad outside demand. This, brokers said, was because prices are at a level where farmers can get about as much money for their new crop by selling it as they can by pledging the grain for government loans.
NEWTON, Ga., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Trammel Scott, widely known Atlanta business man and former president of the Southern Baseball Association, was found dead of a gunshot wound near this community today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20 -- The new Russian offensive launched from the valley of the middle Don River is reported to have bitten deeper during the past twenty-four hours into the hilly country between the Don and the Donetz that the Germans have held since mid-July.

With the lifting last midnight of the drastic restrictions on sale of gasoline to holders of A, B and C ration books in the East, many motorists in the two latter groups faced the prospect of conserving voluntarily their present supplies of ration coupons -- for a few days, anyway -- to avoid having their tanks run dry.

Asserting that religious leaders in America so far had failed to agree on an answer to the question, "What is the stake of religion in this war?" Professor F. Ernest Johnson of Columbia University said yesterday afternoon that "the confusion has been much greater among Protestants than among any other group."

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 20 -- This city, where the cost of living was formerly lower than in practically any other Latin-American capital, is rapidly becoming one of the most expensive to live in. The change is being felt so severely by the people that the press today announces a meeting of protest tomorrow in which 20,000 workers are expected to participate.

IT was bound to happen. For years Mr. Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick of the Giants paid little attention to Branch the Non-Alcoholic Rickey. Those were the years when Mr. Rickey was with the Cardinals, occupying a first-row seat in the St. Louis front office. But Mr. Rickey popped up not so long ago as the president and general manager of the Dodgers.
WITH ADVANCE FORCES, in Tunisia, Dec. 15 (Delayed) -- This front line is as much unlike the war-torn battlefields of two weeks ago as could be imagined.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A program of engineering in advance for a series of war alcohol plants, the plans for the individual plants to be completed and then laid on the shelf until needed, was announced today by the chemicals division of the War Production Board, acting on recommendation of the Industrial Alcohol Industry Advisory Committee.

Your editorial of Dec. 10, "War Aims," correctly stated that "we are in this war because we were attacked (and) that we passed resolutions of war after war had been made against us." Ordinarily the layman feels that until we say we are in a fight we are out of it, but constitutional and factual history discloses otherwise.

The Rev. Laurance I. Neale, pastor of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, in his sermon yesterday declared that the world gives little evidence of Christ's message.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Informed Chinese circles today cautioned against viewing with "undue optimism" the British penetration of Burma. They doubted that the advance was the beginning of a major action.

The historian may not find it strange that in the last weeks of 1942 anxiety over the peace settlements began to manifest itself among the war leaders and the warring peoples. In the perspective it may not appear premature that the first step toward a United Nations' offensive in Europe should at once stir new or dormant questions in or about the nations to be freed.

With two days of a million shares, average prices on the stock market, which on Wednesday had reached the year's highest for industrial stocks, on Thursday went to the high mark for all kinds of shares. The averages of Thursday had not been matched since the day after Pearl Harbor, in December, 1941.

Many dinner parties will be given before the performance of Chekhov's "The Three Sisters" tomorrow night at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, which has been taken over by the local Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, North Africa, Dec. 20 -- General Henri Honore Giraud, the French military leader, narrowly escaped death in a daring dash from France in a submarine and plane and joined Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower only a few hours before the Allied landings in North Africa, Nov. 8, it was disclosed today.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 20 (AP) -- In a commencement address at the University of Notre Dame today, William M. Jeffers, the Rubber Administrator, warned the 392 graduates against "undesirables hiding behind the shield of patriotism" and against others afflicted with "war melancholia."

Since 1940 Harcourt, Brace has issued at intervals the romans policers of Georges Simenon, the Belgian writer who has lived in France for many years (is still there as far as is known) and who has several hundred books to his credit.

Smoke seeping from a stubborn between-the-walls fire in an adjoining building drove Jules Brulatour and his actress-wife the former Hope Hampton, from their three-floor home at 1145 Park Avenue shortly before 6 o'clock last night. Fireman Harry Richman, 29 years old, smoke-poisoned, collapsed while fighting the smoldering two-and-a-half-hour blaze.

Christmastide finds the baker and his assistants busy with many things. There are the cakes to prepare -- cakes in the French tradition that are termed buches de Noel and that are intended to resemble yule logs. Already three of them -- one measuring about a yard and two perhaps half as long -- are ranged in a front window, forming a tableau that forces passers-by to halt in admiration for a few shivery seconds.

Ernst Krenek's "Variations on a North Carolina Folk Song, 'I Wonder as I Wander,'" received its first New York presentation at the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Dimitri Mitropoulos, who directed the program, had actuated the writing of this new work through a letter expressing interest in the Austrian composer's recent creations, and conducted it in a masterly manner.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 20 -- A two-day political-military conference ended yesterday at Adolf Hitler's headquarters with the Reichsfuehrer presiding and Count Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, and Marshal Ugo Cavallero representing the Italians and Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop, General Field Marshal Wilhelm Keitel and Reich Marshal Hermann Goering representing the Germans.
CAIRO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- Notwithstanding the gasoline ban and subzero weather, this mammoth playground in the city's back-yard today served as the attraction for Winter sports enthusiasts, with emphasis upon skiing devotees.

Corporal Barney Ross, the little round-faced Marine from Chicago who once held three world championships and has been doing fine on Guadalcanal lately, yesterday was named winner of the Edward J. Nell Memorial Trophy as boxing's "man of the year."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A United States naval air group destroyed at least 126 opposition planes, knocked out many strong shore batteries, drove back opposing ground forces and finally silenced the heavy guns of the battleship Jean Bart when American forces moved into French North Africa early last month.

Wholesale buying last week was exceptionally brisk as one of the heaviest holiday seasons in history drew to a close, with many buyers also covering early Spring needs, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
Eight new films will have Broadway premieres during the week. The schedule follows:

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Dec. 21 -- Allied tanks and infantry have launched a general attack on the right side of the Buna front of New Guinea, where, with the Japanese commander reported killed in action, the enemy's position is deteriorating, the Allied command announced today.

Christmas tree decorations made from USO doughnuts, pipe cleaners, cardboard milk containers and other unique and economical sources of supply were described yesterday by Mrs. Maurice T. Moore, chairman of the National Women's Committee of the USO.
Samuel Reshevsky and Isaac I. Kashdan played a draw in fifty-three moves in the ninth game of their match for the United States chess championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel yesterday.

A two-point penological program "to get better results in human salvage at less cost to the State" is advocated by the Committee on Youth and Justice of the Community Service Society in a study released today in the form of a thirty-five-page pamphlet entitled "Prisons Cost Too Much."

Perfume, as has often been observed, is one of the nicest gifts for a woman to get, and the easist for a man to buy. It is small, it is light, and it usually comes in such decorative packages that it needn't even be wrapped and beribboned by the purchaser. It doesn't need to be fitted, matched or initialed.

Through the cooperation of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, a series of twenty textbooks on aviation, designed for junior and senior high school students, has been prepared by a committee of prominent educators, and since September nearly 400,000 of these volumes have been introduced in 5,000 school systems from coast to coast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- Robert P. Patterson and James V. Forestal, Under-secretaries of War and Navy, authorized today the joint Army-Navy production award to forty-three more plants for out-standing work on war contracts, as follows:

AT AN AMERICAN BOMBER STATION, Somewhere in England, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Flying Fortresses and Liberator bombers, making their deepest bombing thrust of the war into Europe today, plastered an important Nazi airdrome at Romilly-sur-Seine with tons of explosives and shot down more than forty of Germany's best fighters that hounded them across France and back to the Channel.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Speedy sprinters will give a flying start to Florida's wartime racing season tomorrow in a brilliant Tropical Park inaugural program.

SALVADOR DALI, the Spanish satrap of surrealism, the man who awoke one morning to find himself famous because he had painted those soft, limp and melancholy watches, has written his autobiography. A far greater genius in his own estimation than George Bernard Shaw and William Saroyan are in theirs, Mr. Dali has told all in 400 large and closely printed pages profusely illustrated with reproductions of his own drawings and paintings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- With an American army occupying much of the northern shore of Africa, ready to invade Europe from the Mediterranean side, the Balkans and Central Europe cease to be remote regions and become, at least prospectively, parts of the strategic sphere where the United States fights its enemies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20 --"Girls' Town," a magazine article by Harry Henderson and Sam Shaw, has been purchased by Paramount and will be adapted to the screen as a vehicle for a number of the studio's feminine players, including Mary Martin, Veronica Lake, Helen Walker, Marjorie Reynolds and Barbara Britton, Paramount has announced.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The weather, which had been unfavorable for air activity the past eight days, broke today and a large force of United States Army Flying Fortresses and Liberators swept across the Channel and blasted Romilly-sur-Seine, eighty miles southeast of Paris, where the Nazis have a large airfield.
CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. James Roosevelt, the President's son, was awarded today the Dominican Republic's highest military medal, the Order of Military Merit, first class.

Under the great vaulted roof of the Eighth Regiment Armory at 29 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, former Governor Herbert Lehman received yesterday honors due him as retiring Commander in Chief of the New York Guard, which he organized.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The British Board of Trades index of commodity prices for November, based on 1930 as 100, was 161.0 compared with 160.1 for October, 155.2 for November, last year, and 98.1 for August, 1939.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The Public Service Commission has allowed an increase of 25 per cent on iron and steel products involving shipments by motor truck of under 5,000 pounds but has refused a proposed change in rates on larger shipments.

The headline on the story telling of the death of Joseph F. Sullivan of THE TIMES spoke of him as "a cyclopedia himself." This was thoroughly accurate, but it was his cheerful, patient and pleasantly agreeable manner when called upon to start a search for some information in his "morgue" that distinguished him to rewrite men, reporters and editors.
MOSCOW, Monday, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A special communique:

LONDON, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- Reports from the Continent said today that, following conferences with Collaborationist Marcel Deat and representatives of Reichsfuehrer Hitler. French Chief of Government Pierre Laval has decided to create a "single party" supporting unlimited collaboration with the Axis.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Some comment has been aroused in financial London by the decision of the United States Government to send silver under the lend-lease program to any one of the Allied nations on the agreement that a comparable amount will be returned to the United States after the war.
Before the shutdown on gasoline the North Carolina Conservation Department reported that 642 hunters participated in the annual Holly Shelter deer hunt.

Miss Stella Richardson, daughter of J_rs. H. Bull Richardson, gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother, 345 East Fifty-seventh Street, for Miss Charlotte Armitage Whitman and Lieutenant Kevin Casey, United States Army, whose marriage Will take place this afternoon.
Harry Ernest Houghton, in 912 5th Ave; Leslie T. Harris, in 2 Sutton Pl So; F.X. Lipare, in 50 Park Ave -- Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Bill Cowley literally jammed in a goal from a scramble in front of the net in the sixteenth minute of the final period tonight to lock the Bruins in a 4-4 tie with the Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game before 12,791.

The sanctification of civilization is the only road to peace, Mgr. Philip J. Furlong, principal of Cardinal Hayes High School, declared yesterday in a sermon at Solemn Mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

Extra fuel, warm clothing and nourishing food to build protection against sickness and to relieve suffering are among the good things that gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund will supply to aged couples and distressed families with young children not only for Christmas, but for the remainder of the Winter. Courage to carry on and hope for a better future go with them, as a quick reference to Cases published herewith will show.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Dec. 18 (Delayed) -- A shock force of Australian infantrymen swept a thousand yards through a maze of Japanese bunkers and entrenchments today, completely occupying Cape Endaiadere and, with the cooperation of American troops, clearing the Japanese from a stretch of palm-covered beachland three to four hundred yards wide leading through to the cape.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Wheat futures advanced last week to the highest prices since 1937 and cash grain to the best figure in more than fourteen years on the Board of Trade as the result of lack of offerings and an aggressive domestic demand for flour.

Lacking new developments in parity and price control, the cotton futures market was quiet last week and price movements were narrow. At the close on Saturday active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 10 to 24 points, or 50 cents to $1.20 a bale, above the levels of the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- Alarmed by an acute shortage of nurses for the home and fighting fronts, officials of four government agencies tonight approved plans for a wartime survey of the supply of skilled nurses and to speed up the training of student volunteers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Army Services of Supply, in charge of the procurement of munitions, ordnance and all types of equipment for the forces, now employs 889,963 civilians, according to Robert P. Patterson. In an announcement today the Under-Secretary of War made known that 42,471 are employed in Washington, while another 10,565 have their headquarters in Washington but operate outside of the capital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- It took just four salvos from the eight-inch guns of the American cruiser San Francisco to blast a Japanese battleship completely out of action in the sea battle of Guadalcanal last month.

The zero weather over the weekend resulted yesterday in modification by the OPA of fuel oil rationing to permit the use of No. 3 fuel oil coupons ahead of schedule. At the same time there was a decided slump in motor traffic despite the lifting of the prohibition imposed last Saturday on A, B and C coupon books.

Heavy transfers of March cotton into the October and commission-house buying in the latter month narrowed the differences in the futures market yesterday. Active contracts rose for the fourth successive session, net gains of 2 to 13 points being posted at the close.
