Changes in the present manner of paying customers' brokers of New York Stock Exchange firms are imminent, it was learned yesterday. Ever since James F. Byrnes, stabilization director, issued orders freezing salaries, officials of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms and of the Stock Exchange have been discussing the matter with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the United States Treasury.

Cigars which formerly retailed at 15 cents each and two for 25 cents, must now be sold at no more than 18 cents straight and two for 30 cents, according to an interpretation received yesterday by the regional office of the OPA from Washington headquarters.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Gilt-edged stocks were firmer in the London markets today, the 42,000,000 South African vesting order having an immediate effect in anticipation of reinvestment orders. Old consols and war loan three and a half per cents gained three-sixteenths, but business remained relatively small.

ATLANTA, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Without comment, the government nol prossed today five indictments charging three officials in the administration of former Governor E.D. Rivers with using the mails to defraud.

Under the challenging title "Prisons Cost Too Much" the Community Service Society has issued a timely report which critically reviews the State's handling of its prison problem. It is disquieting to read that the number of prisoners in this State has increased from 6,692 in 1920 to 18,196 in 1940, and that during this period the State spent $178,500,000 for the upkeep of its prisons.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Dec. 21 -- In the first National Labor Relations Board election ever conducted in a Henry J. Kaiser industry, technical workers at the Permanente magnesium plant, near Los Altos, cast forty-four votes today for representation by the C.I.O. Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians, and nine votes for no union at all.
Christmas parties, always plentiful in this city, went into full swing yesterday with the emphasis on service men and invalid children.
MOSCOW, Dec. 21 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, devotes almost a half page today to a review of the American edition of John Steinbeck's "The Moon Is Down."

OTTAWA, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press) -- President Roosevelt praised the British commonwealth air training plan in a letter to Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King on the third anniversary of the signing of the British commonwealth air training agreement.

The War Production Board has decided to rescind its ban on the use of wool for lounging robes and will issue an amendment to L-130 to this effect some time this week, it was learned here yesterday. Removal of the ban does not guarantee any wool flannel cloth to robe manufacturers, but if they are able to buy some they are permitted to do so.

Acceleration of the Maritime Commission's ship outfitting program for 1943 may move up that agency's textile procurement to a point where it will require precedence over less essential parts of Army, Navy and Lend-Lease buying, besides pinching what remains in the way of civilian supplies, it was reported yesterday by Worth Street textile executives.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- More than 11,000 of America's 400,000 Indians have gone to war and "even greater numbers" have left the reservations to engage in war production, John Collier, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, reported today.
When purchases of gasoline were halted last week there was at least one New Jersey sportsman who thought that there might be an extension of the deer hunting in that State.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A strong demand for hogs from Eastern shippers, who took 5,000 head, produced a buoyant market today. Prices soared 25 to 30 cants and best offerings sold at the highest since Nov. 6. Hogs weighing 190 to 300 pounds were taken mainly at $14.40 to $14.55, with the top $14.60.

The young New Yorker was the toast of yesterday afternoon's fashion party at Lord Taylor's. In the center of the floor a pink Christmas tree proudly raised its head. It was hung in pink metal balls and strung with garlands of popcorn.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- Five members of a family were driven into 20 below zero weather and two volunteer firemen were severely frostbitten shortly after midnight when fire destroyed the ten-room, two-story residence of Earle F. Allen on South State Road.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 21 -- The acquisition by the Princeton University library of a 400-year- old Arabic Book of Hours, representing the first attempt at printing Arabic from movable type, was announced today by Philip K. Hitti, Professor of Semitic Literature.
AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 21 -- Texas, cradle of the great American steer, now can tell you how to get the most out of his meat.
Winter Co. arrives in New York officially at 7:40 A.M. today, but its opening performance is expected to be milder than the dress rehearsals of the last few days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The nation's requirements for lumber, one of the current year's most critical materials, will drop from 40,200,000,000 board feet in 1942 to an estimated 31,100,000,000 in 1943, the Lumber and Lumber Products Division of the War Production Board reported today.
More than four and a half months ago United States marines stormed the beaches of Guadalcanal. Yesterday our forces were still fighting in the steaming Solomons jungles.

Doubleday, Doran will publish next Monday "I Saw the Fall of the Philippines," by Colonel Carlos P. Romulo, the Philippine editor and publisher of a chain of newspapers and a member of General MacArthur's staff. Colonel Romulo was the last man out of Bataan, escaping in a makeshift amphibian named "the Duck" that could scarcely get seventy feet above Manila Bay while the Japanese shot around it.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 21 -- Axis comment on the week-end political-military discussions at Reichsfuehrer Hitler's headquarters was as vague as was further news of the subjects discussed. With a singular lack of coordination, there appeared to be a tendency in Berlin to minimize the presence of the Italians and to play up the presence of Pierre Laval.

Minneapolis, Minn. announced yesterday that it would offer for sale Jan. 5 a new issue of $500,000 of public relief bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1943, and due serially from Feb. 1, 1944 to 1953. This issue is in addition to $2,306,000 of bonds previously announced for award by the city.
BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Shelter and care for Massachusetts residents unable to obtain adequate fuel for their homes was provided tonight in an executive order by Governor Leverett Saltonstall.

The Whitney Museum will close for the Christmas week-end at 4 o'clock Thursday and reopen on Tuesday at 1 P.M. The current exhibition, the 1942-43 annual of contemporary American art, will continue through Jan. 6. The museum hours are from 1 to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Sunday.

Agreement is found with Ab Coleman, Mount Mansfield pioneer skier and director of the Eastern Amateur Ski Association, that one of the benefits arising from travel restriction is a greater appreciation of touring skiing among those who have the opportunity at their backdoors.

WITH THE RED ARMY, on the Stalingrad Front, Dec. 19 (Delayed) -- The Red Army has forged an unbroken arc of iron behind the remnants of twenty-two German divisions in the Stalingrad area and considers their extermination inevitable, together with the consequent liberation of the entire lower Don Valley and the Caucasus.

Reporting on operations of Swift Co. and wholly owned domestic and Canadian subsidiaries, John Holmes, president, yesterday informed stockholders that total production of plants and branches in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 was the largest for any year in its history.

The report of the American Cable and Radio Corporation and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year, made public yesterday by John L. Merrill, chairman of the board, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses, taxes and other charges of $610,963, compared with a net of $625,833 in the nine months to Sept. 30, 1941.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Moroccan radio station at Rabat is now being used by the Office of War Information and therefore the news it broadcasts may henceforth be trusted, according to information reaching the OWI here today.
A lease involving 104,240 square feet of space in 42 Broadway has been signed by the U.S. Coast Guard, through the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., in cooperation with Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department forecast today production of Winter wheat in 1943 at 624,504,000 bushels.

Greatly enlarged to include special sections on the war work of the American aircraft manufacturing industry and on airplane armament, the 1942 edition of Aerosphere, international aviation yearbook edited by Glenn D. Angle and published by Aircraft Publications, was released today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Allied bombers again attacked enemy-held docks at Bizerte in Tunisia last night and large-scale air activity has been resumed in all sectors, a French communique said tonight.

The Long Island University basketball team overpowered the invading Springfield College squad, 79 to 50, on the Brooklyn Pharmacy court last night for the undefeated Blackbirds' seventh straight victory.
In his recent letter to THE TIMES, Andre Istel comments upon the basis for arriving at the percentage of error in a poll prediction of an election.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 21 -- The fate of mankind still will hang in the balance after victory is won, Rabbi Ferdinand M. Isserman of St. Louis declared here today at the opening of a four-day round table at the Hebrew Union College on the role of Judaism in the post-war world.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- The Germans have threatened to use poison gas against the Serbian population unless General Draja Mikhailovitch's resistance in the Balkans ceases, the Yugoslav Government in Exile said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Firsthand evidence that the Japanese intended not only to establish a new order in the East when they entered this war but also to conquer the Americas and Africa if it took a quarter of a century was given to the press today by a young Netherland Royal Navy officer, who learned of the enemy's aims while a prisoner in French Indo-China.

In your issue of Dec. 13 Joseph Hanc has raised a number of objections to my suggestion that, immediately after the war, we proceed to establish a European federation by democratic elections. Mr. Hanc denies that Europe has ever been united. He does not take into account the fact that during more than four centuries Europe, from England to Bulgaria, was united by the Roman Empire.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Office of Price Administration issued regulations today rationing new coal and oil heating stoves in the thirty fuel-oil rationed States, while the War Production Board added gas-fired and oil-burning water heaters to the list of products which may be manufactured next year only for use in war housing and other war projects.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 5 (Delayed) -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower commanded the British fortress of Gibraltar during the first days of the North African operations, thus being the first foreigner in two centuries to control that rock of British Empire.

A defense line, as they understand the word in Libya, is a line which Marshal Rommel refuses to defend. Of these there are apparently an unlimited number in North Africa. Rommel has been in motion ever since General Montgomery broke his defense line at El Alamein.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY, in French Morocco, Dec. 20 (Delayed) (AP) -- Thousands of American soldiers who have been lugging packs and rifles fifteen miles a day for the past ten days and are still 100 miles from their destination are chanting: "Off our dogs and on our backs before Christmas."

Fritz Kuhn, who once was national "fuehrer" of the German-American Bund, has deteriorated to the status of a "common felon" in the eyes of some of his former followers, since his conviction for stealing from the bund. This was asserted in Federal court yesterday, in affidavite through which four former bundsmen unsuccessfully opposed a general trial, with Kuhn and fifteen others, of government actions to deprive them of acquired United States citizenship.

Angna Enters is back, after having skipped a season both in the theatre and in New York's realm of exhibitions. The famous dance mime, whose achievement behind the footlights is unique, will give a series of performances at the Alvin just after Christmas, beginning Sunday evening and concluding New Year's Eve.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Gloria Vanderbilt di Cicco and her husband, Corporal Pat di Cicco, can move their furniture out of Manhattan any time they wish, as their debts have been paid and all pending court cases dismissed. Creditors, seeking to attach the di Cicco furniture left behind when the couple moved away recently, had filed claims of $732.22 in the court of C.A. Kimball, justice of the peace.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 21 -- There is sufficient evidence showing that the German naval and air attache, Captain Dietrich Niebuhr, was directly engaged in espionage to justify the Supreme Court in starting legal proceedings against him, according to a unanimous decision reached this morning by Argentina's highest tribunal.

A corrective movement settled yesterday over the stock market in the wake of the great vigor of the rally last week. Irregularity ruled throughout the session with price changes minor and quotations mixed at the close. Volume contracted sharply from the tempo of recent sessions as transfers on the Stock Exchange fell to 771,176 shares against 1,088,284 shares on last Friday.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Newspapermen have as much right to conceal their sources of information as a doctor has in keeping the secrets of a patient, counsel for the New Jersey Press Association told the State Supreme Court today in defending constitutionality of New Jersey's nine-year-old newspaper confidence statute.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- To an increasing extent Germany is looking to women of the occupied countries as a source of sorely needed manpower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The sudden ban on sales of gasoline as motor fuel was accompanied as usual by minatory words and gestures toward the public by the Washington authorities. This recurrent phenomenon is one of the most interesting characteristics of the present administration and will doubtless come in for considerable attention by the future historians of the period.

There was no mistaking the pleasure of the audience of musicians and connoisseurs who gathered last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall to hear Ralph Kirkpatrick play harpsichord music by J.S. Bach. It was proved no less by the absorbed attention given every sound that came from the instrument than by the prolonged demonstration at the end of this the fourth and last of his present series of recitals of Bach's keyboard music.

The Yankees had to come roaring down the stretch to beat out Brooklyn's bewildering and bewildered Dodgers for the distinction, but it is now official -- the Yanks were the biggest sports disappointment of 1942.

To prevent speculation in furs and an unwarranted boosting of prices, fur manufacturers were urged to delay buying of skins until conditions for 1943 become crystallized in a program worked out by the board of directors of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- A local of the United Steel Workers, C.I.O., today staged a four-and-a-half-hour work stoppage in protest against dismissal of a general foreman, not a union member.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) - Twenty-five thousand fans took time from rooting for their favorite teams this Fall to fill out questionnaires indicating that 96 per cent of them want college football continued for the duration of the war. This was revealed today by John L. Griffith, commissioner of athletics of the Western Conference.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 22 -- -- Russian troops, driving with gathering momentum southwestward from the middle Don River gained another fifteen miles yesterday on the heels of demoralized Nazi troops who are fleeing in disorder and "leaving equipment and military supplies on the battlefield," Moscow announced early today.

Tommy Tolan, a stocky freshman with ice water in his veins, stepped to the foul line thirty seconds from the end of the Manhattan-Syracuse basketball game in the Jasper gymnasium last night and calmly flicked in a free throw which meant a 43-42 victory for the unbeaten Green, its third straight.

Lester E. Jacobi, president of the Schenley Distillers Corporation, announced yesterday that $200,000 in war savings bonds and cash would be awarded as a year-end bonus to employes and fellow-workers in the armed services. Those in the military forces will receive checks, while workers will receive war bonds and stamps, at the request of union and employe representatives.

Newspaper linage figures for November reflect graphically the distortions and extremes brought about by the curtailment of civilian goods manufacturing in the war ffort. Whereas some classifications are close to the 1929 high, others are hitting a twenty-year or more low point.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Governor Charles Poletti declined today to supersede District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher of Westchester County as demanded by Horace M. Gray, chairman of the City Managers League, as a result of a scandal in the city of Yonkers.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 22 -- The Royal Air Force returned Sunday night to its heavy raiding of Germany's industrial Ruhr Valley with an attack by a "strong force" of its biggest bombers, apparently numbering several hundred, on Duisburg.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Farm Mobilization Day, proclaimed for Jan 12 by President Roosevelt last week for the opening of a countrywide effort to attain maximum production of vital foods on every farm, will be observed also by organization of agriculture's demands for higher prices and more manpower and machines, it was disclosed at the Capitol today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A revised draft of a proposed national war service act drawn by Grenville Clark, New York attorney who drafted the original Selective Service Act, is now in the hands of Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, for study, it was learned today.

Governor Charles Poletti was urged yesterday by Harold R. Moskovit, president of the Affiliated Young Democrats, Inc., of New York State, to call a Jackson Day conference of State Democratic leaders next month at which plans could be drawn to "reorganize and revitalize" the party.

A determination that those in greatest need in the city, families and individuals stricken by illness or bereavement, helpless old people and homeless children, shall not be forgotten or allowed to suffer unduly because of the harsh demands of war inspires many gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund.

"New Faces of 1943," a revue with book and lyrics by John Lund and music by Lee Wainer, will open this evening at the Ritz. Leonard Sillman is the producer and will appear in the show. June Carroll and J.B. Rosenberg also contributed lyrics and sketches.

An audience of 2,500 filled the auditorium of Hunter College last night for the free Christmas Festival of the United Nations which was presented by the music unit of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The State Department reiterated today a warning to any person or firm who serves as a "cloak" for another person or firm on the government's blacklist of those believed to be acting in the interest of Axis powers.
Plans of the Dodgers to train at West Palm Beach, Fla., for the 1943 baseball season were summarily canceled yesterday.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company opened officially yesterday its new transcontinental telephone cable from New York to San Francisco as the first completely underground cross-country cable route in telephone history.

Here, for those who have yet to work out the details of the Christmas feast, are some simple suggestions. All have been tried and found true by this department and all may be followed successfully by even the most nervous of kitchen artists.

Contending that MPR 287 in its present form will put many manufacturers out of business and "will waste millions of yards of goods," organizations in the garment industry yesterday pushed efforts to obtain an extension of time on the OPA regulation which governs the pricing of women's, misses' and children's apparel for next Spring and Summer.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- While searching for the crew of a British plane that had been forced down on the Bay of Biscay Friday a Whitley bomber had to beat off an attack of three Junkers-88's and then an hour later an attack by three Fock-Wulf 190's.
MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

AN ADVANCED AMERICAN FIGHTER BASE, In Tunisia, Dec. 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- American Spitfire pilots in this most advanced United States fighter field are operating against the Axis on a working day that starts at 5 A. VL and ends at 6:30 P. M.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A British communique:

Permission for the Board of Health to give pre-induction training courses in four New York City high schools on Saturday mornings, thus enabling health officials to give instruction in social hygiene, was granted yesterday in a letter to Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins from Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Mandatory rehiring of seven members of the Jehovah's Witnesses would precipitate a walkout in a Clarksburg, Va., glass plant, officials of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company told the President's committee on fair employment practice today.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Lieut. Col. Lord Apsley, elder son and heir of the Earl of Bathurst and long a Conservative Member of Parliament for Southampton, was killed in an airplane crash in the Middle East, it was announced today.

HAZLETON, Pa., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Hazleton Shaft Colliery local of the United Mine Workers pleaded today with the Department of Labor, the OPA and President Roosevelt to grant a $2 per day "war allowance before the rank and file take action."

Of the $10,229,000,000 of new government securities sold in the nation-wide Victory Loan campaign, as of the close of business Saturday, sales in the New York Federal Reserve District amounted to $4,765,288,668, according to figures made public yesterday by the New York Victory Fund Committee.

Jose Antonio Arze, chairman of the Leftist Revolutionary party of Bolivia, sharply denied yesterday that his party had been implicated in a reported Nazi plot to overthrow the government of Bolivia, as stated in a United Press dispatch from La Paz published last Sunday.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Smiling and confident but train-weary, the University of Georgia football players arrived, forty-three strong, today for their New Year's Day football clash in the Rose Bowl with the University of California at Los Angeles.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday the appointment of Elliott V. Bell, a member of the editorial board of THE NEW YORK TIMES, as State Superintendent of Banks at $12,000 a year.

A letter from Dr. John E. Wade, city Superintendent of Schools, will be read today to the 36,000 teachers in the school system. In it the superintendent pays tribute to his staff for having borne the burdens of the past year "loyally, faithfully and devotedly."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Louis D. Brandeis, former Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, was lauded today in the forum where he sat for so many years. Chief Justice Stone, Attorney General Biddle and Senator Norris were among those who spoke in memory. of "a great American."
LONDON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- United States soldiers in the British Isles have spontaneously dedicated their first Christmas overseas to the British children.
LONDON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Several hundred spokesmen for city employes appeared yesterday before the City Council's Committee on Civil Employes, urging immediate passage of a local law providing salary increases ranging from 5 to 15 per cent for all employes receiving less than $5,000 a year.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 21 -- Houston, with Secretary Knox and Secretary Jones as the chief figures in the program, devoted today to city-wide expression of special support to our Navy in the war.

An unprecedented exhibition will open this morning at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. In the same building that houses works by Cezanne, Van Gogh and other outstanding figures in modern art, will be shown a shoeshine chair and stools, as colorfully decorated as a Christmas tree.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Secretary Ickes and John L. Lewis today clashed in their views on the responsibility for failure of bituminous coal operators and the United Mine Workers of America to see eye-to-eye on a national agreement to modify the union contract for the five-day-week and seven-hour-day in favor of a work week of six days so that additional tonnage for war purposes might be mined.

WINNIPEG, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press) -- The Hon. John Bracken, Premier of Manitoba and newly elected leader of the Progressive Conservative party of Canada, tonight urged the establishment of under-secretaries to Federal ministers in the Dominion during wartime.

Proverbs are supposed to represent the experience of many generations. How about the one that says "Misfortunes never come singly"? The indignation stirred in every just mind by such a multiplication of disaster seems to indicate its comparative rarity. Yet there is more than one instance among the Neediest Cases.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 21 -- Hampered more by mines and the work of maintaining communications than by enemy resistance, British pursuit groups drove westward slowly but steadily yesterday. The latest reports placed the Allied advance elements about 150 miles west of El Agheila, near the port of Sirte.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Nevada divorces must be recognized by other States, the Supreme Court ruled today by a six-to-two decision, Justices Jackson and Murphy dissenting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Marshall Langhorne, formerly of the American foreign service, in which he served for nearly twenty years, died last night in his home. 2211 R Street, after a brief illness, at the age of 72.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- British forces pushing through the thick jungles of Western Burma have occupied Alethangyaw, only forty-five miles from the strategic Japanese-held sea and air base of Akyab, reports from the front said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Gene McCann, the former New York broker, cannot be released from prison on his plea that he was wrong in waiving a jury trial and acting as his own lawyer when convicted of mail frauds in a trial court, the Supreme Court held today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 21 -- A conference between Hungarian and German officials is taking place in Berlin on the subject of Hungarian participation in Adolf Hitler's "crusade against Bolshevism," according to information received here today.

A German broadcast recorded by the Associated Press yesterday said the High Command had announced that "the Russians had succeeded in breaking into the German defensive front on the middle Don" and that the fighting continued with unabated violence.

General Henri Honore Giraud is bound to prove a blessing to future writers of historic fiction. His two escapes this year are true stories that would have strained the imagination of a Dumas to invent -- and which strain one's imagination even now if one tries to account for every detail of them.

The most terrible Winter that Western man has known in modern times began this morning. We are not thinking of the weather which has brought mild hardships to a great many Americans, nor of the annoyances and deprivations which most of us must undergo as the cold strengthens.

AS our harbinger of plenty, Stuart Chase still sings his blithe songs. His latest is "Goals for America: A Budget of Our Needs and Resources,"* which is the second in a series of "guide lines to America's future as reported to the Twentieth Century Fund." As is always the case with a Chase book, this new one makes for beautifully easy reading.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 21 -- The Newark Police Department has been long on expenses, material and manpower, but short of performance, says a study of the department made by the Bureau of Municipal Research, a non-profit organization supported by public-spirited residents, made public today.

Several inanimate objects, embodying current drama all over the world, took up temporary residence yesterday in glass show cases in the Bronx. They were among 3,000 rare and unusual dolls in a victory doll show, which opened in the Sachs auditorium, Third Avenue and 150th Street, under the auspices of the American Hobby Federation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 21 -- With plenty of American beefsteak, chicken and other fresh food, together with the gifts mailed from home, United States troops in the Middle East will celebrate Christmas in the traditional American manner. They will not necessarily get a vacation, but at least they are certain of being remembered in a number of ways.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- In explanation of the now conspicuous hostility that divides and handicaps the two anti-Axis guerrilla movements in Yugoslavia, it is pointed out in diplomatic quarters that the Russian support and propaganda for the Yugoslav partisans approximately coincided with Russian demands for a second front against Germany to relieve the pressure upon Russia.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Free democracy came to America and to the world with the Pilgrims in 1620, Dr. Frederick L. Fagley of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches, declared today as the denomination observed Forefathers' Day.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, and Irving V.A. Huie, Commissioner of Public Works, are within their rights under the City Charter in holding unsalaried positions as members of the City Planning Commission, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday.

When it became apparent that the rural States were being stripped of too many doctors, and that there is an alarming lack of medical care in over 400 boom towns, questions began to be raised about the Army. Did it need an average of 6.5 doctors for each thousand men in combat service?

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 20 (Delayed) -- Christmas is coming and this big sprawling misty city of Calcutta is welcoming hundreds of American soldiers and officers who will do their best to forget "the black dividing sea and alien plain" that separate them from home.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Dec. 20 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American fliers, striking in support of the Chinese defenders of Yunnan Province, made a devastating attack on the Japanese airdrome at Lashio, in Eastern Burma, today, and left smouldering ruins in the town's warehouse area.

Christmas shopping as reflected in sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a gain of 4 per cent last week, as compared with the same period a year ago, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- A plan for merger of three subsidiaries of the General Gas and Electric Corporation into the Florida Power Corporation, a fourth subsidiary, has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was disclosed today.

Robert J. Bottomly's letter on the subject of taxes and life insurance premiums is interesting and timely enough. It makes certain assumptions as to ability to pay both taxes and premiums, which can be proved only by time.

Gary Cooper and Greer Garson lead the list of the year's outstanding screen performers in the second annual poll of newspaper, magazine, syndicate, news service and radio motion picture critics and reviewers undertaken by The Film Daily to determine "Filmdom's Famous Fives" for 1942.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Dr. H.G. Van Mook, Netherlands Minister of Colonies, today awarded decorations to twenty-two members of the Netherlands East Indies Flying Forces, in training here, for deeds in defense of Holland and the Far East; and to one American flier for heroism in trying to rescue two crashed Dutch fliers.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 22 -- Allied troops, supported by tanks, artillery and planes, have driven a wedge into the main Japanese defense lines in the Buna area of New Guinea, capturing one of the two small airfields in that sector, the Allied Command announced today.

Solicitor General Henry Epstein said last night in Albany that in his opinion the Supreme Court ruling recognizing the validity of Nevada divorce decrees "is a great step forward in securing uniform divorce statutes for the country."

The disturbing element in the gasoline situation of the past few days is not the revelation that a shortage exists but the apparent failure of officials in Washington to foresee when the shortage would become critical and to take steps to meet it. Those steps presumably would have included earlier restrictions on unnecessary use of gasoline and an earlier warning to the public.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 21 -- Columbia announced the purchase today of "Ten Per Cent Woman," a screen story by Erik Charell, as a vehicle for Rosalind Russell. It is described by the studio as a comedy about a feminine agent's chores in New York City. It will be filmed late next Summer.

The public utility holding company situation was thrown into considerable confusion yesterday when it was disclosed that the United Gas Improvement Company, the oldest utility holding company in the country, is actively at work on a plan for dissolution in compliance with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
Yale's chess players, who won H.Y.P.D. League honors from Harvard on Sunday, played to a 2-2 tie with City College, Eastern Intercollegiate League champion, at the Marshall Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Now that the food problem in the United States has changed from one of disposing surpluses to rationing scarcity the disposition of the large food stocks accumulated by the Agricultural Marketing Administration to be distributed through relief channels has come up for review.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- As gasoline went back on sale in Eastern States today after a sixty-hour suspension, James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, began discussions looking toward improvement in rationing machinery to prevent similar breakdowns in the future.
Charles Collingwood, Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent at Allied headquarters in North Africa, reported in a broadcast last night from Algiers:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Complete revamping of the wartime control over wholesale and retail grocery prices, with removal of practically all food items from provisions of the General Maximum Price Regulation, was announced today by the Office of Price Administration.
The C.I.O. has presented to Paul V. McNutt, the Manpower Director, a seven-point program for "fullest mobilization of manpower." The seven points are:
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 21 -- New Zealand's strategic position has greatly improved in the past six months, Lieut. Gen. Edward Puttick, Commander in Chief, said today.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- A strike of 1,000 workers in the strip mill of the Republic Steel Corporation tonight stopped production of steel plate needed for the construction of ships.

CAMP CARRABELLE, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Army's new surf-raiders, schooled to strike from shore to shore and stick, moved thousands of heavily armed men with full equipment thirty-five miles over water to occupy a peninsula in the first big test of the seagoing troop training program here.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Dec. 21 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters, in disclosing that the Japanese commander in the Buna area, Lieut. Gen. Tomatore Horii, was believed to have been killed, released a message of instruction the Japanese commander issued to his troops Sept. 9 when the Japanese were at the farthest point of their advance along the Kokada trail toward Port Moresby.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- Mill demand for cash wheat and futures fell off sharply today, and with some increase in hedging pressure in Southwestern and Northwestern markets, prices turned downward in a hurry after a small advance early had lifted the December delivery to a new seasonal high and 9 5/5 cents up from the inside figure of about two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Preparing for a new Congress "more economy-minded" than the one just adjourned, the Joint Committee on Reduction of Non-Essential Federal Expenditures is laying plans to make the more than $1,000,000,000 of slashes effected during the past year only its starting point" for seeking curtailments reaching into many non-war units of the government.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21 -- The Russian advance from the Don River toward the Donets River is being energetically pressed and the Germans are reported to be retreating southwestward, demolishing houses and public utilities behind them as if they expected never to return.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Anaconda Wire and Cable Company of Marion, Ind., and five of its employes were indicted by a Federal grand jury at Fort Wayne, Ind., today in what Attorney General Francis Biddle called "one of the most reprehensible cases of defrauding the government and endangering the lives of American soldiers and sailors ever to come to the attention of the Department of Justice."

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Herbert H. Lehman, in his capacity as director of foreign relief and rehabilitation, revealed here today the broad scope of the plan under which American food and other relief will be used in efforts to shorten the war and to create a better world when the war is ended.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The men of an American Army division had their reward today when they saw a thousand smiling childish faces and heard a thousand childish voices chorus a lusty "Thank you, Uncle Sam!" at the end of a mammoth Christmas party held at Salisbury for children between 6 and 8 years old.

As she has done so often in the past, Katharine Cornell last evening added another distinguished production to her gallery as an actress-manager, and, what is perhaps more important, to the Broadway theatre of this Christmas week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Harvard astronomers had under observation tonight a new comet described by its discoverer, Dr. Fred L. Whipple, as "the brightest since the Cunningham Comet of several years ago."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned to Dec. 13 totaled 11,742,798 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding linters, compared with 9,914,549 bales a year ago, and 11,430,454 bales two years ago.

Four men were sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to die in the electric chair and two others to life terms of imprisonment for three separate murders. It was the first time in the memory of the old court attendants in which sentences had been imposed on as many slayers in separate cases in one day.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 22 -- The Soviet midnight communique:
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 21 -- The big bettors found a way to get to Tropical Park today and sent Florida's racing season off to a flying start.

Mayor La Guardia intends to ask the State Legislature to permit appointment of temporary patrolmen to replace policemen gone to war, and Police Commissioner Valentine is seriously considering women Monitor board operators in station houses to release men now detailed to this chore.

The four-story converted private house, on a plot 25 by 100 feet, at 19 West Seventy-sixth Street, has been sold by the Rexhold Realty Corporation, James H. Cruikshank, president, to a client of Frederick and Jerome Weiss, attorneys.

The West Side Magistrates Court, in Fifty-fourth Street, for forty years a day or night court, will adjourn for good tomorrow, Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran announced yesterday. On that day the new Bowery Magistrates Court will open in the Criminal Courts Building.

Four properties, formerly owned by R.H. Macy Co. and five formerly owned by the United States Trucking Company, were sold at auction in the Vesey Street salesrooms yesterday for a total of $105,300. Joseph P. Day was the auctioneer.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- There are countries in Europe from which Jews can still escape, M. Shertok, head of the political department of the Jewish Agency in Jerusalem, said today. He is in London discussing with the British Government plans for saving these Jews.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The War Department announced today a list of 141 Army officers held as prisoners of war by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands. Among them are seven from New York State and one from Connecticut.

MEMBERS of the every-man-his-own-military-expert society often make up in vehemence what they lack in professional knowledge. A quick look at the headlines, a knowing reference to the Schlieffen plan and a polite mention of the maxims of von Clausewitz are credentials enough for the domination of nearly any conversation.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- Continuation of the State War Council under the Dewey administration was urged today by Governor Poletti, in a letter to legislative leaders, as he made public a comprehensive report of the council's activities during the year.
MOSCOW, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Five Senators from silver-producing States issued a statement today saying that they had agreed to the release of certain of the government's silver stocks for consumptive purposes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 16: Increases of $1,236,000,000 in holdings of United States Government bonds, $234,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, and $1,468,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- An increase in the value of fuel-oil ration coupons in thirteen Middle Western States from ten to eleven gallons each was announced today by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator. He said that similar action might be taken in the East if the present cold spell became as protracted as that in the Midwest.

Is there a large number of persons in this town and region who don't read newspapers or advertisements in newspapers? For a long time the National Director of Transportation has been urging Americans to refrain from unnecessary travel. He has made that request again and again and renewed it in regard to travel during Christmas week.

THE United States Marine Corps now has a pretty good baseball pitcher on its staff, the same being Lieutenant Ted Lyons, late of the White Sox. By the same token, Mr. J.J. Dykes, the White Sox manager, has lost his Sunday pitcher.

Penolo Johnson, 16-year-old Negro student of 122 West 137th Street, was paroled in her own custody yesterday by Magistrate Richard McKiniry in Harlem Court for a trial in Special Sessions for an alleged assault on a teacher at the Wadleigh High School, Seventh Avenue and 114th Street.

While approving acceleration of nurses' training programs, on the basis of a wartime survey announced Monday by the Federal Security Administration, local nursing agencies warned yesterday that speed-up plans should be carefully studied before being adopted.

By a unanimous vote, the City Council adopted yesterday a resolution calling on Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate to grant a general wage increase of unspecified percentage to all city employes receiving less than $5,000 a year, although many Councilmen expressed a fear beforehand that their request would be ignored.

SOMEWHERE IN WEST CHINA, Dec. 21 (Delayed) (U.P.) -The Japanese let 500 to 1,000 ill British and Canadian soldiers die aboard a torpedoed and sinking prison ship and machine-gunned survivors in the water, survivors who reached unoccupied China revealed today.

Directors of the Delaware Hudson Company and those of its wholly owned subsidiary, the Delaware Hudson Railroad Corporation, approved yesterday a plan of adjustment covering the outstanding $47,769,000 of first and refunding mortgage 4 per cent bonds of the Delaware Hudson Company, maturing on May 1, 1943.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- With another beautiful night, marred only by some clouds over the target and on the way in, the Royal Air Force last night made its fifth raid on Munich. It was reported that "a great weight" of bombs was dropped on the birthplace of nazism.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 22 -- General Chang Ching-hui, Premier of Japanese-controlled Manchukuo, has shot and killed himself after poisoning his family and shooting the Japanese adviser to his office and five other high officials of the Manchukuo Government, a War Ministry communique said today.

Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday the appointment of Charles D. Breitel, his law associate and former assistant in the District Attorney's office, as counsel to the Governor at $10,000 a year, effective Jan. 1.

While admitting that the outlook for gasoline and oil supplies in the New York metropolitan area was not good, Laurence B. Davis, director of marketing of the Office of Petroleum Coordinator, declared yesterday that the fuel situation was not as "panicky" as pictured by some sections of the press.

Retailers will oppose any attempt by the Office of Price Administration to put a ceiling on credit service charges, a program foreshadowed by the proposed order setting dollars-and-cents prices on "victory" bedsprings, it was indicated here yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The United States Army Air Forces "are absolutely ready for an all-out air offensive by next Spring," declared Major Gen. Henry J. F. Miller in an interview today.

Consolidated earnings of the Schenley Distillers Corporation for the quarter ended with November increased to $7,982,951 after interest, depreciation and $500,000 provision for contingencies but before tax deductions, it was reported yesterday following a meeting of the directors.
Hitch-hiking now has Emily Post's nod of approval if (and of course there is an if) it's a woman war worker thumbing a ride from a gentleman motorist -- if the gentleman motorist has any gasoline!

When applicants for admission to the bar come before the justices in the Appellate Division in Brooklyn today among them, dressed in the uniform of the United States Navy, will be James J. Thornton, seaman first class.
Children gave unstintingly to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday as they always do. They think of Christmas as a time for joy and they wish to share their joy with others who are in need.

Residents of the Bethpage and Farmingdale area of Nassau County were asked by Army authorities last night to be on the lookout for several explosive depth charges released by an Army bomber that had to make a forced landing early Monday near the intersection of Wantagh State Parkway and Fulton Avenue, East Meadow, L.I. Army authorities have been searching the area continuously without success, it was announced.

AN EAST COAST PORT, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The captain of a United Nations merchant ship reported a murderous attack by shell fire and machine-guns upon both his vessel and helpless men seeking the safety of a lifeboat.

The trend among large manufacturers to take over either complete production and sales of products of small companies or only the distribution of such items is suddenly bringing into the advertising picture goods which in normal times would continue to sell on a small scale.

A display of items showing the Park Department's contribution to the war program was opened yesterday in the window of the Information Center in Pershing Square. The display was made by children between the ages of 8 and 18 who attend the handicraft clubs in the city's parks.

The first in-service consumer training course for teachers to be accepted by the Board of Education as part of the "alertness credit" course -- required for all teachers seeking salary increments -- will begin in Brooklyn and Manhattan in February, it was revealed yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 22 -- Essential workers in the Twin Cities area, about 175,000 of them, have been frozen in their jobs by action of the Twin Cities Industrial Area Committee of the War Manpower Commission.

Appointment of two committees "to inquire into statements made by certain organizations that delinquency in the schools had increased" was announced yesterday by Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -The War Department announced today the names of 132 additional prisoners of war held by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands. The list includes the names of 131 officers and one enlisted man of the Army.

The directors of the Southern Railway Company declared yesterday out of earnings in 1942 dividends of $3.75 a share on the preferred stock. This amount will be paid in three dividends of $1.25 each, the first on March 15, the following on June 15 and the third on Sept. 15, 1943.

Christmas shoppers in record numbers throng the city's stores buying gifts for loved ones, spending more than last year, especially for jewelry, perfumes and other so-called luxuries, for woolen clothing for those who will be cold because of the fuel oil shortage.

Sales of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 rose 31 per cent to a high record of $352,693,500 from the previous record of $268,091,826 established in the preceding year, John W. Thomas, chairman, reported yesterday in his annual statement to stockholders.

With the passing of Dr. Franz Boas anthropology loses its most distinguished interpreter. He was a measurer of skulls and bones, who proved that the human race is very unstable and that since the first settlers came to this country the American physical type has changed; yet he declined to reduce his subject to mere physical measurements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- An investigation by the new Congress of "personal patronage" in government war agencies, by which friends, college classmates and others close to officials in key posts were described as getting the jobs, was proposed today by Representative Ramspeck, majority whip of the House.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Mayor George T. Ashe of Lowell was sentenced to a year in jail today when he pleaded guilty to an indictment charging acceptance of a bribe of $1,000 for the award of a construction contract to a favored contractor.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 23 -Russian troops sweeping across the middle Don River captured "several dozen" more villages in their drive on the key city of Rostov, and raised their seven-day toll of Nazis to 55,000 killed and captured, the Soviet command announced early today.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 22 (AP) -Price control and rationing will be maintained during a "boom period of several years" after the war, Dr. Mordecai Ezekiel of Washington, a member of the War Production Board, predicted tonight at the American Institute on Judaism and a Just and Enduring Peace.
BOSTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Bruins overcame a two-goal deficit during the last nine minutes of play to gain a 4-4 tie with the Maple Leafs tonight before a 10,000 crowd at the Boston Garden.

Grant Wood's painting, "American Gothic," has been added to the exhibition, "Twentieth Century Portraits," current at the Musenm of Modern Art (through Jan. 24). The painting has been lent by the Art Institute of Chicago. This picture could not be shown at the opening of the exhibition, as it was then on view in the Grant Wood memorial show at the Chicago Art Institute.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 22 -- A Lie-long resident of Newark, Mr. Burnett was one of the city's most prominent governmental, civic and business leaders. His political career began in 1903, when he was elected to the old Newark Common Council.

The consolidated report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, excluding certain important subsidiaries, for the first nine months of this year, released yesterday by Colonel Sosthenes Behn, president, shows a net income of $970,957 after operating expenses, taxes and other charges.

Back through the years, as the months have turned sedately on the calendar, there always has been Leonard Sillman collecting material for a new revue, raising the money, at irregular intervals putting on a new revue. They have borne such names as "New Faces" and "Fools Rush In," and history notes that some of them have been better than others.

The program of the Camp Fire Girls has been endorsed for Catholic girls by Bishop John A. Duffy of Buffalo, chairman of the youth department of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, it was announced yesterday by Lester F. Scott, secretary and national executive of the Camp Fire Girls, Inc.

The St. John's University basketball team was beaten for the first time in six years on its own floor and the first time anywhere this season when it lost to Niagara, 46 -- 40, in a hotly contested game last night before a capacity crowd. It was Niagara's eighth triumph in nine starts.

Two of the "Big Five" of the life insurance companies in America announced yesterday additional subscriptions amounting to $125,000,000 for new securities offered as part of the nation-wide Victory Loan drive. The reorders were from the Prudential Insurance Company of America and the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

The city's plans for its dimmed-out, wartime Christmas took shape yesterday with travel mounting to a peak expected to be reached today and tomorrow, while a wide range of holiday parties were scheduled for every day this week.

The aims and ideals of the Ethiopian Pacific Movement were discussed on the witness stand in Federal court yesterday by Lester Eugene Holness, one of four Negro leaders of that organization on trial for sedition. As the first witness for the defense Holness testified that his group was interested in bettering the status of all the "darker races," preferably through peaceful means.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Six million Americans of Italian origin are united solidly against Mussolini, fascism and dictatorship all over the world, Felix Forte, supreme president of the Order of the Sons of Italy in America, asserted tonight as he released resolutions of his organization expressing similar sentiments.

Persons with winning pari-mutuel tickets on horse races may not collect unless they produce the winning tickets, even though the records show that the sum sought is the same as that in the unredeemed fund, according to a decision by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday.

Against a background of high praise for Russia, William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, and Sidney Hillman, special adviser to President Roosevelt on labor problems, declared last night that the future of world security dictated continued close cooperation among the United Nations, especially with Russia, after the war.

If all the freaks on the sports pages in 1942 were laid end to end they would no doubt have Mr. Barnum fighting with Mr. Bailey over the exhibition privileges, but by all odds the oddest of the lot was that turned in by Alex Agase the day Illinois upset Minnesota on the football field.

Following conferences yesterday with OPA officials, Walter H. Pringle, president of the recently organized National Federation of the Fur Industry, warned that "March ceilings on furs may not be exceeded no matter how tempting improved market conditions may be."

The tendency to rest and consolidate the position gained in the two previous sessions prevailed yesterday in the stock market. While there were several individual strong spots, the list leaned to an irregularly lower course at the close.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Dec. 22 -- Brig. Gen. Waldron was stationed at Washington, and attached to the General Staff as a colonel when the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor. His promotion to general officer rank was announced by President Roosevelt last March 15.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- The voluntary program of dissolution of the United Gas Improvement Company, oldest and one of the largest holding companies in the country, was submitted to and approved today by the board of directors, as had been expected. It would have the fundamental effect of transferring control of the prosperous Philadelphia Electric Company from U.G.I. to the United Corporation.

As competitive shopping for waning supplies of butter became livelier yesterday, storekeepers generally reported that in advance of government action they had started their own systems of rationing, allowing from one-quarter to one-half pound to each customer.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 22 -- Because of the constant need for refining and improving the design of military planes, mass production of aircraft in anything like the volume of peacetime automobile output cannot be expected in this country during the present war, L. . Goad, general manager of Eastern Aircraft Division, a branch of the General Motors Corporation, asserted here tonight.

ALIQUIPPA, Pa., Dec. 22 -- Fifty tons of rock and earth, loosened by thaw and steady rain, tumbled from a 100-foot cliff on Constitution Boulevard early this evening and crushed a bus loaded with defense workers, killing possibly twenty-five persons.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- Chinese children screamed and ran to their mothers when they saw "foreign devils" armed with axes on the outskirts of Chungking today. Calm was soon restored when the "foreign devils" were identified as American soldiers in search of Christmas trees.
WITH THE RED ARMY, on the Stalingrad Front, Dec. 19 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- For hundreds of square miles around this battleground in the Don River bend there stretches a mammoth Axis graveyard.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- How Edward Walter Oakes, 28, of Stottville, N.Y., helped save his submarine from possible destructive damage while it was on war patrol was told by the Navy Department today in an announcement that Oakes had been promoted to chief quartermaster.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that it has designated sixteen laboratories, strategically located in various parts of the country, as official testing centers of substitutes for metal springs in upholstered furniture.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Allied patrols stabbing northeast from Medjez-el-Bab were authoritatively reported today to have made contact with Axis forces fifteen miles from that Tunisian crossroads town.

BAYONNE, N.J., Dec. 22 -- Miss Saidee Harriman, 63 years old, of 518 West 152d Street, New York, described by her counsel as an operative of the Val O'Farrell Detective Agency, was given the alternative of a $175 fine or a thirty-day jail sentence on being found guilty in Bayonne Police Court today on charges of possessing six lottery slips.
CAIRO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

More than 1,500,000 pints of blood have been taken by the American Red Cross for conversion into dried plasma for the Army and Navy without a single known instance of the donor having suffered any serious after-effects, it was related yesterday by Colonel Earle Boothe, director of the blood donor service of the New York Chapter.

Differences narrowed further yesterday in the cotton futures market under continued two-sided activity by spot concerns. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts, moving to moderate gains for the fifth successive day, ended the session 3 to 8 points above Monday's final prices and at the highest closing levels since July 22.

Brooklyn residents waiting eagerly for the mail these mornings may not be looking forward to those Christmas presents at all. They may just be waiting for the mail carrier, especially if they live in a neighborhood where one of the 177 women sworn in on Friday will deliver mail for the first time.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22 -- Only 2,369 fans passed through the Tropical Park turnstiles today to witness a nose victory for Mrs. Louis Lazare's Paladin in the sixfurlong Coral Gables Purse. The $4.30 for $2 favorite rallied just in time to gain the photo verdict over Sight, while Zorawar was a belated third in the field of five 3-year-olds, a half length behind.

A rainfall that turned swiftly to ice soon after striking the earth coated highways in the New York area with a thin glaze last night, making automobile travel in many districts impossible. Bus service was badly crippled, leaving thousands parked at bus terminals waiting to get home after trips to shopping centers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Talk revived here today of a plan put forward unofficially by the Office of Price Administration last Summer for the installment sale of automobiles and other consumer goods during the war for delivery in peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The work week in industries engaged largely in war production averaged 45.7 hours in October, Secretary Perkins reported today. This compared with 44.6 hours in September and 45.2 in August.

If Hammering Henry Armstrong, the only boxer ever to hold three world titles at the same time, ever returns to activity here, he will have to undergo a rigid physical examination for the State Athletic Commission. The condition of his eyes, heretofore one of the weak points in his fighting armor, will be especially noted.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Libya, Dec. 22 -- A hundred and twelve prisoners, all Germans this time, have been going along the road to a camp in the rear. They are part of 450 of the enemy captured since the British Eighth Army passed the Agheila positions and the second phase of the battle in this section of North Africa began.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- In five weeks of operations from Guadalcanal airfield, a single Navy dive bomber squadron attacked eighty-eight Japanese warships and six transports, sinking or damaging eighteen of them.

Wall Street analysts appear to have reached the conclusion that many of the "war babies" already are on a peace basis; that is, prices have been dehydrated and are back to approximately their pre-war levels. Republic Steel, Jones Laughlin Steel, Kennecott, Electric Boat, Bullard and United Aircraft, according to one tabulation, are now fairly close to the average of their lowest prices in 1939 and 1940.

During the last war a fine spirit of camaraderie developed among the men who shared the common dangers of the trenches. It has taken the hardships of another horrible war to bring out this fine fellowship again. Every day we read and hear of acts of devotion performed by soldiers, sailors and airmen who have even given their lives as the price to save some stanch comrade.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- The OPA was urged today to consider the effects of its new food price ceilings system and to avoid extending it into other lines of merchandising. The new ceiling system, it was also warned, would work serious damage among small merchants.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 -Fifty employes of Henry J. Kaiser's Oregon Shipbuilding Corporation at Portland, Ore., obtained a charter from the C.I.O. so that workers there would not have to "pay tribute to the American Federation of Labor," a former C.I.O. organizer testified here today.

The superb defensive play which played no small part in bringing the American League pennant to the Yankees by a wide margin seems to be clearly reflected in the latest batch of official averages to be released.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Flying Fortresses operating in the Solomon Islands area probably sank a cargo ship in one of three forays reported today in a Navy communique.

Shipment of 78,220 pounds of scrap salvaged keys to the Revere Copper and Brass Company, acting as agents for Metals Reserve Corporation, was announced yesterday by Alfred S. Walden, chairman for New York of the Key Collection Campaign sponsored by the paper industry.

Sports writers take a more serious view of their duties when it comes to summing up a season or a year than do literary prize committees or laurel-bestowing drama critics. Pulitzer judges have been known occasionally to find no book worthy of an award.

Cries of joy echoed yesterday through the halls of the Beekman Hospital, Beekman and Water Streets, as a throng of small children filed past a Christmas tree to receive presents from a smiling Santa Claus at the twenty-second annual Christmas party.
The threat of prison that hung over James T. Owens for nineteen years was dissipated yesterday by a pardon. He wept when informed of this Christmas present in Felony Court.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Captain Grant Singer, who learned about reconnaissance as a master of the fox hounds in West England, was credited posthumously today with the capture of the German General Ritter von Thoma soon after the British Eighth Army's decisive break-through from El Alamein, Egypt, into the Libyan desert.

A growing scarcity of wanted fabrics may cut Spring coat and suit volume below the potential demand, trade reports yesterday indicated. Certain of the twill fabrics have become extremely scarce. To some degree shetlands have eased possibilities of an acute shortage of the former, but it is expected that supplies of these cloths from now to the end of the season will also be limited.

I feel sure many Americans will be interested in the information which has just reached ne from New Zealand. In Auckland and in Wellington street parades have been held, immediately American troops have arrived, so that citizens might salute the Stars and Stripes.
MOSCOW, Wednesday Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Soviet regular midnight communique:

The array of food that New Yorkers are going to devour during the Christmas season is wonderful to behold. Though each section of the city has its own idea of what is good to eat, all are united on one point -- there must be plenty.

Christian K. (Red) Cagle, All-America football star, halfback of the Army teams of 1927-29, and captain in the latter year, died at 12:40 A.M. today in Physicians Hospital, Jackson Heights, Queens. He had contracted pneumonia after a skull injury.

HONOLULU, Dec. 22 -- Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, commander of the Hawaiian Department and Military Governor of Hawaii, said today that the government of the islands would be returned to the civilian authorities to the greatest extent possible consistent with the development of Oahu as an offensive base.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- To help alleviate the current shortage of evaporated milk, the Food Distribution Administration will immediately release 2,000,000 cases from its present stocks, Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture, said today.
Within a day or two Albert Vanderkogel expects to pack his bag like many another American sportsman has done and head for an Army camp.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Seven associations in the livestock industry today joined the Office of Price Administration and the Department of Agriculture in petitioning the Interstate Commerce Commission to cancel increases in passenger fares and freight rates granted to railroads early this year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Reflecting recently increased taxes on liquor, tobacco and other products, Federal revenues in November soared nearly 50 per cent over those for November, 1941.

The New York sponsoring committee of Junior Programs, of which /irs. Christopher B, Wyatt is chairman, will give a tea next Tuesday on the stage of the BelamcoTheatre after the performance of "Doodle Dandy of the U. S. .,[' the current musical play for children.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -Because of the induction of young men into the armed forces and war industries, the Screen Actors Guild opened the ranks of its class B membership today to recruit new male extras and bit players between 18 and 25 for motion pictures.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 (AP) -Columbus Day, owned by H.C. Richards and third choice in the mutuels, put on a stretch drive today to win the Loyola Handicap, mile and a sixteenth feature of the Fair Grounds card.

Several dinners will precede the American premiere showing of Noel Coward's new motion picture, "In Which We Serve," tonight at the Capitol Theatre to augment the recently established philanthropic fund of the Overseas Press Club. Among those who will entertain dinner parties before the benefit are Mr. and Mrs. William C. Breed, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pierrepont Perry, Mrs. Benjamin G. Paskus and Miss Elsa Maxwell.

Frank Kleinholz, one of the award winners in the current Artists for Victory exhibition at the Metropolitan, is holding his first one-man show at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. It will continue until Jan. 9.

The University of Chicago Press will release next Tuesday another section of "A Dictionary of American English," which has been in preparation for some years at the university under the editorship of Sir William Craigie and James R. Hulbert.
The formula for victory in the Pacific, as the action in the Solomons again emphasized yesterday, must include attrition as well as assault.

A program of Christmas festivities for men in the armed forces to take place in USO units scattered from the Arctic to the Caribbean Sea was announced yesterday at headquarters of the United Service Organizations in the Empire State Building.

Despite retail liquor dealers' expectations of considerably reduced holiday business because of the heavy pre-tax buying in October, sales volume in the department stores and other large outlets suddenly jumped to more nearly normal Christmas levels yesterday.

A pharmacist and chemist who was a poet at heart, the Mayor of Sanfele, Italy, for many years, a civil judge and a friend of King Victor Emmanuel, died suddenly Sunday, it was learned yesterday, at the home of his son, Dr. Vito A. Pittaro of 11 Bay Street, City Island, the Bronx, at the age of 101.
It happens that in my present homeward walk to a new lodging in lower Manhattan I see the vista of Catharine Street, nearly closed by the farther tower of Brooklyn Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The controversy over the request by Secretary Ickes that the bituminous coal industry arrange to work six days of seven hours each per week instead of five days of seven hours was carried a step further today in a proposal by pit operators to the United Mine Workers suggesting that the six-day-a-week agreement made in the anthracite field be applied to the bituminous industry.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- Vichy Chief of Government Pierre Laval reported to the Cabinet late yesterday on the results of his conferences with Adolf Hitler, a French frontier dispatch reported today.

In a visit to the American Women's Voluntary Services headquarters, 11 East Fifty-eighth Street, last night, Miss Helen Keller presented to the evening typists a braille message she wrote to express gratitude for the work they have done for the American Foundation for the Blind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Pointing with pride to "a modern miracle of construction," the War Department announced today that its new headquarters, the gigantic mile-around Pentagon Building just across the Potomac from Washington, had been constructed in fourteen months -- a job which in ordinary times would have required seven years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -The administration was reported today to have abandoned the idea of using subsidies generally to hold down the cost of food.

The board of directors of Sterling Drug, Inc., yesterday voted to absorb sixteen wholly owned domestic subsidiaries into the parent company, effective Dec. 31, when the corporation will become an operating company, and elected three new vice presidents, as follows:
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 22 -- American forces here today rounded out their organization for their first New Zealand Christmas, covering every camp and detachment in the country.

What very short memories we have. When the possibility of gasoline rationing first loomed in August, 1941, Mr. Ickes warned that we might be in for some very serious situations affecting the running of our automobiles due to a possible shortage of gasoline. His prophecies have con]e true.

Two useful purposes would be served if the public could see for itself the story told in today's news stories about the transformation of the seaboard plants that constitute the Eastern Aircraft Division of General Motors Corporation. First, a new realization would be gained of the magnitude of the job involved in converting automobile production to the production of combat airplanes.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Allied ground troops in the Buna area of New Guinea are pushing a slow advance through "intricate and thoroughly prepared positions," General Douglas MacArthur announced today.

SEATTLE, Dec. 22 -- Women in industry has become a familiar wartime phrase, but women "expressmen" are something new in the changing wartime labor picture. More than two score of them are now working at the express terminal here, and more will be hired as soon as they can be obtained, according to H.J. Shannon, general agent of Railway Express Agency.

"Flare Path," a new play by Terence Rattigan, will open tonight at Henry Miller's Theatre. Gilbert Miller is the producer; Twentieth Century-Fox the backer. The cast, headed by Nancy Kelly, Arthur Margetson and Alec Guinness, also includes Doris Patston, Alexander Ivo, Gerald Savory, Helena Pickard, Reynolds Denniston, Cynthia Latham and Bob White.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Republic Steel Corporation said full production of ship plate was resumed tonight at the company's strip mill as C.I.O. steel workers ended a stoppage resulting from a dispute over work schedules.

The first sharp attack on the proposed plan to establish an Office of Technological Mobilization which would control and supervise the country's industrial research facilities came yesterday from Dr. Gustav Egloff, president of the American Institute of Chemists, who asserted that such mobilization would throw vital research programs "out of gear" and slow up the nation's war effort.

Two new films will have local premieres in midtown theatres tonight. "In Which We Serve," a British-made naval drama written, co-directed, produced by and starring Noel Coward, will be the new attraction at the Capitol. The film, which tells the story of a British destroyer from its launching to its sinking off Crete, features John Mills, Bernard Miles, Celia Johnson and Kay Walsh.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Petroleum Administrator Ickes put into effect today a far-reaching gasoline and oil rationing program of his own for the petroleum-starved East to backstop the Office of Price Administration's coupon rationing program.

LONDON, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- Reports from Tunisia said tonight that, despite more torrential rains, the Allies were massing in final battle array all along the Tunisian front for a grand assault to be coordinated with an accelerated British Eighth Army smash through Western Libya to envelop Tripoli and the Axis garrisons in Tunis and Bizerte.

The seldom-discussed fact that the United States Postoffice has a statutory monopoly in the transportation and delivery of "letters and packets" figured in an unusual case yesterday in the Federal court. American Dealers' Service, an organization which has been competing with the Post Office and undercutting its rates for five years, was the petitioner in the case, which was placed before Judge Murray Hulbert.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Raymond Daniell in THE TIMES of Dec. 20 ends his dispatch from London with this question: "If Hitler invades Spain and Generalissimo Franco fights him, what then are the Allies to do -fight him because he is a Fascist or help him because he is on their side?"

A concerted drive to rescind the concentration program for the farm equipment industry and to increase the production of such equipment in 1943 has been started by a coalition of the farm bloc, the Truman committee, the Department of Agriculture and manufacturers, it was learned here yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The outstanding feature in the stock markets today was the gilt-edge section, which already is feeling the benefit of reinvestment of the India loan that has been called in by the Treasury, money from which is to be disbursed beginning with the new year.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 22 -- "China has received the news of British military operations in Western Burma with great delight," said Dr. Chang Tao-fan, the new Minister of Information, at a formal press conference this afternoon in the International Department Building.

To the War Manpower Commission there has been submitted the draft of a proposed National War Service Act drawn by Grenville Clark, a public-spirited citizen of New York, who drafted the original Selective Service Act. The new measure would impose on every able-bodied man and woman in the United States the same legal obligation for wartime national service which now applies to men of draft age.
I thought you might be interested in publishing the following, which I quote from a letter I have received from a British colonel somewhere in Africa.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Royal Air Force fighters, braving heavy anti-aircraft fire, smashed at the Akyab area in Burma and damaged the airfield, a gun position and a river steamer at the Japanese-held port on the Bay of Bengal, a communique announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- December wheat, trading in which ceased at the close of the market today, sold at a new seasonal high of $1.37 3/8 a bushel in the early trading, but late in the session evening-up operations caused a sharp recession and the close was near the bottom at a gain of 3/8 cent on the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- To meet mounting military and lendlease requirements, the government probably will ration food fats and oils in 1943 at a level at least 15 per cent below civilian demands, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Information from Germany indicates that Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels has mobilized hundreds of orators to stump the country explaining away reverses in Africa and Russia and helping to bolster morale at the eve of Germany's gloomiest Christmas of the war.

The remarkable success of the December Victory Fund Drive of the Treasury makes, as Secretary Morgenthau said, "the sort of news that Axis leaders dread to hear." In the space of nineteen days the original goal of $9,000,000,000 has been topped by more than $1,000,000,000.

Further sweeping changes were made yesterday in major league baseball's training plans for 1943 as club owners strove to act in accordance with what they believed the government wanted them to do, and the prospect now looms of seeing this traditional form of the national pastime's Spring activities pared to the bone.
