KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 22 -- Mrs. Janet Roper, for than half a century the House Mother at the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street, New York, was the official and somewhat nervous sponsor of the new cargo ship, Andromeda, at launching ceremonies this morning at the local yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The United Korean Committee in America, representing Korean organizations in the United States, Hawaii, Mexico and Cuba, made public today a protest against conclusions of the Institute of World Affairs that Korea, now a part of the Japanese Empire, should be placed under a mandate of a foreign power after the war.

The steadying influence of the "older woman" is an asset in war industries required to use more women workers because of the manpower shortage, according to a report yesterday by the research division of the National Industrial Conference Board.

The six-story apartment house known as the Pintard Apartments at 650 Main Street, New Rochelle, Westchester County, has been sold by the Prudential Life Insurance Company to Samuel Reznick. Purchase was for cash above a ten-year mortgage of $207,000, with interest at 3 1/2 per cent. The property is assessed for $270,000 and has a rent roll of $46,116.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Because Congress may adopt legislation to correct the existing situation, the Department of Justice asked the Supreme Court today not to erase from its calendar the anti-trust suit against the Aluminum Company of America upon which the Court recently refused to pass when the necessary quorum of six could not be summoned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A flat 10 per cent reduction in the amount of newsprint to be used by each magazine publisher in 1943 as compared with 1942 has been recommended to the War Production Board by the magazine industry advisory committee, WPB announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The effects of yesterday's 5-to-2 Supreme Court decision growing out of Nevada's easy divorce laws are far-reaching with respect to statutes touching property rights, traditional moral standards and the legitimacy of the children of divorced parents who remarry.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Navy Department communique 227:

Samuel Buchler, who was convicted last month of a series of frauds in his operation of the Jewish Court of Arbitration, received yesterday a suspended sentence on a long prison term through Judge Jonah J. Goldstein.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 22 -- A Supreme Court jury which is trying Samuel Nuzzo, ousted business agent of Local 17 of the hodcarriers union, on charges of stealing money from his union today heard him admit that he paid $1,500 to his business agent, Jack Wallace, for bodyguards hired by Wallace for his protection at a labor convention in Atlantic City in 1939.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 22 -- German confidence in victory has been severely shaken by the latest events, particularly the Soviet offensive in the Middle Don sector, according to the Munich Neueste Nachrichten, which tells its readers that the "bitterest and most horrible battle in world history" now rages along the Don.

CALCUTTA, Wednesday, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Calcutta had its third consecutive midnight raid last night, and as before, only a few bombs were dropped. Half an hour after the all-clear sounded every one was back in bed.

At Christmas time the thoughts of most adults go back over the years. They do not go back as far, perhaps, as the event which Christmas commemorates. Few think of the birth of Christianity in terms of the great ideological revolution that it was, or as the beginning of an era that has lasted to this day.

Chester B. Duryea, who spent more than a quarter century in Matteawan State Hospital for shooting his father, Brig. Gen. Hiram Duryea, shook hands and exchanged Christmas good wishes yesterday in Supreme Court with his estranged wife, Mrs. Nina L. Duryea, from whom he parted in 1904, ten years before the fatal shooting.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 22 -- The plan to transport 50,000 men to the Amazon Valley to increase rubber production for United States war needs, tentatively reported early this month, became a reality today when James A. Russell, representing the United States Rubber Reserve Corporation, and Paulo de Assis Ribeiro, representing the Office of the Brazilian Coordinator, signed an agreement setting up bases for the men's travel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Christmas greetings went out tonight to the soldiers on the firing line, the workers on the production front and the men of the merchant marine, who deliver the tools of victory.
Swelling Christmas sales totals here to an all-time high, package-laden shoppers continued to crowd local stores yesterday in a final splurge of last-minute shopping.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. "Fortress on the Volga," a Soviet importation, will have its local premiere at the Stanley. The drama, which treats of how the armies under Voroshilov fought their way across the Volga to join Joseph Stalin's besieged garrison at Tsaritsyn (now Stalingrad) in 1918, was produced last Spring at Lenfilm Studios, U.S.S.R., according to the management.

AN ADVANCED R.A.F. FIGHTER STATION, in Tunisia, Dec. 19 (Delayed) -- United States Army Air Force Flying Fortresses and fighters operating with the Royal Air Force against the German battle lines and targets in Tunis and Bizerte have earned the unstinted praise of the casual young veterans of this station.

DAKAR, French West Africa, Dec. 23 -- American troops now are in Dakar, the nerve center of all French West Africa and the port that repulsed a combined British and Fighting French attack in September, 1940.

IT begins to appear that Florida and California baseball will be out of bounds for Spring training in baseball this coming season. Possibly some of the baseball clan will look on this change sadly as one of the horrors of war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A panel of the National War Labor Board recommended unanimously today a two-cent hourly increase in the starting and minimum rates and acceptance of a job reclassification schedule affecting 18,000 employes of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation at Long Island City, Newark, and Johnsville, Pa.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 23 -- The iron heel of war economy is obliterating the few remaining traces of Yuletide from the German scene. Probably no other German Christmas of this war or World War I has so completely reflected the withering and corrosive effects of war on civilian life.

The recent revised price regulations covering sales of beef, veal, lamb and mutton to non-slaughtering wholesalers and the failure to provide for allocations by slaughterers to such wholesalers have caused a diversion of supplies in this area from consumer channels to hotel and restaurant supply houses to whom meats may be sold in wholesale quantities without the required discount, meat trade groups protested yesterday.

The total sum given this season to the Hundred Neediest Fund was yesterday running about 20 per cent behind the total for a comparable date last year. The total number of contributors was down between 3 and 4 per cent. There are nearly as many generous souls interested in this cause this year as there were last year.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A charge that the government's monopoly suit against The Associated Press had the twofold purpose of assisting one Chicago newspaper while injuring another, and was to harm and harass newspapers generally, was made today at Loyola University's Christmas convocation by Ralph Nicholson, publisher of The Item.

The death early yesterday in Physicians Hospital, Queens, of Christian K. (Red) Cagle, 37 years old, former all-American football player and star Army halfback, was under intensive investigation by the police and District Attorney's office during the day, with indications favoring the theory that Mr. Cagle had been injured accidentally.

From the line of propaganda being handed out in Germany and Italy, it is easy to guess at the line of argument pursued at the emergency conference held at Hitler's headquarters. The days are past when the Axis partners meet at the summit of the Alps to the sound of trumpets and the flash of cameras.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Senator Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico said today that additional shipping for the island has been promised by Federal officials to meet the food shortage crisis there.

PHILADELPPIA, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Connie Mack, celebrating his eightieth birthday today, disclosed for the first time why he was considered a "tricky" catcher back in the Eighteen Eighties and Eighteen Nineties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Final approval was given by the War Department today to a contract under which Andrew J. Higgins of New Orleans will produce a "large number of cargo-carrying airplanes" for the Army Air Forces. Previous announcements have set 1,200 airplanes as the ultimate goal for the contract, but the official announcement stated only that "the total outlay will involve more than $5,000,000."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Already out-producing the Axis countries by a wide margin in steel, the United States by mid-1943 will approach a steel production rate twice that of Germany, Italy and Japan combined, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the WPB, said today in a report on the status of the industry's expansion program.
The Right Rev. William T. Manning has issued the following Christmas message to the communicants of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, of which he is the Bishop:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- A light cruiser and a Navy tug slid into the waters of San Francisco Bay today, the second successive day on which bay area yards had launched two ships to further the war effort of the United Nations.

Six hundred children from the Heckscher Foundation, the Union Settlement, the Children's Society and the out-patient clinics of the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals were guests yesterday afternoon at a Christmas party, jointly sponsored by the Heckscher Foundation, the Junior Auxiliary of the A.W.V.S. and I.M. Strauss, president of the Strauss Stores, in the Heckscher Theatre, 1 East 104th Street.

Bernard M. Baruch, financier and philanthropist who has been giving most of his time to the nation since the war production program was launched, supplemented this yesterday with a Christmas gift of $1,000,000 to the fighting men of the United Nations, and to their families.

For the eighteenth consecutive year Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was hostess yesterday at a Christmas party for children in the Womens Trade Union League, 247 Lexington Avenue. The twenty-five young guests have fathers or near relatives who are members of unions affiliated with the league and who are now in the armed forces.

Weakness developed yesterday in the cotton futures market as pre-holiday realizing found demand wanting. This liquidation by many who had been buyers on the upturn of the last five sessions depressed active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to final net losses of 18 to 21 points, or 90 cents to $1.05 a bale.

Among the business leases reported yesterday was one for 15,000 square feet of space in the building at 53-7 West Twenty-third Street signed by the Jaxton Clothes Company, Inc., for the sale, display and manufacture of men's clothing.
LONDON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A British Admiralty communique:
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Senate committee which is investigating the matter of government questionnaires, has received a complaint from the president of a bank in Washington that he finds himself unable to increase the salaries of two of his 100 employes unless he pays an estimated $300 in attorney's fees for aid in filling out applications for permission to make the raises.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- Strong columns of Russian heavy and medium tanks, with truckloads of special shock troops, were advancing rapidly to the south and southwest today between the Don and Donets Rivers. They were accompanied by Stormovik air squadrons and, having pierced right through the enemy's zone of organized defense, they held the initiative everywhere.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in China, Dec. 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- The final chapter in the glorious record of General Chennault's Flying Tigers has been written with the tragic death of Major Frank Schiel of Prescott, Ariz., last A.V.G. pilot in China, who was killed in a crash while he was returning from an important army reconnaissance mission over Japanese bases.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 24 -- The Red Army has beaten forward across the middle Don plains for gains of seventy-two to 103 miles in eight days, the Russians announced early today, on a continuing and massive offensive that has cost Adolf Hitler upward of 80,000 killed or captured in that sector alone.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 23 -- A storm of criticism in the Helsinki Parliament leveled yesterday at Foreign Minister R.J. Witting for his failure to keep the assembly informed on foreign policy developments threatened today to develop into a movement to oust him, despite German and official Finnish attempts to hush up the incident.

LONDON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Father's Christmas tie will be no laughing matter as a present in England this year. It still costs one coupon -- one-sixtieth of a year's clothing ration. The government is not impressed by the fact that you aren't buying the tie for yourself, but just to pawn off on father.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- A test of the no strike agreement announced by President Roosevelt a year ago is sought in an injunction suit filed in the Circuit Court today in behalf of Tabin, Picker Co.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- American-built Boston planes of the Royal Air Force Bomber Command, escorted by fighter planes, pounded the docks at St. Malo in France this afternoon while other fighters carried out sweeps over Brittany and Normandy.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 23 -- It may now be disclosed that Australia is producing the main armaments of her armored divisions, the chief of which are cruiser tanks of an original design, strongly protected and heavily gunned.

WITH THE RED ARMY, on the Stalingrad Front, Dec. 22 (Delayed) -- Four months ago Lieut. Gen. Vassili Ivanovitch Chuikoff of the Red Army stood on a hill and looked at what seemed like a flaming volcano thirty miles away -- the burning city of Stalingrad. He had received orders to take command and defend the city with the life of every man in it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Traders in wheat were extremely conservative today on the Board of Trade. Reports that an announcement of the government's program to relieve flour millers now squeezed between high prices for wheat and the ceiling on flour might be expected within a few days checked operations.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 23 -- Despite heavy losses suffered since Pearl Harbor, more than 72 per cent of America's 36,000 automobile dealers have strengthened their positions and expect to stay in business for the duration, according to a cross-section survey conducted by Joseph W. Frazer, president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc.

There will be no dimout in the observance of Christmas in the city's churches because of the war. The services will be quite as elaborate and numerous as ever, if not more so. The only difference will be that tonight all midnight masses in Roman Catholic churches and celebrations of midnight holy communion in Protestant Episcopal churches will be according to dimout regulations.

The ban on Canadian liquor and beer advertising imposed on Dec. 16 by Prime Minister MacKenzie King will not apply to periodicals or newspapers published outside the Dominion, George C. Lucas, executive vice president of the National Publishers Association, announced yesterday.

A sharp gain in the nation's gasoline stocks and a heavy decline in fuel-oil supplies last week were reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline supplies at the close of the week were 79,131,000 barrels, an increase of 1,509,000 over the 77,622,000 reported a week earlier.

SYLVAN BEACH, N.Y., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Kenneth Iyenaga, 47, a Japanese widely known in this community, was shot fatally today and his wife, Kei, 44, and mother, Mrs. Yui Iyenaga, 78, were wounded when a man strode into the kitchen of their home this morning armed with a pistol.

Orders for war equipment placed with the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company this year exceeded $1,000,000,000 for the first time in the company's history, A.W. Robertson, chairman of the board, reported yesterday at a director's meeting.

Beau Jack, former Georgia caddy, who is recognized here as the world lightweight champion, will engage Fritzie Zivic, Pittsburgh's former welterweight title-holder, in a non-title match in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 5, if present plans of Promoter Mike Jacobs materialize.

The possibility of a further reduction in gasoline rations for non-essential driving here was seen yesterday by officials of the Office of Price Administration as the district office of the Petroleum Administrator for War announced the daily quotas of gasoline and fuel oils which it will endeavor to move into the six East Coast zones.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- All men and women "who cherish the principles of religion and humanity" should join at Christmas in voicing "complete condemnation" of the Nazi persecution and slaughter of the Jewish people, William Green, American Federation of Labor president, said today in a Christmas statement.

The Appellate Division reversed unanimously yesterday a Supreme Court judgment granted against four officers and directors of British Type Investors, Inc., an investment company, and dismissed the suit, which had been brought by minority stockholders of the company.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Acting in unison the Browns, Cubs, White Sox and Pirates announced today they had agreed to give up their California Spring training camps. In accordance with the suggestion of Director Joseph B. Eastman of the Office of Defense Transportation, the four clubs will seek new locations closer to their home cities.

Screeno and similar games designed to stimulate theatre patronage by the distribution of prizes are legal so long as players are not required to pay the admission price to participate, Magistrate Abner Surpless ruled yesterday in a test case in Queens Felony Court.
Two large adjoining apartment houses in Brooklyn at 1565 and 1585 East Fourteenth Street have been sold to clients of A. Harold Frost, attorney.

A hearing scheduled to deal with the exception taken by Julius Hochman, general manager of the dress joint board of the ILGWU, to the proposal by the manufacturers trade associations for use of $100,000 of the $1,000,000 promotional fund of the New York Dress Institute to present the dress industry's case against MPR 287 was adjourned yesterday afternoon by Harry Uviller, impartial chairman of the industry.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., last night warned Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Transportation that there will be a strike on the city's unified subway and surface lines unless, within the next two weeks, the municipal authorities resume negotiations with the union on wages and working conditions of the 32,000 employes of the unified system.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Christmas messages may be cabled to identified American prisoners of war and civilians interned in the Far East, Germany and Italy through American Red Cross Chapters.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Ray Conger, one of the nation's greatest track stars of a decade ago, has been named head coach of track and cross country at Penn State for the duration.

In an interesting chain-store exchange transaction the F.W. Woolworth Company has sold its property at 26-30 South Broad Street, in Trenton, N.J. to Webb Knapp, Inc., in part payment for the two-story business building at 2515-19 Federal Street, in Camden.

The regional Office of Defense Transportation told yesterday how truck, bus and taxicab owners and farmers may obtain increased mileage and gasoline allotments on the certificates of war necessity, but issued at the same time an eight-point "code" it hopped would keep increases to an essential minimum.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A communique of the United States Army Air Force in India:

Excerpts from "Doodle Dandy of the U.S.A.," a musical play, were presented yesterday morning by Junior Programs, Inc., for the entertainment of nearly 150 young patients in the Psychiatric Auditorium at Bellevue Hospital.

Detectives of the Empire Boulevard station, Brooklyn, made known yesterday their candidate for the title of meanest thief -- a burglar who stole letters of condolence addressed to a mother whose son was killed last month in the sea fighting off Guadalcanal.

Closing of the Brooklyn College gymnasium during the Christmas holidays in the interest of fuel conservation has caused cancellation of the N.Y.U. -- Brooklyn basketball game which had been rescheduled for Jan. 4 at the former's University Heights court.

All banks and financial markets, of course, will be closed on Christmas Day, but some markets will close at noon today. In this group are the Chicago Board of Trade and the New York Cotton and Wool Top Exchanges. The New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange will remain open today as usual.
Of the widespread effects of war on sports, the decline in attendance was the most obvious, a poll of the nation's writers by The Associated Press showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that the combined Spring and Fall pig crops this year totaled 104,734,000 head, or 24 per cent more than the previous record crop of 1941.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 24 -- Japanese fortifications have been breached in many places in the Buna area of New Guinea by Allied troops, General Douglas MacArthur announced today. "Many hundreds of his [the Japanese] dead are being buried by our troops," the noon communique said. "His situation must now be regarded as desperate."

NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Cascading bombs upon widely separated targets, American and British raiders have struck powerful new blows at Rangoon and Akyab, in Burma, in softening-up raids ahead of British troops moving down the Burma coast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Meeting today with Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, representatives of the Council of State Governors pledged full cooperation of the council in the board's program to postpone all public and private construction not directly related to the war effort within State jurisdiction.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Large-scale substitution of glass for steel in the manufacture of precision gauges used to inspect war material is planned by the War Production Board's conservation division, it was announced today.

With one contributor writing "Today's list of 'musts' is headed by War Bonds and the Times Neediest." 670 donors, the largest number on any day in this thirty-first annual appeal, speeded their gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- The Allied communique implied today that a complete victory for American and Australian troops in the Buna sector of New Guinea might not be far off.

Alternate periods of reinvestment demand and tax-selling mixed trends yesterday in the stock market and swelled volume to within striking distance of the million-share mark. Buying of good quality in the morning produced some small gains among the industrial shares, but the demand was not broad enough to give the list an over-all appearance of strength.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Fifteen hundred Americans interned in Camp Woosung, near Shanghai, will have Christmas dinners, complete with turkey pies, under Red Cross auspices, A.L. Schafer, Pacific Area Red Cross manager, reported today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 23 -- As the United Nations obviously prepare their Tunisian offensive, the generals here, naturally, are pondering over the question: "What is General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel going to do?"

Uncashed checks for 2,000,000 marks on an old German bank, a glass nasal douche, a three-act scenario, the campaign literature of the unsuccessful anti-Tammany fusionists in 1917 are among the thousands of unclaimed articles in boxes of the defunct Harriman Safe Deposit Company, which the State has asked court permission to dispose of, it was disclosed yesterday.

Ralph W. Brown, general attorney of the New York Telephone Company, was appointed yesterday vice president and general counsel of the company, and Clayton J. Harcourt, assistant vice president, was made vice president in charge of staff functions. Both appointments will be effective on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Important officials here who deal with international affairs, and particularly those Democrats who were active in the political campaign of 1920, have been deeply disturbed lest history repeat itself and the people of the United States again choose isolationism after this war.

A wartime budget of $4,518,000 has been drawn up for 1943-44 by the finance committee of the Northern Baptist Convention for submission to its General Council, according to an announcement yesterday. An item of $1,000,000 has been included for post-war reconstruction.

Direct services by the American Red Cross to men in the armed forces have grown so rapidly that they now require more time and money than all other activities of the organization combined, it was announced yesterday by C.M. Chester, chairman of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund Drive in Greater New York.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The Admiralty announced today an air attack by a British naval force on Sabang, off the island of Sumatra.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The visit to this country of the Premier of the Polish Government in exile, General Wladislaw Sikorski, has drawn attention to the bitter campaign waged against his government and Russia -- both members of the United Nations -- by the anti-Sikorski Polish press in the United States, especially the Nowy Swiat of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A 600 per cent increase in shipbuilding facilities, coupled with an expected decrease in maritime losses, will improve America's shipping situation next year, Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, said today. But he also warned that the transportation problem would remain difficult because of "more jobs" for the ships to do.

Though Congress now stands adjourned, there are the strongest possible reasons for the appointment at this time of a Presidential commission to make recommendations on the whole difficult problem of manpower. Within the next few months we are certain to face a crisis.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 23 -- Max Wexler's Bryan Station, an E.R. Bradley cast-off that had not been to the post since a few ineffectual races in Florida last Winter, drove to victory in the Okeechobee Purse at Tropical Park today.

Forecast for the future: Every woman her own manicurist -- that is if the growing shortage of beauty shop operators continues. Hints from professional fingertip groomers, combined with a practice session or two, change this chore into fun.

OMAHA, Dec. 23 -- Car owners may have to give up their spare tires, and it might be necessary to take tires from persons who own more than one passenger car if the synthetic rubber program as now set up does not meet war needs, William M. Jeffers, the rubber administrator, said today.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Soviet regular midnight communique:

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The French under General Henri Honore Giraud have driven the enemy back in a sharp engagement apparently in the Pont-du-Fahs area of Tunisia, and have taken more prisoners and war material, African reports said tonight.
The press reported on Nov. 11 that President Roosevelt had proclaimed France an ally of the United Nations. Should we not, therefore, hang out the flag of an ally?

The Russian battle lines grow more and more fantastic. How is one to reconcile continued fighting in the very streets of Stalingrad with Russian armies pushing down toward Rostov? No map that can be drawn on the basis of communiques and censored dispatches can possibly tell the story.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 23 -- Malta has enhanced her reputation as an offensive base by sending out raiders that sank an Axis merchantman at sea, bombed Sicilian airfields and smashed shipping installations in Tunis Harbor, it was announced today.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Dec. 21 (Delayed) -- The terrain on the Buna front that the Australian and American troops have overrun in the last few days stretches as grim and vivid testimony to the character of the Japanese resistance that has been overwhelmed and the savage intensity of the fighting that has brought the Allied success.

This year's list of Police Department awards for bravery and for excellent police duty is headed by Detective Sidney S. Cusberth of the West 123d Street police station in Harlem. The newest award, an honorable mention for the arrest of hold-up men after a gunfight and an attempted stabbing, brings this Negro police hero's total citations in the department to twenty-two, an extraordinary number.

The need for foster homes for more than 250 babies was emphasized yesterday by the "Foster Homes For Children," 105 East Twenty-second Street. This Christmas appeal for the temporary placement of small children under the age of 3 is addressed to families in all five boroughs and within a radius of fifty miles of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Motion pictures came into discussion at a press conference held today by Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, when he was asked about charges that the OWI sought to interfere with film production.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Miss Charlotte Carr has resigned as director of Hull House effective immediately, after prolonged disagreements with key members of the board of trustees, whose president is Mrs. Joseph T. Bowen. She succeeded Jane Addams in 1937.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Governor Poletti disclosed today that he had ordered the State police to investigate thoroughly, with a view to sending the perpetrators to prison, the criminal destruction of Jewish religious property at Lake Placid and Saranac Lake.

This morning finds you on the last lap of your holiday preparations. The bird -- it's a turkey or goose, duck or chicken, depending on family custom -- has been ordered. The menu for the feast has taken some form in your mind, and exists there in outline if not in detail.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The text of the War Labor Board's interim award and order of the arbitrators in the New York newspaper strike case reads as follows:

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 23 -- It will not be a merry Christmas for the French. In the cities Yuletide cheer is out of the question except for those with purses long enough to patronize the black market. There are still many, for the thrifty French have lost confidence even in their currency and have become prodigal of virtually worthless francs.

Two artists' apartments on the top floor of a five-story loft building at 55 East Eighth Street were damaged by a fire that swept through the building at 6 A.M. yesterday, forcing three artists to abandon their studios in which paintings and art collections of a lifetime were destroyed.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 23 -- British pursuit groups following up the retreating German army in Libya yesterday reached the neighborhood of Sirte, 170 miles west of El Agheila, and at the edge of open desert that provides few defensive positions in a fifty-mile stretch.

DETROIT, Dec. 23 -- Approval of pay rises to 12,500 of its salaried employes now earning less than $350 a month was asked today of the War Labor Board and Bureau of Internal Revenue by the Chrysler Corporation.

Charges of war profiteering in electric heaters were made yesterday by the War Production Board and the Office of Price Administration, which announced in a joint statement that illegal heaters, mostly of inferior quality, were being sold at from $6.95 to $12.95.

As a Christmas feature of the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park, the medieval branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, special decorations have been put up and some works of art relating to the story of the Nativity have been installed in special settings appropriate to the season.

"Reform" appears to have struck the Bowery, judging from the showing it made yesterday at the opening of its new spick and span Bowery court in the Criminal Courts Building to almost empty spectators' benches and only nine offenders, one of them a "puller-in" and the rest human derelicts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- Curfew regulations affecting German aliens in eight Western States were lifted tonight by Lieut. Gen. DeWitt, Western defense commander. At the same time he abolished more than 1,000 zones set up in March which enemy aliens were forbidden to enter.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 23 (AP) -- An order directing Merrel P. Callaway, trustee of the Central of Georgia Railway Company, to pay $1,150,633 to mortgage holders in interest which has been accumulating since receivership proceedings were instituted in 1923, was signed today by Federal Judge A.B. Loyett.

An eight-room apartment with three baths at 876 Park Avenue has been leased to John McPike Keresey, president and director of Thomas Mortimer of 42 Broadway, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

While the situation has improved considerably in the last year, a shortage of Japanese and Chinese language teachers still exists in the colleges and in Army and Navy schools, Columbia University's Chinese and Japanese departments reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Although blasted by an enemy torpedo, damaged severely by fire and abandoned by part of her crew, a United States merchant vessel made port under command of a junior third officer, the Navy reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The National War Labor Board is putting in force a decentralization program designed to cut red tape to a minimum and speed the disposition of thousands of requests submitted by employers, labor unions or individuals for wage adjustments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Educational requirements of the Waves, the women's reserve in the Navy, and the Spars, women's reserve of the Coast Guard, have been lowered to admit women with only two years' high school education, the Navy Department stated today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Daniel W. Bell, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, announced tonight that subscriptions to the first Victory Loan had gone $2,000,000,000 above the goal of $9,000,000,000 originally set and that they might reach $12,000,000,000 before the books were closed at midnight tonight on the more important issues.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Dodgers may go north to Yale's huge Coxe Memorial Baseball Cage for their Spring training, it was disclosed tonight by Harold F. Woodcock, the Yale Athletic Association business manager.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 23 -- The Argentine Military Attache, Jose C. Balbin, was expelled from this country early last September by the Mexican Government because of alleged pro-Axis activities, it was learned this evening.
Business properties figured in several of the larger real estate deals reported in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission received today an examiner's proposal for reorganization of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville (Monon) Railway Company which would reduce the capitalization from $45,344,943 to $30,079,094 and cut fixed charges from $1,513,028 to $162,547.

Sorrowing parents and a joyous mother were among contributors to the Christmas appeal for the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. Their heartfelt gifts bespeak the deep sympathy that inspires so many gifts, both large and small, to bring Christmas cheer and comfort and relief from suffering to the hundreds of men, women and children who are the people of the Neediest Cases attested by eight leading private charities.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A special Soviet communique:

Marie Wilkins of Lawrence, Kan., who stepped into the title role of "Lakme" in place of Lily Pons at the Metropolitan Opera House at short notice three weeks ago, became a permanent member of the Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday.

The Dominican Government has taken steps to finance the repatriation of six of its citizens, interned by Venezuela on the island of Guazina, it was announced yesterday by J.M. Troncoso, the Dominican Minister to Washington.

A dispatch from China printed in this newspaper reported that the Axis has sunk the transport that was bringing Christmas presents and special exchange supplies to our forces in India and China. Yet there are said to be 1,800 pounds of turkey in Calcutta. It is hoped that they and quantities of chocolate, cigarettes and tobacco, as well as presents, will arrive by air in time for Christmas.
MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

The statement of five Senators from silver-producing States endorsing the release of Government silver stocks for consumptive use in industry is a hopeful sign. Senators Johnson of Colorado, Clark of Idaho, Wheeler of Montana, Millikin of Colorado and Thomas of Idaho would still retain the subsidy price of 71 cents for domestically produced silver, but they favor making possible a much greater industrial use of the metal.
Twelve Manhattan properties, including three large parcels, were sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The gilt-edge section forged ahead again today on the stock markets. Old Consols, 2 1/2 per cent, were up 5-16 to 81 5-16 and the War Loan 3 1/2s rose 1/8 to 104 15s.

There is a good deal of pessimism afloat at the present time about the economic future of the New York metropolitan region. Some of our native prophets go so far as to forecast the virtual collapse of the area as a center of commerce, industry and finance.

Pre-Christmas parties were on in the city yesterday and last night and the influx of holiday visitors was on in full force, although again the major rail terminals coped smoothly with the rush. They expected even more arrivals today.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended Tuesday totaled 450, which compared with 693 in the preceding week and 203 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Tuesday's arrivals numbered 64, as against 272 the previous Tuesday.

North Africa is pretty far away from Christmas at home for the Americans in General Eisenhower's command. It is nearer home, though not so very near, for the men under General Anderson around Tunis and General Montgomery's men now advancing on Tripoli.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Confidence that Spain and Portugal would remain neutral was expressed by Elmer Davis, head of the Office of War Information, at a press conference today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has announced today that Don Ameche will play the leading role in "Heaven Can Wait," a screen adaptation of Ladislaus Bus-Fekete's, Hungarian play, "Birthday," which Ernst Lubitsch will produce and direct as his first picture under his Fox contract.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique:

New Year's Week will usher in only a quartet of Broadway premieres. Even though the number is slight, optimists point out that the list holds one more than that of last New Year's Week. However, it is a far cry from the pre-depression days, when Christmas and New Year's Weeks brought in more new offerings than could be reviewed by the regular complements of drama departments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The new manpower draft bill of Grenville Clark, New York attorney who drew up the selective service legislation in 1940, is under study at the Capitol as well as in the office of Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

The attrition losses of Japan in the War in the Pacific -- increased yesterday by more American successes -- have been a considerable factor in the first year of war, but they have become a really important factor only since we seized the initiative and occupied the Southern Solomons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Quota restrictions on imports into the United States of crude and fuel oil from Mexico are removed and the tariff duty is reduced 50 per cent under a reciprocal trade agreement concluded today between the two countries.

The German Transocean Agency said yesterday that the "great defensive battle" of the middle Don was still in full swing with no sign that the Soviet drive was slackening, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press London and New York.

As chairman of the German American Emergency Conference, of which organization Professor Franz Boas was one of the founders and a very active member of the advisory board, I would add a few words to your excellent obituary.

H.W. Wilson publishes today "Fact and Fancy in the T.N.E.C. Monographs." The monographs, forty-three of them running to 12,000 pages, are those of the National Association of Manufacturers and they have been analyzed and combed through for their essential content by Noel Sargent, secretary of the N.A.M., and John Scoville, statistician of the Chrysler Corporation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 23 (AP) -- General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery praised the members of his British Eighth Army today for their exploits in the two-month-old drive from El Alamein, Egypt, and expressed the hope "that 1943 will be a very happy year for each one of you."

Leonard Robert O. Jordan testified yesterday in his own defense against charges of sedition that he had always been interested primarily in the betterment of conditions for the Negro race, but that he had never supported Japan in its conflict against the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- After conferring today with the "big four" of the government's petroleum program, James F. Byrnes, economic stabilization director, said he had called railroad operators to come to Washington Tuesday to discuss means of increasing the flow of fuel to the East, but he warned that there was "no hope" of increased allotments for industries or individuals.

Reports from all parts of the country during the season, which ended yesterday in the Central States but continues to Jan. 10 in the Southern zone, indicate more wild ducks for hunters than in many years.

Major Frank Schiel of Arizona, described as the last of the Flying Tigers remaining in China, is dead by a crash in that country. He had stayed there, training fliers, after the disbandment of the American Volunteer Group on July 4. He had won two decorations and had a distinguished record.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- Following four years of investigation at Stanford University, Dr. Maurice Tainter, professor of pharmacology, reported today that "pep pills" containing only one-ten-thousandth of an ounce of methyl-benzedrine would keep a man so stimulated and alert that sleep would be impossible for at least eighteen hours.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 23 -- In a speech to party inspectors in the protectorate assembled in Prague, Reich Deputy K.H. Frank reported that the families of Dr. Eduard Benes, President of the Czechoslovak Government in exile, "and other leaders of an alleged government in London" had been transferred from civilian internment camps to concentration camps.

Major Frank Schiel of Arizona, described as the last of the Flying Tigers remaining in China, is dead by a crash in that country. He had stayed there, training fliers, after the disbandment of the American Volunteer Group on July 4. He had won two decorations and had a distinguished record.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- Following four years of investigation at Stanford University, Dr. Maurice Tainter, professor of pharmacology, reported today that "pep pills" containing only one-ten-thousandth of an ounce of methyl-benzedrine would keep a man so stimulated and alert that sleep would be impossible for at least eighteen hours.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 23 -- In a speech to party inspectors in the protectorate assembled in Prague, Reich Deputy K.H. Frank reported that the families of Dr. Eduard Benes, President of the Czechoslovak Government in exile, "and other leaders of an alleged government in London" had been transferred from civilian internment camps to concentration camps.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Distinguished Service Medal has been awarded to Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, chief of the China Air Task Force of the United States Army. It is his first American decoration. He has also been made a Commander of the Order of the British Empire for the work of his Flying Tigers, the now disbanded American Volunteer Group.

On this Christmas morning the Neediest Cases Fund for the relief of the most distressed men, women and children in New York City stands at $181,942.85. This splendid total was subscribed by 6,630 persons, many of whom contributed, whether in large or small amounts, at a sacrifice to themselves in this year of total war.

So much favorable public interest was created by last month's test campaign of public policy advertising initiated by the Conference of Alcoholic Beverage Industries, Inc., in daily and weekly newspapers of seven Southern States, that the conference has decided to extend the drive to nine-teen additional States immediately.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- This correspondent, who has spent the greater part of the war and the pre-war years in Britain, returned to London recently after five months at home and his first reaction was, "What has happened to Christmas?" He soon found out. It had been a war casualty.

OTTAWA, Dec. 24 -- Legal difficulties that might attend the birth of a baby prince or princess to the Royal House of the Netherlands in Canada next month are likely to be overcome, it was revealed today, by the extraordinary action of granting extraterritorial rights to the place in which the baby will be born.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The greatest coordinated production program this country has ever seen, a program far beyond even his most optimistic imaginings twelve months ago, will be carried out by the United States next year, Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, told a Christmas Eve press conference today.
Victory furniture now being designed for war housing may start a new vogue in 1943, according to leading furniture dealers. Already the public is seeking simpler and smaller furniture for the home.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- General Emile Bethouart, French hero of two wars, arrived here today as head of a military supply mission for the French forces in North Africa.

It's always fun going over the Christmas cards. But some are missing this year. There are good friends who are far from any shops in which Christmas cards can be bought -- in the jungles of New Guinea, the hills of North Africa, the swamps of Guadalcanal or the wide sweep of lonely seas. If they can't write, they are not forgotten. On the contrary, everybody thinks the more of them for it.

Igor Sikorsky talked to the American Society of Mechanical Engineers the other day on the part that intuition plays in invention. A mystical term is this "intuition," as mystical as MacDougall's "instinct of contrivance." To Mr. Sikorsky intuition is a kind of second or inner sight that can be developed like a muscle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Secretary Ickes, in his capacity as Solid Fuel Administrator, appealed again today to bitummous mine operators and the United Mine Workers for settlement of the dispute over terms of extension of the present five-day work week to six days in the soft coal mines.

Christmas brings its message of spiritual victory over trouble, especially to the disillusioned, the Rev. Harry Emerson Fosdick said last night in his Christmas Eve services in the Riverside Church. He contrasted conditions today with those of 1900 years ago and said the Sadducees in the early Christian era did not believe in angels.

Representing many thousands of Long Island commuters and other railroad passengers, the Long Island Transportation Bureau yesterday filed before the Interstate Commerce Commission a brief in opposition to the Long Island Railroad's plea for an increase in commutation fares.

The reactionary movement that had set in during the preceding session was almost totally absent in the cotton futures market yesterday, having been replaced by a moderate amount of trade and commission-house buying which lifted active contracts to final net gains of 8 to 13 points.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) Aviation Cadet Homer L. Hazel, 24, a former Mississippi football star and son of Homer H. Hazel, was killed in a plane collision near McKinnonville, Fla., yesterday. His plane was in collision with one flown by Cadet John F. Mayer, who landed safely.

Among the all-and-sundry requested of Lafayette by General Washington, one hit of investigation might have results today. The Commander in Chief wanted to know why generals had more trouble keeping up the numerical strength of Rhode Island regiments than they had with regiments from other colonies.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24 -- A registration statement covering $22,000,000 prncipal amount of first and general mortgage bonds, bearing 3 1/4 per cent interest and due in 1973, was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, a subsidiary of the New England Public Service Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department announced today a combination government loan and purchase program designed to support prices and encourage production of gum naval stores products for war needs.
The stars looked down last night on a world still dimmed or darkened on Christmas Eve against war's threat of death from the skies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24 -- RKO announced today that Cary Grant has been signed to a five-picture contract by the studio in a deal which specifies no time limits and gives Grant the right to approve his vehicles.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 24 -- New Zealand's war organization is already taking new forms because of the presence of American troops in this country.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 24 -- Allied forces have swept the Germans from the high ground in one area near Medjez-el-Bab, thirty-five miles southwest of Tunis, the first significant offensive action reported on the central Tunisian battlefront in the past two weeks.

Discrepancies in the "perfect alibi" Anibal Almodovar, 21 years old, a Puerto Rican, offered two months ago on his arrest as a material witness in the strangling of his wife, Louise, 24, a Sunday school teacher, in Central Park on Nov. 2, led to his arraignment yesterday in the Homicide Court on a murder charge.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's Christmas message as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec 22 (Delayed) -- It is now possible to reveal that Beaufighters, Britain's crack night planes, are active in some force in North Africa and that the reduction in night bombings in Tunisian and Algerian areas is due in good part to their presence.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Department store sales for the week ended Dec. 19 were 10 per cent up from the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This followed a gain of 17 per cent in the preceding week. Sales in the latest four-week period rose 9 per cent.

With 400 persons watching, fifty-nine children and members of the choir and the clergy participated in a "Feast of Lights" in the Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, Broadway and 155th Street, sang Christmas carols and laid gifts before a creche in which a statue of the Christ Child lay.

After the opening performance of Bach's D major suite, by the Philharmonic-Symphony orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall Mr. Mitropoulos, guest conductor of the occasion, made a speech in behalf of the purchase of war bonds, a brief and well turned address, with humor pervading it.

Nine coast guardsmen, their faces bearded and their uniforms wrinkled and shrunk from long immersion in salt water, told the story yesterday of their twenty-one-day battle against mountainous seas in a dismasted yawl that had once been a racing yacht, yet had the sturdiness to outlive two hurricanes and ten gales in the wintry North Atlantic.

Only a fraction of the collection of medieval art left by George Gray Barnard has been disposed of since his death on April 24, 1938, it was disclosed yesterday by his son and executor, Monroe Barnard, in papers on file in Surrogate's Court.
DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Tigers today were added to the growing list of major league baseball teams deserting their Florida training camps as a travel-saving measure.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The sad Christmas trees of Europe are bringing little joy into the hearts of cold and hungry remnants of families for whom this fourth war Christmas is such an awful contrast to "peace on earth and good will toward men."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Joseph B. Eastman, Director of Defense Transportation, today strongly urged cancellation of all furniture trade shows and marts. Included in the request are the huge midwinter markets scheduled next month in Chicago and in New York.

Bank clearings of $8,292,457,000 for the twenty-three major cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday were 4.3 per cent larger than the previous week and 7.9 per cent above the $7,683,595,000 volume of the corresponding week a year ago, according to yesterday's report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The War Production Board either did not learn its lesson last Thanksgiving or has a short memory, because it came forth again today with a suggestion that housewives save waste fats from their holiday turkeys, geese and ducks.

St. Patrick's Cathedral was as crowded in former years at the midnight pontifical mass, but there were many more men and women in uniform in evidence -- the Waacs being well represented -- when Mgr. William A. Scully, secretary for education of the Archdiocese of New York, suggested in his sermon last night that "perhaps this year America will be more thoroughly religious."

The Johns-Manville Corporation has "shared vigorously" in the wartime program and will continue to do so in 1943, Lewis H. Brown, president, said in a letter sent yesterday to stockholders. "The broad outlook is still troubled, but there is a brighter glow on this December horizon than greeted us at this time last December," he added.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Secretary Hull urged the American people to rededicate themselves to a unity of purpose and unremitting effort in the war in a greeting to the country at his press conference today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- In Russia Christmas Day comes after New Year's, for the Russian Orthodox Church observes the old calendar, which is thirteen days behind the holiday dates in the west. On last Saturday, which was St. Nikolas Day, Moscow churches were well filled and their ikons are still decorated with paper flowers and cheesecloth frills.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Preliminary training over, coaches of the Blue and Gray football squads selected probable starting line-ups today for the North-South contest Saturday.

The four-story house at 221 East Sixty-second Street has been sold by the Chemical National Bank as trustee, Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton Co., agents, to Robert Schmid of Montclair, N.J., who will occupy it as a Winter residence. The house, which was completely modernized three years ago, has a dining room which opens out on a terrace leading to a garden.
MOSCOW, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's noon communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- While saying that the participation of American soldiers in actual combat made impossible a "Merry Christmas," President Roosevelt addressed to all the people today his belief that the Yuletide will be happier than last year because "the forces of darkness stand against us with less confidence in the success of their evil ways."

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. Universal's "Arabian Nights" will be the new holiday attraction at the Rivoli Theatre. The Walter Wanger Technicolor production features Maria Montez as Scheherazade, and Jon Hall, Leif Erikson, Sabu, Billy Gilbert, Acquanetta, Shemp Howard, Elyse Knox and John Qualen. . . . "Over My Dead Body." a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy mystery, will be the new offering at the Central.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Captain James Fife Jr. of the Navy received today the Distinguished Service Medal for exceptional service as Chief of Staff, Submarines, Asiatic Fleet, in the fighting in Asiatic waters early in the war. Captain Fife's home is at 40 West Twelfth Street, New York City.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The noon communique:

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 24 -- During the first thirty-eight months since Canada declared war on Germany 4,000 more men volunteered for service than were obtained in the last war by voluntary enlistment and conscription. The total number of volunteers up to Oct. l was 616,598, which is 27.8 per cent of all males in the Dominion in the age groups 19 to 45.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Renewed reports from Washington that the ceiling price for flour might be raised 78 cents a barrel started mills and professional operators buying wheat futures today on the Board of Trade and prices of that grain rose about 1 cent a bushel from the previous finish.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 24 Happy Family, now the property of Harry Brown but formerly owned by C.V. Whitney and then by Hugh McL. Fenwick, profited by a slow pace and came on to win the Christmas Eve Purse by half a length at Tropical Park today.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed an increase of $89,754,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, a record high. Note circulation also advanced to a new high by an expansion in notes of $134,993,000. Ratios of reserve at the New York bank, and the twelve Reserve banks combined, declined to new lows.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Office of Price Administration today acted to bring butter, cheddar cheese, evaporated milk and bulk skim milk under specific dollars-and-cents price ceilings, except at retail, effective Dec. 30, in an effort to encourage producers to meet the Department of Agriculture's current peak output goals for these essential dairy staples.
CAMP UPTON, L.I., Dec. 24 -- Christmas religious services began at this camp tonight with a midnight mass in the post chapel with Chaplain John McGrath officiating.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Dec. 25 -- Allied airmen have sunk a Japanese destroyer, a transport and a cargo ship to the north of New Guinea in the most widespread air sweeps in the Southwest Pacific in many weeks, while American and Australian ground forces have penetrated to what an official communique today described as "the last line" of Japanese defenses in the Buna area.

Operating schedules to be observed by leading New York department stores for the next two week-ends, and on night openings during the holiday period, were announced yesterday by the Retail Dry Goods Association. The following stores will be closed tomorrow, but are planning to be open on Saturday, Jan. 2:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- A plan to have people slice their own bread took shape today as a prelude to a broad program of holding down the cost-of-living essentials where necessary by eliminating frills.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Satisfaction in the immediate past and optimism for the future was the keynote of various Christmas messages issued today for British fighting men in the mid-East by their leaders. But no hint was there of even a temporary letup nor attempt to minimize the struggle that lies ahead.

Christmas Day, 1942, finds this nation doing all it can to spread death and destruction among its enemies. Yet we can think of peace and good-will without too much sadness. For all our soldiers, sailors, marines and fliers we can join our President in sending heartfelt Christmas greetings.

The War Labor Board in Washington moved yesterday to end a slowdown that has been in progress all week at the plants of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation as a consequence of differences between the management and the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., over job grading and wage classifications.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 24 -- Georgia emphasized forward passing in a brisk workout today, while the Bulldogs' star, all-America Frankie Sinkwich, sat on the sideline nursing two injured ankles -- just eight days before the Rose Bowl football clash with U.C.L.A.

From the Soviet war news and from the speeches of the Soviet leaders the outside world has gained a fair notion of what is the fatherland for which the Russian armies are fighting. It is not the new Soviet fatherland but the old Russian home whose past merges into the present.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Government economists estimate that consumers will have about 10 per cent more money for goods, services and savings in 1943 than this year, but that the volume of goods and services will be about 10 per cent smaller.

WITH UNITED STATES AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Dec. 22 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- American bombers turned the Japanese supply base at Lashio, Burma, into a flaming inferno tonight, strewing tons of fragmentation and incendiary bombs on warehouses, barracks and supply dumps.
The Federal Machine and Welder Company reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended with September net profit of $514,204 after $910,000 Federal income and excess profits taxes, and other charges.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Treasury Department called attention today to the fact that the Revenue Act of 1942 allows a taxpayer owning at least half of the stock of a corporation that has suffered substantial losses by war to treat a portion of his loss upon the liquidation of such a corporation as a war loss.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Last night, according to the Air Ministry, offensive patrols were carried out over Western Germany and Northern France and Belgium, where freight trains and other railroad objectives were sprayed with cannon shells and machine-gun bullets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The original manuscript of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's poem, "The Village Blacksmith," has been presented by Frank J. Hogan, Washington book collector and former president of the American Bar Association, to the Library of Congress as "a gift to the nation," Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Allied forces on the offensive in Tunisia have a "fairly good margin" of superiority over the Axis forces defending Tunis and Bizerte, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson told reporters today at a press conference here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Twelve Midwestern States proved the biggest bulwark for the Republicans in the November elections. A tabulation of final official figures today showed that the Republicans won just about half of their House victories, 103 out of 209, in that area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Further sharp increases in prices in primary market for grains, cotton and certain fruits and vegetables and higher prices for hay, hogs and sheep caused the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of nearly 900 price series to advance 0.2 per cent during the week ended on Dec. 19.

The two arbitrators appointed by the War Labor Board to adjudicate the dispute between the Publishers Association of New York and the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, which tied up delivery of eight major newspapers last week, held its eighth and possibly final session yesterday at the office of the State Mediation Board at 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.

WITH THE ALLIED ARMIES, in Tunisia, Dec. 20 (Delayed) -- While the main Allied forces reconcentrate for a second onslaught toward Tunis small bodies of American and British troops are fighting a guerrilla war between the front lines, smashing up German patrols and cutting communications.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 24 -- Although many have predicted a break-off in relations with the Axis at about this date after increasing pressure from the supporters of the democracies, in all probability the year-end will see no alteration in Chile's present position of "non-belligerency."

LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The weekly statement of condition of the Bank of England, issued today, reported another high record for notes in circulation, with an increase of 12,246,000 to the total of 920,569,000. This was the fourteenth consecutive weekly advance.

MELBOURNE. Dec. 24 -- Representative wool men here declare that a conference of accredited representatives of all branches of the industry ought to be held by the United Kingdom soon to devise plans for the future of the industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- To the ingenuity and humor of an officer of the Navy on duty in the Far Pacific a few families in the United States are indebted for a letter which gives an accurate, though amusing, description of the environment in which their boys are fighting the Japanese.

AT ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, North Africa, Dec. 24 (AP) -- From the foxholes of the front lines to the Rue Michelet in Algiers, Christmas for American soldiers in North Africa will be a day of improvisations and substitutions.

A "slight mishap" to an IRT subway train entering the South Ferry terminal halted all service there for one hour from 3:27 P.M. yesterday and disrupted the entire West Side system to such an extent that normal operation was not resumed until long after the evening rush had subsided.

The fighting in the Pacific yesterday was again concentrated in the Solomons and the New Guinea area, but many observers believed that new "fronts" must be opened in this vast zone of conflict before the Japanese enemy can be defeated.

"Proof Thro' the Night," a play by Allan R. Kenward, will be presented tonight at the Morosco by Lee Shubert. The play formerly was known as "Cry Havoc" and that title will be retained for the moving picture. According to an official announcement, the story now deals with "the heroism of American women under fire" at Bataan and employs an all-woman cast. Originally, the plot dealt with the Army nurses there.

Santa Claus has brought to the Eastern ski world its best snow conditions for the holidays in several years, with those getting a "civilian furlough" from their labors taking full advantage of the good skiing. Snow reports last night indicated that prospects for slope and trail running are bright, indeed.

Service on the city's unified transit lines must and will continue without interruption and the city will not permit itself to be intimidated by threats of a strike, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday, replying to the strike threat made Wednesday by Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O.

Fifteen Boy Scouts of Nature Study Troop 472 of the Kips Bay Boys Club marched to the bridge crossing the Fifty-ninth Street lake in Central Park yesterday morning and started the troop's sixteenth year of providing food for wild birds and small game that seek sanctuary in the city parks.
MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A special communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 24 -- The German retreat in Tripolitania proceeded yesterday with only occasional skirmishes between Axis patrols and those of the pursuing British Eighth Army. Operations are still in the neighborhood of Sirte and the enemy has done nothing to indicate his immediate intention.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- The big Russian offensive across the middle Don swept forward farther last night despite enemy attempts to stem it from prepared positions with counter-attacks by considerable groups of tanks and planes. Russian forces were reported to be within fourteen miles of the railroad junction of {illerovo on the east and twenty on the west.

A few paragraphs in a certain advertisement concerned fishing and yet expressed a good deal of what one might deem appropriate to say today. They seemed to summarize the sentiment that rings through the Christmas messages that have arrived from far and near.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- To meet the situation created by the continuance of abnormally cold weather in most of the seventeen Eastern States, the Office of Price Administration today made usable on Monday third period fuel oil coupons which otherwise would not have been valid before the first week in January.

Favorite of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and Commander in Chief of all the forces left to the Vichy government, Admiral Jean Francois Darlan turned to the cause of the United Nations in one of the most sensational political and military somersaults in history after American forces invaded French North Africa in November.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Estimates of hardwood lumber consumption for 1943 totaling 5,670,000,000 feet were presented by the lumber and lumber products division of WPB today in a bulletin addressed to members of the Hardwood Lumber Manufacturers Industry Advisory Committee, hardwood manufacturers and distributors of hardwood lumber.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Roosevelt continued her annual Christmas Eve custom today of attending parties arranged for needy children, though two of the usual parties had been cancelled. She carried personal greetings from the President to the children.

WITH THE RED ARMY, on the Stalingrad Front, Dec. 22 (Delayed) -- Major Gen. I.N. Chistiakoff, Commander in Chief of the Red Army on the Northwest-Stalingrad front, said today that the twenty-two German divisions trapped in the Don River bend were doomed.

Are you aware that THE TIMES has been an innocent breeder of much suspense and anxiety among the not-yet-reading members of many families which receive the paper daily? It is time you knew on what a tense, nerve-racking race you carry the score every day in that box in the upper right-hand corner, front page.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Treasury Department established specifications today for the new wartime 1-cent zinc-coated steel coin recently authorized by Congress to help meet the small-coin shortage created by the wartime boom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- In the bill which President Roosevelt signed today, providing pay increases for about 1,500,000 government employes, overtime pay applies to the first $2,900 of annual salary and, computed on a basis of a 360-day year, gives employes working forty-four hours a week an increase of 10.8 per cent and those working forty-eight hours a rise of 21.6 per cent.

"Peace" issues imparted yesterday a firmer tone to the stock market as prices generally edged irregularly higher. Switching and year-end tax-selling, principally in the low-priced public utilities, absorbed most of the day's attention, with only meager demand for prime investment shares.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- All Christmas mail sent to troops overseas prior to last Nov. 1, the deadline originally set by the War Department, has been delivered, except for the letters and parcels sunk at sea, it was announced today by Secretary Stimson.

Today is a legal holiday for all banks and financial markets, in normal times, in every country throughout the world, with two or three exceptions. All banks and markets will be closed in the United States, but will reopen tomorrow.

With Boston's Ted Williams setting a fast pace, five American League players, three of them Yankees, cracked the century mark in the highly coveted achievement of runs batted in, according to the 1942 figures just released.

The name given to the agreement signed this week by Spain and Portugal is as significant as anything in the document. It is called the Iberian Neutrality Pact, and the title is as important at the present stage of the war as the fact that the two Governments have chosen this time to cut through the obstacles which have hitherto stood in the way of a common statement of policy.

Dulled a bit by the loss to Niagara on Tuesday night, the basketball picture at St. John's naturally has lost some of its sparkle, but Coach Joe Lapchick, veteran mentor of the Redmen, does not view the future with gloom. In fact, he confidently expects this team may be one of the most successful he has directed there.

KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Five thousand demonstrating employes of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company demanded immediate payment of their wages tonight after they had left their jobs in the plant four hours before the normal quitting time.

OTTAWA, Dec. 24 (Canadian Press ) -- Dominion Government deposits in the Bank of Canada decreased $20,513,000 to $16,453,000 in the week ended yesterday, it was shown today in the bank's weekly statement. Notes in circulation increased $12,192,000 to $692,641,000.

Mrs. Busch Greenough of the St. Regis gave her annual Christmas Eve dinner party last night in the Louis XVI Suite of the hotel. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. Fritz Kreisler, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Morris Phillips, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Busch.

John Fannelli, a fish handler employed by the Beyer Fish Company, 110 South Street, was found shot dead at 1:45 P.M yesterday under circumstances that puzzled the police although they inclined to the belief that he was slain frustrating a hold-up.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- The religious believers of Moscow, like religious folk all over Russia, are preparing to celebrate Christmas Day. Our Moscow churches, renewed by their Summer and Autumn repairs, and resplendent in gilt and electric light, will, as always, throw open their doors wide to the religious at this festive season.
LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Gilt-edge stocks were again a strong feature today on the market here. The 2 1/2 per cent consols rose to 82 1/4 and the 3 1/2 per cent war loan to 104 15/16.

Repercussions of the Treasury's Victory Loan Drive appeared in the Federal Reserve System's figures for the week ended on Wednesday, as disclosed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. To strengthen the reserve position of the member banks in the week the Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System purchased $89,754,000 of government securities, resuming buying which had run twelve consecutive weeks and been interrupted by sales last week.

Samuel Reshevsky captured the tenth game of his match with Isaac L Kashdan for the United States chess championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel last night. The victor, who conducted the black pieces, took a pawn on the thirty-second move and ended the game seven moves later.

Men's clothing manufacturers who failed to take the opportunity to bid for the early Army and Navy uniform business are now feeling the full impact of the war as civilian demand has narrowed, observers in the market declared yesterday.

Wartime shortages and the high cost of living appeared yesterday to have limited the Christmas tree supply this year. But it seemed unlikely that any one would have to do without a tree -- that is, any one willing to pay the price.

A lot of New York families will take second place in the attentions of their feminine members this Christmas while women volunteers maintain their services to the city's needy. A survey of volunteer organizations has shown that both the holiday eve and the day itself, in most cases, are being conducted on the basis of "business as usual."
New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from George L. Worthington to Charles Plohn and from William B. Reilly to Henry Brevoort Seaman.

Joao Alberto Lins de Barros, coordinator of economic mobilization in Brazil, declared yesterday that his country was preparing to increase its exports of rubber to the United States and of food and raw materials to the expeditionary forces in North Africa if the needed manpower were made available next year.

The Treasury's great war loan drive has achieved a real victory on the war finance front. Against the original goal of $9,000,000,000 a total of over $11,000,000,000 has already been announced, and $12,000,000,000 was in sight for yesterday's midnight deadline.

Individual textile converters who depleted their stocks to supply war-aid emergency buying for North African civilian relief have obtained AA-5 ratings to enable quick replenishments, it was reported in the market yesterday. In the absence of official announcement, it was understood such priorities could be applied only to actual replacement and not to acquiring of additional yardage.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Coach Hunk Anderson may throw the T formation out of the window when his National Football League All-Stars battle the Washington Redskins in the Professional Bowl game at Shibe Park on Sunday.

BERNE, Dec. 22 (Delayed) (U.P. i 1 -- The season of "Peace on earth to I men of good wiII" finds Nazi overlords of the oppressed EuropeanI people in a dark mood and this Christmas they are not making even the slight gesture of allowing an extra fuel or food ration for| the holidays.

DAKAR, French West Africa, Dec. 24 (AP) -- United States troops have arrived in Dakar and a special Army and Navy mission headed by Vice Admiral William A. Glassford is at work determining how the city's airports and harbor facilities and the French ships here best can be fitted into Allied plans.

No Christmas sermon reaches a larger congregation than the message Pope Plus XII addresses to a war-torn world at this season. This Christmas more than ever he is a lonely voice crying out of the silence of a continent. The pulpit whence he speaks is more than ever like the Rock on which the Church was founded, a tiny island lashed and surrounded by a sea of war.

The Peruvian Aprista party, seconding the initiative of Dr. Hugo Fernandez Artucio, director of the Latin American Bureau of Free World Association, has agreed to appeal to all the citizens of Latin America to form a Latin-American division, which would cooperate with the armed forces of the United Nations in defense of the democracies.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 24 -- Clean rooms and good food, including such American specialties as hamburgers and hot dogs, will be available to the United States Army enlisted men on leave in Cairo at a special Red Cross hotel and club opened yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, United States Commander in the Middle East.

Though THE TIMES closes today its thirty-first annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest, we know from past experience that gifts to the fund will continue to pour in for a long time to come. There are many old friends of the Neediest, living far from New York, whose contributions will be slow in reaching us, especially in this wartime year of heavy mails and overburdened transportation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Aluminum Company of America declared today that a Justice Department statement that "The war emergency is operating to entrench Alcoa more deeply than ever in its monopolistic position," was "unbounded and unwarranted."

Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, High Commissioner in French North and West Africa and former vice premier of the Vichy government, was assassinated yesterday afternoon as he stepped into the offices of the High Commissariat in Algiers.
