MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 25 -- The fourth major Soviet Winter offensive, in the critical Nalchik area of the Caucasus, was announced early today by the Russians, and the total enemy killed or captured in the continuing advance in the middle Don area of the third offensive mounted to 92,000 Nazis and satellites.

Two courses in the manufacture of synthetic rubber are among the twenty-seven tuition-free evening classes in engineering, science and management to be offered early in January at City College, it was announced yesterday by Professor William Allan, institutional representative of the United States Office of Education, which is sponsoring the program.

Christmas disbursements totaling $136,937 were made yesterday by the New York Community Trust, the largest amount that the trust ever has paid out in one day. There were 106 holiday grants, most of them in or near New York, but appropriations went also to fifteen other cities, including Baltimore, San Francisco, Washington, Seattle and San Diego.

The public reactions to Mr. Henderson's resignation are rather curious in one respect. His critics have emphasized his over-aggressiveness, bluntness, lack of political tact, and the needlessly complicated rules he has fathered. These criticisms may be quite justified.
Salary increases ranging from $180 to $1,040 a year were awarded yesterday afternoon to twenty-eight members of the Department of Sanitation who were promoted to higher ranks.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 24 -- Rudolph Nies, 36 years old, recently indicted for first-degree murder in the stabbing of his wife, Emma, 33, on Dec. 6 at their home in Islip Terrace, L.I., was committed today to Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane at Beacon, N.Y., by Suffolk County Judge L. Barron Hill on the application of District Attorney Fred J. Hunter.

The ODT's urgent request that all furniture markets be canceled was interpreted by the trade here as tantamount to an order, and buyers and sellers alike prepared to call off arrangements on short notice. It was pointed out, however, that unless the cancellation is made mandatory, the decision rests with officials of the buildings in which the events are held.

ALLIED BASE, New Guinea, Dec. 22 -- An American force on the Buna front accomplished last night and today one of the most difficult of all military operations, the crossing of an unfordable stream at night and establishment of a bridgehead on the far side.

A person who is "contaminated with the germ of Nazism" is "totally unfit to rear and guide the destiny of any living thing," Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan declared yesterday in denying to an enemy alien held on Ellis Island the custody of his daughter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Members of Congress in key posts, expecting a determined movement in the new Congress to hold down non-war expenditures, are giving support to a plan for establishing machinery through which departmental and bureau appropriation requests would be checked by auditors and other experts accountable to the national Legislature.

When Christmas Day of 1941 arrived this country had recently received a stab in the back by one of the gangster powers signatories of the anti-Comintern pact to "defend civilization from the Bolshevik menace."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- President Roosevelt approved today a joint resolution increasing the pay of about 1,277,000 government employes and simultaneously ordered all Federal offices to adopt a forty-eight-hour week, to eliminate every nonessential service, to seize every opportunity for improving the speed and efficiency of work, and to conserve manpower, materials and money.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 24 -- "Arms to fight with now and jobs to live by later" were promised today to members of the armed forces, in a Christmas message addressed to them by the American Legion, through Roane Waring, national commander.

An 18-year-old high school youth was wounded and captured at 11 A.M. yesterday after a running pistol battle with a detective which drove terrified crowds of Christmas shoppers on Sixth Avenue to shelter in stores and hallways. Before the youth was captured, however, he had shot and critically wounded Detective Bradley Hammond, a 44-year-old veteran police, officer attached to the West Fifty-fourth Street station.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 24 -- Following is the text of the statement adopted by the American Institute of Judaism on a just and enduring peace:

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- Well-informed neutral quarters close to the Axis said today that Pierre Laval had pledged France to sweeping collaboration with the German war effort, including the sending of 60,000 French "volunteers" to fight the Russians and 300,000 others to work in German plants.

Judge Learned Hand's speech at the meeting in the Supreme Court of the United States to pay tribute to the memory of Justice Brandeis dwelt mainly upon one aspect of his thought. His objection to the great size of corporations is well known. But that was only part of a larger philosophical view.
Contributions from invalids, from school children, from men in the armed forces enriched the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday by their sympathy for the unfortunate as well as by the amounts given.
Miss Elizabeth Upham Yates of Bristol, Ae., former woman suffrage leader and missionary, died on Wednesday in Watertown, Mass., after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday.

Opposition to the use of New York City public schools for the teaching of "sex hygiene" and control of venereal diseases was made yesterday in The Catholic News, which urged Catholic parents in this city to refuse to permit their children to attend these classes.

LEWISTOWN, Pa., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Experts of the State Health Department went on twenty-four hour duty in the quarantined Kishacoquillas Valley farming region tonight to battle a spreading smallpox outbreak among Amish farm folks.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 24 -- A federation of nations with a court of international justice, and a worldwide police force as a means of perpetuating the peace to come, were advocated here today by the American Institute of Judaism after a four-day session.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- President Roosevelt has sent a message to the armed forces and auxiliary services of the Allies conveying the season's greetings and expressing "a fervent hope and player for a speedy and complete victory and a lasting peace."

The Bank of the Manhattan Company announced yesterday the following promotions: Harold Pow elson, from trust officer to assis-i rant secretary; inor L. Wheaton, from assist2nt trust officer to ssistant secretary; Francis E, Curran, James A. Fryatt and Franklin B. Kellogg, from assistant trust officers to trust officers; John W. Gates, Charles B. Iq[cGuire and Stanley V. Malek, assistant cashiers; John A. Gluckert, assistant trust officer.
The following is the official translation of the Pope's address broadcast yesterday over the Vatican Radio Station HVJ, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 24 (AP) -- British troops are steadily pushing into Burma and within the last few days have occupied another district just across the border from India's Bengal Province, Lieut. Gen. N.M.S. Irwin, commander of the Eastern India Army, said tonight.

Only six additional appeals from fuel oil rations granted by local boards have reached the State headquarters of the Office of Price Administration in the two weeks since the first appeal was filed, it was said last night at the State office, 535 Fifth Avenue.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., Dec. 25 -Religious services and a roast turkey dinner marked the observance of Christmas today by the permanent personnel and unassigned selectees of this camp. Otherwise work proceeded as usual throughout the day, followed by dances for the soldiers tonight in the camp and in near-by villages.

Pre-New Year and post-Christmas sermons will be preached in the city's churches tomorrow. Many candle-light services will be held, and in every house of worship prayers will be offered for world peace before next Christmas. The hope will be expressed that 1943 will be "a victorious new year."

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A slight advance by Allied ground troops on the left side of the line was virtually the only operation reported to have occurred yesterday to break the calm of Christmas Day in the Buna battle area of Northeast New Guinea.
At the Savoy-Plaza Hotel the recently organized Officers Wives Club held open house yesterday for officers away from home. Hundreds were present and everything was free.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A special Russian communique

When the winds howl and the thermometer hovers around zero, there is nothing quite so comfortable as a good hot drink. You think first of coffee -- then reconsider, for your allotment permits only one cup a day and you had that for breakfast. Hot chocolate?

BLACK MOUNTAIN, N. C., Dec. 25 -- Complete social, political and economic emancipation for the Negro in a world that is seeking true democracy was advocated here today by the Fellowship of Southern Churchmen in a statement which calls upon all followers of democracy and Christianity to become "color blind."

ALBANY, Dec. 25 -- The beginning of Christmas buying earlier than usual was responsible in part for gains of 4.6 per cent in employment and payroll gains of 3.3 per cent in retail stores in the State from October to the middle of November, Frieda S. Miller, New York State Industrial Commissioner, revealed today.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 24 (Delayed) -- "Most of us will have large holes in the toes of our Christmas stockings this year," said Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. (Uncle Joe) Stilwell, commander of United States Army forces in China, Burma and India, in greetings to the American soldiers under his command in this corner of the world.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- Private First Class Robert Eland Perkins, 22 years old, an Army deserter who had been sought since the robbery and shooting of a war plant worker here on Dec. 9, was booked at the Rye city police headquarters late today on charges of felonious assault and robbery.

The American League still is breaking or tying records, but the 1942 pace wasn't quite up to that of the two previous seasons, it is revealed by a long list of assorted figures released today by the junior circuit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Increasing government control over the electric utility industry after the war, with a common carrier status applied to transmission lines as a means of effectuating creation of regional "grid" systems similar to those existing in Britain, was forecast as a "possibility" today by the American Council on Public Affairs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 25 -A conflict between Monogram and Twentieth-Century-Fox appeared today with Monogram's announcement that "The Grand Street Boys," a vehicle for Leo Gorcey, Bobby Jordan, Huntz Hall and Gabriel Dell, would go before the cameras Jan. 15.
Prayers for victory and an everlasting peace based on justice, sanity and good-will were offered at traditional Christmas services yesterday in churches throughout the city.

A message of hope in which it was stressed that Christianity will triumph and reign despite all evil that men can do was given by Bishop William T. Manning at the Christmas Day service at 11 A.M. yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- Intermittent snow storms have not stemmed the momentum of the Red Army's advance on the central Don front, an advance that is now having its effect on the Kotelnikov and Central and Western Caucasus sectors. As the Russians press toward the Donets bend, the fringes of the great German salient toward the Volga and the Caucasus are being clipped off.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 -- The last-place New York Rangers seized their first National Hockey League victory in nearly a month by downing the Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 1, before 7,890 spectators at the Olympia tonight. The defeat was Detroit's first on home ice in ten games this season.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Dec. 25 -Twelve students of Columbia University who were sent from the Soviet Union to study American life are guest over the holidays of Mr. and Mrs. Rockwell Kent at their country home south of Ausable Forks.

H. Fedotoff White has signed a contract with the Princeton University Press for publication of his book "The Growth of the Red Army," a study in military sociology. White is a former Russian naval officer who now lives in Philadelphia.

Another appeal from the Conservation Department directed to New York sportsmen and especially to those who were successful during the recent open season on deer has been received. The present call asks for contributions of deer hides that may be converted into various types of garments for the armed forces.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Picked teams of collegians from the North and South will clash tomorrow in the fifth annual Blue and Gray football game. Each side has won two of the previous four contests, so this one should be the rubber match.

Train operation through the 4.6-mile underground section of the uncompleted $23,000,000 Atlantic Avenue grade crossing elimination project will begin Monday morning. An inspection trip for public officials and company executives will be made this morning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 (By Science Service) -- Immediate examination by competent pathologists of those first killed in catastrophes is urged, as one lesson of the Boston night club fire, in a report by Dr. N.W. Faxon and Dr. E.D. Churchill, director and chief, respectively, of the West Surgical Service of the Massachusetts General Hospital.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Dec. 25 (AP) -- A two-day strike of bus and street-car operators ended early today after the Citizens Rapid Transit Corporation agreed to reinstate, without prejudice, two union members who had been suspended. Thomas B. Morton, conciliator of the United States Department of Labor, said that the strikers were informed also that the War Labor Board would take up for consideration on Monday the issue of increased wages.

EDGEWATER PARK, Miss., Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Tennessee Volunteers took the forenoon off today but went to the Gulf Coast Military Academy for an afternoon workout that lasted more than two hours. It was the first full-speed session in preparation for the New Year's football game with Tulsa, and one of the hardest drills of the season.

The United Seamen's Service records show that nearly 30,000 officers and men of the merchant marine have availed themselves of its facilities in the fourteen weeks since its inception, Douglas P. Falconer, national executive director of the organization, declared yesterday.

After having withheld her wares from a New York audience for two years, Ruth Draper returned last evening to the New York Times Hall on West Forty-fourth Street, with her familiar sketches, portraits and caricatures reasonably untarnished by the passage of time.
Christmas Day, 1942, found the world locked in combat to establish the kind of peace that day has symbolized for nineteen centuries.
THERE are enough bulldogs serving colleges as mascots to fill any moderately sized kennel. The lions, tigers, leopards, et al, would cause a housing shortage in even a large zoo.

The "expedient" was even more temporary than was expected. Fate, in the shape of an assassin's bullet, has answered the burning question of Admiral Darlan's future role in the unfolding tragedy of France. This question -- how long is temporary? -- lay at the core of the bitter controversy that has clouded the occupation of French Africa.

With the arrest yesterday of three youths in Queens, friends of Nicholas Marchese, 18-year-old high school student who shot and seriously wounded Detective Bradley Hammond, the police said they had solved a series of burglaries in that borough.

The Administration is said to have abandoned the idea of any general use of subsidies to hold down the cost of food. Instead, wherever costs of production exceed price ceilings price advances will be permitted, in most cases, to wipe out inequities that may arise. The Administration is said to have been brought to this conclusion by the excessive cost of subsidies.

DAKAR, French West Africa, Dec. 25 (AP) -- News of the assassination in Algiers of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan was received with consternation today by the people here, who, in view of the recent arrival of American service troops, otherwise would have observed the most joyous Christmas in several years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Navy communique 229:

Wage rates for women in war industries, including the beginning wage, should be the same as for men, a pamphlet just issued by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor declares, pointing out that this policy has been upheld by many agencies.

Hertha Glaz, Vienna-born contralto, who made her debut at the Metropolitan Opera last night as Amneris in the season's second "Aida," is not a stranger to this city or country. Since she came here in 1937 she has sung in concert in New York and out of town, and has appeared in opera as a member of the visiting Salzburg Opera Guild and with the San Francisco, Chicago and St. Louis Opera companies.

The Rev. Dr. Harold A. Cockburn of the Church of Scotland is in New York, having been sent to the United States by the British Government as liaison officer between the churches of Great Britain and America "for the purpose of fostering friendship and increasing cooperation between these two groups of Christians."

The Algiers radio broadcast yesterday the text of a decree issued five days ago by Admiral Jean Francois Darlan in which French citizens in North Africa were forbidden to communicate in any manner with persons in France or other "enemy territory."

Rejoicing in the privilege of being able to give to any charity in "this wonderful land of freedom" marked the spirit in which 602 persons in all walks of life in all parts of the country sent the gifts that reached the Neediest Cases Fund on Christmas Day.

Rabbi William F. Rosenblum, in a sermon yesterday at Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, declared that it was apparent now as never before that men were risking their lives on more than three score battlefronts in order that what had come to be known as the Judaeo-Christian way of life that worships God and holds hu manity sacred may not perish from the earth.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Coach Wallace Butts drove the Georgia football team through another long practice today devoting the first half of the workout to defense against U.C.L.A. plays and the rest to brushing up the Bulldog attack for the Rose Bowl game New Year's Day.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Christmas message broadcast by King George today to the British Empire:

Final returns of last month's voting, reported yesterday by The Associated Press, confirm the conclusion that defection from the Democratic party was the decisive factor in the outcome of the Congressional elections. The Republicans came within nine votes of capturing a majority of the House of Representatives.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's noon communique:

The life of a college athletic director must be a constant headache these days judging from all the statements pertaining to traveling sports teams that have emanated from the Office of Defense Transportation in recent weeks.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
Adolphe de Milly, editor here of the Fighting French newspaper, Voix de France, issued the following statement last night from his home at 306 West 105th Street:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, North Africa, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Christmas ranged from gaudy to dismal for United States troops in North Africa today but the less fortunate shrugged off their luck and, as one said, "if we just get the war over we can do without celebrating."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- President Roosevelt interrupted his holiday today to receive reports on the situation in North Africa resulting from the murder of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, head of the French authorities there.

A Southern team and a Far West five will supply the opposition tonight at Madison Square Garden, where City College stacks up against Oregon State and St. John's University of Brooklyn engages Tennessee, in that order, in an intersectional college basketball double-header.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The War Department has appointed a Subsistence Research Projects Board to develop new food products and rations for the Army. It will both initiate research and review worth while suggestions from outside sources.

The German and Italian propaganda radios broadcast yesterday "explanations" of the assassination of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan in Algiers, and described the murder as a British plot engineered by Prime Minister Winston Churchill to embarrass President Roosevelt.

With trading light because of the holiday, three sales of residential properties on the West Side of Manhattan were reported by brokers. An apartment house and a farm in New Jersey also were listed in new ownerships.

New financing this week was the smallest for any week in three months. Only one issue of tax-exempt bonds, amounting to $350,000, was offered to the public, compared with one of $3,140,000 in the preceding week and two loans aggregating $7,833,000 in this week a year ago.

The efforts of the War Production Board to conserve the use of steel for critical war purposes have shown their effect in the monthly booking reports of fabricated structural steel received by the American Institute of Steel Construction, it was anounced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- An increase of three-tenths of a cent a gallon on the ceiling price of fuel oil delivered to ration coupon holders was authorized today by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, effective Tuesday, to cover additional costs being incurred by oil dealers as the result of emergencies.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- King George VI sounded an optimistic note in his fourth Christmas broadcast to the world today. His speech was aimed directly at the empire and it was full of pride in the achievements of the empire.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Persons familiar with General Charles de Gaulle's basic policies expressed the belief tonight that the Fighting French leader shortly would make a formal declaration of his willingness to cooperate fully with General Henri Honore Giraud if General Giraud became head of French North Africa.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Governors of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange have raised the trading price ceiling on January onion futures from $1.65 to $1.72 a fifty-pound sack and adopted larger contracts for onions and potatoes. The new trading units are 40,000 pounds for onions and 45,000 pounds for potatoes, compared with the former respective units of 25,000 and 36,000 pounds a carlot.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- With thirteen colleges entered in the ski events and eight in the hockey, the annual College and Preparatory School Winter Sports Week of the Lake Placid Club will open tomorrow with preliminary games in the hockey tournament.

Holiday travel in and out of New York, which reached a high point on Wednesday and Thursday, ebbed sharply yesterday, spokesmen for all forms of transportation reported last night, but a new rush is expected Sunday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 25 -- Jockey Champion Johnny Adams scored a triple today as a crowd of 7,114 poured $252,376 into the Tropical Park pari-mutuel windows, just $6,454 less than the handle last Christmas Day. The brisk betting reopened the mezzanine windows, which had been closed in a retrenchment effort.
TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 25 (U.P.) -Staff Sergeant Charles Stuart was married yesterday to Miss Lois Floto, 22, of Jackson, Miss., a music teacher who refused to let an airplane crash come between them.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, North Africa, Dec. 24 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- General Henri Honore Giraud said today that the pro-Allied French Government of North Africa "most certainly" plans to cooperate with if not actually consolidate with the Fighting French followers of General Charles de Gaulle.
It was a quiet Christmas for the women of the fighting forces, the Waves, the Waacs and the Spars. A skeleton force remained on duty, but the majority had leave to spend the holiday as they pleased.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 -- With the proclamation by Mayor Edward J. Jeffries Jr. of this week-end as "Jewish National Fund Sabbath," the "Land for Freedom" conference of the Jewish National Fund opened here today.

As a dairy farmer I was much interested in your editorial "Farm Labor Crisis." I agree that the farm labor problem is serious. In fact, I feel that food production is perhaps the most important war production problem which we have to face, because a real shortage of food would seriously hamper the whole war effort.

In response to the proclamation by President Roosevelt setting apart New Year's Day as a day of prayer in behalf of men and women in the armed forces, eight hours will be devoted to uninterrupted prayer at a service under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches on Friday, in the main auditorium of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

WITH THE BRITISH ADVANCE FORCES IN BURMA, Dec. 24 (Delayed) -- The continuation of the rapid advances in this area by British and Indian forces is not expected because of the difficult communications. Troops must move forward in a series of short hops, pausing between each for road building and the organization of river transportation to permit the next push forward.
In the last few weeks attention has been called to the joyous tidings of President Roosevelt's postwar program to remove want from America.

War is destructive. We think in terms of destruction when we plan and build tanks, planes and ships. We mobilize our resources to lay waste. But while our war industries primarily are concerned with the present, fortunately not all our material war efforts are wasted.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Christmas brought the American soldiers and the British people a little closer together. Individually, United States troops were guests in British homes, but collectively they played host to thousands of children of this island, some so young that they have no recollection of anything but war.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -Bomber formations of the United States Middle East Air Force struck Wednesday night at two of Italy's most important southern ports, Naples and Taranto, it was announced officially today.

Even those in this country, in Britain or among the Free French who were most bitterly opposed to the Administration's recognition of Admiral Darlan as High Commissioner in French North Africa and West Africa must condemn his assassination. It is only the ignorant and the thoughtless who will assume that such a murder at such a moment "solves" a peculiarly difficult problem.

Travel restrictions, particularly in regard to automobiles, were the chief cause of a reduction in Christmas accident fatalities this year to a fraction of the 1941 total, according to a nation-wide survey by The Associated Press.

The final statistics issued by the National Football League show the five leading forward passers to be Cecil Isbell, Slingin' Sammy Baugh, Sid Luckman, Tommy Thompson and Wilson Schwenk in that order, with the last-named having the dubious honor of creating a new record by having the largest number of passes intercepted.
Intelligent liberals who see democracy as something worth preserving in the midst of war will perhaps be perturbed by some of the recent developments touching the conscientious objector.
Ensign Frederick C. Tanner Jr., U.S.N.R., and Mrs. Tanner will give a dinner tonight in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Last September a play called "Cry Havoc" opened on the West Coast, and the tidings rushing back said that it was one of the best war plays to date. Last evening Lee Shubert offered it at the Morosco under the name of "Proof Thro' the Night" and it became pretty clear that the coasts do not always see eye to eye on these matters.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Increasing patrol activity on the Tunisian front, particularly in the northern sector, was reported tonight, although the battle area oozed with mud under fresh downpours of Winter rain. This activity still consisted of feeler thrusts. The major battle apparently waited only for an opportune moment and solid ground for the war machines on both sides.

"Jacare," a feature-length adventure picture filmed in the jungles of the Amazon River last Winter and Spring by Clyde E. Elliott, will have its local premiere this morning at the Globe. The film, which features James M. Dannaldson, also has a foreword and commentary by Frank Buck.

Mayor La Guardia is entirely right in declaring that service on the city's unified rapid transit system must continue without interruption and that the city cannot submit to the threat of a strike on the part of transit workers. The right to strike against government, as the Mayor says, has not, is not and cannot be recognized.

WITH THE ALLIED ARMIES, in Tunisia, Dec. 20 (Delayed) -The notes of "Colors" sounded clearly over the little valley, and two platoons of a tank-destroyer company snapped to attention at the command of Second Lieutenant Louis Romani of 33 Seventieth Street, Brooklyn, who was promoted from sergeant after his gun had destroyed four German tanks in furious action of an hour and a quarter, Dec. 10.

Ludwig Baumann, furniture house, plans to close two of its stores, the Harlem and Brooklyn branches, effective immediately, Howard Kuh, executive vice president, announced yesterday. The Brooklyn store, at Hoyt and Livingston Streets, will be taken over by the government for the duration of the war, while the branch at 144 West 125th Street will be shut down because of the increasing difficulty in obtaining merchandise and personnel.
WITH THE ALLIED ARMY IN TUNISIA, Dec. 25 -- United States and British soldiers had a merry Christmas Day despite the presence of the enemy, many of whom were in rifle shot of our positions.

IT is a popular legend that ministers' sons invariably turn out to be black sheep. The truth is that they often become writers, which Max Eastman, Henry Luce, Forrest Davis and other famous ministers' sons in journalism would deny is a form of black sheepdom. Certainly Ladd Haystead, the minister's son author of "Preacher's Kid,"* has succeeded in sublimating any filial urge toward undue wickedness into the constructive pattern of art.

Still another professional barrier against women appeared yesterday to have fallen, as Robert D. Gracey, personnel manager of Price Waterhouse Co., one of New York's largest accounting firms, admitted that the women taken into its staff last Spring had proved to be "very satisfactory."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 25 -- Argentina celebrated Christmas in the sweltering heat of a midsummer day. A strong sun blazing out of a cloudless sky, coupled with the high humidity, caused acute discomfort to many millions who were prevented by their occupations from leaving the cities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, condemned today, in the name of labor, the Nazi atrocities against Jewish and other peoples of conquered and occupied Europe. He said in a statement:

A soldier cannot have the benefit of the exemptions granted under the Soldiers and Sailors Civil Relief Act if he is able to conduct his business while in the service of his country, according to a decision handed down by Justice Peter M. Daly in the Queens Supreme Court.
LITTLE FERRY, N.J., Dec. 25 -- John Van Wetterling, 12 years old, of 59 Prospect Avenue, was accidentally shot and fatally wounded when playing with a revolver in the home of a companion here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The twenty-two-man Western squad went on a single daily practice ration today, with the East continuing to emphasize passes thrown by Paul Governali of Columbia and a fast, tricky running attack in preparation for the all-star charity game here New Year's Day.

HONOLULU, Dec. 25 -- Soldiers, sailors and marines throughout the Hawaiian area were at battle stations today with only the usual number of liberty passes issued, but Christmas cheer was taken to the men, wherever they were.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- The first contingent of United States nurses arrived here just before Christmas, still excited over their trip from Britain.
The matinee performance at the Metropolitan Opera today will be Mozart's "The Magic Flute," and in the evening "Traviata" will be presented.
The appointment of Miss Helen M. Harris as executive director of the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children was announced yesterday by William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare.
The following version of the The assassination of Darlan was recorded from the Algiers radio by monitors of the Federal Communications Commisison:

OCONOMOWOC, Wis., Dec. 25 (AP) -- A forty-room showplace of the gay Nineties era, now a seminary operated by the Augustinian Fathers of Chicago, was destroyed by fire of undetermined origin today. The loss was estimated at $100,000 by Fire Chief Henry W. Wessel.

Least publicized of the nation's women volunteers, Catholic nuns are filling many new roles in wartime America. Nuns are serving as air raid wardens, operating farm tractors, teaching American youth the science of aeronautics -in addition to their usual tasks of religious instruction, teaching nursing and welfare work.

The war has increased cooperation among the three major religious groups, Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish, Winfred Ernest Garrison, associate professor of church history at the University of Chicago, declared yesterday in a report on "The Year in Religion," prepared for Religious News Service.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A British communique:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- Three times as many Vassar College graduates of the class of '42 have taken paid positions as did members of '41 in their first six months out of college; twice as many have been married; only half as many have gone into teaching, and those engaged in advanced academic, technical or professional study are one-fourth fewer, according to records of the Vassar Vocational Bureau.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Boston College football Eagles, after five days of morning and afternoon practice, got a half-holiday today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 25 -- The nearest thing to a white Christmas for the American troops in the Middle East was the white sands on Libyan beaches, where baseball games made boys from Eastern and Northern States feel they were celebrating the Fourth of July.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Robert E. McLaughlin, 42, night club owner, was found shot to death this morning in a manner typical of the gangland "ride" era, during which, as president of the Checker Cab Company of Chicago, he weathered one of the city's bloodiest taxi wars.

The letters published recently in THE TIMES criticizing the selection of Joe Gordon over Ted Williams for the 1942 American League most valuable player award were good. Many fans consider Williams the best player in recent years in major league baseball.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- All Britain celebrated Christmas today. For the second time since invasion threatened church bells rang and the Christmas spirit prevailed even though some of the normal trappings of the season were missing.

The ten top money-making film personalities of this year, as determined by the annual survey made by The Motion Picture Herald, a trade journal, as well as the best pictures of the year as selected by The National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, were disclosed in announcements yesterday.

"Doodle Dandy of the U.S.A.," a musical play for children will be presented this afternoon at the Belasco Theatre by Junior Programs in association with Gilbert Josephson. Saul Lancourt is the author, Elie Siegmeister did the score and Ted Shawn the choreography.

A Tokyo Imperial Headquarters communique said yesterday that more than ten American bombers of the Flying Fortress type raided Wake Island Wednesday night, flying in from the direction of Midway, according to a Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in London.

Today the members of the "Imperial Council" that Admiral Jean Francois Darlan set up one month ago to back him up in the task of reorganizing French North Africa in accordance with British-American military requirements will meet and try to designate one of their number for the post of supreme responsibility.

American and English children in the United States and Canada talked with their parents in England yesterday morning in the annual Christmas international broadcast arranged by the British Broadcasting Corporation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and the Mutual Broadcasting System.

LEWISTOWN, Pa., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Seven Amish children, including three-year-old twins, were reported today to be suffering from smallpox in Kishacoquilias Valley, the first children stricken in the Amish farm section, already under strict police quarantine.
The USO, through its clubs and centers, reached throughout the country and overseas yesterday to bring Christmas cheer to the armed forces.
ALGIERS, Dec. 25 -- The assassin of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, identified only as a youth of French nationality whose Italian mother lives in Italy, was condemned tonight to die tomorrow morning.

A small amount of reading for the holiday week-end is to be recommended. It makes a grateful pause in the season's louder occupations. It should be a mixed diet; as, for instance, a half hour with the Beveridge report on British social insurance, and a half hour or an hour and a half with Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson.

MONTREAL, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Black Hawks and Canadiens played to a 2-2 deadlock in their National League hockey game this afternoon before a crowd estimated at 7,000, more than half of them youngsters enjoying "Children's Day" at the Forum.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- For the fourth consecutive year, the Westchester Cotillion was held tonight at the Apawamis Club, which for the occasion was decorated with Christmas greens and with flowers appropriate to the holiday season.

Administrative rulings or orders intended to relax the rules permitting children to work have been a source of deep concern to those interested in seeing that children contribute their share to winning the war and who at the same time desire to preserve child-labor standards so far as possible, the National Child Labor Committee declared yesterday in making public its annual report for the year ended Sept. 30.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- The world champion Redskins worked out for the last time today for their Pro Bowl battle with the National Football League all-stars for the benefit of the United Seamen's Service Fund at Shibe Park on Sunday.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Soldiers, sailors and marines charged with protection of the Panama Canal spent Christmas Day on full duty status, a continuing alert being the order for air, sea and land patrols.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 25 -- The usual blackout heralded the advent of Christ's birth as Switzerland settled down to the serious business of commemorating her fourth war Christmas.

Ray Robinson, Harlem welterweight who has never tasted defeat in the professional ring, was named the "fighter of the year" in the listings made public yesterday by The Ring Magazine, a publication devoted to boxing. In a copyrighted article in its February issue, the magazine, through its editor, Nat Fleischer, explains the naming of Robinson for the honor won the last four years by the heavyweight champion, Joe Louis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Competition for custody of the American child during the hours of his mother's war employment is hamstringing the general effort of several governmental agencies to solve the child-care problem thus freeing womanpower for war work.

MATAWAN, N.J., Dec. 25 (AP) -- The battered body of a man between 45 and 50 years old was found beside a highway four miles south of Matawan today, and his car later was found six miles away. The State police said in Keyport that the man had been identified through his papers as Harold Grossman of 2206 Holland Avenue, the Bronx, New York City.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- "The Japanese air force everywhere has been materially weakened" and furthermore the Japanese admit it, Brig. Gen. Clayton L. Bissell, commander of United States Air Forces in India, Burma and China, declared today.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 26 -Russian troops have thrown the Germans back fifteen miles in the strategic Kotelnikov sector southwest of Stalingrad, and the Red Army killed or captured 14,500 more Nazis yesterday in the middle Don offensive that now has taken a toll of 106,700 of the enemy, the Soviet command announced early today in another special communique.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The new food administration took stock today of a bountiful harvest and found the country's larder filled with a record food supply.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- United States troops spent Christmas quietly in the hot sunshine of the Australian Summer today, most of those on leave strolling through the streets and parks, boating or going to the beach.
BLOOMSBURG, Pa., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Four persons, including the President of Bloomsburg Town Council, died of gas fumes here today in two holiday tragedies.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 -- There was speculation today that the Tigers, who yesterday abandoned their camp in Lakeland, Fla., as a war measure, might train at home or at the University of Michigan's Yost Field House in Ann Arbor, but it was a better guess that they would find a spot below the Mason and Dixon line where other major league clubs presumably will settle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -Twenty-four more of Japan's fast-dwindling supply of planes in the Southwest Pacific battle area were destroyed when United States air fighters and bombers from Guadalcanal celebrated Christmas Eve (Solomons time) by pounding the Japanese air field and shore installations at Munda on New Georgia Island, the Navy announced today.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force fighter planes, continuing their air offensive against Burma, again attacked the big Japanese airdrome at Magwe yesterday while British ground forces slowly pushed deeper into the jungles of western Burma, it was announced today.
Don't you think a suspension of large-scale skiing activities is in order for the duration of the war?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- President Roosevelt, in a brief respite from his arduous problems of state, joined with millions of his countrymen throughout the world this Christmas Day in solemn prayer for the cause of the United States and its Allies.
Three fighting musketeers from Canada came down to see what a white Christmas in New York looked like and all they got for their trouble was a Spring day.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 -- The Franklin Institute's exhibit of Newtoniana to commemorate the 300th birthday of Sir Isaac Newton includes a first edition of the English mathematician's "Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica," which once was owned by Thomas Carlyle, English author.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Federal tax officials today entered the investigation of the slaying of Robert E. McLaughlin, owner of a cafe and night club and former president of the Checker Cab Company of Chicago, whose body was dumped out of an automobile on the Northwest Side early Christmas Day.

The plight of the Neediest Cases in this year of war has caught the sympathy of many persons who have contributed to the Neediest Cases Fund for the first time, joining the legions of old friends who year after year have responded to the appeal on behalf of the most distressed men, women and children in the city known to eight leading private charities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The National League of Women Voters is now canvassing members of the Seventy-eighth Congress in thirty-four States on how they view questions of taxation, price control and imminent decisions affecting the course of the United States after the war.

AFTER a year of wartime operation, the retooling of the motion picture industry for war has just begun. The screen has remained an untrammeled entertainment medium, and business as usual -- in fact, a great deal better than usual -- has been the policy of the major producers.

Christmas business continued excellent in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, although a slight tapering off was noted as the holiday approached, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A sharp increase in the quota for the recapping of truck tires for January was announced today by the Office of Price Administration. The January quota will allow for the recapping of 368,200 tires, compared with 149,250 in December.

Six feet three inches tall, the hero of much bitter fighting and of two wartime escapes from German prisons in two World Wars, General Henri Honore Giraud is an almost legendary figure among French fighting men.

Basketball will have its biggest week of the season at Madison Square Garden during the holiday period when three intercollegiate double-headers are staged tomorrow, Wednesday and Saturday. Combined sixth last night's session, the holiday program will embrace four twin bills within a span of eight days.

THIS campaign has one immeasurable advantage for this correspondent over those in France and Flanders -- the Allied army is moving forward. This is ample compensation for sleeping on stone floors and in ditches, eating catch- as-catch-can meals, having the gizzard scared out of you by bombers, living without baths or clean clothes and, worst of all, news of the outside world.

IN your issue of Dec. 6, Carlos Salzedo made the following statement, which I believe should be corrected for the record, when he wrote: "Since this was incompatible with the raison d'etre of the 'New Symphony Orchestra,' Varese resigned and, with him, two of his board of directors.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- The Fighting French, who have not been gentle in their comments on Admiral Darlan, issued a statement tonight condemning the assassination as a political weapon, thereby adopting a line similar to that taken by most of the British Sunday papers.
AN ARMY BASE IN THE ANDREANOF ISLANDS, Dec. 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- After 100 days and a bombing, this looks like a different island.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Paced by Center Jim Seminoff, the University of Southern California's touring basketball team defeated Canisius tonight, 42 -- 25, in the second game of a double-header that attracted 7,486 spectators to Memorial Auditorium.
Thousands of week-end visitors and service men on furloughs took over the midtown area yesterday for one last holiday week-end fling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Mounting protests against rationing programs in gasoline and fuel oil, with numerous charges of extensive "black market" operations in gasoline particularly, had Federal Administrators worried this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Western Co-Coach Orin Hollingbery indicated today that Minnesota's Bill Daley is the Eastern star to watch in the East-West football clash on New Year's Day -- even though Paul Governali, Columbia's pass-throwing marvel, is the most-talked-about player.
Members of the Western Long Island Sound Star Class fleet will gather on Tuesday for their annual meeting and dinner in the New York Athletic Club, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 26 -- Mrs. A.A. Smith's Through Bound, winner of four of five previous starts but away from competition since last July, was not quite equal to coping with a thoroughly fit No Wrinkles, 18-5 shot from Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's barn, in the Key West Handicap at Tropical Park today.

The champion City College team defeated N.Y.U. by 3 -- 0, with one game adjourned, in the first round of the annual tournament of the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League for the Harold M. Phillips trophy at the Chess Studio, 15 West Fifty-sixth Street, yesterday.

"The new year may bring to us the long-desired and ardently sought victory over the Axis armies," Rabbi Louis I. Newman said in a sermon in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday.

GREAT FALLS, Mont., Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- The Army refused tonight to turn over to civilian authorities two military policemen accused by county authorities of displaying a "bullying attitude" when they shot and wounded four civilians in a roadhouse brawl.

DEPARTING from the customary listing of new exhibitions only, for the benefit of out-of-town visitors and other holiday period gallery-goers, the following calendar presents as complete a list as we have been able to compile of current local exhibitions.

THE custom of this department to pick the leading films of each year -- or the films which, in our personal judgment, have most merited critical acclaim -- is reflective this year, as have been most things, of the all-pervading fact of the war.
With the distant months drawing principal attention, the cotton futures market remained on the plus side during yesterday's short session and closed with net gains of 6 to 12 points.
By helping foreign-trained nurses to qualify for State licenses the New York section,-National Council of Jewish Women, has discovered a potential source of new recruits in the present shortage.

Among the last of the shrubs to fade out of the Autumn picture are members of that far flung and vigorous family, the viburnums, which thus round out a long season of distinguished garden performance that starts with the first rush of Spring.

With interest in so-called "layaway" plans for the purchase of post-war products reaching new heights among all segments of business and industry, plans for calling a conference of all those desirous of seeing such a project put into effect are now under way, Dr. R.J. McFall, chairman of the coordinated and cooperative marketing committee of the American Marketing Association, reported yesterday.

Establishment of a "Little War Labor Board" for the New York-New Jersey region, which is intended to decentralize authority of the National War Labor Board and to speed the determination of local cases, was announced last night by Theodore W. Kheel, acting regional director of the WLB.

The industrial section of the stock market was lifted yesterday to the best level in more than a year as fresh demand appeared for the "peace" issues. Year-end trading for tax-record purposes was confined almost entirely to the low priced public utilities.

THIS being the time of year when the assorted pundits of the Film Critics Circle, like so many gleeful Kris Kringles, are busily passing out goodies and bonbons to the year's best ten pictures, it again becomes this corner's task, out of an old and lugubrious habit, to choose a list of the ten worst.

ALBANY, Dec. 26 -- Dr. Irving Langmuir, Nobel Prize winner and associate director of the General Electric Research Laboratory, took issue tonight with that scientific school of thought which holds that general causes rather than individual action shape the course of human affairs.

The possibility that "curfews" restricting the hours during which liquor may be sold in this area might soon be imposed by the military authorities was being seriously discussed by liquor trade observers last week. Full or partial restrictions on sales are already in force in twenty-six States, many of them voluntarily undertaken by the trade itself.

The sulfa drugs were applied in new ways last year with astounding results. A newcomer is sulfapyrazine, a chemical twin of sulfadiazene. Until sulfapyrazine appeared sulfadiazene was the only sulfa preparation that checked streptococci, staphylococci and pneumococci. Sulfapyrazine is equally effective against the three, according to Drs. George W. Raiziss, M. Severac and J.C. Moetsch.

THE theatre has been singularly fortunate in its present First Lady, for Katharine Cornell has remained loyal to it in good days and through bad. And there have been bad days indeed, when the Broadway stream declined to a thin, halting trickle and the road dried up almost altogether.

THE annual holiday exhibition of illuminated manuscripts and other material -- a wide variety of books and documents ranging from the thirteenth to the twentieth century -- is current in the west wing of the Morgan Library.

WHEN Monte Proser unveils his new show at the Copacabana on Jan. 14, Sophie Tucker, frequently billed as "the last of the Red Hot Mamas" and "Queen of the Honky-Tonks," will be on hand as the principal performer.

Opposition to the proposal by the Office of Price Administration to put a ceiling on credit service charges gathered momentum last week as retailers throughout the country, through various trade associations, registered protests that the measure would only add to their burdens without accomplishing anything.

The office of the Petroleum Administrator for War reported last night that all transportation facilities were being strained to bring to East Coast centers fuel oil supplies to relieve a shortage which, in New York City, is most serious in the grade of heavy oil used for heating apartment houses, hotels and factories.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered two government officials today to testify at a hearing Monday on complaints that board members were prejudiced against Henry J. Kaiser's shipbuilding organization.

A sports program, pruned and streamlined to meet the exigencies of wartime restrictions, yet retaining most of its attractive qualities to continue its usefulness both as an entertaining spectacle and as a means for encouraging physical fitness, is the 1943 outlook that the nation's sports leaders envision today for a year fraught with uncertainty.

In North Africa last week attention was centered on the political situation resulting from the death of Admiral Darlan. But on the fighting fronts the war went on. From the east the British Eighth Army was pursuing Marshal Rommel's Afrika Korps across Tripolitania.

By order of the War Production Board many familiar foods and food products packed in protective tin plate will disappear from the civilian larder and the grocers' shelves. At the same time the use of canned products by the armed forces themselves will be immensely expanded, and the skills of the can manufacturer will be extended to the fabrication of articles apparently unrelated to the succulent bean and the refreshing vegetable juice.

Frank Bates, 17 years old, of 39-60 Sixty-fifth Street, Woodside, Queens, was arraigned on four charges in the Brooklyn-Queens Night Court in Brooklyn last night enth Street, Woodside, and asked ride on Christmas Eve.

BRAVE men of every country have their own way of facing death. Americans do it with a joke or wisecrack on their lips. It makes them feel better. During the stress of civil war, Abraham Lincoln once said: "With this fearful strain of war upon me night and day, if I did not laugh I should die."

DETROIT, Dec. 26 -- Sharp criticism of anti-Zionists was voiced today by Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the Jewish National Fund of America, speaking at the first full session of the organization's "Land for Freedom Conference" here.

A novel event, an opera tea, has been planned by Mrs. Arthur Ellis Hamm and Mrs. Merrell Edward Clark for Wednesday afternoon at the headquarters of the New York Smith College Club at the Weylin in behalf of the forthcoming performance of "Der Rosenkavalier" on the night of Jan. 8 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the club's scholarship fund.

THE Imperial edition of "The Parade of the Animal Kingdom," by Robert Hegner, Professor of Protozoology at Johns Hopkins, assisted by Jane Z. Hegner (Macmillan Company, $3.95), is a most unusual history of animals.

Captain Hugh N. Mulzac, the first Negro to receive command of a merchant ship of its size in the American merchant marine, described yesterday at an East Coast port the achievement of his life's ambition.

The recently announced program of the War Production Board aimed at encouraging the increased use of coal-burning stoves in the thirty-State area where fuel oil is rationed focuses the spotlight of attention upon a humble mechanical servant that had all but disappeared from the public ken, despite the fact that until two or three decades ago he had played a most important role in private and community life.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA. Dec. 26 (AP) -- A communique:

Probably the attempts to control cancer by the administration of large daily doses of dried raw egg-white attracted most medical attention. Growth, whether normal or abnormal, is dependent on biotin, one of the vitamins. Avidin, the active principle of egg- white, neutralizes biotin.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- Joseph V. Moreschi, head of the International Hod Carriers Union, with headquarters in Washington, stated today that the general executive board had upheld the validity of the election of Samuel Nuzzo, now on trial for allegedly embezzling funds of the union's Local 17 of Newburgh.

BUFFALO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Walter C. Dobe hopes that when the war is over his flock of Barnevelder chickens will help restock Holland with the breed for which it once was famous. Dobe already has told the Netherland Government-in-exile of his plans and has received assurance that he will be called upon to help in the post-war restoration of the livestock industry in Holland.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 -- Another holding company will file soon with the Securities and Exchange Commission a voluntary plan for dissolution, it was learned today, even as the utilities industry studied with something akin to amazement the action taken this week by the United Gas Improvement Company.

INDIA has played a part in the lives of many Englishmen. To John Mills, English actor, it's the place where he found his good fortune, for it was in Colombo, Ceylon, to be exact, that Noel Coward "discovered" him. That his path converged with Coward's in this far-off place on the globe Mills ascribes to coincidence, not to any Eastern magic.

For the first time in nearly a quarter century, the year-end statements of conditions of banks will show the impact of wartime conditions on the nation's banking system. Judged by peacetime standards, holdings of government securities will be disproportionately large, so much so, in some instances, that a stockholder may well ask whether the institution is a bank or an investment trust.

One of the bitterest financial battles in corporate history drew to a close yesterday when it was disclosed that holders of more than 50 per cent of the common stock of the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation had submitted proxies to be voted in favor of dissolution of the corporation in compliance with the corporate- simplification and integration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

WHILE Ruth Feiner states in a short foreword that her new novel, "Young Woman of Europe," is not autobiographical, its background and its drama are hers by virtue of personal history. She is one of the thousands of young women of Europe who have been shuttled across the continental map in search of refuge.

A LA YANK: American airmen in Britain, according to a flight report last week, have coined a new phrase to describe a direct bomb hit. It's a mixture of Jimmy Durantese and French. They say their missiles have landed sur le schnozzle.

Provisions for withholding the 5 per cent Federal victory tax from the salaries of 200,000 city employes have been completed, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday. A new unit has been created in his office to handle the tax, which will become effective on Jan. 1.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- Harold H. (Prince Hal) Schumacher, 32-year-old right-handed hurler of the Giants, today was sworn into the United States Naval Reserve as a lieutenant (junior grade) and ordered to duty Jan. 7 at an undisclosed post.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Dick Oliver Barrett, the former Philadelphia sand-lot pitcher who has been trying for 17 years to convince big league managers that they need his strong right arm, comes back for his fourth trial in the majors next Spring, and if figures mean anything, it's hard to see how he can miss this time.

A MAN'S biography, in my opinion, begins when he starts earning his own bread. In the Summer of 1930, in Saratov on the Volga, I left the seventh class in secondary school with a certificate attesting that I had "not graduated," but merely "attended" school.

FOOTLOOSE and fancydrafted, the American wife is on the march. She says she's only chasing her husband around the continent until he goes overseas. But while she brightens the immediate corners wherever she is, she is seeing America.

EASTON, Conn., Dec. 26 -- Miss Helen Keller will propose as an air raid precaution regulation in Connecticut that no physically handicapped person, blind, deaf or crippled, be left alone in any home or building at any time, she said today at her home here.

A revival of Chekhov's play "Three Sisters" gets friendly notices from the critics, but not without definite hesitancies and reservations. Presumably the general public's response is the same. It could hardly be otherwise.

Local schoolboy basketball teams, now enjoying a respite because of the Christmas vacation, will get back into action early next month. The third in the series of scholastic quintuple-headers is slated for Madison Square Garden on Saturday, Jan. 9.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A Navy communique yesterday indicated that the new Japanese air base on Munda. New Georgia Island, had been put out of action at least temporarily by two heavy attacks Dec. 24.

MADRID, Dec. 26 (Reuter) -Pierre Laval's newspaper in Paris, louveux Temps, has admitted that "from the practical point of view" nothing was decided so far as France was concerned at /VL: Laval's pre-Christmas meeting with _adolf Hitler and Count Ciano, Ital-i Jan Forein Iinister.

THE idea behind this book is magnificent. It is to catch the fundamentals of America, in photograph and text, and sum up this huge land of ours in a statement that can be encompassed in one slim volume. If the achievement falls short, it is the fault of the vastness of the subject, not necessarily that of the authors.

ALGIERS, Sunday, Dec. 27 -- The man whose life has been that of a soldier and leader of France, who twice and in two World Wars, this one and the last, escaped from the Germans, General Henri Honore Giraud, emerged today as the leader of French Africa.

AN enormous circulation has been gained by several publications of His Majesty's Stationery Office recording the achievements of various branches of the forces during the present war. These have been issued with official authority, and readers of a suspicious turn of mind have sometimes doubted whether their authors have enjoyed perfect freedom in compiling them.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- A British force held off the Japanese on the Burma-India border today, the Indian Command announced. The main British invasion column fought its way southward along the Bay of Bengal toward the important enemy-held base at Akyab.

QUITE a lot of precedent -- both medical and mythical -- lies behind the use of herbs in beauty compounds. The earliest eau de cologne that was ever made contained an extract of fragrant rosemary. The aromatic "wrinkle medicines" of Cleopatra were made with herbs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- In a move to afford consumer protection on an item urgently needed this Winter, the Office of Price Administration has set "ceiling" prices on new types of fireplace grates made by nine companies in New York and New England regions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Praising Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault as "the outstanding genius of aerial warfare developed in this war," Colonel Merian C. Cooper, who served in the China Air Task Force as Chief of Staff, revealed today that American pilots under General Chennault's leadership had scored eighty-three consecutive major air victories in China and were shooting down Japanese planes at a ratio of 12 to 1.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES, Northeast of Medjez-el-Bab, Tunisia, Dec. 23 -- (Delayed) -- These American infantrymen, who, with crack British units, have pushed along the road to Tebourba in the past twenty-four hours, are resting on their arms in strong positions astride the Medjerda Valley, eager to continue their advance to the old battlefields outside Tunis.

Last week the British General Alexander, Commander in Chief in the Middle East, drove a locomotive from Beirut, Lebanon, to "a point called Dog River," and there hammered home a silver spike. This spike marked the completion of a continuous line of rails running from Cairo (or, for that matter, from Matruh in Western Egypt) to the Bosporus.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 26 -- A series of bargaining agent elections which may bring an end to the sporadic and annoying work stoppages of the last several months and remove the tenseness brought about by union rivalry will be held Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday at the six North Jersey plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, one of the greatest producers of airplane engines in the world.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- In London the members of General Charles de Gaulle's Fighting French National Committee were closeted in an all-day session to assess the political situation resulting from the assassination of Admiral Darlan, a man they frankly detested.

THE Postoffice Department will release on Jan. 14 a "United Nations" 2-cents red stamp "as a tribute to the unity with which the liberty-loving nations of the world are marching toward victory over aggressors.''

IN the history of the literature of England there is no more peculiar incident than the friendship between Jonathan Swift and Esther Johnson, the "Stella" of his poems. The exact nature of their relationship has been a beguiling problem for two centuries.

We must wait for events to tell us how the position of the Allied armies in North Africa will be affected by the assassination of Admiral Darlan. The choice of a successor to the strange little figure who so suddenly shifted sides in one of the great crises of the war is not in itself the conclusive factor.

SINCE this is a season of cycles, a list of those being given seems in order. If the concerts of the New Friends of Music devoted to Bach, Haydn and Schumann be counted as three cycles, and the Philharmonic's performance of Shostakovich's symphonies as a fourth and its complete performances of Berlioz's "Romeo and Juliet" and "The Damnation of Faust" as a fifth, the score now stands at seventeen cycles.

To make their groups entirely effective, women's clubs need a greater continuity of purpose and more businesslike procedures, Mrs. John L. Whitehurst, president, states in the foreword of "Twentieth Century Clubwoman" -- a handbook just issued by the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 26 -- A gray-haired grandmother in a fur-trimmed black coat stood at the station with other parents and relatives. Before them passed the soldiers-to-be. The train waited, and Mrs. Alma Yost watched for her son, Howard, one of the group.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 -- The Washington Redskins and the National Football League All-Stars, as imposing an array of athletes as any coach could gather, will clash at Shibe Park tomorrow before a crowd expected to reach 30,000.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Dressed in the Confederate uniform of a major general, O.R. Gellette, 97 years old, last surviving member of General Lee's staff, pinned the gold bars of a second lieutenant on the shoulders of his son, William Candler Gellette, today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

IT was the year, not yet quite gone, in which Arturo Toscanini and Renny Goodman teamed up for a concert, James C. Petrillo forbade the making of phonograph records, Joe Louis said "We'll win because we're on God's side," and a daytime serial took a prize as the best drama on the air.
News from North Africa is slow in arriving and there is complaint. But war news used to be tardier than now. Word of Waterloo took four days to reach London, hardly 200 miles away.

Miss Deborah Verry of Worcester, Mass., was sworn in recently as a member of the women's auxiliary of the United States Naval Reserve by Lieutenant Harriet F. Parker. Deborah has been a major in the Massachusetts Women's Defense Corps, but she was sworn into the Waves as an apprentice seawoman.

Faced with a thirteen-point deficit as the second half opened, St. John's unleashed one of the greatest rallies in Madison Square Garden basketball history to top previously unbeaten Tennessee, 52 to 41, last night and supply a thrilling climax to the season's third collegiate double-header there.

The local drama season for children opened yesterday afternoon at the Belasco, when Junior Programs, in association with Gilbert Josephson, brought back its "Doodle Dandy of the U.S.A." to give matinee performances through next Saturday.

A NEW center for the creative forces of exiles now in this country will be opened tomorrow night with a joint recital by Lotte Lehmann, soprano, and George Chavachavadze, pianist. It will be in the building at the corner of Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street owned by the Presbyterian Brick Church, which was formerly the location of Friendship House, an earlier sanctuary for refugees.

DALLAS, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A demurrer filed in Federal court today attacked as vague and indefinite a recent indictment charging conspiracy to violate the Sherman anti-trust act by the New York Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., eleven subsidiaries and sixteen officials.

America's second wartime Christmas last week found more than a million Americans abroad. Many were in lands they had never expected to see, in settings far removed from their past experience, engaged in a job they hoped to finish as soon as possible. They were scattered from the Arctic to the tropics.

Drastic changes are occurring daily in both the teaching and status of geography from elementary grades through universities. The influence of geography in military strategy, war production, geo-politics, international diplomacy-even the proper interpretation of the daily news -- is recognized by all.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Feeding the fighting men overseas and putting some food on the tables of our Allies has cut deeply into the country's domestic larder this year, a check-up on America's foodstuff shipments for 1942 revealed today.

The situation as regards civil liberties is "far better" today than during World War I, although the view asserted by government spokesmen that civil liberties are intact "must be qualified" by recognition of "serious exceptions," the American Civil Liberties Union, 170 Fifth Avenue, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today in a quiet post-holiday market. Slightly smaller pre-holiday runs this week than usual and large scale lend-lease demand for meats have helped to strengthen prices in all departments. A private forecast that 40,000 hogs would appear here on Monday attracted much attention. The report of the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

ALBANY, Dec. 26 -- Twenty years of uninterrupted domination of the State government by the Democratic party will end the coming week when Thomas E. Dewey takes the oath of office as Governor on Friday.
LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Football stadiums throughout the country were favorite gathering places for British holiday merrymakers. Big crowds reported for nearly every game.

One of the most interesting developments in the capital market in the final quarter of 1942 has been the large number of bond redemptions undertaken by corporations in order to take advantage of the refund clauses in the excess profits tax provisions of the Revenue Act of 1942.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Allied airmen downed eight Japanese fighters over New Guinea and three more Zeros over New Britain yesterday to take the operational spotlight as Australian and American ground forces pressed the comparatively unspectacular but successful envelopment of the enemy's tenaciously held positions near Buna.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Despite shortages, allocations and other merchandising supply problems, Sears, Roebuck Co. put its midwinter bargain flyer in the mails today with a long list of prices reduced from big catalogue levels. Items listed were confined mostly to soft goods lines, linoleums and furniture, and in some keenly competitive items showed smaller percentage cuts than in past years.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Central New York teams captured the opening three games of the intercollegiate hockey title play today. Colgate, defending champion, overwhelmed Middlebury, 12 to 2; Cornell shaded M.I.T., 6 to 5, in an overtime contest, and Hamilton defeated Williams, 6 to 3.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- According to reports from Tunisia today, the Allied Air Forces are now achieving local air superiority. Axis reinforcements are being rushed to Lieut. Gen. Walther Nehring from bases in Southern Europe by glider as well as by big Junkers transports, many of which have been shot down recently.

RAY BROCK is an unusually able and unusually intense but otherwise entirely typical young American newspaper man. That is to say, he is a brash young man, and, since he is quite young, he is very brash indeed.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 26 -- Crack regiments of Britain's famed Guards Brigade control all but the highest ridge commanding the Medjez-el-Bab-Tebourba road six miles north of the former, after a pitched battle with much hand-to-hand fighting that raged throughout Christmas Eve and into Christmas morning and confirmed the Allies' possession of another vital hill.

Edward G. Barrow, president of the Yankees, yesterday made the most revolutionary proposal yet advanced by any one with regard to major league baseball's scrambled plans for the 1943 Spring training season.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The regular Soviet midnight communique:

THIS book is a review of the war. It is a very full review, in fact, and it has been done in an interesting and workmanlike way. In it Mr. Gramling has gathered together the dispatches and letters of about sixty-five Associated Press correspondents who have watched and reported the conflict since Hitler's planes dropped their first bombs on Poland, at dawn on Aug. 28, 1939.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- During the past week several snowfalls have covered the region and skiers are initiating trails and slopes. Tobogganning, skating and dogsledding are excellent and at the New Year all Winter sports will be in full swing.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- Two undefeated football squads -- the Second Air Force Bombers of Spokane and the Hardin-Simmons Cowboys, 1942 Border Conference champions -- began final drills today for their New Year's Day game in the Sun Bowl.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 26 -- Brazil will balance her books at the close of the year confident that her economic and political positions are strong.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, asked all State Federations and city central labor bodies today to support President Roosevelt's forthcoming social security message to Congress.

THE amateur theatre in America is becoming a power to be reckoned with. And as such it is growing more and more irritated at those hard-boiled Broadway authors and managers who continue to tie up their plays from release until the professional theatre as sucked every possible dollar out of them and left the pickings for the "provinces."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (Science Service) -- Seaplanes need no longer suffer the handicap of having their landing pontoons sticking out into the air as major-drags during flight, cutting down speed and manoeuvrability. Retractable pontoons, that pull up Into the body or wings of the plane after the fashion of wheels on land planes, are the subject of United States Patent No. 2,306,269, just issued here to Bertell W. King of Brooklyn.

AMONG all the fine biographies which have appeared in the past few years, each adding its own colorful panel to the panorama of America's past, there has not been, curiously enough, one of our first "First Lady."

Pending final settlement of the question of national registration of women, two specialized surveys are being planned, one by the United States Public Health Service and the second by the American Dietetics Association. Thousands of questionnaires will be issued at the turn of the year, when the Public Health Service will seek to determine the available reservoir of nurses in the country, and the A.D.A. will search for additional dietitians.

The ambition of a generation of civic reformers was achieved in 1940 when New York City brought all its rapid transit facilities under municipal control. The move involved some 250 miles of subway and elevated lines, made civil servants of 32,000 transit workers. Employes of the BMT and IRT systems enjoyed a union shop contract which expired on June 30, 1941.

WITH THE RED ARMY ON THE STALINGRAD FRONT, Dec. 25 (Delayed) -- The most feared weapon along the Russian-German battlefront is the Soviet's "Katusha" -- a gun that is guarded so zealously that each one of them is equipped with an electrical device for immediate destruction if capture seems imminent.

THEY hear that women workers are needed and wonder whether it is more patriotic to get a war job than to stay at home, trying to stretch a small fixed income over rising costs and taxes; they hear of high wages in defense plants and wonder whether, if they want to work. Billy would be all right at a neighbor's or at grandmother's or at a day nursery or a nursery school.

With each visit of Sonja Henie and her Hollywood Ice Revue to Madison Square Garden the skating star enhances her record as an unrivaled attraction at the Eighth Avenue arena. Her appearance in the show here, Jan. 18-27, is expected to be a repetition of her previous successes.

Income tax law recognizes two methods of accounting, the cash basis and the accrual basis, and permits of the use of either in the preparation of income tax returns. The only condition imposed on the taxpayer in the selection of either method is that the one employed must clearly reflect the income.

THE folksongs of a people are part of the region which bore them and they bind generations together with the understanding that arises out of human experience. They glorify human traits, prowess, frailties, achievements, failures.

Though the day is far off when we can telephone underground all the way across the continent, it was a notable achievement on the part of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to lay in three years 1,600 miles of underground cable between Omaha and Sacramento and to open it just when we need it most.
