WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Carlson's Raiders, one of the Marine Corps' hardest hitting units, has received a blanket citation from Major Gen. A.A. Vandegrift for its offensive operations against Japanese troops on Guadalcanal Island.

Eugene F. Moran, president of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company and a leading figure for many years in harbor affairs here, has been named regional director for the North Atlantic Region of the National Rivers and Harbors Congress.

EDGEWATER PARK, Miss., Dec. 26 (AP) -- "Stop that Tulsa passing attack," was the keynote of the Tennessee workout today as the team went through its first full speed scrimmage which lasted almost an hour.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- Lessons learned from aviation will revolutionize the post-war automobile industry, in the opinion of William B. Stout, designer of an experimental car known as the Scarab.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- A year ago the Axis initiated its own second front -- unrelenting submarine warfare, in the Atlantic designed to cripple American maritime might.

The first electron spectrometer, an instrument for determining the composition of minute amounts of a substance, was described by Dr. Albert Frebus (Ohio State University). A better understanding of the viruses is likely to follow and even knowledge of what happens when virus and anti-body defenses struggle for ascendancy and when chemicals kill germs.

"CLOUD-WALKING" is the story of a Kentucky mountain community, of the coming of a school and the many changes that came with it. The author is herself the "Little Teacher" of her narrative, but she has told her story not from the point of view of the outsider but from that of the mountain people themselves and in their own language.

THE long-unguarded border between the United States and Canada is one of our proudest boasts, yet as time and our common aims of democracy and freedom draw us into ever-closer relationship, there has been practically nothing in our literature to give to young people of the States a rounded picture of our friendly neighbor to the north.

LONDON, Dec. 26. -- Britain has just celebrated her fourth wartime Christmas. A new year is about to dawn. The hearts of the British people are filled with a new confidence and high hopes that before another year is out the victory they have dreamed of so long will bless their sacrifices and their efforts.

OUT of his Far Eastern personal experience and his long period of distinguished thinking on the larger and more permanent historical issues involved in the Orient, Nathaniel Peffer has distilled an interesting and challenging formula for post-war settlement in that part of the world.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The German Government acknowledged through its Embassy today the receipt of the Argentine Supreme Court's request that Captain Dietrich Niebuhr, Nazi naval and air attache here, waive the diplomatic immunity protecting him from appearing in court to answer charges of espionage.

Holiday volume was the largest in the history of retailing, despite the fact that the jam of express deliveries was so great that much merchandise did not reach destinations in time, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Its record somewhat more tarnished than usual for an Alabama eleven, Coach Frank Thomas's Crimson Tide embarked today on its seventh bowl jaunt since 1925.

As war industries call for more and more women workers, the question of national registration of women is being argued with increasing fervor, although without unanimity, among women's groups. Those who believe that such a mobilization should be voluntary rather than compulsory, and in critical areas rather than nationally, have the support of the organizers of 'last February's first Statewide survey of available woman-power, held in Oregon.

Mozart's "The Magic Flute" received its third performance of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House before an enthusiastic capacity audience. The cast was identical with that of the initial presentation given during the opening week, and Bruno Walter again conducted.

NORTH CREEK, Dec. 26 -- Plans for the Spring offensive against forest fires are now being promulgated throughout the nation. The attack will be made by the newly formed Forest Fire Fighters Service, one of the five basic Civilian Defense Groups, of which James M. Landis is director.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 -- The curtain rose on the annual New Orleans midwinter sports carnival today with the first matches in the tennis tournament which temporarily lacked its No. 1 star, first-seeded Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif.

UNDER the title. "Wilson's Ideals," Saul K. Padover has collected for the American Council on Public Affairs (Washington, D.C.) a volume of excerpts from Woodrow Wilson's writings and speeches. They are grouped under subject headings, and source and date are given in each instance.

CLOSING with a rush, the biggest holiday business in history was completed last week. Early estimates paced the nation-wide gain at around 10 per cent for the Christmas season. Prices were some 5 per cent above a year ago, so that a lift of 5 per cent in physical volume was indicated.

The eastern wall of Hitler's European fortress encloses an immense conquest -- and an immense graveyard. Since that dawn in June, 1941, when he ordered his Panzers to strike at the first Communist State, the Fuehrer has taken about a half million square miles of Soviet land.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Don't "look down" on the non-white races -- those who do are aiding the propaganda that the Japanese have been pouring out since Pearl Harbor -- and do be extremely circumspect in relationships with Chinese women, American Soldiers are advised in a "pocket guide to China," the latest in the series of foreign guide books published by the Army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The passing of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, whose six-week career as a collaborator with the Allies began in November by a fluke and ended on Thursday by assassination, seems likely to clarify the North African and the French situations.

STETSON KENNEDY'S direct reportorial prose makes a wide shot-gun pattern over the land he calls Palmetto Country -- the southern sections of Alabama and Georgia and all of Florida. He is a keen observer and an honest liberal thinker and his book has both quality and impact.

HARTFORD, Dec. 26 -- Following a meeting this afternoon of seventy Mayors, selectmen and other representatives of the cities and larger towns of Connecticut held in the State Armory, Governor Hurley after consultation with Governor-elect Raymond E. Baldwin, proclaimed a state of emergency on fuel oil in the State effective immediately.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged eighteen manufacturers of chain and chain products and their trade association, Chain Institute, Inc., with unlawfully fixing prices.

GRACE MOORE'S blueprints for a repertory theatre on Broadway for the presentation of operettas, old and new, are fast taking shape. Miss Moore has been signed by Russell Lewis and the first presentation will be "La Belle Helene," the old Jacques Offenbach operetta.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

SOMEWHERE IN - NEW GUINEA, Dec. 24 (Delayed) -- Fifteen Japanese Zero planes jumped a United States B-24 bomber over Gasmata, New Britain, today, but the bomber crew exploded a 1,500-ton Japanese supply ship, bombed the Gasmata airdrome, and shot down one Zero officially probably a second, and possibly a third.

Toronto's speedy Maple Leafs will face the much-buffetted Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Leafs, who are the highest scoring sextet in the loop, will be meeting the Bluejerseyed skaters for the fifth time this season, and they will be seeking their fifth triumph over the New York aggregation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Senator McCarran of Nevada urged today that Congress "about face" and assume "the dignity and prerogatives that by law belong to it."

Under a special order issued yesterday by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh, effective Jan. 1, audiences in legitimate theatres and motion picture houses will hear several times each day a brief talk on public safety and the proper conduct to be followed to avert disaster caused by fire or panic.

Glinka's "Russian and Ludmilla" was presented by Michel Kachouk last night in Town Hall as the first of a series of Russian operas in concert form. The performance, which marked the 100th anniversary of the work's premiere in December, 1842, at the Imperial Opera in St. Petersburg, afforded a large audience with the rare opportunity of becoming acquainted to a certain extent, at least, with a remarkable masterpiece practically unknown in this country.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- The Africa Corps raced along the Mediterranean coastal road tonight toward Tripoli, its last major Libyan base, and indications mounted that it would not attempt a stand before reaching Tunisia.

The High Commissariat of Algiers is a white palace of luxury, a place of heavy rugs and ornate fireplaces, of many mirrors and elaborate candelabra. As late as Dec. 16 American reporters who visited the building noted that it was well guarded: French soldiers and sailors stood stiffly at their posts; detectives were everywhere and papers and credentials of all those who entered or left were closely examined.

ONE of those rare instances when the appropriate title shares equal importance with the picture itself was the "Quotations" competition at the Manhattan Camera Club recently. Victor Keppler, whose work for the Treasury Department calls for making photographic posters to illustrate quotations, was the choice for judge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A Congressional investigator of government questionnaires calculated today that every manufacturer must fill out 512 feet of reports each year merely to hold up his end in the War Production Board's production requirements plan.
"Bookshelves well filled with books," says the Office of War Information in a recent bulletin on heat conservation, "provide excellent insulation for the space they cover."

THERE was trouble, mysterious, inexplicable, but surely trouble, hanging over the Navajo trading post at Wide Ruin when Hepzibah Plumb arrived in New Mexico from Denver in 1886 to help her uncle and aunt. Uncle Ezra was steadily losing the Indian trade, and there was a growing hostility against the kindly, honest little man and big affectionate Aunt Puss.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos, will give a volunteer concert for men in the Army Air Corps at Mitchel Field, N.Y., Tuesday night, under the auspices of USO-Camp Shows.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- As President Roosevelt moves to clarify lines of authority and prevent conflicts in Washington's still-complicated machinery for the conduct of the war, James F. Byrnes is emerging with constantly increasing powers and responsibilities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- About a dozen officials of the War Production Board's aircraft production division have resigned or are considering resigning, it was disclosed today soon after the resignation of the division director, Harold E. Talbott of New York City, was announced.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 -- A.J. Sackett's Richmond gained a close decision over Can't Lose today in the Fair Grounds six-furlong feature on a sloppy track. Jack Twink was third.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- American and Australian troops were closing a steel vise rapidly on the Japanese stronghold at Buna Mission today as part of the Allied plan to weaken enemy fortifications in the Buna area of New Guinea by breaking them up into segments.

With Promoter Mike Jacobs enjoying a brief vacation in Florida, Matchmaker Nat Rogers of the Twentieth Century S.C. spent yesterday eagerly scanning the pugilistic horizon for fresh ring material. Although the outlook is not encouraging, the veteran who books the ring matches for Madison Square Garden has an active campaign planned.

A NEW service to antique collectors and designers as well as to the general public has been instituted by the Metropolitan Museum. Recently it has been made the custodian of the Index of American Design, and through displays, traveling exhibitions and convenient cataloguing in study rooms this remarkable pictorial record of American folk art is now available for practical use.

The one-day ski-trains which used to leave the city's railroad terminals in the early morning hours for the benefit of those Winter sports addicts who didn't mind ten hours of riding for five hours of skiing are another war casualty, but the metropolitan snow fan can find Winter sports almost at his doorstep.

WITHOUT fanfare, and indeed unexpectedly, the Widener Collection went on public view last Sunday at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. Even those hitherto conversant with the diverse material constituting Joseph E. Widener's gift must have experienced a sense of renewed amazement, stimulated by the exceptionally fine installation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 - A post-war planning committee of nine members was appointed today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor. He directed members to begin the immediate preparation of a program designed to give reality to "the ideals for which America is now fighting."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- To contradict reports in some areas of the country that "Negroes were not being inducted into the Army in comparable percentages" to the registration totals, the Office of War Information gave official records today of the Bureau of Selective Service.
The little suit of 1942 is going to step out in a sprightlier mood than it had last Summer and Fall. All sorts of dressmaker frills are being applied to it.
Whether or not a Brooklyn hunter, Walter Newerla, took a deer during the recent open season with record antlers still remains one of the minor mysteries that undoubtedly will be solved soon.

IN many ways 1942 has been a tragic year, but it has been also the year of the turning tide, the year of hopes revived, the year of faith rewarded. Nineteen forty-one was, on the whole, a successful year for the dictators. They acquired, in Japan, a new and strong ally. They occupied town after town, province after province, country after country.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A Soviet special communique: The offensive of our troops in the area of the Middle Don continues.

The Winter term of courses at the New York Botanical Garden will begin on Jan. 4. Plant Breeding, taught by Dr. A.B. Stout, and Economic Botany, taught by G.L. Wittrock, will meet on Monday evenings for twelve consecutive weeks at 8 and 9 P.M., from Jan. 4 to March 29.

WHAT the box office receipts thus far may be one cannot know, but it may be said that from the artistic side, which is the public's principal concern, the Metropolitan Opera Association has reason to congratulate itself on the accomplishments of the last weeks of 1942 and the prospects of the New Year.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 26 -France received two Christmas gifts, one from the Germans, the other from the Chief of State, Marshal Henri Philippe Ptain. The first took the form of twenty-five more executions, the second a pathetic message from a man 86 years old, Marshal of France and Chief of State, every word of which showed isolation and disillusion.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Rationing of canned goods to American consumers as a war conservation measure was authoritatively indicated here tonight.

MORE significant than the hero who appears somewhat starkly in these less-than-pleasant pages is the hero worshiper. What Mr. Gandhi, said to Mr. Fischer is, after all, old stuff, now wearing threadbare But Mr. Fischer. representing a cult, is self-revealed and proves to be a personality deserving of a long overdue analysis.
THERE'S a photograph in this book of the author sitting beside a big drum, and on the drum is this legend:
THIS is the dancingest Army and Navy ever. Fighting men on leave move their feet to the best of swing nightly all over the city. They jive, they waltz, they rumba and they shag.

Lewis Daughtrey, victualing superintendent of the United States Lines for the last eleven years, will retire on Thursday at the age of 63. He has spent forty-eight years in the shipping business, having worked his way up to his present position from the lowly status of potato peeler on an Australian coastal vessel at the age of 15.

Two more sinkings were announced yesterday by the Navy, a medium-size United States merchant ship, with the entire crew of fifty-two rescued, and a medium-size British cargo vessel, from whose crew twelve men are missing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The practice of married persons divorcing their spouses when they cannot agree on continued marital life has had a long history in the United States, and by and large a history of increasing resort to the State laws which permit it.

With the appointment last week of two educational committees to study the question of juvenile delinquency and student discipline in the New York City school system, the serious questions raised by teacher and social welfare groups on how to cope with this problem will come under review in the course of the investigation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Navy reported today that repair work on ships and shore installations damaged in the Pearl Harbor attack actually started before the enemy bombs stopped falling and that immediately after the disastrous raid the production of the navy yard there was more than doubled.

WILL there be records in 1943? There will, plenty of them. A survey of the prospects and conversations with representatives of the three major companies -- Victor, Columbia and Decca -- make it clear that business will continue next year.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- A military funeral was held in Algiers today for Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, who was assassinated on Christmas Eve. American, British and French leaders attended the ceremony and the Algiers Cathedral was decorated with the flags of the three nations during the services, while crowds thronged about the building, radio broadcasts said.

RESOLVE to be a patriotic cook next year. Decide to be the kind of cook, in fact, who is completely attuned to the times. Make up your mind to adapt your art to the changes that the war will work along the food front during 1943. And determine to do it so well that the meals you serve will not only be nourishing but thrifty, not only thrifty but appetizing.
It'll be business as usual only at Pasadena, Calif., and San Francisco on New Year's Day when twelve hand-picked college football teams clash in the annual bowl games, The Associated Press reports.

The many philanthropic projects and the extensive war service program of the Carroll Club, Inc., will be advanced by the opening night performance of Sonja Henie's Hollywood Ice Revue on Jan. 18 at Madison Square Garden. In the interests of the benefit a large junior committee under the chairmanship of Miss Macy Ann Reilly has been organized to assist with the sale of single box seats, promenade and arena seats.

IF Isaac Anderson over in the mystery novel tribunal will allow a little poaching in the crime and detection fields, here are a few notes on how a celebrated late nineteenth-century crime and law trial have had some modern developments, including a literary sequel.

A large advance subscription from patrons, patronesses and box-holders has been reported for the annual benefit opera performance for the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., which this season will be the matinee of "Louise" on Jan. 15 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Two U-boats were sunk and others are known to have been damaged by British and Norwegian destroyers escorting an important convoy across the Atlantic recently, according to an Admiralty announcement today.

Voluntary integration of regional cotton textile facilities may have to be studied shortly, in order that the industry can meet heavy and continuing demands which 1943 will bring from the Army, Navy, Maritime Commission, lend-lease and war-aid buyers, market analysts declared last week.
OTTAWA, Dec. 26 -- With a total of 616,000 men out of a population of 11,500,000 in the armed forces Canadians feel that they have a right to be proud of their contribution to the gathering victory.

BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Dec. 26 (AP) -- The University of Tulsa football team finished its first week of training for the New Year's Sugar Bowl game with rising spirits and in fine condition here today.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Dec. 26 -- Despite an appeal by the government for maximum production to relieve the fuel crisis throughout the East, all anthracite mines in this area, upon which the industry depends for the bulk of its output, were idle today as miners decided to prolong their Christmas celebration over the week-end.

In the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 the Cleveland Tractor Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $855,316 after Federal income and excess profits taxes and after a reserve of $427,000 for operating and other contingencies, according to a report issued yesterday.

The number of jobs offered to women graduates of Columbia University rose 73 per cent above last year, indicating that "pressing war needs have opened to women many new fields formerly the exclusive sphere of men," Mary A. Wegener, acting secretary of appointments at Columbia, said yesterday in her annual report for the academic year ending in June to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

President Roosevelt's birthday on Jan. 30 will be celebrated here again with a ball in the ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. As in the past several years the proceeds from the event will be given to the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, Inc., and its Greater New York Chapter.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Corn assumed leadership today in the grain markets. Persistent buying attributed to commission houses and professional traders disclosed a lack of offerings and prices moved up to new high levels for the season in the July and September. Closing sales were at the top with gains of 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel, with May showing the most strength.

Add to the long legend of unusual requests made to booksellers: A customer came to Scribner's Book Store a few days back. Interested in globes, he was. Was there a globe -- he didn't mind how large -- that would include Bronxville (population, 6,888)?

THIS morning I awakened to the tune of heavy anti-aircraft fire and twice during breakfast in a rough Tunisian farmhouse I rushed out to dive under the near-by trees as swastika-marked planes passed directly overhead a few hundred feet high. A Messerschmitt machine-gunned a road a couple of miles away in clear view.
A serious shortage of fuel developed in Connecticut yesterday and as a result Governor Hurley declared a state of emergency and took steps for sharp oversight of supplies. [1:1.]

NOW is the time for the usual mid-term advent of new programs together with shifts in schedules for existing presentations, an increasing number of which are being affected by the trend toward shows of shorter duration. Attached is a list of some of such events together with an item or two on holiday doings:

HOW American collectors responded with stamps for children evacuated from London to other parts of the British Isles, as the result of a story published in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Feb. 22, is disclosed in a letter received from Mrs. C. Hailey-Williams, an Englishwoman, by Charles H. Hall, president of Charles H. Hall, Inc., New York importers, just before Mr. Hall flew recently to England.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Representative Doughton of North Carolina, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said today that he favored putting Federal income tax collection on a "pay-as-you-go" basis but expressed opposition to the Ruml plan which would wipe out a year's taxes to achieve that object.

It is gratifying news that by mid-1943 the United States will approach a steel production rate twice that of Germany, Italy and Japan combined. Steel, as Donald M. Nelson declares, is the backbone of war.

A room full of pleasure boatmen as well as professional naval architects, builders and equipment executives learned about PT boats the other night from the man who conceived them. The famous English speedboat designer and pilot, flying boat pioneer, and now building MTB boats in Canada, was a guest speaker of the Marine Trades Association at the Hotel Lexington.

The three plants of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation were operating at normal speed again yesterday after a slowdown that had been in progress since Dec. 18, it was announced by C.A. Van Dusen, president and general manager of the company, which is working on vital Navy contracts.

I take this opportunity to contribute an article for your paper on the life of natives with their dear friends, the Americans, now that a period of sadness has descended upon them because these men leave for home. We read in your paper which comes to the camp many stories about troubles between Americans in the United States, black and white, and there are no such troubles here in Africa, as we gladly claim.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 26 -- Captain Edward Macauley, deputy war shipping administrator, issued this statement today:

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 26 -- So thin is the thread on which history hangs that the answer to the question whether the assassin's bullets which dropped Admiral Jean Darlan will be a contribution or a hindrance to the Allied cause still remains in abeyance. Late this afternoon it could not yet be seen whether Darlan's blood would seal a compact in the ranks of dissension or whether the rifts would continue over his grave.

Observance of centennials, enabling us to measure progress in American history and to get a truer perspective on problems of today, has a value that should not be overlooked. The widely discussed Federal basic forty-hour week had its legislative beginning just 100 years ago in 1842.

IN the wars fought by this country the demilitarization, or humanization of its armies at Christmas time began to be practiced only recently. The characteristic observance of the holiday was for the men to keep on fighting -- in other words, to ignore it.

American librarians still are able to obtain many publications from Axis-dominated areas that contain technical and scientific data wanted for wartime research, according to a report yesterday of Harold Lancour, librarian of Cooper Union and chairman of the Engineering School Libraries Section of the Association of College and Reference Libraries.

THE peoples of India would probably attain freedom and security at an earlier date than now seems likely if so many of India's propagandists did not virtually threaten the world with blackmail if independence is not granted at once and on terms set by a group of Indian political leaders.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, announced yesterday that the State administrative offices of the United States Employment Service would be moved tomorrow from 342 Madison Avenue to 11 West Forty-second Street, where the headquarters of the WMC are located.

A shadow of fear flickered across the handsome face of Flight Sergeant David A. Abbot, who had a Distinguished Flying Medal pinned on him by King George VI for various accomplishments, including thirty-three bombing trips across the warring lanes of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The "red light" district has been almost completely eliminated from the American scene in little more than a year's campaigning on a nation-wide basis against venereal disease, the National Advisory Police Committee on Social Protection reported today.

A dinner "for potters and their friends," commemorating the fiftieth year of the New York Society of Ceramic Arts, will be held tomorrow evening at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. H. Aimee Le Prince Voorhees of the Inwood Pottery.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 26 -- The Southern college all-stars defeated a team of Northern varsity players today, 24 to 0, before 16,000 fans in the fifth Blue-Gray football game at Cramton Bowl. The result gave the South a 3-2 edge in victories in this series.
INTEREST in contract bridge has remained high during 1942; some authorities say this is because of the war, while others say it is in spite of the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Office of Price Administration established today a minimum operating margin of 3 cents a gallon at filling stations throughout the country as a means of helping retail gasoline dealers to remain in business despite the curtailment of sales resulting from motor-fuel rationing.

THE United Seamen's Service calls them "Our Fighters in Dungarees." They are the men of the American Merchant Marine, those unsung heroes of the war who brave the icy blasts of the Arctic, the sweltering heat of the tropics, blazing infernos of flaming oil, thirst, hunger, bombs, shells and death.

One of the most eventful and significant years in the history of American education is drawing to a close. Vast changes have taken place in both secondary schools and colleges. School leaders have met the year's problems with a spirit of cooperation. They are confident they will meet 1943's problems with the same spirit.
Whatever may be in store for sports in 1943, at least the new year will start with the full complement of football bowl games on Friday.

THIS first novel, which has won the "All - Canada Award," is the fruit of the crowded life's experience of a Canadian who was a very young man when he joined up with the Canadian Field Artillery in the last war.

When the history of World War II is written, it may well be that 1942 will be hailed as the war's turning point, for this year the initiative passed from the hands of the aggressors. The dramatic shift -- far from decisive and possibly "temporary," as President Roosevelt has warned -- came as the might of America's training camps and factories began to assert itself on the battlegrounds.

FUEL STRETCHER -- "Turn on the heat" is a phrase that has been used literally many times of late. Ways of coddling the furnace to make one ton of fuel do the work of two or three are favorite topics of conversation. People who never have insulated their dwellings are insulating now -- which brings up mention of Gold Bond Rock Wool.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Advance estimates place attendance at Friday's New Year's Day Orange Bowl football game at over 30,000, with a large representation of the armed forces. Competing will be Boston College and the University of Alabama.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- A section of the War Department founded in 1937 to assemble Army exhibits for the New York World's Fair and for the Golden Gate Exposition at San Francisco is now turning out miniature weapons and models of equipment to instruct personnel in new methods, techniques and equipment.

SOFT voices charm the ether waves precious minutes of the early day. News of feminine interest rings out from 8:30 A.M. until tea time. These are the women's programs of the air. They snag celebrities, bag fashion items and advertise home products.

Plants crowned with gay flowers or fruit, typical of this holiday season, usher in the peak bloom time for Winter window gardens. Bloom should be most abundant for the next three months, both from the Christmas plants and the everyday ordinary ones.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 27 -- Russian troops have driven within 105 miles of Rostov in their Middle Don offensive that has taken a toll of 116,000 Germans in eleven days, and another Red Army unit rolling southwest of Stalingrad is nearing Kotelnikov, the Soviet High Command announced early today in another special communique.

Reshevsky and Kashdan -- Sam and Kash, as the initiates call them -- are now playing a match for the chess championship of the United States. Does that seem a minor news item? It is. True, chess has been compared to war and war to chess, but the metaphor was made long before Hitler, and the lessons of chess cannot be applied to totalitarian conflict.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- Looms are humming and the potter's wheel spins briskly at the Westchester Workshop here as wives and mothers of servicemen busy their hands at ancient crafts to turn their minds from the war. Miss Vivian Willis, administrator of the workshop, reports that increasing numbers of women are now appearing where once men were in a notable majority.
Carrying the greatest volume of passenger and freight traffic in their history, the railroads are also finding time to make major improvements along their lines to promote still greater efficiency.

The number of Boy Scouts in New York City increased this year by 4,000 over the number registered in 1941, Perry A. Lint, Scout executive, said in the executive report for December. A total of 44,037 cubs. Scouts and senior Scouts have been registered in 1,149 troops and 200 cub packs.
Subzero weather, additional cuts in the already drastic fuel rationing, combined with no gasoline -- what a background for criticism!

German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, in his latest article in the Reich, a weekly, tries to console German families who face extinction because all their male descendants have been killed by citing the "higher ethical value of the war," the British radio reported yesterday, the Columbia Broadcasting System reported.

THE publication here of the unabridged text of General Giulio Douhet's celebrated writings on aerial warfare -- his original four books in one well-translated volume -- may be justly accepted as marking America's "coming of age" in the matter of aviation thinking.

Fred McNeil, first vice president of the National Ski Association and a pioneer in Pacific Northwest ski circles, gives a clear interpretation of the present ski picture in his article, "Skiing and the War," which appears in the current American Ski Annual, official publication of the N.S.A. He says in part.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 26 -- The Georgia squad got its mind off football today for the first time since its arrival last Monday for the New Year's Rose Bowl game against U.C.L.A.

One of the most attractive of the Winter exhibitions is the annual show of the Pekingese Club of America. The club's fifty-first specialty event has been scheduled for Sunday, Jan. 10, on the roof garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania. The Pekingese, of course, originated in China and it is fitting, therefore, that the proceeds will be donated to United China Relief.

TORONTO, Dec. 26 -- High-scoring Toronto turned back Boston, 7 -- 2, at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight and moved into a first-place tie in the National Hockey League with the Bruins, who suffered their first defeat in their last eleven starts.

/iss Audrey Milliard Blodgett was formally introduced to society last night at a dinner given in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis by her parents. ]Vir. and Mrs. Delos A. Blodgett 2d of 66 East Seventyninth Street. after which the debutante and her young friends attended the ayfair Assembly ill the Viennese Roof of the hotel.

The major leagues are more than a trifle confused about their own plans, but they're going to see that the nation's service men don't have any trouble getting started playing ball as early as they wish next Spring.

The outstanding astronomical event of the year was the discovery in the constellation Puppis of a nova -- a faint star which exploded about the time the Pyramids were built and which is so distant that its new light reached the earth last November. Though there was an increase in glow of about six million times, Nova Puppis is no supernova.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- Senator Austin of Vermont, insisting that voluntary methods of solving critical manpower problems will never work said tonight he would press in the next Congress for the early enactment of a national service act to permit drafting of men and women for the war effort.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Senator Gillette of Iowa asserted today that synthetic rubber production was two or three months behind schedule and blamed "apparent complacency" for what he described as "a desperate situation.''
LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- British and American troops were reported today to have thrust to within twelve miles of Tunis.

Hansel and Gretel, the Princess and the Swineherd, Aladdin and His Wonderful Lamp, and Alice in Wonderland are some of the classic tales of fancy brought to life in a special exhibit of Fairytales at the Brooklyn Children's Museum through Jan. 9. Its popularity with boys and girls, usually occupied with maps and microscopes, confirms the belief of the curatorin-chief, Mrs. William Lloyd Garrison 3d, that there's a place for fantasy in children's lives.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Axis powers have added a new weapon to the arsenal of espionage by forging a system of "bits and pieces" to ferret out war plans of the United Nations.

DAVID LICHINE'S new version of "Helen of Troy" has finally had its postponed world premiere by the Ballet Theatre in Detroit, and, according to Russell McLauchlin's report in The Detroit News, it "left a great audience shouting approval."

Bernard M. Baruch's $1,000,000 gift last Wednesday to the men who are fighting for liberty was cited yesterday as "a challenge to every American" by Dr. Charles V. Vickrey, president of the Golden Rule Foundation of New York, 60 East Forty-second Street.

THE recent announcement of the Army and Navy plan for the colleges has caused widespread discussion, comment and protest throughout the United States. In most of these discussions the question of the essential or the nonessential character of a liberal arts educational has been central.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Office of Censorship issued this statement today:

With ten of the scheduled fourteen games decided in the play-off match between Samuel Reshevsky and Isaac I. Kashdan for the chess championship of the United States, Reshevsky leads by 6 1/2 -- 3 1/2 and may clinch the honors tonight in the test slated at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The new Congress which comes into being on Jan. 6 will be called upon to serve, unless a truce intervenes, as mediator in a New Deal family difference unique in the record of a unique decade in government.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Dec. 26 -- The War Production Board has warned householders of Amityville and adjacent communities that unless conservation of gas is practiced voluntarily, it will be necessary to institute compulsory measures.

Today's Liberty Ship, a vessel built especially for the country's emergency shipping needs, is better than the average merchant ship of the last war, according to a statement made yesterday by J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 26 -- A military funeral was held today for Admiral Jean Francois Darlan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull called today for unified support in pressing the critical battle in North Africa, notwithstanding the assassination of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan.

This is to call attention to the waste of brain power that goes into thinking up funny names for women's branches of the armed forces. Waacs was all right. There had already been a Women's Auxiliary Army Corps in England during the last war, and anyhow the name made some sense.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Dr. Eduard Benes, President of the Provisional Czechoslovak Government, declared tonight that 1943 would "quite certainly bring a victorious decision."

Retail trade in 1942 shattered all previous records, but this achievement largely represented retailers "living on their fat," which is not likely to be repeated in the coming year, according to a telegraphic survey made last week by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

SMITH -- New Courses Listed Changes in the Smith College offerings effective for the second semester beginning Jan. 13 include courses in practical exposition, radio writing and production, a new one in introductory physics and an introduction to college mathematics.

A CHORUS has been formed by employes of Ranger Aircraft Engines. It gave its first Christmas concert recently at the Farmingdale High School. Admission charge consisted of books, magazines and games for the Farmingdale Service Organization.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The choice of General Henri Honore Giraud as Admiral Darlan's successor received unqualified approval in Fighting French circles here today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Fears that any rise in prices of oats futures here would result in further purchases of Canadian oats limited trading in that grain last week on the Board of Trade and prices held within a range of about 1 cent a bushel, closing yesterday at gains of 1/4 to 3/8-cent.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 27 -- There was no official reaction in Vichy to the appointment of General Henri Honore Giraud as High Commissioner in Africa, nor is there likely to be.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Roosevelt and James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, will be called upon in a few days to settle a serious jurisdictional dispute between the War Labor Board and the National (Railway) Mediation Board, it was learned today.

LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Allied bombers, flying from bases in India and China, smashed hard at the Japanese airdrome at Heho in Central Burma, and at Bangkok, Thailand, last night and bombed their Yunnan base at Tengyueh in China Christmas Eve.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A communiqu:

Procedure to be used in renewing liquor and wine licenses expiring Feb. 28 in New York City, and in Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, was announced yesterday by Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority. Renewal application blanks will be mailed to licensees during the first week in January, and formal applications must be filed not later than Feb. 2 in order that licenses be issued by March 1.

Six weeks after the landing of our forces in North Africa General Giraud occupies the place chosen for him by those who planned and prepared the American expedition. Admiral Leahy, who played an important part in the decisive conferences, left for Washington shortly after Giraud's arrival in Vichy, following his daring escape from the German fortress of Koenigstein.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A society placing ownership of production and distribution facilities in the hands of consumers and producers would most closely approximate the American and Catholic ideals of government, Mgr. Luigi G. Ligutti, executive secretary of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference, said today.
Loaded with Christmas gifts from their families and friends, thousands of American and Allied service men and women here on holiday furloughs left the city yesterday to return to their posts of duty.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- Absolute equality among the nations of the world was demanded today in an article in the official Central Daily News, giving China's desires when victory shall have been won. They were divided into three main groups, as follows:

DIXON, Ill., Dec. 27 (AP) -- A Chicago and Northwestern mail train ploughed into the rear of a transcontinental passenger train, the San Francisco Challenger, containing 489 passengers, at the Dixon station shortly before midnight last night, killing two persons and injuring twenty-seven others.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 27 -- A complete program to consolidate all building and loan associations in Atlantic City and neighboring Ventnor into two operating organizations was announced here tonight by the Atlantic County League of Building and Loan Associations.

God's greatest blessing to us is our freedom of will, the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, declared yesterday morning in a sermon in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The American Council on Public Affairs, calling attention to Woodrow Wilson's proposals for American participation in world organization, will issue on the anniversary of the World War President's birth tomorrow a volume high-lighting his pertinent statements.

"Sweet Charity," a comedy by Irving Brecher and Manuel Seff, will be presented tonight at the Mansfield by Alfred Bloomingdale of the department store family. The play has to do "with the plight of club women whose finances become hopelessly entangled in their efforts to raise money for a good cause."

Regent cigarettes, the first to come out in king sizes, will run an expanded magazine campaign for 1943, using a new testimonial technique. The program, which appears in one-half or two-thirds page size, will use not one but three testimonials in each piece of copy.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27 -- During the last three days Russian armored forces reached points on the railroad between Millerovo and Kamensk, cut the trans-Don line at Tatsinskaya and penetrated the Ukraine to a depth of ten to twenty miles.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 -- Despite a growing holiday spirit which held down trading interest, prices for cotton moved moderately higher last week on the Cotton Exchange here, distant months having a shade the better of the movement.

Only four new films are slated to open on Broadway during the week. These are:

Acting under the fuel oil priority order issued last Monday by Petroleum Administrator Harold L. Ickes, the city Department of Health has made recommendations to the local office of the Petroleum Administrator for War on the preferential ratings in deliveries here, it was learned last night.

The employment of large numbers of boys and girls in the accelerated war program is increasing juvenile delinquency and adversely affecting the stability of the American home, an editorial in The American Child, journal of the National Child Labor Committee, declares.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The text of Price Administrator Henderson's statement on the OPA program for rationing commercially processed fruits and vegetables follows:

Democracy will be victorious and will survive and march forward to new advances only if it is conscious of this changing world and is able to pit against the lures of a new order offered by the totalitarians its own constructive program of progress, declared the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday in Riverside Church.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, declared in a sermon there yesterday that service men were making the same discovery that Captain Eddie Rickenbacker and his companions made when they were afloat on rubber rafts in the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- James G. Patton, president of the National Farmers Union, said today that "information from responsible sources indicates our Ambassador to Bolivia intervened in a controversy among the Bolivian Government, tin mine operators and labor" and demanded an investigation.

ALMONTE, Ont., Monday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The death toll resulting from a collision between two Canadian Pacific passenger trains here last night rose to thirty-two today as rescue workers continued to comb the wreckage for dead and injured.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Desecration of the Jewish synagogue here, which Governor Charles Poletti has ordered investigated, "does not represent the true spirit" of Lake Placid residents, District Attorney Harold R. Soden of Essex County asserted today.

WITH FORWARD ELEMENTS OF THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Tripolitania, Dec. 26 (Delayed) -- Shortly after Sirte, slightly more than halfway from Bengazi to Tripoli, fell to British advance elements, enemy columns began a hurried rush to catch up with their main forces, which had evacuated the town several days ago.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. J.C. Merrill, legislative chairman of the New Jersey State League of Women Voters, declared that Arthur F. Foran, State Director of Milk Control, no longer has control of the price paid for milk by the consumers in New Jersey.

German broadcasts recorded by The United Press yesterday in New York reported Soviet attacks in numerous sectors between the Caucasus and the area northwest of Moscow. The communique reported "continuing heavy fighting for the stronghold of Velikye Luki."
A High Command communiqu broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 27 -- Installation of the powerful 105-mm. howitzer on the highly mobile M3 medium-tank chassis, producing the weapon that recently caught Axis armies in Africa by surprise and sent Marshal Rommel reeling on two fronts, is typical of the armament development work being accomplished by engineers of the War Department's new Tank-Automotive Center here.

Motion picture theater operators planning to revive bank night and screeno were warned by Mayor La Guardia yesterday, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall, not to regard as a "license" the decision by Magistrate Abner C. Surpless in Queens Felony Court last Wednesday dismissing a complaint in a test case in that borough.

Woodrow Wilson, as a great modern prophet whose vision and foresight may very well establish a basis for the peace to follow the present war, was eulogized at a service yesterday morning at the John Street Methodist Church, 44 John Street, in commemoration of the anniversary today of the birthday of the First World War President.

A six-point program to reduce juvenile delinquency and improve the local school system has been adopted and will be introduced at the opening of the Spring term in February, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday, in a report to the Board of Education.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Samuel Nuzzo, on trial for allegedly stealing more than $35,000 from the treasury of Local 17 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America, was installed as the local's chief business agent today by a representative of the international after Nuzzo's opponents attempted to balk his installation by adjourning a regular meeting of the organization.

In celebration of its twentieth anniversary, the League of Composers presented a concert devoted to new American compositions by members of the organization, last night at the Museum of Modern Art. All of the works performed received their premieres on this occasion, and, with one exception, the six composers represented on the program had written their contributions especially for the occasion.

CALDWELL TOWNSHIP, N.J., Dec. 27 -- A collision here this evening between a private car and a bus of the Public Service Coordinated Transport resulted in one death and injury to thirteen persons. At least two of the injured, all of whom were taken to the Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, were reported to be in a serious condition.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Governor Poletti appealed today to the people of Italy to "throw out" their leaders. Broadcasting in Italian over short wave, he sent to Italians the holiday greetings of the American people and expressed a hope for their speedy liberation from the yoke of Hitler and Mussolini.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 27 (AP) -- With champion scrap metal collectors from Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont schools sponsoring three of the vessels, four Liberty ships were added to the nation's merchant marine strength today in launching ceremonies at the plant of the South Portland Shipbuilding Corporation.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Dec. 25 (Delayed) -- An American force broke through the Japanese defenses behind Buna Mission today and pushed from Entrance Creek to the sea between the Mission and Giropa Point. The Mission and Giropa Point are heavily defended centers of Japanese strength on the Papua front, and if made to stick today's advance will be one of the decisive strokes in the defeat of the Japanese on this front.
The world of today needs a spiritual mother to whom it can turn for comfort, compassion and courage, the Rev. Francis X. Shea declared in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Combined Raw Materials Board today announced that raw materials available for export from French North Africa had been allocated between the United States and Britain. The allocations which apply after local needs there have been met are as follows:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 27 -- German workers no longer care for victory. Where formerly they dared to proceed only singly to their factory washrooms during working hours they now go in droves to smoke and openly criticize the regime, it is stated here on the most reliable authority.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -The new year will bring calls to the colors for more than 3,500,000 men 18 through 37 years old at the average rate of 250,000 to 300,000 a month, Selective Service sources estimated today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- In a thrill-packed encounter that went all the way down to the wire before the outcome became a certainty, the National Football League All-Stars came from behind to defeat the world champion Washington Redskins, 17 -- 14, in the annual Pro Bowl contest that attracted 18,671 spectators to Shibe Park today.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 109.1 to 109.6. Most of the activity occurred in the prices of agricultural commodities. Increases in fruits, grains, livestock and tobacco were mainly responsible for the 1.2 per cent increase in the farm-products index.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Corn developed independent strength last week on the Board of Trade. Removal of hedges against shipping sales of cash grain and continued light receipts were the main influences. They carried the July and September into the highest ground of the season and choice quality cash corn to the highest level since 1937.

WITH AMERICAN AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Dec. 25 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American airmen attacked the main Japanese Yunnan base at Tengyueh with incendiary bombs Christmas Eve while listening to Christmas carols coming in by radio from the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Allied commander in French North Africa, expressed pleasure today at the appointment of General Henri Honore Giraud as High Commissioner for French Africa, declaring himself delighted to have a man of General Giraud's reputation and character to deal with in North Africa, according to messages reaching London tonight.
With the Christmas week-end safely out of the way, most mortals like to devote the week starting with this morning to make a sort of reckoning of what's behind and what's ahead.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A protest against advance announcement of plans for food rationing came today from Donald E. Montgomery, retiring consumers' counsel in the Department of Agriculture.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Former Judge William L. Ransom of this place gave a reception this afternoon to introduce to friends his daughter, Miss Mary Louise Ransom, who was presented at the Westchester Cotillion Christmas night.

The issue of the Negro's place in American industry is a serious one, for the simple reason that though he is badly needed he hasn't yet won a place in proportion to his numbers. It is estimated that throughout the United States he now forms 20 per cent of the unemployed, though he is less than 10 per cent of the population.

Two 45-caliber bullets, apparently fired early yesterday morning from the gloomy base of a flight of stairs leading into Central Park at West Sixty-first Street, ended the life of Herbert Holtz, film exchange clerk, of 114 West Sixty-first Street.

The Viking Press, making known its Winter-Spring plans, announces the publication of fifteen books. The announcement is unusual in that the publishers have decided in advance the initial printing figures for each book, even though some of them are as far away from release as April.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- The Congressional move to place Federal income-tax collections on a current basis gained further support tonight when two House Republicans urged passage of "pay-as-you-go" tax legislation early in the next session of Congress, which is to convene on Jan. 6.

The choice of General Giraud as Admiral Darlan's successor in North Africa is a fortunate development for the United Nations. Of all the leaders who have escaped from France Giraud is the best known to the French people. The bitterness of his hatred for the Germans cannot be questioned.

New traffic records were set for each month of 1942, and the total volume for the year on the Canadian National Railways System will exceed by a wide margin any previous experience, according to an annual review of operating results by R.C. Vaughan, chairman and president, who places the year's operating revenues at more than $370,000,000.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- A force of eight American bald eagles glided silently into this area this morning from the northern reaches of the Hudson Valley and raided the supply lines of several hundred seagulls.

DETROIT, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings seized sole possession of third place in the National Hockey League by submerging the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 to 1, tonight before 10,386 spectators. Syd Howe and Sid Abel each bagged two goals as Detroit tallied six times in the last two periods.

An audience of 3,800 crowded the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the "Grand Gala Concert" given there "in tribute to the courageous spirit" of Marjorie Lawrence by her Metropolitan opera colleagues. It was Miss Lawrence's first appearance at the Metropolitan since March, 1941.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Following the statement by Joseph B. Eastman, Director of Defense Transportation, that the January furniture markets would be permitted to proceed as scheduled, the National Retail Furniture Association announced today the program for its annual meetings which will be held here from Jan. 4 to 6.

Optimistic over possibilities that the OPA will provide apparel trades with some modifications and possible deferment of effective date of MPR 287, the American Council of Dress Manufacturers, Inc., announced it will sound a call today for a "united front" to plead the cause of the local dress manufacturing industry.

WITH THE ALLIED FORCES, Northeast of Medjez-el-Bab, Dec. 25 (Delayed) -- Just as dusk fell over this rain-swept valley yesterday -- at the hour when you at home were trimming Christmas trees -- dozens of American and British medium and heavy guns loosed the heaviest bombardment of this campaign.

Tribute to the role played by American radio equipment in the war in 1942 is paid in annual year-end statements by Colonel David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, now on active duty with the Army Signal Corps, and Lieut. Gen. J.G. Harbord, chairman of the board of RCA.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 -- Republic has borrowed James Brown, Texas tennis star who turned actor, from Paramount for the leading role in "Shanty Town" opposite Mary Lee, the studio has announced. The supporting cast for the film, which is scheduled to start Jan. 18, will include Margaret Wycherly, Porter Hall and Billy Gilbert. Olive Cooper is writing the photoplay, and Joseph Santley will direct.

LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- All police units in the Netherlands are to be merged into a single force under centralized German control through a new decree "believed to foreshadow an intensified reign of terror against anti-Nazi elements," the Netherlands News Agency, Aneta, reported today.

Angna Enters at the Alvin and Doris Humphrey at her own little Studio Theatre in West Sixteenth Street last night opened their respective seasons in programs quite as far apart as the houses in which they appeared.

C.C.N.Y., Cooper Union and Brooklyn College head the list as a result of yesterday's play in the second and third rounds of the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League's annual tournament at the Marshall Club and Chess Studio.

Untarnished records will be risked by Fordham and Long Island University tonight when they oppose Kansas and Southern California, respectively, in Madison Square Garden in the second of the current holiday period's four collegiate basketball double-headers there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Institution of "point" rationing in February will mean that the housewife must have two types of currency to buy many foods -- money, as usual, and what Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, described today as "rationing currency."

LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Another contribution to Anglo-American amity has just been made by the British Navy, Army and Air Force Institutes, or Naafi, in its four-page pamphlet advising British girls who work in canteens serving United States soldiers, on correct procedure in dealing with the Americans.

What will happen to Conservation Department programs in various States where the revenue from hunting and fishing licenses will tumble is a matter that has been receiving the attention of legislators and officials.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- The British Eighth Army, within 300 miles of Tunisia in pursuit of the German Africa Corps, has passed through Buerat el Hsun and is now "well on the way" to Misurata, seventy-five miles northwest, front dispatches said tonight.

Mayor La Guardia's next step in his campaign to end automobile driving for pleasure or convenience will be to "throw the book of rules" at motorists and make such driving so unpleasurable and inconvenient that they will keep their cars in the garages until the gasoline shortage is eased, it was made clear yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 (AP) -Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were silent tonight on reports that they had started an investigation of the food poisoning of 600 employes of the Harvey Machine Company.

Samuel Reshevsky and Isaac I. Kashdan adjourned the eleventh game of their series for the United States chess championship after forty-six moves last night at the Hotel Henry Hudson, with Reshevsky a pawn ahead. The game will be resumed at a time to be announced later.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 -- The Christmas holidays had virtually no effect on the production of raw steel last week and the national operating rate declined only fractionally to 99 per cent of rated capacity. There is every indication that output this week will rebound a half point or so.

One cannot pass by Christmas without realizing how much emphasis Christianity places on the significance of seemingly little things, declared the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers in his sermon yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street.

Further gains in war production in 1943 are likely to be accompanied by continued declines in the output of nonessentials, according to The Guaranty Survey, monthly review of business conditions published by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

The New York City WPA Symphony Orchestra, which has been giving popular-price symphonic concerts for three and a half years, played yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall before an audience of 2,400 what will probably be its last public program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs today announced the election of Mrs. W. Glenn Suthers of Chicago as president. She will take office Jan. 1 and serve two years.
MONTREAL, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Canadiens defeated Boston, 4 to 2, in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 6,842 tonight.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Establishment of two accelerated courses in social service to meet "special wartime needs" was announced today by the University of Buffalo.
The text of Secretary of Agriculture Wickard's radio address tonight in Washington as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES was as follows:

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 26 (Delayed) -- Calcutta's exciting Christmas has passed, leaving the city considerably less populated as well as somewhat shaken. It is a phenomenon that all cities subjected to bombings for the first time must be expected to display.
Following is the text of Elmer Davis's radio address last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Presidents of colleges and universities throughout the country have pledged full cooperation with the Army and Navy in the new training program. The vast majority of faculty and students in these institutions will heartily endorse this pledge and will do their best to fulfill it.

COOCH BEHAR, Bengal, India, Dec. 24 (Delayed) -- Christmas-time in India has brought the thrill of a lifetime to two American Air Force pilots, not to mention two American newspaper men -- hunting a leopard in the jungle from the backs of elephants.
"I am sorry my check is late and wish it could be larger, for the needs are so sad," wrote M. B.M., expressing the sentiment of many of yesterday's 305 contributors to the Neediest Cases Fund.

Bruno Walter will conduct Verdi's "La Forza Del Destino" at the Metropolitan Opera House the evening of Jan. 9, it was announced yesterday with the release of the repertoire for the seventh week of the season. It will be the first performance of the work at the Metropolitan in seven years.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 22 (Delayed) -- Although the inflationary spiral seems to have been flattening out in the past few weeks, the long and steady rise in commodity prices is still one of the gravest problems in China, working hardship on and causing considerable suffering to salaried people in government employ, missionaries and teachers, who have a vital part in the nation's war effort.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Here are the processed foods to be rationed in February, as listed tonight by the Office of Price Administration:

DETROIT, Dec. 27 -- A program to undertake the reclaiming of 500,000 acres in Palestine for the settlement of unfortunate Jews was undertaken today by the Jewish National Fund Conference in session here.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Representatives of retail associations today termed premature the announcement of a plan for rationing canned, frozen and dried fruits and vegetables, asserting that the announcement weeks before rationing begins would lead to hoarding and shortages in retail stocks.

The final report covering the four-year inquiry by John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor, and two extraordinary grand juries into charges of official corruption and maladministration of law enforcement agencies in Brooklyn, described as the country's longest and most sweeping study of municipal misconduct, was made public yesterday.

With the ski season about to get into full swing, a survey of what the major resorts in the Northeastern United States and Canada contemplate is in order. One should remember that railroads no longer are permitted to run ski specials, and accommodations will be limited to regular trains.

Though crippled and undermanned, the New York Rangers sailed into the Toronto Maple Leafs and handed the Northerners a 3-to-1 defeat in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

The New York Stock Exchange has had a scientific test made of newspaper reader interest in stock and bond quotations and offers the result as a challenge to what it says is "an oft-repeated fallacy that only 4 or 5 per cent of a general newspaper's readers ever look inside the financial pages."

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Armour Co. of Illinois and subsidiaries, meat packers, reported today that their net income, after paying guaranteed dividends on preferred stock of Armour Co. of Delaware, was $11,112,069, or about $1.89 a common share, for the fiscal year ending Oct. 31.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 27 -- It's not, you understand, that the U.C.L.A. Bruins don't trust people, or that they'd even imply that any one would try to slip something by them.
MOSCOW, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communiqu:

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Detailed State reports indicate that the Winter wheat acreage for next year's harvest in Kansas, principal producing State, is smaller than it was a year ago but that the condition of the crop is the best in twelve years.

The port of Akyab, on the eastern side of the Bay of Bengal, was last prominently in the news when the Japanese took it last May. Now it is being whacked from the air by Allied fliers, and a British column is pushing down the coast, with the apparent object of retaking it.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- United States planes sank at least three ships, damaged two others, set docks afire and raked enemy columns along a 180-mile stretch of Tunisia yesterday, African dispatches reported today, while French troops were said to have made some gains.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 27 -- President Roosevelt awarded to Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham, commander of the Allied naval forces in the North African campaign, the Distinguished Service Medal.

LIEUT. COL. CARLOS P. ROMULO, personal aide to General MacArthur, chief press relations officer for the American and Filipino troops on Corregidor and Bataan, Pulitzer Prize winner in journalism, editor and publisher of a chain of Philippine newspapers, is a brave soldier, a good journalist, a man who bears the burden of a double tragedy, both personal and national.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 27 -- Any colleges and universities that are not bankrupted by the teenage draft are likely to become "military reservations," Dr. George W. Pierson, Associate Professor of History at Yale University, forecast in an address broadcast tonight in the "Yale in The News" series.

Miss Lois Coots, 25 years old, who for the last few months has been studying meteorology in a class of Air Force cadets and naval ensigns at the University Heights Center of New York University, will report today as assistant to the head of the Research and Training Section of the Weather Bureau in Washington.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- The approach was undiplomatic to an extreme: "Hello, Sid, it's nice seeing you on your feet again."

A group of prominent Americans of Germans descent issued yesterday an appeal to the German people to "overthrow a regime which is the infamy of German history." The appeal, in the form of a Christmas message and bearing fifty signatures, denounced the extermination of the Jews in Europe and other barbarities practiced by the Nazis.

Despite a setback of more than $1 a bale on Wednesday, the cotton futures market, reflecting a growing conviction that the farm bloe's demands for a revision of the present agricultural parity formula will be viewed favorably by the new Congress, showed last week a definite upward trend.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The stock markets closed for the Christmas holiday in characteristically quiet but cheerful style. With the news from the Russian front becoming daily more encouraging and reports from all other war theatres indicating slower but steady progress, there was no disposition to indulge in last-minute year-end liquidation, but on the contrary an unobtrusive desire to accumulate stock.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- communiqu:

Suzanne Sten, German mezzo- soprano, who made her local debut three years ago in Town Hall, gave her second recital in the same auditorium yesterday afternoon. A large and friendly gathering was on hand to hear the gifted singer, who in the interim between her Town Hall appearances had been active throughout the country not only in solo programs but as assisting artist with important orchestras.

Total resources of the Royal Bank of Canada amounted to $1,291,615,946 at the close of the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, 1942, comparing with $1,075,119,761 a year before, setting a new high record in the bank's history and reflecting the steadily mounting tempo of Canadian business.

ALLENWOOD, Pa., Dec. 27 -- A retired 71-year-old Presbyterian minister who couldn't resist the urge to do something to help win the war for the United Nations became a steamfitter just twenty-nine days after starting work on a military project in the White Deer Valley, a few miles west of this central Pennsylvania town, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Rationing of almost all commercially processed vegetables, fruits and soups will begin in February under the "point" system to insure the equitable distribution of a type of food needed most urgently by the fighting men of the United Nations.

Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee favors putting Federal income tax collection on a "pay-as-you-go" basis, but opposes the Rural plan. This is a puzzling position, for Mr. Ruml has presented the only sensible plan by which a pay-as-you-go basis may be achieved.

"Best face forward" is a pretty good motto for welcoming in 1943. Whether New Year's Eve is planned as a spree of town-painting or as a quiet gathering of cherished friends, a radiant countenance is expressive of hope and confidence in the future.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 27 - Laura Matriss, 17 years old, was lodged in the Bergen County jail early this morning on a charge of murdering her father. Frank Matriss, 38, who was stabbed twice in their home at 10 McKenzie Avenue, East Rutherford, soon after midnight.

Skating at top speed all the way, the New York Rovers blanked the Boston Olympics, 6 to 0, in the feature contest, of an Eastern Hockey League double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. The victory enabled the locals to regain first place with a one-point margin over the idle Philadelphia Falcons.

The United States Steel Corporation faces the new year with determination to do its part in expanding the battle of production to meet the growing requirements of materials and equipment needed for complete victory, according to a year-end statement made public yesterday by Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board of directors.

LOCKPORT, Ill., Dec. 27 -- The submarine Peto was eased into a large floating drydock last night preparatory to her unique trip down the Illinois Waterway and finally the Mississippi River to the Gulf of Mexico.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 27 -- In an effort to obtain reliable statistics on the fuel situation in Connecticut, Wesley A. Sturges, State Defense Administrator, who yesterday was appointed Acting State Fuel Administrator by Governor Hurley under a proclaimed fuel emergency, spent most of this afternoon and evening in a series of conferences.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 27 -- The Ministry of National Defense announced today that several military planes would be sent all over the Republic of Mexico with a propaganda mission to explain to the people that the 18-year-old recruits just enlisted in the army would not be sent to fight overseas.
It seems to me that not enough public tribute has been paid to the overwhelming job done by the Post Office Department, over the past year, but especially during the last three months.

Declaring that Federal enforcement of price ceilings is "far from satisfactory," Mayor La Guardia called on the Federal Government yesterday for prompt action to stabilize prices and wages, regardless of "criticism and punishment," to prevent an inflation that would ruin not only New York but every other city, in addition to inflicting severe hardship on most of the nation's population.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Wheat prices moved within a range of about 2 cents a bushel last week, averaging slightly lower, while cash grain was at the highest level in fourteen years, an advance to 5 to 10 cents or more above the government loan rate failing to bring out the selling by producers that had been expected.

Interrupted as it was by a holiday on Friday, and with another holiday impending this week, it was natural that last week's markets should have become irregular. The high mark of this month and of 1942 was reached the week before.

I read with a good deal of interest a news item in your issue of Dec. 22 which dealt with the proposal to reeducate and reorientate the German youth away from nazism and back toward civilized and democratic ways as a part of the post-war program.

Two Staten Island youths were killed yesterday noon when an automobile in which they were riding was struck by a westbound passenger train of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad at the Bancroft Avenue crossing in Grant City, S.I.

Coldly, realistically, General Hideki Tojo in his capacity as War Minister warned the Japanese people yesterday that the United Nations were preparing to deliver counter-blows of "great importance," and said the signs were that "the real war is starting from now," The Associated Press reported.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 27 -- Major Gen. James H. Doolittle, United States Army Air Force commander on the Tunisian front, today pinned the Distinguished Flying Cross on Lieut. Col. Elliott Roosevelt, son of the President and commander of a photographic unit of the Twelfth Air Force.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The government's first quarter quotas for steel consumers appear to be more liberal and requests have been cut less drastically than for the fourth quarter of 1942, according to some consumers, the magazine Steel reported today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- Allied troops captured "important enemy emplacements" yesterday on the Buna front of New Guinea as Allied bombers knocked out four Japanese ships in a heavy raid on Rabaul, New Britain, and new American fighter planes shot down fifteen Japanese planes in their New Guinea battle debut, the Allied Command announced today.
Sales of several homes, a warehouse and an industrial building in Brooklyn were reported by brokers yesterday.

A glance through the food columns of the past three months -- you always feel like looking backward at the end of the year -- prompts a review. Here, briefly, are some of the things that this department found so interesting last Fall that it is impelled to bring them to your attention once again.

After experiencing record holiday volume in many lines, wholesale markets turned to merchandise wanted for January-February retail promotions, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buyers.

MOSCOW, Monday, Dec. 28 -- Red Army troops continued to smash their way forward in the Ukraine and southwest of Stalingrad yesterday, the Russians announced today, capturing additional villages and killing several thousand more Germans in their effort to bag the entire Nazi army anchored between the Don and Volga Rivers and deep inside the Caucasus.

William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare, has been granted a two-month leave of absence by the city to undertake a confidential mission for former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, now Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, it was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in his weekly broadcast.
Thinning the ranks of undefeated college basketball teams in this area, Long Island University and Fordham went down to defeat before a crowd of 14,526 persons at Madison Square Garden last night.

LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The British point rationing system for foods in short supply has proved successful, simple and elastic and won approval of both consumers and merchants, the Ministry of Food said today.
