LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The United Nations are preparing to establish an international criminal court soon for the post-war trials of Adolf Hitler, Benito Mussolini and other Axis war criminals, reliable informants said tonight.
Our soldiers embarking for foreign shores receive little guide books on how to behave with strangers. Now the British authorities apparently feel that it takes two to make a good understanding.

Over the cold earth that offers no shelter to the invader the Russian armies pound ahead. The two columns that are looped around the German divisions before Stalingrad are now less than fifty miles apart. As they narrow the gap between them they are driving down the road to Rostov, at the gateway to the Caucasus.

Albert D. Lasker, principal owner and president of Lord Thomas, one of the largest and oldest advertising agencies, established seventy years ago, announced yesterday the discontinuance of the agency and his own retirement from business to devote himself to public affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Felix and Charles Ludwig Habsburg, younger brothers of Grand Duke Otto, will be inducted into the Army as volunteer soldiers next Wednesday, the War Department said today. The induction will take place at Fort Myer, Va.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Fifty-eight additional industrial plants have been selected to receive the joint Army-Navy production award in recognition of performance on war contracts, Under Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson and Under Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal said today.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Stock market business here was quiet today, with the tone cheerful. Increased strength in diamond shares was the outstanding feature, De Beers deferred gaining 3/16 to u11 after deduction of the dividend.

The $100,000,000 housing fund for New York City was exhausted yesterday as Edward Weinfeld, State Commissioner of Housing, signed contracts for three additional low-rent housing projects in this city. He said that the incoming Legislature should immediately authorize an additional $150,000,000 to provide homes here for low-income families.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Even a poor start couldn't keep Mrs. W.W. Adams's Arthur Murray from winning the Miami Shores Purse at Tropical Park today by ten lengths. It was his third straight victory.

The Brooklyn Museum has announced that Laurance P. Roberts, the director, has been commissioned a second lieutenant in the Signal Corps of the Army and at present is stationed in Washington. Albert N. Henricksen will be acting director for the duration, and Mrs. Laurance P. Roberts will be curator-in-chief of the department of museums of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- American munition plants scored the largest gain in production last month since the country began to rearm in 1940, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, reported today.

Earnings of the Cuban-American Sugar Company and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 were substantially better than the previous year, according to the annual report announced yesterday.

The Theatre Guild presents its fourth play of the season tonight at the Guild Theatre. It is "The Russian People," a drama of the present war, by Konstantin Simonov, one of the best known Soviet dramatists and a correspondent of Red Star, the Russian military newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Clarification of the situation in North Africa left by the death of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan seemed to be in progress today, with Algiers, London and Washington participating.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 28 (AP) -State Controller-elect Frank C. Moore, announcing today appointment of two of three deputies, said he would abandon the present system of first, second and third deputies, and "adopt a new plan whereby each deputy will be in charge of a separate field of service."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- The Hamilton College sextet dashed Cornell's hopes of winning the Lake Placid Club's intercollegiate hockey series for the S.H. Packer Trophy by scoring a 6-0 triumph over the Ithacans in the big Olympic arena today.
Members of the Turkish Parliament, writing in the Turkish press, have opposed German plans for world domination, the British radio reported yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 28 -- General Vladimir Sikorski was received today by President Manuel Avila Camacho and Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla. His visit elicits friendly comment in the press which, taking the cue from an address of welcome made by President Avila Camacho at the official audience granted to the Polish Premier, emphasized the friendly relations which have always existed between Mexico and Poland.

The holiday's commercial tags began bouncing around the city yesterday. Recovering from a stalemate week-end in which most of the stores were closed, disappointed recipients of Christmas gifts swarmed merchandise counters bent on exchanging, bartering or swelling their pocketbooks or credit accounts.

You are to be commended for the useful page "The House in Wartime." I was particularly interested in reading the article on the heating plant. It is sound in the main, especially on the point about multiple thermometer equipment, but I wish to register exception to some of the other statements.

Total war brings about a scarcity of civilian goods of all kinds. The men who are called into the armed forces are withdrawn from production. A steadily increasing part of those who are not called into the armed forces must be transferred from making the products of peace to making the weapons of war.

"Advertise consistently to achieve the results most desired" was the advice passed along recently to retail druggists by Canadian Pharmaceutical Association from material prepared by the Wartime Prices and Trade Board. Under this heading the material from the Canadian counterpart of this country's OPA listed five yardsticks for guidance of retail druggists in making wartime advertising plans, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Government spokesmen warned today against speculation on the ration allowance of individuals under the forthcoming point rationing of commercially processed vegetables, fruits and soups.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Treasury's Victory loan drive has gone nearly $3,000,000,000 over its original goal of $9,000,000,000 in December loans, Secretary Morgenthau said today. Up to Saturday night subscriptions totaled $11,946,000,000.

The suggestion made Saturday by Ed Barrow, Yankee president, that baseball clubs train at their home bases met with the expected response yesterday. Some club owners came out in support at least of a joint meeting of the two major leagues to decide the issues of home training and a later start of the season, the implication being a favorable response to Barrow's proposal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Specific dollars and cents prices will be issued for packers of grapefruit, lemons, oranges, tangerines and temple oranges (similar to oversized tangerines), the Office of Price Administration announced today.

WITH THE AMERICAN AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Dec. 26 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American fighter pilots shot down seven and possibly twelve Japanese planes over the mountains of Western Yunnan Province today in a fifteen-minute battle against an enemy formation that attempted to raid an advanced United States base.

Record and capacity attendances over the holiday week-end were recorded in midtown first-run motion picture theatres, according to reports from theatre managements yesterday. "Random Harvest," currently in its second week at the Radio City Music Hall, played to the biggest Christmas crowds in the theatre's ten-year history, when it was seen by 94,402 persons from Thursday through Sunday.

Graphic proof that the motorist's vision has been reduced in dimout conditions to between 40 and 60 per cent of its former sharpness was offered yesterday by the New York University Center for Safety Education.

The problem of reducing the size of herds in our forests, a demand for food supply and matters of general conservation policy are all involved in questions which N.S. Dondelinger of the Anaconda (Mont.) Sportsmen's Club raises. Unfortunately, efforts to reach members of the United States Department of Interior to discuss Mr. Dondelinger's letter were unavailing yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- State and local governments decreased their debts by $540,000,000, or 2.7 per cent, in the fiscal year ended June 30, the Census Bureau reported today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 28 -- The British Eighth Army forces skirmished with the enemy yesterday near Wadi Bei el Cheibir, or the Great Wadi [dry water-course], which is eighteen miles east of Buerat el Hsun and another deep gulch, Wadi Zemzem, which pinches the coast road against the soggy salt marshes.

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY, in Libya, Dec. 27 (Delayed) -- British forward patrols have reached Wadi Bei el Cheibir, a fairly easily defended natural obstacle about forty miles west of Sirte, but one that, it now appears certain, the enemy had no intention of defending. His columns are moving still farther westward from this rather shallow gully.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 29 (AP) -Vice Admiral Emile Henri Muselier, former commander of the Fighting French naval forces, declared today in a letter to General de Gaulle that he was "ready to accept any active post at sea or on land in the fight against the enemies of France."
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- A Soviet special communique:

BALTIMORE, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A triple launching today sent the seventy-ninth and eightieth Liberty vessels down the ways at the Bethlehem-Fairfield yard and the nineteenth vessel into the water at the firm's Sparrows Point yard.
I have always thought fools did more harm than the wicked, because wickedness may be uncovered and checked, but a fool is a fool in his own right.

Immediate passage by the incoming Congress of legislation setting up a centralized authority for the nation's entire war economy was advocated last night by the New York County legislative committee of the American Labor party, Left Wing, at a meeting in the Hotel Brevoort, Fifth Avenue and Eighth Street.

Presidents of the four city colleges would get back powers previously held by them before the so-called "democratized" rules of administration were adopted in 1938, under a proposed revision of the by-laws of the Board of Higher Education, circulated among the faculties of the colleges yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 28 (Canadian Press) -- New details of the manner in which the German occupants of Norway plan and carry out intimidation of local populations have been revealed by the Norwegian Government in London.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Federal agents late tonight shot and killed two men they described as "desperate men, badly wanted," and soon afterward J. Edgar Hoover, head of the F.B.I., arrived in Chicago, presumably to take personal charge of the case.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, will submit to his labor-management policy committee tomorrow for the first time a proposal which would implement the wide grant of authority given to him on Dec. 5 by President Roosevelt, under which the chairman may compel all hiring of labor to be done through the United States Employment Service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The War Production Board has been forced to give special consideration to the twin and triplet situation in the United States and allot extra critical materials to some baby carriage manufacturers, the Office of War Information reported today.
ALLIED, HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 28 -- There was heavy patrol activity in the Medjez-el-Bab and Tebourba sector today as the ground dried out a bit after recent heavy rains.

Holding that the trial jury should have been permitted to witness an actual performance of the show instead of merely hearing it described, Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein granted yesterday a certificate of reasonable doubt permitting the release on bail of Isidore H. Herk, producer of the now closed "Wine, Women and Song," pending appeal from his conviction in General Sessions on charges of presenting an indecent performance.

After signing contracts yesterday for State loans for three lowrent, post-war housing projects here, Edward Weinfeld, State Commissioner of Housing, announced that the housing funds earmarked for New York City by the Legislature had been exhausted.

Gaining 7 points as the result of encounters with Yeshiva and Brooklyn College in the fourth and fifth rounds yesterday, City College advanced further toward custody of the Harold M. Phillips Trophy, emblematic of the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A United States Air Force communique:

Price-fixing in near positions and covering in new-crop months yesterday raised the list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to new highs for the current movement and to the best prices in more than five months. With quotations for all contracts at 19 cents a pound or above, the market closed with net gains of 7 to 16 points.

Artur Rodzinski, conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, has been named musical director and conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra beginning with the season of 1943-44, it was announced yesterday by Marshall Field. president and chairman of the board of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -The Federal Government relinquished today all mandatory controls over the wages and salaries of the 3,000,000 employes of State, county and municipal governments.

In a brief article in our Sunday Magazine President Seymour of Yale has given his colleagues and the public something stimulating to think about. He has heartened us all by rising above the depression in which many liberal educators find themselves because of the war.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Mill buying advanced wheat futures around 1 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade at one time today, with May selling at a new seasonal high and going to a small premium over the July. Renewed reports that the price ceiling on flour would be raised had considerable influence on professional sentiment, and there also was a moderate commission house demand for futures.
The farm clubs of the Giants and Yankees, Jersey City and Newark, produced some top talent in pitching and batting this year, according to the International League averages just released.

Spurred by the need of explaining the new point system for rationing many food products, the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office is planning to intensify next week its drive to recruit 95,000 volunteers for training and service as block leaders, Mrs. Robert Russell, CDVO director of training, said yesterday.

The final rush of Christmas buying last week brought sales increases for New York and Brooklyn stores of 12 per cent over last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Sugar Bowl tennis tournament advanced through the semi-finals today. Ted Schroeder of Stanford, national champion and seeded No. 1 here, failed to appear, causing an immediate rise in the stock of Francisco Segura of Ecuador, seeded No. 2.

The play called "Sweet Charity" that has been wandering the outskirts for a time finally put in an appearance last evening at the Mansfield. Produced by Alfred Bloomingdale, it also bears a slogan with the familiar device, "A George Abbott Production," which means that everything is in it, including gags and marijuana.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 28 (Reuter) -- Tonight's Chinese communique announced a new Japanese drive in eastern Kwangtung Province, in South China, where the Japanese have landed troops.

Leonard Robert O. Jordan and three of his fellow Negro leaders of a Harlem movement offered denials or explanations yesterday or statements attributed to them by the government in substantiation of charges of sedition. Jordan ended his testimony, and was followed on the witness stand in Federal court by the Rev. Ralph Green Best and James Henry Thornhill. Lester Eugene Holness, the remaining defendant, had testified earlier.
Federal employes were bewildered by the publicity given to their pay "increase." May I clarify this increase so that the general public may understand it?

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Since Dec. 12, when 1,000 Belgian justices refused to sit in their courts, no legal decisions have been given, Antoine Delfosse, Belgian Minister of Justice and Information, said in London today. The magistrates, the Minister said, had taken this action in preference to submitting to German directions that, they consider, undermine the Belgian law and Constitution.

Three persons were killed last night and several others were injured in a series of traffic accidents attributed by the police to a com bination of rain and the dimout. One of injured was the victim of a hit-run driver. All occurred in the Bronx.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 28 -The death of Sir Sikander Hyat Khan, Punjab Premier, on Saturday eliminated the only Moslem figure important enough to challenge the position of Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES, in Southern Tunisia, Dec. 27 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The story of an American raiding party that dashed into an Italian-occupied town with the battle-cry "Hi, Ho, Silver, away!" and killed fifteen enemy troops, wounded thirty and captured twenty-one was told today by Captain Stephen C. Morrisey of West Medway, Mass.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Navy communique No. 232:

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 28 (Reuter) -- Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts, in a message expressing full agreement with the decision to observe a day of mourning tomorrow throughout South Africa for Jewish victims of German atrocities, said, "I am filled with a dire foreboding at what may be the harvest from these dragon's teeth the Nazis are sowing over Central and Eastern Europe.

LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A rail strike early next year was threatened today as drivers and firemen of Britain's war-strained railway system instructed delegates on the stand that they should take at a vital conference in London next Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Office of Price Administration today made jury members eligible for special gasoline rations, and newspaper circulation supervisors for C rations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -The Navy announced today that a small Norwegian merchant vessel had been torpedoed and sunk early in December in the Atlantic off Northern South America. Survivors were landed at an East Coast port of the United States.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 28 -- One hundred and fiftynine days out of Montevideo, Uruguay, Vito Dumas, 42-yearold Argentine yachtsman and horse owner, sailed his thirtyfoot, nine-ton yacht Lehg-Lehg II single-handed into harbor here yesterday after a lone crossing of 13,000 ocean miles separating New Zealand from South America by way of Cape Town and Tasmania.

American troops are approaching cities and towns in Eastern Tunisia that contain some of the noblest and most important monuments in Islam. At Tunis, Suse and particularly Kaiouran there are thousand-year-old mosques of remarkable beauty and the greatest historical significance, particularly the Cathedral Mosque at Kaiouran, which was begun in the early ninth century and attained its utmost splendor in the tenth.

Year-end adjustments and tax selling produced yesterday contradictory movements in the stock market. Extreme losses of 2 points in some prime investment issues were the widest of the month to date, although others in the pivotal class managed to bypass the trend and finish with small gains.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -Here is an Agriculture Department breakdown showing what percentage of the country's food must be diverted from civilian use to meet military and lend-lease requirements:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 28 -- Seventy-five thousand German families are now unable to find lodgings in Vienna, says the Voelksicher Beobachter, confirming previous reports that more than 400,000 of refugees have been evacuated to the former Austrian capital from Royal Air Force target areas.

Grocery stores throughout the metropolitan area, which for weeks have been rationing canned foods to customers, usually on the basis of one can of any item for a customer, reported with few exceptions yesterday that no buying rush had followed the Wickard-Davis announcement of plans for point-rationing of canned and frozen foods to begin in February.
Here is the way the rationing of commercially processed fruits and vegetables will work, as explained yesterday by E.S. Ferguson, regional rationing executive of the Office of Price Administration:

A plan to grant special production allotments to paper mills which can produce extra quantities by the use of waste paper rather than pulp has been presented by some manufacturers to the War Production Board, it was learned yesterday.

RANCHO SANTE FE, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Sammy Baugh, star forward passer of the Redskins, had definitely planned to play against the Professional All-Stars in yesterday's charity football game at Philadelphia, George P. Marshall, president of the Washington club, said today.

Speaking through the narrow slit of an oxygen tent, Police Commissioner Valentine promoted the occupant, Detective Bradley Hammond, from second to first grade yesterday in a brief bedside ceremony in St. Vincent's Hospital. The promotion carries an $800 annual increase in pay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Climaxing six months of study of the problem, the WPB acted today to place limits on the quantities of consumers' goods retail merchants, wholesalers and stock-carrying branches of manufacturers may keep on hand.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 -- The Sugar Bowl program rolled on toward Friday's football clash between Tennessee and Tulsa today with official reports that 27,000 of the 73,000 seats still are unsold and strong indications that wartime transportation restrictions will prevent a sellout for the first time since the Sugar Bowl inaugural in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -The ban on country-wide publication of war casualty and prisoner lists has been lifted on a decision of high administration officials that the American public can "take bad news," it was learned tonight.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 28 -- With a pontifical mass celebrated by the Most Rev. James E. Kearney, Bishop of Rochester and moderator of the Newman Club Federation, the Catholic Collegiate Congress was opened here today, attended by more than 300 students from all parts of the country. The theme is "Victory in Peace and War."

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 26 (Delayed) -- In a fertile New Zealand river valley, a United States Navy hospital has taken over the task of caring for Americans who need hospitalization. The hospital is largely staffed by specialists, including physicians, a neurological surgeon, a dermatologist and one pathologist internationally known for his research work on the distribution of metallic substances in the body and on benzol poisoning.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 29 -- A headquarters spokesman said that American forces, who have been pushing along the south side of the main airstrip, attempting to envelop strong Japanese fortifications among coconut groves and airplanes dispersal bays met the enemy attempt to break out late Sunday night.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Donald Blythe, with the official blessings of the State of New York, can go on living with his family in Brooklyn, working in a war plant, instead of returning to Massachusetts to serve out, under his real name of Charles Sullivan, a prison term for a crime he committed eleven years ago, when he was 21 years old.

Miss Grace Acel of Cornell, fencing with great steadiness and finesse, won the annual Christmas invitation tournament held under the auspices of the Women's Intercollegiate Fencing Association on the strips of New York University yesterday.

Yesterday was payment day for commercial bank subscribers to the new issue of one-year 7/8 of 1 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness. Allotments aggregated $2,113,605,000, of which the New York Federal Reserve District accounted for $747,562,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -Puget Sound Power and Light Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a registration statement covering $60,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and debentures, the proceeds from which would be used in part for recapitalization of the concern, a subsidiary of Engineers Public Service Company.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- The government's first plant in its million-ton-a-year synthetic rubber program will go into production "some time next month" at Institute, W. Va., with an eventual rated capacity of 80,000 tons a year, William M. Jeffers, Federal rubber director, disclosed here today.
Following is the text of the Woodrow Wilson birthday anniversary address delivered in Washington last night by Vice President Wallace, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

COOCH BEHAR, India, Dec. 25 (Delayed) -- The ruler of this little State of Cooch Behar in Northeastern India is known to his subjects and to his Indian peers as His Highness the Maharaja Jagaddipendra Narayan Bhup Bahadur, but to the fortunate American Air Force pilots and mechanics on leave here he is just "the Chief."
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 28 -Italo-Hungarian economic "unity," based on parity of exchanges, was wrenched today when the Italian Exchange Institute called on all Italians and foreigners living in Italy with credits on Hungary to declare them before Jan. 15.

The first test case was filed in Supreme Court here yesterday under the recent ruling of the United States Supreme Court that each State must recognize the validity of divorces granted in other States even though the defendant was not personally served and did not appear in the divorce action.

Edgar G. Burton, Retail Trade Administrator for Canada under the Wartime Prices and Trade Board, will present American retailers with a first-hand report of the working of Canadian price control at the annual meeting of the American Retail Federation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Jan. 9, it was announced yesterday by Dr. David R. Craig, president of the federation.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Dec. 28 -- Tradition took a trimming today as thirteen women sailed into the portals of the United States Coast Guard Academy, For the first time in American martial history a government military institution swung open its doors to women students.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 29 -Red Army troops, closing in on Kotelnikov, have by-passed and virtually encircled the key railroad town ninety miles southwest of Stalingrad, the High Command revealed today in a special communique announcing a twelve to fifteen mile advance yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Leasing today of the huge wholesale building occupied by Carson Pirie Scott Co. for War and Treasury Department use has left the veteran Chicago dry goods house with the alternatives of going out of business or seeking new quarters.

NEW CITY, Dec. 28 -- At daybreak tomorrow squads of police with high-powered rifles will begin searching three-quarters of Rockland County, determined to shoot every dog at large in an effort to curb the worst rabies epidemic in the county's history.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 27 (Delayed) -- Yugoslav armies under General Draja Mikhailovitch killed or captured more than 6,000 Germans, Italians, Hungarians, Bulgars and Croats recently and seized forty tons of small arms, artillery, ammunition and explosives, according to intelligence reports received here.

Woodrow Wilson's birthday yesterday inspired an eloquent tribute by Vice President Wallace and must have set a great many people wondering whether the present war would have occurred if this country had lived up to its responsibilities in 1919 and thereafter.

The undercurrent of solicitude lest the harsh demands of war make those in great need suffer even more, which carried the thirty-first annual appeal for the Neediest Cases Fund through Christmas, is continuing as a strong sustaining force, even though the active appeal stopped on that day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Next week, only two months after it was elected, the new Congress will assemble and begin its legislative duties. Until eight years ago, whatever the political changes that had been registered by changing views of the people, and whether or not the nation was passing through critical times, a minimum delay of four months and a maximum of thirteen months had to be endured before the new Congress could take office.

Mayor La Guardia is entirely correct in his premise that there should be no driving for pleasure during the emergency which restricts the flow of gasoline on the Eastern seaboard and the still more important nation-wide emergency resulting from the shortage of rubber.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- New Japanese efforts to supply their troops on Guadalcanal Island, this time by parachute, were broken up yesterday (Solomons time) by American airplanes that bombed and strafed thirty cargo-laden parachutes discovered on the beach at Tassafaronga, the Navy Department reported today.
Two kinds of prepared eggnog deserve your consideration if you are planning some sort of festivity for New Year's Day.

Every food warehouse in the city was placed under police guard yesterday after the discovery of the theft of 22,000 pounds of butter from a cold storage warehouse in the heart of the wholesale butter and egg district on the lower West Side.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 28 -Chief of Government Pierre Laval's position -- as well as that of the Vichy government -- was made clear today, even though indirectly. Otto Abetz, diplomatic representative of the Reich in France, has been recalled and will be replaced by "police generals," one in Paris, the other in Vichy.
AT UNITED NATIONS, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 29 -- Allied bombers are believed to have destroyed a Japanese cruiser off Rabaul, New Britain, a headquarters communique said today.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Dr. Edwin R. Van Kleeck, assistant State education commissioner, declared today that boys and girls of high school age were earning "from $40 to $60 and more per week" in industry, and therefore educational provisions for post-adolescent youth would have to be redoubled after the war."

Dr. Forrest G. (Phog) Allen, veteran coach of the University of Kansas basketball team, which opposed Fordham at Madison Square Garden last night, voiced a plea for "more intelligent research" by college mentors yesterday at a luncheon at Toots Shor's restuarant.

A Lewis and Clark Northwest manuscript contest was announced yesterday by Dutton, with the new competition fashioned along the lines of the existing Thomas Jefferson Southern Award. The firm will offer $1,500 as an advance against royalties "for the best book manuscript submitted by an author from Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Montana or Alaska."

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A large force of American four-motored bombers dealt a second destructive blow at Bangkok, Japanese-occupied capital of Thailand, Saturday night, smashing the naval dock area, a large arsenal and powder factory and the air field, a communique announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- A call for an "enlarged temporary power grouping together all French forces inside and outside the country and all French territories which are able to fight for liberation" was made by General Charles de Gaulle tonight.

Although prices have been raised in all but one Broadway theatre in anticipation of a New Year's Eve rush, a survey yesterday revealed that people this year are slow in pan, sing money through the box office windows. Three days before the festive evening not a single house was without .ckets in the racks.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A communique:

ALMONTE, Ont., Dec. 28 (AP) -Thirty-six holiday passengers were killed and 118 injured, many critically, when the locomotive of a Canadian Pacific troop train plowed through the three wooden cars of a local train standing in the station here last night, officials of the railway said today.

On future rainy days, less distinctive and original umbrellas will be seen on the streets. The quantity and type of umbrellas have been restricted by orders of the War Production Board. This fact was announced yesterday by the Regional News Bureau of the Office of War Information, 122 East Forty-second Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -Alfred Hitchcock's first picture at Twentieth Century-Fox under the deal by which Fox obtained his services as a director from David O. Selznick for two films will be "Lifeboat," a yarn about the survivors of a torpedoed American merchant ship and a Nazi submarine who have to share the same lifeboat.

Seventy-three per cent of the York Corporation's business is in the manufacture and installation of refrigeration and industrial air-conditioning equipment for war plants and the nation's naval and military forces, S.E. Lauer, president, said yesterday in the annual report to stockholders.

LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Foreign Minister and several other Cabinet members of the Yugoslav Government in Exile were reported tonight to have resigned, but an official spokesman declared that General Draja Mikhailovitch, who heads a large army fighting the Axis in Yugoslavia, "will remain as War Minister regardless of the composition of the new Cabinet."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Major Gen. Ernest N. Harmon and Brig. Gen. Lucien K. Truscott received Distinguished Service Medals in Morocco today for their leadership of troops who effected the successful landing Nov. 8 on the west coast of French North Africa in the face of considerable opposition, the War Department announced here.

While approving the "point" system of rationing of canned goods, leaders in all branches of the food industry expressed the fear yesterday that the advance announcement would lead to increased consumer hoarding and add to the difficulties of their operations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -An agreement providing for the joint determination of Brazil's civilian requirements from the United States by the Carteira de Exportacao e Importacao of the Banco do Brazil and agencies of this government was announced today at the State Department.

In the final report of John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor in Brooklyn for four years, is an extraordinary record of criminal prosecution. He has investigated and brought to justice rings, rackets, gambling, graft of many kinds. He has procured the dismissal, retirement or imprisonment of many officials.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Maybe a glimpse of Frankie Sinkwich's celebrated ankles is the lure, or perhaps the populace is feverish over what promises to be a bang-up football game. Anyway, another sellout crowd of 93,000 is in prospect for the Rose Bowl game Friday.

Plans to speed rail deliveries of fuel oil to East Coast areas facing alarming shortages will be discussed by representatives of the Federal Government and the petroleum industry at a conference today in the White House offices of James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- President Roosevelt today suspended the Federal eight-hour-day law covering laborers and mechanics employed by the War Department on public works within the United States, but specified that they shall receive overtime pay at the rate of time and one-half.

The new Canada-Alaska highway now has been open for little more than a month. But already through the intense cold of the long northern night ten-wheeled trucks, laden high with the stuffs of war, are rolling and will roll in steadily increasing number from the southern supply depot at Dawson Creek northward along the 1,600-mile length of a wilderness road that was begun in the early months of this year without even a blueprint.

The Algiers radio, in a broadcast transmitted to French Africa and reported by the Federal Communications Commission, revealed yesterday that General Barre, commander of French forces in Tunisia, rejected last month two Nazi ultimatums to join the Germans with his troops and cede virtually all the territory to Nazi military control.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A new record high for heavy sausage hulls at $13.75 was a feature in the cattle section today. Demand for cows and bulls, livestock men said, was based on the fact that meat from these animals is used for lend-lease orders. The average price of steers here last week was $15, compared with $14.55 in the preceding week and $13.08 in the same week last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Vice President Wallace declared tonight that the goal of the United Nations is a world-wide new democracy under which human affairs will be so organized that "no Adolf Hitler, no power-hungry warmongers, whatever their nationality, can ever again plunge the whole world into war and bloodshed."

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had approved the recommendations of a departmental board for the tightening of local safety laws to prevent fires or panics here similar to those recently in Boston and St. John's, where many lives were lost.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -Secretary of State Cordell Hull denied today that the United States Ambassador to Bolivia had attempted to impede the passage of a Bolivian labor code creating more favorable conditions for mine workers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Vice President Wallace declared tonight that the goal of the United Nations is a world-wide new democracy under which human affairs will be so organized that "no Adolf Hitler, no power-hungry warmongers, whatever their nationality, can ever again plunge the whole world into war and bloodshed."

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had approved the recommendations of a departmental board for the tightening of local safety laws to prevent fires or panics here similar to those recently in Boston and St. John's, where many lives were lost.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -Secretary of State Cordell Hull denied today that the United States Ambassador to Bolivia had attempted to impede the passage of a Bolivian labor code creating more favorable conditions for mine workers.
MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 28 -- Proposed increases of a cent a quart in milk and a cent a half-pint in cream faced New Jersey residents today because of a scarcity of milk within the State, brought on by lack of adequate dairy farm labor and higher production costs.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Asserting that newspapers still remain the best protection that the public has against wrongdoers, the Massachusetts Judicial Council declared today that they "should not be hampered by the uncertainty that now exists as to the (libel) laws."
LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- London newspapers today hailed the address of Vice President Wallace as a step in educating the people to the problems of the post-war world.

The new Canada-Alaska highway now has been open for little more than a month. But already through the intense cold of the long northern night ten-wheeled trucks, laden high with the stuffs of war, are rolling and will roll in steadily increasing number from the southern supply depot at Dawson Creek northward along the 1,600-mile length of a wilderness road that was begun in the early months of this year without even a blueprint.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 28 -Another mammoth drive for scrap to replenish Germany's stocks of raw materials has been launched by the authorities in charge of war economy. The new drive, according to reports received here today, will extend to the occupied areas where the Nazis hope to get millions of tons.

MADRID, Dec. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- Although Chief of Government Pierre Laval, by various means, appears -- at least temporarily -- to have checked Jacques Doriot's rising stock, German military authorities in both zones of France recently severed civil cooperation bonds with French authorities.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Paramount the new attraction will be "Star Spangled Rhythm," an all-star musical comedy producted by Paramount. Among the picture's featured players are Bing Crosby, Bob Hope, Fred MacMurray, Victor Moore, Paulette Goddard, Vera Zorina, Mary Martin, Dorothy Lamour, Eddie Bracken, Veronica Lake, Alan Ladd, Betty Hutton, Franchot Tone, Ray Milland and Rochester.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 236, as against 450 in the preceding week and 247 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 166, which compared with sixty-four last Tuesday.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29 -- Miss Helen Griffin has sent her first poem to a newspaper. President and Mrs. Roosevelt heard it read and now they want copies.

Tribute was paid yesterday to the important work that is being done by the National Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States and the Navy League Service in providing comforts to the men in the Navy and merchant marine at a tea given by Mrs. Myron C. Taylor in aid of the "Home Fund Front" of the Navy League at her home, 16 East Seventieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Finnish Information Center in New York has been ordered by the State Department to cease issuing news releases and pamphlets, and the American Legation in Helsinki has stopped sending out bulletins and other material prepared by the Office of War Information.

With a Scottish doll from his collection tucked under his arm, 11-year-old Bruce Birkenhead arrived yesterday morning at Postmaster Albert Goldman's office, Thirty-third Street and Eighth Avenue, to receive his Junior Division award in the Victory Doll Show.
MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 29 -- James N. Gehrig, secretary of the Nassau County Republican Committee for the last twenty years, was appointed today Presiding Supervisor of the Hempstead Town Board to fill the unexpired term of Lieutenant A. Holly Patterson, who was sworn in as a member of the United States Naval Reserve yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Norman Thomas, former Socialist candidate for President, came to Washington today with protests that our propaganda sent abroad did not show a demand for establishment of democratic governments in Europe and that labor conservation would be an inefficient and totalitarian movement.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- The rehabilitated Rangers, thanks to the superb goal-tending of Jim Franks, subjected the Bruins to their first setback in eleven starts on Boston Garden ice during the current National Hockey League campaign by a 5-3 margin tonight before 13,500, the largest crowd of the local season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Rationing of automobile tires and gasoline will bring the neighborhood merchant back to his own, the House Committee on Small Business reported today on the basis of reports made by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and Leon Henderson, Price Administrator.

The body of Mary Rycoitch, 19-year-old war plant worker, was found at 10:45 A.M. yesterday in a field at Bloomfield, S.I. According to Dr. Mendel Jacobi, assistant medical examiner, she had been murdered. There was no evidence of criminal assault, and discovery of her purse, containing money, eliminated the possibility of a robbery motive.

"The Doughgirls," a comedy by Joseph Fields, now represented on Broadway as co-author of "My Sister Eileen" and "Junior Miss," will be presented at the Lyceum tonight by Max Gordon. The comedy's scene is a Washington hotel and the action revolves around the adventures, amorous and economic, of three young women and a host of typical Washington wartime characters, including a Russian girl sniper.
Donald Blythe, 32-year-old war worker, rejoiced yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court with his wife, Marie, mother of their two small daughters, Joan, 5 years old, and Lucille, 3.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis, acting to end the uncertainty surrounding Spring training plans, was in Washington today to confer with the Office of Defense Transportation officials. Landis had an appointment for 9 A.M. tomorrow with Director Joseph B. Eastman.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Dec. 29 -- Stricken with a heart attack as she sat by a window waving a farewell to her youngest son, Roy Moffett, 22 years old, after he left home today to report to Selective Service Headquarters here for his Army physical examination, Mrs. Margaret Moffett, 69, of 231 Elmer Street, died almost instantly.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A British communique:

Countess Edith di Zoppola gave a dinner with dancing last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Mara di Zoppola. The debutante is a granddaughter of the late Mrs. Stanley Mortimer, who was a sister of the late Mrs. Elliott Roosevelt, mother of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The RCA Manufacturing Company, wholly owned by the Radio Corporation of America, will be merged with the parent concern, effective tomorrow, David Sarnoff, president of RCA, announced yesterday following a special meeting of RCA's directors.

UPPER DARBY, Pa., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Small farmers in an eleven-State region stretching from Maine through Maryland have topped their 1942 food production goals "by tremendous figures" and are planning still greater output next year, J.H. Wood, regional director of the Farm Security Administration, said today in a year-end report.

WASHINGTON, Dec 29 -- Selection of a new group of thirty-five industrial establishments to receive the Army-Navy production award for outstanding performance on war work was announced today by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and by James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell resigned today as State Civilian Protection Director to join former Governor Lehman in foreign relief work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- "Streamlining of nursing education is considered a war necessary and is in harmony with similar developments in other educational fields," Paul V. McNutt, director of the Office of Defense Health and Welfare Services, stated in a letter today urging 1,300 nursing schools to shorten their training programs.

Bathtubs, New York newspapers, hot water and dance bands may be lacking in North Africa, but otherwise Army nurses there are having a "wonderful time." Letters received recently from the Roosevelt Hospital unit in that area have stressed the extracurricular activities enjoyed by the girls.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The Industrial Life Offices Association, representing twenty-five industrial insurance companies, issued a long memorandum today offering some critical "preliminary observations" on the Beveridge report urging compulsory social insurance.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 29 -- In one of the few responsive answers to 100 or more questions asked him during a five-hour interrogation today, Prosecutor Daniel T. O'Regan of Hudson County denied that the indictment of Mayor James J. Donovan of Bayonne for alleged misconduct in office, had been "obtained by arrangement with Mayor Frank Hague."

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- British forces, driving sixty-five miles into Western Burma's Arakan Province, are within twenty- five miles of the Japanese-held port of Akyab. Royal Air Force flyers have made three successful attacks in two days against the enemy airdrome at Magwe, on the Irrawaddy River, it was announced today.

Federal rationing and oil industry representatives here, awaiting announcement in Washington of the new priority regulations for fuel oil rationing, heard from good sources yesterday that hospitals, schools, postoffices, court houses, and possibly police and fire stations, would come first in the distribution of available supplies, while amusements, such as theatres and dance halls, would come last if they were fortunate enough to be on the list.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Office of Defense Transportation today asked Federal agencies not to send speakers or representatives to the Chicago and Grand Rapids Furniture Marts next month. The request was made in the interests of minimizing travel.

George W. Norris, the United States Senator from Nebraska whose people refused to return him to Washington last November, gave his Senatorial swan-song last night at the Hotel Commodore. With a stiff bow to the National Association of Manufacturers he said this war was being fought not only to put a TVA on the Danube but on every "other river of similar magnitude anywhere in the world."

The city will celebrate its first dimmed-out New Year's Eve tomorrow night with benefit of unprecedented precautions growing out of the disastrous Cocoanut Grove night club fire in Boston, it was learned yesterday.

Because of wartime unavailability of suitable indoor sites, the Senior Metropolitan A.A.U. Track and Field Committee has decided to conduct its indoor championships outdoors next month, it was announced yesterday by Pincus Sober, chairman of the championship committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Vice Admiral C.E.L. Helfrich, who was Allied Naval Commander in Chief in the Java area earlier in the war, talked with President Roosevelt today and told reporters later that he was "encouraged" at the outlook for the United Nations.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Expecting the battle lines of the Russian front to move westward, the Germans are trying to clear all Poles from wide stretches of territory in Eastern Poland and settle Germans and Ukrainians in these areas, where fortifications and airfields are being built with great speed, it was said today.

The stock market failed again yesterday to start its time-honored year-end rally, but increased tax selling in low-priced issues produced the heaviest turnover of the year. Serious inroads were suffered by some groups in the morning period, but support in the afternoon stemmed the decline and permitted a partial recovery.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 29 -- A law authorizing an internal loan of 60,000,000 pesos passed by the recent Congress requires an investment in a number of instances in "national economic defense bonds" to be issued for the loan. Foreign capital brought into the country must be invested in bonds up to 20 per cent of the total.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Detailed plans for the inauguration of Thomas E. Dewey as Governor on Friday were made public today by Paul E. Lockwood, incoming secretary to the Governor. The plans were worked out, Mr. Lockwood said, to preserve as much of the tradition of the ceremony as possible, consistent with economy.

Arthur Deacon, whose sloop Armade was one of the outstanding Star Class craft last Summer, was chosen fleet captain of the Western Long Island Sound group of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association at the annual meeting last night in the New York Athletic Club.

It would be more than agreeable to report this morning that all of "The Russian People" is as good as its best parts. For it is the first play to come out of Russia in a long, long time, and, as written by one who is on the scene, it tells the story of a magnificent and courageous people in their fight against the Nazi invader.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 29 -- American paratroops by the thousands will descend from the skies Lehind enemy lines on cast-off nylon stockings converted into parachutes by a new process, it was revealed here today during an inspection tour of the du Pont Nylon Research Laboratory and Pilot Plant, following ceremonies at which the Army-Navy "E" was officially awarded to the plant and laboratory.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Returning soldiers and sailors will not be fooled by "the old claptrap concerning 'rugged individualism,' 'American opportunity' or 'American equality,'" but "will demand jobs here and now," the Right Rev. John A. Ryan declared today in an attack on "the authentic Bourbons of our time."

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 29. -- Here at Wright Field, gigantic materiel center for the Army Air Forces, where "imagination and foresight" are the passwords, there is a message for Americans: Don't be overawed by tales of German "supremacy" in planning aerial warfare. America is planning and building, too -- everything from bullet-proof gas tanks to super-block-busters -- and army officers are confident they can outdo the best the Nazis have to offer.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 29 -- The Critica and the Argentina Libre, two newspapers prominent for their attachment to the United Nations cause, were suspended by the police today for violating the state of siege decree which for more than a year has forbidden all public discussion of international affairs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- In two surprise raids here last night and early today agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation killed and captured all that remained of the band of Roger (The Terrible) Touhy, Chicago prohibition overlord who clubbed his way out of the Statesville penitentiary with six followers on Oct. 9.

Mrs. H. Burr Kelsey gave a luncheon yesterday at Trouville for her sister, Miss Henrietta Voorhees, a debutante of this season. Among the other guests were the Misses Edith Fincke, Anne Goodwin, Eleanor Schwarz, Phyllis Haynes, Dorothy Harvey, Mimi deBaubigny, Iola Stetson, Mary Young and Dorothy Scott, all debutantes.

This month of December has witnessed the hurried graduation of thousands of American college men who would otherwise have received their diplomas with a good deal of genial and leisurely formality next June. When the Army-Navy training plan goes into effect a few weeks from now many campuses will take on the look of armed camps.

An attempt is being made in Washington to deal with the great and growing problem of manpower by indirect methods which are of doubtful legality and even more doubtful value. More direct and effective methods are available. They should be used.

A total of 272,794,725 pounds of scrap was salvaged in 11,885 plants in New York and New Jersey between Nov. 20 and Dec. 20 as a result of the efforts of volunteer salvage executives, R. Merrill Decker, regional chief of the WPB's Industrial Salvage Branch, announced yesterday. Mr. Decker said:

By air mail, special delivery, registered letter, from Wall Street financial houses and law firms, midtown business concerns, Park Avenue, Fifth Avenue, all the five boroughs and many distant points gifts for the Neediest Cases Fund continued to arrive yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A French headquarters communique broadcast by Morocco Radio:

Most of the skepticism surrounding this season's Manhattan basketball team was erased last night. The Jaspers, pitted against their second major rival, Niagara, brought down the Purple Eagles, 46 to 39, on the local court.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- A plan for dissolution of the Southern Electric Utilities Company, a subsidiary of the General Gas and Electric Corporation, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- French Somaliland, with its important port of Jibuti on the east coast of Africa, has joined Fighting France and the United Nations. It was the last French colony in Africa to forswear allegiance to Vichy.

An underwriting group headed by Morgan Stanley Co. is being formed for a contemplated issue of $100,000,000 Dominion of Canada refunding bonds. Proceeds of this financing would be used to refund a like amount of the Dominion's 5 per cent bonds due on May 1, 1952, which were issued in 1922.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Acting in behalf of President Roosevelt, Vice President Wallace today presented the Collier trophy for achievement in aviation jointly to the Army Air Forces and the private air lines of the country.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Restoration of republican principles in the French Empire as it returns to the war against the Nazis is absolutely necessary, Andre Philip, Fighting French Commissioner for Interior and Labor, said tonight in an address marking the resumption of the Fighting Frenchmen's regular appearance on the British Broadcasting Corporation's French service.

Those who follow the Harlan Major school of thought when it comes to fishing are not likely to be discouraged by any shortage of tackle. "Sure You Can Fish," Major's latest book, gives a good example of an American fisherman who won't be stopped.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Governor Poletti moved today to assume, with consent and assistance of the Democratic legislative leaders, direction of his party's policies in the State for the next four years, outlining with these leaders a broad program of social reform, for both now and the post-war era.

AT AN AMERICAN AIR BASE, in Northeastern India, Dec. 22 (Delayed) -- Captain John Payne, a crack pilot who was the first to demonstrate that a ferry plane could be taken over the hump of the Himalayas into China at night, casually mentioned at breakfast this morning that he had to make an altitude test in an Army transport.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- To encourage more persons to rent available rooms in their homes to war workers, the Office of Price Administration permitted householders today with no more than two paying guests to evict them in accordance with local laws.

General Charles de Gaulle, the head of the French National Committee in London, and General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner in North Africa, would find it fairly easy to agree if they could be closeted alone. They have known each other for years and their controversies, long buried in the past, did not extend beyond tank tactics.

People planning the new peace and the new postwar world quite properly begin by recalling the mistakes we made in building the peace of twenty-three years ago. They say, Never Again. But the mistakes of twenty-three years ago were not only deeds but also slogans and catchwords; and about these battle cries and formulas of another day we do not say today, Never Again.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Colgate captured the title in the Lake Placid Club's annual college hockey tournament by smothering Hamilton, 9 to 2, in the final at the Olympic Arena tonight. Having retired the old Samuel H. Packer Trophy last year, the Red Raiders gained their first leg on the new prize. The donor, who is general manager of the club here, made the presentation.

The engagement, in the person of Artur Rodzinski, of a single conductor to direct and control the activities of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra beginning with the season of 1943-44 is a procedure which will have the hearty commendation of the public that has this orchestra's welfare at heart.

Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman who was recently named by Governor elect Thomas E. Dewey as incoming Secretary of State, announced here yesterday the appointments of two deputies in his new office which he will assume on Friday.

Answering the recent complaints that they are unruly or rowdy, a group of high school boys charged yesterday that teachers and principals frequently goad students into resentment by slapping, cuffing or other resort to physical violence in direct violation of the Board of Education by-law which forbids the use of force by school officials.

Listening to Mr. Davis and Secretary Wickard on the radio last night I was impressed by the clarity and force of their statements on the subject of food rationing. There was no old-fashioned oratorical attempt to sway the public emotionally. This in itself indicates a notable growth in the public intelligence and its awareness of propaganda, both good and evil.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Paramount announced today that Joel Friend, Broadway actor who succeeded Gene Kelly in the title role of "Pal Joey" and who appeared in "Let's Face It" on Broadway, has been signed to a term contract and will make his screen debut in "Dixie" and "Lady in the Dark."

The sale by allotment of two new issues of New York City revenue bills aggregating $25,000,000 was announced yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick. Both issues are dated Dec. 30, 1942, with one issue of $10,000,000 maturing on March 8, 1943, and the other of $15,000,000 maturing on April 16, 1943.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Wheat forged ahead to new seasonal high prices in a closing burst of strength on the Board of Trade today, aggressive buying attributed to mills and a firm with Southwestern connections catching many of the professional traders short.

Howard Boatwright, 24-year-old violinist from Newport News, Va., gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. The major works on his program were Handel's D major Sonata, Pizzetti's A major Sonata and Prokofieff's G minor Violin Concerto.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Admission to college of superior students at the end of their junior high school year was opposed today by New York's secondary school principals, who urged pupils to remain in school and complete "the full wartime program of studies."

A study just completed by the two family agencies of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities -- the Jewish Social Service Association and the Jewish Family Welfare Society -- reveals that "the strains and tensions of war are throwing out of gear the lives of people of nearly all income groups and of many walks of life."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- An otherwise dull afternoon of racing at Tropical Park was enlivened today when the daily double provided a pay-off of $1,288,20 for $2, easily highest of the current session but not close to Florida's record return of $7,205,40 at this track in 1935, when a Jersey City truck driver named Harry Topser had the lone winning ticket.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller submitted today her resignation to Governor Poletti, effective Thursday, and coupled with it a review of the activities of the bureaus of her department during the past year.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Archbishop Athenagoras of the Greek Orthodox Church in North and South America, at a reception yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the Friends of Greece, 52 East Fifty-seventh Street, gave a New Year's blessing for the work of the organization during 1943.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Allied troops have withdrawn from a hill six miles northeast of Medjez-el-Bab on the road to Tunis "after inflicting severe casualties on the enemy," while Allied fighter planes, striking clear across Southern Tunisia, blasted and set afire an Axis troop and supply-truck convoy near the Libyan frontier, a communique said today.

Although the nation-wide Victory Fund Drive ended on Dec. 23, sales of war bonds and of tax-savings notes of the government continue to be made in substantial volume. Current estimates are that when the December sales totals are in hand war bond sales for the month will be the third largest on record, exceeded only by January and July of this year.

For the first time in more than three months, the general death rate in New York City did not exceed the "anticipated" weekly rate, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday in his summary of the city's health last week.

Taking the children to the theatre in Holiday Week used to be a tradition in many a family. It was a good tradition. A lifelong love for the theatre -- the real, living theatre was often implanted between Christmas and the New Year when one was 8 or 10. There used to be more shows at holiday time strictly for the youngsters.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The New York Yankees lost their star pitcher today to a bigger Yankee crew -- the Army.

Several housewares jobbers have adopted the practice of accepting orders on scarce goods only when accompanied by substantial commitments for items which remain plentiful. Often the items being pushed in this way are new lines, such as paper goods, which have been taken on by jobbers to help them maintain volume.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Ursula Parrott, a novelist of 40, was arrested here tonight on a Federal warrant charging her with aiding a soldier to desert the army.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Circuit Court today appointed a receiver to take charge of all future proceeds of the farce hit "Good Night Ladies," at the request of D.D. Feldman, an oil producer of Houston, Texas, who alleged that he had been defrauded of an interest in the show.

Harley D. Hutchins, investment broker, left an estate of $7,911,340 net, it was shown in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday. Mr. Hutchins, who died in Los Angeles, Calif., on June 19, 1941, but was a resident of New York City, left a bequest of $100,000 to the Association for the Relief of Respectable Aged and Indigent Females, 891 Amsterdam Avenue.

The stock brokerage firm of J.R. Williston Co. has rented large space in 1 East Fifty-seventh Street through Douglas Gibbons Co. for an uptown branch. The Gibbons firm also rented space in the same building to Edward McGuire for executive offices.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 29 -- Anti-aircraft fire on Guadalcanal has shot down more planes than similar guns anywhere else in the world save, perhaps, Malta.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has set for oral argument here on Jan. 18 before the full commission the proceedings covering commutation fares in New York State.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Attorney General Bennett said today that the Appellate Division, Third Department, had upheld the constitutionality of Section 40-B of the Civil Rights Law which was enacted for the purpose of compelling the admission to places of public amusement of all those who held tickets of admission without discrimination.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Governor Leverett Saltonstall said late today that it "would seem better judgment" for Donald Blythe, whose extradition Governor Charles Poletti of New York had refused, to return to Massachusetts, where Blythe escaped from a prison farm nine years ago.

The first Waacs assigned to the recruiting and induction center in Grand Central Palace to receive promotions from third to second officer were congratulated yesterday at the Palace by Colonel Vergne Chappelle, commanding ofricer of the center.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Morocco radio said tonight that a second contingent of American troops had just landed at Dakar and had occupied the airdrome.

A group of students interested in civic administration had a first-hand glimpse yesterday of government in action. Sixteen students of five major women's colleges toured some of New York City institutions under the guidance of the New York City League of Women Voters.

An investor represented by Jerome L. Greene, lawyer, has purchased from the Bowery Savings Bank the fifteen-story apartment house at 343-49 East Fifty-seventh Street subject to a ten-year purchase-money mortgage of $365,000.
From Edmonton the Army planes fly north to secret destinations.

Stockholders of the Hecker Products Corporation at a special meeting here yesterday approved the change in the company's name to Best Foods, Inc., and authorized a write-off of about $2,300,000 to capital surplus, which now stands at $16,652,344.

If we needed Pearl Harbor to cement us on the war front, we only needed Elmer Davis and Claude Wickard's talks to unify us on the economic and food fronts. Now we can advance to victory in a unified tempo with the armed forces of the allies.

Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn, at a meeting of the executive board of the Joint Conference of Affiliated Postal Employes yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, offered to sponsor a bill at the next session of Congress that would assure a $300 annual increase for some 300,000 postal employes throughout the country, if enacted.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 30 -- Russian troops have captured Kotelnikov, ninety miles southwest of Stalingrad, in their onrushing effort to reach Rostov on the Sea of Azov and trap a million-man German Army stalled in the Caucasus and before Stalingrad.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Allied invasion of North Africa and Russia's great second Winter offensive have blasted Germany's hopes of enjoying a "creative pause" during the cold months, the British War Office asserted today in its third annual review of the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, in a message to President Roosevelt, expressed hope today that the bonds of comradeship forged in this war will be a "lasting support in the labors of peace."

Kings County Judge John J. Fitzgerald, who is retiring tomorrow, was the guest of honor at a farewell luncheon yesterday afternoon in the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. More than 200 persons attended the luncheon, which was under the auspices of the court attaches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- An intensified campaign to increase the volume of waste kitchen fats which is being collected from householders under the direction of the conservation division of the War Production Board is expected in the near future.

Americans have been eating good food and plenty of it, according to the Bureau of Home Economics. For reasons that are plain, their diets have been better this year and last than they were from 1936 through 1940. For one thing, family incomes have recently expanded.
The one-family house at 40-19 Robinson Avenue, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by John Geddes to Lillian Lucchetti through the Master Realty Company, broker.

Increased capacity for the production of primary nickel, together with the salvage of nickel-bearing scrap and increased conservation, should provide adequate supplies of nickel for vital war needs, according to Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., in a review of the industry for 1942.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Advance elements of the British Eighth Army were still skirmishing with the Axis rear guard yesterday in the Wadi Bei el Cheibir area, fifteen miles east of Buerat el Hsun, on the southwestern shore of the Gulf of Sirte, a British communique said today.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that he had ordered the members of the Police Department to make an effort for stricter enforcement of the speed limit and had assigned more motorcycle patrolmen to the night shift in an effort to cut down the number of accidents owing to the dimout. He asked all pedestrians to wear or carry something white to make them more visible in the darkness.

Despite a heavy movement of oil overland, there is no assurance that total receipts in the East Coast area will be sufficient to meet the demand in the immediate future under current rationing restrictions, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey declared yesterday in a year-end review of the petroleum industry.

Angna Enters, mime, artist and author, whose dance season at the Alvin Theatre continues through tomorrow evening, has been engaged by the Metropolitan Museum to give a performance of her mime called "Pagan Greece," on the evening of Jan. 25.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes declared today that the Interior Department's efforts to obtain complete utilization of certain domestic minerals had been delayed by "the inertia of the old way," industrial traditions and established practices.

In sentencing three Negro youths who pleaded guilty to manslaughter in a "mugging case," Judge Lester W. Patterson in Bronx County Court yesterday said that something "must be done a little more forcefully" to stop the outbreak of juvenile crimes, such as fighting with teachers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Walla Walla, Wash., with a gain of 74 per cent, led all cities in department store sales for November compared with November a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Vallejo and Napa, Calif., were next with a gain of 70 per cent.

Angna Enters, now just halfway through her series of holiday recitals at the Alvin Theatre, had scheduled all five of the season's new additions to her repertoire of "compositions" for her program last night, but only three of them actually came to light.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A great increase in the number of women undergoing training for war industry was reported today by Layton S. Hawkins, director of the vocational training for war production workers program in the Office of Education.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- Because of numerous unresolved issues in connection with the liquidation of the North American Light and Power Company, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an interim order prohibiting payment by the company to its parent, the North American Company, of about $154,000 of interest on debentures due Jan. 1.

MAX HILL, former chief of The Associated Press Bureau in Tokyo, was number happyaku-rokuju-nana-ban, or 867, for the six months he occupied a solitary confinement cell in the Sugamo prison in Tokyo. The temperature ranged between 20 and 30 degrees above zero, the food was poor and scanty and sometimes maggoty -- filth was everywhere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Increasingly widespread use of substitute rubber has resulted in the production of a variety of new articles, which the Office of Price Administration today brought under its regulations. The war agency announced a specific list of articles, including those made of rubber substitutes, has been added, through an amendment, to Maximum Price Regulation No. 220, effective Jan. 4.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Japan's isolated forces on Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons were reported authoritatively today to be suffering severely from starvation and disease, without fresh supplies for about six weeks.

The Open House for Officers of the Armed Forces of the United States and Allied Nations will more than live up to its name on New Year's Day. In the afternoon from 4 to 7 o'clock an eggnog party will be given in the organization's clubrooms at the Hotel Delmonico. At 8:30 P.M. the party will enlarge and move to the hotel ballroom, where a large dance will be held.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 29 -- The results of four National Labor Relations Board elections conducted yesterday and today a the six Passaic and Bergen County plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation were announced here tonight. Five of the plants are in and around Paterson and the sixth at Wood-Ridge in Bergen County.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 29 -- Sixty students are being enrolled at the engineering personnel office of the Vought-Sikorsky Division of the United Aircraft Corporation at Stratford for the advanced training of women as aircraft engineers.

The undefeated records of two more metropolitan teams will be at stake tonight at Madison Square Garden, where an intersectional basketball, double-header will pit St. Francis of Brooklyn against Wyoming and New York University against Washington State, in that order.

Rationing of goods, scheduled to become effective in February, will have no appreciable effect on advertising campaigns as far as volume is concerned but will result in changed copy appeals, according to agency executives. Plans already made for 1943, which in some instances call for reductions in budgets, will continue unchanged, although most of them are very flexible and on a short-term basis.

A consent decree directing American Bosch Corporation of Springfield, Mass., to cancel all agreements with Robert Bosch G.m.b.H., a German concern that in 1930 acquired stock control of the American organization, was filed in Federal court yesterday by Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

After advancing to new high levels for the current movement through trade and New Orleans buying in the near months, the cotton futures market slumped yesterday in late trading under pressure of profit-taking in the new-crop positions by commission houses.

The Federal court jury of eight men and four women which has been hearing testimony since Dec. 14 at the trial of Leonard Robert O. Jordan and three other Negroes charged with sedition will begin deliberating upon a verdict this morning.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 29 -- Under the pressure of recent reverses on the eastern front, the Germans have begun to pay lip service to the more inoffensive aspects of Baltic nationalism. In reality they continue their "discreet but systematic" efforts to penetrate and colonize these States, particularly Lithuania, according to a reliable report on hand today.
AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Dec. 27 (Delayed) -- Two new methods of attack were brought into use in the savage Battle of Buna today.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 26 Ernest M. Dann pleads for increased prices for agricultural products as the only means whereby a threatened food shortage can be averted. He supports his conclusion by arguments which, I believe, are fallacious.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- The relentless Russian advance southward from Stalingrad and between the Don and the northern Donets River continues. There is no sign of a successful German rally, though desperate attempts are being made to disengage the main Nazi forces and make a stand.
The fate of the nine championship meets conducted by the National Collegiate A.A. will be weighed at a business meeting of the association convening at 9:30 this morning at the Hotel Astor.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- A liver-destroying disease caused by bodily contact with chemicals used in the fireproofing and waterproofing of cable lines has resulted in three industrial deaths among employes at the plants of the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company here and the Habirshaw Cable and Wire Corporation in Yonkers, according to information obtained tonight from Dr. William A. Holla, Commissioner of Health of Westchester County.

A UNITED STATES ARMY AIR BASE IN CHINA, Dec. 27 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American fliers today raided the important airdrome at Lashio, Burma, for the fourth time in eight days, blasted enemy targets at Mongmao, Western Yunnan Province, blew up a Japanese supply train north of Mandalay and strafed trucks along the Burma Road.

Mayor La Guardia called upon representatives of the foreign-language press yesterday to help formulate public opinion at the close of the war after predicting that it will take "75 to 100 years" to recover from its effects in Europe.

The need for maintaining the "American way of life" for men returning from the fighting fronts was stressed yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in an appeal for the support of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies. Mrs. Roosevelt appeared on a federation sponsored program entitled, "Miss Jones of Twenty-second Street," heard over radio station WMCA from 5:45 to 6 P.M.

Further indications of the general decline in the use of books from the circulation departments of the New York Public Library system are recorded in the library's December bulletin, released yesterday. A statistical table for November, covering the central circulation and other departments of the central building on Fifth Avenue and of all branches, showed that the total number of books borrowed for home use in the month was 790,547.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Roosevelt made it clear today that he thought it was the responsibility of Congress to decide what further reductions in non-war expenditures could be made.
