He indicated that he did not think appropriation for the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice should be slashed sharply.

I read every word of the fine addresses of Elmer Davis and Secretary Wickard in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning, and felt thrilled at the thought that the American people would cooperate wholeheartedly in the purchasing of canned goods, until such time as the government was prepared to get out the new ration books.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Roosevelt told his press conference today that he fully expected soon to see General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, who has long planned a visit here from London. Mr. Roosevelt said, however, that no date for the visit had yet been set.

The railroads of the United States successfully handled in 1942 the greatest volume of freight traffic which any form of transportation ever has been called upon to move in any corresponding period, J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, said yesterday in a year-end review.

The exhibition and sale of work by outstanding artists which was organized by the Citizens Committee for the Arts is being held at the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. It will close at 10 P.M. on Jan. 4. Watercolors, prints and pieces of sculpture are priced at $5 each, in order to raise funds for carrying on the work of the committee.

The long-awaited price-ceiling order by which the Office of Price Administration has promised to provide relief for liquor retailers here will probably be issued in a temporary form within the next ten days, it was reliably reported in the trade yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Seven leading railroad executives pledged to President Roosevelt today that the railroads would increase petroleum shipments to the Atlantic seaboard States in January, unless prevented by unusually severe weather.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Business on the stock markets today was on the small side, but it remained steady. There was little movement in the gilt-edge section. But Mexican issues went ahead among the foreign bonds. Home and foreign railway securities were lifeless, but one or two leading industrials showed gains of a few pence where they were changed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A brief strike took place in the cafeteria of the Labor Department at noon today because of a misunderstanding regarding withholding of a wage increase which had been due to go into effect on Nov. 1.
Relief that WPB inventory limitation order L-219, which had been overhanging retailing for many months, has finally made its appearance was the major reaction in trade circles here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Price advances of 25 to 87 cents a barrel for bakery flour and 40 to 75 cents a barrel for "family flour" sold to consumers were authorized today by the Office of Price Administration. The increases average about 10 per cent.

Increased sales of canned and frozen fruits, vegetables, juices and soups were reported yesterday by grocery stores in the metropolitan area, but the government's plan for rationing these products beginning in February apparently did not precipitate anything like the rush that had been feared by some retailers.
City College players, champions of the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League, were on the threshold of still another triumph yesterday after blanking Cornell, 4 -- 0, in the semi-final round.

LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- It is emphasized here that the Sunday's clash with the Japanese at Rathudaung probably represented no more than "a large-scale raid" by General Sir Archibald P. Wavell's troops and that the main British offensive to recapture Burma and reopen the Burma Road into China obviously had not yet begun.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The War Labor Board took another step in its decentralization program today by delegating to the Secretary of Agriculture authority to approve wage and salary adjustments for about 240,000 employes of the Department of Agriculture and its agencies whose salaries are not fixed by statute.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals halted today the "piecemeal" liquidation of the onetime $38,000,000 Transit Investment Corporation, the former Mitten Bank Securities Corporation, by Federal receivers and turned the company back to its stockholders.
The honor of having her son listed as a Navy hero proved more puzzling than exciting yesterday for Mrs. Laura Maresca of 2845 West Fifteenth Street, Coney Island.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Dec. 29 -- News of importance to Eastern ski circles broke today at this serene Green Mountain community with the disclosure that a corps of Sun Valley instructors would operate at both Snow Valley and Big Bromley this season.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The Burlington Mills Corporation had the largest and best production record in its history, resulting in a new high of $83,096,802 in gross volume, compared with sales of $63,165,310 in the previous year, J. Spencer Love, president, reported yesterday in the eighteenth annual report to stockholders.

Those who want to watch the New Year arrive in Times Square tomorrow evening may do so, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday. An adequate force of police will be on hand, he added, to "take care of the situation there."

Despite the holidays, a fair amount of apartment leasing activity was reported by brokers in Manhattan yesterday. Rentals in many buildings on the East and West Sides were on the list. Riverside Drive drew several new tenants, as did the Fifth and Park Avenue sections. The leases follow:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Commander Arnold Ellsworth True, 41, of Corinth, Ky., received today both the Navy Cross and the Distinguished Service Medal for heroism displayed as skipper of the destroyer Hammann in aiding rescues and damage control work when the aircraft carriers Lexington and Yorktown were lost in the Pacific.

The Autonomous Institute for Amortization of the public debt of the Republic of Chile announced yesterday through representatives here that its receipts in 1942 available for debt service amounted to $10,136,144. The receipts represented almost entirely taxes on the profits of copper companies and the government's participation in the profits of the Chilean Nitrate and Iodide Sales Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Proposals for a statutory directive that unmarried Selective Service registrants be "pooled" by States and that all without dependents be inducted before married men were revived at the Capitol today in the wake of continued complaints that inequities in drafting were prevalent in various parts of the country.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today that the Allied ground forces in New Guinea yesterday reduced a Japanese strong point based on a triangle, containing thirteen stoutly built and bitterly defended bunkers, then repulsed a Japanese counter-attack at dusk to consolidate their positions on the left of the Buna line.
MADISON, Wis., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Walter S. Goodland, whom Republican leaders did not want as Lieutenant Governor, fell heir today to the duties of Governor.

Admitting they had set fire yesterday to an air raid warden headquarters at 816 East 149th Street, the Bronx, a 16-year-old youth was held for arson and his 14-year-old companion was held as a juvenile delinquent. Both boys worked as messengers for the wardens in their spare time.

ONE bit of equipment that major league ball players can dispense with for Spring training next year is their golf clubs. Back in the good old days no diamond athlete who had the slightest bit of self-respect would deign to appear without a complete set of divot-digging implements. He would as soon show up without a garish sports jacket and two-toned shoes.
CHUNGKING, Dec. 30 (Reuter) -- A communique of General Joseph L. Stilwell's Headquarters:

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 29 -- Military rule in countries occupied by United States forces will end as soon as hostilities are ended and control will be returned to civilian authorities, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, declared here today.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Dec. 29 -- One hundred and thirteen United States Army enlisted men became second lieutenants today, the first graduates of the officers candidate course in the Southwest Pacific area since the war began.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Dec. 19 totaled 742,911 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday. This was 2,575 cars, or 0.3 per cent greater than for the preceding week: 55,957 cars, or 7 per cent less than for the corresponding week last year, and 45,156 cars, or 6.5 per cent greater than during the corresponding week two years ago.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 29 -- Fighter planes based in the Tunisian war area succeeded yesterday for the first time in hitting General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's forces in Tripolitania. Speedy Lightnings flew 250 miles beyond the most advanced lines in Tunisia to destroy twenty-one enemy trucks between Ey Zania, about thirty miles west of Tripoli, and Medenine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Secretary Knox said today that money collected by citizens of Houston, Texas, to cover the cost of a new cruiser to bear the name of their city was far in excess of the cost of such a vessel and that he would seek to apply the extra funds on a new aircraft carrier.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- An elaborately illustrated 120-page midwinter bargain flyer of Montgomery Ward Co. was in the mail today, featuring a judicious mixture of cut prices and new goods. A year ago, trade circles recalled, the big mail-order house dropped the annual sale event because of the general merchandising outlook.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- That horse racing, with its attendant pari-mutuel wagering, has become increasingly popular is evidenced by the fact that the State derived nearly $10,500,000 in revenue from the sport this season.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A special Russian communique:

Coincident with the debut of paper blankets in a Fifth Avenue department store, believed to be the first such offering in the metropolitan area, established wool blanket mills indicated that for 1943 they "would be lucky" if they were able to offer as little as 10 to 12 per cent of the quantities of wool types bought by individual producers before Pearl Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The proposal made last night by Vice President Wallace of a world council after the war to direct a planned global economy was viewed in some Congressional quarters today as possibly "a trial balloon'' for President Roosevelt's address to Congress on Jan. 7.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Heavier receipts of hogs at principal markets today brought about lower quotations. Most sales here were down about 25 cents a hundredweight, with late sales off as much as 35 cents. Cattle quotations also turned 25 cents lower but fat lambs gained around 25 cents. Receipts of hogs at the principal Western centers aggregated 134,000 head compared with 89,099 a week ago and 128,349 a year ago.
We all listened to the broadcast of the new food regulations, the reasons for same, and the appeals to our patriotism to accept the new scheme of things gracefully and not to hoard.

NEAR MEDJEZ-EL-BAB, Tunisia, Dec. 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Seven miles behind the German lines, out of food, almost without ammunition and cut off from all means of communication, the Allied forces were being attacked continually and one of Britain's crack fighting units was given up for lost.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Indicating that the War Manpower Commission would eventually seek to impose "sanctions" to facilitate the transfer of skilled workers from their jobs to other posts in war industries where their services would be more essential, Paul V. McNutt, chairman, outlined today the manpower needs that still face the country.

"The faculty of Columbia University will not permit the traditional ideals of liberal education, for which Old Kings College was founded to be lowered despite the war influence," President Nicholas Murray Butler told members of Columbia University Alumni Federation at their thirty-fourth annual lunchceon held yesterday in the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The armed services and the War Production Board have never engaged in any real fight over control of the civilian economy, in the opinion of Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman.

A survey conducted by the war committee of the Women's City Club, headed by Mrs. Winslow Carlton, has disclosed that after twelve months of war less than half the nonprofessional women of comfortable income living in Manhattan are giving time to voluntary war service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Roosevelt today predicted action to relax some of the heavy restrictions laid on the Territory of Hawaii when martial law was invoked soon after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

FONTANA, Calif., Dec. 30 -- With the assertion that, given the materials, three West Coast shipyards could produce 1,000 Liberty ships during 1943, Henry J. Kaiser opened today the first integrated iron and steel plant west of the Rockies to help meet the steel shortage.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Ursula Parrott blamed an "impulse" today for leading her into trouble over the flight from an Army stockade of a young private with whom she has been friendly.
MOSCOW, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

When people speak of this little globe of ours in which the airplane has turned us all into next-door neighbors a person is reminded of one of the great forgotten speeches of history. It was delivered at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia in 1787 by a delegate from a New England State now also forgotten. What he said in substance was this:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Japanese efforts to establish a strong base at Munda, in the New Georgia group of the Solomon Islands, has cost them two more cargo vessels, which sank as victims of our bombers yesterday, the Navy Department reported today.

The Metropolitan Opera Association gave a performance yesterday afternoon of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff" of which it had a right to be proud. The opera had its first presentation of the season, for the benefit of the Near East College Association.

Seventy-six war and business conventions, expected to draw attendance of 18,000 persons, will be held in this city during January, it was announced yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

Official recognition of British book publishing as an essential industry was reported yesterday by Curtice Hitchcock, president of Reynal Hitchcock, New York publishing house, who has just returned from an eight-week study of publishing in England.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 30 -- Arrests are being made throughout France, with more than 100 at Toulon after a raid extending to a number of private homes where the occupants had to prove their identity. This is a new departure.

Three more industrial corporations have been acquired by the Joshua Hendy Iron Works of Sunnyvale, Calif., which on Dec. 10 purchased all the assets of the Crocker-Wheeler Electric Manufacturing Company of Ampere, N.J., it was announced yesterday by Charles E. Moore, president of the Western heavy machinery concern.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Prices of farm products advanced sharply at the year-end to reach the highest level since October, 1920.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- It is "impossible" for the United States Senate Restaurant to meet the demands of its steak-minded patrons, D.W. Darling, manager, said today. In the last month three or four steakless days were endured.

Acting on the proclamation of President Roosevelt setting aside New Year's Day as a "National Day of Prayer" for our armed forces and our war effort, worshipers in New York City's churches of all faiths will kneel tonight and tomorrow in supplication for peace before New Year's Day, 1944, following victory for the United Nations.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 30 (AP) -- An ice storm of great severity crippled industry in many parts of Connecticut today, snapped power and communication lines, cluttered highways with fallen trees and poles and left one city without power or light for many hours.

Gratified by the increasing interest shown by women in government, the League of Women Voters will push its program even further in the direction of an understanding of government during the coming year, Miss Anna Lord Strauss, city president, revealed yesterday.

One store may have pork to sell but no beef; another may have beef but no pork. There isn't any way of knowing in advance what meat you may buy for dinner -- just go to the butcher and hope for the best. All meat is scarce. Listed below are average prices for the less expensive cuts as quoted by the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets.
TRENTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- State Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee blamed the war indirectly today for a sharp increase in the percentage of pedestrians killed in automobile accidents.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- For a second year in a row bad weather marred the annual college Winter sports meet of the Lake Placid Club today. A steady drizzle fell throughout the day and washed out the opening ski events.

Footprints and automobile tire marks in mud were the main clues by which Staten Island detectives hoped yesterday to trap the slayer of Miss Marie Rycoitch, 19-year-old defense worker, whose bludgeoned body was found in marshy ground near Bloomfield, S.I., on Monday, a few hours after she had left for work from her home at 16 Catherine Place, Mariners Harbor.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Dec. 28 (Delayed) -- "There are the woods; go and see what is in them." This is the kind of order that a little group of soldiers specially trained in jungle reconnaisance receives almost daily from the colonel commanding an advance force of American troops on the Buna front.

As a life-long student and teacher of the history of Western civilization in its ethical, religious and philosophical aspects, I give high praise to the author of your "Topics of The Times" for his splendid survey on Dec. 24 entitled "Not So Dark Continent." Never before have I seen so good a swift summary.

Floods in many parts of the East made thousands homeless yesterday, forcing some war plants to shut down in a few industrial regions, particularly at Pittsburgh, where the waters reached the highest stage recorded since the disastrous flood of 1936.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Backing up the request of the Office of Defense Transportation that government officials decline to travel to Chicago or Grand Rapids to participate in furniture marts scheduled there next week, government speakers acted to "boycott" the gatherings today.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- A preliminary view of the way in which German bank clerks and industrialists, following up the Reich's armies, have riveted upon Europe a control that may be even harder to break than that of the Nazi divisions and the Gestapo was given in London today.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert refused yesterday to forbid payment of $120,000 to 1,202 stockholders of the Utica, Chenango Susquehanna Valley Railway Company by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company, which leases the former's lines.

Connecticut, under its laws, can never find its State Supreme Court deadlocked, like the United States Supreme Court, and unable to function because of the disqualification of three of its members and the tie vote of the remainder.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- President Roosevelt is ranked by a majority of college and high school teachers of speech as "the best public speaker in the business," says one of the group.

Many stores in the city reported yesterday that they had no butter at all and others, faced with dwindling supplies, made further cuts in the quantity allocated to customers. A few stores were reported limiting sales to an eighth of a pound, or two ounces, to a purchaser.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly review of credit and business conditions yesterday estimated that in the nation-wide December Victory Loan drive $12,300,000,000 was raised. Of this amount the New York Federal Reserve District accounted for $5,865,000,000, with 60,000 subscribers, corporate and individual.
After an ownership of only a few days, Loomis J. Grossman has resold the eight-story and basement warehouse building at 466-70 Washington Street to an investing client of Sternbuch Sternbuch.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Orders limiting the use of newsprint by newspapers and magazines are expected to be issued tomorrow.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Private First Class John R. Fisher is an army all by himself. If you don't believe it, ask the French.

Among the apartment rentals reported yesterday was one signed by Albert Turner, clothing manufacturer, for the eleven-room furnished apartment of Dr. Harold Lamport in 1100 Park Avenue. Warren Marks Associates were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Fighting French representatives here suggested today that their leader, General Charles de Gaulle, might confer with General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner of North Africa, in quest of French unity, before General de Gaulle's expected visit to Washington.

Describing Police Commissioner Valentine's plea for stricter observance and his order for stricter enforcement of traffic laws as "simple and probably efficacious" measures for the protection of lives during the dimout, George S. Van Schaick, director of the Office of Civilian Defense's Second Region, which includes New York City, late yesterday suggested night markers for automobiles.

Gifts for the homeless children, including $20 from "A Navy Man" left at the Times Tower in Times Square, and for the stricken old people of the Neediest Cases featured the designated contributions to the Fund yesterday. But many of the gifts from the 259 contributors were "for the case that has received the least" or "to be used where it is most needed."

A three-point program aimed at immediate modification of Maximum Price Regulation No. 287 has been put before the OPA in Washington by the three manufacturers' associations constituting the New York Dress Institute, it was made known here yesterday.

The New York Telephone Company sold to the Downtown Investing Company, Elias A. Cohen, president, the five-story building at 112-16 West Eighty-ninth Street, formerly occupied by its Schuyler exchange, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., and the buyers immediately resold the property to the Uptown Talmud Torah.

The Securities and Exchange Commission scored two victories yesterday in the application of its "death sentence" program for the nation's public utility holding companies. The giant Niagara Hudson Power Corporation disclosed plans for corporate simplification and ultimate dissolution in conformance with Section 11 (b) (2) of the Holding Company Act, and directors of the Federal Water and Gas Corporation voted to meet the integration requirements of Section 11 (b) (1) of the act.
E. Howard H. Roth has been admitted to partnership in Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and will make his headquarters in the Buffalo office.

The building at 811 East 169th Street, containing six apartments and three stores, and the eight-family house at 1293 Union Avenue, both in the Bronx, have been sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to the Beverly Estates through Hilda S. Dunn, broker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Condemning Matthew Smith, national secretary of the Mechanics Educational Society of America, an independent labor organization, for "highly irresponsible and reprehensible actions" in calling strikes in war industry plants, the War Labor Board unanimously declined today to reinstate seven members of the society at the Briggs Manufacturing Company's Connors Avenue plant in Detroit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Liberalization of automobile rationing regulations to permit persons engaged in any gainful occupation or in work contributing to the war effort or public welfare to buy certain new automobiles for which there has been a limited demand under the rationing program, was ordered today by the OPA.

Out of the cellar at last, if only on the basis of goals scored, the Rangers will try to extend their winning streak when they tackle the Red Wings in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance for New York State, announced yesterday that the department's liquidation bureau had paid more than $45,000,000 to creditors of mortgage guarantee companies in the last four years out of the general assets of companies in liquidation, and bad sold almost $25,000,000 of mortgages and real estate in carrying out this task.

Three young Bronx girls who disappeared from their homes last Oct. 25 with $7,500 in cash belonging to the father of one of them were being detained in Providence, R.I., where they had been living in luxurious comfort, the Bronx police announced yesterday.

More than 1,300 employers in New York and New Jersey have asked the permission of the regional office of the War Labor Board here to increase the wages of their employes since establishment of the office two months ago under the President's wage stabilization order, officials disclosed yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 31 -- Allied planes bombed three more Japanese ships in Rabaul harbor, New Britain Island, as New Guinea ground troops in the Buna Mission area drove their wedge through enemy territory to the sea, splitting the thinning Japanese defenses.

Both the Federal and the city war program will be impeded unless the women of New York respond to the call for volunteers, Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, vice chairman of the Greater New York CDVO, warned yesterday.

Emphasizing that in little more than a year the road's passenger load has more than doubled and the freight load increased by one-half, F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central System, in a New Year's message to the carrier's 140,000 employes says that "the heaviest task we ever had is ahead."
The Ankara radio reported yesterday that the Soviet Black Sea Fleet and its air forces had shelled and bombed "several ports on the Black Sea held by the Germans" and started great explosions.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith faced his sixty-ninth birthday anniversary yesterday with an optimistic outlook toward the war's end next year and the retention of the two-party political system in this country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- As part payment for that future supply of crude rubber expected from the southern republics, the United States is permitting small shipments of rubber tires and tubes to go to four or five countries on the East Coast of South America.

Plans for an international court to try Axis war criminals are taking shape, according to a London dispatch. A well-known American criminologist, Professor Sheldon Glueck of Harvard, is mentioned as one of those who have worked on the project, as is Marcel Dedaer, Chief Justice of Belgian courts in Britain and chairman of the War Crimes Commission of the London International Assembly.

Real evidence of the anticipated year-end rally developed yesterday in the stock market as reinvestment demand in key issues pushed prices up on an average of 2 points. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange crossed the million-share mark for the third consecutive session and for the eighth time this year, transfers totaling 1,121,924 shares, against 1,440,670 on Tuesday.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 30 -- With a temporary stern put on in the Solomons to replace the one that was completely blown away near Tulagi Oct. 16, the U.S.S. McFarland, a 1,200-ton destroyer of 1920 vintage, which had been converted into a seaplane tender, came proudly back to Pearl Harbor under her own steam, it was revealed here today by her commander, Lieut. Comdr. John Clement Alderman, 36, of Portland, Ore.

Supreme Court Justice E. Ivan Rubenstein, who was elected to a full fourteen-year term in the Second Judicial District in November, was sworn in yesterday by Justice Algeron I. Nova in the latter's chambers of Brooklyn Supreme Court.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Allied artillery has shelled enemy strongholds in the Heidous hills northeast of Medjez-el-Bab, announcements from North Africa said tonight as the struggles in Libya and Tunisia continued to merge slowly into a single battle for Africa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- There will be serious trouble in French North Africa unless this country ships substantial quantities of goods and clothing there before Feb. 1, Milton S. Eisenhower, Associate Director of the Office of War Information, said today in reporting at a press conference on a trip to the African zone.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Establishment of new ceiling prices for flour by the Office of Price Administration late yesterday resulted today in an erratic wheat market on the Board of Trade. Neither mills nor grain brokers reported themselves able to decide what price they could pay for cash wheat to keep within the flour ceiling.

The first woman charged with bookmaking to appear in the new Bowery Court appeared yesterday with a man co-defendant on the strength of evidence obtained by wiretapping, according to the arresting officer. The case was adjourned until Monday to permit presentation of a Supreme Court order sanctioning the wiretapping.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 30 -- The German Africa Corps, weak in both equipment and morale, has abandoned its first defensive line of Wadi Bei el Cheibir, or the Great Wadi [dry water course], some twenty miles east of Buerat el Hsun in Tripolitania.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters:

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in a personal appeal for the 1943 Victory Book Campaign, enrolled herself yesterday in a growing list of public figures pledged to aid the drive, scheduled to begin Jan. 5 and to continue for two months. Although no specific goal has been set, the sponsors of the campaign hope to provide 10,000,000 or more volumes for the members of the armed services.

The Metropolitan Museum has opened two exhibitions which are to continue until Feb. 28. North African textiles have been installed in 'a gallery of the Near Eastern section of the museum. This group, assembled from the museum's own collection of silk weavings and embroideries, dates from the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -- Dorothy Lamour, Betty Hutton, Diana Lynn and Mimi Chandler were named today by Paramount to head the cast of "Four Angels," a musical comedy for which Melvyn Frank and Norman Panama are writing the script.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Nearly 100,000 Czechs probably died before Nazi firing squads or were tortured to death in concentration camps during 1942, the Czechoslovak Government in exile charged today.

Because of a jurisdictional fight between two unions, both affiliates of the C.I.O., production of the Fine Art Novelty Corporation of 503 Broadway, making mattress covers for the Army, has been dislocated, it was disclosed yesterday. The concern was said to be willing to deal with the union that obtained the support of a majority of the 140 workers in the plant, but unable to find means by which to determine the issue.
MANCHESTER, Vt., Dec. 30 -- A skiing "natural" would be the best way to describe Snow Valley, new development on East Mountain, five miles east of this peaceful New England town.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 30 -- "Drop up to our place and take a hot bath any time," said Keith Waller, First Secretary of the Australian Legation, the other day.
With 1943 a day nearer, hotels, restaurants and night clubs looked forward to a New Year's Eve as "big" as the limitations of wartime will permit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Senator Byrd, as chairman of the Joint Committee on Reduction of Non-essential Federal Expenditures, expressed hope today that Congress would accept "fully and adequately" the "challenge" he saw in President Roosevelt's press conference invitation yesterday to eliminate all unnecessary governmental spending.

As part of the campaign to recruit 1,000 students for the new classes beginning in February in thirty-two schools of nursing in New York City, Westchester County and Long Island, Mrs. August Belmont gave a tea yesterday at her home, 1115 Fifth Avenue, to members of the New York City Nursing Council for War Service and others active in the campaign.

A hit-or-miss situation in enforcing the new priority regulations for fuel oil rationing, being drawn up in Washington, was disclosed here yesterday by regional officials of the office of the Petroleum Administrator for War and the Office of Price Administration.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- A gift of more than $20,000,000 to Northwestern University by the will of Walter Patton Murphy was announced today by Dr. Franklyn Bliss Snyder, president of the University. The gift, one of the largest in recent years to any institution and the largest educational bequest ever left by a Chicagoan was made known after a special meeting of the university board.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 30 -- Three towns -- Miguel Auza, Rio Grande and Nieres -- in the State of Zacatecas were attacked by bands of armed men on Sunday afternoon, it was learned today. Four men, including the Mayor of Miguel Auza and his son, were shot to death and an unspecified number of persons wounded, according to news from Zacatecas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that a medium-sized British merchant vessel had been torpedoed and sunk by an enemy submarine in mid-November in the Atlantic off the northern coast of South America and that survivors have now been landed at a United States East Coast port.

Dressing tables teetering under their burden of Christmas loot from the cosmetic counters will get the workout of the year along about dusk tonight. It is therefore an auspicious moment to point out that carnival will reign and beauty survive, even though the owners of faces framed in many a mirror wield powder puffs a little less enthusiastically or lean less heavily upon their lipsticks.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Harvard Square, a veteran of the sprint wars flying the Akron-owned silks of Allen T. Simmons, drove to a popular triumph in the Orlando purse before 2,986 spectators who bet $180,147 at Tropical Park today.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The danger signals that have flashed for intercollegiate athletic competition in the drafting of 18 and 19-year-old youths and of many of the leading universities and colleges as Army and Navy training centers changed to a green translucence yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- An important step toward coordinating Anglo-American political warfare with military strategy in French North Africa was taken tonight when Downing Street announced the appointment of a resident Minister to serve in an advisory capacity with the Allied commander in North Africa, Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- United States heavy bombers yesterday scored hits on two Japanese ships at the approaches to Rangoon, Burma, setting one afire. British planes continued their raids on enemy airdromes in Central Burma.

What was probably the classic airplane-submarine battle of all time occurred in the Mediterranean some time between last March and last August, with Flight Lieutenant A. Graham Pockley of the Royal Australian Air Force in command of a flying boat, on one side, and a very large Italian submarine on the other.

VVASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- American housewives and the country's grocers received high praise today from Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, for the orderly manner in which they have responded to the government's appeal to avoid buying and hoarding of canned fruits and vegetables.

Accorded the fourth highest vote ever given a winner of the award, Cornelius Warmerdam of the San Francisco Olympic Club, the world's foremost pole vaulter, yesterday was named as the 1942 recipient of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy.

Declaring that "we ought to create more good-will between teachers and parents," Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday reduced a charge of felonious assault against a Negro mother accused of striking a Brooklyn public school teacher to a charge of disorderly conduct and accepted a plea of guilty.

I should like to draw your attention to one point in your editorial "Concrete Ships" concerning the statement that shipping men will probably object that in these days a capacity of 2,000 tons is too little for ocean ships. Although the size of 2,000 tons, as you go on to say, could easily be increased, there is a definite reason for the choice of so small a vessel to be used in convoy form.

Cooperatives in China are fast becoming a people's movement and are helping to bring economic freedom to that country, according to Dr. J. Henry Carpenter, who arrived here a few days ago after a 43,000-mile trip to India and China on a special mission to the Chinese cooperatives.

Gus Edwards, responsible for launching the careers of quite a few stars during the palmy days of vaudeville, furnishes the motivation for "You'll See Stars," which relights Maxine Elliott's Theatre tonight after a long period of darkness. Recounting in musical comedy form the highlights of Mr. Edwards's life, the story also dwells on the early struggles of such personages as Walter Winchell, George Jesse], Eddie Cantor and the Marx Brothers, to name a few.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A spokesman for Berlin's Foreign Office issued the surprising statement today that Germany hoped that neutral nations would hold steadfastly to their neutrality.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Secretary Perkins certified today to the National War Labor Board a dispute over wages and union security between the New York Stock Exchange and members of the New York Stock Exchange Employes Independent Association.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 30 -- General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner for French Africa, announced today that twelve persons had been arrested for plotting the death of high French officials, including himself, and of Robert D. Murphy, United States Minister in North Africa.

The Inland Steel Company maintained production at well above its rated capacity throughout 1942, despite the loss of hundreds of workers to the armed services and a lack of an adequate supply of suitable scrap, according to its year-end report.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 30 -- Mrs. Alfred J. Mathebat, national president of the American Legion Auxiliary, issued the following statement from the national headquarters today:

Forced to stave off a spectacular Washington State scoring drive in the late stages, New York University's basketball squad remained undefeated by attaining a 66-to-55 decision last night before 13,240 wildly excited fans in Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Pledged to all-out cooperation in curtailing travel during the 1943 baseball season, major league executives will meet soon to work out final details.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Big four-motored United States four-engined bombers with fighter escort this afternoon crossed the English Channel in good weather to bomb the submarine pens at Lorient on the French Bay of Biscay coast. American fighter planes swept over the Boulogne and Abbeville areas, attacking a freight train.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Australian commandos and Netherland guerrillas are constantly harassing the Japanese throughout much of Portuguese Timor, it was officially disclosed today. Ignoring Japanese demands to surrender, it is stated they have been killing the enemy in the ration of a hundred to one.

TRENTON, Dec. 30 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that State Senators George H. Stanger of Vineland and Howard Eastwood of Burlington did not forfeit their seats in the Legislature when the former served as counsel to State Milk Control Director Arthur F. Foran and the latter as counsel to the State Milk Control Board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- In a move to prevent unnecessary shifting of workers, Paul V. McNutt, Chairman of the War Manpower Commission, and Donald M. Nelson, Chairman of the War Production Board, today extended the provisions of the government's labor policy for the automotive industry.
Flood waters swept through many areas of the East and South yesterday, swirling into business sections, halting some war work, clogging transportation and causing many householders to flee.

Because of the acute shortage of fuel oil, after-school activities in twelve of New York's fifty-four oil-burning buildings will be transferred to buildings heated by coal, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday. Transfers are being made wherever comparable facilities in coal-burning schools are available in the neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Millions of wage-earners will find something missing from their pay envelopes beginning Friday: the 5 per cent victory tax which Treasury officials estimate will add $2,000,000,000 to the government's revenues next year.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The Russian war news strengthened the stock markets today. The gilt-edged section showed a firmer tone with old Consols at 85 5/16 and local loans at 97 1/8 each 1/16 better. Home rails also improved. Great Western, London, Midland Scottish and Southern deferred gained 1/4 each and Southern preferred was up 1/2 at 75 1/4.

UNITED STATES SUBMARINE BASE, New London, Conn., Dec. 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- Three naval officers told today how a single American submarine boldly sank a destroyer and eight other ships, some of them so close to Japanese territory that "you could almost spit on the coast."

Dr. Wade has announced a six-point program to be introduced into the schools beginning with the Spring term in February. This is supposed to help curb the rowdyism that has been spreading in the local school system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The first full calendar year of war by the United States since 1847 is drawing to its close, and, though more than $53 billions have been poured out in 1942 for destruction by armament that is itself often destroyed in the process, there have already been many permanent acquisitions through the expenditure.

On the wall of the hiring hall of Bechtel, Price Callahan, American contractors, in Edmonton, civilian workmen brought in from the United States for work in the Far North may read the following sign, printed in bold letters:

JOHNNY MURPHY never had to worry about traveling to Spring training before. The Yankee fireman merely walked across the street, so to speak, and there he was. Murph lives in St. Petersburg, where the champions have been encamping for, do, these many years.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 30 -- The United States is planning and making new bomber and fighter planes of sensational design, and of unprecedented range and striking power, Major Gen. Oliver P. Echols, commanding general of the Army Air Forces Materiel Command, disclosed to newspaper correspondents who visited Wright Field, the A.A.F. materiel center.

Accidents brought death to 47,200 American civilian workers in the country's first year of the present war, or almost six times the approximately 8,000 members of the armed forces killed in action, Dr. Donald B. Armstrong, president of the American Museum of Safety, said yesterday at its headquarters, 60 East Forty-second Street.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Soldiers overseas cast a majority of their votes for Attorney General Bennett, the defeated Democratic candidate for Governor in the recent election, it was disclosed today when the State board of canvassers counted the votes.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 30 -- Two dealers in alcoholic beverages, accused of having sold wine to three boys who later had to be treated at City Hospital for acute alcoholism, will be arraigned here tomorrow before Police Judge Thomas Guthrie on charges of selling liquor to minors.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 31 (AP) -TIe $viet idight cormuniqu:

Four months to the day after the Germans occupied it on their way to Stalingrad, the Russians were back in the railroad town of Kotelnikov. So, for the second time, do the paths of conquest and of glory twist back upon themselves, a full circle of futility -- and worse, for in the four months from Kotelnikov back to Kotelnikov the Wehrmacht has lost far more than the positions gained in the advance.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 31 -- Soviet Armies, pressing relentlessly against the Germans on four major war fronts, pushed deeper into the frozen areas south of Stalingrad yesterday and captured at least a dozen district centers, populated places and stations, the Red Army Command announced early today.

Greater allocation of war contracts to smaller plants is necessary to save America from a changed form of government and a dictatorship, Lou E. Holland, deputy administrator of the War Production Board in charge of the Smaller War Plants Division, declared here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30 -- Surging waters of the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers converged on Pittsburgh today to shut down part and threaten the entire industrial area; drive 5,000 persons from their homes and disrupt transportation and utility service.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 30 (AP) -- A fire roared through the downtown Empire Hotel block early today, claiming one life, and with nine persons reported missing. Officials expressed the belief that there were several bodies in the ruins.

IN 1796, when England was digging in for two decades of warfare against Napoleon, Prime Minister William Pitt advocated a system of compulsory national insurance, family allowances for children, and free technical education. "With reform," so Mr. Pitt declared, "you disarm the Jacobins of their most dangerous weapon."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission today permitted the Associated Electric Company to buy for $1,548,860 plus accrued interest $3,602,000 principal amount of its 4 1/2 per cent bonds, refunding series, due in 1956, from the Metropolitan Edison Company of Pennsylvania.

A total of 6,703 families and 16,016 individuals were aided by the Salvation Army in Greater New York during the year through fifty-eight religious and social agencies, according to a report made public yesterday by Commissioner Ernest I. Pugmire, Eastern territorial commander.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Two Philadelphia colleges were dropped from basketball's undefeated list tonight when Kansas swamped St. Joseph's, 63 to 38, and Southern California overcame Temple, 47 to 35, at Convention Hall.

Transient traffic in the Army Recruiting and Induction Center at Grand Central Palace was startled yesterday morning when an Army captain, having just sworn in a Waac recruit, proceeded to give her a resounding kiss. The officer was Captain Joseph J. La Manna, and the recruit was his daughter, Mrs. Edward Dissell, who had just become the fourth in the family to join the Army.

Recognition of an accomplishment of major value to the war effort is made by the award this year of the Collier Trophy for achievement in aviation jointly to the Army Air Forces and the private American airlines under the American flag, as represented by the Air Transport Association.

City College players retained the Harold M. Phillips trophy, although defeated for the first time this year in the seventh and final round of the annual Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League tournament yesterday.

TRENTON, Dec. 30 -- Its ranks already reduced from approximately 750 officers and men to about 250, due to the draft, enlistments in the armed forces and the lure of high wages in war industries, the Permanent-Duty Battalion of the State Guard will be disbanded on or before Feb. 15, Adjt. Gen. James I. Bowers announced today.

The twelve-story office building at 234-36 West Forty-fourth Street, in the heart of the midtown theatre district, has been sold by Vincent Astor to Theresa Powers of 79-19 Calamus Avenue, in Elmhurst, Queens, according to a deed filed yesterday in the Register's office.
Patrick J. (Paddy) Whelan, one of the old-time Tammany braves of the lower East Side, died yesterday in St Vincent's Hospital after an illness of several months. His age was 70.

The cotton-futures market worked yesterday to new seasonal highs, relinquished most of the gains under realizing, and subsequently rallied moderately, to close with gains for the fifth successive session. On the New York Cotton Exchange buying appeared fairly active again near the close, probably because traders had expected higher parity price, and the list of active contracts finished 2 to 4 points above Tuesday's final quotations.

The violent but ineffective efforts of Leonard Robert O. Jordan and three other West Indies Negroes to create a pro-Japanese element in Harlem led to their conviction in Federal court yesterday of sedition and conspiracy to commit sedition. The verdict was returned after three and a half hours of deliberation by a jury including three Negroes.

National headquarters here of the United Service Organizations estimated yesterday that 1,000,000 men and women in all branches of the armed forces would be guests, while 550,000 American girls and women would serve as hostesses or dancing partners at New Year's Eve parties tonight in 1,500 USO clubhouses and recreation centers scattered over the Western Hemisphere.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The difficulties of the German people in keeping adequately clothed have been accentuated by further cuts in the number of points allowed on the 1943 clothing ration card, as well as a lengthening of the period for which they are valid.

UNITED STATES SUBMARINE BASE, New London, Conn., Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Six officers and men of a submarine, who completed "a highly successful and aggressive war patrol which resulted in the sinking of 29,600 tons of enemy shipping," were decorated today for heroism under fire.

An interesting situation has arisen in Canada because of the presence there of an expectant mother, Crown Princess Juliana of the Netherlands. Juliana and her consort, Prince Bernhard, have two children, 4-year-old Beatrix and 3-year-old Irene. If the baby due to be born to Juliana next month is a girl, Beatrix will remain in direct line of succession.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- While on the middle Don front the Russians now are coping with more determined resistance, south, of Stalingrad they are advancing at a great pace across the Kalmuck steppes, and by capturing Kotelnikov they have wrested from the enemy a point on which the German operations long pivoted.

Further sharp withdrawals were made last week on both light and heavy fuel oil stocks, but gasoline supplies were increased, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the week, gasoline stocks amounted to 80,228,000 barrels, a gain of 1,097,000 over the 79,131,000 a week earlier.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- The University of California at Los Angeles and Georgia held their final hard drills in the Rose Bowl today for their New Year's Day football game as the rival coaches pronounced their teams ready.
Although its report is not yet complete, the New York Conservation Department yesterday gave a substantial account of the recent open deer season in the State.

The banks of New York State have responded unhesitatingly to the government's wartime need for funds and have bought new government securities for their own account far out of proportion to government disbursements in this State, Jackson S. Hutto, New York State Superintendent of Banks, stated in his annual report sent out to banks yesterday.

Harold Rowe, chief of the Food and Food Products Division of the Office of Price Administration, will be the principal speaker at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, on Wednesday evening at 8:40 o'clock. He will explain the government's point rationing system for regulating food purchases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Soldiers in the Army are conservative drinkers and the Army itself is the best behaved in the long history of this country, the Office of War Information reported today after a coast-to-coast survey of drinking in and around Army camps and posts.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Seven enlisted men and four officers were added today to the growing list of United States Army Air Forces personnel decorated for gallantry.

Three new colors will be shown in the Fall of 1943 color card for men's felt hat bodies, according to the Textile Color Card Association, compared with four listed for the Spring season next year and five for the last Fall season. The new shades comprise mocha brown, described as a lively light coffee tone, club gray in the slate range and Autumn blue, a deeper grayed blue.

The designation of George W. Alger as chairman of the Appeals Board of the Motion Picture Arbitration System and the appointment of Robert McCurdy Marsh, former Justice of the Supreme Court of New York, as a board member were announced yesterday by the American Arbitration Association, administrator of the system.

The Japanese defeated the Chinese last night, but it wasn't on the battlefield. It was on the basketball court of the neighborhood house of the Church of All Nations, 9 Second Avenue. The score was 24 to 20.

Sir Nevile Henderson was one of those trained and accomplished British diplomatists familiar with many courts and countries, representatives of a long tradition and possessed of all its advantages and disadvantages. His two years in Berlin were the important part of his career.

The tests that must be undergone by furniture with non-metallic springs, manufactured since the War Production Board's ban on the use of metal for this purpose, were described yesterday in a release sent out by the Office of War Information for the Office of Price Administration.

There will be only one delivery of mail tomorrow, New Year's Day, and that will be the 8 A.M. postman's trip, according to an announcement yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman. The regular holiday collection schedules will be maintained and there will be one delivery of parcel post.

All banks and financial markets in the United States and its possessions will be closed tomorrow, except those in the State of Kentucky and in the Territory of Hawaii. Canadian banks and grain and securities markets will observe the New Year's holiday.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Steps which have been taken to end racial discrimination in the hiring of workers for war industries were told today by the State's War Council committee on discrimination in employment.

Beginning tomorrow employes will find that their employers have deducted (in addition to the 1 per cent Social Security Tax) 5 per cent of all their earnings above $12 a week. This deduction will be known as the Victory Tax.
PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 1 (Delayed) -- A big black weatherbeaten submarine with eleven little Japanese flags sewed to her "So Solly pennant" slid up to a dock while a band played the "Beer Barrel Polka."

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Reduced automobile driving has saved the lives of nearly 12,000 men, women and children who, on the basis of mortality averages in other years, would have been killed in traffic accidents this year.

Joseph F. FitzGerald, State chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, announced yesterday that the Statewide campaign for funds of 1943 would open tomorrow.

A post-war low-rent public-housing project has recently been approved for eventual construction in South Harlem. While there can be no question as to the grave urgency for decent living quarters in that general area, there are elements in the particular project that arouse serious concern as to the soundness of the New York City Housing Authority's policies.

The A.O. Smith Corporation, peacetime maker of automobile frames and other equipment, reported yesterday for the quarter ended with October net profit of $1,421.817 after taxes and all other deductions.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Joined by a goodly crowd of visitors, or at least persons wearing Tulsa and Tennessee colors, New Orleans residents jammed gay Canal Street tonight to greet the New Year in typical, noisy fashion, but curfew rang early along the Mississippi Gulf Coast for the principals of the Sugar Bowl football classic tomorrow.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Picked up at sea by a British trawler from a yacht that had given out distress signals, Johannes Marinus Dronkers, 47-year-old Netherland traitor, who posed as a refugee from the Nazis but who later confessed that he had tried to obtain information regarding the strength and location of United States and Canadian troops in Britain, was hanged at Wandsworth jail today.
The swollen Ohio River wrought serious damage in West Virginia and Ohio last night as a flood crest which had gathered in Pennsylvania made its way westward to the Mississippi.

A novel entitled "Yuyungo," by Adalherto Ortiz, has won the national fiction contest in Ecuador, the United Press reports from Guayaquil. The novel thus automatically becomes Ecuador's entry in the Latin-American literary contest of this year, again sponsored by Farrar Rinehart and the Pan American Union.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 30 (Delayed) -- The tide that carried fugitives out of Calcutta after Japanese air raids is beginning to swing back, and for three days there has been a steady trickle of hungry Indians returning. It is happening more quickly and on a larger scale than the authorities had expected.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 -- The Richmond shipyards of the Henry J. Kaiser organization are to build a fleet of corvettes for convoy duty.

After I expressed in Nazioni Unite of Nov. 6 what I knew to be the thought of forty-five million Italians at the restoration schemes of Archduke Otto von Habsburg, many distinguished Czech, Polish, Rumanian and Yugoslav public men who represent with us the great majority of the former subjects of the Austro-Hungarian monarchy interpreted even more forcefully the indignation of their compatriots.

Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" received its first presentation of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. A satisfactory interpretation of this masterpiece demands lustre and sparkle, qualities not forthcoming in the performance.

We can get perspective on what 1943 may have in store for us by taking a look at January, 1942. Hitler had just announced that the coming year "should bring the decision which will save our people." He wasn't quite as confident as he had been a year earlier, when he had predicted that 1941 would "bring consummation of the greatest victory in our history."

The experience of the other principal countries now at war, friend and foe alike, shows "that in this war a legal obligation for service at home is no less important than the legal obligation for service in the armed forces," Grenville Clark, lawyer and author of the Selective Service Act, said last night in explaining the provisions of the civilian counterpart which he has just drafted, the National War Service Bill.

The Canada-Alaska highway is only one of several projects of great scope now being pressed through to completion in that region by the United States and Canadian Governments. Certainly the highway is central to the whole expansion in the north, but many of the related projects, though they are common knowledge among the people from Edmonton north, are still concealed under military censorship.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, British Commander in Chief in India, and General Viscount Gort, Commander in Chief at Malta, have been made Field Marshals -- the highest rank in the British Army -- in the first half of the New Year's honor list announced tonight. Additional honors will be announced on Monday.

The German High Command said yesterday that Red Army columns had launched attacks from all sides against Velikiye Luki, key railroad point on the central front ninety miles east of the Latvian frontier, but the assaults broke down before the firm stand of the German garrison, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.
OTTAWA, Dec. 31 (Canadian Press) -- Rationing of print paper to newspapers and periodicals was announced today by the Wartime Prices and Trade Board, effective tomorrow.

The disruption of a midtown "reefer rendezvous," frequented by marihuana-smokers from the Army, was disclosed here yesterday and at the same time it was revealed that Ursula Parrott, the novelist, was expected to be an important witness against the alleged operators of the hotel-room resort.

The State Supreme Court has been asked, it was learned yesterday, to put teeth into an order of the Petroleum Administrator for War by forcing the owners of an eighty-family apartment house in Queens to convert from fuel oil to coal heat.
In the capacity crowds of merrymakers that jammed the city's night clubs, restaurants, hotels and bars last night men in full dress, dinner jackets and business suits were the exception.

It was natural to expect that there would be a slump in the 1942 campaign for gifts for the Hundred Neediest Cases. Taxes for 1941 were steep, taxes for 1942 hit the clouds. Fuel was higher. The cost of living was rising. The war had created many good causes response to which seemed imperative to every one who had the means. The prospect for this particular charity seemed doubtful.
AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Major Ed Scott and his "B-17 Hotshots" have been at it again.

Production of tanks by the Chrysler Corporation broke all records in December, when more were produced than in the entire year 1941 were turned out, and on Dec. 28 all daily records were broken by producing twice as many tanks as on any previous day, according to K.T. Keller, president.

Two streaks of which the New York Rangers were mighty proud were shattered by the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden last night. The first, a three-game winning skein which was the blue-jerseyed stick-wielders' high mark of achievement this season, was snapped when the Wings skated off the ice the victors.

Despite the purchase of $362,010,000 of United States Government securities in the open market for account of the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System, excess reserves of member banks of the system fell sharply during the week ended on Wednesday.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Dec. 31 -- Sixty girls in an exclusively feminine class at the University of Pittsburgh are in training for jobs in the new synthetic rubber works in Beaver Valley. Garbed in trim dark overalls, they spend two evenings each week getting actual experience in plant operation.

Duke Ellington's orchestra has been selected as the favorite swing band of the year in the sixth annual poll conducted by the magazine Down Beat, it was announced yesterday. More than 15,000 musicians and readers voted in the poll. This is the first time the top place has been won by a Negro orchestra.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- With the quiet atmosphere of the drawing room in the Executive Mansion as background, Thomas Edmund Dewey took the oath of office as Governor of the State this afternoon, forty-seventh in the long line of Chief Executives who have sworn to uphold the Constitution of the Nation and of the State and to carry on their duties to the best of their ability.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Army moves into the New Year "confident and sure of its mission," backed by a country that today is "the best equipped for war the world has ever seen," Secretary Stimson said today at a press conference.

Adolf Hitler told his armed forces last night in a year-end order of the day that 1943 might be a difficult year for Germany "but certainly it will be no more difficult than the past year," according to German broadcasts recorded in New York by The United Press.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The War Production Board ordered today that the use of newsprint by every newspaper in 1943 be limited to the tonnage used by each publisher to produce his net paid circulation in 1941 plus a 3 per cent spoilage allowance.

Reporting on operations of the American Distilling Company and its former parent and subsidiary companies, Russell R. Brown, president, informed stockholders yesterday that gross sales for the nine months ended with September rose to $32,245,157 from the $20,984,602 volume for the similar period of 1941.

Speakers yesterday at the annual regional meeting of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics at Teachers College urged instructors to strip mathematics down to fundamentals and concentrate on those elements that will equip boys and girls for military and technical duties.

James F. Byrnes, national director of economic stabilization, has approved an average 9 per cent wage increase for 30,000 laundry workers affiliated with the Amalgated Clothing Workers in New York, Westchester and Long Island, it was announced yesterday.

A war curriculum to insure at least two years of basic liberal arts training for girls "so that this generation will not face the post-war world minus intellectual preparation" will go into effect at Hunter College next month, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, announced yesterday.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 31 -- Miss Victoria Smith, superintendent of Englewood Hospital, which needs additional nurses, appealed today to graduate nurses in Bergen County, who have left nursing for marriage or other reasons, to seek employment at the hospital.

All securities and commodity markets in the United States and all banks, except those in Kentucky, will be closed today. Likewise, all banks and markets in Canada will observe the New Year holiday. In London the Stock Exchange will be closed today, but the banks will be open.

The first Saturday of the new year will see five shows leaving Broadway, a record number of the season. In the order of the length of their runs, they are: "Strip for Action," 109 performances; "Native Son," 83; "Flare Path," 14; "Cry Havoc," 11, and "Sweet Charity," 8.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed an increase of $362,010,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, a record high. Note circulation also advanced $33,316,000 to a new high. Ratios of reserve for the system and the New York bank went to new lows.

Henceforth during the war production of umbrellas will be limited to three types, one for men, two for the ruling sex. Perhaps no article worn or borne has a more respectable antiquity or has essentially less changed, steel having taken the place of rattan or bamboo. In thousands of years what must have been the ancient Chinese models have been maintained.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 31 -- The special meeting of stockholders of the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation to pass upon the plan providing for the sale to the Phillips Petroleum Corporation of Columbia Oil's holdings of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company and for the winding up of Columbia Oil took final action today, authorizing all phases of the plan.

Although bank clearings in the week ended Wednesday increased 5.9 per cent over the previous week on a daily average basis, the total volume was down 11.7 per cent due to observance of the Christmas holiday. However, the year-to-year comparison disclosed a moderate increase.

With a big rise in the birthrate, a static general death rate, and new low records achieved in infant deaths as well as mortality from diphtheria, typhoid fever, pneumonia, tuberculosis and appendicitis, the vital statistics for New York City in 1942 are "extremely encouraging,"

Bonds called before maturity for payment in December aggregated $99,778,000, the largest amount for any month since April, when $179,888,000 was retired. The total, however, was the smallest for any December since 1939 when $73,781,000 was redeemed and it compared with $56,004,000 the month before and with $179,694,000 in December, 1941.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Word that it plans a new pricing regulation for Spring garments at retail and wholesale levels, which will contain a prohibition against sales of garments in price lines higher than the seller's highest price line during an appropriate Spring 1942 base period, was given out by OPA today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 31 -- In a new crime crusade in bayonne by Hudson County Prosecutor Daniel T. O'Regan, three policemen and one fireman in that city were arrested today on warrants charging them with offenses related to gambling.

ABERDEEN, Md., Dec. 3 -- A secret weapon, which is already being produced in quantity and is in the hands of infantrymen, will make the American soldier the most dangerous fighting man in the world, according to Major Gen. Levin H. Campbell Jr., Chief of Ordnance, United States Army, who talked to newspaper correspondents visiting the Aberdeen Proving Ground yesterday.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 -- Johnny Adams, the nation's leading jockey, brought the year to a close by riding two winners at Tropical Park today and running his total to 245.

The New York-New Jersey region led the nation in scrap iron and steel deliveries to the mills during the four months ended Oct. 31, it was announced yesterday by George Sutherland, regional salvage manager of the War Production Board's conservation division.

The Appellate Division of Special Sessions yesterday handed down a decision reversing the conviction last Summer by Magistrate Robert P. Levis of Moses Elisberg, 46 years old, a salesman, of 539 East 171st Street, the Bronx, and thirty-day workhouse sentence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The text of the War Production Board announcement on curtailing the use print paper was as follows:

More changes in member firms of the New York Stock Exchange than in many years appeared yesterday in the weekly bulletin of that institution. In the last week there have been three admissions to member firms and thirty-three retirements, while eight partners in member firms have changed their status.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Dec. 31 -- Bromley Mountain, a favorite ski center for metropolitan devotees several years ago, is undergoing a complete transformation. When the mammoth "face-lifting" task of clearing trails and finishing the mile-long "J-Bar" lift is completed shortly it will give this community one of the most varied, and certainly one of the largest, ski developments in Northeastern United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- The sixty-third annual Charity Ball was held at the Bellevue-Stratford tonight. Because many of the debutantes are too busy with war work to rehearse, the elaborate singing and dancing pageant of peace years was replaced by a March for Victory under the direction of Charles Morgan.
MUSSELSHELL, Mont., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Army officials announced today that twelve Army fliers were killed in the crash of a Flying Fortress yesterday near this village.

OTTAWA, Dec. 31 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister William Mackenzie King, in a New Year's message prepared for broadcast tonight, warned the Canadian people that "all our armed force" would be in action during 1943 and that they "must be prepared for heavy losses."
Most of Vice President Wallace's radio speech on Dec. 28 was fine, but it was distressing to read his advocacy of "supervision, or at least inspection, of the school systems of Germany and Japan."

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Buying of Wheat futures by mills gave the market for that grain a firm undertone in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, but hedging pressure developed in the May late in the session and it closed 1/8 cent lower than yesterday while the deferred months were 1/4 to 3/8 cent higher.

" Inside Fighting China," the latest issue in the World In Action series of short subjects produced by the National Film Board of Canada and distributed by United Artists, will open a five-day stand today at the Grand Central and the Rockefeller Center Newsreel Theatres.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 -- Georgia's Rose Bowl outlook was blacked out tonight as Coach Wally Butts said his ace passer and runner, Frankie Sinkwich, was not in condition to start tomorrow's game here against the University of California at Los Angeles.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Over 200 German fighter planes have been destroyed by United States airmen since they began operations from the British Isles last July, according to a 1942 review given out today by officials of the United States Army Eighth Air Force headquarters.

Mrs. Wilbur F. Howell of Sunnyside, nutrition chairman of the Central Chapter of Queens American Red Cross, announced yesterday that because of point rationing scheduled to start in February, the nutrition cQurses offered by her organization are assuming increasing importance.

Your editorial "The End of Darlan" and Anne O'Hare McCormick's sidelights in her always interesting column combined to present and illuminate an unhappy picture to your readers in a most fortunately intelligent light.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Department store sales for the week ended Dec. 26 were 15 per cent up from the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. This followed a gain of 10 per cent in the preceding week.

American industry will be producing a volume of war weapons as great as the output of all the rest of the world by the end of 1943, Frederick C. Crawford, president-elect of the National Association of Manufacturers, said in a statement yesterday.

The Synagogue Council of America made public yesterday a New Year message it had addressed to American Catholic and Protestant groups expressing gratitude for the "evidences of sympathy which have come from Christian leaders and spokesmen" to the Jews of Hitler-occupied Europe.

Tightening up its system of export control through Certificates of Necessity, the Board of Economic Warfare yesterday issued a new and more comprehensive list of products for which such certificates will be required for shipments to Latin America.

Maxie Shapiro's indisposition to go through with his fifteen-round fight with Joey Peralta on the lightweight elimination card at Madison Square Garden a week from tonight caused Matchmaker Nat Rogers to rearrange the bill yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 31 -- Proceedings to denaturalize three native Germans, including Captain William Drechsel of West Englewood, N.J., former New York manager for the North German Lloyd-Hamburg-American Steamship Lines, were instituted today in the United States District Court in Trenton, E.E. Conroy, New Jersey Chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, disclosed here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -- Dennis Morgan, John Garfield and Sydney Greenstreet were named today by Warner Brothers to lead the cast of "Brooklyn, U.S.A.," adapted by Asa Bordages and John Bright to the screen from their Broadway play of a year ago, which closely parallels the Murder, Inc. racketeering record.

In a drastic move to curb traffic accidents over the long holiday week-end, Police Commissioner Valentine directed last night that all intoxicated persons be prevented from driving automobiles and detailed extra patrol crews to enforce his edict.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Kenesaw Mountain Landis, Commissioner of Baseball, today summoned the sixteen club owners of the major leagues to a special joint session to settle all rail transportation problems of Spring training.

Three Brooklyn men and a Queens man, convicted of robbery in the first degree, were sentenced yesterday afternoon to serve from ten t othirty years in Sing Sing Prison by Judge Charles S. Colden in Queens County Court. It was the last official act of Judge Colden in that court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The new year will be marked in the United States by "the greatest volume of production, the highest level of employment and the largest national income ever recorded in history," said Secretary Jones today in a forecast of what 1943 will mean to the country's economy.
Traffic was halted for a few minutes yesterday afternoon at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street. Brakes screeched and drivers whistled.

Like a good omen for democracy at the dawn of another year of war, the helping hand of mercy was extended yesterday to the Neediest Cases of New York, from Chihuahua, Mexico; Dry Creek, West Va.; Dunedin, Fla.; Narrowsburg, N.Y.; and Washington, as well as generously from New Yorkers themselves.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- There's no record of what a football coach thinks about on the eve of a post-season bowl game, but Alabama's Frank Thomas and Boston College's Denny Myers must have been wishing for a cool day.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique:
With another year being ushered in some anglers in New Jersey who have no qualms about bad weather are all set to go again.

In the three weeks required for the sixth Selective Service registration of 18-year-old youths in this city Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, draft director here, announced last night that 280 local boards in the five boroughs had enrolled 22,453 men.

A 38-year-old war worker, father of three children and estranged from his wife, was held in Staten Island last night for the murder of Mary Rycoitch, 19, whose bludgeoned body was found Monday in a marsh a few miles from her home at 16 Catherine Place, Mariners Harbor, S.I.

Although the huge job of converting American industry to a war basis caused widespread changes in products during the first half of 1942, a study announced yesterday by Dun Bradstreet indicated that almost as large a proportion of the 3,500 manufacturers who made them in the first half of the year would be forced to make further changes by the beginning of the new year.

NEWTON, N.J., Dec. 31 (AP) -- The final chapter in the lengthy litigation against the Breeze Corporation was completed today with the filing by Vice Chancellor Henry T. Kays of an order awarding $236,514 for counsel fees and disbursements.

Mayor La Guardia appointed yesterday a City Fuel Oil Administrator, to allocate among the essential municipal services the oil the city administration obtains under Federal rationing, and served notice that this step might "involve the curtailment or elimination of certain city activities."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- A voluntary plan providing for eventual dissolution of the Federal Water and Gas Corporation was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which promptly instituted proceedings against the concern under both sections of the "death sentence" clause and consolidated all of the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Newspaper correspondents covering the War Production Board, War Manpower Commission, Office of Price Administration and other war agencies have formally protested against a transfer of the press room of the Office of War Information from its present headquarters, even though the OWI is taken elsewhere.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- British ships have made contact with the Germans in northern waters and damaged one German cruiser, which withdrew, and severely hit one destroyer, which was last seen in a sinking condition, the Admiralty announced tonight.
