ALGIERS, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- General Henri Honore Giraud, determined to achieve political order in French Africa so he can proceed with the more important task of helping win the war, announced today that "no attempts to divide the French people will be tolerated."

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 1 -- Convoys to Russia are running on a "regular timetable" despite all German efforts, and Nazi capital ships have been contained harmlessly during the year, the Royal Navy Review for 1942 said today. The bitterest convoy fighting occurred on the North Russia and Malta runs, but the Navy proudly declared:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Winter came back to this part of the Adirondacks today and piled fresh snow over the rain-beaten old snow. All day hundreds of guests of the Lake Placid Club and members of the thirteen teams entered in the College Week meet were out on the trails and slopes and the first ski competition of the week, though entirely informal, took place on the seventy-meter Olympic jumping hill at Intervale.

In line with a new policy for decentralization of the War Labor Board's machinery, the recently instituted "Little War Labor Board" for the New York and New Jersey region will begin operation within the next few weeks, Theodore W. Kheel, regional WLB director announced yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 -- A perennial New Year's Day test of Eastern versus Western football will be held tomorrow in Kezar Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Continued advances in primary market prices for farm commodities, particularly livestock, poultry and gains, caused the Bureau of Labor Statistics' Comprehensive Index of nearly 900 price series to rise one-half of 1 per cent in the week ended Dec. 26.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The engagement between British men-of-war and an enemy naval force in northern waters early today was the first flare-up of real naval activity in northern waters, where the German Navy prowls on deadly watch for Allied convoys to Russia, since last August, when the battleship Tirpitz ventured into the convoy lanes from her Norwegian fjord hideout and was reported torpedoed and damaged by a Russian submarine.

Three hundred merchant seamen and fighting men from thirty-two different countries in the family of the United Nations are wishing their kinsmen and compatriots in the occupied lands of Europe and Asia a "Happy New Year" today in a short-wave broadcast from New York under the auspices of the Office of War Information.

United Nations Week will be observed at motion-picture theatres throughout the country from Jan. 14 through Jan. 20 on the initiative of the Theatres Division of the War Activities Committee of the Motion Picture Industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The government's food-stamp program, a subsidy system under which $245,100,000 worth of food was distributed to low-income persons, was ordered suspended today by the Agriculture Department, effective March 1.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- Total loss of German planes in an effort to block American Flying Fortresses's precision bombing of the submarine base at Lorient, France, could not be revealed by American headquarters today, but a partial report showed that the Germans lost at least nineteen aircraft.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Friction between the Japanese and a Chinese hireling army near Peiping, in which the mediation efforts of Japan's puppet premier, Wang Ching-Wei, have failed, was reported by a Chinese communique today.

The independent employes association of the New York Stock Exchange represents 98 per cent of all employes in the floor operations department and approximately 80 per cent of those of the Stock Exchange, M. David Keefe, president of the association, said yesterday in connection with the association's dispute with the Exchange, which has been certified to the National War Labor Board.

Watch night services at which the New Year was ushered in with special prayers for those in the armed forces of the United Nations were held last night in churches of various faiths throughout the city.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- The police tonight issued a nationwide order prohibiting publication of the statement by the British Foreign Office deploring the fact that the Argentine Government is maintaining diplomatic relations "with the enemies of humanity."

LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The unrelenting force of United States bomber and fighter assaults on Tunisian ports and east-coast roads and bases was regarded here tonight as the possible prelude to an increasingly imminent land offensive, to be started perhaps by Lieut. Gem Walther Nehring's Axis forces.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A special Soviet communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The State Department declared today that it was in full accord with the statement of the British Foreign Office deploring "the policy of Argentine in remaining in diplomatic relations with the enemies of humanity."

The six-story commercial building at 55-57 Flatbush Avenue on Brooklyn has been sold by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn to John Mullins Sons, Inc., credit furniture concern, through the Julius J. Klein Company, brokers. Sale of this property, which is assessed by $125,000, was for cash.

Crown Prince Olaf of Norway, arriving yesterday at La Guardia Field aboard a transatlantic clipper, emphasized that despite the "growing tyranny of oppression and the strengthening of terror in Norway, the spirit of the people is unchanged in its determination to win through."

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Wartime restrictions on new output of metal-content goods have caused Sears Roebuck Co. to close four of its smaller stores, three in Ohio and one in Michigan. Three of the units were of the Class C type, which means they were small outlets specializing in household appliances, tires and similar accessories, while the store at Columbus, Ohio, was somewhat larger and in the Class B category.

Winthrop Snelling, retired actors' manager, who had been living at the Elite Hotel, 255 West Fifty-first Street, was reported missing on Dec. 7 by a friend, Mrs. Rose Mumford, of 73 Beechwood Road, Summit, N.J., at whose home he was supposed to have arrived on Dec. 3, according to information made public last night by the Missing Persons Bureau at Manhattan Police Headquarters.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in North Africa, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 31 -- With no means of getting badly needed supplies, equipment and reinforcements, with insufficient air support and with only a doubtful avenue of escape, the German Africa Corps appeared today to be in an extremely precarious position in Libya.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Strong winds and colder weather today harried weary workmen repairing power and telephone lines snapped by heavy ice in Northern and Eastern New York, but flood threats abated in the south and southwest.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Brazil has already served as a springboard for the Allied North African campaign and is preparing for armed action overseas against Germany and Italy, if necessary, President Getulio Vargas said today.

Advertising's aid to the war effort was praised yesterday by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., who expressed thanks, in a year-end message to the Advertising Council, Inc., "for the truly wonderful help you have been giving the Treasury in our war financing campaigns."

I have followed with great interest your editorials supporting the Ruml plan, and while I heartily agree that we must have a pay-as-you-go basis for our taxes, I believe that the adoption of such a plan will be delayed if we insist on the device of skipping a year's taxes.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 31 -- Disorders caused by local political issues have occurred in the town of Reynosa, State of Tamaulipas, according to press dispatches today. They took place Tuesday, two days after similar incidents were reported in the towns of Miguel Auza, Rio Grande and Nieves, in the State of Zacatecas.

THE weary book reviewer tossed in his sleep, rolled, fidgeted, twisted and turned. He was having a nightmare, an annual nightmare that returned to beset him every year during the night of Dec. 31-Jan. 1. It seemed as if a nameless, stern, patient inquisitor were balancing his books on the literary year just passed. Some of the questions didn't always seem pertinent, but he felt a strange compulsion to answer them as best he could.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (/P)-Guy T. Helvering, Internal Revenue Commissioner. said today that withholding the 5 per cent Victory tax, which becomes effective tomorrow, must be made on all wages for payroll periods which end on or after Jan. 1.

Bad weather and the usual post-Christmas buying reaction held down retail sales totals here this week. Department store volume was estimated as about 10 per cent under the comparative 1941 period. December as a whole is expected to show a 6 per cent increase over last year.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 31 -- Allied patrols have been in contact with Axis forces in the vicinity of the station Bou Arada, twenty miles south of Medjez-el-Bab and fifteen miles west of Pont du Fahs, an Allied communique reported today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A communique:

Elsewhere on this page we publish a proposal by a correspondent of a method for getting taxpayers on a pay-as-you-go basis without adopting the Ruml plan. But this serious and well-considered attempt to solve the problem in itself emphasizes the wholly needless difficulties we should face if we tried to get a pay-as-you-go system without technically "skipping" a year's taxes.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Ensign Fred Wolcott of the Georgia Navy Pre-Flight School today won undisputed possession of the Sugar Bowl record for the 120-yard high hurdles by clearing the obstacles in 14.1 seconds before a crowd of 300.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Department of Agriculture notified tonight its marketing administrators in the New York, Chicago and Duluth-Superior milksheds that the subsidy program for milk producers that has been in effect since October will be suspended at midnight tonight.

Manufacturers of cosmetics are now in a position to supply enough goods to satisfy the needs of American women, experts in the field agreed yesterday. Relaxation of government regulations, combined with the discovery of many substitute ingredients, will enable every woman to keep on hand her usual quota of beauty preparations, a brief survey revealed.

The stock market brought its 1942 activity to a close yesterday, and in terminating the first calendar year of the war registered its poorest twelve-month period of business since 1913. Final prices were about on a par with those just prior to Pearl Harbor, and during the session issues with the best peacetime prospects showed the widest additions.

A Washington dispatch described the "bits and pieces" system by which Axis agents sometimes get news that is helpful to them. The source is gossip that seems harmless: A factory worker telling of orders for assault boats; a produce merchant telling of a Navy order for vegetables; a girl telling another girl that her boy friend, a parachute trooper, is "going across Tuesday."
MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The midnight communique:
LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- An admiralty communique:

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 31 -- The lag in the collection of refuse here, a problem for a month or more, became acute this week as a result of the manpower shortage and little hope is held for an alleviation of the situation, described by Mayor Charles H. Martens as "very bad.

The Whitney Museum will be closed to the public today but will be open as usual tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. The 1942-43 annual exhibition of contemporary American sculpture, paintings, drawings and prints [will be current through Jan. 6, and a selection of works from the permanent collection will go on view at the museum on Jan. 8.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Here are some expressions of opinion by leaders of the war effort in Washington on the prospects for the new year:
Year-end evening-up in the cotton futures market yesterday broke a five-day ascent in prices and left active contracts with final net losses of 2 to 8 points.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 31 -- Governor Talmadge's plans for the immediate cash purchase of health and defense text books for Georgia's school children at an estimated cost of $1,500,000 were apparently blocked today when argument on a temporary restraining order was postponed until Tuesday.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- Eleven indictments against ten Boston men, including the City Building Commissioner, James H. Mooney, and Captain Joseph A. Buccigross, a veteran police official, were returned by a Suffolk County Grand Jury late today after a ten-day investigation of the Cocoanut Grove fire on Nov. 28, which took the lives of 489 persons.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The war has changed women's outlook on buying clothes. Women who before the war preferred quantity to quality have revised their ideas. No longer do they buy just because something looks attractive. Clothes rationing on the coupon system has altered that completely.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31 -- The Russians were reported today to be sweeping forward along the caravan trails of the Kalmuck steppes, lengthening their drive parallel with the Stalingrad-Tikhoretsk railroad, along which they continue to advance boldly from captured Kotelnikov.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- The Office of Price Administration tonight issued the following questions and answers to explain the forthcoming program for point rationing of canned, bottled and frozen fruits and vegetables, juices, dried fruits and all soups:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration made "an unwarranted assumption" when it said its order increasing flour prices would not require an increase in bread prices, Ralph D. Ward, president of the American Bakers Association, said in a statement today.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, on Guadalcanal, Dec. 12 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Rough packing-box slats painted green and nailed in the form of rude crosses mark the most hallowed ground in the Solomons -- the cemetery where lie Marine, Navy and Army heroes who died fighting the Japanese.

" Racing broke all records in taxes, attendance, pools and purses, without any conflict with the war effort." The foregoing is the most significant statement in the annual report of Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope of the New York State Racing Commission announced yesterday prior to its submission to the new Secretary of State, Thomas J. Curran, and Govenor Dewey.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 31 -- Sixty-one debutantes, including several from New York, made their formal bows to society tonight at the Bachelors Cotillion at the Lyric More than 1,000 persons attended the ball, which replaced the first Monday German of the cotillon. For the second time since 1807, when the cotillion was organized, the German was canceled this year because of the war, the only time since 1918.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31 -- The flood menace was beyond Pittsburgh tonight, but the crest rolled down the intensely industrialized Ohio River Valley driving thousands from their homes and damaging industrial plants engaged in war production.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The War Labor Board approved today wage increases recommended for 18,000 employes of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation's three plants where, according to the management, a "slow down" was in effect Dec. 18-28 with a loss of 365,000 man hours.

AT A NEW GUINEA, BASE, Dec. 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- The end of the Japanese hold on the Buna sector of the Papuan front is in sight with enemy forces at Buna Government Station and Giropa Point separated by an American-won beachhead which has been widened to several hundred yards in recent days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Lieut. Gen. Hsiung Shih-fei, head of the Chinese Military Mission here, called on President Roosevelt today, preparatory for leaving for London and then Chungking where he will report to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Vice President Wallace said tonight that peace in the post-war world must be insured by force, if necessary, and he recommended an international air corps as a chief implement of enforcement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Sale of the Yankee network of twenty-one stations to the General Tire and Rubber Company of Akron was approved today by the Federal Communications Commission, with dissents by Commissioners Paul A. Walker and Clifford J. Durr.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The British Government made it clear tonight in a statement issued through the Foreign Office that it deplored the policy of Argentina in continuing diplomatic relations with "the enemies of humanity."

Sales of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in December were the largest of the year for a month, but were smaller than in December, 1941. The volume of business for last year dropped to 125,677,963 shares, the smallest for a full year since 1913, the year prior to the World War.

Railroad stations and bus terminals were jammed yesterday with incoming and outgoing crowds preparing to spend the holiday weekend in city and country and everything on wheels was pressed into service. Those seeking reservations had long to wait and often were disappointed.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England issued today reported an addition of more than 81,000,000 to its holdings of government securities for the past week. Private deposits also increased almost 79,000,000.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Jan. 1 -- The New Year's Day communique of General Douglas MacArthur announced that twenty Japanese planes were destroyed at Lae, enemy-held base above Buna on the New Guinea north coast.

ANOTHER new year dawns with its hopes glistening and its prospects beckoning. For the nation at large that hope is vibrant. A year ago the shock of Pearl Harbor had gripped the country with a cold and clammy hand. But that grip has been shaken and the future glows ever brighter.

The United States District Court at Toledo, Ohio, yesterday terminated the receivership proceedings of the Ann Arbor Railroad Company, effective today, according to an announcement made here by the railroad. This makes the third Class I railroad to wind up its equity proceedings in 1942, the Norfolk Southern Railway Company and the Wabash Railway Company having been restored earlier to corporate control.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Rumblings of plans to apply Congressional checks to lend-lease expenditures and to begin an investigation into the more than $7,000,000,000 outlay made since the program started in March of 1941, became more pronounced at the Capitol today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 31 -- A worker in the Reich war industry today, whether native or foreign, has to put in a minimum of sixty hours per week, but more often sixty-five or even seventy-two.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 1 -- In keeping with the increasing wartime "austerity" restrictions, London hailed the New Year this morning more or less "soberly," but no less confidently than ever.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- To several persons here who have been in close touch with events in North Africa, before and since the landings of United States troops, this correspondent today addressed a number of questions. The purpose was to clear up certain confusions in the news from North Africa, if possible.

MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 1 -- The Russians declared officially for the first time today that twenty-two enemy divisions in the area of Stalingrad had been tightly encircled by the Red Army and announced that 312,650 German and satellite soldiers had been killed or captured thus far in the three great drives by which the iron ring was welded around the ruined Volga city in six weeks.

LONDON, Dee. 31 -- Business in the stock markets today was moderate but the tone remained firm. Gilt-edge securities improved further, the War Loan 3 1/2 per cents going to 105. Home rails showed renewed firmness.

With most local grocery stores completely out of butter and some of them also out of oleomargarine, the War Production Board announced yesterday that it had ordered the release from storage of approximately 2,000,000 pounds of butter to ease the situation throughout the country.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Dec. 31 -- A "poultry for freedom" movement swept through this Morris County community of 2,200 persons today, the aftermath of a court hearing last night in which the raising of chickens was outlawed in this restricted residential area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Fighting planes based at Henderson Field on Guadalcanal Island lashed out at Japanese bases in near-by regions on Tuesday and Wednesday (Solomons time) in a manner indicating that our forces there expected early renewal of a Japanese attack in force on our positions.

DALLAS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Consider tomorrow's Cotton Bowl show between Texas and Georgia Tech from every angle and you will be convinced that you are going to see a track meet as well as a football game at the one price.

Although larger than in the preceding month, new financing here in December was the second smallest for any month since January, 1939, and the month brought to a close a year in which new offerings were at the lowest level since 1933.

Just when in 1943 will the war end in a United Nations victory? We can argue along two lines. The last World War started in the first week of August, 1914, and ended in the second week of November, 1918, roughly four years, three and a half months.
Walter M. Dear, president of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association, issued the following statement on the newsprint order in New York yesterday through The Associated Press:

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Joseph Kesselring's "Arsenic and Old Lace," the play wherein murder is treated as a gentle art, was generally well received by the London critics. The Times of London critic, who describes the play as "certainly the most amusing comedy on the London stage today," praises the author for confining his amiable lunatics to a plane from which all but the logic of the actors' own lunacies is excluded.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, one of the most intense and complex musical personalities among modern conductors, gave a program last night, as guest leader of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, which ranged all the way from the overture to Gluck's "Alceste" to a new version of an American Symphony by Roy Harris.

New Year's Eve in Times Square had a weird quality last night. A crowd of some 400,000, swelled by enormous numbers of 'teen-age boys and girls, moved zombie-like through the dimness, blowing in melancholy fashion on old and second-hand horns.

Squat, grizzled Irving Wexler, who was Waxey Gordon and a leading beer baron not so many years ago, heard himself described as a "very much sat upon man" yesterday in Federal court Then he pleaded guilty to charges of having conspired to set up a black market in sugar, through the instrumentality of a substance known as "Vita Cola."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A new Liberty ship, bigger, faster and less vulnerable to submarine attacks, will be produced next year.

As one of his last acts in office, it was learned yesterday, Governor Poletti commuted the sentence of Alexander Hoffman, C.I.O. union official and Left Wing sympathizer, who was sentenced on Dec. 4, 1940, to four to eight years in Sing Sing for attempted arson in the second degree, attempted arson in the third degree and conspiracy.

Leonia Justo, 26 years old, died in Bellevue Hospital at 4:55 o'clock yesterday afternoon of injuries she received a few hours earlier when she fell four stories down a freight elevator shaft while attending a New Year's party for seventy State-wide employes of Sarnoff-Irving, Inc., hat manufacturers, in the concern's shipping room, 404 Fourth Avenue.
New issues of municipal bonds scheduled for award in the first week of the new year amount to $4,869,000, according to Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's revised total of $2,000,500.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The movements of Acting Air Commodore Whitney Willard Straight, 29-year-old American-born millionaire, after he had been shot down over France in August were lifted out of a shroud of mystery today with the announcement that he is now serving in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The investigation of the assassination of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, which led to the arrest of a dozen persons in Algiers yesterday, and may throw new light upon the political situation in North Africa, is not yet completed, according to a statement by Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, today.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 31 -- The Food and Drug Administration filed suit in Federal Court here today against the Salem County Canners, Inc., of Quinton, N.J., charging the company, which supplies tinned fruits and vegetables for the armed forces, with packing its products "under unsanitary and filthy conditions injurious to health."

The theatre had its hangover last night, and it was a corker. For while the rest of the world stood happily blowing horns in near-by Times Square, the faithful gathered at Maxine Elliott's to mourn out the old year with a musical biography of Gus Edwards called "You'll See Stars."

WAUKEGAN, Ill., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Walter P. Murphy, railway equipment manufacturer who bequeathed most of his fortune of more than $20,000,000 to Northwestern University, left $5,000,000 to railroad men, other friends, relatives and institutions.

Frederick Brown has resold the twelve-story apartment building.at 340 West Eighty-sixth Street, containing sixty-eight apartments, for cash above a ten-year mortgage of $270,000. The buyer's name was not revealed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Francis B. Sayre, former High Commissioner to the Philippines, was appointed today deputy director of foreign relief and rehabilitation operations under former Governor Lehman. He will also serve as a special assistant to Secretary Hull.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Bureau of Mines has released for use by industrial and civil defense training classes, for training courses by or on behalf of the Army, Navy and Maritime Service, and for showing by schools, churches and similar groups, a new sound film demonstrating the value of a working knowledge of first aid.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- As the United Nations enter the 1943 war effort, they face a situation where Germany is still economically formidable but past its production peak, while Japan is definitely stronger in raw materials than a year ago and within reach of a powerful and entrenched economic position except for a major weakness in shipping, the Board of Economic Warfare stated today in a year-end review.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Wire Rope Export Trade Association has filed papers under the Webb-Pomerene Export Trade Act for exporting wire rope, strand and rope fittings, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- With the Congress of Industrial Organizations calling for total mobilization for victory in 1943, the American Federation of Labor appealed separately today for a goal by workers of bringing victory in the coming year.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Hardin-Simmons Cowboys hope their coach is wrong. He has picked the Second Air Force Bombers to defeat his team in the eighth annual Sun Bowl football game tomorrow.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- The State Education Department, acting in its capacity as the University of the State of New York, withdrew today its recognition of undergraduate, degrees granted to the University of Chicago because of the recent policy of that institution in "telescoping" its courses to permit completion of the college requirements for the bachelor's degree in two years.

Since three years of war have drawn heavily upon Germany's manpower, the Nazis have been drafting their women for war work in ever-increasing numbers. No estimates of the size of this recruited woman's labor corps are possible, but there are sure indications that its force is tremendous, so vast indeed that its reserves by now are about exhausted.
Adolf Hitler, in a New Year's message to the German people, defiantly pledged yesterday that the Reich would fight on to "a definite victory," despite the hardships admittedly in prospect for 1943.

Mayor La Guardia, in a special New Year's message to residents of the city, called on members of his administration yesterday to give the nation an example of patience, devotion to duty and competence in the critical days ahead.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Navy communique 235:

The letter in THE TIMES last Saturday that attacked the National Football League's method of rating forward passers must have been penned by a newcomer to the sports scene. Certainly no experienced follower of the sport would object to Sid Luckman having a prominent position in the final records merely because the Chicago Bears' ace led Slingin' Sammy Baugh, Cecil Isbell, Tommy Thompson and Wilson Schwenk in interceptions.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 -- The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association in its year-end statement released today, reported that total resources on Dec. 31 last stood at a high record of $2,771,689,000, an increase of $676,054,000 in the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The War Department announced today that "many thousands of tons" of American food, clothing and other supplies for the civilian population of French North Africa, whose movable reserves of foodstuffs and other commodities had been drained away, via Marseille, to the Germans and to a lesser extent to France.

The letter from Kenneth Pritchard appearing in THE TIMES last Saturday, in which he advocated "a suspension of large-scale skiing activities" for the duration of the war, deserves immediate refutation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Office of Price Administration tonight authorized stores of the New York metropolitan area to advance retail milk prices to 14 cents a quart for milk sold in glass bottles and to 15 cents a quart for milk sold in paper containers, starting Monday.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 27 (Delayed) -- If the somber city of Chungking is fairly bright with optimism this Winter the reason is not hard to find. Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, leader of China, is personally optimistic.

A year ago people wanted to know "what can I do?" It was just after Pearl Harbor and every one was frantically trying to get into some sort of volunteer defense work. Today that query has changed to "What do I have to do?" Apropos, of course, of rationing.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 1 -- Since letters take precedence over newspapers, periodicals and books in the mails for China, nothing is more scarce than printed matter from the West, nothing is more prized than a newspaper or a magazine as late as of two monks ago and nothing is more urgently needed in administration than technical and learned journals for specialists in economic and scientific work.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- London waited eagerly tonight for news of how a naval battle was going in the North Sea, where British units were reported last night to be in combat. It was not forthcoming.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Republican associates of Governor Dewey in the new administration, Lieutenant Governor Thomas W. Wallace of Schenectady, Controller Frank C. Moore of Kenmore and Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein of Brooklyn were sworn into office here following the Governor's inauguration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The use of an additional 230,000,000 pounds of oil by manufacturers of margarine was authorized by the War Production Board today in view of the need for increased margarine production arising from the pending butter shortage.

AT A SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Dec. 30 (Delayed) -- Back of our conquest of the Southern Solomons are tremendous achievements of the Naval Transport Service. Month after month vessels of this service manned by naval personnel have carried men and supplies that have steadily sewn up the position on Guadalcanal.

FRANK KEANEY, the shepherd of the Rhode Island State Rams, is as breezy as a cooling Summer wind and just as refreshing. He is bringing his basketball team to the Garden tonight, not to play Fordham particularly, but "merely to let the boys see the sights of the big city."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- American pilots raided the Japanese at Kiska Island twice during the night of Wednesday-Thursday and made direct hits with several bombs on two Japanese cargo ships or transports lying in the harbor, but lost two fighters and one bomber.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 1 -- The statement issued by the Foreign Office in London yesterday deploring Argentine policy in maintaining diplomatic relations with the Axis elicited an angry retort from the Argentine Foreign Ministry, which, after long consultation between Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu and President Ramon S. Castillo, issued a communique in which the Argentine Government in its turn deplored the attitude of the British Government and expressed surprise at it.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street, in a statement last night declared he was opposed to the doctrine that by making Palestine a Jewish sovereign State the Jewish problem would be largely, if not wholly, solved.

The Nesterman Publishing Company, whose main business is in the field of guide books, city directories and similar publications, is making a cautious entry into the trade book field. The firm will publish next Friday a book entitled "Growing Up in the Horse and Buggy Days," by Carl E. Ladd and E.R. Eastman.

High-scoring action is expected to highlight the new year's first Madison Square Garden basketball double-header tonight when Long Island University and Fordham will try to rebound into the victory column at the expense of Creighton and Rhode Island State, respectively.

Characterizing 1942 as a year of both stupendous effort and achievement, the National City Bank, in the January issue of its bank letter, expresses the opinion that the year just ended was one of preparation for even greater effort in 1943.
FORTRESS MONROE, Va., Jan. 1 -- A carrier pigeon, known only as No. 1169, received an Army citation today for meritorious service displayed Dec. 15 in connection with a lost Coast Guard schooner.

General Henri Honore Girauds assertion on Wednesday that he had found close friends among the men arrested in connection with the murder of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan has caused bewilderment. The following may be taken as an elucidation of what he had in mind.

Recall of teachers on sabbatical leaves to meet the city school system's wartime need for additional experienced and permanent teachers was suggested yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in making publica letter he had written to Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the Board of Education.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 1 -- American bombers and fighters gave the Germans a taste of things to come during the new year when they bombed and strafed enemy harbors and installations from Bizerte to the Tunisia-Tripolitania frontier yesterday.
It was with great interest that I read about the physical fitness program of the A.A.U. that was proposed at that organization's recent convention in Chicago.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 -- Texas' massive line beat Georgia Tech into the Cotton Bowl turf for three quarters today and the Yellow Jackets' rally in the final minutes paid off with only one touchdown as the Southeastern Conference team lost to the Longhorns, 14 -- 7.

Officers of the armed forces of the United Nations thoroughly enjoyed themselves yesterday at the eggnog party at the Open House for Officers of the United States and Allied Nations at the organization's quarters in the Hotel Delmonico, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.
This holiday season is keeping the junior hostesses of the College and University Women's Center on their toes -- dancing with service men.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 1 -- Assisted by twenty-six members of the new Women's Auxiliary State Police (Wasps), State troopers went into action today against automobile speeders. They used Governor Colgate W. Darden's detectors to maintain a speed on State highways at or below thirty-five miles an hour.

Mr. Nelson and Mr. Henderson have reported to a committee of Congress that rationing of gasoline and tires will bring the neighborhood merchant back to his own. A number of factors will reduce the desire of consumers to shop around or to buy at a distance from home.
ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's inaugural address:

MOSCOW, Jan. l -- The avalanche that threatens to fall on the Germans' southern salient was vividly depicted in maps published in the press today illustrating the announcement of the Red Army's resounding successes of the last six weeks.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- A fighting French desert force has routed an enemy motorized column some 500 miles south of the Mediterranean coast, but no further progress was reported by the British Eight Army to the east, according to reports received here today from North Africa.

Although I do not agree completely with some of the general statements made by Kenneth Pritchard in THE TIMES last Saturday, I think his letter has merit, especially when one pauses to consider the underlying thoughts contained in it.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 1 -- For the first time since he stepped out of office, A. Harry Moore, known in New Jersey as the Democratic party's "best vote getter," hinted here today that he is wavering in his decision not to seek a fourth term as Governor.

About 11,000,000 volunteers are now engaged in civilian defense activities, George S. Van Schaick, director of the Office of Civilian Defense in the second region, reported yesterday in a year-end review. Of these 1,500,000 are serving in the second region, including roughly 450,000 in New York City, 500,000 in New Jersey and 525,000 in New York State outside of New York City.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (Delayed) -- A highly important article published in Pravda today deals with the present and future situation in the Urals and Western Siberia, where the pressure of war needs has hastened the process of industrialization set going by the long-range planning initiated by Joseph Stalin's first five-year plan in 1927.

" Where transportation is available, skiing facilities should be maintained and operated during war because, I think, the sport should be encouraged as a means of maintaining physicial fitness," declared Bill Howard, veteran skier and superintendent of New York State's Forests and Lands, in a discussion with this department.
Only seven attractions are promised for Broadway this month, or six less than were presented on the local boards last January. The list for the month, subject to change, is as follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Nelson Eddy, who has been absent from the screen since his appearance in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "I Married An Angel," will resume his film career in Universal's remake of "The Phantom of the Opera," the studio has announced.

Substantial economic gains for its 300,000 members during 1942 were reported by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America yesterday in the annual report of Sidney Hillman, its president, and Jacob S. Potofsky, its secretary-treasurer.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in North Africa, Dec. 31 (Delayed) -- The brief announcement by High Commissioner General Henri Honore Giraud this morning in the local press that he had been forced to make arrests of certain persons "who have tried to trouble opinion" came as no surprise to people who had hoped that now affairs would settle down.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 1 -- Anton Kaufman, blind publisher of The Newark Jewish Chronicle and one of the most prominent leaders in Jewish affairs in New Jersey, lost his life early today in a fall from his eighth-floor room in the Robert Treat Hotel, here.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Governor Dewey announced this afternoon the designation of Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close of Westchester as the new Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division for the Second Department, succeeding Justice Edward J. Lazansky of Brooklyn, whose retirement because of the age limit became effective Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Major motion-picture companies were ordered by the War Production Board today to cut the amount of 35-millimeter film they use in the first quarter of this year 25 per cent below their rate of consumption in 1941.

Irra Petina started the new year right with the best break of her career at the Metropolitan Opera last night. The illness of Lily Djanel gave Miss Petina a chance at the title role of "Carmen," and Miss Petina made sure that in the future she will be assigned to Carmen as a matter of right.

The Philadelphia Falcons defeated the New York Rovers, 5 to 2, last night at Madison Square Garden in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League contest. In the afternoon, the same clubs battled to a 7 -- 7 overtime deadlock. As a result of the two contests, the Philadelphians moved into first place, displacing the Rovers.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- A British 2-dmiralty communiqui:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORHT AFRICA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- General Henri Honore Giraud, French High Commissioner, has ordered the liberation on the new year of a "certain number of persons detained because of certain political tendencies," it was announced officially tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board, suggested today that the social security program be broadened to pay disability benefits to injured workers and their dependents and to cover everyone who works for a living.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Civilians face a 15 per cent cut in supplies of consumers' goods for personal or household use in 1943, compared with 1942, according to government reports. As the year starts total food supplies are at record levels, but shortages of many foods impend.

Alleged to have passed indiscriminately among the customers in a restaurant manifest sheets of an American ship company showing cargoes and sailing dates of ships and then abusing a marine corporal who cautioned him against such actions, Burtin Houk, 18 years old, of 82-80 165th Street, Jamaica, pleaded guilty in Queens Felony Court yesterday to a charge of disorderly conduct.
HONOLULU, Jan. 1 -- At Hickam Field today Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander of the Pacific Fleet, decorated three officers and a chief petty officer of the Navy, as follows:

Three policemen were stabbed in isolated incidents on New Year's Eve in Harlem. In each case the patrolman shot his assailant. One assailant died and two were taken to hospitals for treatment. None of the patrolmen was seriously injured.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- On the first anniversary of the signing of the compact by the United Nations, President Roosevelt asserted today that "the unity thus achieved amidst dire danger has borne rich fruit" in that the United Nations were now passing from the defensive to the offensive, and declared that when the war was won it would continue the common effort to maintain and safeguard the peace.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- Basil (The Owl) Banghart, captured early last Tuesday by Federal agents with Roger (The Terrible) Touhy, with whom he escaped Oct. 9 from Stateville Penitentiary, was turned over tonight to the United States Marshal.
With the end of 1942, annual reports are the order of the day, for it is time for many to give account of their stewardship, if they have not done so already.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 1 -- The new year opened with broadcasts by French Ministers who sang their own praises and announced they would accomplish their tasks "under the high authority of Marshall Petain."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Senator McKellar of Tennessee, ranking member of the Appropriations Committee, said today he would be "delighted" to cooperate with the President in eliminating unnecessary expenditures in the Seventy-eighth Congress which convenes Wednesday.

The tragedy at the Cocoanut Grove night club in Boston in which nearly 500 men and women lost their lives, followed only two weeks later by a similar but smaller disaster at the Knights of Columbus hostel in St. John's, carried the warning everywhere that our safeguards against fire and panic in places of public assembly must be more thorough than they have been in the past.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- The Treasury begins the new year about $112,000,000,000 in the red, with prospects of doing it with a much larger public debt.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- A smoothly operating band of college All-Stars today brought the East its first football triumph over the West in five years. The Easterners edged out the Westerners, 13 to 12, in a thrilling charity game before a near-capacity crowd of 58,000 in Kezar Stadium.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Frankie Sinkwich, the country's outstanding athlete in 1942, wrote blazing final chapter to his college football career today as he dreamed with Charlie Trippi to lead Georgia to a 9-to-0 victory over the University of California at Los Angeles before 93,000 spectators in the Rose Bowl.
KANSAS CITY, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Giving up the business which has been their life work, Edward M. and William T. Dixon, bachelor brothers, locked their 79-year-old community grocery store today.
Lady Norton Griffiths of West Newton, Mass., is visiting her mother, Mrs. George F. Schrafft, at Hampshire House.

In celebration of the completion of fifty years in the ministry of the Collegiate Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of the City of New York by the Rev. Dr. Henry Evertson Cobb, a "Service of Thanksgiving'' will be conducted tomorrow at 11 A.M. in the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue, near Broadway.
ABOARD A BOMBER OVER WAKE ISLAND, Dec. 24 (Delayed) -- In a few seconds, we are going to drop seventy-six 1,000-pound bombs on Wake.

After New Year's Eve, business in Broadway motion picture theatres was at low ebb yesterday until noon or shortly after. By mid-afternoon, however, most of the houses reported that they were playing to capacity audiences, including standees.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1 -- Winter quarters of Ringling Brothers' Circus are in Sarasota, Fla., but the greatest show on earth was right here in the Orange Bowl today as Alabama came back from apparent defeat to overwhelm Boston College, 37 -- 21, before 30,000 football fans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that Bernhard Ulmann Company, Inc., 107 Grand Street, New York, has stipulated with the commission that it will cease using the word "cassimere" or any other term connoting cashmere to describe any product not composed entirely of the hair of the Cashmere goat.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The "Vichypacked" French Imperial Council in Africa must be eliminated before General Charles de Gaulle would join forces with High Commissioner General Henri Honore Giraud, a Fighting French spokesman said today.

Times Square was dim when the New Year came in, along with the rest of the city and the rest of the Atlantic Coast. We must think first of all of the men on the merchant ships in the coast lanes, holding intact the life line of our attack on the Axis and against the Axis submarines. For them we must do all we can to reduce the night glow over the land.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 1 -- President Roosevelt and President Getulio D. Vargas of Brazil led a list of five men named in citations announced here today by the Friends of America movement as outstanding figures of the Americas because of their attitudes in peace and war, their Americanism and championing of fair play and their influence in the defense of the hemisphere.

CAIRO, Egypt Jan. 1 -- American heavy bombers, as well as British mediums, damaged important installations at the Tunisian port of Sfax yesterday and Wednesday night, thus increasing the supply problem of the Germans opposing the Allied armies in Tunisia.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- With deposits of $2,052,478,000 at the year-end, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has become the first bank here to reach the two-billion mark in deposits. The increase in the year was $425,667,366.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 -- Tennessee overpowered Tulsa, 14 -- 7, today before a Sugar Bowl crowd estimated at 70,000, but the Oklahomans got off to a fast start and staged a blazing finish that might have tied the score except for a last-minute pass interception by a Tennessee end, Jim Powell.

PASCAGOULA, Miss., Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Ten thousand workers at the Ingalls shipyards formed "a Rickenbacker Squadron" today, in what was said to be the first organized labor move to answer Captain Eddie Rickenbacker's challenge for more war goods.

The contrast between Hitler's New Year's Day proclamation yesterday and other proclamations which he has issued at this time in other years is too sharp, one would think, to be missed even by the dullest eye in Germany.

TRENTON, Jan. 1 -- Five New Year's celebrants were struck by an automobile early this morning as they were crossing a street in near-by Ewing Township and three were killed and two others injured, one critically.

During last month this column suggested ways of coping with the shortage of butter. Today, inasmuch as supplies have become even smaller han they were, it reviews some of these methods, and mentions new ones.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- With a tribute to his successor and to the 50,000 men and women of civil service whose combined efforts contribute toward the successful administration of the State Government, Charles Poletti, retired Governor, stepped down today from the office he held since Dec. 2.

Responding on their own initiative to the task of assuring a satisfactory level of employment in the post-war period and working on the premise that America must be prepared to provide in the neighborhood of 55,000,000 jobs, 9,000,000 more than in 1940, as soon as possible after hostilities cease, American business men have completed the basic organization of their own peace-planning group, the Committee for Economic Development.
AT UNITED NATION HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The noon communique:

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- Allied forces in the Buna sector of New Guinea have driven a second wedge through to the sea, splitting defending Japanese forces into three groups, and our bombers in a New Year's Day raid on Rabaul struck three Japanese merchantmen totaling 24,000 tons with 1,000-pound bombs, General MacArthur's noon communique said today.

Following is the text of Adolf Hitler's New Years message to the German people, as recorded from a German domestic broadcast yesterday over the Breslau radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
The first "Lohengrin" of the season will be performed at the Metropolitan Opera this afternoon. The opera tonight will be "Daughter of the Regiment."

George L. Allin, vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, expressed the belief yesterday that a proposed amendment to the Zoning Resolution now before the City Planning Commission would, if put into effect, "so frighten investors and lenders as to undermine property values and thereby impair not only the security of existing mortgages but also the foundation upon which the city's taxing and borrowing power is based."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Reporting on a two-year investigation of the petroleum industry, a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee today recommended the encouragement of increased production, higher ceiling prices greater incentives for discovering new sources, conservation of existing supplies by rationing, and public cooperation in curtailing the use of fuel.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- Virtually all of Philadelphia's hospitals have imposed compulsory vaccinations on their patients and personnel to prevent the first outbreak of smallpox since the last war from spreading into the city proper.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The A. and T. Aggies of Greensboro, N.C., came from behind to defeat the Southern University Jaguars of Baton Rouge, La., 14 to 6, before a crowd of 2,000 today in the annual Flower Bowl Negro football game.

CHERRY POINT, N.C., Jan. 1 -- For extraordinary heroism in leading Marine scout bombers against Japanese forces in the Battle of Midway in June, Major Marshall A. Tyler of Kingston, R.I., received the Navy Cross today at a colorful ceremony at the Marine air station here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The War Labor Board took the unprecedented step today of threatening the withdrawal of seniority rights from striking workers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Non-agricultural employment in the United States declined seasonally by 41,000 persons from mid-October to mid-November, but manufacturing employment increased 123,000 contraseasonally because of booming war production, it was announced today by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins.

EL PASO, Texas, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Outplayed the first half and trailing for more than three quarters, the red, white and blue clad Bombers of the Second Air Force rallied in the Sun Bowl football game today to score a 13-7 victory over Hardin-Simmons University, Border Conference champion.

CAIRO, Egypt Dec. 31 (Delayed) -- The old year of 1942 ended today like all other years of the African war, with the Allies apparently victorious, but, unlike other years, 1942 appears to have left the Axis no chance of staging a comeback on this continent.

Commencing tomorrow a "Universal Week of Prayer" will be observed in Protestant churches. The observance in the United States will be under the sponsorship of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, 297 Fourth Avenue, and it has been propagated by the council's department of evangelism.

Now in 1943, the curtain rises on a style scene that differs widely from that of a year ago, when we were still in a period of lavishness. The vastness of the war program is making itself felt now and all energies are focused on conservation.

With view to eliminating uncertainty concerning pricing rugs of unorthodox sizes that approximate the standard 9x12, some members of the trade have suggested to the Office of Price Administration that sales be discontinued on all odd sizes between 9'x10'6" and 9'x13'6", according to 9'x10'6" and 9'x13'6", according to A.G. Antolini, associate price executive in the regional office.
Raymond M. Dennis has been named assistant to the president of the By-Products Steel Corporation of Coatesville, Pa., a subsidiary of the Lukens Steel Company.

HONOLULU, Jan. 1 -- The third and biggest announced American raid on Wake Island since the Japanese captured that United States mid-Pacific base on Dec. 23, 1941, was made by a large force of Army heavy bombers early on the day before Christmas, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander of the Pacific Fleet and of American operations in this theatre, disclosed today.

POINT PLEASANT, W. Va., Jan. 1 -- The war factory town of Point Pleasant, its usual activity at a halt, took the full shock of the Ohio River flood tonight, while 100 miles upstream the time approached to clean up after a $1,500,000 loss.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 1 -- A general alarm fire here early today almost destroyed a four-story brick building and part of another structure housing stores, offices and apartments, at 328 to 348 Atlantic Street, in the heart of the business district.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 31 (Delayed) (AP) -- Two United States major generals, Lloyd R. Frendendall and Charles W. Ryder, today received the Distinguished Service Medal for "exceptionally meritorious service" in the North African war.

Citizens must be vigilant to strengthen trends toward democratic participation of workers, consumers and the public in our economic, political and cultural life, Dr. Harry W. Laidler, executive director of the League for Industrial Democracy, 112 East Nineteenth Street, said yesterday in a report listing advances and retreats in the democratic movement in America during 1942.
L Archbishop Francis J. Spellma i held his New Year's Day reception yesterday afternoon at the episcopal residence, 452 Madison Avenue.

Governor Dewey's first statement yesterday was a model of what a wartime inaugural ought to be. It was direct and sober. It pledged the unswerving loyalty of the new Republican Administration in this State to the President as Commander in Chief of the nation's war effort.

The market for new investments here was at a standstill this week -- no bond or stock issues were offered for public subscription. Absence of financing in the week contrasted with a single municipal bond issue of $350,000 offered last week and with $4,819,000 for three State and municipal bond issues marketed in this week a year ago.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- After the score had been tied at the end of the first and second periods, the Black Hawks tonight poured four goals through the net in the final chapter while the Rangers were counting three, and Chicago won a wild National Hockey League match, 6--5, before the largest crowd of the season here, 15,692.

WHERE has Philip Wylie been all these years? Here he is, ringing out the old year and blasting away already at the new, with a book which sounds like a regurgitation of everything that has been said about our civilization by every jaundiced Jeremiah from Count Keyserling (remember him?) to the thirty-odd contributors to Editor Harold Stearns's mani festo of the early Nineteen Twenties, "Civilization in the United States."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- One of President Roosevelt's many tasks as he starts the new year today is that of finding the men for nearly a score of important Federal positions which have become vacant in recent months.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace, stressing the growing friendship of Western Hemisphere nations, suggests that similar ideas of cooperation and harmony could prevail in all parts of the world. His views are contained in an article written for the mid-Winter number of The Los Angeles Times, published tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Many wage-earners who received monthly and semi-monthly pay checks today found cause for renewed New Year's celebrations in the fact that the Victory tax had not been deducted, as expected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System announced today its designations and appointments of chairmen and agents at the system's banks and branches for the new year.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 1 -- With the Republicans in control today of the Town Board after a year's eclipse, Milton L. Burns, an insurance broker of Riverhead and Supervisor of the township some years ago, was chosen successor to Joseph V. Kelly, who resigned as Supervisor last month to enter the Army.

More parents than teachers are now working at the Hunter College Elementary School. Dr. Florence Brumbaugh, principal, said yesterday, explaining that the scarcity of househhold help has caused parents to give up social activities, simplify their housekeeping and pay more attention to their children.

Dominick Taddio, 38-year-old war worker, being held by the Staten Island police in the murder of Mary Rycoitch, 19, whose body was found last Monday in a marshy field at Bloomfield, S.I., was taken to the prison ward at Bellevue Hospital last night from St. Vincent's Hospital, West New Brighton, after his arraignment, scheduled for yesterday had had to be postponed because of a severe cold.
MOSCOW, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique:

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Speaking in the Albert Hall at a pageant in aid of the British and Allied Red Cross funds today, Sir Stafford Cripps, Minister of Aircraft Production, said that the way to victory might be long and bitter, but declared that this people's war must be followed by a people's peace.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 1 -- The Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Park, a recreational waterfront area on Oyster Bay Harbor purchased several years ago by the National Roosevelt Memorial Association, was presented formally to the town of Oyster Bay at ceremonies this morning at the park.
The nation woke to its first 1943 headache yesterday and found that it wasn't much, compared with New Year's Day headaches of the past.

The beginning of a new year impels every one to take thought of time. At Christmas men look back, remembering; at the dawn of another year they look forward, into the opening perspective of the future. If any one lives today who can stand above the battle, he would hear the beat of tragic irony in the voices that rise on both sides of the line.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Pullman Company's fleet of sleeping and parlor cars was credited today by its president as largely responsible for meeting the unprecedented demand for movement of troops and civilians in the first year of the war.

State leaders of the Democratic party have combined to sponsor a program of social legislation. They ask, among other things, for a "Beveridge plan" for New York State. At the coming legislative session, they declare, the Democratic party will recommend a statutory commission to study the problem of social security and to make recommendations.

DETROIT, Jan. 1 -- One of the latest instruments of warfare which the former automobile industry is undertaking to adapt to production line assembly processes is a highly complicated device by which the fire of anti-aircraft batteries against enemy bombers is directed with deadly accuracy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Moving to meet a renewed critical gasoline and fuel oil shortage in the seventeen Eastern States which are under emergency rations, the War Production Board today assigned higher preference ratings to materials necessary for the production and distribution of petroleum products.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Thomas E. Dewey was inaugurated today as forty-seventh Governor of the State, and in his formal address pledged his administration to an "all-out" war effort, but at the same time served a warning on the National Administration that the State must be regarded as a partner rather than a minion of the Federal Government.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Williams and Syracuse divided honors in this snow-swept mountain town today as the annual men's college week ski meet, inaugurated twenty-two years ago by the Sno Birds of the Lake Placid Club, got under way.

President Roosevelt's proclamation setting aside the first day of the year for special prayers was answered here by all faiths yesterday as thousands appealed in places of worship for divine help in the emergency and asked for God's blessing on those in the service of the United Nations.

The Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria was the setting last night for the sixteenth annual Debutantes' New Year's Ball, a holiday party for debutantes of this city. Brooklyn, Long Island, Westchester, New Jersey and Connecticut, as well as from other cities in Eastern States.

You ran this morning a letter from Henry S. Churchill, chairman of a committee on city planning and zoning of the Citizens Housing Council, criticizing the selection of a site in South Harlem for the new Lexington Houses State project.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 31 (Delayed) -- Finance is a battlefield between the British and Indians and Calcutta, where Clive began the long British tradition, is seeing what may be the last stand of the powerful forces that have played a great role in the domination of India.

Because of their composition, shortenings cannot usually be substituted one for the other, measure for measure, without trouble ensuing. The demand of both war industries and the armed forces for technical and scientifically skilled workers has been reflected in the sharp increase in enrollment in science and engineering courses offered by New York's four municipal colleges -- City, Brooklyn, Hunter and Queens -- according to a report on curriculum changes made public yesterday by the Board of High Education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Success of the Treasury's war bond campaign led Senator Taft to declare today that proposals for compulsory savings ought to be abandoned in favor of an intensive drive to raise voluntary purchases of government securities.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- Philadelphia's gay Mummers, star-spangled and light-hearted despite the war which depleted their ranks, cake-walked and clowned up Broad Street today in their last fling for the duration.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- British patrols clashed Wednesday with enemy patrols both east and west of the Mayu River near Rathedaung, twenty-five miles northwest of the Burmese port of Akyab, it was announced officially today.

WITH THE UNITED STATES AIR FORCES in China, Dec. 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Japanese troop and supply center of Mengmao, thirty miles west of the Salween River in Western Yunnan Province, was virtually blasted off the map today as United States bombers and fighters continued their sweeps of the Burma-Yunnan border area.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 -- Bright Gallant, a one-time plater that Trainer Hirsch Jacobs developed into a stakes winner last season, carried Isidore Bieber's silks to a five-length triumph in the mile and a sixteenth Orange Bowl Handicap before 6,681 racegoers at Tropical Park this morning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Tennessee Valley Authority reported today that it is now producing power at the rate of l0,00,000,00 kilowatt hours annually.

The classification of Admiral Darlan as an opportunist is too simple. His classification as a Fascist is likewise too simple. We must give to France and Frenchmen the same motivation that inspires patriots everywhere, be they the "men of Vichy," de Gaullists, English or American.
DETROIT, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Henry Ford predicted in a New Year's Day statement today the ultimate creation of a world parliament "to put the world on a peace basis."

Post-New Year's Day sermons will be preached tomorrow in the churches of New York City. Clergymen will suggest in their discourses that substitutes for "Happy New Year" be "Victorious New Year" and "Blessed New Year." Prayers for victory for the United Nations followed by a "just and righteous peace" before New Year's 1944 will be offered together with petitions for a New Year's blessing upon every member of our armed forces.

The six-story apartment house at 2111 Albermarle Road, in Brooklyn, containing 300 rooms divided into ninety-four suites, has been acquired by an investing client of Murray Adler, broker, subject to a first mortgage of $350,000 held by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank. Isidore Brown was co-broker.
MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- Permit me through the medium of your columns to address the following New Year's greetings to the American reading public:

MOSCOW, Saturday, Jan. 2 -- Velikiye Luki, strongly held city on the central front only ninety miles from the Latvian border, and Elista, capital of the desolate Kalmuck Republic below Stalingrad, have been captured by the Russians in smashing new victories in the northwest and south of Russia, a special Soviet communique said early today.

PATERSON, N.J. Jan. 1 -- The Office of War Information announced today that the Bouchard Charvet Dye Finish Company and the Associated Dyeing Printing Company of New Jersey, both Paterson firms, had been denied the right to order or accept deliveries of anthraquinone dye for a three-month period beginning today because of "willful violations" of conservation orders issued by the War Production Board.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Brandywine's Stable's Madigama, in a thrilling race with four other sprinters today, won the Sugar Bowl Handicap, $1,200 added feature of the Fair Grounds first morning program, by a nose from A.J. Sackett's Richmond, with Eric Guerin up, before 10,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Smaller War Plants Division of the War Production Board reported today that for the period from Dec. 18 to Dec. 26, inclusive, prime war contracts of a value of $9,500,000 were placed with seventy-three firms, while subcontracts with a value of $3,700,000 went to 118 companies.

SAN SALVADOR -- The "Primer Congreso Nacional Eucaristico de El Salvador" (First National Eucharistic Congress of Salvador) series, issued to commemorate that gathering on Nev. 23-26, comprises 8-centavos blue (quantity 100,000) for regular postage and 30c orange (50,000) for air-mail use.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 2 -- Boasting its best snow conditions since 1935 for this time of the Winter season, this usually serene Vermont community was buzzing with activity today as skiers descended upon the Snow Valley and Big Bromley developments.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 2 -- George Hinman, sailing Could Be, had a three-point edge over Ed Raymond in Achilles at the end of the second series of races in the three-day twelfth anniversary Frostbite Yacht Club dinghy regatta at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today.

Common soda pop gas -- carbon dioxide -- is being used to reduce flight hazards of war pilots. Its use to inflate rubber rafts and in automatic fire-extinguishing systems has already been officially credited with saving the lives of many fliers.

Although all war and civilian demands for lumber were met in 1942 and probably will be met in 1943, due to the general decline in building, Government authorities will have to move soon if adequate supplies are to be available in later years, according to Wilson Compton, vice president and manager of American Forest Products Industries, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Pearl Harbor stepped up the nation's thought on problems relating to total mobilization for total war. Of these problems none was greater than the one bearing the general title of "manpower."

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 2 -- Councilman Clarence E. Gates, a member of the committee that supervised the planning and construction of the new $1,000,000 City Hall opened here last year, advocated this week that the city offices be moved back to the old municipal building instead of heeding an OPA edict to convert its heating plant from oil to coal.

Most of the guests in khaki and navy blue hold up the closing hour of the USO clubhouse operated by the Jewish Welfare Board by stopping to say a hearty thank-you all around. But one of the more than 100,000 visitors in the past eleven months has made his mark because he was bent on repaying in kind.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Dec. 30 (Delayed) -- The Japanese are losing the advantage of concealment on the Buna front. American and Australian forces have now squeezed the enemy into such small pockets that positions and movements can be closely observed.

During the first year of the war the United States got the bulk of its tremendous industrial facilities on an all-out basis. There are still formidable problems to solve but by and large our industrial decks are cleared for a year of capacity war production.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 2 -- Sir Harold MacMichael, High Commissioner for Palestine, warned Jews and Arabs in his New Year's message that the Atlantic Charter was a charter of freedom but that it did not mean license.

If the law of probability means what statisticians think it does, Japan may experience a severe earthquake within the next year or so, said Fordham University's seismological authority, Rev. J.S. Lynch, S.J., in a recent General Electric Forum.

INTO this story has gone a bit of that magic which Hans Christian Andersen was in the habit of using to turn everyday things into a fairy tale. Around a wax model wearing beautiful gowns in a shop window and two little motherless children, Ferenc Molnar has built a romantic little story with an element of wonder that holds the interest of the 8-to-10-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The arrest this week of a dozen persons in the interest of internal security in North Africa, and the warning of the urgent need of food and clothing for the civil population if serious trouble is to be avoided, drew attention sharply to the confusion and disunity in which Frenchmen find themselves in that theatre of war and elsewhere.
The automatic cloth laying machine, produced by the Cutting Room Appliances Corporation of New York City, has been speeding production in plants manufacturing war materials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The United States begins the new year with "the soundest economic structure in its history," and with increases in the cost of living still being held to moderate proportions despite the pressure for inflation caused by tremendously increased farmer and worker incomes, Leon Henderson, retiring Federal Price Administrator, asserted in a yearend review today.

Wendell L. Willkie demanded yesterday a United Nations council of grand military strategy on which each of those nations would be represented and through which the ideals of the year-old United Nations pact would be accomplished on a realistic basis after the war.

The colors of most insects are pigments, much like those we use in paints. But in some other insects the colors are produced by interference effects of light-waves like those we see in soap-bubbles and mother-of-pearl. Physicists use finely ruled gratings to obtain these same effects in the laboratory.

In a simple ceremony yesterday at the Essex House, George F. Buskie, special assistant to the directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, received the Order of Honor and Merit of the Red Cross from Roberto Hernandez, the Cuban Consul-General, on behalf of the National Red Cross of Cuba.

American industry, in the prosecution of the war, had the most active year in its history. Production, sales, employment and wages shattered all previous records. Reflecting the peak operations, earnings before taxes climbed to new highs. Net income, however, was reduced from the preceding year through increased taxes assisted by higher operating expenses and conversion costs.

Despite wartime scarcities of sugar, cork, metal crowns and the emergency problems arising through the shortage of manpower and transportation, the soft drink industry is looking forward to a continuance of its activities because of its importance in the maintenance of military and civilian morale, according to Walter S. Mack Jr., president of the Pepsi-Cola Company.

British take the offensive in North Africa and drive back Rommel's Nazi troops. Senate passes tax bill to yield about $8,500,000,000 by the Treasury's estimate and $9,600,000,000 by the estimate of Congressional comittees. Vote was unanimous in both houses.

The Russians have named this, the second wartime Winter, the "Orphan's Winter." It has been kind to the poor and homeless. It has been mild so far by comparison with other Winters. There has been biting weather, but nothing like that of the first Winter of the war, the coldest in 150 years.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Ohio River flood, which already has driven 50,000 persons from homes along its banks and hampered war industries, crested tonight 1.1 feet from the top of the 62-foot wall protecting this manufacturing city of 40,400.

DETROIT, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- The Chrysler Corporation advised the War Labor Board today that it opposed writing union shop, check-off and compulsory arbitration provisions into its contract with the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.).

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 2 -- A significant shake-up in Germany's diplomatic representation abroad was announced in Berlin today with the retirement of Ambassador Eberhard von Stohrer from Madrid, of General Eugen Ott from the Tokyo Embassy and of Prince Viktor zu Wied, German Minister in Stockholm, Sweden.

Retail trade last year reached the unprecedented dollar total of $56,000,000,000, an increase of 3 to 4 per cent over the previous peak noted in 1941. National income rose to an estimated $117,000,000,000, up 28 per cent over 1941. Savings topped $26,000,000,000, an all-time high.

Women serving with the armed forces, including the Waves, Waacs, Spars and Army Nurses, will receive for the first time as a group the same entertainment privileges that have been accorded service men, on Friday afternoon at the New York Vassar Club's annual scholarship benefit concert at the Metropolitan Opera House where Jascha Heifetz, violinist, will be the artist.

Accusing Mayor La Guardia of trying to take over the administration of the public schools, the New York Teachers Guild declared yesterday that the Mayor was usurping the powers of the Board of Education. The guild charged the Mayor with evading his responsibility and of "confusing the public."

HICKAM FIELD, Hawaii, Jan. 2 -- When his big Army bomber took off to raid Wake Island the night of Dec. 23-24, Second Lieutenant Louis Zamperini, collegiate and Olympic Games track star, was not as scared as he had been before his races against Glenn Cunningham, Gene Venzke and Chuck Fenske, he said here today.

Portable steel runways, made by the National Gypsum Company, are enabling American bombers and fighters to get into action quickly from advanced positions in swampy or desert areas. The "magic carpets" are being turned out on redesigned presses which in peacetime produced metal lath for walls.

The outlook for total tea supplies in 1943 is "extremely favorable," with 103,000,000 pounds likely to be available during the year, according to Benjamin Wood, managing director of the tea bureau. Since April 1 of last year American tea drinkers -- about 75 per cent of the adult population -- have voluntarily reduced their tea purchases by 30 per cent, but a further cut is required, he said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Navy made known today that the Waves, its women's auxiliary branch, would have an enrollment at least 50 per cent larger than the previously announced total of 25,000 members and that a nationwide recruiting campaign already had been inaugurated.

In the Dec. 24 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Harold Callender wrote about the visit to this country of Poland's Prime Minister, General Sikorski, using this occasion for throwing some light on the views of the Polish Opposition and Poland's situation in general.

The Grenfell Association of America will benefit from a concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra, with Eugene Ormandy conducting and with Marjorie Lawrence and Freidrich Schorr as soloists, on the night of Feb. 16 at Carnegie Hall. Mrs. Basil B. Elmer is executive chairman in charge of all arrangements and Mrs. Andrew Carnegie is honorary chairman.

It is at that season of the year when the thermometer is likely to drop to its lowest that styles are set for Summer beach play clothes. Play togs are to be found in most of the department stores, but departments are no longer labeled Miami, Palm Beach or Winter Resort. They are called North and South, and they hint at the journeyings of wives to the Southern camps to visit their husbands.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The Admiralty kept silent today on unsupported German claims of success in a running clash on the Russian convoy route north of Norway, in which the Nazis reported that they had torpedoed four cargo ships, sunk a destroyer and damaged several cruisers and destroyers.

COOCH BEHAR, India, Jan. 2 -- The year has ended with the Indian political situation more hopelessly deadlocked than ever. The Indian Nationalists must feel that there is only one ray of light on the horizon -- the appointment of William Phillips as head of an American diplomatic mission here.
