Those who like to see what a connoisseur selects in the way of antique furnishings will doubtless find it worth their while to take in the Conde Nast sale, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

By winning the eleventh game of his match with Isaac I. Kashdan at the Marshall Chess Club last night, Samuel Reshevsky, with a score of 7 1/2 -- 3 1/2, regained full possession of the United States chess championship which he had shared since April with Kashdan as co-winner of the national title tournament at the Hotel Astor.

John Bryan, actor, artist and grandson of William Jennings Bryan, was found dead at 3:10 A.M. yesterday in his one-room studio apartment at 23 West Ninth Street. Although the police at first suspected foul play and listed the death as "suspicious," an autopsy revealed that Mr. Bryan had died naturally and injuries on his body were old ones.

Although the United States has passed through one of the most turbulent years in history, its financial markets are functioning freely, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, has declared in a year-end statement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A picture, drawn by the Office of War Information, of British women at war work which is likely to reflect "much of tomorrow's picture of American women at work," shows that 40 per cent of all British production workers are women and that the figure is rising to a point at which it soon will equal that of men.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 -- The Security-First National Bank of Los Angeles reported today that deposits on Dec. 31, last, reached the highest level in its history at $806,484,204, an increase of $139,917,948 during 1942. Total resources increased $133,357,869.

In one of the most trying periods in its history the advertising field went through a painful conversion last year from its normal peacetime pursuit of selling goods to a full wartime basis as an important adjunct to the government's war effort.

ANY ONE with a misguided notion that screen reviewers are a bored and jaded lot, indifferent to good motion pictures and lacking perceptive taste, should look in upon a fast session of the New York Film Critics at a year's end, when the boys and girls are making their selections of the year's best cinema jobs.

Through the efforts of the Greek War Relief Association more than 80,000 tons of foodstuffs plus considerable quantities of medical supplies and concentrated vitamin units have been shipped in the last nine months from this country and Canada to Greece in an effort to relieve the plight of that country and stave off the starvation of its people, it was announced yesterday by Spyros P. Skouras, president of the association.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Formation of a new Yugoslav Cabinet with Premier Slobodan Yovanovitch taking over the duties of Foreign Minister in place of Dr. Momcilo Nincitch and with General Draja Mikhailovitch continuing as Minister of the Army, Navy Air Force, was announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (Delayed). THERE used to be a time when British films were strictly parochial. Their wilder dissipations included afternoon tea with the vicar, and a shootin' party with a brace of earls. No actor could get a part in them unless he was practically inaudible, in the too, too English accent of the West End stage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A ceremony marking the sesquicentennial of the birth of Lucretia Mott, a pioneer in equal rights for women, and dedicated to equal rights for women throughout the world, was held in the crypt of the Capitol this afternoon under the direction of the National Woman's party and the World Woman's Party for Equal Rights.

Recent events on the various battle fronts inspire the confidence that the victorious end of the war may be nearer than pessimists expected a few months ago. Thus plans for the establishment of a more satisfactory postwar order become more urgent. It is a mistake to assume that it is too early to discuss them seriously before the totalitarian aggressors are completely defeated.

Rising war production and rising national income with supplies of civilian goods at depression levels, in the opinion of Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, will force this country into completely controlled and planned economy in 1943.

Hedges are coming into their own at last, and it's high time. This business of allowing one's garden to leak out on all sides is all very well for a series of twenty-five-foot lots. A place does not deserve the name "home" until it is enclosed along its boundaries or at least has a suggestion of segregation from the surrounding properties or landscape.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, WPB chief, has set the placing of at least $1,000,000,000 in contracts as the goal of the Smaller War Plants Corporation in 1943 and the directorate may be reshuffled for greater efficiency.

New plants of its own and government-owned plants which it supervises have increased the output of explosives of the Hercules Powder Company about 1,000 per cent since the outbreak of war. The company has undertaken to design, construct and operate Federal-owned ordnance facilities with an estimated cost of more than $400,000,000.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP) -- A dejected Boston College squad and some of the happy Alabama football players headed for home today, verbally replaying the spectacular Orange Bowl game, which the Southerners won, 37 to 21.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- When the weather man gives a snowy start to this mammoth playground in the city's back yard, Bear Mountain Park is expecting a boom. Wartime restrictions of gasoline, rubber and rail transportation have darkened the prospects for most of the resorts farther north, but this accessible park is expecting to attract a large turnout of snow and ice enthusiasts this season.

On April 28 the President signed Public Law 528, known as the Sixth Supplemental National Defense Appropriation Act, 1942. Among its general provisions was a section authorizing and directing the principal munitions procurement agencies to insert in any contract for more than $100,000 a provision for the renegotiation of the contract price at a period or periods when the profits can be determined with reasonable accuracy.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 2 -- The Defense Ministry revealed today that it had been sending officer observers to the various Pacific war fronts. Recently two officers returned from New Guinea, where they studied jungle fighting, and the visit of a military mission to the Solomon Islands also was made known.

Spotlighted by a pair of Madison Square Garden double-headers, basketball activity in this area will be greatly accelerated this week. The Garden twin bills, slated for Wednesday and Saturday nights, will be featured by two important intracity encounters pitting City College against St. John's and N.Y.U. against Manhattan.

A new and unusual chapter in banking service in the United States is about to open. A radical departure from time-honored banking tradition will occur some time this month when a system of nation-wide "ration banking" will be established as a wartime measure, with the commercial banks of the country cooperating with the Office of Price Administration.

Pan American-Grace Airways, Inc., known throughout Latin America as "Panagra," achieved in 1942 two notable goals. The first was the increase of service from four to seven flights a week between the Canal Zone and Buenos Aires via the West Coast of South America.

AN EAST COAST PORT, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Nineteen crewmen from a British merchant vessel, the survivors of two torpedoings, spent seventeen days in lifeboats in the South Atlantic Ocean far off the coast of South America last month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 26 were 591,595 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 151,316 cars, or 20.4 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 14,907 cars, or 2.5 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 46,288 cars, or 8.5 per cent, more than in the corresponding week two years ago.

The annual card party arranged by the Ladies Auxiliary of Seton and Nazareth Hospitals, which are located on the Hudson River Parkway, will be held on the afternoon of Jan. 16 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The funds realized will be used to purchase supplies for the general maintenance of the institutions, which provide care for 550 men, women and children suffering from tuberculosis.

The Artemisias or, to give them one of their common names, the Wormwoods have been grown in gardens for many, many years for their aromatic and medicinal virtues and for their ornamental foliage effects. Their dried leaves in earlier days were hung in little bags in wardrobes to drive away moths and other bothersome insects.

To supply the 500,000 barrels of oil required daily for the essential needs of the 12,500,000 inhabitants of the New York metropolitan area under present transportation handicaps is going to be one of the great tasks of the next few months.

Basketball without rhyme or reason, irrational, irresponsible and certainly the wildest ever witnessed at Madison Square Garden, was in evidence last night as Ed Kelleher's Fordham Rams went on a record-breaking spree before a record-breaking crowd of 18,394 spectators.

" THE WISDOM OF CHINA AND INDIA" is a truly magnificent book. It abounds in beauty and charm, both in the material selected and in the manner in which it is edited. Here one can enjoy Dr. Lin Yutang's enchanting style of writing and his poetic conception of life, already so exquisitely expressed in his "The Importance of Living" and other books.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The taking of the oath of office yesterday by Thomas E. Dewey as Governor of New York meant more than a simple change of the personnel administering the State government. It was an important milestone in State political history, vitally affecting the future of the Democratic, Republican and possibly American Labor parties.

IN 1942, its first full year of war, American radio gave a pretty good account of itself, it was noted here last Sunday. Did it? There is a difference of opinion. During the week just past this column has been reading Sherman H. Dryer's new book, "Radio in Wartime" (New York: Greenberg, Publisher), and it is plain to see that Mr. Dryer regards radio's 1942 performance as less than satisfactory.
The First National Bank of New York is now a billion-dollar institution, increasing to eight the number of Wall Street banks in this classification.

The manufacturers of York, Pa., have turned that community into an arsenal and have demonstrated how rapidly American industry can be converted to war work. The community entered the battle of production well equipped with a wide variety of machines in its metal working plants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- United States submarines, hunting in the waters of the Pacific and the Far East for the ships on which Japan's long lines of communications depend, have damaged an enemy destroyer and sent seven more enemy cargo and transport ships to the bottom, a Navy communique announced today.

EDGEWOOD ARSENAL, Md., Jan. 2 -- After a sobering demonstration of the unpleasant potentialities of chemical war here at the "brain cell" of the Army's Chemical Warfare Branch, Major Gen. William N. Porter, Chief of Chemical Warfare Service, speaking with extreme confidence, asserted that the Axis never would catch America napping in the field of poison gas.

The leather and shoe industry believes that it has geared itself to meet the civilian demand for this year, despite the heavy burden which has been placed upon it for military and lease-lend orders, leaders in the business stated in viewing the outlook for 1943.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 2 -- George L. Rihl, vice president of Pan American Airways, said here today that Panair do Brasil, a Brazilian subsidiary of Pan American Airways, would be reorganized with the capital increased to $1,500,000.

The total production of electrical manufacturers, including both electrical and other war materiel, surged upward to a new high in 1942, with an estimated 50 per cent increase over 1941, according to W.J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

The can-making industry has been streamlined to the needs of the Victory campaign as a vital accessory to the production of a most important munition of war, namely, food, according to J.F. Hartlieb, president of Continental Can Company, Inc.

The New York Metropolitan Milk Distributors Bargaining Agency professed last night to be so confused by press reports of the increases in retail store milk price ceilings allowed by the Office of Price Administration as of tomorrow that members were unable to say how the order would affect distribution in this area.

Beset by a host of problems which are increased rather than mitigated by continued expansion of consumer purchasing power, thousands of buyers representing stores all over the country will arrive in the wholesale markets here during the next two weeks to place orders for Spring merchandise.

HOLLYWOOD. A MAN is fortunate if he has but one regret in a lifetime. This is the ease with Felix Bernstein, formerly of Berlin, now a cinema expert on things Nazi. As MGM's representative in Central Europe for many years it was his habit to walk down the Hedemannstrasse to his office at 225 Frederickstrasse.

Present conversations among the United Nations on reconstruction policies should aim at the completion of agreements before the war ends and while the governments are still bound together as comrades in arms, Eugene P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council, declared in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.
I READ with interest about the choruses of factory workers described in the music section of last Sunday's TIMES.

Club owners of the National and American Leagues, still apparently groping for a solution to their scrambled 1943 baseball plans, last night were looking with confidence to an early clarification of their problems.

The women's apparel industries had a relatively good year in 1942, sharing in the expanded consumer demand for "soft goods." However, as the year ended the garment trades were wrestling with intricacies of the new OPA order, MPR 287, which cut mark-ups and required voluminous record-keeping.

In a million American homes and hundreds of thousands of American factories and farms, the United States is today fashioning the noose with which the barbaric ambitions of the Axis powers will be strangled. Individual effort makes up the first fine strands; whether it be in the form of military service, industrial production, farm labor, volunteer service or financial contributions.

July was largely made up of efforts to frame the tax bill, which in the end passed the House and was for $6,271,000,000, whereas the Treasury had asked for $8,700,000,000. Tax bill then went into the hands of the Senate, which was expected to make up the difference.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Upsets and high scores featured British football games today as many teams beaten in the Boxing Day qualifying round play last Saturday avenged their losses. The cup competition involves the leagues of northern and eastern England.

The American farmers remembered, Pearl Harbor. In the first year of war they harnessed Mother Nature to the grocery wagon of the United Nations and drove down the road toward victory, delivering along the way bumper harvests that broke all previous records for the production of food in this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Treasury Department's December Victory Fund Drive for $9,000,000,000 resulted in subscriptions of $12,906,000,000, or nearly $4,000,000,000 more than the goal set for the campaign, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

As a man away past his three-quarter-century mark I try to be of use by breeding new food-bearing trees. From Toronto to Miami I found the cry was for butter, and I noted in a recent issue of THE TIMES that in Detroit butter sold at $1.25 a pound.

Convinced that misunderstanding of the actual functions of wholesale distributors is reflected in the Vinson bill (H.R. 7304), as well as in some activities of Army, Navy, WPB and OPA officials, more than twenty separate organizations of wholesalers have begun to coordinate a program of public relations intended to rectify the situation, it was learned yesterday.

A SEASONAL inquiry into the subject of children's parties reveals, as usual, that the fun and laughter of these merry little gatherings carry an undercurrent of woe for parents. It includes the familiar perplexities over early teen-age demands -- of girls for high heels and lipstick, of boys for the prerogative of taking a girl home in a taxi.

Once a great peacetime business making motors and fans, a Midwestern unit of the American war arsenal has converted its facilities and engaged subcontractors for the large-scale production of power-driven machine-gun turrets for fighting planes.

It has become one of the commonplaces of our time that in order to win a total war a nation must have at its disposal an adequate supply of trained manpower for the armed forces, for war production, for agricultural production and for the production of essential consumer goods and services.

Stock market trading had no "wheel horses" last year. The twenty most active stocks on the New York Stock Exchange accounted for only 18 per cent of the total sales volume, the lowest percentage in history, contrasting with 20 per cent in 1941, with 65 per cent in 1917 and with 62 per cent in 1918.

What are genes -- the particles in every cell that transmit such hereditary traits as tallness or shortness, blue eyes, dark or light skin? Chemicals surely. But what chemicals? Evidence was accumulated by Drs. Alfred E. Mirsky (Rockefeller Institute) and Arthur W. Pollister (University of Chicago) that they are composed of plasmonin, the material of which the gene-containing chromosomes are made.

Anxiety over the welfare of their men at sea, coupled with reduced incomes has piled one difficulty on another for Navy wives and mothers. A number of them, however, have found a solution to both problems in the consultant bureau of the New York City Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States, which has placed 230 in jobs here in the past five months.

One of man's oldest known materials -- glass -- is supplying many of the United Nations' war needs. Few industries were confronted with a more difficult problem than the flat glass industry, but today, through the rapid development of new techniques, glass is fulfilling an important role in the production of planes, ships, guns, precision instruments and other war materials.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- America after the war will have to take world leadership. No other nation will be physically or mentally capable of doing it.

The Parker Rust Proof Company reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended with September a net profit of $862,018 after taxes and other deductions, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $2 a share on the common stock.

The Postoffice Department made available last week a photograph of the "United Nations" 2-cents red stamp which will be released on Jan. 14 to pay tribute "to those nations which, with the United States, are joined in a determined effort to overcome the enemies of democracy and civilization."

The electrical equipment industry in 1942 achieved by far the greatest production victory in its history, George H. Bucher, president of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, declared yesterday. "I am confident," he added, "that the industry will even better its record in 1943 and and will continue to produce in increasing amounts the equipment essential to winning the war."

Individual awards to men on the production lines for new ideas and suggestions for speeding up manufacture of war materials and increasing the efficiency of plant operation were made by the War Production Board during the last year to scores of workers.

" Reorganization rails" stood in the market spotlight last year and garnered most of the speculative applause. "War babies" as a group sold off. "Peace stocks" receded, advanced and receded, finishing the year strong. But the bonds of companies going through reorganizations held speculative interest throughout, even though price performances were not so regular as chart-readers might have wished.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Details of two daring low-level attacks by Flying Fortresses on Japanese warships were related by the War Department today in announcing the award of decorations to thirty-eight officers and men for gallantry in the Southwest Pacific fighting.

In the coming twelve months, the civilized world, from both a social and business standpoint, should have some idea as to what its future will be, H.L. Brooks, president of the Toilet Goods Association and head of Coty, Inc., said in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The War Production Board, which is directing the mobilization of American industry for war, was established by President Roosevelt on Jan. 16, 1942, to assure "the most effective prosecution of war procurement and war production." Donald M. Nelson was named as chairman.

The turn of the year finds the war outlook far more favorable to the United Nations than any one even two months ago had dared to hope. In every theatre of war the Axis is on the defensive; and it is in the most important theatre -- Russia -- that the success of the United Nations forces in the last week has been most sensational.

Although the type and volume of Latin-American commercial credit transactions during 1942 were considerably influenced by wartime factors, the majority of exporters continued to provide liberal terms, according to Philip J. Gray, manager of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau, in a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Summarizing the 1942 activities of British Commandos, American Rangers and other troops trained to raid Axis installations abroad, the Combined Operations Command of the British Army asserted last night that the work would be continued on an even larger scale this year.

The Brooklyn Botanic Garden's new series of radio broadcasts, which are given over Station WNYC on alternate Fridays at 3:30 P.M., will begin this Friday Dr. Arthur Harmount Graves is to speak on "The Story of Rubber."
Increased emphasis on the promotion of wines during 1943 may be expected as a result of the conversion of distillers' facilities to the manufacture of industrial alcohol for war needs.

A nation-wide network of ship in air yards coordinated through the government agency formed several months before we entered the war is keeping both old and new ships in serviceable condition for this country and all the United Nations.

THE comment of Mr. Reves of the Cooperation Publishing Company, printed in the Book Review of Nov. 29, on my discussion of Starhemberg's "Between Hitler and Mussolini," raises certain issues of fact and opinion.

New bond financing in 1942 was the smallest of any year since 1933 and amounted to approximately $1,250,000,000. The 1941 total of new bonds publicly offered was $2,091,023,000. As was the case in the years immediately preceding, State and municipal issues last year accounted for a larger volume than any other classification of new bond financing.

Prices now being paid for furs at country collection points are at the "danger point" if the buyers intend to observe the OPA price ceilings, J.D. Silberman, president of the American Fur Merchants Association and head of the Silberman Fur Corporation, declared in a special statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- As the New Year opens under better auspices than those of the immediate past, thoughtful people in London are beginning to ponder over a problem that will inevitably face the United Nations when it becomes time to rehabilitate the countries of Europe now suffering under Nazi occupation.

EDD WINFIELD PARKE repeats, in appraising Henry Timrod's essays, the accepted theory that a poet's prose has a double value. Struggling with a mixed ancestry of English, German, Irish and Swiss, Timrod, the weak son of a bookbinder of Charleston, had a tumultuous life with little success or relaxation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- Senator Taft of Ohio said tonight that the new Congress should start work immediately after convening on a new tax bill which could stand unchanged for the duration.

THE New York Rangers and the Chicago Black Hawks trade body checks and goals in Madison Square Garden tonight, a news item which is hardly likely to cause any traffic jams or bring out the police reserves. Neither team is too elegantly situated in the standings at the moment.

Constantly beset by orders and warnings from Washington, the home furnishings industry nevertheless struggled through 1942 to finish one of the best years in its history. This was especially true at the manufacturing level, where factories, despite growing material and labor shortages, were able to turn out millions of dollars' worth of war materiel, at the same time shipping almost as much civilian goods as in 1941, a year which set all-time records.

ARTUR RODZINSKI, who comes with brilliant past accomplishments to his credit to be the single controlling conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony next season, has his work cut out for him. Aside from his tasks of interpretation before an exacting public, he has musical discipline to restore and a deteriorated orchestra to rebuild.

The emphasis placed upon the production of steel for war by both government and industry has to a certain extent relegated to the background the vital part being played in the war program by an important sideline of the steel industry, the production of coke by-products.

Thousands of American manufacturing companies and plants of all kinds and sizes, converted from making many varied types of peacetime goods, have participated in the production of guns, shells, small arms ammunition, motor vehicles and miscellaneous munitions of every conceivable kind.

If prior to the current war the United States had been contemplating war or had been a warlike nation, we would have regimented our industries and so regulated production as to make it possible to mobilize our industrial effort immediately upon the declaration of war.

Technical books, considered in peacetime the poor relations of the book business, being outshone by the novels and other general trade publications, have solidly reinstated themselves in the book family during thirteen months of war and have gone on to become one of the important contributing forces on the production lines at home and the battlefronts abroad.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 2 -- Leaving hardly a doubt of the true meaning of the replacement of the German Minister here, Prince Viktor zu Wied, by the former Nazi Charge d'Affaires in Washington, Dr. Hans Thomsen -- to bring increased pressure on Sweden -- the Nazi-controlled S.T.B. Agency reported from Berlin today that competent circles there said the Thomsen appointment arose from an "Anglo-American propaganda offensive in Sweden."

WHEN Dimitri Mitropoulos appears as piano soloist in Prokofieff's Third piano concerto at the concerts he conducts Wednesday and Friday with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall, he will be heard for the first time here at the keyboard.

Too long for this page is a poem received from Professor Encycle. It begins: "There always is something, some unforeseen dumb thing to jolt an economist's pride. For instance, let's mutter of money and butter. Why is it they can't coincide?"

TORONTO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Toronto's Maple Leafs took over first place in the National Hockey League, one point ahead of the idle Boston Bruins, by scoring a 6-3 triumph over Montreal before 11,703 tonight.

At the beginning of 1942, the Malay peninsula was abandoned to invading Japanese. Manila also fell. Roberts special investigating committee placed blame for Japanese surprise of Dec. 7 on Admiral Kimmel and Lieut. Gen. Short. Parliament gave Churchill vote of confidence by 464 to 1. President, in budget message, asked for $9,000,000,000 new taxes.

BY this time, it seems reasonable to believe, you are aware of a young radio writer named Ranald MacDougall, whose current Wednesday night series for WABC-Columbia, "The Man Behind the Gun," has caused a deal of comment along Radio Row.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- Allied air forces, paced by American units, are blasting Japanese installations and communications in a non-stop aerial offensive spanning Burma, official reports disclosed today.

The Rogers Peet Company has signed a long-term renewal ground lease on its store property at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue land Forty-first Street, running through to Forty-second Street, Phillips R. Turnbull, president of the firm, announced yesterday.

Originally regarded as a relatively inexpensive luxury fiber because its early years of expanded output found readiest usage in the women's apparel field, American-made rayon "came of age" in 1942 when war-born necessity to conserve vital rubber supplies focused the nation's attention on high tenacity properties of the synthetic fiber hitherto known only to the comparatively few who kept abreast of recent improvements.

Shareholders in 1942, already burdened with higher income and surtax rates, had their incomes further reduced by another tax, indirectly administered. Incomes from dividends were smaller in the year due to a decline in net earnings caused primarily by a rise of nearly 40 per cent in corporate taxes

Price control in 1943, now in a transitional stage, appears headed toward a dollars and cents-fixed mark-up system supplanting the General Maximum Price Regulation. Simplification of technique has been promised and there may be a trend away from "straitjacket" regulations involving highly complex rules.

RICHARD KOLLMAR, one-third of the "By Jupiter" sponsorship, is about to take a solo plunge into the Broadway producing stream. After making several false starts he has almost made up his mind to do "And So to Bedlam." A little over a year ago Michael Todd was talking seriously of presenting this one.

An industry which has been centered in Germany and Czechoslovakia and developed here since the war started is producing delicate instruments and precision optics in a loft building in one of New York City's side streets, among other places.

Increased demand and decreased facilities for distribution are among the principal problems facing the brewing industry in 1943, according to Alvin Griesedieck, chairman of the Brewing Industry Foundation. Because of these problems, beer sales are not likely to keep pace with the rising national income.

Since before Pearl Harbor it was clear that radio, which moves with the speed of light, was vital to this modern warfare of lightning moves. A glance at the rest of the world would have told even the casual observer that. The leaders of this country's armed forces were, of course, entirely aware of it and were making their plans accordingly.

The country's shipyards are now "the No. 1 customer of the steel industry," according to H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, in a review of the year's shipbuilding achievements made public last week.

Price ceilings, restricted quantities of some merchandise and the complete disappearance of other goods, changes and scarcity of personnel, added taxes, the freezing of wages, the imminence of inventory control, the beginning of rationing are only a few of the new problems that have confronted merchants, according to Earl C. Sams, president of the J.C. Penny Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission continued from its new home here during the first year of the war the relentless administration of the several acts within its jurisdiction.

In a suburb of a large steel center a company that has been making automobile springs and bumpers for twenty-nine years has become the "parent" of a group of its former competitors organized to make armor plate for tanks in huge quantities.

Since the middle Nineteen Twenties the commercial airlines of the United States have been the envy of the world and the model for all nations when they attempted to set up their own air transport routes. The lines hold the same high position today, but in addition, they have demonstrated how great a contribution a highly developed air system can make to a nation at war.

Simplification of pace control and application by the WPB of the principle of stockpiling to civilian goods are essential to distribution in 1943, according to a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Dr. David R. Craig, president of the American Retail Federation.

During 1942 the Celanese Corporation of America made many contributions of a scientific and experimental nature in the chemical, textile and plastics fields which will be accentuated during 1943, according to Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- Thousands of gypsies in the remote regions of Argentina's pampas are systematically raiding ranches of Axis sympathizers, selling cattle and sheep they seize and sending the proceeds to General Draja Mikhailovitch, Yugoslav guerrilla leader, Nadry Vidianu, a gypsy chief, said today.

Employment agencies here last week estimated that since the start of the war sales forces formerly employed by manufacturers, selling agencies and wholesalers have been reduced almost 50 per cent, but explained the figure might be misleading because many former salesmen have been given other work by their employers.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (Reuter) -- A definite increase in Polish resistance to the invaders is gathered from news reaching Polish circles in London. This may account for the extraordinary Gestapo drive with Ukrainian hirelings in a district along the Bug River in Central Poland.

THIS week a call again goes out for books for our armed services. Books are wanted by the men in camps, by men aboard the Navy and merchant ships, by the men of this country who have taken up stations and are fighting on almost every continent.

Machine tools are doubly important to the war production program because they not only build the machines that make tanks, guns and other weapons, but also are the only machines which reproduce themselves.

Many younger women of society have been assigned to various duties in connection with the benefit show entitled "Women Can Take It," to be presented on the stage of the Rivoli Theatre the night of Jan. 12. The show has an all-woman cast and will portray some famous women of history as the principal feature of a diversified program.

Current American production of combat materiel at the end of the year was greater than that of the entire Axis, despite its ten-year head start in arming, and the United Nations were outproducing the enemy by about two to one, according to the most reliable estimates of foreign production received by WPB.

A UNITED STATES ARMY AIR BASE, in China, Dec. 31 (Delayed) (AP) -- First Lieutenant Robert Mooney, Kansas City, Mo., a fighter pilot, and First Lieutenant Rowland Hill of Margaretville, N.Y., a bomber naviagtor, killed in combat with the Japanese, were buried with military honors today at an American air base cemetery.

The WPB inventory limitation order L-219 issued last Monday is currently the chief object of retail interest, according to a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by H.I. Kleinhaus, manager of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

FLORAL PARK, N.Y., Jan. 2 (AP) -- A woman and a 15-year-old girl were stabbed to death and her husband and daughter critically wounded tonight by an assailant who apparently forced his way into an upholstery shop, and police announced that a blood-stained fugitive had been captured a short time later following a brief chase.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The peak of the Axis submarines' hunting season in the North Atlantic has now been on for several weeks, but whether the bag of the Nazi wolf pack will be anything to brag about still remains to be seen.

Of greatest significance in the aviation industry's outstanding performance for 1942 is that the year's achievements point to an even better war record for 1943, in the opinion of Victor Emanuel, president of the Aviation Corporation.

Fritz Kuhn, former national leader of the German-American Bund in this country, with nineteen other former bundsmen will face denaturalization proceedings in Federal court here Tuesday morning. He is scheduled to leave Dannemora State prison in the custody of United States Marshals today and reach here tonight.

With buying by New Orleans the feature, the cotton futures market resumed its upturn yesterday, again establishing new seasonal high marks. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts ended the two-hour session near the day's best levels and at net gains of 20 to 24 points, or $1 to $1.20 a ale.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 -- Picture a long stretch of uninviting mud flats broken by barren hills that dip down to the north shore of San Francisco Bay. Once passed up by real estate promoters, the mud flats were still there a scant two years ago, as the nation slowly roused itself to lend-lease appeals and national defense warnings.

One of the war administration's major projects in 1943 to eliminate from America's industrial economy every last bit of waste, whether of manpower, materials, transportation or power, will be an extension of the concentration-of-industry program, started in May of last year.
Steel, the giant of American industries, has surpassed all its previous achievements in turning out the master metal for the airplanes, tanks, ships and guns with which our armed forces are fighting.

ONE of the by-products of the present controversy between the American Federation of Musicians, led by James C. Petrillo, and the radio and phonograph record companies concerning the use of "canned" music on the air, is the renewed interest in an old question: How much difference can the listener to a broadcast detect between a "live" performance and a recording?

Active war developments shifted largely to the Pacific, where Japanese captured much territory, including surrender to them of Corregidor and military islands of Manila Bay. On the other hand, the British captured Madagascar and, in a battle between the United States and Japan in the Coral Sea, losses of the Japanese in ships and material were extremely heavy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Navy communique No. 236:

HIGH-RANKING military officers and civilian officials of the United States Government responsible for the conduct of the war discovered that much red tape can be cut with a butter knife over a luncheon plate, and they are putting their discovery to good practical effect.

Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey conceded yesterday that a shortage of manpower, plus the need for conserving gasoline and rubber, had caused curtailment of trash and garbage collections in outlying sections of the city.

Voltage to smash the Axis! That is the job to which the nation's electric power and light industry has dedicated itself and in America's first full year of war and all-out war production not a single warship, plane, tank or gun has been delayed by a shortage of electric power.

The Jeep is now universally acclaimed as one of America's notable contributions to mechanized warfare. The origin of this "wonder weapon" is still shrouded in mystery not only to many of the soldiers who have driven it but also to millions of civilians.

While Wellesley College closes for eight weeks this Winter in order to conserve oil, undergraduates are planning to use this time to advantage in various jobs throughout the country. The demand for temporary jobs during this period was so great that early last Fall the placement office enlarged its staff to handle increased placements.

After four years of sweeping changes and reforms, the New York Stock Exchange settled down in 1942 to a calm consolidation of its somewhat shaky position. Important developments were few and of these the adoption and expansion of the special offering system for sales on the Exchange floor was the leader.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Jan. 2 (Reuter) -- A British force has returned to First Army positions after fighting a successful night action with Germans twenty miles inside Axis lines. It was one of the finest sorties of the Tunisian campaign.

IN a letter to the TIMES radio page of Dec. 20 an irate listener to this thing called radio, or to be more precise, Frequency Modulation, complained bitterly about the poor programming job done by FM radio stations in the metropolitan area.

Perhaps more than once last year you had to wait a half hour, or even an hour, before you could get a long-distance call through from New York to Pittsburgh, Chicago or San Francisco. If you were calling Washington you may have had to wait two hours.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 2 -- A thousand fuel oil consumers using 10,000 gallons a year and more each in the seven northern counties of New Jersey were notified today by the OPA Regional Office here that they must convert their heating facilities from oil to coal.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 2 -- Three times yesterday the German air force attempted to attack the vital harbor at Bone, Algeria, near the Tunisian frontier. The first time the Royal Air Force succeeded in blocking the raiders and the other two attacks were turned back before getting near their objective.
Research work in constant progress throughout the aircraft industry has saved tons of strategic materials for use in American warplanes.

The importance of substitutes for rubber is illustrated by the fact that 12,000,000 pounds of resins alone were used to provide replacements in the first six months of 1942, representing an estimated conservation of 18,000,000 pounds of rubber.

The country has become so accustomed to talking in terms of preparation for war that it has lost sight of its own progress in many respects, according to Alvin E. Dodd, president of the American Management Association.

On that November week-end when the dawn came up like thunder over the Axis forces in North Africa, and America's legions swarmed ashore in their snub-nosed barges at half a dozen ports, or plummeted from the clouds via parachute, the "women behind the men behind the guns" got their first taste of victory in this war.

Intensified teamwork between farmers and their distributors, which made possible the record food supply of 1942, is the key to success in meeting the increased food demands of 1943, according to John A. Hartford, president of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (Science Service) -- The principle of the famous French 75-millimeter field gun is applied to hand weapons in a newly issued patent, obtained by Ray R. McCrumb of Lansing, Mich. Semi-automatic rifles and other small-arms ordinarily use coil springs to take up part of the energy of the recoil and utilize it in reloading the piece and closing the breech.
The petroleum industry, in its production of many millions of gallons of 100-octane aviation gasoline, is making it possible for the United Nations to maintain a marked superiority in the air.

Plant conversion and assembly line methods have greatly speeded the building of merchant vessels, as contrasted with the production of the "Ugly Ducklings" in the first World War. The ships pour out of inland and coastal plants in prefabricated sub-assemblies in a continuous stream.

WASHIGTON, Jan. 2 -- Two New Yorkers, Joseph O'Savage, boatswain's mate, second class, of 283 Avenue A, and George F. Lambert, gunner's mate, second class, whose mother, Mrs. Flora Lambert, lives at 18 Norwood Avenue, Stapleton, S.I., are among nine Navy men to whom have been awarded Silver Star medals for heroism by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The names of 407 United States soldiers killed in action in the Southwest Pacific, South Pacific, African and European war areas and at sea were made public by the War Department today.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The New Year opens with financial London facing the future with a spirit of confidence not felt at any previous time during the war. Views naturally vary concerning the probable duration of the struggle but the outlook is encouraged by all that can be seen and by much that can be guessed intelligently.

November was distinguished by victory of the British Eighth Army over General Rommel, who retreated before the British troops; also by capture of French Africa by the American forces with the aid of Admiral Darlan of the French Navy. As Winter began, the Russians turned on the German main army and recaptured many towns. This led to much talk of a shortened war.

March was largely made up of war finance. War news was more or less conflicting, except that the Nazis were held in stationary position by the Russians and our Navy sunk or damaged twenty-three Japanese ships. Congress raised the public debt limit from $65,000,000,000 to $130,000,000,000. Navy announced that General MacArthur had taken command of the United Nations forces in Australia.

War and the regulation of consumer credit had far-reaching effects in 1942 on the volume of credit retail sales and on the receivables arising from these sales. Installment sales in 1942 are estimated to have been $2,800,000,000, or a 60 per cent decline from the preceding year.
The American shipping industry was at war long before the first Japanese plane led the way over Pearl Harbor on a peaceful December morning.

War news of February was unfavorable, notably through the Japanese successes in the Far East, where Singapore was captured. Torpedoing of merchant vessels on our own East Coast by hostile submarines continued. The burden of war taxes was repeatedly increased, the total already appropriated by vote of Congress in February having reached $142,000,000,000. The Senate passed, contrary to the Administration wishes, a bill prohibiting government sale of farm products for less than parity.

There is nothing especially sin ister about yellow violets as such, but when it happens several times in succession that these flowers are found in the immediate vicinity of newly slain corpses it gives one furiously to think. That, at least, is how it affects Private Detective Pat Abbott, who postpones his marriage to lovely Jean Holly in order to investigate.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- The Philadelphia Electric Company, leading subsidiary operating company of the United Gas Improvement Company's holding system, has filed its plan for recapitalization with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was disclosed today.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Greentree Stable's Corydon, favored at 3 to 5, won the Crescent City Handicap of a mile and a sixteenth at the Fair Grounds today, nipping Staretor by a head at the wire. Wait a Bit was third.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The jobs of an estimated 10,000 clothing workers in Boston have been "frozen" for the war's duration by voluntary agreement among unions, nineteen manufacturers and the War Manpow Commission.

AN ADVANCED AMERICAN BOMBER BASE, in North Africa, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Men of the American light bomber squadron, living in tin huts and pup tents on a field attacked almost daily by German planes, have hung up the remarkable record of carrying out forty-one raids on the Germans in Tunisia with the loss of just one plane crew -- and that one is safe.

Since the production of distilled spirits was completely halted in 1942 to permit the all-out manufacture of alcohol by distillers for wartime industrial needs, every new withdrawal from the limited warehouse stocks "amounts to a liquidation of assets," according to Victory A. Fischel, vice president in charge of sales and advertising, Seagram-Distillers Corporation.

RADIO, in theory and practice, made big gains in 1942. From all quarters comes the news that America today is pre-eminent in all branches of the ethereal art and that engineers were never doing more to keep it so. But never have there been fewer facts about what is going on.

Apprehension over numerous political developments rather than consideration for the supply and availability of the commodity dominated the cotton market during most of 1942. The price trend throughout the year was generally upward and at the close prices at the leading spot centers in the South were approximately $11 a bale over those at the close of 1941.

Some 49,000,000 people will have to dig into their pocketbooks for Uncle Sam this year, 32,000,000 for the first time. And everybody who earns more than $12 a week will have to contribute 5 per cent of all wages or salaries above that sum for the special Victory Tax.

The production last year of 120,000,000,000 pounds of milk is expected to be repeated in 1943, but the domestic consumer will face rationing to provide for an increase in the requirements for military and lend-lease purposes.

A political as well as a military battle has been seething in French North Africa ever since Allied troops splashed ashore last November. For those looking on from the outside the fight is cloaked in confusion and mystery. Only its crucial importance is clear.

The food industry, harried throughout the past year by the dilemma of constantly increased wartime demands and rapidly diminished facilities, looks forward in 1943 with new hope for the solution of its problems. Belatedly, but nevertheless definitely, the industry was officially recognized is a prime essential in the war program when Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard last month took over full direction of its operations under a national Food Administration.
In the development of new types of containers and the adaptation of old types to the war program, the tin, glass and wood container industries have made a great contribution to the war.

THE value of recorded music in the camps and stations where the men of our armed forces are training or based for fighting has been discussed in these columns on several occasions. Phonograph and recordings are especially useful in outlying posts in this country and overseas, where it is difficult or impossible to bring living professional talent save what happens to be in the ranks.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Libya, Dec. 31 (Delayed) -- At Wadi Zemzem two roughly parallel defensive systems are under construction. This suggests that the Axis forces plan a determined stand. There are indications also that the morale of the German elements, at least, has received a new lease on life.
Fighting was resumed both by the Germans in Russia and by the United States troops in the Solomon Islands, but no important engagement occurred.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 2 -- An official French spokesman said tonight that "it is the definite desire of the people at the head of affairs in North Africa to come to an agreement with all Frenchmen who are fighting against Germany."

INspite of all obstacles retail trade volume in the year just closed reached the all-time high of 56 billions, according to preliminary estimates. The obstacles included rationing, shortages, delivery difficulties and a host of others, including the removal of more than 7,000,000 men from civilian life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A special British aircraft engineering mission has arrived in this country at the invitation of the United States Government to confer with American aircraft officials and producers on coordination of British and American technical practices and design, the Office of War Information said today.

In THE TIMES of Jan. 1 Emily Corson Poley Longstreth suggests that instead of "forcing our ideals upon another country" by "supervision or at least inspection of the school systems of Germany and Japan," we should "all confess our sins, repent, and try to follow the Golden Rule."

HICKAM FIELD, Hawaii, Jan. 2 -- With Hawaiian air fields as the home bases for a far-ranging United States Army bomber force working in conjunction with the Navy, blows will be struck at Japan's central Pacific holdings for which the Wake Island raid the night of Dec. 23-24 was really a rehearsal, Major Gen. Willis H. Hale, commander of the Army's Seventh Air Force, said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 2 -- Soon the French will have only the news Pierre Laval wishes them to have with the elimination of foreign broadcasts. The French learned today that the tax on receiving sets had been doubled and that the manufacture of sets had been suspended until measures were taken to control production, with the obvious inference that the new models will not permit the hearing of British and American broadcasts.

When war came to the United States at Pearl Harbor, the American chemical industry was in a far better state of preparedness to meet the demands of the military program than ever before in its history. Many plants had already been expanded and new ones built as the war in Europe progressed, and were immediately available for the vast increases necessitated by the entrance of the United States into the war.

Through the courtesy of the FCC and the OWI this newspaper was enabled to publish yesterday the text of Adolf Hitler's New Year's message to the German people just as it was broadcast to them, instead of publishing the watered-down version broadcast by the German Transocean service for foreign consumption.

The nation's railroads are doing one of the great jobs of the war. Accepting the challenge of the Axis powers, they moved a record volume of both freight and passenger traffic last year with unmatched speed and efficiency. Under private management, but with the close cooperation of government and private agencies, the railroads are performing the biggest transportation job in the world's history.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Grain markets started the new year with an advance which carried all deliveries of wheat, July and September corn and September oats and rye to new seasonal high prices, with the cash grain following the futures.

The diamond, the brilliant precious stone and the hardest substance known, brought a sparkle to industry in its use of new production methods. Its development is a result of the need for utmost speed in precision work. Only the diamond can true the wheels swiftly and efficiently.

Government orders accounted for about 30 per cent of estimated 1942 underwear output of 60,800,000 dozens, a record for the industry, according to the Underwear Institute's year-end survey. The estimated total would be 7 per cent ahead of 1941, which also set a record, 28 per cent higher than 1940 and 26 per cent over 1939.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., is credited with being the first firm in the automobile industry to convert completely its manufacturing facilities to armament production in a year which witnessed the steady rise of that industry's daily munitions output to nearly $20,000,000 at its conclusion.

Normal functioning of the woolen and worsted industries during 1942 was prevented by price ceilings, priorities, unknown imports and restrictions on the civilian use of wool, Frank J. Knell, president of the Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange, Inc., said in his resume of the year's activity.

Food production in 1943 is expected to be the greatest in the nation's history, yet as the year begins civilians face widespread shortages, an extension of rationing systems, and a total upset of dietary habits. Such is war.

Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Director of the New York City Selective Service, paid high tribute to the work of the members of the various local draft boards throughout the city yesterday, asserting "it is to the credit of these men that they are unflinching in their thankless duty."

ELSEWHERE on this page today Mr. Pemberton is reviewing a year of the theatre as it passed last Friday and not fully mourned from 1942 to 1943. Aside from its other virtues and vices, the departed season, so recently finished with its macabre jig in the dimmed-out streets of Broadway, should get full credit for one play that has most enlivened the state of the drama.

For every bomber that gets off to Europe in the mass raids on enemy targets, an average of sixty men are required on the ground to put the plane in readiness and for the intricate system of communications necessary to coordinate the departures.

The American system of private enterprise has emerged from its first full year of all-out war flying colors. Never before in the history of the nation have the combined forces of government, industry, finance and labor faced such a herculean task.

The country has prepared equipment for offensive chemical warfare in the event such measures are used against the Allies. In addition it has had to provide defense protection against gas for military personnel and civilian populations.

JACK BENNY, with his customary affability, took time out last week to dwell on a matter or two which, it seems, has been agitating the trade. First, the government has asked him to delay his plans for entertaining troops overseas until mid-March or perhaps later, which in all probability means there will be no interruption of his Sunday night program on NBC.

The American petroleum industry is going to do its part to speed a complete United Nations victory over the forces of greed and hatred if cheerful and ungrudging effort and untiring devotion will do it.

Highway transportation has made possible the efficient operation of the decentralized industries of the country and the subcontracting system which has permitted small companies to put their facilities and manpower to work on war orders, according to B.M. Seymour, president of Associated Transport, Inc.

Because of the wide variety of products involved in war conversion of textile mills, the rapidity of their adjustments during 1942 attracted much favorable comment from Army and Navy procurement officers and emphasized again the latent flexibility of individual textile manufacturers.

PROTEAN is the adjective for Edmund Gilligan. His first novel ("Boundary Against Night") pictured the clash between Boston puritans and police, with overtones worthy of Joyce. "White Sails Crowding" swept over the Newfoundland banks with the Gloucestermen in terms of high romance.

RECENTLY I met a woman volunteer. She was a master sergeant and an excellent shot. She said to me, "At the beginning of the war I was a field nurse. I joined the fighting ranks after the Germans had killed my son." She seemed to me not less than 40. "On what front was your son killed?"

Resin adhesives of the phenolic type are playing an important role in the production of war materials, being used to glue plywood together for gliders, cargo planes, training planes and some fighter planes. They are also used in making wooden propellers. Casein adhesives, a by-product of milk, also are used in the manufacture of aircraft.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

CONFERENCES in Washington and the impact of the Christmas-New Year holidays, which are always lavishly celebrated in Hollywood, have allayed the excitement caused by Lowell Mellett's circular letter of Dec. 9 to studio heads, advising them to submit all scripts and long-cut films to the OWI for approval.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 -- As the first step in a program to put the judiciary of California on a basis to assure speedier justice, the State's lawyers and judges outlined today proposed new rules for appellate procedure.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 2 -- Ambulances of the American Field Service are now operating with the British forward patrols west of Wadi Bei el Chebir after accompanying the advancing Eighth Army all the way from El Alamein, said an account today.

ALL ABOUT ICE BOXES -- With priorities placing mechanical refrigerators "on ice" for the duration and the new food rationing ahead of us, hints on how to make your ice box last -- and how to make its contents last -- should interest every housewife.

The conversion stage was accompanied by the largest construction program ever attempted in the United States in one year, as airfields, cantonments, barracks, housing for war workers, ammunition plants and other new buildings were rushed into being.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 2 -- While denying that the Finnish Government initiated the prohibition against the spreading of United States Office of War Information material in Finland and thereby provoking the Washington veto on the distribution of Finnish news bulletins, the influential Helsinki newspaper Ilta-Sanomat has placed the blame on the Finnish Foreign Minister.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- With the ninth annual Sugar Bowl football game now history, there was talk tonight that the classic and its accompanying week of minor sports might be suspended for the duration.

The petroleum industry definitely is playing a vital role in the nation's war program. Handicapped with the disruption of its transport facilities and with the necessity of readjusting its other operations in the midst of war, it supplied last year the essential civilian and military oil requirements of the United States and also the bulk of the petroleum needs of the other United Nations.

" Lohengrin" was given its first Metropolitan performance of the season yesterday afternoon and was heard by a capacity house, which has been the case at every Saturday matinee performance that the Metropolitan has given thus far this season.

When Germany crashed into Poland in 1939 the American aviation manufacturing industry employed 49,000 persons. By the time the Japanese swooped down on Pearl Harbor this figure had reached the amazing total of 390,000 workers.

Through the combined efforts of Army and Navy directors of physical training programs, national and sectional sports governing bodies, athletic directors and coaches, the ball has been carried to the 1-yard line in the drive to continue intercollegiate sports in 1943.

EVERY outfit a woman buys in these days is tested by the question: Will it look smart now and in the Spring and a year from today? Suits particularly have to stand this test because they are basic garments.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Farmers shared liberally in the prosperity of the country during 1942, the the Department of Agriculture estimating cash income of producers at about $15,000,000,000, probably establishing a new record. In the preceding year farmers took in $11,200,000,000. In 1919 the total was about $14,500,000,000.

The wage stabilization phase of the work of the Economic Stabilization Director and War Labor Board will continue to be heavy this year, particularly in reference to non-war industries, Elmer F. Andrews, labor relations consultant, declared in a year-end statement.

American education begins the New Year with a growing sense of its grave responsibility: first, to do its full part to help win the war; second, to help to win the peace that follows. Education's part in winning the war is integrally related to its part in winning the peace.

The need for plant conversion to speed up war production was illustrated by many firms during the past year. One manufacturer of merry-go-rounds and other devices for amusement parks halted this kind of production immediately when the need for war machines came.

First in single units, then in tens and hundreds, and finally in thousands and tens of thousands, have rolled the 1942 model tanks, trucks, airplane engines, guns, shells and varied other weapons of war from the mass production lines of the great American automobile industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The United Nations were one year old as a formal organization this week and, as their armies moved from the defensive to the offensive in the war against the Axis, there was more and more discussion of the kind of peace which must be written if another world war is to be avoided ten or twenty years from now.

Nearly one thousand enlisted men in the various branches of the United States armed forces, together with many of those of the United Nations, will be invited guests at the forty-first annual entertainment and ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club, which will take place the night of Feb. 10 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Best fed, best clothed and one of the best paid soldiers in the world, the American fighting man is also the best transported.
A MAN should be a polo pony to be a producer in war times. Then he could pivot on a dime and dash after the ball in any direction. A coin of small denomination is chosen advisedly for this allegory.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- In an effort to conserve enough fuel oil to prevent the closing of the County Courthouse and County Office Building next week, the heat in both buildings was shut off today, except in offices compelled by law to stay open.

An answer to the manpower shortage, created by the daily flow of men from factories into the armed forces, is given by Walter C. Mason of the Warner Swasey Co. in Cleveland, who suggests that white-collared men work part-time on the production lines.

The book publishing industry finds itself today in the paradoxical position of seeing some of its most improbable dreams come true and being almost powerless to take advantage of the circumstances. For years book publishers have been bemoaning the fact that the American public had no time to read books.
With its field of service spread over land, sea and air fronts, the Canadian Pacific Railway Company is discharging a vital transportation task in the second World War.

IN case there is some curiosity about what is happening to the three ballet companies, all more or less Russe, which are now touring about in these very perilous days for touring, here are notes from all of them.

Frederick W. Kocher was named yesterday commissary superintendent by the United States Lines, succeeding Lewis Daughtrey, who retired on Thursday. Mr. Kocher has been active in commissary work for thirty years, the last twelve of which were spent with the company.

Whatever else you choose to say about January -- and you can say plenty, if you please -- it does bring days that are lengthening instead of diminishing. The sun will be in the sky today about ten minutes longer than it was last Sunday, and the span will steadily increase until next June.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Thomas E. Dewey settled quietly today into the duties of the Governorship. He worked on his annual message to the Legislature to be delivered Wednesday, discussed patronage to a limited extent, appointed a District Attorney of Schenectady County to succeed Lieut. Gov. Thomas W. Wallace and held a press conference.

A recent letter from N.S. Dondelinger of the Anaconda (Montana) Sportsmen's Association criticizing the reduction of the elk herd in Yellowstone National Park and a plan to use the meat to feed interned aliens, brought a reply from Dr. Ira Gabrielson, chief of the U.S. Wildlife Service and a statement from the National Park Service.
Outstanding among more than twoscore new products and processes for the war developed during the last year by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. is an improved method of manufacturing TNT.

Wall Street foreign exchange dealers spent far more time in 1942 in keeping their files up to date on new restrictions placed on business transactions involving foreign exchange, as issued by governments the world over, than they did in actual trading in foreign currencies.

Wholesale markets were quiet last week, with mails light and very few buyers in town, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co. As stores prepared for January merchandise promotions, it was found that many converters and manufacturers of novelty types of linens have booked substantial volume, are unable to accept any additional business and are now quoting February-March delivery.

The aircraft industry has developed multi-purpose equipment to maintain warplane production schedules while making constant alterations, found necessary after nearly every model has gone into production, to meet the need for better equipment than that of the enemy.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Hard-punching Manuel Ortiz retained his N.B.A. bantamweight championship last night by out-pointing Kenny Lindsay, Vancouver, B.C., challenger, in ten rounds.

An appeal to the people of New York to increase their support of the four municipal colleges -- City, Brooklyn, Hunter and Queens -- was made yesterday by Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education.

Although the wholesale liquor industry enjoyed satisfactory sales volume and profits during 1942, war-time restrictions are such that diminished business and "casualties" among the smaller units in both wholesaling and retailing must be expected as the war continues, according to W.M. Barnett, vice president of McKesson Robbins, Inc.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (Netherland News Agency) -- Despite early Nazi assertions that the Royal Air Force bombing of Eindhoven in December damaged only residential districts, the German-controlled Netherland press has acknowledged the devastation of the important Philips radio plant, it was learned today.
The New Year's resolution of all American citizens should be to do everything possible to help win the war, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday.

With the growing furniture shortage, the question of how to style up the pieces one has is timely. Unusual and dramatic ways of using non-priority materials -- wallpaper and fabrics, for example -- will change a nondescript chair, table, chest or unpainted piece into a smart, up-to-date contribution to home morale during wartime.

THE year which ended last Thursday brought at least 1,906 major and minor varieties of postage stamps, issued by 151 different governments. Scores of others are reported to have been released, but have not reached New York dealers.

There will plenty of liquid carbon dioxide for military and industrial needs throughout the war, in the opinion of John H. Bell, executive vice president of Cardox Corporation, makers of non-explosive mining equipment and fire extinguishing systems.

HENRI CHARLES ROSEMOND, at the office of Haiti's Consul General in New York, has received part of the series which Haiti released last month in honor of the republic's Patroness, Our Lady of Perpetual Help.

Playing a role as vital to the war program as tanks and aircraft, fire-control instruments so far have received very little attention in the public press. While American industry has been winning the battle of production and American forces have been moving out in increasing numbers to the battlefronts, a third major battle of the war has been in progress at home. This is the battle against inflation.

A good start, but no more than a start, was made in the year just completed in the gigantic task of financing the war effort of the United States. Happily, the climax of the increasing tempo of new government financing during the twelvemonth was reached in December.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Impressive details of the rapid progress in 1942 of the industralization of Siberia are given in a New Year letter to Premier Joseph Stalin from the Urals. It tells in simple language of the immense effort made by 1,489,920 men and women in factories and on farms in and beyond the Urals.

Since the American hosiery industry was the biggest peacetime user of two strategic and scarce fibers needed in the war effort -- silk and nylon -- it became one of the first consumer-goods industries to be seriously affected by the war, it was pointed out by Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

MOST Easterners, and many people from the Middle West, know the "Friendly Mountains," if not by that name. They are, as grouped in this book edited by Roderick Peattie, geographer, the Adirondacks of New York, the White Mountains of New Hampshire, and the Green Mountains and Taconics of Vermont, with a brief mention of Katahdin in Maine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- A drive to obtain a greater voice for consumers in the formulation of wartime civilian controls and to develop a "better understanding" between government and consumers was begun today by representatives of twelve national organizations.

When a new white flower appears on the horticultural horizon it is news indeed. White flowers are among the rarities of nature, since almost all flowers have a touch of color somewhere in their make-up. However, the new annual, Anoda Snowcup, displays such spotlessly white petals that the shallow cup-shaped bloom actually glistens with the quality of new-fallen snow in the sunlight.

German broadcasts recorded yesterday by The Associated Press said that because of "further murders" and attempts on the lives of three German soldiers New Year's night the German military commander in Brussels, the Belgian capital, had announced that all places of entertainment would be closed until further notice.

The United Aircraft Corporation, recognizing its responsibility in war production, has voluntarily eliminated the myth of the profiteer in its effort to provide superior machines as quickly as possible, according to Eugene E. Wilson, president of the company.

The terrific drain of war is going to cause the United States to scrape the bottom of its resources barrel in some fields in 1943. One of these is rubber. In fact, in so far as can be foreseen now, rubber is the material in which we will run closest to danger In this critical war year.

Resignation of George P. Rea, its first and only paid president, to become a college president was the highlight of the New York Curb Exchange year. In view of the present condition of Curb revenue, the board of governors elected no successor and Fred C. Moffatt, member-president from 1935 to 1939, was appointed acting chief executive.

Mobile service units, manned by factory-trained experts are moving along with American planes on fine battlefronts in Russia, Africa, China, India, Britain, the Pacific and elsewhere to give warcraft the constant care it needs in fighting the enemy.

The carpet industry will continue throughout 1943 to be interested primarily in increasing the effectiveness of its war production, L.A. Beers, president of the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, declared in a year-end statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET, in the South Pacific, Jan. 2 -- Victory for the United Nations this year is the prediction of Admiral William Halsey, commander of the South Pacific Force of the Pacific Fleet.

Thousands of passengers car owners may face a ban against driving after Jan. 31 unless tire inspections are speeded greatly, E.S. Ferguson, regional rationing executive of the Office of Price Administration, warned last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Office of Defense Transportation warned today that no truck owner -- from the farmer or corner grocer to the owner of a large fleet -- would be immune from more serious problems this year than were encountered in 1942.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 2 -- Allied bombers are inexorably destroying the ports on which the Axis armies in Africa depend for supplies. Of seven ports available, three are already useless and the remainder damaged.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Army, Navy and War Production Board, in a joint statement today, said that "a revised and integrated" program for 1943 aimed at a war output double that of 1942, with the goal for aircraft, merchant shipping and naval vessels vastly increased while the ratio of production for tanks, artillery and other war items would be reduced.

WITH ALLIED FORCES, in Tunisia, Jan. 2 -- An 800-mile trip along the Allied front, in which American, British and French units were visited, offers convincing proof that, although the enemy is penned into the northeast corner of Tunisia, it will take a large-scale military enterprise to knock him out of there.

A year of war has furnished a severe test of American resourcefulness. For the anthracite industry it was the beginning of a test of performance that will greatly influence its future, J.B. Warriner, president of the Lehigh Navigation Coal Company, Inc., announced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, disclosed today that he had communicated on Christmas with General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner in French North Africa, suggesting that they meet on French soil to discuss means of effecting a fusion between their followers and themselves, and that thus far no reply had been received from General Giraud.

American aircraft manufacturers produced 49,000 airplanes of all types in 1942, according to official government figures, and are well on their way to create the most powerful striking force in the world before the end of this year. We are already producing the world's most deadly bombers, have surpassed all others in transport planes, and since last May have been building more aircraft than the entire Axis combined.

The campaign being conducted by Uncle Robert, pioneer radio operator, of Long Branch, N.J., to eliminate the German word "kindergarten" from the English language is attracting nation-wide support from newspapers and individuals in almost every field of endeavor, Uncle Robert announced last night.

America is fulfilling her destiny in the creation of a merchant fleet and a multiple-ocean Navy, each on a scale far outshadowing anything accomplished or dreamed of before. This has been the land of industrial wonder; and our shipbuilding is truly a miracle of production, in the American tradition.

Government controls have done more for the specialty store than that branch of retailing could have accomplished by itself in years, according to C. Ludwig Baumann, president of C. Ludwig Baumann Co., furniture chain, and a governor of the Associated Furniture Dealers of New York City.

Aside from normal yardsticks used to measure extension of business credit, ability to absorb sharply higher wartime and postwar tax rates as well as to help service a large standing national debt must increasingly influence credit determinations in 1943, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men.

While it is only a threat at the present time and may never materialize on the scale previously predicted, the government proposals to ban cross-hauling of raw materials and manufactured goods in order to conserve transportation have created more alarm in the minds of marketing and advertising executives than almost any other war-forced program.

Lawmakers convening tomorrow in Albany for the second New York State legislative session of the war will discover that organized women in the State are rallying their forces to defeat any bills they consider unfavorable to good working standards.
