Praise for the achievements of American industry in 1942 and encouragement for even greater deeds in production this year have been voiced by the two civilian officials in the War and Navy Departments who have charge of the procurement of war equipment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Japan staked her play for an understanding with the United States during the diplomatic negotiations in the months before Pearl Harbor primarily on the proposal which she advanced for a meeting on a warship in the Pacific of her...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- In a message to the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, made public today, President Roosevelt supported the council's action in calling upon Christians to observe the week beginning tomorrow as a Universal Week of Prayer.

THE revival of "Boris Godunoff" by the Metropolitan Opera Company is taking place this season. However glad some of us may be at seeing that the management has decided to bring back some of the lesser known but more deserving operas, the more disappointed and confused we must be at reading that this opera will be sung in Italian.

Geared to an all-out war program, Hunter College Evening Session added thirty new war courses last Fall and is planning to introduce a number of others next semester. The courses were not chosen at random, according to Professor Broderick Cohen, director, but were selected after inquiries had been made and conferences held with war agencies and civil defense organizations.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin is making representations "to the proper quarters" to try to get the Allies to increase their anti-Japanese forces in the Pacific, J.J. Dedman, Minister of War Organization and Industrial Research, said today.

OTTAWA, Jan. 2 -- Just two years ago C.D. Howe, Canadian Minister of Munitions and Supply, was asked in the House of Commons why his department was not building ships. "What is the use of producing guns and ammunition if we cannot get them across the Atlantic?" his questioner demanded, and the Minister, sorely pressed by many other demands, replied: "Where are we going to get the steel and the skilled workers?"

In spite of the numerous predictions of wholesale bankruptcies last year, particularly among smaller concerns, business failures as recorded by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., registered a decline of 25 per cent from 1941 and reached the lowest figure since the 1919 total Of 8,400.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 2 -- With fuel oil heat shut off in the new County Court House buildings and the majority of offices closed, employes in courts of record here today found office temperatures ranging from 48 to 65 degrees.
LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Moscow radio early today broadcast the following Soviet midnight communique:

On top of its record-breaking production in 1941, the paper industry last year achieved an output only about 5 per cent below that peak, according to an estimate by the American Paper and Pulp Association. Actual tonnage was put at about 16,500,000 tons, as against 17,300,000 in the preceding year.

IT is scarcely news when a bibliographer relaxes from his arduous labors and turns to detective stories. But when a detective bites off a bibliographical chore, that is something else again. Taking time out from his hairbreath escapades on the radio and in print, Ellery Queen has applied his peculiar talents to the task of penetrating the bibliographical mysteries of the detective short story.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- The National Labor Relations Board is planning to deny the contention of the Henry J. Kaiser shipbuilding interests that two of the NLRB's three members are rejudiced against Kaiser in a labor dispute, an informed source said today.

A cooperative endeavor between government and business has proved successful in the joint effort of the War Production Board and the Industrial Salvage Committee for Greater New York, which has just completed the organization of the city's 27,000 manufacturing plants into 106 separate salvage groups.

The distilling industry in its "all-out" effort to meet the nation's war-time alcohol needs, has devised a number of improvements in manufacturing technique which will increase its productive capacity during 1943, according to Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman of the board, Schenley Distillers Corporation.

AN ADVANCED AMERICAN FIGHTER BASE, in North Africa, Jan. 1 (Delayed) (AP) -- Flying from a mountainside and living on a diet of canned hash, young American pilots fresh from colleges, factories and country towns have proved what a great fighter plane the P-38 is by shooting down forty German planes with it for a loss of only nine.

THE business outlook for professional writers is growing increasingly somber. As if it were not alarming enough to have had physicians and surgeons by scores invading an already cramped market, now members in good standing of Actors Equity are beginning to appear in ominous numbers upon the publishers' lists.

A series of lectures on "Winning the War" and "Winning the Peace" will be started by Columbia University's Institute of Arts and Sciences and the Civilian Defense Council on Monday and Wednesday evenings in McMillin Academic Theatre, Dr. Russell Potter, director of the institute, announced yesterday.

Wartime conditions will bring informative labeling of consumer goods to the fore in the months ahead, according to Harold W. Brightman, president of the National Consumer-Retailer Council and vice president of L. Bamberger Co.

The Industrial Rayon Corporation is now replacing its regular strength yarn production at its parent plant with high tenacity yarn to be used as cord in the tires built for aircraft, motorized artillery and Army transport vehicles. Long-smoldering antagonisms and hatred of Yarkee imperialism in Latin America will disappear in direct proportion to the help and understanding that the United States offers to the Southern nations, according to nineteen Latin-American students studying here under the sponsorship of the New York City Committee for Latin-American Scholarships, Inc.

The news that comes out of France these days is scanty and has to be put together like a jigsaw puzzle. Reports from Madrid and from Berne represent leakages that even the most news-tight frontier cannot prevent. They agree on one point, that the dismal comedy of "collaboration" is nearing the end of its run.
Greater readiness to try new methods, processes and yarn blends, in an effort to overcome war-created scarcities and restrictions, characterized textile manufacturing in general during 1942.

Kochel of Shillington, Pa., and Douglas F. Hanson of Lowell, Mass., a first class private in the medical and veterinary detachment here, were commended by Major Gen. Francis B. Wilby, superintendent.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 2 -- One of the vital links in America's war production chain, the Great Lakes shipping industry, has completed the biggest season in the history of the inland waters and now is planning to work a nautical miracle in 1943.

While the coming year's recreational programs should be based upon serving the war effort in every way possible, plans for the future must be made in order that vacationlands may be ready for the post-war demands of the public, according to the New England Council, whose first New England War Conference was held recently in Boston.

Why do we read? To live different lives, situations and ideas than our own. Thus we multiply our span into immortality. Or at least we learn more than if we couldn't read and had to depend on the individual experiences of a lifetime rather than the infinite variety of books.

The story of the electrical equipment industry for 1942 is one of partial conversion, sharply increased production and speed in turning out vital war materials. Hidden away in various parts of the country are more than a dozen "modification centers," with special staffs and equipment, where American warplanes are made finally ready for service on some specific battlefront. In spite of the difficulties encountered last year by the operators of the nation's 5,000,000 motor trucks, Ted V. Rodgers, president of the American Trucking Association, in a year-end review, reveals that trucks in 1942 hauled at least 10 per cent more freight than during the previous year and thus set an all-time high record for the volume of goods transported by motor carrier.

The most spectacular wartime growth in the field of metal production has been the tremendous expansion in aluminum output and the pushing closer to completion of new and far-flung facilities that will leave Nineteen-Forty-Two's great record far behind.

IN this, their latest, book the Johnsons, whose beautifully illustrated dog stories have familiarized child readers with many different breeds of dogs, have turned their attention to horses. Although handicapped by a shortage of labor and by other factors incident to the war, the copper industry in the United States established last year a new high in production. With the aid of imports, the industry was able to supply all essential needs and also to ship considerable quantities abroad, principally to Great Britain and Russia.

Consumer cooperatives in the United States made "the most substantial and most dramatic progress in their history" during the past year. Wallace J. Campbell of the Cooperative League of the U.S.A., declared in a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Reports from several community defense councils that there is a serious shortage of volunteer consumer consultants to answer questions posed by ration-stunned homemakers who come to these centers seeking information are verified by Dr. Persia Campbell, consumer chairman for the Greater New York CDVO.

Dollar-and-cents ceilings for kerosene sales throughout the city, effective tomorrow, were announced last night by Sylvan L. Joseph, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration. The new ceilings, for wholesale and retail sales, were established by an order sent from Washington.

By reason of increasing demands from the government for military and war-aid purposes, there will be a further diminution of knitted outerwear for civilian use during 1943, according to Harold Korzenik, acting counsel, National Knitted Outerwear Association.

BEFORE the day's work takes me, I step out to breathe the morning and to see the world from my foothold in it. My house is on a hilltop overlooking a town; I see the streets spread away and, in the countryside beyond, the roads go looping over the hills. There is little moving on them; the town looks toy-like, innocently vulnerable.

Under the honorary patronage of the Earl of Athlone, Governor General of Canada, the Canadian Club of New York will present a variety revue entitled "A Night in an English Music Hall," on the night of Jan. 25 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 2 -- A bullet from a pistol in the hands of a 10-year-old boy who thought it was a toy cap pistol last night fatally wounded Frank Prusakowski, 52-year-old legless proprietor of a cigar store here, as he was preparing to put up the boy and his two sisters for the night on a day bed in the rear of his store.

WRITERS of detective stories are isolationists at heart. They like to place all their characters -- the victim, the murderer, the other suspects and the investigator -- in some inaccessible spot and let them work out their problems without the aid of the constituted authorities.

The Packard Motor Car Company is now producing war materials at the rate of $1,000,000 a day, according to Alvan Macauley, chairman of the board, who places at $206,000,000 the total volume of munitions sales by the company in 1942.

THE 1943 Victory Book Campaign, details of which are given in this week's Notes on Books and Authors, is about to get under way. Beginning Tuesday, it will continue for two months, through March 5. When it is over, there should be no lack of books for the men in the armed services.

ROBERT DAVIS, who seems equally at home in all parts of the world, has followed "Pepperfoot," his fine story of three Berber boys in a tent village of North Africa, with a spirited tale of dog teams in the Eastern Canadian wilderness of James Bay.
Bonds called before maturity for payment in 1942 totaled $982,599,000, the smallest amount for any year since 1934, when $631,954,000 were redeemed, and compared with $2,553,505,000 retired in 1941.

TWO major orchestral jobs are open for next season; at least they were when these words were written. They are the post of conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra which was made vacant by the death of Frederick Stock, and the conductorship of the Cleveland Orchestra, which becomes available to another man through Artur Rodzinski's acceptance of the musical directorship of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

ALCOHOL PRIZE -- The Research Council on Problems of Alcohol, Pondfield Road West, Bronxville, N.Y., offers a $1,000 prize for outstanding research on alcohol during 1943. The winner must contribute new knowledge, in some branch of medicine, biology, or sociology, important to the understanding, prevention or treatment of alcoholism.

The placing of $94,000,000,000 of insurance against damage to American private property by reason of enemy attack, mostly within the single month of July, 1942, was the most spectacular drive in the annals of the fire and casualty insurance industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The nation's railroads loaded 42,818,739 freight cars in 1942, an increase of 528,975 cars, or 1.3 per cent, over 1941, the Association of American Railroads reported today. However, it added, actual traffic was nearly 33 per cent greater than in 1941 because cars were loaded more heavily and hauled longer distances.

Governor General Pierre Boisson of French West Africa said yesterday in a New Year message broadcast over the Dakar radio, that the Allied landings in North Africa had put France on the path to victory and that "tomorrow we will be on the firing line with all our forces."

BEFORE picking up the business of the infant new year it might be interesting to take one final glance at developments of the year just ended, many of which bid fair to carry over into 1943 and perhaps become the big issues of the months ahead.
We must also make our production mesh closer with the grand strategy of the war and the requirements and productive capacity of Britain, Russia, China and the rest of the United Nations.

A moderate note of encouragement entered the stock market yesterday on the first trading session of the new year. Dealings on the New York Stock Exchange were too heavily centered in low-priced issues to permit any worth-while bulge, although prices closed moderately higher on the day.

By the end of 1943 the United States Army Air Forces will number 2,500,000 officers and men, by all odds the world's largest military air force. Whether there will be further expansion probably will depend upon how the war goes this year, Army officials indicate.

Almost all that the public has heard about rubber in the last year has been the need for "stretching" the United Nations' scant supply of it to cover war and essential civilian needs until synthetic can take over.

To consider the subject of taxes in terms of "taking inventory" would be unduly optimistic. Inventories are taken usually with a view to disposing of that which is inventoried. Heavy taxes are here to stay a long time and the "stock" will be substantially increased before it is decreased.

Success in the war and the ultimate peace depend on the scientific application of the principles of anthropology, Professor Elsie V. Steedman of Hunter College said yesterday in a departmental report to Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, urging increased training in anthropology to qualify students for work in thirty-six listed government agencies and other services "secret in nature."

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 2 -- Police today were still seeking a motive for the slaying of Gottfried Seegelken, 35-year-old German-born grocer, whose body, stabbed ten times, was found on New Year's Eve in the cellar of his padlocked grocery store at 86 Garfield Avenue here.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The Norwegian Government's opposition to postwar Scandinavian isolation and its belief in Scandinavian collaboration was rendered clear in a broadcast from London to Norway last night by Trygve Lie, Norwegian Foreign Minister.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- Nine new cases of smallpox were reported in Pennsylvania today as public health authorities in this city adopted further precautions designed to keep the disease from the metropolitan area.

Tanks, armor plate, Hall-Scott motors, shells and other essential tools of war have been flowing in steadily increasing volume from the plants of the American Car and Foundry Company and its subsidiaries since 1939. Today the big manufacturing concern, despite its need to maintain production of "peacetime" essentials, such as railway rolling stock and buses, is well ahead of schedules and is looking forward to new records.

Because of the shortages existing among other types of foods, a considerable shift to the use of cereals may be expected during 1943, Clarence Francis, president of General Foods Corporation, declared in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Students at Brooklyn and Queens Colleges will enjoy an extra week's vacation this year because the fuel shortage has caused their authorities to extend the usual January recess.

The American sulphur makers set high records in production and in building up stocks at the mines, without any great strain on facilities, but shipments declined due to the restrictions on wartime shipping and diversion to war use of vessels which normally carry sulphur from the Gulf of Mexico to Atlantic and Pacific Coast consuming areas.

The steel industry continued to record important technical progress in its first full year under wartime operations, according to Lauson Stone, president of Follansbee Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh. "While materially aiding the war program," he says, "many of the industry's developments of the past year will not be fully realized by the general public until production has been reconverted to peacetime applications.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The announcement in London by a spokesman of the Fighting French -- that General de Gaulle cannot consider making an alliance with General Giraud in North Africa until and unless the Imperial Council, deriving from Vichy, is abolished -- has further complicated the problem of effecting French unity against the Axis.

The shifting from peacetime to war production was solved during the year by a beverage container plant when it put the skill and precision of some 300 workers to the mass manufacture of oxygen cylinders needed in high-altitude bombing planes, with virtually no lost time to the men and no idleness of machines.

New types of United States coin and currency will go into general circulation this year. New pennies, made of steel and coated with zinc to conserve vital copper, will be minted next month. Three-cent pieces are scheduled to be minted soon, but no date has been set.

A comprehensive educational program, expected to check the recent growth of juvenile delinquency and improve classroom conditions generally, is to be introduced in the New York City school system when the Spring semester opens next month.

WITH THE AMERICAN AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Jan. 1 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Japanese air base at Shwebo, almost in the center of Burma, received a New Year's Day blasting from American bombers that flew nearly 300 miles from China into enemy territory over towering mountains and dense jungle.

It is with great delight and satisfaction that I receive the welcome news reports about our successes on the far-flung battlefronts. I refer especially to the disastrous defeat of the "invincible" German Army at Stalingrad which was administered by our valiant Russian allies.

When battleships, tanks, aircraft and shells roll down the ways and off the assembly lines ahead of schedule, there lies behind such visible and dramatic evidences of our war power the silent performance of the machine tool makers. This effort is unheralded only so far as the man in the street is concerned.

A CHAPTER of art history told in the images of people -- that is the current exhibition of twentieth-century portraits at the Museum of Modern Art. Out of that exhibition the six portraits shown on these pages were chosen to illustrate the changing trend of modern art, from the academicism of Boldini to the cubism of Picasso.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- Frankie Sinkwich is going into the movies as soon as he is graduated from the University of Georgia. And so, said his wife tonight, is she.

Until midyear of 1942 management engineers found small interest among industrialists concerning post-war plans. Company officials were giving every thing they had to the Big Job, pushing new facilities, improving management and ironing out production wrinkles.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- To the skiers of the University of New Hampshire went the team title today in the twenty-second annual college men's meet of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds. Though they won, as a team, only the combined event, the New Englanders turned in a very well balanced effort to pile up a total of 468.09 points, leading little Norwich, which finished second with 462.67.

DR. GOEBBELS is under constant attack by powerful, invisible enemies against whom he is helpless. He can only try to silence them by --noise. He cannot counter-attack in public; to do so would make their score still better.

Another year with William L. Sayer, New York lawyer, at the helm is indicated for the United States Power Squadrons. The nominating committee has named him to succeed himself as national chief commander, and the annual elections will be held Jan. 16 during the all-day meetings of squadronites at the Hotel Astor.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- From the bitter campaign fought last Winter each side learned lessons which brought into common military parlance the term "hedgehog" to describe stubborn, bristling garrisons. The Germans were reported in the Russian press to have taken precautions to see that garrisons that might be virtually encircled by advance Russian units were provided for a prolonged siege now.

CONRAD AIKEN'S fertility and versatility are partly due to his adroit combination of old and new styles of feeling and expression. He has never been academically dull, nor ever quite originally exciting. But every book of his brings a variation and some sort of refreshing difference.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- British, Norwegian and Canadian pilots in fighter-bombers and fast bombing planes carried out extensive sweeps over Northern France today, attacking targets, chiefly railway traffic and Nazi troops centers, at St. Omer, St. Valery and other points.

Once more a threat in the National Hockey League race, despite their lowly standing, the Rangers will look for further success tonight when they skate against the Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden. The sudden surge of power exhibited by Frank Boucher's stick-wielders recently has caught the interest of New York's ice followers, and a crowd of more than 12,000 will likely be on hand for the fray.

Prime Minister, Province of Quebec The third full year of war, just closed, shows, as far as the Province of Quebec is concerned, a renewed and even more complete dedication to the ideals of freedom and the task of victory, as well as the marshaling of every possible force to those exclusive ends.

The arraignment of Dominick Taddio, 38-year-old war worker, in the Folony Court of Stapleton, S.I., on a charge of killing 19-year-old Mary Rycoitch of Mariners Harbor while on her way to work last Monday morning was postponed again yesterday because of the continued illness of the prisoner, who is a patient at Bellevue Hospital. Taddio has a severe cold.
LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Royal Air Force fighters and anti-aircraft fire destroyed 738 enemy planes over the British Isles and the Continent during 1942, it was announced today.
Three things are almost certain to be true of that popular institution known as a furlough wedding. It will be short, sweet and -- unexpected.

Faced with a serious problem in the shipping of chemicals, the War Production Board's chemicals division believes that "some type of transportation limitations" will have to be made to assure quicker handling of necessary materials for war production.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 -- Trippi is tops!

The German High Command declared at noon yesterday that Velikiye Luki still was holding out stubbornly on Friday despite fierce Soviet attacks, and the Berlin radio repeated the claim last night, according to broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

Four issues of public utility preferred stocks, aggregating $42,502,000, comprised more than half the total of all new stock financing offered to the public here in 1942. The year's total of all stocks marketed was $80,739,000, representing twenty-three flotations, compared with $301,503,000 for seventy-six issues in 1941.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Sweeping westward from captured Velikiye Luki, the Red Army has driven the Germans into Novo Sokolniki, sixty miles from the Latvian border, athwart the trunk line from Leningrad to Kiev, one of the main lateral railroads of Europe, according to reports released here today.

Mayor La Guardia flew to Washington yesterday "to attend to some odds and ends and various chores," the most important of which, he said upon his return, was a conference with representatives of the Navy Department. He boarded a Washington-bound plane at La Guardia Field at 9:03 A.M. and returned at 5:35 P.M., about twenty-five minutes ahead of time, thanks to a tail wind.

ANTIQUES are one item on today's home furnishings with which priorities have not interfered. In fact, as more and more restrictions limit the manufacture of new furniture and accessories these treasures from the past take on added importance.

When the Japanese delivered their surprise attack on Pearl Harbor a little more than a year ago, they not only put our Pacific Fleet out of action temporarily but also threatened to cripple our war economy by cutting us off from sources of essential raw materials in the Far East and South Pacific.

THIS is a simple and engaging story which combines the charms of the ugly-duckling and the poor-little-rich-girl themes. Damaris King was the rich little duckling, who came from a wealthy family in Ohio. Because she had protruding teeth, a squint, bespectacled eyes and a sallow complexion, her mother didn't give a hoot about her and allowed her to be brought up by her grandfather on large doses of how to manage a fortune.

A CHUNKY, smiling man of 56 recently told a group of flying-school graduates that "we have a secret weapon or two up our aerial sleeves that will deal paralyzing blows to our enemies." He added that our Flying Fortresses and Liberators were perhaps the last of the "small bombers."

A glimpse into the problem confronted by a large electric company in converting its plant from peacetime to war production is given by the information division of the War Production Board as a guide for other concerns.

TODAY the United Nations are at war in Europe, in North Africa, in the Near East, in the Pacific, in Russia -- on the battlefields of freedom throughout the world. Men of courage carry the torch of liberty to the oppressed of all nations. But the war within the war -- the fight against the fifth column -- also is playing a vital role in the march to victory.

Day by day in the ranks of industry and among volunteer workers women are seen in increasing numbers doing the very jobs they were doing nearly a quarter of a century ago. In several categories ranging from industry to civilian defense women are recalling old skills to new war service.

The year 1942 saw a wood product, which was developed nearly twenty years ago, command new and widespread industrial importance by entering many new fields of public service which point to notable expansion for the already sizable industry built up around the product.

One week from today the 1943 dog-show season will open with a double program here. While both shows are specialty events they will provide an excuse for fanciers of all kinds of dogs to get together to look over the new stars of the show-ring and do a little prospecting on the immediate outlook for dogs in general and shows in particular.

Vice President Wallace used the phrase "psychological disarmament" in his recent speech on the problems of peace. He said that "a special problem that will face the United Nations immediately upon the attainment of victory over either Germany or Japan will be what to do with the defeated nation.

Small electric motors, some so tiny they could be hidden in a closed fist, are being used in increasingly large numbers on American warplanes to perform numerous small jobs and permit the pilot to give more attention to details dependent more on human judgment.

MUCH as I take off my hat to the splendid work of the Pasadena (Calif.) Playhouse, I question Gilmor Brown's report that, in twenty-five years, his organization has "produced more plays than any other organization in the world."

After a year of sharply curtailed and severely controlled wartime operations the consensus among foreign traders is that the shipping shortage will continue as their principal problem during 1943, as it has been since the United States entered the conflict.

PALM BEACH -- Plans to swell the list of entertainment for men from near-by training centers, Morrison and Boca Raton Fields, Camps Murphy and Higgins, have been announced by various organizations here.

OTTAWA, Jan. 2 -- The war has produced a revolution in Canadian agriculture. In order to meet the demands of Great Britain, which was cut off from all normal European sources of supply, the farmers have been called on to double and triple their production of hogs, cheese, butter, eggs and milk.
From time to time in this column we have recurred to Elmer Davis's remark: "The democracies have a good story to tell, and they ought to tell it." But how does one go about telling a good story?

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- A "war Engineering education for women" program, to give women an opportunity to train for engineering positions, a program believed to be the first of its kind in the nation, has been introduced at Illinois Institute of Technology, President Henry T. Heald announced this week.

The year closed with favorable war news, except for the confusion which temporarily resulted from the assassination of Admiral Darlan on Dec. 24. He was succeeded by General Henri Giraud, Commander in Chief of the French forces. During the month the Russians advanced, capturing a number of towns and by their own reports inflicting serious losses of men and equipment on the Germans.

June was largely made up, so far as concerned financial interest, with discussion of war appropriations and the revenue bill. Army appropriations were quickly passed in an aggregate of $42,000,000,000, but the tax bill was not out of committee in either house of Congress.
With two sophomores, Everett Finestone and Bob Scheer, leading the way with 13 points apiece, the City College basketball team last night defeated Geneva, 61 -- 46, at the Lavender gymnasium.

Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, was appointed in September as WPB vice chairman, with supreme control over scheduling all production programs; to be, in other words, as Mr. Nelson said, "the top production authority."
Yesterday was the first anniversary of the Pact of the United Nations. President Roosevelt marked the occasion with a call for unity, now and after the war is won. He said:

The formation of a Foreign Trade Reconstruction Committee to work with government departments and other interested groups in the planning of post-war foreign commercial policy has just been announced by the National Foreign Trade Council.

General Eugen Ott, who has been German Ambassador to Tokyo since 1938, was sent to Japan as a military observer in 1933 as one of Adolf Hitler's first acts in assuming supreme command of Germany that year, and is regarded as one of the most important creators of the German-Japanese alliance.

Longer hours, three-shift operation and greater utilization of existing facilities, rather than new plants, have characterized the war program of the drug industry. Production virtually has been doubled, with lend-lease and our own armed forces demanding and receiving annual supplies equal to those still needed by the civilian population.

NO less than 238 concerts, covering many phases of the operatic, symphonic and chamber music realm, have attracted combined audiences of at least 208,260 servicemen in the past eight months. This is a conservative estimate that probably does not take into account audiences in remote bases.

Thousands of cargo planes for the transportation of men, munitions and other supplies to every war front in the world are being built by the American aircraft industry. At present hundreds of these giant transports are flying over four rapidly expanding sky routes to Australia, Africa, Russia, China, Great Britain and other destinations.
A FINE, genuine story of an army horse from the time he was born at an Army remount depot until at the end of the book he carries his rider to Bataan to join MacArthur.

THE training of an actor is not too dissimilar from training a horse. You carefully rule his care and feeding, take him out for trial runs as frequently as possible, and you try to keep him from growing stale. You teach him to behave like a thoroughbred, break him of bad habits, and check on any extra-curricular activities which might endanger his career.

The productive capacity of the Americas has become a powerful influence in the world battle for freedom. In the form of raw materials, food and fighting machines, this vast and growing power has helped clinch Allied military and naval successes in North Africa and the Pacific.

Now that the United States has been a year at war, both in the Pacific and in Africa, it should be more possible than it was a year ago to sum up the good and bad points of the American situation and its favorable and unfavorable aspects.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 2 (AP) -- The swollen Willamette River steadily inched over flood levels at Oregon City and Portland tonight, immobilizing paper mills, curtailing shipyard production and routing additional hundreds from their homes.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Great Britain begins the new year with a financial revenue record as the returns issued tonight show the figure for the first nine months of 1942 was 1,766,597,597 -- a net increase of 545,030,041 over the same period of the previous year.

While there can be little mention of specific applications of plastics because of war censorship, the General Electric Company reports an "astonishing growth" of the industry, making itself, more than 1,000 different plastic parts for every battleship that leaves the ways.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Opposition to repeal of overtime wages for work in excess of forty hours a week, compulsory job-freezing "at this time" and all anti-strike legislation, with advocacy of higher taxes for increased social security benefits are parts of the American Federation of Labor's legislative program for 1943, President William Green stated today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 2 -- No trace had been found today of Mrs. Edna Janssen Gilsenan, whom State police described as "considered very dangerous" when they reported her escape on New Year's Eve from the New Jersey State Hospital in Marlboro, to which she was committed in 1937 after a Union County investigation disclosed a series of unexplained deaths and disappearances in her family.

Following an entire day of conferences here between officials of the Petroleum Administration for War and leaders of the oil industry, a tentative priority list was ready last night for submission to Washington.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Following is the text of the statement issued today by Secretary Hull:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Behind the counter of every retail store and above the manager's desk in every wholesale house there probably will hang, before this year is out, a license from the Federal Government permitting the establishment to do business.

Do you remember walking on homemade stilts, making and flying kites and learning a simpler finger trick to show off with exulting cries of "Ahhaaa -- you're hypnotized!" These employments seem to be as satisfying as ever to the young, and generous space is devoted to diagrams and directions for many of them in the "How Book of Cubbing," published by the Boy Scouts of America.

The peak of shopper sacrifices is expected to be reached by July 1, and although consumer goods will continue to be curtailed this year, Americans are assured of the things they need, according to the War Production Board. Two specific items will remain exempt.

Claudio Arrau, Chilean pianist, made his first appearance as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall at the fifth of the season's "students'" concerts. Dimitri Mitropoulos was the conductor and there was a capacity audience of 2,700.

The milinary industry faces encouraging prospects for 1943, inasmuch as no major curtailment of materials is anticipated, according to a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Joseph Lipshie of the Milinary Stabilization Commission.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The text of General de Gaulle's statement follows:

If price and material regulations are observed and a practical procedure for handling them adopted, "they may prove to be blessings in disguise when the really important conversion -- back to peace -- comes," according to a year-end statement for THE NEW YORK TIMES by George A. Renard, executive secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents and former chief of the printing and publishing division of the WPB.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 2 -- Whirlaway, the turf's top-money winner, heads a list of forty-nine thoroughbreds nominated for the eighth running of the $25,000 added Widener Challenge Cup Handicap, the richest horse race of the Winter.

THERE is a catch in the title. At first the reader will be disappointed to discover that the "headhunters" were not Melanesians, nor Japs, nor even marines. They were two inexperienced "explorers" who went to the Solomons to make portraits -- a "pictorial record" of a group of "backward human beings."

New York perhaps needs a bomb or two to make its residents realize the seriousness of the war, Mrs. Eddie Rickenbacker declared yesterday at a press conference at the Waldorf-Astoria, held under the auspices of the War Savings Staff, Treasury Department.

Down a long moving assembly line, the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation's twenty-eight-ton B-24 Liberator bombers are rolling daily, with production well ahead of schedule. These heavy bombers are capable of flying loaded from this country to Hawaii or to Europe with a margin to spare.

More than ever before in American history are the fortunes of labor tied to those of government. The twelve months that followed Pearl Harbor saw the fruition of governmental labor policies that began with the inception of the New Deal in 1933.

Giant bombing planes roll off the assembly lines of a sprawling, bustling plant on a vast site which only a few months ago was a peaceful midwestern cornfield. New ships take form along a waterfront which was neglected marsh land until the pile-drivers, dredges and steam shovels got busy there just after the attack on Pearl Harbor.

CAMBRIDGE, MASS., Jan. 2 -- It is my belief that the United States and her Allies will be victorious over Germany in two years. Japan will give up soon afterward, because with Germany out of the conflict, Japan would not stick it out. The Nazis of Hitler still are our primary foes.

Welcomed by many of its contributors as an opportunity to help keep the home front strong, the Neediest Cases Fund for 1942 has reached a total of $237,695.31 today, the final Sunday of the thirty-first annual appeal on behalf of the families and individuals in greatest want in the city known to eight leading private charities. This total includes yesterday's 119 gifts, amounting to $3,282.60.

OTTAWA, Jan. 2 -- The war has turned Canada from an agricultural industrial country to an industrial agricultural country. Three years ago Canada had never manufactured even a gun barrel, let alone a complete gun and mounting.
MOSCOW, Jan. 2 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

OTTAWA, Jan. 2 -- Canada's biggest single contribution to the war forces of the United Nations has been her production of pilots and air crews trained under the Commonwealth Air Training Plan and now fighting in separate Canadian squadrons or with the R.A.F. on every front.

The new American Theatre Wing Merchant Seamen's Club, at 107 West Forty-third Street, will be opened tomorrow afternoon by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who will cut a tape at 5:30 P.M. placing the unit in service. A "pound" preview open to the public will be held this afternoon at 2 P.M., and from that hour until 10 o'clock any one may be admitted for inspection by "paying" a pound of food.

Railroad securities offered to the public in 1942 amounted to $35,440,000, representing ten issues of equipment trust certificates and one of bonds, compared with $272,491,000 for forty-one issues in 1941. The total for last year was the smallest for any annual period since 1933, when $12,000,000 in one issue was marketed.

COLLINSVILLE, Ill., Jan. 2 -- A dramatic, mass parachute escape from a doomed and plummeting Army bomber today saved the lives of sixteen of nineteen persons aboard the plane which came to grief from unexplained causes while on a flight from Alamogordo, N.M., to Topeka, Kan.

THERE is a sleepy little village on the edge of a trout stream in Southern England to whose inhabitants the phrase "United States paratroops" simply means a nice bunch of American kids who would be welcome back there any time.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Jan. 3 -- The Allies have won the Battle of Buna, clearing that New Guinea area of all Japanese troops, General Douglas MacArthur announced triumphantly in a special communique today.

In its all-out effort to respond to the country's military needs last year, the plastics industry boosted the production of resins from about 450,000,000 pounds in 1941 to 600,000,000 pounds in 1942 and doubled in dollar value the output of molded and fabricated articles, according to a statement prepared exclusively for THE NEW YORK TIMES by John M. Wetherby of the Society of the Plastics Industry.
American cotton textile mills broke all records in 1942 by consuming more than 11,000,000 bales of the white fiber and weaving and distributing more than 12,000,000,000 yards of cloth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The dogged and seemingly fatalistic perseverance with which the Japanese hold to a plan, once they have committed themselves, finds new exemplification as the battle of the South Pacific progresses.

THE holiday season having passed, the night club entrepreneurs now contemplate their wares and think of improvements and changes. Indicative of this train of thought are the many and diverse events announced for the week.
WINSTON CHURCHILL once described Russian policy as "a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma." Joseph Stalin, on the other hand, expressed the opinion that "our policy is simple and clear."

A TEN-PAGE series of sketches of "The Second A.E.F. -- A Portfolio" by Feliks Topolski appears in the January issue of Fortune Magazine. In the portfolio the artist depicts our Army at its training in the British Isles.

OF the four one-man shows which opened between the holidays, two were primarily traditional, while the other two were distinctly modernistic. Technically speaking, the most accomplished brushwork and most conventionally decorative effects are to be found in the work of the late William Bruce Ellis Ranken, in the memorial show at the Ferargil Gallery.

Some installment sellers will be forced out of business in 1943 by the further drastic decreases in receivables to be expected as a result of credit restrictions, but because of the elasticity of small-store operations the number of failures probably will be smaller than often is prophesied, William J. Cheyney, executive director of the Retail Credit Institute of America, said in a year-end statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A 10 per cent cut in the value of fuel-oil rationing coupons in seventeen Eastern States and the District of Columbia, effective at 12:01 o'clock Monday morning, was ordered tonight by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator.

Within the last few months recognition has been growing that standards are of vital importance in winning the war, according to a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by P.G. Agnew, secretary of the American Standards Association.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 2 -- Max Wexler's Dispose scored his second handicap victory of the Florida season at Tropical Park today when the 5-year-old son of Discovery prevailed by a length in the $2,000 Winter Handicap. The Flamingo Stakes winner of 1941 sped the six furlongs in 1:10 4-5 under Ken McCombs and paid $9.20 for $2.
This is the story of the wartime refrigeration industry, which ceased manufacturing "cold" for housewives early in 1942 and which is now helping to "turn the heat" on the Axis.

Manufacturers of portable lamps led a perilous existence during 1942 and finally were put out of business for the duration on Dec. 10, according to Benjamin M. Robbins, executive secretary of the National Lamp and Shade Manufacturers Association.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Federal Judge John P. Barnes today restrained the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Company from violating price control regulations of the Office of Price Administration.

Looking forward into another year ordinarily involves "uncertainty and the exercise of some imagination, because the trend of industrial activity is constantly changing, at times very sharply," Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, says in a year-end statement issued yesterday.

The annual benefit dinner dance of the Aero Squadron Association has been canceled this season because of the war and in its stead a dinner will be given on Saturday at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street. Proceeds from the fete will be directed to the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, 283-85 Lexington Avenue.

City readers of THE TIMES might be interested in hearing at first hand the problem faced by a farmer. Eighteen months ago I employed steadily a foreman and three men on a fruit farm. Six months later I was reduced to two men, having lost the foreman and two others, and having picked up one unskilled man in their place.

Many of the diamond cutters in New York who formerly concentrated on gems have converted their facilities to make industrial tools, according to James R. McCarthy of Baumgold Brothers, Inc., one of the largest cutters in the country.
Men's clothing manufacturers are looking back upon one of the most hectic years any of them can recall, and most of them believe it was the most unusual twelve months in the history of the industry.
LONDON, Jan. 3 (Reuter) -- The Daily Mail is publishing an editorial tomorrow stating that there is "considerable dissatisfaction" with the course of the campaign in Africa.

The United Hunts Racing Association's proposal to provide financial aid to hunts meets along the Atlantic seaboard during the coming Spring and Summer is being enthusiastically supported, and consideration is being given to suggestions that United Hunts be allotted one or two open dates during the regular New York racing season.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 3 -- "New York" was the password that saved Lieutenant George Humbrecht of St. Louis from Arab suspicion and opened up a bountiful hospitality that never let his plate or glass go empty, the American flier said today after returning to his Twelfth Air Force unit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- You need $6 today for every $5 you spent two years ago to meet the cost of living.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Allied fighters swept over the Faid and Sfax areas of Tunisia yesterday, destroying enemy motor vehicles and armored cars, and supported the slight patrol activity in the north reported by an Allied Headquarters communique.

The new year will provide only what men and women bring to it, the Rev. Jesse W. Stitt declared yesterday at Greenwich Presbyterian Church, 145 West Thirteenth Street, citing racial problems as crying for solution.
A High command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- More than 3,000 looked on today as eighteen skiers sought honors in the first competitive jump of the season, held under the auspices of the Bear Mountain Sports Association. Hans Strand of the home club, former national champion, won in the senior division with jumps of 132 and 133 feet and a total of 221.9 points.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 3 -- Although the German radio reports that General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery is about ready to launch a large-scale offensive, reports from the British Eighth Army reaching Cairo today give no indication of anything unusual in the battle area.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation has received an additional year from the Securities and Exchange Commission before it must restore the balances remaining in its accounts designated "special capital surplus" and "surplus prior to Jan. 1, 1938" to its common capital stock account.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- British fliers, pounding relentlessly at Japanese bases in Burma, yesterday made their fourth attack in a week against the airdrome at Magwe on the Irrawaddy River and blasted two airfields near the west coast of Akyab, objective of Field Marshal Sir Archibald Wavell's land drive, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Operations in oats continue somewhat restricted owing to fears that any upturn of consequence would be followed by increased imports from Canada. That country harvested 692,000,000 bushels of oats last year, compared with 325,000,00 bushels in 1941, and supplies of grain per animal unit greatly exceed those of any other year recorded.

Net equity or the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., in income of subsidiaries for the third quarter of 1942 was $3,674,842, comparing with $3,551,058 in the same period in 1941, and for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 it was $12,920,584, against $12,086,160 in the year before.

Dozens of firm changes marked the year-end, for there was a general reshuffling of partnerships. Many former partners became associated with other firms as employes. Only occasionally was the trend in the other direction, because of business conditions in the financial industry.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 3 -- The ground forces were still bogged down by mud in Tunisia, but the American and British air forces had their most successful day in the air yesterday against the Germans and Italians.

Commissioner Valentine has taken a wise step in calling for stricter enforcement of the speed limit by the police and in increasing the night shift of motor-cycle men in order to safeguard pedestrians in the city during the abnormal conditions of the dimout. The killing of five persons by automobiles and one by trolley car in a single night last week is alarming.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- The American College of Surgeons today released a list of 2,989 hospitals in the United States, Canada and other countries approved by its 1942 survey. The list shows an increase of 116 over last year's roster.

Winter winds are howling around corners these days, taking sly nips at feminine complexions. Steam heating contributes further to drying and chapping processes -- and all this at a time when many women have had to give up complicated beauty routines because their days are full of war work.

Book publishing now enters an active period after the usual December lull when few new books are published. The January schedule contain many titles, though not so many, it appears, as in past years. There is a noticeably small amount of fiction, with war books continuing to dominate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Eight more industrial plants have been selected to receive the Army-Navy production award for outstanding performance on war work, according to an announcement today by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.

The season's first performance of Charpentier's "Louise" at the Metropolitan Opera House will be given on Friday afternoon of next week. The conductor will be Sir Thomas Beecham, who never has conducted the work here. Grace Moore will sing the title role.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 3 -- The only sailor who was not a "Cow Bay" native carried off the laurels today as the three-day anniversary regatta of the Frostbite Yacht Club, the twelfth of its existence, came to a close. He was Ed Raymond from Stamford, sailing Achilles.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Jan. 4 -- General Douglas MacArthur reported today that Allied forces had completed destruction of Japanese forces in the Buna Mission area and that the "enemy's situation is now hopeless."

The people of the United States owe a debt to the nation's railroads that will be most difficult to repay. After virtually relegating them to the status of a stepchild, they called upon the railroads immediately after the attack on Pearl Harbor to supply most of their transport needs.

Although most wholesale markets were quiet last week, following record holiday volume, it was indicated that the coming week will bring a large influx of retail buyers seeking various types of immediate and Spring merchandise, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident offices.

Declaring that "the pattern of the brave new world now is taking shape," the Rev. Dr. Moses Richardson Lovell, preaching yesterday morning for the first time as pastor of the merged congregations of Central Congregational Church and the Clinton Avenue Community Church, at Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, emphasized the rise and continued need of new understanding among individuals, religious denominations and nations.

Pointing out that the time has come for the United Nations to begin considering post-war problems, Sir Godfrey Haggard, British Consul General here, warned yesterday that if a third world war was to be averted the United Nations must be prepared to use force to keep errant nations in line with the accepted code of international behavior.
" I wish I could get out of the business," said the man to a reporter. "The women are driving me crazy. I have no nerves left. I spent all day in bed yesterday trying to get calm."

The New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday will admit to the list and to dealings new $1 par common stock and $100 par class A and B preference stock of the Pittston Company, and will suspend present no par common stock from dealings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In the Navy's official report on her, she was listed merely as a "United States battleship." Yet the story of how this unnamed battlewagon, which previously had survived murderous attacks by waves of enemy dive-bombers and torpedo planes and had shot down thirty-two of them, tore into action off Savo Island Nov. 14 and sank four of the Japanese Emperor's warships, emerged as one of the naval epics of the war.
RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. 3 -- There was a decided military note today in the skiing atmosphere at the lavish Pico Peak development, where some 1,500 snow enthusiasts enjoyed a program of outdoor activity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- "Vigorous action" against draft delinquents will be started by the Department of Justice on Feb. 1, according to a warning announcement issued here today by the War Manpower Commission.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Football -- U.S. version -- made its debut in Bermuda today with a team representing a United States Army detachment defeating a Navy eleven, 19 to 18, in the Lily Bowl.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 3 -- Brazil emerged into 1943 grown greater economically, financially and in both internal and external politics. If bank showings, that is, deposits and money loaned, are an index of prosperity, Brazil is prosperous.

So far as the local quintets are concerned, college basketball resumes a full-time schedule this week, with virtually every squad going into action at least once. Although two double-headers are listed for Madison Square Garden, Columbia, which does not appear on the Eighth Avenue floor, will engage in three games during the week, giving metropolitan court fans their first opportunity on Saturday night to see the Lions this season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today simplification of the method of rationing light grades of fuel oil used by utilities and other industries for purposes other than heating which will eliminate the necessity of handling large numbers of coupons.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 3 -- Raw steel output throughout the nation last week slipped off one point to 98 per cent of rated capacity. Most of this small decline was due to interference by flood waters in certain steel areas. However, by last night, practically all steel plants in the Pittsburgh, Wheeling and Youngstown districts were back in operation.

In 1929 the United States and forty-six other countries entered into a convention at Geneva which covered the reciprocal treatment of prisoners of war and of the wounded and sick of armies in the field. Because of an oversight it says nothing about seamen and others who are not in the armed forces and who must take to lifeboats when their ships are sunk.

Ability to come back in a fence-off against a rival who had beaten her in a final round-robin match enabled Miss Zelda Atkins, senior art student at Cooper Union Institute, to triumph in the women's novice foil tournament at the Salle Santelli yesterday.

A new drive has been started urging dealers to speed up the salvage of old parts in accordance with the instructions for return issued by individual manufacturers, according to an announcement by the household refrigeration section of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 3 -- Louis Valle, 42-year-old waiter of 1597 Castleton Avenue, Port Richmond, S.I., who allegedly stabbed to death his daughter and sister-in-law and wounded seriously two other relatives in Floral Park last night, was arraigned today on a first-degree murder charge and held for the grand jury.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The first promotions of officers of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps were announced here today by the War Department. The list of advancements included all members of the corps's first officer-candidate class, the members of which were commissioned on Aug. 29, and, in addition, outstanding members of later classes.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 3 -- "1918!" -- These numerals now chalked on many a wall in Nazi-occupied countries irk the Germans particularly because of the memories they recall.
MOSCOW, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Mobilization of medical and surgical resources to combat cancer, the second highest cause of death in America, embraces 386 cancer clinics in hospitals of the United States and Canada which appear on the new approved list of the American College of Surgeons.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- British newspapers will be able to maintain publication without loss of circulation and without further reduction in the number of pages under the terms of an agreement reached between government officials and the Newsprint Supply Company, it was disclosed today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- Two Army Air Force sergeants, both of whom had been decorated twice previously, today received Oak Leaf Clusters at the hands of Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, Chief of the American Army Air Force in the Southwest Pacific.
A Brooklyn patrolman, veteran of twenty years in the Police Department, was arrested early yesterday morning at his home, 375 Eighty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, and charged with homicide.
The A.J. Siris Products Company, manufacturers of powder puffs, has rented three floors comprising about 33,000 square feet in 130 East Thirteenth Street through Spear Co., brokers.

The New York Film Critics formally presented awards to the film "bests" of 1942 at a reception yesterday afternoon in the Barberry Room of the Hotel Berkshire. The presentation ceremonies were broadcast over the Blue Network in a fifteen-minute program, during which James Cagney, winner of the best male actor award for his protrayal of the late George M. Cohan in "Yankee Doodle Dandy," reenacted scenes in the film from Hollywood.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- The board of trustees of Hull House denied today that communistic or political activities had any part in the recent resignation of Miss Charlotte E. Carr as head resident.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Air war in the South Pacific flared anew over the week-end, with Army and Navy bombers and fighters in four separate raids crippling one enemy destroyer and probably sinking another in waters off New Georgia Island and taking a toll of Japanese anti-aircraft guns and other installations at Munda, on New Georgia, the Navy Department reported today.

Prices of cotton continued to move upward last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts advanced 34 to 37 points, or $1.70 to $1.85 a bale, following gains of 3 to 20 points in the previous week and increases of 10 to 24 points in the week prior to that.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 3 -- That Finland will never declare war on the United States was categorically asserted by Premier J.W. Rangell at a press conference in Helsinki on Dec. 31, it was learned here today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A communique:

Women desiring to prepare themselves to replace men in war industries were urged yesterday by Professor William Allen, director of the City College engineering, science and management war training program, to enroll in the twenty-seven tuition-free training courses given in the evening at the City College School of Technology, Amsterdam Avenue and l40th Street.

Some of the boys working on the Alaska highway, according to Theodore Strauss, reporting for this newspaper, have radios; and on these instruments "they may get broadcasts from Fairbanks, the excellent reports from Moscow, and, most easily, Tokyo." That is how far away they are, and that is how the earth is shaped 400 miles south of the Arctic Circle.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- According to information reaching the Belgian news agency here today, the Nazis have ordered cancellation of all sports events at Antwerp and Brussels in retaliation for acts of sabotage against German soldiers and police.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Morale is high among members of the Army Nurse Corps serving overseas, according to nurses' letters made public today by the American Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Dies Committee on Un-American Activities was criticized sharply by one of its members today as it made public its annual report, reviewing its work and taking credit for anti-Axis successes on the home front.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Despite operating handicaps mainly due to wartime transportation difficulties, Maryland's race tracks turned revenues totaling $1,612,389, a record high, into the State Treasury in 1942.

With the addition of "You'll See Stars," which had its delayed opening at Maxine Elliott's on New Year's Eve and then vanished after four performances, the number of Saturday night's casualties on Broadway rose to six. The show purported to be a musical comedy biography of Gus Edwards, who developed many stars in vaudeville's heyday, and was written by Herman Timberg and Leo Edwards.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Jan. 1 (Delayed) -- The Japanese forces in the Giropa Point area of the Buna front were shattered today by a new Allied tank attack, and some Japanese appeared to be attempting to break away from the Allied front lines into the jungles and swamps south of the Point.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The capture of Mozdok, announced by Moscow today, apparently meant not only that the German push into the Caucasus toward the oil center of that region had ended but also that the Russians now were engaged in rolling back the Nazis and their Fascist allies.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 109.6 to 109.8, an increase of 2 per cent. Again, most of the activity occurred in the prices of agricultural commodities. The combined rise in the prices of corn, wheat, cattle, hogs and lambs caused the farm products and the raw materials indexes to rise 7 per cent and 4 per cent, respectively.
LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio and heard here by Reuter and the Soviet Monitor follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- Demands for creation of a bi-partisan Congressional committee to assist in prosecution of the war were renewed tonight as legislators returned to the capital for Wednesday's formal opening of the Seventy-eighth Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Miss Marian Anderson, Negro contralto, will sing at the Department of the Interior Building Wednesday night at the formal presentation to the Federal Government of a mural picturing Miss Anderson's "Lincoln Memorial Concert."

LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information tonight officially charged the "charlatans of Hitler's headquarters" with lying in continuing to announce that the German garrison in Velikiye Luki was still resisting the Russians.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- As the Work Projects Administration is liquidated the Army will adopt a number of its sewing projects, which during November repaired 180,000 items of Army clothing.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Jan. 3 (AP) -- River observers predicted a "fairly quick" run-off of the Ohio River tonight as the crest of a flood, turned back by this manufacturing city's five-mile wall, approached Cincinnati.

The first American White Paper published since the war began reviews the foreign policy of the United States during the "fateful decade" from 1931 to 1941. Fateful is the word to describe the crowded years that hurried toward disaster like the developing plot of a Greek tragedy, and this diplomatic record, perhaps because it is summary and impersonal, communicates the sense of hurry and inevitability in striking fashion.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Ceiling prices on flour were raised last week, but it is expected that it will take several days for the milling trade to adjust itself to the new conditions, and especially as to the price that can be paid for cash wheat and still hold the price of flour within the ceiling levels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The long Congressional career of 81-year-old Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska ended officially at noon today by the terms of a Constitutional amendment which he sponsored.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Jan. 4 (AP) -- A communique:

WITH AMERICAN AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Jan. 2 -- (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Captain Charles Wellborn of Daingerfield and Hughes Springs, Texas, scored the United States Air Task Force's first victory of the New Year in this war theater today by destroying a twin-engined Japanese I-45 reconnaissance bomber over Burma.

There is a growing place for the church in the world of today declared the Rev. Harry Hooper, formerly of Boston, yesterday in his first sermon as the new minister of the Unitarian Church of Staten Island, New Brighton. Mr. Hooper preached on "The Church in Wartime."

Alternate frozen and canned strawberries with your traditional morning orange juice, suggest home economists of the United States Department of Agriculture. Or try fresh apples or pears, applesauce or baked apples, or bottled juices -- cranberry, apple, grape.

HOLLYWOOD, Calf., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Bing Crosby's twenty-room home was destroyed tonight by fire believed to have started from a short circuit while his wife and four children were taking down Christmas tree decorations.

Despite protests by Mayor La Guardia, the milk price increase of 1 to 2 cents a quart was put into effect last midnight for all sales in the New York metropolitan milk marketing area except home deliveries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Seven agencies of the Federal Government, six of them war agencies, advised today against blanket suspension of State labor laws.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the affairs of two more State banking concerns had been liquidated and terminated. They were the State Bank of Commerce of Brockport and the Wadsworth Savings and Loan Association of Rochester.

The five-story apartment building at 997 Kelly Street, near Westchester Avenue, in the Bronx, has been acquired by a client of Benjamin Antin, lawyer, from the Vicetta Holding Corporation, for cash above a mortgage of $46,860.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Total civilian employment in the Executive branch of the Federal Government in October was 2,687,093, an increase of 137,619, or 5.4 per cent, over September, the Civil Service Commission reported today.

The five-story loft building on a lot 19 by 100 feet at 254 Fifth Avenue has been acquired by Helen Weiss from James, George and Helen Coggill and Virginia A.J. Beattie for cash. The purchase price was about $21,000, according to Armstrong Armstrong, brokers in the deal.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Large government orders for pork meat and lard were placed last week with packers, keeping the market well cleaned up. Despite the prospects of increased receipts soon, no disposition to sell freely is shown, as the demand exceeds the supply, packers report.

The Feast of the Holy Name of Jesus was celebrated yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral with a solemn mass presided over by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, assisted by the archpriest, Mgr. Bryan J. McEntegart, national secretary of the Catholic Near East Welfare Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The first of a series of messages by prominent Americans on the need for buying war bonds to insure victory was made public today by the Treasury Department. J.P. Morgan, former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York, Dr. William Beebe of the New York Zoological Society, and Major Edward Bowes led the list of endorsers of the government's bond-buying program.

A tie was the best the New York Rangers could do in their National Hockey League game with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. But, viewing the matter from the scoring sequence, the local skaters were more than content to settle for the deadlock.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- Japanese evacuees at the Jerome relocation center in Arkansas have turned the camp into a nest of sabotage and unrest, The Commercial Appeal reported tonight.

Immediate establishment of a State Economic Council to prepare for the industrial recession expected to come with the end of the war was urged yesterday by the State organization of the American Labor party in a legislative program announced by George S. Counts, State chairman, and Alex Rose, State secretary.

ON THE ARAKAN FRONT, BURMA, Jan. 3 (Reuter) -- Seven men crouching in a light sampan, an open native boat, were machine-gunned with dumdum (soft lead) bullets by six Japanese planes. Six men survived.

OTTAWA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- To each of Canada's twenty-five newsprint manufacturers has been assigned an established percentage of total production under a compensation plan for the newsprint industry, which was made public tonight by the Prices Board.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- Acting Air Commodore Whitney Willard Straight, 29-year-old American-born millionaire, escaped from the Germans in France by climbing a rope in a converted gymnasium, swinging through a window and overpowering a guard, The Sunday Chronicle said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Not the least of the preparations going forward today for the opening of Congress on Wednesday was the polishing of the big brass kettle where the Senate's bean soup simmers. That bean soup has been a daily feature on the menu of the upper chamber's restaurant for at least forty years, and one veteran waiter said he reckoned it was "compulsory under the Constitution."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The honors still remain with General Douglas MacArthur as our fighting general. May all our generals be worthy of his example in their coming battle tests.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- Lieutenant Lawrence Durrell of Scarborough, N.Y., today told how he "caught hell" during an American dive-bombing raid on the Japanese base at Lungling, barely got his damaged plane away from Japanese territory, parachuted from an altitude of 400 feet, and then trekked across the rugged Yunnan Mountains.

The OWI's report that "there is no excessive drinking among troops" and that "no American Army in all history has been so orderly" may disappoint those mistaken reformers who are looking for arguments to justify their efforts to inflict the evils of prohibition on us again.

Freight car loadings in the first quarter of 1942 are expected to be about 3.4 per cent above actual loadings in the 1942 period, according to estimates compiled by the thirteen Shippers' Advisory Boards made public yesterday by the Association of American Railroads.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- Informed sources said today that the removal of at least some Vichyites from office in North Africa is "almost a certainty," but doubted that the whole French Imperial Council would be liquidated, as General Charles de Gaulle has demanded.

WITH THE AMERICAN AIR FORCES in Tunisia, Jan. 2 (Delayed) -- The ground has never looked so good to me in my life as it does right now, for I have just returned from the second biggest bombing raid of the war on Tunis.

The German war machine is suffering a serious labor shortage in which the Russian campaign is a major factor, the tenth World Economic Survey of the Economic, Financial and Transit Department of the League of Nations, just released by the Columbia University Press, declares.
A few of the noteworthy experiences listed by local observers of field and stream during the past year appear in the various summaries that crop up in the mail these days.

Pan American Airways Clippers have recently been shuttling back and forth across the South Atlantic with almost monotonous regularity, making twelve crossings in less than fourteen days, it was learned yesterday when a Clipper arrived at La Guardia Field.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A five-point plan, streamlined to gear 1943 baseball with wartime travel restrictions, was expected to be presented by Commissioner K.M. Landis Tuesday at his emergency session with officials of the National and American Leagues.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 -- Claire Trevor has been assigned to a leading role in "Right Guy," a screen story by Hal Smith and Sam Budd which Columbia purchased in October. Lou Breslow and Adele Commandini are preparing the scenario for Producer David Chatkin, and filming will begin early in February.

MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (Canadian Press) -- The Montreal Canadiens battled the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight to a 4-4 draw before a crowd of 8,000, with the result that Toronto dropped to a tie with Boston on top of the National Hockey League, while Montreal continued in a cellar deadlock with the New York Rangers.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- The outlines of the program which Governor Dewey has in mind for the reorganization of the State government are scheduled to become more clear this week, when the Governor, the first of his party to rule the State in twenty years, delivers his first annual message to the Legislature.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 3 -- One of the first acts of the new Fighting French Governor Bayerdelle in French Somaliland was to return the radio sets confiscated two years ago by the Vichy authorities, according to an authentic report reaching Cairo from Jibuti.

Net profit of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 1942, amounted to $2,589,248, equal after preferred dividends to $1.83 a share for 902,432 common shares, comparing with $4,270,312, or $3.70 a share, in the preceding year.
WASHINGTON, Jam 3 -- From today on, every American warplane -- bomber, fighter, transport, trainer or other type -- will have a name of its own and not just mere number.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- United States heavy bombers, escorted by 300 fighters flown by British and Allied pilots, swept over Western France this afternoon and blasted the docks and U-boat base at St. Nazaire again after four attacks there during November.

Singing of unusual distinction was heard from Susanne Fisher, American soprano, at her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Miss Fisher had appeared previously in this city in several leading roles at the Metropolitan, where she made her debut in 1935. after a five-year sojourn abroad.
The Neponsit Beach Hospital, a city institution for children at Rockaway, Queens, will be shut down as a fuel oil conservation measure, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Obscure members of the British Public had their turn today when the second half of the new year's honors list emerged with 872 names of men and women, ranging from a Spitfire test pilot to a donkeyman in the merchant navy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan announced today he would introduce legislation as soon as the new Congress convenes to remove Rexford G. Tugwell as Governor of Puerto Rico.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 3 -- In another three months the Chungking headquarters of the United States Office of War Information expects to inhabit a new $75,000 building midway between Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's house and the American Army headquarters in the uptown section of the city.

UPTON SINCLAIR is a one-man mass-production word factory. He says he has supported himself since he was 16 by writing fiction, a remarkable achievement indeed for an indefatigable political pamphleteer who in forty years of practice has learned very little about the art and craft of fiction. His publications, ranging from fiery pamphlets to monstrously long novels, now number more than 100.

GREENBANK, Del., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Women, manning a machine gun and rifle, will assume another wartime emergency duty tomorrow -- the operation of the main tower guardhouse at the New Castle County Workhouse.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 3 -- In another three months the Chungking headquarters of the United States Office of War Information expects to inhabit a new $75,000 building midway between Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's house and the American Army headquarters in the uptown section of the city.

GREENBANK, Del., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Women, manning a machine gun and rifle, will assume another wartime emergency duty tomorrow -- the operation of the main tower guardhouse at the New Castle County Workhouse.
