The Bishop of Wuerttemberg has written Propaganda Minister Goebbels protesting that "attacks on Christianity pour out from German printing presses" but that "the church is prohibited to print the Bible," the British Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday in an English-language broadcast to Europe recorded by the F.C.C.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- The conservation of natural and artificial gas is urged by Commissioner Maurice C. Burritt in reporting to the Public Service Commission the results of a survey of gas plants of fourteen utilities located west of Albany.
Two properties in Mount Vernon and a large estate at Ossining were among the Westchester holdings reported yesterday as having passed into new ownerships.
Because of the important changes in the 1942 Revenue Act, income tax returns will be required by the government from millions more persons this year.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- In striking contrast to the lack of breeze which hampered New Year's Day racing at Larchmont Yacht Club, excellent sailing conditions made possible a program of six races in the finale of the holiday celebration of twelve years of Frostbite dinghy competition today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- In the face of warnings by Southern Democrats that the action might turn the slim Democratic majority in the House into a minority, Representative Marcantonio of New York announced today "a plan to pass the anti-poll tax bill in 1943."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Members of Congress were inclined today to view the nearly issued American White Book as proof that the Army and Navy disregarded months of warning by State Department officials that the Japanese planned sudden war in the Pacific.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 3 -- Adolf Hitler is becoming gray-haired, it was revealed today in Swedish press quotations from German newspapers.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Two more persons were missing today in the flood waters of the Willamette River, which already had claimed seven lives, as the crest surged into the Portland area.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- Philadelphians by the thousands visited family physicians and city health centers today for vaccination to protect them against the current outbreak of smallpox in the State

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Instead of the predicted economic collapse, a period of great prosperity for a few years immediately following the war is quite likely, but the "real test" mill come "after the comparatively easy period of transition," according to a report published today by the Brookings Institution.

The most recent picture of Hitler has just reached here. It shows the Fuehrer addressing the Nazi meeting at the Munich beer hall on Nov. 8, and was transmitted from London by radio. Radiophotos are usually not as sharp as ordinary photographs, and because of their lack of clarity make no favorable portraits.

" Bigger and bigger taxes, but no waste spending," is the keynote for legislative activities of the New York State League of Women Voters this year. Pledged to back a "pay-as-you-go" policy of taxation, individual leagues throughout the State are studying the functions of State and government agencies on the local level.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Diplomatic circles here today regard the prospects as good for a meeting between General Charles de Gaulle, leader of Fighting France, and General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner for French Africa, on French soil for the discussion of a fusion of all French elements now fighting the Nazis.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (Reuter) -- The capture of Mozdok, one of the most important industrial centers in the Northern Caucasus, is another confirmation of how rapidly and successfully the Russians are exploiting the initiative they have wrested from the Germans.

While the total resources of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York at the close of 1942 came close to $3,000,000,000 for the first time in its history, those of the Irving Trust Company attained $1,000,000,000 for the first time, making it the ninth bank in New York City with assets of a billion dollars or more.

The members of the congregation of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, joined in a double celebration yesterday morning in commemoration of the 110th anniversary of the founding of the church and the tenth anniversary of the rectorship of the Rev. Dr. John W. Suter.

DETROIT, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The astonishing Boston Bruins, who have stayed on or near the top of the National Hockey League race without winning, gained their first victory in eight games by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 2, tonight before 12,209 spectators.

Beginning with news of the assassination of Admiral Darlan, the past week was more or less confused. This was familiar enough in the closing week of a calendar year. But, so far as the war news went, matters were not unfavorable.

MAJOR FRANK CAVANAUGH peered with failing eyes at his Fordham eleven as it was engaged in a runaway game some fifteen years or so ago. The Iron Major, his eyesight almost gone, was near the end of the trail. His shrapnel wounds from the first World War were taking their inexorable toil.
May I comment on Morris D. Forkosch's letter replying to the recent letter of Ernest Dann on increased prices for farm produce to insure the government's needs for 1943?

American diplomacy during the decade which began with Japan's invasion of Manchuria and ended with the attack on Pearl Harbor shows up creditably, if also poignantly, in the White Book issued by Secretary Hull on Saturday under the title "Peace and War." It is hard to see how our Government could have done more, in honor, than it did do to stave off the world-wide war.

DETROIT, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Ford Motor Company described for the first time tonight the extent to which its plants in five States are turning out war materials. A special statement, sanctioned by the War Department, disclosed that Ford factories in Michigan, Minnesota Missouri, Illinois and Pennsylvania are making tanks, bombers, jeeps, gun mounts, armor plate, transport gliders, trucks, aircraft engines, turbo-superchargers, tank engines, truck and jeep motors and tires, tubes and laminated glass.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- Fighting French forces, rolling swiftly across the Sahara, have swept several hundred miles into Libya from the Lake Chad territory of French Equatorial Africa and are "continuing northward" in a drive threatening the rear of the Axis forces, the Fighting French reported tonight.

In a slam-bang contest that matched the fracas staged by the teams two weeks ago the New York Rovers battled the Coast Guard Cutters from Curtis Bay, Baltimore, to a 3-all overtime draw at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The article from Washington stating that the Department of Justice had asked the Supreme Court not to erase from its calendar a case in which four justices were disqualified, which reduced the number below the necessary quorum of six, as set forth in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 23, presents an interesting question.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Japan protested as an "unfriendly act" the prohibition by the United States of the export of iron and steel scrap to that country, but the protest was without avail.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Prices of corn, both cash and futures, went last week into the highest ground of the season, 97 cents a bushel being paid for fancy old crop No. 2 yellow, the highest price quoted for that variety since 1937, and closing sales on futures on the Board of Trade yesterday being about the top.

The State Labor Relations Board has handled 10,002 industrial disputes since its establishment in 1937, 90 per cent of which were settled without the necessity of formal hearings, according to a report yesterday.

The firm of McLaughlin, Baird Reuss, members of the New York Stock Exchange, has been formed to transact a bond brokerage business specializing in railroad securities. The new firm, which will have offices at 1 Wall Street, consists of John F. McLaughlin, who has been associated with A.M. Kidder Co. for the last twenty years; Harold S. Baird.

These days, faintly voiced and in widely scattered areas of thought and geography, a suggestion is being made that some woman be given the high honor -- and, incidentally, be it said, the possibly futile labors and almost unbearable responsibility -- of sitting in with our men at the conference to follow upon the winning of the war.

Three Supreme Court justices, two in Brooklyn and one in Queens, a Kings County Judge and a Queens County Surrogate all ascended the bench in their various tribunals yesterday. They had been elected to office in the political campaign last Fall.

Harcourt, Brace announced yesterday that it would publish this Spring an authorized biography of the Wright brothers. The author of the forthcoming detailed account of the aviation pioneers is Fred C. Kelly, a magazine writer, who is a native of the same section of Ohio where the Wrights made their early experiments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- Speaker Sam Rayburn served notice tonight that the Administration will make an all-out fight in the new Congress for legislation to continue the lend-lease and reciprocal trade agreements programs which will expire in June unless renewed.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 4 -The tightening of the blockade of Nazi-held Europe by the Allied landings in French Africa, cutting off supplies Germany received from that source, has inspired a Berlin charge, voiced in an edition of the Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung that was received here today, of a "world monopoly" of phosphate fertilizer under "American domination."

LONDON, Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- German fighter pilots, smarter and more numerous on the Western Air Front in recent weeks, have developed new tactics with considerable success in their battle against American heavy bombers over France, United States fliers said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The special Senate (Maloney) committee investigating the renewed critical shortages of gasoline and fuel oil on the Eastern Seaboard heard today from the five administrators closest to the situation what the public should expect in the months to come.

In the pre-dawn darkness yesterday, Dorothy Huber, 23 years old, of 785 East 149th Street, the Bronx, was stabbed fatally by an unidentified assailant while walking to work at the Ward Baking plant, 143d Street and Wales Avenue, the Bronx.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The Moscow radio announced in a special communique tonight the capture of the big German air base of Chernishkovsky and the railway station of Chernishkov. The broadcast was heard by the Soviet monitor in London.
A Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique as broadcast to Europe in English by the Tokyo radio and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

As a group skeet shooters should be highly elated when they look back and review the year to find that their sport, along with trapshooting, contributed considerably to the general training of the armed forces.

Cotton prices moved into higher ground again yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed 10 to 15 points above Saturday's final quotations. Moderate trade price-fixing, New Orleans replacement buying and commission-house covering, accounting for the advances, said to have been instigated by the conviction that Congress will act soon to revise the parity computation formula and by strength in the grain markets.

WITH AMERICAN PARACHUTE TROOPS in Tunisia, Jan. 2 (Delayed) -- Tired and suffering from hivelike bumps on their bodies, six American paratroopers returned today and told how they spent nearly a month sabotaging communications far behind enemy lines and of escaping by boldly driving through a German-held town in an Italian truck.

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, 43 years old, the former labor "czar" of Fulton Fish Market, went on trial in General Sessions yesterday with four others on an extortion-conspiracy indictment. His co-defendants are James Carlo, 52, of 265 Lafayette Street; Nicholas DeStefano, 36, Carlo's nephew, of 134 West Fifty-eighth Street; Salvatore Serrago, 38, and Harry (Bonsignore) Ponze, 38, both of 10 Monroe Street.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 4 (AP) -- A communique:

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 4 -- Paying for his great record, the racing champion Whirlaway must carry top weight of 132 pounds when he goes after the Winter's biggest stake in the Widener Cup at Hialeah Park March 6.
ON THE BATTLE FRONT, in Tunisia, Jan. 2 (delayed) (AP) -- Two British tank columns jabbed deep into enemy territory northeast and southeast of Medjez-el-Bab on reconnaissance patrols this afternoon.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- During recent operations off North Africa, the trawler Lord Nuffield detected the Italian submarine Emo and altered course to attack. Just as the trawler was about to release her depth charges, a periscope broke surface a short distance away.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Navy motor torpedo boats hit one Japanese destroyer and scored possible hits on two others out of a total of eight in a series of scattered engagements "in the vicinity of the northwestern end of Guadalcanal Island" on Saturday (Solomons date), the Navy reported today.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (Reuter) -- One hundred eighteen wounded American soldiers from North Africa have arrived in Britain for special treatment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A six-foot model of the John Bidwell, the sixteenth Liberty ship delivered in December by the California Shipbuilding Corporation at Wilmington, Calif., today joined President Roosevelt's collection of ship models, and will be sent to the Hyde Park library.

HEADQUARTERS, ALASKA DEFENSE COMMAND, Jan. 2 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Japanese have reinforced their garrison on Kiska Island with a squadron of single and double-float Zero fighters and apparently have no intention of giving up the base without a fight, Army officers said today.

MADRID, Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- Reports from France today said that the Vichy government had announced a division of the formerly unoccupied zone of Southern France, placing all territory east of the River Rhone -- including the port cities of Marseille and Toulon -- under jurisdiction of the Italian army of occupation and all land west of the Rhone in the German zone.

AMBASSADOR JOSEPH C. GREW knows the Japanese as few Americans know them. His description of them is pungent. In his "Report From Tokyo" he has written: "The Japanese will not crack. They will not crack morally or psychologically or economically even when eventual defeat stares them in the face. They will fight to the bitter end."
May I answer the letter from Lambert Fairchild which appears in THE TIMES of Jan. 1?

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 4 -The establishment of more ration board offices in outlying areas of Westchester County was advocated today by several Supervisors at a meeting by the county Board of Supervisors. John H. Downing, Yorktown Supervisor, said residents of his community must travel thirty miles, round trip, to visit a ration board, causing waste of gasoline and tires.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- The British Eighth Amy was reported today to be pausing in its pursuit of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel in Tripolitania while it brought up supplies over the long desert haul from Bengazi, but it was believed that the lull would be brief.

Consolidation of the Michigan Alkali Company and the J.B. Ford Company, its affiliate, into one company to be known as Wyandotte Chemicals Corporation, Wyandotte, Mich., was announced yesterday by E.M. Ford, president. The action was said to combine one of the largest producers and distributors of chemicals and the world's largest manufacturer of specialized cleaning materials.

The six-story business building on a plot 25 by 100 feet at 574 Fifth Avenue has been sold by the Bank for Savings to an investing client of Adams Co., Inc., brokers. The property is assessed for $390,000. Cadwalader, Wickersham Taft were the attorneys for the bank.

Trial began yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church and a jury in a suit involving claims and counter-claims totaling $3,000,000 for work on the foundation of the new Criminal Courts Building. The suit was brought originally by the city against L.P. O'Connor, Inc., and eleven surety companies, for $1,718,000, on the ground that the O'Connor company had defaulted as contractor in construction of the foundation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 (AP) -Huge United States Liberator bombers rained 1,000-pound bombs in heavy salvos on the German fighter and bomber base at Kastelli Pediadi southeast of Candia in Crete in their raid on Saturday, it was disclosed today by a Reuter correspondent who made the flight.

In addition to the regular income tax imposed by the 1942 Revenue Act, the law provides for a "Victory Tax," payable on 1943 income. Taxpayers will not find any reference to it on the income tax returns for 1942, but payments on the Victory Tax will be made currently by deductions or "withholding" from wage payments made after Dec. 31, 1942.

The various letters and editorials which have appeared in your columns on the Ruml plan have neglected one important element, which is the treatment of income from investments. I have found much opposition to the plan because of misunderstanding on this point.

People in occupied Europe who a few months ago were chalking up "V" signs on walls have found something new. The "V" was never perfectly satisfactory. In both the German and the Italian languages it could be used to indicate victory, as it did in English and French.

Fred C. Moffatt was renominated yesterday as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange for a oneyear term. He has been president pro tem since July 1, when George P. Rea resigned as president. Mr. Moffatt has been a member of the Exchange since 1923 and served as president from 1935 to 1939.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- President Getulio Vargas of Brazil, in a New Year's greeting to President Roosevelt, expressed today the belief and hope that 1943 would bring decisive events.

New attendance and gross receipt records, in some cases higher than the exceptional business of the Christmas week-end, were established from New Year's Eve through Sunday night at the big first-run film theatres in the midtown area, according to reports yesterday from the contented theatre treasurers.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP) -- It looked more and more today as though Mrs. W.W. Adams got a real bargain when she claimed the black gelding Arthur Murray for $2,000 at Narragansett last August.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The War Production Board today ordered that after Jan. 30 no new printing machinery may be manufactured for any one except armed forces operating outside of the United States. The order, which revised previous orders designed to conserve steel, copper and aluminum used in the printing industry, also prescribed regulations on the manufacture of supplies and replacement parts.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday that sales of war savings bonds in the New York Federal Reserve District in December amounted to $161,100,000, compared with $108,900,000 in November, exclusive of sales made through postoffices.

The Metropolitan Museum of! Art ig expected to share exten-{ sively in Mayor La Guardia's post-! war program of public wor. ks, I which is to provide employment for the building trades in the pc-I riod of demobilization.

Kenosha County, Wis., awarded yesterday a new issue of $1,020,000 of refunding bonds to a syndicate, comprising the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis, Mo.; the Lee Higginson Corporation, Estabrook Co. and J.M. Daine Co. of Minneapolis.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Jan. 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- Allied forces methodically engaged in eliminating the last small pocket of enemy resistance in the Buna area succeeded today in cutting off an estimated 100 Japanese troops from escape by sea.

Eddie Cantor, who has been intermittently "through with show business" ever since 1929, expects to have a new musical, based upon his autobiography, "My Life Is in Your Hands," ready for Broadway in the Fall. He now is negotiating on the West Coast with "a prominent author" to do the book and with Frank Loeser and Jimmy McHugh to do the lyrics and music, in that order.

An appeal was made yesterday by the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, Inc., for 600 women volunters to act as troop leaders, assistant troop leaders or members of neighborhood committees to help train 6,000 girls in Girl Scout membership and in war activities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Thomas J. Pendergast, former political boss of Kansas City, and two of his associates escaped prison terms today when the Supreme Court found, 6 to 1, that the three-year statute of limitations prevented their conviction for criminal contempt of court in the case where Pendergast was charged with receiving a bribe to effect the $10,000,000 Missouri fire insurance settlement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 -- "Sherlock Holmes Faces Death" will be the first of three films dealing with the Arthur Conan Doyle detective character which Universal will produce in 1943, the studio announced today. Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce, who are under contract to the studio for the series, will play Holmes and Dr. Watson, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Indictments charging sedition were returned against thirty-three persons and The New York Evening Enquirer, Inc., a corporation headed by William Griffin, by a District of Columbia grand jury today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Senator George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today he thought that Congress would write into law some adaptation of the Ruml pay-as-you-go tax plan, by "either writing off a year's individual income taxes or postponing one year's payments."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- President Roosevelt signed today an executive order clarifying the full authority of the Office of Defense Transportation over all forms of domestic transportation and directing it especially to unify and coordinate measures for the movement of personnel to and from war plants and establishments.
The Soviet midday communique as broadcast domestically by the Khabarovsk radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The war has made the "color line" a topic of international importance and "unless there is a drastic readjustment of racial attitudes the United Nations cannot win this war," Walter White, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, declared yesterday at the association's annual meeting at its headquarters, 69 Fifth Avenue.

In an appeal to women to enroll in sub-professional engineering courses to qualify them for important work in war industries, Dr. Albert B. Newman, regional adviser for the United States Office of Education, said yesterday that at last 50,000 women would be needed for such work in the next six months.

Proper insulation of farm buildings, railroad cars and other temporary food storage facilities, to prevent spoilage that may result from transportation delays in 1943, was stressed yesterday by M.S. Wunderlich, sales manager of the Insulite division of Minnesota and Ontario Paper Company, Minneapolis.

Hammering Henry Armstrong, who held the world featherweight, lightweight and welterweight titles at the same time, is coming back to local ring competition after an absence of two years. The doughty little California Negro yesterday agreed to face Beau Jack, Georgian who holds the New York State version of the lightweight crown, in a ten-round non-title bout at Madison Square Garden on Jan. 29.

On the authority of the War and Navy Departments, the old names of our warplanes -- Army A-24, Navy and Marine SBD, and so forth -- names which were about as friendly as an automobile license or a telephone number -- are to be supplemented with new names for the benefit of their dignity and our pleasure.

As Leon Henderson, retiring OPA Administrator, increases the value of fuel oil ration coupons on the heels of a spell of zero weather or reduces it because of "heavy demands from North Africa," State and regional OPA authorities admit they have not the remotest idea of the number of fuel oil rationing coupons outstanding or the quantity of oil they represent.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governor Dewey said today that he had re-designated William F. Bleakley of Vestchester County as Moreland Act Commissioner investigating the administration of the State Workmen's Compensation Law.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- American Coast Guardsmen stationed in Iceland have seen enough action to refute forever the charge that they are "shallow-water sailors."

An audience of almost 3,000 crowded Carnegie Hall last night to hear Marian Anderson's first recital there this season. The singer was accompanied by Franz Rupp and in Brahms' Two Songs for Contralto with Viola and Piano, Op. 91, which she sang here for the first time, she also had the assistance of William Primrose.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 (AP) -Lulu Costantino of New York outpointed Ellis Phillips of Philadelphia tonight, winning a tenround split decision before a crowd of 6,950 at Convention Hall.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 4 -- Fernando Miramontes, Chief of the Agrarian Department, said today that President Manuel Avila Camacho had distributed more than 6,000,000 acres of land to Mexico's farmers in the first two years of his government.

Responding to an appeal of United China Relief for $7,000,000 last year for relief and rehabilitation in China, the American people topped that goal by contributing $7,083,357, with additional pledges for $2,209,676, or a total of $9,293,033, Wendell L. Willkie, honorary chairman of the relief organization, revealed last night in a broadcast over WJZ and the Blue Network.

Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler, who was set free in the Autumn of 1940 after eight years in a Federal prison, was sentenced yesterday to serve another year's imprisonment. The penalty was imposed by Federal Judge John Bright on the former beer baron's plea of guilty to a charge of conspiring to create a black market in sugar.

Prices pushed yesterday into new high ground since early December of 1941, but volume contracted sharply in the stock market, a natural sequence to the elimination of tax selling. Reinvestment demand, except in a few "blue chips," failed to put in an appearance, and gains generally were confined to fractions up to a point.

A gift from a new contributor and one from a friend who has given liberally for many years and gave for a second time in this thirty-first annual appeal for the Neediest Cases Fund were among the sixty-six donations received yesterday.

The Chase National Bank reported yesterday that as of Dec. 31 its total resources had reached $4,569,496,050. This was the first time that a commercial bank in this or any other country had reported resources in excess of $4,000,000,000. The total compared with $3,899,955,951 for the bank on Sept. 30 and $3,811,802,804 on Dec. 31, 1941.

Yesterday morning the Controller of the Currency formally issued a call for statements of condition of all national banks as of the close of business on Dec. 31. Soon after the Federal Reserve Board, the FDIC and banking superintendents in virtually all of the forty-eight States followed suit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- India should not receive independence during the war because her contribution to the United Nations' war effort would suffer, Sir Ramaswami Madaliar, Indian representative on the British War Cabinet, said tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Harold Macmillan, newly appointed British Resident Minister in North Africa, has arrived at Allied Headquarters there and is expected to confer at once with General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner, and other French leaders in an effort to effect a union with the Fighting French, it was reported today.

RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. 4 -- While the natives of this community were busy digging out from under heavy snowdrifts, a number of ski enthusiasts, including service men and their wives, continued to spend their furloughs today running over the broad slopes and trails of Pico Peak.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Director of Selective Service, said today that he had directed officials of Selective Service Board 17, 412 Sixth Avenue, New York City, to reopen consideration of the cases of twenty-eight members of the Moral Rearmament movement, now classified as 1-A, to permit them to file occupational deferment papers.

Haven't we been making too much of the zoot-suiters and jive hounds? For weeks past I've been shopping in New York. Everywhere I went I found my students as theatre ushers, ticket takers, salesgirls, waiters, shipping clerks, plumbers' helpers, stenographers, orchestra players, receptionists, radio singers, messengers, clerks, delivery boys, floorwalkers, grocery clerks.

The owner of a small store in the uptown section likes to discuss honey in all its interesting ramifications. He may tell you, for example, that a pound of the stuff represents nectar gathered from two million flowers. Or he may say that at the height of the season a colony -- 50,000 to 75,000 bees -- produce twice that amount in a day.

The three-family house at 83 Armstrong Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to Nicholas D'Amore through the George J. Wolf Realty Company. Alfred D'Auria represented the seller. Abraham Miller was the attorney for the buyer.

The Republic Steel Corporation operated at 99.5 per cent of capacity for the whole of 1942, establishing new high records in every major category of steel operations, it was announced by the company in Cleveland yesterday.
DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The tank engine assembly line at the Chrysler Corporation's Jefferson Avenue plant shut down tonight, following a strike of about ninety testers earlier in the day.

An unprecedented demand for tickets for tomorrow night's session at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, when Harold B. Rowe, chief of the Food and Food Products Division of OPA, will discuss the point rationing system, has exhausted the available seating space.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 4 -- A special interstate conference of the Australian Labor Party, sitting in the Melbourne Trades Hall, is considering Prime Minister John Curtin's proposal to add to the defense act, in its definition of the area to which liability for compulsory service extends, "and such other territories in the Southwest Pacific as the Governor General proclaims as being territories associated with the defense of Australia."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Senator Byrd, chairman of the Joint Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal Expenditures, took issue today with the defense of the War Department of its recent purchase of the Hotel Stevens in Chicago, for $6,000,000 for the continued housing of troops.

The National City Bank in its statement of condition as of Dec. 31, in accord with other large Wall Street banks, showed deposits and resources at record highs in the history of the institution. Total resources of the bank amounted to $3,761,671,281, compared with $3,179,688,427 on Sept. 30 and $3,082,860,582 on Dec. 31, 1941, according to the statement issued yesterday.

The Museum of Modern Art will open its 1943 season with an exhibition of archintecture of Brazil on Jan. 13. Entitled "Brazil Builds," the exhibition will fill almost the entire ground floor of the museum. It will include models, enlarged photographs, architectural renderings, drawings, plans, maps and a continuous screen projection of forty-eight color slides.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Walter Kilrea of Hershey remained in front for individual scoring honors in the American Hockey League with 49 points during the last week, an increase of six.
Six out of every 100 workers in war plants remain away from their jobs daily, according to a report made public yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Carbon steels today were included by the War Production Board among the types of steel which can be delivered in sample lots to manufacturers or laboratories without regard to preference ratings. Purpose of the order is to encourage further use of plain carbon steel with a view to having them tested in applications where alloy steels have previously been used.

As the transit strike ultimatum delivered by Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, on Dec. 23 neared its expiration tomorrow, a group of fifteen citizens headed by Professor Herman A. Gray issued a statement last night calling for immediate establishment of adequate machinery to compose differences between the union and the city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, accused Governor Sam H. Jones of Louisiana tonight of "direct encouragement to violation" of gasoline rationing regulations.

Proceedings designed to lay a basis for voiding the United States citizenship of all those former German-American Bund members who assumed it through insincere oaths of allegiance will be started today before Judge John Bright in Federal court here.
Brief practice blackouts were held last night in Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Long Island, the one in Nassau lasting eleven minutes and the test in Suffolk thirteen minutes.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The failure of the Germans to take the Grozny oil fields in the Russian Caucasus after a drive that culminated yesterday in their loss of the key rail city of Mozdok has left the Germans with the most serious fuel shortage since the start of the war, informed sources said today.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Jan. 4 -- The Columbia basketball team defeated the Fort Monmouth quintet, 64 to 50, tonight on the soldiers' floor before a crowd of 2,000 persons. This was a fast game, and although the Lions held the lead most of the way, the contest was exciting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Although the Kaiser shipbuilding companies had closed shop agreements with the American Federation of Labor, a company official said that they were unable to obtain enough employes through the federation and had to recruit them elsewhere, according to an affidavit filed with the National Labor Relations Board and made available today.
Ceremonies at noon today on the steps of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue will mark the opening of the 1943 Victory Book Campaign, a drive for reading matter for the armed service.

A German broadcast recorded yesterday by The United Press in New York reported the High Command had announced that Soviet "partisans" operating in the rear of a German Army on the central front in Russia had been surrounded and more than 1,400 had been killed.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, on his arrival yesterday at his city office, State Building, 80 Center Street, began to check pending cases and interviewed a number of prospective assistants. Mr. Goldstein, who succeeded John J. Bennett Jr., said: "I intend to make a survey of the entire organization for the purpose of streamlining it so as to obtain greater efficiency, more production and reduced expense."

Assurances that the decision to carry paid advertising in the new propaganda magazine Victory does not threaten the principle of a free press and that the magazine in no way will compete with established export publications were given here yesterday by a spokesman for the Office of War Information.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a lower court's decision that school children could not be required to salute the flag in violation of religious scruples, Thus the possibility was raised that the high tribunal might reverse its own decision of 1940 that such a requirement was constitutional.

Eastern basketball, in the opinion of local college coaches, does not suffer by comparison with the type of game played in other sections of the country. Speaking at the weekly meeting of the Basketball Writers Association at Toots Shor's restaurant yesterday, Joe Lapchick of St. John's, Nat Holman of City College and Howard Cann of N.Y.U. defended the brand of ball played in these parts, especially in the metropolitan area.
Your editorial "Pay-As-You-Go Taxes" brings expression to the following:

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 2 per cent for the week ended Jan. 2, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Inclement weather during the first half of the week was held largely responsible for the decrease.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Home railway issues and gilt-edge securities provided the main feature of today's stock market trading. The release of 78,750,000 of India stock due tomorrow was responsible for a further rise of an eighth in the 2 1/2 and 4 per cent consols, while the 3 1/2 per cent war loan gained 1-16.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 4 -- Renewed action against "Gaullism, communism and terrorism," which are now grouped together as objects of repression, was foreshadowed tonight from Vichy "according to a plan elaborated by [Chief of government Pierre] Laval in person."

MOSCOW, Jan. 4 -- An important addition to the Moscow arms factory workers' amenities was provided by the completion of the fast non-stop subway route from a point half way between the huge Stalin and dynamo plants in the capital's industrial belt and the station a few hundred yards from Red Square.

WILSON, N.C., Jan. 4 (AP) -Selection of a jury from a special venire of 200 Eastern North Carolina men was begun this morning as thirteen corporations and sixteen individuals went on trial in United States District Court on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law in connection with trading in potatoes.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The Royal Air Forec paid its first important new year call on Germany last night. Weather had prevented the British bombers going over earlier. It was declared in circles that should know that the night's raiders were the harbingers of hordes that will descend upon the Reich by day and by night this year.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- The Pennsylvania Newspaper Publishers Association reported today that seventy of the Commonwealth's 133 daily newspapers raised their subscription rates in 1942 because of shrinking revenues and increased operating costs.

The ten-family apartment house at 1322 Avenue I, Brooklyn, has been sold by Aron Mohrer to Dr. Louis S. Porter. Daniel L. Beyer was the broker. Breitbart Breitbart were the attorneys for the seller. Benjamin L. Garfunkel represented the buyer.

Miss Angela Toland Place, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hermann G. Place, will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 530 Park Avenue, for a group of young women interested in organizing a USO Scrapbook-of-the-Month Club to send scrapbooks to service men overseas.

The organization of the "Committee on Economic Development" is another encouraging piece of evidence that American business men are beginning to think realistically and constructively about the post-war world. The new organization, which has as its chairman Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, had its inception in a suggestion made by Secretary of Commerce Jones.

With more than 17,000,000 men and women employed in war work, war industries are losing manpower at the rate of 136,000,000 workdays per year, or an average of more than 2,500,000 workdays weekly, through illness alone, according to the annual report of the Industrial Hygiene Foundation, released yesterday.

The Germans are resorting to advertisements in their newspapers in an effort to get men who can run their foreign-labor camps and help exploit occupied Europe, the Office of War Information reported yesterday.
Ruth Kellogg's letter in THE TIMES of Dec. 31 speaks of Superintendent Wade's omission to stress moral teaching in the schools.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -James S. Knowlson, who initiated the conversion of the automobile industry and other peacetime plants to war work, resigned today as vice chairman of the War Production Board, but Chairman Donald M. Nelson said he would be kept on the books as a WPB consultant.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Ford's Theatre, known and loved for almost three-quarters of a century by nearly every star of the American theatre, today became a victim of old age.

I HAD a curious feeling while reading Michael Straight's "Make This the Last war"* of being attracted and repelled in equal measure. I found myself agreeing intellectually with Mr. Straight's proposals for a federalized Europe, and I can readily grant the desirability of a post-war concert of the United Nations to keep the peace and prepare the way or a general increase in standards of living everywhere.
AT THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Jan. 1 (Delayed) -- Soldier couriers risk their lives daily to bring to the British and American newspaper reads news of the fighting front in Tunisia.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Two indictments against Samuel Nuzzo were dismissed today s the defense rested in the trial of the union officer on charges of stealing $9,844 from his local.

Worried by tight supply situations and delayed deliveries, hundreds of buyers representing stores all over the country began to arrive in the wholesale markets here yesterday to place orders for Spring goods. The number of arrivals approximated last year's figures for this time, with the peak due next week, when the National Retail Dry Goods Association holds its wartime conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

One of the most illuminating reports coming out of Russia was the article published in Sunday's Magazine by Ilya Ehrenburg, Russia's "most powerful" war correspondent connected with the Army paper Red Star. In this article he detailed in poignant instances what Russian men and women fight for, and why.

A jubilant official review of the battle off Santa Cruz Island on Oct. 26 between American and Japanese fleets reveals what seems to mark a new phase of naval warfare. For the first time in this war a battleship met repeated and systematic attacks by enemy dive-bombers and torpedo planes, destroyed nearly half of them, beat off the rest and survived almost undamaged.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 4 -- French forces, using some American tank-destroying equipment among their weapons, smashed back a heavy German and Italian tank attack on French positions at Fondouk, Allied Headquarters announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Hogs started the first week of 1943 on gains of 25 to 50 cents today, selling at the highest January level since 1920. A few head brought $15, the highest since Oct. 22. Shippers showed an active interest for the lighter offerings, taking 4,000 head. Most 190 to 300 pound hogs sold at $14.65 to S14.90.

WITH THE FRENCH ARMY in Tunisia, Jan. 2 (Delayed) -- The revival of the French national spirit in this part of French North Africa is best exemplified by the tough colonial soldiers who have attacked German communications to Sousse and Sfax in the last two weeks.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 4 -- The American White Book "Peace and War" drew a broadside attack on President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull from the Wilhelmstrasse today and German press comment equally scathing.

The American "White Paper," summarizing ten years of patient but in the end futile efforts to stop the aggressor nations by means of diplomacy and economic sanctions, has reopened the question of responsibility for Pearl Harbor, and Congressional circles, while putting the State Department "in the clear," are inclined to put added blame for "tragic negligence" on the Army and the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today directed the Carolina Power and Light Company, Raleigh, N.C., to dispose of $20,765,833 in "writeups" claimed as bona-fide costs by the company.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The "wait and see" policy of the major baseball leagues with respect to suggestions made by the Office of Defense Transportation for curtailment of travel in 1943 ends tomorrow.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 31 (Delayed) -- Twenty-three-year-old Harold McFann of Indiana is believed to hold top score in the Marine Corps for citations in the Solomon Islands fighting. He has twice been recommended for the Navy Cross by different commanders of his outfit and once for the Silver Star.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- General Henri Honore Giraud has suggested to General Charles de Gaulle that the Fighting French send emissaries to North Africa to discuss a union of their forces, well-informed sources said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The government order eliminating the slicing of bread by bakers "borders on the absurd," Senator Reed of Kansas said today.

Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie spent an "intensely interesting day" yesterday serving on a Supreme Court jury that awarded a $3,000 verdict for the death of a 15-year-old boy. Mrs. Willkie won the commendation of Justice Samuel Null, who said that her service was "typical of our American processes" and her presence on the jury a "symbol of our faith in America."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -Representative Mahon of Texas maintains that "lavish dinners" by Washington socialites are uncalled for when housewives scan empty shelves in stores for food, and today so told Secretary Wickard and Leon Henderson, head of the OPA.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Creation of a Congressional Joint Committee on Peace and Peace Preparation, to study the geographical, ethnic, social, economic and political factors which may enter into the formulation of a treaty of peace and to analyze plans and proposals and assess their effect upon the welfare of this country is proposed in a concurrent resolution to be introduced in the House on Wednesday by Representative Dirksen of Illinois.

Defending yesterday's rise in the price of milk for all sales in the metropolitan milk marketing area except home deliveries, Sylvan Joseph, regional administrator for the Office of Price Administration, said that the increase was necessary to protect the market here.
From little Morris Harvey College at Charleston, W. Va., to Manhattan College up Riverdale way is the jump that Joe Daher has made.

Sixty women began their training course yesterday as volunteer child care assistants. The course, endorsed by the Greater New York CDVO, will prepare volunteers for work with children in day nurseries, kindergartens and school recreation programs.

OTTAWA. Jan. 4 -- An increase of .2 of a point in the official cost-of-living index from Nov. 2 to Dec. 1 was announced today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. The Dec. 1 level was 118.8, against 118.6 on Nov. 2. The total wartime increase to Dec. 1 was 17.9 per cent.

TORONTO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Cities and towns in Eastern Ontario and Western Quebec struggled today to clear snow-blocked highways and patch disrupted communications systems after the worst Winter storm in fifty years had raged over the New Year holiday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- Allied planes have opened the offensive against Sanananda, last Japanese foothold in Papua, with blistering bombing and gunning attacks, it was announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 4 -- The Chilean Minister of Interior, Raul Morales Beltrami, who will proceed to Santiago tomorrow to give President Juan Antonio Rios of Chile a full report about his journey to the United States, had a two-hour conference today with President Ramon S. Castillo of Argentina in the latter's country residence.

Not to be discouraged by advance warnings that there would be little merchandise to be had, rug buyers and distributors arrived here in large numbers to attend the "informal" market which opened here yesterday. There were few new lines, and buying was restricted to month-to-month allotments, as has been the case since last Fall.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The prospect of an appeal to President Roosevelt to force James C. Petrillo to lift a union ban on recordings of music was raised tonight by Senator Clark of Idaho.

If by this time complacency has been made a statutory crime, punishable by fine or imprisonment, or both, there is trouble ahead for the persons involved in the writing, editing, printing and publishing, or, as the lawyers like to call it, uttering, of one brief paragraph which appeared on Page 4, Column 1 of Section 9 of this newspaper last Sunday, consisting mainly of a survey of America's industrial war effort.

When the peace treaty is to be drawn up, church people will not render any valuable service by advising statesmen and trying to interfere with their work, the Rev. Daniel A. McGregor, executive of the Episcopal Church's national work in education, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Two machinists' unions in the San Francisco area were severely condemned today by President Roosevelt and the War Labor Board for interfering in vital war production.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force fliers, continuing their assault against enemy defenses in the path of the British land drive in Western Burma, yesterday set fire to several Japanese-occupied villages in the area of Rathedaung, twenty-five miles northwest of Akyab, it was announced today.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- A Soviet special communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

The Navy announced yesterday the sinking of two more merchant vessels of the United Nations. One, a British ship of medium size, was torpedoed and sunk in the Atlantic off South America last September by a submarine she tried to ram. The other, an American ship, went down off the coast of Africa with a loss of eighteen men of a crew of sixty-six.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Rent control saved residential tenants $300,000,000 last year and promises to result in savings of "more nearly a billion dollars" next year, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, told a press conference today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 4 -For the first time a Berlin military spokesman today used the expression "the great Russian Winter offensive of 1942-43," according to information received here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The twoweek January furniture and home furnishings show opened here today with a better attendance than sponsors cared to admit, in view of ODT pressure to cancel or limit the event. Buyers appeared to be fairly cheerful in spite of warning by J.C. McCarthy, secretary of the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers, that the industry faces a crucial problem of survival in the months just ahead.

The Bombshell Artists Group is holding its second annual exhibition, which opened with a preview last evening at the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street. It opens to the public today and will continue until Jan. 16.

An experiment whereby psychiatrists and social case workers will try to help maladjusted boys of 16 to 21 by living with them in a pleasant home environment was begun yesterday by the Community Service Society with the opening of Boys House, a residential center.

The Office of War Information admitted yesterday that it had made a mistake. The Almanac Singers -- a hillbilly group that once made a specialty of a number called "Plow Under Every Fourth American Boy," and has been periodically praised in the Communist organ The Daily Worker -- were hired to do short wave broadcasts in the propaganda service.
HAVANA, Jan. 4 -- The Acera del Louvre Association this afternoon announced a boycott of Argentine and Chilean products to be instituted by its members, beginning Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- General Charles de Gaulle's proposal for a "temporary and enlarged central power" in North Africa, bereft of its associations with the Vichy regime, was interpreted in some informed quarters here as a demand for a political upheaval that might hamper military operations and that could hardly be accepted by General Henri Honore Giraud.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Dec. 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Five types of Army medals were awarded today to eighteen officers and men who distinguished themselves in aerial and ground combat in the Southwest Pacific area.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The adventures of three members of a United States Navy photographic unit, who spent about three weeks "cruising" among forward units of the British First Army in the Tunisian campaign, taking pictures, being cut off by the Germans and helping to destroy German tanks, were described today by two officers of the unit, Lieutenants John McClain and Kenneth M. Pier, both of Hollywood.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Columbia Pictures Corporation paid a director, Alexander Hall, $151,208 during the last fiscal year -- $5,608 more than the president, Harry Cohn, received -- according to one of several corporation reports made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt opened formally yesterday afternoon the American Theatre Wing Merchant Seamen's Club at 107 West Forty-third Street. She dedicated it to members of the merchant services of the United Nations, the men who sail cargo ships over lines of supply in dangerous seas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Anti-trust indictments which were to have been handed down charging rate-fixing by motor and rail carriers have been postponed at the request of the Secretaries of War and Navy and the Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, Attorney General Biddle said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 (AP) -San Francisco, without meat for three days, and its grocers' shelves virtually barren, appealed to the Federal Government today for assistance. Meat -- beef, pork, veal and lamb -- practically vanished from butcher shops on New Year' Eve, and none at all has been available since early on Saturday, and supplies are not expected until tomorrow, and then only a scant total, far under the likely demand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The best evidence of the effectiveness of the White Paper issued by the State Department Saturday night on America's global diplomacy during the "fateful" decade of 1931-41 was considered by officials here today to be the rage into which it has thrown Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- American fighting men taken prisoner by Germany or Italy and American civilians interned by those countries receive regular American Red Cross standard food parcels and necessary clothing as soon as the International Red Cross committee in Geneva is notified of their capture and camp location, according to the Office of War Information.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Office of Price Administration issued a second set of questions and answers today explaining the forthcoming point rationing of canned, bottled, frozen and dried foods. It made clear that all the listed canned foods were to be rationed together to avert a rush to buy any unrationed foods which consumers could use as substitutes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Private hiring agencies which fail to abide by United States Employment Service standards may be deprived of their right to use their own employment services, according to Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., the first automobile company to convert 100 per cent to war production, reported yesterday a net profit of $1,265,399 after taxes, contingency reserves and other charges for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- The broad question as to how much the surplus from prosperous years in State finance should be used for tax reduction, and how much should be put aside for leaner years to come is beginning to come up in connection with the financial policy of the Dewey administration.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Leon Henderson said today that people were more indifferent to the need for conserving motor fuel than to anything else.

If Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska hadn't long ago fought for the "lame duck" amendment to the Constitution his term and the terms of other Senators and Representatives who weren't re-elected to the new Congress would have run on until March 4. Instead, they ended Sunday.

Virgil Thomson, music critic of The New York Herald Tribune, appearing as conductor of his own music, and Rudolph Serkin, piano soloist, were assisting artists at the concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

The text which follows is an introduction to a collection of documents concerning the foreign relations of the United States during the years 1931-1941, especially the policies and acts of the United States toward promoting conditions of peace and world order and toward meeting the world-wide dangers resulting from Japanese, German, and Italian aggression.

At the present hour the French troops that are fighting in Tunisia are nearly as numerous as the British and they greatly outnumber the Americans. I speak of British and Americans engaged in that theatre of operations.

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, informed Mayor La Guardia yesterday in an open letter that the Transport Workers Union was willing to submit its dispute with the Board of Transportation over wages and working conditions on the city's rapid transit lines to an impartial agency for adjustment and settlement if further negotiations failed to produce an agreement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 -- In the face of a directive from President Roosevelt demanding uninterrupted work, thirty-four C.I.O. machinists were kept from their jobs at the General Engineering and Dry Dock Company's yard in Alameda today by what was described in one quarter as a "strike of union members against their union."

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 6 -- General Douglas MacArthur's heavy bombers roared down upon a Japanese ship concentration yesterday at Rabaul, New Britain Island, and sank or set afire at least nine and probably ten vessels, totaling more than 50,000 tons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- There were only two strikes in the transportation industry in the year ending June 30, and during 1942 there was not a single strike authorized by the twenty-one labor organizations in the railway industry nor among the personnel of the airline industry, according to the annual report made to Congress today by the National (Railway) Mediation Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. C.L. Scott, commander of the armed force replacement training center at Fort Knox, Ky., said today that all American battle equipment was giving "splendid service" and that recent criticisms of planes, tanks and guns was unjustified.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- The Norwegian Government in exile has enacted a decree that will deprive 30,000 Axis collaborationists in Norway of their citizenship and the right to carry on a trade, business or profession after the war, it was revealed tonight.
MOSCOW, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

DETROIT, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- A strike which had lasted for twenty-three hours at the River Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company ended late today when the workers responded to a plea from their union officials to "remember our pledge to the boys on Guadalcanal."

It is up to the State Parole Board to determine whether Alexander Hoffman, who was freed by former Governor Charles Poletti after serving only eight months of a four-to-eight-year sentence for attempted arson and other unlawful acts growing out of his union activities, may remain as general manager of the Cleaners and Dyers Local 239 of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, it was disclosed yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 5 -- The Chilean Minister of Interior, Raul Morales Beltrami, left by air for Santiago this morning, leaving behind him in Argentina a distinct impression that Chile, in the not very distant future, would break relations with the Axis.
MONTREAL, Jan. 5 (Canadian Press) -- It's still one-two-three for the Maple Leafs atop the National Hockey League scoring race, official figures showed today.
CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- Minister of Information Chang Tao-fan said today that Lieut. Gen. Hsiung Shih-fei, head of the Chinese military mission to the United States, had not been recalled.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 5 -- Airmen who played a major part in closing successively three of the Axis-held African ports and who are now participating in the early phases of the air attack on Southern Europe received Distinguished Flying Crosses yesterday.

Events tonight: "Lucia di Lammermoor." Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 o'clock; New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Mischa Elman, violin recital, Town Hall, 8:30.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 5 -- After considering the case for less than an hour, the Bergen County grand jury reported today no indictment against Laura Matriss, 17-year-old East Rutherford high school student, who fatally stabbed her father, Frank Matriss, at their home on Dec. 27 during a family argument.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 5 -- Girl students and faculty members of the Highland Manor School on the former Shadow Lawn estate of the late Hubert T. Parson, former president of the F.W. Woolworth Company, became maids of all work today by filling the service positions of the school employes who quit their jobs yesterday, according to Dr. Eugene Lehman, principal, in protest against the deduction of the Victory tax from their wages.
The German armies in the Caucasus apparently have started a withdrawal from their advanced positions near the Grozny oil fields.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Secretary Wickard directed manufacturers tonight to set aside 30 per cent of their monthly production of creamery butter for direct war requirements, including military and lend-lease, beginning Feb. 1.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- To Roger Touhy, captured a week ago by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, as a fugitive from the Stateville prison, was denied today his petition for a writ of habeas corpus by Federal Judge Philip J. Sullivan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- "Dick" Jervis was for twenty-six years a member of the Secret Service detail at the White House, and its chief, 1920-1935.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Twenty-one Japanese planes unloaded more than 100 bombs on the southwestern fringe of Kweilin, the capital of Kwangsi Province, in a raid yesterday morning, the Central News Agency reported today, but damage was declared negligible.

A basketball rivalry that dates back to 1914-15 will be carried on tonight at Madison Square Garden, when St. John's clashes with City College. Rounding out the program, undefeated N.Y.U. and Penn State, also without a blemish, will meet in the opener, starting at 8:15 o'clock.

Captain Eddie Rickenbacker will be the principal speaker at the opening of the annual drive of the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America Thursday, Jan. 14, with an 8 A.M. breakfast in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced yesterday.

Women are eligible to attend the Civilian Protection School directed by the Army at Amherst College, the State Defense Council said yesterday. A new course designed to provide basic training in civilian defense will be given Jan. 17 through Jan. 22.

Unless more war work can be obtained in a hurry, there will be a decline in employment and in war output in the city's metal working factories before the end of the month, according to a report released yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement.

At the end of our first year of war, Manhattan College has 1,005 of its total alumni body in the armed services, it was announced yesterday by Brother A. Victor, F.S.C., president of the college. Brother Victor also announced that 539 students out of the total college registration of 1,025 are in reserve corps.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Oil has started moving through the 531-mile pipe line from Longview, Texas, to Norris City, Ill., Secretary Ickes, as Petroleum Administrator for War, made known today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The War Labor Board was confronted with a serious situation today when the labor and industry members created a precedent by outvoting the public members who opposed a wage increase because it broke through the ceiling set by the board in its "Little Steel" principle.

Wendell Willkie, the honorary chairman of United China Relief, announced in his radio talk that the American people last year contributed $7,083,000 to this cause and pledged an additional $2,209,000. This sum will buy far more in China than it could here.
Somebody, by way of parody on the poet Wordsworth's artless style, once wrote:

Appointment of a committee of fifteen persons to consider the feasibility of adapting the council-manager form of government to this city will be requested today in a resolution to be submitted to the City Council by Louis Cohen, one of its Democratic members from the Bronx.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A special Russian communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, predicted today an Axis effort to propose peace in order to avoid defeat, but, as for the United Nations, he said, "We shall make no peace until the forces of the Axis, East and West, North and South, have suffered final, unmistakable and irrevocable defeat."

Fordham had a comparatively easy time against Holy Cross last night on the Rose Hill basketball court in the Bronx, but it was not until the second half that the Rams were able to find smooth sailing. At the finish the Maroon was on top, 62 -- 44, but at half-time held a mere one-point edge, 25 -- 24.

RED ROLFE considers that in these days he is lolling in the lap of luxury, a well-turned alliterative phrase which he undoubtedly found nestling under some ivy at New Haven. All his life the one-time Yankee third-baseman had yearned to be a college coach and now that he has embarked on his career he finds that he went about it the right way.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Democrats and Republicans of the House, divided almost equally in strength by the November elections, caucused today on the eve of the convening of the new Congress in an atmosphere strange to Capitol Hill since the advent of the present Administration.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 5 -- Alfred E. Driscoll, State Commissioner of Alcoholic Beverage Control, pointing to the way in which military authorities had curtailed the hours during which liquor might be sold to members of the armed services on the West Coast, warned here today that this action "should be the handwriting on the wall to New Jersey municipalities" that permit taverns to operate at all hours.

A decision to undergo a tonsillectomy brought about a postponement yesterday of Henry Armstrong's proposed ring battle with Beau Jack, world lightweight champion, a day after Promoter Mike Jacobs had announced the attraction for Madison Square Garden on Jan. 29.

The campaign in North Africa has slowed down. The dash of the initial landing operations is over, the quick realignment of French troops on the Allied side seems to have stabilized into a working program, but Tunis and Bizerte, from whose conquest we expect so much, remain in the hands of the Axis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- M.W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, received authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission today to become a director of the Wabash Railroad.

It seems to me it's about time to stop shedding crocodile tears over the Darlans, the Petains and that tribe. The facts do not bear out the attempts to set them off against Laval as the victims of circumstance.

In the new Congress that meets today the Administration will have the smallest majority it has had at any time since President Roosevelt first took office. Whether this will be a hindrance or a help to the war effort will depend primarily upon the attitude of the opposition party.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,316, which compared with 236 in the preceding week and 1,120 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Chilean Cabinet was summoned by President Juan Antonio Rios tonight to hear Interior Minister Raul Morales Beltrami's report on the attitudes of the warring governments of the United States and Brazil and neutral Argentina toward Chile's apparently imminent diplomatic break with the Axis.

OTTAWA, Jan. 5 -- The validity of the Canadian Government's system of war-time administration, involving the creation of economic controllers with wide powers under the War-time Measures Act, has been upheld by a judgment delivered today by the Supreme Court of Canada.

Gifts both large and small continued to come yesterday for the Neediest Cases Fund on behalf of the most distressed men, women and children in the city known to eight leading private charity organizations. The day's ninety contributions, direct to THE NEW YORK TIMES and to several of the agencies that attested the cases published during the active appeal until Christmas Day, amounted to $3,097.44.

War-aid buying has entered its second stage, in which long-range planning under former Governor Herbert H. Lehman as Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation will replace as far as possible the recent emergency buying of textile fabrics, rainwear, footwear and other essential items for North African natives, it was reported yesterday in the Worth Street market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A total of 61,126 casualties has been reported among United States forces since the outbreak of the war, according to the Office of War Information. This includes those persons killed, wounded, missing, interned in neutral countries or known to be prisoners of war.

At the New York Public Library yesterday the 1943 drive for books for the armed forces was formally begun. Those forces are much larger than they were at this time last year, and this year's quota of books should also be much greater. Books enough were given last year, but unfortunately a large part of the public seems to have misunderstood a condition required of the books to be acceptable.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 4 (Delayed) (UP) -- Neutral observers in close contact with Berlin expressed belief today that the Germans were beginning a gigantic withdrawal that would take them entirely out of the North Caucasus in Russia.

The Lee Rubber and Tire Corporation and its subsidiary showed a net profit of $1,144,765 after taxes and $150,000 provision for contingencies, according to the annual report covering the year ended with October, issued yesterday by A.A. Garthwaite, president.

Phil Terranova, Bronx featherweight, was credited with a technical knockout over Johnny Dell of East New York last night in the sixth round of the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, when Referee Pete Hartley halted the bout.

The German High Command said yesterday that Axis troops had captured a Russian strong point in a surprise thrust in the Western Caucasus and that Soviet attacks in sectors stretching from the Arctic to the Central Caucasus had been repulsed.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- With the British advance into Burma, the Air Ministry said in a report today, the Allied forces everywhere had passed during December from the defensive to the offensive, scoring several unprecedented air successes in the process.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Advertising linage of eight New York newspapers declined 5.5 per cent last month from the corresponding 1941 period, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures. Two morning papers and one evening paper registered increases, while the balance showed losses.
The sale of five apartment houses in New Jersey was reported yesterday.

Report of income must be made to the government on forms prescribed by Federal regulations. The forms are obtainable from any collector of internal revenue, and generally from any bank. Special forms are provided for corporations, partnerships, trusts, fiduciaries and for non-resident aliens.

The power of the Securities and Exchange Commission to regulate communications to stockholders which are preliminary to the solicitation of proxies, in addition to the actual solicitation, was upheld yesterday in a two-to-one decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here.

A list of forty-eight millinery establishments which will participate in the fashion show to be held at the Hotel Astor Jan. 19 was announced yesterday by Walter K. Marks, chairman of the trade promotion committee of the Millinery Stabilization Committee, Inc.

SOMEWHERE IN SOUTH PACIFIT, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Progress of the war effort in the South Pacific "very definitely" is making for a happier New Year prospect this year than last, Major Gem Millard F. Harmon said today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 5 -- Large-scale amphibious operation by the Japanese in an area north of Australia is said to be foreshadowed by reports that were circulated today by the Australian Government of intensive activity in enemy-occupied New Guinea.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- War bonds and stamps paid about a fifth of the cost of war between the attack on Pearl Harbor and the beginning of 1943, but they are financing only a sixth of the current war bill, Treasury figures disclosed today.

J. Terence Blair, a 23-year-old Englishman who is one of the twenty-eight aliens for whom the Moral Rearmament movement has requested draft deferment, has been ordered to report for induction on Jan. 20, it was revealed yesterday at Selective Service headquarters here.

The United States is now at the "desperation point" with regard to its rubber supply and the nation's technologists must solve in the next seven months the problems of adequate synthetics that the Germans "have not solved in seven years," W.L. White, of the advisory committee to the War Production Board, declared here yesterday in an address to the Export Managers Club in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

War "compulsives" rather than long-haired New Dealers are forcing the concentration of industry, the growth of monopoly, the death of small enterprise and the rationalization of business, Leo M. Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, declared yesterday at the weely luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Price Administrator Leon Henderson's parting shot, delivered before a Senate committee, was this: "The things I regret are where I have not been tough enough. If I ever had it to do over again, which God forbid, I'd be harder and tougher 'til they cut me down."

At Velikye Luki the Russians have bagged the first of the famous German "hedgehogs." Last Winter it was these hedgehogs, bristling but isolated centers of defense, which stalled the Russian counter-drive from Moscow. Encircled, the German garrisons nevertheless held out.

Nineteen new leases of executive office space in the Empire State Building and several contracts for more room there by old tenants were reported yesterday by H. Hamilton Weber, renting manager for Empire State, Inc.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 5 -- President Getulio Vargas is opening a credit of 8,000,000 cruzeiros [$400,000] today for payment to the Companhia Mineracao Siderurgia, the lessee of the Victoria Minas Railway. Thus the government will become the sole owner of that railway.

The 1943 millinery season got under way with a bang yesterday morning. For the second time, Lilly Dache, Sally Victor and John-Frederics, composing the Millinery Fashion Inspiration group, launched their unified style-setting trends.

Fritz Kuhn, once national "Fuehrer" of the German-American Bund, took an action yesterday which he was warned might be tantamount to renouncing his acquired United States citizenship. He walked out of the court room in which Federal Judge John Bright had just begun hearings on the government's suit to nullify his naturalization and that of nineteen other former Bundists.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Red Army troops have captured six more key towns in the Don River loop and the Caucasus in their massive smash toward Rostov, whose seizure would trap the entire German southern army in Russia, another special Soviet communique announced tonight.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5 -- The H.K. Porter Company's locomotive plant at Lawrenceville, which is engaged in war work, was closed today by a wildcat strike of about 800 members of the United Steel Workers, C.I.O., in a demand for equal pay for women.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- To meet a shortage of long staple cotton yarns needed in the production of women's rayon hosiery, the War Production Board today imposed rigid controls over consumption of imported English-spun combed cotton yarns and fabrics and established machinery for distribution of specified types of British-made cotton rope and fabrics needed for military and essential civilian purposes.

Ernest Neubacher, 26 years old, American-born member of the Hitler Youth Movement in Germany in 1935 and 1936, who, since Pearl Harbor, had had a job as a machinist in the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, was committed to the Tombs yesterday by Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in the Felony Court for keeping brass knuckles in his Yorkville rooming-house home.

SUMMIT, N.J., Jan. 5 -- A butcher shop devoted exclusively to the sale of horse meat has been opened at 87 Union Place, here, and, according to the proprietor, Fred Weid, who has been selling meat more than forty years, the store already is doing a good business.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The women of the new Congress seem to contemplate all future legislation from the standpoint of the war.
WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES in Tunisia, Jan. 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- American infantrymen bayoneted twenty-five of sixty attacking Germans during a hill battle near Medjez-el-Bab.

Textile research to aid the war effort already has indicated possibilities of chemically modifying the inherent properties of known natural fibers so as to enable them better to compete with synthetics and to give them new and important qualities of their own, according to Fessenden S. Blanchard, president of the Textile Research Institute, Inc.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Ample supplies of live hogs today caused a downturn in prices to around the levels of last Thursday, with the general market 25 to 40 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, when prices were the highest since last Oct. 22. The top was $14.55, compared with $15.00 yesterday.

Mrs. N. Baxter Jackson gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Elise G. Linn, daughter of Mrs. E. French Linn, and Miss Leona Thompson, granddaughter of Mrs. Charles Carter, both of whom will be debutantes next season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Commander Herbert E. Schonland of New London, Conn., who had an important role in saving the cruiser San Francisco through his efficient damage-control work when she engaged superior Japanese forces in the battle off Savo Island in November, received the Congressional Medal of Honor today from President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The first meeting of the Anglo-American labor committee, recently created to advance organized labor's war efforts, will be held at Miami, Fla., coincidentally with the coming session of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, which will open on Jan. 18 for two weeks.
