The La Salle Academy basketball team won its seventh straight game by beating De La Salle Institute, 41 to 31, on the loser's court yesterday. This was the second victory for La Salle in the Manhattan-Richmond division race of the C.H.S.A.A.
New Jersey's deer season was a short one, but it proved to be a record-breaker.

As reports persisted that "A" gasoline ration coupons might be eliminated and "B" and "C" coupons drastically reduced, Russell H. Potter, manager of the New York District OPA office, 535 Fifth Avenue, yesterday instructed all local war price and rationing boards in the New York metropolitan area to examine applications for supplemental gasoline rations with extreme care and to restrict rations to the absolute minimum.

Williamson Pell, president of the United States Trust Company, at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday, reported that net current earnings for 1942 were $1,576,655, equivalent to $78.85 a share. The figure is after expenses, taxes, assessments and amortization of bond premiums, but before transfers to reserves and charge-offs and recoveries.
Gilbert B.J. Frawley has been nominated for president of the New York A.C. and will be elected at the annual meeting at the clubhouse, 180 Central Park South, next Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- The major leagues, in emergency joint session with Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis, decided today to set back the opening of the 1943 baseball season eight days to April 21, but voted to extend the playing period one week, closing on Oct. 3, instead of Sept. 26.
Mr. and Nfrs. Lammot duPont Copeland of Greenville. Del.; Mrs. Henry Belin duPont of Greenville and Mrs. George S. Rice of San Antonio, Texas, are at the Waldorf- Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Women gave direct aid to the war effort by cooperating with retail stores in reducing the number of avoidable deliveries during the Christmas shopping period, the Office of Defense Transportation made known today.

The effort of the stock market to push yesterday into further high territory was checked by realizing sales. Interest cropped out in the session in several issues which seldom attract more than meager volume. Weakness centered principally in the air transportation section, although the aircrafts, steels and chemicals sank in spots.

The United States is fighting the Axis "for the right of men to live together as members of one family rather than as masters and slaves," President Roosevelt has written in a message to the National Conference of Christians and Jews in which he endorses the observance of Brotherhood Week from Feb. 19 to 28 inclusive, Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, administrative head of the conference, announced yesterday.

Columbia College seniors showed little optimism yesterday about a quick victory in the war. The annual poll conducted by Columbian, senior yearbook, revealed a majority of the class believed the war would end in about three years.

Twenty-three local housing authorities in various parts of the country announced yesterday that they would seek bids on new issues of temporary loan notes aggregating $81,880,000. Nineteen of the agencies will open, on Jan. 13, bids for issues amounting to $78,492,000 and on Jan. 20 the four other authorities will offer notes amounting to $3,388,000.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- At least 200 persons were injured tonight as fire swept through a building which houses a bowling alley and cocktail lounge on the West Side.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Economic conditions in Iceland, where until recently there have been no price controls, are of real concern to the American and British Governments, whose troops are stationed on the island as "military visitors" guarding Iceland from Axis aggression.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES, on Guadalcanal, Dec. 20 (Delayed) -- War correspondents straddled the catwalk of the Flying Fortress Typhoon McGoon II last night and gleefully "bombed" the Japanese at Munda, New Georgia Island, with empty beer bottles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- The American Automobile Association recommended tonight an immediate overhaul of country-wide gasoline rationing machinery to prevent the entire program from "bogging down."
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 5 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's attempt to keep the Mediterranean blocked to Allied shipping has turned the Tunisian war into a major effort, with thousands of German and Italian troops deployed from Bi zerte to the Tripolitanian border, along with part of the first-line strength of the German Air Force.

Mrs. John F. Riddell Jr. gave a tea yesterday in her apartment at Hampshire House for Mrs. Eric Neville Baynes and a group of women serving with her on the junior committee for the benefit performance of Sonja Henie's Ice Revue on the night of Jan. 19.

"The Eve of St. Mark" has been chosen for the sixth "command performance" in Washington in connection with the President's birthday. This was announced yesterday by Andrew R. Kelley, drama critic of The Washington Star, in behalf of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, Inc. Mr. Kelley informed the Playwrights' Company, producers of the play, of the selection.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The United States and other members of the United Nations, together with the French National Committee in London, issued a declaration today against the seizure of property by the Axis in occupied countries.

A shivering but good-natured Mayor La Guardia opened the New York phase of the 1943 Victory Book Campaign yesterday noon on the windy esplanade of the New York Public Library. He brought a bundle of six new copies of a book on aviation, mindful, he said, of "my own service, the men of the air," and appealed to several hundred chilled persons to give books generously and intelligently to the armed services.

Walter Florell showed his Spring hats yesterday during luncheon at the Ritz-Carlton. The event was outstanding not only in its unseasonal display of budding flora but in its unrestrained use of flowery names.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Following is the text of a statement by Representative Martin, Republican leader of the House, setting forth the objectives of his party in the new Congress:

A new order governing production of paper has been approved by the War Production Board, allowing on some grades increased output over the present rate, it was learned yesterday. The order was reported ready for issuance some time this week, but in the past there have been delays and changes between approval of an order and its actual issuance so that all reports must be judged in that light.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- Unless some way is found to neutralize the militaristic psychology which has dominated Germany for more than a century, the United States will find itself embroiled in another world conflict twenty-five years hence.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Brig. Gen. Jacques Leclerc's Fighting French army has driven well into the network of Italian outposts in Southern Libya, it was reported tonight, and it appeared that the narrowing Axis corner of North Africa would soon be boxed in on all sides.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Plans for eliminating the practice of cross hauling and circuitous routing in the cotton, wool and leather industries were discussed last week at a joint meeting of three transportation industry advisory committees with officials of the textile, clothing and leather division of the WPB.
A new extended application of the "ability to pay" principle would siphon off a large percentage of increased spending power not now touched by the Federal income tax.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- The Government of the Dominion of Canada filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission its expected registration statement covering three issues of bonds totaling $90,000,000, to be underwritten by 134 investment banking firms operating from coast to coast.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Governor Dewey sat for the first time in a capital case today, as he conducted two executive clemency hearings, one of them involving a slayer who was indicted in 1940 when Mr. Dewey was District Attorney of New York County.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Reports that the Archduke Otto von Habsburg was in control of the organization of the Free Austrian Battalion being recruited by the United States Army were declared vicious and untrue by President Roosevelt at his press conference today.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presented yesterday the enameled gold Maltese Cross, the insignia of Knight Commander of the Order of St. Gregory the Great, to Joseph F. Lamb, industrial engineer and Supreme Secretary of the Knights of Columbus, at a simple ceremony in the archiepiscopal residence, 452 Madison Avenue.

ATLANTA, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Hugh Casey, hard-luck pitcher of the 1941 world series, said today he would report "the latter part of this week or the first of next week" for active duty with the United States Coast Guard.

The police admitted yesterday they have been unable to pierce the mystery of the death of 23-year- old Dorothy Huber of 785 East 149th Street, the Bronx, who was fatally stabbed Monday while walking to work at the Ward baking plant, 143d Street and Wales Avenue, the Bronx.

Robert Moses in his letter that you published last Saturday has somehow failed to answer the essential question raised about the South Harlem housing site: Why, with better located, cheaper land available in South Harlem, was the present site chosen? The blocks to the east are just as bad slums, just as cancerous.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 5 -- Allied planes and guns wrecked twelve to fifteen tanks -- almost half the enemy's force -- in throwing back an Axis attack at Fondouk in the southern sector of Tunisia, but reinforced German troops are still driving hard there in an attempt to flank the Allied anchor at Medjez-el-Bab to the north, it was revealed tonight.

Frauds aggregating $250,000 on investors in the metropolitan area and in Pennsylvania and Michigan were alleged yesterday when a Federal grand jury for the Eastern District of New York brought in five indictments in connection with sales of stock in two small loan companies.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- While the members of the Legislature devoted tonight to preparations for the opening of the 166th session of the Legislature tomorrow, Governor Dewey completed work on his message and sent it to the printer.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Governor Jones declared today that Leon Henderson's letter accusing him of encouraging violations of gasoline rationing regulations was "ridiculous" and "agitated by personal pique."

A late flurry of price-fixing by trade sources and some replacement buying by New Orleans operators, switching from the selling side, won back some of the early losses in yesterday's cotton market, but at the close the list of active contracts still was 7 to 12 points below Monday's final prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The arrival in North Africa yesterday of Harold Macmillan as British Resident Minister in North Africa, and the reported invitation of General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner there, to General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, to send an emissary to Algiers, are expected by informed persons here to hasten a clarification of the outlook for union of the now divided French groups.

Alexandre Barmine, former brigadier general in the Red Army, who fled from his post as Soviet charge d'affaires in Athens in 1937 rather than face recall to Moscow and possible execution in the purge of Stalin's General Staff, today is a private soldier of the United States.

A general alarm for an unidentified Negro woman, about 25 years old, described as having posed as a social welfare worker to obtain possession of an 8-day-old Negro girl and as having disappeared with the child, was ordered last night after the case had been reported to the police of the Grand Avenue station, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Construction of American merchant shipping this year promises to exceed the high goal of 16,000,000 tons which was set, President Roosevelt and Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, stated today.

The War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower, formed by the National Safety Council several months ago to counter-attack national losses of manpower through accidents of every sort, made public yesterday its plans for a national drive from Jan. 18 to the end of February to stimulate public interest in the movement.

The Chungking radio in an English-language broadcast to the United States, reported by the Office of War Information yesterday, gave an account of a lecture in Chungking by Brooks Atkinson, dramatic critic and now correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES at the Chinese capital.

Major Gen. A. Q. H. Dijxhoorn, Netherlands representative on the United Nations' Combined Chiefs of Staff, yesterday inspected the United States Army induction and recruiting center at Grand Central Palace. He was escorted by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, head of Selective Service for New York City, and Colonel Vergne Chappelle, in charge of the center.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Office of Price Administration moved today to provide additional gasoline mileage to salesmen distributing essential commodities other than in the seventeen Eastern States rationed area.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 5 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet, in exercises here today presented the Navy Cross to Captain Ernest G. Small, commanding officer of the heavy cruiser Salt Lake City and the Silver Star to his son, Lieutenant Chester W. Nimitz Jr., for outstanding service as a submarine officer.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Demand for flour has developed as operators in the wheat market become more familiar with the new price ceiling regulations and purchases of wheat futures today by mills and cash interests raised prices 1 1/8 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel to the highest levels in five years on the Board of Trade.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A coroner's verdict said today that Viscountess Castlerosse, who died in a hospital Dec. 12, had been killed by a drug that she took. She was the former wife of Valentine Charles Browne, Earl of Kenmare.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Spurred by fears of shortages of materials, buyers are attending the January furniture and home furnishing show here in much larger numbers than market leaders cared to admit. While no official figures were given out by either the American Furniture Mart or the Merchandise Mart, buyer registrations for the first day totaled 5,954, which topped by 1,019 the previous high record held by the first day of the July, 1941, market.

TEANECK, N.J., Jan. 5 -- The language of the Teaneck Fire Department may become more refined in the near future. For the department already has hired two women and will take on two more within a week.

City Court Justice Edward J. McCullen was formally inducted into office yesterday at a ceremony in the City Court Building at 52 Chambers Street, attended by leaders of the bench and bar. Justice McCullen, who had served as librarian of the Supreme Court before his election, was hailed as the first "career man" to advance through the competitive ranks to the City Court bench.

If the new Food Administrator, Claude R. Wickard, can remove "all of the unnecessary obstacles to all-out production" the food manufacturing industry will "deliver the goods at the time and place they are needed," Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, declared in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The arrival in Algiers of Harold Macmillan as British Resident Minister in North Africa, a rank corresponding to that recently conferred on the American representative, Robert D. Murphy, has a significance beyond the desire of London to play a part in political as well as military developments on the African front.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- Mrs. H. Rene Ruegg, mother of three children, received today the annual Gimbel Philadelphia Award as the city's outstanding woman of 1942, for her twenty years of continuous work as a volunteer worker in child welfare.

MASSENA, N.Y., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Eight persons, seven of them night-shift war workers, died in an explosion and fire which destroyed a small restaurant and filling station on the outskirts of this up-State community today. Five of the victims were passengers of a bus which had stopped briefly to permit passengers to eat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Impending transfers of Works Project Administration war projects to other agencies for completion prompted Senator McKellar of Tennessee today to cast doubt on the government economies involved in the recently ordered liquidation of the WPA.

The Federal Trade Commission, in its annual report submitted to Congress yesterday, renewed its recommendations that Section 7 of the Clayton Anti-Trust Act be amended so "that acquisition of assets be declared unlawful under the same conditions which are already applied to the acquisition of stock."

ATLANTA, Jan. 5 -- Following the refusal of Judge J.T. Grice of Tatnall County Superior Court to enjoin prison officials from disposing of assets of the State prison farm, the suit went to the State Supreme Court as a bill of exceptions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Frankie Sinkwich, who went south from Youngstown, Ohio, to become an all-America football back at Georgia, accepted the Washington Touchdown Club's Walter Camp Memorial Trophy tonight with the comment: "I'm glad Mrs. Sinkwich had this opportunity of coming to Washington."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Lessing J. Rosenwald, director of the WPB's conservation division, has submitted his resignation to Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, to become effective not later than Feb. 1.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 5 (AP) -- James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, told the fourth graduating class of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School today that "if there is any fault to be assayed or any blame to be placed, it is on my generation and not on yours, because mine, which had been through one war, preferred to forget history and to believe an earthly millennium had fallen on an hitherto sinful world."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- American air and ground forces again took the offensive and dealt hard blows to the Japanese in the Solomon Islands yesterday, killing at least 170 Japanese on Guadalcanal, capturing new and dominating positions there and blasting with bombs the new Japanese air base at Munda, the Navy announced today.

WITH SOUTH PACIFIC FLEET, Jan. 5 -- A daring submarine operation under the cover of darkness has resulted in the rescue of twenty-nine men, women and children from a Japanese-held island in the Solomon group, Admiral William F. Halsey disclosed today.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- For the second night in succession British bombers raided the Ruhr last night. The Air Ministry today reported two planes missing from the moderate-size force engaged.

Russeks, Fifth Avenue, Inc., has provided group life insurance for the personnel in the Fifth Avenue store and branches in Brooklyn and Chicago. The group plan, according to Max Weinstein, president, is being underwritten by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, with the entire cost borne by Russeks.

Canned baby foods, which previously have remained in plentiful supply even while other canned foods were disappearing from grocers shelves, were sold yesterday by many food retailers with a limitation of three cans to a customer. They said they were forced to take this step because many mothers sought to lay in large stocks of these chopped and strained foods.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Labor can double the output of war goods in 1943 as compared with 1942 "if we are not hampered by compulsory and punitive legislation," William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today in addressing legislative agents of the federation and its affiliates and of the railroad labor unions.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Releases of large amounts of funds through the Treasury's requisitioning of loans to India and South Africa was responsible today for further sharp rises of gilt-edge issues in the stock markets. Local loans gained 3/8, while the War Loan 3 1/2s and the 2 1/2 per cent and 4 per cent consols rose 1/4 each and the conversion 3 1/2s advanced 3-16.

Now that stockholders of the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation have approved dissolution of the corporation under the terms of a voluntary plan designed to meet the requirements of Section 11 (e) of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, it is understood that directors of the corporation will apply to the Federal courts and the Securities and Exchange Commission for effectuation of the plan of dissolution.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Two physicists at the Radium Institute of Berne -- one a Swiss and the other the wife of a British diplomat -- have announced the discovery of a new method of isolating chemical element 85, the last but one of the ninety-two primary components of matter to be identified, and have named the material "anglo-helvetium' in honor of their countries.

Last October Peggy Guggenheim opened her museum called Art of This Century. Since then this piquant establishment on the seventh floor at 30 West Fifty-seventh Street has been visited by marveling throngs. Only one casualty appears to have resulted as yet, and that not very serious.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The people of Britain were warned again today that they would have to tighten their belts still further. The next six months, according to the Minister of Food, Lord Woolton, will be the leanest of the war thus far -- in the Whitehall terms in which the spokesman for the government framed his warning, there will be a "continuance of the tightening process.

Consider the cabbage, symbol of all that is dull in cookery. The time is right for this humdrum member of the vegetable kingdom to undergo a renaissance. For now, when prices are high, cabbage is cheap. Now, when even familiar foods (meat and butter, for example) are scarce, cabbage is plentiful.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Following up a statement issued Monday by the trustees of Hull House, attributing her resignation as director of the settlement to differences over policy and budget, Miss Charlotte Carr today made public her letter of resignation.

The Self Winding Clock Company, Inc., of Brooklyn, which supplies the self-winding clocks for the Western Union Telegraph Company's time service, has been purchased by the E.J. Manville Machine Company of Waterbury, Conn., manufacturer of automatic machinery, it was announced yesterday by R.W. Phillips, president of the Manville company.

"Tennessee Johnson," a Metro production depicting the rise of Andrew Johnson to the Presidency of the United States, will have its world premiere at the Astor Theatre on Tuesday morning. "For Me and My Gal," the theatre's current tenant, today starts its twelfth and final week.

WASHINGTON, Jan 5 -- A Senate Agriculture subcommittee was informed in a letter from E.W. Reid, chief of the War Production Board chemical branch, today that a $550,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan was awarded to the Gulf Distilling Corporation of Gretna, La., for grain alcohol manufacturing equipment despite the disapproval of the WPB.

A hundred Australian and New Zealand fliers who are visiting the city as guests of the Anzac Club of New York were received yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at his office in City Hall and welcomed to the city.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Two stirring finishes gave a crowd of 2,629 something to cheer about at Tropical Park today.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 5 -- The Mexican Government is planning to establish absolute control of all agricultural and industrial production, the newspaper Ultimas Noticias says this evening.
Warm congratulations on your editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 4, entitled "Help for the Torpedoed."

Joseph Borkin, an assistant of Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold, and Charles A. Welsh, a cartel expert for the OPA, have written at length of the German cartel arrangements in a forthcoming Duell, Sloan Pearce book entitled "Germany's Master Plan: The Story of Industrial Offensive."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Arguments over the use of critical materials to convert oil refineries delayed their production of butadiene for synthetic rubber, Bruce K. Brown, assistant deputy petroleum administrator for war, told a Senate Agriculture subcommittee today.

Declaring that while she believed there would be little opposition to the use of government funds already provided for the establishment of day nurseries in defense areas, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt warned yesterday that there might be opposition to further grants because of public criticism of the spending of Federal money.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Paint and varnish finishes are beginning to disappear from the furniture along with steel springs and other metal parts, furniture manufacturers attending the Winter market at the American Furniture Mart here indicated today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Washington unit of the American Women's Volunteer Services has oryanized farming courses for potential farm labor reserves to be given by the American University next month. The unit, comprising more than 5,000 members, supplied 763 part-time workers to thirty farm operator from Sept. 19 to the middle of last month, many of the workers trained by similar courses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Seriousness marked the demeanor of seven women members of the House at today's opening of the new Congress. Mrs. Frances P. Bolton of Ohio, dressed in a pale blue suit, was the only one except Mrs. Clare B. Luce not dressed in black.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Re-elected Speaker on his sixty-first birthday anniversary, Representative Rayburn of Texas was surprised with a White House birthday party today a few hours after the House had broken tradition by interrupting a speech to sing "Happy Birthday, Dear Speaker, Happy Birthday to You."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The National Labor Relations Board denied today a motion by the Kaiser Company, Inc., and the Oregon Shipbuilding Company requesting the disqualification of two board members from the duty of deciding cases involving alleged unfair labor practices by the companies at their shipyards at Vancouver, Wash., and Swan Island. Portland, Ore.

The possibility that lend-lease transactions will be extended and the private supplier eliminated from the North African and other markets was a principal topic of discussion yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 6 -- Vogel, Goldberg and Sipowsky, Americans -- a Protestant, a Jew and a Catholic -- shipmates on a Navy plane who died in a take-off crash in the harbor on Dec. 31, were buried side by side with Navy honors today.

I was surprised to find a NEW YORK TIMES editorial of Dec. 30 discussing liberal arts education in wartime in terms of "dallying with Elizabethan poetry or the Homeric epics while civilization is at stake."

LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Governor General of French West Africa, Pierre Boisson of once-suspect Dakar, has given assurance that there will be no recession oil his support to the Allies and that he favors alliance of the Giraud forces with the Fighting French, who attacked his capital, Dakar, with British support in 1940.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 6 -- Almost 100 newspapers throughout India, including some of the most important, suspended publication for one day today in protest over the suppression of certain developments connected with internal politics.

Charles B. Williams, former president of the Mexican Chamber of Commerce in the United States, lately honorary head of that body, and for many years Latin-American representative of the Underwood Typewriter Company, died suddenly last night at his home, the Villa Flores, 145-20 Twentieth Avenue, Whitestone, Queens.

Twenty-nine corporations said to produce 80 per cent of the anthracite coal mined in this country were indicted with twenty-six of their officials yesterday on charges of conspiracy to fix prices in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Reuter said today that reports had reached Switzerland from Budapest that Rumanian police had arrested more than 4,000 persons and had already executed eighty after uncovering an Iron Guard plot against Marshal Ion Antonescu, Rumanian Chief of State.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY IN WESTERN BURMA, Jan. 2 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- This is a strange war tucked away in this river-ribbed coastal backwoods. This is no struggle with tanks or big guns, but a contest of jungle wits, of sampans, of dugout canoes.

According to an announcement by the War Department, the United States Army is organizing "foreign battalions" of Free Austrians, Norwegians, Greeks and Filipinos who are anxious to fight for the liberation of their countries from Axis domination. Such a step and such battalions should be warmly welcomed, both as an addition to the manpower and as a demonstration of the solidarity of the United Nations.

The speech made in the Democratic caucus by Representative Rayburn, re-elected yesterday as Speaker of the House, was made behind closed doors and has not been textually reported. But it is described by hearers as "a declaration of independence" from the executive branch of the Government, particularly of its departments and bureaus.

For the unpredictable and amazing Mitropoulos the concert he gave last night with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall was not less than a sensational triumph. Mr. Mitropoulos triumphed personally as an electrifying piano virtuoso as well as conductor, and also as an artist whose remarkable gifts enabled him to do a signal service to modern music.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission reopened today for further hearing the proceedings under which it granted the railroads increased rates, fares and charges early last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- There is probably no mind sufficiently imaginative and far-seeing to produce a full prospectus of the activities that will engage the official group headed by Herbert Lehman before its affairs are completed. No assignment with ramifications so vast has ever been given before, for the simple reason that the ravages of war were never before spread so widely.

To the week's lone opening will be added "Silver Queen," which will have its local premiere at the Globe on Saturday. Produced by Harry Sherman and directed by Lloyd Bacon, the action drama of the old West features George Brent, Priscilla Lane and Bruce Cabot, with Lynne Overman, Eugene Pallette.

A widespread investigation into allegations of evasions of price ceilings on meat and poultry was begun yesterday by local and regional officials of the Office of Price Administration, who questioned a large number of butchers here and in other cities in New York State, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware and the District of Columbia.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- United States and British bombers have blasted and burned vital railway targets at Mandalay, heart of the Japanese supply system in Burma, in three heavy raids within twenty-four hours, communiques disclosed today.
Mayor La Guardia inspected yesterday the equipment and workings of the information center of the New York Air Defense Wing and came away highly impressed. It was his first visit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- All pleasure driving by holders of A, B and C gasoline ration cards in the seventeen Eastern States and the District of Columbia will be outlawed as of noon tomorrow, the Office of Price Administration said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The publication by THE NEW YORK TIMES today of the complete text of the State Department's document "Peace and War -- United States Foreign Policy. 1931-1941" was praised widely in the capital today.

Judged by its magnificent performance in erasing league by league the gains made by the Germans in their Summer campaign, the Red Army seems stronger instead of weaker than it was last Winter. The momentum of the drive increases rather than diminishes as the days go by.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:
THE stranger walked into the billiard emporium, hidden away in the fastnesses of the Pennsylvania hills.

Robert A. McKibbin, 39 years old, a city chauffeur who formerly drove for Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran, was acquitted last night in Queens County Court on a charge of first-degree manslaughter. His wife, Rita, was found guilty of second-degree manslaughter, but the jury recommended clemency to Judge Thomas Downs.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- American, British and Dominion prisoners of war in Japan -- where there are said to be about 5,000 Americans and 5,000 Britons -- are forced to live on the standard of the Japanese soldier, according to a War Office statement reviewing the Japanese treatment of prisoners of war, issued today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Medium bombers and attack planes of the Southwest Pacific Command yesterday swept over the Japanese airdrome at Lae in New Guinea, destroying four anti-aircraft gun positions and a grounded bomber.

LONDON, Jan 6 (U.P.) -- Heavy bombers of the United States Ninth Army Air Force, attached to the Allied Middle East Command, have raided harbor facilities at Sousse, north of Sfax, planting all bombs in the target area, which included a phosphate works, a Cairo communique reported today.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A British communique:

Moreland Act Commissioner William F. Bleakley will open offices for his investigation into abuses of workmen's compensation insurance tomorrow at 36 West Forty-fourth Street and will keep them open thereafter seven days a week, twenty-four hours a day.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- Air Vice Marshal Wilfred Ashton McClaughry, 48, commander of Royal Air Force fighter group in the Middle East, was killed Monday in the same plane crash in which Lady Tedder, the wife of Air Marshal Sir Arthur William Tedder, was killed, it was revealed today.

Despite the curtailment made necessary by the absorption of competitors into the armed forces and the limited competitive facilities obtaining in wartime, the New York Athletic Club compiled a commendable record in the realm of sports through its past fiscal year.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Somewhat fewer than half of the 50,000 conscientious objectors who have passed through tribunals set up for them in this country since conscription began in the Spring of 1939 have been assigned to civilian work related to the war, such as farming, the fire service and air raid precautions.

"Something for the Boys," a new musical comedy, will be presented at the Alvin tonight by Michael Todd. Herbert and Dorothy Fields wrote the book and Cole Porter wrote the songs for the show, which was staged by Hassard Short.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 6 -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Reich Propaganda Minister, says this week's Reich, a magazine:
LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Soviet monitor tonight recorded the following special communique broadcast by the Moscow radio:

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- A Columbia basketball team with a little more savvy ran away from Cornell in the stretch tonight to win, 49 to 40, in the first Eastern Intercollegiate League game of the year.

The Weston Electrical Instrument Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, last, a net profit of $501,951 after all charges including $4,510,000 provision for estimated refund to United States Government on war contracts, post-war adjustments and Federal income and excess profits taxes after deduction for post-war refund of 10 per cent of excess profits taxes.

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange slackened yesterday as dealers awaited today's Presidential message to Congress, which may contain the Administration's attitude on projected changes in agricultural parity prices. Throughout the session the market was sensitive to small orders on either side, and it closed with net losses of to 10 points.

The unit cost of advertising in all the daily newspapers in the United States and Canada is actually less today than it was before the war began in 1939, the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, pointed out yesterday in a new cost study, "All This and Economy, Too."

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- Transportation Director Joseph Eastman said today that industry's efforts to alleviate the transportation shortage have been "disappointing" thus far, largely because some industries suspect the government of ulterior motives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The text of the Office of Price Administration announcement concerning gasoline in the seaboard States follows:

Serious dislocations in the educational systems of this city will occur if the schools and colleges are deprived of oil to heat their buildings, officials dislosed yesterday. Educators were worried over this possibility.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Browns, it appeared tonight, may attempt to cancel the deal which transferred Elden Auker to the Senators in exchange for Paul Dean -- if Auker definitely gives up baseball.

Mr. Esslinger's comments in THE TIMES of Jan. 4 on Mr. Hoover's recent Chicago speech are admirable in courtesy and good temper. I believe that a more careful reading of Mr. Hoover's speech would eliminate many of Mr. Esslinger's misgivings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- Joe DiMaggio, the central figure in numerous baseball holdout controversies, was in the thick of another argument today -- whether his remarks in a recent interview were properly interpreted.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 6 (AP) -- An American communique:

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Specific but limited recommendations for tax reduction and a call for an increase in the social services now rendered by the State to its people, were made today by Governor Dewey as he gave in person his first message to a joint session of both houses of the Legislature.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 6 -- Without actually making direct reference to a break with the Axis, President Juan Antonio Rios fully approved today the manner in which Minister of Interior Raul Morales Beltrami fulfilled the special mission entrusted to him to discuss with government executives of the United States, Argentina and Brazil problems related "with Chile's international position in the presence of conflict."

Harry Boykoff, 6-foot 9-inch sophomore who makes the St. John's basketball team formidable every minute he is on the court, proved too much for City College last night at Madison Square Garden. As a result, the Brooklyn Redmen romped to a 50-42 victory over last season's metropolitan champions in the second game of a double-header.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 6 -- Seton Hall suffered its worst basketball defeat in recent years and its first this season when a fast-traveling, spectacular-shooting Princeton five ran up a 47-30 score before 4,500 in Setonia Gym tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- Casey Robinson, Warner Brothers scenarist for the last eight years, has been signed to a term contract by RKO as a writer-producer, the studio announced today. As a part of the deal RKO has acquired Robinson's screen story, "This Is Russia," and took over a commitment he had obtained from Tamara Toumanova, Russian ballerina, to appear in it.

Henry J. Kaiser, the Pacific Coast shipbuilder, in an interview here yesterday reported that his yards now were producing "close to a ship per way per month." There are nineteen ways at Richmond, Calif., and eleven at Portland, Ore., which would mean virtually a ship a day.

Back from their joint session in Chicago, officials of New York York City's three major league baseball clubs yesterday lost no time settling once more to the task of mending their Spring training fences, which for the second time within a few weeks had been blown down by encroaching wartime restrictions.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Police checks showed 30,000 automobiles parked around the Rose Bowl on New Year's Day. That figure was 8,000 above the high of pre-rationing days.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Gilt-edge stocks were again a feature of strength in the markets today under the lead of the old 2 1/2 per cent Consols which rose 1/8 to 83. Local loans, 3 per cent, rose 1/8 to 98 1/8, while the 3 1/2 per cent war loan was unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Although millions of men have been classified for Selective Service, only the bare fraction of 6,277 has turned out to be conscientious objectors it was learned today. Latest figures show that of this total 5,194 of the men are in the civilian public service camps provided for the objectors and 1,083 have been ordered to report there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration extended to Canadian woodpulp producers today the same treatment with respect to transportation allowances that apply to United States producers for sales in this country.
The text of Mayor La Guardia's annual message to the City Council, delivered yesterday, follows:

Now that the New Year's festivities are behind us, the stores are turning their attention to Spring styles. Once again the luncheon hour fashion shows at the hotels are being held. Yesterday it was Arnold Constable who showed at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in the Sert Room.

The National Institute of Arts and Letters announced yesterday the election of ten new members in the departments of art and literature. This honorary organization was founded in 1898 to promote the highest standards in literature and the fine arts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- The names of 336 American soldiers held as prisoners of war by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands were made public by the War Department today. The list includes 334 officers, one enlisted man and one warrant officer of the United States Army.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Navy communique 241:

The mission of the Republican party is to get the United States "back on the tracks of constitutional government and away from totalitarianism and State socialism, to keep it on the tracks and to see to it that no force, foreign or domestic, shall throw the switch."
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Reports today of wholesale arrests in Rumania in connection with a plot against the Antonescu Government were regarded here as plausible, although they were not confirmed.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 7 -- Russia announced the capture of twenty-one towns and two more railway stations yesterday in the middle Don and Caucasus offensives and said these drives had cost the Nazis more than 339,150 dead and captured since Nov. 19.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 6 -- Civilian expenditures for consumer goods and services will fall 10 to 15 per cent this year and the decrease in production will be 15 to 20 per cent as compared with that of last year, the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Supply predicted today on the basis of completed studies.

The new Congress should devise a tax prooTam which will meet the legitimate necessities of war but leave room for the accumulation of sufficient reserves by industry for conversion to peace production, Frederick C. Crawford, newly elected president of the lational Association of Manufacturers, declared jesterday.

Curtailed by lack of shipping facilities, exhibitors and equipment, the annual New York Poultry Show opened yesterday for a five-day stay in the ballroom of the Hotel Capitol, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street. Only 2,000 birds were shown, compared with nearly 4,000 last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- While German U-boats did not sink as many American ships in December as in former months, the submarine menace is still very serious, Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, declared today.

The problems of adolescent girls in wartime were discussed yesterday by Dr. Alice V. Keliher, Professor of Elementary Education at New York University, at a biennial meeting of executives of the Camp Fire Girls in the Gramercy Park Hotel. The group was from seven States in the East.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Nine "freshman" Senators, eight Republicans and one Democrat, were called in the roll on Capitol Hill today and, judging by the manner in which those present criticized government spending, New Deal policies and "bureaucracy," they will give no aid and comfort to the Administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The first measure presented today for adoption by the new Congress was a proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution, providing that "men and women shall have equal rights throughout the United States and every place subject to its jurisdiction."
Sales of dwellings and apartment houses provided the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan reported yesterday. Most of the deals were on the West Side.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 6 -- A possibility of the existence, between 800 and 600 B.C., of a heretofore unknown "King of the World" is held out by an incomplete inscription on a fragment of bronze dug up in 1927 in Palestine, according to Dr. Chester C. McCown, director of the Palestine Institute of the Pacific School of Religion.

The growing need for nurses in the armed forces will necessitate drawing upon eligible nurses in categories hitherto regarded as essential -- head nurses, instructors, supervisors and superintendents -- in the opinion of Major Julia C. Stimson of the Army Nurse Corps.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The seventy-eighth Congress -- named the Victory Congress by spokesmen of both of the closely matched majority and minority parties -- convened today, with the House pledged to unified effort in winning the war and keeping it won, but to a new independence in action and the writing of laws on the domestic front.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Two aged women were found dead, apparently from exposure, in their home tonight as Thomas F. Sullivan, State Fuel Administrator, announced that "a substantial emergency supply" of kerosene was on it way to Boston to supply householders threatened with evacuation from their homes by the range oil shortage.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Hope for an early solution of the problems impeding the fusion of all French forces opposing the Axis has dwindled lately despite professions of eagerness to unite by such leaders as General Charles de Gaulle, head of the Fighting French, and General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner of French North Africa, and the comment of Pierre Boisson, Governor General of French West Africa, that this was "most desirable."
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Soviet monitor early today recorded the following midnight communique broadcast by the Moscow radio:
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 6 -- Staple crops in 1942 were more plentiful than in 1941, a survey of Mexico's agricultural production up to December showed today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- The movie-going public may have forgotten tall, lantern-faced William S. Hart, old-time Western film star, but Hart, who today had regained sufficient strength to leave St. Vincent's Hospital, where he had been a patient for seven weeks, has not forgotten the public.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique:

Asserting that he had been listed as not qualified for a license to teach children with retarded mentality because he had been a member of the Communist party, from which he subsequently resigned, Frank Valenti, substitute teacher in Junior High School 84, Brooklyn, applied yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred V. Norton in Brooklyn for an order compelling the board of examiners of the Board of Education to certify him for the position.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Boyd David Wagner, hero of the Phillipines campaign, lost his life when his single-engined plane crashed during a flight in Florida, it was disclosed tonight with discovery of the body.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Head men of the American Association, who gave a big sigh of relief when the major leagues adopted a schedule and Spring training program acceptable to the Office of Defense Transportation, today speedily approved a similar plan for their own 1943 season.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Both the form players and the long-shot bettors got a chance to cash in today as Tropical Park ran off a racing card which started before the government announced a ban on pleasure driving.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Three children lost their lives tonight by suffocation and burns when an oil stove exploded in their home and ignited the furnishings. The victims, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Robinson, Negroes, were Eleanor, 2 years old; Mildred, 3, and Gloria, 4.

Mrs. Margaret Carozza of 1344 University Avenue, the Bronx, a 47-year-old mother of five children, received yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court a ten-day workhouse sentence for abusing a principal and causing a disturbance in the school.

Award of $110,000 of refunding bonds due on Aug. 1, 1953 to 1963, has been made by the town of West Orange, N.J., to H.L. Allen Co. and Graham, Parsons Co. The bankers jointly bid 101.31, naming the interest rate as 2 1/4 per cent.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- John F. Tucker, assistant State's attorney general, in his summation at the trial for grand larceny and forgery trial of Samuel L. Nuzzo, accused of looting the hod carriers union treasury, asked a Supreme Court jury today "to reassure the workingman of America that he enjoys the protection of the law."

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- A formula for fireproofing clothes, expected to save the lives of many Allied fliers, has been developed by two Croydon chemists, G.A. Petzoldt and his son, G.E. Petzoldt, refugee residents of Britain.

Mischa Elman, violinist, was the artist last night in the fourth event of Town Hall's thirteenth Endowment Series. Leopold Mittman was the accompanist, and there was a good-sized audience, which received the violinist cordially.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 6 -- "There seems to be a conspiracy in Bermuda to subvert religion to moral chaos by the desecration of the Lord's Day and thus to precipitate a destruction worse than that of the war," the report of the Ministerial Association comments after a consideration of Sunday observance problems.

A story of how Army, Navy and Coast Guard airplanes, working in close cooperation, rescued thirty-one survivors of a ship that was battered and sunk by a storm seventy-five miles off the Atlantic coast recently was told yesterday by the Army and Navy public relations office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Army bombers, operating in the Aleutians yesterday and today, hit two Japanese cargo ships in the vicinity of the Japanese base at Kiska and definitely sank one of them, the Navy reported in a communique issued here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, said today that reports indicated the Japanese are massing a large armada in the Solomons, but that bombers from General Douglas MacArthur's Southwest Pacific Command had done "a very good job" on that fleet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -Spokesmen for five major farm organizations stated tonight after a meeting with Senate farm group leaders that they would ask immediate release from the armed forces of drafted farm youth as a means of relieving the agricultural manpower shortage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Office of War Information gave out figures today to show that the 1939 armed strength of what are now the United Nations was overwhelmingly greater than that of Germany, Italy and Japan combined.

The first casualties resulting from yesterday's ban of all pleasure driving by the Office of Price Administration were Florida's two chief horse-racing tracks -- Hialeah and Tropical Park. Operators of other sports and amusement enterprises expect material cuts in their profits to result.

Foote, Cone Belding, successor to Lord Thomas, announced yesterday that Emerson Foote of New York has been elected president; Fairfax M. Cone, Chicago, chairman of the executive committee, and Don Belding, Los Angeles, chairman of the board.
Some idea of the amount of game that is taken by sportsmen in various sections of the country is suggested by the figures that the Pennsylvania Game Commission has released.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The text of Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature today was as follows:

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 -- The Red Army in the Caucasus, with a spearhead of Don Cossacks combined with tank units, is fiercely pursuing the enemy northward from Nalchik and northwestward from Prokhladnaya. Northern Ossetia is cleared, the capital of the autonomous area of Kabardin-Balkar is again free and the Germans have been driven from the Terek valley.

When housewives register for War Ration Book 2 next month they will not have coupons deducted for moderate amounts of canned or frozen foods they may have on hand, it was revealed last night by Harold B. Rowe, director of the Food Rationing Division of the Office of Price Administration, during a discussion of the new point rationing system held in THE NEW YORK TIMES Hall.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 (U.P.) Dudley Field Malone, New York lawyer, became a movie actor today, playing the role of his old friend, Winston Churchill.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan 6 -- Girls of the Highland Manor School here continued today to make beds, vacuum rugs, wait table and perform other extracurricular tasks as voluntary substitutes for a group of domestics, who quit their jobs Monday night in a pay dispute.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, who on Dec. 23 held out the prospect of a strike by subway, bus and trolley car workers if the city did not meet the union pay demands told a packed hall at Manhattan Center last night that "by arbitration, and only by arbitration" could the transport workers settle their differences with the city.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 6 (AP) -- National and district officers of the United Mine Workers met with rank-and-file representatives late today in an effort to end a production-crippling strike of 9,000 workers over wages and increased dues, who were joined by 4,000 more tonight.

While President Lowell was always faithful to the interests of the professional schools, it is the prime distinction of his administration that he restored, rebuilt and enlarged the College. In the last years of President Eliot's service his pious devotion to the elective system brought unfortunate results.

A bleak picture of community life along the Atlantic seaboard -- with restaurants open only during certain hours, united church services reminiscent of the last war's coal shortage, some empty theatres, closed schoolhouses and non-essential industries put on part time shifts or their machines stilled altogether -- was drawn yesterday by government officials and others as a distinct possibility resulting from the most severe fuel oil restrictions which have yet been imposed.

Further indication of the increasing effectiveness of the campaign against enemy submarine activity along the coasts of this continent was contained yesterday in the announcement of a list of additional reductions in cargo war risk insurance rates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Thousands of 1942 wage and salary increases, which are unpaid because they have not been approved by the War Labor Board, posed a new question today for the Bureau of Internal Revenue: Is the money subject to the 5 per cent withholding tax on 1943 payrolls?

Declaring that the foreign language press has done "a good job" in promoting the American war effort, ten publishers and editors of foreign language papers in this city have declined an invitation to attend a victory conference of the foreign language press of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt on Saturday, it became known yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 6 -- Constituting the first Berlin admission of the German Amy's difficult situation in the east, a period of official silence on important military news from the Eastern Front has been inaugurated in Berlin.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Eighty former railroad executives, who were inducted into the Army as commissioned officers a month ago, were graduated this afternoon from Fort Slocum's new Atlantic Coast Transportation Corps Officers Training School as the first military railway engineers to receive government diplomas in this war.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The wheat market reversed its action today and futures on the Board of Trade closed 7/8 to 1 cent a bushel lower than yesterday under the weight of profit taking, a little hedging pressure and professional selling induced by a report that the Commodity Credit Corporation was planning to call loans on the 1940 and 1941 pledged grain held on farms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt met with the Pacific War Council; conferred with Richard G. Caey, British Minister to the Near East, and was host at an informal birthday party in honor of Speaker Rayburn.

R.W. Gallagher, present chairman of the board, was elected yesterday president and chief executive officer of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey to fill the vacancy caused by the death of W.S. Farish on Nov. 29. The post of chairman will not be filled, the company announced.

Two former United States soldiers and the mother of a youth arrested on Tuesday for possession of brass knuckles were among twenty persons rounded up that day as dangerous alien enemies, it was revealed yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, assistant to J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 6 -- An involved and ingenious plot in which a band of three women and four men allegedly won bingo jackpots by printing winning numbers as they were called was disclosed today following the arrest of four persons here and three in Union City.

Governor Dewey's first message to the State Legislature does not read like the manifesto of a party returned to office after twenty years in exile. Mr. Dewey is in fact a war executive, taking up where Governor Lehman left off, differing with Mr. Lehman on some matters of detail and on some matters of general philosophy.
Supporting the policy announced some time ago by President Abe Greene, the National Boxing Association has declined to recognize Beau Jack, Augusta, Ga., lightweight, as the world champion.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 6 -- Private reports from inside Rumania, late this evening, hinted that widespread police activity throughout the country during the past few days had foiled another revolutionary attempt that the disbanded units of the Iron Guard were on the point of making on the eve of the second anniversary of their "January Civil War."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, cut by 25 per cent today the amount of fuel oil rations now allowed for heating non-dwelling space in the seventeen Eastern States and the District of Columbia, effective at midnight.

The annual report of earnings of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company was mailed to stockholders yesterday, although the annual stockholders' meeting will not be held until Jan. 14. The report shows total operating income for 1942 of $17,254,166 and total operating expenses of $11,206,298, leaving net operating earnings of $6,047,868.
The first crop of rubber grown in New Jersey was harvested yesterday on the plantation of the United States Rubber Company at Paramus, Bergen County, it was announced yesterday by the company.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A communique:

Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and originator of the pay-as-you-go income-tax payment plan, said yesterday that the adoption of such a plan was up to the current Congress. He spoke at a luncheon of the Advertising Club at the clubhouse, 23 Park Avenue.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 6 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, said today that "Princeton has not forgotten that technical training alone is not enough for winning the war and establishing the peace" and declared that the university would keep intact its liberal arts program while participating fully in the Army and Navy training programs.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 6 -- A horrified crowd of 200 persons watched helplessly this afternoon as two 5-year-old boys, trapped on the thinly frozen surface of the Delaware and Raritan Canal here, sank one after the other beneath the water.

Pending an official definition of "pleasure driving" in the ban announced yesterday by the OPA, store executives here felt the order would have an adverse effect on shopping. Because of previous gasoline and tire restrictions, larger establishments have already been losing trade to suburban and neighborhood stores.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Here are highlights of the recommendations made by Governor Dewey to the Legislature in his message today:

If mass production of war goods by small plants is to be accomplished, the Smaller War Plants Corporation must adopt a more aggressive program by establishing subsidiaries in large production areas populated by small plants, George A. Sloan, New York City Commissioner of Commerce, declared yesterday.

Butter, which you have been eating in unusually small amounts of late, is especially significant for its Vitamin A content. Consequently, when you cut down on its consumption you need more of the foods that are rich in this essential.

A fund to establish an annual $25 prize for the reporter writing the oustanding human interest story in a New York metropolitan daily was left by Wilbur Finley Fauley, author and member of the staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES for thirty-three years, according to his will, filed yesterday for probate in Surrogate's Court.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The Democratic minority in the Senate and Assembly introduced at the opening session of the Legislature today a series of bills to carry out the party's legislative program which was drafted last month following discussions between former Governor Poletti and legislative leaders.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Jan. 7 -- Twelfth Night in France passed without cakes and ale. The traditional "galette" was not to be found because prefectorial orders forbade its being baked. As for ale, that has become hogwash.

A listless and narrow pattern set in yesterday on the stock market, with price swings of more than minor fractions confined to a few issues. Buying and selling were balanced more evenly than in any recent session and volume continued to contract.
Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador, and Lady Halifax are expected to arrive today from Washington, and will be at the Waldorf Astoria.

TORONTO, Jan. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Growth and expansion during 1942 of Canada's war industry in all its phases is reviewed in The Toronto Globe and Mail's annual financial review, which will be released with tomorrow morning's regular editions of the paper.

Presumed by the police to have been attempting to re-enact a situation he had seen in a movie thriller, Ralph Lorch Jr., 11-year-old son of Patrolman and Mrs. Ralph Lorch of 574 Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn, was found hanging from the doorknob of his bedroom at 5:30 P.M. yesterday by his father.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 5 (Delayed) -- India faces shortages of her three great staples, wheat, rice and millet. Today's newspapers treat the situation as an outstanding, all-absorbing topic among urban populations.

The twenty-two justices of the City Court elected Justice John A. Byrnes, Democrat, as chief justice of the court yesterday at a brief meeting in the library of the court house at 52 Chambers Street. The jurists departed from the custom of choosing as chief justice the senior in point of service, who at present is Justice Joseph W. Keller, also a Democrat.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- A small group of machinists, the center of an East Bay shipyard dispute which attracted countrywide attention, will return to work at the Alameda plant of the General Engineering and Drydock Company tomorrow morning, representatives of the Department of Labor and the Shipbuilding Stabilization Committee said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- An American naval force ran the gantlet of Japanese defenses around Munda, the new enemy air base on New Georgia Island, to shell that base under cover of darkness in the early morning of Tuesday, the Navy reported here today.

A funeral service for William Hanford (Big Bill) Edwards, Princeton football player of 1897-1900 and a former city Street Cleaning Commissioner and Federal Collector of Internal Revenue, who died on Monday at the age of 66, was held last night at Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- Captain Ernest G. Small of New Haven, Conn., commander of the heavy cruiser Salt Lake City, who played a major role in the smashing of a Japanese fleet headed for Guadalcanal on the night of Oct. 11-12, received the Navy Cross today.

Stocks of gasoline increased sharply last week, but supplies of fuel oil declined further, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period gasoline stocks amounted to 82,420,000 barrels, an increase of 2,192,000 over the 80,228,000 a week earlier.

Among the letters bringing more gifts yesterday to the Neediest Cases Fund was one which seemed to express the thoughts of many other contributors of the day. It was sent "with the hope that this is neither too little nor too late."

Lustrous locks and soft curls may become only a fond memory for many workers in defense plants, experts agree, unless special precautionary measures are taken. Women welders, for example, are discovering that heat, abrasions from steel filings, acids and invisible dust can penetrate the hair shaft and in time destroy it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Pacific War Council at its first meeting of the new year with President Roosevelt today discussed the possibility of developing additional air routes across the Pacific as supply lines, and so strengthening the Allied position in the Far East.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Establishment of State and area food industry committees, empowered to investigate local food shortages arising out of maldistribution of supplies, was ordered tonight by Secretary Wickard as a means of coping with the shortages which have been developing sporadically throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 6 -- War Manpower Chief Paul V. McNutt made it plain tonight that baseball playing -- even where it involved a star "essential" to winning a pennant -- did not constitute grounds for occupational deferment from the military draft.

New Yorkers were assured yesterday by Commissioner of Markets Daniel P. Woolley and leaders in the coal industry that there is "plenty of coal" available for all normal demands. There is a scarcity of some types of coal, such as pea coal, but the over-all supply is adequate to meet the normal annual consumption of ten to twelve million tons in the metropolitan area, spokesmen for the large companies said.

The 1943 financial campaign of the New York City Y.M.C.A. will be headed by Frank M. Totton, vice president of the Chase National Bank, according to an announcement yesterday by Richard W. Lawrence, president of the association.

CHUNGKING, Jan. 6 -- Ta Kung Pao, Chinese newspaper, in an editorial today concerning the American White Paper, pointed out that China was the first of the big United Nations to enter the war, while the United States was the last.

Tucked away in the lowest left-hand corner of the bookcase, close to the floor, is a volume you do not remember handling for a good many years. It is called, "What Would Be the Character of a New War?"
Confidence on the outlook for civilian goods supply this year was expressed yesterday at the ready-to-wear clinic held yesterday by Felix Lilienthal Co., Inc., at its

A plan of reorganization for the Warner Sugar Corporation has been filed in the Federal court here by Francis J. Quillinan, trustee, providing for the acquisition of all fixed assets of the company by Miranda Sugar Estates for $1,915,500 in stated value of common stock.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- The Office of Price Administration began today its first Federal court action for meat ceiling price violations in a suit against the South Philadelphia Dressed Beef Company for $11,807.82, representing triple damages for alleged overcharges made by the company to a New York wholesale meat distributor.

The validity here of a German law requiring residents of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg to sign an offer of sale to the German Government of all securities held by them before being permitted to leave the duchy was presented yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy for decision.

The validity here of a German law requiring residents of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg to sign an offer of sale to the German Government of all securities held by them before being permitted to leave the duchy was presented yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy for decision.

One of the most difficult tasks of the post-war period will be the undoing of the wrongs committed against the youth of Germany and Japan by Hitler and the Japanese militarists, J. Willard Hayden last night told the annual dinner meeting of the board of directors of the Catholic Youth Organization at the University Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- New maximum price ceilings were ordered in effect Jan. 14 on retail sales of butter, fresh citrus fruits, bananas, cheese and poultry by the Office of Price Administration today.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 6 -- For the first time in a week heavy fighting broke out on the northern flank of Tunisia, with one of England's famous infantry regiments, which had been on the northwest frontier of India, playing a major part.
The German High Command reported yesterday that "heavy defensive fighting continued with unabated fury in the Don area" on Tuesday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A new drive to enact legislation creating an over-all Office of War Mobilization, involving the question of civilian or military control over war production, was started today.

WE talk a good brand of inter-Americanism and "hemisphere solidarity," but until very recently both the North and South Americans have understood Europe far better than they have understood each other. Only a handful of North Americans, from Hubert Herring to Katherine Carr Rodell, have written sympathetically of the problems of Chile and Peru, while South American students of North American affairs are rarer than the blue heron.
The German High Command reported yesterday that "heavy defensive fighting continued with unabated fury in the Don area" on Tuesday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A new drive to enact legislation creating an over-all Office of War Mobilization, involving the question of civilian or military control over war production, was started today.

WE talk a good brand of inter-Americanism and "hemisphere solidarity," but until very recently both the North and South Americans have understood Europe far better than they have understood each other. Only a handful of North Americans, from Hubert Herring to Katherine Carr Rodell, have written sympathetically of the problems of Chile and Peru, while South American students of North American affairs are rarer than the blue heron.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Admiral William F. Halsey, United Nations Commander in Chief in the South Pacific, who recently predicted the complete defeat of the Axis in 1943, has a low estimate of the Japanese service man. In an interview in New Zealand, the United States admiral stood confidently on his prediction of an Allied victory this year and added:

Application of scientific principles to the social study of man was urged yesterday by Dr. Leonard Bloomfield, Professor of Linguistics at Yale University, in an address at the initiation of forty-eight new members into the Hunter College Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa.

Associates of Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, gave last night a dinner in his honor in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to commemorate completion of the 100th year of business by the dry goods concern.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 6 -- Recent reports coming in here confirm the fact that there is steadily growing "unrest" in Rumania, where fires, railroad accidents and the severing of telephone and telegraph wires are becoming more frequent.
With Army and Navy officers listed in the draw, the New York State squash racquets championship started last night on the courts of the Downtown A.C.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The State Court of Appeals ignored today a precedent set in June by the United States Supreme Court, and asserted unanimously its own role as protector of civil liberties, under the State Constitution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Mrs. Roosevelt entertained a box party at the benefit concert given tonight by Marian Anderson in Constitution Hall, heading a distinguished and a capacity audience, by whose presence the United China Relief Fund was increased by the amount of $6,500.

A direct if rather crude method of seeking appointment as secretary-treasurer of a union was described in General Sessions Court yesterday at the trial of Joseph (Socks) Lanza, 43 years old, and four other defendants on charges of extortion and conspiracy in connection with racketeering in Local 202 of the Teamsters' Union.

President Roosevelt's annual message to the Congress, unusual since it did not touch on government finance, taxes or legislation, brought yesterday no change of complexion in the stock market. Mixed trends in prices prevailed throughout the day on the Stock Exchange, except for a slight flurry in the final hour, when film issues steadied after early inroads of major proportions.

Waterfowl shooting in the Southern zone, which embraces fifteen States from Delaware to Arizona, will come to an end on Sunday and in some cases on Saturday evening in sections where hunting is banned on Sunday.

Miss Pearl Nickerson is the first, and so far the only woman instructor on the faculty of the Y.M.C.A. Trade and Technical School, teaching radio code to 800 men of the Army Signal Corps Reserve. Yesterday "Y" officials reported the experiment so successful that they were wondering why they had not thought of taking on women for such jobs before.

M.J. Fleming, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, announced yesterday that the bank had temporarily waived the restrictions of Regulation V, covering guaranteed loans, as they apply to extensions of credit to finance the replacement or repair of real or personal property damaged or lost by persons in areas affected by floods in the Cleveland Reserve district.

Mr. and Mrs. Griswold Thompson gave a dinner last night at the St. Regis. Among their guests were Prince and Princess Kyril Scherbatow, Sir William and Lady Garthwaite, Culver Sherrill, Miss Mary Ridgely Carter, Count and Countess Hans Scherr Thoss and Harold Webster.

The Whitney Museum of American Art has purchased 12 and 14 West Eighth Street, near Washington Square, from the Rhinelander Real Estate Company in a cash deal arranged by the Charles F. Noyes Company and H. Stanley Hillyer, brokers.

The wisdom of employing mothers with young children in war industries and the scope to which the practice should be encouraged was the subject of a symposium at America's Town Meeting of the Air in Town Hall last night.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 7 (AP) -German parachutists and a native guide were dropped far behind the Allied lines in Algeria in the St. Arnando region, 100 to 160 miles west of the Tunisian frontier. The guide was captured and shot, said a spokesman in Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Dr. Hubertus J. Van Mook, Netherland Minister of Colonies, said after a conference with President Roosevelt today that he considered "quite logical" the concentration of the United Nations against Germany at present but he was hopeful that a full scale offensive could be undertaken against Japan "the minute we get a chance."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission advanced a proposal today that the revenue from increased fares, rates and charges granted to the railroads last year be set aside for use only to rehabilitate property and to reduce debt.

Incorrect size marking of Army uniforms by manufacturers was criticized yesterday by Major George Christy Jr. of the planning division of the Quartermaster Corps, who declared that the situation was getting worse instead of better.

A new millinery house opened its doors yesterday; in the afternoon to the press and in the evening to a specially invited list of clients. The persons who make up the firm are French. Suzanne Remy had her training in the distinguished firms of Schiaparelli and Agnes in Paris.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 7 -- Germans, counter-attacking fiercely yesterday, succeeded in retaking commanding hills fifteen miles due west of Mateur, Tunisia, that were captured the day before by a crack British infantry brigade and Commando troops.

The heart of Mayor La Guardia's message to the City Council was, of course, financial. If the municipal government could get enough money, the remaining problems could be attended to. Credit, receipts and expenditures are interconnected. A decade ago the city's credit was expressed in terms of 6.50 per cent for the funded debt.

GUADALCANAL, Jan. 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Japanese made the first effective use yesterday of their new Munda airfield on New Georgia Island, sending a fleet of Zeros from there to escort ten destroyers that tried with little success to reinforce and supply the enemy's troops on Guadalcanal.

Almost as fond of alphabetizing as their government, women have formed themselves into another group connected with the war. This time it is the Women's Industrial Production Services or, in the popular mode of the day, the Wips.

DETROIT, Jan. 7 -- The New York Rangers came from behind in the last period to tie the Detroit Red Wings, 2 -- all, in a National Hockey League game tonight before 7,886 spectators at the Olympia. Bryan Hextall's shot squared the count after Jimmy Franks had done a superlative job in the Ranger nets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Senator Barkley of Kentucky won a 34-to-20 vote of confidence tonight from the Senate Democratic caucus after he had threatened to resign his leadership if the conference voted to strip him of power to appoint members of the steering committee.

A one-week shutdown of the city's schools, starting Feb. 1, is under consideration by the Board of Education as a fuel oil conservation measure, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools. If the unscheduled Winter vacation is granted the city's students will have to make up the lost time later -- probably by foregoing their usual Easter leave.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- An agreement aimed at eliminating losses of ship tonnage and manpower in useless litigation has been reached by Great Britain and the United States, the State Department said today.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:
