Sharp but local fighting continued in North Africa yesterday as the campaign of Tunisia ended its second month.

The New York Academy of Medicine properly regards itself not only as a society of physicians but as a social institution. Its offices are needed in these days of storm and stress. Doctors and nurses are leaving in droves for the front. New occupations with new health hazards have appeared with new industrial processes.

In his message to the Seventy-Eighth Congress the President asks for "a sense of proportion" in appraising the momentous happenings of 1942. His own estimate of the relative importance of events leads him to ignore the domestic front almost entirely and concentrate on a review of the war during the first year of American participation.

A sharp curtailment in the number of sabbatical leaves granted teachers in this city has been ordered for the coming semester, Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the Board of Education, announced yesterday. With a few exceptions, leaves will be granted only for restoration of health.

Four Negro youths were held yesterday in $7,500 bail each in Felony Court for a hearing Monday, charged with mugging and robbing Dr. Henry K. Cudmore, 55 years old, of 151 East Ninetieth Street, who was on his way to treat a Negro patient.

Ninety-three Jewish girls and young Jewish women, the pupils and the teacher of a Beth Jacob School of Warsaw, Poland, chose mass suicide to escape being forced into prostitution by German soldiers, according to a letter from the teacher, made public yesterday by Rabbi Leo Jung of the Jewish Center of New York City.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Mortality in the State rose to 11.4 per 1,000 of population in November, making the third successive month increase. The birth rate went up to 20, the highest for that month in twenty-one years.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 7 -- The dues revolt in the ranks of the United Mine Workers of America spread today, closing fifteen collieries in the northern field and involving an estimated 18,000 miners, but there was a note of optimism here tonight after receipt of a request by Secretary Ickes to leaders of the miners and operators to convene the industry's committee of twelve to iron out difficulties and return operations to full production.

Women who desire to take special courses in engineering for work in wartime plants will be welcome at the Cooper Union Engineering School with the inauguration next month of an abbreviated engineering course to prepare students for specific jobs in industry, Dean George F. Bateman announced yesterday.

Three houses have been sold in Brooklyn by the Home Owners Loan Corporation through M.J. Abrams Company, broker. They are the two-family house at 1929 Eighty-fourth Street, to John Agosta with J. Philip Cascio as co-broker; the two-family house at 92 Bay Seventeenth Street, to Paolo Marchica, with Charles De-Palma as co-broker, and the one-family dwelling at 88-08 Twenty-third Avenue, to Mrs. Josephine Steinmetz through Albert Brief, co-broker.
"Saludos Amigos," the Walt Disney musical cartoon feature, will have its local premiere at the Globe Theatre on Feb. 12, it was announced yesterday by RKO and Walt Disney Productions.

Sizeable expansion in wartime uses of all three types of rayon yarns and of rayon staple fiber is slated for 1943, threatening further pinch of civilian textile supplies already feeling the effects of huge diversions to wartime needs of wool and cotton, it was stated yesterday by Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- Troops were reported to be guarding all key points and roads in Rumania today and to be searching trains and other vehicles to check the identity of passengers, following the discovery of a revolutionary plot.

I should like to disagree most strongly with a recent letter in which one of your readers criticized Mr. Wallace's speech for "his advocacy of supervision, or at least inspection, of the school systems of Germany and Japan."

A sampling of the reading tastes of men in the Army conducted by the educational director of the Book-of-the-Month Club and released yesterday by officials of the Victory Book Campaign has revealed, it was announced, not that Army posts particularly lack books, but that the stock of reading matter is insufficiently varied to meet all tastes.

At the close of his forthcoming book, "The Battle of the Solomons" (Houghton Mifflin, Jan. 15), Ira Wolfert, the North American Newspaper Alliance correspondent, allows himself a small quota of prediction mixed with personal feeling.

LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Police said today they had found the handbag of an American woman on a rock in the "Mouth of Hell," a rock crater at Cascais Estoril near Lisbon, last night. They believed the owner fell accidentally into the sea or was washed away by a wave.

Enlisted men from Fort Hancock, N.J., will appear in a tabloid version of Bizet's "Carmen," with Lily Djanel in the title role and Licia Albanese as Micaela, which will be presented as the principal feature of a dinner and entertainment to be sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild, Tuesday night, Jan. 19, at the Waldorf-Astoria, to aid the United Forces Opera Fund.

MOSCOW, Jan. 7 -- The Russians were reported today to be continuing their drive in the Central Caucasus northward from Prokhladnaya and northwest from Nalchik while, farther to the north, the advances that last night had taken them to the Sal River, seventy-five miles from Rostov and along the lower Don, west of Tsimlyansk, were being pressed.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Governor Dewey said today he had ordered inquiries made into the draft board cases involving twenty-eight members of the Moral Re-Armament Movement, formerly known as the Oxford Movement, who have sought occupational deferment on the ground they are engaged in improving the morale of workers in war plants.

Hearty support was voiced by the newspapers over the country for the aims presented by President Roosevelt in his message to Congress. Editorial comment on the address as gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press, included the following:

More than 900 bankers from all parts of this State are expected to attend the mid-Winter meeting of the New York State Bankers Association here on Monday, Jan. 18, it was announced yesterday by John P. Myers of Plattsburg, president of the association. Banking in wartime will be the chief topic of the meeting.

Major league baseball, searching for suitable Spring training grounds north of the Mason-Dixon line that could promise something more than a fine southern exposure, learned yesterday it had barely scratched the surface of places for conditioning its players far from Florida's tropical sun.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner for French Africa, has agreed in principle to a meeting with General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, on French soil, which the leader of the Fighting French proposed in a Christmas Day message, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Inspectors of Price Administration, assisted by State and local law enforcement officers, have gone into action from Maine to Florida to enforce the ban on pleasure driving in the seventeen Atlantic seaboard States, which took effect at noon today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The noon communique:
Golf in 1943 appears to face one of its most trying periods since it became popular.

A detective who took a dying statement from Louis Raines, interior decorator who was shot fatally in the apartment of Miss Virginia Van Wert at 551 West 157th Street a year ago, testified yesterday before a jury in General Sessions that Raines claimed to have shot himself. Miss Van Wert is on trial in a second degree murder charge.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- British Government circles declared unofficially tonight that President Roosevelt's speech to Congress today was one of his best and the British generally cheered the address, which was heard clearly throughout Britain on the radio relay of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 7 -- The Governor of Maryland tonight instructed the Maryland Racing Commission to prepare a bill to allow consolidation of the State's 100 days of racing at Pimlico and Laurel tracks, or at Pimlico alone.

Demonstrations of how to care for pets in an air raid were given yesterday by volunteer animal aides of the Office of Civilian Defense at the seventy-seventh annual meeting of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals at 50 Madison Avenue.

A three-point program for adjusting retail advertising technique to wartime demands is outlined by Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, in the current issue of Journal of Retailing published by New York University School of Retailing.

Secretary Hull's White Book clears the State Department on the Pearl Harbor surprise, the failure to accumulate more adequate stock piles of strategic materials, and the general unreadiness for war in the Far East by making more inexcusable the errors of other departments of the government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The sharp upward movement in primary market prices of agricultural commodities slackened somewhat during the week ended on Jan. 2 and the Bureau of Labor Statistics' all-commodity index of nearly 900 price series remained unchanged at 101.2 per cent of the 1926 average.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that the 1943 national planting goal for American-Egyptian long staple cotton had been set at 160,000 acres, or about 35,000 acres less than in 1942.

Net assets of the Lehman Corporation at the end of December, the half-way mark in that investment trust's fiscal year, were equivalent to $29.54 a share, against $26.92 at the end of September and $25.09 on June 30, according to a report issued yesterday by Robert Lehman, president.

Criticism by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau that "lay-away" plans, whereby the public would start paying now for postwar products, were unfair to soldiers was answered yesterday by Dr. Robert J. McFall, chairman of the committee of the American Marketing Association, which has proposed the "victory merchandise bond" plan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- The Republicans of the House obtained increased representation today on virtually all committees.

The Commonwealth Government of the Philippines has rented the ground floor of the building at 131 West Seventy-second Street through the Apartment Renting Company, Inc. The quarters, which will be used largely for meetings and conferences on government matters, have been elaborately furnished. A special office has been installed for use of President Manuel Quezon when he is in New York.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt's address to Congress was unanimously acclaimed by the British press today for its amazing revelation of America's war production and its pledge of an offensive for victory.

Three American airmen died in line of duty in the take-off crash of a Navy plane in the harbor of San Juan, Puerto Rico, on the last day of the old year. They were Lieutenant Edward Mallory Vogel of Erwin, Tenn.; Issie Goldberg, attached to aviation ordnance, of the Bronx, and Edwin J. Sipowsky, aviation machinist's mate, of Waukegan, Ill.

In a week which has seen some remarkable orchestral performance in this city nothing has fallen upon the ear with such an effect of sheer transporting beauty as the tone of the Boston Symphony Orchestra which Dr. Koussevitzky directed last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Former Governor Charles Poletti, who is entering the War Department as a special assistant to Secretary Stimson, will find his own duties on a "try-out" basis, Mr. Stimson said today.

Calling on the defendant to be a "de luxe salesman for parent-teacher associations," and to build up good-will among teachers and the parents of their students, Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto imposed in Flatbush Court yesterday a suspended sentence of three months in the workhouse on Mrs. Alice Thompson, 28-year-old Negro woman who was accused of assaulting a teacher in an argument over the treatment of a child, and placed her on probation for one year.

Steel production for 1942 reached a high record of 86,092,209 net tons, comparing with a previous high of 82,836,946 net tons in 1941, a gain of 3.92 per cent, according to a preliminary report made yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt's envoy, William Phillips, who is due to arrive at a West Coast port late this afternoon, will find India in the throes of a crisis different from the fiery political furnace into which Colonel Louis Johnson stepped last Spring.

Donald B. Shaw, 22 years old, walked all but fifteen of the 150 miles from Albany to present himself at Grand Central Palace yesterday for induction into the Army as a selectee from this city. His home here is at 765 Eighth Avenue but he was working in Albany when his draft board notified him by mail last week that his number was about to be called.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Bank of England's weekly condition statement today disclosed the first decline in note circulation since the week of Sept. 17, 1942. This item dropped 3,405,000 from the previous week's high record.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress opened no controversies on Capitol Hill today. His critics said they agreed with him. What they termed his generalities were excused, for Congress knew, many members said, that the Com mander in Chief was, in effect, talking over their shoulders to the entire world.

The OPA decree against nonessential motoring wrought a minor miracle yesterday in the streets and highways of New York City. It accomplished what writers of fantasy frequently dream about -- set the clock back some twenty-five to thirty years.
The four-story building at 734-36 Eighth Avenue, near Forty-sixth Street, has been sold by the Bank for Savings to an investor for cash, above a ten-year purchase-money mortgage of $51,000.

That "limited return engagement" of "Claudia," which started May 24, will end tomorrow night at the Forrest. The Rose Franken comedy originally opened Feb. 12, 1941, at the Booth, and ran for 456 performances until last March 7. It then took to the road for an eleven-week tour of Eastern cities.

Preparation of a second annual price index for retailers operating on the "lifo" method of inventory valuation, covering the period from Jan. 31, 1942, to Jan. 31, 1943, is now under way and will be ready about the middle of March, it was revealed yesterday by H.I. Kleinhaus, manager of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The American Women's Hospitals Reserve Corps presented last night two ambulances to the Manhattan unit of the group at ceremonies at the Twelfth Regiment Armory, 56 West Sixty-sixth Street. Both are field ambulances but one of them also may be used as a canteen.

RANDOLPH FIELD, Texas, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- Lieutenant T.W. Berry, mess officer, said today that food rationing, more strict than that practiced by civilians, had been accepted with a grin by thousands of Army airmen in Randolph Field's pilot training school.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 7 -- Governor Stassen of Minnesota presented a definite proposal tonight for a United Nations government to organize the world for peace after the war ends.

Alexander Hoffman, union leader paroled by former Governor Charles Poletti on Dec. 19 after having been convicted of attempted arson against nonunion employers, will not be permitted to resume his union work, the State Board of Parole ruled yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 7 -- Announcement was made today that Governor Charles Edison, acting under his war emergency powers, had lifted the ban on Sunday motion pictures here to provide recreation for more than 1,000 youths in Navy and Army training camps on the Princeton University campus.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Recommendations for the settlement of millions of dollars in intercompany claims, which for years have been the principal obstacle to reorganization of the Midland United and Midland Utilities companies, have been made in a final report by Daniel O. Hastings, special master in the long-disputed case.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The War Department made known today the basic rules governing the selection of enlisted men of the Army who will be assigned to attend special courses at colleges under the Army's specialized training program.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Jimmy Bivins of Cleveland, ranked by the National Boxing Association as logical contender for the light-heavyweight title held by Gus Lesnevich, blasted out a ten-round decision over Ezzard Charles at the Arena tonight.

Floods in the Pittsburgh district last month appear now to have contributed more severely than had been thought to a minor set-back in steel production in December, although only the last two days of the month were included in the high-water period.
American insurance companies paid nearly four billion dollars to the public last year, the Travelers Insurance Companies estimated yesterday.

Augustine J. Smith, member of an old New York family and senior member of the board of governors of the Society of the New York Hospital, shot and killed himself at 9:30 o'clock last night in a private room at the New York Hospital, where he had undergone an operation last Wednesday for an eye ailment. Mr. Smith, who was well known under the honorary title of "Major," was 74 years old.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Industrial shares were the brightest features in a generally cheerful stock market today. In the textile section, Lancanshire Cotton Bleachers, Bradford Dyers and Fine Spinners recorded rises. Rayons also were good under the lead of Courtaulds.

On orders of Mayor La Guardia and Commissioner Valentine the police began yesterday noting the license numbers of passenger automobiles in use on city streets to assist the Office of Price Administration to enforce its ban on pleasure driving.

Herbert Davis, president of Smith College, and Mrs. Davis will be guests of honor tonight at a dinner to be given by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Bingham Jr. before the performance of "Der Rosenkavalier" at the Metropolitan Opera House, which will be a benefit for the Smith College scholarship fund. Mrs. Bingham is chairman of the scholarship committee of the Smith College Club of New York, which is sponsoring the Benefit.

As a housewife I would like to make a few observations. How can anybody save fat from meat when the butchers cut off almost all fat before the meat is delivered? This necessitates using what little fat we may have saved on other meat or using cooking fat or butter -- the last two items being practically unobtainable.

The First National Bank of Boston reported as of Dec. 31, 1942, total deposits of $1,061,369,551 and total assets of $1,168,026,587, compared, respectively, with $962,502,431 and $1,067,595,652 on Sept. 30, 1942. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $351,945,826, against $316,438,096; holdings of United States Government securities to $452,782,398, against $347,248,015, and loans and discounts to $299,469,717, against $331,464,814.

WITH THE ADVANCED ALLIED FORCES, in New Guinea, Jan. 6 (Delayed) -- Captain William Dames, 25 years old, of Oconomowoc, Wis., a company commander whose unit was the spearhead of the American advance into Buna Mission last Saturday, will leave New Guinea soon to start training for service in the Army Air Corps.
The text of President Roosevelt's annual message to Congress as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES was as follows:

All season long the world has yearned hopefully for a big, fast, glittering musical comedy. It has it now, for last evening the fabulous Mike Todd brought in "Something for the Boys," and as it danced its way across the stage of the Alvin is quite clearly was not only something pretty wonderful for the boys, but something for the girls as well.

The volume of bank clearings for the holiday week ended on Wednesday rose 22.3 per cent from the similar short week of the previous year almost reaching the 1942 record figure established in the full week of Oct. 21.

TRENTON, Jan. 7 -- Death from an infection resulting from an insect bite is death by accident within the meaning of the New Jersey Workmen's Compensation Law, the State Supreme Court declared today in upholding a compensation award of $11,000 to the widow and infant son of Anthony J. Cirelli, North Wildwood lifeguard, whose life was taken by an infection several weeks after he had been bitten by a greenheaded fly while on duty.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Jan. 8 -- Allied war planes have sunk two large Japanese transports, at least one of which was heavily laden with troops, in a furious air-sea battle still in progress off the Northeastern New Guinea coast, while the ground campaign to the southeast is in its final phase, with a Japanese army of about 15,000 men annihilated, the Allied command announced today.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Efforts are being renewed and redoubled, it was learned today, to work out a unified Allied plan for administration of post-war relief in Europe.

Forty-two young women began the second step of their transformation from civilian workers to war workers when they arrived yesterday at the Freeport State Aviation School, Freeport, L.I. There they will start a month's training that will eventually lead to positions as engineering assistants at the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation at Bethpage, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- An authoritative person said to this correspondent today that, in planning and executing his Tunisian campaign, Lieut. Gen. Eisenhower "has been plagued as much by well-intentioned persons in the United States and Great Britain, with political minds, as by the tangle of North African politics itself."
LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Soviet Monitor tonight recorded the following Soviet communique broadcast by the Moscow radio:

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- Lana Turner, who said last month that she was expecting a child in June, filed suit today to annul her marriage to Stephen Crane, 27, tobacco heir, on the grounds that his divorce from a former wife was not final when she was married to Mr. Crane.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- While individual exhibitors and buyers waxed enthusiastic over the Winter home furnishings and furniture show now taking place at the American Furniture Mart here, the board of governors of the mart has decided to make a study of requirements of retailers and manufacturers before proceeding with previously announced plans for a Summer market, scheduled for June 21-30.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- The Red Army already has knocked out half of the 1,000,000 Axis troops in South Russia and by Spring probably will have won back all territory lost to the Nazis in 1942, military observers said today as the German radio for the first time acknowledged a retreat in the Caucasus.

The Berlin radio "flashed" the announcement last night that German troops in the Eastern Caucasus had withdrawn their advance strongholds and that the Russians had made massed tank attacks on German rearguards. This followed a period of reticence during which the Caucasus had been scarcely mentioned in German bulletins.

Pointing out that some women might become victims of a recent decision of the United States Supreme Court that Nevada divorces must be recognized by other states, Justice John E. McGeehan in Bronx Supreme Court stopped yesterday a divorce action brought by a husband in Panama against his wife who lives in the Bronx.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Government sources asserted today that air reconnaissance had disclosed a concentration of Japanese shipping at Rabaul, New Britain, even greater than that marshaled by the enemy for his first counter-attack against the American forces holding the Eastern Solomon Islands.

In his letter to THE TIMES of Jan. 5 Richard Welling, chairman National Self-Government Committee, suggests that self-government of students could be a possible cure for the unfortunate condition in the schools and points out Dr. John Dewey's creed of "learning by doing."

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 8 -- Russia announced early today that the Red Army converging on Rostov to trap the Nazis in the Caucasus was less than seventy-five miles from that bottleneck point after having captured more than a dozen villages yesterday, and for the first time the Germans acknowledged formally that their southern forces were withdrawing before the massed might of Soviet tanks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- An official of the American Association of Railroads told a Senate committee today that tank-car oil shipments into the Eastern States had dropped from 856,000 barrels a day in mid-September to 700,000 barrels daily during the last week of 1942, with little hope of resuming peak deliveries until Spring.

Dr. Peter Amoroso, Commissioner of Correction, recently appointed by May La Guardia as chairman of the municipal employes division of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis Annual Drive in Celebration of the President's Birthday, opened the city employes' drive for funds at a luncheon yesterday in Schwartz's Restaurant, 183 Broadway.

Dr. Arthur Freeborn Chace, President of the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital, who assumed office last night as President of the New York Academy of Medicine, said in his inaugural address that medicine is "on the threshhold of solving many riddles, among which it seems safe to place that great enemy, cancer."

The finest snow conditions in several years for this time of Winter are reported from the "North Country," where limited traveling facilities will give those able to get away for a "furlough in the snows" a grand opportunity to enjoy trail and slope running without meeting the interference that huge week-end throngs provided before the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Nineteenth Bombardment Group, Army Air Corps, has received its fourth citation as a unit, the War Department disclosed today in announcing the award of individual decorations to 20 officers and 28 enlisted men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt's discussion of the peace today in his message to the Seventy-eighth Congress has inspired Representative Jessie Sumner of Illinois to hasten her introduction of a resolution for Congressional investigation of acceptable peace terms.

In making out Federal income tax returns, credit may be taken for each person other than husband or wife, whether related to the taxpayer or not, and whether living with him or not, who during the taxable year was dependent on and received his chief support from the taxpayer provided the dependent was either under 18 years of age or incapable of self-support because mentally or physically defective.

William B. Craig, president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, yesterday announced the appointment of special committees for both coffee and sugar to consult with Washington officials in an effort to seek some solution to the problems confronting the Exchange under wartime restrictions.

The domestic mine production of zinc last year was not very far off from past performances, according to Ernest V. Gent, secretary of the American Zinc Institute, Inc., in a review of that industry for 1942. With imports, which are growing in importance, he said that ore supplies were sufficient to keep smelters and refineries operating at maximum capacity.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Here are highlights by main topics from President Roosevelt's message to the joint session of Congress!

A PHILOSOPHY professor, trying to expose the fallacy of the Descartes school of reasoning, once described the Frenchman as "putting Descartes before the horse." The students laughed politely but refused to roll off their seats into the aisles at this most erudite witticism.

Encouraged by the fact that the Presidential address to Congress did not suggest additional price curbs, and because it did not express administration sentiment on the higher parity prices advocated by the farm bloc, the cotton futures market regained yesterday the ground lost in the two previous sessions and pushed to new highs for the current movement.

A PORT SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Jan. 7 -- The British submarine Thrasher has returned to a British port after having operated for eighteen months against Axis shipping trying to run supplies to General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Africa Corps.

Great physicians and surgeons stand apart from the rest of their profession not only because of their exceptional ability but also because of a distinctive quality of mind. They ask questions. Why does one patient die and another live after undergoing identical surgical experiences?

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Maintaining that the ruling princes of India are an indispensable element of that country's life, Leopold L.S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, declared today that they were bound to play a large part in any modification the constitution of India might undergo.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 7 -- Mrs. Frances Stevens Hall, a central figure in the Hall-Mills murder case of 1926, bequeathed $10,000 to her late brother, William C. (Willie) Stevens, and small gifts to relatives of her slain husband the Rev. Dr. Edward Wheeler Hall, it was disclosed today when the will was probated here.

Expressing entire willingness to comply with the Federal regulation cutting fuel oil for heat 25 per cent, religious and business organizations reported yesterday that in notable cases they had already converted or were converting from oil to coal burners or that they were served by the New York Steam Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson officially voiced today the belief that the Germans were being definitely beaten in the Caucasus. It was the first time the statement had been made in high-ranking quarters here. Speaking at a press conference, he said:

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Jan. 5 (Delayed) (AP) -Veteran Flying Fortress crews teamed up with a less experienced Liberator squadron today for a smashing low-level, daylight bombing attack on Japanese shipping at the vital Rabaul harbor.

Many department stores, in their attempt to offset the shrinkage of men's clothing sales, have been endeavoring to establish work clothing departments, but with little success because of the shortage of such garments. Too, manufacturers and wholesalers are allocating their stocks to regular customers and are giving little merchandise to those stores which they had been trying unsuccessfully to sell for years.

Threescore more contributors, some of whom had faced privations themselves, including a family whose possessions were wiped out by Japanese aggression, joined yesterday the long list of those who have given to the Neediest Cases Fund to help the deserving unfortunates.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- A new attitude on the part of doctors and the general public to the necessity for the prevention of illness was necessary for the future, Ernest Brown, Minister of Health, said in opening a Fitness Exhibition in Charing Cross subway station today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- The 24-year-old four-stack destroyer Blakeley, fitted with the entire bow of a sistership after being one-fifth demolished by an enemy torpedo last May, is roaming the high seas again with firepower and cruising radius "greater than ever," the Navy disclosed today.

As the appointment of Robert A. Hanson as chairman of the State food industry committee and John Conoboy as chairman of the food industry committee for the metropolitan area was announced yesterday, the regional headquarters of the Food Distribution Administration at 150 Broadway said it was hoped to have the committees completely formed over the weekend and operating early next week.

Today's events: "Der Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Jascha Heifetz, violin, benefit for Vassar Club Scholarship Fund, Metropolitan Opera House, 2:30; Isaac Stern, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Frank Bishop, piano, George Washington Hall, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 8:30; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30; Artamon Moskalensky, violinist-composer, Menora Temple, Fourteenth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, Brooklyn, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The list of awards includes the following to men in Eastern States:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- American air forces in the Solomons scored a possible hit on a Japanese transport in that region yesterday as they continued to hammer the advance bases from which the enemy might launch a renewed assault on Guadalcanal, a Navy communique reported today.

Increased interest in back-yard poultry flocks, possibly as a means to supplement our food supplies, has been noted at the New York Poultry Show, being held at the Hotel Capitol, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- In order to clear up questions it feels may be raised in connection with its regulation, Limitation Order L-240, which governs the tonnage of print paper newspapers may consume during this year, the Printing and Publishing Division of the War Production Board released today a series of questions and answers in connection with the order.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Fighting French announced tonight that Brig. Gen. Jacques Leclerc's forces in the south of Libya had stormed and captured Um el Araneb, main Axis outpost in the Fezzan area.

Because of the falling-off in demand that usually follows a holiday season, flower shops and stalls are overflowing with corsage blooms, according to the weekly report of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets yesterday.

Extension of the method of establishing food price ceilings through the system of fixed marginal mark-ups on retail sales of butter, fresh citrus fruits, bananas, cheese and poultry was generally welcomed yesterday by operators of chain and independent grocery outlets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- The prospective induction of Alan Ladd into the Army on Jan. 18 caused a revision of Paramount's production schedule today, according to a studio announcement. "Incendiary Blonde," a screen biography of Texas Guinan in which Ladd was to have starred with Betty Hutton, has been shelved, and Miss Hutton has been assigned to the feminine lead in the film version of "Let's Face It," with Bob Hope.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Paul J. Kern, former protege of Mayor La Guardia, lost today his court action for reinstatement as president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission of New York City, from which post the Mayor ousted him last February.

Wage increases of 20 per cent and reduction of the work week from forty-six to forty hours were requested yesterday by Local 32B of the Building Service Employes Union at a conference in the Hotel Commodore between representatives of the union and the Midtown and Penn Zone Realty Associations, covering 200 loft buildings in the fur and garment center.
Many of the letters you have printed lately concerned France. None, however, dealt with the thoughts or opinions of the exiled youth of France in this city.

While the leaders of the pro-Nazi movement in this country were willing to adjust the name of their organization and the tone of their uniforms to please the American public, if possible, they were uncompromising where the value of "German blood" was concerned, according to the testimony of an "old fighter" of the Nazi party in Federal court yesterday.

General Henri Honore Giraud disclosed yesterday that the Germans -- from whom he escaped -- regarded him as "Enemy No. 1." and had shot one of his young relatives in France because a German noncommissioned officer had been attacked in a theatre, the Dakar radio declared in a broadcast recorded in New York by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The national debt will reach a peak of $250,000,000,000 by July 1, 1945, it was estimated yesterday by W.L. Hemingway, president of the American Bankers Association, in an address to the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- Samuel Nuzzo, ousted business agent of Local 17 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America, A.F. of L., was convicted by a Supreme Court jury tonight on all but one of thirty-three counts of theft and forgery in connection with the embezzlement of more than $9,000 from the local's treasury.

From a Washington dispatch in this newspaper it appears that out of the many millions called by the Selective Service Act only 6,277 are conscientious objectors. Five-sixths of these are in civilian public service camps and the rest have been ordered to join them.

Chester Rico, Bronx lightweight, and Bob Montgomery of Philadelphia will clash in the star bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The contest, first of the tournament sanctioned by the New York State Athletic Commission to provide a challenger for the world 135-pound crown, is scheduled for fifteen rounds.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook filed yesterday a notice of his intention to resign on Feb. 13 from the State Supreme Court, after twenty-three years' service, to accept a commission as colonel in the Judge Advocate General's Department of the Army.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- A full and accurate disclosure of reserves established by corporations to take care of post-war readjustments must be made to the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was warned today in an opinion prepared by William W. Werntz, chief accountant of the commission.

Our present income tax system has always been unsound in its requirement that the taxpayer must pay a tax on last year's income out of this year's receipts. There are special reasons, however, why we should change over to a pay-as-you-go system before this March 15.

Furs, with an increase of 83 per cent over last year, led in the November sales gains of department stores in this Federal Reserve District, it was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Umbrellas with 54 per cent and luggage with 52 per cent followed in percentage of sales gains.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City and throughout the country regained excess reserves in the week ended on Wednesday after sharp declines in the preceding three weeks, according to figures released yesterday.

The German radio, in its first comment on President Roosevelt's annual message to Congress, as recorded by The United Press in New York, said last night that the President disclosed that the American war effort had already run into dififculties.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 7 -- Public opinion about several matters of importance in China recently was sampled by the newspaper Ta Kung Pao, in Hengyang, Hunan Province. In the first month 11,262 replies were received, chiefly from students, civil servants, merchants and the military, half below the age of 20 and 26 per cent between the ages of 20 and 30.

Wagner's "Tannhaeuser" received its second presentation of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, with George Szell again at the conductor's desk. Because of the indisposition of Rene Maison, who was scheduled to assume the title role for the first time here, the name part was entrusted to Arthur Carron.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., announced yesterday that it would call for redemption on April 1 one-half of its outstanding $12,135,167 of first preferred stock. Determination of the stock to be redeemed will be made by lot on Jan. 22.
OPA inspectors checking violations of the decree against nonessential driving last night found some explanations extraordinarily feeble, some quite canny.

A group of 116 associations, corporations and individuals controlling 90 per cent of the linen supply business in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut was named yesterday in five Federal indictments alleging conspiracy to fix prices, allocate customers and obtain a monopoly in the industry.
The table shows the highest and lowest points reached in 1942 and a series of past years. All figures in thousands of dollars.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Department store sales for the week ended Jan. 2 were 5 per cent up from the corresponding period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 10 per cent in the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Atlantic Charter and the explanations of that document made by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill constitute the declarations of purpose of Christian people for a post-war settlement and have been widely accepted as such, men and women lay leaders of the Catholic Church asserted today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The prospects of earnings of the proposed unified Chicago traffic system were shown today at a hearing before the Illinois Commerce Commission to have deteriorated since October. The commission's examiners then received an expert's estimate that the earnings of the elevated and surface lines in a combined company would be about $14,000,000 a year, of which $2,000,000 would be required for Federal taxes.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The lull in the pursuit of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Axis forces across Libya is persisting, today's communique of British headquarters here said, with nothing except patrol activity to report from the ground forces and only a slight increase in air activity over the battle area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- For forty-seven minutes today, political animosities were put aside as the law-makers of the United States, joined by Cabinet members and high-ranking diplomats from the country's allies, gathered on the floor of the House to listen with grave attention to the President's report on the state of the Union.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- A note of issue was filed in Supreme Court here today in a divorce suit brought by William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey of Scarsdale, former world's champion heavyweight pugilist, against Mrs. Hannah Williams Dempsey, whom he married ten years ago.

Edward J. Frost, president and a director of William Filene's Sons Company of Boston, has been elected a director of Abraham Straus, Inc., it was announced yesterday. He succeeds the late Louis E. Kirstein.
Frederick S. Wynn, former vice president of the Southern Railway, has leased an apartment in 3 East Seventy-seventh Street through Culver, Hollyday Co., Douglas L. Elliman Co., agents.
Aluminium, Ltd., and its fully owned subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $11,907,399 in Canadian currency for the nine months ended last Sept. 30.

Sir William Beveridge says that Britain's failure to abolish want before the present war constitutes a scandal. The abolition of want "was so easily within the economic resources of the community." But we must not jump to conclusions at the mention of scandal.
Major C. Brewster Rhoads, U.S. M.C., and Mrs. Rhoads of Chilton, Huntingdon Valley, Pa., are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

It is a pleasure to note that spinach dropped 4 cents in price in the last week and Iceberg lettuce dropped 2. Broccoli, cauliflower anl lima beans also are less expensive, although they are still not in the bargain class. Listed below are some of the average prices for vegetables as quoted by the Consumers' Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets:

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 7 -- Guadalcanal's striking power as an air base is being widened, says the New Zealand Government's official war correspondent in a dispatch from the Solomons printed here today. While the Japanese ground forces are being softened up and pushed further from Henderson Field, he states, our Solomons air powers are being stepped up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Published reports that Republican Congressmen planned to investigate a reported gift of $500,000 worth of emerald jewelry to Mrs. Harry Hopkins from Lord Beaverbrook, British lend-lease official, drew a denial from Mrs. Hopkins today that she had received such a gift.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- To facilitate the rationing of canned foods to consumers, the War Production Board today modified its regulations to permit wholesalers and jobbers to increase their inventories of canned fruits, vegetables and juices to an estimated three-month supply.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Owners and handlers of 1,200 thoroughbreds shipped here for the Tropical and Hialeah Park meetings today found they were stuck in horse race-less Miami for a long period and tightened their belts against a lean Winter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A postwar planning commission of thirty-two members to make recommendations regarding the peace aims of this country and the position of the country in international affairs and domestic policies after the war was proposed in a bill introduced in the House by Representative Mundt of South Dakota, a Republican member of the Foreign Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., called upon the legislative agents of the organization today to work for enactment of a sound and adequate tax bill and declared "any form of sales tax, however labeled, must be avoided as a direct threat to workers' health and efficiency and consequently to war production."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Secretary Jones asserted today that testimony given Tuesday before a Senate Agriculture subcommittee concerning a $550,000 loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Gulf Distilling Corporation of Gretna, La., contained misrepresentations.

On Sept. 30 of last year Hitler told the German people of his new and "very simple program" to win the war. "We must let the others attack as much as they wish wherever we have no intention to advance"; but, "under all circumstances we must hold whatever must be held."
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 8 -- Italian press comment on President Roosevelt's message to Congress said that his polemics had no substance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Authority to allocate existing supplies of rubber to meet military as well as civilian requirements was conferred upon William M. Jeffers, rubber director, today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.
Specially chartered commuters' club cars, an Eastern institution fifty years old, are slowly fading from the current scheme of things under war's pressure, a survey disclosed yesterday.

A look at the main streets of this city yesterday was enough to prove that a lot of persons have been indulging in what is now the sin of pleasure driving. Having read OPA's definition of pleasure, they left their cars at home. Reports from other cities and from suburban and country communities tell of the same thing happening there.

German troops engaged in "heavy but successful defensive fighting" against the Russians Thursday in the Caucasus, on the Don and northwest of Stalingrad, the Nazi High Command reported yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

WITH UNITED STATES TROOPS at Buna Station, Jan. 5 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- Mayor La Guardia's former aerial chauffeur. Captain Jerry Crossen of Staten Island, missed death by inches when his disabled B-26 bomber made a belly landing on a crude jungle airstrip after having been hit by a 3-inch anti-aircraft shell.

Efrem Kurtz, who has conducted the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, Lewisohn Stadium concerts and orchestras in various parts of the country, has been engaged to direct the New York Philharmonic-Symphony for two weeks in March. He will appear at the head of the ensemble in seven concerts, the first on March 10 and the last on March 21.

BOSTON, Jan. 8 -- Six hundred executives and salesmen who attended today's opening meeting of the New England wartime sales management conference, sponsored by the Boston Chamber of Commerce, were told that in the postwar world reduction of "the spread between manufacturing costs and final cost to the consumer is socially good" and can be accomplished, and that a better technique of selling will be necessary in the coming peacetime economy.

As a regular reader of the letters appearing on your pages each Saturday and as a sports fan who thinks skiing appeals to a comparatively small minority of sports devotees, please permit me to say a few words concerning the remarks made by "R.P." last week.

In celebration of the birthday of Queen Marie of Yugoslavia, the United Yugoslav Relief Fund will open today a benefit exhibition of the paintings of Milena Pavlovitch Barilli at the national headquarters of the fund, 11 West Fifty-seventh Street.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Rutgers University announced today the election of twenty-six seniors to Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary scholastic society.

Chester Rico's lightweight championship ambitions were shattered last night in the Bronx lad's first appearance in a main bout. He lost on a technical knockout before the punishing blows of Bob Montgomery, Philadelphia Negro, in the seventh round of what was to have been a fifteen-round battle before a gathering of 10,416 at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Ten War Production Board units or parts of units concerned with food-stuffs will be transferred to the Department of Agriculture on Monday, the Bureau of the Budget said tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- An Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Japanese method of fighting to the end from treetops, dugouts and fox holes in swamp and jungle slows Allied tabulations of their casualties.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Newsprint deliveries by Canadian mills are restricted to 90 per cent of their average deliveries between Oct. 1, 1941, and March 31, 1942, under an order issued by the Newsprint Administrator, R.L. Weldon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt endorsed today the principle of putting Federal taxation on a pay-as-you-go basis.

Arthur Daley's recent column concerning the rigors of Northern training for the big league clubs prompts me to write, for baseball enthusiasts will await with eagerness the start of the coming season to observe the condition of their favorite teams.

" Der Rosenkavalier" is Richard Strauss's warmest and most ingratiating opera. Though it has a bite, it also glows with tenderness and compassion. It makes an attractive evening in the theatre, as the Metropolitan Opera proved once again last night when "Der Rosenkavalier" was presented for the first time this season.

Miss Virginia Van Wert, 33 years old, took the witness stand in General Sessions yesterday in her second-degree murder trial before Judge Jonah J. Goldstein and an all-male jury in the shooting of Louis Raines, an interior decorator, in her apartment at 551 West 157th Street in the early morning of last Jan. 10.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Oliver French, president of the Red Wings of the International League, announced today signing of John (Pepper) Martin as manager for the 1943 season.

Retail trade here was quite active during the week, but because of comparison of sales figures with the extremely heavy volume of the corresponding week last year a decline in dollar sales was shown. The drop was estimated at about 10 per cent for department stores.

A Pan American transatlantic clipper, carrying nineteen European voyagers, arrived at the Marine Base at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon, completing 1,000,000 miles of transatlantic aerial service since it was put into operation in 1V/ay, 1939, when the service was opened.

CAIRO, Egypt. Jan. 8 -- Brig. Gen. Elmer E. Adler, United States Air Service commander in the Middle East, has just returned here from a mission to Russia and will leave soon for Washington to report and to accept a new assignment.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 8 -- Ridgewood High School joined today the ranks of New Jersey secondary schools that have adopted the government-approved Victory Corps program when 245 boys and girls, representing nearly one-third of the student body, were enrolled in the corps at ceremonies in the auditorium.
LONDON, Jan. 8 (Reuters) -- The number of business failures in Britain during 1942 was the lowest ever recorded, less than 25 per cent of 1940 and about 10 per cent of the pre-war average.

A General Sessions jury last night convicted Patrolman Morgan Wilson, 44 years old, a World War veteran, on a first-degree man slaughter charge in the shooting of Patrolman William Rooney, 35, at Amsterdam Avenue and 140th Street when they were on their first tour of patrol duty in a police car on the night of last June 20.

When I learned from my brother, who is in a typical Army camp, that his training schedule was so strenuous that he had neither the time nor the energy to read the newspapers or listen to the news broadcasts, it occurred to me to enclose THE NEW YORK TIMES "War News Summarized" column in every letter I wrote him.

W. Bruce Cobb, Acting Presiding Justice of the Domestic Relations Court, made public yesterday figures taken from court records which showed an increase in the city of 10.8 per cent in the number of cases of child delinquency and 11.6 per cent increase in the number of neglected children for 1942 over 1941.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- The War Production Board is seeking in conferences with leaders of the armed services to put a temporary $80,000,000,000 ceiling over the 1943 munitions program, it was said today.

Investment bankers again have their eye on developments in the city of Cleveland, Ohio, with respect to the acquisition of the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, a subsidiary of the North American Company, by the city with a view to municipal ownership.

The story of Heinz Spanknoebel's attempt to take over a New York newspaper for the Nazis and of what the newspaper's publisher told Spanknoebel was related from the witness stand in Federal court yesterday by Victor Ridder. Mr. Ridder, proprietor of the New Yorker Staats-Zeitung und Herold, was the publisher on whom Spanknoebel called, during that brief period in 1933 before he fled the United States, with Federal agents close on his heels.

Reporting on operations for the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, 1942, the International Shoe Company's annual statement, issued yesterday, informed stockholders that shipments were the greatest on record both in numbers of pairs of shoes and in dollars, and that despite forced curtailment in the closing months of the year, total annual production exceeded all previous years except 1941.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The "Big Four" of farm organizations, after a week of joint conferences here, united tonight in demands for changed administration of existing statutes and for new laws on agriculture and labor. They warned of acute food and fiber shortages unless price ceilings are raised and manpower conditions are improved.

Frederick Vaughn Jr., 20 years old, a naval radio technician on temporary sentry duty at the entrance to Pier 6, at the naval base at Tompkinsville, S.I., was fatally shot early yesterday morning by a sailor believed to have been intoxicated who insisted on trying to pass through the sentry gate from the pier to the street.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt's speech was prominently displayed here by the press, which called it "sensational." His statement that the Axis had lost the war because it failed to win it in 1942 deeply impressed thinking Mexicans.

Nine gasoline ration books have been seized here, forty-three others in the vicinity of Binghamton and an unspecified additional number at Rochester, N.Y., for alleged violation of the ban on pleasure driving, the Office of Price Administration disclosed yesterday in making it plain that its latest measure to conserve dwindling gasoline stocks on the Eastern seaboard would be rigidly enforced.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia., Saturday, Jan. 9 -- Another transport and twenty Zeros have been destroyed in attacks on the New Guinea- bound Japanese convoy but some troops may have reached Lae, General Douglas MacArthur announced today.

The Board of Education has announced a sharp curtailment in the number of sabbatical leaves for teachers to be granted during the coming semester, but has taken issue with the suggestion of Mayor La Guardia that teachers now on leave be recalled. Mr. La Guardia called attention to the anomalous situation which exists at present.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- After hearing testimony today before the Joint Congressional Economy Committee that the National Youth Administration has more machine training units than it has pupils in some States, Senator Byrd said that the agency seemed an expensive way to train mechanics, while Senator McKellar added that it was "a fifth wheel on a wagon."

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- The State Parole Board stated today that it would appeal immediately a decision by Justice Pierce H. Russell of the Supreme Court, made today at Troy that the action of the Parole Board in refusing to release a prisoner who had completed his minimum sentence was reviewable by the courts.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 8 -- Allied fighter planes discovered yesterday large numbers of Axis vehicles moving westward along the Tripolitanian coastal road forty miles east of Tripoli, providing almost certain proof that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel was pulling at least part of his German Africa Corps transport out of position 180 miles southeast of Tripoli at Wadi Zemzem.
The Fordham University Glee Club, under the direction of Dr. Frederick Joslyn, presented its twenty-third annual concert last night before a large audience in Town Hall.

A five-year program of research and teaching in tropical medicine, supported by a gift of $150,000 from the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation, will be launched soon at the Columbia - Presbyterian Medical Center, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, announced yesterday .

Gremlins, those funny little men who play pranks on airmen, deserted the ether yesterday and attacked the Third Avenue Elevated. Thousands of Bronx and East Side workers were stranded for more than an hour as the devilish fellows helped a switchman err and send a southbound elevated train down into the subway just above the Jackson Avenue station.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- Broadening of the front against Rostov by the capture of positions along the Sal River south of the Don and a series of localities only twenty miles from the Northern Donets west of the great Don bend, continuation of the drive toward the Spa region of the Central Caucasus and defeat of a determined German attempt to recapture Velikiye Luki -- such is the general outline of today's Russian news.

Including issues of notes of nineteen local housing authorities aggregating $78,492,000, new municipal financing next week will amount to $83,807,274. This figure compares with this week's total of $5,944,000, according to Daily Bond Buyer.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
LYNCHBURG, Va., Jan. 8 -- On the glass-enclosed sunporch of his suburban mountain estate, Carter Glass took the oath of office today for a new term as senior Senator from Virginia.

At his press conference yesterday the President issued a warning against black markets. It is true, as he says, that we have not many of them yet; but it is necessary to face the fact that the black market is an almost inevitable result wherever public demand and means of payment exceed available supplies at the legal maximum prices.

When are the banks, utility companies, department stores and other organizations serving the public going to realize that they cannot continue to observe "business as usual" by sticking to their old 9-to-5 hours? All the members of many households work six and some times seven days a week, and they find it impossible to pay their bills, go to their banks, shop and perform other necessary duties during the hours formerly devoted to peacetime activities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department announced today that Secretary Wickard had issued an order providing for the allocation of the short crop of 1942- grown burley tobacco among dealers and manufacturers. The order became effective yesterday.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 8 -- The War Department opened a peace offensive here today in the hope of ending the dues revolt in the ranks of the United Mine Workers of America and reopening fifteen collieries.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8 -- In March, 1942, the component parts of racing met to devise the best means whereby racing might become a part of the pattern of the war effort. The result was twofold: formation of the Turf Committee of America, headed by Herbert Bayard Swope; organization of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations of the United States, first group of its kind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The standard types of American warplanes which are performing with outstanding success in every section of the world and every type of climate maintain their records largely because of special features for special assignments added to them by "modification centers," the Office of War Information said today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 8 -- A full division of the Reich's new ruthless police troops has arrived in Zagreb and two additional German divisions, including light tanks and armored cars, have by-passed the Croatian capital on the way to the interior under orders from Heinrich Himmler, Gestapo chief, to stamp out terror and anarchy in Croatia.

Edward J. Flynn announced late yesterday afternoon that President Roosevelt had appointed him his Ambassador and personal representative and on Monday would send to the Senate his appointment as Minister Plenipotentiary to Australia.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 8 -- Lieutenant W. J. Hoelle of San Mateo, Calif., has joined the growing company of fighting men who are living on borrowed time as a result of knife-edge escapes in the Tunisian fighting, it was disclosed today.

A NORTHERN BRITISH NAVAL BASE, Jan. 7 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The British naval force that slashed out of the Arctic darkness to aid a Russian-bound convoy under attack from German warships caught one Nazi ship squarely with its first salvo and stampeded the remainder, it was revealed today.

J. Edward Saltzman, 54 years old, owner-manager of the Hotel Diplomat, in West Forty-third Street, agreed in the Municipal Term Court yesterday to pay a $150 fine, rather than go to the workhouse for thirty days, on his guilty plea to imperilling the lives of hundreds of celebrants in the hotel on New Year's Eve by twice blocking the main fire-escape stairway.

Now come couturier uniforms for bus conductorettes. At Bridgeport, where seven women are already in service at the wheels of vehicles owned and operated by the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company, the trim, tailored outfits designed by Helen Cookman of New York are definite lures, executives report, for additional dozens, needed promptly to replace men.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- A committee of union and management representatives urged 15,000 striking miners in Pennsylvania's hard coal fields today to return to their jobs immediately "in order that the nation may receive the maximum quantity of anthracite to which it is entitled during the existing emergency."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 8 -- In a widespread aerial offensive yesterday American bombers continued to blast German bases and barracks in the southern area of Tunisia where the enemy is striving to hold roads southeast to General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Axis Army in Libya.

Faced with the most difficult problems since its inception, the United States Golf Association will hold its annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria at 11 A.M. today. At that time, George W. Blossom Jr. of Chicago who led the organization successfully through the past year, will be re-elected as will all last year's officers with the single exception of the treasurer.

Eight proposals calling for an improvement in the Navy York City public school system were recommended yesterday by Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, in a report to the Board of Education's finance committee, now preparing the annual budget estimate.

May I speak for the American taxpayer and his right to know where he stands regarding the present and future? Congress and the Administration are dealing frantically at present with the crisis of farm and industrial labor because no one in either group was able to foresee what was inevitable.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP) -- It developed today that Warren Wright's Whirlaway, champion money-winning thoroughbred of all time, won't have to join the cavalry at Fort Riley after all.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Representative Jessie Sumner of Illinois introduced in the House today a resolution to appoint a special committee of fifteen members of Congress to investigate peace terms. The resolution was referred to the Rules Committee.
With the March and May contracts drawing almost exclusive attention, the cotton futures market yesterday moved erratically and ended a listless session 3 to 7 points under the previous close.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman will celebrate an annual mass for 400 members of the professional, clerical and volunteer staffs of the bureau of charities of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and affiliated agencies at 9 A.M. Tuesday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Doubt that any of twelve men trapped by an underground fire in the No. 15 mine of the Pursglove Mining Company were alive was expressed tonight by Harry McNary, senior engineer of the United States Bureau of Mines' Mineral Resources Division.
Some of the many questions put to OPA officials at district headquarters yesterday as to specific uses of cars and their answers follow:
Music for the armed forces at home and abroad will be discussed at a symposium in Town Hall Tuesday morning.

Within six hours after she had been designated as an air warden to patrol near her home at 52 West Fifty-third Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, Mrs. John Hampshire, 28-year-old USO worker, was slugged unconscious and robbed of her purse while familiarizing herself with her post, the police made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Results of the attempt to form special battalions of the United States Army recruited from foreigners have increased the disapproval of the scheme which has existed from the beginning in the War Department and some other official circles.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 9 -- Russian troops smashing along the lower Don River and rolling up the vulnerable Nazi salient deep in the Caucasus captured more than a score of villages and railway points yesterday, including Zimovniki, 167 miles by rail southwest of Stalingrad, two Soviet communiques announced early today.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt extended the sympathy of the nation for the loss in battle of their three sons to Mr. and Mrs. J.E. Rogers of Birmingham.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- It was like Babe Ruth wondering if he needed to slide for first -- that question, raised today, whether baseball players would be released from war plants when the infield grass turns green again.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- The State Nursing Council for War Service took steps today to increase the number of students in nursing schools in the State and to provide adequate staffs of nurses for community needs.

Undoubtedly you have heard by this time that the government has set up certain rules and regulations concerning bakers' bread, effective Jan. 18. One of the most important among them, from the consumers' point of view, is the stipulation that all white bread be enriched.

The War Committee of the Bar of the City of New York, of which Charles E. Hughes Jr. is chairman, has sent a letter to 20,000 lawyers in this city appealing for contributions to support its activities. It has spent more than $3,000 since its organization early last year, and estimates that its budget for this year will require about $9,000.
LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Soviet monitor recorded the following Soviet Information Bureau communique broadcast today by the Moscow radio:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Because meat and poultry production appears to be increasing more sharply than expected, Secretary of Agriculture Wickard announced today a revision in the 1943 farm program calling for larger acreages of corn and barley for feed.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The noon communique:

While men are still unemployed in New York City, there is intensified recruiting of women workers in Northern New Jersey because of labor shortages there, it was pointed out in the thirteenth annual report of the Regional Plan Association, made public yesterday.

If ever an inventor satisfied the romantic requirements of a Jules Verne novel it was Nikola Tesla. Communicating with Mars, plucking heat units out of the atmosphere to run engines, using the whole earth as an electrical resonator so that a man in China could communicate wirelessly with another in South America, transmitting power through space -- it was to such possibilities that he devoted the last forty years of his long life.

Like the Army, the Red Cross believes that "a worried soldier is not a good soldier." Delegated to act as the medium of communication between men in the armed forces and their families, the Red Cross has discovered that the men in service are as much concerned about what is going on at home as the home folk are about their absent ones.

Horse shows will be continued during 1943 in so far as war conditions will permit. This was indicated yesterday at the annual meeting of the delegates to the National Horse Shows Association and at the luncheon which followed at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 8 -- Samuel Goldwyn has revived the title, "Treasure Chest," and today engaged Don Hartman to write a pirate comedy for Bob Hope under the label. The producer originally used the title for a projected Hope vehicle which was abandoned after nine writers had worked on it at various times in 1941.

Net earnings of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1942 amounted to $4,568,000, compared with $3,302,000 in the previous year, Allan Sproul, president of the bank, reported yesterday in the bank's twenty-eighth annual statement to member-bank stockholders of profit and loss.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Admiral Harold R. Stark, former Chief of Naval Operations and now Commander of United States Naval Forces in Europe, said here today that he feels the war will be "long and tough."

Four apartment houses in Jackson Heights, Queens, at 37-33, 37-39, 37-45 and 37-57 Eightieth Street, have been sold, subject to a first mortgage of $300,000 held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The assessed valuation is $350,000.

Demands for quick issuance by the Petroleum Administrator for War of the promised priority list of fuel oil users came from widely scattered sources yesterday as discrimination of a serious nature in the allocation of scant supplies among consumers was admitted by the government and "chaotic" conditions along the East Coast were described by industry spokesmen.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Profit-taking and hedging sales came into the wheat market today in sufficient volume to check any advancing tendency, and while July and September equaled the seasonal high, the May delivery was inclined to drag.

The story of how twenty British soldiers were outfitted for a Winter sea voyage in less than two hours was told yesterday by Miss Ruth Jenkins at national headquarters of the American Women's Voluntary Services, 345 Madison Avenue.

A determined fight against the "black markets" in meat was mapped by the kosher butchers of New York City yesterday at the same time that the Food Distribution Administration announced that State and food industries committees would be organized by the middle of next week to assure a fair distribution of foods throughout the State.

The President's message to Congress was addressed in large part to the enemy. For five years, as the State Department's report on "Peace and War" amply demonstrates, he made speeches challenging, warning and threatening the aggressor nations with the potential might of the United States.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Jan. 6 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Fighting together against a common, barbaric enemy has fostered a feeling of deep comradeship between Australian and American troops, Gen. Sir Thomas A. Blamey, commander of Allied land forces in New Guinea, said today.

Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange have been advised that, although New York State stock transfer taxes cannot be collected on transfers by any instrumentality of the Federal Government, they had better accompany stock so transferred with certificates setting forth the facts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- New and uniform margins for retailers and wholesalers were established on nine food commodities today by the OPA. The OPA announced the move as the first step toward realization of its recently announced policy of simplified and standardized food pricing at the retail level.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 8 -- France now has an official Elite Guard in the Service d'Ordre Legionnaire which has just received autonomy under a decree signed by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain. Its creator and leader is Joseph Darnand.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 8 -- Engaged to the limit of her capacity in armament production for the Eastern Front, Germany, according to information received in diplomatic quarters here, has failed to complete her prepayment deliveries of armaments to the Turkish Government in exchange for which the Turks were to begin deliveries of 45,000 tons of chromium ore next month.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- Some quarters speculated that the latest Japanese move might be a feint to divert Allied forces while a major attack was launched elsewhere -- in the lower Solomons or, perhaps, even against Australia itself.

Dr. Herman B. Elster, 56 years old, pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to two of eleven counts in an abortion indictment, the maximum penalty for which is forty-eight years' imprisonment. It was the first time in the memory of old court attaches that a physician had pleaded guilty to such an indictment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A price advance of at least one cent a loaf in the retail price of bread in many areas of the country was predicted tonight by government and trade spokesmen, who said an advance, or a Federal subsidy, offered the only means for relieving the "squeeze" under which many bakers are now operating.
TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- Ruben D. Silliman of East Orange is named defendant in a suit filed by the United States Government in the Federal Court here to recover $881,298.

Today's events: "Lakme," 2 P.M., and "La Forza del Destino," 8, Metropolitan Opera House; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Hope and John Kirkpatrick, soprano and pianist, Town Hall, 3; Mina Hager, contralto, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Ernst Wolff, tenor, Town Hall, 8:30; Robert Casadesus, piano, Washington Irving High School, 8:30.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 8 -- Japan is converting Corregidor Island into the strongest military bastion between Pearl Harbor and Gibraltar, a special dispatch to the Deutsch Allgemeine Zeitung from Manila reports.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 8 (AP) -- William Phillips, former United States Ambassador to Rome, arrived here today by air from Karachi as President Roosevelt's personal envoy to India. He said he hoped to see representatives of all India's political parties in an extensive tour of the country.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

About 2,000 professional American writers have mobilized their talent to aid in the war since Pearl Harbor, according to the first annual report yesterday of the Writers War Board, 122 East Forty-second Street.

Axis radios hammered yesterday at President Roosevelt's address to Congress, but Federal Communications Commission monitors, as reported by The Associated Press, said that the enemy commentators carefully refrained from giving home audiences the specific war production figures cited by the President.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- Ursula Parrott, the four-times married novelist who smuggled Michael N. Bryan, 26, an Army private, out of a military stockade where he was serving twenty days for being absent without leave, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury.

Contracts awarded for engineering construction throughout the country last year amounted to $9,305,829,000, a record-breaking volume that far exceeded the previous high of $5,868,699,000 established in 1941. The figures for 1942 are on the base of fifty-three weeks and with allowance made for the fifty-two-week period in 1941, the volume for 1942 was estimated at 56 per cent over that of 1941.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Large formations of high-flying fighter planes streaked across the English Channel in almost continual shuttle attacks on France today in what apparently was a large-scale daylight follow-up to another night bombing of Germany's Ruhr.
Miss Else Margrete Roed, escaped Norwegian author and woman's editor of the magazine Vi Selv Og Vaare Hjem, has arrived in this country from England after a three weeks' journey.

In the busiest session since the closing day of 1942, the market on the New York Stock Exchange showed yesterday an improved tone, although the strength was confined mainly to low-priced issues, many of them, however, at new highs for several years.

The eighty-two-family apartment house at 101 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Elberne Building Corporation to the Jerrold Realty Company for cash above a mortgage of $330,000. George Patrick and Robert Turner were the brokers. Jacob L. Holtzman represented the seller and Samuel Widder the buyer.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 8 (AP) -- William Talbert of Cincinnati, fifth ranking United States star, and Francisco Segura, the Ecuadorean ace, advanced to the final of the Pan-American tennis tournament today and will meet Sunday for the men's singles title.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Great Lakes Transit Corporation has notified stockholders that it is withholding payment on preferred shares which had been tendered to it at $100 or less a share, pending the result of a lawsuit instituted against it by a preferred stockholder.

American lace mills will be forced to shut down for the duration unless they convert their equipment to make sandfly, mosquito and camouflage nets, George R. Ramsbottom, president of the American Lace Manufacturers Association, declared yesterday at the group's annual meeting in the Hotel Biltmore.

The full impact of the ban on pleasure motoring was felt in the suburban areas of Northern New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester yesterday. Many private and publicly operated amusement places, already reeling from fuel oil shortages, suffered a body blow when the Office of Price Administration decreed that only essential driving could be done by holders of A, B and C gasoline cards.

The trustees in reorganization of the huge Associated Gas and Electric system announced yesterday three major developments looking toward a speedy completion of the reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation and the Associated Gas and Electric Company, top companies in the A.G.
