E. set-up.

Messages of encouragement for a time of struggle will be given in many sermons tomorrow in the city's churches. The topics will include emphasis on home and family life and the implications of freedom as a heritage. The annual celebrations of Epiphany in commemoration of the manifestation of Christ to the Gentiles will take place at many liturgical churches.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 8 -- One hundred million more francs daily is understood to be the German claim on France for the cost of total occupation. This raises the total to 500,000,000 francs a day. The sum fixed by the armistice convention was 400,000,000 francs.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 8 -- In the first and only official graduation exercises for midshipmen at the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School 628 students raised ungloved right hands to take the oath of office as ensigns of the Navy Reserve this morning at Smith College.

Manhattan College and N.Y.U., both undefeated, will clash in the feature attraction of tonight's basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden, after Long Island University has encountered the crack North Carolina Naval Pre-Flight quintet in the inaugural game.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The War Production Board issued three orders today affecting the use and production of papers in the United States.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The stock markets here ended today an active week on the top note. Several gilt-edge stocks put on 2 1/2 points, and shipping and home rails showed further improvements, although foreign rails eased.

Although the child of one of the women had perished, two Brooklyn mothers, assisted by a 70-year-old Bowery "umbrella man," braved flames fed by a blazing Christmas tree yesterday afternoon and rescued five other children ranging in age from 10 months to 5 years.
Of interest to Westchester County and other archery followers in New York is the hunting news from Wisconsin which marizes the bow-and-arrow season in that State.
LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The text of the regular midnight Soviet communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

While civilian deliveries of bed-sheets on a restricted scale may be resumed within thirty days, but not in time to encourage January "white" sales, retailers' supplies may be curtailed for the balance of 1943 by mounting needs of the Army and other war agencies, it was reported yesterday by leading Worth Street sellers.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress, which many Argentines heard over the radio yesterday, was printed with great prominence under conspicuous headlines by the leading newspapers and two English-language newspapers printing the complete text.

Isaac Stern, young American violinist, who made his New York debut in 1937, gave his fourth local recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Stern held the interest of a large gathering by the superior merits of his performances in a formidable program embracing five outstanding works of the literature for his chosen instrument.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senate Republicans, meeting today in a harmony session, unanimously reelected Senator McNary as floor leader. Then they endorsed committee assignments, giving them, in view of their increased numbers in the new Congress, a ratio of two to three with the majority on most committees.

General de Lattre de Tassigny will be put on trial today before the section of Vichy's State Tribunal that operates at Lyon. He was in command of the Sixteenth Military District at Montpellier Nov. 11 when the Germans invaded the free zone.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- A flotilla of British destroyers, by one of the most gallant and most able naval actions of this war, last week-end beat off an attack on a northbound Russian convoy by a German squadron, including a pocket battleship and an 8-inch gun cruiser and destroyers.

" Silver Queen," an action drama of the old West featuring George Brent, Priscilla Lane and Bruce Cabot, will open this morning at the Globe. The United Artists release was produced by Harry Sherman, directed by Lloyd Bacon and includes Lynne Overman, Eugene Pallette and Janet Beecher among its supporting players.

The principal clue -- a six-inch butcher's knife -- available to detectives seeking the slayer of Dorothy Huber, 23-year-old Ward Baking Company employee, who was stabbed Monday while walking to work at 143d Street and Wales Avenue, the Bronx, was traced yesterday to its manufacturer.

WITH ALLIED FORCES IN NEW GUINEA, Jan. 6 (Delayed) -- Some of America's best doctors are treating the American wounded on the Buna front. They are doing their jobs within the framework of a system for handling casualties that is operating with remarkable speed and efficiency in spite of difficulties imposed by jungle warfare.

Isaac Stern, young American violinist, who made his New York debut in 1937, gave his fourth local recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Stern held the interest of a large gathering by the superior merits of his performances in a formidable program embracing five outstanding works of the literature for his chosen instrument.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senate Republicans, meeting today in a harmony session, unanimously reelected Senator McNary as floor leader. Then they endorsed committee assignments, giving them, in view of their increased numbers in the new Congress, a ratio of two to three with the majority on most committees.

General de Lattre de Tassigny will be put on trial today before the section of Vichy's State Tribunal that operates at Lyon. He was in command of the Sixteenth Military District at Montpellier Nov. 11 when the Germans invaded the free zone.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- A flotilla of British destroyers, by one of the most gallant and most able naval actions of this war, last week-end beat off an attack on a northbound Russian convoy by a German squadron, including a pocket battleship and an 8-inch gun cruiser and destroyers.

" Silver Queen," an action drama of the old West featuring George Brent, Priscilla Lane and Bruce Cabot, will open this morning at the Globe. The United Artists release was produced by Harry Sherman, directed by Lloyd Bacon and includes Lynne Overman, Eugene Pallette and Janet Beecher among its supporting players.

The principal clue -- a six-inch butcher's knife -- available to detectives seeking the slayer of Dorothy Huber, 23-year-old Ward Baking Company employee, who was stabbed Monday while walking to work at 143d Street and Wales Avenue, the Bronx, was traced yesterday to its manufacturer.

The nine-story apartment house at 135 West Fifty-eighth Street has been conveyed by the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, represented by Louis W. Dawson, to an investing client of Bernard R. Jankoff for cash, above a mortgage of $156,750.

Eleventh-hour contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund continued to arrive yesterday, making additional relief possible for the unfortunate individuals and families on the rolls of eight leading private charity organizations.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- John A. Kotal, secretary of the National Association of Retail Meat Dealers, said today that retail ceiling prices on pork would probably be revised within a few weeks. Ceilings on beef, veal and mutton would be changed later, he added.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8 -- Cornell defeated Yale, 55 -- 27, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight. Taking the lead in the first minute, the Ithacans more than doubled Yale's score in the first half and held a good lead throughout the second chapter.

New financing in the first week of the new year showed a moderate improvement, following an absence of flotations in the closing week of 1942. Three issues of tax-exempt bonds aggregating $4,336,000 were offered for public subscription, the largest weekly total in a month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Representative Gifford, Republican of Massachusetts, quoting the words "the country knows where I stand" from President Roosevelt's message to Congress yesterday, told the House today that if the country were "in doubt where to get a candidate next year" it would know where Mr. Roosevelt stood.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that six survivors of a torpedoed United States merchant vessel were landed here Christmas Eve after they had drifted fifteen days in an open lifeboat with scant rations. They twice were tossed by huge waves into a raging sea and finally were rescued by another ship when so exhausted that they sat waist-deep in water "waiting for the end."
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The early enthusiasm over the Allied expedition in North Africa has dwindled somewhat with the stalemate in the fighting and is yielding now to misgivings and anxiety.

The Rev. Frank Ray Wilson, rector of St. James Episcopal Church at Hyde Park, where President Roosevelt and his family are worshipers, was sworn in yesterday as a lieutenant in the Chaplains Corps of the Navy.

The recent midday killing of a Brooklyn detective developed an interesting aspect yesterday when the two men whose actions brought about the slaying were arraigned in Kings County Court and held in $100,000 bail each on indictments charging them only with the assault and robbery that were incidental to the murder.

Drives for scrap metal and continuous salvage programs by the electric power and light industry in the last twelve months have yielded about 24,000,000 pounds of copper for the nation's war needs, together with large quantities of aluminum, brass, iron, steel, lead, zinc, rubber and other materials, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday in summarizing the results of a survey conducted among the country's electric companies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Moving to ration dealers' supplies of fuel oil equitably among household consumers, the Office of Price Administration issued an order today requiring every fuel-oil dealer to honor oil-rationing coupons from any householder so long as he has supplies on hand, regardless of whether the applicant for oil is a new customer or not.
A large, white Wyandotte cockerel won the coveted prize as best in show yesterday among 2,000 entries at the annual New York Poultry Show at the Hotel Capitol, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

The practicality of duplicate printing plates, made of a non-critical plastic which conserves copper, has been established by a newspaper test under the auspices of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, the Theodore Moss Company, Brooklyn, announced yesterday.

After watching St. John's conquer City College and N.Y.U. defeat Penn State, I am looking forward eagerly to the "natural" contest between the Redmen and the Violet scheduled for March 3 in Madison Square Garden. I think Coach Howard Cann of N.Y.U. will devise a way to stop the high-scoring St. John's basketball sensation, Harry Boykoff.
In THE TIMES of Jan. 3 there was an item concerning the need of gifts by tax-supported institutions.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The $271,128 paid to Jacob W. Schwab as president of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., and two affiliated companies tops a list of officers' remuneration contained in corporation reports for 1942 made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 9 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur, on returning to his general headquarters from the campaign in the Papua Peninsula, where a Japanese Army of about 15,000 now has been virtually destroyed, highly praised the work of the American Thirty-second and Forty-first Divisions and the Fifth American Air Force.

Presumably it is a hopeless task, trying to wean away a bureaucrat from his long words and long sentences. Nobody has taken to heart the President's reminder that it is much better to say "Put out the light" than to prescribe "termination of the illumination."
WASHINGTON, Pa., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Sammy Angott, who announced three months ago his retirement as lightweight boxing champion, disclosed tonight that he is planning a ring comeback.

The United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's first advanced slalom school of the season will be held at North Conway, N.H., starting Monday morning at 10 o'clock and continuing through Saturday, it was announced yesterday.

It's nice to know that a policeman is stationed near by to protect your home. But with Mrs. Lena Bertish it's different. Since Dec. 12 a patrolman has been posted in her apartment at 867 East 176th Street, the Bronx, on a twenty-four-hour-a-day basis, and Mrs. Bertish isn't too happy about it.

Despite rationing, an acute shortage of coffee is developing here, it was learned yesterday. Imports have declined sharply in recent weeks -- notably after the launching of the North African campaign with its demand on available shipping -- and since the first of the year no cargoes of any important size have been received, coffee roasters reported.

An inkling of what baseball's Spring training, frosted to wartime style, will look like this year was gleaned yesterday when Branch Rickey, president of the Brooklyn club, announced the Dodgers' 1943 exhibition schedule. It is a far cry from the elaborate thirty and thirty-five game bookings of happier days.

The sponsors of "Three Curtains," the trio of short plays by Barrie, Shaw and Pinero, have decided to unfold their attraction in New York during the week of Jan. 25. After its final performance in Boston this evening "Three Curtains" will be minus the acting services of Francis Lederer.

MR. Van Keuren prefaces his brief but beautiful novel with the first eight stanzas of Chapter 3 of the Acts of the Apostles, which tell of a cripple who sat at the gate of the temple and begged alms. Peter and John came along for prayer and seeing the crippled beggar spoke to him.

German troops were declared by their High Command yesterday to have repulse bitter attacks by Soviet forces between the Caucasus and the Don, near Stalingrad and "in the Don district" and to have inflicted extremely heavy losses in counter-attacks.

AN important collection of indigenous stories from Latin America have been selected and edited by Angel Flores and Dudley Porter, and together with an Introduction by Katherine Anne Porter, who knows her subject thoroughly, is published under the title of "Fiesta in November."

" EARTHWORMS AT WAR" is the subtitle for the new Alexander Botts book, and any one who has read any of the preceding adventures of the Botts "peerless earth-moving machinery" may safely look forward to an hour or two of merriment with the latest model tractors.

A FORMER Congregational minister, Albert Rhys Williams was one of the first apostles of the Soviet faith in the United States. Freshly returned from Russia in the first years of revolution and civil war. he painted a picture of the Soviet regime as a noble experiment in social progress and higher humanity at a time when Russia, to the average American, was associated with the ideas of murder, pillage, famine and nationalization of women.
With a livelier tempo than surrounds most service men's lounges, small armies of Waacs and Waves have taken possession of the hospitality centers that have opened for them in this city.
Mrs. Iselin Gilbert will give a tea this afternoon at the Plaza.

The annual Public Schools Athletic League dual meet swimming series came to an end yesterday, with DeWitt Clinton capturing the Manhattan-Bronx title and Brooklyn Tech repeating as Brooklyn-Richmond winner.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Jack Frye, president of Transcontinental and Western Airlines, proposed today that the United States immediately launch a program to cover the globe with millions of airplanes. Such an air fleet, Fyre told members of the San Francisco Press Club, would guarantee permanent security to the American people because no nation or group of nations would dare attack.

When Sonja Henie comes here with her Hollywood Ice Revue at Madison Square Garden, Jan. 18 to 27, she will skate more often and for a longer period than she ever has in any other show or carnival in her career. Miss Henie will have nine major selections in the revue in addition to various other showings in ensemble numbers.

Something new was added to the wartime scene last night as New Yorkers stepped out for their first Saturday night fling since the government's ban on pleasure driving went into effect. Motor cycles, with policemen in the saddles and Office of Price Administration investigators in the sidecars, toured the city to check on passenger cars and learn their business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Although oil production is running at a rate greater than the ability of the country to consume, many citizens sat in East Coast homes this week and shivered, unable to obtain the fuel necessary to keep their oil-burning furnaces in operation.

THE cancellation of sports events is not often worthy of comment, but there was a relatively obscure and unnoticed item buried away among the war news the other day, an item which gives a slightly different slant on the value of athletics. The infuriated Germans -- may their burning under the collar increase -- called off all sports events in Brussels and Antwerp as a reprisal measure for acts of sabotage.

Foreign relief and rehabilitation will go a long way toward shortening the war and "a very long way in helping to create the kind of stable, equitable and enduring peace in which we all are interested," Herbert H. Lehman, who resigned the Governorship of New York to assume the direction of this work, declared last night.

BY way of Portugal last week came word that Greece recently issued two air-mail series. Although they were released presumably under Nazi supervision, they resemble in designs the pre-war Greek stamps and carry no occupation inscriptions.

In his address last week to the new Congress President Roosevelt rightly declared that the "past year was perhaps the most crucial year for modern civilization," and that while the new year will be filled with violent conflict it also holds out high promise of better things.

Miss Alice Burnham won the girls' senior half-mile city championship of the Middle Atlantic Skating Association on Conservatory Lake in Central Park yesterday. The event was held in conjunction with the Manhattan finals in the Department of Parks ice skating carnival.

HEADING this week's list of night club events in New York is the opening on Thursday evening of the new show at Monte Proser's Copacabana. Sophie Tucker, allegedly "the last of the Red Hot Mamas," will be one of the leading performers in the entertainment which Tony De Marco has staged.
Out of the bomber of the last war came the long-distance commercial plane; out of this war's bomber the giant plane of the future is emerging.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Although there will be fewer major sports tournaments here this year than formerly because war has drawn off so many participants, several weekly golf and tennis events are under way. One such is the nine-hole tombstone tourneys each Sunday afternoon at the Everglades Club following a golf luncheon, with prizes donated by individuals.

Manufacturers of men's clothing in the South are mapping plans for an export trade after the war or, if that fails, are employing designers from the Northern markets so that they will be in a position to compete for the domestic business on better grade merchandise, it was learned here last week.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: If you are planning to start seeds indoors, it's none too early to get together all the materials you will need -- soil, compost or peatmoss, and sand to make up a proper mixture; flats or bulb pans; some sphagnum moss; a disinfectant for treating seeds before planting, and the like.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Despite the need for 10,000 more physicians in the armed forces this year, medical-care facilities for civilians will be made possible through the relocation of doctors to meet the demands of regions or communities where there are extreme shortages of practitioners, the War Manpower Commission made known today.

George D. Stoddard, president of the University of the State of New York and State Commissioner of Education, favors the proposed amendment to the State Constitution to lower the age for first voters from 21 to 18, Harold R. Moskovit, State president of the Affiliated Young Democrats, announced yesterday in making public a letter to him from Mr. Stoddard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Many new facts about immersion blast injury, or injury suffered by a man in the water when an underwater explosion occurs nearby, have been uncovered by the Naval Hospital at Pearl Harbor in studying casualties from the Battle of Midway.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Libya, Jan. 7 (Delayed) -- If you drive up on the skyline and remain there more than a minute or so -- in fact, if you show your head over the crest of yonder hill -- you will draw the full fury of some well-concealed enemy battery.
As 1943 gets off to a frosty start, many people are apparently realizing for the first time that a fireplace is more than a desirable decoration.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Governor Dewey, asked to comment on the Flynn case, referred pointedly to a campaign speech he made in the Bronx Oct. 31 in which he expressed sympathy for the people of Mexico. Mr. Flynn at that time was reported to be under consideration for appointment as Ambassador to Mexico.
The lions and tigers of Central Park Zoo are learning to get along on less meat and the monkeys are already reconciled to the sweet potato as an ersatz banana.

In withdrawing recognition of the two-year bachelor's degrees awarded by the University of Chicago, the New York State Department of Education has brought into the open a sharp controversy that has disturbed educational leaders in recent months.

Price fluctuations on the New York Cotton Exchange were contained yesterday to an 8-point range in a small market. Fixing operations by trade sources, though small, absorbed limited hedge sales and liquidation and the list of active contrasts closed 4 to 10 points above Friday's final prices, recovering that day's losses.

Two events of interest to persons supporting and cooperating in projects of the Fighting French Relief Committee will take place this week, the first being a "secret reception" and eggnog party this afternoon at the Durand-Ruel Gallery, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street.

THE mystery once attached to the radio code is rapidly disappearing as literally hundreds of thousands of men and women are mastering in record time one of the most useful of all languages, whether on the home or military front.

From Berne, Switzerland, came the news last week that chemical element 85 has been separated from its radioactive parent substance by Drs. Walter Minder and Alice Leigh-Smith, wife of a British diplomat and a pupil of Mme. Curie.

Reflecting their participation in the $12,906,000,000 December Victory Loan campaign, holdings of government securities by leading Wall Street banks jumped 27.9 per cent in the final quarter of 1942 to a level where such holdings now constitute 51.6 per cent of the total resources of these banks, a new record in the history of banking in the United States.

Illustrated by the author. 151 pp. Philadelphia. J.B. Lippincott Company. $1.75. THE 5-to-10-year-olds who enjoyed "Mr. Tittlewit's Holiday" will be glad to know that the Town Mouse is once more back among his country friends. Mr. Nouggygum, the benevolent field mole, sent for him to help stave off tragedy, for crime had broken out among the denizens of Fern Wood.
Jacques Maritain, Catholic author and philosopher, urged yesterday on his sixtieth birthday that the political and the military problems of France be separated "as far as possible."

What should I say to my neighbor who must have been sorely disgruntled on reading Lucy Greenbaum's article in THE TIMES Magazine when I've not been able to taste coffee for almost a whole year because of doctor's orders? "Sorry! No second cup." Pshaw!

At a distance of thousands of miles from the battle line it is hard to find the right words to express what we think of the men who have fallen in action for our common cause, and of those who are daily risking their lives. What can we say that to the soldier will not seem sentimental, rhetorical or insincere ?

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 9 (AP) -- German General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock, speaking for a number of German generals who were alarmed by the dangerous position of the German armies in the Caucasus as a result of the developing Russian offensives, is reported in Berlin to have urged Adolph Hitler to withdraw his lines while there was still time.

The annual meeting of the American Retail Federation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel adopted resolutions yesterday urging national and State retail associations to petition Congress for enactment of the Rural pay-as-you-go tax plan and advocating a drastic revision of the price control system to make it "practical and effective."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The whole picture of what the War Production Board's inventory limitation order, L-219, is designed to do and how it will affect various types of merchants will be explained in New York next Tuesday at a conference to which all affected trade journal editors, top executives of large buying groups and secretaries of trade associations have been invited.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Revealing for the first time thrilling actions fought by Marine Air Force units at the Battle of Midway Island in June, the Navy announced today that all eighty-four pilots and aerial gunners of those units had been decorated for heroism and that fifty-eight ground crew members had been commended.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 9 -- Streets of Northampton are emptied today of the now familiar blue uniform of 628 women midshipmen who were commissioned yesterday as ensigns and left immediately for active duty in all parts of the continental United States.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Abe Greene, president of the National Boxing Association, said tonight that his organization had decided to withhold action on Sammy Angott's announced comeback until Greene has had a chance to talk with Angott and Manager Charley Jones.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Jan. 9 -- The South Pacific war is finding America's natural leaders and testing the mettle of those holding commands. As a result we are building land forces headed by tough veterans who have proved themselves in battle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- There is in Washington an agency which has no automobile, no publicity staff, no lawyer, and whose active members have not made speeches since they have been with the organization.

The passing of President Lowell of Harvard will quicken many memories of his wise wit and his penetrating vision. On Bunker Hill Day, 1915, when the League to Enforce Peace was organized in Independence Hall, Dr. Lowell was chairman of the Committee on Platform.

Continuance of its ban on championships and extension of its activities in war relief was the keynote of yesterday's forty-ninth annual meeting of the United States Golf Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEXT Wednesday night at Town Hall the Collegiate Chorale will make its first concert appearance of this season as part of the initial program of the Town Hall Music Forum Series. The fact that the chorus is giving these performances may not seem to be an event worthy of extended mention in these columns.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 9 -- The German Government replied negatively this morning to the request by the Argentine Supreme Court that the German naval and air attache, Captain Dietrich Niebuhr, he instructed to waive his diplomatic immunity and answer charges of espionage.

Boy Meets tax Ethelbert Smith said how pleasant it was to see this new intelligent attitude to the business of raising and operating a family. On every side you find the old soft-headed sentiment being discarded and new babies being placed on the same level as new typewriters.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Blackpool, Northern Section champion of the English Football League for the first half of the season, finds the cup-qualifying games troublesome.

A resolution requesting the Office of Price Administration to establish rent ceilings as of January, 1941, in New York City to end what was termed "rent discriminations" against Negroes was adopted yesterday by the second annual conference of the People's Committee, a coordinating organization for Negro and labor organizations in the city, held at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street.

THE "Four Freedoms" 1-cent green stamp announced two weeks ago will be released on Feb. 12. The design presents, within an oval-shaped panel, a bas-relief representation of Liberty holding the lighted Torch of Freedom and Enlightenment.

Friends of Great Britain's civilians who are engaged in many phases of home defense and war work are enlisting here in large numbers as volunteers in the British War Relief Society's greater New York campaign for vitally needed funds to maintain its relief commitment in Britain, established in the days of the Blitz and more urgent than ever after three years of war.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Governor Dewey's annual message, submitted to the Legislature at its opening session last Wednesday, was the first step along the path which his friends hope will lead to a national reputation for administrative abilities, plus the liberalism in social matters which the times require.
MOSCOW, Jan. 9 -- Major Marina Raskova of the Red Air Force has been killed in action, it was announced today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

Hope Kirkpatrick, soprano, and John Kirkpatrick, pianist, were heard in a joint recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. They presented an unusual program in which ultra-modern American works were brought into sharp contrast with classic compositions by Purcell, Bach and Beethoven.

The first word due from an Englishman making acquaintance with the Beveridge report through its American edition is a tribute of thanks to the New York house of Macmillan for the generous enterprise which thus supplies him with the tightly packed, 300-page volume within a month or little more of its appearance in England.

Farmers in New York, New Jersey and the New England States have been slow in applying for mileage adjustments in their certificates of war necessity for farm vehicles, according to William J. Clark, regional manager of the motor transport division of the Office of Defense Transportation.

The signing in London of a new collective agreement by representatives of the Netherlands Government, shipowners, the Dutch Central Transport Workers Union and the Dutch Merchant Officers Organization was announced jointly yesterday by P.J. Vandenberge, secretary, and J.J. Vandeville, general ships' representative, of the New York branch of the Dutch Central Transport Workers Union.

The National Council of American Shipbuilders last week announced its belief that the Liberty lifeboats are the safest, most seaworthy and self-contained boats of their type ever made. Designed to carry twenty-five passengers and built of either metal or wood, the boats are as sturdy as the old whaling craft and incorporate some of the best features of these vessels.

BRISTOL, Conn., Jan. 9 (AP) -- The fear of Judge Roger S. Newell that the conduct of our government by President Roosevelt would result in inflation prompted him to make special provision in his will for the protection of his widow.

EMIL LENGYEL has produced a good background book on Siberia. His description of the country, his resume of its history from the times of the great bandit Yermak through the Civil War, are the best this reviewer has yet seen.

We publish on this page today a letter from Professor T. Harry Williams on the Congressional Committee on the Conduct of the War which was formed in December, 1861, shortly after the outbreak of the War Between the States, and continued until June, 1865. In view of the proposals in Congress for another joint committee on the conduct of the present war, Professor Williams's account should serve as a warning.

THERE are many bridge hands in which the contract depends on finding a given distribution of cards in the opponents' hands. In these cases it, is proper to play on the assumption that such will be the distribution, no matter how improbable it may be mathematically.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 9 -- Federal conciliators won a vote tonight by union officials representing 24,000 striking anthracite miners which will reopen twenty closed mines on Monday. The vote must be ratified by the miners at meetings of their locals tomorrow.
Woman's urge to be pretty can be satisfied in wartime without any waving of wands or fashion abracadabra. The trick is to use a bit of pink.

LONDON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- A Free Austrian spokesman said today that an underground movement is gaining headway in Austria and predicted that it "might prove the turning point in development of resistance against the Nazi invader."

There is no "real dilemma" at present between meeting the nation's immediate needs for trained women and training women to meet the nation's future needs, so far as Vassar College is concerned, President Henry Noble MacCracken, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Japan today, on the basis of reports available from the many battle fronts of Asia and the Pacific, may be either a country that realizes she is on the way to defeat or one that is planning a major stroke designed to undo all the little losses the empire has sustained in the past few months.

THE psychoanalytic method can be a deadly luxury for a writer. "The Looking Glass," William March's first novel since 1936, is a case in point. Mr. March has plunged deep into the cave of the subconscious, with Jung at one elbow and Krafft-Ebing as a polar star.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, said today that he foresaw no further imminent reduction in the value of gasoline rationing coupons in the seventeen East Coast States and also reaffirmed his opposition to the elimination of A ration books.

THE Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation will hold its nineteenth annual series of auditions this season for pianists, violinists, cellists and singers. The contest is open to those of mature talent who are ready for a professional career but have not given a recital in this city reviewed by critics.

After an absence of seven seasons from the repertoire, Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" was revived last night with pronounced success at the Metropolitan Opera House. Carefully prepared, and superbly conducted by Bruno Walter, the performance moved with admirable swiftness and smoothness.

Walter Chrysler's thousand-acre North Wales Stud at Warrenton, Va., where stands the famous English sire Bahrain and other stallions, is to be converted largely to the war effort under the direction of Charles O. Pratt, former official in the Department of Inter-American Affairs and before that a member of the F.B.I.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Decorations were awarded by President Roosevelt today to twenty-five officers of Patrol Wing Four, the group of Navy airmen who defied seemingly insurmountable odds to defend the Aleutians during the early stages of the Japanese attack in June, 1942, from the time when word was received on June 3 that the enemy aircraft carriers were only 400 miles from Kiska until June 15.

New Yorkers, who are sensitive about equal rights and hold for a fair distribution of all sacrifices of luxuries and conveniences entailed in the current war, have been particularly disturbed in recent cold spells by the discrepancy in temperatures in various buildings.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9 -- Harvard's undefeated hockey team scored its sixth straight victory when it routed Princeton, 5 to 1, in the Pentagonal Hockey League opener tonight. It was the Tigers' second setback in three starts.

There was ice on the river, loose drift, where gulls huddled forlornly; tugs and ferryboats plowed it like broken glass, and the gulls winged off, complaining. The wind had an edge and the sun was setting in an icy sky. It would be a cold night in these parts, and some homes were short of fuel oil.

MISS FLORA ROBSON has reformed -- at least temporarily -- and is frank to admit she enjoys being good for a change. Her poison-oak laurels, won for many years playing successfully lethal ladies, are locked securely away this season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Selective Service Bureau told local boards today of thirty-four essential occupations in repair and hand-trade services, including automobile mechanics and electricians, in which occupational registrants may be deferred as "necessary men" in activities which contribute to the war effort.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- The greatest troop-carrying air armada assembled by the United Nations in the present war ferried "many thousands" of American fighting men non-stop 1,400 miles from bases in England to participate in the Allied occupation of North Africa, Colonel H.W. Shelmire, executive assistant to the commanding general of the Army Air Forces, disclosed here today.

WHAT is happening in France today? Much. But little of it is known. One thing is plain, nevertheless: France is living negatively now that "collaboration" has been translated into coercion. She has no army, no navy, no air force, in practice no government.

With the smaller war plants division of the WPB now established on a firm foundation, the amount of subcontracting to small plants arranged by it will show substantial increases in the coming thirty to sixty days, Carl E. Bolte, assistant to Lou Holland, director of the division, predicted here yesterday.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Jan. 9 -- Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, commander of the American forces, spent much time in the actual firing line at Buna. He insisted on seeing for himself the opposition the troops faced and how they were coping with it.

A Japanese broadcast, recorded by The Associated Press yesterday, said Premier Hideki Tojo had announced that Wang Chiang-wei's National Government of China at Nanking had declared war against the United States and the British Empire.

In recognition of the wartime problem faced by many students now about to enter college from high schools and preparatory schools, the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsylvania has adopted an emergency curriculum which will become effective when the undergraduate schools begin their Spring term on Feb.1.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 -- Slackening of retail sales usually encountered after Christmas shopping is not evident this year. Sales are still brisk among the larger stores and sizably ahead of the corresponding period of 1942. Retail sales as a whole, however, are spotty, and some stores with reduced inventories are not doing so well comparatively.

This would normally be the annual January week for the National Motor Boat Show. Lexington Avenue, in calmer times, would be nautical. And the Grand Central Palace, now occupied by the Army's induction station, would have in other days a sheen and a luster of newly polished yachts around which would hover hundreds of persuasive salesmen and brokers with their order blanks and sharp pencils.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Activities at each of the leading resorts of the Pocono Mountain region are centering around Winter sports, with guests enjoying skiing on the many well-marked trails, snow and ice tobogganing, dog-sled riding and sleigh rides.

EVEN antiques exhibits follow the news; the importance of both the Far East and the Near East in today's headlines is being reflected in two current Metropolitan Museum displays. One is made up of highly decorative portraits on silk of Chinese court personages; the other shows antique textiles from Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia.

A CHANCE meeting with Vice President Wallace at a recent dinner party in the Virginia home of a mutual friend has resulted in Gabriel Pascal's undertaking the most "ambitious" film production effort of his varied career as a director-producer.

IN a review of a recent performance of Wagner's "Tannhaeuser" at the Metropolitan Opera House this writer took critical exception to a detail of Dr. Herbert Graf's stage direction of the Wartburg scene.

MANCHESTER, Vt. -- New York skiers are a determined lot. If snow exists anywhere within a reasonable distance they'll find it, and neither crowded trains, heatless stations, eatless hours, long night journeys nor other discomforts of wartime travel keep them from their selfappointed missions.

Miss Helena Mroczkowska of the home club, former national champion, defeated Miss Maria Cerra of Salle Santelli in a fence-off, 4 -- 2, to win the senior fencing meet for the Alice Wendt Voorhees medals at the Fencers Club yesterday.

HE is a tall, quiet old man who still speaks our language with the deliberate, painstaking effort of one who still finds it frequently bewildering. Sometimes he strikes his forehead with his palm as he stops, baffled, and picks up his German-English dictionary: "Ach, this language, it is so difficult," he exclaims.

Marjorie Lawrence, Australian soprano, who sang the Venusberg scene from "Tannhaeuser" at a concert given by her colleagues at the Metropolitan Opera House two weeks ago, will sing the role in regularly scheduled performances of the opera during the season, Edward Johnson, general manager, announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 9 -- Josef Terboven, Nazi Governor of Norway, is about to be transferred to Vienna, according to advices received here through private channels from usually reliable sources in Berlin.

Retail trade was active last week, but comparisons with a year ago indicated a decline in department store volume of about 10 per cent. The opening weeks of 1942 brought hectic buying by consumers of many merchandise items, particularly men's clothing, staple cotton goods, cosmetics and house-wares.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that invitations had been sent to more than 15,000 commercial banks throughout the country to participate in its "ration banking program," which will begin to operate on a nation-wide scale on Jan. 27.

WAR has its by-products. Two of the greatest of this conflict will be the creation of new radio men for the world of tomorrow and the production of much-needed new technical literature now appearing in textbook form.

Because the merits of egg white in the treatment of cancer have still to be proved, it is time to sound a warning. The dried egg white that had been imported from China retained the active factor, avidin, unimpaired. But the commercial American product does not. The reason is that when egg white is heated during the process of drying its avidin loses potency.
GOOD evening, ladies and gentlemen. From Symphony Hall in Boston, Mass., the Blue network presents the incomparable Boston Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky.

WHEN the young Syrian rug peddler reached the town of Ames, Iowa, he stopped, and would go peddling no farther. Here at last he saw the America that had filled his thoughts since he had first heard of it from the school-master in a poverty-stricken village on a donkey trail, in the rough gray hill between Beirut and Damascus.

Additional contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund were received yesterday from individuals who expressed the desire to help other individuals and families whose need was attested by the eight leading private charity organizations.

The report of the Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company and its subsidiaries for the year ended on Sept. 30, made public yesterday, shows a net profit of $3,378,044 after United States and Cuban taxes, provision for contingencies and other charges.

WHEN the earthly destiny of Edward Yancey Tayloe was laid out for him in advance it looked little enviable. He would be, said the Big Boss grumpily, a newspaper copyreader in Texas. After that nothing whatever would happen to him.

Adoption of longer office hours is being studied seriously by management as a means of getting out increased paper work with the same or reduced staffs, it was learned last week. Some concerns have already stepped up the number of hours and are studying the results with respect to diminishing returns.

The screen's excursions into the realm of satire appear to have been interrupted once again now that Preston Sturges has brought forth a more or less conventional or "straight" comedy in "The Palm Beach Story." That he plans no immediate return to the type of film on which his reputation was established seems evident from the announcement that his next production is to be an outdoor drama.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Secretary Ickes declared today that strikes in the Pennsylvania anthracite fields were "intolerable" and called upon the industry to produce "this coal."
LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet Monitor:

LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Field Marshal Sir Archibald P. Wavell's southward thrusting forces have renewed the fighting with Japanese in the difficult lowlands north of Akyab in Burma simultaneously. with raids by American fliers from China and the R.A.F. from India.

Mark Warren, former newspaper reporter, has gone to California for his health and is running a gas station on the desert when his detective instincts are aroused by a series of events at the Manders date ranch near by. Everybody there seems to fear that something dreadful is about to happen, and their fears prove well founded, for one of their number is murdered.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 9 -- American planes spread destruction and death throughout a wide area of Tunisia yesterday. Flying Fortresses, bombing accurately through gaps in heavy clouds, made three separate raids on the Bizerte-Ferryville area and shot down four enemy aircraft during the operations.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The swift new British light bombers, the American-made Vega Ventura planes, blasted the steel mills at Ijmuiden in the Netherlands today as the Royal Air Force resumed its twenty-four-hour offensive operations against Nazi-held Europe, raking Belgian and Northern French railways and sweeping over France.

Because of the special circumstances surrounding commerce with Mexico under current wartime conditions, foreign traders last week expressed considerable satisfaction that no delays were permitted to arise in making effective the recently concluded reciprocal trade agreement between the two countries and that it will enter into full force on Jan. 30.

THE story of how "Yankee Doodle Dandy" came to the screen has finally been told by William Cagney, its producer, half a year after its release. The picture, which grossed $1,500,000 for Warner Brothers in 450 theatre engagements in 1942, will go into general distribution this week, and James Cagney, its star, received the New York Film Critics' award as the outstanding actor of last year for his characterization of George M. Cohan in it.
MANY years ago, when I was a young girl in China, a certain Winter came when I was old enough, my mother said, no longer to be shielded from the sorrows of life.
Several painters and two playwrights were among the ten new members admitted to the department of art and literature at the National Institute of Arts and Letters, it was announced yesterday.

C.J. Hambro, president of the Norwegian Parliament in Exile, issued yesterday a warning against a "great power peace" made by politicians and diplomats. The essential need for security in the future, he said, is a "people's peace" in which small nations are not forgotten.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Francisco Segura of Ecuador and William Talbert of Cincinnati combined to form a tennis doubles team today and quickly won their way to the final round of tandem play in the Pan-American tourney.

THE terminal lay vast and brooding in the darkness. The dimmed-out upper concourse was lit faintly from below by fields of translucent squares. Obviously, Dante's Inferno was not the only place with more than one level.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Captain Sidney Grant of Liverpool revealed today how he hoodwinked a U-boat by pretending to sink, then took his ship 1,600 miles with a 40-foot hole in her side.

Commander Tom Hamilton, head of the Navy's pre-flight physical training program, yesterday was named as the man who did the most for soccer in 1942 by the executive committee of the National Soccer Coaches Association, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Reports that scarce foodstuffs were made available in plenty to Japanese-American war relocation camps in the Far West, while residents of surrounding areas were subject to strict rationing, brought Congressional demands tonight for investigation of phases of the relocation program.

THE recording of Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4, in G, Op. 58, (Victor DM-930, four twelve-inch records) by Artur Schnabel, pianist, and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra directed by the late Frederick Stock belongs on the 1942 list, but the album reached us too late for extended comment at the time.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Civilian activities compete with Army-staged events in Atlantic City this week as midwinter resort attractions for visitors from New York and other metropolitan areas.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 9 -- Invitations have been sent out for the marriage of Miss Ruth Joy Mathes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Mathes of this community, to Ensign James Francis Gerrity 2d, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joe W. Gerrity of Newton, Mass., which will take place the afternoon of Jan. 30 in Christ Episcopal Church here.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 9 (AP) -- St. John's University of Brooklyn scored 7 points in the last ninety seconds tonight to defeat Canisius, 55 -- 45, at basketball.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, is seeking to standardize the physical and educational qualifications of the armed forces, it was learned today. He was reported as feeling that it is "inevitable" the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard must adjust standards to permit induction of men with lesser physical and educational attributes than they have demanded in the past.

As the initial event in the most extensive drive for funds in its history, the Camp Fire Girls Council of Greater New York has taken over the Center Theatre for a benefit performance of "Stars on Ice" next Thursday night. A goal of $75,000 is set for the campaign, and a portion of the funds received will be used to purchase a permanent camp site for Camp Fire Girls of this city.

There were no signs of food rationing in a swank Park Avenue gambling establishment that the police raided early yesterday morning. For the tables groaned not only under gambling equipment but also under piles of food and liquor.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan 9 -- The "Battle of Rubber" in Brazil is developing according to plan, and the officers directing operations report that victory is in sight. They hope to extract from the Brazilian jungle 50,000 tons of rubber this year.

Effects of the war upon retailing will be surveyed by numerous speakers at the Wartime Conference of the National Retail Dry Goods Association which begins at the Hotel Pennsylvania tomorrow and continues through Friday. Stressing the theme "Retailing Follows Through," the convention will deal with both immediate and post-war problems of small and large retailers.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The Luftwaffe, mighty instrument of destruction that it still is, has become perforce a reluctant dragon. It does not want to fight any more where it does not absolutely have to. The fact is that German air strength is declining while the Allies' is increasing and the Nazis now have to conserve and husband their strength.

LONDON, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- The major land developments in the African fighting were disclosed today in a communique from the headquarters of Brig. Gen. Jacques Leclerc, whose Fighting French forces are driving north on Tripoli from French Equatorial Africa.

THIS breezy, kaleidoscopic knowing and readable little book has all the earmarks of the Henry Luce school of news commentators, to which the author rightfully belongs as foreign news editor of Time magazine.

IN the final hours of the tragic fight on Bataan peninsula, even as the decimated lines of American and Filipino soldiers were breaking before the overwhelming weight of the Japanese onslaught, a rickety Navy amphibian, patched up partly from a plane on the scrap heap, and partly from another that had been sunk in the bay at the outbreak of the war, took off under heavy Japanese fire.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 9 (AP) -- W.S. Le Francois, Marine lieutenant from Watertown, N.Y., received the Navy Cross today for extraordinary heroism in the action at Makin Island last August.

For pioneering research in aviation medicine, particularly for the development of the Schneider Physical-Fitness Index used to test the condition of airplane pilots, Dr. Edward C. Schneider of Wesleyan University will receive the John Jeffries Award for 1942 from the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, Major Lester D. Gardner, executive vice president of the institute, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Excess passenger-car tires acquired by the idle-tire purchase plan will soon be made available to motorists who need them for essential driving, the Office of Price Administration stated today.

Educational programs to help combat inflation and to reduce the large number of accidents, which are claiming a serious toll of man-hours, will be major points of emphasis in the National Council of Women's 1943 program. During a closed conference of officers and new committee chairmen last week it was decided that these topics, in addition to post-war planning studies and work to "improve human relationships," would be the major themes of the year.

WITHIN the past twelve months the city of Detroit has changed its occupation. It has beaten its plowshare into a sword. In three or four months more it will reach the crest of the greatest flood of potential mechanical violence from any comparable area in all history.

MR. ELLIOT PAUL writes on page 78 of his book "The Last Time I Saw Paris" with reference to the 1923 inflation in Germany: "The next celebrity was Hugo Stinnes, the German-Jewish multimillionaire who made his fortune while others in Germany were starving in the streets."
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- A total of 4,415,922 fans clicked the turnstiles at American League parks during the 1942 baseball season, President Will Harridge said today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 9 -- The American air leader, Major Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, assumed command of the newly created Allied Air Force in North Africa today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- A number of Japanese will learn eventually that the funny money used by their country isn't so funny after all.

Many of our choicest hardy perennials are natives of cold climates, where seeds remain dormant until the Spring before sprouting. This means that over long years the need for freezing has become a fixed tendency. If gardeners have been disappointed in attempting to grow perennials from seed, it may be that they should have sown the seed in the Fall or Winter.

THE expert care with which the American Army is trained and nurtured nowadays is a far cry from the neglect it suffered in the earliest stages of its development. The army that faced the British in the Revolutionary War was ill-fed, ill-clothed and ill-housed.

Under the rule recently adopted by the American Kennel Club only two applications for judging licenses have been received for consideration by the board of directors at its meeting on Tuesday. One came from the Pacific Coast for a temporary license to judge cocker spaniels, the other from the Middle West to judge obedience trials.

PERHAPS the finest quality of this first novel is its direct human approach toward a most complex problem. Michael De Capite, himself a second generation Italian-American, tells about immigrants and American-born Italians in a simple, truthful manner.
ONE good thing about shortages is the way they're sending all of America scuttling out of its houses into the open air.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Congress in 1941, overriding all but a few suggestions for restrictive amendment, gave to the Executive a black check in the Lend-Lease Bill. Now Congress is displaying a strong wish to audit the account in greater detail than has been furnished by the President's periodic reports.
LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique :
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 9 -- British fighters for the second successive day strafed enemy trucks on the coastal road between Ziliten and Homs, about 85 miles east of Tripoli.

Clear and buoyant, the voice of Franklin Delano Roosevelt rang through the historic House of Representatives chamber last week and out over the air waves to the world. IIe was making his tenth annual address to a joint session of Cong-ress on the state of the Union.

OPEN SESAME: Lieutenant George Hambrecht, U.S.A.A.F., was forced down last week in North Africa. He knew no Arabic. The natives he met knew no English. They were suspicious until the flier spoke two words they understood. Thereupon they wined and dined him, assigned servants to wait on him.

Among the major local college basketball teams New York University now stands alone, proudly pointing to a perfect record. For last night, in the presence of 18,354 spectators at Madison Square Garden, the Violet overwhelmed Manhattan College, 64 -- 49, made it nine for nine and won for itself many new followers.

The prospective bride and bridegroom may ride to church in private cars for the wedding, and so may the minister and any other persons "necessary to the ceremony according to the customs of the church," but the wedding guests must walk or use the public transportation services, the Office of Price Administration said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- President Roosevelt repeated today a request he originally made on Sept. 6, 1939 -- that all local police officers, Sheriffs and other law enforcement officers promptly turn over to the nearest representative of the Federal Bureau of Investigation any information relating to espionage, sabotage and other subversive acts.

Re-enters Gramps Wiggins, the irrepressible oldster who loves murder mysteries, fictional or real, but preferably the latter. He finds one in the bailiwick of his grandson-in-law, District Attorney Frank Duryea, and he immediately declares himself in, completely disregarding the protests of the D.A., who considers Gramps's methods such as might possibly land the old gentleman in jail.

Travel Lines: The Seaboard Railway announces that women are being trained to augment porter service on their trains. . . . The Victory Book Campaign makes an appeal for books for travel-time reading for soldiers making long train trips.

Although the approach of classroom examinations will cause a drop in basketball activity for New York City collegiate quintets this week, several attractive games are on the schedule, with a Madison Square Garden double-header on Wednesday night as the high light.

New Yorkers are getting personal invitations to participate in civilian defense activities, and for the most part they love it. That is the gratifying preliminary report of 5,000 men and women -- vanguard of a tremendous corps now being enrolled as block leaders to quicken the war program through contact with individual families.

MISS JUSTUS'S new book is for an older audience than most of its predecessors, but the background is still the green heights of her native Cumberlands. Girls in their teens will find in Dixie, the spunky, level-headed mountain girl, an appealing heroine, for though she scarcely knew the meaning of the term, Dixie was in spirit a young modern, rebelling quietly but stubbornly against her family's acceptance of poverty and illiteracy.

The State Athletic Commission's lightweight eliminations will be sidetracked for a time on the local fistic front. Injuries, sickness and the indifference of some of the eligibles led to this announcement yesterday by Matchmaker Nat Rogers as he strove to present a suitable card to pull the customers into Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

To enable students to get an Increased amount of pre-military training in the limited time they will have before entering the armed forces, and at the same time to complete the regular liberal arts work at a pace determined by their individual abilities, Colgate University has made a series of revisions in the introductory phases of the fifteen-year-old Colgate Plan for Education, President Everett Case has announced.

ANKARA, Turkey Jan. 7 (Delayed) -- The severe case of Axis jitters over the concrete improvement in Turkish-Russian relations, which began in the middle of December when the writer disclosed British-American progress toward this goal, appears to have reached the fever stage in Rome and Berlin.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9 -- Wait A Bit, 4-year-old son of Espino, owned by William Ziegler Jr., easily won the Shreveport Handicap, six-furlong dash that topped the Fair Grounds program today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- To meet the shortage of professors and instructors due to the war, colleges and universities are lengthening the workday and discontinuing some courses, the United States Office of Education reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The pay-as-you-go method of collecting income taxes, spurned in Congress last year except for a trial at the 5 per cent Victory levy, is now being embraced on all sides. Predictions are free on Capitol Hill and in downtown Washington that it is on the road to adoption and application, in some form.
MONTREAL, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Canadiens pulled out of the National Hockey League cellar tonight, passing the idle Rangers, by defeating Boston, co-leader of the loop with Toronto, 7 to 2.

WITH the publication of "Wide Is the Gate" Upton Sinclair has completed 2,981 pages of his indefinitely continuing pictorial presentation of the history of Europe since 1918. The chronicle started in June, 1940, with "World's End" (740 pp.), picked up in March of 1941 with "Between Two Worlds" (859 pp.) and went into its third installment just a year ago at this time in "Dragon's Teeth" (631 pp.).
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Among seven pending by-elections, several interesting contests are shaping up.
IN kindergarten, Mary Kay was a "bossy" child; Marjorie tried to monopolize the teacher; Norbert spent most of his time watching the other children; Karl was shy.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Jan. 9 -- New Zealand is being organized as an American shipyard, Shipbuilding Controller James Fletcher disclosed today. New Zealand's organization, which in the past three years has established a praise-worthy naval building setup for her own needs, will now be utilized to help meet America's wants, Mr. Fletcher said.

A strong stand in favor of continuation of a full program of tournament activity in 1943 was taken yesterday by the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, in annual session at the Hotel Vanderbilt, and was endorsed by the national president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (Science Service) -- Several nationally known names are included in the list of inventors to whom patents were wanted by the United States Patent Office this week. Among them are John Hays Hammond Jr., well-known engineer; Dr. Robert H. Goddard, leading researcher on rocket propulsion, and John K. Northrop, Los Angeles airplane Manufacturer.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTEALIA, Sunday, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Communique:

BURBANK, Calif., Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Constellation, a new sky giant of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, soared away on its maiden flight today after a brief delay caused by a backfire which set one of its four powerful motors ablaze.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Problems of State finance as affected by wartime economy were brought to the front today as Governor Dewey revealed the make-up of the Committee on Taxation which has been consulting with him since his election and then spent the afternoon and evening in conferences with John E. Burton, his budget director, on the executive budget message.

The two main obstacles hindering the adoption of the Ruml pay-as-you-go tax plan are, 1, the assertion that a loss will result to the Treasury of one year's revenue, and, 2, an aversion to granting a "windfall" to the larger taxpayers whose income tax would be canceled.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- The pro-Axis newspaper Chileno, and Opinion, a newspaper published by former Foreign Minister Juan B. Rossetti, today published unconfirmed reports that Presidents Juan Antonio Rios and Ramon S. Castillo, of Chile and Argentina, respectively, would meet on the frontier.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 9 -- General Jean de Lattre de Tassigny was sentenced today to ten years' imprisonment for "acts of such a nature as to endanger the safety of the French State."

American use of petroleum has groom by leaps and bounds during the past quarter of a century. The black gold that flowed from American oil fields was the basis of the motor age that created new industries, changed transportation and social habits, wrought a revolution in the nation's life.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Jan. 10 -- A mighty victory of the air -- at least seventy-seven Japanese planes shot down, with the figure for probables and grounded planes soaring the total to around 100 -- was scored in a three-day, round-the-clock attack on a New Guinea-bound Japanese convoy which suffered three transports sunk and at least three others badly smashed.

THIS quidnunc certainly doesn't want to build up a situation which has been officially played down as a tempest in a teapot, nor do we wish to fabricate alarm. But the news as reported in these columns by our Hollywood correspondent last week has an ominous implication which cannot be lightly dismissed.

When we are fighting mad two little glands which are called adrenals and which lie above the kidneys are aroused to chemical action. The glands pour out adrenalin. Some classic experiments made years ago by Dr. Walter B. Cannon (Harvard) have shown how essential adrenalin is in the emotional life of all higher animals.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Russia's attitude toward her neighbors on the western frontier after the war is subject to considerable speculation and it was that, in the view of diplomatic circles here, that General Wladislaw Sikorski, the Polish Premier, had in mind when he declared in New York today that a strong Central European federation would constitute the firmest guarantee for a lasting, just, democratic peace.

THERE is more than a superficial timeliness in the publication of that fine anthology "The Wisdom of China and India," edited by Lin Yutang, which was reviewed in last week's issue. We are becoming increasingly aware that in the difficult task of world reconstruction there must be political and economic cooperation between the peoples of East and West, and that there must be a real effort toward mutual understanding and appreciation.

A CHIP off the old block was Jeff Burton, who lived with his widower father near Trail City, a river town in Oregon; the old pioneer had trained the boy early in the expert handling of firearms, taught him all he knew of forest lore, imbued him also with his stanch patriotism, love of the land and an idealism at once practical, individualist and characteristically American.

CHUNGKING, Jan. 9 -- Although President Roosevelt's annual message to Congress was not intended as an answer to recent editorial jitters in Chungking, it has had that soothing effect. The leading independent newspaper Ta Kung Pao, which was attacking "the new isolationism in the United States," a few days ago, feels happier this morning, and especially appreciates the President's statement that China's peace ideals are closely akin to America's.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9 -- Cornell University defeated Harvard's basketball team tonight, 49 -- 34, for its second victory in two nights in the Eastern Intercollegiate League. It was the opening game in the circuit this season for the Crimson, which was no match for the tight-guarding Big Red five.

RIO DE JANEIRO, after long years of experimental broadcasting, now leads the way for Latin-American radio, by inaugurating an inter-continental service with government transmitters comparable in power to those of London and New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Rhode Island State's high-scoring basketball team chalked up a 60 -- 55 victory over St. Joseph's College, and Penn State defeated Temple University, 36 to 29, tonight at Convention Hall.

New York University, Fordham and St. John's competed in an informal triangular meet yesterday on the beard track at Ohio Field on the University Heights campus at N.Y.U. and the large Violet squad captured eight first places in the thirteen events held. Fordham followed with four.

In spite of dire predictions and reports of shortages, visiting buyers were able to place substantial orders for practically all of their early Spring needs, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- As the Seventy-eighth Congress got under way this week the question of whether the Special Committee on Un-American Activities, better known in the headlines of the last four and one-half years as the Dies Committee, would receive a new lease on life -- and, of course, an all-important new appropriation -- came to the fore.

PAOLO GALLICO, pianist, composer and teacher, will give a recital Tuesday night, Jan. 19, in Town Hall, which will mark the fiftieth anniversary of his first appearance in this city. Born in Italy, he began his musical studies at the age of 11 and at 15 entered the Vienna Conservatory, where Anton Bruckner was one of his instructors.

Visiting England on war duty, I was greatly impressed with the amount of ground that was set aside for growing vegetables in every home garden. In addition, wherever I went I saw "allotments" of ground that had been rented for nominal sums and pressed into use for growing both vegetables and fruits.
Comfortably in front during a major portion of the encounter, Fordham's well-balanced varsity basketball team defeated previously unbeaten Columbia, 52 to 44, last night in the latter's gymnasium.

While post-holiday travel has not slumped as much as in other years, a person unskilled in football tactics can now get to a ticket window and, if he has the price, buy a ticket to any part of the United States. In the hectic days just before Christmas it appeared as hopeless to try to get a ticket to Florida or intermediate points as it would be to get one to Mars.

THIS book is a comprehensive, thoughtful and vivid account of the fascist regime in Italy. from its impressive beginning, when the trains ran on time, to its black and dismal present, when not only the Pontine Marshes but all Italy have been drained and Mussolini is tumbling with his country into general ruin.

Of Russia's 5,100,000 battle losses, the Russian War Relief, Inc, says 2,000,000 are back in the war, 70 per cent again as fighting soldiers. With this announcement the bureau tells the first story of another of this war's medical miracles.

A prison sentence of two years imposed in 1940 on Robert William Wiener, financial secretary of the Communist party, convicted here of the misuse of a United States passport, was suspended yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox, who fined Wiener $2,000 and ordered him placed on probation for three years.

Bonnard and Vuillard, appropriately enough, are paired at the Rosenberg -- appropriately, because, while the work of one may not be mistaken for that of the other, these two French artists reveal much in common, and they were close friends until separated by the latter's death in 1940.

After hailing President Roosevelt's leadership and pledging him their "whole-hearted and united support," a victory conference of foreign language editors at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday resolved to organize a "victory council" to effect a greater unity among the foreign-born and to mobilize their full strength to defeat the Axis.

FOR those with a special weakness for the massive charms of hippopotami this picture-story book will furnish much amusement, for within its large, handsomely printed pages are to be found all sizes and ages, their rotund curves emphasized by snugly fitting Eighteen-Ninety costumes.

The Red Army two months ago seemed strained to the utmost. Its leaders were calling for the establishment of a second front in Western Europe to help lift the weight of German military might under which it labored. For more than a year and a half it had been locked in a grim, wearing strug* gie with the Wehrmacht.

EVEN the quite young have an opportunity these days to learn something about vocations, and, judging by the number who can rattle off initials and numbers of all types of aircraft without the bat of an eyelash, an overwhelming number of them are going to be aviators.

BUSINESS reaction to the annual message of President Roosevelt to the joint session of Congress in the week was only partly favorable, judged by various comment. The principal criticism was that certain basic issues in the war program received little attention beyond the offhand explanation that in all such undertakings mistakes are bound to occur.

The Soldiers and Sailors Club in New York, 283 Lexington Avenue, will hold its annual meeting and luncheon tomorrow at the Plaza, commemorating the twenty-fourth year of the organization's existence. William M. Chadbourne president of the club, will preside and the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray will pronounce the blessing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- When the government this week outlawed all but necessity motoring in the seventeen Eastern States, it may have seemed to some persons in that area that it was practically forbidding the use of automobiles for the duration.

Victory over Nazi Germany will come through the might of the United Nations and the massed hatred of the oppressed peoples, but will be merely a prelude to the vast task of working out a just, democratic peace, General Wladyslaw Sikorski, Prime Minister of Poland and Commander in Chief of the Polish Armed Forces, declared yesterday at a reception given in his honor by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall.

The basis which government price adjustment officials have indicated will be used for renegotiation of cotton textile war contracts, previous handling of which had been officially criticized by the Cotton-Textile Institute, will be the Treasury Department's income-tax statistics of the industry's annual income and profits, it was reported yesterday in the Worth Street market.

On this page you see a one-room apartment, once the parlor of an old New York house, equipped with a separate dressing room, thus eliminating a major drawback of many one-room apartments -- that one must dress in the living room. A plywood partition built diagonally across one corner of the room forms the dressing room, which is lined with closets and chests.

TO the artist, by which I mean any creative person, there are two fidelities, the one he gives to his work and the one he gives to the person he loves. They are both equally important, for they are the interlocking roots which nurture his growth.

For the first time in twenty years a Republican Governor addressed the opening session of the New York Legislature at Albany. .Thomas Edmund Dewey, pcaking from the polished mahogany rostrum of the Assembly chamber, marked the occasion with an address that seemed aimed not only at the Empire State but at an audience beyond its borders,

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Florida's Gulf Coast area is operating this Winter on a wartime schedule, with accommodations limited and activities curtailed. Fort Myers, Bradenton and Tampa are busy building battleships and amusing soldiers on furlough.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9 -- Radcliffe Heermance, director of admissions at Princeton University, announced today that Princeton would not change its admission requirements for high school students despite the recently announced modification for enlistment in the Navy's program.

To advance the work of its Children's Health Service, the New York Diet Kitchen Association has taken over as a benefit the second performance of Sonja Henie's Hollywood Ice Revue at Madison Square Garden on the night of Jan. 19.

Two dangers are developing that will affect the operation of the WPB inventory regulation -- pressure by manufacturers upon retailers to take in Fall staple merchandise as soon as ready and "chiseling" that will put at a disadvantage the honest retailer and manufacturer, according to Harry W. Schachter, president of the Kaufman Straus Company, Louisville.

Several paintings by Jean Frederic Schall, French artist of the early nineteenth century, brought high prices yesterday at the final session of the auction of art works owned by the late Conde Nast, New York publisher. The total receipts for the session held in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, were $64,960, bringing the grand total for three days to $101,362.

The official' 'documents nations publish to explain their views on foreign affairs usually 'derive their names from the color of the covers. Each nation has its traditional color. Thus Great Britain and Germany issue .White Books, Mexico and Italy Green Books, France and China ellow Rooks.

Ernst Wolff, German singer who showed he was an interesting musician when he accompanied himself at his first recital here a little less than two years ago, last night gave his second Town Hall recital. This time, however, he was accompanied by Franz Rupp and the appeared as a tenor, for he has changed his voice, which was formerly baritone.

This year may bring wage increases to some 300,000 women and minors in New York State. The need for revising minimum wage orders covering 160,000 such workers in six service industries, and for an additional order to affect 163,000 in retail trades, is the main point of emphasis in the annual report released today by the Division of Women in Industry and Minimum Wage of the State Department of Labor.

In this war of machines the mechanic is as important as the soldier. Tanks and guns in need of repair can't be sent back to the factory. They must be fixed on the field of battle, and they must be fixed without benefit of the overhead cranes and hydraulic presses that are the trademark of Detroit.

IT would be most unfair to the fair readers of this little love story to disclose the plot, which scrambles up the emotions of a quartet of nice young New Yorkers until they don't know themselves who loves whom. Most of the time they are pretty noble about it, but Curt knew he wasn't doing the right thing when he didn't tell Katharine he was engaged to marry Nicole.

Despite the fact that Mrs. Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt Di Cicco, 18-year-old heiress, paid most of the bills for her marriage to Pasquale Di Cicco, Hollywood actors' agent, and helps support several members of her family, she still had left unspent about $4,000 from the income earned by her $4,3341,723 estate last year.
LONDON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Catholic priests in Belgium are helping to organize resistance against German rule, a Belgian refugee reported today.
