The hardy little snowdrops scarcely wait for the snow-covering to melt from off the garden beds before they shoot up their green leaf spears and dainty white flower bells. Each Spring gardeners watch for them eagerly and never fail to be thrilled when the first blossom is spied.

ANKARA, Jan. 8 (UP) (Delayed) -- Reliable informants, in direct touch with Bucharest, said today that a purported Iron Guard plot against Ion Antonescu, Rumanian Chief of Government, was devised by Antonescu himself to give him an excuse to eliminate opposition elements.

Propulsion equipment of the diesel-electric drive type was produced last year by the General Electric Company at a rate of 50 per cent more than the record year of 1941, according to a report issued last week by J.W. Belanger, manager of the company's federal and marine department.

The thirteenth annual judges' and exhibitors' course sponsored by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State will begin Tuesday and continue through Friday in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. In addition to the lectures and exhibits previously announced, ten-minute talks on the gardeners' share in the war effort will be given each day.

Wood has been designated a critical material. Yet it comes forward in wartime with the basic qualities that permit its use as a substitute for even more critical materials. Its use in some articles of household equipment and furnishings has saved up to 80 per cent of the metal formerly going into them.

HONOLULU, Jan. 9 -- Hawaii must retain martial law, Mayor Lester Petrie of Honolulu declared today at a press conference. "The people of Honolulu recognize that we are still in this war and that the danger of attack is just as real today as it was a year ago," he said.

Thomas D. Thacher, former Federal judge and United States Solicitor General, has consented to serve as the city's Corporation Counsel for the duration of the war, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday at City Hall. Mr. Thacher will take over within a week or ten days the post left vacant when Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler obtained leave to become a lieutenant colonel in the Army.

Adding another link to the proposed round-robin chain of exhibition games among New York's three major league clubs in baseball's streamlined Spring training plans, the Giants, through Secretary Eddie Brannick, announced yesterday they had booked three encounters with their arch foes, the Dodgers.

SUCCASUNNA, N.J. -- Sitting in front of a blazing fire toasting marshmallows and toes is a pleasant way to spend an afternoon when the cold winds are howling outside. Riding is presumably the main attraction at a dude ranch, and the horses need their exercise, but the large lounge room, with the warmth of the fireplace assisted by a few radiators -- is the heart of a Western-type furlough.
Connecticut sportsmen believe that there is not likely to be any scrapping of the State's general conservation program, judging from the references in Governor Baldwin's inaugural address.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- Thousands of homes will be without heat before the close of the week-end unless Westchester receives a supply of fuel oil in the next twenty-four hours, Gustave J. Burrell of Portchester, president of the Westchester Oil Trades, telegraphed Governor Dewey today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Government sources said today that President Roosevelt could be expected to make known his choice for the Supreme Court vacancy soon, possibly Monday, and the name of Wiley Rutledge of Iowa, Associate Justice of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, headed the speculation.

NEVER having written Gandhi a bread-and-butter -- or shall I say spinach-and-curds -- letter, the least I can do is to defend him against Mr. P.W. Wilson's amusing yet less-than-pleasant charge that the Mahatma was a bad host. Wilson is wrong; Gandhi did set me at ease.

DR. LUIS QUINTANILLA, until recently Mexico's Minister Plenipotentiary to Washington, is known as a man who says what he thinks. Few nations any longer dress up their diplomats in tail coats and spats and send them out on social errands, but even in these times of changed conventions Dr. Quintanilla has stood out in Washington's diplomatic circles perhaps as sharply as Benjamin Franklin did in Europe, and for somewhat the same reasons.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 9 -- On Christmas Eve the government by decree chose the Argentine national flower, the official choice falling upon a red bloom called the seibo, which though comparatively unknown anywhere but in this part of the world, flourishes in great abundance along the banks of the Parana and Uruguay Rivers and has been for years an established favorite among the Argentine people.

Irving J. Galpeer, noted for his work on the McKesson Robbins investigation, has been appointed principal attorney in charge of law enforcement in the New York regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission. He succeeds John Howley Kelley, who recently resigned to re-enter private practice with Ignatius Stone.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Real peace will come in the world, Vice President Wallace said today, "when we have a greater understanding of and sympathy for the peoples of other nations."

THE Ministry of Commerce of the Royal Norwegian Government in Exile at London has organized a postal service for the 25,000 Norwegian seamen sailing merchant ships and tankers for the United Nations, and for the officers and crews on sixty naval vessels operated by the Free Norwegians, and for the personnel of Norwegian military camps in the United Kingdom and Canada.

Stocks were firm and closed irregularly higher yesterday in the largest Saturday trading in two months. Due to activity in low-priced issues, the turnover on the New York Stock Exchange was 437,790 shares, against 259,940 a week earlier.

More than twenty years as director of a Children's Home left the impression with Dr. Erich Benjamin that "most of these children are suffering from the lack of mother's love." When Dr. Benjamin spoke on the subject of early social adjustment at the Child Research Clinic of the Woods School, he made this point for pediatricians and psychiatrists.

The writer of an article on General Giraud in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine says: "He [Giraud] is said to have shown nothing but disdain for men like Juin, who made peace with the Germans and was freed on condition that he would never take up arms against them."

Leaving to the Bolivian Government the explanation of the real causes for the recent strike of miners, Eduardo Fajardo, secretary of the Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, yesterday stated that the workers of his company receive the highest cash wages paid in that country and other benefits that make conditions in its mining camp there compare favorably with those in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Seventy-eighth Congress which convened this week is sniffing the winds of destiny. Its leaders already have dubbed it the "Victory Congress." It knows, partly because of its awareness of forces that are shaping the pattern of the war and partly because President Roosevelt told it so, that it may be the "Peace Congress."
MEXICO CITY, Mexico, Jan. 9 -- Edward P. Trueblood, United States consular attache in Mexico, will leave by plane tomorrow for Washington, where he will receive another post, it was announced today.

Mayor La Guardia will designate, probably tomorrow, a board to make a study of labor relations between the city and the 32,000 employes of its unified transit lines and to submit recommendations for their improvement, it was disclosed yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 9 -- German morale is suffering a severe test over the reverses in North Africa and Russia, if one may judge from the fluctuations in Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels's policies, hitherto infallible barometers of the state of mind in the rank and file of Germans.

Senator Charles L. McNary of Oregon, minority leader of the Senate, served notice yesterday that the Republicans of that body would demand a hearing and full investigation of the record of Edward J. Flynn if President Roosevelt nominates him for Minister Plenipotentiary to Australia.

A RICHLY interesting story of a pretty wonderful old lady is the new novel by Louis Bromfield. Mrs. Parkington is 84 now -- enormously rich, charming, tolerant. She has had no formal education, but is cultured and extremely well-informed, innocent and yet worldly, with an indomitable quality housed in her small slim body.

Two United Nations merchant ships, both of medium size, were sunk by submarines in the Atlantic and the Indian Ocean, respectively, it became known yesterday after the survivors had been landed in Boston and Miami.

Congressional leaders who have recently advocated the establishment of a joint committee of Congress to sit down with the Executive and the military to formulate war policies and war legislation can find a precedent for their proposed organization in the Civil War.

The Red Army, its flanks flung out over an eighty-mile front, is rolling on toward Rostov and the arterial route of supply for hundreds of thousands of German troops after sweeping aside more than 100 tanks and strong infantry forces that the enemy threw into a desperate counter-attack, the Russians announced in broadcasts early today.

In the light of the educational uncertainties of today it is interesting to see how the colleges and universities faced a similar situation in 1917-18. Many of today's college presidents were then either students or in uniform themselves, and thus not aware of the administrative aspects of the situation.

CHARLES TOWN, S.C., was one of the busiest ports and one of the most important cities in eighteenth-century America. It was wealthy and it loved luxurious living. There the Rutledges were secure in the inner circle of planter aristocracy, and for a time one of them dominated the political scene and elevated himself to a position of national importance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The forthcoming stringency of manpower in war industries is focusing attention on all causes of inefficiency and slow production. One of the foremost causes of a drop in production rates is absenteeism, whether due to avoidable or unavoidable causes.

President Roosevelt's address to Congress was hailed yesterday by rabbis here as an inspiration to the American people, giving assurance of the right conduct of the war and of equitable post-war reconstruction. Other sermon topics included Hitler's New Year speech and a tribute to the late George Washington Carver.

DETROIT, Jan. 9 -- Charles E. (Gus) Dorais, one of Notre Dame's first great gridiron players and the University of Detroit's athletic director and coach for eighteen years, moved into professional football today by accepting terms to become coach and executive of the Detroit Lions of the National League.

Uptown Hunter College, at Bedford Park Boulevard and Navy Avenue, the Bronx, is to be utilized by the Navy for the training of Waves, it was reported yesterday afternoon. This would be the first institution of higher education in the city to be used for the training of women naval reserves.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Flight Lieutenant Richard Hope Hillary, 23-year-old veteran of the Battle of Britain who wrote "The Last Enemy" [published in the United States as "Falling Through Space"], has died on active service with a Fighter Command, it was announced today.

THERE is something pretty close to downright dishonorable about anybody who will write about ballroom dancers in action, for if there ever was a public activity in which people were absorbed in their own doings without any sense of responsibility toward an audience, ballroom dancing is it.

I AM 18. A minor in the eyes of the law, a man by national necessity. Very soon now I shall be making the jump from drowsy lecture rooms to the crashing grimness of war. I am excited, like the rest of the fellows I know, and these days whatever else. I'm thinking about, that lies pretty close underneath.

The George Junior Republic, Freeville, near Ithaca, N.Y., in which eighty boys and girls from 14 to 21 govern themselves, is rebuilding its residence cottages to accommodate sixty additional "citizens," according to the annual report made public yesterday at the republic's city office, 175 Fifth Avenue.

A gasoline service station owner and two other men were arrested yesterday by officials of the OPA and police of the auto squad on charges of acting in concert in the attempted sale and purchase of ration coupons for 20,000 gallons of gasoline.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Corn assumed leadership today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, prices advancing around 2 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish to a new five-year high mark. The upturn carried September and the cash grain above the dollar level for the first tame since September, 1937.

AFTER Pearl Harbor, the Japanese sentenced Max Hill, former chief of bureau of The Associated Press in Tokyo, to eighteen months in prison. He was charged with having filed stories detrimental to Japan's diplomacy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Chairman Donald M. Nelson said tonight that the War Production Board had "solved most of the major problems of production," although it made "many mistakes" in gearing the country's industrial machine for war.

NO matter how acute the fuel oil shortage is likely to become, New York music-lovers won't have to shiver at their concerts. None of the large auditoriums is solely dependent on oil for heat. The Metropolitan Opera House is heated entirely by the coal-heated steam provided by the New York Steam Corporation.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- There is little danger of the Germans taking the offensive in Tunisia except in local actions, it is believed here. The capacity of their supply ports probably would not be sufficient for an offensive by a large force and they would have to advance about ninety miles along the coast over difficult terrain to capture Bone, Algeria, the next port of any consequence to the west.

THE mortality among the holiday theatrical arrivals was high, so high as to be practically overwhelming. Night after night, new plays put in a hopeful appearance to be met, night after night, with stony stares at the region they most hurt, that of the box office.

AS an innovation in its customary activities, the Metropolitan Museum is including the drama and the dance, as well as music, in two special programs. Angna Enters will present her "Greek Mime of Twelve Characters" at 5:30 P.M. on Jan. 25.

An audience of 3,000 crowded Carnegie Hall yesterday to hear Dr. Serge Koussevitzky conduct the Boston Symphony Orchestra in its second Saturday afternoon concert of the season. The program consisted of three Russian symphonies, Prokofieff's "Classical," Shostakovich's Sixth and Tchaikovsky's Fourth.

Adolphe William Bouguereau's "Nymphs and Satyr," the twelve- foot painting that hung back of the old Hoffman House bar at Broadway and Twenty-fifth Street in the Eighties and Nineties, has come to light, even if only briefly, after forty years in the dusty solitude of a warehouse.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Jan. 9 -- Favored with its finest snow conditions in several years for this early period of Winter, the Berkshires, mammoth skiing playground for New Yorkers, today found the problem of transportation too difficult to cope with.

FURS and fires can so temper extreme cold that even in the Frozen North it is possible for men to live without excessive discomfort, but unless air-conditioning can supply a partial remedy it is still impossible to do very much about extreme heat.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9 -- Despite some grumbling over ration rules, the majority of American citizens think the government's rationing program has been handled fairly.

IN answer to Mrs. Eda Rapoport, who believes that many people may take issue with the League of Composers regarding the policy to encourage commissions in lieu of competitions, I would like to bring to your further attention an important fact which is involved in this problem, although rarely discussed.

For "distinguished service to safety" E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. has received a special award of honor from the National Safety Council, based upon a record which all industrial firms could emulate with profit. In the last eighteen months thirty-eight of the company's plants have operated without a single reportable accident.

When the American and British forces landed at several places Algeria and Morocco on Nov. 8 the military power of the Atlantic world, bringing with it manifest promise of victory, knocked at the door of the French jail Would the prisoners rise with uplifted hands and join the liberators?

The remainder of this month has been designated as a "period of grace" to enable delinquents to register for Selective Service "and receive absolution," Colonel Arthur V. McDermott. New York City Director of Selective Service, announced yesterday.

The Federal income tax laws require that the earnings of minor children must be included in the return of the parent unless the child has become emancipated from parental authority under law, or if under the law the child is entitled to his own earnings whether emancipated or not.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- While one batch of workers was being tried today for illegally taking a New Year holiday from war jobs, Attorney General Herbert Evatt and Supply Minister John Beasley ordered 119 miners prosecuted for stoppages in the coal industry.

THE first week of the new year has dealt an odd assortment of gallery attractions. What my colleague encountered about town is reported elsewhere on this page. My own list contained three group exhibitions with no discernible common denominator and several one-man shows that proved likewise diverse.

CURRENT problem in culinary affairs is that of the ugly ducklings. Though they hardly need to be identified, these are foods of uninteresting character, the kind associated with the pallid porridge that is forced on your attention when you are too young to do other than submit.

GLAZED ONIONS are appetizing. To make them, boil the onions first, then allow them to dry on a paper towel. Melt two tablespoons of margarine for every pound of onions, add a tablespoon of sugar and stir carefully over a low flame.

ONE man and five women are showing paintings at the Sixtieth Street Gallery and, with apologies to gallantry, let it be said that the work of the man -- Michael Matera -- really stands out in the show. One canvas of a busy street scene at twilight and another of a side street with antique shops, together with a third of a deserted and weatherbeaten frame dwelling are forthright and arresting statements.
Nathaniel L. Goldstein, newly installed State Attorney General, made his first appointments yesterday, naming five Republican lawyers as assistant attorneys general.

Attorney General Francis Biddle filed yesterday a petition in the Federal court here asking for the appointment of a "three-judge expediting court" to hear as soon as possible the anti-trust suit brought by the government against The Associated Press.

A disposition to await possible amendments to MPR 287, the OPA pricing regulation covering women's Spring outer apparel, together with the fact that many manufacturers either withdrew or did not show their lines because of pricing difficulties under the order, featured developments in the garment industries last week when a large number of ready-to-wear buyers were in the market.
H.E. Grigg raises a fascinating question in THE TIMES of Jan. 4: What would happen were Hitler to run into Switzerland and the Swiss should refuse to deliver him to the Allies?

The Rangers return to the local hockey scene tonight when they oppose the Canadiens in a National League contest at Madison Square Garden. The Blueshirts played their last home game a week ago and they came from behind to earn a 3-to-3 deadlock with the Black Hawks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- President Roosevelt will be joined by other leaders of the United Nations in a broadcast on a Farm Mobilization Day program Tuesday calling upon American farmers for a record production of food for war needs.

THERE have been many great stories told of the courage and loyalty and strength of the men who fight today at sea. There have been undoubtedly many equally great which will forever remain untold. Not always are there survivors of mid-ocean meetings with the enemy.

A day-by-day account of the lives of 3,200 Americans and Britons held by the Japanese in the Santo Tomas internment camp at Manila was made public yesterday by the Committee of Relief for Americans in Philippines, 101 Fifth Avenue.

ARMY slang is bewildering enough to the average civilian, but in some Army camps the soldiers may be overheard saying things like "Ina Kuana" for "Good Morning," or 'Bayarda ni sigari" for "Let's have a cigarette."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, presented today for public consideration a plan to lessen the "inflationary gap" through use of present excess income to buy preferred claims on post-war durable consumer products not now available.

ONE of the suavest and most graceful of story-tellers, Norah Lofts seems to have a strong predilection for period atmosphere and color, and for stories which are laid in the past. Only twice, I believe, has she experimented with contemporary settings, and in neither case were the results quite successful.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Indicating a possibility that $15,000,000,000 to $16,000,000,000 in new revenue might have to be raised in the coming fiscal year, Chairman George of the Senate Finance Committee asserted today that Congress should adopt some pay-as-you-go plan, embodying a compulsory savings feature as a money-producing measure, before March 15, when the first installment of 1942 income taxes normally would fall due.

ONCE again the most important openings I have to record -- from an artistic point of view anyhow -- are of two American plays: Robert E. Sherwood's "The Petrified Forest" and Joseph Kesselring's "Arsenic and Old Lace."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 9 -- Adhering to the United Nations declaration regulating the transfer and control of Axis properties and on expropriations decreed by the Axis governments in occupied territories, Brazil closed the week today with a series of important measures directly or indirectly affecting the war.

BOSTON, Jan. 9 -- Executives attending the second day's session of the New England wartime sales management conference today under the auspices of the Boston Chamber of Commerce were told by practically every speaker that the needs of post-war selling can be filled only by salesmen who have been taught everything there is to know about their products and that sales training programs, therefore, would be of vital importance.

Retail trade continued active last week, with new Spring merchandise beginning to sell in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer-Both Reports.

Seasons come and go, hearts beat regularly, tides rise and fall. Everywhere we find cycles long and short. How important they are business men know. Some years ago, for example, the Hudson's Bay Company found that there were wide fluctuations in the number of pelts offered from year to year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Military and civilian demands on railroads have resulted in the conversion or scheduled conversion of nearly 800 lounge, club, observation and parlor cars into coaches or three-tier troop sleeping cars, the Office of Defense Transportation reported today.

Andrew Jackson High's five, defending City P.S.A.L. champion, registered its fifth straight South Queens division victory yesterday by topping Jamaica's scrappy five, 32 to 28, in one of the battles on the scholastic basketball quintuple-header at Madison Square Garden.
TORONTO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Detroit edged to within a single point of the Maple Leafs and Bruins tonight by routing the Toronto team, 4 -- 0, before 11,958 falls at Maple Leaf Gardens.
The German Caucasus armies commenced to withdraw last week from their hard-won positions in the Central Caucasus as the Russian armies continued their powerful drive toward Rostov.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 9 -- The Naval Academy basketball team, built around two veterans, Al Cameron and Urey Patrick -- opened the season today with a 38-to-22 victory over the Dickinson College five.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- American heavy and medium bombers in separate actions attacked Japanese areas and installations on Bougainville Island and at Rekata Bay on the island of Santa Isabel in the Solomon Islands Thursday morning (Solomons time) and inflicted losses and damage on the enemy, the Navy Department reported today.
John E. Slater, executive vice president of the American Export Lines, has left the company on a leave of absence to undertake an important administrative task for the War Shipping Administration.

Department store sales, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table of percentage comparisons with a year ago for the Reserve districts, for the last two weeks and the latest four-week period:
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The biggest wartime golf tournament for women, the Western open, will be held at Chicago's Glen Oak Country Club, June 28-July 2.

Though local importers said an acute shortage of coffee was developing here, reports from Washington yesterday indicated that there were adequate supplies of coffee to meet the rationing demand, and that the coffee supply situation was better now than at the outset of rationing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The War Department -- giving its tacit but qualified approval to the indoor sport of "handing out a line" to the girls -- today listed conceit, faith, enthusiasm and ignorance as the human characteristics which trap soldiers unwittingly into giving military information to the enemy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- With Harry Hopkins as its chairman, President Roosevelt has established a Russian Proctocol Committee in Washington to assure adequate treatment of Soviet Russia's requests for war materiel from the United States, it was learned today.
Driving to a tire inspection station is not a pleasure trip but a wartime duty for every motorist, the Office of Price Administration explained yesterday.

The parents of Walter Geiger of Jersey City, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Geiger, are residents of Germany and will have to wait until the war is over to learn that their son probably give his life for the United States.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, Greek conductor, gave the last public concert of his third engagement as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. At the conclusion the men of the orchestra joined with the audience in applauding him.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Another large and important convoy won through to England from America early in December, despite four days of almost continuous attacks in which escorting surface ships and airplanes beat off thirty-five separate U-boat attacks.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 8 (Delayed) -- "Got any news," Lieutenant General Joseph W. Stilwell ironically inquired when this correspondent turned up at the house on the side of the hill this morning at an hour no gentleman would consider decent.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- In the closest dinghy racing on record for five contests, four skippers tied today in the regatta off the Larchmont Yacht Club.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- British women who have had long and hard experience of wartime rationing are keenly interested in how the United States is going to tackle the same problem.

The report by Sir William Beveridge on social insurance and allied services is not revolutionary; it is evolutionary, broadening the field and liberalizing its benefits and increasing its contributions. It is well and clearly written and the subject-matter subdivided so that it makes an excellent presentation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Preservation of American opportunity is needed, as well as social security in the post-war period, Minnesota's Governor Stassen declared today in speaking on the University of Chicago Round Table program broadcast over a nation-wide network.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 10 -- Young French metal workers of Saint-Chamond who had been "designated for service in Germany" and who refused to comply voluntarily have been sent to the Reich under police escort, according to a dispatch printed in Swiss newspapers today.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 (AP) -- New York housewives are getting acquainted rapidly with margarine, a table fat that homes of World War I knew well and which was born of war seventy-two years ago.

The Union Square Savings Bank has sold to a physician for a residence and offices the five-story dwelling on a lot 16.8 by 102.2 feet at 13 East Seventy-seventh Street. The property is assessed at $42,000 and was sold through Pease Elliman, who report that this is the fourth town house they have sold in the last few weeks.

The decision by the Board of Education to close the schools the first week in February and keep them open during the usual Easter holiday period in April is a sensible move. With the schools' oil supplies cut to 45 per cent of their normal amount, the school plant faced the bleak prospect of operating part-time or curtailing everything but the barest essentials.

Substitute for the meat that continues to be scarce is poultry and, more especially, chickens. These are in excellent supply, the only drawback being the price, which averages more than it has for some years. Even so, it's wise to buy a fowl once in a while. For one thing, the bird remedies mealtime monotony.
A smart and most attractive black cocker spaniel was the star as the twenty-sixth annual specialty show of the American Spaniel Club opened in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

A survey by the manpower division of an official military agency has revealed that only 26 per cent of women students in colleges in the metropolitan area and New York State are enrolled in courses training them for war work to replace men, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Albert B. Newman, regional director of the engineering, science and management war training division of the United States Office of Education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The American public on the whole has been kept well informed about the war but there is considerable room for improvement in 1943, the American Council of Public Affairs reported today on the basis of opinions of political scientists, leaders of public-interest groups and public-opinion experts.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Performing in a style reminiscent of the great Norwegian ace, Reider Andersen, Arthur Devlin, 20-year-old Syracuse University freshman, spreadeagled a formidable field in winning most of the honors in the President Roosevelt Trophy ski jump today at Bear Mountain Park.
LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- A Soviet communique broadcast by Moscow Radio and recorded by The Soviet monitor:

A radio broadcast from Tokyo announces that the Japanese puppet government of Wang Ching-wei, the Chinese Quisling, has declared war against the United States and the British Empire. It is only fitting that this declaration should be announced not from Nanking but from Tokyo. The only thing remarkable about it is that it comes so late.

Salvation, the central doctrine of the church, is too often neglected, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said in his sermon yesterday at Christ Church Methodist, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street. He pointed out that before the role of religion can be plotted in the building of a better world, the meaning of the word salvation must be clarified.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Income payments of $10,394,000,000 to individuals in November brought the aggregate of such payments for the first eleven months last year to $102,357,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Last week's news from the battlefronts being favorable -- especially in the further advance of the Russian Army against the retreating Germans -- stock market averages at the beginning of the week went above the highest of 1942, but then moved irregularly.

After a three-week holiday layoff, the New Friend's of Music resumed its activities yesterday when it presented its ninth concert of the season late in the afternoon at Town Hall. The program, which was divided between Haydn and Schumann, was performed by the Gordon String Quartet, with Beveridge Webster, pianist, as the assisting artist.

The outstanding feature in silver in the last year so far as the United States is concerned, according to Handy Harman, bullion dealers, in their annual review of that metal, is the "transition of silver from civilian life to active service in America's war effort."

The reports issued independently and simultaneously by the Industrial Hygiene Foundation and Mrs. Anna Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, are in substantial agreement on the need of conserving the health of our war Workers.

That football should and probably would continue in 1943 was the consensus of nearly 100 men closely connected with the sport, as the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Football Officials held its annual meeting and luncheon at the McAlpin Hotel yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- United Nations successes in Russia and Africa appear to have set the stage for an early visit to Washington by Prime Minister Churchill or Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, reliable London observers said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A call to enact the heaviest budget in United States history, expected by some observers to exceed $100,000,000,000, will be submitted by President Roosevelt tomorrow to Congress, which will gather to hear his message accompanying the outline of the staggering war costs.

Liquidation of the WPA here has been somewhat delayed since the President's order for the winding up of WPA activities in sixteen States by Feb. 1, but is now proceeding apace, in accordance with plans, Major Irving V.A. Huie, WPA administrator for New York City, declared yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall, that he had appealed to the Office of Price Administration to put a stop to the "vicious practice" under which retailers of meat have been forced to pay premiums to wholesalers in order to buy supplies.

WITH THE AMERICAN AIR FORCES, in China, Jan. 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- Colonel Robert L. Scott, fighter group commander and leading ace of the China Air Task Force, is on his way home to teach young pilots Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's tricks, which have given his fliers a ratio of twenty Japanese planes destroyed for every loss of their own.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- A spokesman for the French military mission to the United States said tonight that he believed that the assassin of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan was a fanatical anti-collaborationist.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 10 (AP) -- A huge German ammunition dump at Tjoeme in Oslofjord has blown up and a large number of German soldiers were believed to have been killed or injured, reports from Oslo, Norway, said tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -The Economist's index of British commodity i prices, based on 1927 as 100, was i112.7 on Dec. 29, unchanged from i a fortnight before. It compares iwith 111.8 a month before, 108.5 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of i August, 1939.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Jan. 10 (AP) -- A communique:

N.Y.U., having hurdled two important obstacles in a week, Penn State and Manhattan, both of whom found a tight zone defense insufficient, has proved that around these parts the Violets have the basketball team most likely to succeed. To date, they have run up a string of nine victories and find themselves in a class by themselves, the only major unbeaten quintet in this area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Congressional leaders have been notified to expect several nominations from the President tomorrow as the Senate holds its first regular session. The expectation was widespread in the capital today that they would include these three:

A German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York said the defensive battle in the southern sector of Russia continued "with undiminished fierce-been repulsed with the destruction ness" and all enemy attacks had of twenty-six Soviet tanks, according to yesterday's German communique.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 10 -- Attacking by day and night, Allied planes of the Middle East Command are battering enemy trucks and positions from Wadi Zemzem to Tripoli in a manner reminiscent of the efforts that twice played an important part in precipitating withdrawals by the Africa Corps.

The chief concern of advertisers over curtailment of print paper for publishers this year is the possibility of unbalance in publications and eventual rationing of advertising space if further paper cuts are made, according to comment by advertising managers.

Mountains of iron ore were moved in 1942 to establish new records in the annals of the Great Lakes and the vast Lake Superior iron ranges, surpassing by a wide margin the record-breaking goal set by the War Production Board and safeguarding the steel industry against any reduction in the unprecedented pace of output until the next ore-shipping season begins in the coming Spring.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 -- Although production of steel here rebounded last week to slightly above 100 per cent of rated capacity, raw steel production throughout the country was estimated at 98 per cent of rated capacity, unchanged from the week before.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Refusal of farmers to sell their surplus free grain, combined with an aggressive milling and industrial demand, sent prices soaring last week, all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats, rye and soy beans except May rye selling at new seasonal levels.

NEWCASTLE-ON-TYNE, England, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- Herbert Morrison, Minister for Homo Security and Home Secretary, today pledged Britain to the organization of the post-war world along the broad lines of international cooperation outlined recently by President Roosevelt and Vice President Henry A. Wallace.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10 -- The Germans are fighting tenaciously to retain positions on all fronts, but the pace of the Russian drive, led by great tank forces, appears to be increasing. The Germans are straining every effort to stem the Russian advance toward the spa region of the central Caucasus.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Jan. 10 (AP) -- One hundred and thirty-three aircraft destroyed, probably destroyed or damaged was the ruinous price the Japanese paid to provide the most formidable and persistent air cover to date for a convoy attempting to land reinforcements at Lae, New Guinea.

Branding as "incorrect" statements that the steamship Lafayette, formerly the French luxury liner Normandie, was "gutted by fire" at her North River pier berth Feb. 9, when she burned and capsized, Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh, in a statement yesterday of the activities of his department in the last year, declared that the fire was under control less than three and one-half hours after the arrival of the first fire apparatus.

As part of an over-all program to help farmers in this State obtain competent, year-round help and alleviate the labor shortage, a new program to train women for dairy and poultry farm work will be started at the Farmingdale Agricultural and Technical Institute at Farmingdale, L.I., next Monday, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission.

NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 10 -- The Twelfth United States Army Air Force hammered a German airfield ten miles south of Tripoli yesterday in the first Allied bombing attack from this area on a target in Tripolitania.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Persistent reports that ceiling prices will be raised on some lines of pork products tended last week to slow down trading in those lines on the Board of Trade, and the business put through was at ceiling levels generally.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Governor Dewey directed the State police here today to conduct a Statewide survey on reports of widespread shortages of heating oil and deliver their findings to him "at the earliest possible moment."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 -- At a unique midwinter commencement, unprecedented in its 307 years of existence, Harvard College today gave a hail and farewell to its many sons about to enter the armed services. Of its 3,300 undergraduate students, 1,600 are leaving the peaceful classrooms for the battlefields, abandoning, temporarily, the traditional torch of liberal learning, started here three centuries ago, to pick up the sword and musket.

The outcome of the world upheaval will not be settled on the military, industrial and agricultural fronts alone, but will depend on what quality of spiritual faith and life takes possession of the nation and world, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday morning in his sermon in the Riverside Church.

WITH THE AMERICAN AIR FORCE IN CHINA, Jan. 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's bombers and fighters raided Japanese warehouses and river transports at Bhamo in Burma today for the second day in a row, starting fires in the town and sinking at least one barge.

Mrs. Max J.H. Rossbach, niece of former Governor Lehman, is the new director of child care for the American Women's Voluntary Services in this city, it was announced yesterday at the Greater New York headquarters. She succeeds Mrs. Samuel S. Duryee, who resigned because of the pressure of other duties.

" The Moon Vine," the new Patricia Coleman comedy, will go into rehearsal today under John Cromwell's direction, which means it should be opening Feb. 8 or the next night at the Morosco. The cast includes Haila Stoddard, Philip Bourneuf (who will leave "Arsenic and Old Lace" in two or three weeks, despite his recent assertion he would not), Arthur Franz, Dorothy Sands, Will Geer, Frederika Slemons, Julia Rainey, A. Winifield Hoeny and Hale Norcross.

A LEFT-HANDED monkey wrench or a left-handed baseball bat are manufactured in the land of fantasy. Left-handed hockey sticks -- as well as right-handed and neutral ones -- are manufactured in both the United States and Canada. Furthermore, all hockey sticks have such a variety of angles that they are numbered from one to ten like a set of graded golfing irons.
BROOKHAVEN, L.I., Jan. 10 -- Persons who fear a severe war food shortage might take a page from the cook book of Mrs. Alex Kosenkranius of Montauk Highway, this village.

Within a week, New York City will face the most desperate coal-fuel situation in its history because of the complete absence of a reserve supply of hard coal, according to Morton Wormser, an official of the Morton Coal Company. This condition will obtain even though the miners should return to work this week, he added.

The few passenger cars that mingled with the taxicabs on New York City highways yesterday were targets for pedestrian stares, and in some cases for official investigation, while the broad concrete highways of Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey were so bare that it seemed as though a blight had killed off the usual Sunday stream of pleasure vehicles.

The Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of the Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, in a sermon yesterday on "What Are We Fighting For?" declared that there never would be a war to end war, but only a peace to end war.

A round-the-clock, three-day attack by Allied air fleets on a convoy attempting to reinforce the enemy base at Lae, New Guinea, now appears not only to have wrecked the convoy but to have inflicted the most spectacular defeat Japanese land-based planes have ever suffered.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- The Navy released the fourth Merchant Marine casualty list today, listing 310 persons as dead or missing during the period from Nov. 22 to Dec. 21.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Horse racing folks in New Orleans, currently wondering how to extend their operations into springtime, may as well keep the track open indefinitely, according to sharp-eyed legal analysts here.

A new medical care plan involving more than 2,500 doctors, representing every hospital in the metropolitan area and covering all fields of medicine and surgery, was announced yesterday by Group Health Cooperative, Inc., a nonprofit medical service corporation with headquarters at 1790 Broadway.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 10 -- "Pending clarification" of Turkey's attitude regarding eventual deliveries of chromium under the new German-Turkish accord, scheduled to begin Feb. 1, the Germans are reported from Budapest today to have stopped all shipments to Turkey.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at the previous week's level of 109.8. Price increases and decreases occurred almost entirely in agricultural products. The most notable individual price rises were those in wheat, potatoes, cotton and milk.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Four million women are working in war plants, out of a total war labor force of 17,500,000, Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Chairman, said today, and he predicted that soon one out of every four war workers would be a woman.

There are two kinds of boundaries that will plague the peacemakers. The first are those drawn on the ground, the fences which mark title to territory, and while in theory these are reserved for after-war consideration, actually they are already the subject of the old claims and counter-claims, particularly in Central and Eastern Europe.
The report at hand from the New York Conservation Department is the kind that no one likes to receive. It is the annual accounting of hunting accidents.

Five hundred thousand housewives on New York City have made a check-up of their homes for accident hazards, the Greater New York Safety Council reported yesterday, disclosing that "with returns to date, with the high percentage of inspections reported, are most encouraging."

The Italians yesterday reported military casualties of 6,448 men in December -- including 1,449 killed, 2,933 wounded and 2,066 missing -- with more men dying in guerrilla warfare and from other causes in the Balkans and other occupied lands than fell in Russia, The Associated Press said.

The diamond jubilee of the founding of Epiphany parish was celebrated yesterday morning with a solemn pontifical mass at the Church of the Epiphany, Second Avenue near Twenty-first Street. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided and the mass was celebrated by Auxiliary Bishop Stephen J. Donahue.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Herbert Morrison, Minister of Security and Home Secretary, declared today at Newcastle-on-Tyne that without universal prosperity and security, no domestic policy could bring to the people of Britain the well-being they desired.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- The Admiralty announced today the loss of the submarine Utmost, one of the most famous and most effective of British submarines. She was commanded by Lieutenant J.D.W. Coombe, who at the age of 27 had several thousand tons of Axis shipping to his credit.

Replying to Ruth Kellogg's letter in THE TIMES of Jan. 8, where she still insists on "proper teaching and preaching" of good moral principles, what better reply could there be than Dr. I. Edwin Goldwasser's statement after many years as principal of P.S. 20, Manhattan:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 10 (AP) Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced today the creation of a committee to "coordinate and plan the rearmament of the French forces in North Africa with American equipment." The committee is headed by Colonel William T. Gardiner, a former Governor of Maine.

Having discovered that there is no comprehensive anthology of Russian fiction in print, Mark Aldanov and Leo Stilman have set out to do one for Scribner. Aldanov is the Russian-born novelist known for his trilogy of Napoleonic novels ("Ninth Thermidor," etc.); Stillman is a Sorbonne graduate, now an instructor of Russian at Cornell.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Our bombers have again hit at the Japanese air field at Munda on New Georgia Island, 150 miles from Guadalcanal in the Solomons, the Navy reported today.

The Boston Olympics notched two third-period goals and then held off the aroused New York Rovers to beat the locals, 5 to 4, in the main attraction of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

A council of the United Nations should be set up now as the organ for cooperative action in prosecuting the war and in organizing the peace, according to a statement issued yesterday by a group of thirty-eight Protestant leaders who have formed what they call the "Christian Conference on War and Peace."

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Royal Air Force bombers escorted by fighters attacked Japanese targets in and near Rathedaung, about twenty-five miles north of Akyab, in Burma yesterday and other fighter planes strafed a line of enemy trucks near Ingyi, northwest of Shwebo, a British communique said today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Jan. 11 -- Allied bombers, pursuing the remnants of a Japanese convoy that was battered for three days in the Lae area of New Guinea, have scored direct hits on two unidentified vessels and American troops have smashed to within a mile and a half of Sanananda Point in the New Guinea ground fighting, the Allied Command announced today.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER PLANE BASE, in England, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Second Lieutenant Frank Solinsky of 744 East Ninth Street, New York, was one of five American fighter pilots to be decorated for offensive exploits today by Colonel S.W. Towle of Clinton, Iowa, Chief of Staff of the Fighter Command, Eighth United States Army Air Force.

New State and municipal bond flotations in 1942 were only $94,932,000 in 1942, against $171,532,543 in 1941, according to tabulations by The Daily Bond Buyer. Priorities interfered with municipal construction work and reduced the total.

IN Miss Hull's new novel, "A Circle in the Water,"* a flawless girl -- one of the sort who cries only in secret and is always brave and beautiful when her husband is looking at her -- marries a young writer and, as she is a perfect wife and mother according to feminine standards, what happens to her shouldn't happen to a dog.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- A spokesman for General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner in French North Africa, predicted today that the French in North Africa and the Fighting French would join forces, "throw out all the Vichyites and go after the Germans."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 10 -- A movement to defeat President Riste Ryti of Finland at the election in that country Feb. 15 and replace him by Field Marshal Baron Carl Gustav Mannerheim appears to be taking shape within various influential Finnish circles, reports today said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Sharply critical of the way the armed services are handling armament procurement and noting "general concern" over the manner in which Paul V. McNutt's job as manpower director is shaping up, the Tolan committee, in its final report today, renewed its demand for a single civilian board to manage both war production and the civilian economy.
The New York Community Trust reported yesterday grants to philanthropic undertakings in 1942 totaling $547,261, compared to the 1941 total of $398,504.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10 -- Samuel Goldwyn has signed Dinah Shore to appear with Danny Kaye in "With Flying Colors," a musical comedy with a military background which Don Hartman and Allen Boretz are writing for Kaye's screen debut in the Spring.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Philip Murray made public today an eleven-point "C.I.O. Victory Program" calling for a broad social security system to establish freedom from want and for creation of a single administrative body to direct war supply, manpower and economic stabilization activities.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 10 -- Fifty-one-year-old Nils Flyg, one of the two recognized leaders of Swedish nazism and would-be-Quislings, died here suddenly from a heart attack, it was revealed today.

To what lengths may inhospitality go between friends? We should expect George Bernard Shaw to exemplify the maximum, and we are not disappointed when we explore his character through the eyes of Hesketh Pearson.

Generally the manufacturer faced with the question of making or buying a new part that is needed can answer it most profitably with "Buy," according to Dr. James W. Culliton, who has prepared a study, "Make or Buy," which will be released today by the Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration.

Despite the large number of buyers in town last week to make commitments for Spring on all types of merchandise, mail ordering continued exceptionally heavy, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

It is just as bad to scrub your work-smudged hands too vigorously as not to wash them at all. As a matter of fact, Dr. Louis Schwartz, medical director of the United States Public Health Service, finds that irritation and infection and all sorts of dire results have ensued in cases where workers and housewives have cleaned their skins not wisely but too well.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Heavy bomber squadrons of the Royal Air Force, including a large proportion of the four-motored Lancasters and many of them carrying two-ton bombs, attacked Essen last night, causing heavy damage to one of Germany's chief armament centers.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 10 -- Efforts to have more than 20,000 miners return to work failed today in the face of a midwinter shortage of hard coal in the Northeastern States which their strike, causing a loss of 30,000 tons a day, was making more acute.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Jan. 10 -- The 30-day racing season scheduled to begin here Feb. 22 literally will be a horse-and-buggy event if the Oaklawn Jockey Club's permit survives the opposition of Gov. Homer M. Adkins, who thinks all racing should be shelved for the duration.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 -- Cotton futures continued last week to

The designation of Police Consultant Cornelius F. Cahalane as general superintendent of the six interstate bridges and tunnels of the Port of New York Authority was announced yesterday by Executive Director Austin J. Tobin, along with a series of other changes in key positions affecting the operation of the crossings.

MOSCOW, Monday, Jan. 11 -- Red Army troops have seized thirteen North Caucasus towns forming a semi-circle around the important railway junction of Georgievsk, and cut all but one railway line running west of the city, the Russian communique announced today.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Changed emphasis on production of various types of war goods is reflected in ratings and allotments on Production Requirements Plan certificates for the first quarter of 1943, the magazine Steel said today.

" The V mail of daily prayer to the Holy Family" for husbands, sons and relatives in the armed forces was recommended yesterday by the Rev. Thomas A. Dunellen in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral as "the quickest, surest means of contact with those members of the family separated from us by he demands of war."

The Brooklyn Hispano soccer team, American League leader, gained the quarter-finals of the National Challenge Cup competition by defeating the German Hungarians, 3 to 0, at Brooklyn Oval yesterday before 1,500 fans in a third-round tie.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Former President Agustin P. Justo, 66, a stanch friend of democratic nations and an advocate of Pan-American solidarity, died here tonight after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage.

The Soviet Union may now be conisdered to have abandoned its original aim of world revolution, according to a compilation of documents on Soviet foreign policy in the January issue of International Conciliation, published by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
As the German armies of the Caucasus commenced to withdraw last week from their advanced positions near the Grozny oil fields, another Hitlerian ambition was unfulfilled.

A solemn mass was celebrated yesterday at the French Church of St. Vincent de Paul, 120 West Twenty-fourth Street, for the repose of the soul of Admiral Francois Darlan, who was assassinated in Algiers. The Rev. E. Galtier was the officiating priest and gave the absolution of the dead at the catafalque, which was covered with the French flag, with a tricolor floral tribute nearby.

Expectations that the New York Stock Exchange might move gradually to a ten-share unit of trading appear to have hit a floating mine. Although figures on spreads, some of which were published in October, have shown that the new system gives the investor a more responsive market, data on volume for the sixteen stocks cut from 100-share to 10-share units have not been encouraging.

America and Americans have based their ideas of progress on shifting sands, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Sharp increases in accidents during dimout hours have brought warnings from city authorities to pedestrians to wear something white when on the streets after dark. This admonition stimulated Helene Garnell, fashion designer, to devise various ways of manipulating a length of sheer white chiffon -- a nonpriority material -- to serve both as a protection for the woman who wears it and as an integral part of her costume.

Rose Bampton, Marjorie Lawrence and Bruna Castagna will be heard next week for the first time this season in regular performances at the Metropolitan Opera House, it was announced yesterday. This will be the opera's ninth week.
LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- "Brass hats" and gold braid, traditional trappings of the naval officer, are going by the board. The Navy announced today that, effective immediately, simple overseas caps are now the optional uniform headgear to be worn in place of the round stiff-visored hats heretofore required of all commissioned, warrant and chief petty officers.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 10 -- An account of stewardship during 1942 was made today by the National Life Insurance Company of Vermont. Its president, Elbert S. Brigham, reported to policy holders that "despite the dislocations caused by the war, review of your company's activities for its ninety-third year reveals most satisfactory results."

The campus and buildings of the Bronx division of Hunter College at Bedford Park Boulevard and Navy Avenue will soon be the site of the nation's largest training center for Waves and Spars, the Navy Department announced yesterday through the office of Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commandant of the Third Naval District.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- This is just a simple story about the First Lady of this democracy and a private in its army.

A NORTH AFRICAN PORT, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Far-reaching control by the British Fleet now is firmly established in the Western Mediterranean as a result of the North African landings, and sea supply routes to the Allied forces in Tunisia are being tenaciously and effectively guarded by powerful units of the Royal Navy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- In a rough match, interrupted in the third period when Red Hamill and Johnny Stewart waged a fist fight, the Black Hawks defeated Detroit, 2 -- 1, tonight. The National Hockey League game was seen by the largest crowd of the season here, 16,264.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- The Boston Bruins regained sole possession of the National Hockey League lead by coming from behind in the third period to gain a 5-4 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight at the Boston Garden. Despite the ban on pleasure driving, this clash between arch rivals drew a crowd of 14,400, the largest of the season here.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Jan. 9 (Delayed) -- General Douglas MacArthur's Order of the Day issued today to mark the virtual conclusion of the campaign against the Japanese in Papua constitutes an official commentary on the character of the successful offensive as well as a tribute to the men who achieved the Papuan victory.

A five-man committee headed by Ignatius M. Wilkinson, dean of the Fordham Law School, was designated by Mayor La Guardia yesterday "to study labor relations in the city's transit system and to submit findings and recommendations."

Top honors in the Pekingese Club of America's fifty-first American-bred specialty show at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night went to the gray sable Ch. Jai Son Fu of Orchard Hill, bred, owned and handled by Mrs. Richard S. Quigley of Lock Haven, Pa.
This city is about to become the victim of panic-stricken laws hurriedly passed because of the Boston fire. It seems that the revolving door is to be the scapegoat in the process.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Although concerned with the future of State revenues because of the curtailment of civilian activities which have been taxable, Governor Dewey has no intention of backing down on his proposed change in the State's fiscal year.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- The year usually opens bullishly in the stock markets, and the current experience is proving no exception to this rule. After the customary year-end abstinence, the public is again clearly becoming investment-minded and has given the markets a flying start despite the recent tightening of anti-speculation action by the stock exchange committee.

With the President's endorsement of the principle of putting Federal taxation on a pay-as-you-go basis, the sentiment for the change is now all but unanimous. If Congress is to put first things first in the domestic field, it will proceed to adopt this change immediately.

A request for $141,209,407 for the New York City school budget for 1943-44, or $301,130 less than the amount available this year, was presented yesterday by Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, chairman of the Board of Education's finance committee.
Two former New York State champions held the leading places in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club at the conclusion of play in the fifth round last night.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- So far as it goes, which is not far, last week's decline of 3,405,000 in the circulation of the Bank of England is noteworthy. In the same week last year the decline was only 1,897,000, but in 1941 it was 5,403,000; in 1940, 7,189,000, and in 1939, 16,656,000.
Firing four shots past Jimmy Franks in the second period, the Canadiens of Montreal easily defeated the Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, 7 to 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A unit of the National Education Association expressed opposition today to plans of some colleges to admit 17-year-old students for one year on completion of three years of high school training.
The Stuart Machine Tool and Die Company purchased from the Eclipse Building and Loan Association the three-story building at 350 Halsey Street, Newark, N.J., through the Marks Realty Company.

LONDON, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Sergeant Merrel Wayne Fitzwater of Bozeman, Mont., one of 118 American soldiers brought to an American hospital in Britain from North Africa, told today how he and three other wounded men had lain three days outside Oran without food or water.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Corn developed independent market strength late last week, and the highest prices of the season were established yesterday following an announcement that the Department of Agriculture had revised its goal for the 1943 crop and asked farmers to plant 100,000,000 acres in order to assure supplies for a record number of livestock expected to be on feed during 1943-44.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 -- Airplane parts, in which wood is successfully used instead of metal, are rolling from assembly lines at the H.J. Heinz Company, food manufacturers, in a plant converted almost overnight into a vital war factory.

The cotton market continued its advance last week, establishing new high marks for the season. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange had net gains of 14 to 26 points, placing prices at levels 100 to 125 points, or $5 to $6.25 a bale, above those prevailing at the start of the season on Aug. 1.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Montgomery Ward Co. today made public a statement it had filed with the War Labor Board charging that the board had "sabotaged" the process of collective bargaining.

Severin Winterscheidt, former propagandist and instructor for the Nazi movement in this country, admitted yesterday under cross-examination in Federal court that he had considered his "German blood" and membership in the world-wide "German Reich" more important than any other citizenship, even at the time that he acquired United States citizenship in 1938.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A record-breaking $108,903,047,923 budget, of which $100,000,000,000 will go for war costs in the fiscal year 1944, was sent to Congress today by President Roosevelt, who asked for an increase in Federal receipts of $16,000,000,000 annually by the imposition of higher taxes, compulsory savings or both.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Legislative leaders accepted tonight as final the indications from Governor Dewey that he would not seek full powers for himself in connection with emergency war acts. They thereupon continued preparations for the extension of the State war council and the emergency acts under which it functions.

Bundles of old linen suitable for; hospital use in England, and light-I colored material tc make utility kits for women in the British armed forces, will be accepted as part of the admission fee at the scrap salvage cocktail party in aid of the New York Chapter o BundleB for Britatu, on Friday, at 484 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Dollar volume of chain store and mail order sales increased 8 per cent last November over the previous November, the Department of Commerce reported today on the basis of reports from a representative sample of such organizations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Roosevelt today sent the name of Prentiss M. Brown, former Democratic Senator from Michigan, to the Senate as his nominee for price administrator to succeed Leon Henderson, who has sent in his resignation as OPA chief.

Major Irving V. A. Huie, Commissioner of Public Works, who also has been WPA Administrator in the city since April, 1941, announced yesterday his resignation from the latter post and said that under President Roosevelt's directive of Dec. 4, a plan for the orderly liquidation of WPA in this city had been prepared.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- United States forces on Guadalcanal undertook a new attack yesterday (Solomons time) that appeared to involve the possibility of a drive to clean out the Japanese who still infest this island.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities as reported by the Federal Reserve Board today shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 6: Increases of $233,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $502,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $110,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted $347,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 11 (UP) -- Suspension of rowing for 1943 was voted tonight at a meeting of the Syracuse University athletic governing board, along with curtailment of the baseball schedule to eliminate five road games, leaving a card of fifteen contests to be played.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Secretary Morgenthau submitted the Treasury's annual report for the 1942 fiscal year to Congress today with the comment that the change from a national defense to a war basis had been reflected in "every aspect of the fiscal and other operations for which the Treasury Department is responsible."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Official Washington joined in the expressions of sorrow heard in the capital today over the death of General Justo, former President of Argentina.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Edward J. Flynn's translation from the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee to the field of diplomacy, which he himself announced last Friday, had its official beginning today when President Roosevelt sent to the Senate Mr. Flynn's nomination as United States Minister to Australia.

Because of the widespread opposition to the concentration program in the farm machinery industry, the War Production Board will telescope the limitation order, L-170 into the first six months of this year and issue a new order, permitting increased output, reports here yesterday indicated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The White House is short-rationing itself on butter as well as on coffee and sugar, and over the week-end had no meat other than a turkey which, arriving late for Christman, "saved the day," Mrs. Roosevelt told her press conference this morning.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 -- Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that "Love, Believe It or Not," a photoplay to be based on the wartime adventures of two citizens of the Union of South Africa, Olda Mehr and Dr. Benjamin Hermer, has been scheduled for production this season.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied commander in French North Africa, has telegraphed congratulations to General Draja Mikhailovitch, Yugoslav guerrilla commander, referring to his fighters as comrades in arms of the Americans, the Yugoslav Government in exile reported today.

In the new war-created economy that puts men first and money second, which will serve as the base for post-war planning, no nation will permit bankruptcy and ruin so long as men, materials and energy are available, Stuart Chase, noted economist, declared last night in an address before the Industrial Advertising Association in the Hotel Sheraton.

JERRE MANGIONE grew up in Rochester, among the Sicilians of Mount Allegro. When he was home he spoke Sicilian, according to the rule laid down by his mother, who didn't want to hear English in the house. His father, Peppino Amoroso, tried to make him a fatalist; the old man, an accomplished pastry cook and wine maker, explained all things as "destino."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Paul V. McNutt said today that manpower soon must be rationed to halt hoarding of skilled labor and correct unbalanced conditions in labor-shortage areas.

LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The regular Soviet midnight communique, as heard in London by the Soviet monitor, gave details of the Caucasus fighting. Soviet mechanized units broke through German defenses and pushed the enemy into Georgievsk and Minerainye Vodi, it said, and "on the heels of the retreating Germans our troops broke into the towns and after fierce fighting captured them."

A large collection of Russian furs, the first to be auctioned in this country in over a decade, attracted brisk bidding yesterday at a sale for the account of Amtorg Trading Corporation conducted by Lampson, Fraser Huth. When the crowd broke up in the evening almost the entire collection had been taken up.

Westchester County, N.Y., has awarded a new issue of $500,000 of tax anticipation notes to the First National Bank of Yonkers. The bank bid an 0.25 per cent basis for the notes, which are payable on July 7, 1943.

Wartime fashions are well under way. Conservation is the keynote of designer collections for Spring, 1943. Designers are giving Uncle Sam better than he asked for under the L-85 regulation calculated to save 100,000,000 yards of goods for war purposes.

On the basis of a compilation of documents on Russian foreign policy in the latest issue of International Conciliation, the Soviet Union is considered to have abandoned the aims of universal revolution which dominated the first years of its existence. This is an important pronouncement which derives added weight from the fact that it is published by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Louisiana's State Board of Education today placed a wartime ban on intercollegiate athletics at six State colleges in a resolution recommending that coaching staffs devote all their energies to well-balanced physical education courses.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The government today reopened its anti-trust suit to restrain James C. Petrillo and the American Federation of Musicians from halting the manufacture of recordings for public purposes. Judge Barnes in the Federal court here ordered Petrillo and eight officials of the union to appear next Monday to, show cause why a preliminary injunction should not be issued against them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The aircraft carrier Hornet, last carrier to be commissioned in the United States Fleet prior to the outbreak of the war, was sunk as the result of damage inflicted by the Japanese in the Battle of the Santa Cruz Islands on Oct. 26, 1942, the Navy announced tonight.

Champion Nonquitt Nola's Candidate, insinuatingly attractive black cocker spaniel with life and dash, last evening was awarded the highest honors of the twenty-sixth annual specialty exhibition of the American Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 11 -- A century of extraterritoriality, trade concessions and special privileges in China came to a quiet end at 4 P.M. this afternoon when a new treaty between the Republic of China and the British Empire was signed at the Foreign Ministry Building.
The ever-expanding field of electronics, which is steadily opening new horizons on America's industrial production front, has chalked up another milestone in the nation's war-production program.

One strong point in favor of Judge Wiley Blount Rutledge Jr., nominated yesterday by the President to fill the seat on the United States Supreme Court left vacant by the resignation of Associate Justice Byrnes, is that he has already had experience on the Federal bench.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The text of President Roosevelt's budget message to Congress was as follows:
Only two of the four seeded players remained in the tournament as the New York State amateur squash racquets championship reached the quarter-final round at the Downtown A.C. last night.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 11 -- Ignoring government appeals to return to work, members of the United Mine Workers of America, in revolt against the union because of an increase of 50 cents in monthly dues, kept fourteen anthracite mines closed today, crippled operations at three others and made inroads into the working forces at a fourth, cutting production by about 45,000 tons a day, to aggravate the fuel crisis in the East

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 11 -- American bombers swept far over Tunisia yesterday in the fifth consecutive day of a continued great air offensive aimed at preventing the Germans from concentrating ground forces for a prolonged defense of their present positions in Tunisia.

It will behoove you, at least for the time being, to conserve coffee with even greater care than you have been exercising. For a report published Saturday indicates that stocks are only sufficient to last -- if the present rationing system continues in effect -- for some six weeks.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- The appearance of Spencer E. Bates at a tax conference in the executive offices strengthened reports tonight that Mr. Bates would be named Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, to succeed Carroll E. Mealey.
Senator James E. Murray of Montana declared here last night that the government must take the public into its confidence in planning such measures as price control and rationing.

LONDON, Jan. 12 (Reuters) -- The London Times, in an editorial today discussing President Roosevelt's budget message, said it is an expression in financial terms of a war program which might well be considered fantastic but which the President was confident would be fulfilled if the nations manpower and resources were fully harnessed to the tasks of total war and if the necessity were recognized by all.

"THOSE first six weeks were pretty bad," said Master Melvin Ott with a visible shudder. "I was nervous and worried and jittery and scared. When I wasn't doing something I found myself thinking and planning. I'd get one idea, figure it was good and then discard it. I'd wonder if I should have let the pitcher try to get out one more hitter or if I should have taken him out one batter sooner.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Witnesses testifying under subpoena before Federal grand juries investigating violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law are automatically entitled to immunity from prosecution, the Supreme Court ruled by 6 to 2 today. Justice Roberts wrote the majority opinion, which was sharply opposed by Justtices Frankfurter and Douglas.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- Vice Admiral William A. Glassford Jr. declared today that Dakar is an air, army and naval base of the greatest potentialities but at present is without food, oil, ammunition or materials for handling a vast amount of shipping.

Loew's, Inc., in its earnings statement for the fiscal year ended last August, reports that the company's share of net profits, after provision for depreciation and taxes, amounted to $12,133,294, compared with $11,134,593 for the year ended on Aug. 31, 1941.

Leon Barzin, a resourceful program-builder, contrived a pleasant set-up for last night's Carnegie Hall concert of the National Orchestral Association. He turned the evening over to the music of young composers from Mendelssohn and Mozart to a trio living today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 11 -- Without waiting for any further action by the Supreme Court, the Argentine Foreign Ministry today instructed its charge d'affaires in Berlin to ask the German Government to recall its naval and air attache in Buenos Aires, Captain Dietrich Niebuhr, immediately.

Newsboys' House at 244 William Street, home of thousands of lost and friendless boys since 1872, will be formally turned over to the Coast Guard tomorrow morning, it was announced yesterday by the Children's Aid Society.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- German troops have taken over the custody of the American civilians interned at Lourdes, France, with the intention of removing them to Germany, the State Department reported tonight on the basis of advices from our Legation at Berne, Switzerland.

CANBERRA, Jan. 11 -- Edward J. Flynn's appointment as Minister to Australia, announced as it was by the Minister-designate himself, thus anticipating the customary simultaneous announcement from Canberra and Washington, has created an unhappy impression, altogether apart from other misgivings the change in American Ministers evokes.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 11 -- In Lourdes, France, yesterday, the American diplomatic and newspaper party awaiting exchange celebrated the opening of its third month of what amounts to virtual detention. According to private accounts received here, the observance was none too gay, as the realization was dawning that the waiting might be prolonged indefinitely.

The twenty-seventh annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers, Inc., will open with a private view from 4 to 6 o'clock this afternoon in the galleries of the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue (between Eighty-ninth Street and Ninetieth).
