WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--Wiley Blount Rutledge Jr., a 48-year-old Iowan, now Associate Justice of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, was nominated today by President Roosevelt to fill the Supreme Court seat left vacant by the resignation of James Francis Byrnes fourteen weeks ago.

Late yesterday afternoon commercial bank depositaries of the Treasury were notified that the Treasury will withdraw funds from government war loan accounts on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. For the entire country the withdrawals will amount to $192,100,000 on each day, of which the banks in the New York Federal Reserve District will yield $112,180,000 on each day.

Arbitration of the wage and hour demands of Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes Union, affecting loft buildings in the garment and fur section of the city, was agreed upon yesterday at a conference in the Hotel Commodore of union representatives with officials of the Penn Zone and Midtown Realty Owners Associations.

Small sailors vied with visor-brimmed toques, while berets blossomed in every version, from tiny flowered pancakes to wide ones of the Florodora type at Mme, Pauline's hat showing yesterday. She presented her Spring collection in her salon at 6 East Fifty-third Street.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 11 -- The death last night of former President Agustin P. Justo is a blow to the cause of the United Nations in Argentina. He was regarded by many observers as the only man with sufficient political skill and personal prestige to stand any chance of winning this year's Presidential election against a government candidate.

A contributing factor to juvenile delinquency, particularly in the war industry counties of the State, is the lack of parental care and the absence of mothers from homes because of war employment, according to social service workers and others who appeared yesterday before the State Department of Social Welfare hearing in the State Building, 100 Center Street, on trends in delinquency.

Cancellation of market events, as proposed by the ODT for the Spring furniture market, would be a "death blow" to smaller merchants, who would not only be deprived of the purchase of essential civilian goods but also would be unable to learn how to proceed under the government's complex rules, J.T. Meek, secretary of the Illinois Federation of Retail Associations, said yesterday.

Elliott Shapiro, vice president ofi Shapiro, Bernstein Co., music publishers, denied yesterday thatI his firm had at any time refusedI any wartime organization permis-I ston to reprint the words of "The t Caissons Go Rolling Along" for legitimate, noncommerciai wartime purposes.

Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum announced yesterday that on the basis of disciplinary reports for the First Army and the Eastern Defense Command during the last three months it was safe to assume that the service men today were better behaved and healthier than any American soldiers during the forty-five years he has been with the Army.

The President has presented to Congress a budget that calls for the expenditure of $109,000,000,000 in the fiscal year beginning July 1. This total is too huge to carry any real meaning to the mind. It is an abstraction that can only be compared with other abstractions.

Following the recent acquisition of complete ownership of The Best Foods, Inc., by Hecker Products Corporation and change in the name of the latter company to The Best Foods, Inc., the board of directors yesterday made numerous promotions among managerial personnel, announced by William J. Wardall, chairman, and L.G. Blumenschine, president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Mrs. Roosevelt's press conference this morning was shared by Mrs. Florence Kerr, assistant administrator of the Federal Works Agency, who reported on two public health and welfare programs financed in part by the Federal Government under the Lanham act.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- Independence Hall and adjoining buildings, all nestled in Independence Square, became a national shrine today.

The annual statement of the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company of Minneapolis, announced by O.J. Arnold, president, disclosed that insurance in force increased in 1942 to $498,544,076, a gain of $17,346,565 during the year, although new business was $888,099 less than the previous year.

A nine-room furnished apartment in River House, 435 East Fifty-second Street, has been leased for John L. Luse to Bernardo Braga, first vice president of Braga Brothers, sugar brokers. Braislin, Porter Baldwin, Inc., in conjunction with Wm. A White Sons, were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- President Roosevelt reported to Congress today that the Federal Government spent more than $15,000,000,000 on emergency relief activities from 1935 up to the end of the 1942 fiscal year last June 30. Most of the money, the President said, was spent by the Works Projects Administration, which the Chief Executive recently ordered liquidated because of the decline of relief activities due to absorption of excess labor by the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today at a press conference that the FCC had recently received "more than the usual number of complaints" about vulgarity on radio programs.

Sharply critical of Congress and "the upper classes," whom he charged with sabotaging the President's seven-point anti-inflation program, Earl Browder, national secretary of the Communist party, hailed "our Commander in Chief" for his uncompromising war against Hitler.
Travelers just out of Italy report an ostensible change in the attitude of German soldiers there, increasingly apparent during the past week, according to private advices to THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The soldiers listed by the War Department today as killed in action include:

A new series of textbooks that said to constitute a three-month aviation ground school course has been prepared by the McGraw Hill Book Company and will be released this month. The texts have been produced under the supervision of the training division of the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics to meet the special needs of men preparing to be pilots.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- In its first crop report of the new year the Agriculture Department today said that prospects for heavy production of farm products had never been brighter at this season.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first eleven months of 1942, issued yesterday by A.N., Williams, president, shows a net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges of $8,271,927. This was equal to $7.91 a share on the company's outstanding capital stock, and compares with a net of $6,079,274, or $5.81 a share, in the eleven months to Nov. 30, 1941.

NUTLEY, N.J., Jan. 11 (AP) -- The aircraft carrier Hornet was badly crippled by repeated attacks by Japanese planes, some of which deliberately crashed on the decks, with full bomb loads, Marine Private George E. Kindmark, a survivor, related.

Robert Ringling, senior vice president of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, announced yesterday that John Ringling North, president, and his brother, Henry Ringling North, vice president, had taken a leave of absence until the end of the circus's fiscal year in April.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Petroleum Administrator Ickes told directors of Russian War Relief today that he had received a communication from President Roosevelt this morning, directing him and other officials to give Russia preference in "whatever Russia wants and we can supply in munitions of war."

In the first installment of a report submitted to Mayor La Guardia yesterday, Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands charged the Bureau of Supplies of the Board of Education with extravagance, wastefulness and inefficiency in the purchase of school equipment.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Vaccines to prevent the common cold have been "a great disappointment," despite intensive medical research," and "there is good evidence that vaccines may produce little or no protection against diseases of the upper respiratory passages," Dr. Chester S. Keefer, Wade Professor of Medicine at the Boston University School of Medicine and director of the Evans Memorial and Massachusetts Memorial Hospitals, said here today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 11 -- Despite bad weather, the Allied air forces attacked German transport vehicles yesterday all the way from the enemy defenses near Wadi Zemzem to Sfax in Tunisia, where the movement of a large number of trucks was reported.

So important is the home front of the enemy in its bearing on our military strategy that by its correct or incorrect appraisal the lives of hundreds of thousands of American boys may be saved or lost. And healthy home fronts in the United Nations are essential to win the war.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Governor Dewey announced here today that the State-wide survey, made at his request by the State police, on the shortage of fuel oil had revealed that the situation throughout the State was not critical, but that several sections in Westchester and Long Island were hard hit, as were some of the large buildings in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Declaring food to be a primary weapon of war, President Roosevelt recommended in his annual budget message to Congress today that $837,000,000 in agricultural aid funds be appropriated to facilitate a program calling for a record output of farm products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- If the total ban on pleasure-driving in motor cars remains in effect for any great length of time, those country dwellers on whom the ruling is so much more harsh than citizens of the towns will be vigorously heard from through their members of Congress.

Last season the Columbia basketball team won two games, and at the outset of the current court campaign prospects were none too bright for the Lions. Paul Mooney, the coach for many years, had been commissioned in the Navy, a new coach was in charge and the re- turning talent was not of All- America variety.

The war yesterday disrupted the program of the Northern Baptist Convocation, the gasoline situation making it necessary to substitute 178 small individual meetings throughout the nation, in place of State conventions. Locally, the meeting was held at the Central Baptist Church, Ninety-second Street and Amsterdam Avenue, with groups of delegates from fifty-eight Baptist churches in this area attending.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Soviet midday Communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio:

Dr. Charles C. Williamson, dean of the Columbia University School of Library Service, urged yesterday careful study of the granting of professional library degrees "after many years of growing dissatisfaction with the prevailing system of giving a second bachelor's degree as the first professional degree in accredited library schools."

United States export advertising in Latin-American republics will show a definite increase this year, a joint survey by the Office of Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs and the Department of Commerce revealed yesterday. Started in the Summer of last year, the survey was aimed to ascertain the extent to which United States manufacturers would seek to preserve their brand names and good-will in our neighboring republics.
The Yankees will do their Spring training at Asbury Park, N.J., starting March 15, it was announced yesterday by President Edward G. Barrow.

Edward J. Flynn was a politician of far greater party influence than the public generally recognized long before he was named chairman of the Democratic National Committee to manage President Roosevelt's successful campaign for a third term in 1940.

Use of adequate -- check lists of the many and basic changes involved in corporate taxes under the 1942 law was advocated last night by J.K. Lasser, tax authority and writer, at the meeting of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Heavy and medium bombers of the 10th United States Air Force cut Japanese communications be- Northern and Southern Burma yesterday by knocking down the central span of the Myitnge Bridge near Mandalay, an American communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Secretary Perkins was upheld and a Federal District Court was rebuked by the Supreme Court today in a case where the lower tribunal interfered with the Labor Secretary's right to subpoena payroll records of the Endicott-Johnson Company, nationally known shoe manufacturers.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 11 -- The German High Command placed before the Bulgarian General Staff this week-end a complete war plan comprising the defense of Bulgarian-occupied Grecian Thrace and Salonika against feared Allied debarkments on the Aegean coast, the writer has been informed by the usually best-informed foreign military intelligence sources in Istanbul.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 6 per cent for the week ended Jan. 9, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Comparison was with the hectic buying of men's clothing and staple merchandise during the 1942 week.

A general revision of the financial relations between the State Government and New York City and other municipalities that would give the cities new tax sources and relieve them of some of their present budgetary obligations was proposed last night in the report of the subcommittee on State-City Fiscal Relations of the Mayor's Committee on City Finances.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Corn again assumed leadership at the Board of Trade today. All deliveries and the cash article sold at $1 and more for a new five-and-one-half-year high and carried futures of all other grains except rye into new seasonal high ground.
New political troubles in French North Africa were predicted last night in a Columbia Broadcasting System report from Algiers. Charles Collingwood, the CBS correspondent there, said:

Because of the illness of Flora Robson, its star, "The Damask Cheek" officially closed its run at The Playhouse as of last Saturday evening. Miss Robson became ill with an infected throat after appearing in a special performance of the play on Sunday night for the soldiers at Fort Hancock, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- No new export license applications for shipments to Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru or Venezuela will be accepted by the Board of Economic Warfare until March 1, that war agency announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The first concrete step toward the new era that is expected to follow the war in the Far East, with full restoration of China's sovereignty over her own soil, was taken today when the United States and Great Britain signed with China treaties abolishing extraterritorial and other special rights enjoyed by the two powers in China for approximately a century.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Selection of forty-nine additional industrial plants to recive the Army-Navy Production Award in recognition of oustanding performance on war work was made public today by Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson and Under-Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal.

Carlo Tresca, internationally known revolutionary syndicalist writer, militant leader of Italian anti-Fascists and colorful figure in American radical circles for more than a generation, was assassinated at 9:40 o'clock last night at Fifth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- President Castillo decreed today a ten-day period of national mourning for former President Justo.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 11 -- Argentina has lost a great son and Brazil one of her best friends, said Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Brazilian Foreign Minister, today regarding the death of General Justo of Argentina.

BOSTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- commander Thomas J. Hamilton, U.S.N., head of the Navy's preflight physical training program, made a stirring plea last night for continuation of intercollegiate football in an address at the annual dinner of the Boston College Varsity Club.

LONDON, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- When the Yanks landed at Oran and scaled a steep cliff in the face of intense enemy fire, they thought they were really going to town, but when they reached the top they found their general there ahead of them, a Tommy gun under his arm.

The Presbytery of New York adopted a resolution yesterday assuring the Office of Price Administration that every effort would be made to conserve fuel, but at the same time advising the OPA that the church could not be classed as non-essential and that "places of worship must be kept open."

The five-story walk-up at 855 East 163d Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the estate of Samuel Greenberg to Louis Hochberg Realty Corporation, represented by Louis Lovesky. Purchase was for cash, above mortgages totaling $22,355. Title was certified by the New York Abstract Company, Inc.

Forty-one A, B and C gasoline ration books were seized over the week-end by investigators of the Office of Price Administration for violation of the ban on pleasure driving, but Sylvan L. Joseph, regional administrator of the OPA, said he was well pleased on the whole with the patriotic observance of the order by the motoring public.

BUFFALO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- An official of the United States Department of Agriculture asserted today in a letter to The Buffalo Evening News that "a serious health menace and possibly an epidemic" may result from widespread "black marketing" of meat in Western New York.

The American Civil Liberties Union will file a brief and join in the appeal of Isidore A. Herk, producer of the play, "Wine, Women and Song," from his recent conviction for presenting an indecent performance, it was announced last night. Herk, sentenced to six months, is now free on a writ of reasonable doubt issued by Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Members in key posts in Congress found some comfort today in the nonwar economies reflected in President Roosevelt's nearly $109,000,000,000 budget message, but were not satisfied, they said, to accept the $458,000,000 of reductions in last year's estimates as conclusive or final.

The four-story apartment house for twenty-two families at 243 Danforth Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by the Five Corners Building and Loan Association to Mary Sator through the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization, brokers.
Mrs. Norrie Sherman Sellar has arrived from Unionville, Pa., and is at the Plaza.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Opinion in the coal trade here yesterday as to the effects on the city's fuel supply of the strike of 19,000 miners in the anthracite fields of Pennsylvania was that there was no immediate danger of a shortage.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 11 -- The French Fleet at Dakar, French West Africa, will be ready to take its place in the Allied battle line after some months, according to Vice Admiral William A. Glassford Jr., head of the American Mission at Dakar, today.

The Tokyo radio reported yesterday that Emperor Hirohito had decided to send aides de camp to war factories to survey conditions and "to encourage war workers who are working for the destruction of America and Britain."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The War Production Board today issued Controlled Materials Plan Regulation No. 1, defining the rights and obligations of industry under CMP. This basic regulation, dealing specifically with methods of applying for, receiving and making allotments, gives legal standing to procedures outlined in the informational booklet on CMP published early in November.

May I call attention to the splendid health record enjoyed by New York City during 1942, which attests to the really remarkable work which the Health Department is performing, despite loss of personnel, operating economies and increased responsibilities traceable to war conditions?

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Philip R. O'Brien was re-elected president of the Chicago Board of Trade for his third term in the exchange's annual election today, defeating G. Willard Hales by a vote of 370 to 249. Mr. Hales, a Chicago feed manufacturer, whose term as a director of the Board of Trade expired this year, was a candidate by petition.
The latest New England surveys indicate that the deer kill in at least two States was greater than at first reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The War Labor Board and the Senate's Truman committee investigating defense expenditures today telegraphed to John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, and the recording secretaries of twenty-two anthracite locals in Pennsylvania, that strikes in the field were creating a critical coal shortage and called upon the strikers to return to their jobs and settle their grievances through orderly procedure.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- The war has cut so sharply into populations of the Westchester County Penitentiary and the county home at Eastview that few able-bodied inmates remain to operate the county's adjacent dairy farm and vegetable gardens, which produce much of the food consumed in county institutions, Herbert C. Gerlach, county executive, said today in a 4,000-word annual message to the Board of Supervisors.

Many complaints have been received recently by the Office of Price Administration of violations or evasions of the ceiling price on butter, it became known yesterday, but the relatively small OPA staff here has been so occupied by other matters, such as the ban on pleasure driving and the investigation into the alleged black market in meat that it has been unable to follow up the butter complaints.

Organization of the new Congress and election of its standing committees have again been going on before our eyes. The origin of the earlier of those committees remains obscure. The Senate had no standing committees until 1816. The committees then established seem to have been the select committees that previously had reported on parts of the President's message.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Debits to deposit accounts (except inter-bank accounts) as reportedly banks in 274 leading centers for the month of December aggregated $ 64,990,000. During the past three months total debits for the same centers amounted to $170,718,000, or 12 per cent above the total reported for the corresponding period a year ago.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 11 -- Henri Beraud, chief editorial writer for the French weekly publication Gringoire, was an assassin's target in Lyon, it was learned here tonight. A bomb was used, but M. Beraud escaped uninjured. The Gringoire, published in the former unoccupied zone, is virulently anti-British, anti-American and anti-Semitic.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- An American Government commission will go to Bolivia within a few days to inquire into tin production problems there, it was learned here tonight.

Net operating earnings of the Brooklyn Trust Company for 1942 amounted to $720,639, after all expenses, interest and taxes, George V. McLaughlin, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday. This compared with $681,130 in 1941.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 12 -- A Japanese light cruiser or a large destroyer was believed sunk by Allied torpedo planes off Gasmata, New Britain, Saturday evening, the Allied command announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A demand for increased civilian hour production by American labor on the home front and for less interference with the Army's plan for fighting the war as determined by the military experts of the General Staff was made here tonight by Roane Waring, national commander of the American Legion.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Secretary Knox declared in a magazine article today that the "'experts' who had criticized the Navy's planes for being under-gunned will be interested to learn that the Grumman Wildcat packs even more wallop than the famed English Spitfire."

Planning which recognizes maintenance of civilian morale as a military need is vital at this time, and the success with which merchandisers and suppliers meet civilian requirements will be a measure of their contribution to the war effort and during the post-war readjustments, I. Edwin Goldwasser, vice president of the Commercial Factors Corporation, said yesterday.

As scattered instances were reported yesterday of residents of the metropolitan area who were without fuel oil to heat their homes, a spokesman for the petroleum industry here said the shortage was growing more acute daily and that there was no prospect of early relief.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- To meet its 1943 war needs, $125,000,000 has been fixed as the goal of the campaign of the American Red Cross in March, which has been designated by President Roosevelt as Red Cross month, Norman H. Davis, national chairman, said today.

After a year's enforced absence to permit stockpiling of raw wool for military needs, the "all-wool" blanket returned yesterday to the civilian trade when the industry's largest producer, American Woolen Company, offered four numbers for March-to-August delivery.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The stock markets started the week on a cheerful note. With further funds available next month through South African vesting, the upward trend in gilt edge securities continued today.
PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 11 -- A boxing man whose pre-eminence in the sport of fisticuffing is substantial enough to earn his classification as a "boxing big shot" asked me the other day:

The Council of the Boys Brotherhood Republic is disturbed at the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 30 in which emphasis was placed upon one aspect of the unfinished report of our Committee on Pupil-Teacher Relations in the city schools.

WITH THE ALLIED ARMIES IN TUNISIA, Jan. 9 (Delayed) -- Major David Dobie, 29 years old, of Tynemouth, England, told today how a song gasped out by a Welsh corporal dying on the slopes of a shrub-covered hill overlooking Mateur and Bizerte had inspired ninety of his comrades to a fury that carried them through hours of battle against overwhelming odds.

Two new films will have world premieres in midtown theatres today. At the Rivo]i, tonight, the newcomer will be Alfred Hitchock's mystery melodrama, "Shadow o f.a.Doubt.' Heading the cast are Teresa Wright and Joseph Ct- ten, it Macdonald Carey, Patricia Collinge and Henry Travers appeaffmg in supporting roles in the Universal release.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- During the discussion of the Flynn appointment Senator Willis of Indiana commented:

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 11 -- Two hours after a trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board opened a hearing on unfair labor charges against three of Henry J. Kaiser's A.F.L. closed-shop shipyards, Kaiser attorneys went into the Federal District Court today in an attempt to block the whole proceeding.

After having reached new seasonal high marks, the cotton futures market yesterday yielded part of the gains under scale-up hedge sales late in the session. At the close active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 2 to 7 points above Saturday's final quotations.

Boxing followers who flock daily to Stillman's Gymnasium were treated a surprise yesterday. They beheld a boxing manager who is also a sparring partner for his fighter. It was no optical illusion, for the sparring manager was there, stripped for action.

Books on mathematics are having a big sale. It is greatly to be hoped that many of the textbooks are getting into the hands of the general public. People need to learn that you cannot work out problems with too many unknown quantities.

The nation's scrap drive and local law clashed yesterday when an executive of a salvage company was haled before Magistrate Abner C. Surpless in Flatbush Court for refusing to extinguish a bonfire built in a vacant lot to provide warmth for workmen preparing scrap metal for delivery to steel mills.

Roy Hawley, director of athletics at West Virginia University, which opposes unbeaten N.Y.U. at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, was the principal speaker at the weekly luncheon of the Basketball Writers Association yesterday at Toots Shor's restaurant.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Jan. 12 -- Red Army tanks and motorized infantry, swiftly rolling the Germans back in the Caucasus along the road to Rostov, captured six Caucasian cities yesterday, including Georgievsk, Mineralnye Vodi and Pyatigorsk, the Soviet High Command announced last night in one of its most impressive special communiques.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Administration is considering a new approach to the problem of discrimination against Negroes and minorities in war plants and in industry generally, it was reported today after Paul V. McNutt announced that he had postponed indefinitely the hearing scheduled for Jan. 25-27 of the Fair Employment Practices Committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- Navy communique 247:

After the war the large structure housing the American Museum of Natural History at Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street will be modernized completely, both externally and internally, it was disclosed last night at the seventy-fourth annual meeting of the museum's Board of Trustees.

GUADALCANAL, Jan. 5 (Delayed) (AP) -- Three Navy pilots who flew over Munda on New Georgia Island during the United States Fleet's shelling of Japanese positions there early this morning said it was "the most accurate big gun fire we ever have seen or hope to see."

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Horsemen offering to conduct a cooperative race meeting at Hialeah Park were turned down today by track officials, who said the proposal was no solution to the problem of operating during the ban on automobile pleasure driving.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was asked at her press conference today whether the White House housekeeper, Mrs. Henrietta Nesbitt, was driven in a White House car to and from her home in Silver Spring, Md. She replied that she did not know where Mrs. Nesbitt lived, but she did know that "Mrs. Nesbitt drives back and forth" in a White House automobile.

Another annual is among the week's offerings -- An American Group's twelfth, which opened yesterday at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, to remain until Jan. 30. "Our Country's Worth Fighting For" is the slogan adopted this year.

Declaring that the United States would emerge from the war with "the greatest merchant fleet in history," Frederick E. Hasler, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, urged last night that it be preserved as "the greatest for all time."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 11 -- The Swedish budget for 1943-1944, which will be published here tomorrow, shows that during the current year this country will spend 1,260,000,000 kronor [the krona is quoted at 23.90 cents] on defense alone, while the ordinary budget is estimated at 2,515,000,000 kronor for expenditures, with revenue of 2,676,000,000 kronor.

The stock market gave no hint of surprise yesterday over the President's staggering budget of $108,903,047,923. In fact, prices showed moderate improvement. Except for the communications and tobacco issues, however, the additions were confined to fractions and the only general easiness prevailed in the public utilities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -The State Department has been striving since the Germans occupied all France to arrange for the Americans' return.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- As the United States prepares to mobilize agriculture for total war it may be interesting to see what progress has been made in that direction in this country after thirty months of war.

The New York Community Trust celebrated its nineteenth year during 1942 by distributing $547,261 to about 140 organizations in nineteen States. The total is small as sums go today, but the list of beneficiaries, made public on Monday, suggests how much good the well-placed gift can do.

The Anthracite Committee of Twelve, policy making committee of the industry, representing in equal numbers mine operators and the United Mine Workers of America, met at the Hotel Roosevelt last night and condemned the strike of miners in the Wilkesbarre-Scranton district as a violation of the union agreement.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- The British radio said today that the British Eighth Army was about to resume its drive toward Tripoil.

In her Spring hat collection Florence Reichman has banished the exotic and held to the practical, never forgetting for a moment that women, come what will, want to be becomingly hatted. Her showing yesterday afternoon at 1 West Fifty-seventh Street featured small shapes whose concentrated contours held plenty of news and shapes designed to be becoming to many women, young and old.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Steep Rock Iron Mines, Ltd., of Toronto, Ont., told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has agreed to lend it $5,000,000 for developing its iron ore deposits in Ontario.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Home making is woman's greatest career, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce and Miss Winifred Stanley, new Congressional Representatives, for Connecticut and New York, respectively, agreed at a dinner meeting in their honor given by the Women's National Press Club tonight. Other members present were Mrs. Edith Nourse Rogers of Massachusetts, Mrs. Frances P. Bolton of Ohio and Mrs. Margaret Chase Smith of Maine.

A new issue of $37,013,000 New York City Housing Authority refunding bonds, Series A, due serially from March 15, 1944 to 1981, is being offered by a banking group headed by Lehman Brothers, Blyth Co., Inc., Phelps, Fenn Co., R.W. Pressprich Co., Goldman, Sachs Co., Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., the First Boston Corporation and Smith, Barney Co.

Fire losses in New York City, exclusive of the U.S.S. Lafayette (formerly the Normandie), were estimated at $9,346,835 in the annual report of Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh, made public last night. This represents a decrease of $496,836 from 1941.

The German High Command, reporting on Monday's action on the Russian front, said yesterday that "between the Caucasus and the Don, in the area of Stalingrad and in the Don area the Russians again attacked the same focal points as before with strong forces," according to broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

If you have wondered what borsht really is -- besides being a beet soup that reminds Russians of home -- now is the time to find out. Trot down to a city store, place a dime on the counter and ask for the newest acquisition in the dehydrated soup department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -Changes in the periodic tire inspection program intended to minimize public inconvenience and smooth out occasional work peaks for the inspectors, were announced today by the Office of Prince Administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A shipbuilding commission was established by the War Labor Board today to handle labor disputes and pass on wage questions in the shipbuilding industry employing about 900,000 workers.

Functional styles of girdles, corsets and brassieres designed to meet the special needs of women workers in war plants and on the farms have attracted chief interest of visiting retail buyers here to see the industry's Spring offerings, producers reported yesterday.

Contributions of $1,408, including those sent direct to the Neediest Cases Fund and others forwarded through private charity organizations cooperating in its administration, brought the total yesterday beyond the quarter million-dollar mark.
MOSCOW, Jan. 12 -- The ashes of Major Marina Raskova, 33-year-old Russian woman flier, were placed in the Kremlin walls today after an impressive ceremony on Red Square.

Philip L. Goodwin, a trustee of the Museum of Modern Art, gave a dinner last night at the Barberry Room for Mme. Carlos Martins, wife of the Brazilian Ambassador, after the private preview at the museum of Brazil Builds, an exhibition of Brazilian architecture, which will be opened to the public today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A warning to labor against strikes and work stoppages during the war was sounded today by Wayne L. Morse, public member of the National War Labor Board, in a case involving the Miles Laboratories, Inc., of Elkhart, Ind., and the United Mine Workers.

The American way of life and the free enterprise system will survive only if business men understand and cooperate with government and realize that property rights will be respected if human rights are respected, T. Spencer Shore, vice president and treasurer of the General Tire and Rubber Company, declared yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- A plan for the exchange of two properties as a step toward compliance with "death sentence" orders of the Securities and Exchange Commission is being discussed by officials of the United Gas Improvement Company and the trustees of the Associated Gas and Electric System, it was learned today.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Few changes were voted in the directorates of Newark's major banks and trust companies at annual stockholders' meetings today. The sessions were devoted chiefly to analyses of the impact of the war on the institutions' activities.

Louis Ware, president of International Minerals Chemical Corporation, announced yesterday that the board of directors has approved a refunding plan, to be completed today, under which the company is issuing $7,500,000 in new serial debentures to six lending corporations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Repayments on Farm Security Administration rehabilitation loans jumped to 92 per cent of maturities on Dec. 1, compared with 75.4 per cent on the same date in 1941, reflecting better incomes from increased production to meet war demands, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, former Fulton Fish Market labor union racketeer, and four co-defendants unexpectedly pleaded guilty yesterday in their trial for extortion. Judge James Garrett Wallace accepted pleas of guilty from each of the five to the misdemeanor conspiracy count in the indictment and one of the six felon extortion counts.

Virginia Van Wert, 34 years old, a divorcee, was found guilty of manslaughter in the first degree last night by a General Sessions jury in the rifle shooting of Louis Raines, 35 her common-law husband, in her home at 551 West 157th Street in the early morning of Jan. 10, 1942.

Two diseases, a form of mild pneumonia that does not respond to the usual sulfa drugs and an epidemic eye infection, were added to the list of reportable illnesses by the city Board of Health yesterday because of their "increasing significance."

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The hesitancy shown at the close of yesterday's sessions of the stock markets was again in evidence today, when profit-taking sales helped a small decline in prices. Gilt-edge securities were lower where changed, with the 3 1/2 per cent war loan losing slightly to 105 3/8.

While retail inventories have been reduced in relation to sales during the last six months, merchandise stocks are still inequitably distributed among the stores of the country and the outlook for reduced civilian supplies this year makes inventory control all the more necessary, Eaton V.W. Read, Administrator of WPB Inventory Limitation Order No. L 219 said yesterday.
Mrs. R. Henry Norweb, wife of the United States Ambassador to Peru, has come to the Waldorf-Astoria from her home in Cleveland.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 12 -- Seated on a silver throne and with the crown, sceptre and orb at his side, 85-year-old King Gustaf V today for the thirty-sixth year opened the annual session of the Riksdag, one of the two remaining democratic Parliaments in this part of Europe.

Members of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., moved yesterday to adopt the necessary means of coping with any future destruction to park property resulting from juvenile delinquency at the annual meeting held at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

Dr. J. Salwyn Schapiro, Professor of History at City College, has been elected to the council of the American Historical Association for the period through December, 1946, it was announced yesterday. Balloting was held on Dec. 30 in Washington, and word was received of Dr. Schapiro's election in a letter he received yesterday from Professor Guy Stanton Ford, executive secretary of the association.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue warns that care should be used in making out income tax returns. It points out that the Federal income tax return is a report to the government of one's taxable income for the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- An air battle in the Solomons yesterday resulted in the destruction of four Zeros and the probable destruction of two others, with the loss of only one of our fighting planes, the Navy reported today.

On behalf of the Episcopal Pacifist Fellowship, one of the organizations contributing to the support of conscientious objectors in their work under the Civilian Public Service program, may I congratulate and thank THE NEW YORK TIMES for publishing the very comprehensive article about these men in the issue of Jan. 7 and for the very understanding editorial on the same subject on the following day?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A construction battalion of the Navy -- part of the working and fighting "Seabees" -- recently completed repairs on a carrier while she was at sea in the midst of battle, the Navy Department revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Total collections of internal revenue taxes in the year ended June 30 were up 77 per cent from the previous fiscal year, the collections being the highest in the history of the Internal Revenue Bureau and exceeding the combined total of the two preceding years, the Treasury Department announced today.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The appointment of James C. Hagerty, a member of the legislative news bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, as executive assistant to Governor Dewey, was announced today by the Governor in an informal press conference.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The presence here today of several important State Republican leaders served to bring to the surface the patronage situation in Governor Dewey's Administration. The leaders came, unquestionably, to try to get action on other than personal appointments because of impatience back home on the part of the rank and file of the party.
LONDON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Beauty and wartime simplicity were skillfully combined in the Spring costumes displayed by Jonai, Inc., at the Salon d'Elegance luncheon fashion show yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Hats shown were from Lilly Dache.

Most of the shouting about town thus far has concerned the merits of such noteworthy basketball teams as N.Y.U., St. John's and Fordham. Virtually ignored has been the St. Francis College squad Joe Brennan is coaching over in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A statement defining the responsibilities of the War Production Board and the Department of Agriculture with reference to the food program was issued here today by Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, and by Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture and wartime food administrator.

H.G. Wells at the age of 76 is working for an M.A. in science at London University and is writing a thesis on early animal life on earth. He calls it "Personalities of the Mesozoic," which does not quite sound like the ordinary graduate thesis. Candidates for the M.A. or Ph.D. usually manage to escape picturesque titles even when they are writing about a fairly stimulating subject like Shakespeare or the conquest of Mexico.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 12 -- A preliminary balance sheet of the German railways for the year 1942, printed in the Essener National Zeitung today, shows that freight car receipts dropped 178,000,000 marks. Three reasons are adduced in the statement for this change.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Numerous promotions among executive personnel were announced today after meetings of their boards of directors.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 12 -- Acting promptly after the War Labor Board had sent a warning message, sixty-four leaders of 18,000 striking anthracite coal miners voted tonight to hold local union meetings tomorrow to consider the board's statement.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 12 -- Army Air Forces Technical Training Command took over one-third of Yale University's total facilities today. Its cadets, chosen from enlisted reserves and from selected Army enlisted personnel, will leave Yale as second lieutenants after six to twenty weeks of study, depending on the course assigned.

The loss of the aircraft carrier Hornet and of three cruisers and seven destroyers, sunk last October and November in the furious naval fighting around the Solomons, has been more than counterbalanced by the addition of new ships to our fleet.

Herbert P. Howell, chairman of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company, informed stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday that net earnings of the bank for 1942 amounted to $945,443, or $13.51 a share on the outstanding capital stock, compared with a net of $907,357, or $12.96 a share, in the preceding year.

Gilbert B.J. Frawley of Brewster, N.Y., was elected president of the New York Athletic Club at the annual meeting last night in the clubhouse, 180 Central Park South. Mr. Frawley succeeds Henry W. Ryan, who headed the seventy-five-year-old athletic organization for the last two years.

Fred A. Hanson, chairman of the State food industry committee set up under the Food Distribution Administration, yesterday announced the names of four additional chairmen to head sectional committees in the State's major marketing areas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Roosevelt expresed approval in a statement issued by the White House today of a plan of the War Relief Control Board, of which Joseph E. Davies, former Ambassador to Russia, is chairman, for conducting only two major national fund-raising campaigns this year.

One of the basic needs for future peace maintenance is in Hugh Gibson's letter in THE TIMES of Jan. 7 -- the need of "separate treatment for separate problems." This war might never have come if there had been this separate treatment provided and carried out in the League of Nations.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The British people were warned today of dangers of further sacrifices ahead of them before the war is won, and even after, in a number of speeches made up and down these islands.

Corporal Roy Holland, 32 years old, of Memphis, Tenn., attached to Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, was shot fatally by a member of the Military Police early yesterday morning outside the Harbor Diner, 9229 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, after he had shot the M.P. in the thigh and had attempted to escape.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS in Australia, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Four officers and men of the United States Army received the Distinguished Service Cross for extraordinary heroism in action in New Guinea from General MacArthur today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 12 -- Flying again despite unfavorable weather conditions, United States four-motored Liberators raided Naples in daylight yesterday and started a huge fire. A heavy cloud covering obscured the other results of the raid.

Poland's Prime Minister, General Sikorski, said recently that victory over Nazi Germany will come through the might of the United Nations and the massed hatred of oppressed peoples. The might of the United Nations, displayed on many battle fronts, draws many banner headlines, but the hatred of the oppressed peoples must still manifest itself in less spectacular developments recorded in minor items which nevertheless assume significance by their growing frequency.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Allied ground forces gained against the only Japanese still holding out in the Papuan peninsula of New Guinea at Sanananda, General Douglas MacArthur's Command announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- Defining the issues to be resolved at the reconvened "death sentence" proceedings against Republic Service Corporation and its subsidiaries, set for next Monday, the Securities and Exchange Commission has directed that among other things it should be determined whether the holding company should be compelled to divest itself of interest in seven subsidiaries.

An adequate food supply will be assured New York City in 1943 if metropolitan housewives actively cooperate with the government's "Food for Freedom" campaign, it was predicted here yesterday by Ralph Y. De Wolfe, chairman of the New York State War Board of the Department of Agriculture.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that more than one billion pounds of salvage materials had been turned over to processors by the company's plants and dealers in the first eleven months of 1942, and that there was an increase of 4,000,000 pounds of scrap collections in November, compared with October.

William R. Crowley, who resigned last November from the Board of Education, denied yesterday that he had sought to limit school purchases of mimeograph machines to a single make as charged by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, in a report to Mayor La Guardia on the purchasing system of the Board of Education.

One hundred thousand volunteers will storm the hearts and pocketbooks of New Yorkers beginning March 1 to collect $12,920,700 for the 1943 Red Cross War Fund, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of the local chapters at the New York Chapter House, 315 Lexington Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The $96,500 salary and bonus paid by the Spicer Manufacturing Corporation of Toledo, Ohio, to its executive vice president, R.E. Carpenter, was the highest contained in annual reports of corporations for 1941-42 made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Announcement made shortly before trading in grain futures started today stating that the Office of Price Administration had placed a ceiling price on cash corn and futures at the highest prices reached on Monday threw the trade into confusion.

Henry Epstein, former Solicitor General of New York State, made known yesterday that he had resigned as chief counsel to the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice because of the indefinite postponement by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, of scheduled hearings on charges of discrimination against Negroes in railroad employment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Balked by a unanimous Federal Circuit Court from seizing the properties of the Puerto Rico Railway Light and Power Company under the Lanham act, the Federal Works Administration has now taken the properties under the second War Powers Act and on the express direction of the President.

New Yorkers who pride themselves on their skyline will have an opportunity to see some of the outstanding architectural accomplishments of another great nation of the Western Hemisphere when the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opens today its exhibition called "Brazil Builds."
The man who shot Carlo Tresca and drove away in the dimout Monday night left behind him only the evidence that it was a well-planned killing, according to the police twenty-four hours later.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- George E. Deatherage, charged with conspiring to undermine the morale of the armed forces, told newsmen at District Court today that if "Wendell Willkie won't represent me, I want my money back."

Eighty thousand dollars' worth of war bonds were sold and 485 books for the armed forces were collected yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women held at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The Royal Air Force struck another blow at the Ruhr last night -- the sixth British bombing attack there in the past nine nights and bad weather notwithstanding.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Corn prices on all exchanges and in every cash and local market were placed under ceilings at the highest levels at which sales were made yesterday, through an order issued today by the Office of Price Administration.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 12 -- The strike of aluminum foundry workers at Plant 2 of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, here, entered its fourth clay this morning with the striking. employes continuing their refusal to negotiate with the management under the auspices of the C.I.O., which recently won a National Labor Relations Board election at the plant.

CHUNGKING, Jan. 12 -- Most Chungking newspapers took the occasion this morning to express pleasure over the signing of treaties with the United States and Great Britain abolishing extraterritorial rights.

If the nation's health has never been better than it is at present it is not because we have doctors and nurses enough but because we are still traveling under a medical momentum acquired in peace. The truth is that the hospitals have been nearly stripped of their professional personnel, which means doctors, nurses, laboratory technicians.
The sock-eye salmon that caused a flurry of excitement when they were discovered in Twin Lakes at Lakeville, Conn., a few years ago are going to be under regulation soon.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 12 -- American bombers and fighters continued the aerial offensive against the rear areas of Axis forces in Tunisia while minor French forces attacked twice in a southern sector and repulsed an Axis attack southwest of Kairouan, a communique announced today.

A.H. Woods comes back to the Broadway wars this evening as the producer of "Nine Girls," opening at the Longacre. Wilfrid H. Pettitt is the author of the play, which during its tryout period on the road was known as "This Little Hand."

New York University against West Virginia and Fordham against St. John's form the attractive college basketball double-header set for tonight at Madison Square Garden. The opening game, in which the unbeaten Violets will seek their tenth triumph, will get under way promptly at 8:15 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Marcel B. Peyrouton, former French Ambassador to Argentina, who is on his way to North Africa, was summoned there by the French authorities in Algiers, it was learned today. M. Peyrouton had offered his services to the French officials, who have full charge of civil administration, and it is understood that the move is agreeable to the United States military authorities in North Africa.
LONDON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Open revolt was reported spreading in Bulgaria tonight with thousands of workers, students and pro-Russian elements attacking police stations in Sofia and other large cities.

LONDON, Jan. 12 (U.P.)--Reichsfuehrer Hitler has given up the idea of mustering a French army to fight the Allies but has won commitments from Chief of Government Pierre Laval for five French destroyers, 400,000 French workers and complete control of French industry, finance and agriculture, it was reported tonight.

Colonel Andrew S. Rowan, just dead at 85, was famous in 1898. He was one of several officers who undertook at great danger to themselves to get and bring to Washington information from Cuba. He narrowly escaped being murdered. He succeeded in finding General Calixto Garcia at Bayamo on May 1, 1898.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan. 12 -- Immediate cessation of all censorship and propaganda at the close of hostilities and a post-war guarantee of world-wide freedom of the press and communications were demanded today by Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University, in order that a lasting, global peace might follow.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 12 -- Lines were drawn today for a test in the Federal court here to determine whether the National Labor Relations Board is to be permitted to proceed with its case against the three Oregon and Washington shipyards of Henry J. Kaiser.

The murder of Carlo Tresca removes a man who was capable of expressing and inspiring violent disagreement, but whom only an embittered fanatic could have hated. His name carries one's memories back to days which were certainly turbulent enough but also gayer than those through which we are now living.

HICKAM FIELD, Hawaii, Jan. 12 -- The tidy score card of combined United States aerial activities in the South Pacific theatre since the Solomons drive opened last August was revealed here today by Colonel La Verne G. (Blondy) Saunders, commander since the outset of Army heavy bombardment forces in the operations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--Edward J. Flynn, retiring Democratic National Chairman, said today that opposition to his appointment as Minister to Australia was "purely politics."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- Professional golf will go all out for the war effort in 1943. Golf has already raised more than $1,000,000 for the war effort, and the Professional Golfers Association has plans to raise still more funds for the American Red Cross and other war charities.
Possibly it is no less a culprit than the microscopic worm marine that is exposing our blacked-out ships in the Caribbean to the torpedoes of the enemy.

The government moved suddenly and effectively yesterday to obtain the use of thirteen apartment houses in the neighborhood of the Bronx buildings of Hunter College as quarters for the Waves and Spars candidates who will be trained at the college.

"It is clear that the war will bite deeper into the operations of this bank along with the country's whole economy," Gordon S. Rentschler, chairman of the National City Bank of New York, declared yesterday at a sparsely attended meeting of stockholders at the bank's head office at 55 Wall Street.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The "sprout line" accounted for all the scoring as the Boston Bruins shut out the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 -- 0, in the second of their four Red Cross benefit games tonight before 8,170 at the Boston Garden.

If you are trying to evade the draft you can get into serious trouble by not filling out correctly that questionnaire the local board sends to you, but apparently there is no penalty for cheating in order to get yourself into the Army.

Little, Brown announces a forth-coming book and is able to submit a recommendation for it by Theodore Roosevelt. It's Alfred Thayer Mahan's "The Life of Nelson," first published in 1896. President Roosevelt had called it "the best of all naval biographies about the greatest of all sea captains."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 12 -- A small number of persons were arrested Sunday in connection with the murder of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, an official spokesman for the French Imperial Council revealed today. The spokesman re fused to identify the prisoners. The arrests, which shook politics-ridden Algiers, will be followed by a lengthy inquiry into the prisoners' possible connection with the Admiral's assassination, the spokesman said.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek told the Chinese people tonight that the United States and Great Britain had declared their basic war aim was to "sustain the rule of human decency and human right" by singing treaties abolishing extraterritorial rights and special privileges in China.

The seventy-sixth annual exhibition of the American Water Color Society will be held at the National Academy of Design from March 24 to April 14. Prospective exhibits must be received at 3 East Eighty-ninth Street, on March 15, between 9 A.M. and 5 P.M. Only original works in water-color and pastel are eligible.

After a slow start, the Manhattan College varsity quintet rallied and conquered the Ellis Island Coast Guard, 59 -- 42, in the Jaspers' gymnasium last night. The triumph was the sixth in seven starts for the home team.

As food rationing on a large scale approaches, manufacturers, meat packers and canners are rapidly converting their advertising programs to tie in with new developments, agency men pointed out yesterday. Campaigns will emphasize ways of extending scarce products, particularly meat, explanations of point rationing, recipes containing no scarce items and similar themes.

The Giants, always long on up-holding baseball's traditions, turned back the clock almost half a century yesterday when they announced that they would pitch their 1943 wartime Spring training camp at Lakewood, N.J.

LONDON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Japanese suddenly have displayed strong resistance against British troops who have advanced to within about fifteen miles of Akyab in Burma, and have landed several thousand troops in Indo-China to bolster the Burma front, it was reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12--At the height of a violent sea battle in the Solomons, the night of Nov. 12-13, the huge gray hulk of a Japanese battleship came slashing through the darkness, her engines driving her at a speed of close to 25 knots.

Two hundred additional uniformed policemen and dozens of detectives have been assigned to the area bounded by Forty-second and Fifty-ninth Streets and by Sixth and Lexington Avenues, it was learned yesterday.
MELBOURNE, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Surprise is felt in Australian diplomatic circles at the replacement of Nelson T. Johnson by Edward J. Flynn, The Melbourne Herald said.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Passing Paul Governali, famed forward passer of the Columbia University eleven, who soon will enter the Marine Corps, was honored tonight as "the football player of 1942" by the Maxwell Memorial Football Club.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The text of President Roosevelt's statement to the country's farmers today, as issued through Stabilization Director James F. Byrnes, follows:

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 12 -The Board of Directors of the Citizens Trust Company was increased from eleven to thirteen today with the election of Charles A. Cona and John H. Flagg. Frank Woodward was promoted from assistant treasurer to treasurer while Charles S. Zabrlskie, who had been vice-president and treasurer was re-elected vice.president.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's Criterion the new attraction will be "Commandos Strike at Dawn," Lester Cowan's Columbia production starring Paul Muni. The topical drama features Lillian Gish making her first screen appearance in nine years, and Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Elisabeth Fraser, Alexander Knox and Rosemary DeCamp. . . .

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The War Labor Board warned the striking Pennsylvania anthracite coal miners tonight that "unless this threat to the safety of our nation is immediately terminated, the board will exercise all powers within the jurisdiction to fulfill its obligations to the country."

LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Credit for the destruction of an Axis submarine in the Bay of Biscay was given today to the crew of an American Air Force Liberator bomber, piloted by First Lieutenant Walter Thorne of Marietta, Ohio.

TRENTON, Jan. 12 -- Discord, with Democrats and Republicans fighting each other and themselves as well, marked the closing session of the 1942 New Jersey Legislature and the opening session of the 1943 Legislature at the State House here today.

The Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company reported yesterday for 1942 net current operating earnings, exclusive of recoveries and net profits from sales of securities, of $2,478,379 after expenses and taxes, equal to $3.31 each on the 750,000 capital shares outstanding.

The change of Price Administrators in Washington does not mean any laxity in price control as "there will be no retreat on the basic program," Dr. Merle Fainsod warned yesterday at the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Secretaries at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12 -- Lieut. Gen. Nikolai F. Kirichenko's Cossacks were reported today to have advanced another twelve miles on the Caucasus front. These are the cavalrymen who covered the retreat of the Caucasus army across the Kuban steppes last Summer.

Wilbur Nead, chief boatswain's mate at the Manhattan Beach Coast Guard, who held the A.A.U. championship in 1940, won the heavyweight wrestling title of the Third Naval District in the tournament held at the West Side Y.M.C.A. last night.
The New York and Honduras Rosario Mining Company, the first industrial concern to issue a report for 1942, announced yesterday a net income of $538,091 after all charges.

Events tonight: "Lohengrin," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 o'clock; piano recital by E. Robert Schmitz, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; William Schuman evening, presented by the Town Hall Music Forum, Saidenberg Little Symphony, conducted by Daniel Saidenberg; Collegiate Choral Concert, Robert Shaw, conductor, and Rosalyn Tureck, pianist, Town Hall, 8:45; two-piano recital of French music, Robert and Gaby Casadesus, 451 Madison Avenue, 9.

The Russian attacks on the Don and in the Caucasus were launched with a considerable superiority of both men and materiel and they have scored advances "the extent of which is beyond all doubt," one of Germany's foremost military critics has asserted, according to textual extracts from a German domestic radio broadcast released here yesterday by the Office of War Information.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Apparently nobody noticed it until today, but the new hundred-billion-dollar budget will balance.
Your very informative article "Oil for Eastern Area in the Doubtful Stage" in your Jan. 3 issue has come to our notice.

Substantial revision of proposed safety laws here appeared likely yesterday as the result of objections made before a City Council committee by representatives of theatres, department stores, hotels and architects. The new safety requirements had been proposed after recent disastrous fires in Boston and St. Johns, Nfld.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today denied permission to the Cabot Gas Corporation and its parent company, Godfrey L. Cabot, Inc., to abandon natural gas pipeline facilities in upper New York State.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 13 -- Russian troops driving toward Rostov were reported early today to be within artillery range of Salsk, an important railway junction 110 miles to the southeast, while Moscow announced the capture of ten more settlements in and near the Caucasus and the killing of 2,000 Germans along the lower Don, where the Nazis are counter-attacking night and day.

Inventors, Nobel Prize winners, leaders in the electrical arts, high officials of the Yugoslav Government and of New York, and men and women who attained distinction in many other fields paid tribute yesterday to Nikola Tesla, father of radio and of modern electrical generation and transmission systems, at an impressive funeral service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

All is not well upon the German home front today. The Blitz and terror which were to have won a short war have in a large sense failed. Germany has abandoned the hope that she can bring the war to a swift conclusion.

William P. Cosgrove and Harry B. Snyder have been admitted as general partners in Yarnall Co., Philadelphia, members of the New York Stock Exchange, Mr. Cosgrove has been with the firm, as head of the statistical department, since 1938. Mr. Snyder has been in the trading, department since 1931.

The stock market was not able yesterday to maintain either its brighter complexion or its previous tempo of trading, and prices turned irregularly easier. The tilt to the lower side came when investment demand present in the morning failed to follow through, while a break in commodity values tended to shift attention from securities to the staples.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 12 (AP) -- A Federal Grand Jury late today returned two indictments charging four private citizens and a deputy sheriff, all of Jones County, with violation of Federal civil rights statutes in the lyhching of Howard Wash, Negro, at Laurel, Miss., on the night of Oct. 16, 1942.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The Legislature took cognizance today of the serious shortage of butter in the State when the chairmen of the fiscal committees in both houses introduced a bill permitting public institutions to buy and use butter substitutes for their patients and inmates.

Complete agreement with the pronouncement of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York that all available cash should be used for prosecution of the war was voiced yesterday by E. Chester Gersten, president, at the annual meeting of the Public National Bank and Trust Company of New York. Mr. Gersten reported that the bank's holdings of government obligations had risen in 1942 from $45,000,000 to $130,000,000.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, largest commercial banking institution in the world, halted proceedings at the heavily-attended annual meeting of stockholders yesterday to answer a list of questions sent by mail by an Army private now stationed in Camp Barkeley, Texas.

Maybe there's some one among you who remembers Barry Benefield, who once worked for this paper. Anyway, he's written a story about a copyreader; possibly it's the secret life of you or you or you, for Barry learned about newspaper men in his TIMES days, as he explains more or less in his dedication of his novel to Frederick T. Birchall, "the king of all copy-readers."

Twelve passenger - car owners were deprived yesterday of part of their gasoline - ration coupons for violation of regulations of the Office of Price Administration regarding speeding or the improper use of their cars. Among them were three persons who were punished for violation of the ban on pleasure driving put into effect last Thursday.

Charging that serious musicians are not being considered as potentially valuable in the war program, Lawrence Tibbett, American baritone, protested yesterday against an Army regulation which has obliged a well-known American composer, now a private in the Army, to decline an invitation to compose a symphonic score as an American musical greeting to the Russian people.

The American Women's Voluntary Services will open a new unit at 201 East Forty-second Street today, for the purpose of giving women working in midtown offices an opportunity to participate more fully in A.W.V.S. activities, the organization's Greater New York headquarters announced yesterday.

If ever a ship went down fighting it was the carrier Hornet. All one October afternoon the battle lasted in the bright tropic sea off Santa Cruz Island. Wave after wave of enemy fliers swooped on the great craft, most of them to destruction. But at sunset the Hornet -- torpedoed, bombed and burning -- was listing to her death.
A 23 1/2-pound pull in weight, plus fair defensive skill, enabled Tony Musto, Chicago heavyweight, to defeat Herbie Katz, Brownsville, in the feature ten-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 12 -- Dr. Hermann Johannes Boldt, a noted gynecologist, was found dead in a hotel room today, the victim of gas fumes from a small heater. He was 87 years old.

IF the war lasts too long, it almost can be guaranteed that Lieutenant Dyke Raese will be utterly unable to look a basketball in the eye. The presumption here, of course, is that basketballs have eyes. Like potatoes, for instance.

OTTAWA, Jan. 12 -- A strike by 5,000.workers today halted production in the plants of the Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation at Sydney, N.S., one of Canada's largest primary steel-producing establishments.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association was advised by government spokesmen at its thirty-second annual convention, or "wartime conference," at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday that because of the growing manpower shortage they must recruit sales forces from among the nation's 30,000,000 housewives and girl students.
Keen disappointment with the insufficiency of the first amendment made by the OPA to MPR-287 was expressed here yesterday by official spokesmen for the women's apparel industry.

Promising a modernized and more attractive post-war zoo, Fairfield Osborn, president of the New York Zoological Society, last night told the annual meeting of that organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that it had ended 1942 financially "with no major complaint" and with an attendance record of 2,319,000.
The High School Teachers Association of New York City held a meeting yesterday in New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. Dr. Rachel Anderson, president of the association, presided.

Post-war prosperity in the Netherlands East Indies will depend upon a continuance of cooperation between government and business and immediate planning by the other Allied nations for the post-war period, Dr. Hubertus J. van Mook, Netherlands Minister for Overseas Territories, declared yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 12 -- Food -- or the lack of it -- is welding France into a united nation, according to all accounts received here. The realization has dawned that under "collaboration" the first obligation of the French is to feed the Germans.
WATERLOO, Iowa, Jan. 12 -- The five Sullivan boys got what they wanted -- a crack at the Japanese. And they got that chance together, as they wanted it.
HOUSTON, Texas, Jan. 12 -- Few changes in the directorates of Houston banks were made Tuesday at the annual directors' and stockholders' meetings.

"Women Can Take It," a stage extravaganza benefit performance with a star-spangled cast made up almost entirely of women of the stage and society, was presented last night at the Rivoli Theatre in conjunction with the world premiere of Alfred Hitchcock's film production, "Shadow of a Doubt."

The largest number of visiting buyers registered by THE NEW YORK TIMES during any week since such records were begun in 1927 was printed for the week ended yesterday. The total was 2,223. Previous high mark was for the week ended Jan. 16, 1940, when registrations totaled 2,052.

Boldini was a ruling spirit in the John-Frederics hat collection, which was presented yesterday morning in the showroom at 28 East Forty-eighth Street. Not only in hat lines and clouds of veiling, but in hair arrangements, did the artist whose paintings perpetuated the ultra-feminine type of the turn of the century make himself felt in the collection. Antoine collaborated with John in the new styles set.

SYDNEY, N.S., Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Canadian Labor Department tonight asked Philip Murray, president of the United Steel Workers of America (C.I.O.), for his "active intervention" after 5,000 union workers struck at the huge Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation plant here, and another estimated 5,000 at the Algoma Steel Corporation at Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., voted unanimously to strike Thursday.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

While only informal discussions have gone on among New York racing officials since the recent ban on pleasure driving, a survey yesterday showed all the tracks intended to go ahead with plans for the opening of the season on April 8 and continuance until November.

That time-honored vaudeville term, "opened and closed in one," more or less aptly describes what has happened to the lightweight championship elimination tournament so enthusiastically proposed two short months ago after Sammy Angott had decided to retire and take up defense work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Under persistent questioning, James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, told a Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee today that, although he had on Aug. 1 barred members of the union from making recordings or transcriptions, he had not yet made any specific demands on the companies affected.

Babe Ruth today will start a series of personal appearances at Skouras Theatres in the metropolitan area on behalf of the war effort, it was announced yesterday by the motion-picture theatre chain. He will make appeals to youngsters at matinees, during which he will ask the children to contribute such salvageable materials as stockings, rubber and copper.
LONDON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The British Eighth Army was reported about ready for a fresh spurt toward Tripoli tonight.

The patents committee of the National Association of Manufacturers will meet today in Washington with the Patents Planning Commission appointed by President Roosevelt and headed by Charles F. Kettering, in labors intended to do what can be done in speeding up the accessibility of patents for wartime use without discarding the patent system.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The text of the Navy's account of the Hornet's career:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Mayor La Guardia and Walter P. Hedden, director of port development for the Port of New York Authority, presented today to the special Senate (Maloney) committee investigating gasoline and fuel oil shortages a five-point emergency program

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Before looking for the $16,000,000,000 of new revenue for which President Roosevelt asked in his budget message of yesterday, the Ways and Means Committee will go to work to put income tax collections on a pay-as-you-go basis, it virtually decided today.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A British communique:

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Continued strong demand, with volume limited only by ability of manufacturers to promise delivery on orders accepted, characterized today's session of the National Furniture and Home Furnishings Market at the American Furniture Mart here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The fanatical fighting of doomed Japanese on Guadalcanal found an explanation today with the disclosure that they carried documents threatening them with death if they failed to wrest the strategic island from the United States Marines.

Two events for the .benefit of Russian War Relief will he given in the near future. The first will be a musicale in the Hotel Pierre tomorrow afternoon, at which the artists will include George Cehanovsky, baritone; Robert Kitain, violinist, and Jennie Tourel, mezzosoprano.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Picturing the American public as guarded from the battlefronts of the war by a wall that is at least partly of official censorship construction, Wendell L. Willkie objected yesterday to the "what we think best" policy of official news.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 12 -- "Rationing," a screen story by Robert Hopkins, was purchased today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Wallace Beery to follow the current "Salute to the Marines" on his schedule. Grant Garrett has been engaged by the studio to prepare a scenario from the Hopkins yarn, which deals with the aspects of wartime rationing, according to the studio.

A plot by French Royalists to set up a monarchy in North Africa, with the Count of Paris as King, was responsible for the murder of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, Charles Collingwood, the Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent in Algiers, indicated in a broadcast from Allied Headquarters last night.

MOSCOW, Jan. 13 -- The Russians have thrown large units into the Caucasus battle to harry and destroy dense columns of Axis men and armor retreating along the highways and railroads. Communications are being heavily bombed and Stormoviks are making low-flying attacks on the crowded roads.

Persons required to file income-tax returns are reminded by the Bureau of Internal Revenue that 1942 returns should be filed as soon as possible. They must be in the offices of the respective collectors not later than March 15.
