The reports from Central Europe and the Balkans, coming as they must through roundabout channels, are vague and sometimes contradictory, but they leave no doubt that there is serious unrest verging on open revolt in Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary, and that guerrilla warfare of substantial proportions continues in Yugoslavia and Greece.

It is amazing how Washington manages to miss the connection between some of its labor policies and their results. Let us take as an example the anthracite strike, in effect since the beginning of the year and still unsettled, which was estimated to have involved at its peak 15,000 to 25,000 men.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The diplomatic correspondent of The Times of London, in an article to be published tomorrow, suggests that correspondents independent of military control be sent to North Africa to report the political situation there.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 13 -- After trailing at several points, Dartmouth pulled ahead in the final quarter to defeat Seton Hall, 46 -- 40, before 4,500 in Setonia gym tonight. The Indians jumped into an early lead, but lost it midway of the first half to trail at the intermission, 26 -- 22.
Chalky Wright, Californian who formerly held the world featherweight title, is considering the advisability of campaigning regularly as a lightweight.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Jan. 13 -- Francis J. McFadden, cashier, was elected today executive vice president and made a director of the First National Bank of Belleville. Philip Dettlebach, manager of L. Sonneborn Sons, Inc., of Belleville, and former Town Commissioner, also was made a director.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Continuation of local work relief projects for another year, along with the policy of "work or don't eat," a program which the State adopted last year, is sought in a bill introduced in the Assembly today by Chairman Moffat of the Ways and Means Committee.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 13 -- Australian newspapers shied away today from the political aspects of President Roosevelt's nomination off Edward J. Flynn as Minister to Australia and his personal Ambassador to the Southwest Pacific area.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 13 -- Canada is facing a reduction of her steel output by 40 per cent if Saulte Ste. Marie steel workers join their Sydney (N.S.) co-workers as they have threatened to do tomorrow morning.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The new understanding between the French National Committee and the French Communist party, announced yesterday, has caused dismay among many persons eager for the fusion of the forces of General Charles de Gaulle, Fighting French leader, and General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner in North Africa, and consternation among those independent Frenchmen hopeful of the rebirth of a free democratic nation.

Jack Benny's prowess as a violinist will undergo its most severe public test on Sunday evening, when he invades New York's shrine of classical music, Carnegie Hall. This was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, under whose sponsorship Mr. Benny's performance will be held.

Japan is an entirely different problem from the European Axis. Her home front at this time is the reverse of the European home fronts, for her civil population is very well supplied with necessities and generally in high spirits. She is still in the ascendant stages of total war.

On the ground that there has been a "complete and irremediable failure of corporate purpose and of corporate management" for Fiscal Fund, Inc., United States District Judge Paul Leahy in Wilmington, Del., ordered yesterday liquidation of the investment trust and appointed Howard F. McCall as receiver.

When the selective service system was organized the local boards were allotted sums for the rent of their quarters in proportion with the number of registrants on their lists. The sums were penurious, but no one complained or commented adversely on this instance of government economy.

German announcements last night indicated that the Russians had launched at least two new offensives, one in the Voronezh area on the upper Don and the other between Lakes Ladoga and Ilmen below Leningrad.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Although Great Britain has lost warships enough to constitute "a great fleet," First Lord of the Admiralty A.V. Alexander said today that the Royal Navy now was stronger than when it entered the war. The fact, hitherto unknown, that Britain, despite her heavy losses, now has more aircraft carriers than she had in 1939 also was disclosed by the First Lord in a speech at the Northumberland Club.

At a time when many are raising the question of what will happen to fresh-water angling next Spring if the ban on pleasure driving is continued, the Southern New York Fish and Game Association has released the names of the winners of its 1942 fishing contest.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The hulk of the destroyer Laffey rests quietly under the sea off the Solomon Islands, but in her last fight she left a wake of glory that will shine forever in the annals of the American Navy. Racing bow on, the little vessel met everything the enemy had -- cruiser, battleship and lighter craft alike -- pouring her tons of destruction into each before she herself went down with the explosion of her own magazines.

Allen Keeler, a 40-year-old automobile mechanic, was sentenced to eighteen months in prison yesterday, but before going he won a brief moment of freedom. He used the time to deliver a punch on the jaw to a man who had testified against him at his trial for perjury.

Braniff Airways, Inc., in a statement of operating results for 1942, announced yesterday an estimated net income of $946,089 after depreciation, $382,325 provision for Federal and State income taxes and other deductions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- With Dr. Eaton V.W. Read, administrator of the inventory control order, scheduled to be in Chicago tomorrow to explain the program to officials of furniture associations, protests have started to mount. Merchants have taken the stand that they are not indulging in overbuying, but instead are trying to purchase only the items needed to restock depleted inventories.
The National Maritime Union opened yesterday a book store, two reading rooms and a library for its members in the union's headquarters at 346 West Seventeenth Street.

The daily routine of the Kings-bridge Road section of the Bronx was somewhat disrupted yesterday. This is the area affected by the government decision to take over thirteen apartment buildings for quarters for Waves and Spars candidates to be trained in nearby Hunter College.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 13 -- American bombers and fighters destroyed thirty-six enemy aircraft, damaged ten more, blasted a large enemy airfield and two bridges and destroyed about fifty trucks in a day of highly successful air operations yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Autonomous local action on the part of the war relief and service groups merged yesterday into the National War Fund, was urged today in a statement issued by Charles P. Taft, acting chairman of the President's War Relief Control Board.

Westward the public opinion "poll" takes its way. It has now hit China, in the form of a sampling taken by the newspaper Ta Kung Pao in Hengyang, Hunan Province. Of course this is in the Chungking-controlled area, for the Japanese don't ask people's opinions. The sampling was not a cross-section of the population, as it might be in this country.

The Collegiate Chorus, conducted by Robert Shaw, made its first appearance of the season last night in Town Hall in a Town Hall Music Forum program that was devoted, with the single exception of an introductory concerto by Johann Sebastian Bach, to the music of William Schuman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Acting as President Roosevelt's agent, James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, has effected a compromise which will expedite completion of a large part of the synthetic rubber program which had been held up by competing demands for machinery and other parts.

Several of the contributors to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday were persons outside the metropolitan area who expressed regret that their contributions had been unavoidably delayed. There were several from Boston, others from New Haven, York, Pa., Essex, Conn., and Burlington, Vt.

Battered and undermanned, the Rangers will engage the fourth-place Red Wings in tonight's National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. And, appropriately enough from the standpoint of the local stick-wielders, the clash is for the benefit of the American Red Cross.

After a two-year absence from the movies, Paul Muni has certainly returned with what may literally be described as a vengeance in "Commandos Strike at Dawn," which started a Broadway engagement at Loew's Criterion yesterday.
The manufacturers of beauty aids -- practical people that they are -- have put away their holiday tinsel and settled down to the business of keeping us fresh and pretty with a minimum of fuss.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The War Production Board put representatives of the labor division today as staff aides to the regional directors, with authority to deal directly with war production questions affecting labor organizations within their respective regions.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 13 -- Complete mobilization, without fear or favor, of the last ounce of the nation's reserves to offset Russian military successes is demanded by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, in a warning to the home front in this week's issue of the magazine Reich.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 13 -- Boston College beat Yale's sextet in a stubbornly fought game tonight, 4 -- 2. Walt Boudreau, whose two goals in the last period provided the winning margin, was the game's star. Puddo Murphy, with two assists and a goal, also was brilliant for the Eagles.

Local representatives of the Bank of France were ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein to furnish additional particulars of the bank's defense to the suit brought against it on behalf of the National Bank of Belgium for recovery of $228,000,000 in Belgian gold entrusted to the Bank of France for safekeeping before the German invasion of Belgium.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- One of the biggest daylight attacks since the British gained air control over Western Europe was carried out by United Nations planes today in a series of hard-hitting raids on the German-controlled Continent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Lieut. Col. James Roosevelt of the Marine Corps, eldest son of the President, and fifteen other officers and men have received the Navy Cross for extraordinary heroism in a raid on Makin Island, Aug. 17-18.

A capacity audience is anticipated for the benefit matinee performance tomorrow of "Louise" at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over in behalf of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc. The heavy advance sale of tickets has been due largely to the efforts of several cooperating committees, including a special ticket committee under the chairmanship of Mrs. John Heminway, which have been working in the interests of the benefit.

A crowd of 18,319 thrilled to the season's first overtime college basketball game at Madison Square Garden last night as New York University overcame the surprisingly strong Mountaineers of West Virginia, 52 -- 51.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 13 -- Secretary Hull has been "virtually supplanted by Sumner Welles, the Under-Secretary of State, who is the leader of a powerful group of foreign service career officers that is in complete control of the State Department," Hugh G. Grant charged today in an address before the Kiwanis Club.

Ezra B. Whitman, civil engineer of Baltimore, has been elected president of the American Society of Civil Engineers, oldest engineering organization in the United States, with a membership of 18,368, it was announced here yesterterday by George T. Seabury, secretary.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A Soviet information bureau communique broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Salad and other edible oils, precious to the housewife for dressings and for cooking purposes, are now on the scarcity list, it was learned yesterday. There has been a shortage of oils for some time, but it has been stepped up greatly in the last three weeks.

Robert Schmitz, French pianist, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. His program consisted of music by composers of his native land, and the event was a benefit for the Fighting French Relief Committee.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 13 -- The Western Pennsylvania Coal Operators Association and the United Mine Workers of America signed an agreement today providing for a six-day working week for 75,000 miners in the bituminous fields in this part of the State.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt outlined four general principles for "winning the peace," in an address at the McMillin Academic Theatre at Columbia University last night, but, replying later to a question from the audience, she opposed open discussions now between the United States and Great Britain on the structure of the post-war world.

The OPA way of testing a bedspring was described yesterday by Sylvan L. Joseph, regional admininstrator, who announced that standards have been set up for springs and for studio couches and sofa beds to assure their durability and comfort even though non-priority substitutes are used in place of the former steel springs.
The apartment house with thirty-eight suites at 112 Marine Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Ida Lazaroff to a client of John D. Meyer, broker.

Jed Harris, whose last Broadway production was "Our Town," returns tonight with "Dark Eyes," a comedy by Elena Miramova in collaboration with Eugenie Leontovich, at the Belasco. The original title was "Love Is Hot a Potato," when first written by Miss Miramova.

John E. Bierwirth, president of the New York Trust Company, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting that net operating income of the company for 1942 was $3,030,392, compared with $2,680,840 in the previous year.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Allied bombers ranged far, raiding Madang, Finschhafen, Lae and Salamaua, General Douglas MacArthur's noon communique reported today. All the raided points are in New Guinea.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- At the request of the trustees of the Old Colony Railroad Company, the Interstate Commerce Commission canceled today the hearing assigned for Jan. 15 in Boston on the plan of reorganization of the Boston Terminal Company.

In November, 1864, President Lincoln wrote a letter of condolence to Mrs. Lydia Bixby of Boston, five of whose sons had been reported killed in battle. Last week President Roosevelt had the sad duty of writing a letter of condolence to Mr. and Mrs. James E. Rogers of Birmingham, Ala., three of whose sons died on the same warship in the recent battles in the Pacific.

BOSTON, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- The will of Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, former president of Harvard University, was filed for probate today, providing for one public bequest and private bequests totaling $260,500.

Bumper baby crops plus wartime living conditions equal a modern problem in adjustment. According to the infants' furniture departments of leading Manhattan stores wartime mothers are facing a series of questions on nursery planning which they are endeavoring to help them to solve.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Peggy Ann Garner, 9-year-old actress, who was seen as Roddy MacDowall's sister in "The Pied Piper," was signed by Twentieth Century-Fox today to play Jane Eyre as a child in "Jane Eyre," with Joan Fontaine and Orson Welles.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Air Ministry released a three-year-old secret today in tell ing how Wellington bombers helped clear the seas around Great Britain's coasts of the deadly German magnetic mines that once were Adolf Hitler's "secret weapon" and which threatened the supply lines to these islands in the last three months of 1939.

Net operating earnings of the Manufacturers Trust Company in 1942, after all expenses and taxes, preferred stock dividends and net amortization of securities, amounted to $6,646,612, equivalent to $4.03 a share on the common stock, Henry C. Von Elm, vice chairman of the bank, reported yesterday to stockholders at the annual meeting.

Production on the local sequences of Sol Lesser's forthcoming film, "Stage Door Canteen," got under way yesterday at the Fox Movie-tone Studio in West Fifty-fourth Street with the filming of scenes involving Xavier Cugat and his orchestra.

Offering will be made today of a new issue of $90,000,000 of Canadian Government bonds by a nation-wide syndicate of 134 investment houses, headed by Morgan Stanley Co., the First Boston Corporation, Smith, Barney Co., Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.; Wood, Gundy Co., Inc.; the Dominion Securities Corporation and A.E. Ames Co., Inc.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- With reference to the situation at the front, the official German news agency, D.N.B., broadcast a dispatch from the Berliner Boersen-Zeitung, written by Infantry General Paul Hesse, terming Axis reverses in Russia "unavoidable" and admonished his countrymen not to take them "too seriously."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Asserting that "information of a strategic character has been sent to persons in foreign countries in connection with insurance contracts," Attorney General Francis Biddle has sent a letter to insurance companies and brokers throughout the United States calling attention to provisions of the Espionage Act of 1917 and directing them to submit their problems to the Office of Censorship for clearance.

Stanley S. Surrey, tax legislative counsel to the United States Treasury Department, introduced the "withholding infant" to the National Retail Dry Goods Association at its thirty-second annual convention, or wartime conference yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania and explained that "the foundations of a real collection-at-the-source-system have been laid in the 5 per cent withholding tax on wages and salaries."

DAKAR, French West Africa, Jan. 12 (Delayed) -- Vice Admiral Collinet, the commander of the French fleet at Dakar and of all the forces at Dakar itself, told me today: "We will cooperate fully with the American and British fleets."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Manpower shortages in industry threaten to become so acute as to necessitate a concentration of production of some civilian goods in the hands of a few factories.

The constitutionality of that provision of the Public Utility Holding Company Act which is aimed at the forcible streamlining of holding companies, and which is commonly known as the "death sentence" clause, was upheld yesterday in a unanimous decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here.

Advertisers who in 1914-1919 consistently maintained their promotion activities were proportionately successful, while those who curtailed such programs are today almost forgotten, Frank M. Mayfield, president of Scruggs, Vandervoort Barney, Inc., and also president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Exemption of all soldiers, sailors and marines from income tax liabilities on pay they receive in the armed services was proposed today by Representative Woodruff of Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- Director Elmer Davis of the Office of War Information at a press conference today denied German claims that U-boats recently sank thirteen tankers of a sixteen-ship convoy en route to Gibraltar. He confirmed that there had been an attack and that some damage had been done, but he said the losses, which he refused to disclose for military reasons, were not "anywhere near as heavy as the Germans claim."

Curtiss-Wright Corporation's pioneer plan to offer training and jobs to 800 college women upon completion of a ten-month "custom-built curriculum" at eight of the nation's engineering schools, rolled further into being yesterday with the announcement that 400 prospective engineering "cadettes" had signed up.

Although many motorists in the metropolitan area have asked used car dealers to appraise their automobiles since the latest OPA ban on pleasure driving went into effect, only a small number of them have sold their cars, a survey of automobile dealers disclosed yesterday.

WHEN William Allen White was last in New York he was on a personal crusade. Wherever he went he plucked people by the sleeve and urged them to read MacKinlay Kantor's "Gentle Annie." Now he is continuing his crusade, only this time he is urging people, by wire, to read Mr. Kantor's "Happy Land."* "Of all the war books I have read," says Mr. White, "'Happy Land' is the most American."

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Prices of hogs advanced today 5 to 15 cents a hundred pounds to the highest point reached in any January since 1920 amid growing reports that black markets in meat were holding down shipments of hogs to organized slaughtering centers.

Sixty thousand additional barrels of fuel oil or more than 2,500,000 gallons daily will be brought into the East Coast area as a result of the successful application of the pleasure-driving ban, it was disclosed last night by the petroleum industry.

In his letter appearing in THE TIMES of Jan. 9 Louis Bromfield refers to the war savings program thus: "The number of war bonds cashed as quickly as possible will continue to increase at the present alarming rate unless * * *. It is no good taking in bond money by the front door while it pours out the back.

ON WESTERN FRONT OF GUADALCANAL, Dec. 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- American patrols have killed an average of fifteen Japanese to each one of our men lost in the last two weeks in a series of bitter actions in the soggy jungles.

A Japanese broadcast asserted yesterday that the United States aircraft carrier Hornet, identified Monday by the American Navy as the aircraft carrier sunk Oct. 26 in the Battle of the Santa Cruz Islands, was the vessel that carried the planes that raided Tokyo last April 18.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The story of how a United States Navy PBY amphibian patrol plane covering a convoy in the North Atlantic last month sank a German submarine was told in London today by the plane crew.

Dr. Frank Alvord Perret, dead at 75, lived a strange, dangerous, fruitful and fascinating life. He was what may be called the minister of volcanoes. He fell in love with them at 6. He served them for more than thirty years. Whenever they began to be active and explosive he was on the spot as soon as he could get there.

Nineteen local housing authorities in various parts of the country awarded yesterday new issues of notes, aggregating $78,492,000. A syndicate of commercial banks headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company got eighteen of the issues, totaling $76,276,000.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Jan. 13 -- The "soldier of the week," chosen from among the husbands, brothers and friends of the seventeen members of a club of war workers in the lamp division of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company here, is receiving a gift package and seventeen friendly letters under a plan started by two girls who decided that soldiers needed cheer as well as war materials.

Undoubtedly you've remodeled your menus considerably in the last few months. You've changed them this way and that, striving to adapt your cookery to shortages of meat and butter and tinned goods, trying to keep your meals as appetizing as they ever were in the old days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A ten-day inventory restriction, designed to provide more equitable distribution of restricted supplies of petroleum products, has been put on all fuel oil and gasoline resellers and industrial and commercial consumers in the seventeen-State Eastern shortage area, Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator for War, said today.

DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 13 -- Minor league baseball still can see through the fog of a world of turmoil. Just when or where the boat will land is not so easy to determine at the moment, but the fact remains we are not completely blinded mid we are not shedding copious tears.

Although the wholesale price of the best grade of eggs has dropped 10 1/2 cents a dozen recently, the retail price has remained close to its peak, it was asserted yesterday by leaders of the industry, with consequent adverse effects on consumer demands for eggs and on the wholesale market in this city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- An increase of 4,000,000 cases in the volume of canned soups which will be packed this year in metal cans for civilians, the armed forces and lend-lease is authorized by terms of an amendment to conservation order M-81 issued by the War Production Board today.

The President has designated March as Red Cross Month. And at that time one hundred thousand volunteers will ask New York to contribute $12,920,700 to the 1943 Red Cross War Fund. This is about one-tenth of the $125,000,000 total set for the nation. It is estimated that more than 2,000,000 separate contributions will be needed to assure this city's quota.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Maepeace, flying the silks of former Jockey Harry Richards, and Pittistraw, representing J.H. Heaton and W. Wilkerson, raced to a dead heat for first place in the Plaquemine Purse at the Fair Grounds race track today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Informed of Outfielder Joe DiMaggio's decision to enter the armed services, Joe McCarthy, manager of the Yankees, said tonight, "Whatever he does is his affair. I have nothing to say."

Four courses in general business, seven in investment analysis, six in brokerage procedure and eleven in military and civilian defense training have been announced by the New York Institute of Finance for the Spring term, which will commence on Feb. 2.

James Henle, president of the Vanguard Press, said in a statement released yesterday that as far as he was concerned his recent controversy with the American Library Association over "Studs Lonigan" "has now been concluded." He referred to the A.L.A.'s elimination of the James T. Farrell novel from a list of books that English publishers were to import in unbound sheets.
OTTAWA, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Canadian Army casualties from the beginning of the war to Dec. 25 totaled 7,243, it was learned today at the Defense Department.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 13 -- The arrest of seven bearded members of a Negro cult known as the House of Israel, one of the leaders of which was said to have been associated at one time with a Japanese agent in the promotion of the Pacific Movement, was announced late today by E. E. Conroy, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard authorized today the sale of government-owned soft wheat at prices designed to help stabilize the grain at levels which would allow millers to sell flour under government price ceilings without being squeezed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- The corn market continues depressed, with scattered liquidation through commission houses induced by the placing of a ceiling on the cash article and futures, effective today. Prices on the Board of Trade dipped today nearly 1 cent a bushel, but they rallied somewhat on a little short covering and buying attributed to cash interests, and the close was 5/8 to 3/4 cent lower than yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Roosevelt is expected to make public soon an "American Beveridge Plan," formulated by the National Resources Planning Board, with suggestions by the Social Security Board, for an expanded and unified national contributory social insurance system.

Fifty thousand boys in the metropolitan New York area who began pre-service training on Jan. 1 under a program set up by the Boys Clubs of America to prepare them for eventual military service have met all the initial tests in a satisfactory manner and are maintaining high standards for 350,000 other boys enrolled for the courses throughout the country, it was announced yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 13 -- After seeking peace and finding not even appeasement, a Rumanian delegation headed by the Premier, Marshal Ion Antonescu, returned to Bucharest tonight from Adolf Hitler's field headquarters, where it was received last Sunday.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- The Paris radio, heard by the Exchange Telegraph Agency, reported tonight that American tanks, supported by the British First Army, had launched fierce attacks against Axis positions at three points in the central sector of Tunisia.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- The Chicago Bears monopolized honors on the official All-National Football League team released today by placing five men on the first eleven. The Bears' representation on the all-league team was the heaviest any club has had since 1934, when the New York Giants gained five places.

Spring in its colorful fragrance burst upon mid-January yesterday afternoon when Lilly Dache drew aside the curtain and revealed her idea of what brims and crowns should be for the months to come. Brightness and sparkle prevailed. Color abounded.

The Dodgers, whose Spring training plans are still hanging in frosty midair pending final decision on their efforts to obtain the use of the Yale baseball cage at New Haven, were dealt a severe jolt yesterday when word was received in Flatbush that Pete Reiser, their star outfielder, had passed his physical examination in St. Louis and had been accepted for general service in the Army.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Botany Worsted has been called for Feb. 24 in Passaic, N.J., to act upon a proposed amendment to the certificate of incorporation that will permit the payment of dividends on the cumulative preferred stock when net earnings from Jan. 1, 1937, have aggregated $1,500,000, rather than the $2,500,000 total required by the present terms of the charter.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The supplement to the midnight communique took another occasion to poke fun at the Germans, this time reprinting a German report that "Soviet war prisoners taken by German troops are chiefly 15-year-old boys and old men of 60 and more."

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 13 -- Bomb explosions continue to be reported from France. The latest occurred in the Department of Basses-Alpes, in the region now occupied by Italian troops. At the Digne office of the newspaper Eclaireur of Nice material damage was done by a bomb placed in the basement.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- Four American heroes of the New Guinea campaign were decorated with Distinguished Service Crosses by General Douglas MacArthur today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Albert W. Harris, dean of Chicago bankers, resigned today at the age of 75 years as chairman of the board of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank at the anual meeting of the bank's board of directors. He will continue as a member of the board, but will take a less active part in the affairs of the bank, which he has headed since 1913, when he became president.

Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard, head of the Food Administration, will be the principal speaker at the War Council of Wholesale Grocers, sponsored by the National American Wholesale Grocers Association, in Chicago, Jan. 27, it was announced yesterday.

The redoubtable Al Woods, hero of a thousand battles along Broadway, has come back to town, and that definitely can be set down in the column of good news. Once more the Woods cigar fumes through Times Square, and on the telephone the cheerful voice says "hello, sweetheart," just as though the telephone had been invented for that purpose.

Sales of thirty leading mail order and chain store companies showed an increase of 4.6 per cent in December over the same month last year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The gain in November was 9.4 per cent, while the rise reported for December, 1941, was 29.5 per cent.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran attributed today to wartime curtailment of non-essential spending a 37 per cent decline in incorporations of stock companies in New York State during 1942. A result of the slump was that State revenue from incorporation taxes, fees and levies on consolidations of corporate interests were reduced $481,000 below 1941.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 13 -- Strikers at the foundry of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation extended their picket line to the main manufacturing plant on Beckwith Avenue this afternoon after their attorney had telephoned to Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins a request that the five-day-old dispute be certified to the War Labor Board.

The torpedo plane is the "most lethal weapon we possess" but it would be foolish to say it alone will win the war, Lieutenant Harold H. Larsen, commander of the Navy's famous Torpedo Squadron 8, declared yesterday in an interview at the Hotel New Yorker.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Sinyang, important Japanese base in Southern Honan Province on the Peiping-Hankow railway, has been recaptured by the Chinese, the Chinese High Command announced tonight. This was considered the most significant Chinese victory in months in the Central China war theatre.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Countess Virginie Violetta Melanie de Laune, who said a year ago she did not care to see another birthday, reached 105 today. But the sparkle was gone from her eyes and the smile from her lips.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- On the morning of April 3, 1942, the dispatches from and relating to the Russo-German front were far from optimistic concerning the question whether the Soviet armies could survive the Summer intact.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Most markets were quiet today, but the tone was firm and gilt-edged issues hardened. The 3 1/2 per cent war loan rose 1-16 to 105 7-16. Domestic rails remained steady but foreign rails eased.

Today two French armies march across the African desert. The troops of General de Gaulle, pushing up through Libya on the long trek from Lake Chad, have conquered the whole Fezzan region and are proceeding up the Algerian border toward Gadames. General Giraud's forces, moving farther north toward Tunis, have driven the Germans out of a stubbornly defended mountain pass guarding the coast.

The entire blockfront on the north, side of East 135th Street from Locust to Walnut Avenues, the Bronx, has been sold by the United Hoisting Company, Inc., to Albina D. Sardi through J.P. McCann, broker.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 -- Revamping of the taxation program so as to encourage and stimulate private industry may be necessary after the war to prevent disrupted economy, according to William H. Wynne of the National Resources Planning Board, one of a panel of speakers at the industry war conference of the Middle Atlantic Lumbermens Association, who attempted to paint a word picture of what life in America would be like after the war.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Admiral Sir William James, who has just retired from the active list as commander in chief at Portsmouth, one of the most important jobs in the British Navy, has been appointed chief of naval information, it was announced today.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Jan. 14 -- The Red Army pushed rapidly north through sagging German forces in the Caucasus yesterday, advancing fifty miles from the Georgievsk-Mineralnye Vodi area to Juravskoe, it was announced officially early today.

Commission house liquidation, precipitated by the announcement that Secretary of Agriculture Wickard has authorized the sale of soft wheat from the government's surplus stocks as a price-stabilization measure, depressed the cotton futures market yesterday in late dealings to losses of 13 to 14 points.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Jan. 12 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- An outfit of American Lockheed Lightning fighter pilots, which three weeks ago did not have a single Japanese plane to its credit, boasts today five of New Guinea's seven fighter aces who have shot down five or more Japanese planes in combat.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A communique:
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WILKES-BARRE, Jan. 13 -- Striking anthracite coal miners voted by a large majority tonight against returning to work, disregarding a warning from the War Labor Board of action if they did not end their fifteen-day-old strike.

OLD FORGE, N. Y., Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- Timothy Marsh, 79, retired New York City fish salesman, was alive and well today because that motto of the United States postal service about ignoring the elements meant more to Miss Anne Gibbs, 18-year-old girl mail carrier than mere words.

A clue that was noted by a freak of chance two hours before the killing of the 68-year-old philosophical anarchist, Carlo Tresca, led the police yesterday to pick up and hold Carmine Galante, a 35-year-old gunman with a nineteen-year record of crime and prison.

Hunter College has joined Brooklyn and Queens, the city's two other oil-heated colleges, in adding one week to the inter-semester president, announced yesterday. The new term will begin Feb. 15 instead of Feb. 8, as originally vacation, Dr. George N. Shuster, planned.

Several luncheon parties were given yesterday at the Stork Club. Miss M. Van Vryling Dunham entertained with a luncheon there for Miss Evelyn Freeman of Riverdale, who is leaving tomorrow to resume her studies at the Madeira School in Greenway, Va. Another party there was given by Miss Jean Leslie, whose guests included the Misses Emma Converse Davis, Dudley Kenyon, Victoria Goldsmith and Helen McCulloch.

The appointment of twenty-four business executives as division chairmen for the 1943 Red Cross War Fund was announced yesterday by Bernon S. Prentice, financial chairman of the drive's commerce and industry committee. Mr. Prentice explained that this was the first step toward mobilizing executives and the personnel of the city's banks, trust companies, insurance companies, exchanges and security dealers for an intensive campaign.

A public debt of $250,000,000,000 at the end of this war would not impose too great a burden on the national economy of the United States if no efforts are made to alleviate the debt problem through unorthodox means, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance in the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration, said yesterday to members of the N.Y. U. Men in Finance Club at their luncheon meeting at the Bankers Club.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Eighth United States Circuit Court of Appeals was asked today to reverse and remand to the Interstate Commerce Commission for further study a reorganization plan for the Missouri Pacific Railroad and twenty-seven subsidiary lines.

Women's part in the war effort and problems arising from the reshuffling of the country's population were discussed at length yesterday by Mrs. Harrison S. Elliott, president of the Young Women's Christian Associations, who has just returned from a tour of the country.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The first opposition to Governor Dewey's legislative program developed today, as a taxpayers' group attacked his plan to change the date of the State's fiscal year, declaring that it was a "muddled, expensive change."

Events today: "Salome," final performance of the season, also "La Serva Padrona," Metropolitan Opera, House, 8:15 .P.M.; concert by New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Fritz Reiner conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P.M.; benefit recital for Russian War Relief, Jennie Tourel, mezzosoprano; George Cehanovsky, baritone, and Robert Kitain, violinist, Hotel Pierre, 3:30; benefit for the Salvation Army, Arma Symphonic Band, Edwin Franko Goldman conducting, Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street, 8.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Senator H. Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, made charges of "unfitness" today against Edward J. Flynn of New York, Democratic National Chairman and Minister-designate to Australia, who retorted that the statements were "wanton falsehoods" which would be "definitely nailed" at a hearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Prices on the stock market firmed moderately yesterday, but volume was too light and too much centered in low-priced issues to bring any definite conclusions. It was difficult for brokers to read much meaning in the technical behavior of the list, and arguments listed for further advance or nearby reaction rather neatly balanced.

Donald Frame of the Harvard Club, Metropolitan and New York State amateur squash racquets champion, and H. Williamson Pell of the Princeton Club advanced to the final round of the New York State title tournament last night at the Downtown A.C. They will meet at 5:30 P.M. today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Nobody can use his A, B or C rationing card to drive even to any of the President's Birthday Ball celebrations without violating the ban on pleasure driving which was put into effect last week, the Office of Price Administration stated today.

Prices on the stock market firmed moderately yesterday, but volume was too light and too much centered in low-priced issues to bring any definite conclusions. It was difficult for brokers to read much meaning in the technical behavior of the list, and arguments listed for further advance or nearby reaction rather neatly balanced.

Donald Frame of the Harvard Club, Metropolitan and New York State amateur squash racquets champion, and H. Williamson Pell of the Princeton Club advanced to the final round of the New York State title tournament last night at the Downtown A.C. They will meet at 5:30 P.M. today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Nobody can use his A, B or C rationing card to drive even to any of the President's Birthday Ball celebrations without violating the ban on pleasure driving which was put into effect last week, the Office of Price Administration stated today.

A revision of the Friedsam formula, by which State aid for education is apportioned to localities, was urged yesterday by Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the Board of Education, in a letter to Governor Dewey. The present method of providing State aid, based on pupil attendance, is "inadequate to meet present day education needs and to give the intended relief to taxpayers," Mr. Buck said.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- Army's basketball team in its opening game came a cropper at the hands of Columbia University today, the Lions administering a 29-to-23 defeat to the cadets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- East Coast Senators and Representatives called upon President Roosevelt by resolution today ,to exert "every power in his possession" to bring about resumption of mining in the anthracite fields immediately.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The following were among 458 flying officers and men who received decorations yesterday from Brig. Gen. Patrick W. Timberlake, chief of the American Bomber Command in the Middle East:

I was deeply interested in the statement by Dean Newman of the School of Technology of City College with regard to the necessity of having college women enroll in war subjects which would prepare them with specific skills for war jobs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Information received from Army officers tonight indicates that Hugh Grant was, for four months prior to September, 1942, a civilian lecturer in the Army Orientation Courses, telling troops about the Far East.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Charles E. Bedaux of New York, friend of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, has been arrested in French North Africa on charges of trading with the enemy, according to information received here.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique :

Spokesmen for the National Retail Dry Goods Association, holding its thirty-second annual convention -- "wartime conference" -- at the Hotel Pennsylvania, quickly took exception yesterday when Dr. J. Kenneth Galbraith, Deputy Administrator of OPA, declared that price control had not been "tough enough."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The British commanders in the North African war theatre are in full accord with the policies of their American Commander in Chief, Lieut. Gen Dwight D. Eisenhower, in the political as well as the military sphere, even though some political circles in London apparently do not share that accord, it was said authoritatively here today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 13 -- The Federal Grand Jury investigating the alleged $1,000,000 fraud in the construction of the big naval supply depot at Mechanicsburg returned six indictments today naming nine persons, including Theodore Roosevelt Ports of Trenton, second vice president of the General Contractors at the $40,000,000 project.

THE Rangers will play the Red Wings at Madison Square Garden tonight and the winner can be predicted with such accuracy that there is not the slightest danger of there being any mistake. For the benefit of the betting gentry, who always prefer a sure thing, it can be stated without fear of contradiction that the winner will be the American Red Cross, which marches off with all the receipts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The tempo of fighting on Guadalcanal appeared today to be quickening as our forces continued their land and air attacks on enemy concentrations. A communique also revealed that the Japanese had bombed our positions two days ago.

Possibility that the American fur manufacturing industry, chiefly concentrated in the New York metropolitan area, where approximately 5,000 firms normally employ 40,000 workers, may be classified as "less essential" rather than "nonessential," and thus avoid likelihood of its being allowed to "bleed to death" during a wartime economy, was announced yesterday by the National Federation of the Fur Industry, Inc., following a conference with Manpower Commissioner Paul D. McNutt.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Young have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Newport.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 13 -- Flare-ups between counsel for the Henry J. Kaiser interests and a trial examiner and lawyers for the National Labor Relations Board enlivened today's sessions of a board hearing on the "unfair" labor case against three Kaiser West Coast shipyards.

Miss Beatrice Hudson, 23 years old, of 277 Park Avenue, was found injured and in a dazed condition on the roof of a tenement house at 9 West 132d Street, in the Harlem district, last night and was taken to the Harlem Hospital after a tenant in the house had called the police.

One week ago, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City were an even $500,000,000. When the new figure is made known late this afternoon, as of the close of business yesterday, it is expected to be around $300,000,000.
A High Command communique broadcast from Roma and recorded here by The Associated Press:

When our Army reaches its probable total of 7,500,000 men its rations for a month will be nearly equal in bulk to the Empire State Building. The soldier eats five and a half pounds of food a day, or a pound and a half more than the civilian. Figures like these, furnished by Army statisticians, give a hint as to what the American farmer's job in wartime is.

With protracted deliveries looming up as the No. 1 obstacle, retailers must be prepared to increase their initial purchases in basic stock items in dresses and accessories for Spring, Milton Stern, merchandise director of Felix Lilienthal Co., Inc., said yesterday at the second of the ready-to-wear clinics of that buying organization.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 13 -- The days of the hot dog as well as bologna and sausage were numbered tonight when Charles M. Elkington, an official of the Meats Division of the Office of Price Administration, announced that all "cold cuts" soon would be replaced by a standard ersatz product.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The work of the Coastal Command of the Royal Air Force, the jobs of which are so much less spectacular and so much more wearing than those of either fighters or bombers, is told in a government booklet issued today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Pierre Laval, the Vichy Chief of Government, has yielded to German pressure for obtaining control of the American diplomats, consuls, newspaper correspondents and Red Cross and relief workers interned at Lourdes, France, and plans to bargain for their exchange for Germans detained by the Americans, particularly members of the German Armistice Commission in North Africa.

Gasoline stocks throughout the country showed a further sharp gain last week, but fuel oil supplies were down, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the week gasoline stocks amounted to 84,245,000 barrels, an increase of 1,825,000 over the 82,420,000 of a week earlier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- After a table-thumping session with the Senate subcommittee investigating the ban on recordings and transcriptions by the American Federation of Musicians, James C. Petrillo, the president, abruptly promised the investigators today that he would negotiate with the record and radio industries for an early settlement of the controversy.

The report of the Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., incorporated in Canada, and all subsidiaries, announced yesterday, shows for the quarter ended with October a net profit of $4,385,365 in United States currency.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- In an effort to prevent a possible food shortage in the United States this year, the Federal Government will soon start a drive to persuade Americans to grow vegetables and raise chickens in their front and back yards, Donald Brann of New York City told the Middle Atlantic Lumbermen's Association in an open forum today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 14 -- Despite incessant attacks by Axis submarines and aircraft, the ships and seamen of the Royal Navy have successfully escorted 971 transports, supply ships and other vessels with a gross tonnage of about 7,600,000 tons between the Strait of Gibraltar and the North African ports now used by the Allies.

Some interesting facts about food, fishing and conservation are to be found in the statement just received from Charles Jackson, Acting Deputy Coordinator of Fisheries, and much of it is directed to sport fishermen. It is an appeal for all to join in saving and utilizing the vast amount of fish usually taken by the salt water fraternity.

Restrictions on immediate use of the vast fund of purchasing power that will be available, a housing boom, new concepts of regional planning eliminating blighted city areas, and only gradual relaxation of price control were foreseen as after-the-war developments at the forum on "Post-War Realities" held yesterday as part of the wartime conference of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Dusolina Giannini, the Metropolitan soprano, was married to Alan Richter of Mount Vernon, N.Y., on Dec. 26, at the Giannini home in Philadelphia, she announced yesterday. After a brief stay in New York, the couple are now en route to California, where the singer will give several recitals as part of her annual concert tour.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 14 -- A solution of the present tangled French political situation lies in an early meeting between General Charles de Gaulle and General Henri Honore Giraud, according to Harold Macmillan, British Minister at Allied headquarters.

Total business on furniture with wooden springs was excellent in Chicago, manufacturers returning from the market there reported yesterday. With most buyers still skeptical about the new lines, however, the buying was restricted to immediate needs, with the result that most of it was done by stores in defense areas, while some of the larger department stores which had covered themselves heavily on steel springs only sampled the new lines.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A British communique:

Broadway motion picture theatres came through the first week after the ban on pleasure driving with no appreciable dimunition of the record attendance pace set during the Christmas-New Year holidays. In fact, some theatre managers were of the opinion that local business was stimulated due to the storage of automobiles.

Net operating earnings of the Bankers Trust Company in 1942 amounted to $8,467,463, compared with $7,967,486 in 1941, S. Sloan Colt, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday. In addition, he said, the bank realized net profits on sales of securities of $935,754 and realized an additional $364,101 on recoveries and miscellaneous credits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Senate heard Senator Bridges denounce Edward J. Flynn, heard Senator Truman condemn the anthracite coal strike and adjourned at 3:25 P.M. until noon Monday. Its Truman committee heard testimony on the farm machinery problem and discussion of hard coal tonnage.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 14 (U.P.) -- A Federal grand jury indicted the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company of Pawtucket and five individuals today on charges of selling defective wire and cable for combat use of the Army Signal Corps and to the British War Ministry.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Michael J. Quill, fiery head of the Transport Workers Union, would be barred from representing members of his union in negotiations with Mayor La Guardia and the City of New York, under the term of the Wicks bill, introduced on the opening day of the Legislature, it was disclosed today.

Former President Herbert Hoover, who was United States Food Administrator and chairman of the Belgian Relief Committee in the last war, urged public support of the Salvation Army 1943 campaign for wartime activities and welfare needs yesterday afternoon at a meeting in the Hotel Biltmore, opening the city-wide drive for $525,000, which is $125,000 more than was raised last year.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Faced with mounting casualties and growing demands on new fronts, the Germans are making a stern effort to mobilize every available reserve by mustering into the army men previously rejected for military service, reliable diplomatic sources said today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14 -- A new post-war period of growth and evolution of the liberal arts studies was predicted by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, in his annual report to the Harvard Board of Overseers made public here tonight.

Mayor La Guardia, national, State and municipal health officials, Army and Navy officers and members of the Catholic clergy were present yesterday at a conference behind closed doors at the Academy of Medicine. None of the conferees would disclose the subject of the meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- In this space, three days ago, some account was given of the inequitable consequences of the OPA ban against "pleasure driving" to rural citizens in the East as contrasted with those who live in or near the cities and towns.

The annual appeal of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will begin today in New York and throughout the country and will continue through Jan. 30, the day of President Roosevelt's birthday. As usual, there will be parties and dances the night of the President's birthday, "Miles of Dimes" booths and other means of collecting funds by the foundation's 2,900 chapters in every State of the Union.

The State Public Service Commission yesterday sought the help of the Petroleum Administration for War in shutting down the municipal electric plants in Freeport and Rockville Centre, L.I., as a temporary measure for saving heavy fuel oil. Both communities, according to Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the commission, can be supplied with electric power by the Long Island Lighting Company, which generates electricity with coal.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- All five of the pressing production programs will be realized in 1943, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the WPB, told a press conference today.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 14 -- Warren Wright's Whirlaway, sent forth to greener pastures now that Florida's horse racing tracks are closed, shook Miami sand from his hoofs for what may have been the last time today.

Escarole and mushrooms dropped about 4 cents in price in the week but unfortunately spinach rose about the same amount. Most vegetables, however, cost the same as they did last Friday and are fairly inexpensive, as is indicated on the following list.

Directors of Best Co. declared yesterday an extra dividend of 40 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly distribution of 40 cents a share, both payable on Jan. 30. Stockholders received a similar extra payment in January, last year.

LONDON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Note circulation as reported in the weekly Bank of England statement issued today showed a decline for the second consecutive week. The drop amounted to u5,927,000 to the total of u914,098,000. This loss reflected an almost similar increase in the Bank's reserve.

When I was a child one of the chief delights of my leisure moments was to dash down to the Museum of Natural History. Immediately upon approaching the charming old building I was filled with the eager anticipation of participating in another era. Twentieth century became non-existent for those few enchanted hours and I sailed through the centuries on the wings of Pegasus.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 14 -- One war-production worker, accused of having put his machine out of commission to sleep off a hangover, and another, alleged to have tampered with weighing apparatus because he nursed a grievance against his foreman, were arraigned here today before United States Commissioner William J. Bartholomew on sabotage charges and remanded to Hudson County jail in default of $1,000 bail each to await action of the Federal grand jury.

With representatives of the Army and Navy and a group of mothers of service men participating, the campaign headquarters of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York was opened yesterday at 130 West Forty-second Street.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art is opening today an exhibition of paintings by distinguished present-day artists of China, who are as little known in this country as they are well-known in their own.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 -RKO announced today that Kay Kyser and his orchestra and Edgar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy will head the cast of a musical comedy scheduled for Spring production by the studio under the title "Keep 'em Singing." Robert Harari and Eve Greene have been engaged to write the photoplay, which Allan Dwan will produce and direct in March.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 14 -- Between 15,000 and 18,000 men, involved in a revolt against the United Mine Workers of America because of an increase in dues, remained idle today, closing fifteen mines and crippling the forces at two others.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- Lieut. Gen. Maslennikoff's Caucasus army is maintaining contact with the main German forces in all principal sectors. A series of violent battles in the last twenty-four hours resulted in the announcement of general advances this morning.

The temporary board of directors of Triumph Explosives, Inc., which has been nominated for re-election at the annual stockholders' meeting to be held in Elkton, Md., on Tuesday, has selected men who will be entrusted with the management of the company with the approval of the United States Navy Department, it was announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec, 20 -- Once the Germans have been ousted finally from Africa, the North African front will haven a use for an even greater share of American warplanes than is already alloted to it. The land war in Africa may soon be over, but the air-sea war from Africa is just beginning.
The first Pan European Conference to discuss economic and constitutional problems of post-war Europe will convene here March 25, it was announced yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14 -- The Dartmouth hockey team snapped Harvard's winning streak at seven games and extended its two-year record to twenty-four straight tonight at the Boston Skating Club by toppling the Crimson, 10 -- 8, in a non-league game, Deadlocked at 1 -- all after one period, Harvard took the lead twice in the second session before a three-goal surge put the Indians ahead, 7 to 4.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The six New England Governors wound up a day of conferences on oil, lumber and manpower, today by telegraphing to President Roosevelt a request for him to "use all the authority at your command to keep the coal mines running at full capacity."

Thirteen additional contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund, totaling $84, were received yesterday at THE NEW YORK TIMES and through two of the eight agencies that attest the cases. These gifts brought the total of the fund to date to $251,088.

After reading about disciplinary problems in the schools and seeing estimates of the wartime rise in juvenile delinquency, it helps one's perspective to note that the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York is now planning to train 6,000 more girls for various types of public service this year.

With Broadway devoid of any premieres next week, members of the Drama Critics Circle will rest a bit before passing judgment on January's last two offerings. Listed for the final week of the month are "Ask My Friend, Sandy" at the Biltmore on Jan. 27 and "The Patriots" at the National on Jan. 29.

Fritz Reiner, who conducted the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, had not officiated at the Winter concerts of this organization since 1929. In the interval, Mr. Reiner's art as orchestral interpreter has naturally matured.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The men who govern post-war France will be selected on the basis of what they have done to liberate the nation rather than on their political faith, Ferdinand Grenier declared today in a two-hour press conference at the headquarters of the Fighting French.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (U.P.) -Postmaster Frank C. Walker has been persuaded to accept the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee.

The 35-year-old gunman, Carmine Galante, stuck to his story yesterday, after the second day of questioning by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, that he knew nothing of the murder of the anarchist editor, Carlo Tresca.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 14 -- Two small but tactically important French victories in the southern sector of the Tunisian front, which were supported by the Lafayette Escadrille, in its first action with French forces, featured yesterday's reports from the battle zone.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (U.P.) -- Five admirals, two Marine Corps generals and almost a score of naval officers have been put on the retired list, although most of them have been retained on duty in their present posts, the Navy said today.

A General Sessions jury yesterday acquitted Frederick G. Heydt of 4440 Waldo Avenue, and Richard Mugler of 4611 Arlington Avenue, both in the Bronx, on charges of grand larceny in connection with two city contracts totaling $15,000, granted in 1939 to the Heydt-Mugler Company, Inc., of which they were officers.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Reports of an imminent quarrel between Downing Street and the White House over American policy in Algeria and Morocco are causing so much concern here that Brendan Bracken, Minister of Information, went so far today as to allow himself to be quoted, thus departing from the general practice of talking off the record.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- More than 100 tons of high explosives and incendiaries were dropped on Essen in twelve minutes by Royal Air Force raiders last night, the British announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was urged today by its public utilities division to complete liquidation of the North American Light and Power Company under the aegis of a Federal District Court under Section 11 (d) of the Holding Company Act.

DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 14 -- In this period of wartime crisis, when freedom is more than ever at stake, "the destruction of the tradition of the liberal arts" would be a crime comparable with the burning of the books by the Nazis and would lead to the same loss of freedom as if we invited Hitler and his henchmen to rule over us, Wendell L. Willkie declared tonight in an address at Duke University.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command tonight announced the reoccupation of the Honan Province towns of Kwangshan and Loshan and declared that Chinese troops fiercely attacking the Japanese within the city of Sinyang and its environs had made progress.

Random criticisms that institutional advertising by war contractors is actually paid for by the government from money received through taxes were answered yesterday by the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company in a booklet, "Who Pays for Wartime Advertising."

Mrs. David M. Levy, daughter of the late Julius Rosenwald, Chicago philanthropist, was elected treasurer of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the museum's board of trustees. She succeeds David H. McAlpin, now serving with the armed forces.

MONTREAL, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Alex Smart, playing his first game as a professional, led the Canadiens to a 5-1 victory over Chicago tonight in a National Hockey League game before 6,500 fans by scoring three goals and assisting in another.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- United States motor torpedo boats beat off, on Sunday night (Solomons time), the second attempt by the Japanese within a month to send destroyers, presumably carrying reinforcements and supplies, to Guadalcanal Island. They torpedoed two and possibly a third.

William Woodward, master of Belair Stud, was re-elected chairman of the Jockey Club at the annual meeting yesterday when that organization brought its membership up to the prescribed fifty by the addition of three new members.

The first planet ever to be found outside our solar system, an invisible new world revolving around one of the suns in the double star named 61 Cygni, has been named Osiris by its discoverer, Dr. K.A. Strand of the Sproul Observatory, Swarthmore College, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A British Air Ministry communique:

Speaking at Duke University last night Mr. Willkie made an earnest plea for "the preservation of our cultural heritage" among the men and women of the war generation. Manifestly the heritage is, or ought to be, carried in the educational stream, and particularly in the universities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Office of Price Administration ruled today that an importer who had no maximum price in March under the General Maximum Price Regulation for an imported commodity now being sold or one similar to it, may sell the commodity to an intermediate distributor or to an industrial user at a price reflecting a fair allowance above his total landed costs.

Plans for setting up a non-profit clearing house which will ferret out idle machine tools and put them to work in shops with war contracts were developed yesterday at a meeting of the New York chapter of the Machinery Dealers' National Association in the Hotel New Yorker.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The constitutionality of subdivision 2 of Section 17-C of the personal property law enacted in 1940 was sustained in the Court of Appeals today in a 5 to 2 decision, in the case of the estate of Henry C. West against the City Bank Farmers Trust Company.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Walter J. Lepkowski, 48-year-old machinist, was cited by the National Safety Council today for distinguished wartime service to safety in one of the country's huge war plants. The machinist was credited with contributing more than 100 original safety ideas to save lives and prevent accidents to fellow-workers.

Moss Hart, the playwright, and the Warner Brothers are discussing a motion picture production deal, it was learned yesterday. Two story themes, which Mr. Hart would develop and personally produce, are under consideration. One idea concerns a drama about the American colonial period, it is understood, while the other is described as being of a topical patriotic nature.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14 (AP) -The Reynolds Brothers' Fly Ty, an 11-to-1 shot and longest-priced horse in the field of five, captured the St. Tammany Purse, six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today.

An 8.5 per cent drop in carloadings for the first quarter of this year from the corresponding 1942 period for the territory covered by the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board was forecast yesterday at the board's annual meeting at the Hotel Astor.
OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- The lives of two killers, Edmund Sileo, 28, and Joseph Sonsky, 32, were taken in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison tonight.

CENTER OSSIPEE, N.H., Jan. 14 -- The six New England States were shaken today by two earthquakes, the first apparently starting off Portland, Me., and the second ten seconds later off Cape Ann, Mass., with the tremors converging into this area.

Winthrop W. Aldrich announced yesterday that his duties as organizing chairman of the newly established National War Fund, Inc., necessarily required his resignation from the presidency of the British War Relief Society, largest American agency engaged exclusively in foreign relief, and that he would be succeded in the post he has held for more than two years by Clark H. Minor, president of the International General Electric Company.

Swifter retribution, and more of it, for wasters of gasoline took form yesterday as the district Office of Price Administration imposed the heaviest penalties so far on pleasure drivers, set up a system whereby local rationing boards in twelve counties will speed hearings on several hundred alleged violators and uncovered an entirely new form of violation of gasoline-rationing regulations.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 14 -Jasper White, assistant supervisor of Local 542, International Union of Operating Engineers, was sentenced today to thirty days' imprisonment for contempt of court because he refused to produce membership and dues records for the examination of the Federal grand jury investigating charges of fraud in the construction of the naval supply depot at Mechanicsburg.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -Accusing government "bureaucrats" of "attacking our free press," Representative Shafer of Michigan demanded today their "investigation and punishment" by Congress.

A FORWARD UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE, in Tunisia, Jan. 13 (Delayed) (AP) -- Straight-shooting P-40 pilots, some of whom took off from a field on which bombs were bursting, broke up a Nazi dive-bomb attack on this airdrome yesterday, shot down or damaged a third of the raiding force and sent the remainder fleeing home.

It will be a case of get there early if you want to see everything at Madison Square Garden tonight. There are two ten-round bouts listed, but not even Nat Rogers, Mike Jacobs's minister plenipotentiary in the matter of pairing the gladiators, knows which will take precedence over the other.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Department store sales for the week ended Jan. 9 were up 6 per cent over the corresponding period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 5 per cent in the preceding week.

In filing an income tax return, the government requires that all income must be reported except items that are specifically exempt, a list of which may be found in the instructions attached to the return form.

George A. Sloan, Commissioner of Commerce and chairman of the Mayor's Business Advisory Committee, in a radio address last night called upon the Smaller War Plants Corporation in Washington to establish a subsidiary here for the distribution of subcontracts to small manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- While members of Congress clamored today for Federal intervention and use of troops to end the unauthorized strike of anthracite miners, the War Labor Board ordered a public hearing for tomorrow to ascertain fully "why the anthracite miners, citizens of the United States, whose sons and brothers are at the fighting front, are on strike against the national no-strike policy and against the welfare of the nation in time of war."

Fashions in words are like fashions elsewhere. Most of the time they are overworked and become commonplace and then tiresome and then vanish almost as fast as they came, without having done any particular harm.

TORONTO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Labor conciliators tonight were seeking a settlement of a strike for higher wages which had halted two-thirds of Canada's steel production and taken 12,500 Canadian steel workers from their jobs. Today 3,500 workers at Trenton, N.S., and 4,000 workers at Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., joined 5,000 employes at Sydney, N.S., who had been on strike since Tuesday.
The player who had swept the board in squash racquets hereabouts last season went down in totally unforeseen defeat last night at the Downtown A.C.

Richard Strauss's "Salome" received a memorable unfoldment at its third and final presentation of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, on a double bill with Pergolesi's "La Serva Padrona." Again Lily Djanel scored heavily with her superb singing and acting in the title role of the Strauss masterpiece, and the other principals were all in top form.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during December totaled 935,511 bales of lint and 108,113 bales of linters, compared with 913,038 bales of lint and 113,728 of linters during November and 888,379 bales of lint and 109,945 of linters during December a year ago.
Five houses in Newark, N.J., were reported sold yesterday. Through Michael A. Stavitsky Co. the following changed hands:

BOISE, Idaho, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Sir Thomas Beecham, conductor of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra and former conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, obtained a divorce here today from Utica Celectia Lady Beecham on the ground of extreme cruelty.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- The War Production Board is proceeding slowly and cautiously with it controversial concentration-of-industry program and has already reduced its scope as to number of groups affected, Arthur R. Burns, deputy director for programs of the WPB Office of Civilian Supply, indicated today.

Anticipatory price-fixing against purchases of cotton by the government for lend-lease purposes, on which prices will be established on the basis of yesterday's closing quotations at the local futures market, strengthened the cotton market late yesterday following an early erratic movement.

Injunction proceedings against Police Commissioner Valentine, he disclosed yesterday, have compelled him to delay enforcement of amended police regulations that sternly limit nudity and ribaldry in cabarets and that prohibit concessionaires from photographing night-club patrons during the war.

When Russia was invaded she dropped the mental garments of communist internationalism and took on the fighting armor of nationalism. The Russian people rose as of old to defend the soil of Holy Russia. She still holds fast, after the loss of probably 5,000,000 soldiers, 70,000,000 of her population, with a considerable part of her industries and food sources.

Reserving final judgment on the necessity for expansion of social security at this time, the National Retail Dry Goods Association, in one of six resolutions adopted at its thirty-second annual convention and "wartime conference" yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, formally demanded simplification of price-control regulations.

The annual presentation of Wagner's "Ring" cycle in its entirety without cuts will be given on four consecutive Tuesday nights beginning Feb. 9, at the Metropolitan Opera House, it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 12 (Delayed) -- Professor J.P. Bhansali, a devoted follower of Mohandas K. Gandhi, yesterday ended his extraordinary fast of political protest that began on Nov. 12. It almost was the first recorded case of a free man deliberately fasting to death, but he was snatched from the grave in the sixty-first day of his suffering by a compromise with the authorities backed by the common sense of his friends.

Although cheese production in this country was lower in the last few months than during the same period a year ago, there is enough on hand to meet the normal demand, it was learned yesterday. The amount produced for the week of Jan. 7 was 17 per cent under that of the corresponding week for 1942, according to the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -Navy pilots who located Captain Eddie Rickenbacker and his companions on a rubber raft in the Pacific were identified by the Navy today as Lieutenants (j.g.) G.T. Forrest, 25 of Oakland, Calif., and J.G. Boyd, 22 of Richmond, Va.

The widest bulge of the new year was registered yesterday on the stock market with prices at new highs for the recovery movement, or since early December, 1941. The main part of the rally was crowded into the final few minutes of trading on the Stock Exchange, when, after minor offerings had failed to encourage further selling, pivotal issues assumed responsibility for the advance paced by the steel section, and particularly by "Big Steel."

Hobart Ford, widely known cruising yachtsman, whose schooner Jane Dore was seen in ocean as well as coastal waters each Summer prior to the war, last night was elected commodore of the Cruising Club of America. The election was held in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 14 -- A political story without names is almost impossible to write -- but the "political story" of French North and West Africa is not only virtually without names, but also without politics.

While four deputy United States marshals began yesterday to serve eviction notices to 613 families in thirteen buildings in the Kings-bridge section of the Bronx to make room for Waves and Spars candidates to be trained in near-by Hunter College, housewives complained bitterly that landlords in the area were raising their rents on available apartments.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Jan. 14 -- Intent on tripling or even quadrupling 1942's production record, when it turned out about 5 per cent of all combat planes built in the United States, the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation is now producing its battle-tested Wildcat fighters and Avenger torpedo bombers at a rate never before touched in the history of the company, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A question by Representative Lambertson whether two of President Roosevelt's sons had been "jerked" from battlefronts by the Commander in Chief brought a rejoinder today from the majority leader, Representative McCormack, who compared it to a deliberate lie.

At the turn of the year, Governor Poletti, State Senator Dunnigan and Assemblyman Steingut combined to sponsor a program of social legislation and asked, among other things, for a "Beveridge plan" for New York State. At the coming legislative session, they declared, the Democratic party would recommend a statutory commission to study the problem of social security and to make recommendations.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday rose 18.5 per cent from the amount for the corresponding week last year, but the volume tapered off from the enlarged totals of the previous period, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 14 -Further arrests in France by German order come to knowledge as news seeps through despite closed frontiers. They concern men suspected of having been concerned in the preparation of the Anglo-American landing in North Africa and, generally, of being hostile to "collaboration."
