Army post exchange stores are eliminating practices which have caused concern among retailers, Brig. Gen. Joseph W. Byron, head of the Army Post Exchange Service, said in an address yesterday before the wartime conference of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 14 (AP) -Four conscientious objectors began yesterday a program of vigorous work and exercise in the simulated temperature and humidity of the tropics and desert to enable University of Illinois scientists to study the food needs of troops in the Solomon Islands and Africa.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- Admiral William H. Standley, United States Ambassador, on returning to Moscow after several months' absence in the United States, said today that his chief impression on his return from a trip virtually across three continents was of vital importance to the war effort of unity of effort and purpose on the part of the nations fighting to prevent the imposition of other ideologies upon their own.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Allied ground forces have made a successful foray against the Japanese at Mubo, seven miles south of the enemy base of Salamaua, New Guinea, the Allied command announced today in revealing the first action in that area in several weeks.

The twenty-seventh annual exhibition of work by members of the Brooklyn Society of Artists is to be held at the Brooklyn Museum beginning next Friday. The exhibition, which was open to all artists living or teaching in Brooklyn, will be installed in the Special Exhibitions Gallery, where it will remain current through Feb. 7.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 14 -- A trainload of American servicemen journeying several hundred miles into the lush New Zealand farmlands was recently entertained by citizens of a city that hitherto had seen little of the fighting forces.

The 1943 campaign of the Boy Scouts of America to raise a fund of $350,000 started yesterday at a "Dawn Patrol" breakfast at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, with Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker appealing to the patriotism of 450 committee members and representatives of youth organizations to make the drive the success that it deserved to be.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Charging that the nomination of Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Chairman, to be Minister to Australia was the "most despicable" appointment ever made by the President of the United States, Senator H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire challenged the Foreign Relations Committee today to give opponents a full and open hearing on their charges that Mr. Flynn was not fit for the post.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A German spy made his Cape Town jail cell his headquarters and was able to start on its way back to Germany from there valuable information about the movement of British merchant vessels, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -The War Labor Board ordered today a wage increase of 5 1/2 cents an hour, union maintenance and check-off provisions written into contracts between six subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation and the C.I.O. United Steel workers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Among the arguments advanced today on behalf of putting Representative Margaret Chase Smith of Maine on the Naval Affairs Committee and Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut on the Military Affairs Committee was that such placement of the Congresswomen would be "a recognition" of the women's military reserves, the Waacs, Waves and Spars.
A new issue of $900,000 of temporary loan notes was scheduled yesterday by Essex County, Mass., for award on Jan. 19. It will be dated Jan. 15 and will be payable on Nov. 8.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Under no circumstances may local rationing boards in the Eastern States increase gasoline supplies of motorists holding B and C coupons to make up for the recent cut in the value of these coupons from four to three gallons each, the Office of Price Administration said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- A plan for recapitalization of the Southern Colorado Power Company, modified by the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was recommended today to the commission for its approval.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique:

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Frances Farmer, former screen actress, was sentenced to 180 days in jail today for violation of a probation sentence for drunken driving. In a melee as she was taken from court she knocked down one officer but was finally subdued by others.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -The National Labor Relations Board adhered today to its ruling that a closed shop did not prevent the employes involved from transferring to another union at the expiration of the contract.

Despite a decline in the excess reserves of member banks, the open-market committee of the Federal Reserve System, acting on behalf of the twelve central banks, made net sales of $57,029,000 of government securities in the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed in figures released yesterday.

Best Foods, Inc., formerly named the Hecker Products Corporation, had a consolidated net profit of $706,146 in the six months ended on Dec. 31 last, according to the statement issued to stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The American Federation of Musicians now stands ready to arbitrate its ban on phonograph and radio records and will further guarantee "reasonable" performance rights for amateur musicians, Joseph A. Padway told a Senate subcommittee today.

George Theunis, Belgian diplomat, said yesterday that during the last three months of 1942 50,000 Belgian workers were deported into Germany. The Germans, he said, have abandoned all pretense of voluntary conscription of a labor force to man their factories and now, from Belgium alone, are taking workers at the rate of 20,000 per month.

It will not be necessary to surrender ration coupons for baby foods in cans or jars under the new point-rationing system that goes into effect next month, Paul M. O'Leary, deputy administrator in charge of rationing for the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday in a discussion of the new program in The New York Times Hall.

On the front page of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 9, wedged between such headlines as "Pleasure Drivers Penalized," "Sea Battle Saved Convoy for Russia," "Coffee Shortage Now Acute Here" and "U.S. Fliers Pound Tunisian Targets," appears the announcement that Edward J. Flynn is to be nominated by President Roosevelt as Minister Plenipotentiary to Australia.
The value of tennis in athletics was recognized more generally after Pearl Harbor than ever before.
LONDON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio and heard here by the Soviet monitor:

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Prices of hogs dropped today 10 to 25 cents a hundred-weight and closed at the extreme decline as the supply increased with 21,000 head offered for sale and 10,500 shipped directly to packers, most offerings sold at $14.60 to $14.85. The latter price was the top and compared with yesterday's peak of $15.10.

Net assets of the Adams Express Company applicable to the common stock on Dec. 31, last, were $17,116,550, against $15,547,499 a year earlier, or $11.69 a share, against $10.62, according to a report issued yesterday by Henry K. Smith, president.

WATERLOO, Ia., Jan. 14 (AP) -The last slender thread of hope that their five sons, reported lost in the sinking of the Cruiser Juneau, might still be alive, snapped today for Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Sullivan.

Dr. Arthur Ruppin, who died recently in Jerusalem at the age of 67, after early forty years of intensive but modest labor in promoting the colonization and modernization of the Holy Land. deserves an expression of tribute on behalf of the numerous friends and admirers he won in the United States as well as in many other countries.

Brig. Gen. Brice P. Disque, assistant deputy coordinator of the Office of the Solid Fuels Coordinator for War, called last night on hard-coal consumers to burn the coal stored in their bins instead of attempting to buy more coal when they have a seven to ten days' supply in the cellar.

JACKIE WILSON fought in Berlin six years ago and he wants to go back there to fight again. He went about the business of arranging for a return trip the right way, too, since he chose as his most recent manager the Old Gentleman With the Whiskers. In other words, Jackie Wilson enlisted in the United States Army.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu in a statement to The Associated Press denied tonight that a meeting between President Ramon S. Castillo of Argentina and President Juan Antonio Rios of Chile was in prospect and said that there had not been any negotiations for such a meeting.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LYNBROOK, L.I., Jan. 14 -Augustus D. Kelsey, president of the Lynbrook National Bank and Trust Company, informed shareholders at their annual meeting that deposits, which increased on Dec. 31, 1942, to $4,193,627 from $3,448,000 at the end of 1941, and total resources of $4,563,616, were greater than at any other time in the history of the bank.

Immediate steps are being taken to remedy some of the shortcomings found to exist in the Board of Education's Bureau of Supplies, Ellsworth B. Buck, chairman of the board, announced yesterday. In his report issued Monday, William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, criticized the bureau for "extravagance, wastefulness and inefficiency and unbusinesslike methods in the purchase of school supplies."

The Board of Estimate rejected yesterday the pension application of Philip A. Hines, former first deputy city clerk, who resigned on Sept. 5 after Investigation Commissioner William B. Herlands, in a report submitted to Mayor La Guardia, had accused him of improperly accepting gratuities for performing marriages.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Teams of the National Football League played before a greater attendance in 1942 than in any previous year since the professional sport was organized.

THE greatest American industrial novel was written in the Eighteen Fifties. It was called "Moby Dick," and it was about the whaling industry. Pages of "Moby Dick" describe the industrial processes of capturing and reducing the great sea mammal to his commercial elements. But that was the oil and paraffin industry of another day.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade turned upward today as a result of reports of large sales of cash wheat and corn, and cash interests led in the buying of futures.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Treasury officials were reported authoritatively today to have discussed a modified pay-as-you-go income tax collection plan with Congressional tax experts.

The statement made yesterday in London by the British Minister of Information on the subject of Anglo-American policy toward France comes at a timely moment. In this statement Mr. Bracken said that neither the British nor American Government is backing any particular candidate for leadership of the French.

A total of $1,128,000 was collected for the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York in 1942 -- considerably more than was raised in the preceding year -- it was announced last night at an organization meeting of the Archbishop's Committee of the Laity in the Empire State Club.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- China's need of heavy war equipment that could not be transported by plane was emphasized in London today by Dr. K.C. George Yeh, director of the Chinese Ministry of Information in London.

In St. Louis an official of the Meats Division of the Office of Price Administration says that on account of the scarcity of meat a certain amount of substitute would have to be put into sausages. That's all right, and no sausage eater will complain. But the beans spill and rattle when the official talks about "the new victory sausage'"

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 14 -First Lieutenant James R. Carringer, 24 years old, son of J. Raymond Carringer of this city, general manager in charge of manufacturing operation of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, has been killed in an Army plane crash in Hawaii, according to word received by his family from the War Department.

There's nothing the New York Rangers can do about it, it seems. They suffered another defeat last night when they bowed to the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

The abnormal volume of traffic created by the war enabled the New York Central Railroad Company last year to earn in excess of $7 a share despite heavily increased costs for taxes, wages and materials, F.E. Williamson, president, said in a letter to stockholders accompanying checks for the $1 a share dividend payable today.

Objections to the final account of the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, including an objection to the qualifications of former Governor Charles Poletti as referee in the case, were filed yesterday in Supreme Court in connection with a motion by attorneys for the committee to confirm a ruling of Mr. Poletti as referee dismissing the objections.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 14 -- The Allied forces in North Africa have made available a quantity of powdered milk in fifteen of the largest cities in Algeria to be distributed to children up to the age of fourteen.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Many of Flemington's property owners will be able to pay their 1943 tax bill with a $10 banknote. The tax rate for this year is expected to be 27 cents on each $100 of assessed valuation, little more than one-third of the 74-cent rate paid last year, when Flemington had the lowest rate in New Jersey.

MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 15 -- The Red Army rolling northwestward through the Caucasus now has advanced nearly 140 miles, reaching Sotnikovsk, near the Kalmuck steppes, and Cossack cavalry and Soviet tankmen are pursuing the still retreating Nazis, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Senator Truman told a hearing of his Senate committee investigating the war program today that government agencies had so restricted the production of agricultural machinery that farmers, spurred to meet the requirements of the Food-for-Freedom program, were handicapped not only by increasing shortages in manpower but also by inadequate labor-saving devices.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Betty Hansen, 17, slight and blond, was led weeping from a Superior courtroom today after almost an entire day on the witness stand during which she testified that Errol Flynn attacked her during a party on Sept. 27.

William S. Gray Jr., president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that in addition to the net earnings for 1942 of $6,047,869, profits on securiites amounted to $283,647. The latter figure, he said, did not include substantial recoveries made during the year, which were transferred to reserves.

OTTAWA, Jan. 14 -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands has sent by her son-in-law, Prince Bernhard, a gift to the grandchild who it is expected will be born in the Ottawa Civic Hospital within a few days. The gift, Prince Bernhard said today, "will be suitable to either a boy or a girl."

Ski conditions remain favorable in the North Country and those city dwellers able to get away for "furloughs" in the snows are expected to find good trail and slope running, particularly in the Adirondacks, Berkshires, Green and White Mountains and the Laurentians of Eastern Canada.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- A serious shortage of adequate eating facilities for workers in hundreds of war plants throughout the State was reported today by Senator Desmond, Chairman of the State Joint Legislative Committee on Nutrition.

There was considerable gloom in utility holding company circles yesterday as the full import of the United States Circuit Court's opinion holding the "death sentence" to be constitutional on all counts made itself felt. The court sustained the position of the Securities and Exchange Commission in its proposed application of the "death sentence" against the North American Company.

Saved from maximum prison terms of forty years each only by the fact that their efforts to raise a pro-Axis faction in Harlem had been ineffective, five leaders of the Ethiopian Pacific Movement, Inc., were sentenced yesterday to imprisonment ranging from four to ten years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The statement made in London today by Brendan Bracken, Minister of Information, denying that Britain and the United States were at cross-purposes in North Africa and that the British Foreign Office was backing General Charles de Gaulle, Fighting French leader, was welcomed in informed quarters here as indicating the possibility of an early agreement betwen the two governments regarding some of the political issues that have arisen in North Africa.

A list of figures, covering deaths and injuries in New York from accidents in 1941 and 1942, was released yesterday by Captain Matthew F. Skea, in charge of the Police Department's Bureau of Public Safety, and revealed marked contrasts for those two years.

Portraits in hats for Spring were presented by the hat manufacturer Jeanne Tete yesterday during luncheon in the Persian Room of the Plaza. It was a novel showing, for the models were displayed in three deep-shadow box frames which gave a portrait effect.
Lieut. Comdr. Theodore Weld Sterling, U.S.N.R., Mrs. Sterling and their daughter, Miss Sarah Susanne Sterling, have arrived from their home in Annapolis, Md., and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, manufacturers of Navy scouting and bombing planes, stated today that by using printing presses in making steel patterns for the production of airplane part it had "slashed man hours and materials involved by 85 per cent and solved a major production problem.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Senator Coudert and Assemblyman Mitchell of New York City said today that they would introduce a bill tomorrow to incorporate the Interfaith House of Hunter College.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 -- Reprisals against whole villages reflect the inroads made on the morale of the Italian occupation troops by the Greek patriot activities and reveal a truly sinister undertone to the otherwise comic opera performances of the Fascist Carabinieri, according to information released here today by Greek sources.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 14 -- A charge that faith was broken when Henry J. Kaiser shipyards in the Portland area signed a closed shop contract with the American Federation of Labor was made tonight by John Green of Camden, N.J., international president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Reports delivered by representatives of organizations and groups cooperating with the 1943 Victory Book Campaign, at a luncheon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday indicated that the countrywide machinery for getting out books for the armed services is now in working order and that the collection is about to begin in earnest.

A parade and rally, held yesterday in Times Square to launch United Nations Week in the metropolitan area, were sponsored by the War Activities Committee of the Motion-Picture Industry, which will raise funds for victims of the Nazis.

HAZLETON, Pa., Jan. 14 -Leaders of 20,000 miners in Eastern Pennsylvania's southern anthracite field voted tonight to withhold action on joining the strike of 15,000 men in the northern field pending the outcome of a public hearing called for tomorrow by the War Labor Board to determine why the miners are on strike.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Stimulated by the war news from Russia, the stock markets developed today a firmer tendency. Price movements generally, however, were few and small. Gilt-edge stocks were unchanged. Home rails eased and Argentine rails showed fresh weakness following reports of large increases in operating expenses.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- A further step toward establishment of a full-fledged State Department of Commerce was taken today when Irving M. Ives, majority leader of the Assembly, introduced for the second time the proposed constitutional amendment establishing a nineteenth department of the State government.

During the first week of the ban on pleasure driving in the East, tunnel and bridge facilities of the Port of New York Authority handled about 85,000 fewer cars than in the preceding seven days, Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Authority, announced yesterday.

Lieutenant Francis K. Green, U.S.N.R., and Mrs. Green gave a dinner last night in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for Mrs. M. Harris Hamersley. Among the other guests were Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff, Mrs. William J. Hutchinson, Robert M. McBride, Baron Gabor de Bessenyey, and Huntington H. Harter.

Sweeping changes in the Revised Maximum Export Price Regulation will probably be announced by the Office of Price Administration within the next week or two, it was reported in the trade yesterday. Among the principal features of the amended regulation, it was said, will be the adjustment of present requirements on foreign invoicing and a more liberal interpretation of the base period on which the export premium is figured.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics Index of nearly 900 price series in primary markets again rose slightly during the first week of January as a result of further gains in prices for farm products and foods. With an advance of 0.2 per cent, the all-commodity index reached 101.4 per cent of the 1926 average, nearly 1 per cent above the early December level and the highest point in almost seventeen years.

CALDWELL, N.J., Jan. 14 -- A record of 753 consecutive days on the job -- Saturdays, Sundays and holidays included -- doesn't strike Lloyd Van Ness, head of the disposal system of the propeller division of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation here, as anything to get excited about.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, denied tonight charges made by Representative Herter, Republican of Massachusetts, in the House today that the Office of Price Administration had extorted "hush money" from price ceiling violators.

LONDON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The British reported slight enemy activity over the coastal districts of Northeast England last night and said bombs dropped in that area caused little damage and injury to only one person.

There appears to be a second Russian front in the theatre district this Winter. First came "The Three Sisters," or one mood; then came "The Russian People" as a story of a people's fight against Hitler. Finally, last evening, Jed Harris brought to the Belasco the play called "Dark Eyes," to complete the cycle with a comedy about Russian expatriates on a fabulous visit to Long Island.

Sally Victor is an ardent newspaper reader. Headlines (no pun is intended) inflame her milliner's mind. With her spot news goes to other people's heads. That is why, in her collection, held yesterday afternoon in her frosty white showroom at 18 East Fifty-third Street, African desert was a featured shade in straws and felts and Tunisian turbans were designed to flatter the contours of Western faces.
Although it may be all of two months before a baseball is even thrown, events in the national pastime continue to move at a blistering pace.
LONDON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A United States Eighth Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The War Department today published a citation for a Troop Carrier Group of the Army Air Forces for the transportation of several thousand troops, with artillery, by air to battle areas in Papua, New Guinea, during General Douglas MacArthur's recent campaign there.

Ranking contenders of the feline world vied yesterday for the coveted prize of best in show as the forty-first annual championship cat show of the Atlantic Cat Club, Inc., and the twenty-fifth show of the Silver Society, opened jointly in the ballroom of the Hotel Belvedere, 319 West Forty-eighth Street.

Continued Russian attacks between the Caucasus and the Don, near Voronezh and below Leningrad have failed to "bring about a new change in the situation" on the Eastern Front, German military quarters said yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.
The far-flung Russian offensives were still continuing yesterday, almost two months after the Red Armies seized the Winter initiative.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The first official Catholic repercussion to the Supreme Court's decision upholding the validity of Nevada's divorce laws came tonight in a statement issued by the Rev. Dr. Edgar Schmiedeler, director of the family life bureau of the National Catholic Welfare Conference.

Warning that the outlook is that the supply of meat will grow even shorter than it is now, Albert T. Wendel, president of the New York State Association of Retail Meat Dealers, urged yesterday that the present system of fixed ceiling prices for packers, wholesalers and retailers be abandoned in favor of a more flexible plan he said would stimulate the flow of meat to the consumer.

The Book-of-the-Month Club editorial judges have taken Bernard DeVoto's "The Year of Decision: 1846" from its reserve list and the club will distribute the title, a Little, Brown book, in April. The rest of the book club's plans are these:

An increase of 15 per cent in salaries was voted for national officials of the United Lutheran Church in America and their secretaries at a meeting of its executive board yesterday at 39 East Thirty-fifth Street. The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel presided.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The Times of London will publish the following dispatch from its special correspondent in Tunisia tomorrow:

MADRID, Jan. 15 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Carlton J.H. Hayes, addressing a gathering of diplomats and high Spanish officials, declared today that there could be no negotiated peace between the United States and its enemies.

Former Governor Charles Polett explained yesterday that his commutation of the prison sentence of Alexander Hoffman, general manager of the Cleaners and Dyers Union, Local 239, convicted of arson as an act of union terrorism, was done without his knowing that Hoffman had been arrested four times for other terroristic acts.

Monthly magazines are starting the year in encouraging fashion, with the January issues showing a linage gain in excess of 2 per cent over the like 1942 issues. In comparison with the 1941 issues, at which time this country was not involved in war, the gain was about 12 per cent.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Prices of grains advanced 1 cent a bushel or more in early trading today on the Board of Trade, and all deliveries of oats reached the highest marks of the season, Profit-taking caused a reaction from the best price on wheat, but that grain closed 5/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel higher than yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture reported today that cold storage and meat packing plant stocks of most perishable foods on Jan. 1 were materially lower than a year ago because of heavy withdrawals to meet war and civilian requirements.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- In the stock markets here today gilt-edge issues showed little change. Home rails held to yesterday's closing levels.

Howard F. Corcoran, chief assistant United States attorney, completed yesterday the presentation of general evidence on which the government seeks a ruling that membership in the German-American Bund constitutes primary proof of disloyalty to the United States.

Cars of export freight, exclusive of grain and coal, unloaded at all ports of the country in 1942 amounted to 859,276, compared with 632,083 in 1941, an increase of 36 per cent, according to the Association of American Railroads.
Manhattan's basketball team won its seventh game in eight starts last night when it turned back St. Peter's of Jersey City, 49 -29, in the Jasper gymnasium. The quintet has been beaten only by N.Y.U.

The letters appearing recently on your pages regarding skiing and other sports seem to indicate a lack of sportsmanship and some intolerance. I was wandering around the woods near here on a pair of skis before there ever was a snow train.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Ranging over the Mediterranean in a neverending search for Axis vessels endeavoring to run supplies to the German troops in Tripoli and Tunisia, British submarines have sunk three cargo vessels and a minesweeper, with three more cargo vessels listed as "probables," it was announced today.

Next week's new municipal financing will aggregate $20,569,075, compared with this week's total of $86,457,274, according to a tabulation prepared by The Daily Bond Buyer. The new issues will represent requirements of seventeen municipalities and seventeen housing authorities.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:
The smaller retail stores of the United States will face "acute shortages of merchandise" perhaps by midsummer, it was forecast here yesterday by spokesmen for the Office of Price Administration.

A Supreme Court jury late yesterday afternoon awarded damages of $6,000 to Mrs. Alice Appiato Musich of Washington, in her $100,000 assault and slander action against her former employers, Mr. and Mrs. Simon I. Patino of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Publication of a voluminous report on Axis-front activities in the United States, it was learned today, is being held up by the Dies Committee because of inability of members to agree on inclusion of a complimentary reference to the Roosevelt Administration.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- At the hearing today by the Senate Agricultural Committee on the synthetic rubber program, Senator Wheeler of Montana asked:

Reports from the grain trade indicate that wheat still is going into the government loans at a rather rapid rate. The latest figures show that around 385,000,000 bushels from last year's crop are in the loan, and the trade now believes that the total may be 425,000,000 to 450,000,000 bushels.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Governor Dewey gave his congratulations today to three high school students whose schools won the recent New York State school salvage drive.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Jan. 14 (DELAYED) (AP) -- A flight of United States fighter planes strafed Japanese supply and transport installations at Bhamo, Northern Burma, today, setting fire to a big warehouse filled with gasoline drums.

Eight men involved in thefts of $80,000 worth of merchandise, mostly jewelry, from the Long Island City terminal of the Railway Express Agency were sentenced to terms in Sing Sing Prison yesterday by Judge Thomas Downs in Queens County Court.

Two of three Negro youths who participated in the hold-up slaying of a white boy at Fifth Avenue and Ninety ninth Street on the evening of Nov. 1, 1941, were sentenced by Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions yesterday. They had taken part in the stabbing of 16-year-old James O'Connell in the presence of his brother.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- War expenditures by the United States in 1942 totaled $52,406,000,000, or nearly four times the amount spent in 1941, the War Production Board stated today.

After a day and a half without heat or hot water, relief came at last yesterday to 154 families in a large Sunnyside, Queens, apartment house unit, when 1,000 gallons of oil were delivered yesterday at 4 P.M.

Three four-story storage buildings at 28 to 34 Tenth Avenue and 452-4 West Thirteenth Street have been sold by Commander Vincent Astor to Burton Estates, Inc. They are occupied by Swift Co., and are assessed at $228,000. Carter, Ledyard Milburn represented the seller and Samuel S. Isaacs acted for the buyer.

The American International Corporation, an investment trust, has reported assets on Dec. 31 of $16,707,015, equivalent to $7.76 a share of common stock after pro visions for $8,938,000 of 5 1/2 per cent debentures. This figure compared with $5.69 a share at the end of 1941.
LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA Jan. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was slow yesterday and the market moved narrowly. Trade support at the close lifted active contracts to levels unchanged to 4 points higher than Thursday's final quotations from correspondingly slight losses earlier in the day.

Churches and synagogues throughout the metropolitan area were invited yesterday by Rear Admiral E. J. Marquart, Commandant of the Third Naval District and the Navy Chaplain Corps, to participate in a "Navy Church Week-end" beginning next Friday and continuing through Sunday, Jan. 24.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 16 (U.P.) -- American and Australian troops, driving against the last enemy stronghold in the Papua area of New Guinea, broke through and destroyed Japanese forward positions Thursday at beleaguered Sanananda, where 152 Japanese bodies already have been buried, the Allied Command announced today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique:
Some sportsmen are already discussing the problem that will face them if there is to be any waterfowl shooting next Fall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- After completing one of the largest accounting jobs ever undertaken, the Treasury Department's emergency accounting organization, set up by executive order in 1935 to account for expenditures for relief and work relief, has closed its books.
Two long shots galloped to victory last night in the ten-round battles that featured the fistic card in Madison Square Garden before 9,684 fans, who paid $21,315 to see the show.

Benjamin Grogan, a Sing Sing convict, was acquitted of first- degree murder yesterday by direction of Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions on an indictment the prisoner had brought about last Summer when he "confessed" the slaying of Christapher Quinn, 22 years old, a hotel bellhop, in 1939, a confession that Grogan laughingly repudiated at his trial.

A 20-year-old, cheerful young man who has never entered a school, will be graduated in his home as an accomplished milliner Jan. 27 and will receive a diploma from the Central Needle Trades High School.

While retail trade here continued active this week, percentage figures suffered by comparison with the high sales of the corresponding week last year. Department store volume was estimated 6 to 7 per cent under the 1942 week. With less emphasis on traditional January events because of the paucity of merchandise, retailers are trying to build early volume on Spring goods and items in fairly plentiful supply.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Senate Military Affairs Committee today directed a subcommittee to investigate reported demonstrations and outbreaks in Japanese evacuation centers in eight Western and Southwestern States and alleged "pampering" of evacuees by the War Relocation Authority.
BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 15 -- United States Ambassador George S. Messersmith and his wife left tonight by train for New York. Mr. Messersmith will go to Washington next week for conferences with President Roosevelt, Secretary of State Cordell Hull and other high officials before taking a vacation. The Ambassador is scheduled to return here by the end of February.

Alexander Brailowsky was heard in the first of a series of six recitals devoted to the works of Chopin last night in Town Hall. With the exception of the few compositions of the Polish composer in which the keyboard instrument is employed with orchestra or in ensemble, Mr. Brailowsky's cycle embraces Chopin's entire output, amounting to some 170 pieces.

The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations has taken the proper course in deciding to hold hearings on the President's nomination of Mr. Flynn as Minister to Australia. Charges of Mr. Flynn's unfitness for this post on many counts have been made in Washington. The accuracy of these charges should be investigated fully before the Senate votes on the appointment.

HOW the gay Larry MacPhail (sorry, I forgot his military rank) must have groaned when he heard about the offer of the Meadow Brook Club to turn over its plant to the Brooklyn Dodgers for training this year!

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously today to hold open hearings next week on the qualifications of Edward J. Flynn of New York to be Minister to Australia. Veteran Senate employes could not recall any previous public hearing on a diplomatic nomination.

The first principle in organization of the home front distilled by all nations from the last war is that civilian activities must be directed by single-headed responsible administrators. The second principle is that all functions and authority in respect to a particular activity must be concentrated into the hands of one administrator.

AT A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION IN ENGLAND, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The acting pilot was killed, three of its crew were wounded and the Flying Fortress "Dry Martini" was given up for lost by its formation, but a gallant young second lieutenant brought the bomber back from the raid Wednesday on Lille, France.

DAN BROUTHERS of the Orioles started it. It was Mighty Dan, one of the fabulous figures of baseball's early years, who came to Manager John McCloskey of Louisville on July 4, 1895, and said to him: "Collins can play third base."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 15 -- The Middlesex General Hospital and eight other charitable and religious organizations will share in the residue of the estate of William Carpenter (Willie) Stevens, last of the principals in the celebrated Hall-Mills murder case, whose will was admitted to probate here today by Surrogate Frank A. Connolly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Now that women physical therapists and dietitians in the Army have received military status similar to that of the Army Nurse Corps, it will be easier to recruit many more who are needed, Major Emma E. Vogel, director of the physical therapy aides, and Major Helen C. Burns, director of dietitians, said today.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 15 -- So far as public popularity is concerned, the position of the Churchill government in England is apparently more solid today than at almost any time since it took office.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- H.G. Wells, whose forecasts have had an uncanny way of coming true, made a plea tonight for the victors in this war to establish a group of commissions to rehabilitate and reeducate the disordered world. He spoke over the radio in the first of a series of talks on "Reshaping Man's Heritage."

Alfred Kreymborg has been elected president of the Poetry Society of America, it was announced yesterday. New vice presidents are John Hall Wheelock, Jean Starr Untermeyer and Helen F. Stickney. Robert Frost continues as honorary vice president of the group.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Jan. 15 -- Judge F. Anthony Hanlon signed a decree in Probate Court today representing that the estate of John Barry Ryan, who died in Stockbridge in 1942, is insolvent. A petition for the decree was signed by Mr. Ryan's widow. Mrs. Nina M. Ryan, and the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, executors.

The pleasure-driving ban has eliminated the need for traffic policemen at so many street intersections in the city that Police Commissioner Valentine took 126 traffic men off their regular posts last night and reassigned them to the midtown sector of Manhattan, where there have never been enough traffic men.
Apartment rentals in Jackson Heights, Queens, during December were considerably higher than usual for that month, according to the Queensboro Corporation, which reported forty-two rentals were made.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 15 -- The German Charge d'Affaires, Erich Otto Meynen, called at the Foreign Office today to ask that Argentina arrange safe conduct for the return to Germany of Captain Detrich Niebuhr, the Nazi Naval Attache, whose recall Argentina has demanded on evidence that he engaged in espionage.

White anklets, which would make New York women pedestrians visible to motorists 100 feet away on the city's dimmed-out streets, were suggested yesterday by the Public Safety section of the Greater New York Safety Council as part of a five-point program to reduce the mounting number of fatal traffic accidents here.

I have just read with interest Admiral Glassford's statement of Jan. 11 from Allied headquarters in North Africa that "Dakar never has been used at any time by German shipping, especially submarines -- no ship has entered the harbor for two years. Definitely no."

Gambling charges against four men arrested in a raid on the Florida Republican Club, 2035 Second Avenue, Oct. 20, were dismissed yesterday in Harlem Court by Magistrate Edward R. Maguire when Assistant District Attorney Lawrence J. McKenna told the court that he was unable to produce evidence that would show a dice game was in progress when the raid was made.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- In an apparent effort to allay some misgivings caused by the amalgamation of French Communists with General Charles de Gaulle, the French National Committee issued a statement tonight inviting the adherence of representatives of all political groups of France except those that have favored collaboration under Vichy.

Despite the fact that 53 per cent of American families intend to make one or more major purchases after the end of the war, only 19 per cent of the families are saving for a specific post-war purchase, William J. Moll, field director of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States of America, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Market Research Council at the Yale Club.

Daniel P. Woolley, New York City Commissioner of Markets, served notice yesterday that the city intends to see that recent declines of wholesale egg prices are reflected at retail. The warning was part of a review of the local food situation in which he noted that the evaporated milk supply was better and that live poultry prices had been cut 2 cents at the retail level.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 15 --Accurately reflecting conditions in Vichy is the latest French budget. The Journel Official of Jan. 1, containing the full budget text, has just arrived here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Designation of Representative Vito Marcantonio of New York for membership on the House Committee on the Judiciary, one of the highest ranking and most "conservative" of the lower branch's standing committees, has stirred up a storm which threatened today to develop into a major Democratic revolt.

The Rev. Rush R. Sloane will preach his first sermon as rector of St. John's Episcopal Church of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, L. I., on Sunday morning, Feb. 7. He recently was elected to the rectorship by the vestry, of which J. P. Morgan is the senior warden.

Winter racing at the Havana Yacht Club will not start a week from today as scheduled, it was stated yesterday by George W. Elder, president of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association. At the same time it was learned that plans for the proposed spring series at New Orleans had been canceled.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- United Nations Week, now being observed, was commended to all Americans today by Secretary Hull as an occasion for rallying to the common cause.

Questions of rationing, economies in use and priorities make the fuel oil and gasoline situation in this area anything but simple. Its essentials are dismally easy to understand. Last week 1,190,000 barrels of all petroleum products were brought into the area. Spokesmen for the oil industry say that we need at least 1,300,000 barrels "to get by on."

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- An enthusiastic report on progress in United States and Canadian food production was made yesterday by Professor J.A. Scott Watson, agricultural attache of the British Embassy in Washington, who is here on a visit.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The Nazi submarine pens at Lorient and the docks at Cherbourg were heavily bombed last night and today by the Royal Air Force as the Bomber Command directed its offensive against French Atlantic coast bases of Hitler's U-boat campaign.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 15 -- "Hell!" yelled a soldier, "ain't that Martha Raye ?"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Army and Navy have authorized jointly the issuance of medals to members of the armed forces on foreign service in this war. The medals will not be given until after the war, but ribbons signifying the awards will be made available immediately.

As officials of Freeport and Rockville Centre voiced fears yesterday that a temporary shutdown of their municipal electric plants would mean an increase of 20 points or more in their tax rates, the Petroleum Administration for War disclosed that these two Long Island villages were only cogs in a program to eliminate oil-into-electricity operations throughout the East Coast until the fuel-oil shortage is eased.

OTTAWA, Jan. 15 -- A conference with representatives of the steel workers and the steel companies will be held by the government in Ottawa tomorrow afternoon, with a view to settling the present strike.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 15. -- Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, has written to the heads of all government agencies asking them to take the following three steps to lessen the burden on the country's transportation system:

In your editorial "Black Markets" you say that "the OPA made a primary mistake in trying to impose general price ceilings applying to luxuries and semi-luxuries as well as necessities. Where excess purchasing power exists, and where prices are artificially held down, the shelves will soon be bare of goods unless those goods are rationed.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- A proposal by the North American Company to purchase in the open market 12,500 shares of the Detroit Edison Company's capital stock to facilitate its final dividend of Detroit Edison shares was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

There were ups and downs -- and no pun intended -- in the performance of Charpentier's "Louise" given yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund. The opera was presented with Grace Moore in the title part and with Sir Thomas Beecham conducting the work for the first time in this lyric theatre.

Motorists should not delay having their car tires inspected just because the deadline for the first inspection has been postponed, E.S. Ferguson, regional rationing executive of the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday.

The British Information Services supply some new figures on the work of the R.A.F. They show that the weight of bombs dropped on Germany and German-controlled Europe from January to March, 1942, was 50 per cent higher than in the same period of 1941.

Stimulated by the war program, sales of Gar Wood Industries, Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended with October rose 65.73 per cent, or $15,029,644 over the previous record made during the preceding twelve-month period, to the new high of $37,895,795, Glen A. Bassett, president, reported yesterday to stockholders in the twenty-first annual statement.
LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) -The Vichy radio said tonight that more than 100 persons had been arrested in Lyon for "illegal activities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Five to ten thousand American housewives will be enlisted in a few weeks to help the government run food rationing according to the facts of actual housekeeping.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Sixty-five thousand young women must enter schools of nursing between June 30, 1943, and July 1, 1944, if even minimum civilian and military needs of the nation are to be met, Paul V. McNutt, director of defense health and welfare services, said today.

Holders of various issues of Chilean dollar bonds are being notified that those assenting to the Chilean Government's debt-revision plan will receive interest on pres- entation of their coupons to the Schroder Trust Company on and after Feb. 1.
The Greater New York Safety Council issued the following warning yesterday:

The Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York has thus far raised $174,184 toward its 1943 budget it was announced yesterday at a campaign workers' luncheon at 600 Lexington Avenue. Contributions totaling $30,060 were announced yesterday.

The decision as to whether there will be any national amateur tennis championships in 1943 will be made today at the sixtysecond annual meeting of the United States Lawn Tennis Association. The delegates will convene at the Hotel Vanderbilt at 1 P.M. with President Holcombe Ward of New York in the chair.
Developments in baseball's metropolitan theatre of action continued to bristle yesterday with extraordinary activity and no little commotion.

Eat plenty of cereals, the United States Department of Agriculture advises, for they are abundant and cheap, as well as nourishing, and there is small likelihood that they will be rationed. This doesn't mean necessarily, however, that you ought to consume a big bowlful every morning, whether you want to or not, from now until the war is over. There are many other ways of preparing the breakfast specialty.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A liberalization of draft deferments for essential farm workers was agreed upon late today at a conference of administrative officials with farm State Senators.

For about six months I have been trying to find some one who might venture a justifiable reason for our slotted traffic lights -- which I believe to be partly responsible for many traffic deaths, particularly after dark. "Well, they did it that way in London," said one letter writer.

Count Fleet is placed at the head of Jack Campbell's Experimental Handicap, announced yesterday in the Jockey Club's Racing Calendar, annual medium for rating by the New York official of the juveniles of the season preceding.

" United Nations Week," which will begin tomorrow, will be observed by sermons in the churches. Special services of intercession for our armed forces and those of our Allies will be held, and in every church tomorrow and in every synagogue this morning prayers will be offered for the men in service.

A shortage of bakery specialties such as fancy cakes, rolls, buns and special breads may develop soon in the metropolitan area because of the unwillingness of flour brokers to continue operations under existing price regulations of the Office of Price Administration, according to a statement of the New York Association of Flour Distributors issued yesterday by the New York Produce Exchange.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 15 -- John P. Frey, president of the Metal Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor, gave notice today that his organization, which holds a master contract with West Coast shipyards, was prepared for a finish fight to keep its supremacy on this side of the continent.

Lincoln A. Werden in his "Wood, Field and Stream" column the other day wrote that "The Pennsylvania Game Commission raises an issue by urging the teaching of the basic principles of conservation in all public schools."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- There were growing indications tonight that the United States and Britain were moving toward closer collaboration with their principal fighting Allies among the United Nations, Soviet Russia and China, who have complained in the past that their views sometimes were not sought on grand strategy and supply questions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Ginger Rogers of the movies and Private Jack Briggs of Schenectady, N.Y., a member of the Marine Corps, will be married. The actress walked onto a movie set today and proudly displayed a gold engagement ring.

A wife's suit to annul the second marriage of the husband she left forty years ago and her demand that, at least formally, he must once again take her to his "bed and board" was dismissed yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court, the principal piece of evidence against her being the faded photograph of her baby boy on which she scrawled a farewell note in June, 1902.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company failed to cover its $2.25 quarterly dividend rate in the last quarter of 1942 by $5,051,00O, the company's report to stock holders, released yesterday, disclosed. Sharply higher taxes were the main cause, despite the fact that income from operations was at a record level.

FOR the latest spot news on Guadalcanal and the Solomons see the news pages up forward and the communiques on page 2. To find out what that dirty "git or git got" slugging match is like behind the communiques and feature stories see Ira Wolfert's fine reporting and writing job, "Battle for the Solomons."*

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A committee of thirty-two presidents and officers of anthracite locals of the United Mine Workers of America unanimously adopted tonight a motion to return home immediately and make every effort to end the fifteen-day unofficial walkout which has crippled hard coal production.

A program of Swedish short subjects under the title, "Swedish Panorama," will start a two-week engagement today at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. The thirteen shorts deal with various aspects of Swedish life, including community housing projects, Sweden's West Point, important industries, visits to Lapland and a Swedish Boy Scout camp, Swedish sports and glimpses of Selma Lagerlof, Nobel Prize winner.

The Berlin radio has beamed a special death-and-duty pep talk to the Nazi forces on the Stalingrad front, urging them to remember -- when they "see no sense in holding on" -- that the "Fuehrer knows best."

Citing the impetus given their party's revival by the election of Governor Dewey, Republican leaders attending the annual meeting of the Federation of Women's Republican Clubs of New York State here yesterday confidently predicted the election of a Republican President in 1944.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- In proceedings held for the first time in history outside the United States, aliens serving in the armed forces have been naturalized.

The Sandhogs Union, Local 147, won yesterday in the Appellate Division in its fight against Joseph V. Moreschi and other officers of the parent International Hod Carriers Union. The court upheld unanimously an order of Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook restraining the international from interfering with the local or with the employment of its members.

Today's events: "Manon," 2 P.M., and "The Magic Flute," 8, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, Young People's concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A.M.; Isidor Achron, piano, and Lea Karina, mezzo-soprano, Town Hall, 3; Victory concert, with Sascha Jacobsen, violin, and Frank Sheridan, piano, as participants, New York Public Library, 5:30; Bronislaw Huberman, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Wanda Landowska, harpsichord, McMillin Theatre, 8:30; Musical Art Quartet, thirty-eighth anniversary concert, Institute of Musical Art, 8:30.
Although his criminal past is known to the police across the country, Pat Moriarty, 46 years old, is very sensitive about being publicly proclaimed the most expert safe burglar in America.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Peter V. Cacchione, Communist City Councilman from Brooklyn, has suggested to Park Commissioner Robert Moses that the name of Morningside Park be changed to Franz Boas Park as a memorial to the anthropologist who died Dec. 21, but Commissioner Moses rejected the proposal yesterday as "impractical."

A NIGHT FIGHTER BASE NEAR CALCUTTA, India, Saturday, Jan. 16 (AP) -- One British night fighter destroyed three Japanese medium bombers attacking the Calcutta district in only four minutes last night, a record for this area's defenses and possibly a record for such brief combat elsewhere.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration announced today the compensation to be received by banks that take part in the nation-wide ration banking plan beginning Jan. 27:

No particular changes are contemplated in the present policies of the Department of Welfare. Leo Arnstein, new acting commissioner of the department, declared yesterday at his first interview in his new post.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The cultural merits of "leg shows" and the ambiguous scruples of girls who work in munitions plants on Sundays figured today in a debate in the Saville Theatre which at moments had more drama than some productions given there.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Massed Russian artillery, tanks and troops were reported from Stockholm tonight to be hammering the German lines before Leningrad in a full-scale offensive aimed at breaking the sixteen-month siege of the old czarist capital.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 15 (AP) u- Increasing financial burdens will cause many endowed colleges to drop intercollegiate football during the war, Jimmy Conzelman, coach of the Chicago Cardinals of the National Football League, said today, and he predicted they would not resume the sport in peacetime.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- A special committee was named by Governor Dewey to study general revision of the tax structure of all municipalities in the State, as the result of a conference today which started with a discussion between Mayor La Guardia and the Governor on the subject of New York City's revenue problems.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 15 -- Two formations of Flying Fortresses made heavy attacks on the Axis supply ports of Sousse and Sfax, Tunisia, yesterday, and the railroad and highway at Mahares, twenty miles southwest of Sfax, was attacked by B-26s.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- The State Banking Department's Bulletin announced today the appointment of John A. MacCormack of Loudonville in connection with the State Controller to examine and receipt for securities deposited in the Banking Department by corporations and individuals.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Reuter, British news agency, reported from Allied headquarters in North Africa today that the three highranking British air officials in the Mediterranean conferred recently in North Africa, presaging a three-way aerial attack against Axis forces.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Taking elaborate precautions to keep their meeting place a secret, five Democratic Senators held a session for three hours and fifty-one minutes this afternoon to consider the re-election of Chesley W. Jurney, veteran sergeant at arms of the Senate, who is the object of a one-man "war" declared by Senator McKellar of Tennessee.

" Nine Girls," Wilfrid H. Pettitt's murder melodrama which A.H. Woods opened at the Longacre Theatre on Wednesday, will end its Broadway engagement tonight after a run of five performances, it was decided yesterday. The cast, all feminine, is headed by Adele Longmire, K.T. Stevens, Barbara BeL Geddes and Mary McCormack.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Allied planes, swarming into action with improved weather, shot down eight Axis aircraft yesterday in the course of widespread raids on the Libyan front and westward as far as the Tripoli area, it was announced tonight.

As the first families of the 613 that have received notices of eviction from thirteen apartments in the Kings bridge section of the Bronx, which will be used to house Waves and Spars receiving instruction at near-by Hunter College, loaded their belongings on a van to go to their new homes, complaints continued to pour in about landlords raising the rents on apartments sought by the evicted families.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 -- Everything stopped in the Errol Flynn case today when the prosecution called for a mistrial. The motion was based on three affidavits filed by prospective women jurors who were excused from the panel chosen to try the actor on morals offenses and was offered by Deputy District Attorney John Hopkins to Superior Judge Leslie E. Still.

Those letter writers who have been urging a curtailment of skiing for the purpose of easing the strain on transportation facilities and furthering the conservation of gasoline and rubber deserve a pat on the back. Probably it was a mere coincidence, but their patriotic views have brought action.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 15 -- Germany has ordered the conscription of 45,000 Hungarian laborers, of whom 15,000 already have been transported northeastward into Ruthenia to begin work on the construction of defense fortifications in the Carpathians against an eventual Russian break-through from the Ukraine for an attack across South Poland and Hungary into Eastern Europe, according to reports received in foreign military circles in Istanbul from Budapest today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Bombed by Japanese airplanes, hunted by enemy warships and once endangered by a hatch that was difficult to close, Lieutenant Frank Lawson Jr. of the American Submarine Service, reported today that his undersea raider had accounted for at least three Japanese ships sunk and two or more damaged on a series of extensive operations in the Pacific.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A British communique:

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Sugar Ration, owned by Mrs. W.T Westrope and trained by her hus band, galloped to victory in the featured Thibodaux Purse at the Fair Grounds today before a crowd of more than 3,000 fans.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 15 -- That President Risto Ryti will be re-elected when voting takes place in Finland on Feb. 15 is now considered a certainty in the best-informed Finnish circles.

The demand for new homes in the second year following the end of the war may rise to 900,000 dwelling units, while during the post-war decade the rate of new residential building may reach a peak of 1,600,000 units in a single year, F. Vaux Wilson Jr., vice president of the Homasote Company, builders of prefabricated houses, predicted yesterday at a meeting of business and home-building experts in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

As long as baseball serves a useful function for the nation, the National League will be conducting its scheduled pennant race as keenly and as enthusiastically as in any year in the past. If the time arrives when baseball is not fitting into the war line-up to the best interests of the nation, then we'll adjourn.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The British Government has refused to enter into any commitments in connection with war damage to British interests in the Far East.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A $12,000 reward was posted tonight for information leading to the recapture of Hugh McAteer, 25-year-old Chief of Staff of the illegal Irish Republican Army, who with three companions escaped at breakfast time from Belfast prison.

One of the loneliest places in the wartorn world these days is the employment agency that handles domestic help. Once its rooms were crowded with eager, prospective cooks, maids and housekeepers, jockeying for favored positions. Now they are empty or haunted solely by elderly, placid women.

Keen duels in the 600-yard and one-mile runs are expected to feature the first half of the senior Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships scheduled for today on the University Heights campus of N.Y.U.

The Federal Bureau of Internal Revenue urges those filing income tax returns to read carefully the instructions accompanying the return forms, as certain items are specifically exempt and need not be reported as income in the return.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Coach Earl H. (Red) Blaik, Army football mentor for the last two years, returned to active duty as a lieutenant colonel of cavalry today.

This quiet town In the papers are pictures this of a rural peace hovering over motorless Fifth Avenue. That blank sweep of concrete alongside a wide river is the West Side Highway. It sets people turning about in their mind for the appropriate simile -- Goldsmith's Deserted Village, Palmyra the rose-red city half as old as time, the Sahara before the tanks and airplanes came, Nineveh and Tyre.

After the opening of its campaign headquarters at 130 West Forty-second Street, the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York yesterday began the mobilization of 100,000 volunteer workers required to raise the $12,920, 700, fixed as the city's quota of the national drive for $125,000,000.

A special preview of war drawings by Clayton Knight will be held at 4 o'clock this afternoon at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. The exhibition will open to the public on Monday and will continue through Feb. 3.
Executives and outstanding personalities in journalism and literature participated yesterday in the celebration of the twenty-first anniversary of Beekman Hospital at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

With some furniture dealers expeering to be frozen with respect to further purchases starting in the second quarter, the question has arisen whether or not these dealers may "swap" merchandise among themselves in order to maintain balanced stocks

This year the Salvation Army asks the public for $525,000. That is $150,000 more than it needed last year, but in addition to its multitudinous other activities it has, as it has had for a little more than a year, war duties of ample scope. It is always modest in its seeking of funds, and we all know by long experience that every cent it spends is spent conscientiously and beneficially.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Jan, 16 -- A Red Army surging across the Kalitva River cut the Rostov-Moscow railway yesterday at Glubokaya and reached a point ninety miles northeast of Rostov, Nazi communication center serving Southern Russia, it was announced officially early today.

Dr. Franz Ullstein, former head of the German publishing house of Ullstein Co., one of the greatest publishing concerns in pre-Nazi days on the Continent, celebrates his seventy-fifth birthday today. The firm was founded by his father, Leopold Ullstein, and Dr. Ullstein and his four brothers managed the enterprise after the former's death.

May 1 as one of those to whom the memory of Bouguereau's colorful painting, "Nymphs and Satyr," in the old Hoffman House bar, has been revived by the admirable description in your issue of Jan. 10, express my appreciation of your reporter's sympathetic account of the disappearance and recovery of this work of art?

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- Howard Hughes announced today that his independent production, "The Outlaw," for which he had been unable to obtain a release, will have its first showing on Jan. 29 at the Geary Theatre in San Francisco.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Nineteen enlisted men have received letters of commendation from Navy Secretary Frank Knox for outstanding duty in the Solomon Islands last August, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Taxpayers of the country were warned today by the House and Senate committees which will frame the new tax bills that regardless of whether a pay-as-you-go system was enacted, or what form it might take, they must file returns for 1942 March 15 and make at least the first quarterly payment.

St. Francis Prep's basketball team scored its sixth Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. triumph in as many starts yesterday by beating Holy Trinity, 40 to 28, on the latter's court. In other games in the same league, St. Michael's routed Brooklyn Prep, 43 -- 22, and St. John's Prep turned back Brooklyn Cathedral, 52 to ]40.

Japanese worry over the development of American war production and airpower is indicated in a Japanese magazine received at Chungking, China, and quoted by the British radio in a broadcast recorded yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System here.

The Netherlands Unit of the British War Relief Society will give an Anglo-Dutch tea this afternoon in the New Amsterdam Room of Holland House to benefit the British society's current campaign for funds to maintain civilian relief work in Britain.

The first note of dissatisfaction among foreign traders over the Board of Economic Warfare's recent announcement of a "moratorium" on export licenses for seven Latin-American countries was voiced yesterday at a meeting of the Latin-American section of the New York Board of Trade at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

More than 500,000 German colonists have migrated to Danzig and areas seized from Poland in 1939, according to an article in the Swedish newspaper Aftontidningen, reported to the Office of War Information yesterday.

Minnie is a cat with an inferiority complex. However, she stole the limelight yesterday from the leading bluebloods of the feline world at the closing session of the fifteenth annual Atlantic Cat Show at the Belvedere Hotel.

War production plants that succeed in effecting economies on government contracts, especially when they permit release of vital facilities and manpower for additional output, will receive greatest consideration in the renegotiation of wartime profits, Maurice Hirsch, chief of the settlement division of the War Department Board of Price Adjustment, declared yesterday at a meeting held in the headquarters of the Commerce and Industry Association.

Ensign Loraine Cornelisen of the Waves reported for duty yesterday to her commanding officer, Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, Commandant of the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, and became the first woman officer to enter service in the 141-year-old yard.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Population shifts are one of the most important problems lying ahead for business men, it is declared by two speakers at the American Management Association's wartime marketing conference here today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- The Russians are straining every effort to maintain contact with the main German forces retreating in the Caucasus. Today's reports indicate that they are succeeding and still imposing their will on the enemy.
A High, Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The associated Press:

Major games involving five New York City quintets are slated for tonight, but only two of the contests will be staged on local courts. The home attractions will pit Navy against Columbia on the Lions' floor and Fort Monmouth against St. Francis in the latter's gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Conversion to war work of every activity of the Smithsonian Institute which can be turned to useful account was reported by Dr. Charles G. Abbot, secretary, to the Board of Regents at their annual meeting today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- the Children's Art Center has announced award of a $25 war bond to Alice Payne, 9, of the Dalton School in New York City as first prize in a national competition for youngsters in public and private schools and art centers.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Reliable quarters close to the Foreign Office told The United Press tonight that Argentine Ambassador Carlos Guiraldes had attempted to dissuade Chile from breaking relations with the Axis nations and had failed.

A series of rallies in various sections of the country to intensify the recruitment of Jewish women in war industries will be launched next month, it was announced here yesterday by Max F. Baer, national director of the B'nai Brith vocational service bureau.
Polly Adler is in the prison ward of Bellevue Hospital, it became known yesterday, awaiting a hearing for the seventeenth time for maintaining a house of prostitution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Two new plans to iron out kinks in the East Coast gasoline and fuel oil rationing programs are under consideration by Federal rationing officials, it was learned today, and action on both may come in the next week.

Flotation of the largest Canadian loan since October, 1930, together with a sizable block of housing securities, raised the volume of new bonds offered here this week to investors to the highest weekly total in a year. Four issues aggregating $127,573,000 were marketed, compared with three totaling $4,336,000 last week and six offerings mounting to $24,735,000 in this week a year ago.

A man about 35 years old, found dead Thursday morning at the bottom of a dumbwaiter shaft at 551 Hudson Street and tentatively identified as James Rogers Wills of Florida, was identified through fingerprints as Francis McCarthy, alias Arthur McKinley, described as a petty thief wanted by Boston police, it was disclosed at Police Headquarters at 9 o'clock last night.
Your editorial "Abbott Lawrence Lowell" in THE TIMES of Jan. 7 contains this sentence in the third paragraph: "The student world is far more alert and intelligent than it used to be."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The monthly distribution of chemicals for January under the allocation orders of the Chemicals Division was made public today by the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Roosevelt's nomination of former Senator Prentiss M. Brown of Michigan to succeed Leon Henderson as Price Administrator was unanimously approved today at an executive session of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

One of the tangled clues being followed by the police hunting the slayer of Carlo Tresca led yesterday to Philadelphia. Detectives were sent there by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to trace the ownership of the .38-caliber revolver found in an ashcan in the rear of 96 Fifth Avenue, the office of I1 Martello (The Hammer), the radical anti-fascist paper of which Tresca was editor.
LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio and heard here tonight by the Soviet monitor:
COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Two men and a woman died in the electric chair today, bringing to eight the number of deaths in "The Logue Case," which started over a dead calf.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Americans will stand for a lot of rationing, "but when the government seeks to ration a man's right to own a home it's time to do something about it," Cyrus Crane Willmore, St. Louis builder and developer, told several hundred realtors tonight when he was installed as president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Business men on the special gifts committee of the British War Relief Society's 1943 drive for funds were told yesterday by the agency's campaign chairman, Henry Bruere, that American relief to British civilians and United Nations refugees sheltered in the British Isles would surely sustain the fighting morale of the British.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- British women are "humanizing" industry, said Miss Dorothy M. Sells, chief of the personnel section of the Office of Defense Transportation, in talking today of her three months' study of women in transportation in England and Wales. Miss Sells is working now on plans to relieve the manpower shortage in transportation here.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 16 -- Work stoppages spread in the Pennsylvania anthracite fields today despite a back-to-work order from the War Labor Board.

I see by the papers that the reformers of radio have become vocal again, this time accusing it of vulgarity. If they are talking about some of the comedy programs originating in the training camps, I agree with them. A good deal of the comedy has been childish innuendo and less than flattering to the taste and intelligence of the men at whom it is aimed.

BOSTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- DeOrmond (Tuss) McLaughry, Dartmouth College football coach, today was commissioned a major in the United States Marine Corps, the third member of his family to join the service.

Retail trade was fairly good last week, with main floors having an active trade on jewelry, notions and neckwear, according to the survey covering the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles made for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.
Accommodations present the main problem for civilians interested in going to Florida this season -- accommodations on trains, accommodations at hotels.

While clashes among the various claimant agencies under the Controlled Materials Plan are developing more frequently, it is much better that the various demands for materials be thrashed out before allocation rather than afterward, according to comment last week by expert business observers.
The place that fish and game occupy as part of our food resources appears to be receiving more and more attention.

TWO-IN-ONE WAX: The war has brought about a sort of "telescoping" of every woman's life. She probably has just about twice as much to do as ever before -- and not a moment more to do it in. Household preparations that will do two things at once present the only possible solution for her problems.

The brilliant native Cardinal Flower (Lobelia cardinalis) is a hardy, strong perennial that deserves a much more prominent place in the garden. It is often seen blooming wild in swamps or bogs, where its flaming red color is outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- In an important move toward lessening the pressure against price ceilings on such vital cost-of-living items as milk, butter, cheese, eggs and many meats the Office of Price Administration today for the first time brought under price control mixed feeds used for poultry and livestock.

LONDON -- One of the many problems facing the Allied governments established in Great Britain is the education of children who escaped from occupied countries with their parents. This has been gradually solved by facilities given by the British Government through the agency of the British Council.

CHUNKING, Jan. 16 -- Since the transport of military supplies from the west to China involves military information no one in a position of authority is willing to discuss it except in most general terms. All facts would be of use to the enemy and are either confidential or unknown. Many available figures are wrong.
