DARK dresses enlivened with a touch of white are as welcome a sight as a white-painted curbing on a dimmed-our street. While the white accent has long been as proverbial a harbinger of Spring in the fashion world as the first robin is on the farm, this year it is handled in all sorts of new ways -- not just collars and cuffs.

THERE is a river in Eastern Siberia called Chita, and on it is a town of the same name. Peter the Great, that lusty, half-savage monarch, who had an urge to transform Russia into a modern State, sent a royal commission to investigate and map his Siberian possessions.

A call for reorientation of instruction in foreign languages to make them useful for war brought yesterday from teachers a response that local and Federal agencies had not recognized language instruction as a war aid.

A plan to "out-restrict the restrictions" is proposed for New York racing during the season beginning April 8. This became known yesterday when the office of the Attorney General at Albany was asked to rule whether a race-track has a legal right to bar a prospective patron who drives up to the gates in an automobile.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 16 -- When he returned from a routine appointment at 4:30 this afternoon Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, Commander in Chief of the United States Army forces in China, Burma and India, was surprised to find the entire headquarters staff drawn up in a smart row in front of his house on a hill overlooking the Chialing River.
SOMEWHERE ON THE WEST AFRICAN COAST, Jan. 16 -- Over several new and shortened routes, United States bombers are now being rushed, in constantly increasing numbers, to North African war fronts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (Science Service) -- By no means all of the crop of 748 patents issued here this week were on weapons and other warlike devices, although there were many such. Patent No. 2,308,357, for instance, is on a peaceful agricultural implement -- a pneumatically operated cotton picker, the invention of Anthony P. Costa of Athens, Ga.

Harry Williams's letter on the proposed establishment of a joint Congressional committee on the conduct of the war is an able and well-reasoned document, but his strictures on the actual committee that did exist in Civil War days and its activities might have been even more stringently framed.

THE average American likes to chew gum. In fact, if he wants to remain average, he must chew just 109 sticks of it every peacetime year. That is the average consumption (if consumption is the word) per American capita. Some Americans, like former postmaster General James A. Farley, who masticates the good oat of five packs a day. 9,125 sticks a year, take up the slack for the unaverage Americans who never touch the stuff.

Jamaica High, placing three marksmen among the first eight scorers, won the Abraham Lincoln High School interscholastic rifle tournament conducted yesterday on the Brooklyn school's range. Jamaica paced a field of twelve teams with a total of 1,076.

Important English furniture and silver, the property of Mrs. Frank D. Stout of Chicago, will be sold by the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Friday afternoon. Outstanding is a set of twelve finely carved Chippendale side chairs made about 1740 and illustrated in the Francis Lenygon book, "Furniture in England."

Detective Francis A. O'Neill, known familiarly to newspaper reporters as Buck, retired from the Police Department at noon yesterday after twenty-three years in the city's service. He retired on a pension of $1,600 a year.

" ASTRONOMY, MAPS AND WEATHER" (1) was prepared by Professor Wylie at the request of the Flying Training Command to meet the needs of a college course for young men looking forward to service in that branch of the Army Air Corps.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Ginger Rogers, the screen actress, and John Calvin (Jack) Briggs, a Marine Corps private, were married here today in the First Methodist Church. The ceremony took friends by surprise, since Miss Rogers had avoided predicting when the wedding would take place.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Secretary Perkins urged today the retention of the machinery of the War Labor Board after peace is won, saying:

IN spite of the sharp increases set up by scare buying last year at this time, trade volume is managing to creep over the 1942 figures for the country as a whole. Thus, the first full week of the new year showed a rise of 6 per cent in department store sales, according to the Federal Reserve Board.

Day care facilities must be made available to some 88,000 additional children in New York State during 1943, according to estimates of the Child Care Committee of the State War Council. This tentative figure is based on a sample study made in Elmira and on returns from the voluntary registration of women in Rochester.

MOSCOW, Jan. 16 -- Russian infantry, which now has come up to positions seized by the Red Army's mechanized units in their rapid initial advances in the Don region, was reported today to be continuing its progress on a fifty-mile front between the Sal and Manych Rivers.

IF they loved him in St. Joe, as Mr. Benny is wont to recall wistfully, they thought he was terrific last Monday night at the United States Maritime Service Training Station at Sheepshead Bay, N.Y., where audiences numbering 2,500 trainees assembled in the new and cavernous Bowditch Hall at 6 o'clock and again at 8 to gaze at Rochester's boss in person.

" Keep on sailing!" was the keynote last night in the New York Yacht Club at the annual meeting of the Comet Class Yachting Racing Association. It was the word of advice of D. Verner Smythe, president, and accepted unanimously by the seventy-one delegates to the ninth annual gathering from fleets throughout this country and the West Indies.
LONDON, Jan. 16 (U.P.) -- Germany is building defenses frantically and resorting to mass arrests in Poland, Norway and France, according to reports reaching London today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 141 Americans from thirty-five States and the District of Columbia held prisoners of war by the enemy, or interned in a neutral country.

VEREEN BELL is a compartive newcomer to the fiction lists, but he reveals already a gift of which we have rarely had half enough. He writes about sports and the outdoors in a way to warm the hearts of adult readers -- adult male readers, anyway -- who remember the juvenile delight of discovering Jack London and Stewart Edward White.

A War Service Luncheon will be given under the auspices of the Musicians Emergency Fund on Jan. 29 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis to acquaint members of the board and sponsors of the fund with the wartime program of the organization, the principal feature of which is feeing young artists to give concerts at East Coast naval bases.

YOU might think the motion picture people, after the number of times they have been stung with American historical pictures, would have given up such efforts long ago and would just stick to out-and-out fictions or non-controversial chronicles.

Elimination of meat wholesalers and jobbers in the New York area, as suggested by the Federal Government, would tend to place the entire wholesale meat distribution in the hands of racketeers, according to a letter sent to Mayor La Guardia by the New York Council of Wholesale Meat Dealers, Inc., and made public yesterday.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Miss Virginia Winther of Waukegan and Chief Specialist Robert William Feller, U.S.N., better known as Bob Feller, Cleveland Indians' piching star, were married tonight in the First Methodist Church of Waukegan.

Not long after the USO had organized its program for service men, it was asked to manage recreation projects for boom-town workers. This week it is tackling a new problem -- juvenile delinquency. Mrs. Pearl Case Blough, head of women's and children's activities of the USO, has appointed a committee to investigate the wartime need of a special program to occupy teen-age groups.

TORONTO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The three-game victory march of the Montreal Canadiens in the National Hockey League was halted abruptly tonight when they fell victim to Toronto, 8 to 4, before 11,899 fans at Maple Leaf Gardens.

Several hundred of the country's yachtsmen and amateur mariners, some on furloughs and leaves from the Army, Navy, Coast Guard and Marines, spent much of yesterday and until long past midnight this morning at the Hotel Astor for the annual conclave of the Power Squadrons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- As Chairman Connally of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee announced plans to open public hearings Wednesday on the nomination of Edward J. Flynn as Minister to Australia, Senator Bridges of New Hampshire filed with the committee today a list of the witnesses he wants questioned about four episodes in Mr. Flynn's career.

Amateur gardeners very naturally are much concerned with the outlook for plant foods and spray materials. There will, of course, be shortages; but the situation is by no means as dark as many have been led, by loose talk, to believe.

WITHIN a fortnight or so Benny Davis, the songwriter and discoverer of new talent in the entertainment field, will assume the mantle of the Broadway night club impresario, something which he has not done since the early stages of prohibition days when he operated the Melody Club.

EGG-SHELL BUILDING -- The world's largest concrete "eggshell" type of industrial plant, designed to speed production of war equipment, has been completed by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company. The new building is a modification of a European structural design previously used in this country only for airplane hangars, sports arenas and some government warehouses and armories.
The vast Pacific theatre of war was still in uneasy balance last week as Japan and the United States prepared for new operations.

Garden conscious with the awakening of Spring, we turn-to new varieties -- innovations for the Victory Garden of 1943. Emphasis is laid on vegetables from the home garden -- the one place where we escape from ration coupons. But we also welcome the latest all-America flower winners which add interest and beauty to the whole horticultural enterprise.

QUITE a time has elapsed since the last show of water-colors by John Singer Sargent. A round dozen of these are now on view at Henry Kleemann's, including two or three of the most widely known Venetian papers.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Dimitri A. Kellogg of San Francisco is the No. 1 man of the Military Academy Class of 409 cadets which will graduate Tuesday.

As the Office of Price Administration took cognizance of rent increases in the Bronx, a Navy Department spokesman announced yesterday that superintendents of thirteen apartment houses that will be converted into dormitories for Waves and Spars had been asked to remain on their jobs.

THE Museum of Modern Art is giving us a highly profitable glimpse of Brazil's modern building campaign. Made up of photographs and models, the architecture show that opened there last week is compact and trimly installed.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- Sensational shooting in the first half enabled Pennsylvania to open its Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League season with a 47-37 victory over Harvard at the Palestra tonight before 2,000 spectators. This was the first time the Quakers have beaten the Cantabs since 1941.

Haskell, who was Director of Civilian Protection in New York State under Governor Lehman and was a right-hand man of Herbert Hoover in his relief work after the First World War, was appointed by Mr. Lehman today director of field operations of his Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Horses, theoretically now out of the Miami picture, are nevertheless playing an important part in activities of this area. No violation of the recent OPA track ban is implied, for the horses now gaining favor with members of Miami's greatest Winter colony are of the old Dobbin variety.

DETROIT, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Black Hawks slipped a goal past Johnny Mowers in the last ten minutes to gain a 1-to-1 tie with the Red Wings in a National Hockey League game tonight before 12,655 spectators. Cully Dalhstrom fired the puck home for Chicago to offset Rookie Johnny Holota's first-period goal.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A British communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 16 -- The crew of a crippled Flying Fortress of the Twelfth United States Army Air Force fought off swarms of enemy fighters, shooting down six, then nursed the plane they call Thunderbird home on two engines across deserts and an 1,800-foot mountain range.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The 20,123-ton liner Duchess of Bedford -- a tempting target for any U-boat -- will not be bothered again by one of them, it was disclosed today.

A college semester of well-rounded liberal arts education will open at Williams College on Feb. 15 and extend to May 27, President James Phinney Baxter 3d has announced. His statement answers numerous questions concerning the immediate future of the traditional liberal arts offering of this college, which is among those selected to act as host to groups of cadets who will begin training under a Navy curriculum.

Wartime government regulations, problems of personnel bank advertising and such innovations as ration-coupon banking and Victory Fund financing will be among the topics of discussion at the conference of the New York State Bankers Association which will meet here tomorrow at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A Sunday pleasure driver who admitted be also had purchased gasoline ration coupons was penalized yesterday by cancellation of his ration book and the case started Office of Price Administration agents off on a new investigation of black-market dealings.

SOME five or six years ago an observant student in an English class at Colby College asked why, in the chapter on the supposed horse-thieves in Thomas Hardy's "Far From the Madding Crowd," does Jan Coggan's watch strike one and an hour later strike one again instead of two.

American organizing ability will have its test this year in two great nation-wide fund-raising campaigns: one for the Red Cross, opening in March, and one for practically every other war-connected activity, opening in October.

A service center operating for women friends and relatives of men in uniform is the newest version of war work in the metropolitan area. Located at 74 Victory Boulevard, Tompkinsville, the Victory Center offers a friendly meeting place for visitors to the men stationed at Staten Island military and naval posts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The dispute over modification of the 1943 synthetic rubber production program between the armed service authorities on the one hand and Chairman Donald M. Nelson of the War Production Board and Administrator William M. Jeffers on the other has reached a point where real agreement seems impossible.

Drawing of United Nations' war planes in action and portraits of pilots and high officers were shown yesterday at a preview in the Associated American Artists Galleries at 711 Fifth Avenue. The exhibit, which will be opened to the public tomorrow, will be continued through Feb. 3.

BOSTON, Jan. 16 -- The veteran Bill Cowley, pressing Toronto's Lorne Carr for National Hockey League scoring honors, collected three goals and as many assists for a total of 6 points while the league-leading Boston Bruins were overtaking the New York Rangers for a 7-5 victory tonight before 12,800 spectators at the Boston Garden.
The first real setback to women's golf has been provided by the decision of the Women's New Jersey Association to abandon tourney play because of the ban on pleasure driving in the Eastern States.

Magistrate Abner C. Surpless said in Brooklyn Week-end Court yesterday that, if Mayor La Guardia were not so solicitous of particular groups in the city's population, the police could put an end to "muggings."

Rostov has seen many wars. In the Middle Ages its surrounding steppes saw the onrush of Tartar hordes. Later it became a chief town of the hard-riding Don Cossacks. Set on the high banks of the Don, twenty-five miles above the Sea of Azov, it was strategically important as a gateway to the Caucasus.

BY all the usually accepted rules of evidence, this should be an amazingly good year for musical comedies. Being composed mainly of tinsel and tunes, they furnish the most complete method of escapism the theatre has devised.

The Syracuse University swimming team opened its season yesterday with a 49-26 victory over Fordham at the Rose Hill Pool. Taking five first places and seven second places, the up-State visitors had little trouble in-handing the Ram natators their third setback.

The first murder victim in this story is an elderly spinster who has been something of a recluse, mingling as little as possible with her neighbors, and not liked by any of them. The body is discovered by Sheila Scott and Kenneth Burns, two members of a theatrical company playing a neighboring town.

THE Postoffice Department made available last week an advance photograph of the "Four Freedoms" 1-cent green stamp to be released on Lincoln's Birthday with first-day sales at Washington. "Freedom of Speech and Religion, from Want and Fear" is inscribed in capital letters on a plaque under an oval panel containing a bas-relief rep resentation of Liberty holding the lighted Torch of Freedom and Enlightenment.

LONDON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Polish Government in exile today described a new series of executions, arrests and mass deportations reported to have been begun yesterday by the Gestapo in Warsaw and Silesia as the Germans' biggest extermination drive against the Polish people since the start of the war.

Baking cakes and washing dishes, handing out hat checks and manning the elevator are all in the routine of members of the Woman's City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street, who have undertaken an ambitious entertainment program for service men.

The arrest of fifteen German enemy aliens, including a former national leader of the German-American Bund youth organization, was announced yesterday by Thomas Donegan, special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation office in New York. Two were wives of aliens who previously had been taken to Ellis Island.

AS the title would indicate, "The Bride Saw Red" is light fiction, romantic variety. But the book is better than the title. As entertainment it is fast, gay, varied and highly amusing. And it is a great deal better written than many a book intended to uplift and improve the mind.

The executive committee of the New York chapter of the Mazzini Society made public yesterday a statement demanding a thorough investigation of "the political roots of this totalitarian crime" -- the murder of Carlo Tresca, Italian-American editor -- because "in too many lands political murder has been the prelude to totalitarian government."

Bronislaw Huberman, Polish violinist, who at a recital last season engaged a small chamber orchestra and appeared with it as soloist-conductor in two concertos, last night at his second Carnegie Hall recital of the season extended the practice.

Captain Folkert H. Dobbenga, who recently was decorated by Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands for action under fire in the Java seas while in the command of the freighter Sloterdyk, has been named superintendent of personnel of the Holland-America Line.

Fifth Avenue at Fifteenth Street is prosaic New York. Most of the near-by buildings are old lofts, left behind when the garment trade moved uptown, and now converted into offices. Some are occupied by small publishing ventures. On that corner last week Carlo Tresca, 70, a bearded, jovial, almost legendary figure in the history of American radicalism, was assassinated.

THE chief merit of this book is that it tells people of what they want to know. We are escorted into a shrine of socialism where Mrs. Strauss as a priestess of the proletariat chants the refrain, "Looking to Cripps," the one remaining "hope of the people."

" It isn't the heat -- it's the humidity." Probably no catch phrase in America has been more used and abused and less warranted or understood, and yet it has been more responsible for calling attention to something called humidity than any erudite statement of the scientists on vapors or vapor pressures.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, Jan. 17 (AP) -- American and Australian ground forces are pinching in toward Sanananda, New Guinea, from two directions, moving slowly through the rain-soaked jungle with direct support of the air force.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Long Island University suffered its third defeat of the basketball season tonight when Canisius scored a 40-36 victory over the Blackbirds from Brooklyn. A crowd of 4,733 previously had seen West Virginia down St. Bonaventure, 50 -- 37, in the first game of the doubleheader.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The sporting goods industry has gone to war.

REPORTERS in World War II are both luckier and less lucky than their predecessors in World War I. Most of them would certainly say that it is their good luck that they are permitted to share many of the fighting man's dangers, instead of being bedded down many miles behind the lines and allowed an occasional visit to a quiet sector.

IF there was any one thing under heaven that Pop was insistent upon it was that the kids should keep away from the theatre. In his eyes, seared from a lifetime of footlights and cindered by countless one-night jumps, there was no more thankless place in this world than what is called, in varying inflections, the theatre, the stage and show business.

NONE of the songs of this war can compare with 'Tipperary," "Over There" and others that the fighting fathers of today's fighters sang a generation ago. Such is the opinion of Sir Harry Lauder, "that grand old minstrel," as Winston Churchill recently described him, who in this war as in the last is singing to soldiers, sailors and airmen.

The major baseball leagues have solved wartime transportation so successfully that today only three clubs still have to arrange Spring training bases near home, but another obstacle -- the player shortage -- now threatens to throw the whole game out of gear, according to The United Press.

IT might just as well be admitted. Ninety-five per cent of the women in this country wear their make-up for the benefit of men. The remaining 5 per cent don't wear it at all. What, then, do men think of women's make-up? Plenty of them just plain don't like it!

GEORGE ABBOTT is on the verge of another production. On Monday last he read a script and on Tuesday last he bought it. As of now it bears the title "More Than You Know." It is the work of Milton Turet, a magazine editor, who is the brother of Maurice Turet, Molly Picon's drum beater.

IT is a proof of the reality of the characters in Miss Coatsworth's stories, and the imagination and understanding with which she draws them, that she can transplant Sally, the little heroine of those thoroughly New England stories, "Away Goes Sally" and "Five Bushel Farm," to the fairy tale atmosphere of the Sultan's court in Morocco and keep her still the same winning, natural child that she was in the earlier stories.

HENRY LIONEL WILLIAMS knows well how to tell a story that will hold the 8 to 10 year olds, as the popularity with child readers of "Turi of the Magic Fingers," a story of Cro-Magnon man, conclusively proved a few years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Information gleaned from the diaries of the score of survivors of the United States Army Air Forces Twenty-seventh Bombardment Group who escaped to Australia from the Philippines enabled the War Department today to piece together the first complete war history of the group. Most of the members of the group are prisoners of war in the Philippines.

Five thousand persons paid tribute to the memory of Carlo Tresca, 68-year-old Italian-born radical editor of Il Martello (The Hammer), at nonreligious services yesterday in Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue.

FROM Stockholm comes word that Sweden released on Dec. 19 two stamps, 5-ore green and 60o claret, to mark the second centenary of the birth of Karl Wilhelm Scheele, Swedish chemist, on that date in 1742. Under his portrait in the de- sign is his autograph above the dates 1742 and 1942.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Representative McKenzie of Louisiana today urged all Southern Congressmen to join him "unequivocally" against the nomination of Representative Marcantonio to the House Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The unauthorized, "wildcat" strike of anthracite miners has propelled John L. Lewis to the first page of the country's newspapers after months of relative obscurity which he did nothing to discourage.

The tremendous task of the United States in shipping that part of this year's $43,000,000,000 production of munitions destined for our armed forces abroad was emphasized by foreign traders last week. Despite everything that has been done, shipping remains the bottleneck of the nation's offensive effort, it was pointed out by the traders.

A group of women will receive eight months of training in aeronautical engineering at the Daniel Guggenheim School of Aeronautics of New York University under new scholarships established by the Vought-Sikorsky Aircraft Division of the United Aircraft Corporation, it was announced yesterday by officials of the aircraft corporation and the university.

IT is in no Pollyanna mood but in a profound troubled spirit that Henry Wyman Holmes, Professor of Education at Harvard University, approaches the subject of courage, perhaps the greatest of all virtues and never more needful than at this time.

A new clarification of the Office of Price Administration's anti-discrimination order and the likelihood of action in Washington to make it easier for the oil industry to discount in advance military and other government needs for petroleum brought favorable comment here yesterday from oil industry spokesmen.

AT a time when Greece is much in our thoughts it is good to have this story of Nikias, a boy in a little Greek village in the Summer of 1940, who draws together for us the old and the new. Nikias could listen by the hour to his friend Demetrios, the shepherd, while the latter told him stories of the ancient heroes.

CURTICE HITCHCOCK, president of Reynal Hitchcock, is back in New York after his eight-week study of British wartime book publishing, under the auspices of the Book Publishers Bureau and the Office of War Information.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- In the fiscal year that will begin on July 1 the Government of the United States will spend almost as much as the citizens of the United States will earn.

TWO more annuals have become current: the twenty-seventh appearance of the Society of American Etchers, at the National Academy, and the tenth annual of An American Group, at the galleries of the Associated American Artists.

Gasoline rationing stud fuel shortages have impelled the closing of some clubhouses of women's organizations in suburban areas, the complete transfer of activities from others, and drastic changes in program in a third group. Greatly reduced attendance because of transportation difficulties, and falling thermometers within their quarters dictated the changes.

I WAS very much interested in the article on Jan. 3 by Stefan J. Rundt in which he detailed some of the activities of the so-called German "freedom" stations. I say "so-called" because what assurance is there that the "freedom" stations are anything of the kind? Could they not be -- are they not, for that matter -- stations regularly operated by both the Nazis and the British in the tricky, many-sided game of propaganda?

HOW that Mercury Theatre crowd gets on! Not so many seasons back it was just a rather haphazard band of actors earning bread and butter from the government Federal Theatre. Now, one by one, they seem to be cropping up all over the place as stars, prize winners and eminent personages.

In place of its traditional "Night in Poland" Ball, which has projected a colorful note into the Winter scene here in past years, the Kosciuszko Foundation will present next Friday night as its tenth annual benefit dance a Polka Military Ball in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 16 -- Improved performance of American warplanes in the near future was indicated yesterday when the Hamilton Standard Propellers division of United Aircraft Corporation announced that the first flight of an American-built counter-rotating, full-feathering, constant-speed air screw had been successfully concluded here last week.

The establishment of scholarships for the training of specialists in the Elizabeth Kenny method of infantile paralysis treatment for ten doctors, nine nurses and six physiotherapists was announced yesterday in the annual report of the Greater New York Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, issued by George L. Shearer, chapter chairman.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sunday, Jan. 17 -- The Tuxedo Club, one of the famous clubhouses in America, was seriously damaged by a fire last night and this morning which threatened to destroy the $1,000,000 building, headquarters of the club of the Tuxedo Park colony here.

With the intricate matter of setting up their wartime Spring training plans fairly well completed, New York's three major league ball clubs settled down yesterday to their next order of business, the mailing out of contracts and the signing of players for the 1943 campaign.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Bombing attacks such as those carried out against Milan, Naples and other Italian cities in recent months were declared by the Italian press and radio today to be "no longer possible" because of improved anti-aircraft defense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, called for an immediate end to the Pennsylvania coal strike tonight in a radio address in which, for the most part, he complimented the American worker generally on the work done.

The annual benefit theatre party under the auspices of the Church Charity Foundation of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will take place the night of Feb. 9 at the performance of Maxwell Anderson's "The Eve of St. Mark" at the Cort Theatre.

Cooperation among local women's groups in working out problems caused by the labor shortage is urged by the National Council of Jewish Women in letters to 210 member sections throughout the country which suggest that they take the initiative in calling conferences to consider the matter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- One line of a large war production plant at Williamsport, Pa., is manned entirely by thirty-three physically handicapped workers, the War Manpower Commission reported today, and "has given a striking demonstration of the success with which disabilities may be turned into capabilities."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- New York University's high-flying basketball team, playing for the first time without the speedy Ray Lumpp, recorded its eleventh triumph tonight at Convention Hall, overpowering the tall Temple University outfit, 51 -- 43.

JOSEPH E. DAVIES, former United States Ambassador to the U.S.S.R., who has come to Hollywood to collaborate with Warner Brothers on the filming of his work, "Mission to Moscow," is facing the prospect of cinematic glorification with unshaken equanimity.

WITH THE RED ARMY, Southeast of Rostov, Jan. 16 -- The Red Army is advancing over this vast front in amazingly mild weather, disproving any theory that bitter Winter temperatures may have contributed to Adolf Hitler's current Russian disaster.

Retail trade continued active here last week, but as in the preceding week percentage comparisons with the extremely high sales figures of a year ago were not favorable. Estimates put department store volume at 6 to 7 per cent under the 1942 week.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Although transportation difficulties are making a midwinter trip from New York to most of the Berkshire skiing areas an adventure, a few devotees of the sport are arriving weekly to enjoy the great outdoors in what is proving to be a real old-fashioned Winter with many near-zero mornings and plenty of snow over a hard crusty base.

A CURRENT radio job is plaguing its proponents with a lot of engineering "headaches." It is the huge task of boiling down the voluminous technical data on thousands of past and present receiver parts and devising a new "Victory" line to service the country's 50,000,000-odd existing home sets until the war is over.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The combination of Tony Karpowich and Bob Mullens proved too much for Syracuse's basketball team tonight and the Fordham Rams outclassed the Orange in the bold Gymnasium were witnessing last ten minutes to win, 55 -- 38.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES, in Tunisia, Jan. 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- Corporal Walter John Will, a 20-year-old infantryman from West Winfield, N.Y., told today how he faced German artillery and machine-gun fire fifteen times in a borrowed jeep, returning each time with a wounded American soldier.

In joining with the United Nations in the fight against the Axis, Mexico was continuing in the tradition of her revolution, General Manuel Avila Camacho, Mexican President, said yesterday in a message that was read at the Opera Victory Rally, an intermission feature of the eighth regular Saturday afternoon broadcast of the Metropolitan Opera over the Blue Network.

Joseph C. Grew, former Ambassador to Tokyo, warned yesterday that the Japanese were likely to employ "ju-jitsu" military and diplomatic tactics. If in danger of defeat, he said, the Japanese would attempt by trickery to throw the United Nations off guard in a peace offensive, even to the extent of creating a seemingly liberal puppet civilian cabinet so they could renew later their attack for dominance of Eastern Asia and the South Seas.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 16 -- Continuing their assault against enemy supply lines, American planes shot down seven Junkers-52s -- giant German transports -- and set fire to a large schooner yesterday in widespread aerial combats in which Twelfth United States Army Air Force bombers and fighters shot down seventeen enemy aircraft and damaged fourteen others.

FREEPORT, L.I., Jan. 16 -- Officials of this village and Rockville Centre met in joint conference today and announced their intention of fighting the threatened directive of the Petroleum Administration for War ordering them to shut down their municipal electric light plants and buy power for municipal consumers from the Long Island Lighting Company.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Convicted of looting the treasury of Local 17 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America, Samuel Nuzzo, ousted business agent of the local, was sentenced today by Justice Riley H. Heath of the Supreme Court, to ten to twenty years in Sing Sing.

THE ban on pleasure driving has been in existence now for a week and apparently it has had little effect on concertgoing. Nor are the managers particularly concerned about its effect on the future. They figure people will attend concerts no matter to what lengths they have to go to get there.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- No precious commodity within the United States is being pressed into service of the military program at a greater rate than medical skill.

WITH AMERICAN F O R C E S ON GUADALCANAL, Jan. 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- Expert knowledge of tides and currents around this embattled island, gained through years of pre-war snooping, is enabling the Japanese to keep their otherwise isolated troops on Guadalcanal adequately supplied with food by submarine.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Efforts of the National Mediation Board to mediate the dispute between the railroads and fifteen nonoperating unions over the unions' demand for wage increases and the closed shop failed today, but there is little likelihood of a strike developing from the dispute, it is believed.

President Roosevelt last week drew a blueprint for American life in a time of total war. Its outlines were bold and harsh. It encompassed every one of the country's 133,000,000 people. It embodied the concept of ancient Sparta -- the utilization of an national resources, human and material, for the waging of all-out war.

The stock of wool carpeting, once generous, is steadily dwindling. The bales of wool which were bought to go into the making of carpets and rugs are being set aside for Army use, and the huge looms which once transformed wool into broadloom carpets and domestic orientals are now weaving heavy duck for tents, woolen Army blankets, fabrics for parachutes and many other vital war necessities.

In a world at war the garden club has a place -- a large and seriously important place -- for such a club appeals to a numerous group of citizens. The Federated Garden Clubs of New York State have a membership of over 12,000 women, and over a period of years these 12,000 women have been training unconsciously for specialized participation in the war effort.

The first two performances of Sonja Henie's Hollywood Ice Revue at Madison Square Garden will benefit respectively two noteworthy philanthropic organizations of this city. Advance ticket sales, to which several committees representing both beneficiaries have contributed much effort, indicate that both performances will be sell-outs.
Five points behind, with as many minutes to go, Columbia University's basketball team rallied to sink Navy, 56 to 52, and thrill 1,200 spectators in the Lions' gymnasium last night.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Prices of grains edged slowly upward in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, with oats in the lead.

Frank Dixon will have to wait a while before he steps into Leslie MacMitchell's running shoes. The N.Y.U. freshman, phenomenon in cross-country running and favored to take the mile in the annual metropolitan A.A.U. "indoor" championship meet, was beaten yesterday by the more experienced Jim Rafferty, former Fordham luminary now wearing the New York A.C.'s Winged Foot.

American warplanes have finally sloughed the cabalistic letters and names that used to identify them -- at least for people who knew the code -- and have taken on real fighting names, officially selected by the Army and the Navy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Secretary Wickard acted today to bar the employment of dollar-a-year men in the Agriculture Department and its war food production and distribution agencies.

Lorraine Begonias, one of the most beautiful of house plants, and now at the height of their bloom during this season, are often considered short-lived plants. Because of this they are usually discarded at the end of the first flowering period.

IN reading this book one is at once impressed with the intimate approach that the author uses in treating the usually detailed and dry subjects of weather and navigation as they apply to the art of flying. These two subjects divide the book into approximately equal parts and with a definiteness that makes two books in one.

Nine personal appearances by Miss Sonja Henie and seven sparkling group numbers are among the highlights of the sixth annual Hollywood Ice Revue scheduled to open a ten-day run in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- Americans may view 1943 with the "utmost confidence" but should realize at the same time that, if the war is to be won in 1944, all the preparations must be finished by the end of December, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, declared tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- For the second time in twenty-four hours Royal Air Force bombers raided Lorient, major Nazi submarine base on the Atlantic coast of France, last night.

Because of the growth of war industries in many sections of the country, serious educational problems have arisen which have caused overcrowding, teacher shortage and a lack of school materials and supplies. Twelve hundred school communities in all parts of the United States now need additional funds to maintain their education systems in an adequate and efficient manner.

VATICAN CITY postal officials are preparing a series of semi-postals to benefit war prisoners whether of the United Nations or the Axis. This is without precedent in philatelic history, and in the opinion of collectors the stamps should prove to be among the most popular ones of World War II.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Hatred of the enemy and desire for revenge should not be taught in the public schools, the Educational Policies Committee of the National Education Association declared today in a statement, "What the School Should Teach in Wartime."

An attendance of 3,500 persons is expected at the forty-first annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club, which will take place Feb. 10 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Of this number about one thousand will be men serving in the various branches of the armed forces, as well as many Waacs, Waves and Spars.

The monthly meeting of the regional group of the American Rock Garden Society will be held on Wednesday at the Hotel Lexington. After luncheon at noon, Guy G. Nearing will give an illustrated talk on "An Introduction to Dwarf Rhododendrons for the Rock Garden." Gardeners are invited to attend the meeting.

HERE is a first novel of rare promise; a story of a half-breed Indian's struggle to find his destiny and his soul. Set among the mesas of the Utah Territory in the Eighteen Sixties, moving from the Navajo hunting grounds to the settlements of those wonderful bigots, the pioneer Mormons, it blazes with vignettes of the true West -- a picture obscured, for so many readers, by generations of horse opera.

THE advent of mechanized warfare has brought about a considerable interest in weather. Now that "weather" has become a military secret, the nearest approach to a knowledge of the conditions under which our soldiers are fighting in a particular theatre of operation must come through the study of the usual weather conditions that prevail there, called its "climate."

The New York State Parole Board was consulted in the case of Alexander Hoffman, head of the Cleaners and Dyers Union, convicted of attempted arson and terrorism, but only a few hours before Governor Charles Poletti announced the commutation of the labor leader's four-to-eight-year prison term, it was learned yesterday.

THIS story of Irish home life creates an atmosphere of calm and spaciousness very refreshing in these days when even books written for children sometimes show a sense of strain and hurry. In a country house outside Dublin live the six Donovans, father, mother and four children.

Bouguereau startlingly emerges at Durand-Ruel's, where the "long-lost" and once so famous "Nymphs and Satyr" was placed on view a week ago today as a solo benefit for the Fighting French Relief Committee.

Edward J. Flynn's career was founded in the neighborhood political clubs of the Bronx. He spent many nights tramping to the meetings in cellar rooms, vacant stores and faded mansions to "say a few words to the boys" and listen to their troubles. He was for many years the only top-flight New York City political leader with a college degree.

DURING his active career, from 80 to 43 B.C., Cicero played a conspicuous though thoroughly defeated part in the volcanic events leading to the destruction, after four and a half centuries, of the Roman Republic.

HONOLULU, Jan. 16 -- Phil Cass, commander of the American Legion's Hawaiian Department, in a message today to Roane Waring, national commander of the Legion, asked that President Roosevelt be urged to appoint an independent person or board to investigate martial law in Hawaii and especially current proposals to modify it.

Termination by England and the United States of their extraterritorial privileges in China was hailed yesterday by Rabbi Israel Goldstein in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway, as "one of several steps needed to counteract the mistrust of the western democracies by Asiatic peoples seeking life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness."

If a person wants to say that in the last half dozen years there has been a complete change in the American moral climate, it is not compulsory to use big scientific and sociological words. He may say, without being in the least frivolous, that it has been a change from the Little Miss Muffet climate to the Little Jack Horner climate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Fuel oil dealers or suppliers may limit sales to their customers to a percentage of the currently valid ration coupons presented so long as all customers are treated alike, the Office of Price Administration said today in an interpretation of its recent "nondiscrimination" ruling.

Prominent members of the insurance industry here expect to meet soon with officials of the Office of Censorship in Washington, D.C., to see what can be done to meet government actions to prevent insurance information from leaving the country and at the same time continue the strong long-standing ties between the insurance market here and the powerful British insurance exchanges.

Stocks backed away yesterday from their high levels of Friday on the New York Stock Exchange and closed mixed. Volume was heavy -- 504,780 shares, against 437,790 on the previous Saturday -- and the market was broader than in any other two-hour session since Dec. 27, 1941.

The function of a variable-pitch propeller on an airplane is like that of an automobile's transmission. When an airplane climbs at a steep angle its pitch, that is the angle of "bite," is different from what it is in level flight with a following wind. On small airplanes propellers usually have fixed pitches.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The hotel shortage here will be relieved in part beginning Monday by the opening on that day of some 250 rooms in the new Hotel Statler on Sixteenth Street, which is being rushed to completion for opening about Jan. 30.

Net profit of the United States Leather Company and its subsidiary for the year ended on Oct. 31, according to the report announced yesterday, was $1,420,361 after $450,000 provision for income taxes and $1,224,639 reserve for inventories, contingencies and rehabilitation of property and equipment.

The Secretary of Agriculture has urged that every able-bodied citizen who owns, or can obtain access to, a suitable and sunny plot of ground shall this year endeavor to grow as many vegetables as possible, for family consumption.

CARL CALMER'S division of these songs into three categories -- songs of the rivers of the East, South and West -- serves to remind us that we Americans have never sung the rivers of the East as we have the rivers of the West and South.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after a week of irregular fluctuations, due to changing supplies. The report of the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

FRANCONIA, N.H., Jan. 16 -- This serene New England settlement, catapulted into the Winter sports limelight in 1938 when the extensive downhill ski center, serviced by the only aerial tramway in North America, was carved out on Cannon Mountain, is upholding its role admirably in the nation's war effort.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The attention of Winter sports enthusiasts in the Poconos is being centered on the fifth annual Down-the-Mountain ski race at Onawa Lodge, scheduled for next week-end. About fifty skiers will participate in the event, which takes place over a difficult one-mile down-mountain course from Cresco Heights to the village of Mountainhome, and is open to amateur skiers only.

AMERICAN war propaganda programs are heard throughout the Republic of Mexico by means of Radio Programas de Mexico. This is a chain of seventy local stations in different sections of the country that are hooked up with XEW (100,000 watts) and XEQ (50,000 watts), the largest stations in the republic.

Old-crop months on the New York Cotton Exchange showed to best advantage yesterday as traders engaged in substantial price-fixing against the 237,908 bales of cotton purchased by the Government for lend-lease purposes. The market opened moderately above Friday's closing level, declined to slight losses and then retraced its course to show gains of 1 to 8 points finally.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Funds are available for small final distributions to owners of debentures issued by Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and serial gold notes issued by the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, through termination of the long equity proceedings involving these companies.

ZERO weather coupled with fuel oil shortage has opened up many a closed fireplace and brought back into use the quaint yet surprisingly efficient old-fashioned stove. An unprecedented demand for stoves has exhausted the main supply of available antique examples, say metropolitan dealers, but there are still plenty of old-time andirons, tongs and other fireplace fitments to add to the cheer of open hearths.

Notices of appeal from the 1-A draft classification of five young foreign-born followers of Frank Buchman, organizer of Moral Rearmament, Inc., were received yesterday by local Selective Service Board 17 at 412 Sixth Avenue. The registrants on whose behalf the notices were sent are part of a group of twenty-eight M.R.A. members enrolled with Board 17, the cases of twenty-five of whom already have been reviewed by the board and their classifications confirmed.

There's nothing like a mild day in January to stir the gardener's soul. His dreams are as hardy as Symplocarpus foetidus, his hopes as persistent as crab-grass. One look at the new seed catalogues, a glance at the simmering sun, a quick mental summary of the rationing program, and he is all but setting out tomato plants.
MENTION two weeks ago in these columns of the possibility of a symphony orchestra consisting of musicians now enlisted in the Army has aroused immediate and widespread interest.

One of the unique entertainments of the season will be a gala variety show entitled "A Night in an English Music Hall," which will be presented in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 25 by the Canadian Club of New York. The organization has arranged the fete to raise funds for providing medical aid and other assistance for United Nations war-relief projects.

The patronesses of the annual series of subscription parties entitled the Coffee Dances will give an informal dinner, followed by dancing, on Wednesday at the Cosmopolitan Club. The net proceeds will be turned over to the American Red Cross.

Albert Axelrod of the Foils Club, with six victories in the final round-robin, led the qualifiers for the finals of the All-Eastern intermediate foil championship at the Greco Fencing Academy yesterday. The title competition is slated on the Greco strips Feb. 6.

RIDING toward Beauregard City to help a rancher who was losing some of his stock. Pete Piper, young detective for the Cattlemen's Association, came upon a dead man in a rocking chair -- miles away from any house.
MUSIC is a dominant need of our time. It is a great stimulus for our fighting forces and a great hope for our future.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A communique:

AN obscure provision tucked away in the amendments to the Federal income tax law enacted by the Revenue Act of 1942 is of far-reaching significance to the theatrical business and, when generally known, may revolutionize the methods now prevailing for the financing of theatrical productions through angels, or at least, cool the ardor of such angels in rushing in where they should fear to tread.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The achievements of Negro Americans in many fields are recorded in a booklet issued by the Office of War Information today, in official recognition of their important contribution to the war effort and in the armed forces.
LONDON, Jan. 16 (Reuter) -Results of football games played in the British Isles today:

The German High Command said yesterday that "in the area of Stalingrad our troops, who have been engaged in heroic defensive battles there for weeks against the enemy at cking from all sides, repelled further attacks by strong enemy infantry and tank formations."

The American college world has enthusiastically accepted the dictum of the Federal Government that "business as usual" in higher education is over for the duration of the war. The fact that this radical change must be planned nationally by the Federal Government is also accepted by college people.

OTTAWA, Jan. 16 -- Because of the inability of some delegates to get here on time, the meeting of union officials and representatives of plant managements with members of the Federal Cabinet to try to settle the strike in the Canadian steel plants had to be adjourned today until Monday morning.

A severe, if not unexpected, blow to the private-car owner was the recent OPA order which brought to a halt all pleasure driving in the seventeen Eastern States and the District of Columbia, Violators of the order are penalized by the forfeiture of their ration books.

Heaviest influx of out-of-town buyers in the company's more than twenty years of experience was reported by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co. in its weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES. Buying was extremely heavy wherever merchandise was available, but there were very definite shortages in most markets and goods were being sold on an allotment basis only to former customers, it was said.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 16 -- All prisoners detained in jails and concentration camps in French North Africa for political reasons before the advent of the Allied forces have now been freed, according to official sources here.

Mozart's "The Magic Flute" received its fourth performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The presentation marked the first appearance of Mark Harrell as Papageno in the work, and the return of Nadine Connor to the role of Pamina, in which she made her debut last year.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Iraq, which owns some of the world's richest petroleum deposits, by declaring war today against Germany, Italy and Japan, became the first inde pendent Moslem nation to join the United Nations cause.

THE ban on pleasure driving in the seventeen rationed Eastern States and the curtailment on fuel oil deliveries did not cut as sharply into attendance at motion picture theatres during the past week as had been expected.

The most urgently needed single feature in our income-tax system at this time is a general provision for withholding the tax. It is almost futile to expect that an income tax, imposed at extremely high rates, can be wholly collected on the due dates of installments without some form of compulsory withholding at the source of payment.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 16 -- The Berlin propaganda machinery is now working overtime to interpret to the German people the course of the war in such a manner as to "let them down easy." Recent German reverses have made it more than ever necessary to break bad news gently -- but not too gently lest the home front slacken on its round-the-clock producing of war materials and contributing more soldiers to the front.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Two special Soviet communiques tonight announced the opening of a new Russian offensive on the upper Don south of Voronezh, with advances of thirty to fifty-six miles and the capture of more than 600 populated places, and reported that the 70,000 to 80,000 survivors of 220,000 Germans trapped before Stalingrad since Nov. 23 were rapidly being wiped out after their rejection of a Red Army ultimatum.

Isidor Achron, pianist, and Lea Karina, mezzo-soprano, gave a joint recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Mr. Achron's contributions comprised a Chopin group and a sheaf of his own composiitons, two of which received their first performance, namely, "Suite Grotesque" and "Valse de Concert."

WHEN Lou Little starts to talk, the best thing to do is listen. In the first place the Columbia coach is a big fellow with a vibrant voice which can be heard a half-mile away on a clear day. In the second place he always has something worth-while saying.

Mrs. John E. Rousmaniere will give a tea on Wednesday at her home, 115 East Sixty-fifth Street, for Mrs. Mary E. Breckinridge, founder and director of the Frontier Nursing Service of Kentucky. Friends of the organization, who have been invited to attend, have been requested to bring bundles of rummage suitable for resale later at the Bargain Box, 1175 Third Avenue, for the benefit of the Service.

One of the arts that soldiers in this war of many allies have to learn is how to get on with queer people. The adjective is not used disparagingly. If the ways of the Chinese, the Guadalcanal head-hunters, the East Indians, the French, the Egyptians and the British often seem strange to us, how can we suppose our ways seem to them?

The more favorable turn in the war is producing such a flood of peace plans that they threaten to impinge on the common war effort of the United Nations. For that reason President Roosevelt, in his speech to Congress on the state of the Union in wartime, declared that "at this critical period in the war, we should confine ourselves to the larger objectives and not get bogged down in argument over methods and detail."

LONDON -- So little real news leaks out of that large administrative area under German domination known as the "Ostland," or East Country, that the continual struggle going on between the conquerors and the mass of heterogeneous people who inhabit it is almost forgotten. Looting and killings are common.

PARALLELS (or should they be called recurrences?) in history can be either fairly illuminating or extremely misleading. It should always be borne in mind that often enough one century's meat is another century's poison, and, therefore, not all totalitarian, or absolute, rulers can be judged from the same ethical vantage point.

Contending that Army exchange or "PX" stores have expanded in scope beyond the original intent of Congress, retail spokesmen have presented several recommendations to the War Department urging restriction on the type of merchandise sold and on the use of post exchange facilities by civilians.
It is unfortunate that some officers of the American Navy are as ignorant of the Japanese foe as is revealed by your airmail story under Pearl Harbor dateline in THE TIMES of Dec. 31.

The mentally deranged and the newborn will have an advantage over the merely forgetful and the lazy when War Ration Book 2, which will be used for meats, canned goods and possibly for other commodities, is issued next month, the Office of Price Administration disclosed yesterday.

The combination garden is among the most satisfying sights that reward the gardener's skill. During the last twenty years it has been more typical of Europe than of the United States. Often without much design it was seen here in towns and villages, but the emphasis has been increasingly on flowers alone.

Lieut. Col. Walter L. Bayler, the last marine to leave Wake Island before it fell to the Japanese, was greatly surprised when informed of its capture forty hours after he had left the tiny Pacific outpost in a Navy flying boat.

A BABY sits before he stands, creeps before he walks, and no one in his right mind punishes a child for behaving this way. It's another story when he tells tall tales before he tells the truth, holds on to playthings before he shares them -- proclivities which follow the same orderly sequence of development responsible for his ability to get to his feet, keep his balance and go places.

THE period in which we live might well be called the Age of Perplexity. Doubts, confusions, gropings dominate its thought. We seek either to restore our faith in old values or to find new ones. We are a generation in limbo.
SPUR-OF-THE-MOMENT cookery -- an art that depends on tinned and bottled and frozen foods -- is about to enter an eclipse. For next month the plan for rationing processed goods goes into effect.

Describing the book collections in the New York Public Library as "woefully inadequate" to meet current or future needs, Frank L. Polk, president of the board of directors, asked the city for an increase of $489,765 over last year's appropriation in the proposed 1943-44 budget submitted to the Budget Director yesterday.

WITH THE AMERICAN AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Jan. 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- A flight of Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's fighters swarmed into Burma Friday and dive-bombed Irrawaddy River craft loaded with Japanese supplies at Bhamo, destroying two big barges, damaging a third and sinking a tug.

THIS is a minority report on an event which has been so successful that the number of performances originally scheduled has been doubled, which has had standees at all three presentations to date, and which on the two occasions when this reviewer has been present has roused its audience to vociferous cheering.

If you have a houseplant with large, lovely leaves, plentifully blotched with creamy splashes, growing at the top of a long, bare and probably crooked stem, the chances are that you have a Deiffenbachia splendens, though you may know it by the erroneous name "Chinese lily" or "Spotted lily."

" Japan has never lost a war"? I quote not from THE NEW YORK TIMES but the heading of an advertisement quoting the former Ambassador to Tokyo, Joseph C. Grew, as saying that "The Japanese will not crack. * * * They * * * will fight to the bitter end."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 16 -- Yale defeated Army tonight in hockey, 7 -- 3. The Elis had a 4-2 lead at the end of the first period and were never challenged after that. Boynton tallied three times as the Blue notched an easy Pentagonal League victory.

As a demonstration of United Nations solidarity, the Netherlands unit of the British War Relief Society gave yesterday an Anglo-Dutch tea party in the New Amsterdam room of Holland House, Rockefeller Plaza. Several high officials of the United Nations attended.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 16 -- In line with recant pronouncements by German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels and articles in the Schwarze Korps, organ of the Elite Guard, preparing the German people for a general mobilization of women and the sending to the front of the last available reserves of manpower, Dr. Robert Lay, head of the German labor front, published yesterday in the Angriff a new appeal for "total war."

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16 -- The Texas-owned Valdina Farms of Emerson F. Woodward, whose Valdiana Orphan raced here last Winter before going on to achieve national prominence, uncovered a possible threat for the Louisiana Derby of March 6 when Valdina Foe, a $51.40 for-$2 shot in the field of nine 3-year-olds, drove to victory in the six-furlong Audubon Stakes today.
CALL her H.M.S. Chariot. That wasn't her name, but the Royal Navy frowns on naming real names unless officially unmasked in orders, citations or those messages that begin with regrets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Lieutenant (j. g.) Frances Rich of Santa Barbara has been put in charge of the V-mail section of naval postal communications at the Navy Department. She relieves Lieutenant (j. g.) Paul R. Grigsby of Atlanta, Ga., who is now available for sea duty.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Three teams shared first place in qualifying competition for the Football League Cup after the fourth week of play. They are Manchester City, Coventry City and Chesterfield.

Lieut. Comdr. Marvin A. Stevens (MC), U.S.N.R., known to the collegiate football world as "Mal" or "Dr. Mal," now is on the medical staff of the Naval Hospital at the United States Naval Training Station on the shores of Seneca Lake at Sampson, N.Y.

Bobsledding, which in other years carried many sportsmen to Switzerland's famous Cresta Run, will take the spotlight at Lake Placid with the opening of the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic Bob Run the last week-end in January. The first scheduled racing event will be the four-man trophy competition, followed by the two-man championship, on Jan. 31.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 16 -- British forces of mixed arms struck here and there along the Wadi Zemzem line in Tripolitania yesterday, inflicting casualties on the enemy. The "increased patrol activity" reported in today's communique recalls the time at El Agheila when British patrols struck preliminary blows and found that the enemy could not withstand even these.

Fire destroyed a war plant in Maspeth, Queens, last night despite the combined efforts of fourteen fire companies from Queens and Brooklyn. The plant manufactured steel mats for landing fields and ventilators for naval ships.

Due to the postponement of the opening date of the Playwrights Producing Company's latest play, "The Patriots," at the National Theatre, the benefit performance for the Children's Welfare Federation has been changed from Jan. 28 to Feb. 1.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- With the first accelerated graduation that this war has brought to the United States Military Academy approaching -- the first early second lieutenants will receive their commissions next Tuesday -- seven cadet teams staged a field day of sports on the Plains today, with the basketball, swimming, polo, boxing, wrestling, rifle and gymnastic squads in action.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Flying Fortresses striking at ports in Tunisia have left a ribbon of destruction from Gabes to Bizerte along the waterfronts, wrecking an estimated 20 per cent of dock installations in six weeks.
In your editorial "Messenger to Garcia" you say Elbert Hubbard "wrote a piece for his magazine, The Philistine, and called it 'A Message to Garcia'."

WHEN an individual comes of age, it is customary to mark the occasion by some kind of festive celebration. It is none the less fitting to recognize the date when an organization passes beyond the stage of adolescence.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Secre tary Ickes said today that unauthorized strikes were cutting expected hard-coal production under the new six-day week program more than had been estimated.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 16 (U.P.) -- British troops have beaten off a determined Japanese counter-attack near Rathedaung, twenty-five miles north of Akyab, Burma, while Royal Air Force planes battered enemy positions in the Akyab area, a British communique reported today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 16 -- Winter finally prevailed this week in Central Russia. Traces of its sudden overwhelming offensive are visible everywhere.

Recent developments have made possible more optimistic forecast for dogs and dog shows during the late Winter and early Spring. When gas rationing was imposed and followed by the ban on pleasure driving, the dog world became discouraged and shows were canceled that might have pulled through.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Crosses and medals were awarded by the Navy Department today as follows to five officers and two enlisted men for extraordinary heroism during enemy attacks:

The war's first all-service boxing feature for Madison Square Garden was signed yesterday when Promoter Mike Jacobs paired Gus Lesnevich, world light-heavyweight champion, and Melio Bettina, Beacon, N.Y., contender for the heavyweight title, for a ten-round match on Feb. 26. Lesnevich is a member of the Coast Guard and Bettina is in the Army.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 16 -- The process of recasting Alsatians into Germans faces a number of complexities, the results of historic precedents and the absence of a formal French renunciation of all future claims on Alsace. Meanwhile the Germans are enforcing measures that far transcend the limits of a conventional military occupation.

EVERY now and again a bright, cheering spot shows up on our horizon -- an especially good story, a beautiful mist-hung sunset, or a quaint, amusing slant on something we have known well. "Look at Life" (Alfred A. Knopf, $1.29) is an album with that quality; a collection of nature photographs that began as a hobby and became an abiding talent.

Horace Joseph Haase, 34 years old, formerly in charge of the Speakers Bureau of the America First Committee in Brooklyn, was scheduled to appear yesterday before Local Board 100 in the Bronx, preliminary to reporting for induction into the Army.

GEORGE SZELL, who has, recently added considerably to his reputation as a conductor in this country by his Metropolitan performances of "Salome," "Tannhaeuser" and "Boris Godunoff," is a man of many nationalities.

The Nazi Minister of Education once shouted at the director of the American Colony School in Berlin: "Tell America that young Germany is in deadly earnest!" The schoolmaster was Gregor Ziemer and he returned to this country, before the outbreak of war, when the surveillance of some fifteen Reich agencies made it impossible to continue at the school.

WITH THE ALLIED FORCES IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 13 (Delayed) -- The Mediterranean theatre of war will share importance with Russia when Spring clears the skies and calms the long rollers of the great sea which once more is playing a primary strategic role in North Africa.

The WPB has been investigating two distinct types of evasions of the inventory control order L-219, it was learned from unofficial sources here last week. These evasions, both of the letter and of the spirit of the inventory regulations, are alleged to have been put into practice or are being "discussed" by some misguided retailers and manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Ten simple steps, ranging from hanging blankets in doorways to the use of newspapers as an emergency substitute for weather stripping, were suggested by the Office of Price Administration today to save heat, particularly in the oil-rationed home.

The first deduction from this survey of the home-front situations is that the degeneration upon European Axis home fronts will be continuous from now on. It will be disastrous unless they can break through the aggressive ring with which the United Nations have surrounded them.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 16 -- Except for one play, Dartmouth took and kept a safe lead over Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight and won, 48 -- 29.

Dakar, overshadowed by the military and political battles in North Africa, is nevertheless as important as it was in the days when we feared the Germans might seize it either as a springboard for attack on this hemisphere or as a dominating position whence they could threaten Brazil and undermine Pan-American solidarity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator Reed of Kansas, seeking to "sidetrack" the Senate Committee on Education and Labor with his war bill to make forty-eight hours the basic work week, except where there are labor contracts, began a letter-writing campaign today to bring the measure directly to the floor.

Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange fell in December from 551,053 to 501,833 shares, according to a tabulation issued last week. Neither total includes short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers.

IT is the "magical realm" of childhood to which the title of Kathleen Coyle's new book beckons, and the childhood in Northwestern Ireland at the beginning of the century is her own. Yet just as "The Magical Realm" is better described as an "autobiographical book" than as an "autobiography," so the enchantments of childhood, and even its everyday happenings and backgrounds, are not held within the expected limits of the story of a child.

Charles David Gibbons, assistant treasurer of the United States Lines, has been elected treasurer and a member of the board of directors, Basil Harris, president, announced yesterday. He succeeds R.M. Hicks, who recently joined the Army Transport Service.

FOR those who affectionately regard motion pictures as the great art form of this century the year ahead is charged with challenge. They are more fully aware than those who take their movies with a pinch of caviar that there is a specific job to be done, and quickly done, or we lose the peace, which in the end amounts to losing the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- United States Air Forces seriously damaged three Japanese destroyers and shot down thirty enemy planes in the Solomon Islands area yesterday, Solomons time, the Navy Department said today. In addition, a Japanese cargo ship was left in flames.

Many rock gardens are enriched by alpines from the Rocky Mountains, but one hears little about Rocky Mountain shrubs, for it is not a region of deciduous trees and shrubs. However, there are a few of real garden value.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- A new process operating with remarkable success is enabling the Foote Mineral Company here to recapture from the tailings and complex tinny wolfram ores hauled 7,000 miles from the mines in Bolivia great amounts of tungsten ore that has a quality quite comparable with the best ores produced in China and Burma.

CONCERNED with a father who is struck into pity and mourning by the death in action of his son, and is returned to acceptance through the intercession of a kind of Ghost of the American Past, this story that hag received the highest praise from William Allen White and some others may be turned to by many in future months who hope that through reading it their own mourning may be eased.

MOST of us have had the unfortunate experience of encountering precocious children who wearied us out of mind with their self-conscious attempts at smartness. Sometimes they continue on through a long-delayed adolescence.
Metal scrap from the battlefields of the South Pacific and North Africa is piling up at some American ports as ships bring it in as ballast.

FIVE recently written works by American composers now serving in the armed forces will receive their premieres at the first concert in the League of Composers' Young Composers' series for this season, to be given next Sunday afternoon at 3 P.M. in the New York Public Library.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16 -- Don Budge, the world's top-ranking tennis player, has resigned as physical training director for the Embry-Riddle School of Aviation and will leave Monday for California "for a visit with my family before eventually going into the armed services."

RAYMOND KENDALL, now on leave of absence from the Music Department of Dartmouth in order to give full time to his post as USO music coordinator, reports that the experiment of sending out music advisers to camps has worked out so well that the program will be expanded and placed on a permanent basis.

THE seventy-sixth annual exhibition of the American Water Color Society will be held at the National Academy of Design Galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue, from March 24 to April 14. The private view and reception will be held at 8:30 P.M. on March 23.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 16 -- An "unofficial" customs union between the Reich and German-occupied areas has been operating since Dec. 1, it is reported from the Netherlands and other points.
Despite the ravages of the war which have made heavy inroads on its member clubs, the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen has decided to go ahead with a full program for 1943.
SHREVEPORT, La., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Milton Simington, 24-year-old professional football star, died today of a heart aailment.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 -- The Coast Guard has leased Father Divine's seashore "heaven," the former Brigantine Hotel, on an island near Atlantic City, N.J., and will occupy the eleven-story brick structure "sometime in February," Captain E.A. Coffin, Coast Guard officer for the Fourth Naval District, disclosed today.

Dedicated to the armed forces of the United Nations, the 117th annual ball and military pageant of the Old Guard of the City of New York will be given Jan. 29 in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Commodore. Captain Jean A. Brunner is chairman of the ball committee.

Winning from Walter Goldwater in twenty moves, Anthony E. Santasiere, former champion of New York State, strengthened his hold on first place in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. With five straight to his credit, Santasiere is the only contestant with a clean score.

Walter Vignini of the Greco Fencing Academy, topped the field of eleven contestants in the All-Eastern intermediate individual epee championship qualifying trials held yesterday at the Salle Santelli.

Virtual obliteration of the "lost" German army below Stalingrad and a powerful new Russian drive on the central front toward Kharkov mark another week of Nazi disaster in the East. The turning of the Winter tide since Stalin's generals seized the initiative has swept the Germans back from much hard-won territory, but the latest Russian successes seem to promise more far-reaching strategic results.

Nicola Moscona, announced as the "leading bass" of the Metropolitan Opera Association, gave a song recital last night in Town Hall, assisted by Christina Carroll, who had not, to our knowledge, appeared before in this city, and by Constantine Callinicos "at the piano."

Priorities have made armed camps of our colleges, with medicine, dentistry, nursing, physics and chemistry having preference over other courses of study, according to Dr. Walter A. Jessup, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. The thirty-seventh annual report of the foundation was made public yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- One important result of clothes rationing and "utility" styles, is that any woman -- if she uses her coupons well -- can look smart on very little money.

With the Germans conducting an intensive production drive throughout Europe and milking the occupied countries of their produce, the present German food position is far from critical, the Office of War Information reported yesterday on the basis of data reaching the Board of Economic Warfare and other government agencies.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose to a new high of 110.1. Increases occurred in the prices of hogs, cotton, potatoes and oranges, causing a rise in the farm products index of 1.1 per cent and in the foodstuffs index of .7 per cent.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- For the second week-end in succession, Corny Shields today led the sailing dinghy skippers at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Last Sunday he squeezed in ahead of the rest of the fleet with his craft Sissy by 1 point. This afternoon he finished with a 2-point advantage.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 -- Bullish enthusiasm which had pushed cotton spots and futures into new high ground for the season ceased at midweek when the government suddenly placed a ceiling on corn prices. Later a persistent trade demand and a record-breaking December consumption figure stiffened the tone and carried active near positions back to within a few points of the previous closing levels.

MIAMI, Jan. 17 -- On the eve of the Winter meeting of the American Federation of Labor's executive council, considerable interest was manifested tonight among labor leaders as to the possible fate of the proposed joint A.F. of L. Congress of Industrial Organizations committee to settle jurisdictional disputes.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Last night's big raid on Berlin -- and it was a big one knocked out one of those rumors that have recurred again and again since the war started. It proved that there was no truce -- there has never been any -- in the air war or any official agreement between Britain and Germany not to raid each other's capitals.
