Reproving persons who view as "wishful thinking" the recent plea of Pope Pius XII to Catholics all over the world to "consecrate themselves to the Immaculate Heart of Mary in behalf of an early peace," the Rev. Michael J. Deacy, preaching at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, asserted yesterday that "prayer is part of the divine causality in achieving events in this world."
MOSCOW, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Ceiling prices continue to be bid for the small open-market offerings of hog products, with the demand considerably in excess of supplies. Packers are reported as busy filling government orders and taking care of their regular trade to the greatest extent possible, but restrictions on the amount that can be sold to the civilian trade are said to be a factor in causing sectional shortages of the product.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Director General for Operations of the WPB announced today that extension of imports control to about fifteen groups of commodities and the tightening of control of three other products had been effected through an amendment of Imports Order M-63.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 17 -- Americans living in Palestine, Trans-Jordan, Syria and Lebanon will have the opportunity after next week to join the United States Army for service within the Middle East. All native and naturalized citizens wishing to join will be accepted.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The Democrats in the Legislature announced today their opposition to the first of Governor Dewey's program bills, that which would change the date starting the State's fiscal year from July 1 to April 1. They based their opposition on the point that the change would wipe out the $80,000,000 State surplus bequeathed to the Dewey administration by Governor Lehman.

Two brainteasers have local basketball fans puzzled these days. Both concern the unbeaten New York University team, which on Saturday night at Philadelphia notched its eleventh victory of the campaign, this time at the expense of a tall Temple University squad.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Famine, disease, slaughter and degradation are now ravaging Eastern Europe to such an extent that representatives of the refugee governments here fear the probable extinction of some nationalities and the permanent crippling of others in that Axis-tyrannized area unless the United Nations develop active intervention there this year.

One of the largest industrial plants in Northern New Jersey will be used to manufacture clothing for the armed forces as the result of the sale of the former Gotham Hosiery mill at Dover to the Roger Trust, which, in turn, leased it to McGregor Sportswear, Inc.
As the German armies of the Caucasus continued last week to fall back toward the captured Maikop fields, the amount of oil available for German use assumed an increasing importance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Abuses in the use of automobiles by war workers, 73 per cent of whom were found to go to and from work in private cars, was reported today by the Public Roads Administration on the basis of studies of transportation habits of 140,000 employes of ninety-four plants in ten States.

The twenty-fourth annual report of the Commonwealth Fund, made public yesterday, showed that appropriations for the twelve months ended last Sept. 30 totaled $1,777,396, and that the book value of the fund's assets at the end of the year was $50,393,436.

An audience of 3,000 crowded Carnegie Hall last night to hear a musical program of two and a half hours by prominent artists, given for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. The event was part of the foundation's annual appeal, which will culminate on President Roosevelt's birthday, Jan. 30.

Goals were more plentiful than automobiles on Eighth Avenue in the star game of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Gaining their first triumph since last Dec. 27, the New York Rovers, getting six of their goals in the second period, swamped the Philadelphia Falcons, 12 -- 2.

During the next few weeks at various club meetings the discussion is likely to center on what streams and ponds will be the most accessible for short trips, rather than on what the general prospects are for good fishing this Spring.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, Libya, Jan. 14 (delayed) -- The story of the Fighting French column that made its way from Fort Lamy in the Lake Chad territory into Libya was told this morning at an advance encampment of the British Eighth Army by a senior French liaison officer who arrived by air to create a liaison with the British forces.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 17 -- The Maritime Commission, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and insurance underwriters sought an explanation today for the cracking and sinking of the 16,500-ton tanker Schenectady as it was tied up at the outfitting dock of the Henry J. Kaiser Shipyard at Swan Island here late last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Mayor La Guardia won today his long fight for the abolition of the State Transit Commission, whose jurisdiction is confined to New York City, as Governor Dewey announced that he would send to the Legislature tomorrow night a special message urging abolition of the unit and transfer of its necessary functions to the Public Service Commission.

FRANCONIA NOTCH, N.H., Jan. 17 -- A decision in keeping with the nation's physical fitness program was reached today when the Aerial Tramway Commission of New Hampshire announced that the mile-long tram serving the State's superb ski development on Cannon Mountain would operate throughout the Winter.

New York has become a taxicab driver's dream of paradise. Few cars in sight, and the city's streets swarming with cabs cruising in front of theatres, department stores, night clubs, etc. Of course, cruising around that way does not waste gas!

Despite some irregularity, stock market averages last week went to the highest price since Pearl Harbor. Domestic bond averages advanced again, their high price of last week not having been reached since Autumn of 1937.

Eight years before the signing of the Declaration of Independence the Brick Presbyterian Church opened its doors on Beekman Street and celebrated its first services. Yesterday, in its third home since that day, the Brick Church at Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street, observed the 175th anniversary of its founding in 1768.

One by one the men who used to design coiffeurs are drifting off to join the Army, and the girls who once pinned up your curls are enlisting their nimble fingers in the industries of war. Such, in any case, is the state of things as reported to us.

Ewkin F. Jaeckle, Republican State chairman, announced yesterday that Harrison E. Spangler, recently elected chairman of the Republican National Committee, would be the guest of the executive committee of the Republican State Committee at luncheon at the National Republican Club Friday.

Wholesale business was extremely heavy last week, with a record number of buyers in town to cover Spring and Summer requirements and some of them buying ahead as far as Fall on certain staple items, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Unless we come back as a nation to the simple Christian faith, to real religion, all our material strength and effort will be of no avail in the tremendous conflict in which we are engaged, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday morning in a sermon in the Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the Bouwerie, Second Avenue and Tenth Street.

Frank Brimsek, goal-keeper for the Bruins, was too much for the Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Although he let three shots get past him, the Boston guardian came through with enough sensational saves to cause the local skaters to go down to defeat again, 6 to 3.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 9 -- Coffee rationing in the United States affects not only the American coffee drinker but also the Good Neighbor policy and is dynamite in the hands of fifth-column propagandists here.
ALBANY, Jan. 17 (AP) -- New York factory payrolls in 1942, first full year of war, increased 34 per cent as compared with 1941, while employment expanded 11 per cent.

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt called yesterday upon the women of America to understand the meaning of true sacrifice such as the British have made through three years of war, because "if we don't understand it we are not going to be prepared to deal with the nations of the world when the war is at an end."
It seems to be the consensus that the shortage of butter will continue for some time, perhaps for as long as the war lasts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Japanese planes have bombed American positions on Guadalcanal in their first assault in any force in several weeks, the Navy reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A duel between American Air Forces on Guadalcanal and the Japanese forces at Munda, in the Central Solomons to the northwest, was indicated by the reports in today's Navy Department communique.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Sid Abel "floated" before the Chicago net in the last second of play, took a mighty swing and scored a goal which gave Detroit a 2-2 tie with the Black Hawks in a National League hockey game tonight. The contest attracted 15,945 fans.
The combination of an anthracite coal strike and the ban on pleasure driving made it appear yesterday that New York's streets soon may be clearer than its skies.

Acclaimed by capacity crowds in Indianapolis, Buffalo, Chicago and Detroit, figure-skating's premier personality, Miss Sonic Henie, and her elaborate Hollywood Ice Revue will open a ten-day Madison Square Garden visit tonight.

The West Albany laboratory of the New York Central System has saved millions of dollars for the railroad since it was established late in 1892, the railroad company said last week in reviewing its record of achievement in fifty years. Starting as a chemical laboratory and ocupying only two rooms, the enterprise has expanded into several rooms and now is fully equipped for both chemical and physical work.

The words of Jesus Christ have an amazing power which transcends all of our ordinary ideas of them, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A Russian special communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES IN CHINA Jan. 16 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Japanese lost at least seven planes and possibly twelve today when they raided an American airdrome in Western Yunnan Province and three near-by Chinese villages from their base in Burma.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Dividends paid by the twelve regional Federal Home Loan Banks for 1942 amounted to $2,068,438, as compared with $2,004,441 in 1941, James Twohey, governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, announced today.

An "earned income credit" is allowed to those filing individual Federal income-tax returns. In determining the amount of the credit, Instruction 25 accompanying the tax form should be carefully read. The earned income credit is defined by law as 10 per cent of the earned net income, but I not in excess of 10 per cent of the net income.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A spokesman for the War Labor Board predicted tonight that the White House would be asked tomorrow to solve the Pennsylvania anthracite strike.

Harold A. Stevens, one of the two Negro attorneys for the President's committee on fair employment practice in its proposed hearings on complaints of discrimination against Negro firemen and brakemen on railroads, resigned yesterday in protest against an order by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, for indefinite postponement of the hearings.

Fritz Reiner conducted an all-Russian program at his first Sunday concert of the season with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon before an audience of 2,000 at Carnegie Hall. His program was devoted to four composers who, whatever their claims to greatness, are all undisputed masters of one thing -- orchestration.

The united Neighborhood Houses of New York, Inc., 114 East Thirty-second Street, the central organization of forty-two city settlements, announced yesterday that it would call upon the city's budget director to grant the Board of Education's full budget request "in order that the schools may serve the maximum needs of the city during these days of stress."

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 17 -- The aircraft carrier Cowpens, the fourth "flat top" converted from a cruiser and launched here within the last 141 days, slid down the ways at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation yard today at a strictly "Navy family" ceremony.

Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday that "the government's laws are not properly enforced" with respect to ceiling prices on meat and announced the appointment of a three-man board, with himself as chairman, to make a complete study of the meat situation as it affects this city.

Marked progress in promotion of industrial peace in the region comprising New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, the jurisdiction of the New York regional office of the National Labor Relations Board, was disclosed in the annual report made public yesterday by Charles T. Douds, regional director.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A communique:

The desirability of changing our income taxes to a pay-as-you-go basis is now acknowledged on all sides. It is recognized that it means less hardship for the individual to pay this year's taxes out of this year's income, when he still has the money. It is recognized, for the same reason, that only under a pay-as-you-go system (in combination with a withholding tax) is the Government likely to collect all its taxes.
Lee Ping Quan, who was chief steward and chef of the Presidential yacht Mayflower from 1922 to 1929, when she was decommissioned, died Saturday afternoon in Bellevue Hospital at the age of 63.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Selection of thirty-three additional industrial plants to receive the Army-Navy production award in recognition of outstanding performance on war work was announced today by Under Secretary of War Patterson and Under Secretary of the Navy Forrestal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Of 1,519,055 applications received through Dec. 31 for family allowances to dependents of Army personnel under the Service Men's Dependents Allowance Act, 1,294,852 already have been approved by the Office of Dependency Benefits, the War Department said today.

WITH THE RED ARMY, Southeast of Rostov, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Rodion Y. Malinovski, commander of the Soviet troops on this front, is supremely confident of his armies' ability to carry on successfully with the great Winter offensive aimed at German-held Rostov.

The strike of coal miners in protest against an increase in union dues and the forcing of Montgomery Ward to submit to a form of closed shop are two of many instances of the dictatorship of labor leaders which makes a mockery of democracy in America.

Why worry and fret from now on until mid-March about how much the bill will be when it is not too difficult to sit down next week-end and find out exactly? This is, of course, the most compelling argument for early preparation of your income-tax return; another very good one is that the amount to be paid will be a rather stiffish problem in itself, for which a little budgetary wrestling may be needed.

Organized labor can best rebut current attacks of its enemies by a program calling for accountability for funds, responsibility for the acts of its members and dependability of its leaders in perpetuating the democratic ideals of trade unionism, Wayne L. Morse, dean of the University of Oregon Law School and public member of the National War Labor Board, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Development of a method for producing aviation gasoline of such high octane equivalent that airplane motors will have to be redesigned to make full use of its power was announced here today by Eugene J. Houdry, president of Houdry Process Corporation.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Though Britons have become accustomed to colossal figures in war expenditures, President Roosevelt's estimate of America's projected outlay has caused a gasp of surprise here. So far, however, there has been comparatively little comment upon the financial aspects of the President's message to Congress.
CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters issued this communique today:

Misses Marie and Bertha Smidt, in 375 Park Ave; Paul N. Robins, in 25 E 83d St; Seymour B. Jacobson, in 301 E 21st St; George Buckwell, in The Park Lane; Philip G. Patterson, in The Croydon, at 12 E 86th St -- Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 17 (AP) -- British and American air squadrons, ranging from near the Tibet border to the Andaman Sea, blasted Japanese bases and ships Friday and Saturday and returned without the loss of a plane, Allied communiques said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Partial plans for rationing scarce foods to restaurants, hotels and other "institutional users," plans which do not require patrons to present ration coupons to obtain food, were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

Theodore Samuel (Ted) Williams, the slugging former Red Sox out-fielder, who won the 1941 and 1942 American League batting championships, has been chosen to receive the Player of the Year Award by the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- David Lloyd George, elder statesman of World War I, marked his eightieth birthday today with satisfaction, knowing that he had seen the previous conflict won and the present one at least showing a trend in the right direction.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- The class of cadets which will be graduated from the Military Academy on Tuesday was told by the West Point chaplain today that "into your hands we now commit that freedom" -- the freedom of "this nation."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 17 -- Four hundred siringueiros have departed in three days for the Amazon, the last batch leaving today by train for Minas Geraes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A bid for increased cooperation between the Naval and the Military Affairs Committees of the House will be made in Congress tomorrow by Chairman Vinson of the Naval Affairs Committee. Other groups will study the pay-as-you-go tax measure and will consider investigations into policies of the Federal Communications Commission and employment practices of other agencies.

A one-shot institutional advertisement, detailing the story of the conversion of the distilling industry to the production of industrial alcohol for war purposes, will be released today to 250 daily newspapers and three national magazines by the Distilled Spirits Institute.

Declaring that the automobile dimout regulations adopted by the city are more drastic than those required by the Army, J.B. Crossley, vice president of the Automobile Club of New York, said yesterday they should be modified to reduce the number of deaths and injuries from traffic accidents.

CASUALLY, in the midst of talking about something else, Sergeant Cannon in his book, "The Sergeant Says,"* quotes an old Army man as saying, "Any one's got class with me who minds their own business and don't go around lousing up people."

There is something heartening about the way the average American is taking in his stride restrictions and shortages and dislocations of his normal life which, however pretty as compared with the realities of the war fronts and the occupied areas, still add up to a substantial total in the war of nerves.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- An agreement will be concluded within two weeks between General Charles de Gaulle and General Henri Honore Giraud, providing for a final solution of the differences between French political factions in North Africa, it was indicated tonight.

Rib roasts for New Yorkers are apparently provided by superior animals possessing only those ribs that constitute the "first cut," according to the results of a weekend canvass of the city's butchers.

Iraq's entrance into the war on the side of the United Nations takes the mind back to the Anglo-French-Italian conference in the picture-book town of Stresa in April, 1935. That meeting will be recalled as one of the empty gestures of the dreary decade in which the war was hatched.

The Navy needs a score of experts to supervise the handling of scrap metal in Navy yards, Lieut. Comdr. Jacob C. Stone of the Bureau of Supplies and Accounts declared yesterday at the closing session of the fifteenth annual convention of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Although prices of cotton fluctuated over a fairly wide trading range last week, the list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the period with only slight net changes. At the close of the market on Saturday values were 5 points higher to 10 points lower than at the start of the week.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 17 -- The British Eighth Army has resumed its advance on Tripoli. By last evening the British had gained forty miles beyond the original German positions in the Wadi Zemzem area and, at last reports, they were still moving northwest.

Ruth Wilk and Kay Brown have acquired the stage rights to Mary Lasswell's irreverent story about Mrs. Feeley, a junk yard and life on the San Diego waterfront, published in December under the title, "Suds In Your Eye." Nathaniel Curtis is already at work on the dramatization.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 17 (AP) -- With the mother of the late New York Yankees baseball star christening it, the Liberty ship Lou Gehrig was launched today by the South Portland Shipbuilding Corporation.

These are difficult days for boys. Their fathers, their brothers, even their older schoolmates are going to war or into war industry, and those youngsters still in school, still too young for the service, champ at the bit. It is always so in wartime.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 17 -- British Hurricane and Bisley bombers took over the job of blasting the enemy's communications within the last thirty-six hours. Reports of successful bombing attacks on road convoys and railway sidings indicated that there was considerable enemy movement toward a defensive area outside Tunis.

Religion will not do when it is simply a genial optimism colored by a belief in the Divine, said the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor, in his sermon yesterday morning in the Riverside Church. When we talk of a wartime revival of religion, he said, it must not be that kind of religion.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- The Stalingrad garrison was reported this morning to be taking a hand in the liquidation of the Germans trapped before the city. Successes in sectors on the southern and northwestern outskirts were reported.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., Jan. 17 -- Just 100 years ago the Presbyterian Church edifice here was dedicated with a service almost duplicated on its anniversary this morning. The Rev. Herbert E. Moyer, Moderator of the Presbyterian Synod of the State of New York, second to hold the office while pastor of this church, preached the anniversary sermon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Tribute to the men and women of Yugoslavia "who have never surrendered to the Axis powers" was paid here today at the first of a series of meetings arranged by the World Woman's Party for Equal Rights to maintain and renew, and wherever possible to further, the continuation of activities begun abroad while the international headquarters was in Geneva.

The time is approaching when Reichsfuehrer Hitler, hard-pressed by the Russians and facing an increasingly more difficult situation elsewhere, "will take desperate chances" in an effort to escape defeat and may try to use poison gas, James W. Gerard, United States Ambassador to Germany during the First World War, declared last night.

Announcement of the eleventh biennial Harper Prize Novel competition was made yesterday by Harper Brothers, 49 East Thirty-third Street, New York. The contest, one of the most important (and best-paying) of the many literary competitions, offers a $10,000 prize for the best manuscript from an author who has not had a novel published prior to Jan. 1, 1924.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 18 -- German raiders returned to London last night -- their first visit on a major scale since July 28, 1941.

The 1943 Victory Book Campaign for the collection and distribution of books for men in the armed forces will receive practical support from milkmen throughout this area within the next few days. Housewives who have been in the habit of writing notes for the milkmen, telling him how much milk and cream to leave, will now receive notes from the milkman, urging them to wrap up and leave some books alongside their empty milk bottles.

Two six-story loft buildings containing stores at the northwest corner of Canal and Mott Streets have been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Morris Feine. Assessed at $65,000, the property is in the heart of the downtown clothing district, the entire ground floor being occupied by Crawford's, men's clothiers.

Sydney S. Baron, executive secretary of the Committee to Reopen the Flynn Case, said yesterday that he had sent a telegram to President Roosevelt urging him to withdraw his nomination of Edward J. Flynn for Minister to Australia. The telegram read as follows:

Councilman Meyer Goldberg, Republican, of Manhattan, announced yesterday that he would introduce at the Council meeting tomorrow a local law calling for establishment of a New York City Labor Relations Board as a permanent city fact-finding agency to deal with problems affecting the city's 175,000 employes.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 17 -- A move in the direction of creating a French force to enter the field on the Axis side was announced from Vichy today, even though covertly. The Tricolor Legion is dissolved to make room for the new organization "intended to coordinate all efforts and give every Frenchman the possibility of translating into acts his revolutionary and patriotic desires."

Mayor La Guardia resumed yesterday, in his weekly broadcast from City Hall, his earlier attacks on "loan sharks" and bingo games. The making of small loans to workingmen at "unconscionable" rates of interest, the Mayor declared, should be curbed by a State law making it illegal to charge more than 6 per cent a year for such loans.

Mrs. Madeline O'Donnell, 28 years old, was burned to death yesterday in a fire which destroyed her mother's home at 187 Pelton Avenue, West New Brighton, S.I. When the blaze was at its peak, her brother, Dennis Hurley, 29, a city fireman, suffered serious burns when he attempted to reach the second floor, where his sister was trapped.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:
Since manpower has become the dominant factor in victory the normal 40 hours of work does not make sense. The only excuse for such statutory workday was the vast unemployment in the great depression.

Six women who spent Saturday night in police station cells after a raid on a Bronx apartment where card playing was said to have been going on pleaded innocent to disorderly conduct charged and were freed yesterday by Magistrate Raphael Murphy in the Bronx Magistrates Court.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Jan. 18 -- Five Japanese merchant ships in the harbor at Rabaul, New Britain, were badly damaged or sunk in a three-wave three-hour raid by Flying Fortresses last night.
AT AN R.A.F. BOMBER STATION, Somewhere in England, Jan. 17 -- Royal Air Force bombers transformed a large area of Berlin into a particularly hot corner of hell on earth last night.

Swimmers of St. Francis Prep won the Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. championship for the sixth consecutive time yesterday in the Columbus Council, K. of C., pool in Brooklyn. It was also the tenth time in twelve years that Coach Tom Booras's charges finished on top.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Although maintaining the strength displayed in the opening week of 1943, the stock markets here recently have lost business momentum. A pause for consolidation pending a further advance is evidently being experienced, because all conditions point to renewed activity soon.

THERE were quite a few raised eyebrows and a number of snickers when the Dodgers announced that they would train at Bear Mountain, which is better known for its skiing than its baseball. But shrewd Branch Rickey struck the best bargain of all the local clubs because he has the tremendous field house at West Point to fall back on in case of inclement weather.

A taxi driver who carried Carlo Tresca to a mysterious Christmas Eve meeting that he was reluctant to attend and another who brought him back to his home "greatly agitated" three hours later were being sought yesterday by the police to determine if his movements that night had any bearing on his murder a week ago.

Two of the finest of the Haydn Quartets and two Bach sonatas, the one for violin and piano in B minor and the sonata in C for two violins and piano, made the program of the New Friends of Music yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The performers were the Curtis String Quartet, Carroll Glenn, violinist, and Webster Aitken, pianist.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- Although the Tuxedo Club was ruined by the fire that started late last night, it became known today that employes, guests and residents of the colony had braved the flames to salvage most of the paintings, prints, maps and antiques at the club.
Only three new films are scheduled to make Broadway debuts this week. These are:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 -- "Brazzaville," a melodrama to be laid in the French North African military center, has been scheduled by Warner Brothers as a sequel to the recent "Casablanca," the studio has announced. Humphrey Bogart and Sydney Greenstreet will continue their characterizations from the previous film, according to the studio, but Ingrid Bergman and Paul Henreid, stars of the original picture, will not appear in the sequel.

Marie Wilkins, young American coloratura soprano, who made her Metropolitan debut on Dec. 2, when she replaced Lily Pons in the title role of "Lakme" on short notice, will sing the exacting role of the Queen of the Night in "The Magic Flute" in her second appearance at the Metropolitan on Jan. 29, it was announced yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 17 -- Demands of the War Labor Board and the United Mine Workers failed tonight to end a dues revolt in the Northern anthracite field, but the threat of a general strike tomorrow to force an increase in wages was removed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Wheat prices reached a new seasonal high early last week before general selling developed that forced a decline of 4 cents a bushel from the extreme top, but the selling movement quickly ran its course, and a strong rally followed that wiped out a considerable part of the loss.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 17 -- Berlin Sunday newspapers contain long reports of the situation on the Russian front and the accounts concur in emphasizing the severity and difficulties of the fighting.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 18 -- The Red Army is threatening Kamensk, only eighty-five miles north of Rostov, after capturing Millerovo, another important railway junction on the Rostov-Moscow line, and other Russian armies are pushing on into the Ukraine toward Kharkov and toward the Maikop oil fields in the Caucasus.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced two new regulations, effective Feb. 1, establishing maximum prices at all distribution levels for rubber drug sundries.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 17 -- "Preliminary" figures of 31 killed and at least 150 wounded were issued officially in Berlin late this evening as casualties of last night's British Royal Air Force raid on the capital. The death roll, it is admitted, may "be increased considerably since rescue operations are still in progress in many parts of the town where other victims may be found under the wreckage."

Forward pricing, by which excessive profits would be avoided before completion of war contracts and thus eliminate need for renegotiation, is receiving serious consideration by War Department officials. They believe it may be applicable to industries such as textiles which are supplying a product of long-established use, it was learned here last week.

MONTREAL, Jan. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Defenseman Butch Bouchard paced the Montreal Canadiens to a 2-0 shut-out over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a rugged National Hockey League match tonight, scoring both goals and assisting dramatically in blocking attempts by the Leafs to reach the Canadiens' net.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- With 1,500 persons in attendance, including Vice President and Mrs. Wallace, Associate Justice Murphy of the Supreme Court, Senator Mead of New York, and other Senators and representatives of the Diplomatic Corps, the annual Red Mass, traditionally associated with the opening of courts and legislative bodies, was celebrated this morning in the crypt of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception at the Catholic University of America.

If you should meet a young, pink-cheeked Army lieutenant who tells young women that he is "head of the War Department," get in touch with Miss Doris Kavanagh, Chief of Information of the Bureau of Public Inquiries, Office of War Information, 521 Fifth Avenue.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- In an attempt to reassure the German people that the R.A.F. raid on Berlin had been "avenged," the German radio, as heard here, said tonight:

On Jan. 6 THE TIMES published an article giving the results of the most recent poll by Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion, on the manpower program, with some interesting comments.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 18 (AP) -- The sixty-ninth Kentucky Derby will be run here May 1, and the winner will get a major part of the usual $75,000 purse, a gold cup and the traditional wreath of roses, but the crowd probably will be made up of streetcar-riding residents of this area.

The most far-reaching accident prevention campaign in the history of the country opened last night with the departure from Grand Central Terminal of a delegation of seven, headed by William A. Irvin, former president of the United States Steel Corporation and national chairman of the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower, on a tour of fourteen industrial centers as part of an educational drive to be conducted through the National Safety Council.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Arthur F. Foran, State Milk Control Director, today ordered that the retail price of light cream be advanced 4 cents a quart, effective on Feb. 1. This is designed to give farmers an increase of 22 cents a hundred pounds for milk used in making cream.

A German broadcast, recorded yesterday by The United Press in New York, said the High Command had announced that fighting of "undiminished ferocity" was continuing on the southern Russian front, where Soviet attacks were said to have been "essentially repulsed" or held up in "flexible operations."
Buying activity in the wholesale markets here continued heavy yesterday as retailers sought to cover Spring needs in the face of growing shortages of staple goods and threatened delivery delays.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 18 -- If attacked, Sweden will fight to the bitter end and not lay down her arms, the Riksdag [Parliament] was told today by Premier Per Albin Hansson. At the same time he revealed that a special order precluding all possibility of surrender if communications between central and local authorities were interrupted had been given by the Swedish Commander in Chief to all local military and civilian authorities.

The addition of three ordinary seamen to the deck department, the engine room force and the steward's department, a total of nine men for each ship, was advocated yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, a C.I.O. affiliate, to help solve the problem of a superfluity of unskilled seamen and a lack of able-bodied seamen, firemen and water tenders.

Former Governor Charles Poletti, making a radio review of his decision in the case of Alexander Hoffman, one-time general manager of the Cleaners and Dyers Union, Local 239, whose four-to-eight-year prison sentence he commuted in the Christmas orders after the convicted man had served seven months, declared last night that "my conscience is absolutely clear."

Mayor La Guardia denounced yesterday "pressure groups" that he said were undermining the city's school system by issuing "bold and distorted" statements that the school children were being neglected because of undermanned teaching staffs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Ernest Kanzler, director general for operations of the War Production Board, has submitted his resignation giving reasons of health. Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, said today that he had accepted the resignation with regret and added that he has an important assignment awaiting Mr. Kanzler when his health improves.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -Bertrand Russell, British author and philosopher, filed suit in Federal District Court today for $24,000 he contended was due to him from the Barnes Foundation in Merion when he was dismissed as a lecturer.

James MacDonald of our London staff is the first trained reporter to fly with a night raider over Berlin. Seen through his eyes the spectacle of the British bombing is almost as vivid as though we ourselves sat in the nose of the "Dee for Donald." We, too, see the tide of conflagration eat into the heart of the enemy capital.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 18 -- American airmen and British fliers and army men are safe in Allied territory instead of prisoners of the Axis because a British bomber sank an Italian submarine aboard which they were being transported.

Extension of the unusual spectacle of a mid-January rally in the stock market sent prices yesterday to the best levels since November, 1941. Ability of the list to attract buyers to a more representative selection of issues added a stronger tone to the recovery, although lighter interest in low-price stocks brought a contraction in volume.

Concerted opposition on the part of a large cross-section of American industry to the recently promulgated proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission has developed to the point where a special meeting of industry's representatives has been called for Thursday to air the entire matter, it was learned yesterday.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTER, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A dispute between Colonel William J. Donovan and Elmer Davis, respective heads of the Offices of Strategic Services and of War Information, as to which should direct psychological warfare abroad has gone to the White House, reliable, but unquotable, sources said tonight.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- Sheik Tajedding Hassani, proclaimed President of Syria when independence was declared by agreement with the Fighting French on Sept. 16, 1941, died today. He had been ill of pneumonia for a week.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 18 (AP) -- The appointments of J. William Schulze as controller and Mrs. Elinore Herrick as labor consultant for the South Portland Shipbuilding Corporation were announced today by Chester L. Churchill, president.

Completion of the price-fixing against recent purchases of cotton by the government more than the application of any significant selling pressure was responsible yesterday for moderate weakness in the cotton futures market. At the end of the listless session on the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts were 5 to 13 points under Saturday's final quotations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The movement at the Capitol to streamline Congressional procedure for economy and greater efficiency received fresh impetus today with the introduction of legislation calling for a Joint Committee on Budgetary Control and an interlocking of the House's Committee on Military and Naval Affairs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Philip R. O'Brien, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, pledged today that the major goal of the Grain Exchange in 1943 would be to push efforts "which will accomplish most in restoring our marketing system to its proper place as a true instrument of agriculture."

Having garnered ample experience as a musical comedy actor and as one of three producers of "By Jupiter," Richard Kollmar thinks it's about time for him to step out on his own. Accordingly, he has signed Ferde Grofe, who has achieved fame as a composer-conductor, to supply the melodies for the book and lyrics of "Early to Bed," the work of George Marion Jr.

Events today: Annette Elkanova, piano recital, Town Hall, 3:30 P.M.; Efrem Zimbalist, violin recital, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Paolo Gallico, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Yehudi Menuhin, violin recital, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30; Vivienne Simon, song recital, Barbizon, 8:30; Center Symphony Orchestra, Angelo A. Consoli conducting, Army and Navy Building, 426 Madison Avenue, 8:30; Nita Gale, song recital, Hotel Ansonia, 8:30.

Suits certainly set the style in Sally Milgrim's made-to-order showing yesterday afternoon at Milgrim's, 6 West Fifty-seventh Street. Not that there were many actual tailored suits in the accepted sense of the terms, but dressmaker suits, two-piece dresses and dresses with matching jackets that made them look like suits dominated the show.

The tightest situation in the history of the local furniture market developed yesterday with the opening of the midwinter show in the New York Furniture Exchange. Despite the recent appeal by the exchange that retailers stay away unless their business was urgent, first-day attendance soared to 2,841, or 14 per cent ahead of the "run-away" market in the Summer of 1941.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 8 per cent last week as against the comparative week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In the preceding week the decline under last year had been 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Letters continue to pour into this department, giving direct illustrations of the inequitable effects on country dwellers of the city-minded OPA ban against what is termed, and cannot be uniformly defined as, "pleasure driving." It cannot be uniformly defined because few ration boards agree among themselves in specific instances.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The National War Labor Board today unanimously authorized increases, averaging 5.3 cents an hour, to 5,537 employes of the Western Union Telegraph Company in the Metropolitan New York area. Among those affected are messengers, operators and office employes in New York and workers in the Jersey City repair shop and wire houses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The House chamber became a "classroom" for a lesson in pay-as-you-go income tax collection today as the Ways and Means Committee furthered its plans to begin consideration later this week of various proposals.

A controversy has been taking place in our letter columns regarding the revolving doors. One of our correspondents fears that the city is about to become the victim of panicky fire laws because of the recent Boston fire. A member of the City Council replies that it is not the intent of the proposed law to scrap revolving doors but to prohibit their use as a means of egress.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 17 -- The need to add a fifth freedom to those stipulated in the Atlantic Charter -- freedom to develop self-governing institutions by peoples seeking their independence -- was the conclusion that emerged from a long personal conversation between Emir Abdullah Ibn Hussein of Trans-Jordan and your correspondent on the post-war situation of the Middle East and its part in world political and economic reconstruction after the United Nations victory.
LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

To make a New York visit more pleasant for officers of the armed services of this country and the other United Nations, the city's leading college clubs have extended to them special guest privileges without the payment of any dues, it was learned yesterday.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- Syracuse snapped a six-game losing streak and gained its eighth straight basketball victory over Cornell tonight by winning, 52 to 51, in an exciting finish.

Opening a drive that officials predicted would result in reducing the retail price of meat for consumers, the regional office of the Office of Price Administration began the prosecution yesterday of fourteen beef wholesalers and small packers and twenty-nine of their officers and employes in this city, Newark, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh.

AVERY BRUNDAGE stuck his head out a couple of weeks ago and promptly was rapped on the noggin. That should cause no surprise. Avery always has been a beckoning target. Even when he has been right he has been wrong, and when he's been wrong -- well, heaven help him.

For the first time since it was founded in 1829, the College of Pharmacy, an affiliate of Columbia University since 1904, held a mid-year graduation last night in the college lecture hall at 115 West Sixty-eighth Street. Seventeen students, the first class to be graduated under the accelerated program, received their degrees from Dean Charles W. Ballard.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- Albert A. Schmid, "one-man blitz," who killed 200 Japanese in the Solomons with his machine gun before he was blinded by gunfire Aug. 21, came back today to his parents and the girl he is going to marry.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 18 -- Belated comment on President Roosevelt's message to Congress comes today from France in an editorial in the Moniteur, Chief of Government Pierre Laval's newspaper. It says:
In filing a Federal income tax return, the first item to be entered on the form is "Salaries and Other Compensation for Personal Services."
BAYWAY, N.J., Jan. 18 -- "Our combat planes cannot get close to the enemy Flying Fortresses. It is very regrettable that the only alternative is for us to flee from being killed."

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 18 -Counsel for the Henry J. Kaiser interests told Federal Judge James A. Fee today that the National Labor Relations Board's hearing of "unfair" labor practices charges against three Kaiser shipyards in this area was "a sham" and that it would lead only to one result, "a conclusion already reached by two of the three board members."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision holding that Federal District Court lacked jurisdiction to pass on a suit by a stockholder of the Electric Bond and Share Company seeking to enjoin the Securities Commission from preventing the company from purchasing its own preferred stock.

WASHINGTON, Jam 18 -- James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, expressed opposition today, through a spokesman for the Office of Price Administration, to proposed increases of railroad commuting fares in the New York suburban area.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- Rain pools were on The Plain, traditional peacetime greensward for the Graduation Parade, so the ceremony today was shifted to the concrete-paved Central Barracks Area.

MONTREAL, Jan. 18 (Canadian Press) -- The Newsprint Association of Canada reported today that total apparent newsprint consumption of all United States publishers in December was 339,703 tons and was 26,341 tons, or 7.2 per cent, lower than in the corresponding period in 1941.

An attempt will be made this week to resolve the conflict in exhibition dates which has embroiled the Yankees and Giants for the last week. President Ed Barrow of the Yankees, heretofore adamant in his declarations that he will not deviate from his schedule, yesterday proffered the olive branch when he wrote to Horace Stoneham, Giant president, to arrange a meeting at which the situation can be ironed out amicably.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A prediction that the unauthorized strike of Pennsylvania anthracite coal miners "will be all over by Wednesday" was voiced tonight by a well-informed authority after the National War Labor Board had referred the walkout to President Roosevelt for action.

The story might be called "Ten Years After: A Tale of Two Fires." British incendiary bombs last Saturday over Berlin set ablaze Deutschland Hall. It is an immense structure dedicated to animal circuses and to far less innocent Nazi mass meetings.

Reports that M. Peyrouton would become Deputy High Commissioner for North Africa in political affairs drew sharp condemnation yesterday from Adolphe Demilly, publisher of La Voix de France, Fighting French newspaper, at his offices at 306 West 105th Street

Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, suggested yesterday that the city grant all its employes receiving less than $3,600 a year an "emergency" pay rise of 10 per cent to enable them to meet higher living costs. Increases would terminate at the end of the present economic emergency.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 18 -- Reports from Italy during the past three days indicate the outbreak in the northern part of the country of a severe typhoid infection in many of the smaller villages and towns. Semi-official reports to the League of Nations Epidemiological Service place the number of cases "temporarily" at "about 140."
ROCHESTER, Jan. 28 -- Hitler's great strategic plan has been "smashed to pieces," according to Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, and "1943 may well see the prelude to the victory that is coming."

Eager to replenish dwindling retail inventories, but thwarted somewhat by inability of manufacturers to accept all the business offered, retail buyers in record numbers visited the opening yesterday of the combined New York Curtain and Drapery Show and the National Domestics and Linen Show in the Hotel New Yorker.

GUADALCANAL, Jan. 17 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American Army units have concluded their first offensive on Guadalcanal Island with the capture of Mount Aesten, 1,800-foot ridge dominating Henderson Field, and the United Nations position in this sector of the Pacific war today was more favorable than at any time since the marines splashed ashore here five months ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The House Rules Committee approved today a resolution for a five-man House investigation of the Federal Communications Commission sponsored by Representative Cox of Georgia. A similar resolution died on the calendar in December, with expiration of the old Congress.

Newspaper advertising in fifty cities measured by Media Records wound up 1942 with a loss of 5.4 per cent from the preceding year, final figures yesterday disclosed. The decline in December was 4.1 per cent, with only two of the seven classifications, national and classified, registering increases.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company announced yesterday that it would open tomorrow at 11 A.M. bids on eleven blocks of various State and municipal bonds, aggregating $5,565,000, held in its investment portfolio. This is one of the few instances on record in which a bank choosing to sell municipal securities from its portfolio has made a general call for bids instead of negotiating in the dealer market.

For the first public concert of its sixth season the Bach Circle of New York arranged one of the most attractive programs of its career. Bach, Handel, Francois Couperin le Grand, Rameau and Domenico Scarlatti -- all major figures of the eighteenth century -- provided the evening's music, and they were represented, for the most part, by compositions not frequently heard.

Somewhat reluctantly New Yorkers appear to be turning to a long neglected delicacy for added sustenance on meatless Tuesdays. The demand for rabbit since the decline of meat supplies far exceeds quantities available, according to market authorities.

A request to Charles E. Jackson, acting deputy Coordinator of Fisheries, for more details regarding his proposed plan for sports anglers to "fish for food" and thus aid the nation's food problem brought the reply that some of the problems to be solved before such a scheme is feasible depends upon the acts of local authorities.

While a three-ton bust of President Roosevelt stood veiled and alone in the rain, several hundred persons crowded the lobby of the General Post Office, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third-Street, yesterday noon to witness a ceremony opening the 1943 "Mile of Dimes" campaign for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Jan. 18 -- Working on the assumption that furniture and clothing must see longer service during wartime, the Suffolk County Home Bureau began today to teach housewives how to make necessary repairs.

A tentative draft of a proposed regulation providing specific dollars and cents ceiling prices on sales of certain fine chemicals was presented to the trade yesterday by officials of the Office of Price Administration at a special meeting in the Hotel McAlpin.

Our peripatetic drama critic, Mr. Brooks Atkinson, writes from Chungking that Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, Commander in Chief of the United States Army forces in China, Burma and India, was not too well pleased when he came back to headquarters the other afternoon and found that a medal -- the Distinguished Service Cross -- was about to be pinned on him.

Sixty feet below street level in Times Square, on the Forty-third Street Rifle Club's range in a subbasement of Times Tower, a class of riflemen will hold a final session today, completing a course of instruction in the fundamentals of marksmanship.

More than sixty organizations sent representatives to the Board of Education yesterday to plead at a public hearing for increases in the board's tentative 1943-44 budget of $141,209,407. The Citizens Budget Commission, however, pointed out that economies could be made to reduce the proposed amount.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 18 -- How Norwegians are being forced to accept the services of Quisling clergy, who do not shy at taking bodies from undertakers with police aid to perform "new order" funerals, and how the Quisling police forcibly drag children from their parents for the so-called Youth Front are revealed in the New Year message of the Interim Church Council.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 -- Authorization for the enlistment of 17-year-old qualified American citizens in the Army reserves -- to be called into service within six months after they reach their eighteenth birthdays -- was announced today by Major Gen. Sherman Miles of the First Service Command.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH SEAS BASE, Jan. 7 (Delayed) -- Patsy Lee, which probably isn't her name, is only 4, which probably is not her exact age. But on her small body are wounds made by saber and rifle butt of the most brutal war in history, and in her brown fear-stricken eyes is the memory of God knows what atrocities by which her mother and father died.

Abundant in beauty and talent, the Hollywood Ice Revue, headed by the versatile Sonja Henie, opened a ten-day run at Madison Square Garden last night and delighted a near-capacity gathering of 16,000.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 18 -- This tradition-steeped New Hampshire village, the birthplace of intercollegiate skiing back in 1911, is enjoying an old-fashioned Winter, the like of which the native on Main Street will tell you he does not quite remember.

As a foretaste of what may happen to other lines when a concentration or nucleus plant program is followed by rigid allocation to consumers, the established farm machinery distribution system is being completely upset by the county rationing program now in effect, manufacturers charged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that even though a person uses facts from a government indictment in filing a suit to collect double damages and penalties from persons accused of defrauding the government, the "informer" is entitled to receive half of the amount recovered.
Mrs. James A. Renwick will give a dinner tonight in the Persian Room of the Plaza.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

As reported in our news columns today, the Whitney Museum of American Art, founded in 1931 by Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, is to go out of existence as an independent institution. It will not disappear, most fortunately, but will instead be merged with the Metropolitan, there to continue the splendid work already accomplished.

In the final instalment of a report on purchases of school supplies, Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands recommended yesterday that the Bureau of Supplies of the Board of Education be abolished and its functions transferred to the city's Department of Purchase.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation halted today their inquiry into the mysterious splitting and sinking of the new 16,500-ton tanker Schenectady after finding no evidence to support any suggestion of sabotage.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The resolution presented by former Governor E.D. Rivers of Georgia and unanimously approved by the Democratic National Committee today read as follows:

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Sir William Beveridge, author of the social security plan for Britain, tentatively allied himself with the women of this country today in their fight for equal compensation for air raid injuries. One of the last to testify before a committee of the House of Commons, Sir William said he saw little justification for a difference in compensation to persons who were not gainfully employed.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 18 -- The German Foreign Office spokesman, when asked today whether there had been a secret British-German agreement not to bomb Berlin and London, respectively, that the British had now broken, sourly replied that events of the past two nights had given sufficient answer to this false rumor.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18 -- The American Federation of Labor may ask President Roosevelt to intervene in the West Coast shipbuilding dispute between the federation and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, President William Green of the federation disclosed here today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Unfair practices in the securities business have been "materially eliminated" as a result of the industry's program of self-regulation, Wallace H. Fulton, executive director of the National Association of Securities Dealers, told the annual meeting of the organization's board of governors today.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY IN BURMA, Jan. 17 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- British and Indian jungle fighters in Burma today began the second week of assault on three temple-studded hilltop positions from which the Japanese are defending Rathedaung, strategic village on the Mayi River, twenty-five miles north of Akyab.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Fairly liberal profit-taking developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, due in part to limited support in wheat from milling interests and a lack of interest in additional purchases of cash corn and oats by the East. Wheat and oats dipped about 1 cent and corn about 1/2 cent from Saturday's finish before the decline was checked.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Mercer of Passaic, N.J., gave a dinner last night in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria before the opening performance of the Hollywood Ice Revue at Madison Square Garden to aid the Carroll Club. Their party included Mr. and Mrs. Neil Walsh, Miss Elizabeth Demarest, Miss Agnes Everett, Arnold Frese of Houston, Texas, John McIntyre and Philip Everett.
The east and west sides of the midtown area shared the bulk of apartment rentals announced yesterday by brokers and agents.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-R.A.F. communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Congressional action to end discrimination against small business in the distribution of war contracts was proposed today in a report to the Senate by its Committee on Small Business.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- German occupation troops posted along the coastal line of Norway and living under the fear of constant threat of invasion heard a special broadcast today, put out by the German authorities in an attempt to conceal the extent of Royal Air Force raids on Berlin.

Another call was issued by the Treasury yesterday on government deposits in commercial banks throughout the country. The withdrawals will be made on Saturday, Friday and Saturday. For the country as a whole the calls will amount to $129,904,000 on each, and for the depositary banks in the New York Federal Reserve District they will amount to $75,558,000 on each day.
The week-end news from Russia may eventually prove to be some of the most dramatic of the war.

RICHWOOD, W. Va., Jan. 18 (AP) -- James P. Pierce Jr., 52, a, chemical manufacturer of Charleston, who was missing since Thursday night on a flight from Washington to Charleston, was found dead in his wrecked plane late today in an isolated mountain area near here.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Continued and successful attacks by British forces on Axis ships in the Mediterranean were reported today by the Admiralty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- United States air forces on Guadalcanal made five separate and successful air attacks on Japanese bases in the Solomons area in two days, the Navy Department reported today. Meanwhile American ground forces obliterated further spots of resistance on the island itself.

The efforts being made by organizations of all religious denominations to help some of the many thousands of Europeans made homeless and helpless by the war and Nazi persecution were outlined yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Committee for Christian Refugees, held at the Town Hall Club.

Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck scheduled yesterday for trial tomorrow the suit by publishers of racing sheets for a permanent injunction restraining License Commissioner Paul Moss from interfering with the publication, sale and distribution of the sheets.

Forty-three nurse's aides will receive their caps tonight as graduates of the 125th and 126th Red Cross classes of Montefiore Hospital at the nurses' residence, Gunhill Road near Jerome Avenue, the Bronx. The caps will be presented by Miss A.C. Donahue, superintendent of nursing, and Mrs. Lillian Wohl, nurse's aid instructor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- If the war should end tomorrow, says Under-Secretary Daniel W. Bell, the Treasury has enough money in its general fund to redeem nearly half of the $15,000,000,000 in war savings bonds now outstanding. Should additional funds be needed, he adds, the Treasury could borrow them.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 18 -- In a move regarded by political observers as a thrust at Senator I. Grant Scott of Cape May County, with whom he has been at odds, Governor Charles Edison sent to the Senate today the nomination of Assemblyman John E. Boswell of that county to be a member of the Public Utility Commission at $12,000 annually for a six-year term.

Ruth McKenney has done a full-length novel, her first. Since Miss McKenney left newspaper work in the mid-Thirties she has mostly written stories. These, after publication in The New Yorker and other magazines, were gathered together as books -- "My Sister Eileen" and "The McKenneys Carry On."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Now that the war has erased Southern training jaunts, at least for the duration, Robert (Red) Rolfe, former Yankee third sacker, predicted today that baseball players would be better off for it.
CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 18 -- Potential sources of manpower are officially considered sufficient to provide the 210,000 units still required to implement the war program, it was said today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 19 -- For the second night in succession Berlin on Sunday night was lighted by flashes and rocked by the explosions of two and four-ton bombs loosed by a "strong force" of British heavy bombers.

At a meeting last night the National Institute of Arts and Letters elected a group of honorary associates from foreign countries. It was the first time in the organization's fifty years that foreign writers, musicians and artists were elected.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Peggy a heroine of "They Were Expendable," was identified today as Lieutenant Beulah Greenwalt of the Army Nurse Corps. Mrs. Jason R. King of St. Louis made the identification, explaining that Lieutenant Greenwalt, whose nursing on Bataan and Corregidor was eulogized by W.L. White and his naval narrators, was her sister.

A newly formed group enters the exhibition world this week. It has adopted the title American Modern Artists and is holding its first show at the Riverside Museum, 310 Riverside Drive, scheduled to remain until Feb. 27.
Corsets are coming into wider use, but not as the whale-boned contraptions that grandma used to wear, a survey showed yesterday after the peak of the buying season for Spring showings.

An audience of 2,000 attended the Unity Festival presented last night at Carnegie Hall by the American Slav Congress of Greater New York. The bulk of the program consisted of Slavonic music performed by Slav artists, but there were also dances by the Polish Folk Dance Circle, speeches and a "Salute to the United Nations."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that a small Egyptian merchant vessel had been torpedoed and sunk by an enemy submarine during the middle of December in the South Atlantic off the east coast of South America.

The extension of legislation for a ten-year period to permit life insurance companies to invest in the construction of low-cost housing is recommended in a report of Louis H. Pink, who resigned last month as State Superintendent of Insurance.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Postmaster General Frank C. Walker was unanimously elected today to succeed Edward J. Flynn as Chairman of the Democratic National Committee at a meeting marked by denunciation of opposition in the Senate to confirmation of Mr. Flynn as Minister to Australia.

Your "How to Pay as We Go" editorial of Jan. 11 was excellent. Apparently the real objection to the Ruml plan stems from those holding punitive ideas of taxation as far as large incomes are concerned. They are evidently afraid that the estates of large-income-tax payers will benefit by the Ruml plan -- they're not concerned about the little fellow.

Reporting on operations for the fiscal year ended with October, Edward Foss Wilson, president of Wilson Co., Inc., informed stockholders that both the tonnage and dollar volume of sales were the largest on record, but net earnings were increased only slightly over those of the previous year.

As local OPA investigators continued to crack down on motorists accused of pleasure driving and take possession of their ration books, a spokesman for the petroleum industry was certain yesterday that the curb on pleasure driving was proving effective.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- It is generally agreed among representatives of the Eastern European governments here that the status of those occupied and troublous areas for which they hold a refugee mandate would be immeasurably improved if some definite sort of agreement regarding them could be obtained before the end of the war from their great power allies, Britain, Russia and the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee approved today a bill permitting the merger of the Western Union and Postal Telegraph Companies.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Railroad yards, shops, mainline trackage and rolling stock in Japanese service at Maymyo, Burma, thirty-five miles northeast of Mandalay, were hard hit in a series of three week-end raids by United States medium bombers, an American communique said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Ruling unanimously, the Supreme Court upheld today the conviction of the American Medical Association and the District of Columbia Medical Society, local affiliate, for violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law by conspiring to block the activities of Group Health, Inc., a government employe cooperative.

The Appellate Division took up yesterday the legal relation of the City of New York to a twelve-inch eel. The court must decide whether the city is liable for damage resulting from the penetration of the eel into a two-inch pipe supplying water to the plant of the Sunshine Farms, Inc., in the Bronx Terminal Market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The housewife who stocked canned goods last Spring at the request of the government will get special consideration when declaring stocks of canned foods on hand in the new ration program.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Jan. 18 -- From Broadway to the cow barn -- that sums up the change that took place in the first contingent of women recruited by Federal agencies for farm training at the New York State Institute of Applied Agriculture here today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- The historic siege that Leningrad, Russia's second largest city, has undergone for seventeen months was broken today by a Red Army offensive south of Lake Ladoga that shattered the German ring around the city, it was announced officially tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Office of Price Administration has started the first of a series of meetings with retail dry goods merchants in various parts of the country to discuss extension of the simplified and uniform marginal mark-up plan from the food industry to other lines, it was learned authoritatively here today.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 18 -- This is the story of the girl who believes that modesty is the best policy in the war.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 18 -- (AP) -- Jackie Callura, wild-swinging little Canadian, won National Boxing Association recognition as world featherweight champion tonight by outpointing Pittsburgh Jackie Wilson in fifteen rounds in the Providence Arena. Callura weighed 125 1/2 pounds, Wilson 125 1/4.
LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The seventeen- month-old German siege of Leningrad, Russia's second largest city, was broken today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican leader, obtained an extra seat on the House Military Affairs committee and Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut was designated the twenty-sixth member of the group at a meeting of the Republican Committee on Committees today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the employes of warehousemen and wholesalers who sell and distribute products entirely within one State are not subject to the Federal Wage-Hour Law even though the goods may come from outside the State.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 18 -- Hope for an early ending of the dues revolt in the ranks of the United Mine Workers arose this afternoon when Local 1407, regarded as the spearhead of the strike, voted to return to work tomorrow, taking this action before the case was referred to President Roosevelt by the War Labor Board.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 18 -- Lightnings and B-25 Mitchells of the Twelfth United States Army Air Force struck sharply at the enemy's ground and air communications yesterday although generally air activity was on a reduced scale because of adverse weather conditions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (U.P.) -Legislation designed to remove Rexford Guy Tugwell as Governor of Puerto Rico was approved by the Senate Territories Committee today as Bolivar Pagan, Resident Commissioner, accused the Governor of using the island as "a guinea pig for crazy experiments."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Roosevelt's appointment of Prentiss M. Brown as head of the OPA to succeed Leon Henderson, resigned, won immediate confirmation in the Senate today. The Senate waived its rules, inasmuch as the vote for confirmation was not on the calendar.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- High Army and Navy officials will be summoned before the House Rules Committee to explain why their departments authorized war contracts which, the House Naval and Military Committees charged, permitted huge fees and profits.

The Coordinating Committee of Allied Seamen's Unions issued yesterday a statement deploring what they termed a lack of cooperative spirit on the part of Greek Government officials in this country. Copies were sent to Greek authorities and shipowners here and in England.

The basketball situation at Brooklyn College is desperate, undoubtedly in a sorrier state than at any other time in the seven years Artie Musicant has been coaching at the Bedford Avenue institution. It's a sad tale, and the more one hears of it the more one sympathizes with the Kingsmen, but sympathy is one thing the boys over in Brooklyn do not want.

Notices of appeal from 1-A draft classification by four more members of the Moral Rearmament or so-called Buchmanite movement were received yesterday by the local draft board where they are registered at 412 Sixth Avenue. They belong to the group of twenty-eight M.R.A. workers, all aliens, whose cases recently were reopened by order of Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, New York State Director of Selective Service.

Mrs. F. Graham Cootes gave a tea yesterday at the Regency Club for members of the executive committee aiding in the plans for the annual dinner dance to be held on Jan. 29 at the Pierre for the benefit of the Blue Ridge School of Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Confessions that members of an American Federation of Labor union dynamited high power transmission lines and committed other terrorisms in order to intimidate an industrial concern were repeated today in a Supreme Court opinion holding that the National Labor Relations Board must reopen a case in order to consider these outrages.
LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The midday communique of the Soviet Information Bureau, broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 18 -- At a South Pacific port, helping smooth the track for the American war machine in the South Pacific, is one of our little-known foreign agencies, the United States Joint Purchasing Board.

The abolition of the Transit Commission, as proposed by Governor Dewey, is a sensible step which will help us forget some old quarrels between Albany and City Hall and will save the city about $104,000 a year. It is not a world-shaking event. The Transit Commission is simply the metropolitan division of the State Department of Public Service.

In a joint statement the chairmen of the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee have warned taxpayers that, regardless of whether a pay-as-you-go system is enacted, or what form it will take, they must file returns for 1942 on or before March 15 and make at least the first quarterly payment.
The OPA ban on pleasure scoring has brought the Hershey Bears of the American Hockey League some good after all, The Associated Press reports.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The Finlay Institute of the Americas was incorporated today as a membership corporation, to honor Dr. Carlos J. Finlay, Cuban physician who discovered the mosquito transmission of yellow fever.

Leningrad, former Czarist capital and the second largest city of the Soviet Union, with a normal population of 3,000,000 failed to crack under the longest siege of this war. Beleaguered between two Nazi lines since Aug. 21, 1941, the defenders of Leningrad endured such frightful conditions that Nazi propagandists referred to it as "a doomed city."

Add to the films arriving in midtown theatres this week, "Lucky Jordan," a Paramount melodrama starring Alan Ladd, which is slated to open at the Rialto on Saturday. Sheldon Leonard, Helen Walker and Mabel Paige are among the film's featured players.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Gilt edge and home railway issues were the best features of a cheerful stock market today. The 3 1/2 per cent war loan and old Consols gained a sixteenth and local loans an eighth.
The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, founded by the late Ms. Harry Payne Whitney, will be consolidated with the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

IF the American public is still "ignorant" of the Orient in general and our not-so-honorable enemy Japan in particular, it isn't the fault of authors and publishers. By this time the supposedly inscrutable character of the Asiatic people has been studied and combed and turned inside out with such zealous thoroughness that the problems of the Japanese peasant should be no more mysterious than the habits of Jeeter Lester on Tobacco Road.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Allied ground forces captured Sanananda Point and Sananada Village yesterday, according to Associated Press reports from the advanced operational base in New Guinea.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Governor Dewey was upheld in his first legislative test tonight when the Assembly by a straight party vote of 80 to 50 passed the Moffat bill changing the date of the State's fiscal year to start on April 1 rather than July 1. The change is the No. 1 item on the Dewey financial program.

The large multi-family house known as the Grenada Apartments, occupying the blockfront bounded by Magnolia, Summit, West and Sunnyside Streets, Jersey City, has been sold by the Guardian Life Insurance Company to an investing client of M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company, Inc., and Frank Older, co-brokers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Looking back over baseball's first war year, the enthusiastic response of fans to the game during the critical season of 1942 leads me to believe confidently that the game will go on and do as good a job in 1943.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- In the first curtailment order affecting commercial, industrial and governmental users of fuel oil for non-heating purposes, Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Administrator for War, and John Hamm, acting price administrator, issued a joint regulation today requiring a 40 per cent cut in consumption of such oil for the first quarter of this year, by all but an exempted list of users.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Virginia Supreme Court reversed today a death verdict against Samuel Legions, Negro, charged with rape of a young married white woman of Leesburg, Va., on the ground that the failure of the woman and her husband to offer effective resistance or to escape was "unbelievable even to the most credulous or naive."
Traffic accidents in the city decreased last week, compared to the corresponding week a year ago, the figures, released at Police Headquarters, revealed. They follow:

LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A wounded co-pilot's successful struggle to save his shell-punctured Flying Fortress during the United States Army Air Force's recent attacks on the captive French steel works at Lille evoked high praise today from his commanding general.

Lloyd George was 80 on Sunday and congratulations swarmed upon him from all quarters. In his long career he must have had to break many friendships and cultivate fat crops of enemies. Yet his high service as another "pilot that weathered the storm" is remembered by his countrymen without distinction of party; and his own is but a family party.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 18 -- The return of Marcel B.
