Peyrouton from Buenos Aires and Henri de Rose, legation secretary, from Santiago, Chile, and the elevation of the Foreign Affairs Commissioner, Jacques Tarbe de St.-Hardouin, to the rank of Minister Plenipotentiary indicated today that the French Imperial Council in North Africa is ready to make changes.

The aggregate value of building permits issued in 215 cities in December was higher than in the previous month, but considerably lower than in the corresponding month of 1941, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. It was the fifteenth successive month to show a decrease, compared with the similar period of the previous year, and had the smallest December figure since 1935.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- J. Harold Foster and Anthony Damiano, friends of Samuel Nuzzo, convicted labor leader, pleaded guilty today to a misdemeanor count of an indictment charging them with tampering with a State's witness in Nuzzo's grand larceny-forgery trial.

Erik is a millinery designer who knows his public and caters to it. This was evident at yesterday's showing in the salon at 15 East Fifty-third Street. The large collection was above all wearable. That the brim and crown-lines were done with a variety of types in mind was evidenced by the fact that Erik showed them on young as well as mature faces, blond as well as gray coiffures.
LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Local rationing boards of the New York metropolitan area were directed to begin "tailoring" the fuel oil rations of nonresidential consumers yesterday at the same time that Joel Dean, Office of Price Administration fuel rationing director, here for conferences with petroleum industry representatives, asserted that "the coal shortage will never hold a candle to the fuel oil problem."

Warning that the nation's banks must be prepared to add heavily to their already large holdings of United States Government securities, despite increased Federal tax receipts and sales of securities to non-banking investors, Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, told members of the New York State Bankers Association at their annual midwinter meeting yesterday that every bank must now carry its fair share of the load.

Long Island University's basketball team has been paired with the Norfolk Naval Training Station's unbeaten quintet, it was announced yesterday by Director Ned Irish at the luncheon of the Basketball Writers Association at Toots Shor's restaurant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The failure of prolonged and persistent German efforts to control the schools of Norway, which have resulted only in the closing of schools, the arrest of hundreds of teachers and strikes by pupils, were described here today by Harald Land, 31-year-old teacher of a secondary school or gymnasium at Arendal, near Kristiansand, in Southern Norway, who, Norwegian officials here say, is the first escaped teacher from Norway to reach this country.

The aggregate value of building permits issued in 215 cities in December was higher than in the previous month, but considerably lower than in the corresponding month of 1941, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. It was the fifteenth successive month to show a decrease, compared with the similar period of the previous year, and had the smallest December figure since 1935.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- J. Harold Foster and Anthony Damiano, friends of Samuel Nuzzo, convicted labor leader, pleaded guilty today to a misdemeanor count of an indictment charging them with tampering with a State's witness in Nuzzo's grand larceny-forgery trial.

Erik is a millinery designer who knows his public and caters to it. This was evident at yesterday's showing in the salon at 15 East Fifty-third Street. The large collection was above all wearable. That the brim and crown-lines were done with a variety of types in mind was evidenced by the fact that Erik showed them on young as well as mature faces, blond as well as gray coiffures.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Peggy La Rue Satterlee, Hollywood entertainer, described in Superior Court today her week-end cruise aboard Errol Flynn's yacht.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 19 -- Abandoning all reserve and their previous attempts to minimize the force of the Russian offensive, German military leaders admitted today that their lines were being hard pressed by the impact of the reinforced Soviet advance.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19 -- More than 1,000 employes of the Neville Island plant of the Pittsburgh Coke and Iron Company and their families stood in a sleet storm today for ceremonies at which the company received the Army-Navy "E" for excellence in war production.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Jan. 19 -- We are very much concerned regarding the publicity which is being given the strike in the anthracite coal fields, which publicity as written by some newspapers is without question creating the wrong impression regarding the industry and the majority of the men employed in it.

Either synthetic rubber must be produced this year in the volume planned or a narrower definition of "essential requirements" will have to be made, Dr. Charles F. Phillips, chief of the automotive supply rationing division of the Office of Price Administration, told 250 truck owners and operators yesterday at the opening session of a two-day meeting of the National Council of Private Motor Truck Owners, Inc., at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, tonight urged upward adjustment of wage levels and immediate over-all rationing of all foods and other necessities, coupled with "effective enforcement" of price ceilings, as a means of "assuring more living necessities to many people who aren't getting enough."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Curtis E. Calder, utilities executive, of Bronxville, N.Y., has been appointed Director General for Operations of the War Production Board by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the WPB. He succeeds Ernest Kanzler, whose resignation because of ill health was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The White House called for an end within forty-eight hours of the Pennsylvania coal strike. It announced the appointment of Colonel Robert Johnson to succeed Lou E. Holland as chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation.

Less than fourteen hours after his arrest in Harlem, the grand jury returned yesterday a seven-count indictment, involving charges of burglary, robbery and rape, against William Gardner, 21 years old, a Negro, in an attack at 3 A.M. on Jan. 10 on a Red Cross nurse in her apartment in Tudor City.

Efrem Zimbalist's annual violin recitals at Carnegie Hall vary little with the years, as his appearance last night proved once more. His playing has the maturity and authority of a musician who has done his work faithfully and searchingly.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19 The Red Army has reached a point only seventy-nine miles from Kharkov, big Ukraine industrial city, in a continuing westward sweep that has resulted in the capture of 52,000 Axis prisoners in a week, it was announced officially tonight in a special communique circulated by the Soviet news agency Tass.

Private Schmid is the young Marine who accounted for two hundred Japanese with a machine gun in the Solomons on April 21, 1942. He told his story in this newspaper last November. About 1 o'clock in the morning "Smitty" and two buddies were squatting in a machine gun nest on the river bank.

Ned Irish, basketball promoter, former sports writer and publicity director, yesterday was named acting president of Madison Square Garden. He will serve for the duration of the war as active head of the organization, filling the berth held by Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrict, who reported for active duty with the Army last March.

With a cast composed partly of opera stars and partly of enlisted men from Fort Hancock, an abbreviated version of Bizet's "Carmen" was presented before about 1,000 persons last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria as the start of an effort to make seats at the Metropolitan Opera available to service men.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Britain will reach her peak of war production in 1943 and the effort will involve many compulsory transfers of workers, Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, told the House of Commons today.
As always, along with the good news must invariably come the bad. Along with the victories of the United States and Allied Nations must come the sad but inevitable casualty lists.
WILKES-BARRE, Jan. 19 -- The revolt in the ranks of the U.M.W. continued tonight as six locals voted to stay idle despite President Roosevelt's ultimatum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- House Democrats, in a stampede revolt against the designation of Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party of New York, for membership on the Committee on the Judiciary, refused to confirm it in caucus today and sent his name back to the Committee on Committees for another assignment. It approved without controversy all of the other assignments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Senator Clark of Missouri gave notice to Administration leaders in the Senate today that he and Senator Hatch of New Mexico would oppose the confirmation of Edward J. Flynn to be Minister to Australia unless the former Democratic national chairman also resigned as National Committeeman from New York.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 19 -- With the anthracite coal industry tied up for many days by a strike, the American public is overwhelmingly of the belief that Congress should take some action to prohibit or prevent strikes in the nation's war industries for the duration.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Senate adopted and sent to the Governor today the Moffat bill changing the date of the fiscal year from July 1 to April 1, thus clearing the way for the new fiscal plan of Governor Dewey.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Holders of preferred and common shares of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad need expect no dividends for at least another five years, John W. Davin, president, indicated today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The appointment of Marcel B. Peyrouton as Governor General of Algeria came as an apparent surprise to some here who had been in touch with the situation and had predicted that he would be placed in no important post.

" China Girl," a Twentieth Century-Fox production Starring Gene Tierney, George Montgomery and Lynn Bari, will have its local premiere this morning at the Roxy. Produced and written by Ben Hecht, the topical drama's supporting cast includes Victor McLaglen, Alan Baxter, Sig Rumann, Ann Pennington and Myron McCormick.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Lou E. Holland of Kansas City was supplanted today by Colonel Robert Johnson as director of the Smaller War Plants Corporation. Mr. Holland had headed the agency since it was authorized by Congress and set up within the War Production Board last July.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Expansion of the blood-donor program of the American Red Cross to provide for the Army and Navy a weekly supply, for the present, of "at least" 70,000 pints, and an estimated total of 4,000,000 pints during 1943, more than three times the amount contributed last year, has been requested, and action already has been taken to meet the new demands on the organization, Norman H. Davis, national chairman, announced today.

" The American soldier is the greatest potential solider in the world," declared Colonel Le Roy P. Hunt, commander of the Marine task force which captured Guadalcanal in the Solomons last August, and a hero of the Battle of Belleau Wood, of World War I, in an interview yesterday at the Third Naval District Headquarters, 90 Church Street.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Jan. 19 -- A mopping-up job is virtually all that remains for the Australian and American forces in the Sanananda area of Papua, the southeastern section of New Guinea.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Bruins stretched their National Hockey League lead over the Red Wings to seven points by out-shooting Montreal's aggressive Canadiens for a 5 -- 2 victory tonight before a 9,399 crowd at the Boston Garden.

The Army reservation at Fort Hancock, N.J., will be the scene tonight of an international team match between boxers from the British Royal Navy and the South African Navy and American soldiers. The event will be held in the Gage Gymnasium and is the first competition of its kind among the fighting forces of the United Nations.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 19 -- British infantry, tanks and artillery smashed two German attacks in the area between Bou Arada and Goubellat, on the Central Tunisian front, yesterday, and then took the offensive, sweeping through the enemy lines to capture a number of prisoners in the first extensive ground fighting in Tunisia for nearly two weeks.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Dripping skies that sheathed the trees of the Hudson highlands in crystal ice and dampened wedding finery, did not deter thirty-three wartime brides from taking their vows today with their newly-commissioned Army bridegrooms before the altars of the three chapels on the United States Military Academy reservation here.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Intimating that they had about reached the end of their playing days, the Braves today unconditionally released two of the National League's oldest players, Outfielders Johnny Cooney, who will be 42 in March, and the 40-in-April Paul (Big Poison) Waner.

Especially hard hit by the 40 per cent slash is fuel oil for industrial users, spokesmen for some of the larger laundries warned New Yorkers yesterday that it might become "difficult to get a clean shirt" The pinch may also apply to the diaper laundry services.

Albert E. Sindlinger, for five years director of advertising, promotion and publicity of March of Time, producers of the interpretive newsreel, has resigned to become executive vice president of Audience Research Institute, Inc., of Princeton, N.J. The latter organization, founded by Dr. George Gallup and Mrs. Barbara Benson, conducts scientific surveys in the field of motion pictures.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- As the prestige of Soviet Russia increases daily with new victories over the finest armies Europe has ever seen, Eastern European governments are sharply realizing that their post-war alignment will look far more to the east toward Moscow than, as previously, along the Danube Valley to the west.

Prosecution of small packers and wholesale butchers on charges of black market practices has brought about a "substantial improvement" in the situation, it was announced yesterday by Sylvan L. Joseph, regional OPA administrator.

John Walker Burns, 42 years old, the former collection agency solicitor who was convicted on Nov. 17 by a General Sessions jury of a series of thefts with a woman confederate from Mrs. Elizabeth Clark Tyler Miller of 277 Park Avenue and Cleveland, Ohio, was sentenced yesterday to fifteen to thirty months in Sing Sing.

SIR NORMAN ANGELL never gives up. For more than three decades the distinguished Nobel peace prize winner and author of "The Great Illusion" has been fighting on the side of the angels -- fighting for peace and human decency with undaunted courage as the clouds of war and human abasement darkened more and more of the world.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 19 -- The Senate approved tonight, by a vote of 30 to 10, a motion to break off relations with the Axis. Two members abstained.

Three safe blowers, who were interrupted by the police early one morning last October as they drilled into the vault of a chemical plant in Greenwich Village, were sentenced to prison terms yesterday in General Sessions on their recent conviction of burglary.
CAIRO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A British communique:

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 -- Signator, making his first start of the year, carried the Woolford Farm silks of Herbert M. Woolf to a smashing triumph in the Robert E. Lee Handicap at the Fair Grounds today. Leading a classy field from which a threat for Whirlaway may develop before the Feb. 27 running of the New Orleans Handicap, Signator ran six furlongs in 1:10 3-5, smashing the track record of 1:11 1-5.

Largely as a result of paying off all arrearages of dividends on its second preferred stock to Nov. 1 last, a total of more than $3,000,000, net assets of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation applicable to the first preferred stock dropped in 1942 from $26,802,591 to $25,252,289, or from $155 to $146 a share, according to a report issued yesterday.

Seven persons have been named to represent as many industries or professions in the current campaign of the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America to raise $350,000, according to an announcement by Nathan M. Orbach, chairman of the Manhattan Business Men's Committee.

Paolo Gallico, 74-year-old Italian pianist, composer and teacher, who has not been heard here in a solo recital for almost thirty years, last night gave a recital at Town Hall, which marked the fiftieth anniversary of his first appearance in New York. His program was confined to three composers to whom he is obviously devoted, Bach, Beethoven and Chopin.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan, 19 (U.P.) -- Two torpedoes, fired almost simultaneously by a German submarine, sent a medium-sized British merchantman to the bottom of the Atlantic in fifty seconds in mid-December with a possible loss of sixty-six men, survivors reported here.

The six hundred refugee children from Poland whose request for transit visas to Jerusalem has been refused by the Iraqi Government, will make their way to Palestine via Iran and India, it was learned by a cablegram from Telaviv, Mrs. Charles I. Turtz, chairman of the Women's League for Palestine, announced yesterday at the league's annual donor luncheon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

For the first time since it opened, the Stage Door Canteen, where hundreds of service men of the United Nations obtain free sandwiches, dancing and stage entertainment every night in the week, offered a complete show by the Army last night. It was called "General Disorders of 1943" and was presented by the Fort Hamilton Special Theatre Section with the permission of Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- The Navy Department today released Casualty List No. 20, which included 1,218 men who were reported dead, wounded or missing in advices to their next of kin between Dec. 16 and 31, 1942.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,782 which compared with 2,223 in the preceding week and 1,528 in the similar period of 1942, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 785 as against 1,028 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Referring to criticisms of Robert Murphy, the State Department's representative in North Africa under Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Secretary Cordell Hull said at his press conference today that Mr. Murphy was well able to take care of himself and that this would prove true also of his record when it was made known.
MONTREAL, Jan. 19 -- More than 10,000 people filled the Montreal Forum this evening to hear Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt appeal on behalf of the Canadian Russian Relief Fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Total operating revenues for eighty-nine class I railroads in December were $570,839,881, an increase of 43.9 per cent over the 1941 month, the Association of American Railroads estimated today on the basis of preliminary reports.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A communique:

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19 -- Members of the executive board of the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, a C.I.O. affiliate headed by Reid Robinson, with a membership of about 60,000, arrived here this evening to meet with Phillip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in an effort to iron out factional differences which threaten to split the union.

No little interest was caused yesterday in Wall Street circles by the disclosure that several of the nation's leading corporations are scheduled to have representatives at a special meeting tomorrow to express opposition to the recently promulgated proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Stocks of dry beans are huge, topping those of last season by about 430,000,000 pounds and exceeding the five-year average (1936-41) by some 830,000,000 pounds. Because of the unprecedented size of the current supply, the Agricultural Marketing Administration has designated these legumes as the Victory Food Special for the week.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, which is now making its annual appeal for financial assistance, occupies a unique position. It is at once a philanthropic and a scientific institution. Through its far-flung organization it not only treats and rehabilitates those who have been crippled by a dreadful affliction but also finances scientific research in which the services of the best minds in this country are enlisted.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 19 -- Pushing forward over rough desert flats into the rough hill country of Tripolitania, elements of the British Eighth Army were within sixty-five miles of Tripoli yesterday and were in contact with the enemy where the terrain was most suitable for any defense of Tripoli that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel might care to make.

HAWTHORNE, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Reunited with two brothers he had not seen for twenty-five years, Adrianus Van Buren, a 38-year-old Dutch sailor, who has twice survived enemy ship sinkings in the North Atlantic since the war started, had two words of greeting for his wife and five children in occupied Holland today.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (Reuter) -- Viscount Cranborne, Government leader in the House of Lords, told members this morning that the highest rate of sinkings U-boats had yet achieved in this war followed Allied landings in North Africa.

MIAMI, Jan. 19 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor appealed today to President Roosevelt as Commander in Chief of the armed forces to stop the National Labor Relations Board from continuing its hearings in Portland, Ore., on complaints of violations of the Wagner Act in shipbuilding plants operated by Henry J. Kaiser.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Three Naval Reserve flying officers and two petty officers have been missing from a navigational flight since Saturday night, officials of the Jacksonville naval air station said today.

The bombing of Berlin, the capture of Schluesselburg, strongest of the ring of fortifications around besieged Leningrad, and the declaration of Premier Per Albin Hansson that Sweden will fight if invaded are sharp reminders that Europe has a northern as well as a southern gateway.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Henry G. Riter 3d of New York City was elected today chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., at the annual meeting here of the board of governors. He is senior partner in Riter Co. He succeeds H.H. Dewar of Dewar, Robertson Pancoast of San Antonio, Texas, who completed a three-year term on the board.

A sample of recreational trout fishing is given in the report just received from the Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game. It has to do with the Blackledge River section where several tests were made by the authorities.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- British boys of the age of 17 can now enlist in the Army, with the reservation that they will be put on reserve and called up for service on reaching the age of 18 or on an agreed date after having reached 17 years and 6 months, the War Office said today.

A new suit brought by the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation against the former management of the corporation was filed in Supreme Court yesterday, asking recovery of $3,200,000 paid in commissions to the Brewster Export Company and the Hayes Aircraft Accessories Corporation, and an order exempting Brewster Aeronautical from payment of another $2,000,000 due as commissions to Brewster Export.

James M. Cecil, chairman of the Committee of Public Information of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City, announced yesterday that formation of his committee had been completed. Serving as vice chairman are Don Stetler of Standard Brands, who will direct the fund's advertising; Samuel D. Fuson, vice president of Arthur Kudner, Inc., in charge of publicity, and Mrs. Lawrence Tibbett, who will supervise the public education program for women's activities.

Demonstrating hitherto unsuspected sensitivity, members of the City Council spent more than two hours yesterday in oratorical defense against "invasions" of their honor, dignity and privileges. Before the final gavel fell for adjournment, horse meat, health laws, parliamentary procedure, political morals, safety needs of night clubs and disbanding of the WPA had been discussed as matters of "high personal privilege."

Is medicine a learned profession or a trade? Though the question was placed squarely before it in the proceedings instituted by the Government under the anti-trust laws against the American Medical Association the Supreme Court declined to answer it. Instead, the Court considered only the Association's conduct and found it reprehensible in the light of the Sherman Act.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Under-Secretary Forrestal testified today that it was not motives of greed on the part of business that led to the high costs of some war contracts.

WITH THE BRITISH HOME FLEET, at a Northern Base (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The First Lord of the Admiralty, A.V. Alexander, has told the men of the Royal Navy that 1943 will be a crucial year, with Great Britain facing the "greatest attacks on our sea communications" in history.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 19 -- Reduction of at least 70 per cent in the accident toll in the United States is the goal of leaders of a countrywide safety campaign which will be opened here tomorrow with a luncheon of industrial leaders and officers of the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Public Utilities Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission today approved principal parts of the dissolution plan filed last Dec. 31 by the Federal Water and Gas Corporation and thirty-three subsidiaries from Florida to Oregon.

The charge made by Investigation Commissioner William B. Herlands that forty-five books had been deleted from the approved list of library titles for city high schools "at the instance" of William R. Crowley, former member of the Board of Education, was characterized yesterday by Mr. Crowley as "so preposterous there is really nothing to it."

The office of the State OPA director at 535 Fifth Avenue explained yesterday that it had no intention of intervening in the situation in Garden City, L.I., where August B. Weller, Nassau County Rationing Administrator, has cited forty persons to appear to explain their use of automobiles to attend a fashionable wedding last Saturday in the Cathedral of the Incarnation.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- To assume that Great Britain will be poorer after the war is to assume she will be less productive and amounts to defeatism, said Sir William Beveridge in a speech at Plymouth today.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The State Civil Service Commission recommended today in a report to Governor Dewey and the Legislature a careful study of the post-war problem of finding places in the public service for returning veterans without impairing the efficiency of the civil service system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Under a new order issued today by the Petroleum Administration for War, gasoline service stations throughout the country must either stay open continuously or for not more than seventy-two hours a week or more than twelve hours a day.

The merry row over exhibition date priorities, crackling for a week between the Giants on the one side and the Yankees and Dodgers on the other, wound up in a thin blue streak of curling smoke yesterday when the heads of the three major league clubs passed around a pipe of peace.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19 -- General Field Marshal Wilhelm Ritter von Leeb started the attack on Leningrad on Aug. 21, 1941, the sixty-first day of the Soviet-German war. It was launched from three directions and conducted by an army of 300,000 riflemen, four divisions of motor-borne infantry, 1,000 tanks and about 1,000 first-line aircraft.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- Australian troops, supported by Americans, moved with great skill through comparatively lightly-held Japanese positions between two strongly defended coastal positions Monday and captured Sanananda village.

Simon Schuster announced yesterday that a new book by Joseph C. Grew, former Ambassador to Japan, is in preparation. This will be a broader, more thorough work than Mr. Grew's "Report From Tokyo," which consists mostly of his public addresses since he returned from Japan and which had for its main purpose warning and arousing the American public.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, defended today in a speech to the Military Academy's first midwinter graduating class the need for an American Army of 7,500,000 men, and said the size of the armed forces necessary to win the war was "a military problem" for our military leaders to solve.

A widespread movement for standardization of methods and materials is now under way in Latin America and business men of the United States must see to it that our technical and quality standards get consideration in the compilation of such data if postwar trade is to be maintained, Cyrus T. Brady Jr., field representative of the American Standards Association, daclared yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Counsel for Procter Gamble Company, which went on trial with six individuals in Federal Court today on a charge of using the mails illegally in a scheme to steal soap-making trade secrets, fomulae and production data, declared that the concern had no part in the alleged activities.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The appointment of Marcel Peyrouton as Governor General of Algeria had a bad effect here. There was no official comment today, but there was no question that the appointment would be severely criticized.

WITH THE RED ARMY, Driving Toward Rostov, Jan. 18 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- German troops, painfully retreating before the Red Army drive over snow-covered wastelands southwest of Stalingrad, are sick and tired of the war, but are fighting with the desperation of doomed men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Further study of simplification and standardization in the field of distribution, along with a check upon the progress made in those lines to date, has been ordered by the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Supply, Joseph L. Weiner, director, revealed today.

HAVANA, Jan. 19 -- Reports from Hungary that show a growing opinion among political and military leaders that Germany's defeat is inevitable have just been received here by Francis Tamas, editor of the Free Hungarian Review of Havana.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The State War Council has formally protested to the Navy Department against the barring of Negroes from taking special training courses at colleges and universities in this State. It acted, according to information at the Governor's office, on a complaint filed by Walter White, head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
May I make this comment on certain portions of the report of the subcommittee on State-city fiscal relations of the Mayor's Committee on City Finances?

The Amateur Athletic Union's official Athletic Almanac and Track and Field Guide for 1943, with its collection of facts and figures and featuring Dan Ferris's All-America team, came off the presses yesterday.

OTTAWA, Jan. 19 -- A third daughter was born tonight to Crown Princess Juliana of the Netherlands, and the line of succession to the throne, for which a male heir has not been born since 1851, remained unchanged.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Paramount today bought an original screen story "A Medal for Benny" from John Steinbeck, paying a reported $25,000 for the 20-page outline. It is the author's only effort written directly for pictures, excepting the documentary "The Forgotten Village" filmed in Mexico with a native cast.

Mayor La Guardia told a Planning Conference on Sanitation for the Post-War Period, held yesterday at the Engineers Club, that "Congress ought to start with an appropriation of at least $500,000,000 to $600,000,000 for plans for a national post-war construction program that would entail the expenditure of billions of dollars on public works.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A veteran Coast Guard aviator rescued two stranded, wounded survivors of a Flying Fortress crash from the ice cap of Greenland and then, it is assumed, lost his own life in trying to save a third man. The Navy Department told the story today.

" Ask My Friend, Sandy" has been postponed again, this time from Jan. 27 to the week of Feb. 1, at the Biltmore Theatre. Now practicing in Boston, the Stanley Young comedy, starring Roland Young, will extend its tryout there through Jan. 30.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament finals probably will be staged at Madison Square Garden in March, it was learned yesterday. There is a possibility that the N.C.A.A. champion will meet the winner of the national invitation tournament to be held at the Garden March 16 to 24.

The campaign of advertising agencies to get "on-sale" dates of magazines closer to months of issue shown on covers is progressing and additional magazines have agreed to come out not earlier than the tenth of the month. At the suggestion of Lennen Mitchell, Inc., a new group of magazines will start to retard on-sale dates, following the initial action late last month by eight Macfadden publications.

The President's appointment of Edward J. Flynn as Minister to Australia has already begun to have some of the bad effects that many predicted it would have. Among other things, it has tempted the Democratic National Committee into the utterance of a particularly dangerous bit of nonsense.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- The National Football League looks forward confidently to the 1943 season. Continuing operations will involve obstacles, but the growing importance of football amounts almost to a mandate that these obstacles be overcome.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein granted today a preliminary injunction restraining the New Jersey Board of Optometry from refusing to renew the licenses of optometrists on whose premises are displayed advertising signs in the form of eyeglass frames.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- British and Indian troops, increasingly active over a wide front in Western Burma, have captured the village of Kyauktaw, forty-six miles north of Akyab, and made a small advance in the Donbaik area of the Mayu Peninsula, less than twenty miles from Akyab, it was announced today.

A triple Allied thrust to the sea at Sanananda Point has cleared the Japanese from their last organized foothold on the Papuan peninsula. Only a few remnants of the enemy remain on the beaches. This is the end, for all present purposes, of Japan's ambitious plan to capture Port Moresby and launch from it an attack upon Australia.

Still awaiting the outcome of agricultural legislation now pending before Congress, cotton traders yesterday curtailed much of their activity in the futures market. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts ended a dull session with net losses of 4 to 7 points after having moved within a 9-to-11-point radius of the previous close.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The stock markets here continued cheerful today with Kaffir mining shares making a good showing on the statement of the Finance Minister of the Union of South Africa that the government's revenue would make possible in the next year additional expenditures of 16,000,000 for defense without further taxation. Among the issues to go ahead were Blyvoor and West Wit.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Germany is building twenty to thirty submarines a month -- twice as fast as the Allies can sink them -- and will have 500 to 700 to throw against the United Nations supply lines in the Spring, according to the best available information.
LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The mid-day communique of the Soviet Information Bureau, broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 19 -- Flying Fortresses of the United States Twelfth Air Force raided Castelbenito yesterday. The Axis air base at that point, which is thirteen miles south of Tripoli, has been giving Marshal Rommel what air cover it can against the numerically superior air squadrons of the Allies.

Called as a witness for the government at the trial of a suit against himself and nineteen other former members of the German-American Bund, a former Yorkville waiter testified yesterday that he would not fight against his native Germany.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- Fighter and Coastal Command planes of the Royal Air Force attacked railroads in Northern France and a Nazi convoy off the Netherland coast last night while the heavy bombers took a night off after two massive raids on Berlin.

The trend toward handling ordinary commercial cargoes as lend-lease shipments was again a principal topic of discussion among foreign traders yesterday at a meeting of the Export Managers Club in the Hotel Pennsylvania. While the majority of members indicated their opposition to the development, some asserted that until the "principle" involved in such transactions is fully known traders cannot back up their objections.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 -- The city of Philadelphia assailed today the plan for partial dissolution of the United Gas Improvement Company as unfair in view of commitments of the Philadelphia Gas Works Company, a subsidiary of U.G.I., to the municipality, and threatened court action to block the proposed distribution of 80 per cent of the assets of the holding company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Five additional sinkings of Japanese ships by American submarines were announced here today by the Navy Department, raising to 112 the total number of enemy ships sunk by our submarines in Pacific waters in this war.

Several hundred experienced women "sailors" now ashore in the United States want to return to sea and replace men for more arduous war duties, according to a report placed before the national council of the National Maritime Union yesterday.

" White's right for the blackout" was the keynote of a series of all-white and white-trimmed hats featured last night at the Spring and Summer fashion show held by the Millinery Stabilization Commission in the Hotel Astor. White satin, sequin-trimmed white straw and jet-embroidered white faille were stressed in a dramatic trio of "white-by-night" fashions for dress-up occasions.

Long-established price differentials within industries which distribute comparable products to both wholesalers and retailers may be scaled down sharply if the OPA succeeds in working out its present formula of specific prices for a simplified "victory" line of heavyweight underwear for next Winter, it was reported yesterday in the textile market.

Unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Railway Brotherhoods will conduct a joint campaign through the New York Labor War Chest to raise $4,000,000 among members of organized labor in this city in 1943 for the American Red Cross and various war-relief purposes, it was announced yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 19 -- Marcel B. Peyrouton, former Minister of the Interior in Vichy, and Chief of Government Pierre Laval's political arch foe, was appointed Governor General of Algeria today by General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner for French North Africa.

The American soldier stationed in Alaska is glad to get back there after furlough -- there is no rationing and life is pretty much as it was in a Northwestern town before the war. Besides, he feels he is rid of the "complacency of the States," according to Miss Margaret Conrardy, USO hostess in Anchorage, Alaska, who was interviewed yesterday at USO headquarters in the Empire State Building.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Nothing could have flown more directly in the face of the 1942 general election returns than the designation, by the House Democratic leadership, of Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor Party, of New York City, to be a member of the Committee on the Judiciary.

Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey was honored yesterday at a testimonial luncheon arranged by Mayor La Guardia, Sanitation Department executives and heads of other departments. The luncheon was held in his office at 125 Worth Street.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Berwind and their sons, David and Graham Berwind, of Haverford, Pa., are at Hampshire House.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, first of the large tobacco concerns to announce operating results for 1942, disclosed in a report for publication today a new high sales record of $369,212,044, or an average of more than $1,000,000 for each calendar day of the year, and representing an increase of $46,191,931 over the $323,020,113 volume of 1941.

" OPENING night is the worst," said Sonja Henie with a pert little smile, "but after that it doesn't seem so bad. I almost dread that opening, particularly the one in New York. I'm generally pretty nervous before each first appearance."
I read the letter in THE TIMES of Miss Bernstein, the Administrator of the Board of Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- The toll of American ships officially announced or unofficially reported as sunk by Axis submarines totaled 685 today, and a Navy spokesman said that "as it stands now we are not winning the battle of transportation."
NEW DELHI, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A British communique:

Not many young pianists can go before the public with as extensive a repertory as that indicated by the program Miss Annette Elkanova, winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Prize, offered yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. In the same breadth, observing her special capacities in this direction, one is moved to ask if it is wise for a relatively inexperienced and undeveloped player to proceed so ambitiously.

When Edward Joseph, assistant district attorney, was introducing rebuttal testimony yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Anthony Albanese, 31 years old, of 129 Cherry Street, an ex-convict accused of robbery, Albanese decided to plead guilty.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 19 -- The establishment of a school for training doctors, technicians and nurses in the Kenny method for the treatment of infantile paralysis at the Jersey City Medical Center was announced here today by Joseph F. FitzGerald, State chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- Fighting French headquarters disclosed today that it had received reports from Algiers that the mobilization of a French army in North Africa was being sabotaged by pro-Nazi elements, that Vichy collaborators still held their jobs and that communications remained in charge of men appointed by the Germans.

CALLENDER, Ont., Jan. 19 -- By the death of Sir John Henry Jervis-White-Jervis in London his brother, Henry Felix, known as plain "Cap'n" Jervis to residents of Callender for more than a half century, learned today that he had become fifth baronet of the line.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- The first dispatches from the Leningrad front revealed today that, though Schluesselburg was occupied by the Germans, a fortress immediately outside the town remained in Soviet hands throughout the seventeen months of siege.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Exercising his authority as wartime Commander in Chief of the armed forces, President Roosevelt gave orders today to several thousand striking anthracite coal miners in Pennsylvania "to return at once to their job of producing vitally needed coal for their country."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The bitter Senate fight in the last session over the anti-poll tax bill had an aftermath today when Chesley W. Jurney, sergent at arms of the Senate, resigned and his place was given to former Senator Wall Doxey of Mississippi.

A detailed preview of the expanded social security program contemplated by the government -- an American Beveridge plan -- in accordance with President Roosevelt's general proposal in his message to Congress on Jan. 7, when he stressed the need of "assurance that will extend from the cradle to the grave" against the evils of all major economic hazards, was presented in an address here yesterday by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 19 -- For the first time an official spokesman of the Nazi High Command admitted today the possibility of a threat to Germany proper by Russian troops. According to the Nazi-controlled S.T.B. News Agency, the spokesman said:

The United Nations are counting heavily upon the produce of millions of victory gardens this year to alleviate civilian food shortages. Housewives and children in England, Russia and other of the Allied countries will undertake the major share of this work, it is expected, and they will be aided by the arrival of some 500,000,000 Americans seeds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- An assertion that "black market" gasoline sales were far greater than generally believed was made before the Senate Small Business Committee today by a spokesman for the National Automobile Dealers Association.

Pooling of creative talent and resources through a federation of trade associations in the fashion field to establish the United States as the fashion center of the world was urged yesterday by Anton De Haas of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A spokesman for General Henri Honore Giraud's French headquarters announced today that a French camel corps had captured Ghat and Serdeles, 500 miles south of Tripoli, and had wiped out all Axis occupation in the Sahara except Gadames, which is now threatened.
OTTAWA, Jan. 19 (Canadian Press) -- The following communique was issued at 7:45 o'clock tonight at Ottawa Civic Hospital, following the birth of a third child to Princess Juliana of the Netherlands:

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Jan. 20 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique revealed today that the Russian forces in the North Caucasus had crossed the Kuban River, along which it had been anticipated that the Axis would make a stand, and occupied several settlements on the opposite bank in a continuing advance.

The forced landings of eleven American Bell Airacobra P-39 fighting planes in Portugal last week focused attention upon some of the most brilliant but least known achievements of the war -- the flight-ferrying of single-engined fighters overseas.

Forty-three nurse's aides received their caps last night as graduates of the 125th and 126th Red Cross classes of Montefiore Hospital at the nurses' residence, Gunhill Road near Jerome Avenue, the Bronx.

OTTAWA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King in a statement today outlined a government plan providing for making the steel industry a national one in an effort to settle strikes at Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., and at Sydney and Trenton, N.S.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Federal District Judge George A. Welsh today ordered the Pennsylvania Railroad to pay the Pennroad Corporation $23,104,565 for losses and damages suffered by the latter during 1930-31 when officers and directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad handled Pennroad interests.

Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, visited the Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday with Wendell L. Willkie and chose in the pediatric ward a room to be dedicated later in memory of a son of the British representative, Francis Hugh Peter Courtenay Wood, killed in action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The House Rules Committee, seeking the reason for the letting of war contracts upon which millions of dollars in profits can be recaptured, was told today by James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, that the extreme pressure and speed of early war production often made it impossible to gauge profits by accurate yardsticks.

Nashville, Tenn., awarded yesterday $500,000 of airport bonds to a syndicate comprising Estabrook Co., the Commerce Union Bank of Nashville, the Hibernia National Bank of New Orleans, La., and Jac P. Ducournau. The bonds are to mature on Dec. 15, 1943 to 1962.

There is at least one reason why this particular department refuses to get excited about the way President Roosevelt is mishandling the political situation in North Africa. We remember the Second Front. Or we may put it another way.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- More than 500,000 scientists and professional men and women of the United States have been registered, their qualifications catalogued and more than 140,000 names certified to agencies engaged in the war effort, according to a report made today by the National Resources Planning Board, reviewing achievements of the National Roster of Scientific and Specialized Personnel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- An agreement, which will result in "substantial restoration of functions to the appropriate civilian authorities" in Hawaii, was announced today by the White House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd, who is in Washington between overseas assignments, emphasized today his view of the Moral Re-Armament program as important in support of the war effort.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Business on the stock markets here today was quiet but with a steady undertone on good war news. Gilt-edge stocks and home rails eased fractionally.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan 20 -- Mobile striking forces of the British Eighth Army yesterday pushed up to the crest of the Jebel Nefusa, the only defensive terrain between them and Tripoli, and reached the area of Tarhuna, important road junction forty miles southeast of Tripoli.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Governor Dewey told the 200 members of the State Agricultural Society today that the farmers of New York State had "a leading role in this struggle to produce not only the merely important foods, but the absolutely essential foods."

If United States silver certificates of $1, $5 and $10 denominations bear a yellow seal on the face of the note, instead of the familiar blue one, the money is not counterfeit, but bills issued by the Treasury for use by United States forces in combat areas.

A man returning to his home in Manhattan aboard a Bronx express train of the IRT division was assaulted by two Negro youths with knives at about 7:30 o'clock last night as he was riding in the front car with about twenty other passengers between 110th Street and Ninety-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Southern Democrats of the House, who captured the party caucus yesterday, forced the rejection of Representative Marcantonio for Judiciary Committee assignment and won formal designation of the Steering Committee as a policy-making body, moved today to consolidate their gains.

Rex Stout's plea for hate in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Jan. 17 is, I fear, utterly futile. Besides probably arousing a flurry of controversy, it can attain no practical results because, curiously enough, hate cannot be created synthetically at will.

Operating at the fastest buying pace in years, retailers have continued to place heavy orders for Spring ready-to-wear, especially suits, coats and certain types of dresses. In scanning bulging order books, manufacturers in many instances have found volume increases of 40 to 200 per cent over last year at this time.

A total of $16,928,000 of new note issues was awarded yesterday by seventeen local housing authorities located in various parts of the country. Of this amount a syndicate, headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, won the award of $7,745,000. All of the notes are dated Feb. 9, 1943.

Five conditions under which instructors at City College would be willing to waive their claims to back pay owed them since 1936 by the city were disclosed yesterday by A. Mark Levien, attorney for forty-one teachers who brought suit against the Board of Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senator Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, conducted a sort of quiz program today in questioning Edward J. Flynn on his nomination to be Minister to Australia. He asked Mr. Flynn how many States Australia has.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- George Washington University defeated Army at basketball today by 57 to 48. The visitors led all the way, closing the halftime period with the score 33 to 19 in their favor.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company sold yesterday, through competitive bidding, a total of $5,565,000 of various blocks of State and municipal bonds on behalf of trust accounts. Awards were made to ten separate banking groups, with those for the individual groups ranging in size from $70,000 to $1,890,000.

WHEN Harry Boykoff was graduated from grammar school he was 6 feet 1 inch tall. He grew four inches as a freshman at Thomas Jefferson High School and, fortunately for him, only another four inches in the intervening years. Otherwise his appearances in Madison Square Garden would not have been with the St. John's basketball team but rather with the Ringling Brothers circus.

After careful consideration of the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Jan. 17, "We Shall Hate, or We Shall Fail," by Rex Stout, whom I greatly admire, I am still unconvinced that "it is merely another trick with words" when one claims the possibility of hating an evil while not hating the evildoer.

The right of the publishers "at any time to lay off men for economic or business reasons" was fully upheld in a final award made public yesterday by arbitrators appointed by the War Labor Board to settle the dispute between the Publishers Association of New York and the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, an independent organization, which directed the three-day strike last month that tied up deliveries of eight major newspapers of the city.

The epic story of the building of the Alcan Highwawy after overcoming obstacles that appeared insurmountable was told here yesterday for the first time by high-ranking members of the United States Army Engineers Corps, which built the 1,600-mile strategic military road in seven months through the primeval wildernness of forest and mountain, swamp, rock and frozen soil.

WASHINGTON Jan. 20 -- A slow, orderly rise in prices is inevitable under present conditions, but the advances can be held to a normal rate of about one-half of 1 per cent a month, Prentiss M. Brown, new head of the Office of Price Administration, told a press conference today soon after he had assumed the post formerly held by Leon Henderson.
Is the celebrated Roget's Thesaurus something which the F.B.I. should be looking into without loss of time? We are not thinking of J. Edgar Hoover in quest of a synonym, but in quest of treason.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The War Labor Board formally announced today a plan to decentralize its activities through the creation of twelve regional labor boards empowered to make final decisions on labor disputes and voluntary wage and salary adjustments.

As the deadline for moving approaches, Captain William F. Amsden, commanding officer of the Naval Training School to be opened next month at Hunter College, appealed yesterday to the 613 families in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx who must vacate their apartments to provide quarters for Waves and Spars trainees, for patience and understanding.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20 (AP) -- A plea by a group of eleven incandesdent lamp manufacturing companies for an injunction to force the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company to cancel a price cut, which the independents alleged was part of a conspiracy to drive them out of business and establish and maintain a monopoly, has been denied by Federal Judge Phillip Forman, here.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 20 -- Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu was advised shortly after midday today by the Chilean Ambassador, Conrado Rios Gallardo, of Chile's break with the Axis, and he immediately hastened to inform the press that Argentina's position was completely unaffected by this development.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A communique:
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

The National Association of Manufacturers, which has its headquarters in the Time Life Building in Rockefeller Center, plans to expand its activities, so it has leased the south half of the second floor in 22-26 West Forty-eighth Street.

Further sharp declines in fuel oil supplies were registered again last week, but gasoline stocks continued to mount, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline supplies at the close of the period amounted to 84,955,000 barrels, an increase of 710,000 over the 84,245,000 a week earlier.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Following the first session of his special committee on food, Mayor La Guardia said last night that evasion of Office of Price Administration regulations in the meat industry is "the rule and not the exception." He also reported, on the basis of information furnished by members of the industry, that New York City is getting only 55 per cent of its normal meat supply, not the 70 per cent usually assumed.
The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company reported yesterday for 1942 a net profit of $15,754,543 after Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions.

Russell S. Randall, former Mayor of Freeport, L.I., and a member of one of Nassau County's first families, was accused yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court of stealing enough gasoline rationing coupons to cover the sale of 60,000 gallons.

A racket involving the illegal acceptance of $5 fees from persons seeking copies of census records required in obtaining birth certificates, which are in great demand under defense work regulations, has been uncovered in the office of Kings County Clerk Francis J. Sinnott, it was learned yesterday.

August Ihlefeld, president of the Savings Banks Trust Company, which is wholly owned by the 130 savings banks in New York State, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that earnings for 1942 were equivalent to $29.02 a share, compared with $68.68 a share in 1941.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- A passenger suspected of knowledge of ship movements was taken prisoner aboard an Italian submarine which sank an American merchant vessel in the South Atlantic late in December, survivors revealed here recently.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The long-awaited War Production Board order lifting that agency's ban against the use of any wool whatever in the manufacture of men's, women's and children's bath robes and other types of lounging wear, was issued here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Sales of 10,504 independent retailers in twenty-three States representing the Central and Eastern portions of the United States increased 4 per cent in December, 1942, over the same month of 1941, according to preliminary data released today by J.C. Capt, director of the Census. December sales were 28 per cent over those recorded for the preceding month.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Powell Glass and Carter Glass Jr., sons of Senator Carter Glass, after a talk with their father today said that the Senator sent no telegram regarding the use of automobiles at the Adamson-Montgomery wedding at Garden City, N.Y., and had authorized no one to send such a telegram in his name.

Probability that the Office of Price Administration will soon announce an adjustment for importers of finished manufactured goods, along the same general lines of the regulation already provided for "industrial users," permitting the addition of increased landed costs to current ceilings, was indicated yesterday by Dr. Seymour E. Harris, director of the Office of Export-Import Price Control.

In the high-paneled directors' room on the second floor of J.P. Morgan Co., Incorporated, with its thick carpet, open fireplace, and life-sized portraits of J.P. Morgan and his father, the late J. Pierpont Morgan, a bit of financial history was made yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- While a Senate investigating group was learning today that the United States exported 117,100 tons of rubber in 1942 and planned to ship another 110,000 tons this year, an executive order by Vice President Wallace disclosed the fact that William M. Jeffers, rubber director, has taken over control of rubber imports from the Board of Economic Warfare.

Madison Square Garden definitely will be the scene of the 1943 National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eastern regional basketball tourney and championship play-off game. This was announced yesterday by Ned Irish, acting president of the arena.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The midday communique of the Soviet Information Bureau broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Net current operating earnings of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York in 1942 amounted to $14,883,835, comparing with $13,115,640 in 1941, W. Palen Conway, chairman of the board, said at the annual meeting of stockholders at the company's offices at 35 Nassau Street yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Members of the armed forces of the United States have special privileges in regard to deferment of payment of income tax on their 1942 incomes, Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, stated today in setting out these privileges in detail.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Coldstream Stable's Tragic Ending, who had failed to win in twenty-three starts last year and in one previous effort this season, triumphed by a nose in the Monroe Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Allied jungle fighters, moving so fast they did not have time to count the enemy dead, further compressed Japanese pockets around Sanananda Point in New Guinea while Allied bombers attacked ten points embracing nearly the whole South Pacific area yesterday and the day before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- 0n the ground that lack of suitable housing facilities here was detracting from the ability of members of Congress and legislative employes to perform their duties efficiently, Representative Sabath, chairman of the Rules Committee, prepared a joint resolution today calling for the erection of two $1,000,000 apartment houses.

The American Civil Liberties Union raises a timely question as to the power of the Postoffice Department to close the mails to books, pamphlets and individual issues of periodicals on charges of obscenity or sedition. There is no objection to the procedure under which second-class mailing privileges are withdrawn after specifications have been presented and a hearing held.

Without a dissenting vote, the Board of Education adopted at a special meeting yesterday the 1943-44 budget estimate of $141,427,587, an increase of $218,180 over the original recommendation of the finance committee. This budget now goes to the Mayor and the Board of Estimate for final action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The cooperation of officials of the United Mine Workers of America in the effort to end the strike of miners in the anthracite fields was pledged in messages to President Roosevelt from John L. Lewis, president, and Thomas Kennedy, secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers.

TRENTON, Jan. 20 -- The State Civil Service Commission upheld today the Bergen County Board of Freeholders in its refusal to employ as a bridge tender Daniel E. Morgan of 22 West Hamilton Avenue, Englewood, because Mr. Morgan, in respect to religious convictions, was not disposed to salute the American Flag.

A press tour of centers where 500 volunteer health assistants are working was conducted yesterday by the Bureau of Nursing of the Department of Health to promote its campaign to recruit 1,500 more volunteer.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 20 -- In Washington two months ago a Far East authority said China's economic problem was almost as important as the war. In Chungking yesterday another Far East authority said China's economic problem was graver than the War.

From London we are told that Germany is building twenty to thirty submarines a month; that this is twice as fast as the Allies have been able to sink them; and that Germany will have 500 to 700 submarines to throw against United Nations supply lines in the Spring.

The German High Command asserted yesterday that the Nazi "defenders of the area of Stalingrad," though suffering "serious privation," continued to "defend themselves stubbornly against all Soviet attacks." These are the remnants of twenty-two divisions that Moscow has reported trapped before Stalingrad.

ALGIERS, Jan. 20 (U.P.) -- Marcel B. Peyrouton, in his first public statement, announced today that changes would be made in the local North African administration. He intimated to American and British correspondents, however, that the changes would be made gradually.

A new Waac recruiting station was literally blown into existence in Times Square yesterday morning by a bitter January wind, while a group of shivering Waacs and members of the A.W.V.S., who will man the booth, stood by.

Fifty-one women were recognized as volunteer Red Cross nurses aides in a capping ceremony held last night in the main auditorium of Bellevue Hospital. Although 900 aides have been trained at Bellevue, last night's ceremony was the first of its kind ever held in the hospitals.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- As reports were reaching London indicating that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel might be trying to evacuate the German Africa Corps from Tripoli by sea, the Admiralty announced today that British destroyers and submarines and a Greek destroyer operating in the Mediterranean had struck a heavy blow at Axis shipping:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Director of the Office of War Information, Mr. Elmer Davis, informed the press today that the rate of ship sinkings by German submarines is higher for this period of January than for the same segment of December.
Mrs. Peter Christman, who will be 101 years old tomorrow, has on her schedule a quiet family dinner at home, 163 West Ninety-fifth Street.

The brutally battered body of 12-year-old Martha Punt, a student in an ungraded class at P.S. 141, was found yesterday morning in the bedroom of a three-room apartment at 513 West Fifty-ninth Street, a tenement house, just a block and one-half from her home at 14 Amsterdam Avenue.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Governor Dewey, requested Attorney General Goldstein today to make an immediate investigation of reports of discrimination in the sale of fuel oil by large distributors to determine whether there was a violation of the Donnelly Anti-Monopoly Act.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Sammy Baugh, the Washington Redskins' famed passing star, today was officially cleared of everything but "carelessness" by Elmer Layden, Commissioner of the National Football League, for failure to appear with other Redskins in the service benefit game with the All-Stars at Philadelphia on Dec. 27.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order for proceeding and a hearing to determine whether E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., of New York City, and Walter Cecil Rawls, manager of the firm's branch office in St. Louis, had violated provisions of the Securities Exchange Acts of 1933 and 1934 by fraudulent practices in the sale of securities.

New lists of apartment rentals issued yesterday indicate a continuance of the demand for suites in the city. While the bulk of the renting was done in houses on the East Side, the West Side, Washington Heights and Greenwich Village shared in the activity.

Only "brick" ice cream may be available for home consumption this year due to the further curtailment in ice cream production ordered by Secretary of Agriculture Wickard to conserve milk and cream, several manufacturers reported yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A United States Headquarters communique:

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 -- Plans to raise a St. Louis quota of $175,000 toward a national fund of $5,000,000 for a two-year campaign to prevent civilian accidents were started today at a luncheon of business and industrial leaders.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The method by which Germany plucks the greatest possible wealth from occupied territories by devious methods of quasi-legalized trickery is exemplified by the administration of the part of Yugoslavia that has been reconstituted as puppet Serbia under the theoretical rule of Field Marshal Milan Neditch.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced tonight that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company would reduce its long lines revenues by an estimated $50,700,000 per year, of which $34,700,000 would be an immediate saving to the public.

J.H. Beale, superintendent of the arboretum at the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research in Yonkers, opened yesterday a series of weekly lectures on "Planning of Victory Gardens" sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and the New York Botanical Garden in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

Two Washington Heights youths were committed to Bellevue Hospital for mental observation yesterday by Magistrate Harry G. Andrews after they had admitted in the line-up at Police Headquarters that they had held up and robbed six intoxicated men, four high school boys and a dozen small candy stores.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A survey of manpower problems in the intercity bus industry has shown that national gasoline rationing and increasing military travel have put a heavy burden on the industry at a time when shortages of bus drivers and other workers have become acute, the Office of Defense Transportation stated today.

Furniture demand continued far in excess of supply yesterday at the New York Furniture Exchange, although attendance was off sharply from the record set Monday. Most manufacturers were sold up completely, or on some lines by the close of the day, and were refusing additional business.
MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- More details were published today on how the forces of General Kirill A. Meretskoff and Col. Gen. Leonid Govoroff pierced the blockade of Leningrad.
OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 20 -- The name Margriet Francisca was given today to the youngest Princess of Orange Nassau, born here yesterday to Crown Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands.

New York racing, up to now chiefly concerned with the problem of getting the patron to the track under various war restrictions, is faced with a new problem that concerns transporting the horse. The situation in the metropolitan area is causing considerable uneasiness in racing circles because gas rationing excludes van men whose sole business is moving thoroughbreds from one track to another.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- While Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary was declining to answer questions put to him in the House of Commons about the appointment of Marcel B. Peyrouton as Governor General of Algeria, Secretary of State Cordel: Hull wearily brushed aside similar questions at his press conference today.

C.M. Chester, chairman of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York, will lead a party of War Fund committee chairmen, mothers of service men, and Army and Navy officers on an inspection tour of Red Cross activities in the city today.

Rex Stout, in an article "We Shall Hate or We Shall Fail," seems to me confused and to fall into error. He fails to make a very simple factual examination of the theory, "We must hate injustice, but we must not hate our fellow-beings."

LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Britain announced tonight several promotions among her naval leaders, including the elevation of Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham, who commanded the naval forces that supported the American-British landings in North Africa, to the rank of Admiral of the Fleet.

Resignation of Edward J. Flynn as member of the Democratic National Committee from New York would open the way for the selection of James A. Farley as his successor in that post, it was said here yesterday by friends of the former Postmaster General.
The article by Rex Stout presents a problem the solution of which is a matter of first importance.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- Russian forces plunging west-ward into the Ukraine by-passed Rostov 120 miles to the north yesterday, capturing a string of towns curving down within twenty-eight miles of Voroshilovgrad, big industrial captial of the Donets Basin.

WASHINGTON, Jan 20 -- Economic stabilization in the second year of war will require "a more rigorous policy" of price control, including increased taxes, an unprecedented expansion of private savings and broadening of the rationing program, Leon Henderson said today in a final report to Congress coincident with his resignation as Federal Price Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Army Air Forces announced today an expansion of its program for combat and service pilot training which win utilize 100 colleges throughout the country as training centers. "Maximum utilization" of existing Civil Aeronautics Administration facilities is planned.

First Lieutenant Robert T. Levy of the Army Air Force, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. I. Alfred Levy of 40 West Seventy-seventh Street, have just been notified of his death in action in Western Europe on Jan. 3, revealed in a letter they have just received some details about one of the biggest Flying Fortress raids on Nazi-occupied France.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- New offensive operations by United States troops on Guadalcanal resulted in the killing of 1,032 Japanese in the five-day period of Jan. 13-17 inclusive, the Navy Department announced here today.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The will of Edgar Palmer of Princeton, granting specific bequests of $6,000,000, was probated today before Vice Ordinary Charles M. Egan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Chile's severance of diplomatic relations with the Axis was universally acclaimed here today. The move had long been awaited and the action brought a sense of relief. It adds another important country to the growing list of nations allied against the Axis, and it is a significant contribution to continental solidarity.

Two scholarships and three supplementary awards, amounting to $2,700, were granted as a result of the first competition for the annual Marian Anderson Music Award, which has been concluded in Philadelphia, it was announced yesterday.

Declaring that the metropolitan area is "the greatest unused pool of human and physical resources left in the United States," Colonel Robert W. Johnson, newly appointed director of the Smaller War Plants Corporation and a vice chairman of the War Production Board, asserted yesterday that isolated sections of the country which have not yet shared fully in wartime production must be harnessed if American production is to rise above its present level.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The House Rules Committee approved today continuation of the authority of the Naval Affairs and Military Affairs Committees to investigate war costs in an effort to recapture excessive profits, after Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, had testified that the War Department had saved more than $1,000,000,000 through the renegotiation of war contracts.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A British Middle East Headquarters communique:

A subscription dinner dance was given last night at the Cosmopolitan Club by the patronesses of the Coffee Dances, annual series of entertainments given here for many years, but canceled this Winter because of the war. Proceeds from the party will be donated to the American Red Cross.

Dr. James Carleton Bell, Professor of Education at City College for twenty years, founder of The Journal of Educational Psychology and former director of Townsend Harris High School, will retire at the end of this month, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college. Professor Bell reached the mandatory retirement age of seventy last Dec. 11.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The House of Commons went into a secret session today to begin a two-day debate on manpower and to discuss its relation to the coming production drive outlined by Production Minister Oliver Lyttelton.

An extensive program of public improvements in Queens, to be carried out in the post-war period, was outlined yesterday by James A. Burke, President of the borough, at a luncheon of the Kiwanis Club in the Hotel McAlpin.

To help us win the war by curbing illness among women war workers, Albert D. Lasker, retired advertising executive and former chairman of the United States Shipping Board, gave $50,000 yesterday to the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Inc.

Ed Wynn is now tied up with "The Big Time," it was announced yesterday by Paul Small, who will be associated with Fred F. Finklehoffe in the sponsorship of the vaudeville show. Mr. Wynn confirmed the engagement and admitted that he was no longer connected with Peter Arno's much-postponed revue.

BATTLES can't be seen from close up, as Stendhal's hero discovered at Waterloo. But you can see a lot of action that reveals the stuff of which human character is made, and it is human character which wins the battles. These observations are prompted by Richard Tregaskis's "Guadalcanal Diary,"* a companion piece to Ira Wolfort's recent book on the Battle for the Solomons.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 20 -- An enemy force estimated at about fifty tanks and 2,000 motorized infantry troops battered its way seven miles through the French forces on the Pont du Fahs-Robaa road yesterday.

The Federal Government, through a civil action started yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court, seeks to collect damages and penalties of $985,875 from twenty-eight corporations and twenty-nine individuals accused of having defrauded the government by submitting collusive bids for the sale of asphalt emulsion used on WPA projects.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 (U.P.) -- Gene Krupa, swing-band leader, pleaded innocent today to a charge that he contributed to the delinquency of a minor by sending a 17-year-old boy to his hotel room for marihuana cigarettes.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Legislators of both parties from Queens introduced today a proposal for a constitutional amendment coming from the Queens County Bar Association which would make the vote cast for Governor the basis for apportionment of Senate and Assembly districts.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Dr. John Hammond Bradshaw, for twenty-nine years the personal physician of the late Thomas A. Edison and long the physician to members of the inventor's family, was found dead today of gas poisoning in the office of his home at 27 High Street, here.

The battle for North Africa seems to be nearing a fighting climax. In Tunisia the hampering rains are expected to end soon. The struggle in the air, already active, is sure to become intense. On land the western blade of the Allied pincers holds the Axis forces in a narrow strip of coast about fifty miles deep.
