LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- British military observers said today that the Russians in two months had badly mauled and partly destroyed eighty-nine Axis divisions, sixty of them German. At full strength this would represent the demoralization of 1,335,000 enemy troops.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Russia is now the major beneficiary of American lend-lease in important arms and other supplies, passing even the United Kingdom in this respect, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lend-Lease Administrator, said in a statement today.

The Council of Books in Wartime announced yesterday that it would sponsor a new radio program starting this Saturday. The program, with Ken McCormick, editor in chief of Doubleday, Doran, as master of ceremonies, will be called "Fighting Words," and Mr. McCormick will interview authors and publishers of books on the war.

Skiers making their runs down snow-covered mountainsides or traversing the broad reaches of open slopes little realize the vast amount of thought and effort that resorts must expend in preparing their facilities for the Winter months.

MIAMI, Jan. 20 -- The American Federation of Labor will probably be willing to favor an increase in the present social security taxes from 4 per cent of payrolls to 10 per cent, provided that amendments are adopted by Congress liberalizing the act in conformity with the Federation's "cradle to grave" protection policy, and along the lines of President Roosevelt's social security objectives.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Comfortable and painless childbirth safe for both mother and child, is provided by a new type of spinal anesthesia, the Journal of the American Medical Association said today.

Neighbors of two former German-American Bund leaders appeared as witnesses yesterday at Federal court proceedings for the denaturalization of twenty Bundists. Each witness told of becoming infuriated by the clumsy efforts of the two men to win converts to nazism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- American retail enterprises, numbering nearly 2,000,000, while feeling the squeeze of the expanding war economy, have done better in adjusting their businesses to radically changing conditions than was generally expected when the war began, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Dr. Walter B. Pitkin, Professor of Journalism at Columbia University since 1912 and author of "Life Begins at Forty," which is one of a score of books he has written while delving into the problem of what sort of people Americans are, and what they should be, will retire at the end of the current semester at the age of 65.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 20 -- For thirty-five minutes, beginning at 7 P.M., President Juan Antonio Rios broadcast to Chile, announcing the breaking off of relations with the Axis powers -- Germany, Italy and Japan. He spoke slowly in a low voice and devoted most of his time to a review of the different stages of Chile's international position since the war began.

It was Chile which broke relations with the Axis Powers yesterday, yet the nation which one thinks about as one reads the news is Argentina. Argentina is all alone in this hemisphere now. Only Argentina keeps up the pretense that this is a war in which there is much to be said for both sides and in which a nation can honestly have no preference.
Mrs. Elliott Roosevelt has arrived from her home in Fort Worth, Texas, accompanied by Mrs. Robert B. Violette, and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Nine of the twenty-eighth alien members of the Moral Rearmament [Buchmanite] movement whose appeals for occupational deferment from Selective Service have just been denied, were ordered yesterday to report for induction into the Army on Feb. 5 at the offices of Local Board 17 at 412 Sixth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Texas leads all the States in Army enlistments since Pearl Harbor, on a population percentage basis. With 6,414,824 as shown in the 1940 census, the State had 53,015 enlistments to Nov. 1, 1942, or a percentage of 826.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 20 -- Marcel B. Peyrouton, the new Governor General of Algeria, held his first press conference today and declared that agreement among all Frenchmen everywhere was the hope of France.

The Tokyo radio announced yesterday, on the eve of the scheduled reconvening of the Japanese Diet, that Premier General Hideki Tojo was ill and for that reason the resumption of the parliamentary session had been postponed until next Wednesday, The Associated Press reported.

The customer watched the shopkeeper tie a final knot in her package of Scotch oatmeal, took her purchase and started toward the door. After taking a few steps she turned and asked, "By the way, has the haggis come?" The shopkeeper shook, his hand and laughed. "Don't worry, it will be here in time for Burns's birthday."

The stock market resumed yesterday its unorthodox January rally after its one-session interlude in the upturn, and gains of a point and more were distributed in some of the key spots. General strength in the list did not appear, however, until the final hour, when prices had their best enlargements, due to a pick-up in demand.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Cold weather lost today its effect as a price-making influence in grains on the Board of Trade, and there was nothing in overnight developments to induce traders to take a stand on either side of the market. Wheat had a range of around 3/4 cent a bushel.

Proper production scheduling within each plant and supervision and budgeting of parts and raw materials are of paramount importance under the Controlled Materials Plan, because changes in production schedules must be transmitted rapidly down the line, Charles R. Fay, chief of the scheduling methods branch of the CMP division of WPB, said last night at the monthly meeting of the New York City Control of the Controllers Institute of America in the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The French National Committee issued a statement today saying that, far from hastening French union or an agreement between General de Gaulle, the appointment of Marcel Peyrouton would have the reverse effect.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- The combined Red Armies of the Volkhov and Leningrad commands were reported today to be advancing southward. This means along the railroad from Leningrad to Mga and Zvanka, where Leningrad's hydroelectric power supply crosses it.

Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, reported yesterday to stockholders that the bank's net operating earnings for the year were $5,365,659. In the absence of Mr. Johnston because of illness, his report was read to stockholders by Frank K. Houston, president.

The Richmond County grand jury, at the county Court House in St. George, S.I., began yesterday an investigation into charges of violation of the city charter against Borough President Joseph A. Palma and other unnamed borough officials.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Government brought two more food store chain organizations, Safeway and Kroger, under indictment today on charges of violating the Sherman anti-trust law. The charges were promptly denied by officials of the companies.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 21 -- Germany's Luftwaffe reverted yesterday to its tactics in the early days of the Battle of Britain. Stung by the trouncing they took Sunday night, when they came to seek vengeance for the two previous nights' British raids on Berlin, they tried it by daylight this time.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The peril of Nazi submarines was emphasized in official American and British quarters today.

Police Chief Frank Brennan of Elizabeth, N.J., declared war yesterday on the "sneak and walk parkers," after a series of complaints had been received from persons living along quiet, residential streets.

Replacement buying by traders who had sold cotton during the declines of the three previous sessions brought moderate gains in the futures market yesterday. The list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended another quiet session with net gains of 3 to 8 points close to the day's best levels.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- New York City will receive more than $6,000,000 as its share of State-collected franchise taxes on business corporations for the final quarter of 1942, an increase of $2,150,000 over a year ago, Carroll E. Mealey, president of the State Tax Commission, announced today.

Extension of the mortgage moratorium, rescinding of the 1 per cent annual amortization requirement now 'in effect, and legislative studies to bring about "final and equitable" termination of the moratorium after the war was urged by the Twenty-third Street Association at its annual directors' meeting yesterday in the Kenmore Hall Hotel.

The rigorous 5:45 A.M. to 5 P.M. program prescribed for the students at the United States Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School, quartered at Columbia University, apparently isn't enough to dull the taste for competitive athletics.
The bumper crop of ducks this past season was cause for discussion among a group of sportsmen recently.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Prentiss M. Brown, new director of the Office of Price Administration, said at his first press conference today:

A Fifth Avenue beauty salon, where beautiful faces, streamlined silhouettes and sleek coiffures materialize in an atmosphere of serenity, offers an "efficiency plan" -which is the term for a new, war-shortened beauty course.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Monday afternoon American Red Cross headquarters in London received a request from the United States Army to establish a clubhouse for soldiers in a provincial city where one was badly needed. Tonight the clubhouse, with full kitchen equipment, twenty beds, furniture, table tennis and billiard table, was operating there.

Stockholders of the Irving Trust Company, voting as individuals, adopted yesterday with a lone dissenting vote a resolution condemning the Administration's placing of a ceiling of $25,000 on salaries net of taxes. The annual meeting, held on the forty-seventh floor of 1 Wall Street, re-elected all directors of the company.

By maintaining American textile output during 1943 at approximately last year's record rate of 13,500,000,000 linear yards, or within 5 per cent of it, the War Production Board is hopeful that essential civilian supplies can be assured despite mounting military and lend-lease demands, Frank L. Walton, director of the agency's textile division, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute in the Hotel New Yorker.

William Kapell, 20-year-old New York pianist, whose debut recital in October, 1941, was judged the outstanding performance for that year at Town Hall by an artist under 30, last night reaped the rewards of that judgment. He was presented at the same auditorium as the fifth recitalist in the Town Hall's current endowment series.

Streamlining their championship season to the point where they were able to announce a reduction of 33 per cent in railroad transportation mileage, baseball's two major league presidents, Will Harridge of the American League and Ford Frick of the National, practically completed yesterday the laborious task of revising their 1943 schedules.

Despite the efforts of oil refiners to increase their production of fuel oils, there was a further sharp drain last week on the supplies of these products. Production of light fuel oil was 361,000 barrels more than a year ago, while that of heavy fuel oil was up 856,000.

An official statement was issued yesterday by the Westminster Kennel Club that its annual dog show definitely would be held in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 11 and 12. This was the organization's reply to rumors that had been spread to the effect that war con ditions would necessitate cancellation of the famous canine fixture.

" It Comes Up Love," a Universal comedy drama with music, will open this morning at the Palace. Gloria Jean, Donald O'Connor, Ian Hunter, Louise Allbritton and Frieda Inescort head the film's cast. The second-run "Arabian Nights" will be the other offering on the double-feature program.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 20 (AP) -- United States heavy bombers based in India struck yesterday at the docks at enemy-held Bassein in Southwestern Burma and caused damage, a United States Army communique said today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Twenty-five years of litigation over the assessed valuations on New York City's watershed properties in the town of Cortlandt ended today with a settlement out of court that entailed payment by New York of $613,200 to Cortlandt for the last four years' taxes and required the town to reduce future taxes on the New York property by an estimated $9,000 a year.

To the Dutch princess born in Ottawa Tuesday, to the Princess Juliana, heiress apparent to the throne of the Netherlands, and Prince Bernhard of Lippe Biesterfeld, Americans wish long life and luck. The courage, endurance, patience and abounding common sense of the Dutch people have made us all their warm friends.

WILKES-BARRE, Jan. 20 -- All except 3,600 of the striking anthracite miners, heeding warnings from President Roosevelt and top officials of the United Mine Workers of America, voted in local meetings today and tonight to go back to work tomorrow morning after twenty-two days of idleness in protest against a 50-cent dues increase.

Cold weather accompanied by high winds moved into the New York area yesterday as reports from other parts of the country indicated that freezing temperatures were prevailing in all States east of the Continental Divide except on the Florida Peninsula.

Fifteen hundred women, representing 320 member organizations of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations subscribed $200,000 yesterday for the purchase of a bombing plane that will bear the federation's name. The money, in cash and pledges, was raised at a convention in the Hotel Astor.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The advisory board of the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs plans to urge the establishment of special committees to conduct a study of peace and post-war proposals.

In filing Federal income tax returns and arriving at the amount of earned income shown on Item 1 of the return form 1040 (salaries and other compensation for personal services), ordinary and necessary expenses incurred in this connection may be deducted.

AT A FIGHTER STATION, England, Jan. 20 -- The men who defended Britain's capital today against the first big daylight raid in many months were loafing around the station when a call came to action, and Wing Commander R.M. Milne remembered that he was thinking about his next leave when ordered aloft.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 20 -- The Italian occupation of the southeastern portion of France is nearing completion. As German troops withdraw, every type of Italian soldier is brought in to replace them -- Bersaglieri, Carabinieri, infantry and blackshirted militia men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Secretary of Agriculture Wickard has signed an order delegating authority to the Office of Price Administration to ration evaporated and condensed milk, jams, jellies, preserves, fruit butters, pickles, relishes, processed fish and shellfish, and food products which contain meats.
American submarines were prowling the waters off Japan yesterday, as they have been doing for the past year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Alimony of $500 a month and counsel fees of $2,500 were granted today by Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief to Mrs. Hannah Williams Dempsey of New York, defendant in a divorce suit brought by William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey, lieutenant commander in the Coast Guard and former champion heavyweight pugilist.

Sears, Roebuck took over yesterday noon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf. It was different from the high-styled shows that are the general rule in that setting. But the audience loved it. The assemblage was made up of social and professional groups, and there was not a vacant seat.

The preliminary report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for 1942, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges of $16,547,749. This was equal, after preferred dividend charges, to $1.22 a share on the corporation's outstanding common stock and compares with a net of $21,062,383, or $2.04 a common share, in the previous year.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 20 -- An Allied air attack on enemy vehicles parked at Medenine, which is about sixty-five miles this side of the Tripolitanian frontier, and strafing by Lightnings of a convoy on the road between Zuara, Tripolitania, and Ben Gardane, Tunisia, indicate that the Axis is concentrating vehicles in the area west of Tripoli.
United States Army boxers captured eight of ten bouts in the first boxing competition among members of the United Nations last night at a post in metropolitan New York.
Three days of door-to-door collections for the Victory Book Campaign by members of the West Side Defense Council of the CDVO have yielded more than 2,000 books, it was said yesterday.

DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 20 -- Striking back at "gloom spreaders," William G. Bramham, president of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, asserted today that all evidence indicates there will be sufficient players available for the minor leagues next season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -Decoration of a Flying Fortress bombardier for his part in the attack on the 29,000-ton Japanese battleship Haruna cleared up today any remaining doubt as to whether the big warship was listed officially as sunk in the first week of the war.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A United States Headquarters communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Edward J. Flynn, President Roosevelt's nominee as Minister to Australia, defended his diplomatic qualifications and denied charges of unfitness at stormy sessions today of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which ended with an opposition witness accusing Mr. Flynn of perjury.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- Samuel Goldwyn announced today that he has concluded negotiations with Walter Huston for the actor to play a leading role in "The North Star," following Huston's appearance at Warners as Ambassador Davies in "Mission to Moscow."

The women, who of late have been carrying on a Blitzkrieg of their own against the exclusive strongholds of maledom, will break one of the most cherished traditions of New York club life tonight at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- An outright gift of the 175 year old Encyclopaedia Britannica business has been made by Sears, Roebuck Co., to the University of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UP) -- The Navy gave out today the names of seventy-two additional casualties, including fourteen dead, fifteen wounded and forty-three missing. They brought the total number of announced casualties for all branches of the armed forces to 50,662, of which 29,265 are Army casualties.

There is a wide difference between the number of people who think of a particular brand of product in connection with a need or want and the number actually buying that product, Dale Houghton, Professor of Marketing of the School of Commerce of New York University and recently elected head of the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association told a group meeting of the association at the Hotel Sheraton yesterday.

At their seventeenth annual meeting yesterday, held in the Beekman Tower Hotel, members of the First Avenue Association elected Francis Dean, president of Beekman Terrace, Inc., as president to succeed Clyde R. Place, who had held the office for four years.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- The Red Army, driving deeply into the Ukraine, gained seventeen miles in the sweep toward Kharkov and farther south reached a point only forty-five miles above Voroshilovgrad, Donets River industrial center, a special communique announced tonight. The Russians now have rolled back the Germans to an area where the resilient Red Army itself had retreated last Summer when the big Nazi drive began.

The Danube turned to ice under the bridges of Budapest has become a symbol of the hardening despair of the Hungarians as their armies are captured or killed in the losing battle of Russia. Whether or not there are peace demonstrations in the streets of the capital, it is certain that popular revulsion against the Nazi war and Nazi pressure for more and more cannon fodder is as explosive in Hungary as in Rumania.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Manuel Quezon, President of the Commonwealth of the Philippines, announced today the adherence of his Government to the declaration by the United States and other United Nations warning that they rejected the dispossession methods practiced by the enemy.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 20 -- The effective union of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Africa Corps with the German forces in Eastern Tunisia will present to the Allied commanders the most difficult tactical situation that they have yet faced in North Africa.

William Hodson, New York City Welfare Commissioner on leave to join the staff of former Governor Herbert Lehman, director of foreign rehabilitation, has been killed in an airplane accident in Dutch Guiana, his family was notified yesterday by the State Department.

The long-awaited fuel oil priorities list, which would compel dealers to supply oil for heating homes and hospitals before delivering any to a large group of other users, has been shelved in Washington, it was reported last night by usually well-informed sources in the petroleum industry.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

The mothers of six Fordham University seniors who are already in the armed forces will receive their sons' degrees tonight at the ninety-eighth annual commencement exercises in the university gymnasium on the Bronx campus.

War-controlled household schemes dominated new room settings introduced in Macy's midwinter furniture show, which opened yesterday. Colorful maps and globes have been adopted as practical and engaging keynoters for study and living room, while cozy writing nooks and reading tables have been reclaimed from the carriage era to accommodate the growing force of stay-at-homes.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Jan. 22 -- Allied heavy bombers have scored direct hits on a Japanese cruiser and a merchantman in Amboina Harbor, a communique said today. "The cruiser was last seen listing with heavy smoke pouring out," the communique stated.

Beginning the investigation ordered by Governor Dewey into charges of illegal discrimination in the sales of fuel oil by large companies in this area, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein took testimony yesterday from eight small dealers and representatives of dealers' associations.
At the recent meeting of the Democratic National Committee in Chicago, Eugene Casey, an assistant secretary to the President, was quoted in the newspapers as having said:

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Court of Appeals held today that a special committee of the New York City Council, which investigated unemployment relief in 1938, was within its rights in hiring stenographic help, even though the Board of Estimate refused to make any appropriation for the expenses of the investigation, which was headed by Alfred E. Smith Jr., with Emil K. Ellis as counsel.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A British communique:

The United Nations must prepare now, while fighting to defeat the Axis powers, for the peace that is to come after the war if the fiasco of Versailles is not to be repeated and the way paved for another world conflict in twenty years.

A critical inadequacy of public health nursing throughout the country was revealed yesterday in reports of a survey of sixteen typical communities conducted by the committee on administration of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing.

The recent letter by a group of college professors calling for a drastic curtailment in advertising during the war demonstrates again "the great need for widespread understanding of what advertising actually does in the operation of our economic system," the Advertising Federation of America reported yesterday.

Richard H. Depew Jr., test pilot and aviation engineer who has been a licensed pilot since 1911, has become production coordinator of Fairchild Aircraft at Hagerstown, Md., it was announced yesterday. Mr. Depew formerly was general manager and executive vice president of Taylorcraft Aviation Corporation.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Bank of England in its weekly statement of condition, issued today, reported a decrease of 4,718,000 in note circulation.

MIAMI, Jan. 21 -- Declaring that some of the Congressional bills affecting organized labor would "introduce Hitlerian control of labor," William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, made public today a resolution adopted by his executive council urging Congressional leaders to oppose these measures.

Hundreds of volunteer Red Cross workers were busy on such varied kinds of war work as making bandages, preparing food to be served by mobile canteens, and assisting anxious or needy families of men in the armed forces when an inspection party, including leaders of the forthcoming Red Cross War Fund drive, and mothers of service men toured Red Cross centers here yesterday.

All users of oil for heating nonresidential premises must return their coupon sheets no later than Feb. 1 to local rationing boards, which will remove an appropriate number of coupons for Periods 3, 4 and 5 to conform with the 25 per cent cut ordered by OPA.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- The wheat market developed an easier undertone today as the result of scattered commission-house liquidation induced by reports that the Office of Price Administration had demanded that the Department of Agriculture take steps to curb the recent upward trend of prices and either establish ceiling prices on the grain or call Government loans on stored wheat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -The Office of Price Administration said today that many canned baby foods would be rationed under the same point system to be used for rationing of processed fruits and vegetables.
In announcing a list of books through May, Ziff-Davis-Alliance Books puts the novel that Jan Valtin, author of "Out of the Night," was to have ready onto an "unscheduled" list.

Warning that food production is now second only to military operations in winning the war, Herbert Hoover in an address here last night declared that something must be done to remedy the farm labor shortage before the next crop if we and the United Nations are to have enough meat and fat supplies for victory and to save the world from post-war starvation and anarchy.

Net income of the Foote Brothers Gear and Machine Corporation for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, according to the annual report issued for release today, amounted to $914,453 after appropriations of $300,000 to reserve for conversion of plants and facilities to peace-time production requirements and $200,000 to reserve for contingencies, $3,617,500 for taxes and $2,059,965 provision for voluntary payment to United States Treasury constituting a retroactive adjustment of selling prices under certain contracts.

Walter E. Spahr, secretary of the Economists National Committee on Monetary Policy, who is a professor of economics at New York University, announced yesterday that he had sent an open letter to Congress protesting against the issuance by the Treasury of a stock of $660,000,000 of Federal Reserve Bank notes, which had been printed for use during the banking crisis in 1933.

A total of nearly 3,000,000 dwelling units of war housing for immigrant war workers will be required by July, it was reported yesterday before the annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building by Jacob L. Crane Jr., director of urban studies, National Housing Agency, Washington.

After several weeks of unusually good running, metropolitan skiers are confronted with a discouraging picture for the next few days. The recent combination of rain and freezing weather made for icy or crusted surfaces and unless a thaw sets in or sufficient new snow falls to cover these slopes and trails the outlook for good week-end sport is a dark one.

Between bouts with the Japanese in the South Seas, young marines may continue through correspondence courses the high school educations they may have missed and go on all the way to graduation, according to a plan approved yesterday by the State Board of Regents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Twenty-six persons, military and civilian, bound from the United States for missions abroad, and nine crew members died aboard a giant transport plane that crashed in the jungle near the coast of Surinam [Dutch Guiana] last Friday, the War Department announced today.

An estimated 3,000,000 gallons of gasoline have been conserved in New York City in the two weeks since the pleasure-driving ban went into effect, Office of Price Administration officials said last night.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 21 (AP) -- American troops who invaded North Africa needed more than 250,000 pieces or Ordnance equipment, Brig. Gen. A.G. Gillespie, commandant of the Watervliet Arsenal, said today in awarding the Army-Navy "E" pennant to the Westinghouse East Springfield plant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Senator James M. Mead of New York read to the Senate today a Christmas pastoral letter by the Roman Catholic Bishop of Berlin, Konrad Count von Preysing, in which a dignified and resolute defiance of the Nazi ideas of humanity and the rights of the individual were strongly implied.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Frank C. Walker, Postmaster General and new Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, indicated today that he would poll committee members before accepting the resignation of Edward J. Flynn as national committeeman from New York.

What the people of a great democracy owe to Thomas Jefferson, particularly in these challenging days, will be the general theme of a Thomas Jefferson Bicentennial Essay contest for senior high schools, junior high schools and the last two years of elementary schools, both public and private, in the five boroughs of New York City.

At 8:10 last night the sink in the model kitchen of the Y.W.C.A.'s West Side branch at Fiftieth Street and Tenth Avenue looked as if an army of gremlins had just departed. The faucets lay in a shining heap by the drain, and the pipes dripped desolately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -Though the British Foreign Secretary and the United States Secretary of State declined yesterday to comment on the appointment of Marcel B. Peyrouton as Governor General of strategically vital Algeria, Secretary of State Cordell Hull referring questioners to the War Department for an explanation, authoritative military circles in close touch with the North African problem today described the latest political move behind that front in this way:

Assets of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States during 1942 rose more than $190,000,000, bringing the total at the year end to approximately $2,930,000,000, the highest point in the history of the society, Thomas I. Parkinson, president, reported to the board of directors at its meeting yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- Madrid dispatches said tonight that Axis forces were evacuating flaming Tripoli by every available small boat and barge under heavy attack from Allied planes and warships in a minor "Dunkerque" that was expected to culminate in the fall of the city within a few hours.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 21 -- The gold and other valuables that the Spanish Republican Government shipped to Mexico in March, 1939, amounted to only $7,776,732, of which $4,800,000 has been spent, according to a statement by Indalecio Prieto, former Madrid Defense Minister, made public today.

Wholesalers of dry goods and apparel items will receive a single, simple type of OPA regulation, probably one providing specific percentage mark-ups that will relieve them of the necessity to interpret and apply a half-dozen different pricing orders now affecting them, Dr. Bernard F. Haley, director of the agency's textile division, announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute in the Hotel New Yorker.

Two German-born machinists were accused yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court of violating the Espionage Act. Their arrests followed an intensive investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation after the conviction in Brooklyn of thirty-three spies in 1941.

THE firing has grown rather heavy of recent days with volley after volley discharged at the physical educators for their presumed tendency to abolish competitive sports in favor of mass athletics and other non-competitive activities. That fire, it develops, is slightly misdirected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The proposed equal rights amendment providing that men and women shall have equal rights throughout the United States "and every place subject to its jurisdiction" was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Gillette of Iowa.

Although Chief City Magistrate Henry H. Curran last month sarcastically "christened" the old West Side Court House in West Fifty-fourth Street "Pneumonia Hall" when he shifted the magistrates' court down town to the new $20,000,000 Criminal Courts Building on Center Street, its clerical staff in the fifty years of the court's history, seemingly was immune from any kind of a cold.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Labor and public members of the National Labor Board joined today in declarations that labor, and not management, would be punished in cases where the employes were defying a decision of the board or violating the wartime no-strike, no-lockout agreement.

Dwight (Dyke) Eddleman of Centralia, Ill., formerly one of the outstanding schoolboy athletes in the country and now a freshman at the University of Illinois, will make his first appearance at Madison Square Garden when he participates in the invitation high jump at the Millrose A.A. meet on Feb. 6.

In a report published yesterday in The City Record, official municipal journal, the city affairs committee of the City Council recommended that the Council ask Mayor La Guardia to appoint a committee to conduct "an immediate and thorough investigation of the entire problem of juvenile delinquency and crimes by minors," with special stress on problems created by wartime conditions.

As one who has been coming to the United States off and on for some ten years, and in the time of war, I should like to take this opportunity to say something of the appreciation we feel for the people of this country.

The German communique said yesterday that there was "continu ous hard fighting south of Lake Ladoga," where the Russians are battling to widen their supply corridor to Leningrad. Without a reference to specific gains or losses, the communique, quoted in Berlin broadcasts recorded here by The Associated Press, said Axis shock troops "were successfully employed" in local combat on the central front and south of Lake Ilmen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Asserting that the synthetic rubber situation was in "even worse shape than it was," Senator Gillette predicted today that new "corrective" legislation might be introduced in the Senate and that farm Senators might back a move to establish a $10,000,000 government plant to experiment with making rubber from agricultural products.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

One of the first steps necessary to mobilize our national effort against the submarine menace is an information policy that will impress the American public with the gravity of that menace. And the first step in improving our information policy would be a frank statement by the Navy or the OWI telling precisely what our present information policy is.

A city patrolman and a railroad policeman he had been called upon to arrest shot each other twice at 11:30 o'clock last night in front of the Marseilles Garage, 232 East Forty-seventh Street. City Patrolman Christopher Hughes, 41 years old, of the East Fifty-first Street precinct, was taken to Midtown Hospital in a serious condition with wounds in the leg and abdomen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The House was told today through a letter from Ralph Bard, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, that a local C.I.O. engaged in a' wage controversy in the San Francisco area had prevented vessels from meeting schedules which controlled convoys required for the shipment of men and supplies, and that it had disorganized troop movements to ports of embarkation.

With some improvement in the fuel oil situation seen as a result of the order by Harold L. Ickes. Federal Petroleum Administrator, banning tank car deliveries of gasoline into the East Coast area, the district office of the Petroleum Administrator for War announced yesterday the procedure by which consumers may appeal from the recent order cutting deliveries of oil for purposes other than heating by 40 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- "There is a definite possibility that the nutrition level of the population as a whole might be raised even while we are fighting this war," Secretary Wickard told Government officials at a luncheon today to demonstrate better-nutrition program as it applies to Federal employes.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Some details of the part the British are playing toward solving the economic problem as well as the military and political problems confronting Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in French North Africa became known here today.

DETROIT, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Red Wings scored two last-period goals to smash a five-game winning streak of the pace-setting Bruins with a 3-to-2 victory in a National Hockey League game tonight. Eddie Wares slapped home a 50-foot shot for the winning marker less than seven minutes from the finish.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 22 -- Red Army troops striking straight west below Voronezh have reached a point only eighty-five miles southeast of Kursk, thus threatening the entire Nazi 1941 front extending from Central Russia to the Sea of Azov, according to a midnight Russian communique as broadcast by Moscow and heard by the Soviet monitor today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Little more materials suitable for war production can be saved by further cuts in civilian economy, it was indicated today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of WPB.

Whether Thomas Jefferson's political ideas are still valid in this two hundredth anniversary year of his birth must be a matter of opinion. He believed in a democracy of small propertied people living under rural or small-town conditions. He was afraid of big cities and of big governments, and would have been afraid of big business if there had been any in his time.

The Union Towel Supply Company has bought for cash the manufacturing plant at Fairmount and Cornelison Avenues, Jersey City. A large plot of ground for expansion was also included in the sale. The seller was the American Steel and Copper Plate Company.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

To reduce its consumption of newsprint in accordance with a recent government order, The Daily News yesterday opened a campaign to reduce its circulation for the duration of the war. Under the heading, "Don't Buy a News, Borrow One," the tabloid asked its readers to avoid buying copies they could do without.

Nearly every one agrees that a rule to pay Federal income taxes during the year you receive the income would be an act of simple common sense. But, in mulling over the method by which to effect the change, why need the use of common sense be abandoned?

Three months ago Rommel's Africa Corps was within sight of Alexandria, threatening the Valley of the Nile. Today his forces are evacuating Tripoli and racing toward the Tunisian border. Call this flight a planned retreat or a skillful evasion of battle; it measures, nevertheless, the distance between the position of the British Eighth Army at the beginning of the desert offensive and the present position.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 21 -After a search of nearly three years for a new president for Stanford University, the trustees have elected their own head, Dr. Donald B. Tresidder, an alumnus, to the position. He succeeds Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, who became president in 1916 and since June, 1941, has been chancellor and acting president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A few hours after a Senate special committee charged today that the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Supply "has gambled dangerously and unwisely with our nation's food supply" by putting a "drastic limitation" on the production of farm machinery, the WPB authorized a substantial increase in the tonnage of steel to be delivered in the first quarter of the year for manufacture of farm implements.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 21--Werner Best, the Reich's representative in Denmark, has informed the Danish Government that the Reich cannot possibly tolerate elections on a democratic pattern in an occupied country, according to reliable reports received here.

NORRIS CITY, ILL., Jan. 21 -Laying of the world's largest oil pipeline, a 551-mile, 24-inch conduit from Longview in East Texas to this city, was completed today as one of the big transportation projects of the war.

Baron Silvercruys, Belgian Minister to Canada, and his sister, Mrs. Edward Ford Stevenson, are at the Ambassador. Mrs. Stevenson will leave tomorrow to join her husband, Major Stevenson, U.S.A., in Washington.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted to be at the highest of the year. Holdings of United States Government securities decreased $157,209,000 during the week, while reserve note circulation increased $9,015,000.

Taxicab passengers in various sections of the city faced a new problem yesterday when, in a number of instances, drivers refused to take them on any but short trips. The explanation was that "because of existing conditions, passengers could not be taken on long trips."

F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central System, declared yesterday after a meeting of the Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference, of which he is chairman, that one of the most important problems presented to the railroads in the handling of the present expanded passenger traffic is that of distributing the load.

Cooperating with the United Nations' win-the-war program, Swift Co. have vastly expanded their production of food products and developed many new ones to meet the requirements of the armed services, lend lease and the civilian population, John Holmes, president, declared yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting in Chicago.

Action to initiate condemnation proceedings against the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, 1560 Amsterdam Avenue, has been ordered by the Board of Estimate and the motion will come up before condemnation court Monday, it was disclosed yesterday by Julius Isaacs, assistant corporation counsel.

Warner Brothers are now the owners of the screen rights to "The Doughgirls," having paid $250,000 for them. The purchase was confirmed yesterday by Max Gordon, producer of the hit comedy, who said the film version could not be released before June of next year.

University of Chicago is now among the fortunate lovers of reading and culture who have a book. It is called the Encyclopaedia Britannica. Ownership of that publication, which is just 175 years old, has come to the university as a gift from Sears, Roebuck Co., who acquired title to the historic publishing enterprise in 1920.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Moffat-Wallace bills advancing the State's fiscal year from July 1 to April 1 and permitting payment of State income tax in quarterly installments.
MOSCOW, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Soviet mid-day communique:

NEW DELHI, India, Jan 21 (U.P.) -- British and American fliers have made new destructive attacks against Japanese objectives in Central Burma, concentrating their main blows on enemy supply centers along the important Rangoon-Mandalay railroad, it was announced today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of directors of the Chase National Bank of New York, urged tonight the adoption of a Federal retail sales tax and an at-the-source income tax "in order to check the increase in the public debt."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 21 (AP) -- An Allied communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Petroleum Administration for War banned today tank car delivery of gasoline to the East Coast petroleum shortage area in order to make more cars available for transport of fuel oil.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 21 -- With virtually unanimous approval of shareholders now recorded, finance experts representing fifteen building and loan associations in Atlantic City and neighboring Ventnor commenced completion of legal and accounting details toward consolidating the associations into two new companies.

Lieutenant Governor Thomas W. Wallace will officiate at the unveiling of a service flag bearing the names of 5,000 men of Irish descent who have joined the armed forces in a ceremony to be held tonight in conjunction with the thirty-ninth annual ball of the United Irish Counties Association in the Hotel Commodore.
The text of the speech delivered by former President Hoover before the National Industrial Conference Board in this city last night follows:

Formation of an all-embracing national association of business men with the express purposes of assuring full production and employment through keeping prices at the lowest level consistent with these objectives was advocated last night by John E. Webster, former general works engineer of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, in an address before the Society for the Advancement of Management at the Builders Club.

In THE TIMES of Jan. 18 Herman Seid made some interesting and valuable suggestions on union reform, but I fear we are not yet ready for reforms as advanced as those he outlines. It must be borne in mind that there is no way of curbing unscrupulous and greedy labor bosses except by limiting their time in Office.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Five of fourteen enemy planes shot down Wednesday fell to the guns of Great Britain's new high-speed Typhoon fighters.

TORONTO, Jan. 21 -- Toronto trampled the Rangers deeper into the National Hockey League cellar tonight, outscoring the New Yorkers in a third-period outburst to win, 7 -- 4, before a crowd of 9,563 at Maple Leaf Gardens.

Lewis E. Waring has been re-elected president of the United Hunts Racing Association, according to an announcment yesterday which also included the fact that Robert C. Winmill had been re-elected vice president and Richard V.N. Gambrill, secretary-treasurer.

The old stone building at 59-63 Second Street, on the lower east side, occupied for the past seventyfive years by the Olivet Memorial Church, has been sold by the New York City Mission Society to the Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church of North America.

PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 21 -- Hope that post-war industrial employment in the Peoria area, and in the country as a whole, will not fall much below the present wartime mark is carried in the report of a survey conducted by the Peoria Committee for Economic Development.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan 21 -Rita Hayworth, scheduled to be co-starred with Brian Donlevy in "My Client Curley," starting on Feb. 7, was suspended this afternoon from her Columbia contract and the picture was indefinitely postponed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Senator Bankhead told the Senate today that the United States should devote its efforts to raising food and producing weapons and leave to Russia, China and Great Britain the job of furnishing men to fight on foreign fronts.

More than six weeks have passed since the President authorized his Manpower chairman, Mr. McNutt, "to take all lawful and necessary steps" to make certain that no employer "retains in his employ any worker whose services are more urgently needed in any occupation or area designated as more essential."

LONDON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Reports to Allied governments said today that Adolf Hitler had ordered his Gestapo to crack down without mercy on patriot saboteurs throughout Europe who have destroyed or damaged millions of dollars' worth of German industrial machinery and war materials.

A hearing by the OPA on Maximum Price Regulation 287, which gravely affects the apparel industry here, has been asked by Mayor La Guardia in a communication addressed to Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Public support of the policy of "equal pay for women or identical rate for the job" was urged today by the Advisory Board of the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs as it closed a two-day session here.

The death of William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare, in an airplane crash in Surinam [Dutch Guiana], was described by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as "one of the greatest blows that has come to me in a long time."
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Red Hamill's goal in the final two minutes gave the Black Hawks a 4-4 tie with the Canadiens tonight in a National League hockey game before a crowd of 7,451.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- In the stock markets here today gilt-edge securities were dull and old Consols and local loans lost 3/4 each. However, home rails shook off the effects of profit-taking sales. London, Midland Scottish 4s bracketed 1923 rose to 63 3/4; London North Eastern first preference stock to 63 1/3, and the second to 32 3/4.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The noon communique:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -The House assigned its Civil Service Committee today to ascertain whether government departments and agencies were over-staffed with civilian employes.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 21 -As German tank columns made fresh advances in Central Tunisia in the mountains southwest of Pont du Fahs Hurricane bombers came to the support of the French defenders with a devastating attack, pouring 500-pound bombs on enemy troop and supply columns moving up to support the armored units, Royal Air Force headquarters announced today.

This writer wishes that the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Fritz Reiner conducting, last night in Carnegie Hall had stopped at the end of the first half of the program. For that half contained the masterpiece, creatively and interpretively too, of the evening, which was a classic symphony in B flat, numbered 102, by one Josef Haydn.

Government securities amounting to $157,209,000 were sold from the holdings of the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System in the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday in the regular weekly banking statistics.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 21 -Thousands of Connecticut families using kerosene for cooking and heating face a fuel shortage so acute that Governor Baldwin volunteered today to raise a fleet of oil trucks with which to tap New York and New Jersey sources, only to be told that the metropolitan harbor area itself had no excess supply which it could make available.

The Office of Defense Transportation officially approved yesterday the proposal of the Moving and Storage Industry War Transportation Committee, an organization of 104 New York City moving concerns, to set up a registration office here for use by common carriers to conserve transportation facilities.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 21 -Foreign military observers here report that Balkan railways and inadequate roads have been jammed with southbound troops, transport, armored material, munitions and supplies for more than a fortnight and the Germans are accelerating their regarrisoning of fortifications along the Balkan coasts of the Adriatic, Mediterranean and Aegean Seas, as well as the Dodecanese Islands and Crete.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- About 100 Americans against 36 Germans, or 21 Japanese, are being killed by accidents because the need for precautionary measures is not realized, Colonel John Stilwell, vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and president of the National Safety Council, said today at a safety mobilization meeting at the Chicago Club. Half of the Americans lost, he said, were war workers.

In East Side and West Side homes a group of housewives are entering this week the first items in their wartime food diaries to give the OPA a close-up picture of how the war is affecting civilian food purchases. Before the week is over, 170 households selected to represent variations of wage scales and modes of living will receive the detailed forms, as part of a survey of 3,000 families across the country.
Seventeen new leases in London Terrace were reported yesterday by William A. White Sons. The new tenants were:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Production and distribution of dental equipment was put under rigid control by the War Production Board with the issuance of General Limitation Order L-249 by the Director General for Operations, it was announced today.

ALBANY, Jan. 21--The Court of Appeals, in a four-to-three decision, today freed Irving (Knadles) Nitzberg, twice convicted as a member of the Brooklyn murder ring headed by Abe Reles, from the death house. The court's majority decision cleared Nitzberg of the first degree murder charge on the ground that the indictment was faulty.

The Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury handed up indictments yesterday charging the Brillo Manufacturing Company, Inc., makers of a nationally known household product, and two of its officers with violating an order of the War Production Board.

A final-hour rally again invaded the stock market yesterday and the revived demand shot prices up to the best levels in fourteen months for the best gains of the new year. So enthusiastic and broad was the upturn that only a comparatively small portion of the list showed losses at the close of trading, with the additions topping these by a ratio of seven to one.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -Navy communique 257:

The assassination of Carlo Tresca led yesterday to indignant denunciation by leading Italian-American organizations of the Office of War Information for its tactics in seeking to promote anti-fascism here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 21 -- Rear Admiral Jonas H. Ingram, Commander of the United States Naval Forces in the South Atlantic, announced today that "in the last month we have sunk five submarines."

The amount of money required for one month of this country's war effort would finance an ideal public health service for the nation for ten or more years and what we spend on the war in one year would provide proper care for the country's entire childhood during its lifetime, Mayor La Guardia estimated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- When Congress takes a look soon at the inside operations of lend-lease -- a look which will probably prove to be satisfactory and even gratifying in most administrative respects -- the question of the genesis of this unusual and most important measure may again arise.

After putting officials of the company on the stand to testify as to the extent of the business and the "diligent study" used by selectors in handicapping horses, attorneys for the Armstrong Racing Publications, Inc., unexpectedly rested their case late yesterday at the trial before Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck of their suit to make permanent the temporary injunction restraining License Commissioner Paul Moss from banning from newsstands the company's racing publications.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson, in a broad review of the war situation, said today that except for the submarine sinkings of Allied cargo ships "the over-all picture is bright."

Plans for a large war-rescue campaign embracing many neutral and Allied lands in Europe land the Western Hemispher, including refugee aid activities in the United States, to be conducted this year by American Jews through a unified, fund-raising drive by the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine, were announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The British advance to the environs of Tripoli marks the beginning of another phase of the North African campaign.

Major Eric Knight was prepared to die just as he did die. Only last May he wrote, "This war is too big to make any one man or his life of the slightest importance." Just before the transport took off a few days ago he dropped a last letter to his publishers, Harper and Brothers.

Some one in the regional Office of Price Administration, hoping to save Chinese laundrymen trouble in filling out government questionnaires, had the bright idea of printing Chinese characters alongside the English questions.

With activity continuing at a very slow pace, the cotton futures market moved narrowly yesterday, but closed at the best levels in a week by virtue of a late flourish of mill and New Orleans buying. Final net gains on the New York Cotton Exchange were 8 to 12 points, near the best prices of the session.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Hale America open golf tournament, successor last year to the war-shelved national open, in turn may be succeeded this year, but perhaps in name only.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A new army of soldiers of the soil is mobilizing to tend the victory gardens this year and thus supplement the nation's food supply.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 21--Having occupied both Hems and Tarhuna, British Eighth Army columns yesterday were within forty miles of Tripoli and controlled the heights of the Jebel Nefusa and the Jebel Garian overlooking the sandy flats on which Tripoli stands.

Retail credit collections showed an increase of 12.31 per cent in December, according to the twenty-store index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage for last month was 58.76, against 46.45 in the same month of 1941.

Mary Frenna, 11 years old, of 456 West Thirty-seventh Street, can give a pointer to cooks now wracking their brains over menu substitutions and shortages. Yesterday at the Children's Aid Society's West Side Center, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street, Mary won first prize in the center's annual economy meal contest.

About a generation ago it became apparent that the distillation of petroleum by the usual method would not yield enough gasoline for a rapidly increasing number of automobiles. More values had to be extracted from the heavy still-residues, most of them fuel oil and asphalt.

LINDENHURST, L.I., Jan. 21 -- Miss Josephine Haab, 16 years old, of 284 South Fifth Street, this village, died today in Dr. King's Private Hospital, Bay Shore, of pneumonia following an attack of methyl-bromide poisoning that she suffered while working in the Tedlee Chemical Company here.

Many of the railroads of the country reduced their indebtedness substantially last year. Provided net income is maintained around current levels for this year, the belief is that the trend will be accelerated. In 1942, the Southern Railway effected a reduction of slightly more than $18,000,000 in its funded debt.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 21 -- Testimony that Hitler told a group of Bund officials that he wanted all able-bodied Storm Troopers in the United States to report to Germany not later than November, 1939, was offered here today by John C. Metcalf, Chicago reporter, during denaturalization proceedings against twenty-three German-born persons.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Bill Klem, the National League's chief of umpires, who called 'em from behind the plate for forty years, looked into the future and predicted today:

The number of American babies born in 1942 -- at least 2,800,000 -exceeded that for any previous year in our country's history, statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company reported yesterday. The previous record was 2,600,000 in 1921.

Take the omelet pan out of hiding and get it ready for use for eggs are even more plentiful than they were last week and are from 2 to 7 cents cheaper. This good news, the like of which is rarely heard nowadys in food circles, was reported yesterday by the Consumers' Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- A crane still labored with huge chunks of wreckage and rescue workers continued their grim search tonight as the toll rose to forty-seven dead, fifty injured and fourteen missing as a result of yesterday's direct bomb hit on a London County Council elementary school.

The thirty-five Americans who crashed in an Army chartered transport plane near the coast of Dutch Guiana a week ago today died like soldiers in line of duty. It is natural that two names in the casualty list should attract particular attention: that of Major Eric M. Knight, the novelist, and that of Welfare Commissioner William Hodson.

The North Carolina Department of Conservation and Development states that the report of the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission indicating that channel bass along with other game fish were being slaughtered by both sport and commercial fishermen "is not now applicable to North Carolina."

In reaching out for a "windfall," on the basis of a new ruling that building service employes in certain circumstances come under the provisions of the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act, the plaintiffs in a court action here have endangered the integrity of a contract with their employer which was reached through collective bargaining, Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind ruled yesterday.

HONOLULU, Jan. 21 -- Dogs trained in Hawaii for war service, often sent ahead of Army scouting parties in the Solomons, have frequently located Japanese snipers, advance patrols and enemy positions before their human comrades, it was revealed today by Brig. Gen. William R. White, Hawaiian Department Quartermaster, who is in charge of the war dog project here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Department store sales for the week ended Jan. 16 were up 1 per cent from the corresponding period a year ago. This followed a gain of 6 per cent in the preceding week. Sales in the latest four-week period were 8 per cent above a year ago.

Hopes that the unofficial rationing of coal, under which many companies have been limiting families to one ton or even less at a delivery, will soon be ended were expressed last night by dealers who said the return to work of the anthracite miners would permit them to rebuild the reserve stocks which have fallen sharply during the strike.

Check transactions reported at the principal cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday totaled $7,790,324,000, or 11.6 per cent larger than the $6,982,281,000 volume for the similar week of last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The turnover for the week increased $208,220,000, or 2.7 per cent over the previous week.
The Class C tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association started last night at the Harvard Club with an entry of twenty-seven players. The proceeds will be turned over to the Red Cross.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Air and Home Security Ministries:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The American troops operating on Guadalcanal, who recently started a successful offensive against the Japanese there, now are operating under the command of Major Gen. Alexander M. Patch of the Army, the War and Navy Departments announced here today.

Victory over the Axis will be only an incident in the solution of a much larger crisis in which they will soon be playing an active part, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, told 250 graduates last night at the Fordham commencement exercises.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Attributing the decline of the Royal Italian Air Force to corruption among high officials of the Italian Air Ministry, the British Broadcasting Corporation today broadcast to the Italian people particulars from personal documents seized from an Italian group captain in the Mediterranean theatre.

More than 300,000 persons already have seen Noel Coward's British naval drama, "In Which We Serve," which yesterday entered its fifth week at the Capitol. . . . "Yankee Doodle Dandy" starts a fifth week today at the Strand . . . A revival of "Ruggles of Red Gap" will play a one-day stand today at the Beverly Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -The first official confirmation that Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright and twelve other American generals captured in the Philippines actually are prisoners of war was announced today by the War Department.

The words "hell" and "damn" will be permitted to be included in the vocabularies of the tough-talking fighters of the March of Time's production, "We Are the Marines," it was announced yesterday by Charles Francis Coe, vice president and general counsel of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, commonly known as the "Hays Office."

Faced with maturities of more than $40,000,000 by 1956, Robert J. Bowman, newly elected president of the Pere Marquette Railway, announced yesterday that such earnings as will be available must be reserved against these maturities rather than paid out in dividends.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 21 (AP) -As if impatient to undertake completion of the task begun by her great predecessor, the new aircraft carrier Yorktown, carrying much equipment usually added later in a fitting basin, jumped the gun on her launching today and without mishap slid proudly into the James River before a group of surprised and cheering spectators.

Branch Rickey's worries over baseball's waning supply of manpower were regarded as having been lessened yesterday, when the Dodgers' major domo announced acquisition of Paul Waner and Johnny Cooney, venerable National League outfielders who had been turned loose to graze.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Rescue squads, working all day and into the second night to locate the missing children in the wreckage of the London school where forty-seven persons were killed yesterday by a Nazi bomb, praised the fortitude of 12-year-old Molly Kinnerman, rescued with three others after being trapped for hours.

Because of the muddled political situation, French resistance groups in North Africa, although aiding the Allied forces in every way, have remained underground since the American invasion, the Fighting French Press and Information Service, 626 Fifth Avenue, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -Representative Shafer of Michigan introduced in the House today a resolution directing the Judiciary Committee to investigate the "circumstances preceding the filing" of the Justice Department's suit against The Associated Press.

The Jews of Palestine, many of whom are now serving in the British armed forces, are desirous of joining their brethren from other countries of the Near East and Europe to fight with the United Nations as a separate armed force, Rabbi Meyer Berlin, a member of the board of governors of the Jewish National Fund, declared yesterday.

The Save the Children Federation, 1 Madison Avenue, had its first million dollar year in social service for child welfare last year, Colonel John Q. Tilson, the treasurer, reported yesterday at the eleventh annual meeting of the corporation and board of directors yesterday.

Hitler's armies are "facing catastrohe" all long the Russian front, Dmitri Zaikin, Soviet Vice Consul in New York, said last night at a dinner given by Freedom House, 32 East Fifty-first Street, to eleven representatives of the United Nations at the Princeton Club.

The three-story dwelling at 137 Amity Street, Brooklyn, owned by the Sinclaire family for seventysix years, has been conveyed to Warren N. Burbridge by Francis S. Sinclaire, Clothilde Sinclaire Holahan, Catherine Sinclaire Price and Lucy Sinclaire Warren, heirs of Lucy J. Sinclaire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Secretary Wickard announced a program today to help farmers increase production this year by opening up to them a new source of credit for the production of essential wartime food and fiber. Between $200,000,000 and $225,000,000 of additional funds will be made available to assure maximum production, Mr. Wickard said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -Congress found the latch string out at the Office of Price Administration today and legislators seized upon the opportunity to lay before Prentiss M. Brown, the new Price Administrator and a former colleague, an accumulation of complaints and suggestions for the operation of price controls and rationing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -The Navy announced today eighty-three new casualties, including three men killed, thirteen wounded and sixty-seven missing.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Allen T. Simmons, Akron, Ohio, turf enthusiast and radio manufacturer, said today that a group of horsemen was considering the feasibility of holding a cooperative race meeting at Gulfstream Park, about sixteen miles north of Miami.

Higher wages for 130,000 women and minors employed in the restaurant, hotel, laundry, cleaning and dyeing, confectionery and beauty service industries in New York State were recommended yesterday by the State Labor Department as necessary to meet the rising cost of living.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Continued gains in primary market prices for agricultural commodities, together with higher prices for anthracite coal, brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics comprehensive index of nearly 900 series up 0.2 per cent during the week ended Jan. 16.

OTTAWA, Jan. 21 -- C.H. Millard, national director of the Steel Workers of America, in a letter to Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King, announcing that the steel workers had rejected the seven-point plan presented by the government on Tuesday, urged today that negotiations for a settlement of the steel strike be continued.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The House approved unanimously today a continuation of investigations by its Military, Naval and Merchant Marine Committees, which they assert have saved the taxpayers more than $2,000,000,000 in the last year through forced or suggested renegotiation of war contracts.

The war has so reduced the membership of the exclusive Court House Club that it is giving up voluntarily its luxurious home at 206 East Sixty-fifth Street, the furnishings are to be sold at auction, the premises are to be occupied by a commercial photographer and the club probably will dissolve.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Fifteen workers in a munitions factory at Radom in Central Poland have been hanged by the Germans because a bullet found in the body of a Nazi gendarme came from their factory, according to a Polish fugitive who had reached here.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 21 -The spontaneous and leaderless strike of thousands of anthracite miners, which was begun twenty-three days ago in protest against a 50-cent increase in dues, came virtually to an end today with the basic issue still unsettled.

In holding two Negroes for a hearing on a charge that the night before they had beaten and robbed two passengers in a West Side subway train near the Ninety-sixth Street station, Magistrate Samuel Orr yesterday in the Felony Court declared:

The Danish Government has just had notice from Werner Best, who acts as Hitler's receiver of stolen goods in Copenhagen, that the Reich cannot permit the elections to the Danish Parliament which were scheduled for next Spring. This is not surprising. The surprise would be if any representative of the Reich at any time or place were to say or do anything that was not thick-headed and wicked.

The four-story apartment building at 1436-38 Ocean Avenue, in Brooklyn, accommodating fifty-five families, has been sold by Solomon Bloom and Morris Solnet to Ruth Lipschitz, subject to a mortgage of $158,000. Elmer Fanslow was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Iraq, which declared war on the Axis last Saturday, formally entered the ranks of the United Nations today through adhering to the Declaration of the United Nations of Jan. 1, 1942.

Colonel Robert Wood Johnson, recently appointed chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, announced yesterday at a press interview in his office at 80 Broadway that he would begin next week a survey of the administrative capacity of this unit of the War Production Board throughout the country.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The stock markets here were generally quiet today on week-end considerations. Gilt-edge securities remained dull, old Consols being down 1/8, to 82 5/8, and local loans losing 1/16, to 97 15/16. Home rails were quiet, with Southern Railway deferred 1/8 better at 23 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Lieutenant (J.G.) Kenneth H. Muir of Pelham, N.Y., has been awarded a Navy Cross for heroism shown as commanding officer of a gun crew on a merchant vessel torpedoed and sunk by an enemy submarine off the northern coast of South America in December.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- In the mountainous region between Trieste and the Isonzo River on one side and Hungary on the other and from Klagenfurt to the frontiers of Croatia, which is the home land of more than a million Slovenes, the Axis powers are now engaged in a ruthless campaign to entrench permanently not only their frontier systems government but also their own people.

DETROIT, Jan. 22 -- In what was virtually a civic holiday here, Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, ace of the first World War and hero of the recent rescue from the Pacific, toured Detroit's war plants today, urged production-line workers to greater efforts and wound up by addressing industrial leaders at a banquet of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

Continuation of the rally in the stock market was checked yesterday by week-end profit-taking, but only after prices had reached new high marks for the current movement. The realizing in the afternoon produced a mixture of trends at the close.

The Most Rev. William Tiburtus McCarty, a priest of the Redemptorist Order, will be consecrated as a Bishop of the Roman Catholic Church Monday morning at 10 o'clock in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The appointment of Father McCarty as a Bishop by Pope Pius XII was announced Jan. 10 by Archbishop Amleto Giovanni Cicognani at the latter's residence in Washington.

Dr. R.S. Elmer, president of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association, ruling body in this part of the country, has issued the executive ruling on the competitive status of men now in the service.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 22 -- Following the suspension of Rita Hayworth by Columbia over her refusal to appear in "My Client Curley," Brian Donlevy, who was to have been co-starred with her in the film, has released the studio from its obligation for one picture. He probably will be starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in a film tentatively titled "Army Chaplain."

The Federation of Crippled and Disabled, Inc., officially opened its new headquarters yesterday at 163 West Fifty-seventh Street, a modern five-story building that will more than triple the number of persons that can be aided by the organization.

Advertising must play an increasingly greater part in developing production of war material and in building the foundation for post-war economy, it was declared yesterday by speakers at the Midwest conference of the National Industrial Advertisers Association in Chicago.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 22 -- The twenty-four-day revolt in the ranks of the United Mine Workers of America over an increase of 50 cents in dues ended this afternoon when 800 employes of the Payne Coal Company suspended plans for a secret ballot and, by standing vote, unanimously decided to report for duty at Exeter colliery Monday in line with orders of President Roosevelt.

The new Yorktown proved herself worthy of her name. Eager for her proper element and her calling, she beat the gun, rushed off the ways, took her first dip in the James. What may we not expect of a ship that may be said to have launched herself? Her impetuosity and eagerness for action are of the best augury.

Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, was called to the stand yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck in support of the contentions of racing sheet publishers who seek a permanent injunction to restrain License Commissioner Paul Moss from interfering with the newsstand sale of their publications.

A group of Long Island City busines men, taking the gasoline situation in deadly earnest, made the fourteen-mile round trip to Flushing and back yesterday in a wagon drawn by two horses to attend a Kiwanis luncheon. They started about 11 A.M. from the postoffice at Jackson Avenue and Twenty-first Street and made the seven miles to a restaurant at Northern Boulevard and 150th Street in an hour.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Providing still further evidence that times have changed, the Yankees, for years proud overlords of the American League, yesterday reached all the way into the rival circuit and then had to plumb clear to the cellar in order to come up with a first baseman who may ease the manpower shortage with which Manager Joe McCarthy will have to contend this Spring.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A smaller variety of printed fabrics and definite limitations on the introduction of new patterns will result from an order announced today by the War Production Board, according to officials. The order imposes restrictions on the use of copper rollers in the textile printing industry.

The four-story apartment house at 2034 Hughes Avenue, the Bronx, on a plot 50 by 60 feet, has been sold to a client of the Taylor Company, who immediately resold it to Leana Schaefer. The property was held for $25,000 and was subject to mortgages amounting to $19,600.
